column2: CAMP WHEELER, Ga., Dec. 5 -- The destinations of more than 1,000 selective service men from New York City and the metropolitan area who have completed thirteen weeks of basic infantry training with the First and Fifteenth Battalions, and are scheduled to depart next week were announced, it was said today by Brig. Gen. A.R. Emery, camp commander.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 5 -- Never Home, an 8-year-old gray mare, showed a liking for a sloppy track and led every inch of the way in the fifth race, best offering on today's program at the Charles Town Jockey Club.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 5 -- The possibility of Shanghai reverting to the horse and buggy and bicycle age was held imminently probable as further restrictions in gasoline sales became effective today. Although the monthly allotment is cut 50 per cent, no restrictions have yet been imposed on the amounts sold from stations.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 4 (Delayed) -- The Serbian regular army and Chetnik forces now operating in Yugoslavia under the unified command of Major Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch have had considerable success in establishing a front around what had been, since the Axis occupation of Yugoslavia last Spring, the largest guerrilla centers in the mountain regions south of Belgrade, according to information here today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 5 -- From a usually reliable source it is learned that the Finnish reply to the ultimative warning from the British Government has been delivered to the United States Minister in Helsinki, and that, moreover, the note was couched in a very conciliatory tone.

Today's events: "Die Walkuere," 2 P.M., and "Le Nozze di Figaro," 8 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Marcel Grandjany, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Warren Foley's Boy Choristers from the Church of the Blessed Sacrament, children's concert, home of Mrs. John Henry Hammond, 9 East Ninety-first Street, 3 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; Mikhail Sheyne, piano, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M.

District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn angrily charged yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had "scuttled" the prosecutor's broad criminal inquiry that uncovered an organized murder syndicate and had created a smoke-screen to hide his motives by raising the question of excessive expenditures by Mr. O'Dwyer's office.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The value of department store sales during November showed more of an increase than is usual at this season, the Federal Reserve Board said today. The board's seasonally adjusted index, based on the 1923-1925 average, rose to 115 last month, compared with 105 for October.

Although the interest of the New York football public will be concentrated on the game between the Giants and Dodgers at the Polo Grounds tomorrow, fans throughout the country will focus attention on Chicago, where the Bears and Cardinals will hold an intracity battle of their own.

A total of $589,000 of United States currency was shipped to New York from Argentina in November, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday in its monthly compilation of shipments and receipts of United States currency abroad.

VICHY, France, Dec. 5 -- Five days before the time limit set by the occupying authority for the discovery of the authors of a bombing and a shooting, in both of which German soldiers were victims, another German officer was shot in Paris this morning.

The dispute between Mayor La Guardia and District Attorney O'Dwyer over the use made of the police hi criminal investigation has been obscured by the recent rivalry of these two candidates for the Mayoralty and by veiled references to a ten-year-old unsolved Brooklyn murder case, the relevance of which, if any, has not been made clear.

IF the hockey race goes the way it did last year, it will be no surprise to hear the outcry: "Break lip the Bruins!" That was the way it went in baseball. "Break up the Yankees!" At the moment the Bruins look suspiciously like the Yankees on skates.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "Kind Friends and Gentle People." These were the last touching and most beautiful words ever written by your own beloved Stephen Foster.
NEW YORK Governor and Mrs. Sumner Sewall of Maine are at the St. Regis.

Crises Around S -- How much of the old Russia is now at work in Soviet Russia's battles against the German invader is bound to be a subject of discussion. One traditional Russian practice of a minor kind survives in the official Moscow communiques.

Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart died 150 years ago yesterday, but his music goes marching on. Creatively performed, it gathers strength and stature as the years go by. Witness yesterday afternoon's special performance of "Don Giovanni" at the Metropolitan Opera House which, under the inspiring leadership of Bruno Walter, was a source of endless delight.

VICHY, France, Dec. 5 (U.P.) -- Japan has 50,000 troops in French Indo-China, an authorized source said today in denying President Roosevelt's assertion that the Japanese forces there exceeded the number authorized in the French-Japanese accord.

It is out of character for Nazis to appear in the role of peacemakers. Those who live by the sword do not extend the olive branch in one quarter of the world unless they hope to advance their own enterprises in other regions. Yet there are authoritative reports that Hitler's representatives in the Far East have been exerting their best efforts to bring about an end of hostilities between Chiang Kai-shek and Japan.

Although Patrick Hamilton writes his thrillers within a small compass, he writes them with infinite craft and dexterity. "Angel Street," which sent a chill up the spine of the Golden Theatre last evening, comes off the top part of the theatre's top shelf.

The national defense effort has created a demand for complete revision of the national home economics frontier, it was asserted last night by Miss Edna Amidon, chief of the Bureau of Home Economics, United States Office of Education, at the opening session of a special two way conference it New York University's School of Educational West Fourth Street.
DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 6 -- The Rice Owls made one magnificent surge of 86 yards for a touchdown to defeat Southern Methodist, 6 -- 0, in the Southwest Conference football finale today.

WITH BRITISH ARMORED FORCES, North Africa, Dec. 3 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- Noah Hampson, a steel worker, of Waterbury, Conn., has been credited with destroying three German tanks and damaging two in North African fighting, it was learned today.

HOLIDAY shoppers are jamming stores to an uncomfortable point in many cities, but, according to reports, sales do not yet reflect the record throngs. There seems to be more looking than buying so far, except in the very busy defense centers, and in these areas newly established stores may hold down the increases of older concerns.

COROLLA, N.C., Dec. 6 -- Today we had the kind of shooting that justifies our five days of waiting, and although the weather man only partially cooperated we came in this afternoon with a limit bag of geese and a near-limit of ducks.

MIAMI BEACH -- There seems to be no room for doubt that the trains, the planes, the buses and the steamships serving Florida and all points South are going to be crowded on every run during the wintry days ahead.

William Porter Witherow, newly elected president of the National Association of Manufacturers, outlining a program for industry in an address over the Columbia Broadcasting System last night, called for "a new, fair and equitable national labor relations policy" and demanded that such a policy be written into the law.

WE were born at 1:30 P.M. on Thursday, Aug. 14, 1941 -- into the radio world, we mean. Our most arresting first impression was that here existed an entire solar system in which no one ever said to us, "Tell me, how do you two people collaborate?"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A House Military Affairs Subcommittee this week began an investigation into the activities of the "defense brokers" who have allegedly blossomed into riches as middlemen in the placing of defense contracts. Defense officials insist that no legitimate excuse has existed for manufacturers to employ brokers in obtaining defense work.

EVER since New York became the acknowledged center of the fashion world after Paris was blitzed out of the picture the town has bristled with fashion shows. At the height of the season these clothes parades, offering the latest in what the well dressed should wear, are daily occurrences.

SOME people are prone to argue that it is cruel to keep pets, particularly dogs, in the city. The 317,743 dog owners of Manhattan, not to mention all the people who keep fish, cats, monkeys and feathered friends, may be interested to know that this column does not agree.

THE first steamboat on what used to be called the Western Waters descended the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers in 1811, a year of comet and earthquake. In tie decades that followed that historic voyage the steamboat dominated the economic life of those two great valleys.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One group of our citizens fears we will be isolated, while another insists we should isolate ourselves. On this basic difference people of equal sincerity and patriotism split on the question of isolationism.

To strengthen and unify clubwomen's efforts in the national preparedness movement, a chairman for defense has been appointed in each borough by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs. The appointments were announced yesterday by the federation president, Mrs. Guy Percy Trulock, who has called on each department to work for defense as the main objective of her administration.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 6 -- With three-quarters of Italy's African empire controlled by the Britiish and her one remaining African possession, Libya, at present a battlefield for an offensive, it would be scarcely astonishing were the entire Italian public in the doldrums of defeatism.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- The United States is making energetic, practical contributions to the cause of mutual understanding among Western Hemisphere nations through economic and educational means, Nelson A. Rockefeller, coordinator of inter-American affairs, said today.
PLACE: The Yukon country of strong, cold and blinding snows, which James B. Hendryx in many stirring tales has staked out and developed as his own special fictional province.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- Governor James asserted tonight that if there were disunity in America the place to look for its source was in the New Deal Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Strikes in defense industries were at their lowest ebb in the history of the defense program this week as the House of Representatives passed the most drastic anti-strike legislation since the Roosevelt Administration has been in power.

College basketball gets into full swing this week. N.Y.U., Fordham, Dartmouth, Princeton, Syracuse, Colgate, Brown, Temple, Lafayette, Lehigh, Williams and Wesleyan, among others, join the parade, and the first of the doubleheaders at Madison Square Garden will be staged.

MEXICO CITY -- The fiesta most beloved of Mexicans and celebrated, therefore, with the loudest volleys of bangs -- the greatest displays of fireworks -- is dedicated to the Vir- gin of Guadalupe. This year the festival will be honored according to custom for three days, with the climax of the occasion on Dec. 12.

IN the tiny branches of a dwarf deciduous tree may lie the solution to American independence in the importation of rubber. This shrub, the guayule plant, native of the north central plateaus of Mexico, is now being cultivated in California, Texas and Arizona.

The first hulls of a fleet of thirty emergency-type vessels under construction for Great Britain at the yards at the Todd-Bath Iron Shipbuilding Corporation, South Portland, Me., will be launched together Dec. 20, it was announced yesterday by the Todd Shipbuilding Corporation.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 6 -- The New Jersey State Industrial Council of the C.I.O., endorsing unanimously President Roosevelt's foreign policy and pledging an increased output of the material of war, included in the same resolution today a terse warning that Hitler could not be defeated if the trade union movement in America were "shackled" by anti-strike legislation.
BERLIN, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
What will Hitler do if he succeeds in conquering Moscow? How will he take advantage of the temporary lull that would then come to organize the conquered areas of Russia?
ROME, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Today's Italian communique follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The American Medical Women's Association, which met here today, sent a telegram to President Roosevelt asking that women physicians be admitted on a parity with men in the Medical Reserve Corps of the Army and Navy.

The Bruins, holders of the Stanley Cup and the championship of the world, will meet the Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Inasmuch as the contest will be the first one in New York in a week, it is expected that a crowd of 16,000 fans will be on hand to watch the action.

WITH more than fifty new exhibitions on last week's calendar, the harried reviewer can perforce but point a finger here and there to aid the gallery-goer in his quest. To begin with, there is an exhibition of drawings by one of the outstanding living European masters of the medium -- work in pen and ink, in color and in wash -- at the Galerie St. Etienne.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 6 -- Averting defeat by a stroke in his opening match, Charles Brinton, national and intercollegiate squash racquets champion from Princeton University, went on to the semi-finals of the gold racquet tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 6 -- In the desperate struggle for power and influence in the rich and strategically vital Near and Middle East, the tested and successful revolutionary tactics of Germany have collided squarely with a force beyond their scope and control -- the action of the United States to halt the triumphant German Army at the threshold of Asia.
WHAT could be a more attractive climax to a good dinner than a genuine souffle? A delicate dish, the souffle calls for care; there are two great secrets of its success.

A paternal government must not be permitted to do for the individual what he ought to do for himself, the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness was told yesterday at the closing session of its biennial conference in the Hotel Astor.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Premier Luang Bipul Songgram said today that Thailand was ready to resist aggression from any quarter, but had concluded no secret pacts.

The declining birth rate in the nation will bring a demand in the future for smaller homes, the Federal Home Loan Bank will predict in its forthcoming report to Congress for the fiscal year 1941. The steadily decreasing birth rate, as revealed by each Census since 1890, shows that families are shrinking in size and the proportion of older persons in the household is rising.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- American industry may soon take the initiative in asking organized labor to sit down with it and draft a voluntary program for cooperation and uninterrupted defense production for the duration of the emergency.

Elimination or substantial curtailment of unessential and expensive services to customers is gaining ground and promises to feature efforts to hold down rising operating expenses in retailing next year, according to distribution authorities here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- After an air journey that represented, in mileage about threequarters of the distance around the globe, Maxim Litvinoff, new Ambassador from the Soviet Union, landed here today by clipper plane and voiced gratitude to this country for its "substantial" aid to the Red Army."

RUMANIA has postally commemorated the crossing of the Dniester River by Rumanian forces invading the U.S.S.R. "Transnistria" (Across the Dniester) is inscribed along the base of 6-lei light brown, 12L violet and 24L deep blue stamps which present the figure of Duca Voda, a military commander in the Ukraine in 1654-86.
WILL ROGERS is a living figure throughout this book: and his wife's part is notable for its wholesome self-effacement.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -- Winter visitors, already arriving in Florida to escape the early frost and snows, are mingling in the streets of St. Augustine with men in service from Camp Blanding, the nearest military encampment.

IN this story triptych Helen Douglas Irvine has, as in "Fray Mario" and "Mirror of a Dead Lady," made valuable use of her long acquaintance with South America. Soon after 1922, when she first visited the country, she made her home on a fundo (large, farmed estate) in the beautiful Aconcagua Valley whose river is fed by Andean glaciers.
OTTAWA, Canada, Nov. 29 -- Canada, like the United States, has recently observed Education Week, and one word stands out, "responsibility."

ROME, Dec. 6 -- King Victor Emmanuel returned to Rome today from a nineteen-day tour of Sicily to bolster up the morale of those towns hardest hit by the Royal Air Force. The sovereign, the communique stated, visited only the places where "the enemy's wickedness especially persisted and where the enemy prepared his ambush with greatest cowardice."

Two years ago housing, with an emphasis on slum clearance, was widely recognized as a proper field for Federal, State and local agencies. It called for a long-term program, with a proper division of the task between subsidized housing for low-income groups; housing at cost, or nearly so, through limited dividend corporations; and commercial housing accompanied by an effort to bring down expenses of construction and maintenance.

Several hundred members of society, whose average age is in the thirties, are making final arrangements for the annual Gay Thirties Dinner Dance to be given Thursday on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Boys Club of New York.

VISIT: At a Moscow airport one day last week the Soviet's red hammer-and-sickle flag waved besides Poland's white and red banner. General Wladyslaw Sikorski, Premier of the exiled Polish Government, had arrived for a visit with Joseph Stalin. The two Premiers talked about the formation of a Polish army on Russian soil and signed a declaration of friendship and mutual aid.
The Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d and 104th Streets, recently received a number of gifts for its collections that illustrate varied aspects of New York life of the past.

With the last important dog show of 1941 a matter of history, fanciers already are making plans for the coming year despite the uncertainties that loom ahead in this country as well as in other parts of the world.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 6 -- One of the most important developments in the field of nutrition and dietary education has been the attention paid to vitamins and calories -- particularly vitamins, which have been given an enormous amount of publicity in the last decade.

The accomplishments of the American Red Cross were praised yesterday by the Countess of Limerick, a British Red Cross official, who departed for Europe aboard the Pan American Airways Yankee Clipper, which left the seaplane base at La Guardia Field at 11:55 A.M., eight hours after the departure of the Capetown Clipper on the inaugural mail flight to Leopoldville, Belgian Congo, Africa.
Max Baer wants to return to the ring and will do so if present plans materialize.

ISLAMORADA, Fla. -- One of the newest of American hobbies, the collection of treesnail shells, has brought new attention to the coral isles of the chain of Florida Keys, extending southward from the mainland to southernmost Key West and to a few of the Cuban islands.

"While defense must and does come first in our thoughts and activities, General Motors recognizes that it has an obligation to prepare so far as possible for the post-war period," Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation, said last weak in an interview.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- With completion of the extended draft program that Prime Minister Winston Churchill has asked -- and the bill now pending before the House of Commons is certain to become law, though it may be slightly modified -- Britain will have registered 17,175,000 men and women for war services.

Renovations in older houses to provide living quarters for defense workers who are in need of low-rent accommodations offer the best solution of the problem, according to State Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh, who says such workers can pay enough rent to make the cost of the changes profitbale to the owner, a minimum investment would be needed to transform dwellings and tenements into livable structures, he says.

Leading figures in all phases of the ski sport will be on hand today when the progressive Western Massachusetts Winter Sports Council holds its annual meeting in conjunction with the Winter sports section of Massachusetts State College's Recreation Conference.

The diversity of industrial activities in the New York and Northern New Jersey areas and the huge volume of defense orders being placed there are creating many new home communities in those States, points out the modern homes division of Sears, Roebuck Co.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Air Minister Sir Archibald Sinclair in a speech at Newcastle today declared Britain's aim to be to bring the Germans to their knees by the mightiest air attack ever envisaged -- to smash her by internal damage as the sea blockade damaged her in the World War.

IF any one has the idea that The Pierpont Morgan Library is a settled institution, a glance at the report of its history for the last five years will dispel the illusion. The library is a very busy place, continually expanding, changing, working over its resources and identifying them, arranging lectures and exhibitions, and helping other educational centers and research students.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A suggestion that the Office of Production Management set up an agency within its division of purchases, where manufacturers' agents or representatives might be registered, after thorough investigation, much as securities brokers and dealers are registered by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was advanced here today by Darrow Lyons, statistical and research specialist in OPM.

Something of the fears and hopes of education is set forth in current documents at hand. "Times are too hazardous," says Professor Mullins in his report as executive secretary of the College Entrance Examination Board, to warrant any forecast of what the enrollment of the colleges of the board will be even in the near future."

A DVORAK memorial tablet by Agop Agopoff will be unveiled at the ceremonies to be held under the official sponsorship of the Czecho-Slovak Government, through its Foreign Minister, Jan Masaryk, and its Minister Plenipotentiary in Washington, Colonel Vladimir S. Hurban, Saturday, Dec. 13, at 11:45 P.M., at 326 East Seventeenth Street, the residence of the Czech composer from 1892 to 1895.

Executives of Wall Street banks are preparing now for the annual meetings of stockholders in January, and more than one president is debating whether to omit the customary forecast of business and banking conditions. January traditionally is bank-meeting month, and aside from reports of bank earnings stockholders have come to expect bank officers to peer into the future and speak with conviction.

Community groups of volunteers, acting either throught already established local agencey or newly founded organizations of their own, were declared yesterday by speakers at a special conference of home economists to be the nub around which the entire national civilian defense program must grow.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 6 -- Equestriennes from Greenwich Academy, led by the Misses Priscilla Meek and Ethel Skakel, retained the team laurels in the second annual interschool horse show held today at the Round Hill Club stables.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The suggestion offered by Hans Schmidt in your columns recently for bringing about peace with Germany gives one cause for skepticism. It may just be possible that the so-called peace feelers put out by the anti-Nazis within Germany, were actually put out by the Nazis themselves.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States will seek broad changes in the price control bill when hearings are begun next week before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

John Charles Wilson, internationally known television engineer, who held many patents on television inventions, died Friday of Hodgkin's disease at his home, 37-25 223d Street, Bayside, Queens, after a long illness. His age was 32.

Ushering in the observance of First Annual Bible Week this week, rabbis in sermons yesterday emphasized the importance of the influence of the Bible on a wartorn world. The American-Japanese discussions, peace aims and the state of religion were other sermon subjects.

THREE hours by train from Washington, two from New York and only twenty bouncing minutes on the Paoli Local from Philadelphia sit the solid Gothic buildings of Bryn Mawr College. Planted close to the hum and thrum of the world about them, just how near do Bryn Mawr's 500-odd girls feel to the vital goings-on that are paraded across then newspaper headlines each day?

MEXICO CITY -- Today Mexico's Government, through the semi-official tourist bureau, the A.M.T. reports that the "tourist front" has been stabilized. Lucas de Palacio, head of the A.M.T., says "the entire republic is being educated to its responsibilities toward the unprecedented flow of visitors."

Americans are asked to observe this week as Bible Week. To thousands of us the proposal is a pointed reminder of a needless lack in our lives. So many best-selling things are required reading nowadays, so many voices must be heard, that the best of all books stands neglected on its shelf, gathering dust, and the wisest voices of the ages reach us only in echoes from memory.

SOME programs, fortunately enough for them, keep popping up on the air, a happy circumstance which has attended the quiz, "What's My Name?" since its network advent in 1938. Now word has been received that a sponsor has come along to extend the program's string and its next opening is set for Jan. 6 at 8 P.M. over WOR and eighty-one Mutual stations.

A six-day conference on "Spiritual Inter-Americanism" will be held in Miami, Fla., with delegates from various parts of the United States and various American republics, from Dec. 29 to Jan. 3, it was announced yesterday.

OUT in Hollywood, Billy Wilder and Charles Brackett have recently discovered, with pain, how very, very old they are. Happily assigned to write a script for Samuel Goldwyn entitled "Ball of Fire," the authors invented for their central figure a tall, spare, studious professor of English, played by Gary Cooper, of course.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- A German commerce raider, a 10,000-ton converted merchantman, has been sunk somewhere in the South Atlantic by the British cruiser Dorsetshire, which finished off the crack Nazi battleship Bismarck last May, the Admiralty announced tonight.

William J. Mack, chairman of the arbitration committee of the Bar Association of the City of New York, discloses that a plan for voluntary settlement of labor disputes in defense industries has been suggested by the committee in a communication addressed to Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.

MEANWHILE, quite independently, comes another announcement, this time from Samuel M. Kootz, whose "bombshell" letter, last August, started so extended a controversy. Mr. Kootz informs us that he has been engaged by R.H. Macy Co. to arrange "an exhibition of modern paintings" in the Macy Galleries.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- Puerto Rico, a tropical resort under the Stars and Stripes, is prepared for the biggest influx of Winter vistors in the island's history. Heavy hotel bookings for the Winter months indicate that Puerto Rico will attract more visitors this season than it did during the record-breaking Winter of 1939-40.
Police Commissioner Valentine denied yesterday that he was contemplating any change in the staff of sixty-five detectives assigned to the office of District Attorney O'Dwyer of Brooklyn.

THE day may not be far distant when United States Army airmen will lie prone on their stomachs instead of sitting bolt upright as they go into aerial action. For, according to the current issue of the Army and Navy Journal, the United States has been conducting experiments in prone flying for some time.

LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 7 -- At one minute after midinght today [7:01 P.M. Saturday, Eastern standard time] Britain went to war with Finland, Rumania and Hungary. The declaration now effective amounts to little more than the establishment of a political front.

THE story is told of three Hollywood people who sat wishfully brooding over the worst possible things that could befall a paperhanger currently in the news. One suggested boiling in oil; the second dwelt on the possibilities of having him drawn through the streets in a cage.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Soviet dispatches reported today that German forces were retreating in disorder on two vital salients of the Moscow front under the blows of violent Soviet counterattacks launched after a biting wind had sent the temperature far below zero.
MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (Distributed by The Assocated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midday communique said:
Men stood to arms along the shores and upon the islands of the Western Pacific yesterday as the storm of war, roaring eastward out of Europe, clouded the skies of the Orient.

Although shorn of her national crown last season, Miss Helena Mroczkowska of the Fencers Club indicated that she still is a power in metropolitan women's fencing circles when she triumphed handily in the open competition for the Vince prizes on the strips of the Salle Santelli yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board intervened today in the dispute between OPM and the Rural Electrification Administration and handed down as the government's policy for the duration of the emergency the rule that all new power projects, whether sponsored by government bodies or private industry, would be treated alike, and that all must be essential to natoinal defense or the public health and safety.

Plans for the formation of a "volunteer land corps," to consist of high school and college students working on Vermont farms next Summer at "soldiers' wages," were announced yesterday by Dorothy Thompson, writer, and founder of the Ring of Freedom, at the closing sessions of the tenth regional New York conference of the Progressive Education Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Greta Garbo's new picture, "Two-Faced Woman," will be withdrawn from moving picture theatres for revision after showings up to Dec. 16, it was learned today from Eastern sources which quoted an order from the New York office of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures Corporation to its branch offices.

Alarmed over what they term "unfair subsidized competition," builders and developers of Bergen County, N.J., are planning to protest to the Federal Government against any further construction of defense homes in the county by the Federal Works Agency.

GALVESTON, Texas -- The Gulf Highway offers motorists an interesting southernmost route through Louisiana and Texas. From Lake Charles, La., to Galveston, Texas, it laps the blue water of the Gulf of Mexico on one side and a vast oil empire on the other.

WHILE Japanese military leaders talk of upholding the national prestige, Japan is well on the way to losing something that many in nonmilitary circles consider more precious -- the traditional Japanese woman.

Early response to Spring coats and suits in the wholesale market has been excellent, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Production an Winter merchandise was almost at a standstill, as manufacturers threw their efforts into getting out Spring lines.

WITH the approach of "the day" when the season's first snowfall blankets hills and mountains, New York's skiers stop sedentary living. They jam gymnasiums and climb winding stairs to condition their muscles.

Tucked between the lines of this book is an engaging lesson in tolerance, but children will love it first for its pictures which exhibit in minute detail a lively and ingenious fancy. The Whosits are among those creatures which youth has never seen but which it firmly believes, at picture book age, could and should exist, and in this case one agrees heartily.

VICHY, France, Dec. 6 -- While General Maxime Weygand, who retired on Nov. 20, is rusticating near Toulon his immediate predecessor in the post of Chief of the General Staff, General Eugene Debeney, recalls in the Figaro today that he was his comrade in arms and reveals that on May 19, 1940, when he received supreme command as a forlorn hope, Marshal Foch's former aide thought of seeking death in the field.
Freedom and Schools The strongest and sincerest plea for democracy among the books of recent years comes from an exceedingly appropriate source -- namely, the nation's school teachers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Paced by a Seabiscuit in football harness, a human dynamo who went over, under and around his opposition, Mississippi State College scored a 26-to-13 victory over the University of San Francisco's Dons in their intersectional game today.

With nothing more to motivate them than the spirit that brought about the McCoy-Hatfield feud, the Giants and the Dodgers will clash before some 50,000 spectators at the Polo Grounds this afternoon. But the attention of fans and players is bound to be distracted a bit by the Bear-Cardinal battle in Chicago.
Tentative agreement was reached yesterday on a thirty-day truce in the threatened strike against gasoline station operators in Manhattan and the Bronx.

MIAMI, Fla. -- The eighteenth annual Miami $10,000 open golf tournament will start on Thursday at the Miami springs Country Club and continue through next Sunday. Players enrolled from military units within the Greater Miami area are pleased over the tournament committee's recent decision to give the first 175 paid entrants preferred starting times instead of devoting one day to the time-honored qualifying round of eighteen holes.

Clint Walsh, former New York policeman and now a private investigator, is persuaded to go to Shark Island, off the coast of Florida, to hunt for a man who has been kidnapped and who may be dead. Shark Island proves to be a rather desolate place though of great natural beauty.

IT should be a good Summer, in fact, it should be a magnificent Summer, the best since 1924, when for some unaccountable reason Irving Berlin Co. ceased their "Music Box Revues." For here is a wire from Mr. Berlin on the Coast, sent in answer to a question about whether there is to be another such revue:

Proof of the impact of international and national complications upon the minds of college undergraduates has been in evidence on the Manhattan College campus this Fall through the weekly sampling of student opinion and the campus forums sponsored by juniors and seniors majoring in social science.

ABOUT the time of the first snowfall a lot of American families are going to begin to wonder where to go to get warmer, and will begin thinking of the lands to the south. A large proportion of these families will decide on Florida, and it must be admitted that their choice will be a good one.
MANILA, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- The Cabinet, meeting at the Summer capital of Baguio, decided today to cancel plans for inaugural ceremonies on Dec. 30 for President Quezon's second term.

WITH another Florida fishing tournament soon to open, anglers throughout the country are again preparing to seek official recognition of their champion catches. Since 1939 a non-profit organization, the International Game Fish Association has been keeping records which are recognized by the American Museum of Natural History.
"WHY do you think you are officer material?" the major asks bluntly. The private gulps, shifts his feet uneasily as he stares at the board of officers.

Six hundred executives are expected to attend the thirty-fifth annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to be held next Thursday and Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Companies having more than 90 per cent of life insurance in force in the United States and Canada will be represented.
Editor The New York Times Book Review: Frances Grant's comment on the literary likeness of "Rebecca" to "A Sucessora" obliges me to announce another striking similitude.

When old Sheriff Morgan was badly wounded by a gunslinger in Grat Lassiter's saloon, young Jim Nightingale gunned the would-be killer and then took over the Sheriff's job temporarily. He knew that Lassiter was a "yellow skunk" who had framed an innocent cowboy for one of his own robberies.

A new development in the foreign trade field became known yesterday with the announcement that a London firm has established a branch here to handle export trade that has been affected by regulations laid down by the British Government with regard to the activities of British exporters under the lease-lend arrangements with the United States.

Misa Constance Cleveland Cutting, elder daughter of Mrs. Heyward Cutting and the late Mr. Cutting, was formally introduced to society yesterday afternoon at a tea dance given by her mother in the ballroom of the Colony Club. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a gown of turquoise blue taffeta, made with a basque bodice and a full skirt.

THE Germans, in their bitterly fought advance into Russia, have now occupied Leo Tolstoy's ancestral home, Yasnaya Polyana, near Tula Reports do not indicate whether the estate buildings, which had been turned into a museum, have been destroyed.

VICHY, France, Dec. 6 -- Henri Bergson, the French philosopher, who was of Jewish origin, had desired to become a Catholic, according to what is described as his last will and testament as quoted by Floris de Lattre in an article to be published in the current issue of the Revue Philosophique.

THE Winter cruise season is here again. And despite the defense program that continually calls in ships for special duty, there are a considerable number left for tourists, and considerable space on ships carrying men and paraphernalia to our new bases.

AFTER seven years the Shelter Belt project, extending through six States from Northern Texas to the Canadian border, is playing its part in the new winning of the West. By the end of this year 190,000,000 trees will have been planted.

Arthur H. Brasch, a broker who was investigated by the FBI as a suspected German agent after a previous suicide attempt at Atlantic City in September, killed himself early yesterday by leaping from his seventeenth floor room at the Hotel St. Moritz.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The texts of Britain's notes to the governments of Finland, Hungary and Rumania, issued today, follow:

From observations based on a recent tour of the United States, Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick, editorial writer of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday that "a curious dislocation of life," resulting from the widespread migrations of workers, was causing a dangerous uncertainty in the minds of the people.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A saddle horse, which has captured top honors in every major horse show of the past two years added her twenty-eighth consecutive victory tonight with a blue ribbon in the $2,500 five-gaited saddle stake on the closing night of the International Livestock Exposition.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Historic Baltimore City College, beaten only once since 1935, got the call tonight to meet Miami Senior High School Christmas night in the nation's top post-season intersectional high school football game.

THE Fiji Islands, strategic South Pacific outpost of the British Empire, were dramatically linked with the United States when the Pacific Clipper recently made its first scheduled stop at Suva, capital of the islands.

A wider market for mercantile properties in this city is resulting from the demand for space under the national defense program and already has created a new buying trend in the investment field, in the opinion of Clinton W. Blume, vice president in charge of sales of William A. White Sons.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 6 -- It was not wanderlust, but the love of her offspring that caused Claire, the 6-year-old Holatein cow owned by the Tuscan Dairy Farm, Inc., to roam through an underground sewer in Irvington for several hours last Nov. 12.
TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- Japan has known intermittent hostilities for the last ten years. For the past four and one-half years she has been engaged in the biggest war in her history.

AMONG the many books which describe the debacle in France in 1940, and the personal and distressing experiences of various authors, "The Devil in France" possesses qualities beyond comparison. Among many others, there is in this narrative the quality of serenity, of simplicity and genuineness.

OCALA, Fla. -- Florida vacations may be streamlined to fit the slimmest budget. On $30 a week -- and less -- touriats may spend the season at a comfortable hotel and rove over the State, sight-seeing, at will.

THE union of England first with Scotland and then with Ireland ruined two great capitals, turned them into frustrated cities living on their pride in the days of their Parliaments. Thinking of eighteenth-century Edinburgh, a Scots poet wrote:

Stressing a theme of Pan-American unity, the gala Coffee Ball -- Fiesta Pan-Americana to be presented Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria -- will provide for several hundred guests one of the most colorful entertainments yet devised this season.

Each week in these days of national preparedness and defense near-by units of the United States Power Squadrons are laying plans for free instruction courses in navigation and small-boat handling and obtaining even larger auditoriums to accommodate the new throngs of applicants.

KUIBYSHEV, Dec. 6 -- Josef Stalin, as Defense Commissar, has inaugurated during the past several weeks an entirely new series of measures calculated to encourage the hard-pressed soldiers of the Red Army and to improve their efficiency in the struggle against the Germans.

The cotton market moved irregularly yesterday, although the undertone continued steady. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures, after losing as much as 16 points in early trading, closed near their best levels of the session at net changes of 8 points lower to 2 points higher.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Asserting "it's about time somebody did something about it," United States Representative James P. McGranery (D.-Pa.) said tonight he intended to ask Attorney General Francis Biddle to investigate the position of Mike Jacobs, New York promoter, in the boxing world.

Dr. Robert W. Searle, chairman of the social service bureau of the magistrates courts, announced yesterday that a campaign for funds to expand the work of the bureau would be launched at a dinner at the Biltmore Hotel next Wednesday night.

An extensive research program in the fields of post-war planning will be one of the major activities of the American Trade Association Executives in the forthcoming year, it was revealed yesterday by announcement of committee appointments for 1941-42 by W.J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association and president of A.T. A.E.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The United States tonight ordered Finnish ships in American ports put under protective custody, finally and reluctantly taking the view that her one-time close international friend was now part and parcel of the Axis.

HAVANA, Dec. 6 -- President Fulgencio Batista today sent a message to Congress, asking for the declaration of a state of national emergency that would place full governing powers in the hands of the Chief Executive and his Cabinet to prepare the island for war.

THE celebration of the hundreth anniversary of the birth of Hudson marks in the Argentine the development of a great popular movement in favor of the distinguished author and the human and literary values contained in his books.
There is one big advantage in giving people a Christmas gift for the house -- the gift really includes every one, and if it's a houseful of difficult people, you solve a lot of problems at once.

As part of the nation-wide celebration of President Roosevelt's sixtieth, birthday on Jan. 30, a Diamond Jubilee Ball is being planned here for that night. The event will take place in the grand ballroom and adjoining suites of the Waldorf-Astoria and its proceeds will be donated, in equal shares, to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and its Greater New York Chapter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A proposal to centralize administration of the defense program under a new Cabinet officer attracted strong support in Congress today, with Senator Mead of New York declaring that some such plan must be adopted if little business is to be saved from destruction.

OCALA, Fla. -- Marion County in Central Florida is beginning what is expected to be a record Winter season. This week sportsmen are tracking deer in the giant Ocala National Forest; sightseers are thronging Silver Springs, and the "A.T.A." are gathering for their "home-going" at Ocala's municipal trailer camp.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today in a quiet trade after a week of irregularly higher quotations, particularly for cattle and sheep. Wholesale prices for pork loins and dressed beef showed little change.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Mr. Thomas Kernan's answer to my letter in your issue of Nov. 2 unfortunately demands a reply. Not for my personal justification but in the interest of those German refugees who became Foreign Legionnaires and several thousands of whom are today doing compulsory labor in the Sahara Desert.

Prior to 1930 it was observed that the burden of the estate tax fell most heavily upon the residuary legatees of estates, represented as a rule by the widow, children and the closer relatives of the decedent. The cause of this development was the fact that legacies were paid without any deduction for estate taxes, thus compelling the residuary legatees to assume the entire burden of these imposts.

With Helen Traubel singing Bruennhilde in Wagner's "Die Walkuere" for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House and three artists making their debut, yesterday's performance of the music drama took on added interest.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- Tourists to Florida stop off for a visit to the Great Okefenokee Swamp. It is not far off the beaten track, only a few miles from Jacksonville. The swamp lies in northern Florida and southeastern Georgia.

THESE volumes -- listed below -- on the state of the realm are unique. Nothing like them has ever appeared in Canada. Nothing comparable has ever been undertaken in the United States. Long after the present generation has disappeared they will remain a milestone in Canadian history and literature.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Apropos of the letter from Mr. Henry Morton Robinson which you publish in your issue of Nov. 16, allow me to cry, quite frankly, mea culpa and peccavi. Mr. Robinson chides me because, in my review of Madariaga's "Hernan Cortes," I cited Henry Dwight Sedgwick's book on the same subject, published in 1926, but did not cite Mr. Robinson's "Stout Cortez," published in 1931.

Purchases and sales of FHA-insured mortgages by private financial institutions were 10 per cent greater during the first nine months of this year than during the same period of 1940, announces Federal Housing Administrator Abner H. Ferguson.

THE Moffats, five of them, make up the kind of family which we like to think of as typifying some of the nicest American traits. Their adventures with a horse and wagon, and on a new trolley-car line, place their period as some twenty years ago, but they could just as well be living in the beloved yellow house, the very nicest on New Dollar Street, in a Connecticut village, today.

From an Icelandic saga Hedvig Collin the Danish artist, has re- told the story of one of the earliest kings of her country and his small brother. We are first introduced to Roar and Helga, 5 and 7 year old sons of King Halfdan, as they practice the skills demanded of Danish princelings.

A DICTIONARY of American Biography having been provided by the enterprise of the Council of Learned Societies and the munificence of the late Adolph S. Ochs, the provision of a historical dictionary was a natural supplementary step.

NEW YORK'S taxpayers this week could point to their municipal airport as more than a model for all modern terminals, more than a great showplace. Their airport had proved to be an excellent financial investment.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Singapore's mighty and constantly swelling defenses were in a state of mobilized readiness today as urgent orders recalled sailors of Britain's Far Eastern fleet to their ships and all army and air force personnel to their barracks.

Producers of consumers goods in the third quarter of 1941 extended their gains over a year ago despite the heavy increase in taxation. The combined net profits of sixty-nine makers of food and beverages, textiles and apparel, cigars, drugs and miscellaneous items were $72,083,233 for the period, a gain of 32.8 per cent, compared with the $54,259,001 earned in the third quarter of 1940.

In the opinion of Dr. Milan Hodza, the last Premier of Czechoslovakia before Munich, the salvation of Central Europe and the peace of Europe after Germany is defeated will depend upon the formation of a federation of the smaller States between the Baltic and Aegean seas.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 6 -- Moving over from Bowie, where he had won two races, E.J. Johnson's Relious drove to victory today in the Chateau Martin Handicap. With Apprentice Paul Glidewell doing the booting, the 4-to-1 shot came to the wire two and a half lengths in front.

To the Music Editor: MUSICAL snobbery is with us again. Mr. Schnabel and Mr. Sessions (in last Sunday's TIMES) view with alarm the fact that "music for entertainment" is invading places devoted to "music of and for experience."

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- A C.I.O. mass picketing demonstration outside the W.T. Grant variety store at Palisade Avenue and New Main Street here was broken up by the police at noon today. No arrests were made, but the police tore signs off some of the pickets who refused to comply with orders to remove them.

"BIG STICK": In the White House last week newspaper men gathered for President Roosevelt's regular press conference. When the President indi- cated that he would talk about Japan, a white-haired correspondent with a snowy, close-clipped mustache stepped forward and handed the Chief Executive a gray ash walking-stick with a huge, gnarled knob at one end.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Starting in 1942, the America First Committee will carry to the polling places of the nation its fight to keep the United States out of the war. Except in the South, it will mobilize its supporters in a drive "to return to Congress only those Representatives and Senators who faithfully execute the people's trust" and who "oppose further steps to involve us in war."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- The University of California at Los Angeles Bruins and the favored Trojans of the University of Southern California staged another of their crosstown football dogfights today before a roaring throng of 65,000 and wound up in a 7-7 deadlock as the curtain came down on the 1941 Pacific Coast Conference campaign.

Patrolman Thomas J. Casey, off duty and out of uniform, was shot and killed at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning by one of a group of suspicious characters he accosted on Fifty-second Street near Lexington Avenue, a block from his station house, as he was going home.
The rapid and substantial decrease of food rations in Switzerland reflects the serious food situation in Europe.

HAVANA -- Here are twelve hours the traveler does not forget though he lives to be a hundred. And it happens in Havana, ninety minutes from Miami, U.S.A. It begins at 6 o'clock in the evening, at the Floridita, on a slit of a street called Obispo.

NEW ORLEANS -- Grand Isle has a primitive tang that might be a bracer for jaded travelers this season. It lies some seventy miles south of New Orleans, with a group of Islands in the Gulf of Mexico. It is about six miles long and over a mile wide.

Home decorators in many cases are choosing colonial furnishings rather than modern, because in the older style they find a satisfying sense of elegance. Whether it takes the form of unobtrusive beauty or more ornate formality, this quality is becoming an important one in interior decoration.

A general pooling of educational resources, especially among publicly supported institutions, is proposed by Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of Cooper Union, in his annual report to the trustees of the union, made public yesterday. United action by the nation's colleges and universities in order to achieve economies has been made inevitable by increasing financial strain, he says.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the records of earliest jury trials (A.D. 1300) in England, as related from sources by Dean Wigmore ("Kaleidoscope of Justice" -- 1941), there is found an incomparable forerunner of the "blue ribbon" jury which is the subject of some discussion in New York State today.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- The American observer and the two American newspaper men taken prisoner by the Italians in Libya are said to be in a detention camp, where they were first taken, in several accounts from Italian war correspondents published today.

Norman, Okla. MANY wild plants, found in woods, pastures and meadows and now neglected as human food, can be used in cookery. Proof of this can be found in the experiments of Dr. Milton Hopkins, Professor of Botany at the University of Oklahoma.

ERNEST HEMINGWAY'S "For Whom the Bell Tolls" is now a classic or, to be precise, it is, in the opinion of critics, the book by an American author, published in the past three years, "most likely to attain the stature of a classic."

MUCH of the world this week will pause to pay tribute to the genius and pioneering spirit of Marconi, who, just forty years ago, proved that "wireless" might bridge an ocean. Marconi reasoned that if it was possible to signal a few hundred miles over land or water -- a feat he had already accomplished -- perhaps the Atlantic was not too wide for a test.

THOUGH the recording industry is dominated by three large companies, a number of other enterprises produce disks on a limited but valuable scale. Each addition to this latter group enlivens the record scene, for the small company, more often than not, selects an area that can stand more cultivation.
FOR the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City THE NEW YORK TIMES today makes its thirtieth annual appeal.

LONDON. VARIOUS well-known writers have been explaining in The Listener why the present war has yielded such a scanty crop of poetry. Stephen Spender thinks it may ultimately produce an epic and a heroic poetry, but he does not believe it will produce either a Rupert Brooke or a Wilfred Owen, because moods of naive enthusiasm and of spiritual defeatism are equally unsuited to the times.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Binger of 182 Bast Seventy-fifth Street gave a reception with, dancing yesterday afternoon at their home to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Charlotte Hunnewell Binger. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a gown of red velvet and carried a bouquet of orchids.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The javelin throw, ancient event of Grecian warriors, was tossed out of the list of events in the Big Ten today.

IN "The Tall Brothers," a novel of strange and rather complex purpose, Leslie Evan Schlytter has told the story of a Wisconsin lumbering town during the thirty-odd years of its useful existence. In 1897 Cabotville was little more than a woods camp carved out of the heart of the finest stand of white pine in the Wisconsin wilderness.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 6 -- The increasing concentration of power in the Federal Government has been inspired largely by the failure of the States to keep in step with the administrative needs of a changing world, Governor Charles Edison told the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards today at the closing business session of its annual convention.

FICTION How democracy in Austria was executed by that nation's own politicians well before the Hitler march is the subject of "Victory Was Slain" (Alliance Book Corporation, $2.50), a moving novel of the bloody days of 1934, by Hilde Abel.

HOLLYWOOD. THE motion-picture industry's new public relations policy of meeting aggression with aggression crumbled this past week in the face of the Legion of Decency's condemnation of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "TwoFaced Woman" for suggestiveness and a frivolous attitude toward marriage, and Archbishop Spellman's unprecedented advice to his diocese in New York not to see it.

The deliberate will of the German conqueror is to make the resources of France available to him in the present war -- not only the industrial plants which already are filling his orders to 30 or 40 per cent of capacity (a proportion accounted for by dislocated transportation and food restrictions), but also naval and air bases and even the fleet itself.

A VIOLENT upheaval shakes the Atlantic sea bottom somewhere off the coast of Portugal. Its human effects are small. Some chimneys topple into the streets of Lisbon. Lamps sway in Seville. People are frightened -- then they laugh it off.
Fred Trump's new home development along the Belt Parkway, Brooklyn, adjoining Bensonhurst City Park at the Bay Parkway exit will be open for public inspection today.

SPRING FEVER raged in this country for better than a century. It began as an antidote to the fevers that afflicted the low-countries of the South in the Summer, to the fashionable complaint of elegant females of the period -- consumption -- and to the consequences of high living in the males -- gout, rheumatism and gallstones.

WASHINGTON. THE No. 2 men in great enterprises of government usually have much work to do and little public glory to show for it. This is particularly true of the No. 2 men in the Navy and War Departments. These men are unique in one respect: they enjoy the close friendship of President Roosevelt, yet neither of them has engaged in active political work in behalf of the Executive.

LONDON, (By Wireless.) MASSIVE stone forts built in the last century to guard Portsmouth and Southampton against the French now are seeing active service again when an enemy is expected from the direction of France.

The New York racing season of 1942 will run to Nov. 7, an extension of a week, it was learned yesterday from a source close to the State Racing Commission, which now is considering the schedule. Thus the Empire State campaign will last more than 180 days, making it the longest since the early years of this century.

WHEN Ezra Dane and his mother planned this book they decided to concentrate on a single town, instead of telling the whole story of the gold days of California. They chose "Columbia, Tuolumne County, the Gem of the Southern Mines,' whose rise and decline exemplify the history of the region."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- In two experiences with government controls over the productive economy in the United States the controls were relinquished to a large extent at the end of the emergency, according to Henry H. Fowler, assistant general counsel for the Civilian Supply Division of the Office of Production Management.

TODAY, more than ever, the story of Hi Jolly and his convoy of freight ships of the deaert is in high favor, owing to the recently organized move by the Western States to "See the Old West" by visiting those landmarks that dramatize the taming of that region.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Operations in the wheat market today were at a somewhat slower pace than earlier in the week, with traders inclined to even up their positions in the market rather than to make commitments. While selling pressure was relatively light the demand was not aggressive, and prices on the Board of Trade were on the down grade, with the close 1/4 to 7/8 cent a bushel lower than yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- The offensive against Moscow is not going well enough for the Germans to make any official claims as to its progress, and for the third day in succession the High Command communique abstains from any specific reference to the Moscow front.

THE newly organized Philadelphia League of Composers will affiliate with the Philadelphia Twentieth Century Music Group in a joint aim to present contemporary chamber music and promote interest in living composers.

IT has been suggested that travelers embarking for the first time upon a fishing trip in Florida ought to watch the sturdy gentleman in Miami's Seminole village who wreatles with alligators. It is a sort of mental conditioning which will render them immune to surprise at anything that may arise.

Mother Marie Vincentia, Superior General of the Roman Catholic Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul, died yesterday at the Mother House, College of Mount Saint Vincent-on-Hudson. She was 68 years old.

AMIENS, the chateau of the Marquis de Hautecloque, ten miles from that ancient Picardian city, Paris, London and the Calais region are the scenes of an espionage novel of the present war in which Colonel Duncan Grant -- who played the leading part in several other stories by this author, notably "The U Plan" -- matches wits with a brilliant officer of the German General Staff.

Fritzie Zivic will have a chance Friday night in Madison Square Garden to fight his way back into the welterweight championship picture. The doughty Pittsburgher, who held the title until he met Freddie (Red) Cochrane last Summer, is to battle Young Kid McCoy, Detroit challenger, in a bout listed for ten rounds.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Dec. 7 -- At home in colonial America, John D. Rockefeller Jr. has made his house here, Bassett Hall, a headquarters for peace and leisurely living. As the squire of the Virginia town, to restore which he spent $20,000,000, he prides himself on the "simple life" that he and his wife enjoy during the two months they spend there yearly.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- Two goals by Al Everts, sophomore center, in a ten-minute overtime period gave the Harvard varsity a 5-3 victory in its season opener at the Boston Skating Club tonight with the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Indoor polo was resumed at Essex Troop armory tonight after a year's lapse, with the Ramapo Valley trio defeating the newly formed New York Polo Club, 13 to 8. The winners clinched the game with a sixgoal spree in the second chukker.
NEW YORK Governor Charles Harwood of the Virgin Islands, and Mrs. Harwood, are leaving Essex House today for their home in Harrison, N.Y.
WITH the season of conviviality upon us, cocktail parties will abound in the next few weeks. And small wonder, since they are the very easiest, least expensive party of all to give.

REPORTS of the effect the war has had on European civilians have been numerous, telling of the physical and psychological damage suffered under bombings and invasion. But little news has reached this country concerning the effect of the war on wild-life.

Straining to meet the record-breaking demands of national defense production throughout the highly industrialized Pittsburgh region, the natural gas utility companies of that area, deriving their product from the Appalachian gas field, are threatened with the problem of maintaining an adequate supply for the coming Winter.

NOT even a tank driver likes to shift gears. The Army at Aberdeen, Md., is testing 13-ton tanks powered by two Cadillac 8-cylinder engines with "Hydra-Matic" drive for automatic gear changing, according to Automotive News, while Chrysler in its 31-ton medium tanks seeks to substitute its car engines with "Fluid Drive" for the present 450-horsepower radial aircraft engines.

IT is fine we could have our leave at the same time," said a soldier's wife, dining with her husband, to Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle. And the matter-of-course acceptance of the woman's part in Britain's war program may be taken as a text for Mrs. Biddle's entirely concrete little book.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The United States Navy, now in the midst of a record expansion program and recently placed on a war footing with full personnel manning the ships of three fleets, has at this time no superior in the world, Secretary Knox stated tonight in rendering the annual report of the Navy Department.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 6 -- The published Finnish and British notes have not created any surprise in Stockholm. The tone of the Finnish note is moderate and conciliatory, but the substance clearly shows that while the Finns are extremely reluctant to find themselves at war with a country that the majority love and admire, they prefer to accept this risk rather than modify their position.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Congressional pique was displayed tonight over the forthcoming appearance of Thomas G. Corcoran, onetime White House favorite, before a Senate committee to reply to allegations that he used old Administration connections to get defense contracts.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Christmas cheer in practical form will soon be on its way to the American service men stationed in Iceland, Greenland and Newfoundland, from the New Jersey Daughters of the American Revolution, whose 5,000 members have been asked to knit a sweater apiece.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $1,174,706,935 last month, according to a compilation issued by the Exchange. Average price a share of all listed stocks on Nov. 29 was $25.87, compared with $26.66 at the end of October.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A unique story of an infantile paralysis outbreak has uncovered evidence that children can be apparently healthy carriers of the disease, upsetting a general belief to the contrary.
THE exhibition honoring Royal Cortissoz is now in progress at Knoedler's -- sincere and appropriate tribute arranged by a gallery that itself has reached a milestone this year (the ninety-fifth).

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Rapid progress in solving problems of processing has brought about the possibility of using synthetic rubber "as easily" as the natural product, it was disclosed tonight by F.B. Davis Jr., president of the United States Rubber Company, who spoke here as guest of honor at the Montclair Yale Club's annual party held at Nick Robert's Old Yale Barn.

Warning that discrimination in defense employment is not only "the negation of the American tradition of liberty and equality" but a threat to America's national security, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd appealed yesterday for a super-unity that recognizes the values and skills of all American citizens.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Dec. 5:
AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 6 -- The team called Texas' greatest in history reached the end of the gridiron trail today with a smashing 71-to-7 victory over the University of Oregon.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 6 -- The Province of Buenos Aires faces a crucial election tomorrow in which about 880,000 registered voters are called upon to choose their Governor, Vice Governor and Senators and Deputies to the Provincial Legislature.

If the quest for the perfect Christmas gift leaves you baffled or, worse, brings you to the borderline of lunacy, you can always turn to what are known as "toiletries" not only with relief but with pleasure and confidence, and, what is more, a feeling of patriotism.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Paul Gregory, president of Local 37, United Weldors, Cutters and Helpers, said today that he had information that the A.F. of L. would try Monday to bar welders from shipyards for non-payment of dues.

Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Commissioner of Hospitals since Oct. 1, 1940, announced yesterday his intention of resigning on Dec. 31, to resume his post as dean of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University. Efforts by Mayor La Guardia to persuade him to remain have failed so far, but the Mayor said he had not given up and would talk with Dr. Rappleye again tomorrow.

Declaring that increased Federal taxas will compel many engineering student in "high-tuition" schools to resign or to enroll in State or municipal-supported institutions, Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of the Stevens Institute of Technology, warned yesterday that this might seriously hamper the training of engineers for national defense by forcing the State schools to carry a disproportionate share of the training burden.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Leo Richard's last-minute goal gave the Jersey Skeeters a 3-to-2 victory over the New York Rovers tonight and their second triumph of the Eastern Amateur Hockey League season.

Tableaux vivants in the genre of Renoir, designed as faithful reproductions of Renoir masterpieces or as original interpretations of his paintings, will be the dramatic feature of the Renoir Ball to be given Dec. 17 in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton under the auspices of the Free French Relief Committee.

The work of the missionary who toils "to bring in the white harvest of souls" was described yesterday by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman as youth's "highest call and greatest dignity." The Archbishop made an unscheduled address at the fourteenth annual solemn pontifical mass for the Catholic Students Mission Crusade, held for the first time in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

THE social event of the radio week was, of course, the large and elegant party last Tuesday night at the Waldorf-Astoria, where the Columbia Broadcasting System honored the chief of its European staff, Edward R. Murrow, home on vacation from the London post he has fined so well.

SEVENTEENTH and eighteenth century American portraits make a memorable display in one of the New York Historical Society's spacious top-floor galleries. Belonging to the permanent collection, these 125 portraits are now exhibited for the first time as a cohesive -- and an immensely rewarding -- single group.

THE death of Gennaro Papi a week ago last Saturday just before he was to conduct "Traviata" at the Metropolitan Opera House has not caused the management to rush out desperately in search of a replacement.

Several species of wild birds originating in the tropical areas of South America received special awards yesterday at the opening of the eighth annual show of the Bird Fanciers Association at the Hotel Lexington.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A Reuter's summary in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 23 of an article in The Manchester Guardian dealing with the future of the gold standard contains these statements which strike one as rather curious in view of the present world situation:

IF the Great Big Bears of the professional football ranks beat the Cardinals today there will be a tie for the leadership in the Western segment of the National Football League and Stout Steve Owen of the Giants might as well take his waiting Eastern champions to some quiet spot where they can practice football on skates or skis.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Salary increases for 700 Westchester County employes, as recommended in County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach's proposed 1942 county budget, will bear the brunt of criticism Monday night when the Board of Supervisors conducts its annual budget hearing in the Little Theatre of the County Center.
