To cut the demand for consumer goods as one step in the prevention of inflation, women are advised to seek training in how to conserve household furnishings, equipment and clothing, in a bulletin just issued by the American Association of University Women, for the use of social studies committees in its branches.

Seventeen Chilean doctors, each a specialist in a different field of medicine, were among the passengers on the Chilean liner Capiapo which docked in Brooklyn yesterday. They were sent here by Chile for a four-month course of study in American hospitals, according to Dr. Alfred Biondi of Santiago, spokesman for the group.

After two years, an experiment designed to eliminate racial prejudice among pupils and adults, develop attitudes of tolerance and foster democratic principles of good citizenship, conducted in the Springfield (Mass.) public school system, has proved highly successful Dr. John Granrud, superintendent, disclosed yesterday.

Mozart: Sonata No. 5, in G (K. 283) and Sonata No. 17, in D (K. 576). Claudio Arrau, pianist. (Victor, three twelve-inch records, $3.50.) The Chilean pianist makes his Victor debut, and he may be counted as a fine new name to have on records.

Next door to the Connecticut home of Mrs. Jack Prentiss (Agatha Welch that was) is a house that was once an inn, then a private residence and is now again an inn. It is owned and operated by Mrs. May Ingoldsby, considered by Agatha to be the most incompetent woman she has ever known.

AT its concert in Carnegie Hall on Dec. 16, the Philadelphia Orchestra will be conducted by Eugene Ormandy. Dorothy Maynor, soprano, will be the soloist. Mr. Ormandy opens his program with his own new transcription of Bach's organ Toccata in C major, and also will present Sibelius's Second symphony and Eugene Bonner's "White Nights."

In an appeal to the people of Germany to break away from their Nazi leaders. Thomas Mann, German author, broadcast a warning yesterday over the British radio in a German-language transmission admonishing them to make the break while there is still time before the "ever-growing gigantic hatred engulfs you."

F.D.R. Puts A Question The pall of the Far Eastern crisis hung heavy last week over the White House, and from the spacious grounds of the President's home the shadows drifted ominously to the three most concerned departments -- State, Navy and War.

FROM the tips of their toes to the crowns of their heads, women and girls will look pretty at parties during the holiday season. No detail has been overlooked to give them the chance to shine in all their glory.

KEY WEST, Fla. -- This southernmost of Florida's islands is preparing a welcome for Winter visitors. The program will again revolve around variations of La Semana Allegre (Week of Joy), Havana Nights, street dancing, open-air marts sponsored by the large artists' colony, a lavish tropical flower show, a fashion show staged in one of the most beautiful settings in the world, and amateur theatricals.

MANY people think very highly of the Theatre Guild's latest drama, "Hope for a Harvest," in which Fredric March and Florence Eldridge are appearing. Most of the New York reviews were frigid, although some were not only respectful but cordial, and the reviews were generally enthusiastic in the cities where "Hope for a Harvest" had preliminary hearings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6 -- Misunderstanding's of the United States in South America attributed to some books and motion pictures as well as to commercial practices were set forth today at a conference sponsored by Yale University and the International Students Service.

CHARMING parents and a lovely daughter and lively son are the pleasant characters of Miss Patters'on's latest novel, which is a shade more domestic and quite a lot more befuddled in its people's thinking than the one before this.

IN these days, when the horrors and tragedies prevailing in Europe have caused us to turn our eyes more than ever before to the countries which share with us this glorious Western Hemisphere, a veritable deluge of books about Hispanic America is pouring from the press and is being avidly absorbed by the reading public.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- President Risto Ryti and Field Marshal Baron Gustav Mannerheim told the Finnish people in Independence Day declarations today that they must fight on to final victory against the Soviet Union, but they failed to mention war with Great Britain.

Two events of the coming week have been arranged to raise funds to provide holiday entertainment for children. The large cocktail party and auction to be held on Tuesday at the Pierre is sponsored by Bundles for Britain for the benefit of "Christmas for Britain's children and a greeting to Britain's Queen."

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- A report broadcast by the German radio that Leopold III, King of the Belgians, had married Mlle. Mary Lelia Baels, daughter of a former Belgian Cabinet Minister, was termed tonight by Belgians here "incredible" and "strange," but in Stockholm the sister-in-law of King Leopold's late wife confirmed it.

In the fascinating art of flower arranging such a formidable array of "don'ts" is often presented to the beginner that it must recall the familiar anecdote of the anxious English nurse, who, missing the children from sight one morning, sent the maid out "to see what Johnny and Mary are doing and tell them they mustn't."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6 (AP) -- One of the finest plays uncorked in the Yale Bowl this season today gave a husky squad from Fort Terry, N.Y., a 7-0 victory over Camp Edwards, Mass., and the Army football championship of New England.

WAYCROSS, Ga. -- When the annual southward trek of New York motorists begins in earnest during the coming Christmas holidays, those drivers whose destination lies in and around the St. Petersburg area will welcome the completion of a new direct highway to the Gulf Coast region.

Over in Japan the sword rattling goes on with all sorts of threats and dire predictions of what will happen if the United States tries to tell Tokyo what to do; yet the echo in Washington does not hurt the eardrums. The Japanese spokesmen in the American capital wish to continue the negotiations with the United States.

SANTA CLAUS is back again, still the jolly, red-cheeked and twinklingeyed roly-poly, he stands in the streets or sits on velvet thrones in the department stores, bending a large and hairy ear to young America's Christmas order while around his joyous laughter roars the holiday excitement.
TORONTO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs moved into a tie with the idle Bruins for the National Hockey League leadership tonight when they downed the last-place Canadiens, 3 -- 1.

Its trophy case already jammed with important prizes, Xavier High School's first team triumphed for the second straight year in the sixteenth annual New York Stock Exchange interscholastic schoot conducted on the range of the Manhattan School of Firearms yesterday.

While the shortage of seamen to man the fast-growing merchant marine has been alleviated in recent months, the question of manning for the future is serious and is the subject of anxious study in shipping and Administration circles.

WHEN Lourens Steenwyck Baxter sailed from New York for Holland in 1678 he went with the blessings of his family, reconciled at last to his ambition to become a physician. They had hoped he would finally choose some more socially correct career, such as that of a merchant; but through his years of apprenticeship with Jacob Varrevanger, who established the first hospital in the colonies at New York, the boy never wavered from his determination.

VAN WYCK BROOKS has always been one of our most stimulating and provocative critics; he has also been, perhaps, the most fruitful. The seeds of his thought have taken root in many of the writers who came after him.

TWO weeks before Christmas most parents know what the children hope to find in their stockings or on the tree. The department store Santa Claus is getting hoarse spreading the same news. For any other adults in doubt, here are some reminders on the choice of toys.

To the Radio Editor: TODAY you printed a letter from "Zopilote" of Brookline, Mass, in which he attempted to belittle the efforts of the able men who broadcast the play-by-play descriptions of the football games.

TRAVEL LINES: A recent book of interest to travelers and nature lovers is "Pageant in the Sky," about what the author, Raymond S. Deck, calls the "modern sport of bird-watching." The volume discusses the ways of birds from the Canadian north woods to Brazilian jungles, together with local species. . . .

Editor The New York Times Book Review: I think it might be pertinent to recall at this time that the pattern for William Shirer's "Berlin Diary" was set by an earlier book of a similar title, "Berlin Diaries," edited by Dr. Helmut Klotz, with a foreword by Edgar Ansel Mowrer, which was issued by William Morrow in 1934.

Twenty-nine years ago the founder of the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund published his first 100 stories of need in this newspaper. The years since then have justified his faith in human compassion. So sure is that compassion that the Fund has grown beyond his dreams; grown so that it extends aid each year to many times 100 cases.

THE motion-picture industry is on the shady side of forty years old and has, in its more recent lifetime, been the chief purveyor of "culture" in this land. Shelves upon shelves of books have been written about the business of making films; billions of words are spent annually in newspapers and magazines all over the world to comment upon the activities and accomplishments of the glamorous folk engaged in the craft.
AT the present time, when South America, England, and the United States are drawn more closely together, it is fitting to remember W. H. Hudson who embodied their relationship in his person and work.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- In keeping with the trend to an extended season, which, has added in recent years several weeks to the former three or four months, early December finds practically all homes in this and nearby towns filled, with correspondingly earlier opening dates for clubs and hotels.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- Francesco Kauz, the man who is charged with planning to assassinate Premier Mussolini during his visit to Caporetto in 1938, faced the judges of the special tribunal for the defense of the State in Trieste today. The confession that Kauz is stated to have made to the police was read to the court by Tringali Casanova, President of the Court.

OCALA, Fla. -- Florida citizens are spreading their "Welcome" mats across the door of the 1941-42 season. Perhaps the word is written in azaleas along the railroad in Palatka; or glows in lights along the river front at Daytona Beach.

Newspaper publicity in connection with a job of amateur sleuthing comes to the notice of the university trustees, and Carl Wayward, Professor of Psychology, becomes an ex-professor. It is good publicity from a sleuthing standpoint, but bad, or so the trustees think, from the academic point of view.

Leading maritime unions have disagreed sharply on the naming of John M. Carmody, former Administrator of Public Works, as a member of the United States Maritime Commission. The nomination has been, approved by a Senate committee and is expected to receive affirmative action in the Senate this week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator Thomas of Utah, chairman of the Education and Labor Committee, threw his support tonight to speedy consideration of anti-strike legislation in the Senate.

A SMALL camera, well-protected film, and a good exposure meter are all you need for photography in the tropics, says Albert Greenfield, veteran of nine trips through the Caribbean and South America, the most recent one to Haiti.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- A full program of holiday social and sports events is taking shape here on Florida's West Coast As usual, Christmas lights will brighten the city's streets and homes this year, there being no power shortage in this part of Florida.

Philemon Tecumseh Sherman, widely known expert on insurance law and related problems, and the last surviving child of General William Tecumseh Sherman, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack at his home, 1 Lexington Avenue. His age was 74.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Major Gen. Amos Alfred Fries of Washington, former head of the Chemical Warfare Service, now retired, is revealed in a patent (No. 2,264,791) just granted as the inventor of a "ball-bearing" shell which, according to the claims of the inventor, would make the Stokes or trench mortar an effective weapon against tanks, armored trains and "pillboxes."

BUENOS AIRES -- The postal authorities released on Dec. 5 a 5-centavos greenish-blue stamp commemorating the death of Juan Lavalle, army general, on Oct. 9, 1841. Twenty million copies were printed. The design brings philately's first likeness of Lavalle, whose name is inscribed, together with the dates 1841-1941.

USHERS at the Metropolitan Opera House, who ordinarily receive little notice, got newspaper mention recently when one of their members, Joseph Clifford, a tenor, gave his first New York recital. The Horatio Alger story, tentatively titled "From Usher to Artist," might suggest to some persons that this branch of the Metropolitan staff serves as a nest for fledgling singers.

IN this latest volume of poems one can see Engle shifting back completely into his early affirmation of America, but an America in relation to the world's destiny. It is no more the voice of the expatriate praising an old love as in his last book, "Corn," but the singing of a poet with an integral tie to his people and land.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 6 (AP) -- An official Chinese statement today called Japan's reply to President Roosevelt's inquiry an insult to the intelligence of the American people and its publication "another rude setback to Japan's policy of back-stairs intrigue."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- President Roosevelt made a personal appeal to Emperor Hirohito of Japan tonight as a result of reports reaching the State Department of heavy troop movements and concentrations in Indo-China.

Visitors will not be permitted to board ships in this port to bid bon voyage to departing passengers if a suggestion offered last week during a series of conferences on pier protection during the present emergency is adopted by port authorities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A call for a nationwide strike of welders, employed principally in shipyards and on government defense construction, was issued today by the United Brotherhood of Welders, Cutters and Helpers of America.

IT won't be long now. Eighteen more days until Christmas; twenty-five days until New Year. Another cinematic twelve-month is rapidly drawing to a close. Already the ballots are being distributed to those enfranchised to vote for the annual movie "bests."

Forced sales of Manhattan properties during November showed a drop in number but an increase in the total liens involved, according to the regular monthly survey of foreclosures by the Real Estate Board of New York.

The final step in expansion of United States and Mexico, the ex-air service between the United States and Mexico to a four-times-a-day basis was taken yesterday, it was announced in New York by Pan American Airways, when the international air line put its Los Angeles-Mexico City link on a daily schedule.

Seven thousand persons attended yesterday afternoon a service for the young people and children of the Episcopal Diocese of New York at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Three services at the Cathedral today will end the eight-day celebration of the opening of the entire length of the interior of the edifice.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A strong new German flanking drive midway between Moscow and the fiercely contested Donets Basin was reported tonight in military dispatches. The Germans were said to have overrun five towns and to have swung close to the headwaters of the Don River, ap- proximately 200 miles southeast of the Soviet capital.

Yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange saw more different stocks traded and a heavier volume than any other Saturday so far this year. Prices improved irregularly and closed somewhat higher on the day, but a little below the high marks of the week.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Consumer Week, a series of campus-wide programs organized jointly by Skidmore College and the college unit of the Consumer Division of the United States Office of Price Administration, will be observed at Skidmore Monday through Friday.

FROM September, 1939, until February, 1941, Mr. Raymond Daniell was chief London corerspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES. At first, he was inclined to feel cheated because other correspondents were going out to France.

Melvin Ott, whose appointment as pilot of the Giants provided the major sensation of the recent minor league baseball convention in Jacksonville, made his formal managerial bow before the New York press at the club's Forty-second Street offices yesterday and in the short space of four hours seemed at least to have scored a sweeping social triumph.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Completing its 1941 launching program with, a total of $98,000,000 worth of naval and commercial ship construction, the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company today sent the 17,650-ton oil tanker E.W. Sinclair down the ways at 10:15 A.M.

IN batches of ten a hundred French hostages have been shot at Nantes and Bordeaux during these past weeks for crimes committed by some one else. In "batches" -- and there is no other word, and the fact that there is no other word brands this procedure as utterly inhuman. "Groups" would be wrong, for that word suggests a voluntary coming together.

HOLLYWOOD. FOR no other reason than to call on Vera Zorina, which was ample enough reason, a troup of correspondents, all men, turned up the other morning, as prompt as clockwork, at the studio where she is premiere danseuse.

Because of a lively popular interest in government and the citizens' responsibility in a democracy, a permanent group of speakers qualified to provide fundamental information in this field as well as on special issues of the day is being formed by the New York City League of Women Voters.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Bulwark took an early lead and held it to win the $5,000 added mile and an eighth feature race at Tanforan today.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 6 -- To a meeting here Monday of some 400 school inspectors from all parts of Mexico, Vela Gonzales Vasquez, Minister of Education, will explain the aims of the President in framing the forthcoming school law, which is expected to introduce far-reaching changes in the school system, including revision of texts supplied by the Federal Government.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark. -- This scenic and romantic old spot, in a wooded portion of the Ouachita Mountains, to which, for many years, its natural hot springs, tall pines and huge magnolias have lured the travelers, is now an all-year-round resort, although the major season opens on Jan. 16 and continues through May 15.
All Greyhound bus service in New England was shut down yesterday by sympathy strikes growing out of a controversy over the pay of seven charwomen in the Greyhound garage at Cleveland, Ohio.

BUFFALO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- C.I.O. United Automobile Workers at the Buffalo Chevrolet plant voted today to strike "within two weeks," a union official said, if the General Motors Corporation continue to withhold from its employes "the right to bargain and the benefits already agreed to."

A COVER and official information received last week from Pondicherry, capital of French India, combine to convey facts of philatelic interest. French India is one of the French colonies which have thrown in their lot with the Free France movement led by General Charles de Gaulle, and the British authorities are cooperating with those of French India in carrying on affairs governmentally in support of the de Gaulle regime.

SARASOTA, Fla. -- Surf bathing continues to be the favorite pastime of Sarasota's Winter colony as the protracted Indian Summer weather extends into the pre-holiday season. Christmas decorations have appeared in stores and on the streets, but there is nothing about the weather to indicate that it is not June instead of December.
Shooting for pheasants featured the program at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. There were three scratch and five handicap prizes.

Miss Margaret Cornwell of St. Louis was elected vice president for the coming year at the annual meeting of the Women's United States Field Hockey Association, held recently at the Wellesley Country Club, Wellesley, Mass.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- Guardians of the Rose Bowl football game -- the Pacific Coast Conference -- may act to protect the "dignity" of the famed attraction when officials convene at Palm Springs for their annual Fall meeting Monday.
TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 7 (U.P.) -- Japan indicated early today that she was on the verge of abandoning efforts to achieve a settlement of Pacific issues by diplomatic negotiation at Washington.

THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity advanced 3.6 points to a new high record during the week ended Nov. 29. The advance carried it to 133.4, compared with 129.8 for the week ended Nov. 22 and 119.3 for the week ended Nov. 30, 1940.

Henry Williams, Justice of the State Supreme Court, from a vault in West Laurel Hill Cemetery on Tuesday to determine whether there were suspicious circumstances in connection with her death two years ago.

By the time the current edition of the Ice Follies closes with Wednesday evening's performance at Madison Square Garden, it is expected that between 125,000 and 130,000 wili have attended the ten showings scheduled at the arena.

LEWISTON, Me., Dec. 6 -- Students of economics at Bates College are getting a chance to be the interviewers, not the interviewed, in the business world these days as the result of a new series of lectures and discussions on business problems just introduced.

IT is excellent news that Eugene Loring, one of the most engaging talents that has emerged in the field of the ballet in America, is to have a company of his own. Under the title of Dance Players, Inc., he and fifteen colleagues will start formal rehearsals tomorrow in preparation for a brief tour and a week's engagement in New York in the Spring.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuter) -- Results of football matches played in the British Isles today:

IT is one hundred and fifty years, almost to a day, since Mozart's death (Dec. 5, 1791) and a few days less than that since the premiere of his last opera, "The Magic Flute" (Sept. 30, 1791), which the Metropolitan presents, for the first time on its stage in English, next Thursday evening.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Before the last two decades the Western world had formed its ideas of Turkey from what the Ottoman Empire was in the period of its degeneracy, forgetting her achievements at the peak of her history, in the era of Suleiman the Lawgiver, commonly called the Magnificent.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 30 -- The Bolivian public in the last few days has been disillusioned as to the amount of economic support for Bolivia to be expected from the United States, as the result of official declarations to the effect that sums previously mentioned were far from reality.

MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 6 -- In pursuance of its program of preparing graduate students for democratic leadership in international affairs, the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy has inaugurated this year a new type of seminar, which seeks to combine and coordinate already existing advanced seminars in the fields of international law, diplomacy and economics.

BILOXI, Miss. -- National defense activities, though the attendant influx of workers has taxed the housing facilities of the larger Mississippi coast towns, appear nevertheless to have opened new vistas for tourists.

THE national championship tournament which will complete its final session today at Richmond, Va., is in one sense the most truly "national" that has ever been held. Ten players from California, seven of them from Los Angeles and three from San Francisco, were entered in the tournament.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Learning by seeing is to undergo an intensive test at Sarah Lawrence College when a program of "Living Films," aimed to cut across fields of interest to all departments will be presented for the next twenty weeks.

SANFORD, Fla. -- Paths that lead far from the beaten track into Florida's quiet back country tempt the Winter visitors this season. A boat trip on the St. Johns River affords a water route through a section as wild and heavily wooded as when the Indians hunted and fished here.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 6 -- The country's contract bridge leaders trailed less-known bridge experts In the qualifying rounds of the national contract bridge open-pair championship which began here today. The field numbered 130 pairs, two more than the attendance record established at Philadelphia last year.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 -- The Australian Government has completed preparations, in concert with Britain, the United States and the Netherlands Indies, for action in the event of a Pacific conflict.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The British Government has reminded the South American countries that it will regard trading or attempted trading between them and both occupied and unoccupied France in the same light as direct trading with Germany and Italy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- With three problems still confronting them, members of the President's Fact Finding Board seeking to solve various railroad labor disputes returned to Chicago today from Washington.

Walter G. Preston Jr., manager of the public service division of the National Broadcasting Company, ended his life early yesterday morning, according to the police, by taking an overdose of sleeping tablets, in his apartment at 2 Beekman Place.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- Recent criticism by Ford Motor Company officials of the union-shop contract between the company and the United Automobile Workers of America (C.I.O.) has produced from the union the reply that friction up to this point has been more or less inevitable, but that the contract is rapidly working to a proper adjustment.

The Jewish Section of the Interfaith Committee for Aid to the Democracies, which on its first anniversary last week passed its campaign goal of $400,000 set for 1941, has presented $25,000 to Frederick W. Gehle, chairman of the fundraising division of the British War Relief Society, to establish an English nursing home for bomb-shocked children, it was made known yesterday.

A survey just completed by the East Side Chamber of Commerce to ascertain the number of build ings in that lower section of the city which are closed or boarded-up showed a total of 600 structures of which 426 are dwellings or tenements and 174 commercial structures.

Holiday trade in the New York area last week was retarded by unfavorable weather. Department store sales gains over a year ago were estimated at 3 to 5 per cent; customer attendance was good at most stores, but fewer items were purchased than a year ago.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Daniel J. Sweeney, one of Buffalo's Democratic leaders, whose varied career ranged from newspaper work to the oil business, died today of a heart ailment at the age of 65.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 6 (U.P.) -- Two Clippers, carrying thirty passengers in all, took off in a clearing fog today to start a new tri-continent air line linking the United States directly with Africa for the first time.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The decisions of the international tin and rubber committees, made here this week, dominated the week's British commodity news. The rubber regulation committee set the export quota for the first quarter of 1942 and extended the ban on new plantings to 1942 and 1943.

SINCE September last, when Pare Lorentz signed a three-way writer-director-producer contract with RKO Radio for two pictures, there has been much speculation as to just what he's been up to. In announcing the pact, the studio merely hinted that his first film probably would be an "epic of modern American life."

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Dorothy Kirsten, the 24-year-old American soprano, who three years ago was rescued from drudgery and put on the road to a musical career by another American soprano, Grace Moore, appeared this afternoon on the stage of the Civic Opera House with her friend in a Chicago Opera Company performance of Puccini's "La Boheme."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 6 -- What British mobile columns and infantry harassed and routed Axis columns, patrols and outposts, Royal Air Force fighters braved dust storms over the battle area in Cyrenaiea yesterday and shot down twenty-one Axis aircraft in three combats that developed, communiques of British Middle East Headquarters and R.A.F. Middle East Headquarters here reported today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Dec. 7 -- The entire Taganrog area of the southern front in Russia had been isolated by the Soviet Army and the German forces there no longer can receive reinforcements or supplies, it was announced this morning by a military commentator on the Moscow radio.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., Dec. 6 -- The Rev. Dr. Charles S. Macfarland, clergyman and author who became widely known for his peace efforts during the first World War, will celebrate his seventy-fifth birthday Friday at his home, 95 Ball Road, here, where he has lived for twenty-nine years.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Daniel J. Sweeney, one of Buffalo's Democratic leaders, whose varied career ranged from newspaper work to the oil business, died today of a heart ailment at the age of 65.

LOS ANGELES -- Whether visitors seek the snows of the Yosemite Valley and Lake Arrowhead or the oleanders of Pasadena, whether water carnivals or senioritas dancing in the streets, they will find them at this season in that long State whose shores are slapped by the blue Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission issued today a statement of its general policy regarding requests for acceleration of the effective date of registration of securities on national securities exchanges under the discretionary authority given it by Section 12 (d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

THERE is afoot today in the theatre a problem which to a legal mind appears to present some curious and nationally important aspects. Perhaps I exaggerate the importance out of all proportion; certainly I do not feel that society will be jeopardized by a failure to solve the problem.

TORONTO, Dec. 6 -- Step by step Canada is being carried along into a more and more complete organization for war. Last month wages were stabilized throughout the country with a safety clause that if and when the cost of living rose there should be an automatic bonus.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 6 -- At the conclusion of the second day's running in the national open allage retriever stake in the covers and coves of Penniman's Point, in the village of Quogue, today, eleven dogs remained for the final series tomorrow.

A large and influential section of the Hungarian language press in the United States, which is read by many thousands of members of the American-Hungarian working classes, is openly and strongly pro-German and anti-British in its editorials and in its presentation of news, a survey of foreign language papers has disclosed.

MANILA, Dec. 6 -- The Commonwealth Government appealed today to Manila residents who have homes in the Provinces to leave the city as soon as possible and remain away for the duration of the emergency to simplify the expected compulsory evacuation of all women and children and men whose services are "non-essential."

THE Red Cross is almost unknown in America, Clara Barton wrote to one of the organization's executives in 1877. "Not one person in a hundred ever heard of it; not one in 500 has a clear idea of its purpose.

The West Chester (Pa.) Teachers proved stubborn opponents for the C.C.N.Y. quintet in the first half last night, but the Beavers, playing their first intercollegiate game of the season, triumphed by 51 -- 23 in the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium.

TORONTO, Dec. 6 -- Step by step Canada is being carried along into a more and more complete organization for war. Last month wages were stabilized throughout the country with a safety clause that if and when the cost of living rose there should be an automatic bonus.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- The Russian war, with its formidable additional call on the Reich's armament industries and war expenditures, is believed in financial circles here to be the main factor accounting for the accelerated pace at which both the note circulation of the Reichsbank and the national debt have been rising in the last six months.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 -- After a lapse of nearly a week the battle between the British and German tank forces in Libya was resumed yesterday in the area between Bir el-Gobi and Rezegh.

AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 7 -- Recreational skiing, in all its phases featured the agenda at the eighth annual meeting of the Western Massachusetts Winter Sports Council combined with the Winter Sports Section of Massachusetts State College's recreation conference today.

"Grim, indisputable proof" of the importance to the United States of strategic air bases in Alaska was the way Miss Mary Joyce last night characterized Japan's sudden and unprovoked attack on American possessions. Miss Joyce, whose home is at Taku, Alaska, and who arrived in New York on a good-will survey of Northwest airlines only two days ago, emphasized that these bases provide a short cut by plane to the Orient.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Hostilities between the United States and Japan are expected in labor circles to unify labor support of the defense program and curb work stoppages in vital war industries.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Prices of lard on the Board of Trade here were on the upgrade last week, with liberal buying by cash interests and some let-up in liquidation by holders of December and January contracts.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Japanese Army and Navy surrounded the International Settlement at 4:40 A.M. today and served notice on the commander of the United States gunboat Wake that war had been declared.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Directors of the National Live Stock and Meat Board, at their semi-annual meeting this week-end, approved eight fellowships at colleges and universities for meat nutrition studies and authorized the carrying forward of a new program of meat preparation and instruction for the Army.

Making his final report as president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, Frederick P. Keppel, who retired from the presidency of the foundation on Nov. 18, announced yesterday that grants totaling $2,706,834 were made by the Carnegie Corporation in the fiscal years that ended Sept. 30.

LINDENHURST, L.I, Dec. 7 -- Coming down for an emergency landing, an Army P-40 pursuit plane attached to Mitchel Field struck two parked automobiles and a group of persons standing near them in Montefiore Cemetery near here at noon today, killing one of the group and injuring five others.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Going to greater lengths than Prime Minister Winston Churchill in his latest proposals for extension of national conscription, Viscountess Astor, American-born member of Parliament, not only would make certain classifications of married women liable to compulsory service in the auxiliary branches of Britain's uniformed forces or in war industries, but also would conscript every male and female from the age of 14 up.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The further increase of L50,000,000 in the fiduciary issue of the Bank of England, made last week to provide for the bank's increased circulation, disappointed many critics who had advocated a much larger increase on the ground that it would have been better to take one big bite at the cherry instead of the numerous nibbles adopted so far during the war.

Buying in the apparel market last week was spotty. Purchases of Christmas gifts continued at a good pace. Action on coats and furs slowed due to continued mild weather. Business picked up on street dresses. The demand continued strong for evening wear.

The public demand for government or official regulation of the quality of consumer goods through establishment of standards is not strong and is not increasing, George B. Hotchkiss, Professor of Marketing, New York University, reports in a study, "The Movement for Standardization and Grading of Consumer Goods," made for the Association of National Advertisers.

Far from being a forbidden fruit, the apple has in recent years been recognized as a paragon of dietetic virtues. Apples are pretty, palatable and economical They contain four vitamins, four important minerals and the all-important pectin. According to one distinguished physician, the apple is a compact, precisely compounded combination of health-giving foods, one of the most complete that we possess.

AMSTERDAM (Via Berlin), Dec. 7 -- Although official and unofficial warning's against the continued rise in the prices of shares continue, the markets of the small Continental countries apparently are unable to indulge in longer term reaction, every recession being only of a temporary nature and followed almost immediately by a fresh buying wave caused by a demand for reinvestment and holders are selling with reluctance.

Artur Rubinstein, who played the Chopin E minor piano concerto with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Thursday and Friday, yesterday afternoon presented with the orchestra the Brahms B flat major concerto at Carnegie Hall.

SINGAPORE, Monday, Dec. 8 -- The Japanese landed in Northern Malaya, 300 miles north of Singapore, today and bombed this great British naval stronghold, causing small loss of life among civilians and property damage.

War in Europe, which set the brakes on the machinery of production of many types of merchandise formerly exported to these shores, has on the contrary set the looms and factories in South America working and they are now moving with accelerated speed to take up the slack in this international exchange.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Secretary Morgenthau impounded tonight the $131,000,000 which Japan has invested in this country and broke off all trade dealings.

HONOLULU, Dec. 7 -- War broke with lightning suddenness in the Pacific today when waves of Japanese bombers attacked Hawaii this morning and the United States Fleet struck back with a thunder of big naval rifles. Japanese bombers, including four-engined dive bombers and torpedo-carrying planes, blasted at Pearl Harbor, the great United States naval base, the city of Honolulu and several outlying American military bases on the Island of Oahu.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Slingin' Sammy Baugh rifled three touchdown passes to give the Washington Redskins a 20-14 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Football League game today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- The Chicago Black Hawks went on another scoring spree tonight, but were forced to fight off a late rally by the Brooklyn Americans to win their National Hockey League game, 5 -- 4, and retain their hold on third place.

The U.S.S. Oklahoma, a 29,000-ton battleship in service since May, 1916, reported a casualty in yesterday's attack on Pearl Harbor, was one of Uncle Sam's watchdogs off the extreme southwest coast of Ireland during the last World War.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: By virtue of the British declaration of war on Finland, this unhappy country is now classed with the international brigands and outlaws. We have expended immense amounts of sympathy and admiration for Finland. Today we appear to be spending an equal amount of self-righteousness and lack of understanding.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Facilities of the United States Employment Service, by arrangement with the Maritime Commission, will be used to speed the manning of ships for the expanding merchant marine.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 -- With war striking suddenly 2,000 miles, and perhaps less, from the mainland, the Pacific Coast went "on the alert" today to cope with whatever might be demanded of its military and naval establishment, its great industrial plants and its home defense units.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Magdalen Marchioness of Canossa was beatified in the solemn and traditional ceremony at the Basilica of St. Peter's this morning, while many thousands of people knelt in veneration. This afternoon at 5 o'clock, in the presence of fully 50,000 faithful, Pope Pius XII descended from the Vatican to worship the new blessed.

Miss N. May Karff of Boston yesterday regained her title as woman chess champion of the United States when, at the Marshall Chess Club, she finished her match with Mrs. Donald Belcher by winning the sixth game in thirty moves.
HONOLULU, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Japanese bombs killed at least seven persons and injured many others, three seriously, in a surprise morning aerial attack on Honolulu today.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Dec. 8 -- Attorney General Francis Biddle announced early this morning that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been directed to take into custody for questioning and temporary detention a selected group of Japanese aliens.

In a desire to maintain the gasoline supply for the motoring public at its present high quality the refining and marketing committees for District 1 under the Petroleum Coordinators Office have adopted a resolution urging government authorities to allocate sufficient chlorine and pig lead for the manufacture next year of 210,000,000 pounds of tetraethyl lead, which quantity is the estimated actual requirements for the oil industry, including 50,000,000 pounds for direct defense needs.

An over-sold condition in the stock market wherein price relations to earnings, dividends and outlook had been sacrificed on the altar of nervousness, found partial and dramatic relief last week as the share list experienced its best recovery of the year.

Myron C. Taylor, breaking the self-imposed silence he has maintained since his return from Rome several weeks ago, yesterday paid eloquent tribute to the peace efforts of President Roosevelt and Pope Pius XII and urged Americans to so act that they need never torment themselves with "the ominous words, 'too late, too late.'"

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 28 (Delayed) -- Despite the fact that the Germans have been in military control of much of the Ukraine for a considerable length of time, they have been unable to organize any sort of puppet, theoretically independent government such as had been foreseen by Nazi political theorists and, despite the exigencies of martial law and ruthlessly enforced discipline, they are having the most difficult time administering even small local regions.
NEW YORK Mrs. Fenton B. Turck will give a luncheon on Thursday at the Savoy-Plaza for Mrs. John Allan Dougherty of Washington who will join her on Wednesday at the same hotel for a visit.
WEST TISBURY, Mass., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Charles A. Lindbergh, visiting at Seven Gates Farm in this village, refused tonight to see newspaper men or accept any messages.

VICHY, France, Dec. 7 -- Official announcements today manifest satisfaction from the fact that violators of economic regulations are being punished in ever greater number and that the fines imposed "show marked progress from month to month."

The three-man arbitration board appointed by President Roosevelt to arbitrate the union shop dispute in the captive coal mines last night reversed the decision of the National Defense Mediation Board and ruled that all workers in the captive mines should be required to join John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers as a condition of employment.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Complete revision of the screen version of "Panama Hattie," which was finished two months ago, has been scheduled by Metro at an estimated cost of $200,000, it was learned today. Virtually all footage in the picture except the singing and dancing sequences reportedly will be rephotographed.
MANILA, Monday, Dec. 8 -- There had been no bombing of Manila or Cavite, so far as I have been able to ascertain, up to 9 o'clock this morning.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Dec. 7 -- The Panama Canal was put on a war footing tonight, with a blackout throughout the Canal Zone and both Army and Navy on the alert. Patrol planes were in the air and all outposts were on watch, although an attack on the Canal was not considered likely.

The metropolitan district reacted swiftly yesterday to the Japanese attack in the Pacific. All large communities in the area, including New York City, Newark, Jersey City, Bayonne and Paterson, went on immediate war footing.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Dec. 7 -- Field Trial Champion King Midas of Woodend, a finished golden retriever, this afternoon was named as the winner of the first national open all-age retriever stake, which was completed after three days of intensive work on land and in the water.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7 (Canadian Press) -- All air personnel on leave in the Pacific Air Command were ordered to report to their units and at headquarters here authorities said every precaution for just such a blow-up as has occurred in the Pacific had long since been taken.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Moscow radio asserted tonight that the Russians had broken the German line at two points on the Moscow front. In one break-through, north of Moscow, two German divisions were said to have been completely wiped out.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Although security prices again were higher in the stock markets here last week, business dwindled from its recent active phase under the influence of renewed war uncertainties. These included the gathering storm clouds in the Far East and the absence of a military decision in Libya.

VICHY, Dec. 7 -- Attention is being given in the press to questions of economic reorganization, notably that of the role of money in the new regime being established in France. It already has been decided that the franc's value will no longer be expressed in terms of a certain weight in gold.

The Japanese attack on the United States brought to an end eighty-eight years of peaceful relations between the two countries, breaking a friendship that began when Commodore Matthew Perry's flotilla of warships opened Japan to foreign intercourse and modern civilization in 1853 after she had been voluntarily shut off from the world for two and one-half centuries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- As a crowd of more than a thousand looked on and Washington police stood by, the Japanese Embassy late today burned its official records and papers in the side yard of the embassy property.

WASHINGTON, Monday, Dec. 8 -- Sudden and unexpected attacks on Pearl Harbor, Honolulu, and other United States possessions in the Pacific early yesterday by the Japanese air force and navy plunged the United States and Japan into active war.

Trailing by two goals to none in less than seven minutes of play, the New York Rangers staged a magnificent comeback to defeat the world champion Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

A NUMBER of books on Latin America, some good, some pretty bad, have been mentioned here during recent months. There are at least a half dozen others, of which one in particular ought to be mentioned even at this late date: William Lytle Schurz's so-called "Descriptive Survey."*

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Maxim M. Litvinoff, the new Russian Ambassador, arrived in Washington today and assured the American people that the Red Army would continue its stout resistance against the Nazi invasion.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's last-minute peace appeal to Emperor Hirohito of Japan, sent late yesterday and made public today at the White House:
Two admirals and two generals -- all of them officers of long experience -- share major responsibility in the direction of United States naval and military forces in the Pacific.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- If there isn't a lot of trading at the major league meetings here this week, it won't be because the market closed early.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 7 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Bad December Figures Normally this month is one of the worst in the year from the point of view of traffic accidents. There are several reasons why. One of them is the longer periods of darkness and another is the rush of holiday shopping.
SINGAPORE, Monday, Dec. 8 -- British planes are bombing Japanese ships off the coast of Malaya. Their attack followed a Japanese bombing of Singapore in which there were a few casualties.
The Newark Bears of the International League were in possession of both the individual and team batting championships when the 1941 season ended, according to official averages.

NYACK, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Political scientists, legislative leaders from all parts of the country and nearly all non-elective job holders in the State are anxiously awaiting the report on the nearly completed civil service survey in Rockland County, it was said here today by Civil Service Commissioner Howard P. Jones of Upper Nyack.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Civil Aeronautics Authority issued orders tonight grounding all private airplanes in the United States and its possessions, except commercial airliners.

The Third Naval District, which includes New York harbor, was placed on a war footing yesterday afternoon by Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, Commandant of the district. War orders later came from Washington.

The flare-up of war in the Pacific will be the signal for more stringent controls over strategic raw materials and the production of civilian goods, business men agreed yesterday. For the first time the American people, whose daily living habits have been affected little by the two-year struggle in Europe, will start to feel the pinch of an all-out war effort, it was said.
MOUNT HOPE, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- For the second year in a row and the seventh time since 1931, a St. Andrews entry triumphed in the annual curling bonspiel for the Utica Cup.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 7 -- Fresh German demands were delivered last week to the governments and army high commands of Italy, Hungaria, Rumania and Bulgaria for fifteen infantry divisions to police the occupied countries, according to reports from foreign military intelligence sources here today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The war manoeuvres in the Carolinas are over. Several hundred thousand troops have gone through two months of intensive training. Every branch of the service has been represented. Weather conditions, while somewhat dry, have been conducive to very effective operations.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 -- The steel industry last week, for the time being at least, had settled down to more or less of a routine, with incoming business being still greater than the volume of production but with some companies making a negligible dent in large unfilled order backlogs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- War came to Washington on a wintry, windy Sunday afternoon, on a day which, perhaps prophetically, had followed weeks of deceptively mild and sunny weather seeming to say that hard, dark nights of frost and snow would never come.

Nora Conklin, a Canadian contralto, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. She was accompanied by Edwin McArthur and her program included works by Handel and Beethoven, lieder by Brahms and Hugo Wolf, the aria "Du Christ avec ardeur" from Herman Bemberg's cantata "La mort de Jeanne d'Arc," four songs in French and a concluding group in English.

The foreign trade community last night accepted war with Japan as a development long expected. Although traders shared other Americans' surprise and indignation over the suddenness of the Japanese attack upon Honolulu, they said that long ago they had discounted the actual outbreak from a business standpoint.

The Russell Construction Company leased to Alfred Yeston for a men's shop a two-story store building 24 by 90 feet, which will be erected at 2859 Boulevard, adjoining the Jersey City Elks Club, at Journal Square, Jersey City, N.J.

Japanese warplanes killed 350 men at Hickam Field and set fire to the United States Battleship Oklahoma yesterday in the sudden raid on Pearl Harbor and Honolulu, a National Broadcasting Company observer radioed direct from the scene yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

The Dodgers stripped the Giant of about everything except their Eastern championship yesterday as the season's record professional crowd of 55,051 saw the Brooks hammer the New Yorkers from pillar to post at the Polo Grounds. They probably would have made off with the title as well if the Giants had not had the forethought to clinch it a fortnight ago.

The upturn in cotton prices that was in evidence in the latter half of the previous week was extended sharply last week. At the close of trading Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains for the week of 60 to 74 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Japan was accused by Secretary of State Cordell Hull today of making a "treacherous and utterly unprovoked attack" upon the United States and of having been "infamously false and fraudulent" by preparing for the attack while conducting diplomatic negotiations with the professed desire of maintaining peace.
BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- The German Army now appears to be almost entirely on the defensive along the 1,500-mile Russian front.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Evidence that Japan was planning today's thrust at the United States as long ago as late August was disclosed today by Kilsoo K. Haan, Washington representative of the Sino-Korean People's League, a volunteer anti-Japanese society.
POPLAR BRANCH, N.C., Dec. 7 -- Yesterday was the day.
BERLIN, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The German High Command issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Japan was reliably reported tonight to have sent "a number of commerce raiders" into the Pacific and Indian Oceans to attack unprotected merchant vessels carrying essential war materials to the United States and Great Britain.

Valter Poole, youthful conductor from Oklahoma, conducted last night's concert of the New York City Symphony Orchestra, given in Carnegie Hall under the auspices of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project. Igor Gorin, baritone, was the soloist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- President Roosevelt will address a joint session of Congress tomorrow and will find the membership in a mood to vote any steps he asks in connection with the developments in the Pacific.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 8 -- Britain was at war with Japan this morning, instructions for action having been flashed to the recently strengthened Far East Fleet, to the Singapore garrison and to other places where preparations for war had been made.

The Bronxville Field Club strengthened its hold on first place in the Westchester Division standings of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League yesterday by defeating Apawamis, 5 to 2, on the Apawamis courts in Rye. It was Bronxville's second triumph in as many matches and the first defeat in two starts for Apawamis.

NOT a ball has been pitched or a base stolen since Mel Ott was named manager of the Giants and yet Master Melvin already shows signs of breaking under the strain of his new job. It isn't the work he has to do or the responsibility that weighs on his shoulders; it's the hours he has to keep. When he took the job he knew nothing about the night life of a baseball manager.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The rigid financial structure of railroads, caused by their reliance on debt instead of equity financing, has been largely responsible for their many bankruptcies, according to a report of a study just issued by the American Council on Public Affairs.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 7 -- French North Africa has apparently undergone an important change, passing from an apathetic desire for peace at any price, which was characteristic just after the collapse of France, to the prevalent adverse criticism of Vichy, which became noticeable during the Syrian campaign.

When Roentgen discovered the X-rays nearly half a century ago no one suspected at first that medicine had been enriched with a powerful diagnosis and therapeutic aid. And so it was when neutrons were discovered. Here were particles that could penetrate to a far higher degree than X-rays.
BATAVIA, Monday, Dec. 8 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Netherlands Indies Government today declared war on Japan and then proclaimed a state of "danger of air attack."

Equal suffering, equal sacrifice, equal pay and equal work should be the demands today of women who want parity with men in the task of defending their homelands, Mrs. Alva Myrdal declared yesterday before 100 members of the International Federation of Business and Professional Women at a tea in the Hotel Biltmore.

Hunter College students training to teach young children make a dozen toys each term as "homework" for the required course in industrial arts, and 135 girls enrolled in the course this term are taught to utilize material that would otherwise be discarded.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7 -- Canada has declared war on Japan and orders have been given to the armed forces to engage the enemy whereever found. Technically this war declaration still awaits the approval and signature of King George but it is expected that notice that this has been given will be received during the night.

A week of services attendant upon the opening of the entire length of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine bad its climax yesterday morning when 1,000 worshipers partook of Holy Communion. This was the largest group to come up to the altar rail for communion at any one service in the history of the cathedral.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 7 -- Sidney Silidorf and Mrs. Ralph Young of Philadelphia won the national pair bridge championship tonight with 687 points. Other leaders vere Philip Abramsohn and Harry Fishbein, 658; Miss Ruth Sherman and William Levin, 656 1/2; Fred D. Kaplan and Morrie Ells, 655, all of these from New York.

Charging that New York State never had carried its proper share of the cost of higher education, Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, yesterday described the Regents' Report Into the Character and Cost of Public Education as "one of the most remarkable feats of learned obfuscation in the literature of professional education."

Manhattan's daily influx of people has been growing more rapidly than the population of either New York City or the entire metropolitan region, it was anonunced yesterday by the Regional Plan Association. Analysis of points of entry discloses that Long Island continues to be the source of the largest percentage of commuters to southern Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Minister of Finland, Hjalmar J. Procope, today said in a statement that it is "not only regrettable but inexplicable that the British Government has found that its interests call for consent to the Soviet Government's demand that Great Britain declare war on Finland."

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Before announcement here today that Japan was at war with the United States and Britain, both official and unofficial quarters were silent about President Roosevelt's message addressed to Emperor Hirohito, the existence of which was disclosed in Washington late Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Japanese attack on the United States is only one phase of the war being waged against the United States by the Axis powers, Donald Nelson, Executive Director of the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board, said tonight in a broadcast over the Mutual network.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Following are the texts of a statement by Secretary of State Cordell Hull, the American note of Nov. 26 to Japan and Japan's reply:

Bombers with the Rising Sun flag of Japan painted upon their black wings flew over Pearl Harbor, "key to the Pacific," shortly after dawn yesterday and thus merged the Chinese war and the European war into a war of the world.
The thirtieth annual appeal for the Hunded Neediest Cases of New York started yesterday with contributions totaling $25,697.20 already received from 146 donors.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 7 -- The unswerving loyalty of the New Jersey State Industrial Union of the C.I.O. to the nation and to the President in all military means taken to repel the attack by Japan was pledged today at the closing of the fourth annual convention which was thrown into a turmoil by the news from the Pacific.
DETROIT, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings strengthened their grip on fifth place in the National Hockey League tonight by downing the rookie-studded Montreal Canadians, 3 to 2, before 8,417 fans.
AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 7 (AP) -- This is the story of a team that couldn't afford to lose its self-respect. Some chapters are tragic as football stories go.

The New Friends of Music presented the Gordon String Quartet yesterday in the seventh of its series of late afternoon concerts of chamber music at Town Hall. The assisting artists were Lois Wann, oboist, and Harold Bauer, pianist, and the program was divided between Mozart and Dvorak.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 7 -- A succession of stunning reversals in the semi-finals and final of the fourteenth annual squash racquets tournament of the Rockaway Hunting Club established Donald Frame of the Harvard Club of New York as the new holder of the Gold Racquet today.
ROME, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

Declaring that the Japanese attack upon Hawaii and the Philippines was the direct result of Nazi "master-minding" and an application of the "Nazi technique of mass murder," Mayor La Guardia took prompt and vigorous action yesterday in his dual capacity of Mayor and Federal Director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Dec. 8 -- "The cynical and sinister plan of Mr. Roosevelt was to oblige all the peoples of the world to furnish cannon fodder to serve the interests of the United States," the Italian radio said early today in a comment broadcast on the Japanese declaration of war against the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Nov. 25 at 107.4, compared with 107.4 a fortnight before, 107.2 a month before 99.8 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.
BERLIN, Monday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Obligated under the Axis Tripartite Pact to go to Japan's assistance if Japan was "attacked," Germany referred early today to hostilities in the Pacific as "clashes."

In their apparently well-coordinated surprise attacks on the Hawaiian Islands the Japanese have assaulted not only the hub of our strategical universe, but at Oahu, a mid-Pacific Gibraltar, they hit at one of the most heavily fortified and garrisoned strongholds in the world.

Any strike-control legislation which provides merely for a mandatory "cooling-off" period, but fails to modify the Wagner act, will be an attempt to treat the final symptoms of the disease while ignoring one of its fundamental causes. If Congress is to pass strike-curbing legislation with the necessary promptness, there will be obviously no opportunity to make a fresh start on this problem.

The 1942 advertising campaign for Gulistan floor coverings by A. M. Karagheusian will mark a departure from previous drives in that the company's popular-price lines will be stressed in addition to the top brackets. In New York, full-page roto ads will appear in two Sunday papers and, in addition, the back cover of a home magazine will be used.
