This is so clear and so inescapable that Congress can be relied upon to act with all possible speed and to give its answer with that unanimity which will speak for a united nation.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Finnish communique issued today:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The circumstances of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor were such that national unity was an instant consequence. You could almost hear it click into place in Washington today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The country's output of paint products is reaching a high record this year, with sales for the nine months ending with September, 34.8 per cent above the corresponding period of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- While there was comparatively little rain in the main agricultural States last week, high humidity and cloudy weather prevented fields from drying out in many sections and slow progress was made in the harvesting of soy beans.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 8 -- Japan went to war against the United States and Britain today with air and sea attacks against Hawaii, followed by a formal declaration of hostilities.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 7 -- The Finnish Foreign Office last night made public the text of its note to Britain, transmitted through the United States, as follows:

A building containing sixty-eight apartments and seven stores on a plot 150 by 100 feet at 1057 Boynton Avenue, corner of Watson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Retmo Realty Corporation to the Hai-Lawrence Realty Corporation.

Britain's gallant Royal Air Force, which stood off the onslaughts of the superior Luftwaffe, earning for itself from Winston Churchill the praise that "never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few," furnishes the atmosphere for "Golden Wings," tonight's delayed premiere at the Cort.

Juan Jose Castro, one of the Argentine's best-known composers and conductors, is visiting here to conduct the NBC Symphony Orchestra, and the League of Composers took advantage of the occasion to pay its respects to a South American confrere last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Office of Production Management has given orders that "dubious promoters" seeking commissions on defense contracts shall be barred from defense production associations now being organized by groups of small manufacturers to handle in a group contracts or subcontracts they cannot handle individually.

The Indian sign that the Rovers have held over the Washington Eagles this season was shown yesterday at Madison Square Garden, where the New Yorkers subdued the spangled skaters, 6 to 5, in a bruising Eastern Hockey League battle, feature of an amateur double-header.

Last week the Irving Fisher Index of wholesale commodity prices showed a gain of 0.2 per cent, thus reaching a new 1929-41 high point of 99.2. In the farm products group increases in grains, cotton, cotton-seed oil and cattle outweighed decreases in other livestock, eggs and fruits, resulting in a slight rise in the index.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Nov. 30 (Delayed) -- Seizing the occasion of Vice Premier and Foreign Commissar Vyachesloff M. Molotoff's note to foreign governments outlining German atrocities in the occupied areas of the Soviet Union and the barbarous treatment of war prisoners, the Greek Minister, Jean Pipinellis, has submitted in the form of an official note to the Foreign Commissar a detailed report on similar outrages committed by Bulgarian and German forces in occupied Greece.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Sympathizing with the anxiety of parents who have sons in the services, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt expressed today "a sincere hope that the certainty of what we must now meet will make you rise above personal feelings."

SHANGHAI, Monday, Dec. 8 -- The United States gunboat Wake was seized by Japanese forces early this morning after they had caused the burning and sinking of the British gunboat Peterel. The Japanese flag was unfurled on the aft mast of the Wake.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The world champion Chicago Bears defeated the Chicago Cardinals today, 34 -- 24, and feed the idle Green Bay Packers for first place in the Western Division of the National Football League. The result created the necessity for a play-off next Sunday between the Bears and Packers to determine which will meet the New York Giants, Eastern champions, for the league title on Dec. 21.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- In his annual report, which by a coincidence was prepared for release to the press tomorrow, Admiral Stark, Chief of Naval Operations, stressed that the time factor had achieved "the greatest urgency" in United States naval preparations for eventualities.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- With the entire West Coast on a virtual war basis, Mayor Angelo J. Rossi declared San Francisco in a state of emergency tonight and demanded the immediate cessation of all strikes "in order to present a united front."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An editorial, "Nazism vs. Humanity," in THE TIMES of Dec. 2 was one of the most challenging statements I have seen anywhere with regard to standards of national and international conduct in today's warring world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The War Department sent orders tonight to the commanders of the Panama and Hawaiian Departments and the Fourth Army Zone, embracing the Southern Pacific coastal region, to round up all "previously known suspicious aliens."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 -- The following is the text of Emperor Hirohito's proclamation declaring war against the United States and Britain, as picked up and translated by the National Broadcasting Company's listening post here:

The attack by the Japanese on United States possessions in the Pacific Ocean is expected to have repercussions in both the financial and commodity markets of the nation when they open for business today.
Five new films are slated to arrive in Broadway theatres during the week. The program follows:

Dismissing from their minds everything that happened in the game with the Dodgers on Sunday, the Giants spent yesterday in idleness, but this morning preparation for the East-West play-off on Dec. 21 will be launched in earnest at the Polo Grounds.

With steel production for the current week scheduled at 97.5 per cent of capacity, virtually unchanged from the rate of 97.6 per cent reported last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute made public yesterday more complete figures for November, showing output at an average weekly rate of 98.3 per cent.
BERLIN, Tuesday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A D.N.B. dispatch from Tokyo today said Japanese Imperial Navy Headquarters had announced that an American airplane mother ship had been sunk off Honolulu.

Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York led the congregation in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at the 5 o'clock service yesterday afternoon in prayer for divine guidance for the President of the United States in the national crisis.

A sharp increase in strictly wartime advertising campaigns was forecast yesterday by agency executives as the chief result of the outbreak of war with Japan. Increased defense stamp and bond drives, greater conservation campaigns, along the lines of that now being conducted for waste paper, and more institutional copy by industry were predicted.

Five thousand eight hundred employes will receive a holiday bonus from Loew's, Inc., the company announced yesterday. It will apply to those employed in Loew's theatres and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Picture exchanges throughout the country and in Loew's home office and at radio station WHN.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- Two formations of "many planes," described as undoubtedly enemy aircraft, flew over the San Francisco Bay area tonight, it was announced officially by Brig. Gen. William O. Ryan, commander of the Fourth Interceptor Command, after a progressive blackout had blotted out naval and military establishments and whole cities along the Pacific Coast.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Separate meetings of top executives of the nation's motion picture producing and exhibiting companies were held here today preliminary to a general meeting tomorrow, at which plans will be considered for the formation of an all-industry congress to handle common problems.
CORVALLIS, Ore., Dec. 8 -- It's a peculiar team, this representative of Oregon State College that will meet Duke in the Rose Bowl at Pasadena, Calif., on Jan. 1.

World-wide changes in cargo war risk rates, effective immediately, were announced yesterday by marine underwriters here following the declaration of war against Japan by the United States. Generally, the more moderate rates previously prevailing for shipments on United States flag vessels were scrapped and charges for "all flag" vessels are now at the same level.

That Japan, having determined upon war, should launch her attack upon the United States with such reckless daring may, perhaps, be explained by the desperation of her economic situation. If Japan is to win she must win quickly. In a long-drawn conflict she is the most economically vulnerable of any major nation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation has taken 345 Japanese residents of the United States into custody and, although more arrests are likely, the "majority" of those sought are in custody, Attorney General Francis Biddle announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Indication of the principles which would guilde the government's financial conduct of the war and their meaning to business and citizens generally was given today in statements by Secretary Morgenthau and the governing board of the Federal Reserve System.
American naval vessels are named in accordance with a definite policy that received President Roosevelt's approval in 1938.
The flames of war spread rapidly across much of the Western Pacific yesterday as the Japanese struck by air, sea and land at widely dispersed points.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Like other Eastern Intercollegiate League swimming teams, Princeton has one ambition as it prepares for the coming season -- a victory over Yale.

PANAMA, Dec. 8 -- The defenders of the Panama Canal are on the status of "alert" and everything is considered satisfactory, according to a statement made to the press by General Andrews, commanding the Caribbean area.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: George Bittner, in his letter to last Sunday's TIMES about the "Paneuropaeische Bewegung," has a very simple explanation why this movement had no success: "Europe has the misfortune to have in its midst sixty-three million Germans."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- Spencer Tracy was named today by Metro for the starring role in "Keeper of the Flame," a story by I.A.R. Wylie which the studio purchased last week from R.K.O. for $50,000. He will be seen as a newspaperman who is assigned to write the biography of a deceased politician and uncovers the dead man's plot to establish an American dictatorship.
Recruiting stations of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard were said yesterday to be receiving applicants in numbers unprecedented in the history of the nation.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 8 -- Mrs. J.Y. Christmas's Rough Time, many times a stake winner on major tracks, drove to victory today in the Rome Schwagel Purse, named for the graduate athletic manager of Georgetown University.

Possibly "Golden Wings" is a livelier play than it seemed to be last evening at the Cort a few hours after the United States had declared war. Possibly we were too preoccupied with our own affairs to surrender to a gaudy yarn about the ground life of some R.A.F. fliers.

George E. Browne, who until his recent conviction of extorting more than $1,000,000 from the movie industry was president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, paid out $20,000 yesterday as a kind of insurance against serving ten years in prison.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 8 -- Japan's unannounced attack upon the United States Fleet and Army and United States island possessions in the Pacific electrified the Turkish capital, galvanizing the Turkish Government and the foreign diplomatic corps into activity extending long after nightfall tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The outbreak of hostilities in the Far East had a far-reaching effect on the grain markets today, with wheat opening as much as 5 cents a bushel higher and soy beans up 6 cents, the permissible limit for one day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- All classes of hogs, cattle and sheep scored substantial gains on the livestock market today as buyers bid actively for offerings in the belief that war between Japan and the United States would increase the demand for meats.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A statement accusing Germany of having done everything in her power "to push Japan into the war" was issued this evening at the White House.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Canal Zone police, with close cooperation from Panamanian authorities, began rounding up Axis nationals today as the United States clamped a tight wartime guard over the vital area. In Cristobal the activities of the police were coordinated with a roundup at Colon where Panama police had taken eleven Germans into custody and were combing the city for more Axis nationals.

Following the broadcast of President Roosevelt's message to Congress yesterday afternoon a student rally at City College sent a telegram to the President endorsing his stand and offering to serve the nation in any way as students.

Previously isolationist groups pledged yesterday their full support to the prosecution of America's war against Japan. Among the spokesmen to make such declarations were Charles A. Lindbergh, one of the leaders in the America First Committee, and John T. Flynn, chairman of the New York Chapter of the same committee.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A British communique said tonight:
The high-scoring Chicago Bears gained four places on the 1941 National Football League all-star team selected by Associated Press sports writers and released yesterday.

The N.Y.U. football team made its all-opponents selections yesterday and named three Texas A. and M. players to the first eleven and four to the second. The Aggies placed Jim Sterling, left end; Martin Ruby, left tackle, and Derace Moser, left halfback, on the first squad picked by the Violet.

This Christmas season will be a dark one, so far as hosiery is concerned. For decades women have clung to the bland beige and suntan shades, but now the trend is toward the dark colors, which are doing volume business.

Although Nat Holman said yesterday he would rather talk about his C.C.N.Y. basketball team after the season, he did not hesitate to express his confidence in the squad that will face Oklahoma A. and M. in part of the twin bill at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night.

Shostakovich's Sixth Symphony, which was performed by Leopold Stokowski and the NBC Symphony Orchestra three weeks ago, had another outing last night at the concert of the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall. Leon Barzin was the conductor, and he directed the score as the concluding work of a Russian program.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One of my friends, a member of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, is still burning with indignation about the President's not-so-long-ago "Shoot on Sight" speech in which he compared the Nazis with rattlesnakes. He refers me to the following statement in the Encyclopaedia Britannica:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 8 -- Along with the United States and Britain the Free French possessions holding strategic importance in the Pacific are at war with Japan.

VICHY, France, Dec. 8 -- "Yesterday the Japanese suddenly entered into war against the United States and Great Britain." This opening sentence of an editorial this evening in the Journal des Debats may be considered to reflect French opinion so far as it can be reflected in a controlled press.

LONDON -- The parliamentary turmoil that preceded the transfer of Reuters News Agency jointly to the Press Association, a company financed and controlled by the provincial newspapers of Great Britain, and the Newspaper Proprietors Association, a representative corporation of the London press, reflected a public awakening concerning the sources of some of its information.
The United States' first full day at war found the radio industry enlisting "for the duration" and, for the most part, on a 24-hour-a-day basis.

KUIBISHEV, Russia, Dec. 6 (delayed) -- Parallel with the success of her armies in recent weeks, the diplomatic position of the Soviet Union has been greatly consolidated in respect to both the present war and to the peace conferences that would follow the anticipated victory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Months of controversy in the Senate over international and domestic issues ended today when by a vote of 82 to 0 it adopted the war resolution with such dispatch that some members, hurrying to their posts arrived too late to participate.
Tha Tokyo radio reported last night under a Shanghai dateline that both Guam and Wake Islands were under the Japanese flag. The broadcast was heard here by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Battle of the Pacific spread tonight over a 5,000-mile "front" from Hawaii to the Philippines while a badly battered United States Fleet fought back at Japanese sea and air forces that launched severe attacks yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Dec, 8 -- Many Americans serving with the British forces, including members of the American Eagle Squadrons of the Royal Air Force Fighter Command, are eager to get into the United States fighting forces now that their country has been attacked by the Japanese.

At a reception held yesterday afternoon at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street, Mr. and Mrs. Frank Chapman of Redding Ridge, Conn., formally presented to Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University the large set of drawings made by the late William Yarrow as preliminary studies for series of sports murals at Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The United States went to war today as a great nation should -- with simplicity, dignity, and unprecedented unity. The deep divisions which marked this country's entrance into the wars of 1776, 1812, 1861, 1898 and 1917 were absent.

As Prime Minister Churchill said in his broadcast yesterday, Great Britain acted ahead of her engagements by declaring war on Japan, not "within the hour," as he had promised, but, because of the difference in time, before Congress even assembled for its momentous session.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 8 -- After a day of consultations with the diplomatic representatives of most South American republics and two conferences between Foreign Minister Ruiz Guinazu and United States Ambassador Norman Armour, the Argentine Foreign Ministery announced tonight that a Cabinet Council would be held tomorrow to issue a decree declaring the United States would not be considered a belligerent power in its conflict with Japan.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 9 (From Official Broadcasts, Distributed by The Associated Press) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters announced last night the sinking of two United States battleships and a mine-sweeper, severe damage to four other American capital ships and four cruisers and the destruction of about 100 American planes in Japan's surprise blows at Hawaii, the Philippines and Guam.
New York women responded with a rush to the nation's emergency yesterday. Focal points for civilian defense registration were swamped with volunteers eager to donate their services.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 8 -- The Japanese in the first eighteen hours of their attack on the Malaya peninsula have forced Thailand to capitulate, but do not now appear to have achieved any appreciable success in an invasion of British Malaya.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- New York State moved into a wartime status today with Governor Lehman directing various activities.
Mrs. Everett T. Tomlinson of Elizabeth was hostess yesterday to members of the Monday Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 3: An increase of $40,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills, decreases of $42,000,000 in "other securities" and $128,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and an increase of $155,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- The German forces in Libya are feeling the effects of continuous battering by British mobile columns. Yesterday General Erwin Rommel was marshaling his remaining active units along a line extending from the Tobruk area through El Adem to the Bir el-Gobi region.

The declaration of a state of war between the United States and Japan had rather severe repercussions yesterday in the market for fixed-interest-bearing securities in the local markets. Conspicuous, however, in the readjustment that brought about declines in a long list of the highest grade bonds as well as among many foreign government obligations, was the absence of any severe selling pressure.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Hawaii has been calm since Sunday's Japanese aerial Blitzkrieg, Governor Joseph B. Poindexter told Delegate Samuel King by transpacific telephone tonight.
In the tightest photo finish the race has ever boasted, Whirlaway nosed out Alsab yesterday to become the horse of the year for 1941.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 8 -- The following symposium of comments represents the immediate reaction of a number of persons of diversified nationality in one of the few remaining neutral capitals in the world, to the news that the United States was at war.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Federal Judge M.M. Joyce imposed sixteen-month prison sentences today on twelve of eighteen members of the Socialist Workers party who were convicted of advocating overthrow of the government by force and violence.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Almost every one in Little Tokyo, largest Japanese settlement in the United States, expected war between America and Japan.

OTTAWA, Dec. 8 -- As stoutly and generously as she has supported Great Britain throughout the past two years of war in Europe, Canada will stand beside the United States in the war in the Pacific. That is the attitude today of every man, from the Prime Minister down.

Railroad shipments of war material to the Pacific Coast have been heavy in recent months, it now may be revealed as the result of the war declaration, rail officials said yesterday. The nature of these shipments has been kept secret.
Organized labor of New York State and City, regardless of affiliation, spoke in one voice yesterday in support of the nation's war effort.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board, supreme policy-making agency in the war production drive, expressed tonight its determination to bring arms output to the highest possible physical level in a gigantic "victory program," which it is reported would call for expenditures of about $4,000,000,000 per month in 1942 and 1943.

Among those reported yesterday as having signed contracts for commercial quarters was Roure-Dupont, Inc., importers of chemicals and perfume oils, who leased a full floor of about 4,000 square feet at 366 Madison Avenue through A. Sheldon Jaffe, broker.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command today issued this communique:

The American food industry is prepared. Despite the suddenness of the outbreak of war in the Pacific, representatives of food manufacturers, distributors and can makers declared yesterday that they were ready and able to meet the nation's dietary requirements.

Stockholders of the Connecticut Light and Power Company, at a special meeting yesterday at Hartford, paved the way for a large-scale financing program by approving steps looking to substantial expansion of facilities and the retirement of the outstanding preferred stock, Charles L. Campbell, president of the company, announced after the meeting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The United States today formally declared war on Japan. Congress, with only one dissenting vote, approved the resolution in the record time of 33 minutes after President Roosevelt denounced Japanese aggression in ringing tones.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today the 1941 cotton crop at 10,976,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight. The estimate was based on Dec. 1 conditions. A month ago the department estimated the crop at 11,020,000 bales.

Meeting in the offices of the Carnegie Corporation, 522 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon, the trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace adopted resolutions offering its help to the government in dealing with international affairs incident to the war, commending the Administration for its efforts to find a peaceful solution of the Pacific problem, and denouncing Japan for "a betrayal of one of the most fundamental principles of international law."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Maxim Litvinoff, the new Soviet Ambassador who arrived here only yesterday, lost no time in taking over his official duties by presenting his letters of credence to President Roosevelt today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Dec. 9 -- The Permanent Military Commission of the Tripartite Pact, which was scheduled to have met in Rome yesterday afternoon, postponed its meeting until sometime late this morning, according to information in American diplomatic quarters here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- When the Japanese began their naval and air attack on United States outposts Sunday they followed the same tactics of surprise attack without declaring war that they utilized when they attacked Russia in the Far East in 1904.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Alaska prepared today for the possibility that Japanese warships might swing northward from Hawaii.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Dec. 8 (AP) -- John Wallace Riddle, former Ambassador to Russia and Argentina, died here tonight at the age of 77. He also had held other diplomatic posts, including assignments in Turkey, Egypt, Rumania and Serbia.

The antlerless deer season opened in Steuben County yesterday, and although no reports were received on the results of the first day, many hunters were convinced that they knew just where to get a big doe in an hour's hunting.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- The Reich has not announced the course she intends to pursue in consequence of her Tripartite Pact partner, Japan, declaring war on the United States, but a Wilhelmstrasse spokesman said today that the German Government had maintained "active contact" with Tokyo throughout the progress of the Washington conversations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Roosevelt arose at dawn, examined latest war dispatches, conferred with military and naval leaders, completed his draft of the message to Congress asking for a declaration of war against Japan, delivered the message and then signed the resolution for war adopted by Congress, and conferred with Mayor La Guardia on civilian defense on the Pacific Coast.

Buddy Baer, younger and bigger brother of Max, arrived yesterday to start training for his return bout with Joe Louis for the heavy-weight title on Jan. 9 in Madison Square Garden. The proceeds of this bout, together with Louis's purse, are to go to the Naval Relief Society.

What's in a Name Once upon a time there was a certain Foundation which had a large sum of money to invest in a study of the nutrition deficiencies of the American people. The available funds were not big enough, however, for a nation-wide survey.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Belden gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza to celebrate the anniversary of their marriage. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Dixon, Mr. and Mrs. S. Perry Howze, Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Cornell, Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd G. Schultz, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clendenin, Mrs. David Boies, Mrs. Mortimer B. Fuller and Louis Batchley.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Dec. 8 -- Due to the developments in the Pacific, it was announced on the Bourse that losses exceeding 5 points require the sanction of the Bourse committees. Prices were weak, but resistance was met at the lower levels.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's war message to Congress, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES from a broadcast:
BERLIN, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The High Command issued this communique today from "the Fuehrer's headquarters":

The State of Minnesota will be in the market on Jan. 5 with an issue of $2,700,000 of rural credit deficiency fund certificates, for which bidders are asked to name the rate of interest. The obligations, to be dated Jan. 15, 1942, will mature on Jan. 15 and July 15, 1948 and 1949, and will be optional for call on Jan. 15, 1945.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Protests against the salary increases provided for 700 county employes in the proposed $12,925,251 county budget were filed here tonight at the annual budget hearing called by the Westchester County Board of Supervisors at the County Center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 State Department officials said today that there was no accurate census of Americans in Japan, but that developments in Japanese-American relations in recent weeks had caused all but a few American citizens to leave that country.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 -- The government reported today that Japanese aircraft had bombed Nauru and Ocean Islands, more than 1,700 miles northeast of Australia. It was not known whether damage or casualties had been caused.

Sewing implements of long ago, including a bronze Egyptian thimble 2,300 years old, were placed on exhibition yesterday in the Cooper Union Museum for the Arts of Decoration. The collection, loaned by Mr. and Mrs. De Witt Clinton Cohen of this city, will be on view until 10 P.M. from Mondays to Fridays and until 5 P.M. on Saturdays until Jan. 1.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- Italy, like Germany, let Washington do the speaking today, but even though President Roosevelt said nothing about war against the Axis, there is little hope in the long run of avoiding the conflict. However, no official stand has been taken and until then one is entitled to rest upon the fact that the arguments seem all against either the Axis or the United States precipitating matters now.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Argentina informed the United States today that, in view of Japan's attack on this country, she intended to comply with the terms of the 1940 Havana compacts of the American Republics that define such an attack as directed against the entire Western Hemisphere.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill declared war on Japan in the House of Commons today and later, after most Britons had listened to President Roosevelt's message to Congress, the Prime Minister went on the air with his strongest appeal thus far for British workers to make a supreme effort in production.

Opening losses of 40 to 49 points or $2 to $2.45 a bale marked the cotton market's first reaction yesterday to the outbreak of war between the United States and Japan. Mill buying, however, soon lifted prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange as much as 77 points or $3.85 a bale from these lows.

BATAVIA, Dec. 8 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Hubertus J. van Mook, Minister of Colonies, this evening in an address to "our allied citizens," declared that Japan "has thrown off a mask of peaceful intention and has shown the world clearly and unmistakably" that she is after "destruction, domination and loot."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 -- A jittery Los Angeles, apathetic up to yesterday to war fears, went through a practice air-raid alarm tonight as its harbor area, the adjoining oil fields and the great aircraft factories, shining targets for hostile bombers, were partially blacked out from 5 to 7 o'clock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 6:
Using Japan as a "stooge," Germany declared war on the United States Sunday, Elizabeth Knaust, former archivist for Propaganda Minister Josef Goebbels from 1933 to 1937, declared yesterday.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Japanese troops were reported today to have landed with the probable help of "fishermen" Fifth Columnists on Lubang Island. Enough credence was placed in the report that defense officers were trying urgently to make contact with the Provincial Governor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A state of war all but lifts the limit from Presidential powers.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 9 -- After a day of widespread aerial attacks throughout the Philippines, Japanese bombers swept in over Manila Bay early this morning and attacked Nichols Field, the United States Army air base on the outskirts of this capital, and simultaneously reports were received of a Japanese landing on Lubang Island, off the northwestern tip of Mindoro.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Mayor F.H. La Guardia, Director of Civilian Defense, appealed to the American home population today to stand firm against air-raids, then hurriedly took his departure by plane to the Pacific Coast, the only part of continental United States, it is thought, which Japanese bombers could reach now.

Growing out of the work of the War Prisoners Aid Committee of the Y.M.C.A. is a small book of essays written by sixteen British officers and soldiers who were detained in a German prison camp. The publication department of the National Council of Y.M.C.A.'s has the book on the press under the title of "We Prisoners of War."

Disagreeing with the Brooklyn court that last week restrained Mayor La Guardia from naming a city-wide Sheriff to replace the five County Sheriffs, Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora upheld yesterday the validity of the county reform proposition adopted by the voters at the last election and dismissed a petition to restrain the Mayor from appointing a city-wide Register.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Fred Corcoran, the Professional Golfers Association tournament manager, followed up a ban on big bets and winner-take-all contests with a blast today at sideshow ballyhoo for the pros' appearances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- On careful examination, the Japanese note in response to Secretary Hull's proposals of Nov. 26 is disclosed as a fit target for the Secretary's shocked indignation. When its overtone of sweet and injured reasonableness is subtracted from the composition, the warlike strains of its real theme are as plainly to be heard as Honolulu heard the bombs that treacherously preceded its delivery to Mr. Hull by the Japanese envoys.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday Dec. 9 -- The "annihilated" Russian Army of Crimea, which has been steadily re-forming and reinforcing its units on the Taman Peninsula of the Caucasus following its retreat from Kerch in October, has recrossed the Kerch Straits and is fighting fiercely against German positions on the eastern end of the Crimean Peninsula, Moscow's military spokesman declared in the regular Russian broadcast this morning.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The governments of the Netherlands, Greece and the French National Committee under General Charles de Gaulle announced in London today that they had acted on Japanese aggression against the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Operations of the Office of Production Management were being stepped up to wartime tempo today as executives moved to convert the former "defense" organization into a full-time war agency to direct armaments production.

An exceptionally large class of 219 new lawyers, including eighteen women, one of them a police detective, an Army corporal, a city fireman, a business executive, the son of a rear admiral, a nephew of former Mayor James J. Walker and the sons of two former judges, was sworn in yesterday at the Appellate Division, Madison Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, by Presiding Justice Francis Martin.
ROME, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Among the Living," a Paramount melodrama, with Harry Carey, Albert Dekker, Susan Hayward and Frances Farmer, which will arrive at the Rialto on Saturday.... The double-feature bill starting today at the New York Theatre is composed of "Tonto Basin Outlaws" and "Borrowed Hero."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Organized labor pledged tonight its full support to the government in allout production effort to repulse Japan and defeat the Axis powers.

Miss Hilary Winant of Princeton, N.J., niece of John G. Winant, United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James, is a member of the committee working toward the success of the performance of Noel Coward's "Hay Fever" to be presented by students of the Theatre Arts Division of Finch Junior College on Thursday night at the Finch Theatre, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, for the benefit of United China Relief.

The nation's sport leaders are prepared to conduct business throughout the war, providing the government agrees, and most of them believe that the task of providing recreation and boosting morale is more important now than ever.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Profoundly mindful of the storm clouds gathering over the nation and as uncertain as the next one about the future, major league baseball men gathered today for their annual Winter sessions in an air reminiscent of the war days of 1917 and 1918.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- This country has "vast and vital interests" in raw materials available in the Pacific and for that reason must use every effort to keep supply lines to the Orient open, the Office for Emergency Management stressed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The House adopted today, 388 to 1, the resolution declaring war with Japan forty minutes after it was presented and would have done so sooner but for speeches by a few members, who pledged unity of action by this nation in winning the war.

Civilian defense facilities in New Jersey, Westchester and other near-by communities were quickly mobilized yesterday as a wave of patriotism brought scores of offers of assistance to governmental officials and notably spurred recruiting for the Army, Navy and Marine Corps.

United States plants are already producing more explosives than were made at the peak of production in the last war, and further capacity is under construction, according to traders in the chemical field, who said yesterday that vast quantities of chemical materials normally used for production of civilian goods of all kinds were now being devoted to powder output.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The grounding of all private aviation in the United States was only a temporary measure, it was learned here today, and all flying licenses may be reinstated immediately by pilots who show proof of citizenship and satisfy the authorities that they are patriotic Americans.

Congress has spoken -- no, thundered -- its answer to the madmen of Japan. With a swiftness of action never before achieved in the whole history of this country and a unanimity of mind and spirit which for all practical purposes is complete, the challenge of the treacherous friend that now becomes the mortal foe has been accepted.

Large shopping crowds in many local stores tended yesterday to ease fears that the sudden outbreak of war with Japan would react seriously upon Christmas trade, which normally reaches its peak within the next two weeks. Estimates in well-informed quarters indicated that only about one-third of the expected holiday business has been done up to this time, and merchants here, as well as throughout the country, have assembled the largest gift stocks on record.

The foreign-born people of the United States will rally to the national cause with full loyalty in the present crisis just as they have always done in the past, Hugh De Lacy, national chairman of the American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born, declared yesterday in a telegram to President Roosevelt.

America's official entry into the war found the securities markets braced for an impact which, in the final analysis, proved less severe than the blow suffered when the Nazis overran the low nations of Europe.

In any time of crisis there is no more sensitive indication of the public's frame of mind than the action of the financial markets. Nor is there any community, unless it be Washington, better equipped to appraise the longrange implications of a war than the Wall Street community.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- By a vote of 5 to 4, the United States Supreme Court set aside today the contempt-of-court convictions of Harry Bridges, West Coast C.I.O. leader, and The Los Angeles Times and its managing editor, L.D. Hotchkiss.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am writing to protest with respect to a situation which has not only caused considerable distress to many Jewish citizens, but more significantly and of vastly more importance, must have caused misunderstanding and criticism on the part of our non-Jewish co-Americans.

Clay from all parts of the Americas, which has been made uncommon by the craftsmanship of ceramic artists, diverted the thoughts of many New Yorkers from the war yesterday afternoon as the Exhibition of Contemporary Ceramics of the Western Hemisphere was opened at W. J. Sloane.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 8 -- Artillery and "tank destroyer" units of the federalized Forty-fourth Division returned to Fort Dix tonight from ten weeks of war games in the Carolinas just a few hours after war was declared on Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The extraordinary news control invoked by the White House in the first reports of war news has imposed a restriction more drastic than normal censorship, and one which showed today signs of contributing to the grave fears which in emergencies spring from lack of authoritative information.
Representatives of Latin-American countries here yesterday expressed their support of the United States and the war policy of the Administration in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Japan was trying to deliver a knock-out blow against American air power in the Pacific to forestall the bombing of Tokyo and other major centers, authoritative military quarters said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Congress showed signs today of being ready to remove all restrictions heretofore laid on the use of troops.

Fighting between the democratic forces and Japan will be severe when the battle is joined because the Japanese Navy is "very formidable," it was said yesterday by Brig. Gen. H.S. Sewell, commander of the First Cavalry Brigade of the British Army in France in the last war and now military expert attached to the British Library of Information.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan demanded court-martial procedings tonight against five Army and Navy commanders, including Admiral Husband E. Kimmel, Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet, for "the naval debacle" at Pearl Harbor.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The text of Prime Minister Churchill's speech in the Commons announcing a declaration of war on Japan follows:

Even in this time of national crisis the appeal of the needy here at home is certain to be heard. They speak with a compelling eloquence through The Neediest Cases. The Fund is too well established and too close to the heart of the city to permit them to be forgotten.

Because exchange control regulations and the rigors of economic warfare had curtailed operations in recent years, American concerns doing business in Japan had few employes caught in that country by the outbreak of hostilities, they reported yesterday.

THE demands of the defense program were felt in the field of sports. The impact of war will have a far greater effect. How athletes, teams, sports promoters and athletic organizations are going to be "hurt" by war conditions is a minor matter not worth bothering about as long as hostilities continue. Let there be no mistake about it: everybody is going to be "hurt" more or less in this war.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (U.P.) -- Russian offensives on the Moscow and southern fronts were reported today to have carried across the Mius River ten miles west of Taganrog and recovered complete control of the Tula-Serpukhov highway south of the capital.

A group of security dealers headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers will offer to the public today 53,690 shares of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Merck Co., Inc. The stock will be priced at $105 a share.

Voluntary codes of fair competition under the joint direction of employer and labor groups were defended as essential safeguards against commercial chaos and labor strife in competitive small-unit industries in the answer filed yesterday by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, through its counsel, Wendell L. Willkie, to charges by the Federal Trade Commission, alleging trade restraint and monopolistic practices.

No serious disturbances to our markets are to be expected as a result of the war with Japan. This was the statement issued on behalf of the group of leading Wall Street, bankers, insurance executives and the president of the Stock Exchange, who form the Federal Reserve Bank's general consultive committee, which met at the bank yesterday morning.

Immediate mobilization or volunteer air-raid wardens was ordered by the police last night following an earlier Army call for volunteer aircraft spotters to report to their posts, as, with the United States barely as war, the vast civilian defense program on which citizens have been practicing for months began to go into effect.

During the days that lie ahead we must fight and win not one but two wars. The first, fought by our men, our ships and our planes, will be dramatic, grim, fast-moving. The second will be fought on the home front. It will have little of the high adventure of the first.

The reaction of New York to the national crisis was prompt and decisive yesterday. All classes and groups of society immediately offered whole-hearted support and allegiance to the President and the government.
The round-up of Japanese aliens that detectives and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents started Sunday night continued last night with the arrest of additional Japanese and also Germans.

During the days that lie ahead we must fight and win not one but two wars. The first, fought by our men, our ships and our planes, will be dramatic, grim, fast-moving. The second will be fought on the home front. It will have little of the high adventure of the first.

While long lines of men of fighting age waited impatiently outside of every Army, Navy and Marine Corps recruiting office in the city yesterday, representatives of the city, State and Federal Governments went ahead with the grim business of making New York City ready for war.

Retail Sales Even With 1940 Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were unchanged from the corresponding week a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The conservation of food and elimination of waste in the present crisis was advocated by Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs, Inc., at the monthly meeting of the organization at the Lobster Tap House, 145 West Forty-fifth Street, last night.
Invitations to bombers may be limited in the future if Americans heed the call to camouflage, issued yesterday for the first time in this city.
BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- Winter has stopped the Germans short of Moscow and the capture of the Soviet capital is not expected this year, a miltary spokesman declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The War Department announced today that a cost-plus-a-fixed-fee contract has been awarded to the Fraser Brace Engineering Company, Inc., of New York, for architectural and engineering services and construction management in connection with the recently announced TNT plant to be located at Geneva, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Dec. 3 aggregated $12,078,000,000.

Supervision No heroic measures were taken yesterday to protect the New York Stock Exchange or markets generally from the effects of the war. Officials were at their posts early, Emil Schram, new president, arriving at 8:15 o'clock and conferring immediately with the staff members who canvass member firms whenever there is an unusual situation.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold to a client of Newman Bisco, attorneys, for cash above a first mortgage of $60,500 the five-story apartment house at 142 West Fifty-seventh Street, on a plot 20 by 100 feet. There are six two-room apartments and several stores in the structure, which is assessed for $120,000.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 6 (Delayed) -- Premier Wladyslaw Sikorski of Poland announced today that, as a result of his meeting with Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union, which ended in conclusion of a declaration of friendship and mutual aid between the U.S.S.R. and Poland, the Polish Army now being formed in Russia would no longer be confined to two divisions, which had been the limit, but be "several times as large."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Wartime prohibitions on disclosure of information deemed of possible value to the enemy were invoked today by the Navy and Army.

Large claims were made yesterday and early today by Japan or Axis agencies in connection with the fighting in the Pacific between the United States and the Japanese. The assertions of damage and the sources are listed below; all the claims were made yesterday except those otherwise designated:

One hundred and fifty-seven contributions were received yesterday for the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York in quick and heartening response to the appeal, published last Sunday in THE NEW YORK TIMES, for men, women and children in greatest distress throughout the city.

Although Ethel Merman, star of "Panama Hattie," is able to appear at every performance of the hit musical, a doctor is in constant attendance. Unless she regains her health before the show leaves for the road, it will be necessary to replace her.

An entertainment to be known as "Stars in Khaki" will be given by service men on the afternoon of Dec. 27 in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Recreation Service Fund of Governors Island Army Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association.

EDDYSTONE, Pa., Dec. 8 -- The first heavy tank ever built in the United States, an all-welded behemoth of fifty-seven tons, roared with ease today through a series of grueling tests before a large throng of Army and industrial experts who were hard put to conceal their pleasure at the demonstration of the power contained inside its armor-sheathed body.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Officiate of the Board of Trade took swift action this afternoon on a request of the Commodity Exchange Administration to prevent a further advance in wheat and soy beans. At a special meeting it was ordered that no sales of the two commodities tomorrow could be made above the closing prices of today.

An entertainment to be known as "Stars in Khaki" will be given by service men on the afternoon of Dec. 27 in the main ballroom of the Pierre for the benefit of the Recreation Service Fund of Governors Island Army Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association.

EDDYSTONE, Pa., Dec. 8 -- The first heavy tank ever built in the United States, an all-welded behemoth of fifty-seven tons, roared with ease today through a series of grueling tests before a large throng of Army and industrial experts who were hard put to conceal their pleasure at the demonstration of the power contained inside its armor-sheathed body.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 9 -- Making his twenty-first try of the year, R.B. Hall's Residue finally drove his way into the winner's circle in the fifth race today. Completing a double for Danny Scocca, lightweight Washington rider, Residue withstood a long drive to score by a length over the favored My One.

After a ten-day vacation from gridiron activities the Sugar Bowlbound Fordham Rams yesterday launched preparations at Fordham Field for their New Year's Day encounter with Missouri at New Orleans. Late classes prevented Jim Blumenstock, Steve Filipowicz, Jim Noble, Steve Hudacek, Stan Ritinski, Tom Bennet and Alex Santilli from attending the workout, so that most of the first-stringers were absent.

The American Communications Association, an affiliate of the C.I.O., which last week declared that its wage negotiations with the East Coast shipowners had bogged down and that a strike had been authorized, sent word to President Roosevelt yesterday that there would he no interruption of service by any of the ship radio operators who belong to the union.

The air-raid warnings, with accompanying excitement and control of pedestrian traffic in important areas of the city, took toll of retail trade here yesterday, merchants reported last night. The initial shock of the war developments was not so bad on Monday so far as Christmas trade was concerned, but declines under a year ago ranging around 10 per cent or more were noted yesterday.

Robert Mann, 19-year-old violinist from Portland, Ore., gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, and the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation was able to pride itself on having introduced still another talented young artist, for the young violinist was this year's winner in the foundation's violin auditions and the debut recital was his reward.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The British foresee Japan waging an all-out war along the most modern lines for at least one year and possibly a few months longer, judging solely by her present strength and estimated stocks of essential materials, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Appearing before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today at the beginning of hearings on the House Price Control Bill, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, offered a complete draft of amendments to this measure which, if accepted, would restore it in all essential aspects to the form in which, he first proposed it.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Metro today purchased "Teach Me to Live," an unpublished novel by Forbes Parkhill, dealing with the early settlement of Colorado, as a vehicle for Walter Pidgeon. Pidgeon's schedule also includes "Full Glory," an aviation story by William Wellman and Lester Konig.
All, recruiting records of the nation's armed forces were shattered in this area yesterday as thousands of men attempted to enlist for combat duty with the Army, Navy, Marine Corps or Coast Guard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 --The House Naval Committee heard one of its members, Representative Vincent, Democrat, of Kentucky, brings the undercurrent of criticism of the Navy for what happened at Pearl Harbor Sunday into the open today by declaring that "some one was asleep" -- some one responsible for the defenses.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "Birth of the Blues," a comedy with music, will be the newcomer at the Paramount. Bing Crosby, Mary Martin, Brian Donlevy, Carolyn Lee, Rochester and Jack Teagarden and his orchestra are featured in the film, which tells of the early days of American jazz.

The plant occupying six acres of land, formerly occupied by Stylepark Hats, Inc., John Katz, president, at Camden, N. J., has been sold to the R. M. Hollingshead Corporation, manufacturers of chemical products. Stylepark Hats will continue to be manufactured in enlarged quarters at 2550 Reed Street, Philadelphia.

Hearings on its charges of conspiracy to fix prices and the maintenance of an alleged boycott by the National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association and 112 affiliated trade associations and individuals were resumed yesterday at 45 Broadway by the Federal Trade Commission after a lapse of eleven months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The serious effect on Japan's domestic economy of her military policies in East Asia was emphasized in a review of Japan's foreign commercial relations issued by the Department of Commerce today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Japanese attack on the United States brought an expression of "warm sympathy" from the Russian to the American people by Maxim Litvinoff, the new Soviet Ambassador, in presenting his letters of credence to President Roosevelt.

The advertising profession was called upon yesterday to support the government's war effort in all its phases by pushing the sale of government bonds, obtaining enlistments, aiding the national nutrition and by providing advertising media that help maintain the morale of the people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Flood lights which illuminate the dome of the Capitol were ordered turned off tonight for the duration of the war. Arrangements were completed for darkening, at a moment's notice, of the White House and the grounds in which it stands.

Governors of twenty-five States and Mayors of a hundred cities, including Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia, are calling upon the citizens of their communities to observe next Monday as Bill of Rights Day, according to an announcement yesterday by the Bill of Rights Sesqui-Centennial Committee.

A serene collection was offered at the preview held by Bergdorf Goodman yesterday afternoon in the custom-made department on the fourth floor. There was no excitement of new silhouettes in these clothes destined for sunny climes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Rumors today that police guards were within the Japanese Embassy as a precaution against possible attempts at hari-kiri by Ambassador Kishisaburo Nomura or members of staff were denied by the State Department officials who said:
Charles Walzer, the realty operator, yesterday reported that he had purchased one large Manhattan business property and has sold another in separate deals.

Reflecting the uncertainty and apprehension in municipal bond market circles over the effect of the war on money market conditions and municipal credit generally, moderately lower bids for new loans were the rule in yesterday's market.

VICHY, France, Dec. 9 -- The excitement caused by the opening of hostilities by Japan having subsided, a more matter-of-fact view obtains here today. The official stand remains unchanged -- France is out of the war as a belligerent and is henceforth merely an observer.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Carroll C. Hincks turned down several parts of the Interstate Commerce Commission plan for reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 10 (Distributed by The Associated Press) -- The Moscow radio broadcast this communique today:
MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- The sinking of a Japanese aircraft carrier off Zambales Province was reported today without confirmation.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 9 -- In a radio address to the nation tonight Manuel Avila Camacho, President of Mexico, appealed for national and hemispheric unity and support of the cause of the United States. But he did not -- as some had predicted -- call for a declaration of war by Mexico or for any further action.
Two Appellate Division decisions speeding to the Court of Appeals the legal controversy over the county reform proposition adopted by the voters in the last election were made yesterday.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 10--Two Japanese landings on this Philippine island of Luzon were reported today by the Filipino Constabulary, and an Army spokesman announced that "all indications point to a heavy enemy attack with land troops supported by naval contingents and aircraft."

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Members of the Association of American Railroads decided today to ask for a 10 per cent increase in basic passenger fares to help compensate for an estimated $300,000,000 annual payroll rise.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--American industry must swing into a seven-day-week schedule of production immediately to meet the expanded armaments requirements created by the war, President Roosevelt said today at his press conference.

Military, naval and commercial airfields along the Eastern Seaboard got their first taste of warlike conditions yesterday afternoon when air-raid warnings reported enemy aircraft approaching New York City.

Active liquidation operations erased early gains in the cotton market yesterday and carried prices on the New York Cotton Exchange early in the afternoon to their low marks for the day at losses of 48 to 54 points, or $2.40 to $2.70 a bale.

Showing their conviction that the neediest men, women and children in New York City must not be forgotten because of the grave war crisis confronting the country, 281 persons sent contributions to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Though the Hawaiian fortifications and bases are the most powerful under the American flag and the concentration of warships and heavy fighting planes there was very strong, enough has now been learned of Sunday's attack on Pearl Harbor by the Japanese to support the conclusion that even in this sector the United States was not prepared for war.

Until war came to the United States there was a disposition in some quarters to regard air-raid precautions as a slightly ridiculous preparation for something that would never happen or, at best, as a device for stimulating civilian morale in support of the national defense effort.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 9 -- Japanese operations against the Thai-Malay peninsula had developed today into a large-scale offensive against Northern Malaya. Into this savagely pressed drive the Japanese were hurling large reinforcements in an effort to gain vital points and advance along main lines of communication.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Administration will urge Congress this week to authorize President Roosevelt to utilize the war equipment of this country in any way and in any place he deems most effective in prosecuting the war, not only against Japan, but against the entire Axis.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 -- A protecting curtain of clouds hung over Los Angeles for the third night of the war as the city moved toward a war footing. The blackout was extended to cover not only the harbor area and the industrial south side but the manufacturing center of Glendale, north of the city.

A continued easing of fur prices in the immediate future, followed by a reverse in the trend that will bring prices by the second quarter of next year to a point far above current levels, was predicted last night by J.D. Silberman of the Silberman Fur Corporation at the annual meeting of the American Fur Merchants Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Roosevelt conceded tonight that the United States had suffered a serious defeat at Hawaii and at other outlying bases and called upon the American people to prepare for a long war, "which we are going to win."

A charge that student Communists at City and Brooklyn Colleges have gained control of many of the important undergraduate organizations and are in charge of the four student newspapers was made by the Rapp-Coudert subcommittee, in the last of a three-section report, released yesterday.
Bliss Laughlin Bliss Laughlin, Inc., voted a dividend of $1.25 on the common stock, increasing the total for the year to $2 from $1.50 distributed in 1940.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 9 -- The Berkshire ski centers, always popular with the city dwellers, are anxiously awaiting the first big snowfall for what the natives will tell you should be another "biggest" season for the sport.

Another repercussion of the uneasiness in the market for highgrade bonds caused by the war situation was the recommendation made yesterday by the United States Housing Authority to the officials of nine local housing authorities that they postpone the sales, scheduled for today, of $7,672,000 of long-term Series A bonds.
MANILA, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- Admiral Thomas C. Hart, Commander in Chief of the United States Asiatic Fleet, established today a huge "strategic area" in the southwestern Pacific and the Indian Ocean.

Orderly and alert, 1,000,000 children and 40,000 teachers in the New York City school system poured out of their classrooms into the streets yesterday afternoon, responding to the first air-raid alarm in this city's history. Swiftly and quietly the schools of the world's largest system were emptied in fifteen minutes.

BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- A German government statement, clarifying in a clear-cut manner German-American relations in view of the Far Eastern conflict, may be expected soon, it was said here tonight in official circles. "Soon" may mean tomorrow.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address last night as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES from the broadcast:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that representatives of organized labor and organized industry would be asked to confer soon in an effort to reach an agreement on a war labor policy guaranteeing uninterrupted production as a substitute for drastic anti-strike legislation now pending in the Senate.

A teletype order went out from Police Headquarters last night requesting all borough commanders to notify all zone, sector and post air-raid wardens to report to their respective precincts at 7:30 tonight "for special defense instructions."

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 9 -- Like a swarm of angry hornets, British mobile columns were reported to have continued to sting German forces in Cyrenaica again and again today. So sharp and frequent were the British attacks yesterday that British headquarters here report some westward movement by German forces between Tobruk and Bir el-Gobi, perhaps to gain temporary respite from the battering.

The eastern seaboard received yesterday its first baptism of air-raid warnings, and the stock market promptly responded by cracking 2 to 8 points. These were the extreme losses of the session. It must also be pointed out, however, that the worst declines were accompanied by comparatively small volume in relation to the total business, and at the close the list had recovered about half of these losses.

President Roosevelt summoned his countrymen last night to partnership "in the most tremendous undertaking of our national history." That undertaking is the defense of democracy in the hour of its greatest trial. The war upon which we have embarked will be a long war and a hard war, the President conceded.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins regained undisputed possession of the top place in the National Hockey League tonight by coming from behind for a 2 -- 2 overtime tie with Chicago's young and speedy Black Hawks before 10,000 spectators at the Boston Garden.

Cooking experts -- usually those boasting a great-grandmother who was married to a French chef who was decorated with a Cordon Bleu -- are reverently transformed when they talk about sauces. Their tones become hushed and their eyes roll. For by such exhibitions these experts would have you know that a sauce is the magical culmination of culinary genius.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies in November again showed a smaller percentage gain over 1940, according to a compilation by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The gain -- the smallest since June -- amounted to 18.8 per cent, compared with 21.5 in October, 26.7 in September and the year's high of 29.8 in August.

HONG KONG, Dec. 8 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Captain Fred S. Ralph of Northeast Harbor, Me., said today that so many Japanese planes attacked his Pacific Clipper plane they were in constant danger of colliding with each other.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, said at the annual convention today that agriculture has been stabilized and that farm prices generally are satisfactory.

The uncertainty of the times has not caused the duck hunters to forego a final day of sport before both the war and the closed season make this recreation impossible, for several gunners called yesterday to report good bags of broadbill from Great South Bay and Long Island Sound.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9 -- American aircraft and presumably warships searched hundreds of miles of ocean off the Pacific Coast tonight for Japanese aircraft carriers, while high Army and Navy officers warned that "death and destruction" from bombs was a distinct possibility in this area.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We were all pretty well shocked by the events of Sunday. Even though we felt the inevitability of war, the thought of it actually having come upon us was sudden. I must confess that when I first mused over our predicament I was horrified.
Two air raid warnings -- the first of the war in this part of the country -- swept New York City and part of the Eastern seaboard yesterday afternoon.

In refusing citizenship to 150 persons of German, Austrian and Italian birth, Judge Marcus B. Campbell in the United States District Court in Brooklyn yesterday announced that the Attorney General's office in Washington had directed that applications for citizenship from nationals of the above countries for American citizenship be indefinitely adjourned.

New York, with its great polygot population, experienced the first air-raid warnings in its history yesterday, and its people, on the whole, took it without panic. Though they hadn't the slightest idea whether it was real or sham, they were more bewildered than alarmed.

Plans were filed yesterday in Brooklyn for an apartment house containing accommodations for seventy-two families to be erected at 161-77 Corbin Place at a cost of $230,000. The specifications were drawn for Nutine Homes, Inc., the builders, by Seelig Finkelstein, architects.
HONG KONG, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A British communique said today:

Wool goods selling agents continued to keep their lines off the market yesterday and it was indicated that prices would not be named, even unofficially, until after the turn of the year, or until the Office of Price Administration has announced its schedule of ceiling prices for wool.

ROME, Dec., 9 -- The atmosphere in Rome became much heavier today as regards the United States and, while it is Still considered highly doubtful that an Axis declaration of war is imminent, the chance of some decisive gesture in support of Japan became great.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary Morgenthau, who has hitherto opposed any "high pressuring" of the public to buy Defense Savings Bonds, today informed all State chairmen and State administrators of the defense savings program that the bond selling campaign must be stepped up immediately.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 10 (From Official Soviet Sources; Distributed by The Associated Press) -- Red armies have blasted the Germans out of Tikhvin, important rail center 110 miles east of Leningrad, in a ten-day battle that cost the Nazis 7000 killed, the Moscow radio announced today in a special communique.

A large exhibition of work by American Negro artists opened to the public yesterday at the Downtown Gallery, 45 East Fifty-first Street. A few examples produced in the last century are shown in the Folk Art Gallery on the ground floor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Swinging resolutely into action in a determined effort to conduct their affairs as usual, though expressing at the same time an eagerness to accede to any demands made upon them by the government, the club owners of professional baseball's two major leagues opened their annual December conclaves today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Full support of the nation's war effort was pledged at the opening session of the State Grange convention today and the pledge was wired immediately to President Roosevelt, a brother Granger.

A reception held yesterday in honor of Mrs. John G. Winant, wife of the Ambassador to Great Britain, and Miss Caroline Haslett, adviser to the British Ministry of Labor on the registration of women power serving the Empire, took on a signifcance it did not hold when originally planned.

Some light on childern's tastes in art has been thrown by the selections made by child juries in a competition for prize-winning silkscreen prints suitable for children held by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. The awards were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The time has come for American women, "who up to last Sunday were trying to find defense work that wouldn't interfere with their bridge or their matinees," to volunteer for nursing jobs just an dangerous as the first-line trenches, Dr. George Baehr, chairman of the Medical Advisory Board of the Office of Civilian Defense, said tonight.

Mme. Helle Bonnet, the Parisian milliner, has leased for a New York establishment an entire floor in the building at 38 East Fiftieth Street, according to Warren Marks Associates, who arranged the rental.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Vessels of the United States Pacific and Asiatic Fleets continued today to fight back at the Japanese forces that had attacked them without warning last Sunday and about which the White House had released no further news up to late hour tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Major packers and Eastern shipping interest bid up the prices of live hogs 35 to 50 cents a hundred pounds on the livestock market today. It was one of the largest advances scored on any single day this year and followed a gain of 15 to 25 cents yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 9 (AP)--The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

The Berkshire Music Center will open its third season at Lenox, Mass., on July 5, 1942, the trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra announced yesterday. Serge Koussevitzky will again be its director and Igor Stravinsky, Russian composer, is a new addition to the faculty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- President Roosevelt laid down two primary rules of censorship of war news today, reserving to himself and high-ranking officials the right of decision over material released. News to be released, he said, first must be true, and then it must pass a test whether it conforms with a rule that it must "not give aid and comfort to the enemy."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- With Germans and Italians now joining Japanese already caught in the FBI dragnet, President Roosevelt today proclaimed that "an invasion or predatory incursion is threatened upon the territory of the United States" by Germany and Italy and that an invasion had already been perpetrated by Japan.

In the last two days ten times as many nurses have enrolled for service each day in the First Reserves of the American Red Cross at the New York Chapter headquarters, 315 Lexington Avenue, as in any day since the last war, it was said yesterday.

AMSTERDAM (via Berlin), Dec. 9 -- A very keen demand developed for the shares of home industrials at continually rising prices on the Bourse today. The advances in some cases reached 15 points. A.K.U. 3 1/2 points up at 161 1/2; Philips 13 at 293 and Unilever 10 at 179.

As a preventative to possible excessive speculation and runaway prices, the New York Cocoa, Coffee and Sugar and Produce Exchanges were asked yesterday to suspend trading in cocoa, coffee and pepper futures by Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Price Administration.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 9 -- At the end of a Cabinet council today lasting two hours, under the chairmanship of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo, a decree was announced whereby, in accordance with a communique issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs yesterday, Argentina will not treat the United States as a belligerent.

Directors of the First National Bank of New York voted yesterday to reduce the regular quarterly dividend of $25 a share, which had been maintained for nearly ten years, to 520 a share. The dividend will be payable on Jan. 2 to shareholders of record of Dec. 15.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Consultations on strategy in the Far East to assure the closest possible cooperation by United States, British and Netherland forces are going on between the three countries, it was reported in London today.

Listening to Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson play two pianos, as they did last night at Carnegie Hall, is like conversing with truly civilized people. Their playing is intelligent, sensitive and as varied and stimulating as good talk. What is more, they have what Ernest Hemingway once gave as a definition of courage -- grace under pressure.
The war of the world raged from the icy steppes of Russia to the jungles of the Malayan peninsula yesterday as the democracies and their allies fought furiously against the Axis powers.

Scores of organizations representing many diverse racial strains and conflicting political and economic beliefs united yesterday in offering their full support and all their facilities to the government and President of the United States to aid in winning the war against Japan.
Women volunteers offering their services to National Defense in numbers surpassing Monday's totals rushed to focal points for registration again yesterday.

While gongs, buzzers, loudspeakers and flashboards went into action yesterday summoning doctors and nurses in the city's hospitals to their posts, nearly all their patients were calm and somewhat skeptical of reports that enemy planes were headed for New York.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 10 -- Reuters [British news agency] reported today that a Japanese communique issued in Tokyo claimed that the 35,000-ton British battleship Prince of Wales and the battle cruiser Repulse had been sunk.

Currency Expansion Aside from the usual expansion of currency that normally characterizes Christmas trade, there has been some evidence this week that, due to the war with Japan, many householders of small means have withdrawn currency from the banks to anticipate future requirements of food and clothing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Legislation to extend the period of service of selectees and other members of the armed forces to six months beyond the period of the war emergency, and to make these men subject to service outside the Western Hemisphere, was approved by the House and Senate Military Affairs Committees today.

TOKYO, Dec. 9 (From official broadcasts; distributed by The Associated Press) --The Japanese announced tonight that their forces had captured more than 200 merchant ships of "enemy nationalities," including the American liner President Harrison, along the China Coast and in the Whangpoo River.

Air-raid precautions following the first alarm at 1:30 yesterday afternoon were carried out so thoroughly along the city's waterfront that work was stopped in three shipbuilding and ship repair plants for nearly four hours.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9--Unofficial reports picturing as exceedingly grave the toll taken in ships, men and defense facilities by Japan's wide-area assaults in the Pacific Sunday threw both Senate and House into hot debate today. It was sharpened by criticism of the Navy for "being caught asleep" and demands for full, detailed public information on what happened.
Dry points and color prints by Mary Cassatt, from the S.P. Avery collection, will be placed on view at the New York Public Library, in the Print Gallery, from Dec. 15 to Feb. 28.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A British communique said today:

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Dec. 10 -- For the first time since June, when the conflict started, Russian forces on the entire German front appeared this morning to have seized the initiative and in all principal sectors to be inflicting terrific punishment on the Germans' defensive lines.

Three hundred years ago George Herbert, collecting the ancient wisdom of the English people, found among their proverbs this one still familiar: Half the world knows not how the other half lives. In the Hundred Neediest Cases we see as through a modern all-glass house an illustration of the old adage.
