WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Japanese firms and individuals in the American republics tonight were put by the State Department on a blacklist and so denied the benefits of American trade. Similar action, has previously been taken with reference to individuals and firms having German and Italian business connections.

Federal agents working with the police of New York City, Westchester and Long Island had brought to the Federal Building in Manhattan between Sunday and last night 367 aliens. Of this number 205 were Japanese, 108 German, 54 Italian.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- From all parts of the country pledges of support of the American Red Cross campaign for a $50,000,000 war relief fund for civilian aid and services to the armed forces were received at national headquarters here today.

In a few scattered Instances heavy buying of sugar and pineapple juice was reported here yesterday, but officials of some of the larger chain stores and independent dealers denied that any general wave of "war-panic" buying by consumers was under way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Mexican Government is sending troops to Lower California, where Japanese raiding attacks and landings might be attempted. The movement will begin tomorrow and the troops will pass through United States territory. Announcement of the movement was made today by the State Department, which welcomed it warmly as a striking instance of cooperation in hemispheric defense.
HONG KONG, Dec. 9 -- Japanese invaders on the mainland have been checked by all defense positions, the communique announced today.

With 900 persons, many of them famous former and present-day figures in football, jamming the dining room, the seventh annual dinner for the presentation of the John W. Heisman Memorial Award was held at the Downtown Athletic Club last night, with Bruce Smith, Minnesota's great left halfback, the center of attraction.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 8:

Acting Mayor Newbold Morris called the members of the city's Board of Disaster Control to City Hall yesterday for a four-hour session immediately after receipt of the first air-raid alarm to consider further steps for the safety of the city's residents.

The same thing has happened to the United States that happened to the countries invaded by Germany. The balance sheet of the first days of the war goes heavily against us. The initial losses to the Pacific Fleet and the outposts on which naval and air power is based run into a total that staggers Americans even more than the shock of the attack itself.

The reports of life insurance companies covering 1941, which will be issued early in 1942, are expected to set a new high from the standpoint both of being informative and developing reader interest, the Institute of Life Insurance said yesterday in releasing the results of a survey of reports to policyholders in connection with its annual meeting to be held today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Relations between the boxing governing bodies of Pennsylvania and New York were severed yesterday when Leon L. Rains, chairman of the Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission, formally served notice on the New York State Athletic Commission that his board would no longer recognize the working agreement which has existed between the two organizations.

Coach Steve Owen's crippled New York Giants began practice yesterday morning at the Polo Grounds for their National Football League championship play-off date with either the Chicago Bears or the Green Bay Packers on Dec. 21.
Herbie Katz, 176 3/4 pounds, Brooklyn, defeated Tony Musto, 205 1/4, Chicago, in a sensational eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night before a crowd of 4,500.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Major executives of all phases of the motion picture industry, meeting in general session for the first time in fourteen years, took a first step here today toward a unification of interests.

Jan Smeterlin, Polish pianist, who has appeared here frequently since his debut eleven years ago, last night gave a recital at Town Hall at which he played three sonatas, Beethoven's in E major, Op. 109; Haydn's in A flat, No. 41, and Chopin's in B flat minor.

Owen Davis, who last was represented on Broadway by "Mr. and Mrs. North," has completed a new comedy called "Husband Trouble." The author describes the work as "an obstreperous farce that defies the accepted classification." Its action is laid in New York of the present time and the story is about a young married couple.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Westchester County's expectations of building an airport with Federal funds were dashed today when August R. Butz, district airport engi- neer of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, notified County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach that the $1,850,000 Federal grant for a county airport had been withdrawn.

While out in the street the sharp tones of announcers, voices rang from taxicabs giving instructions to New Yorkers in case of a blitz; inside the Ritz-Carlton Oval Room the spirit of peace and Christmas cheer prevailed. The threadlike treble of children's voices -- four little girls in red and one in white flannel nightie -- caroled "Silent Night."

Mrs. Walter E. Travers gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Joan Dempsey, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Dempsey of Westbrook, Westbury, L.I. The debutante was graduated from the Fermata School.

MANILA, Dec. 9 (U.P.) -- A United States Navy communique today reported that Japanese planes in two flights attacked Guam yesterday and admitted that the United States minesweeper Penguin, 840 tons, was attacked and sunk outside Guam.
NEW YORK Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay has returned to her home at 15 East Ninety-second Street for the Winter.

While a witness related an Alphonse and Gaston story of exaggerated politeness between two men planning a murder, Carlo Barone, one of the alleged killers, jumped from his seat in the crowded Kings County courtroom yesterday, ripped open his shirt and began shouting curses at the jury adn Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic Seaboard at the close of last week were 19,421,000 barrels, a decline of 14,000 from the 19,435,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks were down 186,000 barrels to 21,906,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks dropped 388,000 to 12,151,000.

There were definite indications yesterday in the market for United States Government bonds that the Federal Reserve Bank had either inserted a firm bid of par for the two latest issues or had given assurances to dealers and other buyers that they could purchase the issues with safety at that price.

A booklet entitled "The Schools and Civilian Defense" was issued yesterday by the Board of Education's Committee on Civilian Defense in the Schools for the guidance of officials and for safeguarding children. Excerpts from the instructions follow:

As a step in meeting the demand for more small homes in the Fort Lee section of New Jersey, Persyl Homes, Inc., has bought a large group of lots in the section centering in Anderson Avenue and McKay Drive, at Fort Lee, and plans to start construction of 100 dwellings there within ten days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The War Department made public today an incomplete list of casualties in Sunday's surprise bombardment of Oahu, Hawaii.

Worth While Defending A mural picture 118 feet long and 100 feet high, consisting of twenty-two photographs pieced together, will be dedicated next Sunday in Grand Central Terminal. It is part of the sales campaign for United States defense bonds and is designed to show what America has to defend and how we will defend it.

Let us hope that the decision of the President's special arbitration board in favor of the closed shop in the captive mine case marks the end of a phase of the Administration's labor policy. That decision can only be interpreted as a capitulation by the United States Government to John L. Lewis.

Just at a time when marketing and market research men thought they had begun to iron out problems created by the European war, the outbreak of war in the Pacific has created a new series of problems, they reported yesterday. Chief barrier to accurate measurement of markets will be the increased activity in strictly defense towns and the siphoning off of several million additional men to the military services.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The following was issued today by British Middle East Headquarters:

John Dickson Carr, the mystery novel writer, has cabled his publisher, Harper, that he is returning from England. The author has been doing a series of radio plays in England. He says that he and Mrs. Carr have lost a series of houses, including a new one they had built.

Impatiently awaiting State Department clearance on a priority rating for transportation back to Hilo, Hawaii, Miss Charlotte Whittaker, executive secretary of the Girl Scout Council in the Hawaiian Islands, told yesterday of preparations made by 4,000 Girl Scouts in the four largest islands for just such an emergency as arose Sunday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The National Hockey League scoring race has tightened into a five-way tie for the top spot, with another five marksmen only a point behind the leaders, official statistics revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- All civilian industries faced the prospect of sharp curtailment before the end of this month, if not sooner, as Federal officials here prepared tonight to put into effect the wartime production program on which they have been at work since early yesterday.

VICHY, France, Dec. 9 -- An announcement of the Vice Presidency ot the Council issued here tonight says that in the past three days 1,850 Communists have been rounded up in the large centers of the unoccupied zone, in addition, to 11,000 others arrested in the last six weeks.

Buyer Registrations Off The number of out-of-town buyers reported in the market last week totaled 499 against 562 in the preceding week and 516 in the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

THE country seat of Olmsted County, Minn., is known the world over. It has only 25,000 inhabitants or so and lies in a river valley surrounded by typical Minnesota farms and fields, but tens of thousands of strangers filled with hope, anguish or, as it may be, mere idle curiosity visit it every year.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Ah, that wave of deep nostalgia which swept over me upon reading toward the end of your editorial on cider! "The time will come, if you but wait and watch, when at the first sip you will know that here is moonlight and fire-glow, frosty sky and shimmering sun."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The New England Public Service Company, which was ordered by the Securities and Exchange Commission last May to change capitalization to one class of common stock or liquidate, has filed with the commission a reorganization plan which provides for divorcement of utility and industrial subsidiaries by distribution of the stock of the utility subsidiaries to the holders of the company's prior lien and plain preferred stocks.

Professor Horace W. Stunkard, head of the Department of Biology, New York University, was elected last night president of the New York Academy of Sciences at the annual dinner meeting of the academy and its affiliated societies at the Hotel Astor.

BERLIN, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- German troops have hurled back "local attacks" up and down the Russian front, inflicting "heavy casualties," while the Luftwaffe continued to cause heavy damage from the air, the High Command said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Navy stated today that Rear Admiral Isaac Campbell Kidd was killed in action during the attack on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, Sunday.
ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- The war blotted out lights in up-State New York for the first time tonight as communities alert to air-raid dangers began "practice" blackouts.

HONG KONG, Dec. 10--Two Japanese attacks on this British Crown colony from the direction of Shanghai have been beaten off and the situation has been stabilized, a British communique announced late today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- The film industry, facing "a crisis" due to influences within and without the enterprise, started today a unity program with the formation of the Motion Picture Industry Conference Committee, which will seek to end conflict between producing and exhibiting units.

The warring world and its tribulations were partly forgotten for the moment when a long procession of resort styles was paraded before the luncheon guests in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday noon.

Cossack whoopings resounded through Town Hall last night and the near-capacity audience was entertained by dancing as well as singing, for the General Platoff Don Cossack Chorus appeared there in the third event in the twelfth Town Hall Endowment series.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- One of the chief questions being considered by the high command in Washington, now that a long war with Japan is in prospect, is the extent of Japanese oil reserves. In a modern war these are more limiting than the supplies of any other strategic material.
NEW HAVEN Conn., Dec. 10 -- Yale undergraduates were urged by President Seymour today to render the greatest possible service to the university by carrying on their studies to their normal course.

A bright-colored wool scarf was shoved aside yesterday afternoon by a pair of sensitive hands. Declaring it "too thin" for its intended purpose, Miss Helen Keller chose instead three warmer articles of clothing to be sent to Britain from the twentieth annual Christmas sale of articles made by the blind.

Suspension of strikes for the duration of the war and fullest cooperation in the nation's war effort were voted yesterday by the New York State Federation of Labor meeting jointly with the New York Central Trades and Labor Council at an extraordinary meeting called to consider the emergency at Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street.

On the assumption that the expansion of racing is good for civilian morale, as well as the production of taxes for the State and nation, New York's racing leaders are planning a wide increase in hurdle and steeplechase racing in 1942.

HONOLULU, Dec. 10 -- Martial law has been proclaimed for the Territory of Hawaii with the full approval of President Roosevelt. It is reported to be functioning smoothly and the method of operation and results to date have been reported directly to the President.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 10 -- German, Italian and Japanese banks in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo drew crowds wishing to withdraw their deposits today. The crowds were almost riotous in Sao Paulo, while in Rio de Janeiro, experiencing one of its hottest days, the long wait soured tempers already embittered by feelings against the Japanese.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 10 -- Captain Ted Harrison, star pitcher last Spring and football wingback in the Fall, led the Yale hockey team to an 8-to-0 victory over Boston University at the Arena tonight.

After New York's third air-raid alarm in two days, at the height of the rush hour yesterday morning, military and civilian authorities announced that plans were being made to correct defects that have shown up in the system and to prevent unnecessary warnings hereafter.

New York University's student editors, who have been agitating for open subsidization of football at the university, decided to suspend the campaign "for the duration" yesterday, but the Letter Club, composed of former Violet athletes, indicated through John O'Neill, its captain, that "war or no war, we still want some changes made before N.Y.U. opens another football season."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A meeting of Foreign Ministers of the American republics to be held in Rio de Janeiro the first week in January to consult on measures for hemispheric defense, was proposed to the governing board of the Pan American Union today by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt has approved a plan for the emergency evacuation of 60,000 civilians from Honolulu City, Samuel W. King, Hawaii's delegate in Congress, disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Roosevelt sent a personal message to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek today welcoming association of the United States with China in the war with Japan and pledging victory, even at the cost of a long war.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 10--Although official sources still avoid the word "retreat," it is established that the Germans in Libya are withdrawing westward at an accelerated pace, having left the Tobruk garrison free and even abandoned some positions on the partly fortified Axis line stretching southward from Tobruk's western defense perimeter through El Adem to the Bir el-Gobi area.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Dec. 10 -- Mrs. Hallie Flanagan Davls, Professor of Drama at Vassar College and the first woman to receive a Guggenheim Award, has been appointed dean of Smith College and Professor of Drama. In this appointment the board of trustees recognizes both her administrative ability and her work as director of the Experimental Theatre and the Federal Theatre.

In the face of the attack that has been made upon our country, the greatest desire that comes to all of us is to be able to do something to help. There is one thing that each of us can do at once, and keep on doing, to help strengthen the defenses of the United States.

In these days charity is warm, as it ought to be. It is not bestowed coolly or grudgingly or ignobly or at random. Imposters are excluded. The agents of the organized societies are friends and advisers, fully acquainted with the circumstances and needs of each beneficiary.

J.A. Tapee, assistant treasurer of Austin, Nichols Co., testified yesterday his company never collaborated with retailers on price policies, nor was the concern approached by retailers on discount questions, at the hearing being conducted by the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway on its charges of price-fixing and boycott against the National Retail Liquor Package Stores Association and affiliated associations and individuals.
The August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy, symbolic of the mythical Eastern championship, was awarded to the Fordham football team last night at a dinner at Toot Shor's.
The Federal order to close all Japanese stores and offices operating in New York, issued almost at the moment the war broke out, has left landlords and their agents with quite a few rental problems.

The fight between the open and closed shop should be postponed temporarily because it is necessary for labor and employers to present a united front "to lick the enemy," Westbrook Pegler, columnist and critic of the leaders of organized labor, declared yesterday.

Flashlight Sales Heavy Manufacturers of flashlights reported yesterday that their season's sales and the volume booked by their distributors were running well ahead of last year. Holiday promotions and the general improvement in business were cited as reasons, however, and it was said that there had been no appreciable reflection at wholesale of any demand which may have sprung up in anticipation of blackouts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Continued expansion of the flow of income payments to individuals was reported in October, the Department of Commerce reported today, with October payments amounting to $8,262,000,000, representing an annual rate of $95,000,000,000, the highest on record.

Exporters, although expecting that increasing curbs on shipments abroad will lead to additional red tape, expressed confidence yesterday that their business would continue despite difficulties. In the first meeting of an export group since the Japanese attack on Hawaii, members of the Overseas Automobile Club at a luncheon at the Hotel Lincoln agreed that while the export business was almost halted for the moment, it would be resumed shortly.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of the operetta. "Sunny River" tomorrow night at the St. James Theatre for the benefit of the Episcopal Actors Guild. Mrs. Charles R. Richter heads the patroness committee for the event.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- Puzzling factors in the city's second successive night of air-raid warnings were studied today. Residents in many parts of the bay district reported the sighting of signal flares.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 10 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Alan Gordon Cunningham's second major offensive in Libya is gathering speed and, according to reports to foreign military sources here, there are evidences of a general westward withdrawal of the defeated armored forces of German General Erwin Rommel.

Orders by the Police Department to be followed by all residents in a total blackout were issued to thousands of air-raid, wardens last night at special meetings. The principal orders and instructions follow:

LONDON, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Russian troops have recaptured Yelets, 225 miles south of Moscow in the Orel sector, after four days of fierce fighting in which two German divisions were "annihilated" and 12,000 Nazi dead and wounded left on the battlefield, a special Russian communique said today.
ROME, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The names of three more officers and 85 soldiers were added today to the Army's first casualty list of the war. The dead were at Pearl Harbor where, the White House said yesterday, casualties might run to 3,000 dead and wounded, almost half of them dead.

Mrs. Hugh Peters gave a luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Miss Isobel K. Cox, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Cox. Miss Cox was introduced to society here at the Junior Assembly last Friday night and the Bachelors Cotillon held recently in Baltimore.
WITH THE BRITISH ARMY, in Libya, Dec. 10 (AP) -- British troops were reported officially today to have lifted the siege of Tobruk, and another heavy tank battle was expected soon west of El Adem.

As a result of confusion Tuesday in the new Criminal Courts Building, when people rushed into the street contrary to instructions during the air-raid warnings, Superintendent William Jorgensen yesterday posted new orders. He said an air-raid alarm would be indicated by the Morse code V symbol -- three dots and a dash -- on a signal system inside the building, and the all-clear by the symbol 3, three dots, sounded three times.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 - -The threatened strike of 42,000 Railway Express employes was averted by an agreement early this morning, and Wayne L. Morse, chairman of the President's fact-finding board, moved to expedite final details of the settlement before moving into the differences between the railroads and the fourteen non-operating unions over putting paid vacations into effect.

Outbreak of war with Japan and the government's upward revision of its estimated national defense requirements have resulted in a change in the original draft of a letter to stockholders of the United Aircraft Corporation calling a special meeting at East Hartford, Conn., on Dec. 30, to approve the sale of $26,000,000 in new preferred stock.

For the first time in the memory of veteran court attaches, a defendant on trial in Kings County Court was placed in a straitjacket and gagged with a towel yesterday to prevent him from, making outbursts while feigning insanity before Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz and a jury.

OF the books I read during 1941, the following seem to me to stand out above the rest. The list is not supposed to be a list of the "best" books of the year, for there are good ones and important ones that I haven't read, but it does include a number of the best. With Christmas just two weeks off, it may have its uses as a reminder list.

The sinking of two of Great Britain's mightiest capital ships -- the powerful new 35,000-ton battleship Prince of Wales and the 32,200-ton battle cruiser Repulse -- follows close upon the heavy damage done at Pearl Harbor, the probable loss of the vital aerial stepping-stones at Guam, Wake and Midway Islands and the landing of Japanese troops at several points in the Philippines.

Activity in the field of new municipal bond financing became further restricted yesterday as banks and dealers faced the task of reappraising the value of new loans in line with the decline in prices of outstanding high grade bonds. The few sales that were completed, or announced, yesterday reflected substantially higher borrowing costs for the municipalities.

The British suffered a staggering blow yesterday in the loss of two capital ships off Malaya. Added to the serious American losses at Hawaii on Sunday, the twin tragedies probably represent the heaviest blows the democracies have suffered since German troops marched into Poland in September, 1939.

Columbia will award 121 varsity insignia to athletes who represented the Light Blue in eleven sports during the past year at the annual Varsity C dinner tonight at the Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third Street. Football, cross-country, basketball, swimming, wrestling, fencing, indoor track, rowing, baseball, outdoor track and tennis are the sports which will be represented.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Larry MacPhail and his Dodgers, who have been keeping themselves more or less in the background ever since the baseball conclaves got under way in Jacksonville, Fla., a week ago, moved back into the spotlight today with three player transactions.

The C.W. Lyon Gallery, 15 East Fifty-sixth Street, is holding this month an exhibition of early American prints, including views of old New York and other important cities as they appeared more than 100 years ago. Most of the prints on display are in color.

SINGAPORE. Dec. 10 -- British forces in North Malaya have reorganized south of Kota Bharu, an important air base on the east coast 350 miles north of Singapore, the air base being the only point on the frontier with Thailand that the Japanese have breached, a communique said tonight.
Radio stations in the metropolitan area continued yesterday to take further precautions against the possibility of sabotage to broadcasting facilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Hearings on the O'Mahoney-Fulmer Sugar Bill, which would cut the sugar import quotas of Cuba, Puerto Rico, Hawaii and the Philippines over the next three years were completed today by the Senate Finance Committee.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The announcement of the loss of the battleship Prince of Wales and the battle cruiser Repulse in Far Eastern waters depressed the stock markets today but there was no serious slump, although, prices were marked down in all directions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Steers and yearlings advanced today 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight to the highest prices for the current crop. Hogs declined 15 to 25 cents, and lambs held steady. The top in the cattle section was $14.25 for choice to prime long yearlings. The advance was attributed primarily to a better dressedbeef market and indications that producers were withholding cattle from the market.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Freed of a temporary ceiling on prices of wheat which had been imposed on, Tuesday, trading in that grain fell off materially today and there was a lack of aggressive buying of futures by mills which had been such a factor in causing the market to show great strength earlier in the week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Roosevelt accepted today "with sincere regret" the resignation of Miss Harriet Elliott, who explained that she desired to devote full-time attention to her duties at Woman's College of the University of North Carolina.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 10 -- The war in the Pacific is bound to have a serious bearing on the British position in the Middle East, for with the landing of Japanese troops on the Malay Peninsula and the occupation of Thailand a new front has been created for Britain, this time to the gates of India.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The communique of the Finnish Army follows:
CAIRO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

While the extent to which the Federal Reserve Bank was called upon to support the market for some of the United States Government bonds yesterday by actual purchases remains unknown, it was believed, in the more important trading circles that the principal support of the market from that source continued to be the assurance that a bid of par would be available on any of the loans when it became necessary.

Coordination of the procedure for giving air raid protection to children in public, parochial and private schools was announced yesterday by James Marshall, president of the Board of Education. In the future the schools will have a unified air raid protection service.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 10 -- Reports circulating in high foreign diplomatic circles in Ankara late this evening said that a German declaration of war against the United States was imminent. Opinion among usually well-informed diplomatic quarters was that Italy would make a simultaneous declaration.

HONG KONG, Dec. 10 (U.P.)--Imperial land forces defending Hong Kong have repulsed a Japanese land attack on this British Crown colony, but fighting is continuing, a communique issued at 11 A.M. said today [the early communique].

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--A reassessment in responsible quarters of the position of Russia as a potential ally of the United States in the Pacific war has resulted, on the basis of reports by persons recently returned from Russia, in a realization that not too much should be expected.

Students at Long Island University are so optimistic about their team's victory chances in its initial major test Saturday nigh in Madison Square Garden that their pre-game predictions radically distort the expectations of Head Coach Clair Bee and his valuable assistant, S.J. (Pic) Picarello.
Disciplinary action was taken against four New York City teachers yesterday by the Board of Education at its regular meeting at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn. Three of them were dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- In his capacity as Commander in Chief, President Roosevelt today authorized military control or closure of as many private radio facilities as the government deemed necessary. Action would be taken immmediately, the Defense Communications Board stated.

Booming along the National Hockey League trail under the impetus of four straight conquests, the Rangers will seek their fifth in a row when they clash with the Americans, victims of six straight in reverse, tonight in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- It was reported in diplomatic quarters but not officially confirmed tonight that the new German battleship Tirpitz, sister ship of the Bismarck, was operating with the Japanese Navy in the Far East and took part in the sinking of the British capital ships Prince of Wales and Repulse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Roosevelt decided today to call eight spokesmen for organized labor and eight industrialists to meet here next week with four public representatives in an effort to reach a binding, but voluntary, agreement on a basic war-labor policy guaranteeing not only uninterrupted production but greater productive speed for the duration of the war.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Two destroyers, the Earle and the Doran, went down the ways at the Boston Navy Yard today and they were hardly afloat before the keels for two others, the Bennett and the Fullam, succeeded them, on the ways.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Further evidence of the sincerity of this government's efforts to maintain peace with Japan was disclosed today in the revelation that, months ago, the White House and the Departments of State and Justice employed their combined influence to ward off a public investigation that they feared would embarrass and perhaps disrupt the sensitive relationship between the nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Federal Government has arrested 2,303 "enemy aliens," Attorney General Biddle said today. The majority of them will be sent soon to detention camps and held there under Army supervision for the duration of the war.
Investment buying of apartment properties formed the bulk of realty activity in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Roosevelt held a staff conference with military leaders, authorized military control or closure of as many private radio facilities as the government deems necessary, instructed the War and Navy Departments to release news on fighting in the Pacific, sent a message to General Chiang Kai-shek welcoming American-Chinese association against Japan and assured General John J. Pershing, who offered them, that his services will be of great value.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 10 -- Premier John Curtin, in announcing today the loss of the battleship Prince of Wales and the battle cruiser Repulse, said it was a bad blow, illustrating the gravity of Australia's position. He indicated that the government's emergency measures would be consequently accelerated and expanded.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Isaac Brown, New York insurance broker, took the witness stand today at his trial on attempted first degree murder charges in Westchester County Court and for three hours denied the accusations of Miss Mathilde Le Boyer, 17 years old, of New York, that on last Dec. 19 he strangled and stabbed her to conceal their alleged friendship.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am a visitor from the Far West and, as always, find New York stimulating and inspiring. But a really wonderful thing happened to me a few days ago.

United States Attorney Harold M. Kennedy, summing up for the government yesterday in the Brooklyn espionage trial, asserted that the evidence produced during the fourteen weeks of the trial had clearly demonstrated that the alleged conspiracy to transmit information about the United States defense effort had "emanated from the German Reich."

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Governor Lehman advised the people of the State tonight to remain calm in the present crisis, to put down wild rumors and assured them that in case of disorder the State Guard and State Police would be available to supplement law enforcement officials.

Among the persons now in the United States who have already experienced a blackout are the thirty-four passengers from Bermuda who arrived at La Guardia Field early yesterday morning aboard Pan American Airways' Yankee Clipper and reported that they had had to grope their way in darkness through Hamilton, Bermuda, to the island's seaplane base.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 10 -- The Foreign Ministry stated today that negotiations had been begun with Chile with a view to reaching an agreement that would permit Chile to erect defensive works on the Strait of Magellan. In contrast with news from Chile, however, it was stated that no agreement had yet been reached.

Gerard S. Nollen, president of the Bankers Life Company of Des Moines, was elected yesterday chairman of the board of the Institute of Life Insurance at its third annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. Nollen succeeds M. Albert Linton, president of the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company.

The playing heard from Ray Lev at her piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall was energetic and full of life. Miss Lev had a wide variety of dynamic effects at her command, and her tone, which was of singing quality and under admirable control in softer work, never lost its mellowness when employed at the full.

A resolution asking that the city government do everything in its power to dispel the false rumors that New York is unsafe during the war which have caused guests to check out of hotels and organizations to cancel dinner reservations was adopted last night at the annual meeting of the Hotel Association of New York City, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Donald M. Nelson, director of priorities, issued today a prohibition on the sale of new automobile tires, except for top defense orders, beginning tomorrow and continuing through Dec. 22.

Although the final returns on the Maine deer season are not in as yet, 19,663 deer have been reported taken by hunters, and, when the tally is completed, it is expected to fall only slightly behind last year's kill.

Major advertising media felt the full impact of the war this week, as the startling news from Hawaii boosted newspaper circulation as much as 50 per cent in some instances and as radio listening increased substantially. Afternoon papers brought out numerous "extras," while the networks cut frequently into commercial programs to announce new developments.

Alfred Nobel, the Swedish industrialist whose philanthropy is usually commemorated on Dec. 10 in Stockholm or Oslo with the announcement of new Nobel Prize winners, was honored instead at a dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt, last night with nine previous Nobel Prize winners as guests of honor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The War Department issued the following today:
BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Dec. 11 -- It was officially announced early this morning that Adolf Hitler would address the Reichstag at 3 o'clock this afternoon [8 A.M. New York time].
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rhinelander are at the Carlyle.

The New York Athletic Club Class A squash tennis team, last season's Metropolitan League champion, last night moved into sole possession of first place in the league by defeating the visiting Bayside Tennis Club, 3-2. It was the Winged Foot players' fourth victory without a defeat.

TOKYO, Dec. 10 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- The Japanese reported today the sinking -- certain or probable -- of two British capital ships and two battleships, two aircraft carriers and a submarine of the United States Navy, together with a number of smaller vessels.

Naval censorship of cable, wireless and telephone messages leaving the North American continent is proving very trying to foreign correspondents here, especially the British, it was disclosed yesterday as a group of English journalists appealed directly to Secretary of the Navy Knox for relief.

A survey of leading New York City hotels showed yesterday that their managements were making or had completed elaborate plans to meet the dangers of real air raids and to participate in practice blackouts and alerts. All of the spokesmen said that they would comply with all official regulations.

Formerly set back for revisions because its theme concerned naval officers and their wives stationed at the Pearl Harbor base, "The Admiral Had A Wife" has now been "withdrawn permanently," it was announced yesterday by Jose Ferrer and Ruth Wilk, co-sponsors of the Lowell Barrington play.
Rules to be followed in case of an air raid were made public yesterday by the Office of Civilian Defense and by Acting Mayor Newbold Morris in a radio broadcast.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -- An air raid alarm from the Fourth Interceptor Command brought a three-hour blackout to Southern California and part of Nevada tonight as "unidentified" planes were reported over and near Los Angeles for more than an hour.

Public service agencies in both the administrative and operative fields began yesterday a check-up on their arrangements to provide an uninterrupted flow of facilities, so far as possible, during air raids or blackouts. Plans for transportation, water supply, food distribution, electric power and gas in such emergency periods have been worked out in cooperation with Mayor La Guardia's emergency board and representatives of the armed forces.

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 11 -- One Filipino Army division has repulsed light attacks by Japanese troops at a point 150 miles north of Manila and the Philippines situation "is completely in hand," the United States Army announced today in a communique that also revealed that a United States bomber had made three direct hits on an enemy battleship, setting it ablaze.

SINGAPORE, Thursday, Dec. 11 (AP) -- British destroyers and patrol planes swept over the South China Sea today in a search for survivors of the mighty battleship Prince of Wales and battle cruiser Repulse, while British troops consolidated their positions along strong new lines in Northern Malaya, where the Japanese had driven a wedge across the frontier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The bill to amend the Selective Service Act to permit the use of selective service troops outside this hemisphere was blocked in the Senat today by Senator Johnson of California, who said he wanted to ponder the legislation for a day or so, since he believed that it would call for another A.E.F.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The activities of the American Red Cross in the last twelve months of intensified preparation for national defense and its plans for the future on behalf of a nation now at war were approved at the annual meeting of the board of incorporators today.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Another German, spy -- Karel Richard Richter, a Sudeten-born German -- has paid the penalty of his daring by execution in a British jail today. Richter was brought to Britain by a plane last May 13 and dropped by parachute near a village in Hertfordshire.

Wall Street's precautions against the physical effects of air raids have been in progress for some time, air raid wardens and building managers revealed yesterday. The skyscraper construction throughout the financial district has made it one of the safest places in the country, but the density of its daytime population has given air raid wardens a panic problem not equaled elsewhere.

The Estate of Heinrich Freese, Inc., through August and Minnie A. Freese, trustees, has sold to Harry Stoller the two-family dwelling at 49 Randolph Avenue, Jersey City, in a transaction arranged by the George J. Wolf Realty Company, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Organization of the Civilian Air Patrol will proceed at meetings here tomorrow and Friday with Reed Landis, aviation aide to Mayor La Guardia as director of the Office of Civilian Defense, and other defense and aviation officials of the government, it was said today.

American Brake Shoe and Foundry Directors of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company authorized yesterday payment of an extra dividend of 40 cents a share and another dividend of 40 cents on the common stock. Three months ago a dividend of 40 cents plus an extra of 10 cents was declared.
Figures of the stage, movies, the law, business and literature appeared in the lists of residential rentals submitted yesterday by broers and agents.

Dollars are a poor, inadequate measure of the effort that this war will take, but the Victory Program that is being worked out by the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board is nevertheless a striking forecast of what lies ahead. Our defense program had been stepped up from $28,000,000,000 in January, when President Roosevelt delivered his budget message, to $68,000,000,000 by the time the war struck.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 10 -- Repercussions of the Far Eastern war continued today in the Turkish capital. While the Turkish newspapers devoted almost their entire editions to that conflict, diplomatic activity was intensified, with diplomats traveling to and from friendly legations and embassies and to the Turkish Foreign Office.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Two Senate committees put wartime limits today on investigations of military and naval activities.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 10 -- If the United States formally goes to war with Germany and Italy, Mexico is expected to follow suit, but until then or until a direct attack is made on Mexico, this government is likely to maintain diplomatic relations with the European Axis powers and to refrain from declaring war on Japan, it was stated in well-informed quarters here today.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 10 -- The Federal Government needs at least ninety more days for its investigation to determine if any connection exists between the General Aniline and Film Corporation of New York, the largest manufacturer of dyes for Army uniforms, and I.G. Farbenindustrie, A.G., commonly known as the German dye trust.
Menace to Whom? The final installment of the Coudert report finds that student organizations and publications at City College and Brooklyn College are almost completely under Communist control.

A six-month campaign to bring correct diet to all New Yorkers, as an essential phase of civilian defense, was begun yesterday by the city Health Department with the cooperation of other city bureaus, the Federal Government, the organized medical, dental and nursing professions, the food industry, and private welfare agencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A wartime production program, demanding the twenty-four hour day, seven-day week in basic arms industries, the expenditure of about $1,000,000,000 weekly, and yet further expansion of the nation's industrial plant has been devised by governmental agencies and already is partially in effect, William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, announced today.

The Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque, awarded annually to boxing's outstanding figure, yesterday was voted to Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, at a luncheon of the Boxing Writers Association of New York at Toots Shor's Restaurant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Japanese threats against Pacific trade routes today prompted Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce and Federal Loan Administrator, to warn Congress that new rubber sources must be found.

Electric power output topped all previous records last week, rising more than seasonally, and the adjusted index rose to 121.2 from 118.8 for the week ended Nov. 29. The index, however, is still below the Autumn peaks, since the subsequent gains in actual output have fallen short of the usual seasonal rise for the period.

A reception in honor of the seven young women of Latin America, called "Coffee Queens," now on a good-will tour here, was held at Inter-America House, 11 West Fifty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- "The peak of usefulness and service is before our organization," Fred J. Freestone of Interlaken, former State master and chairman of the executive committee of the National Grange, told a sixth-degree session of the State Grange here tonight.

GLOUCESTER, N.J., Dec. 10 -- The Princess Stefanie Hohenohe-Waldenburg-Schillingsfurst has been arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation as a dangerous alien and interned here at the detention home of the United States immigration station, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A new tax bill became more likely today. Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Senator George, chairman of the Finance Committee, will confer with Secretary Morgenthau Friday at the Treasury.

War developments dominated the cotton market yesterday and prices on the New York Cotton Exchange vacillated with the favorable and unfavorable reports. The close on the active futures showed net losses of 11 to 30 points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The government prohibited today the production of coin-operated gambling machines after Feb. 1 and simultaneously told manufacturers of juke boxes and some other coin-operated devices to curtail their output 75 per cent by the same date.

Three challenges have been made for the Eastern Championship Pennant put up by the Rumson Club of the Shrewsbury River, it was reported last night at a dinner of members of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association, given last night by George E. Ruppert in the Ruppert Brewery, 1639 Third Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- An assertion that the national economy would inevitably go into "an inflationary price spiral" unless power were given the Administration to prevent farm prices from going above parity, was made by Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.

Under the auspices of Historic St. Paul's Church, Eastchester, Mount Vernon, N.Y., a group of prominent persons will give a dinner next Sunday night in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to commemorate the 150th anniversary of the Bill of Rights.

Afternoon practice, a rarity for the Giants, kept the Eastern Division champions occupied for two and a half hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Usually Steve Owen drills the New Yorkers in the morning, but the coach thought it might be warmer after lunch.

Governor Lehman is to be commended for ordering practice blackouts in all the cities in New York State. It is to be hoped that his example will be followed at once throughout the industrial East. Blacking out any city in this incandescent age is not an easy task, nor one that can be accomplished in one or two attempts.

Secretary Hull proposed yesterday a meeting of the Foreign Ministers of all the American republics to consider the problem of hemisphere defense. The efforts of Japan and her Axis partners to belittle the actions that have already been taken by Latin-American states in support of the United States are not convincing.

Philippine Gold It would appear that virtually all the gold due here from the Philippines reached the United States before the storm broke over the Pacific. The Department of Commerce reported yesterday that a shipment of $1,868,747 arrived just before the war started.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Life insurance companies in this "insurance capital" of the world have started to invoke "war-risk clauses" in their policies, a procedure similar to that established for World War 1.

MANILA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Invading Japanese troops and parachutists were reported tonight to have won footholds of uncertain tenacity along 160 miles of the northern and northwestern Luzon coast, despite a smashing assault by United States Army and Navy fliers on one transport convoy of six ships.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Great Britain was plunged into sadness today by the staggering blow suffered by the Navy in the loss of two of its most powerful vessels, the 35,000-ton battleship Prince of Wales, flagship of the newly constituted British Far Eastern Fleet, and the 32,000-ton battle cruiser Repulse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Chairmen Joseph W. Martin Jr. of the Republican National Committee and Edward J. Plynn of the Democratic National Committee, in an exchange of telegrams, have agreed in the interests of the national war effort to work in close collaboration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- The only deep sea cable connecting the United States with its Pacific outposts and with British Hong Kong has been cut by the Japanese, it was disclosed today.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 10 -- In reprisal for the detention of German and Italian correspondents in the United States, Berlin and Rome acted today against United States reporters in those capitals.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Clothing sales and collections were better in November than a year ago by a substantial margin, the monthly report of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers revealed today. The report also indicated that, spurred possibly by reports of materials shortages, holiday buying started earlier in the Middle West this year.

Comforting news for the metropolitan ski army was made known last night by the New Haven Railroad, which announced a comprehensive snow train schedule for this Winter. This news checked rumors that the popular low-rate excursions to New England centers would not be operated because of the Defense program.

The United States alone can produce three tons of steel for every two that can be made by Germany, Italy, Japan and all countries occupied or dominated by them combined, according to a special survey by the American Iron and Steel Institute, which finds that the combined capacity of the United States, the British Empire and Russia is considerably more than twice the Axis total.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Out of a star-dotted field of 213 starting play tomorrow in the $10,000 Miami open, the 1940 winner, Byron Nelson, put the finger today on golf's H boys, Hogan and Heafner.
A war-time window decoration appeared in the city yesterday when the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, taped its large glass areas as an air-raid precaution.

A little opera called "The Chaplet," with music by Dr. William Boyce and book by Moses Mendez, which had its premiere in Drury Lane in 1749, was put on at the Museum of Modern Art last night as the sixth program of the series of "Coffee Concerts."

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Dec. 11 -- During the second day of their general counter-offensive along the entire front, Russian troops, according to a special communique issued last night, advanced in the south central sector for another important gain, capturing the town of Yelets on the Orel-Kursk front.

Three new films will make their first local appearances today in midtown theatres. Columbia's romantic drama, "The Men in Her Life," starring Loretta Young, will be the newcomer at the Radio City Music Hall. Produced and directed by Gregory Ratoff, the film's supporting cast includes Conrad Veidt, Dean Jagger, Otto Kruger, John Shepperd and Eugenic Leontovitch.
When Japan made a direct attack on American and British possessions, two great wars coalesced. There is now a single world war. It is global war in a far more complete sense than the first World War.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The shock of war and the surprise over the first air-raid warnings wore off yesterday to a considerable degree in financial circles, and although the stock market started the day with news of the blow to the British Navy, prices improved late in the session to provide a steady closing.

The shock of war and the surprise over the first air-raid warnings wore off yesterday to a considerable degree in financial circles, and although the stock market started the day with news of the blow to the British Navy, prices improved late in the session to provide a steady closing.

With the release of the final statistics for the five offensive departments yesterday, Don Hutson of Green Bay officially became the National Football League's champion pass receiver and scorer, the latter honor also having been his in 1940.

Numerous business organizations here began yesterday to prepare on the one hand to set up machinery for blacking out their own premises and on the other hand to supply materials for blackouts both here and throughout the country.
A large Bensonhurst apartment property changed hands in one of the leading Brooklyn realty transactions reported yesterday.

Piled up on a desk in the General Postoffice yesterday morning were 700 documents of faith-faith in a round, fat, white-whiskered gentleman who in the minds of most little boys and girls lives at the North Pole and is very much interested in behavior at this time of the year.

Because of the war with Japan, the short-lived priorities system will have to be changed drastically and it is probable that no new construction of any type except that vital to defense will be permitted, Sullivan Jones, head of the housing division, OPM, declared yesterday.

On Tuesday, the first day of actual wartime test for the city's air-raid wardens, 32,227 of them turned out for duty, it was learned last night at the office of Assistant Chief Inspector John J. O'Connell of the Police Department.

In order to alleviate the effect of materials shortages on production and employment in the city the Commerce and Industry Association of New York yesterday proposed a ten-point program designed also to provide for the transition from civilian to defense production in this area with as little shock as possible.
MANILA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- One day of war at Manila has made tough, determined soldiers out of a good many American youngsters who only yesterday were just kids in soldiers' uniforms.

Under the personal auspices of Mme. Getulio Vargas, wife of the President of Brazil, a gala cafe dansant. will be given this afternoon in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis as a Benefit for Mme. Vargas's favorite home philanthropy, the Cidade das Meninas ("City of Girls") situated in Petropolis, Summer capital of Brazil, about fifty-five miles from Rio de Janeiro.

Through the arrest of two men, one an ex-convict on parole, the police said yesterday they had solved the killing of Patrolman Thomas J. Casey early Saturday morning at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-second Street. It was understood, although without official confirmation, that they were still seeking a third man as a participant in the crime.

Plans for placing the Times Square area, stretching from Forty-second Street to Fiftieth Street, from Fifth Avenue west to Twelfth Avenue, on a complete war-footing that would meet any emergency in a possible air-raid were disclosed last night at a meeting of 750 air raid wardens at the Hotel Astor.

Unless the food industry is able to keep prices within bounds during the present emergency, it may expect immediate governmental price control, Gerrit Vander Hooning, OPM advisory consultant, warned yesterday at a meeting of the National Association of Retail Grocers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Until today the exclusive property of deep-sleep lovers and sun-haters, heavy window shades and closely woven curtain draperies that permit no light to enter a room may soon become the possession of every city dweller.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 10 -- Today is the happiest day the British and Allied forces at Tobruk have seen since Australian infantry, attacking in cooperation with British tanks and a Free French detachment, swept into the city last January and captured 15,000 Italians.

The last American steamship line carrying passengers between this country and Europe is expected to end that service, withdrawing its vessels for operations elsewhere on orders of the United States Government, it was reported here yesterday.

Salvatore Sabbatino, who had previously pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter in the fatal shooting of Emil Camarda, was sentenced yesterday to a Sing Sing prison term of five to ten years. Sabbatino, who is the 54-year-old official of a stevedoring concern, shot and killed Camarda, vice president of the Atlantic Seaboard Branch of the International Longshoremen's Association, A.F. of L., in his office at 52 Broadway on Oct. 2 during a quarrel.

Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh and six veteran fire officers who entered the Fire Department with him forty years ago agreed yesterday that the fire in the Triangle shirtwaist factory at Greene and Washington Streets on March 25, 1911, where 147 lives were lost, was the worst blaze in their experience.

At the headquarters of the American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue, Mrs. William Howard Taft 2d, assistant director of volunteer services, announced yesterday that three times as many volunteers had applied for defense work since early morning as had offered their services on any previous day since the declaration of war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The President has laid down a rule which, he said, will govern that censorship of military news at the source which is both inevitable and essential in time of war. The information, he explained, must first be completely verified by the government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- Bearing sixteen bullet holes as scars of the Japanese attack on Wake Island on Sunday, the big Philippine Clipper of Pan American Airways settled safely on San Francisco Bay today after a thrilling experience which left its commander and crew unshaken.

Without waiting for official requests from the government, the steel industry at midweek already was gearing itself for activity as never before against obstacles that include serious shortages of such raw materials as scrap steel and pig iron.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10--The Battle of the Pacific apparently centered tonight in the Philippines, where a War Department communique reported that severe air attacks had been made at the Cavite naval base in the vicinity of Manila. American military and naval forces were fighting aerial and naval bombardments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- On the ground that the war makes the unity of the country a matter of first concern, the State Department urged Americans today not to serve on governing committees of "free movements" or groups representing foreign countries whose activities are contrary to American policies.

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 11 -- United States and Filipino armed forces pushed back invading Japanese in at least one zone in Northwestern Luzon yesterday, but they apparently still retained a foothold today.

An order to show cause why the United States branches of three large Japanese insurance companies should not be dissolved and their business liquidated was granted yesterday by Judge Cornelius Smyth in the Supreme Court here on the application of Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, represented by Attorney General John J. Bennett.

Manufacturers will be allotted plastics, solely on the basis of "functionality and non-substitutability," A.E. Peterson of the Priorities Division of OPM, chemical section, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Society of the Plastics Industry, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 10 -- Captain Ewart Johnson's Royal Business, "queen of the small tracks," smashed the track record for a mile and a furlong to capture the Dr. Dudley King Handicap today.
As Germany and Italy rounded out the Axis war declarations on the United States, and America responded in kind, the stock market had yesterday its first "victory" market.

Vice Admiral Sir Tom Spencer Vaughan Phillips, among those missing after the flagship of the Far Eastern Fleet, the Prince of Wales, went down off Malaya, is called the "Tom Thumb" of the British Navy. Only 5 feet 4 -- the height of Nelson -- he is an inch shorter than Napoleon.

HONOLULU, Dec. 11 (U.P.) -- In addition to two deadly attacks on the United States naval base at Pearl Harbor last Sunday, Japanese bombers followed with a third attack later that day and with a fourth Monday morning, it is possible to disclose today for the first time.
John Gunther, author of "Inside Asia," "Inside Europe" and the recently published "Inside Latin America," is on his way home from London.

To speed production on more than $3,000,000,000 in defense orders, the nation's three largest automobile manufacturers were asked yesterday by the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., to put their arms plants on a twentyfour-hour, seven-day work schedule immediately through introduction of a fourth work shift.
The Japanese began yesterday to pay the red price of war.

The declaration of war between the United States and Germany and Italy yesterday intensified the already unprecedented recruiting rush to the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard here as jeers and cat-calls from long lines of volunteers around the recruiting stations showed the quick willingness with which the applicants "took on" two more foes.

Thousands of nationals of countries now the enemies of the United States owe a total of something more than $2,000,000 to New York companies, and credit men yesterday afternoon began the long task of checking the degree of loyalty and the citizenship status of these many small accounts.

County Judges Thomas Downs and Charles S. Colden and District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens have reached an agreement that persons committing any crime during a blackout will be prosecuted literally "to the full extent of the law," it was announced yesterday by Mr. Sullivan after a conference with the judges.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (U.P) -- Russian troops are driving toward the once important industrial city of Stalino in an attempt to sweep the Germans out of the Donets Basin and they are gaining ground around Moscow, Russian dispatches said today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Wheat moved up today on a wave of general buying which carried prices as much as 4 3/4 cents a bushel higher, or within 1/4 cent of the permissible limit before the rise was checked by profit-taking. All futures went into new high ground for the season.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 11 -- A merger of eight of the largest Protestant interdenominational agencies in the United States and Canada, including the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, was recommended today at the final session of the Conference on the Cooperation of Interdenominational Agencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Senate again broke into bitter and personal exchanges today as new demands were made that American losses in men, ships, planes and defense facilities in the Pacific be spread in detail, and at once, upon the public record.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 11 (AP) -- The war-time feminine style note is uniforms. Women in war service uniforms are appearing in the nation's capital and will soon be a familiar sight throughout the country.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's address to the House of Commons today:
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- The America First Committee will disband, Gen. Robert E. Wood, acting national chairman, said tonight at headquarters here.

"The Magic Flute," which Mozart wrote in the last bitter year of his life 150 Summers ago, remains one of the great operas of all time, and the revival that the Metropolitan Opera mounted last night becomes the most important of the season It has been produced with excellent taste, and it is sung and played with unity of perception and loftiness of purpose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Every employed citizen of the United States is to be asked to make regular investments in United States Defense Savings Bonds under a new program to be worked out by the Treasury at a conference in Chicago next Tuesday and Wednesday with State chairmen and administrators of the Defense Savings organization.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- For the first time in eighteen months net reductions in employment and payrolls from October to November were reported to the State Labor Department, Frieda S. Miller announced today. The decline was 0.6 in employment and 0.2 in payrolls.

All telephone, cable and telegraph messages to Continental Europe, except for England and Russia, have been stopped by Navy censors, it was disclosed yesterday after Congrress had declared war on Germany and Italy. The ban even extended to dispatches filed by correspondents of foreign newspapers.

The Aviation Cadets' poster contest, held by the Southern New York Recruiting District of the United States Army in collaboration with the Art Students League, closed on Wednesday. All of the entries have not yet been collected from the Army recruiting sub-stations in the district, but the estimated number of posters submitted will exceed 300.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The text of the German note delivered to the American Charge d'Affaires in Berlin and to the State Department here was as follows:
Private investors have supplanted lending institutions, for the time being at least, as the chief source of new mortgage money in Manhattan.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 11 -- With Germrny and Italy joining Japan today in war on the United States, preparations for the protection of industrial plants, public utilities said the,life and property of every one were accelerated in New Jersey.

Automobile Restrictions The further cuts in the quotas for production of passenger cars and light trucks for the current month and the first two months of 1942 were regarded yesterday as "stunning" in automobile circles, but there is no question as to the readiness of the manufacturers to go along with a program intended plainly to conserve materials for national defense at an intensified rate.

The onset of war, rather than the problems of underwriting individuals, crowded the thoughts of life insurance leaders from all parts of the country and Canada yesterday at the thirty-fifth annual convention of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

United States Attorney Harold M. Kennedy ended his summing up in the Brooklyn espionage trial yesterday with the assertion that the acquittal of any or all of the fourteen defendants accused of espionage and failure to register as agents of a foreign government would be a "disaster" to the United States.

QUTNTCY, Mass., Dec. 11 -- Workers in the Fore River plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company are claiming a new world's speed record in shipbuilding: as proof of their rallying cry "we can build ships faster than they can be sunk."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The apathy shown to the air-raid warnings cannot be dispelled by mere repetition of the same measures. Bold, clear steps should be taken by the municipal and civilian defense authorities. Speaking as one who observed and participated in the precautionary actions to date, I submit several proposals which seem vital to the attainment of effective air-raid protection.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Bullish enthusiasm swept today through the livestock market, raising prices of sheep as much as 25 cents a 100 pounds, setting a new top of $14.35 for the current cattle crop and restoring the $11 hog, although $10.90 was the practical top.

There was plenty of verve in the well-edited showing, the second of the series of Thursday luncheons, that took place yesterday in the Cotillion Room at the Hotel Pierre. Only fifteen models were offered. All were from Lillian-Park Avenue.

Steve Owen marshaled his football Giants on the frozen Polo Grounds turf yesterday and sent them through a light hour-and-a-half workout as part of his early preparation for the National Football League championship game with an at present unidentified opponent a week from Sunday.

For a book that examines the essentials of Western civilization and inquires into the basic conflicts between fascism and the way of life for which the democracies of the world now fight, W.T. Stace, an English-born Professor of Philosophy now lecturing at Princeton University, yesterday received the $2,500 prize in a manuscript contest sponsored by the publishing firm of Reynal Hitchcock, Inc. Professor Stace's winning manuscript is entitled "The Destiny of Western Man."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Wholesale prices during the week preceding the Japanese attack on our country were comparatively steady, although the general level was nearly 23 per cent above that of August, 1939, when war broke out in Europe, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.

Although bank clearing's for the week ended on Wednesday declined 9.9 per cent compared with the preceding week, the rate of gain over the corresponding week in 1940 was maintained at about the same high level as that reported the week before.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 -- Golf's mighty atom, wiry Ben Hogan, the year's leading money winner among tournament-playing pros, today made a brilliant start toward adding several thousand dollars more to his bank account.

Chemical Bank and Trust Directors of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company approved yesterday payment of bonuses to all officers and employes amounting to 5 per cent on the first $5,000 of annual salary, 3 1/2 per cent on the next $5,000 and 2 per cent on amounts above $10,000.

For the second successive year, the Middle West's football strong-holds gain plurality control of the seventeenth annual All-America team, chosen today by the Associated Press after a nation-wide survey of expert opinion.
LONDON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following communique today:

College students were advised at two meeting's held yesterday at Columbia University and City College, not to "lose their heads" and succumb to emotion in seeking to aid their country. Speakers at the meetings asserted that it was better to "stick to their work," until the government called them rather than to decide individually what they think they should do.

ALBANY, Dec. 11 -- The reduction in the State's public-assistance population and expenditures since January, 1939, has greatly exceeded the downward trend for the rest of the country, Dr. David C. Adie, Commissioner of Social Welfare, said today in his annual report, a report issued on the tenth anniversary of the creation of the State's unemploymentrelief measures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Department store sales increased 9 per cent during the week ended Dec. 6, as compared with the like week of 1940. After a rise of 15 per cent for the week ended Nov. 29, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 12 (From Radio Broadcasts Recorded by United Press Stations) -- The Japanese today welcomed German and Italian declarations of war against the United States as cementing a fighting Axis alliance that would achieve "inevitable victory."

The outbreak of hostilities between the United States and Japan brought an increase of 30 per cent in the volume of traffic on the Western Union Telegraph Company system in the first three days of this week, it was announced yesterday by A.N. Williams, president of the company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- In a voice so weak the clerk had to call for her vote a second time -- and in a tone very different from her distinct "No" of Monday -- the lone member of Congress who had opposed declaring war on Japan answered "present" today to the rollcall on accepting Adolf Hitler's challenge to fight.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Eight bodies and about eighteen survivors of the big, new American motorship Oregon were brought into this port today, after the vessel plunged to the bottom following a pre-dawn collision with a United States Navy ship yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 -- A test blackout scheduled for tonight by Mayor Bowron of Los Angeles was canceled on order of the Fourth Interceptor Command, which wants no false alarms, as the city counted one dead, over 100 injured and thousands of dollars of property damage from its first blackout and air-raid alarm last night.
Special precautions in the event of an air-raid warning have been taken in the McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West Forty-second Street, which has an unusually large numer of windows.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 11 -- "If the Hitlerian band of aggressors in Europe have any hopes of saving their skin by suing for separate peace with Russia, they are going to be sadly mistaken. The Soviet Union will make its peace with the German nation and the other members of the aggressive powers only at such time as the United States and Britain, and not a minute before."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The War Department today issued the following communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- "A small number" of German, Italian and Japanese newspaper men stationed in the United States are being detained. They will be exchanged for American newspaper men who have been arrested in Axis countries, it was indicated tonight, if the necessary arrangements can be made.

With all the figures in for the monthly issues of December magazines the total shows that these publications managed to register a gain of slightly less than 1 per cent in advertising linage over 1940 for the entire year. The increase in December linage over last year contributed about two-thirds of this rise.

Patriotic housewives are urged by the Consumers Division of the Department of Markets to do their wartime shopping calmly; to buy what they "really need and no more." There is enough food to go round, and hence no cause for excitement.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE NEW YORK TIMES published an article last Thursday on what Captain Pepper of the Walter Reed Hospital said the day before at the Long Island College of Medicine urging young doctors of 25 to 35 to accept commissions as lieutenants on a basis of patriotism, but a false emphasis was put on the matter by the heading "Young Physicians Called Shirkers."
Through the generosity of 262 contributors the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund received $6,111 yesterday, making the total for the thirtieth annual appeal $53,942.95 to date.

A "unity" meeting of the Affiliated Young Democrats held last evening at the Hotel Piccadilly, designed to make a start toward bringing all Democratic factions together, took on pretty much the form of a patriotic rally.

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, and Police Commissioner Valentine appeared yesterday under the guidance of John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor, before Brooklyn and Queens grand juries investigating allegations of official corruption.

Young Kid McCoy, Detroit welterweight, will face a former ruler of his division when he tackles Fritzie Zivic, veteran Pittsburgh campaigner, tonight in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden. Although the battle is not slated over the championship distance, it will have an important bearing on the title, and for that reason more than 10,000 fans are expected to attend.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- President Roosevelt, hailing offers of the major political parties to help the war effort, asserted today that they were capable of "inestimable service" and probably could function to the best advantage in the field of civilian defense.
1. Keep Cool Above all, keep cool. Don't lose your head. Do not crowd the streets; avoid chaos, prevent disorder and havoc.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Arthur Charles Wellesley, fifth Duke of Wellington and great-grandson of the "Iron Duke," died of pneumonia here today. His age was 65.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Conrad devised the only airplane radio set to see much action during the World War.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The German and Italian declarations of war on the United States definitely strengthened hopes here today that the Soviet Union would be found completely on the side of the Allies.

Bundles for Bluejackets, an organization established three weeks ago by the sponsors of Bundles for Britain to send aid to men of the United States Navy, announced yesterday that within a week it had spread into a national organization with branches in every State of the Union.
Textual excerpts from the address Reichsfuehrer Hitler delivered yesterday in the Reichstag, as recorded by Reuter and The Associated Press, follow.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 11 -- The main German forces in Libya, with British mobile columns harassing their flanks, continued yesterday their withdrawal westward from the El Adem area. The Germans fought some rear-guard actions, but seemingly they were making no major effort to stem the rising British tide.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The war declarations against Germany and Italy caused scarcely a ripple at the Justice Department, as the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been apprehending wanted Germans and Italians under authority of the proclamations made by President Roosevelt on Tuesday.
With less than a minute to play Lynn Patrick rapped home two goals and gave the New York Rangers their first triumph of the season over the Brooklyn Americans at Madison Square Garden last night.
Don U. Bridge, advertising director of THE NEW YORK TIMES since 1931, announced his resignation this week. He intends to take an extended vacation before announcing his plans for the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Administration is considering the possibility of registering all men between the ages of 18 and 65 for military service, civilian defense and other purposes, Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said today.
