WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The following long-range view of the stakes and goals in the conflict that has now officially become World War II is not the theorizing of an amateur. It is not the opinion of an arm-chair strategist, a type that now abounds, or of one without knowledge or the pretense of knowledge in these matters, such as this correspondent.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 9 (delayed) -- General Field Marshal Fedor von Bock, who had been charged with the Nazi drive on Moscow and control of the enormous armies on the central part of the front since the outbreak of hostilities between Russia and Germany, has been replaced by General Field Marshal Siegmund Wilhelm List, it was learned today from most reliable sources.

Complete cooperation by theatre managers, unions and actors to protect playgoers in the event of an air-raid warning has been effected, Robert K. Christenberry, general manager of the Hotel Astor, who is air raid warden for the Times Square zone, between Fortieth and Fiftieth Streets west of Fifth Avenue, said yesterday.

Authorities of the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange, after consultations with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Treasury Department, announced yesterday the formal suspension of trading "until further notice" in the securities of the Axis governments, political subdivisions and companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Congress swiftly eliminated prohibitions against American expeditionary forces today and continued terms of enlistment or induction to a date six months after hostilities end. Acting without debate, the two houses dropped the A.E.F. ban by removing restrictions in the Selective Service Act on the use of troops outside the Western Hemisphere.

Now, at long last, the great issue has been joined. Now the inescapable struggle of our time begins. Now all masks are dropped, all doubts are gone, all values stand revealed. Now Germany and Italy join treacherous Japan in her attack on the United States -- and the American people go to total war in defense of their lives, their liberties, their very existence as an independent nation.

The people of New York City received the news that we are at war with Germany and Italy as well as Japan with profound calm and a quiet, stern determination to see it through, no matter how long it takes. Patriotism and loyalty were the spontaneous order of the day in every household, every business office, every factory, every school and every institution.

Endeavors by property owners to secure bomb insurance on properties in the United States and its possessions were virutally negated yesterday owing to the uncertainty among insurance companies as to what rates should be asked.

Commenting on the Russian campaign in his speech before the House of Commons Winston Churchill said: "We can already see, after six months of fighting, that Hitler made one of the outstanding blunders of history and the results so far realized constitute events of cardinal importance in the final decision of the war."
NEW YORK Henrik de Kauffmann, the Danish Minister, and Mme. de Kauffmann have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Coach Howard Cann is none too optimistic regarding the prospects of N.Y.U.'s basketball team but admits that, if hard work has any bearing on developing a good quintet, this may become a top-flight aggregation.

The maintenance and development of the inland waterways of the Eastern coast are important factors in the nation's war effort, government officials and other leaders in this field declared yesterday at the thirty-second annual convention of the New York State Waterways Association, Inc., held in the Hotel Astor.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 11(U.P.) -- The defenders of British Malaya are still beating back Japanese attacks on the northern border, it was announced today.

The Banco di Napoli Trust Company of New York, which has its main office at 526 Broadway and has five branch offices in various Italian neighborhoods in this city, was taken over yesterday by William R. White, New York State Superintendent of Banks, in co-operation with the Treasury Department.

Senhora Getulio Vargas, wife of the president of Brazil, was titular hostess at a cafe dansant held in the Hotel St. Regis last evening for what is believed to be the first foreign, non-war relief charity to receive aid from a New York society benefit.

Gladioli in luscious shades of deep reds and fragrant pinks are the outstanding choice to make in selecting flowers for table decorations or week-end corsages. It was reported yesterday that 10,000 bunches have been arriving on the New York market each day in the last week.

CHUNGKING, China, Friday, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Chinese troops attacking all along the Kwangtung Front to relieve Japanese pressure on Hong Kong have inflicted 15,000 casualties on the Japanese in a continuing two-days offensive, the China raido announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 11 -- At noon today [5 A.M.E.S.T.] Joachim von Ribbentrop, Reich Foreign Minister, in a note handed the United States Charge d'Affaires George L. Brandt in Berlin informed him that Germany had declared war on the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, closed his testimony today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee with an appeal for prompt action on the House price control bill and the amendments he has offered.
ROME, Dec. 11 (From, Italian broadcast) -- Premier Mussolini lini's address at the Palazzo Venezia today:

Convinced that New York will receive at least a "token bombing" within the very near future, Herbert H. Scott, a veteran of 100 air raids on Eastbourne, on the south-east coast of England, yesterday urged New Yorkers to learn quickly the lessons England learned through grim experience in the great bombings of London and other cities.
The Harvard Club squash racquets team retained first place in the Metropolitan Class A tournament by defeating the Princeton Club, 4 to 1, on the Harvard Club courts.

Under significantly altered circumstances, 115 members attended a dinner of the Keep America Out of War Congress at Town Hall last night. Certain of the group's leaders felt that the dinner was to be a sort of swan song to the organization's original aims, but the members revealed that they still held some of their original views when they cheered attacks by Norman Thomas on British and American "imperialism."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Following are the texts of the documents wherein the President asked a war declaration against Germany and Italy, and Congress acted:

The organized support in the market for United States Government obligations in the weak markets early this week by the Treasury, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, was revealed, in part, yesterday by the regularly weekly figures released by the Federal Reserve Bank.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Dec. 12 -- Further impressive progress by Russian forces in the Moscow region was claimed by the Soviet military commentator in his broadcast this morning. North and south of the capital Soviet troops, in the third day of their general counter-offensive, were reported to have smashed the German lines at three points in the Kalinin sector, where impressive, but unspecified, advances were claimed.

Following the traditionally generous policy of this democracy, every kindness and humane consideration will be shown to subjects of Germany and Italy and to other alien enemies resident here, but if any violates his status, the government will deal with him swiftly and unmercifully, Mayor F.H. La Guardia said yesterday in a radio broadcast at Tacoma, Wash.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Mrs. Alfred King Jr. of the Apawamis Club won the third annual Bronxville Field Club women's invitation squash racquets tournament by defeating her club-mate, Mrs. J.K. Crimmins, 13 -- 15, 13 -- 16, 16 -- 13, 15 -- 13, 15 -- 11, today.

The engagement of Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, 17-year-old heiress, who was the center of a bitter court fight in 1934, to Pasquale (Pat) Di Cicco, Hollywood actor's agent, was announced here last night.
ROME, Dec. 11 (From an Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique todays:

The Civil Aeronautics Administration has lifted the ban on private flying which was imposed following the initial Japanese attack on Sunday, but has imposed a strict set of rules in its place, J.E. Sommer, regional manager, announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- Sandbag barricades, protectors against bomb fragments, began making their appearance in San Francisco today as new blackouts were ordered for parts of the Pacific Coast and this area advanced its preparations against possible Japanese attacks from the air.

A few industries, which do their peak business during the Christmas season, face a temporary pinch in paperboard and containers during the next two weeks but it will not be serious enough to cripple deliveries to any extent, manufacturers reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The State Department made public today the latest available list of foreign service officers and others attached to the American Embassies in Berlin and Rome with their home addresses in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Hans Thomsen, the German Charge d'affaires, got the cold shoulder from Secretary Hull when he called at the State Department early this morning to communicate officially that Germany was at war with tin United States.

TONIGHT, during the theatre hours, the Garden will have another of its fight shows. A blond youngster who, not so long ago, was carrying heavy things around in the Ford factories near Detroit has his chance against a crafty, seasoned campaigner, a veteran at the ripe age of 27 -- Young Kid McCoy against Fritzie Zivic.

Weather Spurs Coat Sales While the outbreak of war is regarded as having ruined what otherwise would have been a good week for men's clothing' sales, the cold weather has stimulated some interest in overcoats, retail executives reported yesterday.
The new Victor Moore bus terminal on the triangular plot at Roosevelt Avenue, Broadway and Seventy-fifth Street, Jackson Heights, L.I., was officially opened yesterday.

While plans went forward yesterday for New York City's first practice blackout, the date for which has not yet been set, the Board of Estimate unanimously approved an appropriation of $25,000 recommended by Acting Mayor Newbold Morris to purchase air-raid sirens and other civilian defense equipment.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 12 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- The army reported today that Japanese troops in the northern part of the island of Luzon, in the Philippines, were advancincg after having thrown back the "enemy, who Is fleeing in the direction of Manila."

Sibelius's Fifth symphony and Strauss's "Till Eulenspiegel" were the principal offerings on the program presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Artur Rodzinski, last night in Carnegie Hall. The Handel-Harty "Water Music" and the SmetanaByrns "Bohemian Dance Suite," which received its first concert performance, rounded out the schedule.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Navy announced tonight that one officer was killed, two officers an' three enlisted men were missing and five enlisted men injured as the result of a crash of an Atlantic Ocean patrol bomber.

Declarations or war by the United States on Germany and Italy spurred buying yesterday in the cotton market, which was devoid of substantial offerings. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures consequently rose as much as 43 points, or $2.15 a bale, over the opening lows and then receded in late trading under hedging pressure to close with net gains of 29 to 36 points, or $1.45 to $1.80 a bale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The five largest anti-Axis powers -- the United States, Great Britain, Russia, China and the Netherlands Indies -- have more of the world's wheat, petroleum, coal, iron ore and sugar than their enemies.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The declarations of war between the United States and Germany and Italy, although something for which most thoughtful Britons had been hoping for for months, followed upon the fateful events of last Sunday and Monday, and hence came as an anticlimax today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11 -- With the outbreak of war against Japan, one of the pertinent questions of interest is this: Did the common people of the United States make a realistic appraisal of Japanese-American relations as those relations developed over the past few years?

Long before Great Britain went to war an elaborate system of air-raid defenses had been created. In all parts of London and throughout the provinces air-raid shelters were constructed; entrances to buildings were sandbagged to provide protection against blast and to minimize the danger of flying glass.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 11 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian dealers in all commodities are being granted licenses by the Wartime Prices and Trade Board and a detailed explanation of this general licensing system will be issued soon, the board announced today.

Settlement of a fourteen-week-old labor dispute between the aircraft division of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., and the Bell Aircraft Corporation was announced yesterday by Thomas E. Murray, who served as arbiter at the request of Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins.
The return of cold weather had skiing enthusiasm running high last night in the metropolitan area, but the outlook for an early start in the sport this week-end was indeed discouraging.

The annual Gay Thirties Dinner Dance, one of the most popular charity subscription parties of each Winter season, was given in Christmas setting last night on the Star-light Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The dance derives its name from the average age of its subscribers, who include young married couples and their friends.

Marshall Goldberg, once a sensational back for the University of Pittsburgh, has been somewhat in eclipse as a member of Jimmy Conzelman's Cardinals, who won no 1941 championships. But final National Football League figures, released yesterday, indicate that he still is a lot of football player.

While womenn volunteers eager to share the burden of the present emergency continued to register yesterday by the hundreds for national defense jobs, new plans were under for training and recruiting at the American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue; the Office of Civilian Defense, 93 Park Avenue, and at the American Women's Voluntary Services, 40 East Forty-first Street.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 11 -- From the famous balcony overlooking the huge Piazza Venezia in Rome, Premier Benito Mussolini addressed upward of 150,000 people gathered below him and millions of others assembled in the squares of all Italian cities, towns and villages to tell them their country was at war with the United States.
Preparations for conducting churchgoers to places of safety during air raid alarms coming at hours of worship were in progress yesterday in the city's churches.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Barbara Stanwyck, Olivia de Havilland and George Brent will play the leads in the screen version of Stephen Longstreet's novel, "The Gay Sisters," which will go before the cameras early in February with Irving Rapper directing, Warner Brothers announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The war Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 10:
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 11 -- Germany and Italy, through their Ambassadors, formally notified Argentina today that they were at war with the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The news that more than 2,000 survivors were rescued from the Prince of Wales and the Repulse brightened the stock markets today, and after the heavy selling of the two previous days stocks were in urgent demand.

Some cancellations of orders from Pacific Coast stores were reported in the wholesale markets here yesterday, but comment indicated that this action was not taken by any large number of stores. Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Johnny Mize, 28-year-old slugging first baseman, became a Giant tonight when Manager Melvin Ott and General Manager Bill Terry completed a deal with General Manager Branch Rickey of the Cardinals which sent Pitcher Bill Lohrman and Catcher Ken O'Dea, as well as cash, to St. Louis.

The Chicago Bears and Green Bay Packers dominate The United Press all-professional football team selected yesterday. The Bears placed four men on the first team and the Packers three. The Giants, Eastern division champions in the National League, landed, only one man on the first eleven.

American Metal Directors of the American Metal Company, Ltd., authorized a year-end dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, making payments $1.50 this year, against $2.25 in 1940. The year-end dividend last year was 75 cents.

MONTREAL, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Montreal's last-place Canadiens snapped a five-game losing streak in the National Hockey League tonight by beating Toronto, 2 -- 1, in an overtime game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 6 were 833,375 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
