TO ski or not to ski is no longer the question. This Winter almost every mountain slope and hillside in the snow belt will be criss-crossed and dimpled with the ski-prints and sitzmarks of millions of lovers of the Great White Art. And from now on it will not all be just for fun; America is hardening its muscles, toughening up. The only questions on everybody's tongue are -- where and how?

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Until Japan's treacherous attack on us, the United States was not actually at war and most Americans found it very difficult to change their peacetime habits of thought and action. The peacetime habits of business men and of leaders of organized labor are ill-suited to bring about that maximum production at high speed which is essential to national defense in time of emergency.

MANY a parent has lived through a childhood weary and heavy laden with precept, under a regimen of "Yes, Mamma," and "No, Papa"; of rising when elders entered a room, of speaking when spoken to, and of snapping into action not later than the moment of final, awful command, "Did you hear me speaking to you?"

With these words the President ended his solemn call to arms. They are words worth remembering and repeating in the dark days to come. We have not been drummed into this conflict by slogans. We have been attacked by Japan in a coup as treacherously planned and as dastardly as any ever delivered by the Germans.

TEN years ago Jacob Perlmuth was a lower East Side boy who had left medical school after two years, eloped with a girl named Alice Kaye, and resigned himself to being a fiddle player in scratch dance orchestras recruited for single engagements from among the members of Local 802 of the musicians' union.

DAUPHIN ISLAND, Ala. -- Legends of buried treasure and tales of swashbuckling rovers of the Spanish Main lend an atmosphere of enchantment to this wind-swept island at the mouth of Mobile Bay. Today a peaceful, picturesque strip of land fronting the Gulf of Mexico, Dauphin Island looks back on a turbulent history.

To the Radio Editor: SOME afternoon, in the very near future, a new script is going to appear on the air, sandwiched in between the "Life Can Be Scrumptious" show and the "Wrigglings of Delight" program.

The plan of Theatrical Protective Union 1, A.F. of L. to have a test blackout of theatres in West Forty-fifth Street at 9 P.M. last night was canceled "forthwith" yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine. Irate at what his aides described as "usurpation of authority" he made clear that there would be no blackouts of any kind in any part of New York without the approval of the Mayor and the Police Commissioner.
Despite the outbreak of war, the National Academy did not alter its plans last week to open its new home to the public early in the new year.

SEVERAL new group shows opened last week or recently. The twenty-sixth annual of the New York Society of Painters has been current since Dec. 4 at the American Fine Arts Building. Only thirty artists participate in this report, tout since several are represented by more than one work, the picture total is forty-four.

KINGSTON -- Winter sports enthusiasts for whom the Northern Catskills' snowcovered slopes and frozen lakes symbolize speed, thrills and allaround outdoor fun, will have five championship events added to their week-end calendars, while near by two important regional programs are scheduled.

OF all the occasions when the movie maker has a chance to practice at his hobby Christmas ranks among the best and most productive. The average movie maker was probably first persuaded to buy his camera because he wished to have a record of the family's big moments.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- In recruiting stations in Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana and Michigan, the Central West, long the heart and soul of the fight to keep America out of war, is giving a rousing answer to the brazen attack on the United States by the Axis powers.

MILK -- Pasteurization does not kill all the bacteria in milk, Dr. Robert S. Breed of the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station informs us. Two groups survive super-pasteurizing temperature. Luckily they are harmless to man.

MANILA, Sunday, Dec. 14 (AP)--American fliers smashed hard yesterday at a Japanese bombing attack on Manila--the war's worst on the Philippine capital--in which at least seventy-five persons were killed and 300 wounded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A drive to dislodge "enormous quantities" of "dormant" scrap scattered through industrial plants, retail stores and city, county, State and Federal storage yards over the country will be started tomorrow by the Office of Production Management's Bureau of Conservation, a unit headed by Lessing J. Rosenwald.

MUSIC has been a lifelong hobby for Elizabeth Mitchell, wife of Charles E. Mitchell. She has played and studied it since she was a child, and she has worked for it on committees, in fundraising campaigns and as a hostess in her fashionable home.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Navy Department announced today that the small United States garrisons on the islands of Wake and Midway in the Pacific Ocean were continuing to resist Japanese attacks, but that Guam had probably been captured.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Roosevelt today instructed Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, to call a conference "to consider a program for voca- tional rehabilitation." The President wrote Mr. McNutt that he acted "in view of the unhappy casualty prospects of a national war."

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- As it was made known today that reinforcements of planes and airmen were being sent to Malaya by the Royal Air Force, the clamor became louder here for joint command between all nations fighting the Axis powers.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 13 -- Until last Sunday most of the inhabitants of the Pacific Northwest regarded a bombing attack on their far-flung region as beyond all likelihood. Since Sunday they have lived under the imminent threat of such an eventuality.

Calling the rise of 4 per cent in non-farm property foreclosures for October "somewhat unfavorable," in view of the customary 3 per cent decline at this time of the year, the Federal Home Loan Bank states that the foreclosure record for the first ten months of the year remains extremely favorable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A single, responsible head for the war production set-up and prompt enactment of anti-strike legislation on the lines of the Smith bill, already passed by the House, were urged today in resolutions passed by the directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States at the end of a two-day meeting.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- What could not happen to Americans did happen this week, and air-raid warnings sounded in New York and San Francisco as they have so many times in London and Chungking.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 13 -- The Foreign Ministry at noon today published the expected decree extending to the United States the privileges of non-belligerency in its war with Germany and Italy and declaring Argentine neutrality toward the two European Axis powers.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 13 -- The question which the country has been asking the Middle West and which the Middle West has been asking itself, whether it was more isolationist than anti-Axis, has been emphatically answered. The bombs which fell on Pearl Harbor settled opinion for this part of the country and settled it one way.

OTTAWA, Dec. 13 -- In the social history of Ottawa the events of last Saturday night are likely to become a legend, for on that evening the Japanese Minister, Seijiro Yoshizawa, entertained twenty guests at dinner, among them three members of the United States Legation staff in Ottawa with their wives.

MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- Ancient Moscow, with its Byzantine cupolas and snow-banked streets, now is the principal behind-the-lines supply depot for the greatest counter-offensive ever launched against Adolf Hitler's army. As Joseph Stalin's generals press home their powerful drive in the center, gun caissons, trucks of motorized infantry, tanks and armored cars rumble over the streets and there is the steady tread of fresh battalions marching out to pursue retreating Germans.

Speedier and more convenient handling of industry conferences to supply policy-making information to defense executives, and a streamlined system for handling inquiries and requests for interpretations of existing price regulations, will be provided by the opening of a New York City regional office by the Office of Price Administration, according to Sylvan Joseph, regional director.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Smith bill for curtailment of strikes, while undoubtedly a brave political effort, is but another illustration of the bad legislation which has been issuing from the halls of Congress for several decades.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- The placing of ceilings late Saturday on prices of oils and fats by the Office of Price Administration at levels materially lower than those then prevailing, dominated the action of grains today. There was general selling early in sympathy with drastic recessions in lard, soy beans and cottonseed oil, wheat dipping around 2 1/2 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade and other grains following its lead.

In the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow a large luncheon will be given under the auspices of the British-American Ambulance Corps to raise funds for its dental ambulance unit. Lady Davis of Montreal, now staying at the Hotel Pierre, will preside.

In an atmosphere bristling with news of the attack on Hawaii, and to an obbligato of telephone calls, thousands of volunteers swelled the relief corps of the American Red Cross last week. Among the most gratifying developments were applications for training as nurses' aides.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Capturing every event, Princeton University's swimming team swamped Fort Monmouth, 66 to 9, today in Brokaw pool.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- "It may be entirely laudable" for a college student to want to complete his course but that is not sufficient reason to win his exemption from military service, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today.

A prediction that rental conditions on the East Side will show some improvement during the Spring, Summer and Fall of 1942 was made yesterday by Francis S. Bancroft, vice president of the Pease Elliman realty firm.

Preliminary surveys of the immediate effect of a shooting war upon the credit structure of this country indicated last week that, with adequate precautions, there was little danger of any serious weakening of the credit picture. Clarence L. Riegel, executive director of the New York Credit Men's Association, said yesterday that there were three major problems to which credit men must give their attention.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 14 -- The Red Army continued its victorious advance yesterday on the Moscow front along a 530-mile line between the Tikhvin and Elets salients through punching gains of as much as twenty miles at some points.

LITTLETON, N.H. -- Franconia, Littleton, Lisbon, North Woodstock, Lincoln and Bethlehem, the towns that form the Franconia Notch area of New Hampshire, have prepared for a busy Winter by improving many of last year's facilities and by developing new attractions.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Santa Claus will climb down a tree instead of entering via the chimney when he appears before 300 crippled children at the party a group of members of the Miami Beach colony are giving Christmas Eve at the residence of Mrs. George A. Halman.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13 -- The popular South American reaction to the Japanese aggression against the United States, after a moment of shocked and incredulous surprise, has been one of anger -- blazing, red-hot anger -- that any power foreign to this continent should have dared to attack one of the American republics.

The American Rock Garden Society, Middle Atlantic region, will meet Wednesday at 11 A.M. at the Hotel McAlpin. Montague Free, horticulturist at the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens will discuss "Ways and Means of Growing Alpines."

LONDON, Dec. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Britain's football defenses took a severe beating today. Prolific scoring marked scheduled games and the total approached the wartime record of 212 goals scored in forty-one matches on Dec. 16, 1939.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Orders making it impossible to make, sell or ship aviation gasoline except with his approval were issued today by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- A committee of five prepared to leave tonight for San Francisco to discuss with Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt, commander of the Fourth Army, his request that the New Year's Day Rose Bowl football game and the Tournament of Roses Parade be canceled.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 13 -- The recruiting stations of the Fourth Corps Area, of which Atlanta is headquarters, were overwhelmed with young men Monday and Tuesday. "They were in bitter fighting moods," said Colonel Charles L. Clifford, in charge of recruiting for the area.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 13 -- Secretary Knox, returning from a quick trip to Hawaii to survey the naval situation there, arrived at the San Diego naval base this morning, Eleventh Naval District Headquarters announced, and left immediately for Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The cataclysmic events of this week have created on paper a coalition of powers whose potential strength is far greater than that of the Axis, but the successful operation of this coalition in the immediate future depends largely on Russia; and Russia's part in the Far East is still not clearly defined, although the Russian Ambassador in Washington today called Japan the "common enemy."

THE widest diversity of subject-matter and range of prices are reflected in the Christmas group exhibitions. NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Roig will give a dinner dance in the Wedgewood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 22 to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Leila Roig.

To mark the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Spence Adoption Nursery, the Spence School Alumnae Society will give its annual Silver Spoon Tea Dance next Saturday at the Stork Club. The party will serve also as one in a series of events celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of the school.

Overnight news that ceiling prices had been imposed on lard and oils chilled sentiment in the cotton market yesterday. Influenced by the latest restrictions on commodities trading, liquidation operations carried prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net losses of 20 to 30 points, or $1 to $1.50 a bale.

LEADERS in the bridge world are still in a state of complete uncertainty as to what effect the war will have on the playing of contract bridge and upon the bridge business. CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 13 -- Racing conditions for the second Saturday at this racing meet were far from ideal today, but some 5,000 fans braved sleet and rain to witness a card that was headlined by the Spirit of Jefferson Purse, which drew a capacity field of eight 3-year-olds and upward.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Governor Culbert L. Olson telegraphed Pasadena authorities tonight, forwarding a request of the Army that the Pasadena Tournament of Roses and the Rose Bowl football game between Duke University and Oregon State College on New Year's Day be canceled.

A bronze tablet, commemorating the 100th anniversary of the birth of the Czech composer Antonin Dvorak, was unveiled yesterday morning in ceremonies at 327 East Seventeenth Street, where the composer lived during his visit to America from 1892 to 1895.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 -- The marriage of Miss Marjorie Arm- strong Pendleton, daughter of Mrs. William Simpson 3d and A. Patter- son Pendleton of this city, to Lieutenant Arthur Pue German 2d, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Doug- las Gorman, also of Baltimore, took place this afternoon in Emmanuel Protestant Episcopal Church.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 13 (U.P.) -- The Stadswacht [City Guards] were called to armories today to receive defensive equipment for use against enemy parachute troops and Fifth Column elements. All leaves were canceled. Police guarded warehouses and food shops against sabotage and to prevent hoarding, although there are plentiful food reserves.

VANCOUVER, Canada -- Virtually from a standing start Canada has made long strides in the manufacture of aircraft since the war began and while the production program has not been all plain sailing the chief barriers appear to have been overcome at last.

The nineteenth Metropolitan Equestrian Club Horse Show, to be held on the afternoon and evening of Dec. 27 at the Riding and Polo Club, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street, will be a benefit for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

George Chavchavadze, pianist, who made his local debut last season in Town Hall, made his second appearance yesterday afternoon in the same auditorium. The young expatriate Russian Prince disclosed his fine talents to the best advantage in the Chopin group presented, where his playing had so much to commend it that one wished the artist had devoted his entire program to that composer.

TOMORROW night four networks, which is plenty, join circuits to remind you that 150 years ago some Virginians gave an official okay to a document composed earlier in New York City. To celebrate the occasion President Roosevelt, two symphony orchestras and some very fine actors of the cinema will come together in a program intended to dramatize and illuminate certain truths; the great and fundamental truths implicit in the phrase: "We Hold These Truths."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Extension of the production requirements plan to cover replacement and maintenance requirements of wholesale establishments, thereby making available to the government a cross-check on the distribution as well as production of goods on a national scale, has been worked out by the Office of Production Management in cooperation with other Federal agencies here, it was learned authoritatively today.

RIVER VALE, N.J., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The New York Rovers downed the Jersey Skeeters 6 to 2, tonight and stepped into a three-way tie with the Johnstown Blue Birds and the Boston Olympics for first place in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The war Department released the following orders today dated Dec. 11:

A ten-point physical education program designed to fit municipal college students and civilian defense workers for the "rigorous work" which lies ahead of them in the war has been formulated by the Hygiene and Physical Education Association of the College of the City of New York embracing City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens Colleges, it was announced yesterday by Professor Joseph Bressler of Brooklyn College, president of the association.

MONTREAL, Dec. 13 -- There was an indication that the government is preparing to mobilize the whole man and woman power of the nation in a speech here this evening by Air Minister C.G. Power. He hinted also that the burdens of taxation and vexations of restrictions would be increased "until it hurts."

TOKYO, Dec. 13 (From a Japanese Domei News Agency Broadcast Recorded by The United Press) -- Premier-War Minister General Hideki Tojo warned today against "intoxication by initial victories" and said Japan should be prepared for a long, hard war necessitating sacrifices.
America Enters It We are now in this war. We are all in it -- all the way. Every single man, woman and child is a partner in the most tremendous undertaking of our American history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Military cooperation of the Netherlands was pledged in the Pacific war by Queen Wilhelmina in a message to President Roosevelt, given out by the State Department today. Her message follows:

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- In the Berkshire uplands of Western Massachusetts are ten skiing areas officially designated as such by the Berkshire Hills Conference, whose headquarters are at the Court House in Pittsfield.

The Nation Mobilizes M-Day has been the symbol for the day on which the United States would leave the ways of peace and embark upon the path of war. Army, Navy and Government officials have long been drafting blueprints for that day, blueprints which have been revised and broadened many times since martial theories first met their test in total war overseas.

L.W. Hutchins, director of the Safety Research Institute, points out that multiple dwellings, or apartment houses and homes in which three or more families live independently should be adequately safeguarded against fire as an important civil defense measure.
FEW novels have been so minutely planned as was "Storm" by George R. Stewart. The notes are most efficiently compressed but they make a sizable bundle.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Battle of the Atlantic -- that fierce struggle for maintenance of the transport of supplies from the United States and Canada, on which so greatly depends Britain's ability to continue fighting the war on the European front, has taken on more serious aspects than ever as a result of United States involvement in the conflict.

FOR the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund THE NEW YORK TIMES renews its thirtieth annual appeal today. The first hundred cases, whose stories were published last Sunday, have been assured of aid, thanks to the warmhearted response of readers in the last week. But other hundreds are as gravely in need as the first group. Help must come for them also.

A reduction of assessed values, the lifting of the mortgage moratorium, and a curtailment of local and State spending were among the items urged by various speakers last week at the sixth annual Metropolitan Realty Conference at the Hotel Commodore.
The business of the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building yesterday set a record for any Saturday in the last year. Scores of applicants were still in line when the bureau closed at noon.

Prices of shares on the New York Stock Exchange moved yesterday to the highest levels of the recovery movement in the most active Saturday of the year. Trading was 629,310 shares, the best figure since December, 1940, and 740 issues were involved.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 -- New England is unanimous. Unity is the magic word in these six States today. There has been a swift transformation of all differences into complete solidarity of intention and action.

MEXICO CITY -- Sanborns is to Mexico City what the American Express was, once upon a happier time, to Paris. But Sanborns is more versatile. There the people who came down on the same train or boat from the States run into each other as they buy anything from milk of magnesia to antiques of the Spanish Colonial period.

ALTHOUGH there is a possibility of seat and space priorities for government use, the air-lines will not be materially affected by the war, a survey of airline officials, whose planes use La Guardia Field, revealed last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Soviet Union intends to concentrate its war effort in Europe and smash Adolf Hitler and his legions, but will not open a second front against Japan in Eastern Asia at present.

"NATIONAL unity to be real has to be something more than words." Wendell Willkie so declared in one of last week's tense hours. The man who is titular head of the Republican party and in Britain would be leader of the "loyal opposition" has pleaded often for a nation in which recrimination was adjourned and a people stood forth as one before the towering menace of the totalitarian world.

Thirty-two law students and graduates of New York University have been elected to Alpha Chapter of Theta Sigma Lambda, na- tional honor law society, George O. Arkin, secretary, announced yesterday. Among them is United States Circuit Court Judge Florence E. Allen of Ohio, who was admitted to membership as of 1913, the year of her graduation.
A new type of construction using pre-cast concrete slabs is being tried out by the USHA in a fifteenunit defense housing project at Alexandria, Va.

FROM American radio workshops, every once in a while, comes word about some new device that may find its way into everyday use when the war is over -- perhaps to change the modern conception of broadcasting or world-wide communications.

SOLUTION of a mystery surrounding a United States stampless cover owned by William C. Michaels, a Kansas City insurance attorney, was made known by him last week on his arrival to attend a national insurance convention at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The White House announced late today the selection of twelve industrial management representatives and twelve leaders of organized labor to meet here next Wednesday to draft a basic War Labor Policy.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Dec. 13 -- Don Faurot, coach of the University of Missouri's Sugar Bowl-bound football team, today named forty-six men to make the trip to Edgewater Park, Miss., for a week and a half of training before clashing with Fordham.

Practically all types of retail distribution in the New York area were affected last week by war tension and the series of air raid warnings. Business fell off sharply during the earlier part of the week, but it recovered somewhat in the latter portion.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago, in the sedate Chicago suburb of Oak Park, two high school youths stood crestfallen before their composition teacher. Teacher had just said, "Neither one of you will ever learn how to write."

A MAN on a hillside near the American coast line looks up at the sky. He is one of thousands on duty night and day since Japan attacked the United States. He has been watching that sky for several hours, and its appearance no longer has either striking beauty or novelty for him.

The Winter conclaves over, baseball observers yesterday seemed agreed that the major league club owners had deported themselves with rare good judgment in their Chicago meetings, which got under way at the very moment the nation found itself plunged headlong into actual war.

Navy censorship headquarters here reported yesterday that the handling of outgoing press dispatches was somewhat speeded up as the new war-time organization began to get into stride. Service will expedite even more when installation of pneumatic tubes between cable companies and the censor's office is completed, a spokesman predicted.

The city's Red Cross units will unite in an appeal for $7,330,000 toward the $50,000,000 war fund being sought nationally by the American Red Cross, it was announced yesterday by General James G. Harbord, head of the New York chapter.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- The fiftieth anniversary of the founding of Drexel Institute of Technology will be observed at traditional Founder's Day exercises to be held on Wednesday, according to an announcement by Dr. Parke R. Kolbe, president of the college.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of rather strong advances, attributed largely to American involvement in the war. Imposition of temporary ceilings on lard prices at levels below yesterday's quotations had no immediate effect on the market for hogs.

Back at his desk in City Hall yesterday after his flying visit to inspect and direct civilian defense activities on the Pacific Coast, Mayor La Guardia took personal command of the city's program for protection of its 7,000,000 inhabitants against air raids or other hostile attacks.

MEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 13 -- The first post-war workbook on technical writing, prepared by three members of the Tufts College faculty, is beginning to produce dividends for the authors in the form of increased interest in the study of English among engineering students, who according to tradition were reputed to regard this subject as the fly in their curriculum ointment.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 13 -- Not having succeeded in separating the United States from Great Britain, the Germans are now apparently putting high hopes on the possibility of dividing the United States from South America.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 12 (Delayed) -- The sympathies of the Soviet Government and people in the Far Eastern conflict have now been made abundantly clear. The Communist party organ Pravda has expressed the conviction that Japan will undoubtedly suffer defeat, and private individuals are constantly proclaiming their hopes for an Allied victory.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

Vichy officially announced the new executions -- bringing the total of reprisal executions to 303 -- and said a great number of Frenchmen have been deported to Eastern Europe for hard labor, according to United Press reports last night.

The occupied and conquered countries of Europe gave their praise and support to the cause of academic freedom last night when representatives of several governments-in-exile addressed 100 European scholars at the opening meeting of the new Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes.

Juniors in society, including future debutantes and young men of "prep" school and early college years, will attend several subscription dances arranged for their diversion during the Christmas season.

A civilian defense volunteer spokesman at the Manhattan office revealed yesterday afternoon that total enrollment throughout the first week of war totalled 2,400 persons. At the outset, she said, women volunteers outnumbered the men by two to one, but, she added, "the number of men registrants is increasing rapidly."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The following foreign service changes since Dec. 6 were announced by the State Department today: H. Merie Cothran, Tucson, Ariz., assigned for duty in the Dept. of State.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: I should like to convey my compliments on your decision to inaugurate a regular page of criticism dealing with modern poetry, and at the same time to express the hope that the page hereafter will contain no such inauspicious remarks as those made by Mary Colum (in the issue for Nov. 30) in discussing the poetry of Louise Bogan.

WITH "The Mikado" stricken from the rolls of a Savoyard troupe, there have been a few agitated inquiries about "Madama Butterfly." After all, it extols a Japanese dancing girl at the expense of an American -- and a naval officer at that.

DENVER, Col. -- Nobody knows why it takes wars and catastrophes to make Americans sit up and take notice of what they have in their own back yards or front yards, depending on which side of the Mississippi you hail from.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--Although some restrictions have been placed on the naturalization of Germans and Italians in this country, the sole purpose is to enable the government to weed out "the relatively few enemy aliens of the subversive classes," Attorney General Francis Biddle stated tonight.
TWO authors have made useful contributions to that kind of exploration -- now happily coming into vogue -- which approaches history via the ground floor of human life.
Orders by the Police Department to be followed by all residents in a total blackout have issued to thousands of air-raid wardens. The principal orders and instructions follow:

During the first eleven-month period of the present war, more than $9,000,000 was paid into county tax offices in New York State in advance of due dates by financial institutions acting as agents of new home owners, reports Thomas G. Grace, State FHA director.

In a furious burst of pre-holiday activity, the college basketball teams of the Eastern sector will play an imposing list of major games during the coming week, with much of the interest centered on a heavy local program which includes the second of the Madison Square Garden double-headers on Saturday night.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Dec. 13 -- In compliance with the request of the War Department, Republic Aviation Corporation, manufacturers of the super-powered Thunderbolt interceptor planes, tomorrow will start a three-shift, "around-the-clock" seven-day work week, President Ralph S. Damon announced today.

"READY": In the early years of the last World War, when airplanes were "flying boxkites" which might at any moment collapse in mid-air, a group of British officers organized the force now known as the R.A.F. At the time, it was established as an irregular "Air Battalion of the Royal Engineers."

A PHOTOGRAPH of the design of the seventh stamp in the Union of South Africa's war series reached New York last week from Pretoria. A halfpenny green, released on Nov. 19, is in honor of the infantry units in the South African forces.

Air raid wardens, selected and trained by the Police Department from citizen volunteers, are expected to be the principal liaison agents between the 7,000,000 people of New York City and the elaborate structure of air raid precautions and services that is being organized to meet the danger of bombing.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 13 -- The Dartmouth basketball team, defender of the Eastern intercollegiate title for the third successive year, made its local debut tonight by drubbing St. John's of New York City, 74 -- 55. It was a wildscoring game in which the Big Green tallied 48 points in the first half and the Red Indians from Brooklyn 37 in the last session.
ROME, Dec. 13 (From an Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command broadcast this communique today:

THE adjective "illustrated" in connection with this volume has an uncommonly intimate meaning. Not only is Mr. Klitgaard's lively prose accompanied by eight color reproductions of modern American paintings, thirty-three reproductions in black and white and some chapter headings by the author, but it is explicitly through the eyes of artists that Mr. Klitgaard has chosen to view the United States.

For one of the outstanding successes of her ring career, Miss Betty Anne MacLeod captured the horsemanship championship to supply one of the chief features of the annual Brooklyn Winter horse show concluded last night at the Teevan Riding Academy.

War in the Pacific has thrown the spotlight on one of the most vital commodities required by the United States in the pursual of its fight against the aggression of the Axis nations. A continued supply of this commodity -- rubber -- has been seriously endangered by japanese threats against Pacific trade routes and the Federal Government, in conjunction with the rubber industry, is working feverishly to develop new sources of supply.

The magnified role of the tanker in the American merchant marine, both in peace and war, is discussed in the forthcoming issue of the Department of Commerce publication Domestic Commerce. A survey made of the merchant marine disclosed that sea-going tankers represent 38 per cent of the total tonnage in operation, and of ships under construction in American yards tankers amount to 2,054,000 gross tons, or 30 per cent of the total.

Householders and apartment dwellers can do various little things that will add greatly to the safety of their families, their neighbors and themselves in the event that bombs actually should fall in this city. The experience of London and other bombed cities has taught many lessons that have served to save lives and lessen injuries among their residents.
Local recruiting offices of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard were jammed again yesterday as hundreds of determined men of all ages sought to volunteer for service in the armed forces.

HEADQUARTERS, Ninth Infantry Division, Somewhere in the U.S.A. -- Next time you see army vehicles zooming down nicely paved highways, remember that these same command cars, jeeps, trucks and trailers are sent just as regularly over washboard roads, forgotten bumpy wagon trails, marshy fields, mud holes and streams.

J.C. Treadwell of the New York Athletic Club captured the Na- tional Squash Tennis Association's Fall B and C tournament on the City A.C. courts yesterday by defeating Newton Kutner of the City A.C., 15 -- 10, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 11.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- Should the war dictate a need for the evacuation of San Francisco, either on the basis of individual citizens or whole institutions, a plan to accomplish that end is ready to be put in immediate operation.

A SCORE of small paintings by Winslow Homer have been brought together at the Babcock Gallery. Many of these are sketches, perhaps for projected larger canvases that were never executed. They cover the period from 1865 to 1890 -- the first ("A Game of Cards") relating to the Mount-Eastman Johnson genre tradition and the last a full-fledged work in its own right -- "Winter, Prouts Neck, Maine" (reproduced on the preceding page).

The largest plant in the world devoted exclusively to the manufacture of milling machines will be introduced to public ownership this week, if market and investment conditions permit a nationwide banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and the Wisconsin Company to carry through its plans for the offering of 198,083 shares of common stock of the Kearney Trecker Corporation.

An official list of the American Roman Catholic missionaries at present stationed in the Far East war zone was made public yesterday by the national office of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, 109 East Thirty-eighth Street.

It would be a difficult task to locate a really ardent angler or hunter who did not have at least one of Van Campen Heilner's books on the shelf of his library, but we are convinced that this writer's latest book, "Our American Game Birds," is a must for every American hunter.

The offering to the public on last Tuesday morning of $5,637,450 market value of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Merck Co., Inc., established what is reported to be some sort of a precedent in Wall Street history in respect to the "timing" of a major security flotation.

TRAVEL LINES: A Christmas week cruise-tour to Colonial Virginia and Washington is announced by the Transmarine Travel Service of the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel. Leaving New York on Dec. 27 the party travels via train to Washington, steamer to Norfolk, motor to Williamsburg.

WASHINGTON. THE President of the United States. Those words designate the man who has the greatest power this world has ever known in a democracy. On his shoulders rests the burden of decisions which affect every one of his 130,000,000 fellow-citizens.
WORKS by Bach and Mozart will form the programs to be given by the New Friends of Music Orchestra at its concerts on Sunday afternoons, March 1, 8, 15, 22 and 29, in Town Hall.

COMMUNITY pride, an enormous help in traffic safety, also may be a drawback. This is especially true in accident statistics. How many persons were killed in your city in 1940, in the eleven moths of 1941? Who counted them?

The American Women's Voluntary Services announced yesterday that information about the training courses it offers might be obtained at its district offices listed below. Applicants for the Motor Corps of the organization, after registering at local units, should report to the Greater New York Headquarters at 11 East Fifty-eighth Street.

Despite the wretched weather, 17,598 persons turned out at Madison Square Garden last night for the season's inaugural college basketball double-header, in which C.C.N.Y. and L.I.U. took the measure of the Oklahoma Aggies and Oregon, respectively.

Despite the wretched weather, 17,598 persons turned out at Madison Square Garden last night for the season's inaugural college basketball double-header, in which C.C.N.Y. and L.I.U. took the measure of the Oklahoma Aggies and Oregon, respectively.

The policy of the Federal Housing Administration of recognizing only permanent changes in home building costs has helped check inflation of home values under the emergency conditions of the past eighteen months, according to an article in the quarterly issue of the Insured Mortgage Portfolio, official publication of the FHA.

The three most important military outposts of the United States are the Panama Canal, Hawaii and the Philippines. Each of them has a distinct function and plays a different role in the strategy of the war of the Pacific.

FROM Maine to Illinois (to use the present column's books only) there never has been a better turnout of well printed and well written books of verse. James Laughlin with his regular and uniformly good series of The Poet of the Month is the most helpful editor of contemporary verse, and of his poets I find Theodore Spencer much the most interesting.

A group of young good-will ambassadors are giving brief glimpses of South and Central American countries to audiences here through a plan put into action last month by the hospitality committee of Inter-America House. More than one hundred young men and women from the Southern hemisphere -- students in colleges and graduate institutions in the metropolitan area -- form the speakers' bureau which is under the chairmanship of Mrs. James B. Hollingsworth.

To establish further control over the movement of all ships in harbor and coastal waters, and guard against sabotage or attack, the commandant of the Third Naval District has issued orders covering all merchant ship activity, it was disclosed here yesterday.

A New Front Opens Suppose the land surface of the globe could be pushed together into a contiguous mass, picked up and dropped into the watery expanse known as the Pacific Ocean. Terra firma would vanish beneath those waters, for they cover an area larger than that of all the earth's continents and islands.

If there are still any blanks opposite names on your Christmas list, names of girls who would appreciate something on the glamorous side, maybe this column will be a help. It is about gift possibilities dug up with an eye to avoiding the obvious present and finding something special and not necessarily something that flattens the purse.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13--Everything as ready today for the titanic meeting at Wrigley Field tomorrow between the Chicago Bears and the Green Bay Packers except the weather man. Both teams are in excellent physical condition for their long-awaited battle for the Western championship of the National Football League, the park has been sold out to its capacity of 46,000 for four days but the weather forecast, ominously, is either a drizzle or snow flurries.

LEST careless cataloguing result in this collection of essays being placed on the shelf with other "how to" books (except Mr. Cuppy's own), It must be stated emphatically that it is utterly impractical. It offers no information as to the implications of its title, no relief to the seeker for the means of eventual oblivion.

The most extensive and most devastating war in history began a new and fiercer chapter last week. Many smaller nations followed Japan and the United States into the swift-moving "War of the Continents" and by the week-end some thirty-four countries or dominions were at war, with only a handful of neutrals still clinging to a precarious non-belligerency.

BY a remarkable stroke of unconscious timing, the exhibition of industrial camouflage, sponsored by the Civilian Camouflage Council (of which Greville Rickard, the architect, is chairman) opened about twenty-four hours after Japan's declaration of war on the United States.

Proclaimed Bill of Rights Day by President Roosevelt, tomorrow will be observed throughout the nation with solemn fervor, intensified by the fact that the document embodies those principles that America has been forced to defend in world-wide conflict.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- Puerto Rico's national forests hold much that is of interest to visitors. Luquillo, or Caribbean (as it was renamed in 1935), with its El Yunque peak, at the eastern end of the island, is the most advanced in development, and because of this and its close proximity to San Juan it gets the lion's share of attention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Faced with the problem of raising $4,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000 of new revenue in a country already carrying the heaviest tax load of its history, Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, accepted the job today with reservations.

The objectives of the Ski Union of the Americas, formed at the recent convention of the National Ski Association of America for the purpose of replacing the "Nazicontrolled" Federation Internationale de Ski in the Western Hemisphere, were outlined yesterday by Roger Langley, president of the N.S.A.
Pledges of support of the government in the war against the Axis powers came yesterday from many labor unions.

CHAMPIONS ON PARADE, an exhibition of portraits of seventy dog champions of the larger breeds, photographed by Arthur S. Mawhinney, F.R.P.S., associate of the Oval Table and president of the Miniature Camera Club, will be shown in the American Museum of Natural History from today through Jan. 4.

The annual dinner dance and en- tertainment in behalf of Colony House, Inc., of Brooklyn will be held next Saturday in the main ballroom of the Hotel Commodore. The occasion will mark the twenty-eighth anniversary of the founding of the beneficiary by Mrs. John L. Swan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The sinking of four dreadnaughts, Japanese, British and American, in the Battle of the Pacific amid impressive reports of the effectiveness of aerial bombers aroused Congressional demands today for a reappraisal of the warship-airplane controversy.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Viscount and Lady Halifax, William C. Bullitt, former Ambassador to France; Governor and Mrs. Arthur H. James and Mayor and Mrs. Bernard Samuel are among the patrons for the New Year's Eve ball to be given at the Bellevue-Stratford under the auspices of the Foreign Relief and Home Defense Divisions of the Emergency Aid of Pennsylvania.

The flowering plants of Christmas time are among the jolliest aspects of this merry season. For those who "have everything," for those who have almost nothing, and for all the in-betweeners who delight in growing things, there is no gift more welcome.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 13 -- Whatever isolationist sentiment Minnesota Congressmen may have reflected in their votes during the past few months disappeared with Japan's attack and the declaration of war on the United States by the Axis.

LOS ANGELES -- "Into the snow by Christmas" is the unofficial slogan of 200,000 California ski enthusiasts who have been rarin' to go ever since the first Autumn leaf turned yellow. The 1941-42 season offers the biggest Winter sports program in California's history.

NORTH CREEK -- Visitors returning to North Creek will find the most spectacular improvements made since the little Adirondack village loomed into the Winter sports world almost ten years ago. These are in the main the result of a WPA project costing $35,000, which is rapidly nearing completion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Some seven tons of muscle and murderous intentions, the Chicago Bears and the Green Bay Packers, await the opportunity of committing legal assault and battery on each other at Wrigley Field tomorrow afternoon. Whenever those rivals get together, they never fool. They play for keeps.

The Florida racing season will begin on Saturday with the renewal of the sport at Tropical Park, where a new regime will try its luck with the race course which hap been the stormy petrel of the sport in the Peninsula State.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 13 -- The British have retired slightly in the State of Kedah, it was indicated here today. There was no confirmation of rumors of Japanese landing attempts in Southern Malaya.

In his first interview with the American press Ambassador Litvinoff answered the question this country has been asking during the long, eventful week since the Japanese launched their attack in the Pacific. Russia is going to concentrate on the Moscow front; for the present, at least, she is not joining the other powers in the Far Bast in fighting Japan.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Abandonment of the Rose Bowl game cast considerable disappointment today over this site of the historic New Year's Day classic, but the reason -- the war -- was thoroughly and patriotically understood by all.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- Cancellation of the Rose Bowl game between Oregon State College and Duke University, scheduled for New Year's Day, was announced today following a conference of football officials with Lieut. Gen. John L. DeWitt, head of the Western Defense Command.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman presided in the sanctuary at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, the administrator, led the congregation of 2,500 in reciting aloud the pledge of the Legion of Decency.

Operations of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 resulted in a consolidated net profit of $809,258 after all charges including Federal taxes but before provision for preferred dividend requirements, according to the annual report of Joseph W. Frazer, president, which will be mailed today to stock-holders.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, Dec. 15 (Australian Associated Press) - A communique issued today by the Royal Australian Air Force reported that within the last few days Japanese planes bad been seen over New Guinea, large island north of Australia, and the Bismarck Archipelago, east of New Guinea. Australian air patrols sighted the Japanese, the communique added, but the enemy disappeared before they could be intercepted.

The world's largest photo-mural, symbolizing the defense of America and her traditions, was dedicated yesterday in the Grand Central Terminal with a stirring ceremony conducted under the auspices of the United States Treasury Department and attended by 3,000 persons.

Basing his instructions on how to act in air raids upon the practical experience he received in the four weeks he spent in Britain last Summer, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell told his congregation yesterday morning that he believed "there is not the remotest possibility of New York receiving more than a small fraction, of the damage that London, for instance, has suffered."

VICHY, Dec. 14 -- On last Monday the Bourse faced two laws published on the previous day affecting transfers of French and foreign stocks. Their character was a surprise in view of rumors which had been current. It had been said that there would be a reduction in the tax on excess profits on stocks bought since last March.

Thousands of New York unionists will gather tonight at a "Defend America" rally in Madison Square Garden. The rally, under the sponsorship of the Greater New York Industrial Union Council of the C.I.O., will be the first mass gathering of workers in this city to pledge support to the national war effort.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Portugal is in an increasingly precarious position as the war develops, and her political independence and territorial integrity in the last analysis will probably be determined by the needs of the Axis military strategy, the Foreign Policy Association reported in a special survey today.

TOKYO, Dec. 14 (From Japanese broadcasts) -- The Japanese opened a general land and air offensive against Hong Kong at dawn today in an all-out effort to take the British Crown colony after rejection of an ultimatum for surrender.

Responses to the call for volunteer civilian defense workers were recorded yesterday from the Girl Scouts, the Association of the Junior Leagues of America, and the Beekman Hill unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- A proposal for the Institution of a scheme for the rationing of man power as a step toward Insuring increased production emerged today while the Ministry of Labor issued a call for more scrap metal and it was indicated that compulsory powers might shortly be accorded the Ministry of Works for speeding up its collection.

Warning of the approach of raiders will be sounded by the sirens of police and fire apparatus -- one long and one short blast alternately for five minutes. The all-clear signal will be sounded by the same apparatus and will consist of a series of short blasts over a five-minute period.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll calls in Congress during the period Dec. 6 to 12 are given in the appended tabulation:

The cotton market fluctuated nervously last week as a result of the outbreak of war between this country and the Axis powers. Trading, however, was orderly. On the New York Cotton Exchange active future deliveries showed net declines for the week of 43 to 53 points.

Describing the "spirit and courage" of Columbia University in these difficult days as "of the highest order," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, the president, predicted yesterday, in his annual report to the trustees on the condition and needs of the university that Columbia would become one of the greatest intellectual centers in the world.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- This is the story of Moscow and its people, who for ten bitter weeks gallantly withstood the greatest massed military assault in all history. Seven hundred and fifty thousand men, bearing with them a monstrous array of tanks, aircraft and all the many death-dealing instruments conceived by the ingenious Nazi mind, thundered close to the city limits and beat savagely upon the gates. They did not pass.

While voicing approval of the Rapp-Coudert committee's revelations concerning the activities of an "irresponsible minority" of the faculty, Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, revealed yesterday his disappointment with the committee's work on the problem of student activity, which he declared "seems to have been less well advised" and brought out "little that was not already known."

Because flying glass splinters in the vicinity of an exploding bomb are among the most serious hazards of an air raid, the Office of Civilian Defense has had prepared, under the direction of the Chief of Engineers, United States Army, a pamphlet dealing with methods of protecting window and roof openings to minimize danger.
MANILA, Monday, Dec. 15 -- United States Army bombers badly damaged two Japanese transports yesterday off Legaspi, on Luzon Island 250 miles southeast of Manila, Army Headquarters announced today.
VICHY, France, Dec. 14 -- "The French Government has made known its sentiments regarding the latest measures of repression taken by the German occupying authorities."

"Extravagant economy" is a foolishness that must not be indulged in if this nation is to function at a fine point of efficiency during the days to come. And one of the most serious manifestations of false economy, demonstrated during the First World War, is the partial elimination of meats from the normal diet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Cash wheat and futures went to new four-year high prices last week. The outbreak of hostilities in the Pacific and declarations of war against the United States by Germany and Italy brought a flood of buying orders for flour from the domestic trade, which in turn was reflected by a removal of hedges against the grain needed by mills to fill the flour orders.

The Bank for Savings sold to Hettie Epstein the two-family dwelling on a plot 30 by 100 feet at 2154 East Twenty-third Street, Brooklyn, for cash over a purchase money mortgage of $4.700. The parcel is assessed at $9,500 and was sold through Hy D. Agar, Inc., brokers.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Informed circles here tonight said that Britain would place no obstacle in the path of members of the American Eagle squadrons of the Royal Air Force or United States citizens in other units of British armed forces who wished to transfer to United States service.
The first week of the War of the World ended yesterday in a sprawling aeries of bitter engagements in the Western Pacific and with new moves impending in Europe and the Atlantic.

CORK, Eire, Dec. 14 -- When Premier Eamon de Valera came to this southern capital today to review an impressive parade of the Regular Army and volunteer defense forces he made his first public reference to the United States entry into the World War and its effects upon the policy of his government.

A five-event program featured the Indoor swimming season's first open A.A.U. water carnival in the London Terrace pool yesterday. Miss Gloria Callen, the national outdoor back-stroke champion, failed to annex her specialty because of liberal handicap allowances, but she accounted for the fastest time, 1:10.7.

A demonstration to symbolize the solidarity of all the nations of the Western Hemisphere with the United States was held yesterday afternoon when seventy-five members of the Inter-American Cultural Association participated in a wreath-laying ceremony at the foot of the equestrian statue of Simon Bolivar, Central Park West at Eighty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (Reuter) -- The United States entry into the war will surely considerably influence women's fashions. The general amplification of styles that followed upon the eclipse of Paris will probably continue. In any event it is pretty safe to prophesy that some extreme creations that emanated from New York and Hollywood in recent months will be supplemented by chic but essentially sensible and practical clothes.

TO THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES : The Navy, no doubt, will find many things to learn from what has happened at Hawaii, but for the country at large j the immediate lesson is to be on guard against pessimistic conclusions. An overwhelming surprise has inevitably brought a strong undercurrent of rumor and speculation and pseudo-confidential disclosures.

The need for greatly increasing the number of women engaged in courses of instruction that will lead to fitting them for jobs in defense industries and for expanding the training facilities of women's trade schools throughout the State was emphasized yesterday in the report of a survey made by the State Employment Service and the Division of Women in Industry and Minimum Wage.

John Haynes Holmes, minister of the Community Church, offered his undated, resignation yesterday after telling 1,200 members of his congregation that he could not use his ministry to "bless, sanction, or support war."

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 14 -- Byron (Lord) Nelson, gaunt ex-Texan, now serving as pro at the Inverness Club in Toledo, and considered by many the greatest shot-maker of the era, today annexed the fourth "big money" tournament of his career by winning the annual Miami $10,000 open with one of the most sensational finishes in the history of the golf event.

A large property at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge has passed to new hands with the sale by the Bank for Savings of the fourteen-story and penthouse loft building at 216-218 William Street to an investing client of the Kempner Realty Corporation.

Because of the war the city will no longer claim exemption of policemen called for military duty under the selective service regulations, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in an address to 200 new patrolmen, members of the first "war class" of the Police Academy.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Directors of the East-West contest, bringing together senior college stars and held here annually for the benefit of the Shrine Hospital for Crippled Children, tonight canceled local arrangements for the game at the request of General DeWitt.

Thoughts of native land and family predominate in the minds of the seventy French seamen from the liner Normandie who have been quartered since Saturday night in the Seamen's House Y.M.C.A., 550 West Twentieth Street.

Two hunndred and fifty boys and girls between the ages of 13 and 17 assembled yesterday in Queens to be instructed in the requirements of junior air wardens and to make an initial enrollment for service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Soaring prices for lard, with a maximum advance of around 60 cents a hundred weight induced by the quick change in American relations with Japan, Germany and Italy, came to an abrupt halt on Saturday with an announcement that the Office of Price Administration had placed ceilings on oils and fats.
ROME, Dec. 14 (From an Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique issued today follows:

WHEN one recalls what a strange razzle-dazzle major league meetings are, even in normal times, it ought not to be difficult to picture the sort of turmoil that exists when one of these sessions is held in a moment of great national crisis. It is still a merry-go-round, but with the horses not only going up and down but backward and forward, round and round and hindside first.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 14 -- Charles M. Howell Sr., who for many years was the law partner of former Senator James A. Reed, learned about the principles of the Democratic party while a youth on a farm. His father was judge of the County Court and a Democratic leader for many years.

Civilian defense preparations and enlistments in the nation's armed forces were "greatly accelerated" in New York's four municipal colleges during the first week of the war against the Axis, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education.

Christmas buying fell off in the wholesale market last week. While there was a lull in dress activity early in the week, reorders started to roll in for popular-priced merchandise later. All types of casual costumes were stressed. Medium-priced Spring coats and suits had a good demand.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Despite clear and cold weather, which is reported to have increased harvesting operations, prices of corn were on the upgrade last week on the Board of Trade here and closing sales yesterday, while somewhat under the top, showed gains of 2 1/2 to 3 cents a bushel for the week.

The nation pauses today to observe the 150th anniversary of the Bill of Rights. The meanings of that document have never been clearer than now. Never before have we seen so plainly that a world ruled by its principles can be a world of light, liberty and life, and that a world in which they are denied is doomed to darkness, slavery and death.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 -- A declaration by Mme. Maxim Litvinoff, British-born wife of the Soviet Ambassador, that "our war is your war, just as your war is our war," marked a Russian war relief rally which packed the Boston Arena today with 10,000 cheering persons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- "Listening Post," a story of radio pick-up stations which listen for foreign broadcasts and signals of enemy aircraft, has been purchased by Paramount from Edward Haldeman and will be prepared for immediate production by Sol C. Siegel.

The necessity "to think now about the kind of post-war world in which America would be willing to share," was emphasized by the Rev. Dr. Bverett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, in an address yesterday morning at Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street, near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Taking off and landing in the face of possible Japanese air attacks, United States and Chinese pilots ferried more than 275 persons out of beleaguered Hong Kong during the first two nights of the Japanese siege.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- The Red Army has punched a gaping hole in the German lines west of Elets and Livny and advanced several more miles in the general direction of Orel, cutting off the rear of retreating German divisions and pounding at their weakened flanks with a large force of tanks.

The winning of the war will depend, to a great extent, upon physical fitness, Miss Alice Marble, former tennis champion, now assistant director of physical fitness in the Office of Civilian Defense, declared in a statement made before she left last night for a tour of the nine military and civilian defense regions of the country.
MANILA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A communique issued at 5 P.M. today at the headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Douglas MacArthur, commander of the United States Far Eastern Army, follows:
BERLIN, Dec. 14 (From a German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today follows:

In a volume that will be released by Columbia University Press late this month, twenty-six scholars approach the subject of war from five positions -- from its causes, strategy and tactics, effect upon the concept of neutrality, its larger influence on social institutions and (this book was planned before the previous week's events) the implications of the present war to the United States.
NELS ISLAND, Conn., Dec. 14 -- Yesterday ended the waterfowl season in Connecticut for this year, and if ever there was a duck shooting day this last one certainly qualified.

Mayor La Guardla has bean named honorary chairman of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York and will be active in the drive to raise $7,330,000 here toward the $50,000,000 war fund for the American Red Cross, Leon Fraser, chairman of the five-borough appeal, announced yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 14 (Reuter) -- "The Navy will surmount this set-back. Never fear, the enemy will be repaid."

Although the reservoirs that supply New York City obtained about 15,000,000,000 gallons of water from the heavy rain Saturday that drenched the metropolitan area, Patrick Quilty, Commissioner of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, repeated yesterday his warning to house-holders to conserve water.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices reached another new 1929-41 high of 100.1. Gains occurred in the prices of several commodities, chiefly in agricultural groups as usual. Higher prices, especially for livestock, but also for eggs, grains and cottonseed oil accounted for most of the 1.3 per cent gain in the major raw materials index and the 2.3 per cent gain in farm products.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The United States, engaged in a war against what President Roosevelt has called the Axis challenge to "life, liberty and civilization," will commemorate tomorrow the anniversary of adoption of the Bill of Rights -- funndamental charter of liberties.

In the first week this country was at war 40,555 New Yorkers enrolled as air raid wardens, according' to figures made available at Police Headquarters yesterday,' which showed that from a normal daily enrollment of 145 in the preceding: week the applications shot up to a peak of 9,061 last Thursday.

War in the Pacific had a mixed effect on the foreign exchange last week, with the Chinese currencies holding steady around prevailing levels, while the South Americans showed gains at the expense of a corresponding decline in the American dollar.
An appeal to Canada and the United States not to "let England down" while fighting: a common enemy in the Pacific was voiced here last night by Lelghton McCarthy, Canadian Minister to Washington.
KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 14 -- The Irish - Americans defeated St. Mary's Celtic, 4 -- 3 , in their American Soccer League match at Scots Field today. At half time the teams were deadlocked, 3 -- 3.

The standard form of insurance upon homes and other property specifically excludes losses resulting from the hazards of war. A citizen whose house is insured against the ordinary risks would find himself unprotected if it were set on fire by an incendiary bomb.

Combating age and experience with superior speed and passing, the New York Rovers handed the rugged Johntown (Pa.) Bluebirds a 5-to-4 setback yesterday afternoon in the Eastern Hockey League feature at Madison Square Garden and catapulted into first place.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 14 -- Stalled for two periods, the Long Island Indians marched fifty-nine yards in a sustained drive to score a touchdown in the third period today and eke out a 7 -- 6 decision over the Jersey City Giants in the semi-final round of the American Football Association play-offs.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : We are now in an official state of war induced by the aggression of militaristio Japan. The conflict -- long since fore-tokened as a protracted one -- may very soon be extended to cover Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Slim, fair-haired Draja Mikliailovitch, a mere colonel in the Yugoslav Army before the Germans overran his country, has been raised to the rank of full general in recognition of his "magnificent work" in organizing resistance to the Nazi occupation, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Eleven auxiliary military airfields will be developed in New York at a cost of $5,369,595.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces driving to relieve besieged Hong Kong are within thirteen miles of the border of the British Crown Colony on the northeast, according to a Central Daily News dispatch from Shiukwan, in Kwangtung Province.

BOSTON. Dec. 14 -- On the quarterdeck of "Old Ironsides," the most famous warship in American history, the Navy held solemn memorial services today for the 100 hero-dead of the United States destroyer Reuben James, first American warship lost in the conflict that now has engaged this country.

The Trapp Family Singers returned to Town Hall yesterday afternoon to give the first of two Christmas concerts. Like those they gave last year, it included motets and other church music, folksong's, early music for recorders, virginal and viola da gamba, and a final group of carols which were sung seated around a candlelit table.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Japan's entry into the war a week ago today had astonishingly little effect on the stock markets here. No development comparable in importance ever had smaller "reactions. Although Japan's final decision came as something of a shock to financial circles, it had lost its potency from the earlier trend of events, which recently had led the markets to anticipate the worst while still hoping for the best.

ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Although 430 law students passed the October examinations for admission to the bar, the names of only 397 out of a total of 885 applicants, will be certified to the Appellate Divisions of the State, according to an announcement today by the Board of Law Examiners, composed of John Kirkland Clark of New York City, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and John T. DeGraff of Albany.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Turkey today notified the United States she would remain neutral in the "new conflict which has just broken out.''

The subscribers to the regular concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra have bought all the individual seats for the series of six Beethoven concerts which Arturo Toscanini will conduct at the end of the present season. A few boxes in the lower tier are all that remain unsold.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Frederick Elmes will give a reception on the afternoon of Dec. 29 at their home, 1067 Fifth Avenue, to introduce their daughter, Miss Cecily Elmes.

Max Gordon has consented to give Morris Carnovsky, a leading actor in his hit comedy, "My Sister Eileen," a leave of absence to appear in "The Crown Cafe." Mr. Carnovsky will retire from "Eileen" after Thursday night's performance. His role will be taken over the next night by Louis Sorin.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- German Stuka bombers and Nazi pilots were shot down together with Japanese by the defenders of Oahu in last Sunday's sudden attack on that Hawaiian Island, according to an eyewitness account of the raid by Dr. Bernard Witlin, United States Health Service bacteriologist, stationed at Honolulu, in a letter to his sister, Mrs. Samuel Weisfeld, 5718 North Marvine Street.

The sports council of the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday appealed yesterday through its chairman, Grantland Rice, to 10,000 high school coaches and college athletic directors throughout the nation to aid the 1941-42 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign.

The most distressed folk in all the city -- large families staggering under repeated illnesses, homeless children, lonely men and women fighting to rehabilitate themselves -- whose cases are cited by eight leading private charities, received gifts of only $4,420.25 yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 14 -- Germany is facing an internal crisis of extreme gravity, according to reports reaching Stockholm today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The world champion Bruins rallied against the Black Hawks with two goals in the third period of a National Hockey League game tonight to tie the score at 3 -- 3.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 14 -- Despite determined German - Italian rearguard actions west and south of El Gasala, the British main forces drove farther westward yesterday. New Zealanders covering the Axis troops trapped in El Gazala, thirty-five miles west of Tobruk, continued to close in on them.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 14 -- British and Australian air forces that were credited with smashing Japanese landing attempts on the eastern coast of Malaya have been hurled against Japanese tanks and armored cars in an attempt to stem the drive southward from Thailand on both sides of the Malay Peninsula, it was reported tonight.

In launching a drive to raise $500,000 for the Army and Navy Commission of the Protestant Episcopal Church the Right Rev. Henry Knox Sherrill, Bishop of Massachusetts and chairman of tne commission, chided those church members who respond generously to war effort appeals but neglect to help meet the spiritual needs of the men in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Today, a week after Japan launched her deadly surprise attack, the United States Marines on Wake Island were still resisting and were striking back at the Japanese. A Navy Department communique' announced there had been two additional bombing attacks on this mid-Pacific fragment of American territory, second of three important stepping stones between Hawaii and the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- War Department officials made clear today that it would be a long time -- perhaps never -- before any men outside the 21-35 age group were drafted for the Army despite the proposal to require all men from 18 to 64, inclusive, to register.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Clarke H. Kawakami, for seven years a correspondent for Domei, the official Japanese news agency, today denounced Japan's treacherous attack on the United States as "the blackest and most shameful page in Japanese history."

SAN FRANCICSCO, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- Following the cancellation of the Rose Bowl football game today, immediate negotiations were started to play the Oregon State-Duke contest on Jan. 1 in an area outside the Western Defense Command jurisdiction.

WATERVILLE, Me., Dec. 14 -- Coincident with the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the American Bill of Rights, Colby College announced today that its effort to obtain funds for erecting an auditorium memorializing Elijah Parish Lovejoy, America's first martyr to the freedom of the press, will be sponsored by a committee headed by Herbert Hoover, and include nationally known newspaper publishers and members of the Lovejoy family.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- The Navy's representative in the Sugar Bowl service football game withdrew today, hoping for an invitation again "when conditions permit."
Reluctant to place the Police Department on an emergency schedule. Police Commissioner Valentine will start active organization this week of an auxiliary force of at least 15,000 men.

Because of President Roosevelt's "sincere and far-sighted" good-neighbor policy, Mexico is a firm friend to the United States and is fully capable of controlling any Nazi or Japanese subversive activities within its borders, Josephus Daniels, former Ambassador to Mexico, said here yesterday in an interview in the Hotel Plaza.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 14 -- Bulgaria's declaration of war against the United States and Great Britain, coupled with greatly intensified military activity in Bulgaria, preoccupied Turkish and foreign diplomatic and military circles here throughout the week-end.

In accordance with the proclamation of President Roosevelt designating this as Bill of Rights Day, New York City will celebrate the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Bill of Rights today with a program of patriotic rallies and other events extending from morning until night.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 14 The German and Italian war bulletins continue to give a minimum of information about land fighting in North Africa, although both agree today in saying that attacks by British troops on Axis forces in the region, west of Tobruk were repulsed.

Leaders in the drive to sell defense bonds and stamps are to meet tomorrow for a two-day conference in Chicago with Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. and Harold Graves of the United States Treasury. Nevil Ford, New York State administrator, announced yesterday that workers in this area were in the midst of a three-day meeting to prepare for the conference in Chicago.

Artur Rodzinski was on the podium for the last time this season as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at its concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The program he had arranged contained two special features. One of these was the performance of the Sibelius concerto by Carroll Glenn, 22-year-old violinist from South Carolina, who was entitled to this appearance as winner of the Schubert Memorial Award for 1941.
The city's program for civilian defense moved steadily forward yesterday, with Mayor La Guardia at the controls and City Hall buzzing with activity.

Rudolf Firkusny, Czech pianist, was heard in a recital last night in Town Hall, where he had made his sole previous appearance here three years ago. In the interim the youthful artist had developed a definite style of his own and a far more imaginative approach.

Official confirmation of the tremendous batting feats performed by Ted Williams of the Red Sox and Joe DiMaggio of the world champion Yankees will come as no surprise even to casual observers of the doings in the American League in 1941.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 14 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Two more Japanese ships were sunk today off the east coast of Malaya by submarines of the Royal Netherlands Navy, a communique of the Navy Commander in Chief announced today.
Santa Claus Under Convoy It is sad to think that Santa Claus has to travel under convoy when he goes from the United States to Britain, but it is good to know that he can still make a happy landing.
Men by hundreds continued yesterday to volunteer their services to the Army, the Navy, the Marine Corps and the Coast Guard as recruiting offices remained open.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 -- The steel industry went last week on a strict war footing, with first reactions in the trade pointing toward complete cutting off of non-essential steel requirements.

The publicity concern of Constance Hope Associates, which numbered many leading musicians and operatic singers among its clients, has closed its offices at 29 West Fifty-seventh Street because of labor difficulties, it became known yesterday.
Rounding out a career of thirty-one years in public service, Magistrate Michael A. Ford announced yesterday his resignation from the bench, effective with the expiration of his term on Dec. 31.

TOKYO, Dec. 14 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- Domei, the Japanese news agency, quoted a Shanghai dispatch to the newspaper Asahi regarding the planned drive on Singapore, adding that Japanese planes were raiding such targets as the world's largest graving dock at the base.

MANILA, Dec. 14 -- Rear Admiral Francis W. Rockwell, commandant of the Sixteenth Naval District, narrowly escaped death in the bombing of Cavite last Wednesday. A Filipino workman near him in an air raid ditch was killed.
