Since the outbreak of the war last week, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross has registered 1,000 applicants daily for first-aid training, Captain Charles B. Scully, first aid-service director, reported yesterday to General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the chapter.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 14 (Reuter) -- There is no doubt that a major battle is going on in the Kedah area of Malaya, although official communiques are very cryptic and give no details about it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- Coincident with the issuance here today by the Army of an official communique declaring that "enemy aircraft" apparently had dropped flares over the San Francisco Bay region during Friday night's long blackout, a Pan American clipper brought in safely from Hawaii the first group of air passengers to reach the mainland since Japan began hostilities last Sunday.
AN absorbing and significant Negro study by Melville J. Herskovits has just appeared: "The Myth of the Negro Past."*

When Maxim Litvinoff left Russia to take up his duties as Soviet Ambassador to Washington the Nazi Wehrmacht was hammering at the very gates of his nation's capital. Now German forces are in retreat from the Black Sea to the Arctic; and Japan and the United States are at war, with this country aligned with Russia and Great Britain against the European end of the Axis as well.

John S. McClelland of Atlanta, Ga., Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, has telegraphed to President Roosevelt a pledge of "an all-out effort" on the part of the 500,000 members of the Elks to assist the government throughout the war, it was announced here yesterday.

Since the time has come to act, let us mobilize at once for this great struggle the full manpower of the country. Committees of Congress will report today a measure calling for the registration of every man in the United States between the ages of 18 and 64. That measure should be adopted as the first elementary step to be taken in the defense of American freedom.

Confidence in America's "ultimate, smashing victory" in this war was voiced by the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers in a statement released yesterday to mark the 150th anniversary of the adoption of the Bill of Rights.

Rossini's "II Barbiere di Siviglia" will receive its first presentation of the season next week (the fifth) at the Metropolitan Opera House. Lawrence Tibbett, who sang the role recently in San Francisco, but has never sung it here, will take the part of Figaro;

Formation of an emergency "Committee of 100," composed of 119 civic and business leaders who will help conserve man power in the New York area through a program planned to reduce accidents in New York homes, plants and on the streets, was announced yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council.

The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, through Edward M.M. Warburg, chairman, explained yesterday in a message to community leaders throughout the country how it would continue to function under wartime conditions.

The possibility of food shortages will in no way affect America's high food standards, it was predicted here yesterday by Colonel H.A. Toulmln Jr., a lawyer and an authority on Federal food legislation. Colonel Toulmin pointed out that Federal agencies have more control than ever over labeling and urged consumers to become "label readers" to keep unscrupulous manufacturers from introducing low standard foods during the emergency.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 14 (U.P) --Two strong earth shocks rocked this capital at 5:40 A. M. today, as President Manuel Prado Ugarteche and other government officials were preparing to leave for Huaraz. The earth tremors caused panic among the population, but no casualties or damage were reported.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (U.P.) -- The Sunday Dispatch demanded today that Eire grant naval bases to Britain and the United States, to ease the strain of the Allied navies, intensified by losses suffered at Pearl Harbor and in the China Sea.

The quiet of Sunday morning in some parts of the metropolitan area was shattered yesterday by the reverberations of a factory explosion in Edgewater, N. J., that killed one man, injured another and created the impression that an aerial blitzkrieg had started.

Many of the problems that are of such immediate importance to Mr. and Mrs. John Doe and their children during an air raid alarm were raised yesterday at the first meeting of the Bronx Civilian Defense Committee, at which an attempt was made not only to evaluate national and local plans but also to apply them to individual needs.

The suddenness with which the United States, while peace proposals were still officially discussed, was swept into war last week by Sunday's Japanese attack on our Pacific possessions left the financial mind in some bewilderment. It is probable that we have even yet been unable clearly to take the reckoning; but the feeling was rather general that financial markets had on the whole behaved themselves rather better than might have been expected.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Office of Civilian Defense made public today emergency instructions for school teachers and pupils in the event of air raids.

She inquired about selling two flags. They had been given to her husband upon his discharge from the Union forces in the War Between the States. Carefully protected in a glass case, they had been the family's prize possession, occupying the parlor's position of honor down through many years.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A tremendous waterslide that struck the departmental capital of Huaraz yesterday took a toll of more than 500 lives and wiped out the city's entire residential section, according to reports reaching here today.
Following is a transcript of Mayor La Guardia's speech, delivered last night from his office at City Hall over WNYC and other stations:

Predicting a long tight, and without minimizing the dangers that are confronting this country, Lieut. Gov. Charles Poletti warned yesterday that "we must accept our Individual responsibilities and saorificies." He addressed an all-day meeting of the Hias Council of Organizations at Central Plaza Hall, 111 Second Avenue.
DETROIT, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The speedy Toronto Maple Leafs blasted the Detroit Red Wings for a 4-to-0 victory tonight in a National Hockey Leagne battle before 10,888 fans.

A plea against war hysteria on the part of those in charge of college sports was expressed yesterday by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics at Princeton University, at the annual meeting of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association at the Hotel Lincoln.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The only thing hot today was the Chicago Bears. The Monsters from the Midway routed Green Bay, 33 to 14, before a chilled gathering of 43,425 on the snow-fringed gridiron at Wrigley Field, thus won the Western championship of the National Football League and gained the right to meet the Giants here next Sunday for the world professional crown.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Because of the war, the Maritime Commission decreed today that henceforth merchant ships will be launched without fanfare.

There is a woman "general" in the United States Army. She is stationed at Fort Monmouth, N.J., headquarters for the Signal Corps, wears a brigadier general's stars and is accorded the salutes due an officer of that rank by the 1,200 men under her command.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Designation of Civilian Conservation Corps camps, equipment and personnel for emergency use in the event of mass evacuation caused by enemy action was disclosed today in an agreement between the CCC and the Red Cross.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 -- Unexplained anti-aircraft fire in Los Angeles, a radio blackout, an air raid alert and the fatal wounding of a woman motorist by an Army sentry brougnt intensified realization of the war to Southern California today.

Industry is ready to meet all the requirements that the nation will put on it, Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management, said last night at a dinner of the woolen and clothing division of the merged campaign of the New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities.

There is a woman "general" in the United States Army. She is stationed at Fort Monmouth, N.J., headquarters for the Signal Corps, wears a brigadier general's stars and is accorded the salutes due an officer of that rank by the 1,200 men under her command.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Designation of Civilian Conservation Corps camps, equipment and personnel for emergency use in the event of mass evacuation caused by enemy action was disclosed today in an agreement between the CCC and the Red Cross.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 -- Unexplained anti-aircraft fire in Los Angeles, a radio blackout, an air raid alert and the fatal wounding of a woman motorist by an Army sentry brougnt intensified realization of the war to Southern California today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Treasury, which a week ago took custody of many Japanese enterprises in the United States and stopped all Japanese financial and commercial transactions, today relaxed to some extent these and other restrictions.

Lew Jenkins of Sweetwater, Texas, yesterday reached the tapering-off stage in training for the defense of his world lightweight title Friday night hi Madison Square Garden against Sammy Angott of Washington, Pa., who is recognized as champion by the National Boxing Association.

In Boston yesterday officers of Little, Brown Co. and the Atlantic Monthly Company signed a fifty-year contract that will continue the publishing collaboration of the two houses. Since 1925 Little, Brown has brought out books under a joint imprint of the firm and the Atlantic Monthly Press.

As a precaution against air raids, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, one of the world's great treasuries of art, will evacuate some of its "most irreplaceable objects," but will keep the great bulk of its collections in its own galleries, safeguarded by special measures.

The 150th anniversary of the Bill of Rights was celebrated grimly by an America at war yesterday with warnings that the nation is engaged in an "all-out fight" against the "irreconcilable enemies of freedom" and that we must "win the war or lose our freedom."

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- Smashing through ever-weakening German lines of defense, Soviet troops continued their brilliant operations in the fighting yesterday, recapturing Klin, important rail point on the Moscow-Leningrad line, and three communications centers south of Moscow.

Death Reported Retired Fireman William Rosenow, formerly a member of Engine Co. 275, residing at 248-32 88th Road, Bellerose, Queens, died Dec. 13. Funeral from George Werst Funeral Parlor. 71-41 Cooper Ave., Glendale, Queens, 2:45 P.M. Wednesday, Dec. 17. Interment Evergreen Cemetery.

SUNGEI PATANI, North Malaya, Dec. 14 (Delayed) -- Against Japanese based on airdromes in Thailand that apparently had been prepared for them long before the attack on Malaya began, British, Australian and Netherland air units in this region are putting up courageous and effective opposition. One Royal Air Force source told me that the Japanese were op- erating from five different airfields in Southern Thailand within forty-eight hours after the war broke out.
The Times Square area had two practice air-raid alarms yesterday morning for the benefit of newsreel camera men.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- A continued Japanese advance in the northernmost Malay State of Kedah was reported in dispatches from the front tonight, but the people took cheer in news that opposition by British fighter planes had halted air raids on the Island of Penang.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Soy beans dropped today the permissible limit of 6 cents a bushel for the second straight day on the Board of Trade with scattered longs intent on getting out of their holding's. While there was a fair demand short after the opening which lifted prices somewhat above the low levels, all deliveries were offered at the low point when the market closed.

A collection of 150 weeds and grasses that irritate the skin and thus play the role of fifth columnists against our military forces was exhibited yesterday at the opening sessions of the American Academy of Dermatology and Syphilology at the Waldorf Astoria.
Arundel Corporation An extra dividend of 50 cents together with the regular quarterly of 25 cents were announced by the Arundel Corporation.
There is one item that seems to be on the Christmas shopping list of every woman -- blackout cloth for curtains.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The United States plans to ship vast quantities of eggs in the shells to Britain in the next few months despite the shortage of refrigerated boats and the disastrous results reported last Spring, it was revealed today in a Department of Agriculture warning to concerns selling eggs to the government to watch their packing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 Republican Presidential nominee, had luncheon with President Roosevelt today, reviewed initial American reverses in the Battle of the Pacific and told reporters later that damage to the Navy had been serious "but not enough to destroy American effectiveness in the defeat of Japan and her Axis partners."

The Christmas Week schedule of Broadway openings has undergone further revision because "Brooklyn, U.S.A.," advanced its premiere from next Tuesday to Sunday at the Forrest. This move permits "Letters to Lucerne" to have Tuesday evening to itself.

Accused of homicide, leaving the scene of an accident and drunken driving, Gable O. Maros, 34 years old, of 103-15 130th Street, Richmond Hill, was arraigned yesterday in Queens Felony Court in the death of Frank Van Ness, 77, of 73-34 Sixty-seventh Drive, Middle Village, who played Santa Claus each year at many of the community clubs.

New York's historic 130-year-old City Hall, one of the outstanding pieces of Italian Renaissance architecture in the country, underwent a violent transformation yesterday as Mayor La Guardia converted it into a wartime headquarters for his staff of volunteer civilian defense aides.

An underwriting group headed by Smith, Barney Co. offered to the public yesterday afternoon an issue of $2,500,000 of fifteen-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures of General Shoe Corporation. The debentures, which will mature on Dec. 1, 1956, were priced at 99 and accrued interest.

Albert Hirachfeld, with whose work readers of THE TIMES drama pages are so familiar, is having a one-man show at the Guy Mayer Gallery, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street. It opened with a beer and frankfurter party yesterday afternoon, and will continue, minus the refreshments but otherwise intact, until Jan. 3.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 -- Attempting to slow down or halt the British advance in Libya, German tanks and truck-borne infantry counter-attacked twice yesterday and were twice repulsed. Driving forward in a cold drizzle despite fierce opposition, British armored forces moved farther westward in the area southwest of El Gazala.

Lily Pons made her first appearance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night in Leo Delibes's "Lakme," the opera which was revived for her in 1932 and which has since been kept in the repertoire every season except 1937-38 as a stellar vehicle.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As an example of what our undergraduates are thinking and saying in these difficult days, I believe that many of your readers will be interested in this editorial comment of the Bryn Mawr College News, published under the title of "What Sureties?"

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- A call for home economists and nutrition experts, who would direct the feeding of civilians driven from heavily populated areas by air raids, was made today from New York defense officials.

Except for an early spurt of activity, during which prices rose as much as 35 points, or $1.75 a bale, the cotton market yesterday was quiet. Final quotations of active features on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 17 to 26 points, or 85 cents to $1.30 a bale, over Saturday's close.

While the world's attention has been focused during the Fall on the growing tension in the Pacific and the start of actual hostilities there, Germany has considerably increased the efficiency of her antiaircraft guns with the aid of a new and, in some ways unusual development, according to reports from abroad.

Aided by an extra Sunday, newspaper advertising linage throughout the country registered a substantial gain last month. In fiftytwo cities measured by Media Records, Inc., linage rose 6.6 per cent, bringing the gain for the year to date to 3.7 per cent.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- After nine days of a war that at first they could not realize was war the Filipino people have now become throughly aroused at the temerity of the Japanese threat to their promised independence.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, once the boy wonder of billiards and now -- at 54 -- one of the patriarchs of the sport, will defend his world three-cushion title in a tournament at Chicago starting Jan. 12.

Acting on Governor Lehman's decree that State laws governing hours of employment shall be relaxed for the duration of the emergency where such action is needed to speed up production, Miss Frieda Miller, Industrial Commissioner for New York State, announced yesterday the appointment of a special committee through which all requests for extension of working hours for women will be cleared.

Charley (Lulu) Costantino, East Side lightweight, last night registered his forty-eighth straight ring triumph. Before a crowd of 3,154 at the St. Nicholas Palace the East Sider won the decision from Joey Fontana, Brooklyn, in the main bout of eight rounds.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- First details reached here today of an engagement at Lingayen Beach, 110 miles northwest of Manila, where a Filipino Army division, lining the shore with artillery, blasted 154 motorboat loads of invading Japanese soldiers without letting one of them reach land alive.

The greatly expanded war program will force sales of heavy electrical equipment and industrial materials to even greater heights in the coming year than they have reached this year, manufacturers reported yesterday. The industry has a staggering backlog on hand and is already forced to schedule its 1943 production of turbines.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 15 -- The possibility that the Argentine Government might declare a state of siege to curb pro-Axis propagandists and others in the country who aided the powers that were at war with the United States was indicated today by Acting President Ramon S. Castillo.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- The besieged Marine garrisons at Wake and Midway Islands, tiny United States outposts in the Pacific, still flew the Stars and Stripes tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Major General Henry H. Arnold, Deputy Chief of Staff for Air and Chief of the Army Air Forces, today was promoted to the temporary rank of lieutenant general in a list of 15 nominations for promotions sent to the Senate by President Roosevelt.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- The momentum of the Red Army's advance has now attained such a peak that the Germans are believed to be withdrawing all their behind-lines bases, and as a result there has not been a single air-raid alert in Moscow for forty-eight hours.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 15 -- Contrary to announcements that the Russians are merely occupying the Soviet territory that the German troops are evacuating "according to plan," a report from Berlin today declares that the Russians are savagely attacking along the entire front.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- John F. Wilkins, former publisher of The Washington Post and a prominent business man of this city, died today at his Massachusetts Avenue home. His age was 69.

The N.Y.U. basketball team remained undefeated last night, turning back Queens College by 49-35 at the Heights gymnasium in its third game of the season. The first half ended with the Violets ahead, 27 -- 20.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A message of friendship and encour- agement for the French people was given by Secretary of State Cordell Hull in response to questions at his press conference.

In this "grave hour" the American machine "has become the protector of people's right to work and live in a free America," Paul Garrett, vice president and director of public relations of General Motors Corporation, said last night at the anniversary dinner of the Adcraft Club of Detroit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A series of "conversion" conferences, in which committees from durable goods industries can plan the pooling of productive resources for war work with government officials, is planned by the contract distribution division of the Office of Production Management, Floyd B. Odlum, division director, revealed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Dec. 10 aggregated $10,914,000,000.

BATAVTA, Netherlands Indies, Tuesday, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- The Netherlands Indies High Command announced that unidentified aircraft were sighted flying over certain areas today but that no hostilities had occurred within the Indies territory during the last twenty-four hours.

The war with Japan is and will continue to be primarily an air war. This fact can hold both serious and reassuring implications. Which they will turn out to be depends largely upon existing circumstances and future action. The layman does not know how many planes, and of what kinds, were at the Philippines, and what losses or disorganization were caused by the initial and later air raids.
DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Football fans of North Carolina jumped from the depths of gloom to something approaching hysteria today when the canceled Rose Bowl game was revived, to be played here.

The annual Little All-America football team, announced by The Associated Press yesterday, features the selection of a player from the University of Hawaii for the first time in its eight-year history.

With Mayor La Guardia present to give his official endorsement, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman announced yesterday plans to raise $750,000 by direct appeal to all New Yorkers for the modernization of St. Vincent's Hospital, Seventh Avenue and Eleventh Street, so this ninety-two-year-old institution may competently meet the requirements of another wartime emergency.

The eighth day of record-breaking recruiting for the armed services was marked here yesterday by an unprecedented outpouring of volunteers to the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard. Long queues of anxious applicants at enlistment offices showed no signs of diminishing.
THOSE who are looking for escape literature, so called, ought not to overlook James Ramsey Ullman's history of mountain climbing, "High Conquest."*

Five celebrated French chefs collaborated last night in preparing an elaborate five-course dinner that was served in the French manner at the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to five hundred guests for the benefit of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A communique of the War Department :

SINGAPORE, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- Hong Kong's Imperial garrison dug in today behind a maze of barricades and bristling defenses along the world-famous waterfront facing the mainland, to resist the Japanese besieging the island.

Five men, including the captain and radio officer of the Spanish ship Isla de Tenerife, were in Federal custody yesterday, charged with an attempt to transport quantities of radio parts, airplane silk and lubricating oil to Europe in circumvention of the exportcontrol provisions of the neutrality act.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- After seven years of labor strife on Pacific Coast waterfronts, marked by rioting and bloodshed, leaders of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific and the C.I.O.'s International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union appeared close together today on a plan to keep shipping going at top speed, withotu interruption, for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A summary of President Roosevelt's third report on lease-lend aid to those countries resisting the Axis forces discloses that two-thirds of the population of the earth is included among the beneficiaries, although all have not yet received aid.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, acting president of City College since February, 1941, was elected permanent president of the college last night by a majority vote of the Board of Higher Education at its meeting at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue. Dr. Wright, who is also director of the school's Summer and evening sessions, thus becomes the sixth City College president in its ninety-six-year history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Prospects that the Senate Banking Committee will recommend a fiveman price-control board with the administrator as an executive member or officer, in place of the administration plan for a single administrator, loomed today as the committee opened its second week's hearing on the price-control bill.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 15 -- With clear skies and warmer weather, some 5,500 fans turned out at this course today as the racing swung into the final week of its eighteen-day meeting. In the Russ Hodges Purse, for all ages, the field was reduced to seven at the last minute when Trainer J.Y. Christmas scratched Rough Time, probably because of the muddy track.

Our Forefather Days A man can't be a good Mayor of New York, a linguist, an orchestra conductor and the master of other accomplishments and never make a slip. So it is no trouble at all to forgive Mr. La Guardia his little error about the Half Moon.

The International Longshoremen's Association, which planned to call a meeting today to map a campaign of opposition to legislation inimical to labor and to oppose American entry into the war except for defense, will attempt instead to provide for prevention of strikes during the conflict, Joseph P. Ryan, its president, said yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 15 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

Mayor La Guardia believes "if the present situation in the Atlantic continues, in all likelihood we will not be required to have regular blackouts." This is another way of saying that unless Axis Powers gain a foothold closer to the American continent than they have yet, the danger of sustained and heavy air attack upon East Coast cities is remote.

Fordham's football team began its last week of practice on Rose Hill yesterday in preparation for its game with Missouri in the Sugar Bowl New Year's Day. The Maroon party will leave New York Sunday night and will resume drills upon arrival at St. Stanislaus School, Bay St. Louis, the following Tuesday.

Hong Kong's defenders, now besieged in their island stronghold, may not be able to withstand the Japanese assault indefinitely. But, as Prime Minister Churchill reminded them in his message, each day that they delay the fall of the British naval base brings nearer the day of victory.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- The condemned man ate a hearty dinner and promptly returned to New York. The execution is scheduled for next Sunday, when Steve Owen brings his Giants out here for the championship game with the Chicago Bears.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Westchester County received today from the Federal Government a new offer of $634,000 for the construction of a defense airport, with an annotation by the Civil Aeronautics Administration that an intercepter base in Central Westchester had become a military necessity and that more funds would be granted if today's allocation proved inadequate.
BERLIN, Dec. 15 (From, German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The High Command issued this communique today:

Skylights and other roof openings are serious sources of danger in a blackout, according to students of the problem, who pointed out yesterday that air-raid wardens and policemen on the street level were in a position to detect and correct quickly any failure to black out windows properly, but could hardly determine whether roof lights were properly obscured.

A further climb was attempted yesterday with some success by the stock market, and, while those issues that stand to benefit from war-time operations without scrapping present production made some encouraging gains, the list on the New York Stock Exchange was held back by such groups as the motors and rubbers.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 15 -- Japan's mechanized troops aided by dive-bombers have smashed their way into Southern Kedah, the 100-mile-long Northwestern Malayan State bordering Thailand, the British acknowledged tonight. [This indicated a Japanese penetration of more than fifty miles on the road to Singapore, some 400 miles away.]
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Representatives of twelve organizations interested in public housing approved yesterday in substance a resolution adopted by the National Housing Conference that condemned certain features of the Lanham bill appropriating $300,000,000 additional for defense housing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Office of Production Management ordered a speedup in the 10,000,000-ton steel expansion program today, granting high military priorities to expansion projects authorized and under way.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 15 -- All signs indicate today that Mexico, within the week since the Japanese attack on the United States, has been undergoing rapid unification which extends -- with some exceptions -- from the extreme Right to the extreme Left.

For the second time within nine months, the fifteen-story Butterick Building at 161-67 Sixth Avenue changed hands yesterday when Ralph Dudley, an investing client of Aaron Zanger, purchased the property through the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., from a syndicate comprised of Samuel Wasserman, M.J. Shagan and Lorna Noyes Findlay.

The program of debt refunding by the various county road and bridge districts in Florida under the 1841 State legislation that recognizes the State's responsibility for the obligations issued by the counties will be speeded up this month, according to announcements of proposed sales announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A $10,077,077,005 emergency appropriation for the armed forces and supporting establishments was delayed for a while today when the Senate became angered at the House for striking out a $216,000 item which would give each Senator a $4,500 executive assistant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- With the government facing a bill for "perishable" machine tools that will rise soon to nearly $12,000,000 a month, about $5,000,000 of it will go into the pockets of defense contract brokers unless that practice and profits are curbed, a special House investigating committee was warned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The American Federation of Labor Executive Council late today unanimously adopted a "no strike" policy in all war industries and called for creation by President Roosevelt of a national agency, similar to the 1918 War Labor Board, to act as a voluntary mediation and arbitration unit to handle all disputes without work stoppages.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 10: increases of $82,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $101,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $358,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $121,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

The Civilian Defense Volunteer Offices in Greater New York moved yesterday at an accelerated pace as organization plans were virtually completed and the Queens and Richmond branches started to enroll applicants.

The Fifth Avenue Playhouse will introduce on Saturday the first part of a four-part screen program consisting of twelve experimental films of varying length and generally titled "A Festival of Surrealist and Fantastic Films." The initial program consists of "The Blood of a Poet" (French), "Lot in Sodom" and "Object Lesson."

Reports from major skiing areas in the North yesterday indicated that sport was possible on most of the open slopes and limited on trails where the undergrowth was too high. Skiers in centers where the week-end snowfall was light are not discouraged.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- Five hundred women who have completed instruction courses of the Massachusetts Women's Civilian Defense School, were welcomed into the Massachusetts Women's Defense Corps this evening at exercises in Symphony Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- The United Artists Distributing Corporation today announced a reversal of its traditional policy, coincident with the election of a new board of directors. The announcement disclosed that the company's management will be independent of United Artists' owner-members, Charles Chaplin, David O. Selznick, Alexander Korda and Mary Pickford, who have heretofare always personally been members of the board of directors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The government, through the Secretary of the Navy, has now made as full and candid an account of the great disaster in Hawaii as any citizen had a right to expect.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: An all-out war demands an all-out national effort, financial, industrial and military. Munitions, planes, tanks and ships of war are essential to victory. But they are useless unless trained and courageous men are available to operate them.

Losses in local retail trade last week because of war tension and air-raid warnings were less than expected. Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 5 per cent under the corresponding week last year, whereas an average drop of 10 per cent or more had been feared.

Florence Stove Directors of the Florence Stove Company voted yesterday to pay Christmas bonuses of $60 to employes of more than a year's service and $30 to those employed for five months. More than 2,000 employes in the company's plants at Gardner, Mass., and at Kankakee, Ill., will participate.

Important steps looking toward the refinancing, corporate simplification and recapitalization of the Associated Gas and Electric system and its ultimate conversion into three major integrated systems were announced yesterday by the trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "No aliens residing in the United States can volunteer for service in any branch of the Army, Navy and Air Force. They are compelled to wait until drafted."

Manhattan's combined varsity and freshman swimming teams scored a 42-33 victory over Queens College yesterday at the Park Central pool as the Jaspers inaugurated their 1941-42 season. The use of both varsity and freshman performers was agreed upon by the coaches.
The text of President Roosevelt's Bill of Rights Day address over the radio from Washington last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was as follows:

It has long been apparent that the financial problems of this war would be very different from those of the last war. Despite the magnitude of the arms program, there is no question whatever about the ability of the Treasury to raise whatever money it requires in the open market at rates determined by itself.

The National Association of Insurance Agents yesterday volunteered its service to the newly created War Insurance Corporation, which is to provide reasonable protection against losses resulting from enemy attacks on private property in the continental United States.

An acute shortage of trained switchboard operators, stenographers and automobile drivers was reported yesterday by the American Women's Voluntary Services when it announced that 10,000 women had enrolled for defense training courses in the first week of the war.

Sales of defense bonds by banks in this city last week and yesterday were so large that the Federal Reserve Bank was unable to fill the reorders from the institutions in full, the bank disclosed. The condition applied to sales by commercial banks as well as savings banks and savings and loan associations.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 15 -- Prince and Princess Alexis Zalstem-Zalessky gave a dinner tonight at their new residence for Mr. and Mrs. John Moffat of New York, who arrived today at the Everglades Club. Other guests included Mrs. Woolworth Donahue, who arrived today and has taken an apartment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Here are the ships the Navy reported were lost at Pearl Harbor:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Virginia, whose ratification on Dec. 1, 1791, was the last necessary to add the Bill of Rights to the Constitution, observed the day with reenactment of the ratification by colonial-costumed players on the portico of the State Capitol.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind set eighteen months in prison and a fine of $2,500 yesterday as the penalty Carlo M. Flumiani must pay for the frauds he perpetrated on would-be authors. Flumiani, a "vanity publisher," who produced volumes of poetry, philosophy and anything that came his way.

Failure to obey civil defense regulations or refusal to comply with the orders of air raid wardens would be made punishable by a Jail term of not more than six months or a fine of not more than $500 by a local law to be introduced at this afternoon's meeting of the City Council by majority leader Joseph T. Sharkey of Brooklyn.

Two special meetings will be conducted this week under joint auspices of the Board of Education and THE NEW YORK TIMES to acquaint mothers from all five boroughs of New York with the plans that have been made for protection of children of school age during the war, the board announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Review of a lower court decision empowering the National Labor Relations Board to police continuing relations between employer and employe under a collective bargaining agreement was refused by the Supreme Court today.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company, one of the largest gas utilities in the State, was ordered yesterday by the New York State Public Service Commission to write $6,357,548 out of its property and plant account so that its assets will represent actual original cost of utility property in service.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The text of Secretary Knox's statement detailing losses in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor follows:

NEW YORK Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw will give a dinner next Monday at her home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, for three debutantes of the season, the Misses Lispenard Crocker, Marie Hoguet and Barbara Riggs.

Commercial paper outstanding in the United States is now at the highest level in about five years, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its monthly survey of the market based on reports to it from commercial paper dealers.

VICHY, France, Dec. 15 (U.P.) -- A dynamite bomb exploded with terrific force today in a Paris restaurant requisitioned by German occupation troops in one of two new acts of terrorism carried out in spite of the fact 100 Frenchmen are awaiting execution for previous disorders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt told Congress in a quarterly report today that lease-lend aid to the countries opposing the Axis amounted in the last nine months to $1,202,000,000, of which $723,000,000 represented war equipment, food, raw materials and other defense articles transferred, and $595,000,000 represented goods exported.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Emperor Hirohito was accused today by President Roosevelt, in effect, of personal complicity in Japan's course of carrying on peace negotiations with the United States while putting into operation the plan for a treacherous attack upon this country.

ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Warning that every home owner should prepare at least against the eventuality of incendiary bombs, the State Fire Defense Committee and the State Education Deparment today issued instructions for the guidance of citizens who may have to become "home firemen."

A representative gathering of members of society filled the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon when a concert was held under the auspices of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation as a tribute to the late Albert Morris Bagby, who founded and conducted the famous Musical Mornings, features of the season in New York for more than fifty years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Office of Production Management asked the country's 27,000,000 motorists today to save rubber by using street cars and buses when possible and to hold pleasure driving to a minimum.

The talk about town concerning Fordham's basketball team is that the Rams, for a change, are "loaded" and that prospects for a banner season are rosier than in years. Coach Ed Kelleher was asked about the situation at Rose Hill yesterday and agreed to go along halfway with the rumors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Tiny two-man submarines, believed to be the smallest submersibles ever used in modern warfare, took part in the surprise Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Japan did not administer a knockout blow or destroy the effectiveness of American naval forces in the Pacific when she attacked at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, at dawn on Dec. 7, and thus failed to achieve her objective, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox reported today on his return from a flight to Hawaii to investigate the attack.

With the memory of the Bears' devastating second-period attack in Sunday's game still fresh, Stout Steve Owen, Mike Palm, Bill Owen and Wellington Mara climbed from a Chicago train yesterday and went almost immediately to the Polo Grounds to start building the Giants' defenses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress today reviewing Japanese-American relations follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Moving swiftly once a course of action was determined upon, the government last week seized an estimated 590,000 pounds of tin plate in a New York warehouse, and put it aboard a steamer which sailed on Saturday for Chile, it was learned here yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Responding to the appeal for help for the families and persons in greatest distress throughout the city, 307 contributors sent gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. Their generosity resulted in a total of $5,422.74 received during the day, bringing the fund to $79,452.07.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- An increase of 15 per cent in net operating earnings of the Girard Trust Company for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 was shown in the annual report today by James E. Gowen, president of the bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau announced today at his press conference that the market for government securities was now taking care of itself, support by the Treasury and Federal Reserve Bank having been withdrawn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The common stock of the Chicago Rivet and Machine Company will continue to be traded on the New York Curb Exchange on an unlisted basis for a trial period of six months, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
TRENTON, Dec. 15 -- Three infantry battalions of the recently organized State Guard were called to active duty today by Governor Charles Edison for the protection of strategic highways and bridges.

Our idea of Christmas morning is mapped out in our mind like a very detailed and specific scenario. First -- around 9 o'clock -- there is the warm, sleepy realization that it is a very special morning and that something exciting and pleasant is about to happen.
ROME, Dec. 15 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's High Command communique:

Paul L. Davies, president of the Food Machinery Corporation, a leading manufacturer of food processing machinery, reported yesterday to stockholders in the annual statement covering the year ended on Sept. 30, that sales, income from leased machinery, unfilled orders, wages and profits all established new high records.

The first transatlantic flying boat to arrive here since Germany declared war on the United States came in yesterday. The Pan American Airways' Atlantic Clipper docked at the marine terminal at La Guardia Field in midafternoon, marking the 500th crossing of the Atlantic by the airways' fleet of "flying hotels."

Wholesale Tone Better Most of the women's apparel and accessory markets were quiet yesterday with progress reported in some quarters toward a greater degree of stabilization following the war tension last week. Reports were received that Coast store volume showed a pickup toward the end of last week, following declines of 20 to 25 per cent in sales of some leading establishments last Tuesday.

With "textile starvation" becoming a reality in Europe and the Orient, the United States will be the chief source of supply during the present war and after it, according to the annual textile review issued yesterday by Scheuer Co., textile brokers and consultants.

Secretary Knox's report of the damage done by the Japanese attack at Pearl Harbor is so much more favorable than either the Japanese accounts or the rumors that have been traveling by word of mouth across the country for the last week that it was almost possible to hear the immense sigh of relief that arose yesterday when news of his statement reached the American public.

Describing tolerance as "a kind of Santa Claus word in which whiskers are hiding reality," the Rev. Francis X. Talbot, editor of America, Jesuit periodical, declared yesterday that where oppression and aggression were involved there could be no such word as "tolerance."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Congressional committees speeded legislation today to give full wartime powers to the President and extend the registration requirements of the Selective Service Act to all men from 18 to 64, inclusive.
The work of clearing up the status of 500 enemy aliens rounded up by Federal agents and local police in this area may begin this week, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa announced last night.

Sales volume of furniture stores, which has depended to a great extent on sales of bedding, springs and appliances, will be decreased materially next year unless the stores do a better job of selling such items as rugs and draperies, Lorenzo Richards, president of the National Retail Furniture Association, told distributors and salesmen of Alexander Smith Sons, carpet manufacturers, last night at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.
The work of clearing up the status of 500 enemy aliens rounded up by Federal agents and local police in this area may begin this week, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa announced last night.

Clothes in action were placed on view at a novel fashion show at Gimbel's yesterday when members of the cast of "It Happens on Ice" modeled skating costumes on a small ice rink constructed on the third floor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during November totaled 849,733 bales of lint and 117,628 bales of linters, compared with 953,600 and 133,006 bales, respectively, during October this year, and 741,170 and 107,892 during November last year.

Stage folk pledged $75,000 for war aid yesterday at a meeting held to reorganize the American Theatre Wing because of United States participation in the war. Nine hundred persons from all branches of the theatre attended the session in the Hudson Theatre.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- The Japanese are pressing southward in British Malaya with absolute disregard for casualties, already estimated at several thousands, latest dispatches from Singapore said this morning. The dispatches described the general situation in Malaya and Burma, both exposed to Japanese attack through Thailand, as "full of dangerous possibilities."

Warning of the approach of raiders will be sounded by the sirens of police and fire apparatus -- one long and one short blast alternately for five minutes. The all-clear signal will be sounded by the same apparatus and will consist of a series of short blasts over a five-minute period.

MANILA, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Behind Japan's every military move in the past weeks of war and preparation for war has been the hardly hidden hand of key Nazi agents taking an increasing part in directing the correlation of Japanese and German total war efforts.

Tomorrow morning will find thousands of New Jersey deer hunters taking to the deep woods and pine barrens, in groups of from two to sixty, each, hoping for a shot at a nice buck, and anyone who thinks these hunters don't take their hunting seriously has only to drive around the back roads of Ocean County.

If the United States will provide India with supplies necessary to her developing industrial economy "we can not only raise an army of four or five million men but we can also equip that army," Sir R.K. Shanmukham Chetty, head of the Indian Purchasing Mission, said yesterday.

Jacques Abram, young American pianist, who gave an impressive piano recital last season, returned last night to the Town Hall. In many ways he has changed, and not for the better. He still possesses a formidable technique that can manage anything and his tone is capable of striking contrasts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The issue of the war is whether a "revival of barbarism" is to be imposed upon the world by tyrants, President Roosevelt declared tonight. He pledged that the United States would not lay down arms "before liberty is once again secure in the world."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 -- The war cut deeper into the Far West's sports program today when Governor Culbert L. Olson ordered Santa Anita racetrack officials not to hold the Winter meeting, scheduled to open Dec. 31.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 16 (From Japanese Broadcast) -- Premier Hideki Tojo, addressing an extraordinary session of the Japanese Diet, today reiterated his assertions that Japan had declared war on the United States only after trying all means of peaceful settlement. He declared:

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Gnawing steadily at Axis lifelines supplying the German and Italian forces in North Africa, British submarines operating in the Mediterranean have sunk six more enemy vessels, one of them probably of about 12,000 tons, and damaged at least two others, the Admiralty announced today.

Resolutions pledging full assistance to the American war effort have been adopted by the Italian Cloak, Suit and Skirt Makers Union, I.L.G.W.U., it was announced yesterday by Edward Molisani, manager and secre- tary.

Merck Co. Financing It is understood that a post-effective amendment to the registration statement of Merck Co., Inc., may be filed shortly, on the basis of which public offering might promptly be made of the block of 30,000 shares of the company's outstanding common stock which is covered by the orginal registration statement.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- The United States armed forces in the Far East continue to take a toll of Japanese air and land forces but it is clear that no major land engagement has yet developed in the Philippines. The most recent communiques have reported that enemy activity is confined to aerial activity.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 15 -- "The Anglo-Saxons made a fatal mistake in judging the Japanese war potential," says an article in today's Tribuna of Rome.

The offices occupied jointly by the Free American and Deutscher Weckrufund Beobachter, the German American Bund and the German American Business League, Inc., at 178 East Eighty-fifth Street have been taken over by the United States Government, it was learned yesterday.
Orders by the Police Department to be followed by all residents in a total blackout have issued to thousands of air-raid wardens. The principal orders and instructions follow:

Buddy Hassett, the Bronx thrush who between renditions of his favorite ballad, "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling," has played an acceptable game at first base in the major leagues for half a dozen years, became once more the property of the Yankees yesterday.

While there is currently some reshuffling of advertising campaigns for 1942 as a result of the war, the net effect will be little change one way or the other, according to agency men. Temporarily, automotive manufacturers have had their schedules completely thrown out of gear because of the likelihood of sharper curtailment or even complete stoppage of passenger car and light truck output ...

Business enterprises of a varied nature selected buildings along Fifth and Madison Avenues and the side streets near those arteries in which to lease quarters, rental reports received from brokers and agents indicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Navy's 5:30 P.M. communique follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- "Challenge to the Night," a novel by Cecil Lewis published in London in 1938, was purchased today by RKO as a vehicle for Michele Morgan, French actress, who will make her American screen debut in the studio's recently completed "Joan of Paris."
FOR Lincoln enthusiasts there is one obvious prize this season-a new picture book edited, with a brief biographical commentary, by Stefan Lorant and called "Lincoln: His Life in Photographs."

A fabulous chapter in the history of Broadway comes to a close this evening at the Majestic when the curtain descends on the final New York performance of "Hellzapoppin." The management reports the revue will have been seen here 1,404 times, a figure it does not consider accurate, however.

Harry M. Prince, consultant in the Office of Civilian Defense who made a survey of bombed buildings in London a year ago, startled 350 real estate men last night with the statement that 98 1/2 per cent of the buildings in New York City would be unsafe in a bombing raid.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 17 -- Yesterday was Manila's first day without an air raid since war began, but the naval station at Olongapo underwent a second, and light, raid by Japanese bombers. Liuet. Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters announced that there had been no major activity on any Philippine land front and that the situation remained unchanged.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The British General Headquarters communique follows:
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 16 -- A state of siege was proclaimed this evening throughout Argentina in a decree signed by all members of the Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Alas ka has not only paid off the original purchase price of $7,200,000 more than 300 times since its acquisition in 1867, but is now declaring "extra dividends" of vital military protection to the United States, Ernest Gruening, Governor of the Territory of Alaska, told Secretary Ickes today in submitting his annual report.

Reminiscent of the year 1754, when Columbia College's first students dressed in seventeenth century costumes and dragged a pine log across the snow-covered campus to Hartley Hall, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, will light the traditional Yule log today at 5 P.M. in the Iounge of John Jay Hall, 114th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, to open the Christmas festivities at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Prosecution of persons arrested for alleged seditious utterances must not be undertaken unless consent is first obtained from the Department of Justice, Attorney General Biddle told United States Attorneys all over the country today.

Swinging Into action yesterday, the local chapter of the American Red Cross formed a coordinating committee to meet the city's quota in the $50,000,000 war fund drive and also completed arrangements to take over three floors of the old Tiffany Building to relieve the severe congestion that has developed at Manhattan headquarters during the past week as thousands offered their services.

The United States Maritime Commission has called two meetings in Washington today to study two problems affecting American ocean shipments -- labor and insurance. Representatives of ship owners and operators, merchants, insurance underwriters, seamen and officers and stevedores have been invited to one or both meetings.

A group headed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler received yesterday the award of $18,465,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Pennsylvania Railroad on a bid of 100.18 for certificates bearing interest at 2 3/8 per cent and will offer them to the public today at prices to yield 0.75 to 2.60 per cent.

The undefeated Long Island University basketball team gained its tenth victory by defeating Morris Harvey of Charleston, W. Va., 62 -- 54, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy last night. The victors led at the intermission, 37 -- 22.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The champion Boston Bruins pulled into another first-place National Hockey League tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight by registering their first shutout of the season, 4-0, against the Montreal Canadiens before 9,500 at the Boston Garden.

The career of the "pinball squad" at Police Headquarters ended yesterday with the return of eight patrolmen and their captain to uniformed duty. The patrolmen were reassigned to their original precincts. Six other members of the squad were reassigned last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Counsel for the Missouri Pacific Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to specify that any plan of reorganization for the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad leave the voting power in its common stock.

Rapid Robert Feller, the ironarmed young man who won more games, pitched more innings and struck out more men than any 1941 major-league hurler, wasn't able to lead in the two departments highly prized by pitchers, the percentage in games won and lost and the earned-run averages.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- British Imperial forces were reported today to be girding for a big-scale counter-attack in Kedah Province of Northwestern Malaya in an effort to prevent the Japanese invaders from establishing coastal bases in that area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The port of Kahului, on the island of Maui, 100 miles southeast of Honolulu, was attacked by the Japanese in the last twenty-four hours, a Navy communique stated today. It was "shelled by an enemy submarine" at about dusk.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- American stay-at-homes remembered Pearl Harbor today with cash gifts to Uncle Sam.
ROME, Dec. 16 (from Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

A long shot by Alex Shibicky flew past Goalie Charley Rayner and gave the New York Rangers a 3-to-2 triumph over the Brooklyn Americans in the National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden last night. This tally, coming midway through the overtime period, put the Blue Shirts ahead, two games to one, in the intracity series for the William J. Macbeth Memorial Trophy.

Thirty-eight years ago this morning Wilbur and Orville Wright came to the end of their rainbow on the sands of Kill Devil Hill. Through the perseverance, skill and courage of the brothers of the bicycle shop, man had attained powered wings. The flimsy machine which they then made to fly was destined in less than four decades to change the face of the world.

If we needed any evidence that science and war go hand in hand, we have it in the Government's decision to discontinue the publication of weather maps. No extensive battle on land or sea is fought without information on temperature, barometric pressure, clouds and precipitation; for all these factors are of importance even in the firing of an anti-aircraft battery's and a battleship's guns.

Buyer Registrations Off Registrations of visiting buyers in the market last week totaled 354 as against 499 in the previous week and 420 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 113 as against 205 for last Tuesday.

Disclosing that he has ordered an hour's daily drill for every air raid warden in New York City henceforth, Mayor La Guardia reviewed yesterday the entire organization of the civilian defense activities of the city at a meeting of the City Defense Council in the Board of Estimate room in City Hall.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 16 -- Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrapont entertained with a dinner tonight at Sandrift.

Add to the list of films opening this week "Girl From Leningrad," a Russian importation, which will arrive at the Stanley Theatre on Friday.... Also opening this week will be "No Hands on the Clock," which will be the Globe's new attraction on Saturday.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 16 -- Completing a round trip opening mail and passenger air service between the United States and Africa over a new tri-continent route which includes South America, the Pan American Airways Cape Town Clipper arrived here tonight with twenty-one passengers.

A new apparatus, named the rheotron, that produces X-rays traveling with energies of 20,000,000 volts, the most powerful by far ever developed, was announced yesterday by the General Electric Research Laboratories. The rheotron, it was said, "opens up a new field of scientific exploration by its production of an electron stream far more penetrating than the electrons from radium."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- Isaac Brown, 41 years old, New York insurance broker, was found guilty tonight by a jury before Judge Frank H. Coyne In WestChester County Court on all charges in a three-count indictment alleging first and second degree asaults and attempted first-degree murder.

ABOARD A BRITISH CRUISER OFF LIBYA, Dec. 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Loosing one of the heaviest barrages of the Mediterranean war, a squadron of British cruisers and destroyers beat off a seven-hour combined Nazi high level, divebombing and torpedo assault off the Libyan coast today.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Wednesday, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- An air raid alarm sounded in Macassar on the south coast of Celebes yesterday as Netherlands Indies forces prepared to meet any possible Japanese landing attempt from bases in Thailand or Malaya.

Despite the plans for air raid drills during the daytime, all evening extra-curricular activities, consisting of class plays, concerts or club work will continue without change in the 800 school buildings operated by the New York City educational system, James Marshall, president of the Board of Education, disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Reports that a modification of the price ceiling on oils and fats was being considered, as well as firmness in cotton and soy beans, led to fair professional and commission house buying of wheat early today which lifted prices around one cent a bushel above yesterday's finish.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 15:

BERLIN, Dec. 16 (from German broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- The High Command claimed today that German forces had inflicted heavy losses on the Red Army in local hostilities along the eastern front.

Members of the faculty and 850 officers and cadets of the Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps at Xavier High School paid tribute yesterday to Ensign Robert N. King, 27 years old, a graduate of the school in 1932, who was killed in the attack on Pearl Harbor.

As the first shock of war and treachery gave way to a calm, grim determination to fight through to victory, New Yorkers In increasing numbers began yesterday to rally to the support of their neighbors whose distress is rooted in sickness, in sudden misfortune, in personal mental conflicts -- the Neediest Cases.

NEW YORK Jules Bache has recalled invitations for the reception he had planned to give on Friday at 814 Fifth Avenue after the marriage of his granddaughter, Miss Dorothy Richards, to Walter Hirshon. The reception will take place at the home of the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Frederic W. Beckman, in Princeton, N.J.

A "speed-up" of the academic program of City College to enable the students to be graduated before entering military service will be considered by the Board of Higher Education, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, newly elected president of the college.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 16 -- The industrial potential of the United States is stressed as the probable, ultimate and deciding factor in the present war in correspondence reaching Free French quarters here from observers in France's North African possessions, it was learned today.

LONDON Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- Japanese invaders of Malaya are developing a large-scale land offensive aimed at Singapore, and "there is definitely a danger" to the British naval base, the greatest British base in the Far East, a military spokesman said today.
Agents of the United States Government boarded the Spanish liner Isla de Tenerife at 6 o'clock last night and took possession on orders of the Secretary of the Treasury.

It is Hitler's habit to scoff at the ability of democracies to make war effectively. It is doubtful, however, whether his skepticism is shared by those of his people who are old enough to remember how the tide turned in the World War after the United States became a belligerent.
VALLETTA, Malta, Dec. 16 (Reuter) -- A communique issued tonight said: ...

ATLANTA, Dec. 16 (U.P.)-- Josephine Lady McKechnie, widow of Sir James McKechnie, former director of Vicker's, British armament firm, was under technical arrest here tonight after being found unconscious under mysterious circumstances at a rooming house.

Children of the kindergarten attached to the James Center, conducted by the Children's Aid Society at 154 Hester Street, received a surprise visit from Santa Claus yesterday just as they had finished decorating the tree in their playroom on the seventh floor of the building.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the libor-industry conference meets in Washington to draft a basic war labor policy it ought to be clearly understood by every one that this is an important step toward insuring against stoppages but not a substitute for legislation in this area.

A movement to put sales of benzol, toluol and xylol on an f.o.b. basis was effectively halted by a request of the Office of Price Administration that prices for the first quarter remain within one cent of the Oct. 1 level and that trade practices in effect on that date be retained, according to trade reports yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- British-American consultations paralleling the forthcoming Anglo-Russian talks, all of which look to some form of a unified high command of the anti-Axis powers, will be held soon, probably in Washington, it was learned tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Dec. 17 -- Relations between the occupying authorities and the Parisian populace were considerably worsened early yesterday when a series of three "outrages" in the Paris region cost the lives of at least seven Germans -- and the assailants escaped.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Byron Price, executive news editor of The Associated Press, was put in charge today of a partly mandatory, partly voluntary wartime censorship of the nation's press, radio and communications, with the title of Director of Censorship.

The nation-wide rush to buy defense savings bonds and stamps continued unabated yesterday, and many banks and branch post offices ran out of securities and gave buyers receipts for their money and promised deliveries within the next few days.

"Buy your honey in a teapot," say the storekeepers who have found this oddly presented product and perched it gayly on their shelves. It is a fat, round teapot of crystalline glass -- impervious to the fieriest of flames -- with a beribboned wicker handle and a slender, curving spout with a butterfly bow tied saucily at the end.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- In obtaining today from the House of Commons an additional grant of a credit of u1,000,000,000, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Kingsley Wood, announced that war expenditure had now reached u11,750,000 daily.

La Guardia opened last night tha Greater New York 1942 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign by calling on all citizens of this area to enlist in the battle against the "brutal tyrant that deals out death and damage with all the savage fury of a modern Blitzkrieg."
Pledges of total support for America's war effort continued yesterday from racial and national groups and other organizations.

The New York Dressmakers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, with, a membership of 85,000 in New York City and vicinity, last night placed 1,500 of its trained members, consisting of shop chairmen, and stewards, at the disposal of the civilian defense authorities.

The heaviness of the automotive issues, augmented by the mail order shares, stifled yesterday a further recovery movement in the stock market. In the morning, prices had pushed into new high ground for the current rallying but selling reasserted itself in the afternoon to produce an easier closing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Thomas G. Corcoran, long-time White House adviser and former $10,000-a-year special attorney of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation advised the Senate defense investigating committee today that he had received fees totaling $100,000 thus far this year for legal and organizational work for clients on four defense projects.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- Within a week after the War Department had designated the Far West as a theatre of military operations and Governor Olson proclaimed a state of emergency, the Legislature will assemble Friday in a special wartime session to consider defense appropriations, which may reach $50,000,000.
The German Transocean broadcast, recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES last night, summarized an article by an announced German military expert in Adolf Hitler's newspaper as follows :

The SEC and Regulation Under present war-emergency conditions, the Securities and Exchange Commission apparently is reappraising its "regulation as usual" approach in the handling of its many duties under the Federal statutes it administers.

After making numerous criticisms yesterday of Mayor La Guardia's proposed local law imposing fines of $500 and jail sentences of six months on violators of air raid regulations, members of the City Council adopted the measure by a vote of 18 to 0 as a framework for future legislation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Creation of a government bureau staffed wifh technologists capable of analyzing facilities in small manufacturing plants and suggesting steps necessary to convert them from peacetime to armaments production, was urged today upon a Senate "small business" committee by a succession of witnesses.
BERLIN, Dec. 16 (from German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued the following today:

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Eight elderly bedridden men and women burned to death today, trapped in a raging convalescent home fire attendants said they believed was starter by a patient smoking in bed. Seven patients were helped and carried to safety in their night clothes through snow and sub-freezing temperatures as the flames spread quickly through the two-story frame structure about four miles west of the General Electric Company plant.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Dec. 17 -- A special communique issued in Moscow this morning announced the recapture of Kalinin and the destruction of the Ninth German Army Corps of six divisions, rushed to that front from the central sector only six days ago in an effort to stem the Russian onslaught.

There will convene today In Washington a conference of twelve leaders of industry and twelve leaders of labor to attempt to reach "a unanimous agreement to prevent the interruption of production by labor disputes during the period of the war." With good-will on both sides, with the nation now aroused and united as it is by the sudden attack of the Axis Powers, it should not be difficult to arrive at such an agreement.

Dr. Paulo Bettencourt, editor and publisher of Correio da Manha of Rio de Janeiro, one of Brazil's leading newspapers, and recent recipient of the Maria Moors Cabot Prize in Journalism, indicated yesterday the belief that Brazil would take a more active part In the war.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Former Mayor Richard W. Reading and twenty-two co-defendants in the three-month-old Wayne County numbers conspiracy trial were found guilty last night by a circuit jury of eight women and four men after eighteen and one-half hours of deliberation.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I set at rest some of the "powerline questions" propounded in your editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 6.

The regular 1941-42 city P.S. A.L. basketball campaign will continue as scheduled, the High School Games Committee decided yesterday at the monthly meeting held at the Hotel Astor. It was thought at first that present world conditions might bring about a halt to the current court session.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho today asked the Senate to adopt a law declaring that no American nation at war with a non-American nation would be treated by Mexico as a belligerent and that troops, warships and planes of belligerent American nations be permitted to use Mexican territory, waters and ports.

Among those reported yesterday as having leased apartments was Hossein Navab, Consul General of Iran, who took an apartment in 952 Fifth Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., agent, and Wm. A. White Sons, brokers.

The cotton market moved irregularly yesterday and, except for flurries of activity early in the session and near the close, trading held quiet. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 2 to 6 points.

The final report luncheon of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society was held yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. It was announced that a total of 548,732.26 had been contributed toward the society's goal of $110,000. The drive was conducted to celebrate the 110th anniversary of the society.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 -- Sugar Bowl sponsors who have raised one husky football fixture today adopted a war orphan and thereby acquired college football's first post-season double-barreled climax.

Even at the height of any possible "hysteria" here, "there will be no talk of evacuating children from our East Coast as England did," William L. White, a foreign correspondent, yesterday told 350 persons attending a luncheon of the National Association of Day Nurseries in the Hotel WaldorfAstoria.

Record-breaking enrollments for training in civilian defense courses continued yesterday at the headquarters of the American Women's Voluntary Services, 11 East Fiftyeighth Street, and also at the Civilian Defense Voluntary Offices in Greater New York, 93 Park Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Three obstacles stand in the way of French-German collaboration.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The spread of typhus along the Eastern Fronts is being closely watched here. Recurrent reports indicate that fear of epidernics is uppermost in the minds of both the Russian and German Commands.
This morning the public will nave its first opportunity to see some of the literary rarities of the Berg Collection of the New York Public Library.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 -- Apparently well over their war jitters, Los Angeles people began a rush today to catch up on their Christmas shopping.

Warning of the approach of raiders will be sounded by the sirens of police and fire apparatus -- one long and one short blast alternately for five minutes. The all-clear signal will be sounded by the same apparatus and will consist of a series of short blasts over a five-minute period.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- The traditional Hunt Ball of the Goldens Bridge Hounds, Rock Ridge Farm, Brewster, N.Y., will be given on the night of Dec. 27 at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club. The American Red Cross will benefit from the party through its North Salem, Katonah, Bedford and Mount Kisco branches.

HONOLULU, Dec. 15 (Delayed) -- Honolulu entered the second week of the war with Japan today as cheerful and unflinching as it was when the might of Japan's air arm was unleashed against the island of Oahu.

HONOLULU, Dec. 16 (U.P.) -- Honolulu and vicinity were quiet late today, and a Navy announcement that Japanese war craft had shelled Johnston Island and a point on the northeast coast of the Island of Maui caused little excitement.

Work on the Whiteface Mountain ski project, which was to begin next Spring and be completed by Fall, is to be postponed until the conclusion of the war, it was announced yesterday by the New York State Conservation Department.

An issue of 240,000 shares of $1.25 dividend preferred stock of Vultee Aircraft, Inc., is being offered publicly today at $25 a share, or an aggregate of $6,000,000, by an underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and Emanuel Co.

Plans for protecting its nine grams of precious radium, its patients, staff, equipment and building in the event of an air raid have been worked out by Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, 444 East Sixty-eighth Street, it was learned yesterday from Harry Pelham Robbins, president of the institution.

Winchester Repeating Arms The Winchester Repeating Arms Company announced yesterday that bonuses amounting to between $500,000 and $750,000 will be paid to about 12,000 workers on Monday. Employes with continuous service from Jan. 1 through Dec. 22 will receive two weeks' pay based on average earnings.
DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Duke's campus took on all the aspects of a gay madhouse today in hectic preparation for the transplanted Rose Bowl game between the Blue Devils and Oregon State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Leon K. Shanack of New York told the special House committee investigating defense brokers that he cleared 552,773.06 in profits in ten months for his services in subcontracting defense orders of $262,663.83.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today preliminary State cotton acreage allotments for 1942 totaling 26,598,000 acres.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 16 -- The fate of Northwestern Malaya and its principal city, Penang, admittedly hung in the balance tonight as the British fought against what official quarters described as "Japanese attempts to press home attacks with fanatical deter-...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Roosevelt appointed a fiveman board today to investigate the circumstances surrounding the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, in which important units of American forces in the Pacific suffered serious damage.
LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique early today said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Leaders of about 100 American Federation of Labor unions, extending their no-strike policy to cover all their 5,000,000 members in every industry, urged today that the "general principles" of American labor policy in the first World War be readopted.

The Fulton Street branch, of the Eighth Avenue subway in Brooklyn, running from Borough Hall to Rockaway Avenue, was tied up from 4:36 to 6:15 o'clock last night when a power substation at Tompkins Avenue and Decatur Street was flooded by water from a burst main.

HONOLULU, Dec. 16 -- It was revealed last night on the island of Kauai that a stalwart six-foot Hawaiian had killed a Japanese pursuit pilot who landed on the island of Niihau, fifteen miles west of Kauai, on the day of the raid on Pearl Harbor.
