WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Moving at wartime speed, the House and Senate today dealt with an extensive program of legislation designed to make men and ships available on the fighting fronts abroad and to confer on President Roosevelt almost unlimited powers to regulate the nation's emergency effort at home.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Roosevelt declared today that plans for cooperation of the war staffs of the various countries fighting the Axis powers in order to coordinate Joint action were coming along very well.
Lofts and other commercial and Industrial buildings figured prominently in the list of realty sales reported for Manhattan yesterday.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the East Coast at the close of last week were 19,675,000 barrels, an increase of 254,000 over the 19,421,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil stocks declined 760,000 barrels to 21,146,000, but heavy fuel oil supplies were up 658,000 to 12,809,000.

The eleven-acre vacant tract of land at 321 Broad Avenue, Ridgefield, N.J., has been purchased by the B.G. Corporation of New York, manufacturers of airplane spark plugs, and will be improved with a plant to be used as an auxiliary of the firm's existing plant in Manhattan.

Export managers yesterday expressed concern over their present inability to obtain and transmit information regarding sailings of vessels on which they hope to ship, because of wartime restrictions on such data. The matter was a principal topic of discussion at the regular luncheon meeting of The Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Requests for temporary relaxation of protective State labor laws already have been received from eighteen concerns employing skilled women workers on defense contracts, State Industrial Commissioner Frieda S. Miller reported yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 16 -- Although no details are yet available in Stockholm as to the true extent and localization of the spotted typhus epidemic that, according to German sources, now rages in the "Eastland," it seems that the danger is immediate and grave.

Shields Co. head a banking syndicate that offered to the public yesterday afternoon 112,740 outstanding shares of common stock of the Maryland Drydock Company, marking the first public distribution of securities of a drydock company in some time.

Mildred Dilling, American harpist, who has not been heard here in almost three years, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. She was assisted by Frances Blaisdell, flute; William Primrose, viola, and Arpad Sandor, piano. Her program, following the pattern of previous ones, included chamber music as well as solo selections.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, Dec. 17 (From, Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau today issued the following:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Alabama Power Company has applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission for permission to refund its outstanding debt of $95,600,000, to reduce its stated common capital from $51,278,782 to $20,762,600, to eliminate $23,148,901 from its utility plant account and to increase its depreciation reserve by $2,217,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Diplomats drafting a program for the meeting of American Foreign Ministers next month in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, predicted today the session would center attention on hemisphere defense and economic cooperation among the twenty-one republics.
American Stores The American Stores Company declared a 25-cent dividend to its stockholders, making the total of $1 for 1941, against 75 cents paid in 1940.

WASHINTON, Dec. 16 -- Weather information was sharply curtailed today for the duration of the war. Thus data that might be useful in air or naval operations against our coasts or shipping will not be available to the enemy. The order calls not only for radical restrictions in the distribution of forecasts, but on the publication of current data on air pressure, fogs, clouds, winds and other elements.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Following is the text of today's declaration of war labor policy by the officers of the American Federation of Labor and all affiliated unions:

Joe Louis was quartered at Greenwood Lake, N.Y., last night, prepared to start boxing workouts today for his twentieth defense of the world heavyweight championship. He is scheduled to meet Buddy Baer of California in Madison Square Garden Jan. 9 for the benefit of the Naval Relief Society.

The incidence of pneumonia rose sharply in New York City last week, Dr. John L. Rice, city Health Commissioner, reported yesterday. There were 173 new cases of this "Winter" disease, compared with 121 the previous week.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 16 -- A plane of the Italian Lati airline, which up to now has connected Rome with Buenos Aires by way of Dakar, Pernambuco and Rio de Janeiro, left this morning for Rio de Janeiro on what is believed to be its last journey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Midget submarines used in the attack on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, Dec. 7, apparently were put into the sea from larger vessels within 100 miles of the great American naval base, the Navy announced today after examination of one of the small undersea craft that was captured in the engagement.

VICHY, France, Dec. 16 -- Reorganization of the Paris municipal government and that of the Seine Department is ordered in a law to be published tomorrow. Charles Trochu, attorney and released war prisoner who has been serving temporarily, will become permanent President of the Paris Municipal Council.

Space made available on steel rolling mill schedules by the further sharp contraction in automobile production was taken immediately by highly rated defense tonnage, according to Iron Age, which says that "the OPM is already in the process of allocating heavy tonages of drum stock for barrels which will crowd all strip mills.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 16 -- Herbert V. Evatt, Minister of External Affairs, tabling in the House of Representatives a "white paper" reviewing United StatesJapanese pre-war conversations, said today that Australia was working for a full alliance with Russia against Japan.

During an air raid alarm, under no circumstances will any one in the Empire State Building be permitted to use any of its elevators, according to announcement yesterday by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, who disclosed that detailed plans have been made for setting up an air raid precautions organization in the 102-story structure, the world's tallest building.
Orders by the Police Department to be followed by all residents in a total blackout have issued to thousands of air-raid wardens. The principal orders and instructions follow:

The four-story apartment house containing forty-eight apartments on a plot 145 by 125 feet at 32-38 St. Paul's Place and 48-54 Woodruff Avenue. Brooklyn, was purchased by Charles Walzer, operator, from a client of Samuel Landow, broker.
The situation in the Pacific continued to have its bleak aspects yesterday, as indeed it must until the first impetus of the Japanese surprise attacks has spent itself.

It was the ninth day of war with Japan yesterday, but throngs of young and old men, besieging the recruiting offices of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard, showed no signs of letting up the rush to enlist that was begun with the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- It was learned today that as early as Nov. 27, immediately after the special Japanese envoys in Washington had received this government's final proposals for settlement of the Far Eastern situation, the Secretary of State issued a warning to all departments concerned to prepare for the worst.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs in leading market rose substantially today, effectively checking the rapid price upturn of the last several days. With the previously popular lightweights displaying most weakness, quotations sagged as much as 25 cents a hundred pounds. Heavier offerings lost 15 cents.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 16 Plans for development of substitutes for wool and other essential garment materials were discussed here today at a meeting of the executive committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 16 -- While British and Dominion forces in the area around El Gazala and eastward in Libya picked up more than 1,000 prisoners, long probing fingers, each representing a heavy British striking force, today reached westward from El Gazala.

For a great part of the two and a half hours they spent yesterday scampering over the Polo Grounds turf the football Giants were busily brewing a barrel of trouble for the Bears, which they hope to pour over the Halas forces at Wrigley Field, Chicago, Sunday, when the teams meet for the National Football League championship.

The legal fight by parents of puplls in the Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, to prevent the college from merging the school with Horace Mann School, was lost yesterday in Supreme Court. Justice Carroll Cr. Walter dismissed their action for an injunction to restrain Teachers College from carrying out the merger and from using any part of the Lincoln School plant or endowment for purposes other than the maintenance of Lincoln School.

TOKYO, Dec. 16 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- The Navy Minister, Admiral Shigetaro Shimada told a war session of Parliament today that so far in the war Japanese forces had sunk three American battleships, one submarine, one minesweeper and one large transport; damaged four battleships, four cruisers, one destroyer, one submarine and one auxiliary vessel and captured one gunboat.
ORDINARILY, about this time, Jock Whitney's broth of a butler would be back North from Carolina to set the scene for one of the pleasantest sporting festivals of the Christmas season.

Favorable action by the priorities division of the Office of Production Management granting retailers general priority for maintenance materials, repair parts and operating supplies is expected momentarily, it was learned here yesterday.

In Kings County Court yesterday a young woman held as a material witness in a murder case against her mother received $729 for the time she spent in custody, while a Brooklyn underworld figure similarly involved in the same case was turned away with only a denunciation.

A banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. received yesterday the award of $2,000,000 of bonds of the Washington Suburban Sanitary District of Maryland at an interest cost basis to the district of 2.542 per cent. The offering consisted of $1,000,000 of water main and sewer bonds.

Plans were filed yesterday by the Department of Public Works for part of a new sewage treatment installation in the Carnarsie section of Brooklyn. The project will occupy a site 115.8 by 281 feet at 1133-45 Miller Avenue, and that section covered by the specifications submitted yesterday is estimated to cost $1,000,000.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many loose statements have appeared that Congress "almost" unanimously voted to declare war on Japan. It is true that Miss Rankin cast a single and only vote against H.J.R. 254, which was adopted by the House by a vote of 388 to 1, but attention is called to the fact that, immediately after this vote.
In the flag-bedecked ballroom of the Hotel Biltmore 200 delegates and officials of the Metropolitan Golf Association gathered for the annual meeting last night.
The Proud Gesture They have canceled the Rose Bowl game, and they have canceled next year's soap-box derby at Akron, and no doubt other fixed events are being wiped off the schedule.

Now that we ourselves have been attacked, the advantages to us of the program of lease-lend aid are even clearer than they were before. According to the President's report, the countries now entitled to lease-lend aid cover two-thirds of the earth's surface and contain nearly two-thirds of its population.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Federal Trade Commission today issued an amended complaint against the Specialty Accounting Supply Manufacturers Association and thirty of its members who sell sales books and continuous form sales record stationery, charging combination to restrain and eliminate competition.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 16 -- Although Nassau County has made appreciable strides in civilian defense preparation since the outbreak of the war, much remains to be accomplished before the county is prepared for an emergency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- With imports of rubber from the East jeopardized by war in the Pacific, Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, requested today that the two leading American sellers of guayule rubber refrain from raising prices above those prevailing on Dec. 6.

A work by an American composer and an appearance by an American soprano as soloist were among the good thing's at last night's concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Dorothy Maynor was the guest artist, singing music by Mozart, Handel and Beethoven.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 16 -- Total mobilization to fight a desperate and long war requires not only anti-inflationary price controls but commodity controls, Herbert Hoover told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today. The former President outlined in detail his plan and methods of administering it.

Announcing that its work of eliminating extreme fire hazards in old-law tenements in New York was virtually completed, the Department of Housing and Buildings reported yesterday that it was turning its attention to the removal of similar dangers in socalled "converted" dwellings.

A work by an American composer and an appearance by an American soprano as soloist were among the good thing's at last night's concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Dorothy Maynor was the guest artist, singing music by Mozart, Handel and Beethoven.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 16 -- Total mobilization to fight a desperate and long war requires not only anti-inflationary price controls but commodity controls, Herbert Hoover told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today. The former President outlined in detail his plan and methods of administering it.

Announcing that its work of eliminating extreme fire hazards in old-law tenements in New York was virtually completed, the Department of Housing and Buildings reported yesterday that it was turning its attention to the removal of similar dangers in socalled "converted" dwellings.

More details of the intricate financial operations of Serge Rubinstein, international financier, came out yesterday as the hearing into the affairs of the Chosen Corporation was resumed yesterday before Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Proposals for tripling the output of 100-octane aviation gasoline through a plant-expansion program were approved today at the regular meeting of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Plans of the Treasury to sell at least 400 million dollars a month in defense bonds to the wage-earning public through payroll deductions and pledge cards were explained today to State directors of the bond sales. The $400,000,000 figure is only a temporary goal and it must ultimately rise to well over $1,000,000,000 a month, it was said.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Protesting that England had continued horse racing under even greater war dangers, owners of 1,400 of the nation's top thoroughbreds kept their horses at Santa Anita Park tonight, hoping the Army would lift its ban on the meeting.
The Cuban peso, which has shown considerable strength in recent weeks, rose 28 points yesterday to 100.28 cents in terms of the United States dollar. This was the highest level in several years.
South American countries know less about each other than they do about the United States, it was agreed yesterday at a panel discussion conducted by a group of Latin-American women.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- In another move to encourage the spirit of Polish national unity, the Polish Government, by special arrangement with the British authorities, began today selling its own issue of postage stamps, some of which depict memorable war scenes, such as the bombed ruins of the United States Embassy in Warsaw.

Several problems confront Artie Musicant, coach of the Brooklyn College basketball team. Not the least Important is the fact that the squad cannot use its spacious gymnasium for practice sessions earlier than 5 P.M., and by that time the men are tired and eager to get to their homes.

The war in the Pacific may last a year and a half, and one of the events in that widespread battle may be the fall of Hong Kong, "not easy to defend," which will not be a great loss to the British, according to Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, who made a brief stop at La Guardia Field yesterday on his way to Washington from Toronto.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Princeton's basketball quintet staged an early-season display of power as it overwhelmed Lafayette, 47-20, in the university gym tonight.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 17 (From Japanese Broadcasts Recorded by the Associated Press) -- Japan's Domel agency broadcast today a letter written almost a year ago in which Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, Commander in Chief of the Japanese Combined Fleets, said: "I am looking forward to dictating peace to the United States in the White House at Washington."

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The announcement by the Chancellor of the Exchequer of a special issue of government bonds for large taxpayers who would otherwise keep their money idle in banks came as a surprise to the City. These bonds -- interest and other terms of which will be made known later-will be on sale to the public, companies and surtax payers but not to ordinary income taxpayers or investors.

Evidently every duck hunter who went out on the last day of the season had his best shoot of the year, for the only enthusiastic letters we have received since the opening of the season arrived yesterday.

The last of four Wednesday evening lectures at the Museum of Modern Art will be given tonight at 8:30 o'clock by Ruth Olson. The subject will be the three current exhibitions: "Image of Freedom," protographs; "Useful Objects Under $10" and "Brio Mendelsohn, architect."

LONDON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Great Britain charged today that German submarines were sinking French and Spanish merchant ships indiscriminately and throwing the blame on Britain to stir up new trouble and gain "relief from the serious military situation" in Russia and Libya.

A warning against food hoarding was sounded yesterday by William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets, as retail grocers organized and prepared to appeal for Federal intervention to stop hoarding. Both Mr. Morgan and spokesmen for the food industry were agreed, however, that the rush for a few food items such as sugar and tea had been reduced.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN LUZON, Dec. 16 -- A constabulary private has arrived at this inland town with a story of a fight by a single constabulary company, which had become separated from the main Filipino force, against a Japanese invasion party of considerable strength that had effected a beach landing.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- After a year of training 30,000 civilian defense workers and curbing the subversive activities of 2,500 persons, Westchester County is prepared to combat sabotage and to minimize the effects of bombing attacks, county officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- The State Department announced tonight a reciprocal plan under which German, Japanese and Hungarian diplomats and some nationals will receive certain privileges in exchange for comparable treatment of American officials and nationals In their countries.
Men and women wishing to join or aid the military and civilian defense efforts may do so through the following agencies:

The Down Town Glee Club of 190 male voices, which is now in its sixteenth season, last night gave its annual Christmas concert at Carnegie Hall. An audience of 2,700 warmly greeted the club and its new conductor, George Mead.

Recollections "of a little boy of 3 whom I met in an English lane with his tiny gas mask over his shoulder, on his way to infants' school," moved one contributor to give anonymously to New York's Neediest Cases yesterday.
Orders by the Police Department to be followed by all residents In a total blackout have issued to thousands of air-raid wardens. The principal orders and instructions follow:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Faced with a war-impelled academic speed-up, athletic directors of the ivy-clad Big Three today studied the possibility of a curtailment of intercollegiate sports activities at Harvard, Yale and Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Admiral Chester William Nimitz, who will be the new Commander of the Pacific Fleet, is a tanned, whitehaired Texan who entered the Naval Academy in 1901 and reached the rank of Rear Admiral on June 23, 1938.

Speaking at a "Unite for Victory" rally of 15,000 at Madison Square Garden last night, Jan Masaryk, Foreign Minister of the Czecho-Slovakian Government in Exile, declared that Hitler had "lost the war," but that the democracies have not yet won it.

It was voted unanimously, at the annual meeting of the New York Chapter, Baseball Writers Association of America, at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday, that the net proceeds of the nineteenth annual dinner be turned over to the Red Cross.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- As the Pacific Coast increased the tempo of its defense preparations today, 200 buildings in San Francisco were selected as daylight airraid shelters, a speedily built submarine tender was launched at Mare Island Navy Yard, and Dr. Fritz J. Hansgirg, German-born inventor of a new method of manufacturing metallic magnesium, was arrested as an enemy alien.
A taxpayer deal in Yonkers led the Westchester realty trading reported yesterday by brokers.

Twenty-one Christmas trees, erected and decorated at various points in the city, are to be lighted tomorrow afternoon, the Park Department announced yesterday. Thereafter, the trees will be illuminated from 4:30 P.M. to 2:30 A.M. until Jan. 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The proposed merger of eight Eastern trucking companies into Associated Transport, Inc., with operating rights over 24,338 miles of highway along the Atlantic seaboard, was vigorously opposed before the Interstate Commerce Commission today by the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice on the ground that it was a disguised attempt by the railroads, with the help of Kuhn, Loeb Co., to get control of Eastern trucking.

This month's issue of Decision is a large-sized edition that marks the rounding out of the first year of this "review of free culture" edited by Klaus Mann. The issue includes a Free French anthology and presents work by Gide, Sartre, Bernanos, Pierre Cot, French artists and others.

Jim Crowley sent his Fordham football team through an hour of scrimmage yesterday on Rose Hill, the first contact work the Rams have had in the two weeks they have been preparing for the Sugar Bowl game with Missouri.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 17 -- Your correspondent returned here this morning from a week at the Northern Malay front, where British and Japanese forces are entangled in a bitter, no-quarter struggle for control of the rice lands, rubber plantations and jungles in the State of Kedah.

HAVANA, Dec. 17 -- The Cuban Senate this morning, after an all-night session, approved the declaration of a state of national emergency and granted to President Fulgencio Batista and his Cabinet special wartime powers. Prompt approval by the House is expected.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 17 (North American Newspaper Alliance) -- British Empire forces withdrew from Kowloon -- the chief mainland area of Hong Kong -- last Saturday after inflicting heavy losses on the Japanese invaders. The heroic defense of mainland positions by Canadian, British and Hong Kong volunteer units lasted for five days.

The College of Engineering at New York University announced yesterday the immediate introduction of a "speed-up" program for senior students designed to make 200 trained engineers available to the Army, Navy and defense industries by April 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a bill to increase the authorized strength of the Navy by 150,000 tons. There was no debate and the voice vote was unanimous after Senator Walsh, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, briefly explained its purpose.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : We, the faculty of Harlem Evening High School, were shocked and dismayed to see some newspapers' labeling of Harlem as a "crime center." Those of us who have had day-by-day contact with the adolescent and adult population of our school and community have only respect, admiration and affection for the courage, fine character and deep desire for knowledge which our students possess.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Vice President Wallace, in behalf of President Roosevelt, presented the 1940 Collier Aviation Trophy jointly today to Dr. Sanford A. Moss of Lynn, Mass., a General Electric Company engineer, and the Army Air Corps for "outstanding success" in developing the turbo-supercharger, an engine device which makes possible high altitude flying.

Although enrollments for training in civilian defense courses dropped yesterday from the previous record-breaking marks set since the declaration of war, interviewers at the headquarters of the American Women's Voluntary Services, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street, and also at the Civilian Defense Voluntary Offices in Greater New York, 93 Park Avenue, were still busy handling volunteers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- When the Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet and two generals who were in charge of American forces which, according to Secretary Knox, were "not on the alert" against the surprise Japanese attack on Hawaii, Dec. 7, were relieved of their commands, it was one of the most drastic shakeups in American military and naval history.
WASHINOTON, Dec. 17 -- Following is the official White House text of informal remarks delivered extemporaneously by President Roosevelt today to the indiistry-labor conference:

Harry E. Ward, president of the Irving Trust Company, in notifying stockholders yesterday of the annual meeting to be held on Jan. 21, called attention to two questions on which stockholders will vote -- one to put into effect a new retirement pension plan and the other a plan' to change the by-laws by which the bank would indemnify directors against expense in "defending unjust attacks upon them for alleged negligence or misconduct in office."

The efforts begun last month by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels in two magazine articles to prepare the German people for a long, hard war have now been modified apparently to prepare them for news of the reverses on the Russian front.

Five employes and one former employe of the Vital Records Bureau of the City Health Department were accused yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, of having taken tips from applicants for supplying birth certificates and other documents.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Commission men managed to get 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight more for hogs in the early livestock market today, but a part of the advance was lost in later trade. Shipping demand was substantially less than it was last week. The top price today was $11.40, or 10 cents lower than on Monday.

MEMBERS of the local WPA Writers Project have just compiled a volume that ought to interest local readers from Hell Gate and Spuyten Duyvil south to Sandy Hook -- a "Maritime History of New York,"* sponsored by, and with an introduction by, Mayor La Guardia.

MANILA, Dec. 17 -- Two Chinese armies battled toward Hong Kong today to aid the besieged British garrison, according to Chinese radio advices. One column was reported slashing fiercely at the Japanese rear after penetrating almost into the colony. The other was smashing along the coast from the Swatow area, 120 miles to the northeast.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- Newspapers described in close detail and with furious invective today what the German Army did to the group of buildings and their adjacent forest and fields that are known throughout the world as the birthplace and home of one of the greatest geniuses of all time.

Christmas cards designed by Cyrus LeRoy Baldridge are being sold by the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China, a member agency of United China Relief. The cards depict typical Chinese scenes, each carrying a Christmas greeting in English or Chinese or both.

HONG KONG, Dec. 17 -- Japanese attacking forces and the Hong Kong island garrison maintained their artillery duel today, with the late afternoon communique reporting the continued superiority of British marksmanship.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 17 -- Although actual American participation in the war is only a few days old, aid "short of war" previously given by the United States Army to Great Britain in the Middle East made possible the victory at Tobruk -- the heaviest blow yet felt by the German Army outside Russia.

Hundreds of retail Btores in all sections of the country are already well advanced in precautionary air raid work, according to reports reaching the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which yesterday issued a special survey emphasizing that retailers should lose no time in the organization of their own civilian defense units.

Warning of the approach of raiders will be sounded by the sirens of police and fire apparatus -- one long and one short blast alternately for five minutes. The all-clear signal will be sounded by the same apparatus and will consist of a series of short blasts over a five-minute period.

The flotation yesterday of $18,465,000 of Pennsylvania Railroad 2 3/8 per cent equipment trust certificates turned the spotlight, at least temporarily, upon the market for such securities, both in respect to the substantial readjustment that has taken place recently in the cost of these funds to the carriers and in the steady supply of issues.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- Development of a process in photography which will enable any amateur with an ordinary camera to obtain full color prints instead of blacks and whites from his negatives was described before the Franklin Institute tonight by Dr. C.E.K. Mees, director of research and development for the Eastman Kodak Company.

The first of two meetings to explain plans for the protection of school children during wartime emergencies will be held at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon in The New York Times Hall, formerly the Little Theatre, on West Fortyfourth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

In the belief that the presence of pickets on city streets is not conducive to good morale, Mayor La Guardia has sent to seven employers involved in strikes that began before the war telegrams urging acceptance of union offers to arbitrate, discontinue picketing and resume work.

The First Boston Corporation heads an underwriting group that today will offer to the public $1,400,000 of Mobile Gas Service Corporation first mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, due in 1961, and 6,000 shares of the corporation's 6 per cent $100 par value cumulative preferred stock.

Many Buyers Due Next Month Although uncertainty continues the rule with respect to Spring operations, resident office executives said yesterday there was no doubt that many buyers will make their appearance in the local markets early next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that eighty-nine Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $373,511,353 in November, compared with $309,014,147 in November, 1940.

Sales of defense bonds continued yesterday in record-breaking volume throughout the city and reports from other parts of the country indicated increases rather than temporary slackening of the demand. Most issuing agents, commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations, as well as post offices, which have run out of bonds of the $25 and $50 face maturity values, issued receipts and promised deliveries as soon as fresh supplies arrived from the Treasury.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The executive committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board established today an emergency committee, designed to foster orderly continuation of the industry in wartime and to lend its full assistance to the nation's war effort.

Two feminine stars will quit Broadway on Jan. 10 and take to the road. Cornelia Otis Skinner is the latest one announced to end her engagement on that date, after chalking up a run of seventy performances for "Theatre," the Guy Bolton-Somerset Maugham play at the Hudson.
CAIRO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A Middle East Command communique:

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 17 -- Imperial Impy, owned by J.L. Friedman of Baltimore, rallied in the stretch today to shake off Mrs. J.Y. Christmas's Rough Time and went on to win by two lengths in a drive. Only five horses competed in the seven-furlong feature.

Forget for the moment that the football season is just over and think of the three men whose names were most prominent in sports news during 1941. You'll probably come up with the names of the athletes who were listed one, two, three in the consensus of eighty-two sports experts participating in the annual Associated Press poll.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The 10,000-ton U.S. cruiser Columbia was launched at the yards of the New York Ship Building Company here today only sixteen months after its keel had been laid and only six weeks after its sister ship, the Cleveland, entered the water.

Nothing better illustrates the utter unreality of some of the alignments in this conflict than the announcement that Albania has declared war against the United States. As far as this country is concerned, Rome's act of ventriloquism for its helpless little vassal is merely ludicrous, but for Albania it borders on the tragic.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The shipments of defense materials to the Allied powers continue, despite our involvement in the war, and will inevitably increase, Secretary Stimson stated today.

Bright basketball years seem close at hand for Manhattan College again. That is the general opinion up on Riverdale Hill, even though injuries to talented Tom Courtney and the inexperience of several highly rated sophomorea may handicap the Jaspers a bit this season.
NEW YORK Don Rodolfo Michels, the Chilean Ambassador, has arrived from Washing-ton, and la at the WaldorfAstoria.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 17 -- A usually reliable diplomatic source reported today that the Germans were withdrawing all their troops from Finland and that three-quarters or three-fifths of the four to five German divisions that the Germans recently had on Finnish soil had left the country.

Special Notice The Director of the Budget has notified this department, as well as all other city departments and agencies, that It has become necessary to economize In every possible way in the use of .supplies, materials and equipment.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- The government announced tonight that it had met at 5 P.M. to study "serious events that had occurred" in the Portuguese colony of Timor in the southeastern part of the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Japanese attacks yesterday on the island of Maui, in the Hawaiian group, and Johnston Island, 700 miles southwest of Honolulu, caused no casualties and little property damage, it was stated today in communiques issued by the War and Navy Departments.

The Giants, who think more of their chances against the Bears at Chicago on Sunday than does the man in the street, had done no contact work since their meeting with the Dodgers. At that time it will be recalled, the Dodgers did most of the contacting.

A policy of "wait and see" in regard to athletics and the war emergency has been generally adopted by the major local universities and colleges, a check with authorities last night revealed. There is a definite feeling that it is best to hold fast to present setups rather than to take what might be premature action.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Fruit exchanges of California and Florida, together with ten auction houses and numerous individuals, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

Thirty-eight years to the day after he and his brother, Wilbur, made the world's first controlled flight in a power-driven, heavier-than-air plane, Orville Wright last night expressed the belief that aircraft would eventually help to bring a guarantee of human liberty and lasting peace to the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a bill which would amend present veterans' insurance laws to give $5,000 in death benefits to relatives of all members of the armed forces who have died while on active duty since the middle of October.

The President has shown good judgment in putting an experienced news man at the head of the partly mandatory, partly voluntary system of censorship which is now to be established in Washington. His appointment of Byron Price of The Associated Press to this office is an excellent choice.
CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A British Embassy communique:

Elaborate preparations for the treatment and transportation of those injured in air raids or any similar emergency have been worked out by the Emergency Medical Service for Civilian Defense and were described last night by Dr. George Baehr, chief medical officer in charge of the medical division of the Office of Civilian Defense.

LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Lord Moyne, Colonial Minister, disclosed tonight that Hong Kong had rejected a second Japanese overture for its surrender and that he had sent the Crown Colony's Governor, Sir Mark Young, a message approving his decision and telling him to "hold on."

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 18 -- The inter-island passenger vessel Corregidor, crowded with persons going from Manila to the central islands, sank in darkness early yesterday after having struck a mine at the entrance to Manila Bay.

In the minds of a great many people the name of former President Hoover is inseparably linked with the phrase "rugged individualism." He above most men in public life might be expected to oppose any unnecessary interference by Government with the normal life of the people.

To the vast majority of NOT Yorkers, tests of two different types of air-raid sirens yesterday afternoon were unqualified failures Whole areas of the city, like Times Square and the theatrical district, the upper West Side, the Bronx and Staten Island, for the most part awaited the experimental alarms in vain.

Lew Jenkins and Sammy Angott yesterday reached the stage where they require only limbering up exercises to keep at fighting edge for their fifteen-round battle tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden. The bout will carry undisputed possession of the world lightweight championship.

During his four-week engagement with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, which begins tonight, Dimitri Mitropoulos, Greek conductor, will offer the world premieres of five new works, the first New York performances of four others and the first performances by the Philharmonic of a Glazounoff Overture and four Busoni works.

Samuel W. Reyburn, chairman of the board of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, has leased a furnished apartment of seven rooms and three baths in the building at 383 Park Avenue through the Madison Realty Company. Another lease negotiated by the latter concern was with Dr. A.C. Howell, who took a suite of six rooms and three baths in 25 East Eighty-sixth Street.

The Rutgers varsity swimmers defeated Columbia, 46 -- 29, in the Morningside Heights pool last night in the first meet of the season for both squad In the traditional basketball opener, the Lion varsity quintet overwhelmed an alumni team, 67 -- 27.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Fines totaling $54,000 were imposed at Newark, N.J., today upon four corporations and five persons charged with conspiring with German and other European interests to restrict the importation and manufacture of medicinal hormones in the United States and to control other world markets, according to an announcement by the Department of Justice.

The recovery scored by stocks since the break occasioned by the Japanese attack on Hawaii was practically eliminated yesterday under the weight of selling ascribed to domestic and foreign factors bearing on the war. Losses on the Stock Exchange ran as high as 4 points before moderate support made its appearance, although the rally was negligible and at best not more than a point of the decline was reclaimed.

Two New York lawyers entered a suit for $40,000,000 damages in Federal court yesterday against the Bausch Lomb Optical Company, Carl Zeiss, Inc., and three men described as officers and directors of both corporations. The complaint charged bid-rigging on military contracts.
BERLIN, Dec. 17 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A German High Command communique:
BATAVIA, Netherland Indies, Dec. 17 (AP) -- A direct hit was scored by a Netherland bomber on a Japanese destroyer covering enemy landing operations at Miri, Sarawak, a communique announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Action of the wheat market today was dominated by the announcement that the government was willing to sell 170,000,000 bushels of its holdings of 1939 and 1940 crop wheat at the market price or 15 cents a bushel over the loan, whichever is higher.

If the Allies hold Singapore, the war will be a relatively short one, for continued control of Singapore would assure our access to many vital materials, according to Dr. N.Y. Elliott, deputy chief of the materials division of the Office of Production Management.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Approval of a conservation program designed to assure the most efficient and least wasteful production of continuing supply of California petroleum for the war in the Pacific was announced today by Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator.

In one of the largest cash transactions of the year in the Manhattan real estate field, the Manufacturers Trust Company has acquired from the heirs of Mary Mason Jones the modern fifteen-story bank and office building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, known as 1 East Fifty-seventh Street and 741 Fifth Avenue.

The main British forces in Libya, sweeping past El Gazala, have now driven forward approximately 150 miles from the line at which they started. Berlin and Rome both admit that the British still hold the initiative. Despite heavy losses they continue to throw in fresh fighters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A suggestion that the government advance delivery dates on most of its outstanding contracts for armament and thereby force large contractors to whittle down their "backlogs" of orders by subcontracting, was placed before the Senate's Aid to Small Business Committee today by James B. Ingebretzen, Washington representative of the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce.

Methods similar to those adopted in England to solve problems of labor and to protect small business in the expansion of defense industries were recommended yesterday by Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin in an address to members of the Advertising Club, 23 Park Avenue.

Arrangements for use of the political clubhouses for civilian defense were made yesterday by Bert Stand, secretary of Tammany, representing Christopher D. Sullivan, and George H. Sibley, representing Thomas J. Curran, Republican County Chairman, at a conference at the National Republican, Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The House, by a voice vote, decided today to extend military liability to men between the ages of 21 and 44, inclusive, after refusing to accept President Roosevelt's request to lower the age of draft registration to 19 years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The area of the war and the divisions of resources among the belligerents are such that a total allied effort by the nations opposing the Axis, to meet the pool of strength against them, is now an immediate necessity. This is generally conceded.
Trading in cotton futures continued quiet yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures closed at their worst levels for the session, with net losses of 11 to 19 points.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- Pennsylvania intends to go through with its regular 1942 athletic schedule, according to a statement made today by Dr. E. Le Roy Mercer, dean of the Department of Physical Education.

Replying to a question as to when Russia's armed forces might be able to aid this country's fight against Japan, Major Gen. Alexander Reppin, head of the Russian military mission here, declared yesterday that "all the enemies of the United States now also are the enemies of the Soviet Union."
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 17 -- In a rough contest in which thirty-two fouls were called, Dartmouth's basketball team continued in the undefeated class by staving off Fordham tonight, 53 -- 52.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Roosevelt called today upon representatives of labor and management, summoned here to establish a policy under which defense production stoppages will cease for the duration of war, to reach unanimous agreement "just as fast as you can," and suggested Friday night, "at the latest," as a deadline.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17 -- In the first South American-North American swimming meet held in the Payne Whitney pool at Tale tonight, Miss Maria Lenk of Brazil gave the most colorful performance when, swimming alone, she covered the 200 - yard breast - stroke in 2:49.8.

SQUANKUM, N.J., Dec. 17 -- If parachute troops had landed in the rural sections of Alonmouth or Ocean County today, they would have been wiped out before they had dropped below the tree level. After tramping the woods all day we ate almost ready to believe there was a, deer hunter behind every bush.

Women in fur coats and flowered hats climbed as many as nine flights of stairs yesterday at the New York chapter headquarters of the American Red Cross, where elevators were overloaded for the ninth day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- New York City has the largest foreign-born white population of any city in the country, according to figures etstablished in the recent census.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 17 -- Activities to which colonists are devoting much time include the newly organized Volunteers for Victory and the local unit of the Palm Beach County Red Cross Motor Corps. The objectives of the former include promotion of the welfare of local service men, coordination of wartime efforts and full cooperation with the Red Cross.

MOSCOW, Thursday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Red Army troops were reported officially early today to have thrown the Germans back almost 100 miles beyond this capital in their sixteen-day Winter offensive to lift the sieges of Leningrad in the north and Sevastopol in the south.

The New York Athletic Club's Class A squash tennis team gained its fifth victory to remain unbeaten last night in the metropolitan interclub series. The Winged Footers scored a 5-0 triumph against the Yale Club.

The Marine Trust Company and associates received yesterday the award of an issue of $979,000 of funding and highway bonds of Rensselaer County, N.Y., on a bid of 100.31 for 2.10s. The bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1942, will mature on July 1, 1942, to Jan. 1, 1957.
As Christmas shoppers poured through midtown, the area's perpetual business-day traffic congestion mounted yesterday toward its annual peak in the final week before the holiday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17--The three commanders of Naval, Army and Army Air Forces in Hawaii were relieved of their commands tonight in orders issued simultaneously by the War and Navy Departments.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 17 (AP) Hope bloomed anew along Santa Anita's famed horse row today. Track officials expressed confidence the multimillion-dollar turf meeting would get under way sooner or later-possibly toy Jan. 15.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The war news from the Far East had a restricting influence on stock markets today, few new commitments being entered into. In the giltedged section selling developed in the Australian and New Zealand loans and British funds weakened fractionally.

Four new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. Metro's screen version of the John P. Marquand novel, "H.M. Pulham, Esq.," will be the new attraction at the Radio City Music Hall. Robert Young portrays the title role in the drama, and Hedy Lamarr, Ruth Hussey, Charles Coburn, Van Heflin, Bonita Granville, Fay Holden and Leif Erikson head the featured cast.

Even before the United States entered the war, the first real crack became evident in the morale of the German people, according to information printed yesterday in Inside Germany Reports, a bimonthly publication of the American Friends of German Freedom.

In what may be the beginning of a holiday price war, metropolitan department stores and independent liquor dealers yesterday reported reduced prices on certain popular brands of rye whisky despite existing price-maintenance contracts. Department stores which reported the lower prices included Macy's, Bloomingdale, Gimbels and Hearn.

MANILA, Dec. 17 (U.P.)--United States fliers led by Lieutenant Boyd D. Wagner of Johnstown, Pa., first American ace of the war, have blasted out a nest of twenty-six Japanese airplanes at Vigan, more than 200 miles northwest of Manila, it was announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 17 -- The first application of the national state of siege declared yesterday was an order today from the Ministry of the Interior canceling permission for an open-air mass meeting scheduled for Saturday by Accion Argentina to "pay homage to President Roosevelt" and to reaffirm the adhesion of the Argentine people to the democratic cause.

The war cast its shadow over the traditional lighting of the Yule log at Columbia University yesterday, as Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler told 200 students and their guests that he could hardly wish them a merry Christmas this year, but hoped that it would be "one of peace and abundance and quiet thought."

City Hall assumed a martial air yesterday as twenty women uniformed as defense volunteers were assigned to various points in the building to serve as messengers and receptionists after one day of drill at Police Headquarters.

HONOLULU, Dec. 17 -- The islands settled farther into their war routine today as the rationing of gasoline thinned out motor travel and definite food restrictions on, the island of Hawaii were announced.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 17 -- Heavy sandstorms that turned day into night forced the advancing British troops in Libya to take cover at times yesterday and definitely hindered the attack against the Germans and Italians southwest of El Gazala and in El Gazala itself.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 17 -- The Bolivian Government is endeavoring through diplomatic channels to obtain a revision of prices for metals exported to the United States under present contracts.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- A drastic revision of penalties for illicit operations in the black market was announced today in the House of Lords by Lord Woolton, Food Minister. Strengthening of the courts' powers came in response to widespread public anger over the activities of food racketeers.

Proof that the Army these days is harassed by more than military problems was offered yesterday when a member of the Quartermaster Corps was called upon to taste a casserole of "glamourized" baked beans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Jean Gabin's second American picture will be "Down to the Sea in Ships," nineteenth-century New England whaling story, if Twentieth Century-Fox adheres to current plans for the French actor, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- The government expects every one of the nation's 35,000,000 recipients of regular income to set aside some part of his pay regularly to buy defense savings bonds. Secretary Morgenthau said today in addressing an assemblage of defense bond chairmen from all the States.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- For the first time since World War I, women are on the production line at the plant of the Wallace Tiernan Company in Belleville because of a shortage of men workers. The plant, one of the largest in Essex County, is making sanitation equipment and parts for tanks and signal equipment for the Army.

The New York State Defense Council, set up in the Summer of 1940, is now ready with a "sound structure for the part New York State must play in the war," Lieutenant Governor Charles Poletti, State Defense Coordinator, told the Kiwanis Club at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel McAlpin.

Otto F. Muller, who was discharged last month from the Army "without honor," was arrested last night and charged with having started a fire in an old-law tenement on the West Side yesterday morning that resulted in the death of an aged man and serious injury to his wife and daughter.

more and harder work for all and the nation again will have to combat internal forces of intolerance and prejudice, Wendell L. Willkie, Republican candidate for President in 1940, declared yesterday at a luncheon of leaders in the entertainment field, held in the Hotel Astor under the auspices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

Net paid circulation of twentyone national magazines during the year ended June 30 was 1,103,150,116, an increase of 5.5 per cent over the previous twelve-month period, according to the eleventh annual edition of "Analysis of Net Paid Circulation and Subscription Production," issued yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers, 330 West Forty-second Street.

Mrs. John Mead Howells gave a luncheon yesterday at the Colony Club for Miss Lispenard Seabury Crocker, debutante daughter of Edward Savage Crocker, former first secretary at the United States Embassy in Tokyo, and Mrs. Crocker.
Adams-Millis The Adams-Millis Corporation voted a 25-cent dividend on the common stock, raising the total to $1.25 this year, against $1 distributed in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- News releases will continue to be issued through regular government departments rather than through one central official agency, Stephen Early, Presidential press secretary, stated today in discussing government censorship plans.

RIO DE JANIERO, Brazil, Dec. 17-- The independent press in Rio de Janeiro presented today a novel and varied fare in its comment on the war situation. For the first time the newspaper Imparcial went so far as to refer to "Nazi assassins" in a headline.

The 900-seat Rivoli Theatre, at 1374 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, on the northeast corner of Harmon Street, running through to Himrod Street, has been sold by George Giegerich to the Hartle Realty Corporation, a client of Moses H. Hoenig, attorney.

Though there are some nations which are at war with Germany but not with Japan, and other nations which are at war with Japan but not with Germany, this is an indivisible struggle. It cannot be fought successfully in segments. For it is clear beyond all possibility of doubt that any important gain or loss on any single front immediately and vitally affects the situation on all other fronts.

The shake-up last night in military and naval high commands in the Pacific, following hard upon the tragedy at Pearl Harbor, should do much to ease the public doubts that the attack on Pearl Harbor engendered.

In the belief that the air raids precautions that have been developed will prove adequate to meet any situation that may arise, the Bronx zoo has decided against destroying any of its animals, at least for the present, its officials announced yesterday.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau yesterday announced the appointment of Robert W, Sparks, vice president of the Bowery Savings Bank of this city, as director of the field service of the defense savings staff.

Land of Drowsy Syrups Long before anybody heard of anti-aircraft protection they knew about antimacassar protection. Perhaps no other symbol of a now extinct Victorian civilization provided so much amusement for insurgent young generations as those little white doilies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Temporary price ceilings were set today by the Office of Price Administration on a broad range of textiles, including finished goods. The prices were established at levels prevailing prior to Dec. 6. A unique feature of today's order was that it marked the first time OPA has set prices for such finished goods as blankets, towels, tablecloths, sheets and pillow cases.

After an absence of fifteen years from the local concert platform, Moissaye Boguslawski, pianist, was heard in a recital last night in Town Hall, where he was welcomed by a large and demonstrative audience. His program contained as its main items the Bach-Busoni organ prelude and fugue in D major, Brahms's Paganini variations.

BERLIN, Dec. 17 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by The United Press) -- The Premier and War Minister of Japan, General Hideki Tojo, in a war review before Parliament, said today that "two Japanese columns have landed in Northern and Southern Luzon and now are on the march in the direction of Manila."

Treasury Requirements Sales of defense bonds are booming throughout the nation and will continue to boom as plans for organized speed-up of sales are put into operation. However, there is no disposition now in banking circles to regard this windfall to the Treasury as likely to cause any deviation by the Treasury from its regular financing plans with respect to the general government bond market.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17 -- San Pedro, in the harbor area, had a brief bomb scare today when firecrackers, probably discarded by an Oriental who didn't want to be caught redhanded with combustibles, began going off in an incinerator.

Rules for the care of dogs and cats in air raids, based on experience in England, have been prepared by the American Red Star Animal Relief Society and are being distributed jointly by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, the Women's League for Animals, the New York Humane Society and the Bide-a-Wee Home.

To help American artists participate most effectively in the country's war effort, the Fine Arts Federation of New York, representing: seventeen leading art organizations, has organized the National Art Council for Defense.

The boards of trustees of the American Surety Company and its affiliate, the New York Casualty Company, have authorized the payment of bonuses by Dec. 24 to employes who were on the regular staffs on Monday and who were receiving salaries not exceeding $10,000 a year, A.F. Lafrentz, president, announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A denial by Charles West that he claimed a $700,000 fee from the Empire Ordnance Corporation on the sale of his "influence" in Washington in aiding the company to get war contracts was made to the Senate Defense Investigating Committee today.

Mayor La Guardia announced at City Hall yesterday morning that a Regular Army regiment of 3,000 men would arrive in the city at noon to guard points considered vital in the city, on direct orders from President Roosevelt. No announcement was made as to their actual arrival.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Roosevelt talked with Secretary Perkins, William H. Davis, Senator Thomas and members of the labor-industry war policy conference, and conferred with Richard Casey, Australian Minister.

WITH THE RED ARMY ON THE MOSCOW FRONT, Dec. 17 (UP) -- The Red Army offensive northwest of Moscow is gaining momentum across a great frozen battlefield cluttered with an unrecognizable mass of wrecked machines of war.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 17 -- Eight units and forty-two individuals were commended today by Brig. Gen. James I. Muir, Forty-fourth Division commander, for meritorious and outstanding service during the recent First Army manoeuvres and will receive divisional certificates of commendation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- Fines totaling $35,500 were imposed on five baking firms and seven individuals in the Federal District Court today when their pleas to a charge of illegal fixing of bread prices were changed from not guilty to nolo contendere.

WASHINGTON Dec. 17 -- To meet the emergency requirements of the nation's armed forces and civilian population an increase of 50,000 in the American Red Cross first reserve of trained nurses, now numbering 24,000, will be needed, Miss Mary Beard, director of the Red Cross Nursing Service, said today.

A new major league record of 196 double plays by the world champion Tankees provided the highlight of defensive play in the American League for 1941, according to the official fielding figures released for publication today. This mark topped by two the previous mark of 194 twin killing's set by the Reds in 1928 and duplicated by the Cincinnatians in 1931.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Erie Railroad to issue new securities to put into effect a plan of reorganization for the company.

RYE, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Princeton's sextet suffered its first loss of the still-young campaign tonight, bowing, 3 to 1, to the St. Nicholas Hockey Club on the Playland Casino ice. The Tigers previously had beaten their alumni and Boston University.

Despite the apparently inclusive language of the insurance coverage described in the announcement of formation of the War Insurance Corporation by the Federal Loan Administration on Dec. 13, some local property owners and real estate operators are disturbed by the absence of precise knowledge as to what protection from damages to property "by enemy action" can be expected.

With hopes fading but not altogether gone, Red Dutton will guide his harried Brooklyn Americans through another bid to win a National Hockey League skirmish tonight in Madison Square Garden. The star-spangled band clashes with the Red Wings, a sextet the Brooklyn stick wielders have yet to beat this year.

Clashes of opposing counsel occupied most of the hearing yesterday before Supreme Court Referee Richard P. Lydon investigating the affairs of the Chosen Corporation, Ltd. At the close of the morning session Judge Lydon adjourned the proceedings sine die.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 17--Two long-range threats to Singapore mounted tonight on the basis of reports that Japanese forces had made landings in the British part of Borneo and had crossed the Muda River in Northwest Malaya only 10 miles from the Penang naval base.

Calling upon American business to "resist centralization with bitter determination" and "demand now, in the middle of the war -- that the shackles be struck from it" to permit it to prepare for the absorption of labor after the war, Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University, yesterday scored regimentation and the surrender of individual rights to the State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, has been selected to head the United States delegation to the Pan-American Conference in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, reliable diplomatic sources reported today. The governing board of the Pan-American Union set Jan. 15 as the date of the gathering.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Emphasizing that the nation's food supply was of record proportions, Secretary Wickard said today there was little excuse for any substantial increase in prices of farm products as a result of this country's entry into the war.

A little applied psychology will smooth out the bumpy spots in the approaching holiday, says Miss Lilian Anderson, children's nutrition expert of the Community Service Society. The bugaboo of too much Christmas candy, which has baffled many a mother, may be easily vanquished by the simple expedient of dragging a few red herrings across the trail of the candy-conscious child.
LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- An Admiralty communiqe:

A painstaking New York University basketball team, especially overhauled for the occasion, scored its fourth victory in four games last night, defeating Newark University, 55 -- 17, at the University Heights gymnasium.
VICHY, France, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- Germans began rounding up many Americans in the occupied zone tonight, including wealthy expatriates and hundreds of students, reports from Paris said.

With, a plea to sports authorities to avoid hysteria and premature action, Executive Director Asa S. Bushnell of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics announced yesterday that the fifth annual schedule-making convention on Jan. 9 in this city would take place as planned.

The war will not affect activities of symphony orchestras in the United States, managers of sixteen major American symphonies, who have been meeting in New York since last Sunday, unanimously agreed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Secretaries Knox and Stimson, Adimiral Harold R. Stark, General George C. Marshall, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander of the Pacific Fleet; Admiral Ernest J. King, commander of the Atlantic Fleet, and Lieut. Gen. H.H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Corps.

MANILA, Friday, Dec. 19 -- More than thirty Japanese planes yesterday bombed the port of Iloilo on the island of Panay, a rich sugar producing area, in the central Philippines, headquarters here of the United States Army for the Far East reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Army will soon cease to accept enlistments and will fill its future needs, including those of the Air Corps, exclusively through the machinery of the Selective Service, Secretary Stimson stated today.

Complications developed yesterday in the market for new issues of railway equipment-trust certificates that disrupted, for the time being, the smooth course that this type of financing had followed this week, even under the strain of wartime conditions.

NEW YORK Walter C. Dowling, formerly Third Secretary of the United States Embassy at Rome, and Mrs. Dowling are at the Waldorf-Astoria before sailing for Rio do Janeiro, where Mr. Dowling will be attached to the United States Embassy.

ALLAIRE, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Because of the driving activities carried on yesterday, the deer were scattered and were easily frightened, and in most of the areas we checked the kill was much smaller than on the opening day.

Acker Man, Inc., makers of window cleaning and safety equipment, purchased yesterday from the 630 Broadway Corporation, Samuel B. Shankman, president, the six-story mercantile building at 120-122 West Eighteenth Street. They acquired the property under the name of the C. H. Holding Corporation and will spend $15,000 on improvements to care for expansion of their business.
American Meter The extra dividend of 20 cents a share declared by the American Meter Company, Inc., makes a total of $3.45 for 1941, or 20 cents more than payments in 1940.

Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx jeered at Mayor La Guardia's "non-partisan, non-political administration" yesterday when he dissented from the Board of Estimate's action in granting a one-year extension to Frederick J.H. Kracke, chairman of the Board of Assessors and a powerful influence in Republican circles in Brooklyn.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- The British Embassy here today reported successful British bombardment from Hong Kong Island of Japanese positions in Kowloon.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 -- Scattering the last remnants of the German tank strength in Libya, British armored forces and infantry units have broken the Axis line west of El Gazala and have sent the Germans reeling backward in headlong retreat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The course of the French-German negotiations that culminated in the Saint-Florentin meeting on Dec. 1 is no longer entirely concealed from the outside world. A corner of the veil seems to have been lifted.

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 18 -- Duke University officials said tonight that the transplanted Rose Bowl football game here Jan. 1 between Duke and Oregon State was a sellout. The Duke Stadium, with temporary stands installed, will seat about 55,000.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 18 -- Mrs. Flynn Stewart entertained with a dinner tonight at D'Alja for Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Licensed amateur radio operators of the country were asked today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, to apply for free training in marine radio-telegraphy to prepare for posts as radio operators on merchant vessels.
Roses, arriving daily in lots of more than 100,000 blooms, are the outstanding flower choice of the week-end for abundance and price economy.
The out-of-town soldiers talk about New York and the New Yorkers talk about pretty girls at the New York City Defense Recreation headquarters, 99 Park Avenue.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 18 -- Speaking to the women of Italy on the occasion of the sixth anniversary of the "Day of Faith," when gold wedding rings were surrendered for the conquest of Ethiopia. Premier Benito Mussolini today warned that "this war will be a long and a hard one" because "it is a war that is changing the destinies of mankind" and "directly or indirectly more than 2,000,000,000 human beings are involved."

Mess bugle blew yesterday at the headquarters of the Army recruiting station, Whitehall Street, just as it does in regular service. But the cooks who served the food were no ordinary potato peelers. They wore the uniforms of the American Red Cross.

Metropolitan enthusiasts anxious to test their skis for the first time this week-end will have to travel to Upper New York State, the Green and White Mountains of Vermont and New Hampshire and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada. Limited reports, owing to wartime regulations, indicated last night that the open-slope type of sport will be possible on a fairly large scale.

Phelps, Fenn Co. head an underwriting syndicate which received yesterday the award of $3,940,000 of city of Minneapolis, Minn., bonds. The bonds were sold at two separate sales and consisted of $2,555,000 of refunding bonds, due on Jan. 1, 1943, to 1952, for which the group paid 100.159 as 1.80s, and $1,385,000 of public relief and permanent improvement bonds, for which a price of 100.1317 was paid for 1.90s.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 13 were 807,225 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 26,150 cars, or 3.1 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, but 70,885 cars, or 9.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 129,093 cars, or 19.0 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Roosevelt conferred today with high Army and Navy officials, including Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, new commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet, and Admiral Ernest J. King, commander of the Atlantic Fleet.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 18 (From Finnish broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

TRENTON, Dec. 18 -- Leaders of the Republican majority in the Legislature agreed today to center all authority over the State's civilian defense machinery in Governor Charles Edison, and the Governor, a Democrat, announced that his agent in the task of coordinating the civilian security program would be Brig. Gen. Richard P. Williams, who was appointed State secretary for defense several months ago.

Only five of Broadways shows have decided to stick to their regular evening price scale for the performance on New Year's Eve -- when, by tradition, things are apt to be a little higher around Times Square. The five are "Brooklyn, U.S.A." and "The First Crocus," which are scheduled to open next week, and "Macbeth," "The Corn Is Green" and "Watch on the Rhine," which are well established.

The annual Christmas exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum has been assembled in a room in the Junior Museum as a fitting place to illustrate the Christmas story in art. The walls of this room are painted in Madonna blue.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (U.P) -- It was learned today that British and Netherland officials had notified Lisbon that they hoped the Portuguese Governor would continue to exercise his office in Timor. The British Ambassador, Sir Ronald Campbell, was said to have explained fully to Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar in Lisbon the strategic necessity that had prompted the Allied action.

Excess Reserve Drop Reflecting the Treasury's new bond financing, together with tax payments on Dec. 15, and a sharp increase in money in circulation, due to the Christmas season and to some evidences of hoarding, excess reserves of member banks of the entire Frederal Reserve System dropped $750,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $3,090,000,000.

The property at 759 Farragut Place, West New York, N.J., which has been used as a tavern for more than seventy years, has been sold by Anton Hrinda to Eugene A. Fischer, who recently sold his tavern at 7008 Park Avenue, Guttenberg.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 19 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- One Japanese destroyer is missing, the navy section of Imperial Headquarters reported yesterday.

Despite the disapproval of the school officials, a teacher who has rendered thirty-five years of service may retire if she so requests, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins ruled yesterday, in denying the Board of Retirement the right to block the pension of Miss Louise Tucker, an elementary school principal, who was dismissed on charges by the Board of Education last Spring.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The new Lanham bill appropriating funds for war housing has now passed the House and awaits Senate action. If enacted in its present form it must seriously threaten the war effort.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 -- One hundred enemy aliens rounded up in the San Francisco Bay area were started by train today to a concentration camp at Missoula, Mont., as a big magnesium plant at Los Altos, described as vital in the defense industry, faced "complete shutdown" because of an alien's arrest.

Warning or the approach of raiders will be sounded by the sirens of police and fire apparatus -- one long and one short blast alternately for five minutes. The all-clear signal will be sounded by the same apparatus and will consist of a series of short blasts over a five-minute period.

Springfield's hard-playing basketball team staged a Golden Ball victory over Manhattan last night triumphing, 51-45, in an overtime game that was one of a series marking the national observance of the golden jubilee of basketball. Scoring honors went to Rosa Merrick, center for the Indians, owho netted 15 points. Manhattan's Dick Murphy netted 13.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Japanese have pushed 100 miles into Malaya in eleven days of attacks prosecuted with fanatical disregard of a constantly high death toll but have not yet managed to convert their jungle offensive into a major push, the British reported tonight as their own main defense line was pulled back to about 300 air miles north of vital Singapore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, at odds for more than five years on basic questions of labor organization, policy and political activity, were said to have offered to industry today a joint plan for uninterrupted production during the war.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The British Headquarters communique said today:

More than 500 representatives of parents' organizations in Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond attended a special meeting yesterday afternoon in THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall, formerly the Little Theatre, in West Forty-fourth Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, to hear Mayor La Guardia and others tell what the city is doing to protect their children in case of air raids, and how school and family can best cooperate for individual and social welfare.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Frank Cohen, founder of Empire Ordnance Corporation and affiliates, which are building cannon for British tanks and ships for the United States Maritime Commission, denied today that he hired Charles West, former Democratic Under-Secretary of the Interior, for his "influence" in an attempt to obtain defense contracts.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The shattered German and Italian armies in Eastern Cyrenaica were officially reported tonight to be in full retreat, pursued by British-manned, United States-built tanks and blasted by Royal Air Force bombers.

The decline in demand for major electrical appliances which started in October has become more severe in the last ten days, distributors reported yesterday. At the same time, they are finding that dealers in most cases will be able to meet the Christmas rush for small appliances, a development which they did not think possible two months ago.

In spite of a minor flurry of inflation at the beginning of this week -- according to a report of the consumers service division of the Department of Markets -- meat prices this week-end seem to be settling into a normal mid-winter condition, comparatively high but not exorbitant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- German diplomats and newspaper correspondents, under detention pending their repatriation to Germany, have been moved from Washington to a mountain resort in an Eastern State.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Roosevelt wrote a letter today "To the President of the United States in 1956," requesting that Colin P. Kelly 3d, eighteen months old and the son of Captain Colin P. Kelly Jr., who lost his life bombing to destruction the Japanese battleship Haruna, be appointed to West Point fifteen years hence.
LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Admiralty today issued the following communique:

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Allied military and political experts were authoritatively reported tonight to be conferring on the establishment of a Supreme War Council to direct strategy, pool resources and checkerboard their man power around the globe in the fight against the Axis.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The National Football League's championship game Sunday between the Bears and the Giants will match the circuit's best ground-gaining club against its top defensive unit.

Alfred Emil Andersen Jr., an 18-year-old American boy of Norwegian parentage, who went to Norway in 1932 to attend school, returned yesterday on an American vessel after visiting various countries since last June in his efforts to get home.

The perfect antidote for hours of work in a uniform is to be found in the evening creations of Joseph Whitehead. Their delicate femininity banishes, at least for a while, thought of bandages, alarms and other war activities of women.

A leading apartment leasing transaction reported yesterday by Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., calls for occupancy of a suite of fourteen rooms and seven baths in 895 Park Avenue by Edward C. Delafield, partner of Delafield Delafield, bankers.
AIR RAID WARDENS -- Men and women, 18 to 55 years of age, may join at nearest police station. Must be American citizens.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Substantial changes were recorded in the Bank of England statement issued today with note circulation establishing another record high. This Item has increased steadily for fifteen weeks. The jump last week amounted to u13,467,000.
