LONDON, Friday, Dec. 19 (U.P.) -- Four-motored British raiders, diving into terrific Nazi defense fire, laid cargoes of "very heavy" bombs across the German battleships Gneisenau and Scharnhorst at Brest yesterday and were believed to have scored direct hits, the Air Ministry reported today.
A 20-year-old golfer has emerged to check the threatened monopoly of tennis players on the title of outstanding woman athlete of the year.
Whitehead Fischer Employes who have been with Whitehead Fischer more than a year will receive a Christmas bonus of two weeks' salary. One week's salary will be paid those employed less than a year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A program for internment in camps in the Southwest of enemy aliens whose confinement is thought necessary was made public today by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The roll-call vote by which the Senate rejected the Danaher amendment to the Draft Extension Bill seeking to limit compulsory military service to those 21 to 44, inclusive, was as follows:

With civic, political and professional groups offering the entire memberships of their respective organizations for civilian defense duties, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Offices in Greater New York, 93 Park Avenue, yesterday announced the need for 10,000 men and women for regular community service.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and holdings of government securities for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.

The State Liquor Authority would support a method of sales that would give all retailers the opportunity to buy from distillers at a uniform price, with quantity discounts eliminated, Henry E. Bruckman, chairman of the Authority, declared yesterday at a mass meeting of the Metropolitan Package Stores Association and the Brooklyn Action Committee at the Hotel Park Central.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- Netherland air and sea forces struck back fiercely today at Japanese incursions into the Indies islands, blasting Japanese warships and transports off Northwest Borneo and beating off an air attack on Netherland New Guinea at a point about 700 miles north of Australia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Raw wool, wool tops and wool yarns were subjected to price ceilings today under orders from the Office of Price Administration. Under terms of the order the products must not be sold at prices higher than those which prevailed between Oct. 1 and Dec. 6.

The weekly statement of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City, as of Wednesday, as revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, showed that these institutions added $118,000,000 to their holdings of United States Government bonds, presumably reflecting the extent of their subscriptions to the new Treasury financing.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- Dr. Rikita Honda, reputed head of the Los Angeles unit of the Japanese Imperial Reservists Association, who killed himself while detained by Federal authorities Sunday night, was disclosed today to have been the head of a society directing Japanese espionage on the Pacific Coast.

RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- "Come back and save Thailand." Citizens of that country, choked with shame at their government's surrender to the superior forces of the enemy, thus begged the few Americans and Britons able to leave Thailand before the frontiers were closed after the Japanese occupation.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies fighting forces issued this communique today:
ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 18 -- Thirty-eight members of the Naval Academy class which is to graduate tomorrow, received prizes and awards today for work accomplished during the year.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, who made an impressive series of appearances with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last season, returned for a four-week stay as guest conductor last night. As his collaborator for the evening he had Sergei Rachmaninoff.

The problem whether to permit the traditional merry-making crowds to gather in Times Square on New Year's Eve is receiving "serious consideration" because of the war, and a decision may be reached next week, Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- With Christmas nearing, department store sales last week were only 1 per cent more than last year at this time, compared with a gain of 9 per cent last week over the corresponding week of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The Julia Ellsworth Ford Foundation announced yesterday its ninth annual children's book contest which offers $2,000 for the best juvenile book manuscript submitted between now and March 31. Julian Messner will publish the winner.

Responding to the government's appeal for conservation, more than 50,000 members of various boys' clubs in the metropolitan area began yesterday a door-to-door campaign to salvage waste paper for defense purposes. They will present housewives with red, white and blue cards, provided by the Office of Price Administrator Leon Henderson, telling the day and hour each week that a boy will call to collect paper.

Sidney Hillman, associate director of the Office of Production Management, told 2,500 C.I.O. clothing workers at a meeting here yesterday that the OPM was setting up advisory committees of labor and management to cooperate with the government in putting each basic Industry on a war footing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Six football players, the nucleus of what will grow into a twenty-three-man All-Star squad, left tonight for New Orleans and the transplanted East-West charity game to be played in the Sugar Bowl Jan. 3.

Isidore Juffe, an underworld swindler for twenty-five years, whose remark that he had "paid plenty" to avoid criminal prosecution in Brooklyn resulted three years ago in the appointment of Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amer to conduct a sweeping inquiry into official corruption, died last Monday in obscurity, it was learned yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 (AP) -- British General Headquarters here today issued this communique:

As a result of the publication in this country within the next few days of the authorized collected works of Rudyard Kipling, the British War Relief Society, Inc., will receive a donation of $10,000, it was learned yesterday. The works will be brought out in a limited signed edition as requested by the author.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Representatives of coal, coke, steel and associate groups, conferring today on call by Secretary Ickes as coordinator for national defense, agreed to form a seventeen-member industry committee to serve with Mr. Ickes in an advisory capacity, and pledged 100 per cent cooperation in production on behalf of their organizations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Three members of the Canadian Women's Army Corps arrived here today to serve "for the duration" at the Canadian Legation in posts usually held by men.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Tentative schedules of the Department of Agriculture for 1942 indicate that the American farmer is expected to produce more next year than in any other year in history.

Means to expedite the movement of freight to meet wartime needs were discussed by the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference at the Yale Club yesterday. The presidents also discussed the protection of railroad property.

Business men were urged to support Leon Henderson in his effort to prevent price spiraling, in a statement issued yesterday by Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Corporation. Mr. Melville, who was recently elected president of the Institute of Distribution, pointed out that the Price Administrator's effort to curb the inflationary trend in fats and oils this week had brought an immediate attack from a small element in Congress.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 19 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press) --According to official claims today, large formations of Japanese Army bombers carried out a mass raid yesterday on Kunming, capital of Yunnan Province and a key point on the Burma Road.

Divers philosophers, mainly ancient, have prattled about the benefits of poverty, but their definition of it usually means that you are to have all you need but no superfluities. So the Greeks, not strikingly moderate, were always praising "measure," and warning against the arrogant excess of prosperity that invited punishment from fate.

The cotton market moved irregularly in quiet trading yesterday as developments in Washington on price-control measures confused the trade and discouraged buying enthusiasm. On the New York Cotton Exchange final prices of active futures were 2 points lower to 8 points higher than Wednesday's close.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Trading in wheat and other grains was limited today as a result of the highly conflicting reports from Washington in regard to price-control legislation. Prices fluctuated in an aimless manner with wheat having a range of about 1 cent and corn 1/2 cent a bushel.

Puccini's "Tosca" was revived at the Metropolitan last night, with Grace Moore making her initial appearance of the season in the title role, which she assumed for the first time here. The opera, which was not performed at the Metropolitan last year, attracted a capacity audience at this welcome restoration, which had been carefully prepared.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The Senate approved by a vote of 79 to 2 tonight an extension of the draft age for military service to 19 to 44 years, inclusive, and a provision for registration of all men from 18 to 64, inclusive. The only negative votes were cast by the two California Senators, Johnson and Downey.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Among problems of importance raised by our entry into this great international war is the future military status of the various State Guard units throughout the nation.

Outplayed much of the time, but never outgamed, St. Paul's School of Concord, N.K., just failed in a stern chase of the Yale freshmen yesterday in Madison Square Garden and lost, 7 to 6, on its annual vacation hockey appearance in Manhattan. The youngsters made a specialty of finishing each period with a roaring attack that left them only a goal behind each time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Major Gen. Herbert A. Dargue, commanding general of the First Air Force, Mitchel Field, N.Y., and seven other officers and men on an Army transport have been missing in the West since Friday, Secretary Stimson reported today.

For the first time since 1938, the Harvard Club's Class A squash racquets team carried off the Metropolitan Interclub Association crown last night by administering a 5-0 setback to the Downtown A.C., champion for the past two years, as the 1941 season ended.

In one of the greatest buying rushes ever noted in the sporting goods field, golf enthusiasts here bought thousands of dozens of golf balls yesterday to beat the impending restrictions of the Office of Price Administration, which are expected to slash civilian consumption of rubber products by about 80 per cent.

THE big, genial chap was shaking his head and saying, "Those Syracuse boys are fast. They move around that court all the time. They look pretty good to me." The stockier fellow with the eyeglasses refused to sympathize. He had his own problems.

The $1,000,000,000 Associated Gas and Electric system discharged its final debts to the Federal Government yesterday by the payment to the Treasury Department of $6,619,336 in settlement for back taxes piled up by Howard C. Hopson, former head of the system, who is serving a five-year term in the Federal penitentiary for defrauding investors of $20,000,000.

The House of Representatives deserves great credit for the promptness with which it has adopted the bill to mobilize the manpower of the United States. This measure has two parts and two purposes, which the President describes as "of equal and prime importance."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Senate Elections Committee's vote on Senator Langer came after a year's consideration of charges involving moral turpitude which grew out of Mr. Langer's actions as an attorney and former Governor of North Dakota.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- General and sharp price rises during the week following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor caused the general level of wholesale prices to climb to the highest level reached since December, 1929, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that $193,416,000 of securities had been registered in November compared with $154,47,000 in the previous month and $161,748,000 in November, 1940, and that, as compared with the showing a year ago, an unusually high proportion of the flotations were for new money and consisted of common stock.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY in the Libyan Desert, Dec. 14 (delayed) (AP) -- This little pig didn't stay home -- and thereby hangs a tale of fantastic events in the desert and how a band of indignant Scotsmen garnered a fortune in food and supplies and captured nearly 200 German prisoners.

Another boxing championship title-search will take place at Madison Square Garden tonight when Lew Jenkins of Sweetwater, Texas, opposes Sammy Angott, veteran campaigner from Washington, Pa., in a fifteen-round battle. Each battler will enter the ring with a lightweight title claim, Jenkins with the recognition of the New York State Athletic Commission and Angott with the regard of the National Boxing Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Laura Ingalls, woman flier, was arraigned before a United States Commissioner today, charged with being a paid agent of the German Government and as such failing to register under the Foreign Agents Registration Act.
Man Also Counts Orville Wright holds fast to the hope that the airplane can be made an instrument for peace and freedom if taken out of the hands of barbarous men.

Medical schools along the Eastern seaboard are preparing to remain in session throughout the calendar year and eliminate the normal long Summer vacations in order to accelerate medical training and provide more physicians to meet the wartime needs of the country, it was announced here yesterday by Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Commissioner of Hospitals and national chairman of the Preparedness Committee of the Association of American Medical Colleges.

Though possibility of enemy bombing of United States industrial plants and public building may be remote, it is "essential that protective organization be developed at once to guard against the disruption of normal activities and for the safety of the personnel in an emergency," a warning from the Office of Civilian Defense declares.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 18 (U.P.)--Reorganized and reinforced Imperial jungle fighters, manning a new defense line south of the Krian River, were reported tonight to have stemmed a Japanese sweep down the northwest coast of Malaya, which apparently by-passed the Penang Island base.
George Emlen Roosevelt, investment banker, last night was elected commodore of the New York Yacht Club at the organization's annual meeting, held in its clubhouse at 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- Completion of the new assembly plant of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, at Johnsville, from which Buccaneer dive bombers soon will be rolling for the United States Navy and Bermuda dive bombers for the Royal Air Force and the Netherlands East Indies, was announced tonight by officials of the company.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 -- The first contingent of the American Field Service, volunteer ambulance corps service with the British forces, has arrived in Egypt and placed its full facilities at the disposal of the Middle East Headquarters in Cairo.

The blind are doing their share for national defense, several hundred having been taken off relief rolls and several hundred more kept off them through defense orders for the government, M.C. Migel, president of the American Foundation for the Blind, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- More than $2,000,000 has already been contributed to the American Red Cross's $50,000,000 war relief fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The authorities of the statute and of the executive power will be of secondary importance to the human factor in the Federal censorship that is forthcoming. Its success or failure, both in winning full press and public support and in keeping valuable information from the enemy, will depend as greatly on the policy and quality of its administration as they do in any public or private activity that comes to mind.

LONDON, Dec. 18--Netherland and Australian forces have occupied the Portuguese section of the Island of Timor, between Java and Australia, to forestall its seizure by the Japanese as a base of operations against the Allies, it was officially announced today.

A "token bombing of New York by German planes is well within the bounds of possibility, but it is "absurd" to think that the city will be subjected to such continuous large-scale raids as those undergone by London, Albert Emil Davies, former chairman of the London County Council, declared last night at a dinner meeting of civic organizations held in the City Club of New York at 55 West Forty-fourth Street.
It finally happened!

The Columbia School of Engineering will "speed up" its present course leading to the bachelor of science degree with the adoption of an accelerated curriculum, which will turn out fully qualified engineers for the war effort in three instead of four years, it was announced yesterday by Professor James Kip Finch, associate dean of the school.

One of the media hardest hit by the planned curtailment in automotive advertising will be outdoor advertising, which depends on the field for about 30 to 35 per cent of its billings. In newspapers the figure for last year was under 5 per cent, against 7.5 per cent in 1929, when automotive copy was considerably heavier.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- New York's 1942 "surplus" melon which both Republican and Democratic leaders hoped to slice at the coming legislative session, shrunk drastically today with announcement of government rationing of automobile tires.

The war and expansion of industry to meet defense needs threaten to bring an increase in tuberculosis in this country, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, warned yesterday in urging that industrial establishments make periodic check-ups of the health of their workers.

WITH THE RED ARMY, North-west of Moscow, Dec. 17 (Delayed) -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's badly beaten German Army is retreating westward in a desperate series of forced marches. The Russians, using everything they have, are routing unit after Nazi unit and retaking vast areas of territory.

Christopher S. Sullivan, leader of Tammany, and Charles H. Hussey, chairman of its executive committee, yesterday led a walkout on Jeremiah T. Mahoney, leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, after the committee had called a meeting for Monday evening at 400 East Fifty-first Street to nominate a candidate for State Senator at the special election on Jan. 13.

The Tokyo report of a Japanese landing on the island of Hong Kong subtracts nothing from the defiant spirit of Kitchener, Gordon and other British soldiers who held fast to the outposts of their empire against siege and superior numbers. That spirit rang in the reply of Sir Mark Young to the Japanese demand for the surrender of Hong Kong.
BERLIN, Dec. 18 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau today issued this communique:

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The Black Hawks returned to third place in the National Hockey League standing tonight by defeating the Rangers, 5 -- 1, before 7,402 spectators in the Chicago Stadium. The New Yorkers dropped from third to fourth as a result of their defeat.

As the war in the Pacific spreads across the vast leagues of the world's greatest ocean, the board appointed by the President to investigate the Pearl Harbor tragedy will soon commence its sittings at the scene where so many Americans died in the first act of a war for survival.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Dec. 19 -- Russian forces on the south-central front advanced to within nineteen miles of Orel during yesterday's fighting, the Moscow military spokesman said in his broadcast this morning.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 18 -- Partly because of preoccupation with a multitude of urgent domestic problems arising from the Pacific war and partly through disinclination to indulge in futile armchair criticism and speculation, the Australian press is sparing in its comment on the grave outlook in Malaya and the threat to Singapore.

Declaring that the city is living beyond its means, due to unsound fiscal practices of the present administration, Major Henry J. Amy, executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, said yesterday the measures the city has adopted to keep down the budget and tax levy were only to postpone the day of reckoning.

Girding of the nation to an all-out war economy took yesterday a further toll of stock values on the Stock Exchange. Persistent and heavy selling in the motors brought on a sympathetic wave of liquidation in several other groups, but after prices dropped to new low levels since June, 1938, the selling appeared to have run its course, with a resultant slight firming.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday, substantially higher than the preceding week and the year before, exceeded the peak recorded in the week ended on Oct. 22 and set a new high mark since the first week of October, 1931.

Fastidious women who love beautiful perfumes are coming to realize that they are possessions to be prized and cherished. The supply of essential oils formerly obtained from abroad is now entirely cut off. Stocks have been laid in here, and American designers are working steadily to develop excellent native products.

In Greenwich Village, specifically at the Cherry Lane Theatre on Commerce Street, a valiant troupe, known collectively as the Savoy Opera Guild, is keeping the town's Gilbert Sullivan enthusiasts in fine fettle these evenings. As a matter of record, it has been doing this sort of thing for some eight months.

The proposal to revise the State Income Tax Law so as to permit the deduction from taxable income of the amounts paid out for Federal income taxes, just as the Federal tax law permits the deduction of State income taxes, is opposed by Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 18 -- Before teaming up to help defeat the Axis -- which will mean actual service for most of them -- about 200 of Uncle Sam's finest athletes will battle here among themselves within two weeks in one of the greatest carnivals of sport this country ever has seen.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Large supplies pushed prices of hogs down as much as 25 cents a hundredweight today, with heavy "lard hogs" pacing the decline. Light hogs confined losses to 15 cents or less. It was said changes in prices would be more likely to follow supply and demand now that the first shock of America's entry into the war had passed.

Pledging themselves to concentration on "two fronts," 600 members of the Manhattan chapter of Hadassah crowded the Jewish Center at 131 West Eighty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon in a mobilization rally for civilian defense. Speakers emphasized the importance of increasing the work in Palestine of the Women's Zionist Organization while bending all efforts to protection of the American "home front."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Navy announced tonight that American submarines in the Far East had sunk a Japanese transport and probably an enemy destroyer.

Typhus is reported to have broken out in Poland. If there is any disease that armies and governments dread it is this. They dread it so much that during the first World War the Germans for a time kept aloof from Serbia, where 30,000 died, but not before 25,000,000 Russians were infected.

New York will have the first post-season football game of the "bowl" category in its history at the Polo Grounds on Jan. 4 when the winners of Sunday's championship game between the Giants am Bears meet an all-star squad selected from the other nine clubs in the National Football League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP)--The Council of State Governments and Governors Conference called on all States and municipalities today to back up the war effort by postponing nonessential public works, maintaining present tax levels and planning for post-war reconstruction.

As the biggest recruiting rush in the history of the armed forces slowed up here yesterda, it was announced by Colonel George H. Baird, in charge of Army recruiting for the Corps Area, that all recruiting offices will be kept open day and night "until final word is received from Washington to the contrary."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The Senate Election Committee voted, 13 to 3, today to recommend that on the grounds of moral turpitude, William Langer should be barred from taking his seat as Senator.
MOSCOW, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information today issued the following communique:

Asserting that he had received information that the defendants were members of the gang headed by the Esposito brothers and had furnished the pistols used by the Espositos in slaying a policeman in a Fifth Avenue hold-up, Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday sentenced Carlo Barone and Dominick Grippo to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing Prison during the week of Jan. 18 for a Brooklyn murder.

In the Christmas spirit of giving not only to loved ones but to aid those in dire distress, 433 old and new friends of the Neediest Cases Fund sent contributions yesterday that will help to relieve the bleakness of Christmas for some of the city's most distressed inhabitants and also aid them for months afterward.

THEY still write college novels. Gertrude Carrick's story of Vassar, "Consider the Daisies,"* is hardly the most distinguished of the lot, but it has a fresh, unpretentious charm. The best thing about it is the fact that it provides no easy peg on which to hang a sermon about the Younger Generation of A.D. 1941. For this relief, much thanks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 18 (U.P.) -- Colonel H.C. Kress Muhlenberg, former commandant of Hickam Field in Hawaii, was ordered confined to quarters at Fort Hayes today during an investigation of his remarks at a banquet last night when he referred to the United States Navy as "a gone gosling."

The headquarters of the Southern New York Recruiting District announced yesterday the winners in the "Keep 'Em Flying" Aviation Cadet Poster Contest, which it sponsored in collaboration with the Art Students League of New York City.

The United States must win this war and Mexico will do everything in its power to help achieve victory, Miguel Aleman, Mexican Minister of the Interior, said in an interview in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

Waite Phillips, wealthy Tulsa (Okla.) oil man, has presented as outright gifts to the National Council, Boy Scouts of America, his 91,000-acre Philmont Ranch in New Mexico and the twenty-three-story Philtower Building in Tulsa to be used "for the advancement and development of the Program of Scouting," it was announced yesterday.

Much to the dismay of the American Woman's Voluntary Services, several hundred women, most of them without switchboard experience, swamped the offices yesterday offering their services as telephone operators in answer to a plea made this week by the organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Demands have been made from time to time by Congressmen and naval experts and editorial writers for the seizure of Martinique on various grounds ranging from debt satisfaction to defensive necessity. President Roosevelt stopped off at Martinique on his Caribbean cruise of August, 1940, and his visit was saluted in a communique issued by the Colonial Government.
The Brooklyn Real Estate Board, through its special committee on defense, issued yesterday to its membership a list of instructions on what precautions to take during emergencies such as air raids.

The headquarters of the Southern New York Recruiting District announced yesterday the winners in the "Keep 'Em Flying" Aviation Cadet Poster Contest, which it sponsored in collaboration with the Art Students League of New York City.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 19 (From Japanese broadcasts) -- Imperial headquarters announced at 6:55 A.M. today [4:55 P.M. Thursday, E.S.T.] that the Japanese Army and Navy had succeeded in landing on the Island of Hong Kong, which has been under siege and bombardment for more than a week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A warning that in the midst of a production boom, this country is raising a new crop of "depressed or stranded areas" similar to those which arose during the depression ten years ago, was sounded before the Senate's aid to small business committee today by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Demands have been made from time to time by Congressmen and naval experts and editorial writers for the seizure of Martinique on various grounds ranging from debt satisfaction to defensive necessity. President Roosevelt stopped off at Martinique on his Caribbean cruise of August, 1940, and his visit was saluted in a communique issued by the Colonial Government.
The Brooklyn Real Estate Board, through its special committee on defense, issued yesterday to its membership a list of instructions on what precautions to take during emergencies such as air raids.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The text of this morning's War Department's communique follows:

More than half the capital that was sent out of Mexico in the past has been returned to that country as evidence of the new confidence of Mexican business in the Avila Camacho Administration, according to Salvador Ugarte, president of the Banco de Comercio of Mexico City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The State Department announced today that it had received a message, dated Dec. 11, from Joseph C. Grew, former United States Ambassador to Tokyo, asserting that the entire personnel of the American Embassy was assembled in the embassy compound and were in good health and supplied with adequate food.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Confronted by defense requirements, Westchester County officials ended today eighteen months of bickering over the necessity for a county airport and summoned the Board of Supervisors to a special meeting Saturday to vote on a $300,000 appropriation for acquisition of a site in the exclusive estate area of Purchase.

War Communique 1 of the United States Junior Army (G.H.Q., Hyde Park, N.Y.) was issued yesterday in the form of a letter from "Capton" E.L. Barlow to Major Edward G. Riekert, executive director of the Second Civilian Defense Region, respectfully advising that the U.S.J.A. has the situation in the President's home town well in hand

The report or Secretary Knox, in Which Secretary Stimson concurs, that our armed forces in Hawaii were not "on the alert," made an investigation as necessary as it was desirable. President Roosevelt lost no time in appointing a committee, headed by Associate Justice Owen J. Roberts, to ascertain the facts and to fix the blame.

Pennsylvania Gross revenues of the Pennsylvania Railroad in November were about $52,829,000, up 25 per cent from November, 1940, M.W. Clement, president said yesterday. Operating revenues in the first week of December ran substantially ahead of the sum for the same week last year.

Trading in all Bulgarian and Hungarian securities has been suspended by the New York Stock Exchange until further notice. Trading was held up on Monday pending yesterday's action by the board of governors. All German, Italian and Japanese securities were suspended on Thursday of last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- In its final report of the season, the Department of Agriculture said today that production of all crops this year was of a near-record volume, although the harvested acreage was 7 per cent smaller than the peak acreage of 1932.

Rejecting a petition signed by nearly 300 undergraduates advocating that every member of the football squad of forty-three players be taken on the trip, Fordham athletic authorities announced last night that thirty-five athletes would make the journey to New Orleans for the Sugar Bowl game with Missouri on New Year's Day.

Father Knickerbocker in full colonial costume was on hand bright and early yesterday morning as customers began to arrive at the new men's and boys' retail store opened by Howard Clothes at 1600 Broadway, at the northeast corner of Forty-eighth Street.

Michaels Co., Inc., operator of a chain of furniture stores in the metropolitan area, has purchased from the Studebaker Corporation the four-story reinforced concrete building at 1000 Dean Street, Brooklyn, for use as a warehouse, shipping and service center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A price control bill which was declared to be "in substantial accord" with Administration desires, has been approved by a six-man Banking and Currency subcommittee. Senator Brown, the chairman, stated today in a report to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Department of Agriculture added its weight today before the Interstate Commerce Commission to yesterday's protest by the antitrust division of the Department of Justice against the proposed merger of eight Atlantic Seaboard trucking companies by Associated Transport, Inc.

New film, attractions will be presented in two theatres this morning. "Girl From Leningrad," reportedly the first Soviet film about the present war, will have its local premiere at the Stanley Theatre. The picture, which deals with a Russian nurses' unit under fire at the northern front, features Zoya Fyodorova.

MANILA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Today's relative inaction brought opportunity for these notations upon a lengthening list of American heroes of the air -- men whose cool courage is more than out-matching the suicide complex of the Japanese and is adding to the roll of seventy Japanese planes already officially announced destroyed:
SINGAPORE, Dec. 18 -- British Empire forces opposing the Japanese in Malaya are expected to make a strong stand in the State of Perak, south and east of the present fighting zone.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- An Army bomber, apparently taking off for target practice, crashed on the bombing range at Muroc Dry Lake in the Mojave Desert today, killing its six occupants -- two flying officers and four enlisted men. Three of the latter were from New York City and the fourth from New Jersey.

ALEPPO, Syria, Dec. 17 (Delayed) -- The British Ninth Army, commanded by General Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, would no doubt have been bearing much of the brunt of the war now if the Russians had failed to push the enemy back from the gateway to the Caucasus.

In a speech at the victory dinner of the All-American Committee for his re-election, composed of Americans of foreign descent at the Hotel St. Moritz, Mayor La Guardia declared last night that the presence of two hundred representatives of a score of racial strains demonstrated the unity of the American people in the war against the Axis powers.

Passage of legislation to put "teeth" into enforcement of precautionary measures during air-raid alarms and blackouts, a problem now being studied by the New York City Council's Defense Committee, is urged as vital in the pamphlet, "Blackouts," prepared by the War Department and distributed by the Office of Civilian Defense.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana and other defendants won yesterday from the Appellate Division a reversal of a judgment for an estimated total of $50,000,000 to $70,000,000, one of the largest on record, which had been awarded against them in Supreme Court in an accounting suit by minority stock interests of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Board of Investigation and Research called today on governmental, shipper, carrier and trade organizations for "cooperation and suggestions" in its investigation of the nation's transportation facilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Deadlocked on the union shop issue, President Roosevelt's industrylabor conference recessed tonight until Monday morning, and some conferees privately were doubtful that they ever would reach the unanimous accord requested by the President on a program guaranteeing uninterrupted production of defense materials for the duration of the war.

The Gallup Poll, Clifton Fadiman, the Quiz Kids and Ernest Hemingway, among other things, were the subjects of satire last night at the Mansfield Theatre, where the Triangle Club of Princeton University presented its fiftythird annual musical production, "Ask Me Another."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Industrial production was maintained at a high rate in November and the first half of December, although a decline is usual at this season, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The entry of the United States into the wax was reflected in a sharp advance in the prices of some commodities, some decline in security prices and further curtailment of non-military production.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19 -- Russian cavalry and tanks plowed into Ruza, northeast of Mozhaisk, today and forced a German retreat along the central part of the Moscow front as infantry and mechanized units continued to roll up the Nazi flanks.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuter) -- Sir Hugh Clifford died yesterday at the age of 75. He was former Governor of the Straits Settlements and High Commissioner for the Federated Malay States. Sir Hugh, who had served in nearly every quarter of the world, was known as a scholar and writer on the East and in particular as an authority on Malaya.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Trading on the stock markets today was overshadowed by the news from Hong Kong but there was a fairly steady tendency. Gilt-edge issues held unchanged, Brazilian bonds improved and some home rails gained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) --A 1942 Winter wheat crop of 630,913,000 bushels, or about 150,000,000 bushels in excess of the goal of the Agriculture Adjustment Administration under the "food-for-defense" program, was said today by the Department of Agriculture to be indicated.

PAWLING, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Representatives of thirty private and independent schools in the East and Middle States, gathered at a two-day conference to determine their role in the present war, were urged today by Army and Navy speakers to put greater stress on mathematics and citizenship training in the preparation of young men for military service.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 20 (From, Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's Soviet Information Bureau communique follows:
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The following communique was distributed today by the Netherlands Indies news agency:

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Dec. 20 -- Fighting on the Moscow front yesterday was particularly intensive in the southern central sectors, where Russian troops pushed the major part of the Nazi forces out of the Oka River elbow and, pounding the retreating German lines, crossed that river to take Tarusa, according to the midnight Russian communique Recapture of the town has broken the menace to the central sector around Maloyaroslavets and the Yakovievsk heights.

In the event of an air raid on New York City, parents of children attending schools in the five boroughs are asked by the Board of Education to abide by a series of suggestions drawn up by the board as part of its school defense program.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Netherland bombing planes have attacked the Japanese forces that landed in Northern Borneo, the Netherlands Indies Command announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Perhaps, as one worker expressed it over the noise of a massive machine which under her guidance took powerful, though carefully gauged jabs at the sensitive heads of rounds of ammunition in assembly, "working with powder is less nerva-wracking than making hosiery," her previous occupation.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Tristram C. Colket of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Mrs. Colket's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. William Coxe Wright of St. Davids, Pa., are at the Ritz-Carlton.

A client of Frederick and Jerome Weiss, attorneys, has purchased from the New York Life Insurance Company the property at 470 Park Avenue, East Orange, N.J., consisting of two four-story buildings on a plot 112 by 250 feet. There are twenty-one apartments in the two structures, and at the rear of the plot is a separate building containing nineteen individual garages.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 19 (Reuter) -- The Japanese drive through Malaya has been brought to a temporary halt, and the Japanese, after penetrating just over 100 miles in eleven days, are regrouping their forces.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Walls of sandbags will be built around the vital buildings and other installations of this reservation as a protection in event of all raids, and for this purpose all Army cooks and "kitchen police" stationed here were ordered today to save all empty potato sacks, which will be turned over to the post utilities office.

MANILA, Saturday, Dec. 20 -- Japanese troops have landed in force at Davao, on the Southern Philippine island of Mindanao, and heavy fighting occurred throughout this morning, the Army announced in a communique shortly before noon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Douglas MacArthur, commander of the military forces in the Philippines, became a full general in the Army of the United States today for the second time when President Roosevelt promoted seventeen senior officers one rank in recognition of their services in the islands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today setting up an Office of Censorship, to be directed by Byron Price, executive news editor of The Associated Press on leave, who will have "absolute discretion" in censoring all communications between the United States and any foreign country.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 19 -- Fifteen topnotch sprinters will flash around the lightning-fast Tropical Park track tomorrow in the feature event of the card opening Florida's Winter horse racing season.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Mrs. Dorothy Milligan, wife of Edward D.W. Milligan, lieutenant commander in the Navy during the World War and now a landscape architect and contractor with main offices in Hartford, Conn., was arrested here tonight as the alleged hit and run driver who had killed an 11-year-old boy earlier in the evening.

Eastern District High'a tossers scored their third straight Section 1. Brooklyn P.S.A.L. triumph and gained a firmer hold on the lead by defeating Alexander Hamilton High, 41 to 32. on the former's floor yesterday. The winners held a 26-11 lead at the half.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Aroused by our just cause and armed with unmatched power, we Americans are certain of ultimate victory whatever it may cost. We stand ready to sacrifice our wealth, even our lives.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 -- The first bad news of the Libyan campaign was given to the Italian people today when the war bulletin of the High Command revealed that Axis troops were now fighting "hard battles" around Derna "where the adversary with the support of new armored units from Egypt is Increasing his pressure against the troops of the Axis, which are struggling with exemplary tenacity."

That morning -- the 5th of September, 1939, and pitch dark -- Paris was awakened a little before 4 A.M. by the gloomy call of the sirens. For months we had been told what to do, what to avoid doing at that moment. We were prepared, even accustomed, to the sound of the sirens.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 19 -- Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Sibley Dow entertained with a dinner tonight at their villa for Dr. and Mrs. Harbeck Halsted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The German Embassy staff and German newspaper correspondents, numbering about 150, were sent to White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., today pending their departure from the United States when arrangements have been completed.

CAMP CROFT, S.C., Dec. 19 -- The last thirteen days have seen this infantry replacement training center change from a sight-seeing center of the Carolina Piedmont into a military reservation that is completely at war.
"You don't stand over a stove during an air raid-you get under it."

OSWEGO, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Fort Ontario, with its well-staffed officer and enlisted personnel, is the examination center for Reserve officers in this section. Last week more than 100 men called from civil-life occupations were examined as to physical fitness to servo as officers in the Army.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 19 (U.P) -- The bulk of the Penang Imperial forces left the Island Wednesday and the last defenders yesterday afternoon, it was announced hera today. The first shipload of evacuees, including some policemen, arrived in Singapore today, scantily clad, indicating a hurried departure.
It probably won't come as a surprise to the other American League clubs, or to the Dodgers, but for the record it may be stated that the Yankees have been, chosen as the No. 1 team of 1941.

Colby M. Chester, vice chairman of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York and chairman of the commerce and industry division for the fund, announced last night the receipt of gifts from four large companies.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 -- Italians are now softening their claims of Mediterranean domination. At this morning's press conference in Rome, the spokesman admitted that they were having as much difficulty in keeping open their lines of communication between the mainland and Libya as "the British are experiencing" in passing from one end of the Mediterranean to the other."

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 19 -- Walter Haight, a 2-year-old son of Mowlee and Noras Grace, sprang a surprise in the Panhandle Purse, featuring today's program, by withstanding a long stretch drive to win by a half length. In graduating from the maiden ranks, Walter Haight went under the wire in front of Mrs. C.L. Larkin's Top Transit, with C. Lorenz's Hedda Gab third.

TUNIS, French Tunisia, Dec. 15 (Delayed) (AP) --Five thousand Italian seamen and troops apparently en route to Libya were drowned on Dec. 12 when British naval units sank two Italian cruisers, a destroyer and three transports in a fierce night fight off Cape Bon on the Tunisian coast.

Increases in receipts from Christmas mail, including parcel post and defense bonds and stamps, were announced yesterday by Postmaster Albert Goldman as indicative of a busy holiday season at the New York Post Office.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

The struggle that now engulfs nearly all the nations of the world is being fought on many, fronts. Yet it cannot be emphasized too often or too strongly that these fronts are all battlefields in a single war. Whatever happens on any one front has an inevitable effect upon all the others and consequently a direct bearing upon the outcome of the whole conflict.
Fordham University's basketball team rang up its third victory in four starts this season by routingWilliam and Mary, 59-27, last night in the Fordham gymnasium.
It was revealed yesterday by Leo J. Bondy, treasurer of the National Exhibition Company, better identified as the Giants, that his organization had spent more than $300,000 in 1941 for ball players.

Tulsa, Okla. The city of Tulsa, Okla., awarded yesterday a total of $3,833,000 of various purpose bonds to a banking syndicate headed by the Northern Trust Company of Chicago on a net interest cost basis of 1.8973 per cent for the entire loan. The group paid a premium of 5455 for the total issue, taking $1,267,000 as 2s; $1,177,000 as 2 1/4s, $669,000 as 1 3/4s and $720,000 as l 1/2s.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The House and Senate, working under the spur of wartime needs, passed and sent to the White House today a $512,000,000 appropriation bill, including 5300,000,000 for defense housing which President Roosevelt asked for in June.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Your Mr. Drebinger reports that the New York Giants' Mr. Brannick once again is his old chipper self now that Giants have begun cleaning house. This leads the ordinary baseball layman to suppose that Mr. Brannick believes everything he reads in the newspapers.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The fate of Hong Kong, farthest Imperial outpost of Britain's far-flung empire, was apparently sealed tonight as the hard - pressed garrison fought a gallant but seemingly hopeless fight against Japanese forces landed on the main island of the Crown Colony.

Acme Steel The Acme Steel Company of Chicago, an independent strip steel producer, is distributing $225,000 in Christmas checks to its employes. The equivalent of two weeks' pay will be given to those who have been with the company more than six months, while those employed since July 2 will receive one week's pay.
Today will conclude the deer season in New Jersey, and the reports indicate that it has been a successful one, with several sections producing larger hills than in several years.

MANILA, Saturday, Dec. 20 -- Twenty-four high-flying Japanese bombers flew over Cavite at 12:40 P.M. yesterday, with Manila under air-raid alarm during the bombing of the vicinity of the Cavite naval base again.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The British today wrote off Hong Kong, although there was no official confirmation of Japanese reports that the colony had been captured.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The House and Senate swiftly agreed today to set the military age of Selective Service Act registrants at 20 to 44, inclusive, and rushed the measure to the White House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Among the ships recently acquired by the Maritime Commission, bringing to eighteen the number in its training fleet, are the 5,000-ton liners Boston and New York, chartered from the Eastern Steamship Company.

On village slopes and mountain trails the powder snow once more HOB deep. This is a weather report no wartime censor could have the heart to suppress. For thousands of Winter sports enthusiasts it is the news that marks the real beginning of the year. Now is the season when old acquaintance is renewed in the easy informality of the ski train and before log fires at mountain lodges.

In July Douglas MacArthur was nominated Lieutenant General, a rank his father held before him, and became Commander in Chief of the Army of the Far East He has been defending the Philippines brilliantly. Yesterday Mr. Roosevelt nominated him to be a General.

CAMP WHEELER, Ga., Dec. 19 -- After an Inspection of troops at this Infantry center in the first ten days of war, Brig. Gen. A.R. Emery, commanding general here, stressed his "complete gratification at the spirit and enthusiasm displayed by the officers and men of Camp Wheeler, who are accomplishing maximum training results in a minimum of time."

Dr. Albert Degener, who since the early days of the Hitler regime has been an energetic promoter of German-American trade, has been taken into custody by Federal agents and is now among the hundreds of Axis aliens now on Ellis Island, it was learned yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The movement of hardwood lumber during 1941 will exceed 1940 by 40 per cent, John W. McClure, secretary treasurer of the National Hardwood Lumber Association, estimated today on the basis of inspection figures.
CAMP UPTON, L.I., Dec. 19 -- With money in their jeans, the soldiers of this camp prepared for a gala celebration of Christmas week, despite reduction of furloughs.

Two melodramas, which will open in Broadway theatres this morning, complete the week's list of film newcomers. Universal's "The Wolf Man" will be the attraction at the Rialto. Lon Chaney Jr., Claude Rains, Maria Ouspenskaya, Ralph Bellamy, Warren William, Bela Lugosi, Evelyn Ankers and Patric Knowles head the cast. . . . Paramount's "No Hands On the Clock" will be the Globe's new offering.

Another light practice was the order of the day on Fordham Field yesterday as Jim Crowley sent his football squad through its penultimate workout on Rose Hill. The players will depart tomorrow night for New Orleans and the Sugar Bowl game with Missouri on New Year's Day.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 19 -- Secretary Knox told the graduating class of the Naval Academy today that the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor would, in the end, contribute to certain American victory in the war by the effect of this "damning account of infamous treachery" in unifying the nation for war.

Disdaining the majority opinion, which gives them little chance against the Bean in the National Football League championship play-off tomorrow, thirty-two members of the Giants climbed aboard the first section of the Commodore Vanderbilt at Grand Central last night and headed for Chicago.

Warning of the approach of raiders will be sounded by the sirens of police and fire apparatus -- one long and one short blast alternately for five minutes. The all-clear signal will be sounded by the same apparatus and will consist of a series of short blasts over a five-minute period.

This rather quiet week in the theatre will come to life tonight with the opening of "The Criminals," by Ferdinand Bruckner, at the Studio Theatre of the New School, 66 West Twelfth Street. The play dealing with the miscarriage of justice in the courts of Berlin during the last years of the Weimar Republic, has been produced in Berlin and Paris, but never before in New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Congress may soon be requested to approve funds for the purchase of 50,000,000 civilian gas masks, Mayor F.H. La Guardia, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense revealed this afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It might help some of your readers to appraise the reports which come out of Japan, especially from the Domei Agency, if evidence were given by some of us who have had previous experience with such reports.

FORT BENNING, Go., Dec. 19 -- Lieutenant B.J. Hatfield Jr. will direct the Protestant choir in a Christmas cantata at the post Chapel. Chaplain Thomas J. Montgomery, Catholic chaplain, and the Rev. Patrick Moore of Holy Trinity, Ala., will conduct masses.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The controversy over the relative merits of Fordham and Navy on the gridiron has interested me no end, and from a strictly impartial viewpoint I have looked into this subject.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Axiscontrolled airports have dotted strategic areas of Latin America and arms caches, fuel storage depots and short-wave radio stations owned by agents of the enemy powers were to be found along both coasts of South America, a special House committee investigating air transportation, reported tonight.

Sammy Angott of Washington, Pa., today is undisputed lightweight champion of the world. The National Boxing Association champion won a clear claim to the title last night in Madison Square Garden, where he carried off the decision over Lew Jenkins of Sweetwater, Texas, who had been recognized as titleholder by the New York State Athletic Commission.

Convinced that a woman's mood is reflected by her clothes, three of America's leading designers forecast yesterday a generous use of color in future fashions. Not "blatant" or "vulgar bright" colors, they specified, but clean and becoming ones to give an appearance of health, freshness and cheer.
Expenditures on relief in this city have dropped nearly $20,000,000 a month since the low point of the depression six years ago, Welfare Commissioner William Hodson reported yesterday.

Hanukkah, the Jewish festival of lights, which began Sunday at sundown and is observed for eight days with services and the symbolic lighting of candles, will be a general theme of sermons by rabbis here today and tomorrow. The festival commemorates the triumphant struggles of the ancient Maccabees for freedom of worship against the oppressive forces of Antiochus Epiphanes, Syrian tyrant.

Steps to reorganize virtually the entire educational system of the State to meet war conditions, directly affecting everybody from pre-school age children to adults long out of school, were taken yesterday by the State Board of Regents at its first meeting since the United States entered the war.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Princeton's basketball team nosed out Rutgers by a 39-36 count for its third straight victory of the campaign before 1,000 fans in the Rutgers Gym tonight. Throughout the fray neither team led by more than four points and the score was tied eight times.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull at his press conference today described as the foulest sort of fifth column propaganda a report that during the diplomatic conversations with Japan the State Department prevailed upon the Navy Department to suspend patrols around Hawaii and other American islands in the Pacific.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 19 -- A labor dispute threatening disruption of the production of airplane motors at five plants of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation was precipitated this evening: when the company posted notices announcing changes in its incentive bonus plan.

According to eyewitness accounts, fewer than fifty bombers and torpedo planes attacked either the Prince of Wales or the Repulse, and not many of these planes were reported shot down. Yet from several hundred to a thousand bombers (depending upon the type) can be constructed for the cost of one super-battleship.

A satisfactory deal has been arranged between the Southern Pacific Company and a group of bankers headed by the First Boston Corporation, after negotiations all day yesterday, for the sale by the railroad to the banking group of an issue of $4,430,000 of one-to-ten-year equipment-trust certificates.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Senate passed a bill today to continue for three years the quotas now dividing the American sugar market among domestic, Philippine, Hawaiian and Cuban producers. Immediate acceptance by the House late this afternoon completed Congressional action and sent the measure to the White House.
ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 19 -- The prepared text of Secretary Knox's speech here today to the Naval Academy graduates was as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- Trading in grain futures continued restricted today as operators awaited further developments on price control legislation, and the ceiling that is likely to be imposed on agricultural products. All other influences were ignored and speculators showed so much disposition to keep close to shore that business on the Board of Trade was said to have been the smallest in several weeks.

Because the blanket insurance bond covering the brokerage houses in Wall Street contains a war risk exclusion clause, the Association of Stock Exchange Firms has been working since the declaration of war to devise a system for reducing the hazards to the securities business.

In an effort to improve and coordinate the servicing of radio sets, Philco Distributors, Inc., New York division, has started to reorganize Radio Manufacturers Service in the metropolitan New York and New Jersey area. All present memberships in the service have been withdrawn and a new roster, made up of the best servicing organizations in the area served by Philco, New York, will be selected.

The news focuses on islands. Since the Pacific exploded with the Sunday morning attack on the water-girt base of Oahu, the devouring flame has leaped from one to another of those dreaming atolls in the western ocean that men turn to when they long to get away from the iron horses of industry and the iron complexes of war.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Another heavy run of hogs today pushed salable receipts in the local market above 100.000 head for the week to date, highest of the year and prices again reacted. While light weights were steady to 10 cents a hundred pounds lower, heavy "lard hogs" lost 10 to 15 cents.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times; Hans Lobert's appointment as manager of the Phillies adds another John J. McGraw protege to the list of National League managers. Six of the eight played on the New York Giants under the observing eye of the Little Napoleon.
As the Japanese continued their desperate bid for empire yesterday the pertinence of the inquiry into what happened at Hawaii was again emphasized.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 19 -- The situation on the Finnish front, where the Russians have started their offensive operations virtually everywhere, still remains unclear, although it is known that violent battles are raging, particularly on the Svir River.

New York University's rebuilt basketball team, a scoring powerhouse in its early-season games, will make its debut in major competition against Syracuse tonight, while St. John's will seek solace for the debacle at Dartmouth against Oklahoma in the other half of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.

From a detailed questionnaire sent out to a large section of the pulp writers of the country the Authors League is able to release a few facts about this particular literary group. For instance, the average pulp writer clears about $1,800 a year; his average word rate is three-quarters of a cent; top-flight writers receive as high as two and a half cents a word from a limited group of magazines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Two more Japanese attempts to reduce the island of Wake failed yesterday and today, the Navy announced in a communique based on information received up to 9 A.M., Eastern Standard Time.
Orders by the Police Department to be followed by all residents in a total blackout have issued to thousands of air-raid wardens. The principal orders and instructions follow:
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19 -- A new instrument of democratic government which did not exist during the last World War is in the hands of the United States and other leading democracies in this war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Office of Production Management today carried out organizational changes under which the industry branches of the governmental agency charged with responsibility for converting civilian facilities to wartime purposes henceforth will report directly to William S. Knudsen, OPM Director General, and Associate Director General Sidney Hillman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- All Americans in Malaya are safe, according to a message dated Dec. 17 received by the State Department today from Kenneth S. Patton, United States Consul General at Singapore. The number of Americans now in that area is not known here.

On March 15, 1942 Decision of the Treasury to arrange its future discount-bill financing so that four of these issues, aggregating $600,000,000, will mature on March, 15, 1942, will enable the buyers of these securities to obtain payment just when they will need it, on tax day.

The Rockefeller Center Choristers gave the first outdoor program of Christmas carols of the season here at 5:30 o'clock last evening beneath the huge Christmas tree overlooking the skating pond in the lower plaza.

The larger sporting goods stores reported yesterday that their supplies of golf and tennis balls were exhausted as a result of the unprecedented buying rush to beat impending OPM restrictions, which are expected to slash by 80 per cent the manufacture of rubber products for civilian consumption.

The Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York and Military Vicar of the Catholic Armed Forces of the United States, will bless the new National Catholic Community Service Clubhouse, 17 East Fifty-first Street, across the street from St. Patrick's Cathedral, tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. There will also be a presentation of the colors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- "Aloha Means Goodbye," a magazine serial by Robert Carson, was purchased today by Warner Brothers for 512,500. The story, which was published before the outbreak of the American-Japanese War, involves espionage at Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Less than a half of 1 per cent of the critical material stocks available in the United States, even excluding aluminum, would enable 90 per cent of the small plants threatened with complete shutdowns in the next two months to continue operating at least for six months more, Floyd B. Odium, director of the Contract Distribution Division of the Office of Production Management, said today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 19 -- The people of the Soviet Union, for the first time, are tasting in full the sweet cup of revenge and their ebullience is expressing itself in savage new songs, grim jokes and posters bitterly ridiculing the retreating Germans.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The dates for the registration of women liable for call-up under the terms of the measure recently enacted by Parliament summoning single women who are 20 years old but who have not yet reached 31 years were announced today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Federal Judge Robert N. Wilkin today admonished the Erie Railroad to "keep 'em rolling" as he announced he would sign an order tomorrow freeing the historic line from reorganization.

HONOLULU, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons took over command of the Hawaiian Department of the Army from Major Gen. Walter C. Short today, within twenty-four hours of his arrival, and found that the blackout was Honolulu's most immediate war intrusion now that the shock of the first raid and the change in top commanders had largely been absorbed.
HONOLULU, Dec. 19 -- Two Japanese airmen who took part in the raid on Oahu on Dec. 7 never will get home, it was revealed today in a Navy announcement.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Dec. 19 -- Daylight air-raid exercises will be held here in addition to the frequent blackout practices, it was announced by Colonel John T. Kennedy, post commander. No advance notice will be given for any alarms.

Lily Pons made her first appearance of the season In last night's performance of Donizetti's "The Daughter of the Regiment" at the Metropolitan Opera House. As Marie, the youthful vivandiere, after whom the opera is named, Miss Pons found immediate favor when the work was revived last year, and the role again proved one of the most rewarding in her repertoire at this latest hearing.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 19 -- The usually well-informed and reliable Berlin correspondent of the Social Demokraten reports today that "for the next four or five months the Eastern front will be degraded to the rank of a peripherical war theatre" and that "surprises" elsewhere may be expected.

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- In accord with the new formation adopted for armored forces, Major Gen. Henry W. Baird is organizing a tank defense battalion, to be known as the 704th, as a unit of the Fourth Armored Division here.

Trading along the West Side of Manhattan, reported yesterday by brokers, was marked by the sale of a corner on Columbus Avenue, now occupied by two apartment and store buildings which are to be demolished to make way for a onestory taxpayer.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 19 -- Portugal demands that Britain and the Netherlands withdraw their occupation forces from Portuguese Timor immediately, Premier and Foreign Minister Antonio de Oliveira Salazar told a special session of the National Assembly in Lisbon today.

Defense plans for school children are being revised toward keeping the children in school buildings in the event of an air raid, it was indicated yesterday by speakers at the second and final parents' meeting sponsored jointly by the Board of Education and THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Appellate Division, in a three-to-two decision, yesterday held that small loans secured by autos or personal property are illegal if the borrower is compelled to pay out of the proceeds of the loan a premium for insurance of the auto or other property.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 19 -- While the R. A. F. strafed and bombed retreating Axis forces, a British armored brigade and lorry-borne infantry yesterday occupied the Derna airdrome, some forty miles west of El Gazala along the Cyrenaican coast.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) --Freddie Cochrane of Elizabeth, N.J., the world welterweight champion, won a split decision from Bobby Britton of Miami tonight in a tenround, non-title fight.

The four-story brick flat on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 12 and 14 Sixty-fifth Street, West New York, N.J., valued for taxation at $30,000, was sold by the K.C. Building and Loan Association to John Kammerer, who gave back to the Hudson City Savings Bank of Jersey City a purchase money mortgage for $9,500.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Governors of forty-seven States have joined with leaders of business, labor and farm organizations in signing a pledge of undivided loyalty in the defense effort, and this was presented today to President Roosevelt.

Traders in cotton continued yesterday to refrain from making any substantial commitments, pending clarification of the general price control picture and of several recent price ceiling rulings. As a result, values of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange drifted aimlessly in a quiet session and closed with net gains of 5 to 6 points.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: If the National Football League played a full round-robin schedule of games, it is very likely that the current situation of a late December championship play-off would not exist. It seems to me that Elmer Layden and the club owners of the professional circuit should devote some serious thought to making this improvement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The House today unanimously voted to President Roosevelt the same power of control over all wire and cable communications and facilities in the United States which he now has over the radio.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Germany is growing short of labor and Italy short of food because of German demands on normally selfsufficient Italian agricultural resources, the Foreign Commerce Weekly of the Agricultural Department reported today.
MADRID, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The government announced today that Spain was a "nonbelligerent" in the Pacific war between Japan and the United States, Britain and other powers.
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Bears, champions of professional football, frolicked through a final two-hour workout today for their title game with the Giants on Wrigley Field Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Classing the Communist party of the United States and the German-American and Kyffheuser Bunds as direct agents of foreign governments, the House passed a bill today ordering them to register at the Department of Justice and identify for public record not only their officers and directors but all their members.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Navy Department communique No. 12 on the situation as of 9 A.M. today follows:

New State and municipal financing will show the usual seasonal decline next week-the final week of the year-with only one sizable offering on the calendar. Scheduled sales to be made by thirty - six municipalities will amount to 54,433,139, compared with $15,992,718 in the current period and with a weekly average of $29,583,214 for the year to date.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 18: ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Dec. 6 was 6,285,080 shares, compared with 5,164,270 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Coincident with announcements in the New York Stock Exchange Bulletin that five more member firms will be dissolved before the year-end and that three new ones will be formed, Bernard E. Smith revealed yesterday that he will retire as a partner of the Exchange firm of Thomson McKinnon.
Today, after forty years of virtual suppression, a ladies' annex will be opened officially at Columbia University Club with a tea dance for women who are "intimate members of the family of a member."
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.
Published reports indicating that New York City is contemplating the purchase of 500 air-raid alarm sirens are "false," Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine declared yesterday afternoon.

Many Confident Signs The best kind of morale is, of course, the kind that needs no stimulus but comes as naturally as breathing. It is gratifying to look about and see people on every hand expressing their faith in America's future by simply taking it for granted.

LOS ANGELES. Dec. 19 -- Search for the missing Army transport plane in which Major Gen. Herbert A. Dargne, commander of the First Air Force, and seven other Army officers and men disappeared a week ago was centered tonight in the Tejon Pass area of the Tehachapi Mountains, some sixty miles northwest of Los Angeles.

Singapore, gateway to the Far East, is vital to the defense of Britain and the United States in the Orient. The Japanese drive to take it hinges on the surprise attack at Pearl Harbor. This, of course, was a bold attempt to destroy or immobilize the American fleet in the Eastern Pacific, in order to free Japan's hands for a push to the south.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 19 -- Federal Judge Hincks today authorized the trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad to pay about $15,000,000 in back interest on bonds of the company and on underlying bonds.
MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Dec. 19 -- Although there will be no reduction in vigilance, Army authorities here are making every effort to have this year's Christmas holiday surpass previous ones.

SHAWNEE, Okla., Dec. 19 -- J.V. (Bud) Honeycutt at the age of 64 has Joined the Navy to "do all I can to help whip Japan and Germany," thanks to an age limit waiver from, his old buddy, Colonel Frank Knox.

American business, with a record in 1941 of exceptional performance in the production of the tools needed for the survival of democracy, predicts even greater performance in the coming year as the United States, greatest industrial unit in the history of the world, gears its whole plant to the prosecution of the war.

The first of the new pins commemorating the Diamond Jubilee Birthday celebration of President Roosevelt for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was presented yesterday to Mrs. Roosevelt at a brief ceremony in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

At first we in London thought an air raid would come any day, every day. We had carried our gas masks, diligently, and then became rather shamefaced about them. We had never gone to bed without our flashlights, first-aid equipment, warm coats, jewelry and cash on a chair beside us.

Steel jobbers and warehouse men will receive a quota of slightly more than 9,000,000 net tons of steel per annum for the first quarter of 1942, J.R. Stuart, chief of the warehouse section of the iron and steel branch, Office of Production Management, said yesterday afternoon at an open forum attended by 1,000 steel distributors and government officials in the Hotel Astor.
Special programs of Christmas music will be presented in the churches of New York City and vicinity at tomorrow's services, Christmas Eve services Wednesday and at Christimas service Thursday.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- British and Allied military authorities were prepared to order the complete destruction of millions of rubber trees and hundreds of plantations in Malaya and the Netherlands Indies to prevent their falling into Japanese hands, the Colonial Ministry said today.

The General Aniline and Film Corporation, third largest dyestuffs manufacturer in this country, wag accused of trade restricting and market dividing conspiracies by a Federal grand jury yesterday a few hours after sweeping changes in its board of directors had been made.

NEW ROCHELLE, Dec. 19 -- Lieut. Col. Cecil L. Rutledge, executive officer of Fort Slocum for the last two years, became commandant of the garrison this week by reason of his rank, when the transfer of Colonel Edwin Gunner to other duties became effective.

The nation faces no easy task in the war against the Axis powers, but "we are already on the road to victory," Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commandant of the Third Naval District and commander of the North Atlantic Naval Coastal Frontier, told 150 naval officers who were graduated yesterday in the first wartime class of the Naval Training School for Indoctrination at Fort Schuyler, Throgs Neck, the Bronx.

The Christmas trade rush, slowed last week by the first shock of war, is under way again at a pace comparing favorably with early December, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. In wholesale markets reports continued to indicate a spirit of watchful waiting.
Feeling that at any moment they may be in uniform, a group of young men not at the moment in the Army have banded to form a junior committee of the New York Defense Recreation Committee.
ROME, Dec. 19 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The High Command communique today said:

William Jay Schieffelin, chairman emeritus of the Citizens Union and one of the leaders of the reform movement which swept Mayor La Guardia into office, called upon the Mayor last night to stick to his municipal responsibilities and turn over his civilian defense duties to somebody better fitted to perform them.

Military equipment, materials and supplies must come from the United States for the defense of the Philippine Islands, and time is of essential importance in their delivery, President Manuel Quezon said last night in an address broadcast from Manila over a network of the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Planning and coordination of the nation's home gardening activities was urged at the opening today of a two-day conference on food production for defense called by Secretary Wickard and Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

War has brought disruption to American life, some of which will remain "for the duration." Before the first blast of a Japanese bomb had shattered the Sunday tranquillity of the Hawaiian Islands, the old order had vanished. But now that nearly two weeks have passed, signs are manifold that women as well as men have rallied from that initial staggering shock, and are beginning to adapt themselves to new days and new ways.

Elaborate programs of Christmas music will be heard at all Sunday services in Brooklyn and Queens churches. Special Christmas services have been arranged for late afternoon and evening, also for Christmas Eve and Christmas Day at some churches.

No atom has ever been annihilated by bombardment in a laboratory. If the battering is to have any effect the blows must be hard, for which reason the projectiles of a cyclotron are both fast and heavy. But the cyclotron can deal only with positively charged particles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Ten thousand employes in a dozen Federal agencies and their families will be removed from Washington to other cities because of shortage of office space in the capital.

A new destroyer, the 1,650-ton Bailey, was launched at 8:50 A.M. yesterday at the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard on Staten Island, it was announced here by naval authorities. The ceremony was held in secrecy in accordance with a recent Navy announcement that no launchings or commissionings of warships were to be publicized.
