WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Three major steps to coordinate the war effort of the Federal Government with the activities of State and local governments were announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Roosevelt issued an Executive order establishing the Office of Censorship and appointing Byron Price as its head, and Bent to the Senate the nomination of Lieut. Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur for promotion to the rank of full general.

A strong appeal to several hundred organizations and groups throughout the city to enroll their respective memberships for volunteer work in civilian defense tasks was issued yesterday by Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, 93 Park Avenue.

The possibility of giving basic training to boys of high school age in the United States for air service when they are older is being considered, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, indicated yesterday in welcoming a group of Canada's military airmen of the future.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Damage estimated at $100,000 was caused early today to the Steel and Alloy Tank Company's plant, 1 Bessemer Street, by a threealarm blaze. The fire halted work on a $500,000 defense contract. All precision tools and welding rods used in the manufacture of large steel containers were destroyed, Charles R. Vincent, vice president of the company, reported.

Starting and finishing its year with international matches in Mexico City between Mexican and United States teams, polo played all of its regular championship events during 1941 and the season saw wider activity among lowhandicap men than at any time in the recent past.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: MR. E. IRVINE HAINES'S comments (THE NEW YORK TIMES Book Review, Nov. 30, 1941) on the discussion of Carl Van Doren's "Secret History of the American Revolution" have introduced certain misstatements of fact and are likely to leave certain impressions unfair to Mr. Van Doren.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The White House confirmed tonight reports that the United States is seeking "joint planning for unity of action" by all the anti-Axis military forces. Simultaneously, it was reported in well-informed quarters that at home President Roosevelt is considering establishment of a Supreme War Council of three to five members with broad powers to coordinate prosecution of the war on the military, industrial, labor and civilian fronts.

Paced by Saul Cohen and Dick Holub, whose sharpshooting accounted for 16 and 14 points, respectively, the Long Island Univerity basketball team defeated Davis and Elkins, 65 -- 22, at the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy gym last night.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- A defense employment conference of the United Automobile Workers, C.I. O., fearing a layoff of 350,000 Michigan auto workers by Feb. 1, tonight demanded immediate conversion of the motor-car industry to "full military production."

The men's North American figure skating championship was decided by a slim mathematical margin. When the statisticians completed their calculations one evening last February at Ardmore, Pa., the winner proved to be Ralph McCreath of Toronto over Eugene Turner of Los Angeles.

LITTLE FALLS, Minn., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Richard E. Dehler, a 16-year-old farm youth, "tired of being bossed around," according to County Attorney Austin L. Grimes, has signed a statement admitting the shotgun slayings of his parents, a younger sister and a younger brother, and the starting of a fire in the family home, sixteen miles east of here.

What Lies Ahead Ethelbert Smith said he understood how people would be wondering what kind of world and what kind of nation we must have after the war. At first he was inclined to think it a bit premature to worry about such things.

High income taxes and the certainty of more drastic Federal levies now that the country is at war are having a stimulating rather than a depressing effect on real estate investment, according to Aaron Zanger. He is the broker who recently negotiated the sale of the Butterick Building at the northwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Spring Street to the Curtis Electric Corporation.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuter) -- Football matches in Britain today resulted as follows:

The Olympic stimulus is gone from track and field but the urge for better performances and better records still keeps the sport racing along at breakneck speed. Ordinarily the post-Olympic year is the dullest of them all. Hence nothing should have been expected of a year that followed no international games at all.

LAWRENCE TIBBETT will be heard in the role of Figaro for the first time here when the Metropolitan Opera Company presents "The Barber of Seville" Wednesday evening. The American soprano, Nadine Conner, will make her debut with the company, singing Pamina in "The Magic Flute."

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 20 -- One officer of the Forty-fourth Division was cited posthumously find six enlisted men were commended today by Major Gen. Lloyd R. Fredendall, Second Army Corps Commander, of Wilmington, Del., for especially meritorious and outstanding service during the First Army manoeuvres in the Carolinas last month.
THE chairman of the house committee was awakened from a sound slumber and dazedly began telling what had happened during the past year.
A means by which artists may contribute immediately to the country's war effort has been announced by the Division of Information of the Office for Emergency Management, Washington, D.C.

Veteran shipping men in New York recalled last week that during the first World War a weekly passenger and mail service had been maintained by four American liners, the Philadelphia, the New York, the St. Louis and the St. Paul, between New York, Queenstown and Liverpool.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The International Air Force, composed exclusively of fliers who resigned from United States Air Forces to defend the Burma Road, had its first clash with Japanese warplanes today and shot down four of them, it was reported here tonight.

The new 489-foot passengercargo liner African Comet, the first of three sister vessels under construction for the American South African Line by the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation at Pascagoula, Miss., has completed her first sea trials on the Gulf and will soon be ready for delivery, it was announced yesterday.

A Christmas display of unusual interest will open today at 10 A.M. at the New York Botanical Garden. It will be centered around the Nativity scene, with figures in life size. Outstanding in the exhibit is the complete reproduction of the inn yard, planted with such plants as are known to have been grown in Bethlehem at that time.

A Princeton undergraduate, Charles Brinton, forged to the top in squash racquets during 1941, winning both the national amateur and national intercollegiate singles. Brinton, who is a Philadelphian, followed in the footsteps of others who have won national titles while still in college.

CONCERTGOERS who eagerly scan the programs for future events may have been a little surprised and puzzled by the announcement that in his appearance with the Saidenberg Little Symphony tomorrow night Emanuel Feuermann would play a Mozart 'cello concerto in D major.

In spite of a sharp drop in residential construction due to restrictions of the defense program, non-farm home financing during October rose to the new high level of $448,000,000, economists of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

CIVILIZATION has not advanced much, since armed conflict continues to be the recognized method of settling international disputes. The ancients considered the art of war one of the branches of classical learning.

The incomparable Willie Hoppe, whose name has been synonymous with billiards since the day in 1906 when he conquered Maurice Vignaux in Paris and annexed his first championship as a lad of 18, achieved a brilliant and successful defense of the world's three-cushion title to provide the 1941 high spot in the green baize sport.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 20 -- German as well as Italian forces in Libya were definitely "on the run" yesterday as the British offensive swept into a phase that seemed certain to presage an overwhelming success.

Declaring that 2,000 physicians are needed immediately, Colonel Franklin D'Olier, regional director of the Second Civilian Defense Area, yesterday issued a call for doctors to volunteer their services to the Red Cross as instructors in first aid.

With many a Christmas wish that their gifts would help to cheer families beset by misfortune or illness, aged couples in the twilight of their lives, lonely men and women struggling to re-establish themselves, and homeless children, 312 contributors came to the support of the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

With the opening next month of the $3,500,000 Benjamin Franklin High School in this city a new school-community program will be started by the educational leaders in the New York City system. This school is to embody the latest designs to enable it to act as a community center for the entire neighborhood.

LAST-MINUTE exhibitions before the holidays are upon us include paintings by three artists whose work is in high contrast, at the Gallery of Georgette Passedoit. Vladimir Boberman reminds one of Marquet in his more sweeping water-colors, but Boberman's small oils are even more sketchy and somewhat more shyly sensitive.

From time to time a crack thoroughbred is likened to Man o' War, who has been dubbed the superhorse, but the season just closed produced two such horses. At the beginning it was Whirlaway, triple crown winner and standout 3-year-old.

The South American way toward hemispheric amity was shown before a large, enthusiastic gallery in the New York A.C. pool last night and turned out to be a complete success for the little band of visiting swimmers.

MARK VAN DOREN discovered among several pages of an Illinois county history an incident which gave him the start to write "The Mayfield Deer." It may be legend, and if it is, it's a composite history of local myths in America.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors, after two hours of wrangling and bickering in special session today, postponed until Monday morning a vote on its budget committee's recommendation that a site in the Rye Lake district of the town of Harrison be selected for a Westchester County airport.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- An appeal from Reichsfuehrer Hitler, read on every radio station of the Reich tonight, acknowledged that his army faced an enemy superior in numbers and material and begged the straitened German people to contribute their warm clothing to enable the soldiers to endure the
Despite the nation's concern with problems of defense in a war-torn world, intercollegiate football had a flourishing season in 1941.

The perennial question of the taxability of college fraternity property reached the highest courts of two States in 1941, with diverse results. The Supreme Court of Georgia holds in a test case that a sorority house at the University of Georgia is taxable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Strategic defense areas of the United States are facing serious power shortages in 1942 and 1943, the Office for Emergency Management warned today. These shortages, it was indicated, threaten not only to affect normal civilian life but also to curtail production in industries not vital to the defense program.
AT the Christmas season, when good-will finds its warmest expression, let the Neediest share in your giving. They, above all others in the city, need remembering and befriending.

After many months of uncertainty because of international conditions the National Horse Show Association was able to announce that it would hold its fifty-sixth National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. Arrangements and exhibition were carried thorugh to a successful conclusion.

SCOTT PUBLICATIONS, INC., which annually issues the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue and releases monthly a supplementary "Chronicle of New Issues," announced last week that for the duration of the war it will refrain from listing and illustrating all further stamps originating in enemy countries or in countries which are under enemy control.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Armed Services issued this regular communique today:

Men with steady jobs in defense industries, men too old to expect a call from the draft board, heads of families and hard-handed youngsters continued to swarm into the offices of the State Employment Service at 87 Madison Avenue yesterday, responding to an appeal for shipyard workers to repair the damage done in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The threat to the British Government's commodity price policy has been increased greatly in the last week. Beginning on last Monday 2,000,000 workers in the shipbuilding and enginereing industries received an increase of 5 shillings in weekly wages, equaling u26,000,000 yearly.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Prices of soy beans on the Board of Trade soared today almost the permisible limit of 6 cents a bushel as the result of a report from Washington that the ceiling on some oils and fats might be raised to around the level that prevailed on Oct. 1.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

The movement for public ownership of utilities received added impetus yesterday with the disclosure that a far-flung organization, with a potential membership of 3,000 municipal power plants, 800 Rural Electrification cooperatives and numerous Federal and State public power systems, had been set up in Washington under the name of the American Public Power Association.

"Americans must dedicate themselves to simpler and sterner living, harder work and the conservation of their own powers and of all our national resources," Rabbi David De Sola Pool declared in the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street, yesterday, the Sabbath of Hanukkah Week.

IN covered-wagon days, when settlers fought their way into the Far West, Death Valley was the final obstacle. "If you can only survive the valley!" they said. Today it is a far different story, with visitors flocking there over paved highways to sunbathe, ride horseback and play tennis and golf, and at not-too-far Boulder Dam they frolic in the sand on Lake Mead's Hemenway Beach, afterward bass-fishing and speed-boating into the canyons of the Colorado.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 20 -- The German internal situation, although it is probably still far from the breaking point, has never since the beginning of the war been as unsound as it is today. The Russian fiasco and the declaration of war on the United States are to blame.
Joe Louis, for the fifth successive year, stood out as the greatest figure in boxing during 1941.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 20 -- Yale defeated an alumni hockey array, 8 to 4, tonight before a scattered crowd of 300 fans. The alumni closed with a rush, tallying three goals in the final period with help from the Eli reserves.

Dedicated this Winter as a tribute to the New York Guard, the 116th annual military ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York will be given on Jan. 30 at the Commodore. Major Gen. William Ottmann, commandant of the New York Guard, will be reviewing officer for the military parade and ceremonial which always is a feature of the ball.

To prevent a surprise holiday air attack on the Northeast, Brig. Gen. John C. McDonnell, authority for air-raid warning in the Second Corps Area, ordered yesterday all military and 43,000 civilian observers to keep unabated sky watch in the Christmas-New Year season.

IN the last few years the Christmas wrapping jobs done by many stores have eclipsed homemade efforts. Leaving out the question of sentiment, the professional packages usually look far more dramatic and effective. But there is no reason why amateur efforts can't be just as good, and many people still prefer to do their own because of the spirit and fun involved.

LONDON. ANY ONE attempting to compile a survey of the contribution made by our writers to the war effort, apart from their writing, would have to collect his material from items scattered from time to time in the press.

While the Canadian price control system has been in effect less than three weeks, leading merchants of the Dominion have reported favorably on the initial results of this over-all method of price regulation and they believe the scheme has a good chance of functioning successfully, H.I. Kleinhaus, manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said here in an interview last week.

WHAT is America? Well, Mister, if you don't know, nobody does. It's your America. You helped make it. You're fighting for it, right now. You and me both. You've got the answers, down deep in the marrow of your bones.

"THESE volumes covering the years 1937 through 1940 are dedicated to the continu- ance of faith in democracy as the world's best hope." Thus the opening words of this second installment of the great collection of public papers and addresses which President Roosevelt and Samuel Rosenman have prepared for us -- words felicitous and appropriate.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 20 (U.P.) -- Guerrilla troops, especially trained in night-time jungle attacks, were reported today to be slashing at the Japanese rear lines in Kedah, along the Northwest Malaya coast. All able-bodied men were being mobilized to aid in the defense of Singapore, and trenches were dug in open spaces.

According to the magazine Freehold, published by the National Association of Real Estate Boards, San Diego, Calif., appears to be the first city to issue emergency regulations for home building aimed to cope with any material shortage that may arise from the recent priority rulings.

The last days before the holidays are humming with festivities or philanthropies, and frequently happy combinations of the two, planned by the women's organizations for the least fortunate among the city's population. Children, orphans, the handicapped and the aged -- all are on the Christmas lists of the clubs, and gifts and entertainments are planned to make the season more joyful.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Nowhere is the vaulting ambition of the two chief Axis powers more clearly revealed than in their state religions. Let us fully understand the underlying philosophy of official German paganism and official Japanese Shintoism, as well as their striking similarity.

RIO DE JANEIRO. AARON COPLAND returns to the United States from his four months' trip through the Latin-American republics with an excellent plan in mind which he hopes will materialize in a time not too far off.

TO lessen harsh features of the State Motor Vehicle Safety-Responsibility Law, which will go into effect on Jan. 1, the Legislature is expected to amend the law within the first few days of the 1942 session in Albany. Two primary amendments are planned.

RADIUM AND BOMBS -- The Memorial Hospital of New York, one of the largest institutions in the world devoted to the treatment of cancer, has decided not to bury its nine grams of radium in case of air raids, despite British practice.

Slowly, but effectively, in construing income tax legislation, our courts are building up what might be called a system of common law in the field of taxation. This movement has already progressed sufficiently to place us on notice that in the interpretation of taxing statutes the spirit as well as the letter of the law will be taken into consideration.

MR. SITWELL'S stories and his style of telling them are as dated as a period piece and they have the same value. It is a useful value. The stories are not particularly good in themselves. They are not memorable as stories, in the way that Stevenson's or Poe's or Hemingway's are.

FROM RETIREMENT: A blackhaired, green-eyed man of Tarascan Indian blood departed a year ago this month from the President's desk in Mexico City s National Palace. General Lazaro Cardenas, having led his country through six years of strenuous social revolution, was succeeded by General Manuel Avila Camacho.

During the last nine months more than $1,000,000 has been contributed to the New York City drive of the United China Relief, it was announced yesterday by Raymond Rubicam, chairman of the city committee of the organization, at his campaign headquarters, 285 Madison Avenue.
ROME, Dec. 20 (From Italian Broadcasts Recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique today follows:

The accomplishments of the Boston Bruins through the season of 1940-41 were such as to leave little doubt in the minds of hockey followers that the Massachusetts sextet was truly a wonder team. Records meant little, indeed, to the Hub athletes as they swept through to the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world.

THE Assistant Financial Counselor of the Embassy of Poland, W. Narajowski of 14 Wall Street, has made available photographs of four stamps in the series of eight released by the Polish Government in Exile at London last week for use on mail carried on "Free Poland" warships and merchant vessels when on the high seas.

The sentimental scene known to all the English-speaking world as "A Christmas Carol," in which Scrooge, the hateful lawyer, peeps through the window and sees the Cratchit family enjoying its goose and gravy, was re-enacted yesterday for the benefit of the British War Relief Society, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Dec. 19:

Thirteen pieces of jewelry including diamonds and emeralds, valued at $140,000, were listed last night by the police as "missing" from the apartment of Mr. and Mrs. David Townsend of 975 Park Avenue. The jewels were said to have been insured with Lloyd's for $80,000 to $100,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Word that a memorial service had been held at Belleville, Ill., for naval seamen erroneously reported to be dead prompted Army and Navy assurances today that careful precautions were being taken to prevent mistakes in casualty lists.

Activity continued brisk on blackout equipment last week, while the market as a whole remained quiet, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

LONDON. THE surprise news of the month is that the government will shortly reopen Pinewood studios, dark since the beginning of the war, as the headquarters of a big, nationally sponsored propaganda drive, jointly housing the Army Film Unit, the R.A.F. Film Unit and the Crown Film Unit of the Ministry of Information.

In these days it can no more be education as usual than it can be business as usual. The colleges are speeding up their programs, planning to use Summer as well as Winter months. The draft ages are becoming more inclusive; the universities are losing the faculty members as well as their students; scores of them have lent scientists to the government and will lend more.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Pierre L. Barbey were dinner hosts tonight at their residence.

THE EXPANDING need for airport facilities throughout the country to meet the demands of the war, and the probability that the return of peace will bring a vast impetus to civilian flying and extension of airplane freight and passenger service, are causing many communities to seek ways of meeting this challenge even though they may be too poor or too crowded for space to provide landing fields of their own.
BERLIN, Dec. 20 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Regulations for thirteen defensive sea areas designated by executive orders were issued today by the Navy Hydrographic Office. The areas include New York Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Admiral Ernest J. King, in command of the Atlantic Fleet since February, was designated today Commander-in-Chief of the United States Fleet, directly responsible to the President under general direction of the Secretary of the Navy and in supreme command of all naval operating forces in Atlantic, Pacific and Asiatic waters.

Bowling's big show, the fortyfirst annual A.B.C. tournament staged at St. Paul from March 13 through May 6, was marked by three all-time records. The attendance of more than 150,000 was a new high and the recording of twenty five singles totals of 700 or better and 1,952 of 600 or better was also unparalleled.

TRAVEL Lines: A new luxury resort atop Mont Gabriel at St. Sauveur, Que., has just been opened. The Marquise is situated on a former private estate; its main building boasts modern features; its grounds, curling and skating rinks.

Plans for a housing development at the easterly end of Suffolk County to accommodate workers in near-by shipyards were revealed yesterday when Thomas G. Grace, State Director of the Federal Housing Administration, announced commitments of insurance for about $100,000 in mortgage values on a project at Greenport, L.I.

WHAT kind of films ought a country to make when the enemy's Panzer divisions are in its front yard? The Soviet studios have responded by creating a new type of morale film, the essentials of which are brevity, wit and variety, according to word received here by Artkino, the Russian film distributing agency.

Because of its flexible and informal organization, Columbia University Extension is in a unique position to respond to the wartime needs of this country, Professor James C. Egbert, director, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday.
EMERSON, writing in his Journal in November, 1862. set down some thoughts about the Civil War and what was to come after which might, with equal pertinence, have been written yesterday.

REPORTS from the Coast indicate that the film studios in Hollywood took their first steps toward a war footing last week. On Monday the studios adopted a new work day, 8 A.M. to 5 P.M., which automatically canceled all night work.

Rallying around the slogan "America's victory is Italy's freedom," representatives of 110,000 Italian-American trade unionists in the metropolitan district voted yesterday to set up a permanent organization to spur the participation of workers of Italian descent in all phases of the war effort.

A united effort by manufacturers of prefabricated, demountable homes to improve interior and exterior design and to make their product generally more useful to the defense worker has grown out of the building program of the division of defense housing, Federal Works Agency.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 20 -- Informed quarters here believed today that long before the oil appraisers named yesterday to make reports to Washington and Mexico City get down to their tasks the need of increased oil supplies by the United States and its allies would be so great as to alter the whole Mexican oil question.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 20 -- The University of Wisconsin philosophy department will commemorate the centenary of the birth of William James, philosopher-psychologist, at a two-day program Jan. 11 and 12.

WHAT'S IN A NAME? In Western Texas there is a little town -- three stores, a school and a few dozen houses -- called Tokio. Last week the local postmaster declared that "we don't want to change the name of the town, but we'd like to see some American bombers change the city it's named for."

Nothing has changed America so Illicitly as the attack on Hawaii by the Japanese. Where there were strident, quarrelsome voices, there is now one cry of a unified and a determined people. A universal desire to be of service to our country has filled the hearts of all. Every one, young and old, wants to help.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When we examine the history of the war during the two years prior to our entry, three indisputable facts emerge:

TORONTO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A surprise goal on a long shot halfway through the first period gave the Chicago Black Hawks the necessary momentum that carried them to a 2 -- 0 victory over Toronto in a National Hockey League contest tonight before 11,714 fans.

Springfield College's Golden Jubilee basketball team, victor over Manhattan and Hofstra in previous starts on its metropolitan tour, proved a surprisingly easy victim for City College at the Beavers' gymnasium last night, the Lavender crushing the Maroon, 59 -- 39, for its fourth straight victory of the season.

THESE are the days when Papa, who is too old to write a letter to Santa Claus. takes an afternoon off and makes pure that young Tommy will find what he wants under the Christmas tree and you can pick your own antecedent for that "he."

Hundreds of relatives and friends of the members of the Yale Dramatic Association will throng the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow night for the New York production of the association's latest offering, "The Waterbury Tales."

EVEN if Christmas busines closes with a rush, which it appears to be doing, it is plain now that earlier estimates were on the over-optimistic side. Stores will be fortunate to attain an increase of 10 per cent over last year, and they may fall several points below that percentage.

MANILA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Captain P. Kelly Jr., who became the Number One American hero in the Second World War by destroying a Japanese battleship and was killed in the flaming crash of his bomber after ordering his crew of six to save themselves, has been awarded the Distinguished Service Cross, the Far Eastern Command announced today.

Establishment of what may be termed an "Allied materials command" will probably be announced in the next few weeks, according to business men who discussed the subject with high defense officials last week. The duty of the board would be to coordinate the flow of both war materials and vital civilian needs in the best interests of the Allies as a whole, rather than those of each individual country.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Japanese successes in the Far East -- and they are admitted here to be successes and important ones -- have been sharing the headlines in the British newspapers with the German reverses in Russia and the continuing success of the Russian Army.

THE American Theatre Wing War Service, in which all groups of theatre workers -- from actors to their critics -- are uniting for war aid, is busily making plans for the immediate future. While one group is raising money, with $100,000 as the first goal, other committees are working out schemes for its disbursement.

Perfect either as gifts or as decorative accessories are some of the new woven materials and metal, pottery and tooled-leather objects which have the unmistakable air of having been made by hand. An exhibition at the Alma Reed Galleries, 46 West Fifty-seventh Street, offers many examples of the way in which master craftsmen are adapting their work to new trends and ideas adrift in the world today.

SET for war emergency, the road system serving New York City and its New Jersey, Connecticut and up-State suburbs can "within a few hours" be channeled to separate military and civilian traffic, the Metropolitan Defense Transport Committee gave assurance last week.

MOBILE print shows to brighten the leisure hours of the men in Army and Navy posts and on fighting ships at sea are now in preparation following the organization of the Photographic Exhibit Committee of the Citizens Committee of the Army and Navy.

WASHINGTON -- This capital, electrified only two Sundays ago by the news from Pearl Harbor, has already settled down with calm firmness to the stern business of winning this war. A united and determined nation shares the intense conviction of its leaders here that our victory program takes precedence over all else.

The great Pacific war, spread over unprecedented longitudes of space, raged last week from the foam-white beaches of the Hawaiian Islands to the steaming jungles of Malaya as the Japanese drove relentlessly for dominion or death.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 20 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Late last night it was officially announced that the number of casualties of the Japanese air raid on Pontianak yesterday has further increased.
HARLINGEN, Texas, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Henry Picard ignored a driving rain today to rush home with a 31, 33 -- 64, seven under par, in the first round of the Rio Grande Valley open golf tournament.

HONOLULU, Dec. 20 -- A good deal of Honolulu's normal poise has returned to the city since the stunning shock of the Japanese attack two weeks ago. The impact of war, coming as it did from a completely clear sky, shattered in an instant the happy, complacent existence that had become known around the world as "the island way" of living.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- With reference to the intrepid, but apparently futile, defense of Hong Kong, a British spokesman said today:

The importance of maintaining essential governmental services at high standards in spite of the priority demands of defense in wartime is emphasized in the legislative program of the Women's City Club for 1942.

The cotton market made moderate gains in quiet trading yesterday as buying orders absorbed the limited offerings. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures closed with net increases of 4 to 10 points. The December, 1942, contract, traded at the opening for the first time since it went on the board last Wednesday, showed the best gain, closing nominally at 17.14 cents, 10 points above the previous final quotation.

SINCE the usual holiday lull in the exhibition world has set in, only a few local shows were visited by this reviewer last week. Of them the most exhilarating proved to be that composed of lithographs by Albert Hirschfeld at the Guy Mayer Gallery.

Full speed ahead on a plan for community education in governmental affairs has been ordered in all units of the National League of Women Voters as their special wartime duty. As a result, local and State boards are being called into executive session to mobilize their memberships for the tasks.

WE found ourselves, last Christmas Eve, lying at anchor in the river in pitch darkness. The troops were aboard and the sharp blink of a Morse lamp from a near-by vessel told us that we were not alone. Around us lay other ships packed with men tense and waiting.

IN the raid on Pearl Harbor, a man hunched over a chart with a protractor in his hand and dividers by his side was just as much responsible for the success of the treacherous Japanese bombing attack as the pilot of the plane or bombardier who pushed the button that released the tons of explosive on the unsuspecting United States naval base.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The formation of the first of a large number of enemy alien boards which will decide what shall be done with enemy aliens arrested since the war began were announced today by Attorney General Biddle.
Pleasure boating's biggest year, now nearing its end, and an even more eventful one, just ahead around the 1942 New Year corner, are obeying commands from a stern-visaged skipper and master mariner.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It appears obvious that if we are to defeat Germany, Japan and Italy and win the war which has been thrust upon us the profit nature in human affairs must be suspended for the duration -- for labor, for the farmer, for the war contractor and for the business man in general.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Sinking of another Japanese transport, the second known to have been destroyed by American submarines in the most recent Far Eastern operations, was reported today by the Navy Department.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- The advancing Red Army, which in some regions is moving into territory held by the Germans for as long as two months, is being greatly aided by partisan groups, according to the army newspaper Red Star. These groups had been harrying the Germans in a more or less sporadic fashion, but now they have become an important arm of the Russian striking force.
TOO many cooks may spoil a broth, but can six epicures concoct a Christmas dinner that you'll enjoy from hunger to repletion -- and their reputations still survive?

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Scoring two goals in the overtime period, the Boston Bruins defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 2, tonight to take over sole possession of first place in the National Hockey League race.
High lights of the 1941 soccer season included visits of teams from Brazil and Cuba, which fared none too well in their games here.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Direct bomb hits on two Japanese cruisers, a transport and another warship presumably used to carry planes were reported officially tonight by Netherland airmen operating big American bombers off Japanese-occupied Miri, Borneo.

Following is a translation of the radio speech made yesterday to the German people by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, in which he appealed for clothing for troops on the Russian front, as recorded by the National Broadcasting Company:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Orders restricting tin can production are expected from the Office of Production Management before the close of next week, according to reports circulating here among can manufacturers and food packers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Roosevelt signed today the bill broadening conditions under which pensions may be granted at wartime rates to members of the armed forces or their dependents.

DETROIT -- As indicated by the government's control over tires, all motorists will share the burdens of war economy. After the present tire sales ban, extended to Jan. 4, all future tire supplies will be rationed.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 20 -- Three cargo ships built for service in the United States and British merchant fleet were launched today in two Maine shipyards before cheering crowds of workers and visitors.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Dec. 21 -- Continuing their march westward to free Moscow from the German menace, Red Army troops recaptured the important town of Volokolamsk, sixty-two miles northwest of the capital, it was announced in the Russian midnight communique.

His head lowered against the icy winds blowing across the Fordham campus, Jimmy Crowley followed his Ram players to the showers last night after their last workout in New York. Tonight they will board a Baltimore Ohio train heading for Bay St. Louis, Miss., and their training camp there for the Sugar Bowl game with Missouri in New Orleans on New Year's Day.
As operations in the Western Pacific continued yesterday over widespread areas, the importance to our war effort of determining and analyzing what happened at Hawaii was again underscored.

SUNDRY persons have been busy selling savings stamps and bonds around the countryside, and their government is properly grateful to them, but by all accounts the super bond salesman of the moment is probably Larry Elliot.

Spread of the war to the Pacific, affecting the free flow of vital materials to this country, is an additional factor which will make the curtailment of civilian goods far more stringent than in the first World War, executives pointed out last week.

Shortly after midnight tonight occurs the Winter solstice. If you care to look it up you will find that at 12:45 A.M. Dec. 22 the sun will reach that point in the ecliptic at which it attains its greatest southern declination. If you don't care to look it up, it's still the beginning of Winter -- and much easier to say.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Acting with speed and directness possible only in time of war, the government has taken in the past week long steps toward establishment of a powerful National Army of whatever size may be essential for ultimate victory.

EVENTS of the last few weeks have revealed again, only too brutally, the working of the totalitarian mind. And they have demonstrated that wherever that mind exists -- whether it be in Japan or Germany -- it is marked by the same sinister characteristics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The following Foreign Service changes since Dec. 13 were announced by the State Department today:

LIKE Mrs. Gaskell, like Wilkie Collins,Thackeray has never had an authorized biography. "Let there be none of this when I am gone," he is reported to have admonished his daughters, raising his eyes from a particularly bad book about a recently deceased contemporary.
THE illustration of the first chapter of the Book of Genesis is a task to shake the imagination, yet here are two books, widely divergent in approach, both of which are stirring and deeply evocative.

Discussing some of the parking problems in large cities, Gordon Whitnall, planning consultant of the Urban Land Institute, told the delegates at a recent convention in Chicago that the urban pattern today represents practically a tidal surge converging toward a single center at the beginning of the day and an ebb tide later when the human mass is spread out in the direction of the car lines.
Western eights once more dominated the scene at Poughkeepsie in the climax event of the year's rowing for the college crews.

AS is the custom at about this time of year, the boys have been communing with their adding machines in an effort to determine the best program, the funniest comedian, etc. Among the more extensive surveys is that conducted by Motion Picture Daily, which again has consulted 600 radio editors, who reached these conclusions:

IRVING BACHELLER is the author of "Eben Holden," which sold more than a million copies a long generation ago. His also was one of the most popular books about Lincoln, "A Man for the Ages." This and his "The Light in the Clearing" are, in his opinion, his best books.

ELSEWHERE in these columns today are sundry hints that the radio's Christmas Week stocking will be amply filled, as usual. If it is not impolite to point, here is a further note or two on some -- by no means all -- of the headline events.

WHEN Luis Munoz Marin, leader of the Popular party of the island territory of Puerto Rico, visited the United States last Summer, he was vaguely troubled by what he saw and heard. "It seems to me," he said on one occasion, "that you continental North Americans take your democracy entirely too much for granted.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of the New York State Solicitor General, Henry Epstein, about the blue ribbon jury, in THE TIMES of Dec. 7, was very interesting. The picture painted presented a contrast which is not a correct one and is likely to cause the layman to believe that the jury that tried William of the Palace was similar to our petit jury.
Looking back on a year of hunting and fishing in New York State is not the type of reminiscence that requires a fragrant pipe and a seat in an easy chair by a glowing fireplace.

MANILA, Sunday, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- Scant reports from Mindanao yesterday indicated that American troops, commanded by Lieut. Col. Rogers Hilsman, were still holding Davao, key point on the southeast coast of the large island.

Fencing celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the Amateur Fencers League of America with another year of steady growth. During a period which saw other sports handicapped by world conditions, sword-wielders enjoyed a highly interesting campaign, the climax being the Golden Jubilee championships in this city in June.
Robert Grant 3d of New York and Alastair Bradley Martin of Locust Valley shared the honors in racquets and court tennis during the season of 1940-41.

It was somewhat of a surprise when Craig Wood crashed through to win the Augusta National golf tournament last Spring. It was still more of a surprise when the blond professional, then 39 years of age, beat the nation's best in the national open championship and two months later routed Vic Ghezzi, P.G.A. titleholder, in a special match.

ONLY thirty-eight years ago last Wednesday man made his first controlled flight in a power-driven heavier-than-air plane. Wilbur and Orville Wright had lifted their flimsy plane off the sands of Kitty Hawk, N.C. Today there is no nation that does not respect the military might of the offspring of that awkward craft.

Steeplechasing and hunts racing enjoyed a successful year marked by larger purses and a general increase in interest. The climax was reached in the United Hunts meet at Belmont Park Nov. 4, when a crowd of 16,972 poured $699,976 through the mutuel machines, breaking all records for hunts programs in this country.

Many were the crowns that were tumbled at the national skeet championships at Indianapolis this year, and the straight-away trap-shooters at Vandalia's Grand American conformed to tradition by fitting laurels to new heads, as repeaters are unknown in this contest.

ON the first Christmas morning the good tidings of great joy were to all people. "Glory to God in the highest," the heavenly host said to the frightened shepherds, "and on earth peace, good-will toward men." They are simple words; they are understood and they have not been forgotten. But what a strange sound they oppose to the shriek and roar of guns and armies today!

Harold (Pete) Reiser, freshman star of the Dodgers last Summer, made something more than a mild splurge in his first campaign in the majors, according to the official National League batting averages released for publication today.

Congress Acts Sight-seers on Washington's Capitol Hill last week could pass through the pillared portals without being halted by sentries. Inside they could gaze undisturbed at the statuary in the great rotunda and the paintings in the corridors.

Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador to the United States, and Mme. Ciechanowska, who are now in Washington, have consented to serve as honorary patrons of the Polka Ball, ninth annual benefit dance of the Kosciuszko Foundation, which will take place on the night of Jan. 23 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Open-market sales of Manhattan real estate during November showed increases in the number of sales, the total considerations involved, and the percentage of assessed valuations realized by vendors compared with the same month of last year, according to the regular monthly sales survey by the Real Estate Board of New York.

From Malaya to Hawaii Last week's battle front in the Pacific, the world theatre's most tremendous in point of distances involved, spanned 4,720 miles from the humid forests of Malaya to the white sand beaches of Hawaii. The Japanese, riding the momentum of their sudden initial assault, were everywhere on the offensive.

Support of a campaign for $750,000 for expansion of the wartime services of St. Vincent's Hospital was urged yesterday by Governor Lehman, Mayor La Guardia and Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Commissioner of Hospitals.

The biting cold on Columbia's South Field had little effect on Les MacMitchell of New York University yesterday as he tuned up for his Sugar Bowl mile test with a 1:56.4 half-mile in the anchor leg of the Violets' winning twomile relay quartet.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Railroad was held liable today by Federal Judge George A. Welsh for losses of the Pennroad Corporation in a decision on a suit by Pennroad stockholders. The stockholders sued to recover $95,000,000, but the actual amount is to be determined by an accounting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- All chlorine produced in the United States will be subject to direct allocation after Feb. 1, and from that date no deliveries may be made without specific authorization from Donald M. Nelson, Director of Priorities, the Office of Production Management announced today.

YOU can't judge a book by its cover, but you can generally tell a motion picture by its press book. Press books -- publicity manuals put out by the studio advertising and publicity departments as guides to exhibitors -- are "productions."

DR. FRANK CONRAD, who died a few days ago, won almost universal acclaim during life as the "father of radio broadcasting." His was the amateur radio station from which sprang the epoch-making KDKA in 1920.

A LETTER, dated Sept. 24, received last week from the postal administration in Moscow, said that a 30-kopecs red had been released to symbolize the "struggle against fascist Germany, who treacherously attacked the U.S.S.R."

Well-known women of society are taking an active interest in the plans for the three weeks' exhibition of Britisn royal and heirloom lace which will open on the afternoon of Dec. 30 with a reception and tea on the ninth floor of Lord Taylor.

T.F.J. Moffett, editor of the Plumbing and Heating Journal of this city, explains some interesting facts regarding the effects of metal corrosion in heating systems. He states from an item on corrosion of metals recently published in the Sunday Real Estate section the im- pression might have been taken that it applied to heating systems whereas it really referred to sup- ply systems.

Although born amid gathering war clouds that in the end enveloped the nation as well as practically the entire world, 1941 saw sports write indelibly upon the pages of time another notable chapter of brilliant and fascinating achievements.

Harness horse racing flourished during 1941. Several new important tracks were opened, increased purses aggregating more than $2,000,000 were offered, and the country's trotting and pacing contests attracted approximately 15,000,000 fans.

Formation of a "Coordinating Committee for Intercollegiate Defense," which will serve as a campus agency for the Office of Civilian Defense, was announced yesterday following a meeting of student delegates of seven New York colleges representing 150,000 students.

"NEVER" in the course of its thousand years existence has the Catholic Church in Poland suffered such persecutions and torments as at present under the German occupation." These are Cardinal Hlond's words quoted on the front page of this book.

THESE legends, retold from the Apocrypha, are a lovely heritage from an age when faith burned bright, fed by an intimate personal quality in its love for the Christ child. They are of a nature to appeal inevitably to young children of any period, no matter how unorthodox their training, for they are of miracles of birds and beasts and trees which succored the young Jesus.

Juvenile vandalism on vacant properties has been reduced by half recently due to the cooperation of nine city departments and agencies, Justice Stephen S. Jackson of the Domestic Relations Court told the apartment house group of the Real Estate Board of New York last week.

Highlights in swimming during 1941 were sensational performances by 17-year-old William Smith Jr. of Honolulu, an overwhelming triumph by the Alexander House Community Association of Hawaii in the men's national A.A.U. outdoor championships, and a totally unexpected victory by the naiads of the Riviera Club of Indianapolis in the women's outdoor classic.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 20 -- The government made further sweeping demands on New Zealanders today with a series of decrees. The people were told they must lay plans for the blackout of sufficient rooms to house the inhabitants of every building throughout the hours of darkness.

If you have visions of bedecking your house and your tree and your table with trimmings this Christmas as never before, you'll find the shops most cooperative. In fact, if the Christmas spirit has been elusive so far, one way of whipping some up is to make a tour of the places that sell trimmings and decorative holiday things.

Nazis Retreat The war that came to Europe in September, 1939, is entering its third Winter. Its first was one of great uncertainty -- the period of the "phony war," when millions lay in idleness along the 'Western Front while Germany, flushed with victory in Poland, quietly prepared her next Blitzkrieg.

PAWLING, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- A comprehensive educational program to be followed during the war period was proposed here at the closing sessions of a two-day conference on the effect of the war on education, attended by representatives of thirty Eastern and Middle States private and independent schools.

Dealings in low-priced shares to establish losses for income-tax purposes continued yesterday to dominate trading on the New York Stock Exchange and the day's volume was the second largest of the year for a short session -- only a shade below the record-making Saturday of the preceding week.

THE last few years have seen a remarkable growth in interest in the sources of American music. Through publications, recordings, radio and concert performances, the musical public has come to know that elu- sive thing called folksong, found it enjoyable and exciting, and accepted it as part of normal musical experience.

American colleges and universities are now formulating a program that will enable them to avoid any disastrous consequences from a lowering of the draft age to 20, Dr. Guy E. Snavely, executive director of the Association of American Colleges, discloses.

QUITE apart from the privation, mental anguish and abominable physical suffering that war needlessly inflicts on millions of people, it destroys many of the finest flowerings of man's skill and creative powers.

The movement of iron ore from the ore ranges of Lake Superior to the lower Lake ports which service the steel industry set this year a new high record of 80,116,360 gross tons. This is 26 per cent above the 1940 shipments of 63,712,982 gross tons and 23 per cent higher than the previous high mark of 65,204,600 tons in 1929.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today that the State Department has been and is giving attention to conditions in Latin America that were the subject of the report issued yesterday by the special House committee headed by Representative Jack Nichols, Democrat, of Oklahoma.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe are leaving Tuesday to spend the Winter at Cherokee Plantation, Yemassee, S.C.

The sudden Japanese attacks upon the United States and their initial successes should not blind one to the fact that Germany remains the heart of the Axis war effort. Unless Hitler wins his partners cannot win in the long run. If the Nazis cave in or miss victory in any other way, Japan and Italy will not be victors in the end.

To the Music Editor: A SHORT time ago we read that Baldur von Schirach, the leader of the Nazis Youth movement, declared on the anniversary of Mozart's death on Dec. 5 that the music of the great master was in line with the thinking and acting of the National Socialist party and that he should be a watchword to lead on German youth in the battle against the "Anglo-Saxon barbarians."

WITH the tournament bridge season over for 1941, it appears that top rank among American tournament players, based on their achievements in competition during the year, will for the first time go to a woman.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 20 -- The statements over the radio tonight by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, coming as an aftermath of his latest article in the magazine Reich, which appeared yesterday, speak volumes for the efforts at present being spent by the German Propaganda Ministry to "get the German people's mad up," it is believed here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Text of a Navy communique issued today follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Sunday, Dec. 7, in the midst of peaceful negotiations, Japan treacherously attacked the United States, and on Dec. 11 Hitler declared war against this country, putting the blame for it on Woodrow Wilson and President and Mrs. Roosevelt. The purpose of this letter is to analyze the legal consequences of the treacherous attack on America.
Devotees of chess in this country enjoyed a rich bill of fare during 1941.
Terrace Village in Pittsburgh, Pa., the second largest USHA public housing development in America, is now almost completely occupied, it was announced yesterday.

This Christmas of all Christmases you will want to look your prettiest. Not every girl, by any means, can be a Helen of Troy, but you can never aim too high. American women are almost the only women on earth who still have on their dressing tables all of the little props and aids to loveliness.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- From the Arctic Ocean to the Black Sea the Russians continue to register successes. In the north, it was reported today, Russian submarines sank three convoyed and fully loaded German transports, presumably carrying reinforcements to the Finns.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- About the only persons here who seem to think that the Giants have a chance of beating the Bears in tomorrow's National Football League championship game at Wrigley Field are the Giants.

THIS is not precisely the morning to venture a windy discourse on the brainier aspects of the cinema or the esoteric angles of the art. Too many folks will be busy wrapping packages and addressing Christmas cards, or dusting off last year's tree ornaments and keeping junior from snooping under the beds to put any furrowed-brow thinking into a matter of some intellectual depth.

The office of Port Director of the United States Navy will remain open hereafter on a twentyfour-hour schedule so that necessary activities in connection with merchant shipping may be carried on at any hour of the day or night, it was announced by Captain Frederick G. Reinicke, Port Director.

LOS ANGELES -- Recent completion of more than sixty miles of good-grade desert road has opened up to the motoring public one of the strangest forests on the North American continent -- the 1,200-square-mile Joshua Tree National Monument, approximately 125 miles east of Los Angeles.

Bishop Loughlin Memorial High's athletes once again stole the show in track and field and cross-country in New York City senior schoolboy competition during 1941. The Brooklynites matched their grand record of 1940, when they captured six important track and harrier championships.

Wearing lace gowns patriotically designed in shades of red, white and blue, with matching jewels, many debutantes of the season will participate with their escorts in a jubilee waltz at the Diamond Jubilee Ball to be given Jan. 30 in the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria as part of the nation-wide celebration of President Roosevelt's sixtieth birthday.

Officials of the Westminster Kennel Club have announced two changes in the slate of judges that were made too late to appear in the eighty-four-page premium booklets mailed to thousands of exhibitors throughout the country during the past week.

The new repair, maintenance and operating supplies order issued by the OPM last week, under the designation of Order P-100, will result in much speedier handling of preference ratings for repair and maintenance needs and is of particular importance to manufacturers and suppliers in the New York area, according to a statement yesterday by Sydney Hogerton, district manager of the Priorities Field Service.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- British Imperial Forces in hard-pressed Hong Kong were still holding out today against the Japanese invaders, according to reports received in London up to a late hour tonight. These reports, although meager, were greeted with some surprise because they came on the heels of undenied Japanese claims yesterday that the main island had been captured.

One of the most interesting and important pieces of legislation enacted by the American Kennel Club during this year, especially in its implication for the future of the sport, was that relating to match shows. Briefly, sanctioned matches are now permitted on the lines of regular big all-breed shows, with the difference that these matches do not carry championship points.

For three years dividends paid by American industry have advanced on a broad front, according to a study contained in the current issue of The Exchange, magazine of the New York Stock Exchange. In 1940, more than 300 common stocks listed on the Exchange paid more than in 1939.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A thorough gingering-up of the civilian defense program, which is now parceled among Federal, State and municipal authorities, appeared inevitable this week. There is a serious shortage of personnel; 6,000,000 men and women are needed and less than 1,000,000 have enrolled, according to the latest figures available.

The National Orchestral Association, under Leon Barzin, continued its Winners Series at the second of the season's Gabrilowitsch Memorial concerts given yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The program included works by the late Henry Hadley.
LONDON. SO much has been heard in recent months about the public unswerving devotion to the classics that the success which has attended the concerts of contemporary music promoted by Messrs.
The season of 1941 will stand out in golf history for one reason if for no other.

The gift of a well-packed box of cut flowers, delivered on Christmas Eve or the first thing Christmas morning, will bring the warmest of messages from the giver, and be happily welcomed. A few fresh blooms included in a package will provide a real bit of Christmas spirit even with such practical gifts as clothes or food.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- Enemy submarines today attacked two American ships off the California coast and a third in Pacific Northwest waters, according to reports not denied by the Twelfth Naval District here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Plans for two plants to increase production of 100-octane gasoline, the special fuel for fighting planes, were announced today by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Coordinator. The coordinator and the oil industry seek to treble the output of the fuel.

PAUL HENRY LANG'S new book is a tremendous achievement, product of comprehensive and comprehending scholarship. Mr. Lang's range of vision is vast, moving from ancient Greece to the beginning of the twentieth century.

THE Dessoff Choir Series, consisting of choral works edited by Paul Boepple, is announced by Music Press of this city as one of its new publications. The series will be devoted to important but hitherto not easily obtainable compositions, introduced here by the Dessoff Choirs and directed by Mr. Boepple at its concerts.

In the present critical World War situation there is no room for complacency or overconfidence, but those who are unduly pessimistic may take heart by reviewing the amazing history of Hitler's invasion of Russia, which began just six months ago tomorrow.

Southern architecture, with its characteristic tall columns, copious wings and rambling verandas, was an expression of the pattern of life in the Old South before the Civil War, J. Frazer Smith, regional director of the Gulf States District of the American Institute of Architects, declares in "White Pillars," a study of the early life and architecture of the lower Mississippi Valley country.

In these midwinter days, when the plant lover seeks added color for the window garden which will outlast the holiday season, the begonia family offers many possibilities. The showy "Christmas" begonias, while glorious in appearance, are short lived under average house conditions.

A greater and more direct participation of the school system in the war effort than was the case Juring the first World War was foreseen yesterday by Professor Pliny H. Powers of New York University. Professor Powers, former superintendent of schools in Youngstown, Ohio, is chairman of the Department of School Administration at the N.Y.U. School of Education.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- With a declaration that enemy submarines are destroying American shipping off the coast of California, Rear Admiral John W. Greenslade, commandant of the Twelfth Naval District, expressed today the Navy's gratification that few welders had refused to lay down their tools in response to a strike call.

Entertaining at this season of the year centers around children, especially the little tots, all of whom are anxiously anticipating a visit from Santa Claus four days hence. Their older brothers and sisters, boys and girls in their early 'teens, home from preparatory schools for the holidays, too, will come in for their share of parties, but it is the little ones who make Christmas merry.

An advance of 0.6 point carried THE NEW YORK TIMES index of business activity to 133.3 for the week ended Dec. 13. It stood at 132.7 for the week ended Dec. 6 and at 121.3 for the week ended Dec. 14, 1940.
WASHINGTON, DEC. 20 (AP) -- Prices of sugar were "frozen" today by the government at current levels.

Last Christmas we bought a beautiful Jerusalem Cherry plant. It looked lovely with its gay red fruit, but its gayness was shortlived, as in spite of our trying to follow all the florist's instructions the berries began to drop after a few days.

Free meals will be served to 5,000 to 7,500 soldiers and sailors by night clubs, hotels and restaurants of Greater New York, beginning on Tuesday and continuing through the Christmas holidays, it was announced yesterday by the New York City Defense Recreation Committee.

Several Eastern railroads have become in recent months sponsors for a fund-raising campaign among their employes to aid the British Empire. The largest effort of this kind is that of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.

Was Coal Made by Microbes? Dr. Walter M. Fuchs of Pennsylvania State College, comes forth with a new theory of coal's origin. Instead of heat and pressure he thinks that microbes carbonized vegetation into hard and soft coal.

PRAYER comes so naturally to the young child who has been given any intimations of divinity that it is a joy to welcome in this troubled age these two books which bring it into his own scale of thought and experience.

A group of eight women appointed to carry out home defense activities among affiliates in this States has just been announced by Mrs. Guy W. Cheney, president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs. The new appointees will follow the plan of work of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, as outlined by the president, Mrs. John L. Whitehurst, and the defense chairman, Mrs. Gustav Ketterer.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Last week several American experts brought their testimony on the true position of France: John Elliot in The Herald Tribune, John Erskine in his article "Be Fair to France" in Collier's, Brig. Gen. Henry F. Reilly and Varian Fry at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association.
The Patent Office granted 748 patents this week, among them being the following inventions:

SINCE the Ballet Theatre closed its third New York season a week ago, it is impossible any longer to put off making some comment upon its accomplishments under its new regime. It would be more agreeable all around if the whole matter could be quietly dropped, but the past record of the company is far too brilliant to permit of such procedure.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Edith Maxwell, a young brunette school teacher whose trial for the murder of her father attracted wide attention six years ago, has been freed after serving a fourth of her twenty-year prison sentence.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Evidence that workers in the defense industry are ready to roll up their sleeves and go to work to speed production of warplanes, tanks, guns, ships and other essentials of wartime is revealed in a nation-wide survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Floyd B. Odlum, director of the Contract Distribution Division of the Office of Production Management, said today that more than 11,000 small manufacturers, after visiting "Red, White and Blue" trains sponsored by the OPM and inspecting the types of equipment wanted by the Army and Navy, had decided they could fill war orders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The freedom of the press in the United States, guaranteed in time of peace by the first article of the Bill of Rights but clearly incompatible with national security in time of war, officially ended Thursday afternoon, when the President signed the revived War Powers Act of 1917, including censorship authority. A little after 3 o'clock Friday afternoon came the first official proclamation of this power.

Stella Roman, the Rumanian soprano, sang a German role for the first time here when she appeared as Elisabeth in last night's performance of Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" at the Metropolitan Opera House. Hitherto Miss Roman had been active solely in the company's Italian repertoire.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 -- Mrs. G.C. Winfrey's Aboyne splashed from out of the pack to a hairline victory in Tropical Park's Inaugrural Handicap today. It gave the longshot players a happy send-off for Florida's Winter racing season.

A PARENT'S nervous hope that Johnny will shake hands properly isn't confined to the Christmas season, but holiday entertaining can bring it to a peak. This goes, too, for pulling out grandmother's chair at the table, thanking auntie for her lovely present, and remembering not to interrupt grandfather.

THE boys at the fire station roll out the ladder truck and sound long blasts on the siren. Along the block windows open, heads peer out. Many people stop and look at the sky. Some laugh and say, "Another phoney." Some hurry on nervously or dodge into apartment house entries.
Death took a heavy toll in the sports world during 1941.

TRUST Bernard Shaw to start controversy. The latest is over Handel's "Messiah." A writer to The London Times suggested that a good way to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the great oratorio would be to perform it with the orchestra score exactly as Handel wrote it.

Unlike the previous year, when nine teams were in position to claim the mythical national honors, the 1940-41 college basketball campaign produced two outstanding quintets. Whereas the previous season wound up with Colorado, Duquesne, Indiana, Kansas, New York University, Purdue, Rice, Santa Clara and Southern California sharing the bulk of the laurels, completion of the last schedule brought general acknowledgment of superiority to Long Island University and Wisconsin.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Princeton University will continue its policy of supporting student claims for deferment in strict conformity to the letter of the law and the spirit of administrative regulations, President Harold W. Dodds said today.

SOME months before the outbreak of the present war Andre Maurois made a visit to Henri Bergson, and even in the knowledge that the 80-year-old philosopher was ill the caller was shocked to find him almost competely paralyzed.

The war between the United States and the Axis powers is rapidly arousing favor for the United States and apprehension as to fifth column activities in Latin America, Earl I. McClintock, vice president of Sterling Products, Inc., said yesterday after touring Central and South American countries for eight weeks by airplane.

Economic factors will weigh heavily in this war. There are involved not merely questions of raw materials and industrial capacity but the efficient functioning of our entire economic system. Soaring prices and a rising cost of living will inevitably hamper our war effort.

The exhibition in the 1941 International Flower Show, put on by the New York Botanical Garden, of plants of Bible times proved so popular that it was difficult, if not impossible, to get near it during the show. Now we have a book on the same subject with descriptions of trees, herbs, flowers, grains, perfumes, water plants, thorns and thistles of the biblical era.

A MERRY CHRISTMAS? Well, yes and no. Across the year's most beautiful feast day lies a shadow: and the radio being a reasonably faithful mirror of the world, even the children must sense its presence there. Between Dickens's "A Christmas Carol" and Handel's "Messiah" will come certain grim tidings, not from Bethlehem.

THE twenty-two million Americans who are expected to file Federal income tax returns in 1942 need not lack for expert advice. David Joseph, certified public accountant and tax expert, has prepared a manual entitled "How to Prepare Your Income Tax," which has just been published by the Garden City Publishing Company at 25 cents per copy.

BRILLIANT sun streamed through the fourth floor window. Its beams gently played on the black, tousled hair of 9-year-old Roy Bogas, late of Vienna, who was seated at the concert grand piano. Roy's technical resources diminished the size of the keyboard as he ran through the lyric classicism of the first movement of Mozart's B Flat Piano Concerto.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau communique broadcast by the Moscow radio at mid-day said:

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davies gave a small reception yesterday afternoon at their home, 2 East Ninety-second Street, to introduce to society Mrs. Davies's daughter, Miss Nedenia Hutton. The guests, who included some of the older friends of the host and hostess, as well as debutantes of the season and other younger friends of Miss Hutton, were received by Mr. and Mrs. Davies and Miss Hutton.

Easily the number one item in 1941 baseball was the Dodgers' capture of their first National League pennant in twenty-one years. Piloted by Lippy Leo Durocher, Brooklyn's "Beloved Bums" nosed out the St. Louis Cardinals in the hottest race of many a blue moon.

Holiday trade in the New York area improved sharply toward the end of last week, recovering from the slump of the previous week caused by the outbreak of war. The gain in department store sales over a year ago was estimated at 3 to 5 per cent.

MURAL activity in Washington, as conducted by the Section of Fine Arts, Federal Works Agency, Public Buildings Administration, has gone steadily ahead since the program was started by the government years ago.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 20 -- Portugal's reactions to the Timor question are being closely followed by the Italian press, which sees in the speech made yesterday in Lisbon by the Portuguese Premier and Foreign Minister, Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, a manifestation of "frankness and firmness worthy of attention."

SIR THOMAS BEECHAM will make his first appearance as a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera on or about Jan. 15 with a double bill composed of Bach's "Phoebus and Pan" and Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Coq d'Or." Arthur Carron is among the singers listed for the former.

THE taking over of the Swedish-American Line's Kungsholm by the United States puts an emphatic, though regretful, period to perhaps the most remarkable twenty years in all maritime history. It was twenty years of mass roving, twenty years of democratizing pleasure travel.

DOUBTLESS the pattern evolved by war correspondents for their books has served a good purpose, often in a distinguished manner. Equally doubtless, Mr. White and his publishers are to be congratulated on providing variations in the manner of presentation and the format.

HOLLYWOOD. WILLIAM SAROYAN, whose talent has been described as the most undisciplined in the theatre today, has joined forces with the cinema's most conservative citadel, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, on a basis of such limpid mutual trust that the misanthropes at the studio are rocking on their heels.

DOUBTLESS the pattern evolved by war correspondents for their books has served a good purpose, often in a distinguished manner. Equally doubtless, Mr. White and his publishers are to be congratulated on providing variations in the manner of presentation and the format.

HOLLYWOOD. WILLIAM SAROYAN, whose talent has been described as the most undisciplined in the theatre today, has joined forces with the cinema's most conservative citadel, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, on a basis of such limpid mutual trust that the misanthropes at the studio are rocking on their heels.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A new united front of anti-Fascist Italians -- including Socialists, Communists and just plain Mussolini-haters -- has been formed to foment a revolution in Italy and force a separate Italian peace, the Russian Embassy said today.

Aerial bombardment of the coastal cities of the United States by Axis warplanes is technically possible, the threat being greater to the Eastern Seaboard than to the West Coast. Even though the direct military value of such raids is likely to be negligible, they would be extremely useful to the Axis powers if they caused confusion, or worse, panic, among the civilian population.
Robert L. Riggs Jr. regained the men's national tennis championship in 1941, and Mrs. Sarah Palfrey Cooke became the first native of the East to win the women's crown since 1908.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- "No matter what the emergency, the mails must go through, Frank O. Walker, Postmaster General, said tonight in giving instructions to all postmasters and employes relative to the present situation. Coordinating protective measures to be taken with those employed by State and local Civilian Defense organizations, Mr. Walker emphasized that the inviolability and protection of the mails must be maintained at all times and under all circumstances.

Action on a petition submitted to the Interstate Comerce Commission last week calling for rate increases on eleven ship lines operating along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts and in tributary waters is being awaited with interest not only by executives of the lines but by waterfront officials as well.

Books on urban planning, housing and population trends are among those chosen by Robert H. Armstrong, of Armstrong Armstrong, as the "ten best" volumes of the year from a realty standpoint. Mr. Armstrong has been compiling such a list annually for eleven years.
Skiing enthusiasm reached record proportions in the United States and Canada during the 1940-41 season, even though snow conditions were not what they might have been.

Particularly noteworthy because two drivers shared the distinction of piloting the winning car, the annual Memorial Day 500-mile Indianapolis classic as usual was the prime feature in automobile racing circles during 1941.

Acting swiftly in an effort to meet emergency conditions, colleges and universities throughout the country have started to gear their educational program to a war-time basis. Drastic changes have taken place in both administrative and instructional phases of higher education, while further revisions, even more radical in nature, are scheduled.

THE past year in jazz may be remembered, by musicians if not by the general public, as the year in which swing music went high-hat. There were no strictly musical developments to match this sudden assumption of dignity in a musical form that is fundamentally undignified.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a labor attorney, I read with great interest the letter of Murray T. Quigg in your issue of Dec. 14 expressing the view that the closed shop is an exercise of dictatorial power.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Paper and strong, flexible, self-supporting films made from clays instead of organic substances are revealed in a series of three patents (Nos. 2,266,636-7-8) awarded to Dr. Ernst A. Hauser of Cambridge, Mass.

BACK in 1804, when South Carolina's planting families came to Newport to escape the sickly season in their own Low-Country, John C. Calhoun, a Yale undergraduate, found that "a rather old appearance" gave the place "a somewhat melancholy aspect."
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Antiaircraft guns along the Thames set up a rolling fire tonight to repulse raiding planes, and machine gun fire could be heard in the darkness aloft.

The United States-Canadian Permanent Joint Defense Board announced yesterday, after a seven-hour meeting at City Hall, that "the board members are pleased to be able to state that military, air and naval plans heretofore made are in satisfactory operation."
