MANILA, Sunday, Dec. 21 -- United States Army headquarters announced today that because of communication difficulties the situation at Japanese-invaded Davao, on Mindanao Island, was obscure. No word had been received from there since yesterday afternoon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- Two powerful financial families of China were united by the marriage here today of Miss Jih-iung Woo, daughter of the San Francisco resident director of the Bank of Canton, and T.A. Soong, brother of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the generalissimo.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 20 -- Since Japan's aggression against the American flag and Mexico's official professions of solidarity with the United States, the Mexican press generally has decided that the time has come for a closed season on neighborly hostility.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 20 -- The Argentine Ambassador to Italy, Dr. Manuel Malbran, who came here a month ago to report to his government on the European situation, will leave for Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, tomorrow en route to Rome to resume his post, it was stated today.

THE recent publication of volumes by Walter de la Mare, John Masefield, Laurence Binyon, all wellknown names before the first World War, makes us aware that few of the poets of that interesting period have really survived.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 20 -- The Bruins from the University of California at Los Angeles outlasted the Florida Gators to win, 30 -- 27, today in a thrill-packed intersectional thriller before a scant crowd of 8,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- With the conference called by the Administration to decide on a plan for averting all strikes during the war emergency in recess until Monday, it appeared tonight that only the personal intervention of President Roosevelt could now break the deadlock on the union shop issue and bring the accord desired by the White House on a basic war labor policy guaranteeing uninterrupted production of military materiel.

A reorganization of personnel and guidance services in American colleges to aid students in adjusting themselves to the various problems engendered by the war is urged by Dean Herman Feldman of the City College School of Business and Civic Administration, in the second section of his report to the faculty, made public yesterday.

VICHY, France, Dec. 20 -- Although France has given notice of her intention to remain neutral in the conflict as it has developed, that does not mean that questions connected with the war will not arise periodically. For instance, two such, issues arose today.

Gathered at Cooper Union under auspices of the Mazzini Society, 1,000 persons of Italian descent pledged their lives last night to the cause of freedom, identifying victory for their adopted land with the liberation of the people of their ancestral home.

Handel's "Messiah" is one of the supreme masterpieces of the human spirit and last night at Carnegie Hall the Oratorio Society of New York, under Albert Stoessel, gave a splendid performance of parts one and fourteen of the thirty-two sections that make up parts two and three.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- Two powerful financial families of China were united by the marriage here today of Miss Jih-iung Woo, daughter of the San Francisco resident director of the Bank of Canton, and T.A. Soong, brother of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the generalissimo.

IN view of the psychological importance of the uniform, both in peace and war, there is surprisingly little in print concerning the uniform of the United States Army that is either accurate or comprehensive. The volume under consideration contains twenty-four hand-colored plates, chronologically arranged, each showing the uniform of one or more branches of the service at the period indicated.

Holding that the nation must dedicate itself to "Spartan simplicity and hard work" for the duration of the war, Wendell L. Willkie declared last night that ultimate victory for the United States and its Allies over the Axis powers would come only when this country put its vast production facilities into complete operation and out-produced its totalitarian enemies.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 20 -- Three British naval vessels were hit, and one of them was sunk, just north of the Gulf of Sidra during an encounter Wednesday with an Italian naval force protecting a convoy bound for North Africa, it was asserted in today's Italian High Command communique.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The nation's football coaches will gather here Dec. 29 to mull over at least seven rule proposals.

Calculated at prices in effect in September of this year, the fifth annual minimum adequate budget report of the State Department of Labor, released today, indicates that approximately $50 must be added to the ideal minimum earned income to enable the woman worker to meet rising costs.

UPON receipt of orders from Brig. Gen. G.L. Van Densen, this department proceeded to Fort Monmouth, Red Bank, N.J., a few days ago to see a soldiers' performance of "Whistling in the Dark." In wartime every one is under orders and must jump to attention when summoned.
To the Radio Editor: TODAY'S column by W.T. Arms, reviewing last week's short-wave radio warfare, says that new British voice stations are springing up all along the dial.

In what is described as an effort to facilitate the shipment of essential materials during the wartime emergency, American foreign freight forwarders, who have currently been protesting the system by which they are eliminated in the handling of lease-lend supplies in favor of government agencies, are now ready to offer their services on the government's own terms, it was learned yesterday.

CONCERTS in the Pennsylvania Station have been going on at 7:30 Sunday evenings since the middle of October, so that by now, even before the musicians arrive, little knots of people gather near the stairway on the Thirty-first Street side.

Harvard's chess players, out to recapture the Belden - Stephens Trophy, held by Yale for the past two years, were leading their ancient rivals last night after two rounds of the annual tournament of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The President in his proclamation of Dec. 9 pronounced every German national an enemy alien. The question arises therefore: Who is a German national? At first sight this term seems to include people who should not, I submit, be regarded as such in accordance with the President's proclamation.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The British Middle Eastern General Headquarters communique follows:

La Meri, who has been training a group of dancers in her School of Natya for the last season or two, presented them at the Guild Theatre last night in their first public appearance. The program was made up of three dance-dramas of India, composed and choreographed by La Meri, directed by Guido Carreras, costumed by both of them, and accompanied by recordings of music by Vishnu Dass Shirali and Wana Singh.

United Newspaper Advertising, Inc., has been organized in Chicago to provide a national coverage unit of daily newspapers for national advertisers. The program, known as the national unit plan, embraces one selected newspaper in each of ninety-six key markets to form a circulation unit of more than 10,000,000 and will have its first rate card as of March 1, 1942.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Navy Department issued the following communique today:

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Uncertainty over price-control legislation and price ceilings on many commodities has created extreme pessimism in the grain trade and speculative interest in the markets has become unusually small pending clarification of the situation.

Thousands of Jewish officers and enlisted men on duty with the Army and Navy have decided voluntarily not to ask for Christmas furlough in order to make it possible for the maximum number of those of other faiths to be with their families during the holiday.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 22 -- Defiant although heavily outnumbered, the British, Canadian and Indian troops at Hong Kong still held out, according to information reaching here early today, against a relentless Japanese attack.

WITH THE RED ARMY, on the Central Front, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- For the second time in a week British and American correspondents are visiting the battlefields in the Moscow district and they have found a widening front being steadily pushed back at an accelerated tempo.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Dec. 9 at 108.4, compared with 107.4 a fortnight and a month before, 100.9 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

The Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, in his sermon yesterday morning reminded those dismayed by the present world outlook that "the world into which Christ was born was also a hard and merciless one."

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Horsemen found cheer today in returns which showed that the bettors had turned out for Florida's rainy racing inaugural yesterday in spite of war, taxes and a no-pass rule.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A British far Eastern communique said today:

A series of lectures and demonstrations for New York doctors on first-aid care of casualties, sponsored by the Chief of Medical Emergency Service for Manhattan, the New York Academy of Medicine and the Medical Society of the County of New York, will start today at the Academy Building, 2 East 103d Street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Programs of anthems and carols, oratorios and candlelight services marked pre-Christmas observances in Westchester churches today. One of the principal programs was given this afternoon in the County Center here, under the direction of the County Recreation Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- Picket lines were ordered established at shipyards and other defense plants in the Bay area today by striking independent welders, and by nightfall troops had been moved into industrial sections to "prevent molestation" of men wishing to go to work.

The traditional Christmas Eve midnight services will be held as usual on Wednesday night in New York's cathedrals and many other churches, it became known yesterday. In several other cities, notably Boston, such services will not be held this year.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Dec. 22 -- "We have lost a considerable amount of territory and a large number of men and much materiel during the war's first six months, which ended today," said a military commentator on the Russian radio this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Defense spending by the Federal Government raised the total debt burden of the United States at the close of the fiscal year on June 30 to a new high record of $69,162,000,000, despite a slight decrease in the indebtedness of State and local governments, the Census Bureau reported today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One can imagine the havoc that would result from a bomb dropped by a plane in Times Square during: a New Year's Eve celebration. The possibility of a "token" raid on New York is not remote, as the Germans could send over a few planes loaded with light bombs, which could be dropped, and the pilots descend at near-by fields as prisoners of war.

HARLINGEN, Texas, Dec. 21 -- Henry Picard of Oklahoma City posted a total of 131, eleven under par, today to hold the lead in a field of the nation's top golfers at the halfway mark of the $5,000 Rio Grande Valley open golf tournament.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 -- All welders of the two main Los Angeles shipbuilders, both engaged in construction for the Maritime Commission, were ordered by their leaders today to stay away from work tomorrow in the move to force recognition by the American Federation of Labor or the government of their independent union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Japan is believed to have about forty submarines with a range permitting operations off the West Coast of the United States, where attacks have been made on American vessels.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Secretary of War Stimson, in his annual report to President Roosevelt today, written before the attack on Pearl Harbor, said that the United States was building a powerful long-range air force able to strike from our outlying bases against attack from overseas or South America long before such attacks could reach our shores.

NICHOLS FIELD, Philippines, Dec. 21 -- I was here when this much bombed airport outside Manila was attacked yesterday. Most of the time I spent flat on my face. You can't see much from that position, but there is nothing to prevent you from hearing.

A new sphere of activity for women eager to promote home defense was suggested yesterday by Louis L. Horch, city-wide superviser of the Surplus Marketing Administration. He called for volunteers to assist in establishing child-feeding programs under the sponsorship of public and private welfare agencies.

The Department of Parks announced yesterday the widening of the old four-lane Hutchinson River Parkway extension in Pelham Bay Park between the Westchester County line and the beginning of the new three and one-half six-lane parkway extension opened to traffic Oct. 11.

Twenty nationalities living in the Yorkville area were represented at the third annual good-will service yesterday afternoon in the auditorium of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, 331 East Seventieth Street. The association's children's choir gave a program of Christmas carols, and carols were sung before the thirty-foot Christmas tree in the center of Park Avenue at Seventieth Street, which was donated anonymously by a resident of the neighborhood.

EDGEWATER PARK, Miss., Deo. 21 (AP) -- Don. Faurot hasn't any high hopes that his Missouri Tigers can stop Fordham's attack in the Sugar Bowl New Tear's Day -- so he is depending upon a vicious counter-offensive for victory.

MANILA, Monday, Dec. 22 -- While heavy fighting was in progress yesterday between Japanese forces, advancing from several coast points, and United States and Philippine troops, the Filipinos were enraged by two outrages by the invaders.

The cotton market moved irregularly over a rather narrow range last week. Gains, however, more than offset losses, with the result that at the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cottor Exchange showed net advances of 19 to 31 points.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, in his first wartime address as Military Vicar of the armed forces of the United States, called upon all Americans yesterday afternoon to "forget the Irremediable past" and to make certain that there will be no work stoppages "from whatever cause" until the war is won.

Chiefly known, for the staging of many musical shows, Edgar MacGregor is now represented as cosponaor with Lyn Logan and director of a farce called "Pie in the Sky," which will be inspected this evening at the Playhouse.

The first bound volume containing personal greetings from 20,000 American citizens to Queen Elizabeth, accompanied by a cabled draft of $16,000 representing the contributions of the signers to a fund for the relief of British war children, was dispatched yesterday afternoon by Bundles for Britain from La Guardia Airport aboard a Canadian-Colonial Airways plane to Montreal on the first leg of its journey to London.

The electric power and light industry of the United States in the past year successfully met in every section of the country, except for a few weeks in the Southeast, the great increase in demands for power arising out of the national defense and war effort, Charles W. Kellogg, president of the Edison Electric Institute, reported yesterday.

Framed in a native setting that must have been familiar to Mary and Joseph, as they journeyed to the hillside stable in Bethlehem on the first Christmas, a life-size reproduction of the Nativity scene was opened for public display yesterday in the main conservatories of the New York Botanical Garden, in Bronx Park.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The National Hockey League champion Boston Bruins and the Detroit Red Wings battled to a 2-2 overtime tie at the Olympia tonight before 7,951 fans. As a result, the Bruins' league lead was cut to one point when second-place Toronto won.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 21 -- Adolf Hitler announced tonight that he had removed General Field Marshal Walther von Brauchitsch as Commander in Chief of the German Army and had himself assumed the post so that he could direct personally all military operations.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 21 -- The news that Thailand has signed a military alliance with Japan comes as no surprise here today where it is realized that the alliance will add appreciably to the strength of the Japanese attack on Malaya and Burma.

The Bankers National Life Building, a three-story structure with a frontage of ninety-five feet at 904-910 Bergen Avenue, in the Journal Square area of Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America to the 910 Bergen Avenue Corporation for cash over a mortgage of $192,500.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Howard MoMichael, with his B boat Ordeal; Scotty Isdale, with Don Laflin's X craft Carrie Nation, and Harry Herbert, with his 110 Hobby were winners in the regatta today at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21 -- Orders for steel for war purposes increased last week and authorities in the steel trade believe this trend will continue, with the distinct possibility that so-called "rated" tonnage will take the bulk of all steel produced.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 20 -- Continued Japanese pressure on the right flank of British forces in Northwest Malaya was revealed in the Singapore noon communique, which also reported that Malayan troops had "successfully countered an enemy attack in the Lenggong area south of Grik."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I call your attention to a sentence in a wireless message from England printed in THE TIMES of Dec. 15. It reads: "Mr. Ince estimated the number of unemployed British women, at 11,000,000, nearly nine-tenths of whom are married."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- Thirty-two survivors of the United States tanker Emidlo were rescued and twenty-two other crew members were missing today after their ship had been torpedoed and "her lifeboats shelled in one of two known attacks against shipping yesterday by enemy submarines operating as close as twenty miles offshore along the Pacific Coast.

Ninety musicians of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, with Bruno Walter conducting and Bronislaw Huberman, eminent Polish violinist, as soloist, were heard in a notable concert given last night in Carnegie Hall under the sponsorship of the Austrian-American League and for the benefit of the British-American Ambulance Corps.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Another week of favorable weather has resulted in the completion of harvesting of corn and soy beans in many sections of Illinois, Iowa and surrounding States and unless rain or snow occur this week it is believed that field work virtually will be completed by the end of the month.
With an impassioned appeal to his soldiers to hold the line, Adolf Hitler has assumed personal command of the Wehrmacht.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A labor-industry agreement under which collective bargaining may be conducted without the threat of strikes in war industries was predicted today by Senator Mead of New York. He said he felt certain that the President's labor-industry board would be able to reach an accord this week.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 21 -- The second attempt at sabotage in Southern California within a week failed to destroy Miguelito Canyon reservoir in Santa Barbara County early this morning when civilian guards won a gun battle with unidentified saboteurs.

The daily life of children in war areas must be kept as normal as possible and their parents and supervisory adults must attempt above all to give them a sense of security, Mrs. Edna Blue, executive chairman of the Foster Parents Plan for War Children, 55 West Forty-second Street, declared yesterday.

Net income of the Cudahy Packing Company in the year ended Oct. 31 was $3,652,316, against $2,116,223 in the preceding like period, according to a report issued for publication today. Net sales and revenues were $260,704,578, up 23 per cent from the preceding period.

As the stock market plunged last week to new low levels for World War II after having made a valiant effort to climb out of the shell-hole into which the shock of the Japanese assault on Hawaii hurled it, the question was poised in the mind of Wall Street whether a fundamental change in investment policy was sweeping the nation.

The Colosseum, a thirteen-story apartment building with a curved front at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and West 116th Street, near Columbia University, has been sold by the 435 Riverside Drive Corporation to Frederick Brown, the operator.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 -- The presence of enemy submarines off the California Coast occasioned little surprise today along the Los Angeles waterfront. What would cause even less surprise would be information that they were being refueled and were operating from a secret base somewhere along the west coast of Latin America.

Vignettes of life in London are graphically sketched in correspondence from Miss Daphne Cory, who has been serving since the start of the war as an ambulance driver for the A.T.S. (Auxiliary Territorial Services) in England, to a sister, Miss Kathleen Cory, in New York.
Business in the foreign, exchange market last week, while continuing light in volume, produced an irregular trend in some currencies.

A tract containing 1,026 acres on the south side of the Jericho Turnpike, west of Smithtown, L. I., has been sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company to Hamilton and Leeston-Smith, Inc., of 82 Wall Street, Manhattan.
NEW YORK Mrs. John McKesson Camp and her son, Gregory N. Camp, have returned from Watch Hill, R.I., and are at Mayfair House for the Winter.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- That greatest of all football teams, the Bears, struck the Giants with explosive force in the second half of their professional championship contest at Wrigley Field today, routed them with a 28-point outburst and thus became the first team in National League history to repeat as titleholders in a play-off.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Conversations of unprecedented importance to the course of the war and the future of the United States, Great Britain, Russia and the associated powers will take place this week at the White House.

Not the least bit disappointed to escape New York's current cold wave, Fordham's football forces headed last night for the sunny South with high hopes of gaining additional gridiron prestige in the New Orleans Sugar Bowl game with Missouri on New Year's Day.
MANILA., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The United States Far Eastern Command issued this communique this morning:

The American Ballad Singers and their conductor-arranger, Elie Siegmeister, gave their third Town Hall concert last night before a large audience that greeted them like old friends at the start and shouted out the encores they wanted at the end.

POMFRET, Conn., Dec. 21 -- The village of Pomfret, clinging on the windswept hills of Northeast Connecticut, this evening put on its annual nativity play, "Holy Night." It was the twenty-ninth performance of the Simple pageant which was started in 1912, and taking part in it tonight were three members of the original cast and the sons and grandsons of some of the others.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -- Ann Sheridan and Dennis Morgan have been assigned to the leading roles in "Aloha Means Goodbye," a story of espionage in Hawaii by Robert Carson, which Warner Brothers purchased Friday for $12,500.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox announced tonight that the Navy had probably sunk or damaged fourteen enemy submarines in the Atlantic, and that in the Pacific United States naval forces "have already effectively dealt with several Japanese submarines.'' The Secretary's statement followed a Navy communique earlier in the day regarding enemy submarine activity off both the East and West Coasts.

The men who sell gold bricks have nothing on a group of men who have set up practice in parts of Nassau County and are taking advantage of the fears and needs of defense-conscious residents there to operate a few petty rackets of their own.

The Red Cross added last week to its list of volunteer seamstresses sixty women from eighteen Latin-American countries. The formation of a Red Cross sewing unit at Inter-America House, 11 West Fifty-fourth Street, is believed to be the first instance in which Latin-American women have come together in this country to work for a common cause.
I HAVE read at last, with admiration much tempered by mystification, Rebecca West's extraordinary two-volume work on her travels in Yugoslavia, "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon."*

Following are the texts of yesterday's German statement on the change in army leadership and Reichsfuehrer Hitler's proclamation to the troops, as broadcast by the German official wireless and recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- By announcing his assumption of supreme command of the German Army tonight Reichsfuehrer Hitler raised a crop of speculations in London, among the largest fruits of which is the belief that his action, and the internal evidence of his appeal to the army, suggested that the long-heralded attempt to invade Britain might be nearer than is suspected.

General Field Marshal Walther von Brauchitsch became Commander in Chief of the German Army as the result of a shake-up made by Adolf Hitler on Feb. 4, 1938. Until yesterday's announcement of his displacement by Herr Hitler, it was expected that Marshal von Brauchitsch would take his place alongside Moltke, Schlieffen and Ludendorff as one of Germany's great military leaders.

It is deeply to be regretted that the representatives of industry and labor have not been able to arrive, as the President had hoped, at a prompt and unanimous agreement to prevent the interruption of production by labor disputes during the period of the war. The chief stumbling block appears to be the issue of the closed shop.
The art museums of the United States collectively announced their intention yesterday of doing everything possible to increase their usefulness to the public during the war.

Reporting continued success in his campaign to attract new industries to this city, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that in the first nine months of this year New York had recorded a net gain of 1,394 factories and 14,515 employes.

The expected fall of Hong Kong after only two weeks of war and a few days of sustained assault is not a major military defeat for the Allies, but it does represent a serious moral setback and reveals surprising and dangerous weaknesses in the allied concepts of strategy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Emergency priority assistance for smelters and refiners of copper lead, zinc, antimony, mercury and cobalt was authorized today by the OPM, which already had provided similar assistance for mines producing these metals.
BERLIN, Dec. 21 (From German broadcasts recorded, by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique issued today follows:

A program calling for 250,000 Jewish war veterans to aid defense, the sale of $25,000,000 in defense bonds and the purchase of six pursuit airplanes for the government has been adopted by the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, Benjamin Kaufman, national commander, announced yesterday.

Radio broadcasters are warned against sensationalism, carelessness, "second-guessing" and commercialization of news in a wartime guide announced yesterday by the National Association of Broadcasters. The guide, described as the result of "careful consultation with the military branches of the government as well as other agencies," amplifies the general policy of war news treatment laid down by President Roosevelt in his speech of Dec. 9.

If "Brooklyn, U.S.A." is the toughest melodrama to come along for years there is a reason. It is based on fact. It comes out of the savage underworld of urban rackets. Asa Bordages, who is one of the co-authors, has had a good education in the loathsome affairs of "Murder, Inc," as a reporter for The World-Telegram.
MANILA, Dec. 21 (AP) -- "It's tougher'n hell out there, but we can take it," said a big, unshaven American bluejacket today.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Dec. 21 -- Five persons, including a 10-weeks-old infant, perished early today in a fire that swept through a three-room frame bungalow on Old York Road in Burlington Township, about three miles from this city.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- How an unarmed American tanker, trailed and fired at during a half-hour period by a big enemy submarine, manoeuvred skillfully out of the way of the shells and tried to ram the undersea craft was told here today when the 6,771-ton Agwiworld of the Richfield Oil Company put in through Golden Gate.

The policy of the Federal Government, acting through the Department of Justice, is to allow the widest latitude possible under war conditions to all enemy aliens in the United States, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday in a broadcast from City Hall over WEAF and the Red Network of the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The American Council on Education has recommended that the high school and college education of boys and girls of high ability be speeded up so that they can be graduated from college at the age of twenty, it was announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The increasing gravity of the situation in the Far East overshadowed the stock markets last week. An acute weakness was displayed by shares of tin, rubber and oil companies operating in the Pacific area. British capital invested in these concerns approximates u150,000,000, while there are largre funds invested in government securities which may become involved.

Declaring that war-risk insurance covering air-raid damage to business and industrial property in the United States has become a distinct possibility, the United China Relief, 1790 Broadway, in a statement issued yesterday, reported that it had received a dispatch from China saying that the China Central Trust, auxiliary organization of the Chinese Ministry of Finance, has issued to date $865,000,000 in war insurance policies.

ALONG this time of season baseball somehow finds it necessary to yield to an overpowering urge to shower the country with its annual splurge of vital statistics known as the "official averages." It is a pleasing practice and serves a number of purposes, such as reminding us the holiday season is upon us and Winter's first snowstorm is just around the corner.

One man's carelessness or negligence cannot be permitted to endanger the lives and safety of others. If the bill approved by the City Council went no further than this it would be worthy of unqualified support.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 21 -- Harassed by the British advance guard and under constant attack by British air forces, German columns poured through Bengazi yesterday, apparently headed for Agedabia and Tripoli.

VICHY, Dec. 21 -- The latest measures applied to the French financial markets are far from, producing the intended effects; instead, the situation on the Bourses of Paris and Lyon is more and more difficult. The disproportion between demand and offers increases, and as increases in prices are authorized only in slight proportions there are very few stocks which can be reported.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 21 -- The Wilmington Clippers' three-year quest for a championship in the American Football Association was rewarded today when the Delaware eleven trounced the Long Island Indians from Valley Stream, N.Y., 21-13.

Upon her arrival at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon after a flight from California in a Beechcraft biplane, Ruth Nichols, executive director of Relief Wings, Inc., declared that there was a serious need for civilian ambulance planes in the United States.

The efforts of the police to avenge an assault on one of their number were ended successfully yesterday after more than five months of pursuit and legal bickering that finally dragged in President Roosevelt and the Department of State.

TOKYO, Dec. 21 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- General Senjuro Hayashi, former Premier and War Minister, today urged the Axis nations to open simultaneous offensives against the Anglo-American forces in Africa and the Far East.

Now that everything is closed in New York State and New England, with the exception of foxes and rabbits, the hound dog is once more king, and according to reports received during the past week he is getting an opportunity to earn his crown.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Ace Parker, star football player of the Dodgers of the National League, suffered a broken collarbone in the Smoke Bowl game today between all-star teams representing Norfolk and Richmond.

The 1941 Neediest Cases Fund appeal opened its third week yesterday more than $10,000 behind the 1940 Fund for the corresponding day, and with the number of contributors falling off sharply instead of increasing just before Christmas, as it did last year.

Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday morning at Riverside Church.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Some quarters here believe that Japan may launch a major drive for Ipoh, an important tin mining center twenty-five miles south of Lenggong, at almost any hour.

Today the flurry and hurry of the great American sport, Christmas shopping, has reached a pinnacle of concentrated confusion. Subways overflow, postal delivery wagons with the hope message "Mail Early" emblazoned on their sides pull up at almost every door, and there are still ten names left on your list.

A seven-story building down in Hudson Street, no different outwardly from the many busy warehouses that surround it, shelters more unpaid labor than is contributed anywhere else in the United States. From dawn to dusk it hums with activity on all its floors but one, retained for his own purposes by the original tenant.

The Slanting Eye It must seem queer to a Chinese that Americans can tell the difference between an Italian and a Swede -- or think they can -- but have some trouble in distinguishing between a Chinese and a Japanese. Yet this does seem to be the case, and Chinese in this country have taken to wearing buttons to establish their identity.

Columbia Aircraft Products The Columbia Aircraft Products, Inc., will pay bonuses to employes with service of one month or more. Employes who were with the company for six months or more prior to Nov. 30 last will receive one week's pay and those with less service proportionate amounts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) --Toronto's Maple Leafs, knocked out of a first-place tie in the National Hockey League last night, regained a point in that direction tonight by defeating Chicago's Black Hawks, 3 to 0. The defeat snapped at six a string of games in which the Hawks had gone unbeaten and left them in third place, three points behind Toronto.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices continued its march into new high ground, reaching 100.9. As in the previous week, most of the rise occurred in farm products and foodstuffs, since practically all of the individual commodities in these two groups showed gains, with an especially sharp increase taking place in the price of pork.
In a Christmas message to the Camp Fire Girls, of which he is honorary president, President Roosevelt greeted the organization's 308,000 members and related its work to the democratic ideal.

The 5,000,000 members of the Congress of Industrial Organizations throughout the country were urged yesterday by Irving Abramson, chairman of the National C.I.O. Committee for American and Allied War Relief, to contribute at lease one hour's pay a month to the $1,000,000-a-month war relief program that the labor organization will begin on Jan. 1.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Four prominent members of the Labor party, all of them men of independent outlook and forceful debating powers, three of them outstanding figures in the House of Commons, have been elevated to the peerage, it was announced today.

The National Board of Review of Motion Pictures yesterday announced its sixteenth annual selection of film "bests." On the basis of "artistic merit and importance" the board's committee on exceptional photoplays voted Orson Welles's "Citizen Kane" as the best Hollywood-made picture of 1941, the French "Pepe le Moko" as the top foreign production and "Target for Tonight," British war film, as the best documentary production.

LONDON, Dec. 21 (U.P.) -- British Imperial defenders of Hong Kong, doomed by an overwhelming Japanese siege to seemingly certain death or war-long captivity, told the world by radio today that "organized resistance continues" in "heavy fighting."
Preparing for the holiday crowds. Broadway motion-picture theatres will bring In ten new films this week. Of these, six will open on Christmas Day. The lineup follows:
KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 21 -- The Philadelphia Nationals triumphed over the Scots-Americans today, 7-6. The victors enjoyed a 4-3 advantage at the half. Gonsalves made four goals for the home team.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- The New York Americans tied with the Philadelphia Americans, 1-1, today. Both goals were scored in the . second half.

VICHY, Dec. 21 -- I.G. Farbenindustrie, the German chemical corporation, has acquired 51 per cent of the stock in the new French dyestuff and chemical company, Francolor, it appeared today from the reports to the annual assembly of the Kuhlmann establishments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Acceptances of invitations to serve on a national advisory committee in connection with the appeal for a minimum Red Cross war fund of $50,000,000 have been received from fifty-three representative men and women, Norman H. Davis, chairman of the Red Cross, announced today.

Citing the wartime conditions that make it imperative that our streets be kept clear to enable essential services to move unimpeded, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that his department soon will start a vigorous drive to curb illegal parking.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for November, based on 1930 as 100, was 155.2, compared with 154.6 for October, 146.9 for November, 1940, and 98.1 for August, 1939.

It is essential that we stop thinking at the very outset of the present struggle in terms of the last World War. Some of the lessons we learned then no doubt will prove useful again. As the Greater New York Red Cross War Fund drive gathered momentum with receipt of additional large gifts, plans were announced yesterday by two important campaign committees to send 22,000 workers into the field to help raise the $7,330,000 that is New York's quota in the $50,000,000 national War Fund drive.

Demand continued fair on popular-priced dresses last week, despite a general lull in apparel buying. Print jersey dresses were among the best reorder items. Manufacturers were busy on Spring lines to be shown after the first of the year.

The New York Rovers passed up a fine opportunity to go into a first-place tie with the Johnstown (Pa.) Bluebirds yesterday afternoon when they fell before a two-goal attack by the Washington Eagles in the third period to drop a 3-2 decision to their Eastern Hockey League foes at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Dec. 15 to 20 are given in the appended tabulation:
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 21 (AP) -- A B-26 Army bomber crashed, exploded and burned near the Jackson air base today, killing its crew of five.

PELHAM HANOR, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Mr. and Mrs. Winfred Byron Holton Jr. gave a reception here this afternoon at their home to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Patricia Curran Holton. Christmas greens, silvered and white birch branches, and lilies with green garlands were used in the decorations.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The British Government today has taken what is considered here as the most unusual step in issuing a statement explaining to the Portuguese people that Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar was quite right in telling them that everything would toe straightened out after the war so far as Timor is concerned.

THE CRIMINALS, a play in three acts, by Ferdinand Bruckner, as translated by Edwin Denby and Rita Matthias. Staged by Sanford Melsner; scenery by H.A. Condell; lighting by Hans Sondhelmer; produced by the Studio Theatre of the New School tor Social Research at 66 West Twelfth Street.

A definite plan for the allocation of wood pulp, based on the need for the expanded use of the nitrating types in the production of ammunition, is being drawn up by the Office of Production Management and will be announced soon, it was learned here yesterday.

The medical division of the United States Office of Civilian Defense issued yesterday its second bulletin, described "equipment and operation of emergency field units," with the recommendation that "State and local defense councils adopt the plans set forth so as to secure the advantages of uniformity in organization, equipment and operation."

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Dec. 22 (AP) -- S. G. Hibben, director of applied lighting for the lamp division of Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, said today plans for dousing lights in alternate streets to outwit enemy fliers during blackouts were being considered.

Women's Suits Reordered Reorders have already begun to come in for women's suits, confirming previous indications that these garments would be notably outstanding for the coming Spring season. Thus far retailer interest has been noted for two-piece tailored versions in covert or gabardine.

For many of the 10,000 government employes involved there will be heartaches in the wholesale shifting of agencies and bureaus out of Washington to make room for the expanding war personnel. Men and women in some of these agencies face the prospect of separation from wives or husbands who are employed in other branches of the Government.

Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe The Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railroad declared yesterday a dividend of 51 on the common stock. Similar payments were made on Dec. 1 and Sept. 2, making total disbursements this year $3, compared with $1 in 1940.

Christmas holiday celebrations gained momentum throughout New York City yesterday as charitable fraternal, civic and other organizations held scores of Christmas parties for the less fortunate while preparing to discharge newer responsibilities entailed by war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A new plan for distributing critical materials to civilian industry on a high priority basis has been worked out by the Office of Production Management and will be put into effect as soon as the office gets the results of its most recent survey of available supplies of commodities.

As 17-year-old Adolph Weissman of 1826 East Third Street, Brooklyn, was sworn into the Navy yesterday, he vowed that the Japanese had made a mistake when they wounded his big brother, Dan, a first-class seaman, "somewhere in the Pacific."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22 -- Emerson W. (Spike) Nelson resigned today as head coach of the Yale football team, which won only one of eight games during the past season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Preholiday dullness descended on the wheat market today and there was sufficient scattered commission house selling to cause a slightly easier undertone. Closing out of December contracts, trading in which, ceased at the close, resulted in that delivery finishing 1/8 cent a bushel higher, while the deferred months were 3/8 cent lower.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Aldo and Mario Palazzari, University of Illinois forwards from Eveleth, Minn., the United States' most productive hockey center, and Lou Ferronti of West Springfield, Mass., scored in overtime tonight at the Chicago Arena to give the Illini a 4-to-1 victory over Dartmouth.

Santa Claus played host to 200 children, patients of the pediatric clinic and neighborhood youngsters, yesterday at the Midtown Hospital, 309 East Forty-ninth Street. It was the fiftieth annual Christmas party held by the hospital and was attended by children ranging from 1 to 10 years old.

There is no mistletoe hanging from the lights at the headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue, but everything else connected with Christmas is in readiness for visiting service men.

Miss Emily Sloane Franklin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Franklin of 825 Fifth Avenue and Glen Cove, L. I., was presented to society last night at a dance given by her grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Hammond, and her parents, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Hammond, 9 East Ninety-first Street.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 22 -- Constitutionality of the 1935 capital stock tax was unanimously upheld by the United States Supreme Court today in a decision rendered by Justice William C. Douglas.

Nadine Conner, young American soprano, made good in her debut at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. She entered the company in the role of Pamina in Mozart's "Magic Flute" and she immediately took her place as a sensitive, integral member of the cast.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The stock markets were more cheerful today with the gilt-edged section hardening 1-16 to 1-8 point and 3 1/2 per cent war loan closing at u104 3/8. The industrials were firm with the Dunlops at 32 3/8 and Woolworths, Fine Cotton Spinners and British Match steady.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors adopted by a vote of 34 to 6, a 1942 county budget amounting to $12,888,691 gross and entailing a net tax levy of $7,756,935. These figures are slightly lower than those for 1941 but due to a drop in assessed valuations the county tax rate will rise from $4.91 to $4.95 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation.

Possibilities for a wide new field for women workers in factories making instruments for aircraft, for military medical units and for fire control-aiming and firing of guns, torpedoes and bombs -- were seen yesterday in a study of defense factories by Mary Anderson, director of the women's bureau of the United States Department of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Dec. 17 aggregated $14,224,000,000.
The welders' strike in the San Francisco Bay area may help to clarify our thinking in several respects about the problem of labor relations during wartime.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Robert B. McNitt, 30, secretary of the McNaught Syndicate, was killed instantly tonight beneath the wheels of a New York, New Haven Hartford train leaving the Greenwich station.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau today welcomed two offers to buy millions of dollars' worth of Defense Savings Bonds; one from the United Automobile Workers Association and the other from the Railway Labor Executives' Association.

Charles Miner Thompson, who died the other day in Cambridge at the age of 77, spent thirty-five years of an active career as associate editor, and later editor-in-chief of the old Youth's Companion. He was a translator, a novelist and in his last years a historian of his native Vermont.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 23 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- The British garrison at Hong Kong is still holding out despite furious Japanese artillery and aerial attacks, it was acknowledged in a broadcast here today.
TRENTON, N. J. (AP) -- Three District Court judgeship nominations and an appointment to the State Board of Education were sent to the New Jersey Senate late today by Governor Charles Edison.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Representatives of industrial management rejected today a three-point labor peace formula advanced by Senator Thomas of Utah, and President Roosevelt's Industry-Labor Conference seemed on the verge of collapsing without the unanimous accord asked by the President to guarantee uninterrupted production of military materiel for the duration of the war.
The reports of Manhattan realty sales yesterday evidenced a continuance of the recent demand for business properties. A majority of the day's transactions involved such holdings.

More people live in the area bounded roughly by Avenue B, Avenue D, East Fifth and East Ninth Streets, on the lower East Side, than in any other limited area in the five boroughs of New York City, a breakdown of statistics issued by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce showed yesterday.

From the depths of its heart this country will bid Winston Churchill welcome. We know this man. We have watched him under fire. We have long admired from afar the gallantry of his leadership and the splendor of his faith in all that freedom means to us. He comes to us now in a moment of great crisis, when his democracy and our democracy are fighting for their very lives.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 22 -- The Italian and German forces in Cyrenaica continued to retreat all day yesterday without offering organized resistance anywhere, but it is not possible from a reading of the Axis communiques or from semi-official information from Rome and Berlin to say how far westward the British Imperial forces have gone.

The Philadelphia Electric Company announced yesterday that, starting today, it would offer to holders of its $5 preferred stock, of which there are 280,058 shares outstanding, the right to exchange on a share-for-share basis present holdings for new 4.4 per cent preferred stock of $100 par value.

CHUNGKING, China. Dec. 20 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- General Lieu Wei Chang, vice chief of the Chinese Military Operations Board, said today in an analysis of Japanese army strength that "short of a miracle" Japan could not raise enough divisions to meet the commitments of its expanding war fronts.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- American forces were reported today to be locked in a widespread battle with thousands of Japanese troops landed on the shore of Lingayen Gulf, northwest of this island capital.

Led by the national amateur champion, Charles Brinton, Princeton University's representatives gained three places among the eight in the quarter-final round of the University Club's intercollegiate invitation squash racquets tournament yesterday.

W. J. Sloane received the grand award yesterday in the Fifth Avenue Association's annual Christmas window display competition, which was held during the week of Dec. 1 to 6. Announcement of the winners in the competition was made at a reception given by the association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The cotton market made moderate gains in quiet trading yesterday, and final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were 7 to 9 points above Saturday's close. The market continued featureless as traders awaited clarification of the price-control situation in Washington.

Tax Selling The selling of securities to establish losses for income tax purposes is an old story so far as the stock market is concerned. This year tax selling in the bond market, including the government bond market, is no novelty.

Lack of a definite air raid defense program, conflicting instructions as to what to do in an air raid and the absence of a central agency to coordinate and direct defense activities were charged yesterday at the first session of a two-day "Air Raid Precautions Conference" attended by seventy-five architects, engineers, city officials and representatives of business organizations at Pratt Institute, 215 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 -- Shipyard workmen went to their jobs in the Bay area today under protection of the Army, as welders, "on strike against the American Federation of Labor," continued to picket defense plants in defiance of condemnatory statements from their own national office in Washington and from the Office of Production Management.

Exemption of export items from pending price control legislation was urged yesterday by the Committee on International Trade of the Advertising Club of New York. The suggestion was contained in a letter to Senator Robert F. Wagner from John A. Zellers, the committee's chairman.

Governor William H. Wills and Donald W. Smith, chairman of the Board of Conservation and Development, were the principal speakers yesterday as the State Ski Lodge in Smugglers Notch, outside of Stowe, Vt., was officially dedicated.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The British did not name the site of the Axis base 150 miles inside Tripolitanig, the demolishing of which by a daring desert patrol was announced today, but the distance suggested that It was at Sirte or near by on the Bengazi-Tripoli coastal highway.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 22 -- Berlin was reported tonight to be dazed by recent and conflicting developments and to be seeking the real reason for the dismissal of General Field Marshal Walther von Brauchitsch as Commander in Chief of the German Army.
MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 23 -- Newspapers today carried an announcement by Francis B. Sayre, United States High Commissioner, concerning preparations to protect financial interests.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- Count Leo Tolstoy's "War and Peace" will be filmed next Summer by Alexander Korda with Merle Oberon in the role of Natasha Pavlovna, the United Artists producer announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- The strangest player draft that the National Football League ever has conducted was completed early today after an unprecedented all-night session. The club owners and coaches sorted the current college seniors until 3 A. M., and all are wondering how many of their selections they will sign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Now more than ever, and for Americans above all others, the "spirit of Christmas, which is love for our fellow-men" should be kept alive and held high as a shining light in a world at war, Mrs. Roosevelt, wife of the President, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management, today termed the strike of independent welders in West Coast shipyards a "shocking act of disloyalty to the nation."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Patiently all day long a large group of reporters waited at the President's executive offices today, and, whether or not as patiently, their editors in distant cities waited, too. Every one knew that a most important announcement was to be made at the White House, but they were in no doubt what it was to be.

FRANCONIA NOTCH, N. H., Dec. 22 -- Wendy (Chummy) Broomhall of the Rumford (Me.) Chisholm Ski and Outing Club won the first major cross-country ski race of the season today, leading a field of thirty-nine as the annual two-day meet on Cannon Mountain was completed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Congress began today a fortnight of informal holiday idleness, but members already were worrying about war problems -- taxes, price fixing, non-defense economies and how to deal with labor disputes -- which will confront them at the new session beginning Monday, Jan. 5.
BERLIN, Dec. 22 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German radio broadcast the following dispatch today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- An allocation order applying to the entire burlap supply was issued today by OPM. Under terms of the order the use of burlap in the production of furniture, upholstery, rugs, carpets, textiles generally, meat-packing and rubber industries is forbidden once current inventories of broken bales are used up.

War news from the Philippines hung heavy over the stock market yesterday, and prices slipped back again but only after a rally had been attempted. New lows since the start of the world conflict were established and trading expanded to the largest in almost two weeks with tax selling again the force behind the heavy business.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- After four hours of stormy debate the Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted, 36 to 3, to night to buy the Rye Lake site in the exclusive estate area of Purchase for development as a national defense airport.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorials of the last few days, and particularly in Mrs. McCormick's column today, you seem to take the point of view that Russia owes it to us to open a second front against Japan, that she is morally culpable in not doing so immediately.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 22 -- Today's noon communique revealed little change in the land positions of British and Japanese forces in Northern Malaya. There was continued fighting in the Grik Road area, where the Japanese were said to be using rafts on the Perak River to bring up reinforcements and the British were said to have inflicted heavy casualties on the enemy.

Manhattan's twice-beaten basketball team turned back a favored Niagara quintet 45 -- 43, in a nip-and-tuck battle last night. A capacity crowd of more than 1,100 taking part in alumni homecoming night saw the Riverdale five score its first major victory.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 23 -- After an announcement that tank combat and heavy land fighting were in progress in the Lingayen Gulf area -- issued at the headquarters of the United States Armed Forces in the Far East at 5 P. M. yesterday -- no news emanated from the combat area for more than fourteen hours.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Suggestions that Adolf Hitler was planning to lunge out soon in new or currently inactive theatres, perhaps in the Near East or in the West, now that he has taken personal command of the German armed forces, were strong today in official Berlin broadcasts.

LONDON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A source which often has had remarkably accurate behind-the-scenes information, said today that Reichsfuehrer Hitler's assumption of full command of the Germany Army and new Axis movements indicated that the Germans were preparing for a swift attack to close the Mediterranean.

The holiday spirit ran high at Arnold Constable's yesterday afternoon. The Fifth Avenue end of the third floor was packed with college girls. The party was theirs. An at-home was held in their honor from 3:30 to 5:30 o'clock. A thousand girls were invited.

The automotive industry shattered all recent records for third-quarter earnings this year as a result of the steadily increasing proportion, of national defense production by the companies in the field. Eleven makers of passenger cars and trucks earned $59,871,700 in the 1941 period, a gain of 278.9 per cent over $15,804,427 earned in the third quarter last year.

OTTAWA, Dec. 22 -- Shortly after the news of the arrival of Prime Minister Churchill in Washington was released the Prime Minister's office here announced that W. L. Mackenzie King had been invited to attend the Washington conference and would leave Ottawa probably tomorrow.

Unconditional surrender of the Axis powers must be the first war aim of the United States, Dr. fames Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University and chairman of the National Defense Reserch Committee, declared last night at the annual dinner of the New England Society of New York at the Hotel Plaza.

HONOLULU, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Lieut Gen. Delos C. Emmons, in his first broadcast as commander of the Hawaiian Department, today praised Hawaii's morale, stressed the necessity of censorship because of the potential threat of enemy raiders and urged everybody to work together.

The Japanese attack on the United States, unexpected in Hawaii, did not take Singapore and Burma by surprise, H. H. Craw, former counsellor to the Governor of Burma and one of the last evacuees from Singapore, declared yesterday.

Harvard's chess players yesterday regained possession of the Belden-Stephens Trophy, which they had held consecutively from 1935 to 1938, inclusive, by defeating Yale, custodian of the prize for the last two years in the final round of the H.Y.P.D. College League tournament at the Marshall Chess Club.

Miss Caroline Haslett, adviser to the British Ministry of Labor on the employment of women in war industries, who is leaving soon for England, yesterday received a check for $50,000 to be applied for war relief in her home country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Nine hundred and eighty-one out of each thousand depositors in insured banks have accounts of less than 55,000, and thus are fully covered by the 55,000 individual deposit insurance limit of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, according to a survey made public today by that organization.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Steve Owen is the unlucky one. Most of the other Giants can console themselves with the happy thought that they have seen the last of the Chicago Bears for a long time to come. But Stout Steve, a robust citizen who never flinches, still has to coach a team which has yet to meet the Monsters of the Midway.

Christmas dinner, according to the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, will be somewhat more costly this season. The bureau estimates that a dinner that could be assembled for $8.50 a year ago will now take about $10 out ot the family purse.

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 22 -- The Legislature, both branches of which are under Republican control, turned over today to Governor Charles Edison full authority to direct the State's military and civilian defense effort, provided for the addition of 100 troopers to the State police, heeded the Executive's plea for economy in expenditures not related to war emergency and then recessed until Jan. 13, the day the 1942 Legislature will organize.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, through an assignee, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday against three of Its own subsidiaries in Nazi-occupied countries of Europe to obtain payment of $800,000 in dividends that the companies have declared but have refused to pay to the parent company on its controlling stock.

The traditional New Year's Eve festivities in Times Square will not be banned this year, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday in response to a question. He thus ended speculation that the annual gathering of hundreds of thousands of persons in the heart of the city might not be permitted because of the danger of an air raid.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A bill to increase the authorized enlisted personnel of the Navy from 300,000 to 500,000 and of the Marine Corps from 60,000 to 104,000 was unanimously passed by the Senate today within a few minutes after the Naval Affairs Committee had completed a hearing on it and reported it.

The food coordinating committee of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, representing 10,000 grocery stores throughout the city, moved yesterday to stop consumers from hoarding foodstuffs as a new public buying rush to stock up certain canned goods was reported.

As part of a defense mobilization campaign, 300 meetings were held throughout the country last night by Junior Hadassah to register its 20,000 members for specific tasks in connection with the national war effort. One thousand young women members of the local unit at Temple Emanu-El presented a check to Mrs. Hortense M. Odium for the purchase of $10,000 in defense bonds.

The assets of a liberal education were taken for a merry ride last night in the musical production of the Yale University Dramatic Society, "Waterbury Tales," at the Waldorf-Astoria. In the grand ballroom twenty-eight undergraduates from New Haven momentarily forgot midyear examinations and intellectual footnotes as they interpreted the classics with music and spirit that might have shaken the dignity of Elihu Yale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Extension of the government's war insurance to property owners in Alaska, Hawaii, the Philippines Islands, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands was announced today by Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator. When the plan has been worked out, the statement said, premiums probably will be charged on insurance covering losses over some stated amount.

More extensive use of corn in production of ethyl alcohol is expected to result from the sharp boost in the ceiling for this commodity announced over the weekend by the Office of Price Administration, and it is believed that a number of whisky distilleries will be put to work on ethyl alcohol as an aid to defense, according to trade reports yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Mayor La Guardia of New York disclosed here tonight that he was attempting to obtain Federal compensation for air-raid wardens hurt in the performance of their duties.

Gerald Falcone, captain of the Barringer High School team; John Marzulli of Seton Hall College and Robert Siff, New York University cub, won the chief honors yesterday in the all-day invitation fencing tournament of the Riverdale Country Day School for scholastic, prep and college freshman entries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- An employer has the right to express his views freely on labor policies or problems, so long as his statements are not linked with a design to coerce his employes, the Supreme Court held, 7 to 0, today in a ruling of major importance on the Wagner Act.

Smoky, a missing wire-haired terrier, is being sought by his owner and officers of the Greenwich Village Humane League. If he had been available yesterday morning he would have been guest of honor at a Christmas party and the recipient of a medal, a certificate of valor and an assortment of dog food.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 22 --Although Britain is making a successful offensive in Libya and although Libya is widely advertised as a tank campaign, General Sir Claude J. E. Auchinleck, Commander in Chief of the British Middle East forces, has more than once declared that without the predominance of the Royal Air Force, which approached that of the German Air Force in the Battle of Crete, the Western Desert drive would not have been possible.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 20:

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 23 -- A heavy force of Japanese sea-borne troops supported by airplanes landed yesterday at Santo Tomas on Lingayen Gulf, more than 100 miles northwest of this city, but General Douglas MacArthur's head-quarters announced that American defenders had the situation "well in hand."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 17: Increases of 594,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, $355,000,000 in holding's of United States Government bonds, and $571,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and decreases of $631,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $622,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

A decision to carry on the customary racing in Southern waters was voted last night at the annual meeting of the Western Long Island Sound Star Class Fleet, held in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Suspension of hunting licenses in 1942 and announcement of Governor Lehman's fifth-term candidacy were among "developments" today as legislative reporters in New York's Capitol temporarily took over the "making" of news.

The Seidenberg Little Symphony, founded and directed here last season by Daniel Seidenberg, grave its second Town Hall concert last night. Mr. Seidenberg, who is an uncommonly progressive and alert musician, put together a program that blended novelties with delightful, old works and that made for an absorbing evening.

Reminding publishers and others in the book trade that books can become, as they have in England, "a fighting front," Frederic G. Melcher, editor of Publishers Weekly, yesterday called upon the trade to accept new responsibilities in the emergency and to plan its activities mindful that national needs in resources and materials come first.

WILMINGTON, N. C., Dec. 22 -- To occupants of 435 automobile trailers lined up near a shipyard two miles from here home is a long distance away and Dec. 25 is a ten-hour working day, but it will be Christmas just the same.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 --"Cessation of payment on German bonds has generally extended and in recent months has affected payment of the Dawes and Young loans," it was stated today in the report of the Board of Visitors to the Foreign Bondholders' Protective Council published by the State Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which supplies the personnel of the visiting board.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Following is the list of senior college football players chosen by teams of the National Football League in the annual draft (players named in the order of selection by each club; teams named in reverse order of finish in championship race):

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 22 -- "So far, so good," just about covers the situation as Fordham's special rolled through Georgia today bound for New Orleans and some of football's heaviest "sugar," upward of $70,000.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22 -- The Navy revealed today that it was recruiting shipyard workers for duty at "Pacific naval bases" and had signed up twenty-five welders at the union hall after yesterday's strike meeting there.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 -- Hirsch Jacobs, who once again is on his way to topping all American trainers in winners saddled over a season, accounted for his initial triumph of the Tropical Park meeting and his 121st of the year when his wife's horse.

Two thousand of New York City's physicians and surgeons attended two meetings at the New York Academy of Medicine yesterday afternoon and evening to obtain instructions on the roles they are to play in emergencies.

CALLANDER. Ont., Dec. 22 (Canadian Press) -- It will be all right with the Dionne Quintuplets if Santa Claus brings along a doll's carriage, a set of dishes, a dog, a wooden horse and a set of water colors this Christmas.
HAVE you ever heard of the scandalous case of the late Colonel Redl, sometime Chief of Staff of the Prague Military District in the Royal and Imperial Austro-Hungarian Army?

A plan that would permit use of the new Benjamin Franklin High School. 116th Street and East River Drive, by community organizations after school hours will be offered for approval by the Board of Education at its meeting today. The proposal was regarded as a movement to promote neighborhood morale.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 22 (U.P.) -- The general executive board of the Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes, A. F. L., tonight ordered an immediate general strike of 1,200 employes of the Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., throughout the entire company system from Boston to Chicago.

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 23 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill went to Washington at his own suggestion, it was said today. Obviously one of his reasons was to coordinate the war effort of the United States and Britain.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 -- Enemy submarines, presumably Japanese, prowling in coastwise shipping lanes, made a new but unsuccessful attack today on an American tanker. United States Navy patrol planes, responding quickly to the tanker's alarm, dropped depth charges with undisclosed results.

One More Hint There must be a considerable number of laggards among the holiday shoppers For their benefit we might reprint a Christmas suggestion which has appeared in this column from time to time, though without visibly affecting the Yuletide habits of the American people.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Commander John E. Whelchel, U.S.N., was named head football coach at the United States Naval Academy today, succeeding Major Emery E. (Swede) Larson, U.S. Marine Corps.
The 1,700-ton destroyer Hambleton, the first combatant ship to join the Navy since the United States entered the war, was commissioned a 11 A.M. yesterday at the NewYork Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

VICHY, France, Dec. 22 -- Now that practically the whole world is in the war, all fronts interlock, at least strategically, and react one on the other; indeed, observers here held today that the defeat of any belligerent on one front might produce major repercussions on all the others -- European, African, Asiatic, Atlantic and Pacific.

These surveys are made by a system of highly selective samplings in each of the forty-eight States in proportion to voting populations; thereby, the American Institute of Public Opinion holds, is obtained a result which would not vary from that of a much larger canvass.

A labor shortage is in prospect if not imminent, the National Industrial Conference Board declared yesterday on the basis of a survey of the total labor force available in the country and of the number of unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Testimony that upward of 260,000 workers would be dislocated through the curtailmetn of automotive production was given today to the Tolan committee investigating migrant labor. William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, intimated that even a greater number might be affected because of the disruption of the rubber supply.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Winston Churchill, Prime Minister of Great Britain, arrived in Washington late today to confer with President Roosevelt on "all questions related to the war effort."

Gaiety will be added to the life of soldiers and sailors from coast to coast when the USO Camp Shows, Inc., launches fifteen more new shows Jan. 12 to travel over the "Star-Spangled Circuit." More than 1,000 actors will be signed to participate in the entertainment program covering 114 Army Camps and naval stations.

Transportation lines disclosed yesterday that they had mobilized all their available equipment to handle this year's Christmas holiday travel, which began last Saturday and is expected to continue through New Year's Day.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Dec. 23 -- Both the Russian midnight communique and the military spokesman this morning announced further progress by Russian forces on the Leningrad, Moscow and southern fronts during exceptionally heavy fighting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Canadian Press) -- President Roosevelt promised his complete cooperation today in combining the wartime production of Canada and the United States into one all-out effort by the two countries.

Though the German armies in Russia have not been destroyed, they have failed in their primary objective. This was to destroy the armed forces of the Soviets. They have also failed in their secondary objectives, which were to reach the southern oil fields and to take Moscow before the coming of cold weather.

MELBOURNE, Australia. Dec. 22 -- Despite assurances from London that the United Kingdom Government is taking energetic action to retrieve the Malayan situation, and though the government is expected to announce any day the appointment of an Australian of high standing to represent the Commonwealth in the War Council, Singapore newspapers continue to insist that there is no time to spare in making the appointment.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 22 -- While British mobile columns attacked German covering positions east of Bengazi and pursued other enemy forces retreating toward Agedabia from the Mekili area, a small British mechanized patrol bobbed up at an Axis airdrome 150 miles inside Tripolitania and carried out a brilliant surprise raid, during which it destroyed twenty-four German and Italian planes on the ground and demolished gasoline and bomb dumps.

Antilla Sugar Estates has notified holders of its twenty-year 6 per cent income debentures that copies of the plan of reorganization just promulgated are now available at the corporate trust department of the National City Bank.

Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw gave a dinner last night at her home, 60 East Sixty-sixth Street, for three debutantes of this season, the Misses Marie Hoguet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Hoguet; Lispenard Crocker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Savage Crocker, and Barbara Riggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Riggs. Later Mrs. Laidlaw took her guests to the performance of "The Magic Flute" at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that so great is the demand for the defense bonds of the smaller denominations that each night it ships out to issuing agents in this district all of the bonds it receives during the day from the Treasury.

With Filipinos, Greeks and Chinese the first to organize here for Red Cross aid, 1,000,000 persons linked to twelve different nations by birth or cultural heritage, will be solicited by the foreign language division of the Greater New York Red Cross War Fund, Red Cross officials announced yesterday.

As a more stringent curtailment of certain types of consumer goods looms some manufacturers have decided to bring out new products, which previously they had planned to hold "on the shelf" until the war was over. This is particularly true in the case of makers of consumers' durable goods.

Mr. and Mrs. LeRoy Kent Howe of 1120 Fifth Avenue and Mr. and Mrs. John Clark Pickering of the Hotel Westbury and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., jointly gave a dinner dance last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis for Miss Nancy Sawyer Howe, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howe, and Miss Anne Joers, debutante daughter of Mrs. Pickering.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 22 -- Mrs. Sarah J. Atwood of 156 East Fifty-second Street, New York, veteran employment agent credited with having put 1,000,000 laborers to work on big construction jobs throughout the United States and its possessions, died yesterday in Nassau Hospital here of injuries received in an automobile accident on Saturday at Roslyn, L. J.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed New Year's Day as a day of prayer, a day "of asking forgiveness for our shortcomings of the past, of consecration to the tasks of the present, of asking God's help in days to come."

Because he had furnished the "leads" that brought the successful prosecutions by District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn's murder ring, William Jacknis, 31 years old, an ex-convict, was freed yesterday in General Sessions on a suspended sentence of twenty-five years to life imprisonment.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- William Patrick Colling, a 42-year-old navy yard worker, was arrested today by Federal agents on charges of sabotage, including the cutting of a power cable by means of which, a United States Attorney said, he hoped to "blow up" a shop in which naval construction was taking place.

Clutching a copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES in which the story of 5-year-old Tommy's dread of insecurity was told, a very young Army sergeant walked into the office of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street, yesterday afternoon.
HARLINGEN, Texas, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Henry Picard of Oklahoma City won the $5,000 Rio Grande Valley open golf tournament today with a total of 266 for seventy-two holes. He was eighteen under par.

Twelve thousand commuters from points in Nassau County who use the Bee Bus Line buses to Jamaica were stranded yesterday morning by a strike on the Bee line called by the Transport Workers Union of the C. I. O., which went into effect without warning at 4 A.M.

Dwight Deere Wiman's contribution to the holiday collection of openings is "Letters to Lucerne" arriving tonight at the Cort. The Fritz Rotter-Allien Vincent play marks Mr. Wiman's first offering of the season. It concerns itself with the effect of this war on six girl students at a fashionable Swiss school.
