MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- Though the Germans are offering stiff resistance in most sectors and there is no attempt here to underestimate their capacity to fight, even though in rear guard action, the Russians are reported today to be making excellent progress wherever they are pushing hard.

Recent actions of Maryland courts in upholding the right of publishers to sell their books under contracts calling for minimum resale prices constituted an important victory for those interested in the enforcement of fair-trade laws, according to Harry Meixell, executive vice resident of the American Fair Trade Council, in a bulletin issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Newton Paper Company of Holyoke, a paper manufacturer, a die cutters' trade association and its executive secretary, seven operators of stay die cutting businesses and three New York distributors of "bogus" paper have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to cease "understandings, combinations or conspiracies" to restrain competition in the sale and distribution of the product, it was announced today.
UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS in the Far East, Philippines, Dec. 22 -- The battle of Lingayen Gulf may tell the story of the United States' future in the Pacific.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- The military organ Red Star reveals that the Soviet Army has trained special night-fighting troops to storm German positions under the cover of Winter darkness. It has been evident in the last few weeks that the Russians favor night operations.
Boston, Mass., will be in the market on Friday with $4,000,000 of tax-anticipation notes dated Dec. 30, 1941, and to be payable on Oct. 15, 1942.

Mayor La Guardia warned yesterday that maximum penalties would be invoked against fifth columnists who started panics, as he signed the city's first piece of wartime legislation fixing the punishment for air raid precaution violators at a fine of $500, six months' imprisonment, or both.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Organization, rather than reorganization, of the nation's civilian defense effort is what this country needs, according to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 22 -- The Fordham basketball team registered an impressive 68-35 victory over Rutgers tonight. The triumph was the fourth in five starts for the Rams.

Aided by the spurt in last-minute buying, Christmas trade here has a good chance of going about 5 per cent ahead of last year, local merchants said yesterday. Volume yesterday was heavy in many of the gift departments and sales during the two remaining shopping days are expected to push business ahead of 1940 by a substantial margin.

Under a program approved last night by Dr. James E. West, chief Scout executive of the Boy Scouts of America, Boy Scouts of the United States will have an option of preliminary training in aviation, similar to a program worked out since the start of the war in Great Britain and Canada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- With the Draft Extension Bill signed by the President, Selective Service oficials began making plans for registering the nation's 23,500,000 men between the ages of 18 and 64, inclusive, who have not been registered.

Having experienced the odd sensation of victory after ten straight setbacks, Red Dutton and his Americans are confident that they will quit the National Hockey League basement tonight in Madison Square Garden, where the Brooklyn band will clash with the Black Hawks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Edward Corsi, formerly Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization at Ellis Island, will head an Alien Enemy Hearing Board to sit in New York City, Attorney General Francis Biddle announced today. Other members will be two attorneys, James A. Fowler Jr. and Robert M. Benjamin, both of New York City.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Fairly heavy arrivials of salable hogs depressed prices 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds In a moderately active market today. Light pork loins were down another cent at 17 1/2 to 18 cents a pound.

ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- The New York State Guard, which replaced the National Guard when that unit was called into Federal service, is ready for any emergency duty, according to Governor Lehman. In a radio address this evening he gave an insight into the organization of the guard, declaring that while the unit primarily is for emergency assignments and soon may be called into active duty to protect "some of our most sensitive spots."

The Eighty-sixth Street Casino Theatre, one of the leading houses for the showing of German-made films in this city, which has been closed since the German declaration of war against the United States, will reopen Christmas Day with a revival of the Soviet picture, "General Suvorov," the management announced yesterday.

The Rev. William H. Pott, rector emeritus of St. John's Episcopal Church of Rosebank, S. I., died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 326 Westervelt Avenue, New Brighton, after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Still lacking a solution to problems harassing some railroads under New Jersey's new railroad tax laws, the Legislature granted a further extension of time today for payment of 1941 railroad franchise taxes.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- Connie Mack, baseball's most beloved character, will be 79 years young tomorrow. As spry and enthusiastic as ever, he figures he has accumulated the "makings" of a great pitching staff for his Athletics as a birthday present for himself.

The public sale of tickets for the Joe Louis-Buddy Baer world heavy-weight championship, to be held Jan. 9 in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society, got under way yesterday.

New York University announced yesterday that beginning next semester, in February, it would place four of its major undergraduate divisions on a three-year basis. This wartime move will affect 20,000 undergraduates now enrolled.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Scattered commission house buying of wheat, largely on resting orders proved sufficient today to prevent any demonstration on the bear side of the market by professional traders, and prices held within narrow limits.

It is gratifying: to learn that an agreement has been reached by the employer and union representatives at the President's conference that there shall be no strikes or lockouts during the war, that all disputes shall be settled by peaceful means, and that the President shall set up a proper War Labor Board to handle disputes.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 23 -- Three big Japanese transports and a tanker have been sunk west of Borneo by a Netherlands submarine, the Commander of the Netherlands Navy was informed tonight.

FAYETTEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Police Captain L.F. Worrell said tonight that Silvio Coucci of New York, widely known as a jockey, jumped or fell to his death, from the roof of a hotel here yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- War Department Communique No. 24, outlining the military situation as of 9:30 A.M., follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Office of Production Management took control today of essential civilian as well as wartime production of industry. In an amendment to priorities regulation No. 1, OPM directed that all orders bearing a priority rating, including those with the B ratings accorded to essential civilian products, must be accepted by producers in preference to any unrated order.

MANILA, Dec. 23 (AP) -- "The Filipinos are plenty mad, and morale is excellent among troops and civilians," Melville Jacoby, correspondent for Time and Life magazines, declared today when he brought back an eye-witness story from the Lingayen invasion front.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 23 -- It is reported there have been mass resignations of conservative German military leaders, who are said to be looking askance on the "intuition" of Adolf Hitler as a basis for military operations.

OTTAWA, Dec. 23 -- Brigadier J.K. Lawson, commander of the Canadian contingent in Hong Kong, is believed to have been killed, and his senior staff officer, Colonel Patrick Hennessey, was killed by shellfire yesterday during fierce fighting on the island, it was announced by the Defense Department today.

Two properties in Brooklyn have been acquired by the Salvation Army through the Charles F. Noyes Company, brokers, to replace those condemned to make way for the Brooklyn Navy Yard housing development, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Office of Price Administration today revised the ceiling prices for cotton fine goods tied to the market price of raw spot cotton.

With Bob Tough and Johnny Geilen setting the pace, St. John's University beat a fighting Niagara University quintet, 49 to 46, in a Golden Ball game for the Naismith Memorial Fund in the DeGray gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night. It was the fifth triumph in six starts this season for the Redmen and Niagara's third setback in seven contests.

To relieve the uncertainty of volunteers as to which defense organization they should offer their services, Mrs. Kathleen Small of the division of volunteer participation of the New York State Defense Counsel urged yesterday that they register only with Civilian Defense Volunteer Bureaus.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 23 -- Dartmouth evened its ice hockey series with Illinois tonight by defeating the Illini, 5 to 4, in overtime.

By action of the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday, the new $3,500,000 Benjamin Franklin High School, at 116th Street and East River Drive, will be operated on a twenty-four-hour basis and be used after school hours by community organizations. Custodial fees will no longer be charged to groups that meet in the late afternoon or evening.

Miss Sally D. Mather, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Malcolm Mather of 1172 Park Avenue, made her debut last night at a dinner dance given, by her parents in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis. Mrs. Mather and her daughter received the guests in the Louis XVI Suite.

MANILA, Dec. 23 -- Here is the remainder of the story of the heroic action of Captain Colin P. Kelly Jr., who has already received a posthumous award of the Distinguished Service Cross for gallantry in action beyond the line of duty.

Dr. Harry woodburn Chase, chancelor of New York University, announced yesterday that Lucius N. Littauer had donated a Christmas gift of nearly a quarter million dollars in stocks and securities for the establishment of a medical research fund at the College of Medicine.
CAIRO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Japanese forces that have been battering a small Navy garrison on Wake Island since Dec. 7 effected a landing there on "the morning of the twenty-third," the Navy Department reported today, but it appeared that the garrison still was fighting back at its attackers tonight.

WAILUKU, Maui, Hawaii, Dec. 22 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Thirty survivors of the Matson freighter Lahaina, shelled and sunk by a Japanese submarine, were reported weak but otherwise in good condition today after drifting, rowing and sailing for ten days through heavy winds and waves.

Three officials of the Office of Price Administration agreed yesterday to meet with a committee of steel exporters to consider revision of OPA Order No. 49 which sets export ceilings on steel, after some 350 exporters had joined in a vociferous protest against the order.

Election of three new vice presidents of the New York Trust Company and promotion of nine other officers was announced yesterday by John E. Bierworth, president. Manice deF. Lockwood Jr., secretary since 1930, was named a vice president, as was Herbert J. Stroh, with the bank since 1919.

Christmas celebrations reached full swing throughout the metropolitan area yesterday as New York City, in accordance with its tradition, generously made provision for the less fortunate and entered wholeheartedly into the entertainment of thousands of soldiers, sailors and marines returning home or arriving here as visitors on Christmas furloughs.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23 -- There was a distinct Saratoga Springs atmosphere to the racing at Tropical Park today. The Saratoga Stable, owned by George H. Bull, president of the Saratoga and Empire City tracks, and John A. Morris, secretary-treasurer at the spa, was represented in two races and both bearers of the scarlet and black silks were triumphant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Prime Minister of Great Britain sat in the White House today, side by side with the President of the United States, just one hundred and twenty-seven years-lacking a day -- after the signing of the Treaty of Ghent.

Under the impact of sharply higher taxes and increased operating costs, the New York Telephone Company reduced yesterday its dividend for the last quarter of this year from $2 a share to $1.50, breaking a dividend record of thirty-two years.

government spokesmen today declared the shipyard welders' strike "a total flop," Karl V. Morris, national president of the United Welders, Cutters and Helpers, appealed to President Roosevel to instruct the Navy to take over immediate operation of all West Coast shipyards.

Christmas will be observed today, tonight and tomorrow morning with services in cathedrals, churches of many faiths and missions throughout the city. Everywhere prayers will be offered for a victory for the Allied nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Roosevelt promulgated today a three-point formula designed to guarantee uninterrupted production during the war by providing final arbitration of all disputes between employers and employes. He turned down industry's demand that the closed shop be ruled out as an arbitrable question.

Frankie Kovacs, who will make his professional tennis debut on Friday night in Madison Square Garden, began tuning up his game on the Heights Casino court in Brooklyn yesterday. Kovacs appeared to be in good condition and was confident that he would give a worthy account of himself in the pro ranks.

A supply of food sufficient to feed the 12,000,000 persons in the New York metropolitan area for one month to six and a half weeks is on hand, William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of City Markets, reported yesterday. Mr. Morgan's estimates were based on a survey made by his department as of Dec. 1.

A gay Christmas party for 1,100 newly enlisted sailors, who assembled around a huge tree in the Navy Armory at Fifty-second Street and First Avenue, Brooklyn, was given yesterday by Bundles for Bluejackets, auxiliary of Bundles for Britain, the American war relief agency now providing comforts and necessities to the men of the United States Navy and merchant marine.

The persistence of tax selling and the further dislocation of domestic industry argued against anything better than a steady tone yesterday for the stock market. Although Wall Street had expected to see the turn of the week bring a cessation of sales to establish losses for income returns, the first two sessions certainly did not fulfill this hope.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Operations in the Leningrad sector continue to be highly favorable for the Russians. The main action there, according to reports released here today, is occurring against German forces that had tried to form a second line of blockade, reinforcing the pressure of the forces beleaguering the city.

A warm, intimate portrayal of a housewife's reaction to bombs and blackouts at Honolulu emerges from letters written by Mrs. Helena Mowat, wife of John Mowat, accountant for Castle Hill, Matson agents, to her sister, Mrs. Arthur Lewis of 601 West 110th Street.

Three infantrymen from Camp Devens, Mass., who were due back from a three-day leave at reveille Tuesday, won a battle yesterday at 5 A.M. on the East Side subway station at Prospect Avenue and East 163d Street, the Bronx, with three Negroes, two armed with six-inch hunting' knives, who are accused of attacking the visitors after calling them "tin soldiers."

UNITED STATES BOMBER COMMAND, Philippines, Dec. 23 -- In the area of the newest Japanese activity in the Philippines today I experienced a bombing attack by high-flying Japanese planes against the "Flying Truck Drivers" -- Uncle Sam's Far East bomber squadrons.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 23 -- The Berlin correspondent of the newspaper Social Demokraten indicates today that further dismissals of German generals, particularly General Franz Halder, the head of the Army's General Staff, are impending.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 24 -- Official Army reports today said that greatly outnumbered American and Filipino troops were battling valiantly against a Japanese invasion force that landed from forty transports at Atimonan, 135 miles by air southeast of Manila, during the night.

The Union Securities Corporation, Lee Higginson Corporation and A.C. Allyn Co., Inc., offered 75,000 shares of General Motors Corporation common stock at 29 5/3 until 10 A.M. today and thereafter, if available, at 29 5/3 and an amount equal to the New York Stock Exchange commission.

NEAR THE LINGAYEN FRONT, Dec. 23 -- American planes and tanks are blasting at the Japanese invaders only a quarter of a mile from the spot from which I am telephoning this first dispatch from the Philippine fighting front to Manila.

LONDON. Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- The British Embassy in Chungking, China, reported tonight that the defenders of Hong Kong, "still fighting valiantly," had destroyed two Japanese vessels taking part in the land, sea and air siege of the crown colony.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- Emphasizing the seriousness of the shortage of rubber for domestic purposes Governor Lehman directed the chairmen of the local defense councils in the State today to organize local rationing boards to supervise the rationing of all motor vehicle tires after Jan. 5.

It had been several months since we dropped by to see Uncle Dan, the old gunsmith, and when we finally walked in his jumbled shop the other day it was to find him getting ready for the annual Christmas "swapping."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Sitting at President Roosevelt's right in an extraordinary dual press conference at the White House today, Prime Minister Churchill declared that anti-Axis war plans must be based upon defeating Germany by military knockout blows from outside.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Mortimer Ward and Mr. and Mrs. Abel I. Smith gave a. small reception yesterday afternoon at the clubhouse of the National Society of Colonial Dames, 215 East Seventy-first Street, to introduce to society Miss Mary Paige Cartmell, daughter of Mrs. Smith and granddaughter of Mrs. Ward.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Reports originating "somewhere in Europe" and received here tonight said that Marshal Henri Philippe Petain had resigned as the French Chief of State, as a protest against German pressure, and that he had been succeeded by Admiral Francois Darlan, the Vice Premier.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Norma Shearer and Robert Taylor will be co-starred in Metro's remake of "Her Cardboard Lover," which will be filmed under the title "Love Me Not," starting the middle of next month, the studio announced today.

The firm of Morrow, making known its January and February plans, lists a dozen books. The schedule includes a new novel by Nevil Shute, "Pied Piper," coming' out on Jan. 5; a new Erle Stanley Gardner mystery novel, a novel called "Attack in the Desert," by Michael Home; several Westerns, and a novel by Roderick L. Haig-Brown about the Pacific North-west loggers.

Familiar Westchester Faces It is a pleasure every little while to come across the long list of Westchester cities and towns with the corresponding figures for population or tax assessments, though we understand that Westchester taxpayers themselves do not find these tables an unmitigated joy.

Regardless of the fact that he battered Buddy Baer into submission in their previous meeting last Spring in Washington, Joe Louis is engaged on a campaign of all-out preparedness for his return bout against the Californian, Jan. 9 in Madison Square Garden.

Fulton Fish Market had on Monday its biggest day in twenty-five years, with 2,000,000 pounds of salt and fresh water fish, clams, lobsters and other forms of sea food being received, it was reported yesterday by the Fish and Wild Life Service, a Federal Government agency.

Depositors in the closed Banco di Napoli Trust Company who are United States citizens, or who are licensed aliens, will be able to receive their deposits, beginning today, through three branch offices of the Manufacturers Trust Company, it was announced yesterday in a joint statement issued by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the New York State Banking Department, and the Manufacturers Trust Company.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Dec. 24 -- German lines before the Moscow front collapsed at several points during yesterday's fighting to give the Soviet forces one of their most fruitful days of gain since they retook Klin, according to the Russian military spokesman this morning.

Commenting upon his trip to London to establish a unit of Colonel William J. Donovan's Office of the Coordinator of Official Information, to tap the domestic broadcasts within the Axis countries, Lloyd A. Free, director of the foreign broadcast monitoring service of the Federal Communications Commission, declared yesterday afternoon that his mission was "quite successful."

SINGAPORE, Dec. 23 (UP) -- British and Japanese airplanes traded heavy blows over the Malaya area today and there were signs that the British were building up for a big offensive, throwing everything that could be spared from Netherlands, American and British Imperial striking forces in the Western Pacific area.

How funds raised through the annual appeal for the Needles Cases play a vital part in the work of the eight participating private charitable organizations among the. distressed and the sick of the city is told in a letter from one of the organizations.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. "Tarzan's Secret Treasure," the latest in the Metro film series built around the Edgar Rice Burroughs character, will be the newcomer at the Capitol. Johnny Weissmuller again portrays the title role and Maureen O'Sullivan, Johnny Sheffield, Reginald Owen, Barry Fitzgerald and Philip Dorn are among the picture's featured cast.

Those great Chicago Bears won the world football title by walloping the New York Giants in Chicago last Sunday, but George Halas's champions are going to be faced with the proposition of at least partially demonstrating that superiority again a week from next Sunday.

A number of fibers native to South America have already been found to be suitable substitutes for burlap and the OPM order issued early this week restricting use of burlap here is likely to stimulate commercial production of these fibers, according to A.L. Brassell, vice president of the United States Testing Company.

Arriving at Henry Miller's Thetre the week of Jan. 19 is "All in Favor," the initial offering of the new producing firm of Robert Montgomery, Elliott Nugent and Jesse Duncan. The Lou Hoffman-Don Hartman comedy revolving around "the more or less frenzied activities of a boys' club in Washington Heights" will receive preliminary performances in Wilmington on Jan. 9 and 10 and in Baltimore the week of Jan. 12.
To Brooklyn fans it was the tragedy of a lifetime, but to the nation at large Mickey Owen's muff of a third strike in the fourth game of the world series was just the sports freak of the year.

A call to American Legion posts throughout the country to respond to the appeal of the American Red Cross for $50,000,000 was followed here yesterday by an announcement of plans to enlist in the drive the support of New York's 42,000 Legionnaires.

LONDON, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- American, British and Netherland leaders have conferred at Singapore at the suggestion of President Roosevelt and have agreed on important strategic recommendations, it was learned today.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek shook up his government today, making T.V. Soong, former Finance Minister and his brother-in-law, the new Foreign Minister, and it was announced that China ever would conclude a separate peace with Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Official dispatches from the Philippines today reported that strong resistance was being waged against the Japanese invaders, but also noted that the enemy had landed light tanks to support the advance of forces south of Agoo on the shores of Lingayen Gulf.

The Celotex Corporation had consolidated net earnings of $1,749,099 after provision for Federal income taxes and all charges, according to the annual report for the year ended on Oct. 31, issued by Bror Dahlberg, president, for publication today.

Buying a last minute present is, like death and taxes, inevitable. For part and parcel of the day before Christmas is the business of snatching a few minutes in a crowded store selecting a tie for an almost forgotten great-uncle or a scarf for a nearly neglected maiden aunt.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- News of the arrival of Prime Minister Churchill in United States coupled with the Christmas cheer permeated all sections of the stock market today with bright sentiment. Gild-edge issues improved with the old consols rising 5-16 and local loans up 1/4 point.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 23 -- Yale's quintet opened its holiday invasion of the Middle West before 4,000 spectators in the University of Toledo field house tonight, but could not quite cope with the highscoring Rockets. Toledo won 52 to 40.

AFTER years of futile talk and agitation for an open tennis championship, a young man who had taken no part in the conversation up to this time stepped into the picture and signed up the makings of his own open tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The War Department, through Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary, opposed today a proposal that an all-civilian board be set up to take over war production and war procurement.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest your editorial of Dec. 18 entitled "False Alignments," and am in full accord with your statement that it is tragic irony, if not worse, to view seriously the declaration of war against the United States by Albania, that unfortunate nation which has every reason to be profoundly grateful to America.
The Harvard and Tale squash racquets captains will meet in the final of the University Club's inter-collegiate invitation tournament today.
On Oct. 3, 1941, Adolf Hitler, speaking in Berlin to "German men and women" on the progress of the Russian campaign, declared that the Red Army "is already broken and will never rise again."

Beck Shoe Corporation More than 1,100 members of the 112 stores and offices of the A.S. Beck Shoe Company today will receive a bonus, M.L. Friedman, president, announced. This is the fifteenth consecutive year that the company has given an employe bonus in addition to other welfare and health benefits.

Adding its protest to the growing volume of objections by foreign trade groups which feel they are being discriminated against by the present methods of handling lease-lend orders, the Export Managers Club in a letter sent yesterday to Lease-Lend Administrator E. R. Stettinius Jr., and other government officials, urged return of such business to established private trade channels.

ALBANY, Dec. 23 -- By a vote of 5 to 2 the Court of Appeals upheld today the city referendum that abolished the offices of county Sheriffs and Registers and replaced them with a city-wide Sheriff and a city-wide Register. The prevailing opinion, written by Judge Finch, held that the county officers who were elected the same day the referendum was passed did not have any "vested rights" to the offices.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Colonel Robert T. Phinney, post commander of Fort Custer and a veteran Army officer, was fatally injured today when his automobile struck a car driven by an Army private from Fort Sam Houston, Texas.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 23 -- A two-hour Cabinet meeting this evening to consider Argentina's attitude at the Rio de Janeiro conference broke up without reaching any decision. The discussion will be resumed Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- All sections of the livestock market scored substantial advances today as buyers ignored pre-holiday weakness in dressed quotations and bid actively in anticipation of a stronger demand for pork, lamb and beef after Christmas.

Mrs. Rose Cohen, 42 years old, 105 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, who had pleaded guilty to four fraud indictments, promised Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions yesterday that, if she were released in bail, she would make restitution with $100,000 she said she had cached in other cities.
BERLIN, Dec. 23 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:
A LAST-MINUTE list of a dozen miscellaneous and more or less specialized titles, none of which has been mentioned here before and any of which might suggest itself for that last-minute gift problem.

The Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor track and field championships will be held at the Coliseum in the Bronx on Jan. 24, it was announced yesterday by Chairman Pinky Sober. This will be the second successive year for the Coliseum to house the title track show.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Sumner Welles, Undersecretary of State, was designated by President Roosevelt today to represent the United States at the third meeting of American Foreign Ministers in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on January 15.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., today turned over to the Army ninety-five buses tied up at Cleveland and New York by a strike of A. F. of L. motor coach employes.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Horse racing, which helped make gay old New Orleans the sporting town it was, will return to the Fair Grounds Christmas Day after a year's layoff caused by an argument over betting laws.

A steady absorption of contracts by trade sources lifted the cotton market yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and final prices for active futures were 3 to 6 points above Monday's close. Trading continued quiet and the volume of business was small.
NEW YORK Colonel and Mrs. Le Ray Berdeau left their apartment at Hampshire House yesterday to spend the Winter at Villa Today, their place in Palm Beach, Fla.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The British Headquarters communique said today:
Responding to a desire to do good at Christmas time that was urgent as the needs of the unfortunates for whom they sent funds, many contributors speeded gifts to the Neediest Cases yesterday.

Former King Carol of Rumania, in refuge at Mexico City, now considers his abdication as void and hopes to return to his throne with the consent of the Rumanian people in the event of a victory of the democracies over Hitler, it was reported yesterday by a royal representative here.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 23 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 22:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A final judgment against twenty major oil companies, fifty-two pipeline companies and seven subsidiaries or affiliates, limiting to 7 per cent the returns the oil concerns may receive from investments in pipelines, was approved by the United States District Court for the District of Columbia today with the consent of all concerned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A program for the expansion of the production of synthetic rubber, three times the size of the undertaking contemplated before the beginning of the hostilities with Japan, received the approval today of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The American-British War Council met at the White House tonight following a historic press conference at which President Roosevelt presented Prime Minister Winston Churchill and practically turned over the conference to him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- In recognition of the transpacific formation flight Sept. 5-12, which is ranked as one of the greatest in aviation history, seventy-five officers and enlisted men of the Army Air Force have been recommended to President Roosevelt for awards of the Distinguished Flying Cross.
Reasoning that you can't get too much of a good thing, two Santa Clauses appeared to greet 700 children yesterday at Madison Square Garden. The welcome had twice the customary fervor.

Lowell Mellett, director of the Office of Government Reports, has been appointed by President Roosevelt to act as Coordinator of Government Films for the duration of the war, it was announced yesterday by the War Activities Committee, Motion Picture Industry, 28 West Forty-fourth Street.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 23 -- The presence of hostile submarines off California led defense experts here today to suspect that they might be refueling at small harbors or along the almost uninhabited coasts of the Gulf of California or on the Pacific side of the Lower California Peninsula.

Mr. Churchill's uniform, his favorite dress since the war began, is that of the Elder Brethren of the Corporation of Trinity House, situate since 1795 in Trinity House, Tower Hill. It began as a society of sailors in Deptford -- the "p" is silent. Henry VIII gave it, already ancient, a charter, built at Deptford a royal dockyard and put it in charge of the society, which supplied pilots.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- About 425 names of individuals and companies, including 250 Japanese firms and persons in Latin-American republics, were added tonight to the blacklist, which prevents them from trading with the United States.

His round, apple-cheeked face and the shrewd twinkle in his eye suggest the most familiar visitor at this season. On the eve of Christmas he descended out of the cloudy skies above the White House chimney as softly as if borne by reindeer. But Winston Churchill does not come to Washington as Santa Claus.
Enlistments in the armed forces continued brisk yesterday, a feature of the day being the swearing in of a 17-year-old youth who was fourteen pounds overweight when he applied last week.

Market Holidays All markets throughout the world will be closed tomorrow and many will observe early closings today. The New York Cotton and Wool Top Exchanges will close at noon, but all other commodity markets in this city, as well as the New York Stock Exchange and the Curb Exchange, will operate until the regular closing time.
The city of Indianapolis will enter the market on Jan. 6 with an issue of $990,000 of temporary-loan notes. The obligations will become payable on May 15, 1942.

In "Letters to Lucerne," which was acted at the Cort last evening, Fritz Rotter and Allen Vincent have written a tender play about a harsh topic. They show what effect the war has on the friendships of six girls who live in an international school in Switzerland.

Loew's, Inc., completed yesterday arrangements for the sale of $13,000,000 principal amount of 3 per cent fifteen-year debentures to nine insurance companies and for the borrowing of $5,000,000 in the form of a 2 1/4 per cent five-year loan from the First National Bank of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- James L. Fly, Federal Communications Commissioner, said today that the government did not plan any general seizure of private telegraph, telephone or radio facilities under the pending bill to give President Roosevelt broad control over all communication lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Rear Admiral Russell Willson, superintendent of the Naval Academy at Annapolis since Feb. 1, was designated today Chief of Staff for Admiral Ernest K. King, new Commander in Chief of the United States Fleet.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops have landed in heavy force in the vicinity of Atimonan, about 135 miles southeast of Manila, it was announced officially today. Atimonan is on the main north-south network of highways leading to Manila, and is only ten miles from Malicboy, a town on the Manila railroad.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

Elmer Riddle, 24-year-old right-hander of the Reds, who last Summer was making his debut as a full-fledged starting hurler in the majors, carried off the lion's share of pitching honors in the National League for 1941, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

The New York State Public Service Commission took issue yesterday with the Long Island Lighting Company over a proposed refunding program by the utility and outlined restrictive conditions that must be met if the financing is to become effective.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 -- British mobile columns, slashing ahead of the main body of the British advance, reached the coastal plain of the Gulf of Sidra yesterday and, possibly, cut off at least part of the Germans who are retreating from Bengazi in the direction of Tripoli.

Efforts to place the city's 16,000 traffic lights under some form of central control for air raid emergencies have disrupted the system in some parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn, it was disclosed yesterday as Police Commissioner Valentine forbade air raid wardens to touch the lights in the future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- President Roosevelt today called a meeting of the "United States-Great Britain war council" at the White House this afternoon. The council held a two-hour session, but no official statement was issued.
The boys and girls shoved so many deuces through the mutuel windows this year that every racing State in the country reported a boom in betting for 1941.

Boris Karloff, the star of "Arsenic and Old Lace" and actor of horror parts in the movies, changed roles yesterday to play the part of Santa Claus to 200 underprivileged children between the ages of 5 and 12 in the Beekman Hospital, Beekman and Water Streets, in the lower East Side, where he distributed toys and candy to the children, assisted by former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 - Cuba grants concessions involving thirty-eight tariff items on products imported from this country and the United States makes concessions on sugar and a number of other important Cuban products under a supplementary trade agreement signed in Havana today by George S. Messersmith, the American Ambassador, and Dr Jose Manuel Cortina, Minister of State.

ALBANY, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, asserted today that the State's "actual true" surplus on June 30 was $4,735,464 instead of $7,029,256 as previously stated by Governor Lehman.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 23 (AP) -- If Ivan B. (Ivy) Williamson, former Michigan end and an assistant here for eight years, wants to be Yale's next head football coach, reliable sources disclosed today, all he has to do is say so.

HONG KONG, Dec. 23 (U.P.) -- British Empire troops, aided by civilians of the Colonial Civil Service, are fighting still today, in prepared positions and in Isolated strong points, against the attacking Japanese.
Mayor La Guardia dropped a gentle hint yesterday that he might surrender his duties as Mayor, but would not amplify the matter when the question was put to him directly.

The present situation in the Far East demonstrates beyond all doubt the imperative necessity of the unified command and the single, central, global strategy which Mr. Churchill and Mr. Roosevelt are attempting to create in their conferences in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Following is the text of the executive order by which President Roosevelt established today an Office of Defense Transportation:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 -- Lieut. Comdr. Odber Rutledge McLean, 50 years old, died of "an undetermined cause" at 1 P.M. today in the United States Naval Hospital here, nearly eighteen hours after he had been found dazed in a Camden (N.J.) street.

After considerable debate yesterday the City Council voted to receive the third and final section of a report on the Municipal Civil Service Commission by Emil K. Ellis, which holds Paul J. Kern unfit to continue as president of the commission.

Dr. George Heinsius, 60-year-old German refugee physician, plunged to his death at 5 o'clock yesterday morning from the roor of a sixteen-story apartment house at 250 West Ninety-fourth Street onto the roof of a second-story extension. The police, who said he first had slashed his wrists with a penknife, listed the death as a suicide.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- The volume of orders booked during November by Massachusetts mills and factories showed a decrease of 13 per cent as compared with October, it was announced today by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts. This decrease, it was explained, while only 1 per cent larger than the estimated seasonal amount, would have been greater had it not been for the appearance of "new, heavy demands for equipment."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Members of Prime Minister Churchill's official party were listed by the British Embassy today as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 -- Enemy underseas raiders sent the 8,272-ton American tanker Montebello to the bottom of the Pacific off the California coast today and machine-grinned lifeboats in which unarmed crew members were pulling hard for shore.
LONDON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Roosevelt established today an Office of Defense Transportation "to assure maximum utilization of the domestic transportation facilities of the nation for the successful prosecution of the war," and named Joseph B. Eastman, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, as director.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Laura Ingalls, the flier whom the Department of Justice recently charged with failure to register as a German agent, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on that ground. Deputy marshals were trying to find her tonight in order to serve a bench warrant for her arrest.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The resident of the New York metropolitan region is being forced to the conclusion that the civilian defense effort in this region is being badly bungled. The events of the last two weeks have been shocking in their revelation of lack of planning, lack of preparation and incompetent administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Confidence that the Army and Navy would triumph on "all fronts" was expressed tonight by President Roosevelt in a message of greetings sent to the services by himself as Commander in Chief. His message read:

Hundreds of thousands of gallons of water flooded a square mile of Brooklyn streets yesterday morning when a forty-eight-inch water main, one of the largest in the city, burst at Ashland Place and Willoughby Street, in front of the Civil prison, which adjoins the Brooklyn City prison.

A campaign for the liberalization of Army specifications on uniform and other military woolen needs to allow greater use of reused and reworked wool has been started by the National Association of Waste Material Dealers, following the threatened shortage for 1942 of the virgin material, Charles M. Haskins, secretary of the association, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A special war commission was established today in the United States Office of Education, on the recommendation of Dr. John W. Studebaker, Commissioner, presented at the request of Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, and approved by the representatives of more than thirty educational organizations.

The coming year will witness the greatest repackaging splurge in the history of the industry, as a result of shortages in so many vital materials, packaging men said yesterday, in this particular case, no comparison can be made with the last war, because at that time packaged products were only getting their start and manufacturers had comparatively few problems to face.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- British submarines operating in the Mediterranean have claimed six new victims among Axis ships that are attempting to take men or supplies to the hard-pressed Axis forces in Libya.

Mel Hill and Harry Watson did all the scoring for the Brooklyn Americans last night and their combined efforts proved just enough to enable Red Dutton's sextet to chalk up a 4-to-3 triumph over the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

BATAVIA, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Official circles anounced that 500 civilian casualties have resulted from Japanese air raids on Netherlands Indies cities and villages since the war began. The latest information from Tarenpa, in the Anambas Islands between Malaya and Borneo, was that 100 persons were killed in raids there on Dec. 17.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Representative Worley of Texas was ordered into active service today as a lieutenant commander in the Naval Reserve, thereby keeping a campaign promise in spite of his rejection by two other branches of the armed service.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline on the Atlantic Seaboard at the end of last week amounted to 20,218,000 barrels, an increase of 543,000 over the 19,675.000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 23 -- After approximately thirty-two hours in cramped berths and stiff chairs, Fordham's thirty-six travel-worn football warriors today reached this gulf-lapped city of 2,700 inhabitants, their training ground from now until time to leave for the Sugar Bowl New Year's Day classic with Missouri at New Orleans fifty miles distant.

An offer made by a Japanese bank agency here on Dec. 2, five days before the attack on Pearl Harbor, to settle immediately for cash, payments scheduled to be made to an American company through 1942 and 1943 was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday.

Yesterday morning Helen Cookman gave a fashion breakfast in her place of business, 48 East Sixtysixth Street, at which the city's leading style experts were present. They turned out because they expected this distinguished designer to offer them something unusual.

TRENTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Governor Charles Edison signed into law today a bill giving him sweeping wartime powers. The act authorizes him to commandeer any State resources during the defense emergency.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Unity between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations was regarded tonight as an immediate objective of the Roosevelt Administration in the wake of an Industry-Labor Conference which showed the solidarity of the two labor groups on fundamental questions of policy.

THE TIMES closes today its thirtieth annual appeal for The Hundred Neediest with the largest daily total ever received in its history, more than $46,000. A single generous gift, from a kind-hearted friend who remembered the Neediest in her will, accounts for a large portion of this unprecedented sum.

LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 25 -- The people of Dover yesterday had their Christmas shopping interrupted by the screech and blasts of shells, while two exiled monarch and one Foreign Minister, similarly in exile, appealed to their people over the radio to be calm and to be of good Christmas cheer.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The call up of a big Indian loan which will release funds for reinvestment lifted British funds to their best levels for some time. On the stock markets today the 3 1/2 per cent war loan, old consols and local loans promptly appreciated by about u15,000.000.

As a result of a split in the Manor Reformed Church congregation, it was learned last night, the Rev. Dr. James Palmer has resumed, after an interlude of twenty-eight years, the guidance of part of his old flock in quarters lent by the Eighteenth Street Methodist Church.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Prices of hogs soared 25 to 50 cents a hundred pounds on the livestock market today as producers again cut shipments drastically below the preceding day's estimate. A top of $11.60 was paid for best offerings, a new high for the movement. The market also received strength from firmer dressed prices.

An emergency appeal for aid in solving the recreational problems of the increased number of service men assigned to Alaska since the United States entered the war has been received at headquarters of the American Women's Voluntary Services here.

Two young gunmen cowed a clerk, an elevator operator and a woman guest while they calmly took $400 from the cash drawer in the lobby office of the Bryant Hotel, Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street, at 5 o'clock yesterday morning and then escaped after wishing their victims a merry Christmas.

The Germans' failure to accomplish their objectives in Russia -- emphasized again yesterday by the continued Nazi retirement -- and the retreat of the German North Africa Corps in Libya are only two of the body blows that have been administered to German morale since the beginning of December.

OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- An exciting encounter with Japanese gunboats that left him afloat in the China Sea for six hours is told by the Rev. Joseph Sweeney, director of Maryknoll Leper Asylum in South China, in a letter from Hong Kong that reached Maryknoll headquarters here today.
CHAPEL, HILL, N.C., Dec. 24 (AP) -- If Oregon State loses the Rose Bowl football game to Duke at Durham on New Year's Day, Coach Lon Stiner is going to put part of the blame on Southern hospitality.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Although trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today was of a pre-holiday character, bullish sentiment was more in evidence on reports that ceiling prices on agricultural products would be raised to at least the levels on Oct. 1.

MANILA, Dec. 24 -- The Philippine populace in both Manila and the provinces has concentrated efforts on making living conditions as nearly normal as possible under the circumstances. There was some last-minute Christmas shopping in downtown stores by families making a brave effort for some kind of observance of the Yuletide between air raid alarms.

Twenty American newspaper correspondents in London exchanged Christmas greetings with their wives, children and other relatives over the radio last night in a two-way hook-up between London and New York arranged by the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Thai Minister, Rajawongse Seni Pramoj, announced at a press conference today that he would carry on as Minister notwithstanding the capitulation of Thailand to Japan, and would work for the independence and liberty of his country.

Paper rationing restrictions have been drawn even tighter in the last year in England but The Times Literary Supplement obtained enough stock to issue its traditional Christmas number in twenty-eight pages. The issue that reached this city this week is only twelve pages smaller than last year's.
America prepared last night to observe its first Christmas at war since 1917.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 24 -- Flamingo Patio was filled late this afternoon for the eleventh annual Christmas Carol program, sung by a male quartet. The event, adranged by Mr. and Mrs. James Taylor Terry, who was assisted by Mr. and Mrs. Clegg Monroe, will aid war relief.

Outbreak of war in the Pacific found our Pacific Coast already launched on a marked industrial expansion and there are opportunities for further growth, the conference board's division of industrial economics reported yesterday. The most notable opportunities for further expansion are in the Pacific Northwest, where an abundance of hydroelectric power makes it possible to establish and develop several processing industries for production of raw materials for shipbuilding, aircraft, ordnance and munitions.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- Field Marshal Ritter von Leeb's siege army on the Leningrad front is threatened with entrapment and extinction by three Russian columns closing in on it through crumbling German defenses south and east of the old capital, Soviet dispatches said tonight.
The U.S.S. Atlanta, first of a class of light cruisers, new to our Navy in both design and purpose, was commissioned at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Mrs. Edward Joseph King, wife of Admiral King, new Commander in Chief of the Fleet, is one of the most popular and well-beloved of "Navy wives." She is described by her friends as "perfectly charming and most attractive," and by her children, who are devoted to her, as "the most beautiful woman in the world."

The 160-family apartment house at 1620-40 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Steeples Management Corporation to the Scherman Land Corporation for cash above a first mortgage of $367,500. The building is on a plot 380 by 150 feet and the combined assessment is $325,000, of which $55,000 applies to the land.

VICHY, France, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, the Chief of State, broadcast a Christmas message to French prisoners of war tonight, promising to do everything in his power to have them liberated soon and setting at rest reports abroad that he had resigned.

Six thousand persons, including a group of service men in uniform, attended a holy communion service last midnight at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. It marked the first such service on Christmas eve, for in previous years there has been only a plain service with hymns.

We have long been convinced that one of the vital needs of thousands of New York sportsmen is a good hunting and fishing exchange. And, after looking over some of the gadgets found under a tree this morning, we believe there are many who will agree with us.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 24 -- After tomorrow, it may be possible for those seeking it to get an inside line on how Fordham and Missouri are going to fare in the New Orleans Sugar Bowl game on New Year's Day.

A common bond of compassion for the aged and the blind, the families hit by sudden misfortune but struggling to remain together, the orphaned children, the lonely men and women of the Neediest Cases bound the 672 contributors who sent their gifts of mercy yesterday not only from New York and its suburbs but from many other cities and States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Members of the crews of American flag merchant ships have been protected by a $5,000 war-risk life insurance policy since Dec. 22, and warbonus rates, to be established" soon for mariners entering dangerous waters, will probably be retroactive to Dec. 7.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- What is everyday fare to many Americans gives a real thrill to Prime Minister Churchill -- two eggs on a breakfast tray.

The King of Denmark, through Henrik Kauffman, Minister to Washington, announced yesterday that, because of existing conditions, it will not be able to meet the maturity on Jan. 1 of $30,000,000 of the 6 per cent Joan. However, it was stated that the Jan. 1 coupons would be paid.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 24 (UP) -- Firmly entrenched imperial defenders of Malaya were reported to be exacting a high toll on the invaders at "surprisingly light" cost to themselves.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Christmas fires blazed in hundreds of poor homes throughout the city today all because of an eighteenth-century Santa Claus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Army's High Command tonight considered the possibility of removing military headquarters and Philippine Commonwealth government offices from Manila and declaring it an "open city" in an attempt to save it from further Japanese bombardment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Mrs. Roosevelt put through a fifteen-hour day program today. It began with a Central Union Mission party for poor children at 9 o'clock in the morning and ended with a midnight church service, which she never fails to attend on Christmas Eve.

The anti-aircraft troops of theFirst Army, all of whom will remain on duty at their posts from Maine to Florida over the holidays, were described here yesterday as their country's "split second men," or modern replacements for the famous "minute men" of history.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 24 -- The United Taxpayers Association of this city will try to upset the 1942 municipal budget here, it is announced by George W. Whitbread, president. This is because of the sudden rise in the tax rate from $2.51 to $2.66 per $100 following the discovery of a $2,200,000 clerical error in adding up the taxable real estate.

Unless the weather man reverses himself, there will be little for the army of skiers in Northeastern United States and Canada to be cheerful about this Christmas day. Unlooked-for rain struck the North Country yesterday from the Poconos to Mont Tremblant, in the Laurentians, and did considerable damage to the snow covers at the major ski centers.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- Westchester County officials viewed with scorn today Mayor La Guardia's proposal that New York City give $10,000 to Westchester County so that the $285,000 Hugh J. Chisholm tract in Purchase could be bought for a county airport instead of the $275,750 Rye Lake site, also in Purchase.

Those youngsters who came whooping down at dawn today for a first wide-eyed look beneath the tree were summoning us all to a peculiarly poignant Christmas. The shouts were the opening notes of a day-long carol, American to the core.
BERLIN, Dec. 24 (from German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command said today:
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 23 (delayed) (AP) -- A British communique said today:

A man who remembered the Maine quite literally -- because he was aboard when she was blown up -- and another who had been personal chef to two Presidents aboard the yacht Mayflower tried to re-enlist in the Navy yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Nine horses have accepted the weights for the Pontchartrain Handicap, $2,500 added race that will feature the Fair Grounds opening tomorrow.

TWAS the night before Christmas and all through the house -- oh, well, you get the idea. That stylish stout gentleman in red made it again. It mattered not whether you had a chimney, Santa Claus climbed down it last night.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 24 (from Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

There was a heaping measure of good cheer at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, where "The Barber of Seville" had its first performance of the season. Rossini's gem of a comic opera thrives even in poor productions with third-rate singers, but it overflows with good-will when done with real singing actors.

The voice of Pius XII is a lonely voice in the silence and darkness enveloping Europe this Christmas. The Pope reiterates what he has said before. In general he repeats, although with greater definiteness, the five-point plan for peace which he first enunciated in his Christmas message after the war broke out in 1939 His program agrees in fundamentals with the Roosevelt-Churchill eight-point declaration.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 24 -- At sunrise tomorrow Guy D. Moore, 72, of Tyringham, will start on a six-mile journey to the summit of Round Mountain in that town to place wreaths on the tombs of Mr. and Mrs. Robb de Peyster Tytus and their daughter, Miss Mildred M. Tytus, the parents and the sister of Mrs. Lawrence Coolidge of Boston.

Santa's whiskers may conceal the identities of Joe Di Maggio and even Boris Karloff, but they fell down miserably yesterday on Jimmy Durante. In spite of his red coat and its accompanying props, a little boy and girl could see but one thing -- the famous "schnozzle."

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 25 (AP) -- United States Army forces with General Douglas MacArthur personally in the field staved off Japanese advances toward Manila from both the north and south this Christmas Day, but the invaders continued to land in such numbers that it was obvious the battle for the Philippine capital was under way.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24 -- Spotting his rivals many lengths by running out at the turn for Home, B.A. Dario's consistent colt from New England, Blue Warrior, proved much the best in the Christmas Eve Purse at Tropical Park today.
Apparently a lot of folks expected the Indians to win the American League pennant -- or at least make a fight for it -- and Lou Nova to do more than talk a good fight against Joe Louis.

BATAVIA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Netherlands Indies Army bombers attacked a concentration of Japanese ships off Kuching, capital of Sarawak, today and left one transport in sinking condition, it was announced officially.

If Hitler, frustrated in Russia, plans to strike through Spain into North Africa, he can afford no delay. In the Libyan desert the sands are running low for the Axis. General Rommel's "army of reconquest" is plainly in peril. The British seem to have him in a trap and to have cut across his only line of retreat.

Holiday With all markets throughout the world closed today, various weekly financial compilations and statistics usually released on Thursday for publication on Friday morning will not be published until Saturday. In some instances, boards of directors of financial institutions which normally would hold their weekly meetings today, met yesterday.

The stock market, for all of the news it had to contend with from the Philippines, had its best recovery yesterday in approximately two weeks, and although the rally was of minor proportion, it indicated that stronger hands were once again at the helm.

After holding back all official forecasts for today until late yesterday afternoon -- because of wartime restrictions -- the Weather Bureau finally announced last night that fair and somewhat colder weather would be the rule in the New York City area this Christmas.

HONOLULU, Dec. 23 (Delayed) -- The damage done by Japanese bombs at Hickam Field, the huge United States air base guarding Pearl Harbor, and Wheeler Field, the pursuit base adjacent to Schofield Barracks, was shown to newspaper men today for the first time under the guidance of Army officers.

The Bulova Watch Company yesterday presented to its employes Christmas bonuses amounting to $250,000 in cash. All employes, regardless of length of service or employment, received percentages of their year's wages. The company urged all employes to invest in defense bonds.

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Japanese planes yesterday deliberately bombed the business district of Manila for the first time of the war, concentrating on the port area, and reports from the provinces indicated that ruthless air attacks on civilians were in progress throughout Luzon Island.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Navy reluctantly closed today its chapter of exploits at Wake Island, which is now assumed lost to the Japanese, by revealing that 378 Marines, assisted by seven members of naval medical personnel, held off Japanese attacks by sea, air and land for fourteen days before radio silence signaled the end of their vigil.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- The army newspaper Red Star reports today the appearance of three types of German planes hitherto unseen over the Eastern Front -- the Heinkel-113, the Messerschmitt-115 and readaptation of the Henschel-123. Each of these planes appears to be specially adapted for fighting on the Eastern Front.

What the good parson preached, and how the sweet music soared, one Christmas morning in rural England in the latter days of George III. The reporter is Washington Irving, who was living in England at the time and happened to spend the holiday with the Bracebridge family, whom he later immortalised in "The Sketch Book" (from which the following is taken) and in "Bracebridge Hall."

A campaign to collect stamps for the entertainment of war-in-valided English children will be launched with a children's exhibition of paintings Jan. 15 at the Wildenstein Galleries, 18 East 64th Street, under the sponsorship of Bundles for Britain, Inc.

Bank clearings at twenty-three leading cities throughout the United States in the week ended yesterday amounted to $7,855,844,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This represented an increase of 24.6 per cent over the five-day week in 1940 when clearings were $6,303,747,000.

VICHY, France, Dec. 24 -- The third Christmas of the war and the second of the French-German armistice finds France struggling with difficulties of all kinds, marked by restrictions, dearth of food and rising prices. Housewives stand in line outside stores and there is no fire on many a hearth.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 24 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's trip to Washington has proved that Britain has subordinated herself to the United States, according to the Axis propaganda machine. Any declarations that may result from the Washington meeting are scoffed at in advance as mere words, and it is reiterated that it is actions that count.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- All members of the Senate and the House, veterans and first-termers alike, are to be required to carry an identification card bearing a photograph as they move about the Capitol and Congressional office buildings during certain hours.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- To place America's fighting troops under men combining the vitality and daring of youth with the judgment of age, the War Department is turning today mostly to officers who began their military careers in the first World War.
"Dear Mr. Mayor: It is with regret I have to report the chiseling in the price of sugar that is going on in the neighborhood."

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 24 -- Harvard's basketball team suffered its second consecutive defeat tonight on its invasion of the Midwest, dropping a 39-28 decision to Michigan State before a slim crowd of 1,500.

The last package has been opened with shrieks of delight. The waste basket is so bedecked with streaming silver paper and scarlet ribbon that it looks like a present itself. Dad and Junior are tussling with a coal car whose coupling apparatus does not operate with the efficiency demanded by the maintenance crew of the Father Son R.R. Co.

Transcending the splendor of the pontifical midnight mass and the beauty of the carol service af St. Patrick's last night, the changeless spiritual message of the Christmas festival this year was directed especially toward the war worries of the faithful who once again taxed the capacity of the cathedral.

On Christmas Day, in a world fraught with suffering and the horrors of war, the Neediest Cases Fund stands at $210,142.88, greatly strengthened in its aim to help the most distressed men, women and children in the city by 672 gifts received yesterday totaling $46,833.86.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 24 -- With German strength definitely broken throughout Cyrenaica, the battle of Libya has resolved Itself into a vast chess game in which British forces are trying to checkmate the German nucleus, to cut it off or smash it to pieces before the Germans can get substantial reinforcements of men and materiel into Tripoli and possibly, make a stand.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -- A submarine mistaken by shore watchers for a fishing boat sailed boldly through a zone of heavy ship traffic off the California coast today, sent a torpedo into an American freighter and submerged when bombers appeared and dropped a depth charge.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Defenders of the United States, from Iceland to the Philippines, will receive clothing, cigarettes, playing cards and other Christmas gifts tomorrow from the Red Cross.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 24 -- The Senate this afternoon unanimously ratified a Presidential decree permitting the use of Mexican harbors and soil by the armed forces of any American republic at war with a non-American power. The measure now becomes effective, only the Senate's approval having been necessary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- In the name of more than 20,000,000 members of their church in this country, the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States today pladged to President Roosevelt "whole-hearted cooperation in the difficult days that lie ahead."

Reporting substantial gains in sales of Pepto-Bismol this year, Frank L. McCartney, president of the Norwich Pharmacal Company, announced yesterday that advertising for both this product and Unguentine would be increased about 40 per cent in 1942.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -- In the face of the "no strike-no lock-out" agreement reached by the labor-management conference in Washington, D.C., striking shipyard welders of the East Bay area retained skeleton picket lines today at six defense plants in their fight against the American Federation of Labor for union autonomy.

The Appellate Division approved unanimously, in a decision made public yesterday, the settlement for $1,585,000 of a stockholders' action against George W. Hill, president, and four vice presidents of the American Tobacco Company, for recovery of alleged excessive bonus payments.

Establishment of fine gray goods ceilings on a sliding scale tied to raw cotton was welcomed in the market yesterday as a more practical methods of controlling values but it did not produce any appreciable market activity. Aside from the fact that preholiday tradingis normally dull, the position of raw cotton prices at the ten spot markets was not such as to induce offerings.

The Office of Civilian Defense has come in for a good deal of criticism in the past two weeks as citizens, anxious to play their part, have discovered the serious deficiencies in planning, personnel and materials which exist. But it has remained for Mrs. Roosevelt, who is second only to Mayor La Guardia in the direction of OCD, to make the most sweeping, though brief, comment on the inadequacies of the existing set-up.
Louis Repouille was freed yesterday on a suspended sentence of five to ten years for chloroforming his 13-year-old son, a blind imbecile, "to put him out of his sufferings."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Connecticut Light and Power Company of Hartford, Conn., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the issue of 336,088 shares of cumulative preferred stock without par value, its stated value being $50 a share.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 24 -- Out of the blood, sweat, privation and suffering of their two years' war experience, the common people of Britain hope the American people will avoid certain mistakes which they feel Britain has made since the war began.

Though turned back on Tuesday by the league-leading Bruins at Boston, the New York Ranger are looking forward to rounding out a perfect Christmas in Madison Square Garden tonight. Lester Patrick's stick-wielders will meet the Chicago Black Hawks for the fourth time during the National Hockey League season and the Blue Shirts are hoping for another triumph over the Hawks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Speaking from the high south portico of the White House, in the twinkling lights of the community Christmas tree on the lawn below them, President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill this evening called on the people of their two nations to rededicate themselves in a righteous cause and to "arm their hearts' for labor, suffering and for the ultimate victory ahead.

A Christmas appeal to New Yorkers to remember the Red Cross was issued last night by Leon Fraser, general chairman of the campaign to raise $7,330,000 in the five boroughs toward the $50,000,000 national emergency fund.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A British headquarters communique today said:

MADISON, Fla., Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- Toys, checks and defense bonds -- Christmas gifts for little Colin Kelly 3d -- have been pouring into his grandfather's home here from all parts of the nation for a week, his mother said today.

Johnson Johnson, manufacturer of surgical dressings and accessories, has purchased the Armstrong Cork Company plant on Codwise Avenue and the Pennsylvania Railroad, New Brunswick, N.J., in a move to expand its productive facilities.

The world heavyweight championship battle between Joe Louis, the titleholder and Buddy Baer, California, challenger, scheduled for Jan. 9 in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the Navy Relief Society, faced cancellation for a few anxious moments yesterday.

See No Silk Hosiery Markdowns Although, a number of stores were understood to have carried over an appreciable inventory of women's full-fashioned silk, stocking's, it was not expected that there would be any widespread postholiday markdown sales, since in many instances the inventory is irreplaceable.

A sharp spurt in liquor sales featured the close of Christmas shopping here yesterday. Heavy eleventh-hour buying was also reported of many main-floor "pick-up" items ranging from cosmetics and perfumes to gloves and men's furnishings.

BETHLEHEM, Palestine, Dec. 24 -- There are crowds in the crooked and abruptly rising streets of this hallowed little town this Christmas Eve and they are larger, it is estimated, than at any other time since General Allenby's soldiers flocked here after having occupied the Holy Land in the last war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Japanese Government has declared, in an official communication received by the State Department today, its intention of treating American officials in Japan, Manchuria and China fairly, courteously and on a basis of reciprocity, pending their departure.
NEW YORK Mrs. Benjamin R. Kittredge left the Savoy-Plaza yesterday to join Mr. Kittredge at Dean Hall Plantation, their Winter home at Oakley, S.C.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 24 -- New Jersey prepared today for Christmas festivities, despite apprehension in the mind of every adult over the dictators' threats to national freedom and security and warnings from military authorities to be on guard against the possibility of attack on the holiday dedicated to peace and goodwill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Wherever duties find Navy men on this Christmas, from the North Atlantic to the South Pacific, they are united in confidence in each other and devotion to their country, Secretary Knox said today in a Yuletide message to the forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Led by further sharp advances in wholesale prices of farm products and processed foods, the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of nearly 900 price series rose another 1 per cent for the week ended on Dec. 20.

The chief problem upon which depends the livelihood of many independent tire dealers here and throughout the country is whether a price ceiling will be set upon retreading and recapping work, and if so what the ceiling will be, and Charles F. Root, executive secretary of the Greater New York Tire and Battery Association, said yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Germany's Minister of Propaganda, appealed openly tonight to Germans in countries abroad to "remain at your posts." He declared that "you pioneers serve our Father-land."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The War Department released the following orders today. dated Dec. 23:

They Bring Tidings It is a day with which the newspaper business might claim its own sentimental connection. A name which one frequently encounters in the shrinking volume of neutral news from Europe is the Stockholm Tidningen.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies Command issued this communique today:

BATAVIA, Dec. 24 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Officials here said today that the Netherlands armed forces would press an ever-widening offensive against the Japanese in the conviction that "the only effective defense for the Netherlands Indies consists of striking at the enemy wherever possible, without asking whether it is happening within or outside our territory."

Tonight Eddie Cantor is returning to the street which brought him fame and fortune in the musical show, "Banjo Eyes," opening at the Hollywood Theatre. All of which adds up to quite a sentimental occasion for the star after an absence from the legitimate stage of more than a decade.

Mayor La Guardia told 156,500 city employes yesterday that this Christmas might be the last holiday they would have for the duration of the war. The notice was included in a Christmas message of greetings and warnings to all the people of the city.

The cotton market was quiet yesterday with business limited. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange ended at noon, in observance of Christmas Eve, and final prices of active futures were unchanged to 2 points higher than on Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today purchased "Cherie Jolie," a screen story by Jacques Thery and Louis de Vohl, as a vehicle for Walter Pidgeon. The yarn deals with an English adventurer who goes to occupied-France to capture ten Nazi generals as hostages for his wife, who is a prisoner in Germany.

The texts of the Christmas Eve addresses of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill from Washington, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES, were as follows:

Six new films will open holiday engagements in Broadway theatres today. "Remember the Day," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama starring Claudette Colbert, will have its world premiere at the Roxy. Included in the supporting cast are John Payne, John Sheppenl. Ann Todd and the child actor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- War Department communique No. 26, outlining the military situation up to 9:30 A.M., follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Prime Minister Churchill will address an informal joint session of Congress Friday, Senator Barkley announced tonight.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 24 -- While the spirit of Christmas predominated at Fort Dix today there was every indication that the United States was at war and that the troops here would not be caught unprepared for any eventuality. Due to the war several thousand men must be on duty at all times, but nowhere was there any grumbling heard.
The New York Stock Exchange has been notified that the name of the Amerada Corporation has been changed to the Amerada Petroleum Corporation.

It is not easy to keep the spirit of Christmas in time of war. The sad and ancient problem of the evil in men's hearts, and of the difficulty that all men meet with in trying to find a course of action that has no evil at all in it, seems this year further than ever from solution.

The purchase by an investor of a large business property in the Columbus Circle section was announced yesterday when the American Bosch Magneto Company of Springfield, Mass., sold the elevenstory store, office and showroom building at 17 to 23 West Sixtieth Street, Occupied largely by concerns in the automobile industry and allied Lines, the property is assessed at S300.000 and is about 94 per cent rented.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Dec. 24 -- Eighteen physicians, constituting the nucleus of Naval Base Hospital No. 33, organized at Bryn Mawr Hospital, have been ordered to report for duty at the Washington Navy Yard on Jan. 5.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A stanch but ragged British line athwart the mangrove swamps and mountains of North Malaya appeared today to have fought the Japanese advance on Singapore to a standstill.

Now under way, the first task of the new production engineering section of the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics is organization of a skilled engineering staff from civilian sources, it became known yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 24 -- In the most pessimistic speech he has uttered since the war began, Pope Pius XII, delivering his third wartime Christmas message to the world from Vatican City, clarified his position regarding the conflict.
