CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Disregarding the precedent set earlier in the year by its chief competitor, Sears Roebuck Co. today mailed out to mail order customers its annual midwinter bargain flyer of 122 pages, accompanied by an announcement that "Sears midwinter sale goes on even in these difficult times."

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- Over snowy roads littered with hundreds upon hundreds of German vehicles, the Red Army swarmed down tonight on Orel, 200 miles below Moscow, and on the ragged remnants of Col. Gen. Heinz Guderian's Second Tank Division.

The weather and the impending holiday combined to keep the National Football League All-Stars indoors yesterday as ten of them reported to Steve Owen, coach of the New York Giants, who will handle the team for its game against the Chicago Bears at the Polo Grounds on Jan. 4.

Christmas will be observed today by the crews of British ships in all parts of the world, regardless of the war and the dangers of submarines and mine fields. The time-honored Christmas dinner consists of turkey, goose, roast pork or fowls, or any fresh meat that can be obtained.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two seemingly unrelated items in THE TIMES of Dec. 21 appear to me to converge and thus become raised to prime importance.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (U.P) -- Isolated and weary but "with plenty of fight left." the British defenders of Hong Kong hung on grimly today in a defense that assured them a place in history beside their fathers who fought at Mafeking and Ypres.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Members of alien enemy hearing boards in twenty-four judicial districts, including two for New York City, were appointed today by Attorney General Biddle. Officials said two were needed in New York because of the number of arrests there.

Mr. and Mrs. Jean Ulyxes Koree of 40 East Eighty-eighth. Street gave an afternoon reception with dancing yesterday at the York Club to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Moycah Bronson Koree. The debutante received with her mother, her aunt, Mrs. Horace Niles Trumbull of Cleveland and Stonington, Conn.; the Misses Peggy Keasbey, Joan Carpenter, Jean Dunnington and Cecily Flanagan.

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- Tass dispatches from Istanbul appearing in Moscow newspapers indicate that the view, apparently held in London, that Reichsfuehrer Hitler is planning to strike in a new direction soon is shared here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A new emergency schedule setting prices for leather of all types, grades and qualities at levels no higher than those which prevailed between Nov. 6 and Dec. 6, was issued today by Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- An exchange of messages between King Haakon of Norway and President Roosevelt as "comrades in arms" in "a common fight" was given out by the State Department today.
Production of war materials and equipment this week reached levels which are already making the prewar efforts, or before Dec. 7, look unimpressive by comparison, Iron Age says this week.
ST. PIERRE, Dec. 24 -- A Free French naval force under the command of Vice Admiral Emile Muselier made a surprise landing on the Vichy-governed Islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon today.

Mounting employment in defense industries and increased consumer buying power brought a drop of $31,000,000 in State unemployment insurance payments during 1941 the Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance of the State Labor Department reported yesterday.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24 -- The following is the official English translation of Pope Pius XII's Christmas Eve broadcast to the world:

The First National Bank of Portland, Ore., received yesterday the award of an issue of $1,000,000 notes of School District No. 1 of Multomah County, Ore. The bank paid a premium of $3,875 for 2s. The bonds, dated Jan. 2, 1942, will mature on April 2, 1942.
BUFFALO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Myrtle Pickering, eight-year-old orphan, has "adopted" President Roosevelt for the duration of the war.

The Bendix Aviation Corporation reported yesterday consolidated net income of $13,267,988 for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, after taxes, reserves and amortization charges, equal to $6.30 a common share, against $7,861,371, or $3.75 a share, in the preceding year.

FLINT, Mich., Dec. 25 -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of the Buick division of General Motors Corporation, said today that the Army Air Corps had authorized the doubling of Buick's aviation engine production. The division has moved immediately to put the authorization into action, Mr. Curtice added, and will establish plant operations on a twenty-four-hour-a-day basis.

The news from Manila is bad news. It is evident that we do not have in the Philippines today a sufficient air force to prevent the Japanese from landing at widely scattered points in heavy force. Our failure to command the air has cost us the initial advantage of an otherwise strong defensive position.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- W.L. Mackenzie King, Canadian Premier, was en route to Washington from Ottawa tonight to participate In the vital White House conferences which will determine the conduct of the war in the Pacific and elsewhere.

The feminine rush for silk stockings last Summer has now been paralleled by the masculine rush for golf balls. Perhaps the stampede around the sporting goods counters may prove as silly as was the silk-stocking scare, but both episodes teach a lesson. In both instances it became necessary for merchants to resort to rationing -- no more than so much to a customer.

The big fellow who ordinarily is coach of the Giants and at the moment directs the National Football League All-Stars gave a little ground to Christmas yesterday, but didn't yield all the way. Fifteen of the men chosen for the game with the Bears at the Polo Grounds on Jan. 4 spent about an hour on the field yesterday.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midday communique broadcast by the Moscow radio said:

The doorman at 233 Madison Avenue, headquarters of the National Democratic Club, got a valuable piece of advice yesterday noon. As soldiers and sailors began to arrive for Christmas dinner, one of the club governors said:

The light and hope of Christianity as the one sure guide to a distracted humanity in a world at war was the theme of sermons delivered yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral and at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- The Soviet Union's Christmas message to the German people took the form of a series of grim postcards with forged six-pfennig stamps, which presumably were smuggled into Germany and posted by agents there.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The time is now at hand when the war-chest idea must once again come to the front.
Christmas trade ended with a rush that was sufficient to cancel the lag of two weeks ago in many stores, Dun Bradstreet said yesterday in the weekly review of business.

BATAVIA, Java., Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Netherland air and sea raiders have sunk a heavy Japanese destroyer of the Amagiri class and another transport to raise their toll of Japanese ships to fifteen, but a Netherland submarine, returning from a successful mission, struck a mine and sank with all but one of its crew lost.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 25 -- Residents of the colony celebrated Christmas in various ways, many of them including not only their families and friends but the young Englishmen training for the Royal Air Force at Clewiston in their plans.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mien., Dec. 25 -- Demand for furniture in the last few weeks, both by consumers and dealers, has followed an irregular, sidewise trend at a level well under the recent peak, according to the monthly bulletin issued by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Even while long-delayed communiques from Hong Kong reached here today, the Colonial Office announced the colony's fall after a sixteen-day siege. It appeared that Governor Sir Mark Young had been instructed to seek a negotiated surrender rather than attempt to stand off the Japanese to the last defender.

Producers Releasing Corporation's "Swamp Woman," which opens at the Central, is today's sole film newcomer. The film marks the screen debut of Ann Corio, burlesque headliner, and includes Jack La Rue, Mary Hull, lan MacDonald and Jay Novello among its featured players. . . . "Girl From Leningrad," the Soviet feature at the Stanley, enters its second week today.

MANILA, Friday, Dec. 26 -- General Douglas MacArthur, commander of the United States Far Eastern Army defending the Philippines, declared Manila an open city today "in order to spare the metropolitan area from the possible ravages of attack either in the air or on the ground."
CAIRO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters here today issued the following communique:

As his Christmas gift to New York motorists, Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that insurance rates for regular automobile bodily injury and property damage would not go up next year despite an increase in auto accidents during 1941.

Of the four Labor M.P.'s ennobled for transfer to the House of Lords Colonel Josiah Wedgwood is best known in the United States, which he has visited more than once and lately. He is a single-taxer, a naval architect, an author, a pacifist who has been a first-class fighting man.

ON THE LINGAYEN FRONT North of Manila, Dec. 25 -- The Japanese Army rushing toward Manila from the Lingayen Gulf are is an ill-uniformed, untrained mass of young boys between 15 and 18 years old, equipped with small-caliber guns and driven forward by desperate determination to advance or die.

Although shorn of most of their other laurels last Summer, the Cincinnati Reds, according to the official National League averages for 1941, released for publication this morning, still remain the best defensive club in the loop.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A renewed move for legislation to prevent wartime strikes gathered strength today as some members of Congress expressed dissatisfaction with the agreement reached between representativs of labor and industry earlier in the week.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 25 -- Head Coach Jimmy Crowley gave the Fordham football team a rest today, the only work for the Sugar Bowl game with Missouri on New Year's Day being a showing of motion pictures of the Tiger's contest with New York University.
BATAVIA, Dec. 25 (Reuter) -- The command of the Netherlands Indies Fighting Services issued today the following communique:

A warning to the United States not to overestimate this country's capacities to "do the job" of winning the war or to "underestimate the evil strength of our adversaries" was given on the radio yesterday by Attorney General Francis Biddle.

City dwellers and out-of-towners exchanged places in great numbers yesterday as indicated by reports of officials of railroads, bus lines, tunnels and bridges. All spokesmen reported that "more persons left the city than arrived here but, they added, reservations over the coming week-end were much higher for New York bound trains and buses.

MANILA, Dec. 25 -- The open city suggestion first reached the public here by the local radio yesterday, and, lacking clarification, the official announcement created the wildest rumors, the general belief being that the enemy would enter the city immediately.

Greetings. Eddie! Eddie Cantor, that is. After slumming through some opulent years in other forms of show business, Mr. Cantor has decided to return to the stage in "Banjo Eyes," which were opened at the Hollywood last evening. That is one of the best decisions he has decided for some time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- An Army bomber has blasted an enemy submarine into "debris" off the California coast, an official announcement today said, accounting for one of perhaps four submarines that have been harassing coastal shipping for a week.

The Long Island University basketball team will depart for New Orleans tomorrow night for its Sugar Bowl game with Tennessee on Monday. The Blackbirds will leave Madison Square Garden immediately after the L. I. U. Southern California contest, which will be played as the first game of a double-header so that the team can make a 10 o'clock train.

The Rangers gave the Black Hawks two early goals in their National League game at Madison Square Garden last night, then gave the Chicagoans a lesson in the fine art of hockey. In so doing the Blue Shirts recorded a 5-to-2 triumph.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Hooves flew again around the historic old Fair Grounds race track today, after a year's lay-off, while an opening day crowd estimated at 7,500 dodged intermittent showers to watch the seven-race card.

After staging a thrilling third-period comeback to get four goals, the New York Rovers saw all their great work undone by Ducky Skinner, who notched a goal in 7:43 of the ten-minute overtime session to break a 7-all tie and give the Baltimore Orioles an 8 -- 7 success at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The following is the text of King George's Christmas Day message, broadcast to the Empire:

MOSCOW. Dec. 25 -- Claiming that 20,000 Germans have been killed at the defenses of Sevastopol during the six-day assault on the Black Sea naval base in Southwestern Crimea, Russian dispatches reported today that the defense line was steady.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 -- Wartime restrictions on private flights were relaxed today to allow New England's flying Santa Claus to keep faith as a Christmas package-laden airplane carried cheer to lonely islands and lighthouses along the coast.

MANILA, Friday, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- This great capital of the Philippines, with a population of more than 600,000, was declared an open city today in an effort to spare it the ravages of modern warfare brought to the islands by the Japanese invasion, and President Manuel Quezon announced that the government was evacuating the capital.

BENDIX, N. J., Dec. 25 -- Early resumption of private control at the Army-operated plants of Air Associates, Inc., was forecast tonight after representatives of the management and the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., had reached agreement on terms of a one-year contract providing wage increases and a modified union shop.

The country has good reason to be satisfied with the selection of Admiral Ernest J. King as Commander in Chief of the United States fleet. Few naval officers, not only in our own forces but in any navy in the world, have had his well-rounded experience. None has shown in any of the varied branches of the service more outstanding qualities of intelligence and leadership.
TORONTO, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs cut Boston's lead at the top of the National Hockey League to one point tonight by beating the Bruins, 2 -- 0, in a whirlwind finish.

"My Sister Eileen" celebrates its first anniversary tonight at the Biltmore. According to statistics compiled by a spokesman for the production, the Joseph Fields - Jerome Chodorov comedy starts its second year with a profitable past for all concerned.

MITCHEL FIELD, L. I., Dec. 25 -- Gift bearers infiltrated into the west gate house of this United States Army Reservation today, executed a swift encircling movement around the guard and left him "blitzed" under a bombardment of gaily decorated Christmas packages.

FORT DIX, N.J., Dec. 25 -- Compelled to remain in camp and on the alert for a possible attack, the soldiers of Fort Dix, aided by their uncles and their cousins and their aunts, celebrated Christmas today in a setting that was an admixture of the trappings of Santa Claus and Mars.

WHITE PLAINS. N. Y., Dec. 25 -- With family reunions, church services and special dinners for the poor, Westchester County observed Christinas today in traditional style, but because of the war there were fewer Yuletide displays on lawns and fewer groups of neighborhood carol singers than in many years.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- King George VI, delivering today his third wartime Christmas broadcast to the British Empire, spoke from his own home in the English countryside with his wife, Queen Elizabeth, and their children near and stressed the value of family life at this season and in a war-torn world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Specific slashes in nondefense governmental outlays, aimed at bringing total savings of $1,716,965,061 during the coming fiscal year as a contribution to the financing of the war program, were recommended to President Roosevelt and the Congress today by the Congressional-Executive Department Joint Committee on Non-Essential Expenditures, headed by Senator Byrd of Virginia.

The world listened in yesterday as a little boy in America told his daddy in London that he'd "got a Bible with a zipper on it" for a Christmas present, and a little girl pleaded with her father, a United States Army major on duty in London, to "come home, daddy" because he was sorely missed.

As the nation observed its first wartime Christmas since 1917, accidental deaths totaled 394 yesterday, according to a survey made by the Associated Press. Traffic crackups caused 301 to lose their lives, although weather and road conditions in almost every part of the country were ideal. Miscellaneous causes were responsible for ninety-three deaths.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 25 -- Shrieking and screaming in the quiet of Christmas morning, ten persons had an agonizing death and twenty-two others were injured today in the flaming wreckage of a bus.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 25 -- The Chief, Maxwell Howard's temperamental, unpredictable veteran, equaled Ringie's Tropical Park record today by speeding to victory in the mile and seventy yard Christimas Handicap in 1:41 1-5.

ST. PIERRE-MIQUELON, Dec. 25 -- In the first free expression of opinion permitted Frenchmen who have been governed since the Summer of 1940 by "we Henri Philippe Petain," Chief of State of the Vichy regime, the male population of this island today voted better than 98 per cent for the policy of Free France, ally of the United States and Britain.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 25 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops are still on the offensive in the Hong Kong area, despite the surrender of the British Crown Colony, but in the interior of China the Japanese have launched a new drive toward the vital food supply point of Changsha, it was announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 25 -- Coincident with the outbreak of spotted typhus on the northern front, reports received here from Helsinki and Stockholm during" the last few days tell of the outbreak of yet another scourge that is taking a heavy toll of the German troops there.

New York made Christmas warm and pleasant reality for the men of the nation's armed fore here on leave yesterday. It gave them handsomely wrapped and useful presents, treated them to Christmas dinners in swanky places and followed these up with shows and movies and dancing with pretty girls.
Santa Claus apparently was too busy Christmas Eve to spread cheer among the thousands of skiers in this part of the country as he left them holding empty stockings.

DETROIT, Dec. 25 -- The Detroit Red Wings withstood a threat on fifth place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the revitalized Brooklyn Americans, 3 to 2, on Sid Abel's overtime goal before a holiday crowd of 6,314.

TOKYO, Dec. 25 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- A dispatch from Hankow, China, says that a large-scale Japanese offensive was started last night in Kiangsi and Hunan Provinces.
The two six-story buildings at 244-48 West Twenty-seventh Street were sold by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company as trustee to an investing client of Morgan Barry, Inc., brokers.
"On the job." That was the terse report given to describe how the 30,000 men and women volunteers of the First Interceptor Command spent the Christmas holiday.

Isabelle Hallin, 31 years old, the former school teacher of Saugus, Mass., who became known in 1937 through charges that she had served cocktails to members of her high school class, was found dead here early yesterday, a victim of gas poisoning.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 -- Joel McCrea has been assigned to the male lead opposite Veronica Lake in Paramount's "I Married a Witch," a Preston Sturges production which Rene Clair will direct. Dalton Trumbo and Robert Pirosh are writing the scenario for the novel by the late Thorne Smith.

OTTAWA, Dec. 25 -- All over Canada there is pleased satisfaction at the manner in which the problem of St. Pierre and Miquelon has been brought to a climax by the action of Vice Admiral Emile Muselier and his Free French naval forces.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This is to suggest that the registration of men between the ages 19 and 65 ought to include, on a wider basis, those who have already registered under selective service, excepting only those who have actually been inducted into the armed forces.

Declaring that "war does not stop research in the United States -- it spurs intensified study and work," David Sarnoff, President of the Radio Corporation of America, predicted in a year-end statement yesterday that "the specific achievements of this period of national emergency will come to light in later years in much the same way that the wartime developments of the radiophone, short waves and the vacuum tube were revealed after the Armistice in 1918."

A loan exhibition of the Dutch painter van Gogh's works will be held in January at the gallery of Paul Rosenberg Co., 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, for the benefit of the American Red Cross, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The following communique from Hong Kong's now surrendered garrison was issued there Thursday morning and received here by Renter:

Patrons of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra who do not like to stray far from the established symphonies of Beethoven, Brahms, Tchaikovsky and the like did not have much to celebrate at last night's Carnegie Hall concert conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos.

Today, somewhat anticlimactically but inevitably, is the Day After Christmas, Tinsel and crumpled wrapping paper trail dejectedly about the house, the first few needles have fallen from the Christmas tree, and a partly devoured turkey sits sadly in the refrigerator.
Now that the Northern hunting and fishing are about over for the Winter, letters have begun to arrive from sportsmen who have saved vacation time and want to sample the possibilities in the South.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Much has been written, and with some justification, criticizing the Office of Civilian Defense for the apparent lack of proper preparedness to cope with possible air raids in this city. However, much more has been unsaid. What has been unsaid is equally important.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 25 -- It is reported in informed circles here that dealers in foodstuffs are being urged to board as part of the fifth column propaganda seeking to provoke an economic crisis and to persuade the Mexican masses that rising food prices are caused by the United States' demands.

Bishop William T. Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York yesterday circularized the clergy under his jurisdiction asking that New Year's Day be observed as a day of special intercession for the nation. The text of his letter follows:

The unanimous decision of the Supreme Court in the case of the Virginia Electric and Power Company will greatly reduce at least one serious ambiguity presented by the Wagner act. This concerns the extent to which the act restricts the employer's freedom of utterance.

Feminine ears returned to public notice when the upswept hairdress came in again for daytime coiffure many months ago and since then have received more attention than for a decade past. Flourishing concurrently with their reappearance is the vogue for ear ornaments, in every price range and type of design.

BLOCKS of glassy ice, embedded lights shining from them, line the winding streets of Lake Placid. The ridge poles of the sprawling Lake Placid Club are etched in colored lanterns against the night sky and the Olympic Arena flares with all the gayety of Broadway and Forty-second Street. Once more for the fun Of it the little Adirondack village is entertaining the young folks over the Christmas holidays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A war expenditures program totaling $78,212,000,000 has been authorized by this country to date, the Bureau of Research and Statistics of the Office of Production Management announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Colonel Eugene L. Eubank, of the Air Corps, has been recommended by the War Department to receive the Distinguished Flying Cross "for heroism and extraordinary achievement" in leading a mass flight of heavy four-engine bombers from San Francisco to the Philippine Islands just before the beginning of the war, it was announced here today.
Deep gravity and concern tool the glittering edge off Christina throughout the world yesterday Peoples in all continents and in all climes found the Star of Peace obscured by war clouds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- This is not the moment to pass judgment upon the delicate political problems raised by the bold action of Vice Admiral Emile Muselier, the Free French Navy leader, in St. Pierre and Miquelon yesterday. Considerations of opportunity may prove supreme in the present juncture and they vary from day to day.
PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Dec. 25 (AP) -- An admiral in command of a combatant force of United States warships said today that "the lesson of the Dec. 7 attack has been taken to heart."

The Burlington Mills Corporation, manufacturer of textiles, had net earnings of $3,373,558 for the twelve months ended on Sept. 27, according to a report issued for publication today. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $4.87 a share on the common stock.

With more than 109,000 blossoms arriving in the city by train and truck during the past few days, carnations are the outstanding choice in the flower market this week end. Although 220,000 carnations weree offered for sale here at the same time last year, the supply still is considered abundant.
Christmas in the Far East found American forces in the Philippines fighting -- as they long knew they would have to fight -- with their backs to the wall.
NEW YORK Carlos Martins, the Brazilian Ambassador, and Mrs. Martins are expected to arrive at the St. Regis today from Washington.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The opening of a direct radio-telegraphic communications system between this country and Australia was recorded by the State Department tonight through the release of an exchange of messages over the new system between President Roosevelt and John Curtin, the Commonwealth's Prime Minister.

BERNE Switzerland, Friday, Dec. 26 -- German forces on the Russian front continued in yesterday's fighting their headlong retreat from strategically important centers as the various Russian offensives from Moscow to Kharkov took on more of an appearance of a connected front on which one of the largest counter-offensives in history is ending its third week.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I note that a proposal has been submitted by certain farm groups under price-control legislation for a price ceiling on farm products at 182 per cent of parity.

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Vice Admiral Emile Muselier and his Free French naval forces took over the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon because the population wanted such action, the Free French headquarters here said in a statement issued tonight after the United States State Department's criticism of the occupation.

Mrs. George F. Baker will head the Manhattan Women's Committee of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Leon Fraser, general chairman of the city-wide appeal for $7,330,000 toward the national goal of $50,000,000.
Used to doing things in a big way, New York City strove yesterday to make its first wartime Christmas since 1917 an all-out celebration that no one who shared it would ever forget.
GARDEN SCHEDULE TONIGHT 8:30 -- Frank Kovacs vs. Donald Budge. 9:30 -- Robert Riggs vs. Fred Perry 11:00 -- Riggs and Kovacs vs. Budge and Perry.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 25 -- Just thirty-six days after the start of Britain's offensive in Libya, Royal Dragoons, followed by other British troops, drove into Bengazi yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Dr. Alexander Lowy, internationally recognized authority in the field of organic chemistry and professor in that subject at the University of Pittsburgh, died today after an illness of four months. He was born in New York fifty-two years ago.

The American Government takes a stern view of the seizure by Free French forces of St. Pierre and Miquelon, two small islands off the coast of Newfoundland which are chiefly distinguished because they constitute the oldest foothold of "France D'outre-mer." The bloodless investiture of these surprised islands by four little warships under command of Admiral Emile Muselier was accomplished with a display of style and manners in the best tradition of Alexandre Dumas.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 25 (AP) -- Lake Placid's twenty-first annual college Winter sports carnival opens tomorrow, with Colgate seeking a third straight triumph in the hockey tourney, opening event on the ten-day agenda.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Hardy, bare-footed Sarawak troops, descendants of Borneo headhunters, were reported rallying tonight against Japanese Invasion forces that landed yesterday at Kuching, the capital of the oil-rich kingdom of the "White Rajah" in British Borneo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Once the representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations had agreed to recommend that there be no strikes during the war, the delegates of industry never had a chance to stand out for the status quo in the matter of the closed shop.

New York Pattern Twenty nationalities were represented in a pre-Christmas service of good-will in the Yorkville district. One of the speakers claimed for Yorkville the distinction of harboring a greater diversity of nationalities, faiths and traditions than any other section in the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The War Department announced today that the interceptor commanders and "their designated agencies" now had sole responsibility for initiating orders for blackouts, radio silence and discontinuance of other activities which might help the enemy in finding its objective.

Since yesterday was Christmas 1941 -- and a very good day to file fondly in the pages of our mental memory books -- it was apt and oddly moving for the Roxy to bring in a sweetly nostalgic picture entitled "Remember the Day." Other local theatres, in a wholesale barrage of new films, may have enticed their patrons with more noisy or more topical fare.

A COUPLE of weeks ago I was driving through Vermont from White River Junction to Barre. The fog was thick, something more appropriate to the Grand Banks than the cold northern hills, and as it struck the wind-shield it kept freezing. Every mile or so I piled out to rub the pane clear of ice. Finally, exasperated with Vermont, with fog, and with useless windshield wipers, I pulled into a gas station.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Establishment of a Small Business Unit in the Department of Commerce to coordinate the activities which are of use to proprietors of small manufacturing and distributing firms in the war period was announced today by Secretary Jesse Jones.

LONDON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The story of a 30-hour pursuit of a German tanker, possibly a submarine tender, with its eventual sinking off Northern Spain under attack by relays of various types of British aircraft, was told in an Air Ministry communique this afternoon.

FORT JACKSON, S.C. -- Thousands of soldiers who took first furloughs and spent Christmas at home are scheduled to return here tomorrow (Sunday) to allow a second group to leave on ten-day holiday furloughs which will have them home for New Years.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 26 -- Netherland raiding forces, out to destroy "an enemy ship a day," have sunk another Japanese destroyer or transport off British Sarawak in the area where they sent a destroyer to the bottom yesterday, a Netherland communique announced today.

HONOLULU, Dec. 26 (U.P) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, new commander of the United States Pacific Fleet, has arrived in the Hawaiian area preparatory to assuming command, the fleet headquarters announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Greatly increased armament production by the United States in 1942, fulfillment of lease lend aid to Soviet Russia and some forward steps in the plan for an international defense of Singapore, particularly in the naval and air sense, were reported to have been agreed upon today in Anglo-American conferences at the White House.

Even if the struggle for the Philippines and British Malaya did not remind us that there is a war in the Far East in the outcome of which we are vitally concerned, we would know it because of the pass to which we have been reduced for lack of rubber. For rubber is the one major essential that we must import in enormous quantities.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- California oil producers today were requested to cut down petroleum output to individual quotas established under a governmentapproved conservation plan to assure a constant supply of oil for war in the Pacific.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed reserve note circulation and holdings of government securities for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 -- American patrol work in the air and on the sea appeared today to have put a temporary damper on the activities of enemy submarines off the California coast.

The Church Life Insurance Corporation has increased its capital from $100,000 to $250,000 by means of a stock dividend, with approval of the New York State Department of Insurance, it was announced yesterday by Bradford B. Locke, executive vice president.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Wheat "prices held within a, range of 1/4 cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade, with outside and professional interest limited. Brokers said the aggregate sales of grain futures was the smallest for any single day since August, 1933, when the total in all pits was 3,159,000 bushels.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Twin invasion drives on each side of the rugged backbone down the middle of Malaya met mounting resistance as British reinforcements bulwarked the defenses and the natives, including many Chinese recruits, fought the Japanese.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 26 -- The bulk of the retreating German and Italian force in Libya was trying desperately today to stave off complete disaster by standing and fighting heavy rear-guard actions near Agedabia.

This country will adhere to provisions of the Geneva convention relative to the treatment of prisoners of war and "hopes" that Japan, which has not ratified the agreement, will reciprocate, according to word received yesterday from the State Department by Dr. Darius A. Davis, executive secretary for war prisoners' aid of the World Alliance of Y.M.C.A.'s.
Misfortune struck the professional tennis tour, presenting Robert Riggs and Frank Kovacs the top two amateurs of 1941, on its opening night at Madison Square Garden last night.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26 -- Dr. and Mrs. Daniel J. McCarthy were dinner hosts at Blarneagh tonight to Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer, who are their house guests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company of Kansas City, Mo., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $10,000,000 of 3 per cent first mortgage and first lien bonds, Series C, due 1962, and 150,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

Organization of Morgan Stanley Co. as a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, effective on Jan. 8, was announced yesterday by the Stock Exchange. Partners will be Harold Stanley, Henry S. Morgan (general and limited partner), Perry E. Hall, John M. Young, A.N. Jones, E.H. York Jr., A. Shriver, S.B. Emerson and William Ewing (limited partner).
Two apartment houses in Jersey City and one in Hackensack were among the New Jersey properties reported yesterday to have passed into new hands.

Exports of steel in 1941 were sharply lower than in 1940. For the first eleven months they represented 7.54 per cent of production of finished and semi-finished steel products, against 13.06 per cent in all of 1940, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Now that the annual Fishing Guide has been issued by the Martin County (Fla.) Chamber of Commerce we can rest assured that the Southern fishing season is definitely under way, with sailfish lying inside the Gulf Stream off St. Lucie inlet in good numbers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The American-Filipino forces defending the main line of Manila defenses in the Philippines today stopped Japanese attackers advancing from Lingayen Gulf, and fighting in that sector tonight turned into "heavy artillery dueling."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The name of James A. Farley cropped up today in informal discussions concerning the membership of the new war labor board which President Roosevelt has agreed to establish to handle industrial disputes.
BERLIN, Dec. 26 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command, communique today follows:

Lieut. Col. Randolfo Pacciardi, who founded and commanded the Garibaldi Anti-Fascist Brigade for the Loyalists in Spain at their victory over the Italians at Guadalajara, arrived yesterday on the Portuguese liner Serpa Pinto to organize a free Italian military unit in the United States along the lines of the de Gaulle Free French forces.

The cost of food mounts slowly but steadily. Between mid-October and mid-November retail prices increased 1.3 per cent, with the largest advances reported for eggs and fresh fruits and vegetables such as apples, bananas, carrots and green beans. Seasonal increases in these foods, however, are to be expected in the late Fall and early Winter.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Intensive training in defense against chemical warfare was given this week to soldiers stationed at Fort Slocum.
The holiday brought a spurt in business among Broadway's major film theatres with the reports by managements yesterday of record and near-record Christmas attendances.

The survey of housing accommodations for women, children, the aged and infirm who might have to be evacuated from New York City in case of bombing raids has been completed in three up-State counties, Edward Weinfeld, State Housing Commissioner, reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 -- The 800 employes of Jack Heintz, Inc., a recently established war production plant which has more than $20,000,000 of government orders, declared today that the company had outdone Santa Claus.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Downtown quarterbacks today established the Southern team as 1-2 favorite for the fourth annual North-South all-star football game tomorrow.

From the evidence on hand thus far it appears that there will be little curtailment in the number of books published in the coming season although it will be impossible to judge accurately until more publishers have made known their plans.

Sermons on the responsibilities of the new year with this country at war will be preached tomorrow. In all pulpits announcements will be made of the observance next Thursday, New Year's Day, by proclamation of President Roosevelt of a day of prayer to ask forgiveness "for our shortcomings of the past, of consecration to the task of the present, of asking God's help in days to come."

BERLIN, Dec. 26 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- The German High Command said today that Russian attacks along the Donets River had been repulsed with heavy losses and that Italian and Slovak troops had participated in the defense.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26 -- Having consolidated their positions after the capture of Zarusa and Alexin, northwest of Tula, General Ivan V. Boldin's forces were driving westward along the Oka River today toward the ancient city of Kaluga, whose capture would seriously endanger the German's forward positions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Winston Churchill, the first wartime Prime Minister of Great Britain ever to address the Congress of the United States, told that body today that anti-Axis forces probably will be able to undertake a world-wide offensive in 1943.
JUNCTION CITY, Kan., Dec. 26 -- Ninety-six second lieutenants received commissions at graduation exercises Tuesday morning at the second officer candidate school of the Fort Riley Cavalry School.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 27 -- Prime Minister Churchill's speech was broadcast yesterday on all wave-lengths, and the British public for the first time in history heard a Prime Minister addressing the United States Congress.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 26 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Netherlands Indies fighting forces today issued the following communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Prime Minister Churchill's address was described by Senator Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, as "a demonstration of the fine unity that exists between the United States and Great Britain."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Donald M. Nelson, OPM Priorities Director, today relaxed the restrictions on rubber consumption to permit continued manufacture of fire hose and other fire-extinguishing apparatus. Officials pointed out that fire hose is essential for protection of property in the event of incendiary bomb raids.

OTTAWA, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Further restrictions on consumer credit buying, affecting installment purchases, charge accounts, lay-away plans, financing charges and advertising were announced today by the Wartime Prices and Trade Board.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read your editorial of Dec. 18, "False Alignments," and the letter written to you by C. Diamantopoulos, the Minister of Greece, attacking Hungary and Bulgaria. I, as an American of Hungarian origin, would like to say a few words for Hungary.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A government communique today said the Chinese attacks on the Canton-Kowloon railway, originally designed to relieve the siege of Hong Kong, were "developing satisfactorily."

Some of history's high moments are unseen except in retrospect, when a certain event is shown by its train of consequences to have started a tide in the affairs of men. Others, like Winston Churchill's speech in the Senate, are instantly recognized as they occur. In the grave, quick cadences of the Prime Minister's address to America, every listener felt in his own pulse the beat of history.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: It is usually too much to expect any all-star football team to defeat a tested veteran combination, but I confidently expect to see the National Football League all-stars lick the Chicago Bears when they meet at the Polo Grounds on Jan. 4.

Clifford Odets's latest play, "Clash by Night," starring Tallulah Bankhead, finally will make its local debut this evening at the Belasco Theatre. It originally had been due to arrive as early as last April, but was temporarily shelved because of casting difficulties.

Every time a college football player carried a ball over the goal or booted an extra point or field goal last Fall he was, without realizing it, doing his bit to establish the outstanding trend in sports for the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A general meeting of Russian women at the temporary capital of Kuibyshev has sent a message to the women of the United States and Great Britain calling for "one antiFascist front to unite all forces" to combat Hitlerism, it was learned tonight through a radiogram received at the Soviet Embassy.

The stock market attempted another recovery yesterday, but weakness in some of the high-grade issues caused it to close irregular. Tax selling in these prime investment issues on the Stock Exchange cast a chill over the share list, although some buying appeared in the shares of the heavy industry sections when Prime Minister Churchill supported recent statements of President Roosevelt concerning a long war.

Many football fans in this area either received cash gifts for Christmas or else did not spend all their spare dollars during the Yuletide shopping spree. That was apparent yesterday when a strong public demand was made for tickets for the benefit game on Jan. 4 between the Chicago Bears and the National League All-Stars at the Polo Grounds.

OTTAWA, Dec. 26 -- A comment attributed to Prime Minister King on his way to Washington -- that he believed the situation in St. Pierre and Miquelon was "mainly a matter between the French and the Free French" -- had wide approval today in Canada, where public sentiment, with some exception, is strongly behind the action of Admiral Muselier.

From Dec. 8, when the United States declared war against Japan, until Dec. 23, only 2,400 persons in Manhattan had registered for training in civilian defense courses and for volunteer work in health and welfare agencies, Mrs. A.J. Lamme Jr., chairman of the placement division of the Manhattan Branch of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, 93 Park Avenue, revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Major Gen. Millard F. Harmon, commander of the Second Air Force at Fort George Wright, Washington, is reported to have been selected as successor to Lieut. Gen. Delos Emmons as chief of the Army Air Force Combat Command.

An apartment in 15 East Thirty-sixth Street has been leased through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, Inc., brokers, by Thomas L. Johnson, president of the Tohickon Hosiery Company and vice president of the Alka Manufacturing and Sales Company.

Mr. Williams's piece in this newspaper about the plum, duff served on Christmas Eve to British sailors was a dish to be relished by mind and memory even more than palate, though it was a good shoehorn for the night's English plum pudding. "Duff" is a lovely word; a Cinderella that began life as a mispronunciation of "dough."

The volume or money in circulation" has just risen above $11,000,000,000 for the first time in history. This represents a rise of more than $2,300,000,000 in the past twelve months and an increase of nearly $500,000,000 in the past month. Obviously no such enormous sum as this is actually "in circulation."
Following is the text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address to the Congress yesterday, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

CAMP CROFT, S.C., Dec. 26 -- With only 2,000 of its 16,550 soldiers and seventy-five officers away, this infantry replacement training center celebrated an "at home" Christmas on Thursday -- marked by the consumption of about a ton of young torn turkey, delivery of the heaviest load of mail in the post's history and a wide round of community parties.

Miss Faith Griswold Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Griswold Hall of 1120 Fifth Avenue, was introduced to society last night at a dinner dance given by her parents in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Receiving with Mrs. Hall and her daughter were Mrs. Jefferson Armstrong and Mrs. Harold A. Throckmorton, sisters of the debutante, and Miss Margaret Nichols of Bronxville, N.Y., Miss Hall's roommate at Vassar College.

Proving that his Christmas Eve auto accident held no serious consequences for him, Buddy Baer, California heavyweight, resumed training at Lakewood, N.J., yesI terday for his fifteen-round return bout with Joe Louis, world champion, Jan. 9, in Madison Square Garden for the Navy Relief Fund.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The United States Lawn Tennis Association would be totally unjustified, in my opinion, in altering the 1941 individual rankings so as to exclude Bobby Riggs and Frankie Kovacs, the No. 1 and No. 2 selections on the recently published list.
"Swing your partner" is one command that will be obeyed with gusto tonight by service men.

BENDIX, N.J., Dec. 26 -- At an election this afternoon and tonight of 250 Air Associates, Inc., employes, members of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O., unanimous approval was given to a proposed contract that may mean the return of the company to private management.

A joint Congressional and departmental committee has recommended for the fiscal year 1943 Federal savings of $1,301,075,000. This is not quite 20 per cent of the nondefense spending budgeted for the current fiscal year. The committee urges the abolition of the Civilian Conservation Corps and the National Youth Administration, at a saving of $338,727,000, and calls for cuts of $400,000,000 in WPA, $400,622,000 in aids to agriculture and $161,726,000 in public works and highway expenditures.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP) -- The nation's stability will not be upset by the realities of war, Dr. G. Kirby Collier, psychiatrist, asserted today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Surplus Marketing Administration bought agricultural commodities valued at more than $73,000,000 during November, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 26 -- Prime Minister John Curtin in a national broadcast said today that the watchwords of the New Year must be unstinted service, undaunted courage and unswerving determination. He warned Australia to prepare for further reverses in the Pacific before the tide turned in favor of the Allies.

George Roberts, law partner of Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, was named yesterday by Leon Fraser, general chairman of the Greater New York Red Cross War Fund, to head the men's special gifts committee for the campaign to raise $7,330,000, the city's quota of the $50,000,000 national goal.

Men's Wear for Sales Ample Local men's wear stores will have larger stocks of Fall and Winter merchandise for the clearance sales starting next week than they did a year ago, reports yesterday indicated. Business in the final quarter of last year was so brisk that carryover stocks were small and fill-ins could not be obtained.
NEW YORK Mrs. Howland S. Davis will give a reception at her home, 150 East Seventy-third Street, today for Miss Charlotte Whitman, debutante daughter of Mrs. Sturgis Whitman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26 -- Dorothy Comingore, Orson Welles's leading lady in "Citizen Kane," who has been suspended from salary at RKO for the last six months because she refused two assignments, will return to the screen in "The Little Pinks," if she accepts the leading feminine role, it was learned today.

Mayor La Guardia again warned the people of the city to keep cool under air raids as Boy Scouts began the distribution of 18,000 illustrated posters informing the public on the best means of protection against air attacks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 24:
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 26 -- Christmas was observed quietly at Fort Du Pont, although almost all of the men spent the holiday on the post, or within a short distance of it.

Winning two games, drawing one and postponing another, the chess players of Brooklyn College yesterday made a promising start in defense of the Harold M. Phillips Trophy by defeating Cooper Union by 2 1/2 -- 1/2 in the first round of the annual tournament for the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club, 23 West Tenth Street.

MANILA, Saturday, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces at Binalonan are retreating, The Manila Bulletin reported this morning. The fighting around Binalonan, on the road to Manila from Lingayen Gulf, was not very heavy, the newspaper added.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Emergency legislation designed to set up a uniform approach, to problems arising from the war will be submitted to the Legislatures of at least eight States in 1942.
FORT DIX, Dec. 26 -- Two of three indoor target ranges, constructed at a cost of more than $100,000, will be opened for training infantry troops here next week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- John H. Sorrells of Pelham Manor, N.Y., since 1930 executive editor of the Scripps-Howard newspapers, and John H. Ryan, vice president and general manager of the Industry Company of Toledo, Ohio, owners and operators of six radio stations, were appointed assistant directors of censorship today.

Recruiting activities by all branches of the armed forces were resumed at a brisk pace early yesterday morning, following the Christmas holiday, but recruiting officers still are expecting the big upsurge to start after the first of the year.

A plan that will enable law students to complete their studies in two calendar years instead of three is now being studied by the deans of schools preparing students for the New York bar, it was learned yesterday. It was devised because of the lowering of the draft age to 20 and because of the inroads of the draft on law school students.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 26 -- The Serbian armies of General Draja Mikhailovitch have renewed their large-scale attacks upon German forces in Central and Western Serbia and German garrisons have been dislodged from much of the territory recaptured from the Serbs in the early December fighting, according to reports to foreign military and intelligence sources here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 -- Contrary to the declared intention of welders strike leaders in the East Bay area, pickets failed to appear today at shipyards or other defense plants to continue the welders' protest against the American Federation of Labor.

ED KELLEHER has his fingers crossed so firmly these days that he is very likely to acquire a permanent twist in both hands. He has a potentially great Fordham basketball team playing for him this season, probably the best that has cavorted on the Rose Hill courts in a dozen years.

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Dec. 26 -- With soldiers receiving many gifts from relatives and friends and Christmas decorations in abundance everywhere, the holiday spirit prevails here in no little degree.

I READ Forrest Davis's "The Atlantic System"* before Dec. 7, when I was still hoping that our participation in the struggles which were then limited to Europe, Africa and Asia could be kept "short of war." But Forrest Davis had no illusions about the American future, even though he finished his book before we were attacked at Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma introduced a bill today to establish a national saving's fund which he said would kill the "numbers racket, slot machines, pinball nickel-grabbers and bookie establishments."

VICHY, France, Dec. 26 -- "French official circles have received with, satisfaction the news that the Federal Government [in Washington] has publicly condemned the initiative taken against its knowledge and against its sentiment by former Admiral Muselier at St. Pierre and Miquelon."

An organization meeting of prospective school defense aides was held yesterday afternoon in the Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, 131 Livingston Street. More than 150 women formed the nucleus of a suggested group numbering 2,000, which will assist in the protection of public school children in case of air raids.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- About a quarter of the personnel of Major Gen. Henry W. Baird's Fourth Armored Division at Pina Camp passed Christmas at the houses of members. A strike of bus drivers and a shortage of railroad passenger equipment created some transportation problems, but those on leave who own cars helped by loading their vehicles to capacity.

In The Bill of Rights Review Attorney General Biddle's paper, read at the National Conference of Social Work, appears under the title "Civil Rights in Times of Stress." The fact that it was written before our entry into war makes it not less but even more pertinent to the greater stress to which the country is now exposed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Winston Churchill is a master phrasemaker and passages from his addresses have a majestic cadence. Highest honors for a single sentence probably go to eleven words Churchill uttered on May 13, 1940, after Great Britain had dropped the Chamberlain government and was adjusting itself to the prospect of total war.

As the Fire Department prepared to give its highest funeral honors this morning to the first hero of Its emergency auxiliary corps, Commissioner Patrick Walsh declared last night that the city's voluntary defense firemen were ready, despite lack of special equipment and adequate numbers, to give full protection "if there should be an air raid tonight."

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Receipts of hogs at most major livestock centers today showed a substantial decline from last Friday, but the salable run here was about the same as a week ago and prices were only steady to 10 cents a hundredweight down. Eastern shippers gave the market much of its support, taking 4,000 head.
The cotton market drifted lower in quiet trading yesterday and final values on the New York Cotton Exchange were at their lows for the day, at net losses of 10 to 11 points.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Dec. 27 -- Russian troops in the central Moscow sector registered important gains in yesterday's fighting as their long-awaited general frontal attack appeared to get under way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Senators, looking ahead to ultimate victory over the Axis, are already discussing peace terms. Senator Lucas of Illinois said today that "Japan should be reduced to the point where for 1,000 years she will have no control or force in the family of nations."

ON THE NORTHERN MALAYA FRONT, Dec. 24 (delayed) -- Even the most confident Japanese generals cannot hope that their land advance in Malaya can be converted into an immediate threat to Singapore's back door, but the land offensive will undoubtedly be pushed with the utmost effort to obtain air bases even more advanced than those already in Japanese hands.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Members of Congress greeted with, enthusiasm today the speech of Prime Minister Churchill and many referred to it as the "greatest" they had ever heard.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 26 -- British headquarters announced tonight without explanation that there was Japanese patrol activity north of Kemaman, which is on the east coast of Malaya only 175 miles north of Singapore.

CAMP WHEELER, Ga., Dec. 26 -- Commending the American Red Cross for its "invaluable contributions of comfort and cheer to the nation's armed forces," Brig. Gen. U.R. Emery, camp commander, started a supplementary fund drive last night aimed at meeting a quota of $31,000 in the district of Macon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- As yet unsung, but undoubtedly as gallant and as determined as were the defenders of Wake Island, a band of United States fighting men apparently still holds Midway Island.

Gayly hued birds, composing the greatest collection of Colombian feathered wild life ever exhibited at one time in a zoological garden, will be placed on display at noon today in the Bronx Zoo, it was announced yesterday. Consul General Abel Cruz-Santos of Colombia and other officials of that nation will attend the opening ceremony, a feature of the Zoo's holiday season.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 26 -- Reports circulating today in high foreign military and diplomatic circles at Istanbul said that the German High Command, under the personal direction of Adolf Hitler, was expected to launch a massive offensive in Africa and the Near East before March 1.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, yesterday called upon the 7,000 churches of that communion to observe next Thursday, as a special Day of Prayer. He endorsed wholeheartedly the proclamation of President Roosevelt setting aside the first day of the new year for that purpose.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Bank of England note circulation continued its uninterrupted rise for the sixteenth consecutive week, the total being lifted to the new high record of L751,245,000 as of Wednesday. Early this month the Treasury authorized a L50,000,000 increase in the fiduciary note issue, making a total of L780,000,000.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 25 (Delayed) -- The 3,000,000 Chinese in Malaya are to be mobilized against the Japanese invasion as a result of decisions taken today at a meeting of Chinese leaders with the Governor, Sir Shenton Thomas.

New bond financing this week was restricted to the formal offering to the public of only two new loans, aggregating $7,833,000. This compared with $36,461,000 in new bonds marketed last week, and with $9,500,000 offered in this week a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Adjustment of the St. Pierre-Miquelon situation by withdrawal of the Free French occupying forces was indicated as probable today through a joint stand to be taken by the United States, Britain, Canada, and the Vichy government.

Standard Brands, Inc., announced yesterday that it would not transfer the Chase Sanborn coffee account from J. Walter Thompson Company to another agency. On Nov. 1 the company had made known that the account would be handled by Kenyon Eckhardt in the future and that plans for 1942 were in preparation.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente, ruling yesterday in a minority stockholders' suit against present and former directors of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, upheld the corporation's bonus and incentive compensation system, but held that the directors must return to the corporation sums estimated at $1,100,000 which was paid out of corporate funds in the settlement of earlier stockholder actions based on similar charges.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday that he would appoint the first city-wide Sheriff and citywide Register at noon today from lists given to him yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission. Civil Service tests were held for both positions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Since the United States entered the war President Roosevelt has received more than 200 telegrams from foreign-born groups and individuals, citizens and non-citizens, pledging loyalty and cooperation.

Considerable success in making newsprint from pine slashings has been reported by the Southland Paper Mills, Inc., which opened its first 50,000-ton unit at Lufkin, Texas, Jan. 1, 1940. For the first eleven months of the present year the net profits were $295,000, it was reported yesterday.

A banking group composed of the Chase National Bank, Salomon Brothers Hutzler and R.W. Pressprich Co., received yesterday the award of an issue of $4,000,000 city of Boston tax-anticipation notes at an interest rate of 0.92 per cent, plus a premium of $32.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- The War Office day by day account of the siege of Hong Kong, made public today, shows that the garrison never had the remotest chance of holding the colony.

To enforce a demand that Loew's, Inc., withhold Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer films from independent theatres employing nonunion projectionists, Local 306 of the Moving-Picture Machine Operators Union, A.F. of L., threatened yesterday to call a strike of 400 operators, all union members, in sixty-five Loew theatres in New York City.
Two business property sales in Manhattan led the city realty trading reported yesterday by brokers.

In last night's performance of Mozart's "Don Giovanni," conducted by Bruno Walter at the Metropolitan Opera House, the role of Don Ottavio was assumed by Richard Crooks for the first time this season. Don Ottavio can easily become a lay figure, but Mr. Crooks lent a vitality and dignity to his interpretation that gave it the human values Mozart obviously intended.

What American would have dared to predict even twelve months ago that within the year the Prime Minister of Great Britain, by unanimous invitation, would have been addressing Congress in Washington? That event, with its enormous symbolic value, will be recognized years hence as a landmark in the history of England and America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The question whether the British Empire will act as a unit in any Supreme War Council or other body set up to coordinate the strategy of the anti-Axis nations or whether the British dominions will have separate representation has been raised by the arrival in Washington today of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King of Canada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Department store sales during the last week before Christmas rose 7 per cent over the corresponding week of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Revised figures for the previous week show a gain of 2 per cent over 1940.
FORT BENNING, Dec. 26 -- Preparing for any eventuality, this Army center observed a half-hour blackout yesterday under orders from Brig.-Gen. Omar N. Bradley, post commander.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Prime Minister Churchill was immensely pleased and touched by the unprecedented demonstration which followed his speech before Congress. In a brief and moving speech at a luncheon in the Capitol he told Congressional leaders: "It is the finest compliment I have ever received."

It will be Southern California against Long Island University and Rice Institute against Fordham tonight in the first of three intersectional college basketball doubleheaders within four nights at Madison Square Garden.

Edward L. Parker, 36 years old, Professor of English at New York University, was arrested last night on a charge of felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law, after admitting, police said, that he had stuck a sharp-pointed hunting knife into the back of Donald McQuiston, 18 years old, of 15 Park Avenue, Bronxville.

The report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and certain of its subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year, issued yesterday by Sosthenes Behn, president, shows a consolidated net loss of $356,330, after expenses and charges, compared with a loss of $402,257 in the first nine months of 1940.

TORONTO, Dec. 26 -- As Canadians turn, their attention ahead to the war effort of the coming year, two salient facts regarding their attitude are revealed in surveys by the Canadian Institute of Public Opinion.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Four assistants to Emerson (Spike) Nelson, who resigned as head football coach at Yale, and Reginald Root, former varsity gridiron coach and present head mentor of the Eli freshmen, have been notified by the university that their services will not be required after June.

Wartime restrictions temporarily immobilizing most of the smallboat fishing fleet along the southern shore of Long Island were placed in effect yesterday to the consternation of scores of wouldbe fishermen.
FORT BRAGG, N.C., Dec. 26 -- Brig. Gen. John A. Crane of the field artillery made extensive inspections of the men and material of his command this week.
Despite their geographical isolation and the numerical weakness of the defending forces, the Philippines still flew the American flag yesterday.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 26 (AP) -- R.H. Macy Co. announced today it will close tomorrow the experimental merchandising unit which it has maintained in Syracuse for the past year.

Christmas gifts for New York's neediest men, women and children, sent on Christmas Eve or Christmas Day, poured in yesterday in a heartening flow. These contributions, totaling $6,287.20, and in- creasing the Neediest Cases Fund to $228,412, thus extended the work of mercy that the eight important private charity organizations participating in the appeal will be able to do in the coming months among the most distressed families and individuals known to them.

CHUNGKING, Dec. 26 (U.P.) -- A Chinese communique today regarding the conferences of Generals Brett and Wavell with Chiang Kaishek said the "problems discussed were concerned with joint war action of the democratic countries" and that a Military Council, the first Allied council of this war, was created.

Declaring that the "tone in our millions of homes will determine the tone of the nation," the Child Study Association of America announced the publication yesterday of a fifteen-page pamphlet of advice to parents on caring for the emotional well-being of children during wartime.
Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANTS -- Thomas E. O'Neill, from 43d Precinct to Brooklyn West and Richmond Headquarters, for 15 days, from 8 A.M., Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The War Department issued the following communique today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a proposal under which the National Power and Light Company would offer 500,000 shares of the Houston Lighting and Power Company's common stock in exchange for National Power and Light's outstanding preferred stock.

The weekly Federal Reserve figures, one day late this week on account of the holiday, revealed no extensive banking support for the government bond market. The combined statement of the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System, as of the close of business on Wednesday, showed an increase of only $3,397,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Major. Gen. H.D.G. Crerar, commander of the Second Canadian Division has just arrived in Britain with thousands more Canadian troops, airmen and special service forces. It was announced today that General Crerar will take acting command of the whole Canadian Corps during the absence of Lieut. Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton on sick leave.

Although Christmas trade in hosiery was frankly disappointing for many stores and the carry-over of all-silk types was surprisingly large, selling agents said yesterday that they still expect a good demand for whatever silk numbers they are able to offer for shipment during the first quarter.

Gay laughter of children filled the Heckscher Theatre yesterday afternoon during the opening performance of "The Emperor's New Clothes," produced by the Young Theatre Players. With color and song the play, based on Hans Christian Andersen's story, delighted the youngsters and brought forth a chuckle or two from older folks.

An official stamp of approval that has just been placed on the Girl Scout program by the National Catholic Welfare Conference, made known yesterday, clears the way for expansion of the organization within the ranks of that denomination, and for what may become a greatly accelerated participation by girls eligible for membership in the activities connected with national defense.

Eight first-grade detectives, who have conducted all confidential investigative work in Kinga County District Attorney William O'Dwyer's uncovering of the notorious Brooklyn murder ring, will return at 8 A.M. today to the precinct headquarters from which they were drawn nearly two years ago for the special detail.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: The holiday program of basketball double-headers at Madison Square Garden is bringing to New York representatives of virtually every important collegiate conference in the country-Southern California, Oregon State and Washington from the Pacific Coast; Rice, from the Southwest; Creighton, from the Missouri Valley, and Colorado and "Wyoming from the Rocky Mountain.

TOKYO, Dec. 26 (from Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Japanese completed the occupation of the fallen British fortress of Hong Kong at 11 A.M. today, the official news agency Domei announced, and the surviving British garrison -- estimated here to number 6,000 men -- was ordered to stack arms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- All the nation's average motorists -- including even traveling salesmen, taxi drivers and residents of isolated rural areas lacking other transportation -- will be prohibited from buying new automobile tires under eligibility requirements established today for the government's new tire rationing program.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- In a g-ame that started slowly but ended like a whirlwind, Colgate advanced to the second round in the annual intercollegiate invitation hockey tournament at this resort by beating M.I.T. of Cambridge, Mass., 6 to 5, tonight.

Shell of Peace Winston Churchill for his first White House breakfast is authoritatively reported to have had two poached eggs with all the familiar accessories. At home he gets one egg a week on his ration card.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 26 -- Fordham was up to some of its old tricks today. Battling Andy Kerr's Eastern All-Star team in a two-hour scrimmage on St. Stanislaus Field, the Rams had to rally to outscore their opponents, 12 -- 6.

Theatre, hotel and restaurant managements said yesterday that booking's for New Year's Eve, which have been slow to start because of the war, would begin with a rush on Monday and in some cases would tax their capacity.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Broadway made a contribution to Uncle Sam's Army this week, when a truckload of scenery, stage ma chinery, lights, etc., arrived at Port Ontario. The paraphernalia was set up in the recreation building at the post and will be used by the soldiers in dramatic productions.

BEAUMONT, Texas, Dec. 26 (AP) -- E.J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., blistered the Country Club course from start to finish today to take the eighteen-hole lead in the $5,000 Beaumont open with a 4-under-par 67.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

MANILA, Saturday, Dec. 27 -- The Japanese invaders struck yesterday with heavy force on the main Southern Luzon front, where a major tank battle raged inconclusively with heavy losses to both sides in the Lamon Bay area, but the Japanese limited their offensive action in the more vital Lingayen Gulf sector in the north to strong and concentrated artillery fire.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York notified member banks yesterday that beginning on Jan. 1 ownership certificates must be filed by holders of United States Government obligations which have interest coupons, regardless of the date of issuance of such obligations.

Excess Reserves While excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $45,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $935,000,000, according to figures made available yesterday, excess funds of the Reserve System as a whole declined $30,000,000 to $3,060,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I had occasion this afternoon to visit City Hall with a guest, to whom I was showing the beauties of New York City. To my amazement, I noticed that the East Room of the Governor's chambers was occupied by a group of uncivil people who claimed to represent the Office of Civilian Defense.

ST. PIERRE-MIQUELON, Dec. 26 -- While at least four world capitals -- Washington, Ottawa, London and Vichy -- were experiencing such mixed emotions that the buzz of them reached even this obscure and isolated island, Free French forces and newly freed Frenchmen were sitting pretty here today, rocking along blissfully in their own jubilant emotions.

An Increased interest in religion as a result of the war and disturbed conditions throughout the world was reported yesterday by Winfred Ernest Garrison, associate professor of church history at the University of Chicago, in a review of the year in religion, copyrighted by the Religious News Service.
CAMP UPTON, L.I., Dec. 27 -- The civilian personnel of this camp is on the increase, with both men and women being employed for duties formerly assigned to soldiers.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Armed with home-made hand grenades and a sub-machine gun, eight men held up a brewery cashier today, killed a guard and the driver of a commandeered automobile and wounded two other guards and a woman.

A request that should not go unheeded was made for the second time yesterday by Lieut. Col. George Clarke, morale officer at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn, to the Brooklyn-Long Island Division of the National Catholic Community Service (USO).

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 26 -- The first open indications of disagreement in matters of policy in the Fascist party hierarchy since Feb. 4 this year were announced this evening in a special communique" from Rome reading:

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Besides the immediate task of stemming the Japanese invasion of Malaya, Lieut. Gen. Sir Henry Pownall, new British Commander in Chief at Singapore, must coordinate Britain's Far Eastern military activity with that of her allies.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 26 -- Public choices fared poorly at Tropical Park today, and when the last race had been run, no favorite had graced the winners' circle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- minority report disagreeing sharply with proposals for slashing $1,716,965,061 from the government's non-defense outlays during the coming fiscal year was made today by members of the Congressional-Executive Department Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures.

SAN FRANCISCO. DESPITE blackouts and airraid alarms, cities of the Pacific slope, from Seattle to San Diego are giving support to an uncurtailed Winter season of music. Symphony orchestras are playing before audiences which in some instances bought season tickets in greater numbers than ever before.
To Map High Strategy The Prime Minister of Great Britain, Mr. Churchill, is now with Mr. Roosevelt in the White House.

The metropolitan district of New York is "particularly fortunate" with respect to the adequacy of its housing accommodations for defense workers, with only the Northern New Jersey section in need of any major amount of new living quarters for families of these workers, according to a report made public yesterday by the office of Charles F. Palmer, Defense Housing Coordinator.

By 1980 there will be only one child in the average family in this country, compared with three in 1790, Paul C. Glick of the United States Census Bureau forecast yesterday at the opening session of the thirty-sixth annual meeting of the American Sociological Society at the Hotel Roosevelt.

NEW YEAR'S DAY is the time when friends assemble to salute the future. It has been so here-about since the debonair gentlemen of Little Old New York in their gray beaver toppers made their round of calls from noon to midnight and the ladies stayed properly at home to receive them.

The last ten days of training confront Joe Louis, world heavy-weight champion, and Buddy Baer, California's giant challenger, for the title battle in which they will engage for the Navy Relief Fund Jan. 9 in Madison Square Garden.

HERE is an autobiography full of punches, none of them pulled. The gypsy in Konrad Bercovici makes him write with great gusto. There is a devil-may-care, take-it-or-leave-it attitude about the book, which by turns gives pleasure and exasperates.

Some method of control of prices of food will be instituted by the government as an essential part of the nation's war-time economy, Professor E.J. Working of the University of Illinois predicted yesterday at a panel discussion of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Commodore in conjunction with the annual meeting of the Allied Social Science Associations.

Fifty per cent of the nation's productive capacity will be devoted exclusively to armaments during the war. M. Joseph Meehan of the United States Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce declared yesterday at the 103d annual meeting of the Amercan Statistical Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

WHILE Christmas trade closed with a rush and the advantage of an extra shopping day, sales for the entire holiday period failed to come up to earlier estimates. The slow start and then the sudden impact of war proved to be handicaps too heavy to overcome.
