Realization that Federal tire rationing after Jan. 5 will prevent considerably more than 85 per cent of the nation's motor vehicle users from obtaining tires stunned automobile owners here yesterday.

Eighty per cent of Columbia College's freshman class could pass the Selective Service requirements for military duty, Dr. William H. McCastline, university medical officer, announced yesterday. This means that about 400 members of the class of 1945, one of the healthiest in the school's 188-year history, will be eligible for officerships in the country's armed forces, his report revealed.

WITH its flight deck loaded with swarms of reconnaissance, fighter, divebombing and torpedo planes, the aircraft carrier has materially cut the vastness of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. Cutting swiftly through blue water, this mobile landing field is the "eyes" of the fleet and, with its bombers and torpedo planes, the extended striking power.

AS these columns ventured toward the press the people who assemble radio programs comprising the year's leading events were working away at their annual stint and a pretty job they must have been having this time.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The British middle East Headquarters communique said today:

It is becoming more and more obvious that education has tremendous tasks ahead of it in a world whose future is so obscure that no man can even guess what it will be like in the next few years. What to educate people for is one of the problems.

MUCH has been written about the technique of copying the photographic print, so much, indeed, that one must wonder whether or not there is anything left to be said. Too little attention, however, has been paid to the positive transparency, to copying images that must be viewed by transmitted rather than by reflected light.

Determined to carry on regardless of what an uncertain future may have in store for them, the Brooklyn Dodgers, National League champions of 1941, yesterday announced the details of a Spring training campaign as enterprising and arduous as any mapped out for the Flatbush Flock since the advent of Larry MacPhail.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The undefeated Canisius basketball team routed Wyoming, Rocky Mountain champion, 56 -- 44, in the second game of a double-header tonight before 5,250 after Oregon State had beaten St. Bonaventure, 38-33.
With January snows comes the Winter flurry of white sales.

THE year which will end on Wednesday has been for stamp collectors a heavy one numerically. With philatelic developments influenced by events of the war, the total number of stamps thus far reported exceeds by more than 200 the number of major and minor varieties which appeared during the preceding calendar period.

THE Philadelphia Festival Society, Henry S. Drinker, president, will hold a ten-day Brahms festival Feb. 27-March 8 in Philadelphia, James Alien Dash, the festival's musical director, will lead the Brahms Festival Chorus, with Rose Bampton, soprano, and Igor Gorin, baritone, as soloists.

Prom nearly every branch of the Allied armed services, wearing a variety of uniforms, some discomfited, some at ease, some shy, some brash, the 4,000 service men at the New York City Christmas Dance last night exhibited every accent in the scope of the English language but found complete harmony in their applause when Mayor La Guardia shouted:

WRITING in the Winter issue of the Virginia Quarterly Review on "Books and Best-Sellers" Philip Van Doren Stern remarks that

E.L. Caswell, export manager of Thompson Products, Inc.. of Cleveland, Ohio, newly elected president of the Overseas Automotive Club, Inc., will hold office during the club's twentieth year of operation. Composed of export managers of companies which together handle about 90 per cent of the overseas automotive supply volume, the club was originally formed to formulate policy in the handling of exports and to provide a medium, for mutual assistance in business problems.

College basketball reaches a peak of activity this week in a program featured by three intersectional double-headers at Madison Square Garden and many other important contests involving teams from the Eastern sector. This will be the last fling of barnstorming before the major quintets settle down to the steady grind of conference competition.

A STARTLING contrast brings home to motorists the difference between life in time of peace and in time of military emergency. The amount of gasoline used to test a new aircraft engine of medium horsepower before it leaves the manufacturing plant for use in a combat plane would be sufficient to drive a passenger car 14,000 miles in nearly two years of operation.
The Duplan Corporation in its report for the six months ended with November, issued for publication today, disclosed a net profit of $397,126 after all charges, including provision for Federal taxes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Roosevelt announced tonight that "excellent progress" had been made during the conference of 25 Allied governments toward a plan for marshaling all the military and economic resources of anti-Axis nations on a "world-wide front."

THROUGHOUT the length and breadth of the country American women in all age groups are going in for defense activities. Girls are being trained to inspect houses and find and map gas, electric light and water mains. They are learning to locate street-light boxes, to open them and to switch lights on and off.

Science Makes Strides If you ask us, we think that the most important scientific event of the year was not any discovery made in the laboratory or field but the International Conference on Science and the World Order held in London last September.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Commissioner of Markets since Jan. 8, 1934, and one of the original members of the Mayor's "cabinet," resigned yesterday on the ground that he could no longer tolerate the Mayor's making appointments in his department without consulting him or even talking to him about them.

FROM Sir James Jeans down to lesser known names, English scientists and engineers seem to share a peculiar ability to transcribe their technical knowledge into readable prose. Here, for example, a consulting chemist and a factory manager in the British plastics industry collaborate to produce a little book which is in its modest scope, an admirable bit of popularization.
LONDON. THERE are omens which point to the possibility of the present war having a different effect on music than the last. That war, ending in unstable peace, produced unstable values.

The fundamental difference between radio in 1941 and radio in 1942 lies in our philosophy of operation. In the year to come we will be thinking only in terms of national defense. We will be concentrating instead on winning this war.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Jungle-trained imperial troops and mobile Japanese forces were moving into the North Malaya front tonight in strong numbers as both sides reinforced their lines in a fight swiftly developing into a major test of strength.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 20 totaled 798,697 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 8,528 cars, or 1.1 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 100,942 cars, or 14.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 147,305 cars, or 22.6 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

THE time-honored wont of this department to pick the "ten best" pictures of each year enjoins upon us, on this last Sunday, a responsibility and an indulgence too. It's a tough job to designate ten pictures out of the several hundred which this department sees in a twelvemonth as the unqualified best of the boiling, but it is also a welcome treat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Maxi- mum spot prices for green coffee were increased one quarter of a cent a pound today by Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, in a schedule replacing the emergency schedule of Dec. 11.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- Britain and the Soviet Union were understood tonight to have reached full agreement in Moscow negotiations regarding conduct of the war, the necessity of destroying Hitlerite Germany, and the approach to post-war problems in Europe.

Moved to action by the immediate need of promoting American health and energy as part of the war effort fifteen leading food manufacturers, after more than three years of consideration, have formed a Nutrition Foundation, with Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as its head, it was announced yesterday.

THE Alumni Orchestra of the National Orchestral Association has been popping up all over the place, playing for the New York Opera Company, providing the music for the Ballet Theatre and giving a "Pop" concert of its own at the new Concert Theatre.

FREDERICKSBURG, Texas, Dec. 27 (AP) -- This German-American settlement in the hill country of Texas broke out its flags today to honor a famous son -- once a village pond admiral, now commander of the Pacific Fleet.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A basketball squad from the University of Washington swamped Temple, 64 to 36, tonight to inaugurate its Eastern invasion in a most impressive manner.

The savings and loan institutions of the country are developing into few and stronger units "more capable than ever of adjustment to the needs of the future," according to Fred W. Catlett, member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

Drastic curtailment -- "and possibly the complete elimination" -- of Federal subsidies for relief milk, penny-a-day milk and lunches for school children, and surplus commodities bought through the food stamp plan was predicted here yesterday by Roy F. Hendrickson, Federal Agricultural Marketing Administrator, if Congress accepts the recent report of the Byrd Committee recommending a cut of nearly $1,717,000,000 in non-defense governmental appropriations.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Supreme Court Justice Gerald Nolan ruled today that unless specifically provided, a beneficiary is not precluded from benefiting by a double indemnity accidental death clause in a life insurance policy simply because the insured met death during the commission of a felony.

Main floor accessory, lingerie and toy departments were outstanding in gift buying last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

THIS year hearts of palm will appear on many dinner menus in luxury hotels and restaurants of the Southern States. Commercial growers in Florida have finally become interested in this unusual American vegetable and are undertaking large scale mar- keting for the first time.

AFTER making the careful study of period and background which we have come to expect from her. Lois Lenski tells the story of the first two years which Molly Jemison, the 12-year-old white girl who was carried off by Seneca Indians, spent with her captors.

Warning that "excessive working hours actually lower output," a committee of women unionists and social workers headed by Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, urged Governor Lehman yesterday not to permit general suspension of labor laws during the war.

"I SUPPOSE it is unwise to knock my own trade," said Struthers Burt, who has just completed a new novel, "Along These Streets," "but I can't help wondering why people should read novels now. I can't keep my mind on them -- haven't been able to since the war started in Europe.

While the exigencies of war will have some effect on the sport this Winter, organized skiing plans to carry on as normal a program as ever. This was revealed yesterday by Roger Langley, president of the National Ski Association of America, and Dr. R.S. Elmer, fourteentime president of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association, when they were asked to express their opinions on behalf of the organizations they guide.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The events of the past three weeks have illustrated only too clearly why Winston Churchill is in this country trying to re-establish between the United States and Great Britain the unity of action which brought us victory in the last war and without which we have been plunged into a second war under unfavorable conditions and without adequate plans.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In answer to my assertion that the closed shop, aided and abetted by rulings under the Wagner Act, creates an industrial dictatorship, David I. Ashe alleges that "the position of non-union workers under the act is no different from that of any other minority group in a democratic society."
Individually and collectively, the Dodgers ware the power team of the National League last Summer, according to the official 1941 slugging and miscellaneous records announced yesterday.

Extraordinary measures to safeguard from air raids the densely packed throngs that traditionally gather in Times Square on New Year's Eve were revealed yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine when he assigned 2,100 men to duty in that area.

WASHINGTON FOR eighteen out of every twenty-four hours foreign propagandists are pounding the air waves over North and South America in a relentless war of nerves against the United States. President Roosevelt is vilified as a power-mad warmonger.

General Realty and Utilities Corporation -- Year to Sept. 30: Consolidated net income before depreciation, $515,623, and after depreciation, $61,692. Net income after depreciation in previous year was $76,115. Statement excludes from income corporation's share of loss of Lefcourt Realty Corporation for same period applicable to stockholdings of the corporation, which was $256,934 after making provision for dividends on preference stock.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The War Department released the following orders today dated Dec. 26:

LITTLE, BROWN CO. and the Atlantic Monthly Company have signed a fiftyyear contract continuing the successful association between these two publishing houses which began in 1925, by virtue of which Little, Brown Co. publishes all Atlantic Monthly Press books.

The Medical Expense Fund of New York, a non-profit corporation selling insurance against doctors' bills, announced yesterday that starting on Jan. 1 it would extend its present coverage of individuals to provide medical expense insurance for entire families.

"FOREST PATROL" is an excellent story, fresh and unhackneyed in setting and incident, with characters that convince, and so much genuine outdoor atmosphere that it is likely to give any lover of wild, unspoiled country a touch of homesickness.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27--The ruthless bombing of Manila drew strong condemnation and warnings of retaliation here today.

A NUMBER of announcements from the General Electric Company this week lead off with the introduction of two "blackout" photoflash bulbs designed for night photography without revealing the flash. One of the bulbs is identical in size and shape with the Mazda "mighty midget" No. 5, the other resembles the No. 21.

IT IS fortunate that radio broadcasting had been forged and tempered into a potent instrument of democracy before America became Involved in the supreme test of the war. From the moment of the first bulletin of the treacherous attack on Hawaii broadcasters have been able to bring to bear responsible judgment, trained personnel and world-wide facilities.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- The Hunt Ball of the Goldens Bridge Hounds, a traditional event for nearly a decade, took place here tonight at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club. The dance was given for the first time as a benefit, the proceeds going to the American Red Cross through its North Salem, Katonah, Bedford and Mount Kisco branches.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, United States Forces on Northern Luzon Front, Dec. 27-- Japanese forces tonight advanced slowly against stubbornly resisting American and Philippine troops in a huge north-and-south pincers upon Manila.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of Dec. 24 "The Labor Agreement" you state that the government "must declare, as the War Labor Board did in 1917, that any demand from either side for a change in the status of the closed or open shop shall not be considered a proper grievance for submission to a war labor board or to arbitration."

DETROIT -- Spurred by heavy "scare" demand, automotive production and sales during 1941 reached near-record levels, topped only by the banner year of 1929. Except for curtailed output, observers here believe production and sales would have set all-time records.

The first slump in recruiting since war enlistments began on Dec. 8 was reported yesterday by all branches of the armed forces, but recruiting officers still are expecting an upsurge immediately after the first of the year.

Knowing that the Neediest Cases Fund alleviates suffering and want through the months from one Christmas appeal to the next, many regular contributors, who have been absorbed in the war emergency and in Christmas preparations, sent their gifts yesterday with apologies for being late.

YOUNGSTERS raised in the public schools forty years ago saw on the walls of their classrooms an impressive array of bearded gentlemen who represented in toto, at least for them, literature. One or two were beardless, Emerson, for instance, but the holy aura of the beard, that spreading oriflamme of dignity and sanctity, was, all the same, invisibly present, so to speak.

LAST vestiges of carefree and sometimes wasteful American habits in motoring will vanish with the year. The current tire sales ban ends and rationing starts next Sunday. Gasoline rations are forecast for Spring. New cars are diminishing in output toward the vanishing point.

Readers of this page need no introduction to the author of the able and charming book, "Your Garden in the City." She here presents her first full-length volume and in it retains all the vitality, originality and spirit which characterize her articles.

HONOLULU, Dec. 26 (Delayed) -- Drowsing beneath the mid-Pacific sun, Honolulu snows outwardly few signs of the Japanese attack of Dec. 7, unless it be an increased activity of all military forces in strengthening America's main bastion against further raids.

IN the coming year, destined to be one of the most critical -- perhaps the most critical -- in the history of the United States, the American people have a grueling ordeal to meet. The country will have to pull itself as rapidly as possible into a genuinely heroic mood -- and to keep that mood.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 27 -- Many of the villas have been opened for the season, and nearly all of them are filled with house guests over the holidays. There is much enteraining in a quiet way with luncheons and dinners, many of the hosts and hostesses including among their guests the young men in uniform stationed at camps near here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: "A penny saved is a penny earned," said Benjamin Franklin. In these days of monumental piling up of our national debt and the making of appropriations in astronomical amounts, the average citizen cannot see how what he is able to do will help.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Dec. 28 -- Methodically picking their way through treacherous mine fields and maintaining steady pressure against retreating German columns, Soviet forces on the vast Moscow front made further progress yesterday in their drive to straighten their lines, it was announced this morning by a military commentator on the Moscow radio.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- In the words of one who has participated in the Anglo-American war councils since the arrival here of the British Prime Minister, Mr. Churchill has had the effect of what in chemistry is called a catalyst: he has accelerated a desired reaction.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Colgate earned a place in the final of the annual Lake Placid invitation hockey tournament, which it won in the past two years, by downing Cornell in an exciting contest at the Olympic Arena, 4 to 1, tonight.

NEW ORLEANS. Dec. 27 -- Earl Bartlett of New Orleans, a student at Tulane, blasted second-seeded Wayne Sabin out of the running with a 6-1, 6-4 upset victory in the opening round of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today.

LONDON. IT is not the libraries of colleges and other institutions only that have suffered heavily through air raids. An article by Rose Macaulay in The Spectator reminds us that many private persons have found themselves suddenly bereft of valuable collections which had taken many years to assemble -- a loss that bears with special severity upon professional writers.
HONOLULU, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Fourteenth Naval District headquarters announced that twelve survivors from the freighter Manini, sunk about Dec. 17, were brought into Pearl Harbor this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Richmond, Va., instead of New York City, originally chosen, was designated today as the future home of the United States Patent Office in the impending migration of government agencies to make office room here for 40,000 defense workers by July 1.

A NEW piano concerto by Carlos Chavez will be given its initial performance here by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra Thursday night. The young American pianist Eugene List will be the soloist, and the concert will be directed by Dimitri Mitropoulos.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Dec 27 -- An air raid shelter system, built around available basements in private homes, public schools and churches, is being rapidly developed throughout Suffolk County by members of the American Legion Auxiliary.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27--Incoming, bred and formerly owned by Mrs. Parker Corning, but now representing Mrs. S.S. Zell of Baltimore, began his Winter campaign with a smartly earned triumph in the six-furlong Key West Handicap for a purse of $2,500 at Tropical Park today.

BATTERED and bruised, but from all appearances still a happy warrior, appears to be the condition of the motion picture industry as 1941 rushes off the calendar. For in the past twelve months the industry has gone through a series of trials the magnitude of which has perhaps been unequaled in its short and turbulent history.

Department store sales in the New York area showed gains of 30 to 35 per cent last week over a year ago. The increase was somewhat deceptive, however, since the period included not only the peak selling day of the season on Monday but also three selling days before Christmas, against only two last year.

The accounts that come from the Russian front of German difficulties with lubricating oil strike a new note in warfare. Probably horses -- and there are many despite mechanization -- cause less concern to German officers than the engines of airplanes, trucks and tanks. Horses can at least be covered with blankets, but engines must run if they are to be kept warm and oil is to flow.

BEFORE Japan attacked Pearl Harbor the ABCD alliance existed, but the arrangement among America, the British Empire, China and the Dutch in the Netherlands Indies -- was rather informal. With the blast on Hawaii, it became a league of nations working toward the overwhelming defeat of Japan, the sort of police power that Woodrow Wilson dreamed of to be used by his League against an aggressor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Manufacture of farm machinery, which requires large quantities of copper, rubber, aluminum and other vital war materials, will be reduced to 83 per cent of 1940 production under an order issued tonight by Donald M. Nelson, Director of Priorities in the Office of Production Management.

Al Homewood, piloting the well known bay mare Flay Girl, won the touch-and-out jumping class for H. L. Norton of Orangeburg in the nineteenth fixture of the Metropolitan Equestrian Club yesterday at the Riding and Polo Club. The show was held for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: TO lovers of the Netherlands Mr. van Paassen's latest book is distressing reading. My own six years of residence in that country, the intimate view I had of the Dutch people, the grateful impressions I carried away of their many admirable traits, their present tragic plight -- all these considerations prompt me to protest against judgments so harsh and ill-founded as those of "That Day Alone."

THERE is a code of rules for writing mystery stories, just as there is a code of international law, but nobody is bound by either of them. The Nazis, the Fascists and the Japs make their own rules as they go along, and so do some of our mystery writers.

Empire at Stake The main defense line of the Allied Powers in the Pacific extends about 7,000 miles from Pearl Harbor to Singapore. The line protects the oil, rubber and tin of the East Indies and Malaya. It guards the communications to Oceania, Australia and New Zealand.
Stocks had yesterday the largest and broadest Saturday session in more than a year and closed irregularly higher under the leadership of tobacco shares. These gained 1 to 4 points.

SEATTLE, Dec. 27 -- Duke's powerful gridiron machine, which entered the Rose Bowl three years ago with a reputation as an immovable object, will enter this year's transplanted classic as the nation's top collegiate offensive team.

Subs Off California On the rocky headlands and surf-pounded beaches of California's coast, lifeboats from American merchant vessels piled up last week. Rescuers pulled exhausted seamen from rough waters. Within sight of shore the dark hulks of enemy submarines emerged, fired deck guns, loosed torpedoes.

With Mrs. Josephine Windle Korber, tournament chairman of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, representing several thousand tourney golfers, announcing that the schedule of events is heavier than ever despite the war, one wonders what will be the outcome in view of the statement from Washington, that due to the world conflict, the manufacture of golf and tennis balls will be virtually eliminated.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Three weeks of trial and error with government censorship of news point already the direction policy is apt to take.

Industrial buyers were urged to follow a policy of coverage for replacement of normal working inventories and were cautioned against overcommitment at abnormally high prices in the monthly report issued yesterday by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents.

BOMBER LEADER: Over San Francisco Bay and out into the empty sky over the Pacific Ocean roared a flight of Army bombers last Oct. 17. The resonant thunder of their engines caused many a San Francisco resident to crane his neck at their passing and watch them disappear to seaward.

Prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with net gains of 1 to 3 points as trade buying absorbed the few offerings that appeared. Trading was quiet. Outside news had no apparent influence.

ISTANBUL, Dec. 27 -- Less than twenty-five minutes flying time from this citadel on the Bosporus, where Istanbul stands guard over the Dardanelles, lies one of the most formidable military airdromes in Southeastern Europe -- the Luftwaffe's huge air base on the outskirts of Jambol in Bulgaria.

Last Summer when the first units of the armed forces of the Philippine Commonwealth were inducted into the United States armed forces in the Far East, General Douglas MacArthur admonished the young and untried soldiers:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 -- Espino Gold, a 4-year-old colt owned by Mrs. Krank Nugent, captured the Jefferson Handicap, $1,500 added feature at the Fair Grounds today. Us was placed second and Maihigh third.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 27 -- The new Radcliffe College Health Center, now nearing completion, will have as one of its chief aims the aiding of national defense through increased student health and efficiency, Dr. Harriet L. Hardy, college physician, stated today, in announcing her plans for the work of the center.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- William S. Knudsen and Sidney Hillman, directors of the OPM, urged today that defense plants keep going on New Year's Day "and speed collapse of the Axis by millions of man-hours."

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Punctuating wise cracks and crowd-pleasing gesticulations with beautifully hit forehand and backhand shots. Frank Kovacs defeated Bobby Riggs, 6 -- 0, 8 -- 10, 6 -- 3, tonight to become the only undefeated player in the current troupe of professional tennis players.

In an effort to meet the needs of Intellectually gifted children on the one hand and the slow learners on the other, the New York City school system is forming special classes throughout the city, to provide individual programs in areas where this practice has been deemed advisable.

TOKYO, Dec. 27 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Navy Minister Admiral Shigetaro Shimada told the Japanese Diet today that the Japanese Navy now had air and sea control over "four oceans."

Editor The New York Times Book Review: That readers and critics should differ from one another is a very common case, so common that it is quite unnecessary for Mr. Humphries to assume that I had "a fit of obscure malevolence" because I do not happen to rate Miss Bogan's poetry as highly as he does.

HIS first venture into the field of fiction is not, for Carl Carmer, so new a departure as readers of his earlier works may imagine. He has proved already, in books like "The Hudson" and "Stars Fell on Alabama," that he can translate local history into a fresh and convincing and irresistibly contemporary idiom.

A gift of $100,000 to the Red Cross War Fund of $50,000,000 by the Anaconda Copper Mining Company was announced yesterday by Colby M. Chester, vice chairman of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York and chairman of the Commerce and Industry Committee in the local campaign.
More than thirty years ago Japan signed an international agreement to which its signature is still attached. Article 25 of that agreement stated:

The course of the war in the Far East may be such in the next few weeks that it will be necessary for the American people to recover their perspective and hold it. America has been fighting on the defensive in the Far East for the first three weeks of the war.

For years the Lombardy poplar has been almost the only tree used wherever the need arose for one that was tall and yet very narrow. However, there are a number of others that are just as desirable, for the Lombardy poplar is not only short lived but its wood is very brittle and susceptible to wind damage, and the roots are particularly troublesome wherever there are sewers.

Carrying on in the darkening shadow of war, which has all but brought about a blackout of sports on the West Coast and is reaching out to enlist the services of many of the stars of 1941, college football will put on its usual show of bowl games Thursday to start the New Year.

Henry Rogers Benjamin gave a dance last night at his home, 2 East Eighty-seventh Street, to present to society his daughter, Miss Anne Rogers Benjamin. The debutante received with her father and stepmother, Mrs. Benjamin.

Reviewed as a group, sixty companies in the construction and home-equipment field are seen to have made slight headway in the third quarter of 1941, compared with the 1940 period. In the face of heavier taxation combined net profits were $43,906,031, against $40,703,986 last year, a gain of 8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sunday, Dec. 28 -- The War Department announced just after midnight that seven new Army air bases were being planned in the Midwest and Southwest to aid in the defense of Continental United States.

From the beginning of the club season until the holiday respite, the feminine club world, not wholly unlike the rest of the citizenry, has taken long strides in approaching the ideal of unity in the national interest. From a generally detached viewpoint with regard to world events, their organizations have demonstrated again an ability to turn from programs planned in more serene days to active tasks.

To handle some of the abnormal burdens thrown on the department by the war, the customs service is to get 200 extra employes for duty in New York, it was announced last week by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.

THE thought of air raids has sent New Yorkers by the thousands to the city's fire stations to learn the technique of fire-fighting. They are mostly working people and they must study the hard way -- by giving up their free afternoons and evenings to answer the call for fire auxiliaries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The weight of man power and natural resources which must inevitably bring defeat to the Axis powers, is shown in a special Census Bureau survey just issued here. The cold statistics leave no doubt that so long as man power and steel and oil and food are the major factors in warfare, along with physical stamina and moral determination, the powers allied against the Axis cannot but win.

New wall decorations are being devised to give rooms a touch of the unusual or a note of urban sophistication. Some of them are three-dimensional, while others, consisting of pictures recessed in the wall and equipped with indirect lighting, achieve somewhat the same effect.
When the United States withdrew its forces from Manila and declared that island port an open city it was acting in accordance with The Hague Peace Conference of 1907.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A considerable amount of dreary prophesying of a five-year war is circulated about. This writer takes a less pessimistic view and believes that the probable duration of the war will not be far from one more year. This opinion is based more upon the economic factors than upon the military strategy.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass. THREE or four symphony concerts by visiting orchestras have been the usual fare in recent years in this city. This season, our joy knew no bounds. Six symphony concerts were scheduled and that was occasion for unbounded deligrht, even if four of the programs came within five days the other week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 27 -- At the Itamaraty Palace, or Foreign Office, there is a great bustle as worker's prepare the palace for the reception of the delegates to the meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the Americas on Jan. 15.

The Home Insurance Company announced yesterday that a permissible endorsement it had proposed for the New York standard mortgagee clause used in fire policies, to affect holders of an interest in a second mortgage on property for which the company held a first mortgage, had been approved by the New York State Insurance Department.

AN actor without superstitions is like a ship without barnacles. The condition can be but usually isn't From John Garfield's pet pair of old shoes, which must be in every picture he makes, to Jerry Colonna's refusal to sign anything on Friday, the acting colony has more fetishes and taboos than even a quaint native tribe in the South Seas presided over by Dorothy Lamour and a couple of script writers.

SPEAKING of the boys who trail herded from Texas up the Chisholm Trail, Mr. Lomax once wrote, "They brought new songs back with them for the entertainment of their friends." So the coonskin-capped flat boatmen who floated south to New Orleans with boats full of produce brought back the new songs to their homes in the Ohio Valley.

THE Army's Chief of Staff, General George Catlett Marshall, has some things in common with his Navy counterpart, Admiral Stark. Like Stark, he is 61, has a way with Congressmen, and likes to mess around small boats. Also like Stark he is a Pennsylvanian. Marshall is not a West Pointer because his father had the stubbornness to remain a Kentucky Democrat in an overwhelmingly Republican State.
Discussing the meeting of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, Rabbi Elias L. Solomon in Shaare Zedek Synagogue, 212 West Ninety-third Street, said yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- Characterizing the Japanese attack on Manila as "barbarism in its worst form," Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska expressed what appeared to be a universal sentiment when he asserted that the Japanese had desregarded all rules of warfare and in turn could claim no immunity under such rules.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- War Department communique No. 31 on military developments up to 9:30 A.M.:

MONTREAL, Dec. 27 -- The New York Rangers came through with two goals in the third period to send the Canadiens down to their fourth straight defeat tonight by a 4 -- 2 score. The victory tightened the New Yorkers' hold on third place in the National Hockey League standing, while the Habitants remain in the cellar.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Mr. Thomas Kernan's letter to your paper in answer to Mr. Heinz Pol's communication to you of an earlier date has just been called to my attention and because the subject with which these two letters deals is one in which I am profoundly interested, I would like to add my word of protest to Mr. Pol's.

Exceptional effort is being expended on the organization work for the twenty-ninth annual International Flower Show to be held in Grand Central Palace March 16 to 21. Planned along new and different lines, the exhibition will present possibly a more striking appearance than any shows of the past.

To relieve some of the strain on the facilities of the Red Cross, the Young Women's Christian Association of New York has extended to the local chapter the facilities of assembly and workrooms in ten of its centers and residences. The offer now makes possible the expansion of classes for which long waiting lines of applicants have already been enrolled.

Tracy H. Lewis, who had not competed at the traps of the New York Athletic Club on Travers Island for some time, won the high over-all scratch cup yesterday, taking the trophy after a shoot-off against J.J. VanGonsic. In the original shoot each had 95.

A forthcoming holiday dance that has elicited the interest of many younger members of society is the fifteenth annual Debutantes' New Year's Ball, which will be held Thursday night on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The fete since its inception has served as the formal introduction to society of several debutantes of the season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Japan is losing troop and supply ships at the rate of more than one a day, fast enough, to reduce her great merchant marine to insignificance in two years if losses go unchecked in a Pacific naval war of attrition.

Efforts to protect manufacturers whose special abilities load them up with defense contracts in their competition with other companies in the same industry not working in government orders are being worked out by the Office of Production Management in the pulp and chemical fields and will establish a pattern for similar action in other industries, executives said last week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission formally took over at noon today sixteen Finnish-owned merchant ships laid up in United States ports.

Two meeting's will be held this week by committees actively interested in plans for the annual opera benefit of the Grenfell Association of America, for which the performance of "The Daughter of the Regiment," with Lily Pons and Salvatore Baccaloni in the leading roles, has been taken over for the night of Jan. 24 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

AFTER describing "Brooklyn, U.S.A." as a melodrama last Monday, I looked that word up in the dictionary. "Melodrama," say the estimable Brothers Fowler: "Sensational dramatic piece with violent appeals to emotion and happy ending."
NEW YORK Lieut. Comdr. John Jay Ide, U.S.N. has joined Mrs. Ide at the Plaza.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- At the outbreak of war all branches of sport in Britain were hit hard, but despite ever-recurring blows as the conflict progressed sport has managed to keep its head above water and provide much-needed recreation for the war workers' Saturday break.

HOLLYWOOD could scarcely have the nerve to make up anything like the true story of Astrid Varnay, the 23-year-old singer who recently stepped into two of the most difficult and exacting Wagnerian roles at the Metropolitan Opera House on no more than twenty-four hours' notice for either of them and got an ovation both times from astonished audiences.

America's entry into war with the Axis powers, following Japan's attacks in the Pacific and the declaration of a state of war by Germany and Italy, finds this nation, as 1941 nears its close, in the most advantageous maritime preparedness position in its history.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. Dec. 27 (AP) -- Blondie Cunningham scored three goals in an overtime period tonight to give the Atlantic City Sea Gulls a 7-to-4 victory over the New York Rovers in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 27 -- It is Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham and the men of Great Britain's Mediterranean Fleet under his leadership who have made possible Britain's Libyan victory.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Here are some questions and answers clarifying details of the government's tire-rationing program:

NINETEEN HUNDRED FORTY-ONE is about to pass into history as a year that saw the beginning of almost miraculous things in the radio field. An all-out radio effort now is well under way and results are forthcoming in proportion.

They Studied Maps Fifty years from now people will laugh heartily over specimens of the art of photography as it was practiced at the beginning of the year 1942. People in those days will be particularly amused by the constrained and almost hieratic attitudes in which the photographers of 1942 insisted on pillorying their subjects.

ASPIRIT of restlessness has prevailed in ski ranks the past few weeks in anticipation of Winter. Enthusiasts of the fast-rising sport have been busy conditioning themselves and making last-minute check-ups on steel edges and wooden runners for the first heavy snowfall.

NEW YORK, now host to huge holiday crowds, is the most misunderstood city in America. The oddest notions are current about what it costs to visit it. One explanation that can be offered is that so much of the city's publicity deals with the cafe-society side of New York life.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Reinforcement of the unimpaired striking power of the Netherland forces for an offensive based in the East Indies was urged upon the United States by an authoritative commentator today as the sinking of two more Japanese ships by bombers was announced.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 27 -- Razzle dazzle football paid off at 16 -- 0 today as a daring team of Southerners defeated the heavier Northern All-Stars in the fourth annual Blue-Gray game before 15,571 spectators.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27 -- By plane and train, from East and West, across the great expanse of Canada, the members of the Canadian Senate and House of Commons have begun their journey to Ottawa for the great occasion on Tuesday when Prime Minister Churchill will speak to the two Houses of Parliament meeting together.

Period furniture and Georgian silver, belonging to Leona Jane Hertz, will be sold at auction on Saturday afternoon, Jan. 3, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition of the collection opened yesterday at the galleries.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Although detailed information about the present discussions in Washington have not been available here thus far, the impression prevails that the meetings of Prime Minister Winston Churchill with President Roosevelt and others have opened a new stage in the position of commodities in the international market.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- There was a growing belief among London observers today that Germany and Italy were rushing heavy reinforcements to Tripoli and thence eastward into the Libyan battle zone, in spite of heavy losses of ships in the Mediterranean.

Assurance that contractors throughout the country now will be able to go ahead with thousands of dwellings on which they had stopped work for lack of priority ratings is seen by Sydney Hogerton, district manager of the OPM Priority Field Service, in the new preference rating order making materials available to complete privately financed nondefense homes for which foundations were in place on Oct. 9.

Department store sales, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table of percentage comparisons with a year ago for the various Reserve districts, for the last two weeks and the latest four-week period:

The New York Telephone Company is doing the biggest business in its history. Gross revenues are at a record high. Instead of advertising for more business, the company has published notices asking its subscribers to refrain from long-distance calls over the holidays except in cases of urgent necessity, and then to make them brief.

IN his talk at the Grolier Club with which he opened the current exhibition of his books, George Arents pointed out that the word "tobacco" need not appear on the title page for a book to qualify for his collection. In forming his unique and famous library illustrating the history of tobacco, any important reference to the subject, however incidental, was all that mattered.

To have something attractive for the table during Winter to take the place of the usual vases of flowers, the writer each Fall selects several low pottery bowls in colors to harmonize with dining and breakfast room, china. In each of these a thin layer of gravel or small rocks is placed for drainage, then a layer of compost made up of one-third garden soil, one-third leaf mold or woodsy dirt, and one-third builder's sand.

Anticipating that many of the present senior class will be called to military duty upon graduation and the possibility that the draft age may be lowered and affect to some extent the lower classes of the college, Fordham University has recently increased its first-aid training.

HAROLD R. STARK, Chief of Naval Operations and the Navy's top man, is mild-mannered, white-haired and bespectacled. His Annapolis nickname "Molly" was a lamentable historical lapse. His classmates thought it the name of the wife of General Stark, who predicted her widowhood were he defeated.

Exports of American wines will be of increased importance in the world markets and will comprise a growing percentage of foreign trade after hostilities have ceased, according to Paul Dubonnet of the French wine-making family, who has just re-established his business in this country.

A couple of years ago, when the enthusiasm for skiing first hit hereabout in large proportions, the ski clothes and things to go with them ran heavily to trimmings, usually hearts and flowers, and to a band-box look that was fine in store windows but a little silly out in the snow.

Pouring into the USO clubhouses opening during the holiday season are contributions of musical materials collected by the New York State Federation of Music Clubs as a result of their November drive.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- A plea to young women in professional or technical college programs to stand firm and complete their courses, in spite of the natural desire to "do something" immediately and the active demand for their services in the war crisis, was issued today by President Bancroft Beatley of Simmons College, in a message addressed to all students of the college and their parents.

FORT DIX, N.J. All goes suddenly dark. Unlovely barracks, service clubs, mess halls, signal towers, convoys streaming along reservation roads merge with the night. The gray, rutted road on which you stand in the cold wind fades from under your boots.

Three series of lectures on the history of painting and sculpture, the aspects of art, individual works, research problems and great artists, will be presented during the Winter season at the National Gallery of Art, in the Lecture Hall.

One stabbing shot forty seconds from the end preserved Long Island University's winning streak last night as the Blackbirds strung out their two-year string to twenty-three in a row with a 46-to-45 triumph over Southern California before 18,080 howling fans in Madison Square Garden.

Losses sustained by mortgagors on the reconveyance or surrender of title to property to mortgagees may constitute either ordinary or capital losses. If ordinary losses, they are fully deductible for income tax purposes; if capital losses, they are subject to limitations of laws as to deductibility.

According to an announcement by the Norwegian Shipping and Trade Mission, the first step in a plan by which merchant ships built in Britain are being made available to other Allied governments to compensate for tonnage they have lost in war action took place at an English shipyard recently.
A NEW pendulum-type passenger coach, representing a revolutionary step in car building, is being placed in service by the Santa Fe on its all-coach streamliner, El Capitan.

ST. PIERRE, Miquelon, Dec. 27 -- Vice Admiral Emile Muselier ordered Free French naval forces to the alert here this evening and, under international law, barred access to the islands' territorial waters to warships of any nationality except on the basis of special permission previously asked for and granted.

"THE SONG OF JED SMITH" completes Mr. Neihardt's "Cycle of the West" (1822-90), which deals with the story of the exploits and adventures of Jedediah Smith and his comrades, the Ashley-Henry men, discoverers and explorers of the great central route from the Missouri River to the Pacific Ocean.

FROM Quito has been received Ecuador's series, mentioned in these columns last May, commemorating the "Primera Exposicion Nacional del Periodismo" (First National Exposition of Journalism). The uniform design is the seated figure of Dr. Francisco Javier Eugenio de Santa Cruz y Espejo (1740-96), Ecuador's first newspaperman, above a reproduction of his autograph.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Gaston Henry-Haye, the French Ambassador, predicted after a conference of more than an hour with Secretary of State Cordell Hull today that the sovereignty of Vichy would be restored over the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon that Free French forces have occupied and that guarantees would be established for the proper supervision of the wireless station on St. Pierre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes of America, A.F. of L., agreed tonight to accept the government's recommendation for terminating a strike of Greyhound bus line operators and submitting the dispute to arbitration.

WITHIN the studio the dress rehearsal, as usual, left the cast vibrating with nervous tension. The author, sitting in the control room, could hardly be described as a bronze of serenity. The second hand ticked around relentlessly, however, until the appointed moment and the curtain went up on the opening scene of one of the longest-running dramas on record.

BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 27 -- All the good that yesterday's scrimmage with Andy Kerr's Eastern All-star team did Fordham -- putting the Rams on edge for their game with Missouri in the Sugar Bowl on Thursday -- may turn out to be bad tidings.

THE museums of New York are founding out a year of very considerable activity. It has been a difficult period, full of unexpected demands. These they have met cheerfully and valiantly. They have carried on. They have carried on at a time when their services are of peculiar value.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Throughout this country members of the various religious faiths will join with co-religionists in the United States in observing a day of prayer Jan. 1. An appeal for the prayers was issued today by the Archbishop of Canterbury, primate of England.

MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- The Russian armies operating on the southwestern front are menacing the main rail line between Kursk and Kharkov and are nearing Belgorod, a large hilltop town fifty miles above Kharkov. These operations are reported in the army newspaper Red Star.

Owners of properties damaged by enemy bombs will not be required to repair them to make them acceptable for FHA mortgage insurance debentures, Federal Housing Administrator Abner H. Ferguson announced yesterday.

IN accordance with its aim of testing new methods in operatic presentation the National Orchestral Association will employ a portable revolving turntable in its music play productions this season in Carnegie Hall, the first of which will be Mozart's "The Abduction From, the Seraglio," slated for Jan. 12. Furthermore, the orchestra, instead of playing behind a semi-transparent scenic curtain as used to be the case, will be placed in the pit.

THE annual conference of the managers of the country's major symphony orchestras was held here recently and the consensus of opinion among them was that the war, far from dampening American orchestral life, will substantially increase the attendance at concerts.

Arterial highways in the New York district, developing ahead of schedule, will serve as major links in the motor transport service arising out of wartime needs, the Regional Plan Association reported yesterday in a review of the progress made in this field since the organization projected its forty-year highway program thirteen years ago.

OUTGROWENG all office, hangar and shop facilities at the Allegheny County in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania-Central Airlines will move its general offices and operations and maintenance bases to the Washington National Airport early in 1942.

COLLECTORS of war-censored covers, formerly finding much material available, from now on will be limited in their choice because so many sources have been shut off. With the postoffice regulation suspending delivery of all mail originating in the "United States or its possessions and addressed to Germany, Italy, Japan or any enemy-occupied territory or possessions, a good part of the world is closed to correspondence with the allied countries.

St. Vincent's Hospital, which is seeking $750,000 in a public appeal directed by former Governor Alfred E. Smith, announced yesterday broadcasting of first-aid training courses and intensification of the work of St. Vincent's Volunteers to relieve doctors and nurses of nonprofessional duties.

Every person in the United States and its far-flung possessions who is interested in pure bred dogs -- whether breeder, exhibitor, handler, or in any other capacity -- must start the new year with a full realization that our country has been plunged into the greatest war in its history.

The magnificent "all out" effort of women of wartime Britain is worthy of great praise, but the long working week of fifty-six hours and the registration of young people from 16 to 18, which may mean the limitation of education, are not wise policies, Professor Winifred C. Cullis of the Physiology Department of the University of London, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Any shortage of wool which may be brought on by the war period may be alleviated by the giant sequoia or redwood trees of the Pacific coast forests, it is indicated in a patent (No. 2,266,907) awarded here to Harmon B. Riehl of Boston.

MR. NORRIS HOUGHTON has been a mighty traveler in the cause of the theatre. In 1935 he covered the Soviet stage, and the result was a superb book, "Moscow Rehearsals." In 1940 this indefatigable investigator started on a tour of approximately 19,000 miles through the United States on a Rockefeller Foundation grant.

"BUSINESS as usual" is the order of the day in the city's parks and playgrounds as Winter approaches. In accordance with Mayor La Guardia's request that the population pursue as nearly as possible its normal routine of work and play, Park Department officials have planned a variety of cold-weather recreational and sports events and have increased play facilities both indoors and out.

The Brooklyn Americans will be confronted with a dififcult task against the powerful Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The job would be no easy one under ordinary circumstances, but with the Dutton aggregation weakened on its defense line because of a leg injury to Andy Bramgan.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Stirring music, much of it patriotic, will be part of the program for this season's Orange Bowl Festival Week which opens with the fashion show of Tuesday night in Bayfront Park. A fifty-piece orchestra, under the baton of Caesar LaMonaca, will present a program of old and new classical favorites for the show.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Like all peoples of ancient origin, the Japanese have a wealth of proverbs. Homely expressions of the wisdom born of experience, the superstitions, cynicisms, prejudices and popular fallacies, they illustrate the folkways of a people probably better than anything else could.

TORONTO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Toronto crashed back into the lead of the National Hockey League tonight by downing the fifth-place Detroit Red Wings, 5 -- 3, at Maple Leaf Gardens. The victory gave the Leafs a one-point advantage over the idle Boston Bruins, who dropped to second place.

MANILA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Japanese airmen who waited until Manila's anti-aircraft guns were hauled away and her defenses stripped under an "open city" declaration left the center of the capital bloodied and aflame tonight in their longest and fiercest attack of the war.

P.J. O'Hara Jr., executive director of the New York Is a Friendly Town Committee, an organization that works in close cooperation with the New York City Recreation Committee at 99 Park Avenue, predicted yesterday that about 20,000 invitations to dinner would be available for members of the armed forces on New Year's Eve, as well as 3,000 invitations to entertainment programs throughout the New York area.

THE record business has done famously this year. More disks were sold than in any other twelve-month period of the industry's existence, and the quality of the output has been high. The album of the Tchaikovsky piano concerto, made by Arturo Toscanini, Vladimir Horowitz and the NBC Symphony, has sold, in two months, nearly four times as many sets as all the albums put out by Victor in the entire year of 1933.

FOR many years beginners in reading have loved the little books by these two authors which tell, with childlike charm and humor, of "Charlie and His Kitten Topsy," or "Charlie and His Puppy Bingo"; slightly older children enjoy "The Golden Goat," "The Little Lost Shepherd" and other stories with their background of French country life which these authors know so well.

Employment in war industries will double in the next two years and organized training of women to help manufacture war materials must begin immediately before American industry can attain the twenty-four-hour, seven-day week production schedule necessary to win this war, H.G. Crockett, senior partner in the management engineering firm of McKinsey Co., said yesterday in a discussion of what management can do to speed production.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Two recent news dispatches cause me to express my thoughts about a present and future grave situation that calls for prompt and sober consideration by the whole nation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- Three main-line colleges -- Haverford, Swarthmore and Bryn Mawr -- executing another move in their program of close cooperation, announced today that joint action will be taken in the future on all appointments to their faculties.

WHILE the musical world remembers Ferruccio Busoni as a great pianist and teacher and a challenging composer, the conductor and two soloists taking part in this afternoon's Busoni Memorial Concert by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, which WABC is broadcasting at 3 o'clock, recall him devotedly as a friend and mentor whose high artistic standards still are dominant seventeen years after his death.

LONDON. IN the last fortnight Shaftesbury Avenue has seen two new plays which have one thing in common -- each is the work of one of the best of our younger established dramatists. Apart from that, they could hardly be more sharply contrasted.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 27 -- A distinguished Mexican close to the government said today that the reason why Mexico merely broke off relations with the Axis without declaring war was that formal hostilities would have increased the strategic dangers to Mexico's Pacific Coast and that it required large American forces to be stationed there to protect it.

Coast Guard officers said yesterday that their new orders regulating commercial and sport fishing off the Atlantic Coast were essential to prevent espionage and sabotage. Shipping is vital to national defense and must be protected against every possible menace, they asserted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- On the eve of a vast expansion of the land forces, the War Department ordered today that the accompanying temporary promotion of Army officers be based entirely on demonstrated merit. Setting aside the remnants of the time-honored peacetime system of advancement based mainly on length of service, the order followed a 1917-18 precedent.
THE soap-opera schedule is in for quite a shake-up tomorrow, an item of more moment than you might think just off-hand, the soap-opera public being what it is. Like this:

SINGAPORE, Dec. 27 -- A resumption of Japanese attacks in Northern Malaya is believed foreshadowed by action that flared yesterday and today at Sungel Siput, southeast of Kuala Kangsar in Northern Perak.

A Long Island yacht club, aware that throughout the land boating organizations have offered personnel and instruction facilities to the government, has gone them all one better. The Freeport Y.C. has offered its entire club to the Navy "for whatever use may toe mutually agreed upon."
DETROIT, Dec. 27 -- While it has been, suggested before, it appears that the proper time has arrived to transform American spectator sports into a program of mass participation.

CONTRARY to the custom of other years, several galleries opened exhibitions in the day or two preceding Christmas. Among these shows was the group exhibition of oils, water-colors and sketches by late nineteenth and early twentieth century artists, chiefly French, at Carroll Carstairs.

HOLLYWOOD. IN Hollywood, as much as anywhere else in the country, the first 340 days of 1941 now seem singularly remote. But the record shows that it was a prosperous period, though the opening months were marked by public apathy toward the box office.
To the Radio Editor: In the Sunday TIMES of Dec. 14 Norman Corwin told of his problems in working on the radio script for "We Hold These Truths" and he finished with the words, "I hope you like it."

MICKEY ROONEY still is top man at the nation's box offices. For the third consecutive year theatre owners throughout the country have voted him first among the ten biggest money-making film personalities, according to the annual survey made by The Motion Picture Herald, a leading trade journal.

THIS is a lively, amusing story of the struggle between a successful playwright and a modern New England town. John Diggs at 30 was rated a $50.000-a-year man on Broadway, and he didn't care a thing about money. Redwood, his home town, regarded itself as an up-and-coming community eager to grow, and it was inclined to judge success in dollars.

The glory of the rock garden is appreciated by every one in May and June when rock plants, despite their small stature, make a riot of masses and ribbons of gay colors. But how does the same garden look on New Year's morning? That is the real test of the skill of the planter.

NOW that the year is in its wee hours, other members of the Broadway Professional Pallbearers Association, sometimes known as the Film Critics Circle, are busily commemorating the ten films which they privately believe best fitted for screen immortality.

Sidor Belarsky, basso cantante, who has made frequent appearances in this city, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Society for the Advancement of Jewish Music. In a program composed entirely of Jewish selections, Mr. Belarsky was assisted by Emma Shever, soprano, and Nicolas Zadri, violinist, each of whom was heard in a group of solos.

PLANNED and executed upon a novel and striking pattern by a professor of law at Columbia and an anthropologist on the faculty of New York University, this book appeals to the lawyer, the sociologist and the collector of Indian lore, as well as to the general reader.

ON one of the darkest days in his country's history, Winston Churchill, as Prime Minister, pledged the British people in their island kingdom and the dominions beyond the seas to carry on the struggle against Nazi Germany, if necessary alone, "until in God's good time, the New World, with all its power and might, steps forth to the rescue and the liberation of the Old."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 -- Two slayings in two days, in which one victim was a Japanese and the other a Filipino, caused the police in Northern California communities to increase their vigilance today against possible outbreaks of violence due to the invasion of the Philippines.

Holiday business wound up last week in a whirlwind of activity which put most stores over the top, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. Monday and Tuesday volume throughout the country was record-breaking, following the previous week's lull.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Prices of grains and soy beans were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade as the result of a report that the Office of Price Administration was contemplating raising the price ceiling on oils and fats to the level prevailing on Oct. 2, and also the signing of a bill by President Roosevelt providing for government loans on grain at 85 per cent of parity for the next five years.

DR. T. HARPER GOOD-SPEED, director of the University of California Botanical Garden at Berkeley, has initiated the first large-scale introduction of temperate South American plants into the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Navy Yard employes and other civilian workers at Pearl Harbor not only "stayed on the job" during the Japanese attack of Dec. 7, but rushed repairs under fire and helped put guns in position to fight the sudden foe, the Navy Department said in a report made public today.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 27 -- British columns continued to harass Axis forces in the Agedabia area yesterday, and artillery was brought up to shell columns of enemy trucks along the coastal road.

Tentative dates which probably will be made permanent were adopted yesterday for next Spring's regattas by the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association, the delegates of which met in the New York Yacht Club. They were set in the carry-on spirit that has prevailed in all the other yachting gatherings held since the war began.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: I need hardly add my sincere congratulations to the many you have received concerning your new poetry view page, but I perforce add to the complaints about the reviewers. Peter Monro Jack reviewed my book of poems.

While the champion team of Brooklyn College was having trouble with a clever quartet representing New York University in the second round of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League tournament at the Marshall Chess Club, C.C.N.Y. students gained half a point on their old rivals by making a clean sweep on four boards in the match with Cooper Union.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: I need hardly add my sincere congratulations to the many you have received concerning your new poetry view page, but I perforce add to the complaints about the reviewers. Peter Monro Jack reviewed my book of poems.

As the New Year is about to ring in, the fact incontrovertibly told to the vast listening public of the air is that the American system of broadcasting, in the supreme test of sudden and treacherous war made upon the nation, has been tried and not found wanting.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 27 (AP) -- American farmers may be able to help ease a crude rubber shortage by large-scale cultivation of a rubber-bearing dandelion plant, agricultural research disclosed today.

Both men and women are guided by the most laudable instincts in Christmas shopping, but that doesn't prevent returns and exchanges from pouring into stores the day after Christmas. It's the normal Christmas urge to give people something special that they wouldn't get themselves -- whether they need and really want it or not -- that leads to the trouble and exchanging later.

Editor The New York Times Book Review: Yes. Mr. Aldington did include Dryden's "All, all of a piece throughout" in the Viking Anthology. He devotes fifteen fine pages to Dryden, and I did not notice the last six-line Dryden poem on the top of the next page.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 27 -- Mr. Moore was born at La Grange, Mo., on June 30, 1878, the son of William Pike and Catherine Linn Threlkeld Moore.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Prices of livestock were steady today after a week of further gains that reflected a sharp reduction In receipts, due partly to the holiday period. Prices of dressed meats were lower, however, as a result of poultry competition. Wholesale pork loins lost about a cent a pound and dressed beef was off about 1/2 cent.

ROCKY MOUNTAIN TROUT, for a fine fling of extravagance at a New Year's Day dinner, will be caught fresh to your order, flown to New York and delivered with a flourish at your door. A half-dozen must be ordered at a time and a few days' notice is necessary.

IT is a matter of great satisfaction and a cause for gratitude that in these days, when the history of our country and the doing's of our pioneer forebears have a special significance for us, we can turn to such a group of stories as those Mrs. Wilder has been writing for the last ten years.

Miss Anita Lyon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart G. Lyon of 3 East Eighty-fifth Street, was introduced to society last night at a supper dance given by her parents at their home. The debutante received with her parents, her grandfather, Dudley M. Irwin of Buffalo, who came here for the party; her sister, Miss Shirley Irwin Lyon, and Miss Lloyd Dearmont.

IN 1941 the game of contract bridge had its biggest year in all respects since 1935, and tournament bridge enjoyed the biggest success of its history. It is probable that the "bridge prosperity" of 1941 will not be equaled for several years to come.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- The big Spring and Summer mail order house catalogues will make their appearance on schedule in the latter part of January, but priority orders and unexpected material shortages have made the task of the catalogue staffs at both Sears Roebuck and Montgomery Ward the most difficult in many years.

While the champion team of Brooklyn College was having trouble with a clever quartet representing New York University in the second round of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League tournament at the Marshall Chess Club, C.C.N.Y. students gained half a point on their old rivals by making a clean sweep on four boards in the match with Cooper Union.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Dec. 27 -- A studious boy of about 13 sits in Burlington City Hall, reading, drawing and listening to the radio, while Burlington police, State police and other authorities endeavor to find out who he is.

TRAVEL LINES: Bubble baths and bubble pipes have longbeen part of the everyday scene. But now comes the bubble boat, a noncollapsible platter-shaped craft in which Miamians are having fun. It is a circular tube covered with waterproofed canvas; three minutes with, a bicycle pump inflates it. ...
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- Five or six South American goodwill swimmers easily defeated their American opponents in an exhibition at the Pennsylvania Athletic Association tonight.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Don't neglect those Christmas plants -- so easily overlooked in the excitement of the holiday season. Azaleas, cyclamen, ferns and others requiring plenty of moisture are best soaked in a pail a couple of times a week. . . . Birds appreciate their share of the holiday festivities. How about some special meals for them?

With centers of war industries showing the widest gains the semiannual survey of the realty market made by the National Association of Real Estate Boards reveals a further absorption in dwelling space in most communities and an upturn in trading and in prices.

This is a grim holiday season. At a time that is ordinarily the happiest of the year we are realizing with increasing clarity that we are fighting for our very existence as a nation. All that we hold dear is threatened by a political, economic and social system so alien and hostile to our own, so irreconcilably opposed to our own way of life, that both systems cannot exist together on the same planet.

An increase of 1 cent a package In the wholesale price of Lucky Strike cigarettes was announced yesterday by the American Tobacco Company. Retailers and jobbers said the rise would be reflected in the retail price of Lucky Strikes within a few days.

MANILA, Sunday, Dec. 28--Japanese subjected this undefended "open city" to murderous bombings yesterday, and today great fires crackled through the historic buildings of Manila's ancient walled city. The angry populace roared a demand for the United States Army to return for a "last man" stand.

WASHINGTON. THE secretary who has more secrets to keep than any other in the United States is Miss Grace Tully, acting secretary to President Roosevelt. For years she has taken all his dictation and done his typing.

WAR came to America in 1941. And so for the second time within the experience of many of its practitioners war came to the theatre. But this was a different kind of war and its approach was different.

Generalissimo Hitler In wartime, a major shake-up in an army general staff marks a period of crisis, generally a defeat. It is also the herald of a change, for new men seldom pursue the policies of those whom they replace. To fighting armies and to populations such a shake-up is a portent of new things to come, proof that methods used before must be revised.
SQUADRON and group insignia is an old story in the Army Air Forces, but individual insignia is something brand new that is being added for reasons of morale.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 27 -- Not before the secrets of Nazi Germany are unveiled by some future and, it is to be hoped, better Germany, will the whole truth and the full meaning of the taking over by Reichsfuehrer Hitler of the High Command of the army become definitely known.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 -- The question, "Will Russia fight Japan?" might be more easily asked in reverse -- "Why is Russia not fighting Japan?"

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Every Japanese, German and Italian alien living in seven West Coast States who has a short-wave radio set or a camera must turn them over to local police by 11 P.M. Monday night under an order issued by Attorney General Biddle today.

Chicago RECENT acquisitions to the Chicago Art Institute's collections have been hung in the New Accessions Gallery. Twenty-two works of art in all are shown, including water-colors, etchings, lithographs, engravings, pastels and a drawing, "Cliff Dwellers," by George Bellows.

American industry has taken a significant step in erasing its antipathy toward certain features of public education and has thrown its support behind a move for future close cooperation between industry and education, it was declared yesterday by Dr. Alonzo F. Myers, chairman of the National Education Association's Commission on the Defense of Democracy Through Education.

SEVERAL exhibitions have been planned by the exhibition committee of the Architectural League for the comng Winter. During January drawings and photographs showing the development of the city of Washington will be shown.

In a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia and made public yesterday at City Hall, William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, charges that "a prominent Brooklyn politician" is said to have received $4,000 from two associations of pinball machine operators to fight proposed legislation to outlaw such devices.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 27 (U.P.) -- British reinforcements on the Perak River front were reported tonight to be fighting off attacks by strong Japanese forces, some of which were guided by paid aboregines along secret jungle paths in an effort to outflank the imperial defense line.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Snow recently visited the Poconos and provided the region with its first taste of skiing, skating and tobogganing, and in view of this good omen, it is expected that snow sports will highlight the activities of the New Year's celebrations.

THAT rich and opulent setting, the Hotel Splendide of a dozen years ago, suits Mr. Bemelmans very well. It is with Mr. Bemelmans as guide a fascinating scene. "Women with fortunate faces and figures were as common as champagm bottles." at the Hotel Splendide.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The nation welcomed this week promulgation by President Roosevelt of a three-point labor policy banning strikes and lockouts for the war's duration, but there was no disposition in official quarters to believe that all work stoppages would be eliminated by this action.
THE exhibition "Modern Mexican Painters" recently closed at the Boston Museum. It will later be shown in Washington, Cleveland, Portland (Ore.), San Francisco and Santa Barbara.

FOR once New Year's resolutions are not going to be just a pleasantry in the dance world this year, for there is a definite need for resolve. The first dawn of 1942 will come at the end of approximately two dozen days of the most profoundry upheaving mental readjustment that dancers have ever faced.

"There comes a time in the affairs of men when they must prepare to defend not their homes alone hut the tenets of faith and humanity, on which their churches, their governments and their very civilization are founded. The defense of religion, of democracy and good faith among nations is all the same fight. To save one we must now make up our minds to save all."
LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuter) -- Results of football matches played in Britain today follow:

THE Katharine Cornell revival of "The Doctor's Dilemma" was definitely on the successful side. From the time it opened its preliminary run in Detroit last February, through thirtytwo weeks to its closing a fortnight ago in San Francisco, it took in $612,991,95.

Joseph D. Basson, president of Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, A.F. of L., assured the union's 2,000 members yesterday that its campaign to force Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and other distributors to withhold films from theatres that did not employ A.F. of L. projectionists "cannot fail -- Thurman Arnold, lawsuits or any one or anything else to the contrary notwithstanding."

At 2 P.M. (E.S.T.) on Friday, Jan. 2, the earth is in perihelion or at its closest approach to the sun. It will then be about 91,341,000 miles from the sun, or about 3,000,000 miles nearer than in July, when it is in Aphelion.

Establishment of a "Victory Production Headquarters" for the New York area by consolidating the bulk of the defense agency offices here at a single address in the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street, was announced yesterday by the regional information office of the Office for Emergency Management.
