MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin declared in an article written for The Melbourne Herald today that Australia refused to regard the war in the Pacific as a side issue to the war in Europe and placed her chief reliance in the United States.

Plans for the enlistment of a vast army of spiritual force in the metropolitan New York area were announced by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale at yesterday's morning's services at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 28 -- German military preparations in Bulgaria are being intensified and, with the massing of German troops in Southern Rumania along the Danube, German Army engineers are stringing staff telephone and telegraph lines between Sofia and strategic army bases, including Svilengrad, on the Turkish-Bulgarian frontier.
LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique said today:

MANILA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- An American officer arriving from the Northern Luzon front in the Lingayen Gulf zone reported tonight the Japanese appeared to be falling back at one point and that the situation in general was "very well in hand."

An honor accorded no other boxer in history goes to Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, in the ratings for the year 1941 by The Ring, a boxing publication. In a copyrighted article in its February issue, the magazine, of which Nat Fleischer is editor and publisher, names Louis "the fighter of the year" for the fourth time.
MANILA, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- A little cluster of Dominican fathers gathered around the main steel vault of the destroyed Santo Domingo Church today and prayed that the treasures stored in it were safe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 -- Through the device of the direct lie, Axis propagandists today sought to create panic among Americans in the Philippines by broadcasting that San Francisco had been bombed by Japanese aircraft which left it in flames.

American labor is showing "great powers of adaptability" in shifting the full force of its production strength from normal peacetime work to all-out war work, J. Douglass Brown, chief of the priorities branch of the labor division of the Office of Production Management, declared here yesterday.

There is a rather touching tale about the young Britishers who were bundled off to America at the beginning of the war, many of them without any more baggage than the smallest of satchels, and most of them ignorant of their destination.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Frankie Albert, All-America quarterback, who completed his last season of college football competition at Stanford this Fall, has been signed by Columbia to star in "The Spirit of Stanford." The studio will assign writers to the photoplay next week and production is scheduled to start in April, with the release planned for early next Fall.

HONOLULU, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- General Delos C. Emmons, commander of the United States Army in Hawaii, thanked the civilian population of Honolulu today for their cooperation since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 -- The Sugar Bowl was assured of a new tennis champion today when Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta, the only former winner in the tournament this year, bowed out, 7 -- 5, 7 -- 5, in the quarter-finals before Francisco Segura of Ecuador.

To the chefs of New York, the city that made him famous, Oscar Tschirky, "Oscar of the Waldorf," has given his 320-acre country estate at New Paltz, N.Y., for a retreat, a place where they may go for week-ends and Summer vacations, and for retirement when their days of catering to fastidious tastes are over.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The present world-wide conflict would have been avoided if the United States had accepted Woodrow Wilson's League of Nations peace plan, Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania said today in a radio talk marking the eighty-fifth anniversary of the late President's birth.

Immediate completion of the metropolitan area's system of express highways because of their strategic importance is urged in a report of the Regional Plan Association, Inc., released yesterday by George McAneny, chairman of the board.

Rents have been increasing only moderately throughout the country except in defense areas, Karl Borders, chief of the rent section of the Office of Price Administration, reported yesterday to the American Statistical Association on the second day of its 103d annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

Fortune, a seemingly sworn enemy of the Brooklyn Americans this season, decided to smile on Red Dutton's sextet instead last night. In their clash with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden the Brooklyn athletes were credited with two decidedly lucky goals, just enough to give Dutton's men an unlooked-for 2-to-l triumph over the National Hockey League leaders.

Advocates of a Federalized system of unemployment insurance benefits told the American Association for Labor Legislation yesterday that the present State system was inadequate to cope with the problems of post-war reconstruction and that the job insurance administrations of some States were threatened with bankruptcy even before the end of the war as a result of priorities unemployment.

Next week, the seventh of the Metropolitan Opera Association's season, will be marked by the first performance of Wagner's "Lohengrin," the role of Elsa to be sung by Astrid Varnay, the young Swedish-American soprano who has already appeared on short notice as both Sieglinde and Bruennhilde in "Die Walkuere."

HONOLULU, Dec. 28 -- One last chapter remains to be written about the heroic defense of Wake for fourteen days by an outnumbered detachment of fewer than 400 Marines -- how many survived and what toll they took of the attackers.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- German pressure against Moscow has been eased so much that factories dismantled during the period of greatest danger are now preparing to resume limited production, and workers in other plants, who to avoid travel during air attacks worked twenty-four-hour shifts and then rested for two days, are reverting to a normal schedule.

HONOLULU, Dec. 28 -- Thirteen survivors of the crew of the Lykes Brothers freighter Prusa landed today at Honolulu after nine harrowing days at sea in an open boat following an attack by an enemy submarine somewhere in the Pacific.
Three weeks of war in the Pacific ended yesterday with the Japanese still on the march toward death or conquest.

There may be a temporary setback in advertising volume in January, according to agency executives, but by February or March schedules in most cases will again be running freely on the bulk of nationally advertised products. The outbreak of war has temporarily upset the promotion plans of many advertisers and the instinct has been to cancel or curtail until new themes could be worked out.

Larry Adler, whose playing has considerably raised the status of the harmonica, and Paul Draper, whose performances have done a similar service for tap dancing, last night gave a joint recital in an auditorium in which neither of them had appeared before -- Carnegie Hall, no less.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Speculative interest in the wheat market last week was regarded as having established a new low record, but there was a sharp recovery in prices late after a moderate decline. The recovery was a result of unconfirmed reports yesterday that the Office of Price Administration's ceiling on fats and oils would be lifted to about the basis prevailing on Oct. 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Federal non-defense expenditures can be reduced by more than $2,000,000,000 without curtailing essential social services, the Brookings Institution declares in a study made public today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- Two men were killed and their companions, two women and two men, were injured when their station wagon skidded on Lancaster Pike in Haverford and struck a pole early today. All in the group were returning from a wedding.

HONOLULU, Dec. 28 -- The first Japanese pilot shot down of the group that launched the Dec. 7 attack on Pearl Harbor and other Army and Navy bases on the Hawaiian Islands found his belt of 1,000 stitches no protection against American bullets.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 -- Hurling his long, lithe frame over the cross-bar at the dizzy height of 15 feet, the thirteenth time he's reached that pole-vault pinnacle, Cornelius Warmerdam of San Francisco gave the spectators at the Sugar Bowl track meet their greatest thrill today, but it was a young New Yorker, Leslie MacMitchell of N.Y.U., who performed the real feat.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 -- Although the nation's output of steel dropped last week to 93 per cent of capacity, a decline of 4 1/2 points from the week before, this holiday curtailment was one of the smallest in the industry's history.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 28 -- The New Jersey Guard, designed as a force to substitute for the Federalized National Guard units of the State in an emergency, is being reorganized with the object of getting a personnel that can give extended periods of service without making an undue sacrifice of earning power in private pursuits.

Operating on the belief that turnabout is fair play, the New York Rovers gained two important objectives in their Eastern Hockey League game with the Atlantic City Sea Gulls at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon before 12,289. First of all, the Red Shirts avenged a setback at the hands of the Sea Gulls Saturday night by downing the visitors, 6 -- 4.

A new women's auxiliary police force to be stationed eventually at La Guardia Field will report this morning for duty at City Hall, it was announced yesterday by the Greater New York Office of Civilian Defense, 93 Park Avenue. The new corps, composed of forty volunteers from Queens, will begin immediate police training for their defense emergency posts as assistants to the regular airport patrol.

Further softening of the Canadian dollar represented the only significant variation in foreign currency values last week. On Friday remittance on the Dominion fell to 85.68 cents, lowest since April 1, with the close on Saturday at 86 cents, a loss of 5/8 cent from the preceding week, and 2 1/2 cents since the beginning of December.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Evidence that the nation's colleges intend to hold fast to full athletic programs in the war crisis was offered today as early birds arrived here for four administrative conferences headed by the twenty-first annual session of the American Football Coaches Association.

The American Student Union, at its seventh annual convention opened yesterday at the Cornish Arms Hotel, adopted a resolution putting itself at the service of the country "to secure the destruction of Hitler and his partners, Japan and Italy."

We would not for one moment question the good intentions of the executive council of the New Jersey Licensed Beverage Association in instructing its members "to be on watch for spies and subversive whisperers in taverns." We don't want subversion, sedition and plots against the public safety, either in taverns or outside of taverns.

Before very long, Americans will have to become accustomed to doing without many of the things they have been in the habit of taking for granted. To many brought up in the tradition that this was a land of plenty, an almost self-sufficient nation, this will come as a shock.
The New York Americans and Brookhattan played to a 1-1 draw in their American Soccer League game at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday before 4,000.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just returned from the South if France, where I have been living both during the war and for a year and three months after the armistice.

ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- New York State's residents are growing healthier, according to a demographic report issued today by Dr. J.V. de Porte, director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Department of Health. The mortality rate for persons between 25 and 45 declined 34 per cent in the ten years from 1930 to 1940, while the decrease was 15 per cent for those between 45 and 65 years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Pointing out that they can replenish their stocks at the prices prevailing when the United States entered the war, Price Administrator Leon Henderson today called upon retailers to hold stable the price of sugar and prevent hoarding and profiteering, which, he said, constituted a "scandal" in the last war.
MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 -- Year-end evening up was the main trading interest in cotton futures here last week, with prices narrower than for many weeks and would-be traders inclined to await price control legislation before taking sides.

Determined that illegal day or night parking must go in the interest of city safety, Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran announced yesterday that the penalty for such violations would be increased from $2 to $4 for first offenders, while second offenders must appear in person before a magistrate.

Events in the Pacific recall an interview in The Hague about a year before the outbreak of the war with Dr. Hendrik Colijn, then Prime Minister of the Netherlands. Dr. Colijn is now reported under arrest by the German authorities, and his fate will surprise him no more than it surprises those who remember his independent spirit.

Tomorrow night's scheduled premiere of "The Lady Comes Across" at the Forty-fourth Street has been delayed until Friday evening. This indicates quite a sacrifice on the part of the management, because it is foregoing the profitable returns from the New Year's Eve performance.

Bishop Manning of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in his Christmas Sunday sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday, declared that it had become clear to all that the forces that this country and its allies are fighting are seeking to destroy all that Christmas represents in the lives of men.

Holiday and year-end influences prevailed in the cotton market last week. Trading was slow and price movements unusually narrow. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts made net gains for the week of 1 to 6 points.

TOKYO, Dec. 28 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese forces in the Philippines refuse to be bound by the United States declaration of Manila as an open city, a War Office spokesman said today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 28 -- That the British naval action off the Norwegian coast, which included landings at certain points on the coast, was a considerable success appears from the admission of Norwegian official sources that "heavy fighting broke out at several points" and that "the enemy succeeded in carrying out some destruction" and had sunk several "harmless Norwegian ships."

TALL, dark and handsome Fritz Crisler, the most successful president of the American Football Coaches Association in some years, will rap for order in a, Detroit hotel today and the annual three-day convention of the master minds of the gridirons will get under way.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The Norwegian coast was raided last night by a British attacking force, including small units of the army, navy and Royal Air Force, the Admiralty announced today. The operation, which was "entirely successful in all respects," was the first in which it was stressed that all three fighting services took part.
MANILA, Monday, Dec. 29 -- Undefended Manila received a second savage bombing yesterday, leaving an inferno of burning churches, homes and office buildings. Many dead are still in the debris.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 -- The New York Rangers climbed to within one point of the second place Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League race tonight by defeating the Detroit Red Wings, 3 to 1, before 7,887 fans.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Curtin's emphatic views concerning the paramount importance of the Pacific front in the war have received an encouraging reply from Prime Minister Winston Churchill, official sources said today.
NEW YORK Mrs. Charles F. Havemeyer, now at the Beekman, will give a dinner tonight in the Persian Room of the Plaza.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Free French must be shocked and disillusioned by the United States' movement to return the converted islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon to Vichy.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Optimism overshadowed anxiety for the first time today as British Malaya began its fourth week of war in the Pacific with the announcement that imperial troops had beaten back the Japanese, inflicting heavy losses, in the Chemor area of Perak State.

VICHY, Dec. 28 -- Last week, interrupted by the Christmas holidays, could have little interest from the financial viewpoint. The Lyon Bourse was open only three days, with the same tone as in the preceding week, and many stocks could not be quoted.
ST. PIERRE, Miquelon, Dec. 28 -- Vice Admiral Emile Muselier, head of the Free French forces here, said tonight the organization of the defense of the islands was now completed.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 28 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 29 -- The outstanding gap in the general public's official knowledge of antiAxis conferences throughout the world was closed last midnight, when British censors finally released an announcement that Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden had been conferring in Moscow for some time.

No doubt the gravity of this hour contributes something to a playgoer's appreciation of Howard Koch's and John Huston's "In Time to Come," which was acted at the Mansfield last evening. But even in the ambiguous period that preceded our going to war, this drama about Woodrow Wilson and the League of Nations would have been profoundly sobering and impressive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- All-out production by the nation's cotton textile mills was urged by the Office of Production Management, which said increasing defense demands and "certain requirements for lease-lend and friendly foreign governments," were responsible.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FORCES on Southeast Luzon Front, Dec. 28 (U.P) -- Outnumbered American and Philippine troops dug in among the coconut groves fringing the Tiaong River about sixty-five miles southeast of Manila today for a stand against 10,000 to 15,000 Japanese invaders pushing up the Tabayas Isthmus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Office of Production Management called today for the operation of vocational schools and other training programs twenty-four hours a day to help offset a shortage in skilled workers for war industries, and also appealed against year-end shut-downs of defense factories to prevent the loss of any man-hours of labor.

Catholic sociologists must go further than analysis of situations and presentations of findings -- they must "do something about it that will make for the good society" -- the Rev. Francis J. Friedel, president of the American Catholic Sociological Society, told 200 members of that group yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor.

A marked desire on woman's part to tuck her feet into sturdy, comfortable shoes for daytime wear is reported by New York's shoe buyers and stylists. The acceleration of civilian defense, it would appear, has caused an increase in the sale of the lowheeled oxford and the sport shoe, particularly those made of enduring, easy-to-groom leather.

Declaring that we restrict our thinking about sacredness too much to Sunday, the church and the Bible, Bishop Herbert Welch said yesterday that we need, more than anything else today, to remember the spirituality of common things in life and to consecrate our labor to the service and glorification of God.

The race between Brooklyn College and City College for the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League championship became closer last night after the fourth round, with the champion Brooklyn quartet holding the lead with a point total of 12 -- 2, against the Lavender's 11-1.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 28 -- The Japanese today began what appeared to be their first attempt at an invasion of the Netherlands Indies, heavily bombing the big airport at Medan, Sumatra, across the Straits of Malacca from British Malaya, and also landing parachute troops.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Gloria Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, 17-year-old New York heiress, the best known of the nation's "poor little rich girls" because of family quarrels as to guardianship, became a bride at noon today at a low nuptial mass in Santa Barbara's "Queen of Missions."

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Coach Lon Stiner has two left-handed right halfbacks on his thirty-one-man Oregon State squad and he's so sure the passing offense he's built around them is going to astound both Duke and the 56,000 fans who are going to be stuffed into Duke Stadium for the Rose Bowl football game on Jan. 1 that he's paying little attention to polishing the Beaver defense.

In final days before the State's "Safety-Responsibility" law becomes effective Thursday, motorists are hastening to obtain automobile insurance as protection against harsh legal penalties, a survey indicated yesterday.

The telephone was busy Saturday, for every angler who had planned a trip offshore to haul in cod, ling or whiting was disappointed at the dock, when he found the open-party boats had been discontinued pending a decision by government authorities as to what regulations will be enforced.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The American Association of University Professors rebuked Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia today for his "political interferences" in the University of Georgia. The protest was made at the closing session of the association's annual convention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Extensive revisions of the paper-board price schedule, which will permit mark-ups by wholesale distributors and exporters on the same basis as during the twelve months ended on Sept. 30, were ordered today by Price Administrator Leon Henderson.

Two basketball powers of the Far West -- Oregon State and Wyoming -- will make their Madison Square Garden debuts tonight, encountering Manhattan and City College, respectively, in the second of three holiday season doubleheaders at the arena.
BEAUMONT, Texas, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Chick Harbert of Battle Creek, Mich., won the 55,000 Beaumont open golf tournament today with last-day rounds of 67 and 71 for a 72-hole total of 276.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The texts of President Roosevelt's message to the people of the Philippines and the Navy's statement on the fleet follow:

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The new women's corps in General Charles de Gaulle's ever-expanding forces is led by a woman with a price upon her head. Her name and the story of how she got to London from Paris will have to be told later because her son is a prisoner in Occupied France.

MOST of us still wonder about the Soviet Union. There are a few ossified partisans, pro or con, who know all the answers and knew them from the start, but these are the special illuminati. Most of us still wonder, and with good reason.

Further criticism of Mayor La Guardia's dual status as the city's chief executive and the nation's Director of Civilian Defense developed yesterday in the wake of his acceptance of the resignation of William Fellowes Morgan Jr., Markets Commissioner.

Rose Pauly, the Metropolitan soprano, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. The program contained Cleopatra's aria from Handel's "Alexander Balus"; German Lieder by Schumann and Brahms; two "Biblical Songs" by Dvorak and the "Song to the Moon" from that composer's opera "Rusalka," given in Czech; a group of Czechoslovak folksongs, "Granados's "Lamajo dolorosa" and "El majo timido," sung in Spanish, and Ariadne's monologue, "Es gibt ein Reich" from Strauss's "Ariadne auf Naxos."

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- With Christmas intervening, the stock markets here experienced an exceptionally quiet week. They managed nevertheless to shake off some of the depression caused by the gravity of the war news from the Far East and to take a more hopeful view of the military situation.

LONDON, Monday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Premier Joseph Stalin have been in conference in Moscow for the past two weeks and have reached an agreement in full on conduct of the war and especially on "the necessity for the utter defeat of Hitlerite Germany," the Foreign Office disclosed in a historic announcement at midnight.

FIELD HEADQUARTERS, United States Forces on North Luzon Front, Dec. 28 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. J.M. Wainwright's defense army, blasting to bits several Japanese tanks that charged the American lines with bright lights, have "considerably slowed up" the enemy advance in the Lingayen zone some ninety miles north of Manila, a communique said tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Texas Christian's Orange Bowl football team arrived today and within an hour Coach Dutch Meyer had the players on the practice field. Several hundred persons greeted the Texans at the railroad station.
BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Dec. 28 -- Fordham got the good news today that Jim Lansing's injury, sustained in the all-out scrimmage against Coach Andy Kerr's Eastern All-Stars on Friday, was not serious.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Paced by several members of Michigan's intercollegiate champions, Western swimmers swept to a 62-30 victory today in the annual East-West relays held as part of the International Aquatic Forum.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Dimitri Mitropoulos, was heard yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall in a program devoted to works by Ferruccio Busoni and presented in commemoration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of that composer's birth.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 28 -- The main body of the Australian Expeditionary Force still are at their battle stations between the Japanese advancing through Northern Malaya and Singapore. Those who have talked to these men and their leaders are confident that if and when the Japanese reach their preserve they will meet defense in depth and offensive tactics far more formidable than the British have been able to offer in Northern Malaya.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- The third Secor Farms schooling horse show was held today, with a card of thirty-one well-filled classes.

Activity in the wholesale market last week centered for the most part on last-minute Christmas orders. Occasional calls came in for January sales and new Spring merchandise. A fair volume of business was done on popular-priced dresses, on which stores reported very good sales.

Except for some isolated incidents, there has been a marked absence of hysterical outbreaks against aliens in this country since Japan attacked us and since Germany and Italy declared war against us. People generally have seemed to realize without admonishment that victory will not be hastened by kicking dachshunds off the streets, by chopping down Japanese cherry trees or by refusing to eat spaghetti.

Consolidation of a large stock exchange firm will become effective today when Winthrop, White-house Co. open their doors at 1 Wall Street. As a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange the new concern will continue the business of the eastern division of Winthrop, Mitchell Co., formed in 1929 as an outgrowth of the former Harris, Winthrop Co., and that of Whitehouse Co., established in 1828.

The task of finding out what civil liberties mean "in real life" and in what form they can be preserved now without giving aid to the enemy or impeding the war effort is a major job for the sociologists today, Dr. Stuart A. Queen, retiring president of the American Sociological Society, told 600 members of that group last night at the Hotel Roosevelt.

In a pastoral letter read in all Catholic churches in the New York archdiocese yesterday, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman declared that President Roosevelt's proclamation designating New Year's Day as a national day of prayer "is an answer to the prayer of many Americans that all Americans may realize that the fundamental strength of our country is the strength that comes from God."

The Treasury Department, Walt Disney and Random House are devising "Walt Disney's Victory March," a combined children's book and defense bond enterprise. Some perforated sheets with spaces for defense stamps will be included, and the publishers will start off the idea by including a first stamp in each book.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 27 (delayed) -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell's visit to Chungking, China, underlines indications that a joint British, Chinese and American military effort of major proportions through Yunnan Province and Burma against the Japanese flank in Indo-China and Thailand is likely before long, it was believed here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The American Automobile Association declared today in a warning broadcast to the 27,000,000 private passenger car owners of the country that tire conservation is no longer a matter of choice or money-saving, but rather a necessity if motor transportation is to hold its place in American economy and play its proper role in the victory effort.

The newly named Concert Theare in West Fifty-eighth Street last night played host to Martha Graham in her first appearance of the season, and an audience of typical Graham size made the walls fairly bulge.

Changes in the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Engine-men's life and disability insurance to meet changed requirements and provide a wider selection of policies were announced yesterday by David B. Robertson, president. The insurance is backed by reserves of $23,500,000 and covers 56,000 of the union's 100,000 members.

In addition to its program for civilian defense and emergency relief, the American Red Cross War Fund will also aid men in the armed forces, Leon Fraser, general chairman of the Greater New York Red Cross War Fund, which is seeking to raise $7,330,000 toward the national goal of $50,000,000, explained yesterday.

Until last week there had been little check to the decline which started with the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, on Sunday, Dec. 7. From, the highest of the month, THE TIMES'S stock average had declined 9 points at the beginning of last week, and the bond average had lost about 2 points in a few days after outbreak of war in Hawaii.
BERLIN, Dec. 28 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The text of the German communique today follows:

Without preliminary warning Mayor La Guardia made a flying inspection tour yesterday of five key police precincts in Manhattan, remaining in each station house long enough for a discussion with the commanding officer of plans for meeting an air raid emergency, and checking on the manner of enrollment of air raid wardens and the keeping of their registration records.
A Coast Guard official said yesterday that shipping in the New York area, which has been disrupted by new restrictive regulations, probably would be "back to normal operation" in three days.

Town Hall is arranging a group of defense courses to be given in the midtown area in cooperation with the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross and the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, it was announced yesterday by George V. Denny Jr., moderator of Town Hall.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose another 0.2 per cent up to 101.1. In general, price changes were moderate throughout the list. The farm products index rose 1.1 per cent to 92.7 as increases in fruits, poultry, cattle, cotton and potato prices more than offset decreases in hogs, lambs and grain prices.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- How to get $16,000 worth of equipment for the local civilian defense organization without spending any money seemed an insurmountable problem a week ago, but today the riddle is virtually solved, because the entire community of 3,500 persons pitched in.

Military requirements have become the overwhelmingly predominant factor in the financial position of the United States Government and, in the face of official warnings that the war may be a long one, "the country must be prepared to face tax and debt burdens of a magnitude never before conceived," the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, its monthly review of business and financial conditions, published today.
BURLINGTON, N.J., Dec. 28 The boy amnesia vicitm who has been a guest at Burlington City Hall since last Monday, when he was found here cold and hungry, was identified today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: D.A. Saunders criticizes Americans for making use of the slogan "Remember Pearl Harbor." In his letter he states that: "This struggle is too great, too fraught with consequences for all history, for ourselves, to insult the intelligence of our own people and belittle ourselves in the eyes of our allies with such childish nonsense."

The All-Stars who will meet the Chicago Bears in the National Football League Navy Relief Society benefit game next Sunday worked out at the Polo Grounds yesterday morning. Then they packed bag and baggage aboard a bus and moved to Garden City.

SOMEWHERE IN EUROPE, Dec. 28 -- The first major test between a French policy of collaboration and one of "wait and see" since the ousting of General Maxime Weygand is foreshadowed in reports reaching foreign diplomatic quarters here tonight.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Raw German troops 17 and 18 years old, making up most of the entire German division, dropped their arms and fled at the first Russian assault in the Kalinin sector, ninety-five miles northwest of Moscow, Red Army dispatches reported today as the Russian counter-offensive continued to regain ground north and south of the capital.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Raw German troops 17 and 18 years old, making up most of the entire German division, dropped their arms and fled at the first Russian assault in the Kalinin sector, ninety-five miles northwest of Moscow, Red Army dispatches reported today as the Russian counter-offensive continued to regain ground north and south of the capital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Senator Austin of Vermont predicted today that the United States, Britain, Russia, China and other nations battling the Axis powers would have to work out a plan for stabilizing their monetary exchanges "in order to coordinate efficiently our full war effort."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Striking back at Japanese claims that our Pacific Fleet had been sunk and that we were powerless to aid the hard-pressed defenders of the Philippines, the Navy tonight promised "positive assistance" and President Roosevelt pledged the entire resources of the United States in the "great and common, cause."

Henry W. Ralph appointed by Mayor La Guardia Saturday as first city-wide Register, announced last night that he would start work immediately after being sworn in at the Mayor's office at I1 A.M., New Year's Day.

HARRISBURG. Ill., Dec. 28 -- Eight men were trapped by an explosion in Peabody Coal Mine No. 47 at Harco, seven miles northwest of here, at about 3:30 A.M., today and tonight seven bodies had been recovered. Eight men fled to safety. Two others were injured.

Air defense of the Atlantic coastal frontier, from Maine to North Carolina and west to the Mississippi, is based on the enemy's capabilities rather than his probable intentions, Brig. Gen. John Chilton McDonnell, commanding general of the First Interceptor Command, Mitchel Field, said yesterday.

The first group of Latin-American youths who will receive aviation training in the United States at the invitation of the Federal Government arrived in this country yesterday on a United States liner.

The colorful ski patrol is one of the most interesting developments of warfare. Receiving its first big test in the World War, skiing revealed its value as an effective mode of travel and transport in the high mountain valleys.

The world faces collective suicide unless it becomes one family, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday morning in a sermon at Riverside Church on "The Christmas Message Girds Us for the New Year." He asserted that it is God's desire that man develop "a federated world that will outlaw war, and create a human family decent for future generations to be born into."

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Corn showed independent strength last week in the grain markets as the result of limited country offerings and official reports indicating that the number of hogs on farms in 1942 would be the largest on record.

Deep sympathy for the orphaned, homeless children among the Neediest, which has been marked throughout the 1941 appeal on behalf of the most distressed men, women and children of the city, was shown again by a number of the eighty-three contributors who sent $1,602.75 yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- There were twenty-seven boats out under sail on Long Island Sound today in the dinghy regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. The winners were Dick Baxter with his Class B craft Stinger and Bill Dodge with his X boat Moth Ball.
Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, issued yesterday the following year-end statement:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The plebiscite of St. Pierre and Miquelon reminds one of that taken in the Sudetenland when Hitler imposed his will on the people of that State, but the reminder is such only in its difference of free and untrammeled expression of an honest opinion.

Others may think of the waning year in their own terms, but the countryman recognizes any year for what it is -- another round of the seasons, another time of planting, of growing, of reaping. These are matters of eternal consequence, and nothing that man may do can change them.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 28 -- While operations in Western Cyrenaica paused, apparently awaiting either a battle or the complete retreat of the Germans into Tripolitania, Royal Air Force and Free French bombers pounded the isolated enemy force at Bardia yesterday, blasting pillboxes, gunnery defense positions, trucks and barracks buildings.
For the New Year John Smith is considering the subject of New Year's resolutions and finds that this year it is not the simple matter it used to be.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 29 (AP) -- British mobile columns drawing a noose around the main Axis forces at Agedabia, eighty miles south of Bengazi, were reported officially tonight to have smashed six tanks in a sharp prelude to the conclusive battle in Cyrenaica.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The prospect of further improvements in gilt-edge securities is considered encouraging as large interest disbursements will be made early in the new year, and it is expected that a substantial amount of the Indian requisition money will seek reinvestment in this market.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Dr. Albert Einstein, once a militant pacifist, said tonight the democracies eventually would win over the totalitarian powers, but that "we must strike hard and leave the breaking to the other sides."

The twelve-story apartment house at 563 Park Avenue, on the northeast corner of Sixty-second Street, and the adjoining three-story dwelling at 111 East Sixty-second Street, have been purchased by a syndicate headed by Nathan Wilson, the realty operator, from the 563 Park Avenue Company, King Smith, president, in a transaction negotiated by Wm. A. White Sons.
In the face of many handicaps, the steel industry accomplished an extraordinary feat of production in 1941. according to Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

President Roosevelt's message to the people of the Philippines, expressing his admiration for their gallant struggle against the Japanese aggressor, and his pledge that the independence of their islands will be established and protected, evokes an echo in the heart of every American. It is true that the Filipinos have the strongest and most primitive motive for fighting -- the defense of their homes and families against an alien enemy-but that is not all.

Mayor La Guardia brushed aside questions yesterday about the resignations on Saturday of Commissioner William Fellowes Morgan Jr. and Mrs. Preston Davie from the Markets Department by saying "E finita la commeddia" -- Italian for "the comedy is finished."

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday anticipated by fifty-eight years the scheduled redemption of the mortgage held by Vincent Astor on part of the land where First Houses, its initial project, was erected six years ago, and now holds the property free and clear of liens.

McCOMB, Miss., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Will Price, a local boy who went to Hollywood and made good as a film dialog director in "Gone With the Wind" and other hits, married Maureen O'Hara, screen actress, whose latest starring role was in "How Green Was My Valley," this afternoon in the picturesque St. Mary of the Pines Convent at near-by Chatawa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Dec. 13 was 10,701,960 shares, compared with 6,285,000 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

An intensive sale of defense bonds and stamps in Manhattan and Brooklyn stores will begin within the next few days, it was announced yesterday by William M. Holmes, president of Bonwit Teller and chairman of the retail division of the Greater New York Committee of the New York Defense Savings Staff.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A British Headquarters communique issued today:

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The main spearhead of a broad Japanese offensive in Central China was reported in Chinese dispatches today to have driven southward to within forty miles of Changsha, capital of Hunan Province, and now for the third time the objective of a major Japanese drive.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Temple rebounded from a 64-36 defeat at the hands of Washington two days ago to down Southern California, 49 to 46. in the feature of a college basketball double-header at Convention Hall tonight before a crowd, of 4,000.

Toward the close of the last war we began to hear of the importance of nutrition in maintaining proper standards of health and to talk of vitamins instead of calories. Then came a justified concern for the health of the millions of young men drafted for military service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Senator Elbert D. Thomas, Democrat of Utah, who probably is the only member of Congress who can speak and write Japanese, said today he was confident that Japan will be crushed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- With salable hog receipts close to the year's record run, buyers would take offerings only at substantial mark-downs today. Losses ranged from 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds, with a top of $11.40 compared with $11.60 last week-end. Dressed pork was relatively strong, with light loins at 20 to 21 cents a pound.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 29 -- While reporting new successes in explorations of the universe, astronomers are laying plans to help win the war, in many cases using the same instruments for the second purpose as the first. Amateur astronomers, already absorbed in the nation's heavily burdened optical industry, are also in demand as navigators of long-distance bombers.

MANILA, Dec. 29 -- Not the least problem facing the United States authorities in Manila, in the absence of Francis B. Sayre, High Commissioner, and General Douglas MacArthur, is the disposal of three to four thousand Americans with maximum safety in the event of the occupation of this city by the Japanese.
Meeting defense needs was the prime objective of the Canadian National Railways in 1941, R.C. Vaughan, president, said yesterday in his annual review.

Deploring the increasing number of marriages among Selective Service registrants in an attempt to evade military service. Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service for New York City, defended yesterday as "eminently logical and just" the recent measures adopted by the government to eliminate "draft-dodgers."
William Atkinson Walling, former Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, died yesterday at Post-Graduate Hospital of a brain in-jury suffered in an automobile accident Dec. 21. He was 74 years old.

Not Mark Twain One badly needed New Year's resolution is a pledge not to attribute funny stories to Mark Twain without looking up the chapter and page. This column the other day credited Mark Twain with a remark about an angel effectively disguised as a small boy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- After an unprecedented conference of two and three-quarter hours with the presidents of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, Secretary Perkins said today that it was likely that President Roosevelt would appoint a War Labor Board this week to settle all labor disputes without strikes or lockouts.

For the season s first performance of "Rigoletto" last night, the Metropolitan Opera assembled a cast that was peopled, save in one minor role, by American singers. Not only could it be done, but the management could also provide replacements for most of these roles with other Americans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Australian and Netherlands Governments have both expressed the strong view to this government that the Western Pacific is an area of warfare equal in importance to Europe and have insisted that this be taken account of in arranging disposal of anti-Axis forces and supplies.

A FEW days ago our beloved Mr. Cornelius McGillicuddy, known almost since the beginning of time as baseball's Connie Mack, celebrated his seventy-ninth birthday, and when you stop to consider that close on to sixty of those years have seen him actively associated with our national pastime one begins to get an idea just how vital a part of the game Philadelphia's Grand Old Man of the Tower really has been -- and still is.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 -- The nation's football coaches today adopted a hands-off policy on their playing code and passed only relatively minor suggestions, all designed to aid the offense, on the game's rule makers.

Heretofore announced as an offering by the Shuberts, "Johnny on a Spot" will bear the name of young John Shubert as its sponsor when it opens on Thursday night, Jan. 8, at the Plymouth. This venture will mark Mr. Shubert's formal entry into the Broadway managerial ranks.

The rate of rearmament in the United States is proceeding faster than it did in Germany or any other country, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Statistical Association at the Hotel Biltmore. The report was made by Lester Kellogg of the Office of Production Management and was read by Richard O. Lang, a War Department official.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- More than 1,000 librarians and library trustees from all parts of the country today pledged the full resources of their institutions to the government in its all-out war effort, and concurred with Charles H. Brown, president of the American Library Association, in his appeal to avoid, at all costs, "a wave of hysteria."
WASHINGTON. Dec. 29 -- The War Department released the following orders today; dated Dec. 27.

Dr. Sumner H. Slichter, president of the American Economic Association, appealed, last night for broad cooperation among conflicting groups in our economy as the only means of solving the problem of private employment. Dr. Slichter spoke at a joint meeting of the American Economic and Statistical Associations at the Hotel Commodore, where he and Winfield W. Riefler delivered presidential addresses.

Governor Eugene Talmadge of Georgia once boasted that he could carry any county that didn't have a street car. He didn't say what the probable effect of a bus line might be. Presumably he intended to suggest that voters who were not exposed to the debilitating influences of newspapers, radios, electric lights, and vitamin B would naturally vote for Talmadge.

Incendiary bombs became more than words yesterday to 150 women attending a fire-fighting lecture and demonstration. Through the efforts of a Fire Department representative, they were translated into understandable possibilities, easily curbed by a well-equipped, properly informed home owner.

In the Iridium Room of the St.Regis last night Mr. and Mrs. J. Carlisle MacDonald gave a dinner with dancing to introduce their daughter, Miss Dorothy Joan Mac-Donald. The debutante, who was born in Paris, attended the Cours Fenelon and the Cours de Champs Elysees in France and also schools in England before coming to this country.

The cast of the Japanese military mind is such that it is really not surprising to find the commanding officer of Tokyo's expeditionary forces in China declaring that the fall of Hong Kong at last removes "all fetters" imposed by foreigners on China and at last "frees" the Chinese people for co-operation in the building of a New Order.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Eight enemy ships, totaling 15,650 tons, shore batteries, oil tanks and ammunition stores were destroyed in Saturday's spectacular daylight raid by British army, naval and air forces on the German-occupied islands of Vaagsoe and Maaloy, off the Norwegian coast, it was revealed today.

Following the capacity pace set on Christmas Day, Broadway's first-run film theatres continued to play to record audiences over the week-end, a survey yesterday disclosed. The Roxy's tenant, "Remember the Day," broke all records for that theatre since its opening in 1927 when 89,749 persons paid a total of $58,858 during the four days ending Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The upward swing in production of electric power for public consumption continued in November, the Federal Power Commission reported today. The total was 14,230,305,000 kilowatts, an increase of 13.7 per cent over November, 1940.

LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force dealt heavy blows on Western Germany and Nazi-held continental teases last night in a fiery and destructive climax to a week-end of assaults by land, sea and air along the 1,000-mile front from Norway to occupied France.

The Good Neighbor policy is "just a phrase" that cannot be made to work until the elimination of "resentment and mistrust" between the Anglo-American and the Latin-American, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. Lucio Mendieta y Nunez, director of the institute for social investigation of the University of Mexico.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a physician, the welfare of the people in the Yorkville-East Harlem district where I have resided for more than thirty years has been for a long time in my mind. More recently, since 1940 to be exact, when I was elected as Republican representative to the State Senate, I have been thinking: in general terms as well as of the individuals known to me.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 29 (AP) -- A. woman's place may have been in the home, but that was before our entry into the war.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Adams of 4 East Seventy-second Street gave a dance last night on the St. Regis Roof to present to society their daughter, Miss Phyllis Anne Adams.

Temporary Assignments SERGEANTS Thomas A. Corcoran from 14th Precinct to 3d Division, assigned as Supervisor of Plain Clothes Patrolmen, for 15 days, from 8 A.M. Jan. 1: Thomas A. Mooney from 30th Precinct to Motor Transport Maintenance Division, assigned to clerical duty for 15 days, from 8 A. M. Jan. 1.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 29 -- Steve Owen, the man who's coming back for more, was in a surprisingly cheerful frame of mind today as he supervised the National Foot-ball League's All-Stars in preparation for their clash with the Bears in the Navy Relief Society benefit game at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 29 -- Mounting Japanese pressure in Northern Malaya has pushed back the Imperial defenders and driven a spearhead through or around Ipoh, from which a first-class highway and a railroad run 290 miles down to Singapore, British Headquarters reported today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Katharine Hepburn and Spencer Tracy will be co-starred by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in "American Cavalcade,'' a panorama of American history from 1620 to the present, the studio announced today. George Froeschel and Arnold Phillips are writing the scenario from a screen story by Froeschel and Sidney Franklin has been named to produce the photoplay.

NORTHERN LUZON FRONT, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- A United States Army lieutenant, rifle at shoulder, crouched at the end of a bridge a few days ago. picked off one by one the Japanese manning a machine-gun nest and saved a Filipino battalion.

Miss Grace Uhthoff of Hunter won the annual Christmas invitation fencing tournament held at Brooklyn College yesterday, when she defeated the intercollegiate champion, Miss Grace Acel of Cornell, in a fence-off, 4 to 2.

The b uests made to charitable and educational organizations by Frederick W. Vanderbilt, railroad director, yachting enthusiast and grandson of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt, founder of the family fortune, were disclosed as totaling $11,114,609 in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday by Deputy State Tax Commissioner Jacob Manicoff.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Admiralty, Army and Royal Air Force issued this communique today:

Tax selling ran roughshod over the stock market yesterday, and with volume again concentrated in low-priced issues business on the Stock Exchange was the heaviest of 1941 and in more than a year and a half. Marking the fourth time this year that sales had crossed the 2,000,000-share mark, the total was 2,925,455 shares, compared with 1,410,810 on last Friday.

Following up his drive to cut traffic congestion, Mayor La Guardia warned garage owners yesterday against increasing their parking charges as a result of the police drive on street parkins and signed a local law banning itinerant peddling, which he described as another important source of street congestion.
The off-shore fishing boats may continue to operate on the fishing banks, and anglers need only supply sufficient identification to prove their citizenship in order to spend a day off-shore.

Two Far Eastern insurance companies that have had an active part in the American ocean marine insurance field here for many years are continuing in business without any impairment from the seizure of Hong Kong and Shanghai by the Japanese military, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Dec. 24 aggregated 512,784,000,000.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 29 (A.P) -- The British Middle East Command issued the following communique today:

The resignation of William Fellowes Morgan Jr. as Commissioner of Markets is a serious loss to the City of New York. As a member of the original "cabinet" for the past eight years, Mr. Morgan has served with great distinction. It was largely because the Mayor had brought into the service of the city officials of the character and ability of Mr. Morgan that so many people supported his administration in the recent election.

Benjamin Caplan of the Office of Production Management called yesterday for a master plan in the allocation of scarce raw materials to assure their smooth flow into defense industries. He said current procedures were inadequate.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin today completed plans for a tremendous expansion of aircraft production, which the War Cabinet is scheduled to approve tomorrow.

Pledging the efforts of the country's largest retail food distributing organization to back government agencies in prevention of unwarranted advances in food prices, John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, has begun publication in some 3,000 newspapers of an advertisement outlining a working program for company cooperation in the war effort.
BERLIN, Dec. 29 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

CORAL, GABLES, Fla., Dec. 29 -- When the Saratoga Stable's roguish gelding Volitant finished out of the money in the Miami Shores Purse at Tropical Park today it marked the sixth time in six races that the favorite failed to finish as good as third.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 30 -- Corregidor Island, the strongest fortress in the Orient, was raided by Japanese bombers yesterday. The United States Armed Forces in the Far East announced that a number of enemy planes had been shot down.

J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., as fiscal agents, announced yesterday that $281,000 of Republic of Cuba 5 per cent bonds of 1951, due in 1949, have been drawn for redemption on Feb. 1, 1942, at 102 1/2. Holders may receive payment by presenting the bonds at the office of the fiscal agent, or at the office of Morgan Grenfell Co., Ltd., in London on or after Feb. 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 24: Decreases of $92,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $101,000,000 in ballances with domestic banks, $66,000,000 in demand deposits-adjustjed and 5193,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and an increase of 558,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Japan's "treachery" and "barbarity" in her attacks on Pearl Harbor and undefended Manila have made it certain that American bombers eventually will bring "terrible retribution" to her capital of Tokyo, it was asserted today by Senator Barkley, majority leader, in a formal statement.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Political leaders viewed as extremely important tonight reports from officials indicating that the All-India Congress was about to overrule the policies of Mohandas K. Gandhi in favor of an approach toward war cooperation with Britain.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 29 -- Mr. and Mrs. Le Ray Berdeau entertained tonight with a dinner at which Lieut. Col. John W. Monahan, commanding officer at Morrison Field, and Mrs. Monahan, were honor guests.

CHICAGO Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- The National Football League called the roll tonight of the best professionals on the gridiron in 1941 giving fifteen of the twenty-two places on the twelfth All-League teams to Western Division clubs.

Service men may spend a leisurely New Year's Eve at an informal party at the New York City Defense Recreation headquarters 93 Park Avenue, or if they are more inclined to "do things," they make take advantage of the free entertainment tickets provided there for them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- In response to protests from commuters, the Interstate Commerce Commission has announced that it will hold a hearing on the application made by the Erie Railroad Company on Dec. 12 for permission to abandon its ferry service between its Jersey City and West Twenty-third Street terminals.

The transformation of Blitzkrieg warfare into a war of attrition, marked by the failure of the German Autumn campaigns against Moscow and the Caucasus, has steadily increased the toll of casualties. For the first time during this war Germany may soon begin to experience some shortage of manpower.
Two floors comprising about 18,000 square feet of space at 440 Fourth Avenue have been leased to the Brie Furniture Company, Inc., for showrooms through Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers.
Elizabeth, Lady Cheylesmore, left the Savoy-Plaza yesterday for Pinehurst, N.C.

In 1942, Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company will see to it that consumers continue thinking about "electrical living" and Westinghouse appliances, even though many purchases will have to be deferred until peace comes, Frank R. Kohnstamm, sales manager, announced yesterday.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 29 -- Nature is fighting on the side of the democracies, thereby making certain the downfall of their enemies, Dr. Albert F. Blakeslee of the Carnegie Institution of Washington told a large gathering of scientists in his address tonight as the retiring president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Germany, the Agriculture Department reported today, has encountered trouble in her campaign for a bigger 1942 crop of the bread grains so important to Europe's food supply.
Miss Joan Appleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Appleton of Newark, is visiting Miss Sue McLeod of Pittsburgh.

The most productive working week is limited to forty-eight hours for any one worker, it was unanimously agreed yesterday by labor department officials from New York and eight other States who met at the Hotel Commodore to formulate industrial policies for maximum war production.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 28 (Delayed) -- Many informed observers here believe that the way the Japanese have carried out their attack in the Southwest Pacific and in the South China Sea indicates a strategy of encirclement against the key objective -- Singapore -- instead of a direct assault. Netherland quarters here especially are watching the direction of the Japanese operations with this in mind.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 26 -- Preparations for the filming of an educational motion picture designed to further the economic development of South America and foster increased trade relations are under way here under the sponsorship of the Foreign Policy Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Dec. 20 totaled 243,617,000 barrels, according to data reported to the Bureau of Mines. Compared with the total of the preceding week, this represents an increase of 934,000 barrels.

As part of Police Commissioner Valentine's extraordinary precautions against the danger of air raids or panic when the expected New Year's Eve crowds fill Times Square tomorrow night, eight loudspeakers were hooked up at vantage points about Times Square and Duffy Square and tested yesterday.

A four-and-a-half-year study on the economic effects of advertising, conducted by the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, shows that advertising has been an essential ingredient in expanding the material welfare of the country, Professor Neil H. Borden of Harvard University reported yesterday to the American Marketing Association.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 -- Football's "war of nerves" is now on.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The first American outpost in the Pacific to fall into Japanese hands was the island of Guam. This valuable grain of sand in the infinite ocean lies about 1,500 miles east of Manila and 5,000 miles west of San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- More than 120,000 evacuees from areas in the Philippines bombed by the Japanese are being cared for by the American Red Cross, which has the "relief situation in the Manila area and the reception towns well in hand," according to a cablegram received here today from the island capital by Norman H. Davis, national chairman.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Nine-tenths of the low-numbered plates which, may be displayed on passenger automobiles after Thursday will be the same as last year, Carroll E. Mealey, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said today.
New York's historic 130-year-old City Hall received a new influx of 126 bright-eyed women volunteers yesterday, forty of whom were destined for duty at La Guardia Field.

Establishment of a Tire Rationing Board of six members to control the sale of tires and inner tubes to New York City car and truck owners was announced yesterday. Harold W. McGraw, vice president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, will serve as chairman and will be assisted by one representative for each of the five boroughs.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A communique issued here today said:
A dinner with dancing was given last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza by Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Lewis of 140 East Eighty-first Street to introduce their daughter, Miss Betty Lewis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced it will establish a ceiling over all manufacturers' cigarette prices on levels prevailing in the trade on Dec. 26.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 29 -- New effects of the parasites which kill disease germs in the same way that the microbes hill man were announced today at the annual meeting of the American Society of Bacteriologists.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. C.C. Winters's Off Guard was best of a field of six today in the Audubon Purse, mile and one-sixteenth feature of the Fair Grounds racing card.

Birmingham, Ala. The city of Birmingham, Ala., will enter the market on Jan. 15 with an issue of $4,250,000 of water works refunding bonds, for which bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent.

The final week of Christmas brought an increase of 34 per cent in sales for New York and Brooklyn department stores over the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A decline in the volume of reading done through the nation's libraries in the last twelve months was reported yesterday by the American Library Association. Attributing the decreased demand for books to the reading public's pre-occupation with, the war, the association also reported that the public's awareness and desire to be informed had resulted hi sharp shifts in reading tastes.

TOKYO. Dec. 29 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and Manila) -- The Japanese High Command announced today that it had received no request to respect Manila as an open city and, therefore, would continue to bomb it as long as is necessary "for military purposes."

Suits charging conspiracy and wasteful management were filed yesterday in six Federal courts by William G. Heiner, trustee of the Pittsburgh Terminal Coal Corporation, against the North American Coal Corporation, the Pittsburgh and West Virginia Railroad, the Pennroad Corporation, the Colonial Trust Company of Pittsburgh, the Land Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia, the Estate of Frank E. Taplin and others.

A thousand physicians filled to overflowing yesterday the lecture hall in the Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, at the second of a aeries of lecture conferences designed to prepare them for first-aid tasks in war-time. The meeting was part of the program to marshal community resources for civilian defense.

ST. PIERRE-MIQUELON, Dec. 29 -- Mgr. A. Poisson, Apostolic Prefect of the islands of St. Pierre, Miquelon and He aux Marins, posted the following message on the bulletin board in his church here today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- In indignant words the State Department denied today that ten Japanese nationals had been killed by Americans during the Japanese attack on Davao, island of Mindanao, in the Philippines. A Japanese protest against such an alleged incident was delivered through the Swiss Legation.

A steady demand for contracts by trade and commission house sources aided the cotton market yesterday to veer from the narrow course which characterized the movement of prices last week. Net gains of 12 to 15 points were registered in active futures traded on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The volume of business of Armour Co. (Illinois) and subidiaries, including Armour Co. of Delaware and its domestic and foreign subsidiaries, in the fifty-two weeks ended on Nov. 1 showed a gain of 26 per cent in dollars and 6 per cent in tonnage over the fifty-three weeks of the 1940 fiscal year, George A. Eastwood, president of the parent company, said yesterday in the annual report.

City College, by sweeping the boards against Rensselaer in the sixth and semi-final round of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League tournament last night, moved to within half a point of the leading Brooklyn College quartet.

Leaders of the C.I.O. and A.F. of L. were urged yesterday by Senator Joseph H. Ball, Minnesota Republican, to "grow up," stop their insistence on the closed shop principle and organizational drives and devote all their efforts to placing the nation's production facilities on an all-out war basis.
Asking that his contribution of $250 "In Grateful Memory of Capt. Colin Kelly Jr." go to meet the needs of a child, one of yesterday's donors to the Neediest Cases Fund wrote:

LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 30 -- Anthony Eden arrived in the United Kingdom last night full of pleasure over his Moscow conferences. Apparently the Foreign Secretary was most satisfied with the progress made at the conferences, and he had only such words as "generous" and "hospitable" to use about his visit.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick sold yesterday by allotment an issue of $30,000,000 of New York City revenue bills, dated Dec. 30, 1941. They were sold to the usual twenty-five banks and trust companies at an interest rate of 0.50 per cent.

Miss Gertrude Gretsch, daughter of Mrs. Walter Gretsch of 3 East Seventy-seventh Street, was presented to society last night at a supper dance given by her mother in the main ballroom of the Pierre. The debutante, who is now attending Finch Junior College, received with her mother in a bower of green smilax.

WITH THE BRITISH COMMANDOS, Somewhere in Southern Norway, Dec. 27 -- British Commandos, in a brisk five-hour, daylight house-to-house action, following a surprise dawn landing, fought to a virtual standstill crack Nazi troops of the Trondheim military area guarding the small German-occupied port of Vaagsoe, approximately half way between Trondheim and Bergen.

Another high honor was added to the laurels already gained by Leslie MacMitchell with the announcement yesterday that the New York University senior, the nation's premier miler, had been selected as the recipient of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy for 1941.

Market Activity Brokers ascribe most of the year-end market activity on the Stock Exchange to trading for tax purposes but they emphasized that 1941 is seeing not only tax sales but tax purchases. Traders wish to establish profits, fearing that the next tax bill will take a larger cut than the present one.

MANILA, Tuesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- This open city, still smoking from the week-end Japanese air raids, had a seventeen-minute alarm this morning, but no planes appeared, and the United States Armed Forces in the Far East at 11:45 A.M. issued its shortest communique of the war:

The railroads moved without congestion or car shortage this year a record volume of freight, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, said yesterday. They are confident they will meet demands in 1942 if materials for rolling stock and maintenance are available, he added.

BATAVTA, Java, Dec. 29 (U.P) -- Netherlands Indies bombers attacked another Japanese transport off Borneo, a communique announced today, while reports from Medan, on Sumatra across the Strait of Malacca from British Malaya, said that thirty persons had been killed and seventy wounded in the Japanese bombing of the airdrome there yesterday.

The purchase of $1,000,000 in defense bonds was pledged by members of Local 10 of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union at a meeting in Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue, last night.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Top-seeded Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., and Francisco Segura of Ecuador battled their way into the final round of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today.

Another collegiate basketball double-header is scheduled for Madison Square Garden tonight, the third in four days. This show will conclude the big holiday intersectional festival as Colorado University plays St. John's in the opener and the University of Washington squares off against N.Y.U in the finale.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Creation of a volunteer women's auxiliary corps which would take over many rear-line duties now performed by soldiers was recommended today by Secretary Stimson.

Although present world conditions have affected real estate, they have not left it bewildered, but instead have made it devise new methods of coping with a constant stream of new developments, according to C.T.S. Keep, president of Previews, Inc.

Norman H. Davis, national chairman of the American Red Cross in Washington, telegraphed yesterday to Leon Fraser, head of the Freater New York War Fund drive for $7,330,000, urging that this quota toward the national goal of $50,000,000 be pushed to "rapid oversubscription."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Domestic Finance Corporation of Chicago has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 61,484 shares of no-par value common stock.

COLUMBUS. Ohio, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Hay fever victims who blame ragweed as their irritant and those persons who break out in a rash if they get in the same county with a patch of poison ivy can take some hope from, an announcement of the uses of sulfamic acid made today at the symposium of the American Chemical Society's Division of Physical and Inorganic Chemistry by Dr. M.E. Cupery and Dr. W.E. Gordon.

Japanese air attacks upon the Corregidor Island fortress at the entrance to Manila Bay may mark the start of an attempt to reduce the fortress and to open the bay to Japanese warships. The island, on which Fort Mills is located, is America's "Gibraltar" and should be able to hold out under siege for several months.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Many suggestions have been made in regard to the saving of electricity for national defense use. I believe one of the greatest of these savings, aside from the adoption of daylight-saving time throughout the nation, would be the curtailment of the use of electric signs, especially in the cities.

A City College quintet that the seers had predicted was the best in the metropolitan area was upset by Wyoming, 49 to 45, before 14,377 fans at Madison Square Garden in a rough, ragged, but always exciting game last night. This startling development came after Manhattan had been toppled, 47 to 34, by quick-breaking Oregon State.

A show of broadsides called "Napoleon, the Invasion of England and the Downfall" opened yesterday at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain current until Jan. 10. It is installed in the two rear exhibition rooms on the ground floor.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Colgate, leading all the way, defeated Williams, 5 to 1, in the final round of the Lake Placid Club's Sam Packer Trophy hockey tournament tonight.

The Brewster Aeronautical Corporation announced yesterday that its directors had decided to omit declaration of a year-end dividend to conserve working capital for further expansion of wartime production schedules.

Three thousand city employes who had gathered outside City Hall last evening to listen to a Council discussion of pay increases for all city employes were informed half way through the hearing that Mayor La Guardia had ordered loudspeakers cut off because they were annoying him.

The conflict between price control on the one hand, which tends either to reduce production or switch industrial equipment to other lines, and the demand for more production of defense materials, which has been smoldering for several months, appeared yesterday to be approaching a show-down when cotton-mill executives learned that the Office of Production Management had set in motion plans to bring pressure upon them to make more bag materials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Treasury disclosed today that in the first twenty-six days of this month it spent $2,197,358,728, as compared with $2,061,000,000 in December, 1918, the most expensive month in the first World War period.

OTTAWA, Dec. 29 -- From sessions of Allied war planning in Washington and first-hand knowledge of the determination of the United States to fight the war to a finish. Prime Minister Winston Churchill came to Canada today to thank the government and people of the Dominion for the "magnificent aid" they had given during the past two years and for what was being done more and more intensely to win the conflict.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 29 -- Reports abroad confirming Ankara rumors that the British Ambassador to Turkey, Sir Hughe M. Knatchbull-Hugessen, had participated in the Moscow conference with British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden shocked and surprised Axis diplomatic and military circles here today and created a profound impression in neutral foreign circles in the Turkish capital.

Warning and exhortation alike have failed to clear the city streets of illegally parked cars. Chief Magistrate Curran now announces that fines for such violations will be doubled. More-over, habitual parkers who cannot pay the 54 fine will face two days in jail.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies fighting services issued the following communique today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Completing a two-year survey of relief expenditures in Westchester County, a special committee of the Board of Supervisors said today in a 30,000-word report that it had found case workers lax and inefficient in the handling of 14.5 percent of the 502 cases chosen for study.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- American forces fighting in the Philippines held their own today in the face of growing attacks by the Japanese, while United States naval forces sank two more enemy ships.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Dec. 30 -- Mechanized operations on the Moscow front have been forced to a virtual standstill since late Saturday by extremely heavy snowfalls, the Moscow military commentator revealed this morning in explaining the apparent absence of "important gains" in the central sector following the Russians' recapture of Kaluga's northern rail outlet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A "big stick" must be wielded in Washington if small business is to be brought into the armaments program, Senator James M. Mead of New York said here today in urging an expansion of administrative authority, including the extension of Federal loans and grants to small business.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., Dec. 29 -- The 20-year-old wife of an Army flier told here today the dramatic story of seeing her husband's plane shot down into tHe sea during the Dec. 7 attack on Pearl Harbor and of his swimming 200 yards to shore, climbing into another plane and resuming the air battle.
CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 29 -- Premier John Curtin's Melbourne Herald article, issued on Sunday as a statement to the press, generally has evoked a lively discussion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The staff of the Japanese Embassy, including Ambassador Kichisaburo Nomura and Saburo Kurusu, the special "peace envoy," was sent today to Hot Springs, Va., there to remain until the United States Government permits them to return to their own country.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -- Independent welders, seeking autonomy in the American Federation of Labor, continued their strike today in the East Bay district here and in Los Angeles, but A.F.L. boilermakers in Los Angeles routed a picket line in a melee which sent several combatants to hospitals for first-aid treatment.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The proposals for savings on non-defense expenditures advanced by Senator Byrd's committee deserve careful public scrutiny, and nowhere is this needed more than in the section dealing with cuts in the agricultural program.

Serving civilian needs effectively in a war economy is the theme of the major sessions of the thirty-first annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association to be held from Jan. 12 to 16 at the Hotel Pennsylvania, according to the advance program issued here yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 29 -- A violent dispute has broken out again between the Rome fascist party organ, Roma Fascista and the Catholic daily newspaper, Italia, on the duties and prerogatives of the Catholic Church.
