The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials. The number of commodities included in each group is given.

For her second and final performance at the Concert Theatre lastnight, Martha Graham restored to the program her "Every Soul Is a Circus," with music by Paul Nordoff, putting it in the place of the new "Punch and the Judy," which had its premiere the night before.

New Yorkers put aside their worries for a while yesterday, dug into their slenderized wallets and flooded hotels, night clubs, theatres and transportation facilities with orders that will add up to a New Year's Eve celebration that may equal that of last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -- With California cities and counties requesting about $50,000,000 in State aid to meet costs of the civilian defense program, Congress will be asked to help. In particu-lar it will be asked to help main-tain State guard organizations in all three Pacific Coast States.

New Yorkers put aside their worries for a while yesterday, dug into their slenderized wallets and flooded hotels, night clubs, theatres and transportation facilities with orders that will add up to a New Year's Eve celebration that may equal that of last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -- With California cities and counties requesting about $50,000,000 in State aid to meet costs of the civilian defense program, Congress will be asked to help. In particu-lar it will be asked to help main-tain State guard organizations in all three Pacific Coast States.
ROME, Dec. 29 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's Italian High Command communique:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Office of Production Management today took over the direction of distribution of fats and oils in an order affecting more than 1,800 different varieties of the commodities. Under terms of the order inventories of processors and manufacturers are limited to a ninety-day operating supply.

IT is three weeks since we had our last air raid alarm in New York, and it may be three months or three years before we have another, but something ought to be said here even so about a group of more or less useful books on the subject. To begin with, "Bombs and Bombing;,"* by Willy Ley, Science Editor of PM.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company's tool and die department resumed operations this afternoon after 1,000 workers had been idle for hours in a dispute over rest periods and a company complaint that employes smoked on the job.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- From State Department and British sources was obtained tonight a compilation of the countries now at war with Axis powers. At Ottawa Prime Minister Winston Churchill said that more than thirty "States and nations" now faced the Axis group in war, but the preliminary list furnished showed only twentynine, although it was said that it was subject to revision.

The shifting of the Canadian national economy from a peacetime to a wartime basis has resulted in Government regulation of practically every economic pursuit, according to a bulletin issued today by Dean John T. Madden, director of the Institute of International Finance of New York University.

In his address to the Canadian Parliament yesterday, as in his speech before Congress last Friday, Winston Churchill magnificently proved that nearly twenty months in the forefront of battle have not weakened his lion's heart. He spoke, indeed, not only to Parliament but to all the free peoples of the world, with a confidence not felt in the first black days of "blood, toil, tears and sweat."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 --Former Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who resigned in April from the Army Air Corps Reserve, has volunteered his services to the Army's air forces, it was disclosed today by Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, chief of the corps.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Roosevelt, possibly by way of striking a blow at Japan's nerves, today raised the possibility that American war materials might be sent to Kamchatka, Siberia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Conceding that suffering and the probable separation of some families would result, the removal of several civilian agencies from Washington was declared by President Roosevelt today to be a war measure.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- An unnamed destroyer caught by the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on the morning of Dec. 7 reported that it shot down six Japanese planes.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 -- The Fordham and Missouri football teams are almost ready to escort the New Year in two days hence, not by clinking glasses and quaffing each other's health, but by slamming each other around in the Tulane Stadium, where the eighth annual Sugar Bowl classic wall be staged in the presence of a capacity crowd of 73,000 persons.
BARDOLI, India, Dec. 30 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, at his own request, was relieved today by the working committee of the All-India National Congress party of his leadership of the party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Independent retail store sales for the second month in succession showed less of a gain over the corresponding month of 1940 during November than was registered in any previous month of this year, the Department of Commerce announced today as a result of a survey of 24,356 firms in thirty-four States.
The License Department has begun to license the city's estimated 35,000 barbers, who must comply with the sanitary regulations filed with the City Clerk yesterday by Paul Moss, License Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Navy announced tonight that it suspected the presence of Japanese craft in Alaskan waters uncomfortably close to Kodiak Island, where a naval air station is under construction.

The sixteen-story loft building on the southeast corner of Broadway and Twenty-first Street, two blocks south of Madison Square, has been sold by the 912 Broadway Corporation, and Harvey T. Mann as trustee to the Alvic Realty Corporation, the sellers taking back a part of the consideration a purchase money mortgage of $173,100.

Sharp curtailment of automobile production has forced dealers of the metropolitan area to effect economies and in many cases to concentrate on their parts and service business to tide them over the war, it was explained yesterday by spokesmen for the motor car industry.

Year after year the Winter constellations appear on scheduled time in their appointed positions. Nothing on earth disturbs them. Mundane conflicts leave them unmoved. And for that imperturbability we can thank our stars. Not only because of the philosophic consolation of something stable in an uncertain universe, but also for very practical reasons.

At the last meeting- of its official two-year life the City Council yesterday recommended general pay increases for 156,000 city employes to offset rising living costs refused the privileges of the floor to Peter V. Cacchione, Brooklyn Communist who was elected to the Council last month, and adopted the Ellis report calling Paul J. Kern unfit to continue as president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- American Trucking Associations, Inc., the national organization of the trucking industry, asked leave today of the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in the petion of the railroads for a general 10 per cent increase, with certain exceptions, in passenger and freight rates to meet recent wage advances.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Dr. Alwin M. Pappenheimer of the New York University College of Medicine received tonight a prize of $1,000 and a bronze medal of the Eli Lilly Company for his work in developing a new science combining bacteriology, chemistry, physics and nutrition in the treatment of disease.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 30 -- Dropping considerable weight from his two previous outings here, W.H. Berri's fleet sprint veteran. Early Delivery, found the third time the charm and won the Pompano Purse at Tropical Park today.

The University of Washington basketball forces struck unbeaten New York University with cyclone fury at Madison Square Garden last night, virtually swept the Violet off the court with the fastest-breaking attack seen hereabouts in many a moon and cracked three Garden scoring records in achieveing a 72-38 victory.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Brazilian State police and organized Nazis have clashed "with some dead" in the State of Rio Grande do Sul, where more than half a million Germans live, and many fifth columnists have been arrested, said dispatches from Porto Alegre today.

The Continental Motors Corporation, and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday, in the annual statement covering the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, net profit of $3,231,724 after normal and excess profits taxes totaling $3,250,000 and $250,000 reserve for post-war adjustments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Washington enthusiastically received a suggestion from General Douglas MacArthur today that, when the proper time comes, Japanese cities be devastated from the air in retaliation for the ruthlessly cruel bombing' of Manila.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Red Army, in fighting the Germans and pushing them back on all fronts, has the intense cooperation of Russian engineers and working gangs, who labor in the rear and rebuild railroads, bridges and telegraph lines, according to a report received by the Soviet Embassy today from Colonel Nikolai Klimoff, an engineer officer at Kuibyshev.

Nearly 1,200 persons attended yesterday in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, a meeting to mark the opening in the lobby of a volunteer defense work information desk, conducted in cooperation with the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office of 93 Park Avenue.

Although he held that the city had power, by a local law passed last year, to abolish the offices of Commissioner of Records in New York and Kings Counties and transfer the duties to the county clerks, Supreme Court Justice Denis O'Leary Cohalan ruled invalid yesterday provisions of the law that made the retention of existing exempt and non-competitive employes subject to the approval of the Board of Estimate.

VICHY, France, Dec. 30 -- It was learned today that Leon Jouhaux, secretary of the General Federation of Labor at the time of the Popular Front in France, had been arrested and interned administratively at Vals-Les-Bains for opposition to the government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- "Desperate Journey," a photoplay by Arthur Herman dealing with a forced landing in Nazi-controlled Europe, will go before the cameras at Warner Brothers in ten days with Errol Flynn in the leading role and Raoul Walsh directing, the studio announced today.

BUFFALO, Dec. 30 -- Dartmouth's classy sextet gained an easy 7-to-2 victory over Colgate at Memorial Auditorium tonight, scoring three goals in both the first and second periods and one in the final. Colgate registered once each in the second and third sessions.

The text of Mr. Churchill's address is on Page 6. OTTAWA, Dec. 30 -- Pouring out phrases that rang like a bell, that were filled with impish humor and that sometimes hurt like a kick on the shin, Prime Minister Winston Churchill today laid before the Canadian Parliament the complete picture of the war, how we got there, how we have strugSled through, what must be done to win and what must be done afterward.

MANILA, Dec. 30 -- President Manuel Quezon and Vice President Sergio Osmena were inaugurated today for their second terms in a brief wartime ceremony in an underground refuge near General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters "somewhere in Luzon."

On the eve of the end of his term as District Attorney, Thomas E. Dewey revealed yesterday that 96.5 per cent of the persons prosecuted by his office from Jan. 1 to Dec. 15 had been convicted or pleaded guilty, a record, and spoke in praise of the work of his prosecuting staff, the judges of the various courts in which the offenders were tried and the police.

While recognizing the need of planning for post-war reconstruction as part of the war effort it''self, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, declared yesterday that the primary task confronting file American people was to win the war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Congress voted today to end next Friday, after 365 days, the session which started January 3 with a sharply divided legislative body striving to keep war from the nation, but which saw solidly united forces declaring war against the Axis powers before its close.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 30 -- Only Don Hutson, the pass-catching end from the Green Bay Packers, was missing today from the squad of pro All-Star players who will meet the Bears in the Navy Relief Society benefit game at the Polo Grounds Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The ban on new tires for private motorists, may not bring the United States back to horse and buggy days as has been predicted, but it will bring it back to the era of railway transportation, in the opinion of J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads.

A "serious problem of priorities unemployment" will face the United States within six months, Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, predicted yesterday at a joint session of the American Statistical Association and the Association for Labor Legislation at the Hotel Commodore.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This is a war of surprises. Norway was a surprise. Holland and Belgium were surprises. Russia in June, 1941, was a surprise. Parachute troopists, panzer divisions, glider troop-carriers were all minor surprises to the bulk of the public.
NEW YORK Archduke Otto has returned to Essex House after spending Christmas with his mother, the Empress Zita, in Quebec. He will leave today for Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- On the basis of reports received before 9:30 A.M., the War Department issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Production of airplanes, tanks, guns and other armament and munitions will be increased as rapidly as possible to a point where 50 per cent of the national income is expended upon the war program, President Roosevelt stated today.
Robert Hood Bowers of 45 Prospect Place, composer of musical comedies and conductor, died Monday night in Doctors Hospital after an illness of ten days. He was 64 years old.

An excellent record of responsibility was set up in the four years ended June 30, 1941 by farm families who borrowed funds from the Farm Security Administration for the purchase of farms, the Department of Agriculture reported yesterday.

JAMES JOYCE has been dead about a year. It is about thirty years since "Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man" was completed, twenty years since the publication of "Ulysses" and two and a half years since we first had in their entirety the staggering ambiguities of "Finnegans Wake."

Local boards will be set up in various districts to handle applications for permits to buy new tires and tubes, Harold W. McGraw, Tire Rationing Administrator for New York City, said yesterday after conferring with the deputy administrators in charge of each borough.
After only two hours of voting, the shortest session on record in seven years, the New York Film Critics yesterday made known their selections of the screen's "bests" for 1941.

Mayor La Guardia congratulated Councilman Genevieve B. Earle or her re-election yesterday as he administered the oath of office to her and four other members of the incoming administration at City Hall.

The elements continued to annoy Eastern, skiers last night as reports from the North Country indicated that extremely limited sport will bo available for the next few days Unless snow falls today, the thousands already gathered at resorts and others who have planned trips for the New Year holiday will be doomed to disappointment.
BERLIN, Dec. 30 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic seaboard at the close of last week were 20,040,000 barrels, a decline of 178,000 from the 20,218,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks of light fuel oil declined 631,000 barrels to 19,062,000 and heavy fuel oil stocks were down 278,000 to 12,320,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- West Indies Sugar Corporation of New York City has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for 453,691 shares of common stock of $1 par value each. These are outstanding shares and 436,691 are owned by the City Company of New York, Inc., in dissolution, all of the stock of which, in turn, is owned by the National City Bank of New York.
The current drive to clear the streets of parked automobiles, as a measure of air raid precaution, ran into complications yesterday in Bronx Traffic Court.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- The year 1941 has rolled up a new all-time record for traffic deaths in the United States, according to an analysis issued today by the National Safety Council, based on latest figures and trends.

New Year's Eve celebrants who prefer their hockey thrills as the foundation for the annual spread of good fellowship, will have their appetites whetted tonight in Madison Square Garden, where the Rangers, fighting grimly to scale the National Hockey League heights, play hosts to the Americans in their fourth interborough skirmish of the campaign.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 31 -- The Japanese invaders are driving In great force on Manila from both north, and south, with their divebombers in almost complete command of the roads from the air, and with great quantities of tanks and armored units pressing relentlessly on the capital.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Dec. 30 -- Both Argentine and German quarters this evening denied any official knowledge of the reported recall to Berlin of the German Ambassador, Baron Edmund von Thermann, within twenty-four hours of the recall to Buenos Aires of the Argentine Ambassador in Berlin, Ricardo Olivera.

The Edison Electric Institute, fact-finding and service organization for the electric power and light industry, announced yesterday a reorganization of the activities of its various committees with a view to aiding the nation's war effort.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Dr. John R. Steelman, Federal conciliation chief, announced tonight that the Greyhound companies had accepted a proposal for arbitration and that the union would call off its strike, affecting 1,800 bus drivers from Chicago to the East Coast, at midnight.

Now more than ever, as the New Year comes in, most of us will want to gather our friends around us for a salute to the days that He ahead. Big parties and extravagant displays may be temporarily set aside, and many of us will join the President in his custom of offering the first toast to "The United States of America."

SINGAPORE, Dec. 30 -- Martial law was proclaimed throughout the Singapore area tonight after four heavy Japanese air assaults last night were beaten off with only eleven casualties and negligible damage to this big British base.

Robert Emmet Manly, whose death in a Japanese concentration camp at Naga in Southern Luzon, was reported yesterday by The Manila Bulletin, took part in the American conquest of the Philippine Islands, first from the Spaniards and then from, the Filipinos.

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 30 -- A rose by any other name would smell as sweet and here in Tobacco Land, no less than in the indigenous venue of Pasadena, the Rose Bowl football game has caught the fancy of the countryside as has no other athletic event of the year.
Steady buying by the trade lifted cotton sharply in active trading yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures made net gains of 19 to 22 points, or 95 cents to $1.10 a bale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Critics of the denunciation by the State Department of the Free French occupation of St. Pierre-Miquelon have apparently forgotten all about the Convention signed by the American Republics at Havana in July, 1940; the reasons for the compact; and the possible present consequences of acquiescence of the United States in its violation.

Title to the site of the proposed new municipal airport in the Idlewild section of Queens was conveyed to the city yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn with a warning to the property owners that they must vacate the 1,200acre area at the earliest possible moment.

Stockholders of the United Aircraft Corporation approved a company plan to issue 265,669 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible $100 per preferred stock at a special meeting in East Hartford, Conn., yesterday.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $519,000 of city of Scranton, Pa., school district bonds, receiving the award on a bid of 100.54 for 2%s. The bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1941, and maturing from Dec. 1, 1942 to 1951, were reoffered to the public at prices to yield 0.60 to 2.75 per cent, according to maturity.

Only three years ago tonight one could still sing "Auld Lang Syne" in a French restaurant in London, while a party of convivial Germans joined in at the next table and raised their glasses to a group of Polish diplomats celebrating across the room. The masquerade was nearly finished; but the Europe that was died cheerfully.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Allied reinforcements were reported by Netherlands Indies newspapers tonight to be en route to the Pacific war theatre even as Lieut. Gen. Hein ter Poorten, the Netherlands Indies Commander in Chief, urgently called for more bombers, fighter planes and antiaircraft guns to ward off expected Japanese invasion thrusts at Indies' soil.

The customary countless thousands who, barring an emergency, will jam Times Square tonight to greet the New Tear may have to celebrate without any assistance from horns, sirens and other noise-makers, in keeping with a request issued last night from Washington by Mayor La Guardia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Expanding wartime price controls today brought cigarettes and new tires and tubes for automobiles under the discipline of governmental price ceilings.
"Upon the fields of friendly strife Are sown the seeds That upon other fields and on other days Will bear the fruits of victory."
SEATTLE, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A state of war and the operation of enemy craft off the West Coast have brought to the Alaskan fishing industry the greatest uncertainty in its history.

Leaders in ocean marine insurance here expect that a Federal plan of underwriting war risks will be announced within the next week by the Maritime Commission at Washington. The purpose will be to seek the stabilization of rates at some "reasonable" level by setting up a yardstick compatible with general price policies of the government, in the consensus of insurance circles.

Visions of men wearing frayed shirts and school children sporting patched clothes as a patriotic duty were conjured up in Worth Street yesterday as traders estimated that, despite a reported impending request of the Office of Production Management that cotton mills operate twenty-four hours a day and seven days a week, it would not be possible to increase total production by more than 5 per cent over the current figure.

A special meeting of stockholders of the National Distillers Products Corporation has been called for Jan. 26 to authorize a new issue of 150,000 shares of $100 par preferred stock to provide additional permanent capital, according to Seton Porter, president of the company.

Miss Frances Le Baron Stoddard, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Francis R. Stoddard of 791 Park Avenue, was introduced to society last night at a dance given by her parents on the Pierre Roof. The early part of the evening was devoted to an old fashioned cotillion, led by the debutante's father.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As one who has been closely allied with civilian defense for the past five months, I find that one of the weakest links in the chain is night patrol. I have made inquiries and find that a body of men some 10,000 in number, each equipped with an automobile, ablebodied, already fingerprinted and photographed, have not as yet been made available.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The national capital had its first "blackout" test tonight in preparation for the air raid it hopes never will take place.

Since the reading public's interest will shift sharply toward "subject books" on the war, it is the duty of publishers, editors and authors to turn their attention toward Washington as "a primary source of information and ideas which are the raw materials of books," Frederic G. Melcher, editor of Publishers Weekly, declared yesterday.

Tony Cuccinello, veteran infielder, yesterday received his release from the New York Giants as manager of their Jersey City farm club. The announcement, made by Secretary Eddie Brannick, said that Tony, at present wintering in Florida, would now sign himself as a free agent with the Boston Braves.

Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. returned to his desk yesterday after spending several days in Miami, resumed direction of the Joe Louis-Buddy Baer heavyweight title battle to be held Jan. 9 in Madison Square Garden for the Navy Relief Society, and announced two matches had been made, involving champions in non-title bouts in the Garden.
Drawings of any phase of Army or Navy life will be eligible as entries in the Service Men's Cartoon Contest sponsored by the New York City Defense Recreation Committee.
TOKYO, Dec. 30 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The following official report was issued today by Imperial Headquarters:

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Foreign exchange control regulations covering transactions between Canada and the sterling area countries are simplified under amendments published today in extra editions of The Canada Gazette.

"If men are faithful to their religious obligations they necessarily must be good citizens," Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday told a meeting of eleven Monsignori, representing all sections of the Archdiocese Union of Holy Name Societies, held in the Hotel Commodore.

Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cook gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for their debutante niece, Miss Marianne F. Dean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard B. Dean. The debutante, who was introduced by her parents at a dinner dance in advance of the Junior Assembly on Dec. 5, is now attending Bennett Junior College.

The Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, decorated in holiday motif with holly, smilax, poinsettias, ferns and palms, was the setting yesterday afternoon for a tea dance given by Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Francis D. McGarey of Brooklyn to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Margretta Anne McGarey.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops are hurling back a force of 40,000 Japanese at a point thirty miles north of Changsha, capital of Hunan Province, toward which the Japanese were driving for the third time since the start of the Sino-Japanese war, a military spokesman announced today.

Buyer Registration Up Visiting buyers registered in the market last week numbered 247, as against 203 in the previous week and 212 in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the listings published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 198, which compared with fifty-nine for a week ago.

The continuance of "Sunny River" at the St. James after this week seemed uncertain last night, although Ben Boyar, general manager for Max Gordon, posted a closing notice backstage, effective on Saturday. This step is by no means definite yet, Mr. Boyar insisted, saying the decision would be made tomorrow.

Dr. Paul T. Borchardt, a German military geographer who spent a year in England posing as a refugee from Hitlerism before he was admitted to this country, was linked yesterday to the group of German-Americans accused of spying on United States national defense secrets.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Westchester County has sufficient fire equipment and personnel to protect the Bronx and part of Queens if an emergency required the transfer of New York City apparatus from those boroughs to other areas, Roi B. Woolley, civilian defense coordinator of the Westchester Fire Chiefs Emergency Plan, said today.

The New Year's Holiday All markets and banks throughout the world will be closed tomorrow, and in some instances there will be closings at noon today. Dealings in the grain pit of the Chicago Board of Trade will cease at noon today, central standard time, as will trading in the Winnipeg grain market.

KILLINGWORTH, Conn., Dec. 30 -- The first fox hunt of the year is always a long-anticipated event and, although there are times, such as today, when no dead fox can be produced to give evidence of a successful run, this does not mean that the hunt was a failure.
OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 30 -- The text of Prime Minister Churchill's address today follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Professional baseball, whose battle cry is "keep 'em slugging," launched its balls-and-bats-for-service-men campaign today by placing orders for 1,500 baseball kits which will be distributed free to the men in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Lieut. Col. Frank J. McSherry was designated deputy director for labor supply and training in the enlarged labor division of the Office of Production Management today. The organization will meet the expanding man power needs of war industry.
Picking them out on a strictly cash basis, Variety today publishes its list of the year's top money-making pictures, stars and directors.

As the Japanese drove slowly toward Manila yesterday and Japanese transports continued to disgorge men and supplies on Luzon's shores, the whereabouts and activity of the United States Navy were the focus of public interest.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 -- Long-wave broadcasts from powerful domestic radio stations not subject to the same censorship restrictions as short-wave stations can be heard at this time in the Western Pacific and intervening points, it was disclosed today.

An underwriting group headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and the Wisconsin Company will offer to the public this afternoon, subject to the registration statement becoming effective, 198,083 shares of common stock of $3 par value of the Kearney Trecker Corporation.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 30 -- A battle appeared today to be imminent in Libya after General Erwin Rommel, the German commander, sent out a column heavily supported by tanks, only to have it smashed and driven back with twenty-two tanks destroyed and twenty more damaged.

Determined to back up their hopes for a happy new year with something more than good resolutions, workers in defense plants in the metropolitan area will spend New Year's Day at their work benches turning out planes, guns and ships to defeat the Axis, a survey indicated yesterday.

To celebrate the beginning of its second century of business, Gimbel Brothers today will unveil six specially decorated store windows facing Broadway, between Thirty-second and Thirty-third Streets. Each display will depict one of the six challenges that, in the opinion of store executives, America has met and overcome during the last century.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The $125,000,000 North American Light and Power Company was ordered today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to liquidate and dissolve. North American Light and Power Company and its parent, the North American Company, were ordered to submit to the commission a plan for this purpose and to take no step to carry it out without the commission's approval.

Donaldson Brown, vice chairman of General Motors, called upon the United States Government yesterday to exercise a "dictatorship" over industry until the war has been prosecuted successfully. The normal purposes of industry must be suspended for the duration, he said, and controlling decisions be made by our military strategists.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 30 -- Charged with having conspired to set arbitrary rates for sand and gravel supplied to WPA projects in this State in 1935 and 1936, nine contractors and ten companies, all in New Jersey, were ordered to pay fines totaling $18,400 after they pleaded guilty today before Federal Judge Guy L. Pake, here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, Massachusetts, drafted today new legislation to set up a Women's Army Auxiliary Corps of undesignated size to take over some non-combatant duties now performed by enlisted men and civilian volunteers.

Three new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "Louisiana Purchase," Paramount's film version of the stage musical of the same name, will be the newcomer at the Paramount. The picture features Bob Hope, Vera Zorina, Dona Drake, Irene Bordoni, Victor Moore and Raymond Walburn.

Organization of the National Committee to Keep Prices Down, which will soon open a nation-wide campaign to mobilize manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers and consumers into a movement to prevent a rising price level, was announced yesterday by Julian Goldman, president of the Goldman Stores Corporation and national chairman of the committee.

For the first time canned fruits and vegetables packed under the continuous inspection system of the Agricultural Marketing Service of the Department of Agriculture will be advertised widely to the public through a cooperative campaign by canners using the service, it was learned here yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 30 (Canadian Press)-The Canadiens ended a four-game losing streak tonight when they came through with, three goals in the third period to defeat the Black Hawks, 5-3. Joe Benoit, who paced the Habitants' attack with two goals, banged home the clincher at 14:59 of the last period.

The ten best dressed women in the world -- or, anyway, in that part of the world visible to American stylists -- were listed yesterday in the "official" annual poll, formerly conducted by Paris couturiers.

As darkness enveloped the enclosed roof of the Madison Square Boys Club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street, late yesterday afternoon, fourteen university students of Colombia. South America, finished their coffee and pie and voiced the unanimous opinion that "brigand stea.k," American style, was a most delectable dish.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Ten reappointments of Westchester County department heads were announced today by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach, who will begin on Thursday his first full term as the head of county government here.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Under existing War Department regulations we have an active and an inactive reserve, in addition to the retired list of regular officers who have passed 64. There are many former World War officers not on these lists who for various reasons could not accept continued reserve service.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The stock markets saw today further improvement in the gilt-edged issues. The 3 1/2 per cent war loan rose to u104 15-16, old consols to u82 3/4 and local loans to u95 3/4. Bank shares also were better.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Speculators showed more interest today in the corn market, and reports that shipping sales aggregated 300,000 bushels, the largest single day's business in some months, led to sufficient buying early to lift prices fractionally.

Oscar Tschirky, internationally known as "Oscar of the Waldorf," transferred title and deed to his 320-acre estate at New Paltz, N.Y., to the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique, to provide a home for aged, disabled and indigent members of the culinary profession, at a reception given yesterday afternoon in the Assembly Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 30 (U.P.) -- Waves of Japanese planes sweeping in through brightly moonlit skies raided Singapore four times before dawn today. The raid was the first since the sneak punch in the opening hours of hostilities.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Francisco Segura made a gallant effort today to add the Sugar Bowl Trophy to his collection of cups, which represent about all the tennis championships of South America, but Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., finally won with magnificent placements.

MANILA, Wednesday, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- United States troops on the South Luzon front have fallen back to a line reaching within thirty miles of Manila, abandoning most of Laguna Province, including the capital, Santa Cruz, and Pagsanjan, a tourist resort, reports from that sector said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Dec. 31 -- Russian troops from the Caucasian mainland, after two days' fighting, have retaken the towns of Kerch and Theodosia, at the eastern end of the Kerch Peninsula, in Crimea, according to a special communique issued in Moscow shortly before midnight.

DETROIT, Dec. 30-The greatest mass indulgence in sports in American history was proposed by the Office of Civilian Defense today as it called upon the nation's schools and colleges to build a wartime society of young men and women unexcelled in physical fitness and morale.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, celebrating his birthday yesterday, looked back over his sixty-eight years and voiced complete confidence in our victory in the war.

Urging greater volunteer participation in child care and development as a vital part of the civilian defense program, Mrs. Bess B. Lane, co-chairman of the Advisory Committee on Schools for Young Children, announced yesterday that it would sponsor several training courses in this activity at the Cooperative School for Teachers, 69 Bank Street, Manhattan.

As Mayor La Guardia lashed back yesterday at critics of his civilian defense activities by declaring that air raid warden's were well trained, it developed from other sources that the Mayor had assigned members of the New York City Defense Council to investigate complaints of local civilian defense activities.

City College players regained the championship of the Eastern Intercollegiate Chess League at the Marshall Chess Club yesterday by defeating Brooklyn College, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, in the final round. This was just enough to nose out the titleholders of 1939 and 1940 for first place.

TOKYO, Dec. 30 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in the United States) -- An official spokesman said today that Calcutta, or any other Indian city, would be bombed if it were converted into a base to supply China over the Burma Road.

More Than Comedy Mayor La Guardia lightly dismissed the whole problem of his late Commissioner of Markets by remarking, in the Italian language, "E finita la commedia." We sincerely trust that things are not really as serious as all that.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Union Oil Company of California, with headquarters at Los Angeles, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering the sale of $15,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures, due Jan. 1, 1667.

To round out the city's program of war safeguards, Mayor La Guardia set up yesterday an emergency repair service designed to patch up air-raid damage to buildings, sewers, water and gas mains and telephone and electric systems.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 -- A new type of stellar research, carried on by Schmidt cameras, now operating or building, may provide the greatest advances in astronomy in the next ten years, according to astronomers meeting here for the dedication of the 24-36 inch Schmidt-type telescope of the Warner and Swazy observatory.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 30 -- Premier John Curtin of Australia has received from Prime Minister Winston Churchill of Great Britain a message described as containing welcome news of development of cohesive inter-Allied strategy, placing Australia in a far more satisfactory position than before the week-end.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- With their Kitchener line performing in spectacular fashion, the Boston Bruins regained the National Hockey League's top berth by turning back the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-1, tonight before an overflow crowd of 15,835 at the Boston Garden.

SYRACUSE, N.T. Dec. 30 (AP) -- Lieutenant Governor Poletti, contending that some educators had grown "careless about education for stamina and ruggedness of body," called today for improved health education in schools and adequate programs for out-of-school youths and adults.

Two lovable bundles of black and white fur were deposited at Bronx Zoo yesterday, a gift from the Chinese people to the children of America in appreciation for their gifts to the Chinese war relief. Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, on behalf of the Chinese Government, made possible the new additions to the Zoo by sending a seventy-man expedition into the Tibetan hills to obtain a male and a female baby giant panda.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- About 40,000 nurses registered in the State under a law passed in 1938 are eligible to carry on their duties after midnight tomorrow, while 5,000 to 10,000 others who have failed to comply with the requirements of the law will probably continue their work for the present until the law, effective Thursday, is amended.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A prior agreement by the Senate to abstain from transacting legislative business this week defeated a move which Senator Wiley of Wisconsin made today to restore the wartime rank of brigadier general to the late William L. Mitchell.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Dec. 29:

There is little danger, even in wartime. of tyranny or centralization in the United States, or even of "that vague thing called domination by Washington," Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, declared yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 -- A fighting Tennessee quintet gave away plenty in height to Long Island University and beat the Blackbirds in a bristling contest, 36-33, before 9,000 spectators in the sixth annual Sugar Bowl basketball game at Municipal Auditorium, tonight.

HONOLULU, Dec. 29 (U.P.) (Delayed) -- A Japanese sailor, trapped in one of three midget submarines destroyed or captured during the Dec. 7 attack on Pearl Harbor, has been buried in a section of his own two-man undersea craft, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Contributions to the Red Cross $50,000,000 War Fund total $10,780,341, including $56,000 from the Hawaii chapter, national headquarters reported today, adding that 297 local chapters had exceeded their quotas and two in Montana had more than doubled them.

DALLAS, Dec. 30 -- The mind of man in our time has pushed back the frontiers of space to such an extent that he observes a region of the physical universe about 1,000 million light-years in diameter, throughout which are scattered 100,000,000 individual universes, each comparable to our own system of the Milky Way, which is composed of 100,000,000,000 individual stars and suns dwarfing our own.

Patrolman Joseph L. Ruggles, 41 years old, of 674 Chandler Avenue, Westerleigh, S.I., and Patrolman James P. Hennessey, 35, of 65 Bank Street, were indicted for attempted extortion by the New York County grand jury yesterday. They are accused of trying to get $200 from a Manhattan gasoline station and automobile repair shop owner by promising to "quash" a fake charge that the man had stolen automobile tools in his possession.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A triple by Jockey Walter Lee Taylor featured the Fair Grounds racing program today.

Wartime congestion of Red Cross facilities for registering volunteers will soon be relieved, it was announced yesterday at headquarters of the New York chapter, 315 Lexington Ave. Two floors in the old Tiffany building at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street have been lent by the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, acting as representatives of the English Astors interests.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You published recently letters concerning the status of enemy aliens. This question deserves, particularly in the present war of ideologies, a special consideration of the authorities lest situations should arise, as stated below, which would appear incompatible with either logic or justice:

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 30 -- Colonel Geoffrey Keyes, son of the World War hero who organized Britain's black - shrouded Commandos, was killed leading thirty of them on a night raid on the headquarters of German General Erwin Rommel, commander of the Axis armies in Libya, it was revealed tonight.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 30 -- In connection with the Mexican-United States trade treaty soon to be negotiated in Washington, it was stated in authorized circles today that Americans were considering building several refineries in Mexico as part of a program for trebling the American gasoline output.

To round out plottage which the firm has been assembling for about two years as an investment, Webb Knapp, Inc., John H.P. Gould, president, has purchased from the Dry Dock Savings Institution the five-story store and apartment building at the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Sixtythird Street, known as 820-22 Lexington Avenue.

As the result of President Roosevelt's proclamation appointing "the first day of the year 1942" as a national "Day of Prayer" there will be many more church services tonight and tomorrow than in previous years.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 30 -- Chemists have successfully invaded woman's most cherished culinary province, the baking of biscuits and cakes, Dr. Howard Adler, chief chemist of the Victor Chemical Works, Chicago, said here today at the symposium of the American Chemical Society's Division of Physical and Inorganic Chemistry.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Another unusually large supply of salable hogs arrived on the livestock market today, breaking prices 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds, as buyers showed an unwillingness to take offerings without mark-downs.

In the widest reversal of form in more than a year, which was accompanied by a volume of trading only shaded so far in 1941 by the previous session, the stock market staged yesterday a rally which raised prices 1 to more than 5 points.

Although uncertainties continue to confront the industry, prices of furs entering into popular and medium price fur garments appear to be "jumping bottom." at this time, according to J.D. Silberman, president of the American Fur Merchants Association and head of the Silberman Fur Corporation.

Unless parents learn how to deal successfully with the question of security within the home there will be no collective security for the nations of the world, Eduard C. Lindeman, Professor of Social Philosophy at the New York School of Social Work, warned yesterday.

Welcoming the opportunity to help the most unfortunate men, women and children of the city through a Fund that cuts across all barriers of race and creed and gives all the money donated to the needy, 163 contributors, rich, wellto-do and poor, poured a heartwarming flow of gifts totaling $7,140.09 into the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.
A fifth column and espionage network, patiently organized over many years, paved the way for Japan's surprise blow at Pearl Harbor.

The annual report of Loew's Inc., and subsidiaries issued for publication today reveals a net profit for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 of $11,134,593 after all deductions, including $3,747,298 provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Jan. 1 -- Kaluga is in Russian hands, and has been since last Friday, when all that the world learned about it was that the railway terminal of Tikhinova, a few miles north of the town, had been seized when Russian forces by-passed Kaluga to the northeast. The midnight communique said it had been thoroughly invested since Tuesday.

We are being brought to a full realization of the magnitude and power of the threat to our national existence and we are awakening to the effort which we must make to defeat it, Sir Edward Beatty, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, said in his annual review issued yesterday.
AGAIN some notes at the end of a busy book year, very random:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today sugar marketing and import quotas for 1942 amounting to 8,032,074 short tons, raw value, for various producing areas entitled to share in the United States market under the 1937 Sugar Control Act.

The Safety-Responsibility Division of the State Motor Vehicle Bureau set up to administer the new automobile insurance law that became effective today will begin its duties tomorrow morning at the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

The bitter political fued that flared publicly between Mayor La Guardia and District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn three weeks ago appeared yesterday to have been smoothed over in a half-hour conference in which the Mayor agreed to the creation of a new confidential investigating squad responsible only to the prosecutor.

In a last "fling" before the city tightens up on automobile parking and rates are stabilized next Monday, some garages and parking lot s boosted rates 50 to 100 per cent last night in theatre and night club areas.
One year ago this New Year's Day morning Adolf Hitler said in a proclamation to his then undefeated army: "Soldiers, the year 1941 will bring consummation of the greatest victory in our history."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- In an effort to prevent any labor dislocation by the contemplated curtailment of wool goods for civilian uses, labor representatives put before Sidney Hillman today a six-point program for meeting the emergency.
There will be 8.1 per cent more freight cars loaded in the first three months of 1942 than in the same period last year, the Shippers Advisory Boards announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Prompt and equitable settlement of the oil expropriation controversy with Mexico is important to both that country and the United States, it was emphasized today by Morris L. Cooke, who will represent this country in the conversations in Mexico City on compensation to be paid nationals of the United States for their expropriated properties.

PALISADES PARK, N.J., Dec. 31 -- Norman Wist, 19 years old, and Joseph Cristini, 22, of Palisades Park, picked themselves up unhurt this afternoon after the automobile in which they had been riding was demolished and carried several hundred feet by a passenger train of the Northern Railroad of New Jersey.

If New Year's Day dawns dark land drear, our readers may be in a receptive mood for an indication of the rigors of the year to come, with its inevitable demands upon our energies and ingenuities, and a suggestion for the manner in which we may meet them.

Mayor La Guardia took the oath of office for his third term of four years at 10 o'clock last evening from Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook in the home of Samuel Seabury at 154 East Sixty-third Street.

Leading by two goals with less than four minutes gone, the New York Rangers had to fight to the limit to defeat the Brooklyn Americans, 4 to 3, in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 31 -- Fines totalling $1,600 were imposed here today by Federal Judge Guy L. Fake on six more New Jersey sand and stone contractors, who pleaded guilty to having conspired to set discriminatory prices for supplies furnished to WPA projects in the State in 1935 and 1936.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 1 -- Men and women who have worked well for the British Empire are rewarded in a long King's New Year's honors list published today. While hundreds of persons were mentioned, there were possibly as many more who missed honors this time by a narrow margin, but they have a good chance of being included next year.

If Axis ears did not hear last night's revelry in Times Square it was not that New Yorkers didn't try. Tremendous waves of sound washed against the midtown towers when the traditional lighted ball slid down THE NEW YORK TIMES flagpole at midnight and the lighted legend "1942" broke bright against the murky sky.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Britain goes into the new year with a budgetary outlook that is optimistic beyond expectations.
City College, after crushing the University of Maryland basketball team in the first half last night at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium, had to brace near the end to win, 57 -- 40.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A Governor's Executive War Cabinet was appointed today by Governor Charles Edison, and the future course of the State Defense Council, composed mostly of key State officials, was left in doubt.

Cash contributions and the value of articles given to Bundles for Britain, 475 Fifth Avenue, since its organization in December, 1939, amount to $5,518,907, Mrs. Wales Latham, national president, announced yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 -- All is in readiness for tomorrow's Orange Bowl contest that will present the Bulldogs of Georgia against the Horned Frogs of Texas Christian. Both squads went through their final light preparations today and were declared fit and ready.

New securities offered to the public here in December aggregated $127,072,000, composed of $114,589,000 in thirty-three bond issues and $12,483,000 in four stock offerings. These totals compare with $184,365,000 bond and stock emissions in November, consisting of $169,197,000 in twenty-seven bond issues and $15,168,000 in five stock flotations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Nonagricultural employment last month included 40,693,000 persons, an increase of 3,165,000 over November, 1940, and of 4,114,000 over November, 1929, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, announced today.

The Hammond Instrument Company plans a further expansion of its dealer cooperative advertising on the Solovox for the first quarter of 1942, following the success of its 1941 campaign. The company will cooperate with dealers on a share cost basis on an unlimited budget in approved media, which include newspapers, radio and regularly issued programs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- George A. Schmidt, chairman of the American Meat Institute, said today the start of 1942 would find America with ample livestock and meat supplies for military, domestic and overseas trade throughout the year.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 31 -- Prime Minister Peter Fraser said in his New Year message:

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad and its personnel are in a high state of preparation, William White, president, said yesterday in his annual message to officers and employes. His message read in part:

SINGAPORE, Dec. 31 -- The air attack on Singapore Monday night was the first important air bombardment of the city since the initial bombing that announced the beginning of the invasion of Malaya. The chief damage was to a petrol dump.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The rush program to build and man a war-size merchant marine today prompted the United States Maritime Commission to cut about in half the training period required for officer cadets and to lower the qualifications for candidates.

Morito Moroshimo, the Japanese Consul General, his wife and two daughters were taken into custody early Tuesday morning by FBI men, placed on a train and transported to Hot Springs, Va., it was learned yesterday.

What can I do to help? I have heard that question asked hundreds of times recently. I have asked it of myself, and I have answered it in this way: I will go on with the work that has been mine over the years, with this difference -- I will do more and will do it better than ever before.

A decision said to bring 50,000 building service employes in this city alone under the minimum wage and maximum hour provisions of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act was handed down by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek told the 400,000,000 Chinese in a New Year's message today to strive for the inevitable day way when "overwhelming punishment" could be inflicted on Japan, whose mad attack against the United States and Britain he likened to "a draught of poison taken to quench thirst."

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The Stock Exchange finished the year in good style, strengthened by Prime Minister Churchill's speech and the Russian successes. Gilt-edge issues showed little fresh change, but a number of industrials went ahead, particularly the stores and wireless shares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Over unidentified short-wave radio stations, Senator Thomas of Utah addressed the Japanese people in their own tongue tonight, speaking the New Year's Day message of a former friend who lived long among them but who now told them that they have been betrayed by the war lords and "sold out" to Hitler.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- OPM's new National Labor Supply Policy Board plans to have 23,500,000 persons working in war industries by 1944, it was learned today. Five million are employed in the industries now.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 31 -- Under the headline "German Crisis on the Eastern Front" the military expert of the newspaper Dagens Nyheter draws an unusually pessimistic picture of the German position. This pessimism impregnates all Swedish comment on the German situation at home and in the field.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Britain ended the year tonight with a brief and, in large part, sanguine review by the Admiralty of the situation at sea, which emphasized the necessity of keeping Singapore at all costs.

Recently the New York Red Cross chapter, 315 Lexington Avenue, had to change overnight from defense preparedness activities to all-out war work, but its executive director, General Robert C. Davis, declared yesterday in a review of the last year that it is continuing with all its usual functions and foreign war relief efforts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Promotion of 575 lieutenant colonels of all branches of the Army to the temporary rank of colonel was revealed today by the War Department.

Changes in the constitution of the New York Stock Exchange to care for the interests of members in the armed services of the United States and its allies have been approved by the board of governors and are now before the membership.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Enemy aliens throughout the United States, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands are required to surrender hand cameras, short-wave radio receiving sets and radio transmitters not later than 11 P.M. Monday. The Justice Department order originally applied only to the West Coast area.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 -- The necessity for speed in the organization of municipal tire and tube rationing boards was emphasized today by Robert W. Johnson, who was appointed State Rationing Administrator by Governor Edison on Monday.

The wave of sugar buying that developed immediately after the outbreak of the war has calmed down, Charles Ackerman, secretary of the United Independent Retail Grocers and Food Dealers Association, said yesterday, and as a result sugar prices are now reverting to normal.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 31 (U.P.) (From Chinese broadcast recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- A Chinese war communique today claimed Chinese successes against Japanese forces on three scattered fronts. The communique covered yesterday's activities on the North Hunan and North Kiangsi fronts and week-end fighting on the distant Suiyuan front in Northwest China.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 -- The automobile industry pooled its production facilities, technical experience and managerial talents today for the manufacture of war material by creating an Automotive Council for War Production.

COLUMBUS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Ohio officials protested to President Roosevelt today what one described as "a sneak in the back door plan" of the Federal Social Security Board to assume control of claims-personnel in the bureau of unemployment compensation.

BUFFALO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- William J. Conners Jr., publisher of The Buffalo Courier-Express, was named today chairman of the board of the Great Lakes Transit Corporation under a merger, effective tomorrow, of it and the Minnesota Atlantic Transit Company.

Thousands who preferred to welcome the New Year in the spirit of sober contemplation thronged the city's churches last night to attend traditional Watch Night services and to listen to sermons that stressed the heavy demands that the nation's entry into the war will make on its spiritual and material resources in 1942 and the years to follow.

At Pearl Harbor the Japanese introduced, in addition to two-man submarines, another new weapon in the form of 15-inch armor-piercing shells, fitted with fins to convert them into aerial bombs and dropped from tremendous heights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Roosevelt today appointed Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce and Federal Loan Administrator, as a member of the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board in an effort to speed up the production of military materiel.

The lowest general death rate in New York City's history and new low records in infant and maternal deaths were achieved in 1941, Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, reported yesterday afternoon to Mayor La Guardia.

Principals in the city schools, returning tomorrow from the Christmas holiday, will receive official notification that the Board of Education -- reversing its previously announced policy -- has decided that children are to be kept in school buildings in case of air raids.

Graduate students from Colombia who are studying in this country met yesterday afternoon before the statue of Simon Bolivar in Central Park to honor him as the first proponent of democracy and inter-American unity in South America.

At a meeting held before the opening of the market yesterday, the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange ordered a temporary suspension of trading in both domestic and world sugar futures.

H.S. Wherrett, vice chairman of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, says in his year-end comment that America's battle for national survival has taken precedence over all other activities of business and industry, and that all actions will be directed toward this primary objective.

The aim off the General Motors Corporation at the threshhold of 1942 "is to expand just as rapidly as possible the production of war materials, and thereby to contribute its part in what undoubtedly will be -- in fact, already is -- the greatest industrial effort expended by any nation at any time," according to Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the company.

Production of armament, the President declares, will be increased as rapidly as possible to a point where 50 per cent of the national income is expended upon the war program. As he estimates that the national income will reach $100,000,000,000 in the fiscal year of 1943, this implies the existence of a war budget alone for that period of $50,000,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 -- In a joint statement of policy with Jack H. Helms, regional director of civilian defense for Western States, Gen. John L. Dewitt, commanding general of the Western defense command, stated today that gatherings of any nature along the Pacific Coast should be restricted to 5,000 persons or fewer.
All German citizens in Switzerland more than 18 years old have been called back to Germany, according to information received here yesterday from a reliable source in a European country.

Because of a shortage of registered nurses, both in New York City and up-State, Miss Jane Todd, member of the Assembly from Westchester County, announced yesterday that she would ask Governor Lehman for an emergency message to the Legislature asking for a time extension to the State Nurses Practice Act, of which she was sponsor and which is to go into effect today.

Former Representative James H. Fay, his wife, son and a nephew were carried down ladders by firemen last night during a fire that damaged their four-story brownstone house at 241 East Seventeenth Street, between Second Avenue and Rutherford Place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The United States-Filipino Army fought back tonight from shortened lines around Manila against constantly growing Japanese armies after General Douglas MacArthur had sent some of his wounded out of Manila Harbor aboard a hospital ship bound for Australia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Further restrictions were clamped upon civilian uses of tin today as the Office of Production Management acted to conserve an additional 15,000 tons of the metal in 1942.

Mayor La Guardia complained at a press conference in City Hall yesterday against newspaper reports of an apparent conflict between his request for a subdued celebration of New Year's Eve and Police Commissioner Valentine's statement that the police would not quiet noisemakers.
CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 29 (delayed) -- About 1,200 United States nationals were trapped in Hong Kong by Japan's conquest of that British crown colony.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Buffeted by winds which blanketed El Paso in old-fashioned Southwestern sandstorms, Texas Tech and Tulsa University ran through final practice sessions today for their Sun Bowl clash tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- A carnival motif marked the decor for the New Year's Eve Ball given tonight by the home defense and foreign relief divisions of the Emergency Aid of Pennsylvania at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel. Mrs. Benjamin Ludlow of Bryn Mawr is chairman of the home defense division and Mrs. Cooper Howell is chairman of the foreign relief division.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Pre-holiday dullness prevailed in the grain markets today with wheat holding within narrow price limits. As has been the case for several days, speculators were not inclined to take a stand on either side pending developments in price control legislation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 -- In the last hours of 1941, as the Pacific Coast stayed "on the alert" against possible holiday surprises by the enemy from sea and air, scores of men wounded in the Japanese raid on Pearl Harbor were brought through the Golden Gate, the second batch of Army and Navy casualties to reach the mainland.
Seventy-six youths representing five South American countries arrived here yesterday on a United States ship to study aviation on scholarships provided by this government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The tapering off in wholesale sales gains in November as against previous months this year reflects the trend in consumer goods lines, the Census Bureau reported today. The November gain in wholesale trade was only 24 per cent over the same month last year as against a gain of 31 per cent for the first eleven months of the year.

William P. Witherow, who assumes the presidency of the National Association of Manufacturers today, issued a report yesterday in which he found that in certain essential war materials American industrial production in 1941 was as great or greater than the production of the Axis countries.

With $1,500,000 in United States Savings Stamps of all denominations on hand, the retail stores in Manhattan and Brooklyn are all ready to launch tomorrow their spectacular defense savings sales drive, William M. Holmes, president of Bonwit Teller and chairman of the retail division, Greater New York Committee of the New York Defense Savings Staff, said last night.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Asserting that modern war had brought the battlefields to the doors of civilization," Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, Deputy Commissioner of Education, recommended today a five-point program to utilize school buildings and personnel in hastening and expanding civilian defense training.
HONOLULU, Dec. 31 -- The rescue of nine Army fliers who had been forced down at sea was announced today by the Navy.

A special meeting of common stockholders of the Hamilton Watch Company has been called at Lancaster, Pa., on Jan. 8, to approve the issuance and sale of 39,382 shares of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative $100 par preferred stock to effect dividend savings and reimburse the company in part for the construction and equipment of a new plant.

Daniel Berkeley Updike's founding of the Merrymount Press in 1893 began an epoch in typography. The books that he printed illustrated the principles which he set forth in his writings, especially in "Printing Types," a work of large and continuous influence, begetter of new researches.

A need for cooperative effort among Protestants, Catholics and Jews during the war period was stressed in a report submitted yesterday to the trustees of the National Conference of Christians and Jews by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the organization, at a meeting in the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 31 -- Drawn from various animal organs, the chemical core of living matter, the main constituent of the living cells serving as the building blocks of the animate world from amoeba to man, has been isolated in pure form for the first time.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 31 -- Venezuela today broke off diplomatic relations with Germany, Italy and Japan, it was announced by President Isaias Medina Angarita.

A Federal appropriation of $100,000,000 for the development of synthetic rubber was urged yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Holmes, new president of the American Chemical Society. At the same time the Office of Price Administration in Washington made public January tire quotas that are less than 7 per cent of the normal January requirements, according to leaders in the tire industry.
DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 31 -- Carl Snavely, head football coach at Cornell University, is going to the University of Southern California, according to information received here tonight.
MEXICO CTTY, Dec. 31 -- The Chamber of Deputies today named a committee of five to act as a kind of Dies committee and investigate propaganda, sabotage and espionage by Axis agents in Mexico.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The usefulness of New Jersey's first consumer information center, established several weeks ago at Elizabeth, was commented on favorably today by Mrs. Harriman N. Simmons, chairman of the consumer interests committee of the New Jersey Defense Council, and Mrs. Eleazer Barth of Nutley, newly appointed executive secretary of the committee.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- City Manager Raymond J. Whitney served notice today on the incoming Common Council that he would not resign from the post, referring to reports that three of the five members of the council taking office tomorrow would ask for his resignation.

VICHY, France, Dec. 31 -- "I am absolutely convinced that France has escaped the danger of monetary collapse," declared Finance Minister Yves Bouthillier at a press conference here this afternoon on the figures for the budget of 1942.

BURLINGTON, Wis., Dec. 31 -- The Burlington Liars Club went "hook, line and sinker" for a fish story today and awarded its annual world's championship for a tale about catching fish with a barber pole.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 31 (UP) -- Japanese destroyers shelled Menado, a town of 28,000 population near the northern tip of the Netherland island of Celebes, without causing serious damage or casualties, but Japanese planes killed three persons in raids on "various small places in the outer provinces," it was announced here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Evidence that diet can cause tremendous chances in the vitality of an insect was reported today to the Entomological Society of America.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange in December was the heaviest for any month since May, 1940, and since 1936 for a corresponding month, but the turnover for 1941, of 170,534,363 shares, was the smallest in twenty-three years, or since 1918.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The text of a British Middle East communique follows:

A woman burglar who, according to a report submitted to Judge Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. in General Sessions yesterday, was suspected of being a member of a gang of forgers, was sentenced yesterday to a one-year penitentiary term on her guilty plea to petit larceny to cover an indictment containing six counts of forgery and two of petit larceny.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -- Fordham and Missouri are at their peak and every ticket has been sold for tomorrow's Sugar Bowl football game in Tulane's mammoth stadium. Seventy-three thousand persons have poured $225,000 into the coffers of the New Orleans Mid-Winter Sports Association, sponsor of the event, to be divided three ways.

Merrymakers gathered last night in festive celebration to herald the advent of 1942 at the smart hotels, restaurants and night clubs. At all these glamorous spots in the city there were capacity throngs in evening gowns and jewels, tailed-coats and white ties, at $15 a person for supper, and paying high prices for imported wines and liquors.

Industry expects necessity to be the mother of invention in the distribution of steel supplies into channels expediting the production of war materials, Iron Age says this week. "Some steel companies making steel ingots and slabs," it continues, "may find some of this material ordered by OPM to be sent to other steel companies where it will be fabricated into plates and other highly rated material.

India's contribution to the British war effort has been tremendous. How much greater it might have been had it not been for the policy of non-cooperation and limited civil disobedience advocated by Gandhi, and adopted by the powerful All India Congress, it is impossible to say.

RICHMOND, Calif., Dec. 31 -- After only a few months of activity, during which a busy shipyard was developed on a mudflat on this shore of San Francisco Bay, the 10,000-ton freighter James Otis was launched today for the Maritime Commission at the new plant of the Richmond Shipbuilding Corporation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The Department of Justice began action today to halt alleged domination of radio broadcasting by the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System. Two civil suits were filed in Federal District Court to break up alleged monopolistic holdings and enjoin network owners from practices through which it is charged that they hold control.

Sales of wine and liquor reached their holiday peak yesterday with domestic wines in such demand that retailers estimated the volume of holiday wine business nearly 50 per cent greater than a year ago. In the department stores and larger retail outlets, unit sales during the holiday period since Christmas week were estimated to be about 10 per cent greater than in 1940.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 1 -Their spirits "all clear" and undaunted, Londoners greeted the third New Year's Day of this war with a gayety reminiscent of peacetime.

National defense work took an increasing amount of the time of New York City Boy Scouts during 1941. During the year they gave more than 200,000 hours of civil service, according to a report yesterday by Kenneth Collins, chairman of the activities committee of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York.

A resolution to amend the State Constitution to merge the Court of General Sessions and the County Courts of Kings, Bronx, Queens and Richmond will be introduced at the coming session of the Legislature, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The nation's railroads placed in 1941 the largest orders for locomotives, freight cars and materials since 1929, and much larger orders for rolling stock than in that year, according to a survey by Railway Age, the industry's journal.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 31 -- Germans turned to the New Year tonight in sober contemplation of Adolph Hitler's two New Year's proclamations -- one addressed to the people and the other to the army.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday that as long ago as 1933 he warned the United States Government of Japan's intention to renounce all existing treaties with the Western world and pursue a militant policy in the Far East.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31 -- The aviation industry of the United States built in 1941 more than a billion and a half dollars' worth of warplanes, engines and propellers, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America said tonight.

Happy New Year! What a fine opportunity there is this morning for the cynic who contrasts the gay words with the grim realities that are certainly waiting for us in 1942. How much happiness can any honest and kind-hearted American enjoy during the next twelve months?

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and its subsidiaries had in the twelve months ended on Nov. 30 a consolidated net income of $6,424,509, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, according to the report made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Federal funds totaling $134,062,500 were apportioned to the various States and territories today for improvement of the Federal highway system, including $17,062,500 for secondary roads and $19,500,000 for elimination of hazards at railroad grade crossings.
HONOLULU, Dec. 31 -- Admiral Chester William Nimitz, a tanned, white-haired, 56-year-old Texan, assumed command of the United States Pacific Fleet today in a simple war-time ceremony at Pearl Harbor.

Miss Olga Chechila, 26 years old, daughter of the Rev. Alexander J. Chechila, pastor of SS. Peter and Paul's Russian Orthodox Church, in East Seventh Street, and Harry S. Fischer, 49, an executive of the Brand Chatillon Corporation, jewelers at 703 Fifth Avenue, made charges of grand larceny against each other yesterday in the Felony Court, resulting from a fracas on the night of Dec. 23 in Mr. Fischer's penthouse apartment at 737 Park Avenue.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- November business activity in the six New England States showed a gain of 3 points over that of October, it was reported today by the New England Council. The index of activity now stands at 126.4 per cent of estimated normal as compared with 123.4 per cent in October.
WASHINGTON Dec. 31 (AP) -- Representative Baldwin of New York said today he had been ordered to report for Army duty on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Federal Trade Commission today, ordered Life Savers Corporation, Port Chester, N.Y., to cease and desist from violations of the Robinson-Patman act through paying to some, but not all, of its retail outlets, a sum equal to 10 per cent quarterly of the net dollar value of purchases of this candy product made at regular invoiced prices.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Consolidation of Middle East positions from the Caucusus to Bengazi, bringing it into "direct touch with our Allies, Russia and Turkey," was cited authoritatively today as the British Army's major accomplishment of 1941.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- An observer arriving from Greece has given the Allied authorities here information of extensive Axis military activity in Greece and has described the extent to which German-Italian plundering has brought on famine in Greece.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 -- The nations of the Western Hemisphere can be brothers only through the acknowledgment of God as a common father, declared speakers at the opening session at Barry College for Women of a four-day conference for hemisphere defense through spiritual inter-Americanism.

" The Man Who Came To Dinner," Warner Brothers' screen version of the George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart play, will have its local premiere at the Strand this morning. Monty Woolley portrays Sheridan Whiteside, the role he created in the stage production, and Bette Davis and Ann Sheridan are co-starred with him in the comedy.
