Today marks the beginning of a new year and, although millions of our active anglers and hunters will participate in war work of some nature, those not in actual armed service will continue to turn to these sports as a favorite form of recreation.

Public Administrator Alfred J. Kennedy was directed yesterday in Surrogate's Court, Queens, to take charge of a $26,500 estate which would ordinarily go to Mrs. Giovania Salvatore of Castelguidone, Italy. Settlement of the estate, it was announced, has been made impossible by the war.
The Weather Bureau looked back yesterday on the year 1941 and pronounced it good.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Dec. 31 -- President Getulio Vargas addressed the nation by radio today on the threshold of a year that may see all the American republics drawn into the world conflict.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- Travelers returning from Bulgaria reported today that twelve to fifteen new German and Italian divisions -- 180,000 to 225,000 men -- were being moved into Bulgarian-occupied Western Thrace near the Turkish frontier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Senator Connally, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, warned the country today that it must steel itself to face the loss of men and materiel before the real fighting strength of the United States could come to its full test.

Manufacturers' shipments in November declined from the peak established in October; new orders were unchanged; value of manufacturers' stocks continued to climb for the twenty-sixth consecutive month, and at the end of the month both inventories and unfilled orders were at record highs, according to seasonally adjusted indices computed by the National Industrial Conference Board and issued yesterday.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 31 -- Country clubs on the North Shore were scenes of dinners and dances tonight as hosts gathered their friends about tables long reserved, and welcomed the new year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- Preliminary indications today were that enlistments in the proposed women's Army auxiliary corps would be heavy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- As labor leaders pledged in New Year's statements that their members would give uninterrupted and speedier production of military material in 1942, Secretary Perkins moved forward today with plans for a twelve-man War Labor Board equally representative of employers, employes and the public.

Three steps recently taken by the British Treasury serve to emphasize the development of India as the eastern arsenal of the Allies. First, it announced requisitioning for repayment in /Vfarch of the Indian 3 per cent and 2/2 per cent loans, amounting to $296,000,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The High Command announced today that "necessary counter-measures" were being taken against the Russian forces landed at Kerch and Theodosia, at the eastern end of the Crimean peninsula.

VICHY, France, Dec. 31 -- Although the theatres of war are correlated, there is a growing belief in competent circles here that operations in Europe may end first, with consequent speculation as to what will occur then.

Immediate appeals from the recent price ceiling order on wool floor coverings are planned in view of the proposed plan of the Office of Production Management to limit use of carpet wools to 50 per cent of that in the first quarter of last year, mill men said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Senator Connally of Texas let it be known today that in spite of recent administration sponsored actions looking to the establishment of a war labor board for the voluntary settlement of management-labor disputes in defense industries, he intended to press for Senate action on his bill for stringent legislative strike curbs.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- With several veterans from last year's meet scattered among the team representing the twelve colleges entered, the twenty-first annual college men's Winter sports meet of the Lake Placid Club will get under way tomorrow with a cross-country race.

Five major committees of the St. Vincent's Hospital Building Fund have enlisted 1,581 volunteers and all arrangements have been completed for the formal opening of its drive next Monday, the fund's general chairman, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, announced yesterday.
Searching for words to express an idea, I found in Topics of The Times the very ones I wanted to prove my point -- "coincidences are happening all the time. That is what coincidences are for."

William J. Dempsey, retiring Sheriff of Richmond County, injected yesterday a new complication into the transfer of the offices of the five county Sheriffs to the new city-wide Sheriff by demanding payment of $6,000, a year's salary, but consented to turn over his ofice on a stipulation that none of the legal rights he might have would be impaired.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Contributions to the national defense in the last fiscal year are stressed in the annual report of the Tennessee Valley Authority, made public today. An increase of nearly 50 per cent increase in net income from power sales, even after spending $1,590,000 from its gross power revenues for navigation and flood control, both non-revenue producing activities, is also reported.

TOKYO, Dec. 31 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in the United States) -- The Navy Section of Imperial Headquarters indicated today that Japanese land forces had tried to take Corregidor fortress, in the entrance to Manila Bay.

After an overnight carryover of trade demand had been satisfied early yesterday, the cotton market drifted lower under hedge selling and year-end liquidation. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures closed at levels unchanged to 4 points lower than on Tuesday, except for the January contract, which closed nominally at 16.98 cents, up 8 points, after being untraded all day.

The first issue of OPM Contract News, a weekly bulletin on defense work in the State, which among other things will carry a list of invitations for bids, was mailed last night to 10,000 manufacturers, trade associations and other interested parties by the New York Division of Contract Distribution, 122 East Forty-second Street.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- The Red Army reported tonight that it had routed six German army corps [possibly 255,000 men] on the south-central front, recapturing Kaluga, key railroad junction 100 miles southwest of Moscow, and unhinging the Germans' defense line so completely that they might have to fall back another 110 miles to Bryansk.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 31 -- A horse with a patriotic name -- Army Song -- led all the way to score with ease in the New Year's Eve Purse at Tropical Park today. The son of Man O' War and Song, a 7-to-2 shot in the field of seven, carried G.C. Greec's silks to the wire two lengths in advance of Inscolad.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Dec. 3l (AP) -- Headquarters of the Netherlands Indies Fighting Services today issued this communique:

Hope that 1942 would mark a full reunion between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations and that relations between government, management ant labor would be so harmonious that no legislative restraints or penalties would be required was expressed in a New Year's statement issued yesterday by Matthew Woll, second vice president of the A.F. of L.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -- James Cagney and his producer-brother, William Cagney, announced today that they will form their own producing company after the completion of their current Warner Brothers film, "Yankee Doodle Dandy."
BERLIN, Dec. 31 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique said today:

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Texas Aggie cohorts warned today that the "one weapon team" appellation hung on the big red machine was a misnomer as Alabama's versatile Crimson Tide would find out when the squads trade touchdowns in the sixth annual Cotton Bowl game tomorrow.
This afternoon Broadway will mark the advent of the New Year with twenty-three matinees out of twenty-nine current attractions. Divided into musicals and plays, the list follows:

Millions of school children in elementary and secondary schools have been stimulated by war events into taking a vital new interest in geography, it was reported yesterday at the opening of the annual three-day conference of the National Council of Geography Teachers at the Barbizon Plaza Hotel, 101 West Fifty-eighth Street.

Four official uniforms, authorized by the Office of Civilian Defense, will go on display tomorrow at the Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, 131 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Miss Mary E. Dillon, chairman.

As had been commonly expected for months, Edward C. Eicher, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been nominated by the President to become Chief Justice of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. He will be the fifth SEC chairman to resign from that post in the seven and a half years of its existence.

In a recent article "Hungary Divided Against Itself" it is stated that I am working with "nine Hungarian diplomats" who are supposed to have revolted "for a free Hungary either with or without the endorsement of the Horthy regime."

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Dec. 31 -- The newspaper Pravda said today in a leading editorial that the United States used "Petain" tactics in its efforts to spare Manila from Japanese air bombing and asserted that failure to transform the Philippine capital into a "Tobruk" or "Leningrad" constituted an act of cowardice.

Our first salute this New Year's Day is to the heroic defenders and the brave people of Manila. The Japanese hordes are closing in on a city that already bears the unforgettable marks of the contempt of the invaders for the elementary rules of war. But there are no signs of panic or dissension.

No thoughtful citizen can possibly question the validity of your editorial "Doing Without," nor is any one with a spark of patriotism in his make-up going to cavil at any necessary hardships, not to mention mere inconveniences, to which the people will inevitably be subjected when the nation is thoroughly launched on the supreme task which lies ahead.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H. Dec. 31 -- Skiers dashing down the snow-covered mountainsides little realize the vast amount of work that is required in preparing slopes and trails for satisfactory use during the Winter month. The care and conditioning of ski terrain is neeessary for the preservation of base snow.

The New Year's Eve celebration at the Versailles Restaurant, 151 East Fiftieth Street, was upset at 10:30 P.M. by a waiters' strike. Promptly at that moment a number of waiters walked out and a picket line was formed outside the building.

The New York Stock Exchange firm of Stern, Lauer Co. announced yesterday that Carl T. Naumburg had been admitted to general partnership and that Conrad H. Liebenfrost and John W. Flanigan had become associated with the firm.

Blyth Co., Inc., offered yesterday after the close of the Stock Exchange 10,000 shares of common stock of the Alpha Portland Cement Company at 18 3/8, less 65 cents a share concession to dealers. The bankers informed the Stock Exchange that they may stabilize the market to facilitate the offering.

TRENTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The "big push" to speed New Jersey man power into the armed forces started today as all 202 local draft boards were ordered to operate New Year's Day and all employes of the State Selective Service System were hastily notified by telegram to report for duty tomorrow.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 31 (AP) -- British tanks and planes, hacking away at the remnants of German General Erwin Rommel's Libyan army, were reported tonight to be closing in for the kill at Agedabia.

Subtracting from the year 1942 the year 1492 we get 450 years. In other words, we enter this morning on the 450th anniversary of the discovery of America. Under brighter circumstances it is very likely that we should already be getting set for a large celebration, though probably not another World's Fair.
Publishers and their staffs are beginning to lay plans for the coming season. By the publishers' calendar it is the Spring season and new catalogues are being prepared.

Hope for a "just peace" in 1942 was expressed last night by Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, in leading a one-hour prayer and meditation service that began at 8 P.M. A similar service was held again between 11 P.M. and midnight.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A little dry powder which may be the first step toward immunizing human beings against influenza was described today to the American Society of Bacteriologists.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 -- The patriotic motif was stressed in decorations for tonight's dinner dance given at the Everglades Club to greet the new year. War posters, assembled by Hugh Dillman, the club president, adorned the walls and the inner patio was dominated by a huge figure of Uncle Sam.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 31 -- Answering questions popped at him simultaneously from all sides of the room, Prime Minister Winston Churchill gave in a press interview today some of the reasons for the confident tone of the speeches he made in Washington and Ottawa this week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The country's automobile drivers, who use an average of 4,000,000 new tires a month in normal times, were told by the Office of Price Administration today that national quotas for civilian use next month will be 356,974. In the first monthly war rationing by the OPA a maximum of 114,191 new tires was fixed for passenger cars, motorcycles and light trucks, and a total of 242,783 for buses and trucks.

After an eventful year featured by many important actions taken to protect policy holders' interests and to improve further the functioning of the business, the opening of 1942 finds 66,000,000 Americans owning life insurance policies, Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance, said yesterday in his year-end review of life insurance.

Emphasizing that the developments that affected the anthracite industry in Pennsylvania in 1940 continued their beneficial effects throughout last year, the Anthracite Institute in a year-end statement said 1941 would be recorded in the annals of the industry as a period of regeneration.

Emphasizing that the developments that affected the anthracite industry in Pennsylvania in 1940 continued their beneficial effects throughout last year, the Anthracite Institute in a year-end statement said 1941 would be recorded in the annals of the industry as a period of regeneration.

A strong continuing interest in New York's Neediest Cases, not deflected by the war emergency, on the part of 7,852 New Yorkers and persons living in distant communities, has brought the Fund to $251,550.74 on this New Year's Day. Yesterday's 166 contributors gave $6,155.60.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 31 -- Attention in many quarters is being directed to the importance of the Netherlands Indies in the Allied prosecution of the war in the Far East against Japan.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Germany's submarine fleet has suffered such losses that the Nazi High Command apparently is finding difficulty getting and training new crews, the Ministry of Information declared today.

Not universal disarmament and reliance upon vague principles but a League to Enforce Peace, supporting itself upon the pooled force of nations willing and able to maintain law and justice, must be the objective of those now engaged in war against the Axis powers, Dr. Hu Shih, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's new 50,000-watt international short-wave transmitting station, WCRC, was opened last night, as 1942 began, with a one-hour program for twenty Latin-American nations. At the same time, the older Columbia short-wave station, WCBX, broadcast the same program southward, to produce additional coverage.

Should further Federal control of retail credit extend to charge accounts, retail credit men may want to consider voluntary community credit policies to be carried out under the direction of local credit associations, according to J. Anton Hagios, manager of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

A 78-year-old man, who confessed that he had been a kibitzer at card games for a long time, walked into Flatbush Court in Brooklyn yesterday and asked Magistrate Charles Solomon for a simple assault summons to be served on a friend who had become indignant at his kibitzing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The War Department's communique No. 37 today said:

Victory for the Chicago Bears in their coming Polo Grounds charity clash with the National Football League All-Stars is almost beyond the realm of possibility, according to pessimistic George Halas, who has guided the crack Western club to two straight pro gridiron titles.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- The Cramp Shipbuilding Company yard, reclaimed from rust and dust less than a year ago to become a major manufacturing plant for cruisers and floating workshops for the Navy, said today that in 1942 it would become a major builder of submarines as well.

With all financial markets, and business generally, throughout the world closed today, the usual financial compilations and statistics customarily published on Friday will appear on Saturday morning. A few markets, chiefly small ones in other nations, will remain closed until Monday, Jan. 5.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Governor Lehman notified local defense councils today that a county administrator of tires must be nominated at once by the city and defense councils of the counties outside New York City.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in London) -- The Japanese Premier, General Hideki Tojo, warned the Japanese people today to expect a long war, despite great early successes, because the Allies were striking in "desperate counteraction," the news agency D.N.B. reported from Tokyo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Navy today placed the name of Major Paul A. Putnam, Marine Corps flier from San Diego, Calif., beside that of Major James P.S. Devereux on the honor roll of Wake Island defenders.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- E.N. van kleffens, Foreign Minister of the Netherlands Government, said tonight that the Allied position in the Far East "at the moment is serious, but far from being irretrievable."

Dr. William H. Walker, State Athletic Commission physician, yesterday examined Joe Louis at Greenwood Lake, N.Y., and found the world heavyweight titleholder in tip-top condition for the fifteen-round bout in which, for the second time, he will defend his title against Buddy Baer, California challenger.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- For the first time in the Pacific war the British army was reported officially today to have seized the initiative in Northern Malaya, hammering "with good results" at Japanese positions along the Perak River some 300 miles above Singapore.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 31 -- Frank P. Slack Jr., 19, of Proctorsville, Ohio, a Princeton University freshman, was injured critically, and Miss Eloise Long, 19, a Smith College student, suffered facial injuries today in an automobile accident near Huntington. He was brought to St. Mary's Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- History can now take over 1941, and, grouping it with several of its predecessors, begin much later to formulate verdicts as to the responsibility for the return of war to the entire world. The verdicts will be reached by some who now are infants in arms and better reached by those yet unborn.

CHUNGKING, China, Dec. 31 (U.P.) -- Three British soldiers and a Chinese official were killed when a Japanese patrol boat hit and sank one of the five speed boats in which an intrepid group of seventy-two escaped from Hong Kong before the Japanese completed occupying it Christmas Day, it was learned today.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The recent influx of the carcasses of big fish along the New Jersey Coast is attributed by fishermen to the explosion of depth bombs released by Navy blimps and planes on the offshore patrol for enemy submarines.
Corregidor, symbol of strength and final citadel of American power in the Philippines, has commenced its trial by bombs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Formal announcement of an agreement for joint military and naval action between the United States and Great Britain is likely to be made by the White House after the return of Prime Minister Churchill from Ottawa to Washington, according to indications today in official circles.
TULSA, Okla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Josephine Davis is dead and her 24-year-long sitdown strike in the Court House is ended.

Sitting in Essex Market Court where he heard his first case twenty-three years ago, Magistrate Jacob Eilperin tried his last yesterday afternoon prior to his retirement at midnight. Magistrate Eilperin, 61 years old and a bachelor, was first appointed to the bench by Mayor John F. Hylan in 1918.

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 31 -- Three thousand miles removed from the scene of its annual holding since 1916, and without benefit of the floral pageantry of Pasadena, the Rose Bowl football game will be staged here tomorrow as a refugee from the war.

Profound changes in attitudes toward sex problems will take place in this country as a result of the war, Professor Leonard C. Cottrell Jr., head of the department of Sociology and Anthropology at Cornell University, predicted yesterday.
MOSCOW, Thursday, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The following regular communique was issued this morning:
TULSA, Okla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Josephine Davis is dead and her 24-year-long sitdown strike in the Court House is ended.

Sitting in Essex Market Court where he heard his first case twenty-three years ago, Magistrate Jacob Eilperin tried his last yesterday afternoon prior to his retirement at midnight. Magistrate Eilperin, 61 years old and a bachelor, was first appointed to the bench by Mayor John F. Hylan in 1918.

DURHAM, N.C., Dec. 31 -- Three thousand miles removed from the scene of its annual holding since 1916, and without benefit of the floral pageantry of Pasadena, the Rose Bowl football game will be staged here tomorrow as a refugee from the war.

Profound changes in attitudes toward sex problems will take place in this country as a result of the war, Professor Leonard C. Cottrell Jr., head of the department of Sociology and Anthropology at Cornell University, predicted yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 27 -- Forecasts made a year ago by Arthur de Souza Costa, Brazilian Finance Minister, that 1941 would be a banner year for trade despite the war have come true. Brazil will end 1941 with a favorable trade balance of more than $70,000,000, greater than that of 1939, when Brazilian markets were free to export to Europe and the Axis Powers were grabbing raw materials for war purposes.

A three-point program that will insure retailers' remaining "a vital force in holding prices to reasonable levels" is recommended by Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman of the Retailers Advisory Committee, representing all forms and lines of retailing, in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. The program follows:

BRIDGEWATER, Mass., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Three guards were brutally beaten and hacked to death today when two young inmates ran amuck at the vast Bridgewater State Farm, set fire to a building and fought off a charging riot squad for an hour and a half.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Dec. 30 (delayed) -- I have just returned from the northern front, where the Japanese have brought up tanks and heavy artillery. Although British Empire troops are weary after two weeks of heavy fighting, they are completely confident of their ability to defeat the Japanese as soon as tactical circumstances of the campaign permit them to make a stand.

VICHY, Jan. 1 -- The outstanding feature of this financial year in France was the plethora of funds available for investment and the decline of interest rates. The discount rate was further reduced by the Bank of France March 17 from 2 per cent to 1 3/4 and money constantly was obtainable on market below that rate.

The F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company marks the beginning of its hundred anniversary year today with full pages in newspapers in New York and New Jersey and with ceremonies at the company's brewery, 430 Kent Avenue, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The War Department's communique No. 39 today said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Through research, education and proposed legislation, the Senate Small Business Committee is hoping this year to provide remedies for some of the serious problems with which small business is confronted, Senator James E. Murray of Montana, committee chairman, told THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Rearguard units of the British Eighth Army, concerned lest an Axis "Tobruk" develop on the flank of Britain's desert advance, have struck hard at the well-fortified Italian-German forces isolated in the Bardia-Halfaya region of Eastern Libya.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A British Middle East Command communique today said:

EL PASO, Texas, Jan. 1 -- A long, lanky halfback named Glenn Dobbs, whose six-foot four-inch frame supports 182 pounds of football dynamite, led the Golden Hurricane of Tulsa University to a whirlwind finish in the Sun Bowl today and a 6-0 victory over the Red Raiders of Texas Tech.

John J. McCloskey Jr., Greater New York's first city-wide Sheriff, announced yesterday the beginning of a non-political new deal in the sheriff's office and the appointment of an under sheriff and four chief deputies.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 -- A Royal Australian Air Force officer has brought to Australia a crude leaflet dropped on Malaya by Japanese fliers urging the Australians to cease fighting. It says:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The defending forces in the Philippine Islands, now engaged in a "major battle" with the Japanese invaders, have consolidated their positions into a single combat formation, with their backs toward Manila, which they contain in a semi-circle.

For the first few months of this year, retailers should expect sales in dollars to be at least equal to those of 1941, or even show a reasonable increase for the first quarter, according to Isaac Liberman, president of Arnold Constable Co.

Additional measures are being invoked to conserve existing supplies of tires and tubes, it was disclosed yesterday as the New York Tire Rationing Board announced that it was establishing eighteen local boards in twelve separate locations to handle applications for new tires from car and truck users who meet the eligibility requirements.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- A two weeks furniture and homefurnishings market that will be of record-breaking proportions in attendance will get under way here next Monday. Gone will be the hectic scramble for goods that marked the 1941 showings at both the American Furniture Mart and Merchandise Mart.

HONOLULU, Jan. 1 -- The islands of Kauai, Maui and Hawaii, all of the Hawaiian group, were shelled early yesterday morning by enemy vessels, believed to be Japanese submarines, the Army announced today. It was said the shelling was apparently aimless, did little damage and caused no casualties.

Of all the types of securities held widely by investors, none appears in a more basically advantageous position than medium-grade bonds, and indeed, bonds of somewhat lower grade classifications, according to Henry J. Simonson Jr., president of the National Securities and Research Corporation.

Supplies of drugs and chemicals for medicinal uses are sufficient that, even in the event of epidemics, there is no cause for alarm over ability to meet the need, according to Charles L. Huisking, president of Charles L. Huisking Co., commission merchants in chemicals.

MEXICO, Jan. 1 -- The outstanding events in the economic life of Mexico in 1941 were the financial agreements with the United States in November and the entry of the United States into the war in December. The first event provided assurance that the United States would support the Mexican economy, which now is dependent upon that support.

The investment banking industry, the nation's machinery for the distribution of securities, enters 1942 with the objective, common to all other lines of business, of doing its part in preparing for and waging war. Its part is aiding in the financing of this unprecedented effort.

A record total of $6,800,000,000 for retail installment sales during 1941 is indicated by Department of Commerce estimates, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Malcolm L. Merriam, in charge of credit research in the current business analysis unit of the Department of Commerce.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A Far East British Headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Cyrus Eaton, Cleveland banker and industrialist, urged the Roman Catholic Church today to call on all its members to oppose "the pagan German and Japanese forces that seek to enslave the world."

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 1 -- A long line of flatcars traveling westward across the level central Russian plains signified the recent change for the better on the Soviet front more precisely than any military dispatches.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook became today Lieutenant Governor General of the Netherlands Indies, surrendering the post of Colonial Minister to which he was appointed two months ago because greater need was seen for his services with the colonial administration, the Netherland Government here announced.

Reflecting the periods of unsettlement in securities markets and investment conditions generally arising out of the war, the total of new securities offered to the public in this market in 1941 fell moderately below that for the preceding year.

Although the industrial finishing industry has been thrown out of its normal course by the defense program, and many of the ingredients commonly used in lacquers and enamels have been diverted from civilian industry, there are numerous developments of finishes based on materials not needed in defense, according to G. Finkelstein, vice president and technical director of Maas Waldstein Company.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 1 -- The revelation by the British Admiralty of the second raid on the Lofoten Islands has created a sensation throughout Scandinavia.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 1 -- Reported plans to sabotage City Hall here caused a guard of police and American Legion members to be thrown around the tall building, Mayor George E. Brunner announced today.

The piano concerto by Carlos Chavez, conductor of the Symphony Orchestra of Mexico, received its world premiere at the concert given last night in Carnegie Hall by the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under Dimitri Mitropoulos, with Eugene List as soloist.

The outlook for 1942 in the carpet and rug industry, as in many other industries, depends more upon what is required to prosecute the war than upon the demands for merchandise made by consumers, according to Leroy A. Beers, president of the Institute of Carpet Manufacturers of America, in a year-end statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Maritime Commission established today a $40,000,000 fund to provide war-risk insurance and reinsurance on American ships the owners of which are unable to obtain adequate protection at "reasonable terms and conditions" from commercial underwriters.
ROME, Jan. 1 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique today follows:

Government control of industry virtually has "blacked out" for the duration of the war many of the most difficult business problems of the last several years, according to George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Crippled by the nation-wide rush to turn all available factories into arsenals, the consumers' durable goods industry will become in 1942 the first major industrial casualty of the war, after having reached an all-time record in production and sales last year.
I have addressed to the Presidents of the American republics a letter by air mail requesting that unconditional amnesty to all political prisoners and exiles be granted now.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- To a scientific presentation describing the discovery of "the rosetta stone of life" was awarded today the annual $1,000 prize of the American Association for the Advancement of Science for an outstanding contribution to science reported at its annual Winter meeting.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 -- In the reorganization of the commands of the Home Defense Forces Brigadiers H.C.H. Robertson, E.C.P. Plant, G.A. Vasey, C.A. Clowes, J.J. Murray and S.G. Savige, all of whom have been serving in the Australian Imperial Forces in the Middle East, are returning to Australia to assume field commands with the rank of Major General, it was revealed here today.

" DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The world's largest telescope shows that the universe probably is not exploding but is a quiet, peaceful place, and possibly just about infinite in size. The observations were made with the 100-inch telescope at Mount Wilson, Calif., and reported to the American Association for the Advancement of Science tonight by Dr. Edwin P. Hubble."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Henry F. Grady, former assistant Secretary of State, was appointed today chairman and Federal Reserve Agent of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.

The fifteenth annual Debutantes New Year's Ball, a holiday dance that always draws a large attendance from younger members of society, was held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Debutantes from this city, Long Island, Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey were in the assemblage, the party serving as the formal introduction to society of several of these girls.

BATAVIA, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- The news agency Aneta quoted today two newspaper correspondents back from an airdrome that the Japanese bombed recently as saying the twenty-seven Japanese planes in the raid had achieved very little damage and wounded only one man. Craters showed, they said, that most of the bombs had fallen outside the field.

DETROIT, Jan. 1 -- The order of OPM banning the sale of new automobiles and trucks, pending rationing, was anticipated in the industry by the formation yesterday by the Automobile Manufacturers Association of the automotive council for war production.
A swift and complete shift in the thinking of management was the first requisite as business entered the war, according to Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Contending that the problem of labor supply would become increasingly serious due to the entrance into the war and the big industrial effort, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged President Roosevelt today to give entire responsibility for labor supply problems to the Department of Labor and end the duplication among various agencies.

The Treasury Department in 1941 bought approximately $75,000,000 of silver in the domestic and world markets. The total was the smallest for any year since enactment in 1934 of the Silver Purchase Act. It compared with $99,400,000 in 1940 and a high of $346,500,000 in 1935.

The textile industries, operating for about half of 1941 under some price control and constant threat of additional control, set new production records in each of their major branches. Entering 1942, they are preparing to operate under virtually complete price control and to make some further expansions in production.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- One person was killed and several were injured as two German planes opened the new year with machine-gun attacks on towns along the southeast English coast.

Our entry into a shooting war provided changes in the position of leather and shoes that may prevent a modest decline in volume that would have resulted from admitted overproduction of shoes in 1941, according to a review prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Merrill A. Watson, executive vice president of the Tanners Council of America.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 1 -- Oregon State, the miracle team of the Pacific Coast, came 3,000 miles across the country to end the winning streak of heavily favored Duke by 20 -- 16 today in a thrilling, seesaw Rose Bowl football game, transferred for the first time from Pasadena, Calif., because of the exigencies of war.

Recognizing their responsibility in the slogan "Food Will Win the War," the food industry has been girding itself for an all-out effort to fulfill that pledge. That the task is not inconsiderable is indicated by present estimates under which the armed forces during the next six months may require about 50 per cent more food than in the same period of 1940.

Before Britain can make the shift from her present tactics of defense to the tactics of offensive operations a vast amount of industrial and military preparation will be necessary. Not only must the superiority of the Axis in tanks and planes be overcome but the weak points of the enemy must be discovered and exploited.

War activity was largely transferred to the Mediterranean area during January. Minor Greek victories over the Italians continued, but in North Africa the British troops, though outnumbered three to one by the Italians and with air force hardly one-fifth of the Italian contingents, advanced with great rapidity, capturing large Italian detachments on the way. Bombing of London by the Germans slightly decreased from preceding months.

LITTLE FALLS, Minn., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Richard Dehler, a 16-year-old farm youth charged with slaying four persons, broke out of the Morrison County Jail here tonight after slugging and seriously injuring Sheriff William B. Butcher.

Despite restriction on sales to certain companies in South America, occasioned by issuance of "blacklists," there has been no resultant decline in the American manufacturing exporters' volume of trade with that continent, according to Kenneth H. Campbell, manager Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau, National Association of Credit Men.

With receivables probably at the highest level in history, with record taxes in the immediate offing and with adjustment from civilian to war production only now beginning to become a reality on a wide scale, an appreciable slowing down in payments may be expected in the early part of 1942 and the recovery from this letdown may be a long process, credit men for companies in widely separate fields agreed.

New records in consumer cooperative sales and production were set last year, according to a special analysis prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Wallace Campbell, an executive of the Cooperative League of the U.S.A.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- By the slender margin of an automatic safety, acquired in the first period, Fordham's football forces turned back Missouri in today's Sugar Bowl football game in Tulane's double-decked stadium, crowded to the last available seat by 73,000 onlookers despite a steady down-pour of rain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Manila apparently still stood tonight, and in the outlying jungle battlefields all defending forces had been consolidated by a bold military manoeuvre into a single, united death-dealing army.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 (AP) -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Commander in Chief of Britain's forces in India, told his countrymen in a New Year broadcast today to "look forward to 1942 with courage and confidence."

A special "Day of Prayer for the Nation" service was held last evening at 6 o'clock in the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street. Among the worshipers was Edgar J. Nathan Jr., new president of the Borough of Manhattan, who is vice president of the congregation, the oldest Jewish synagogue in America.

A listing of the New York offices of defense agencies, their addresses, their executive officers and their functions has been prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the regional information office of the Office for Emergency Management. It is understood that, as the war effort expands, additional offices will be opened here to reduce the necessity for business men to go to Washington to participate in the defense program.

Americans begin their first year of war with an experience that has be-fallen every other nation in the initial stages of the struggle against Axis aggression. It is cold comfort to know that the reverses we suffer are due to the unexpectedness and treachery of the attack on our distant outposts.

America's entry into the world conflict overshadows every other event of 1941 for all industries and clarifies the objectives to which they must dedicate themselves in 1942, Roy A. Hunt, president of the Aluminum Company of America, declared yesterday in a year-end statement reviewing the activities of the Aluminum Company with respect to the national defense program.

Charters for the present and the future, in which the dominant themes were maintenance of the democratic ideal, preparation of plans for widespread military action and increased production and the mobilization of an army for post-war spiritual service in the lands of the enemies were outlined by three rabbis yesterday at a special union New Year service in the Free Synagogue House, 40 West Sixty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Prime Minister Churchill welcomed the new year by proposing a Victory toast at a midnight ceremony in the dining car of his special train "somewhere in Vermont," with members of his staff, newspaper correspondents, the train crew and porters.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- A Japanese attack upon Australia may come at any moment and this country must rely on itself, not on American or other outside aid, Lieut. Gen. Sir Iven Mackay, commander of the Australian home forces, warned his officers today.

Retail trade last year shattered all previous records in both dollar volume and unit sales of merchandise. Total volume approached $54,000,000,000, a figure about 19 per cent larger than in 1940. The 1929 peak was $48,459,000,000.

There has been a "notable increase" during 1941 in the public acceptance of beer as an essential food, according to R.J. Schaefer, president United States Brewers Association. He explained that the industry was making "no unreasonable claims upon the allocation of scarce materials," adding, "we have availed ourselves of the abundance of grains essential to our business, such as hops and malting barley, in themselves non-competitive to other foods."

Declaring that the 300,000 single family homes in Queens make the borough's problem of civilian defense radically different from that of the rest of the city, Borough President James A. Burke announced yesterday at his induction into office that he had worked out a civilian defense plan taking into account the special features of the Queens situation.

The coming into effect of the New York State motor vehicle safety-responsibility law at the start of 1942 marks the beginning of an effort to reduce the huge annual losses, in lives and property, of the most populous State in the Union.

It is more difficult than usual to sum up the good and bad points in the financial outlook, for the reason that war developments, especially as affecting Japan and the United States, came in full force very suddenly during December, and the resultant situation had not clearly defined itself at the year-end.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- The slightly mad Mummers of King Momus, who usually send their barbs of wit and satire toward persons and things dominating the national scene, shifted their accent to the Axis today to the delight of more than 700,000 persons who braved cold and rainy weather to witness the annual event.

To facilitate the shipment of merchandise and the negotiation of drafts under credits issued by banks in this country, E.C. Zimmerman, Trade Commissioner for the Netherlands Indies, has requested that banks authorize certain changes in their letters of credit necessitated by the war, R.F. Loree, chairman of the Foreign Exchange Committee, announced yesterday.

The largest new bond issues offered to the public here in 1941, according to their respective classifications, included $135,000,000 of Commonwealth of Pennsylvania short-term securities which were offered in July. This financing, which constituted the largest individual transaction in the tax-exempt field offered directly to the public, consisted of $90,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent tax-anticipation notes, due in 1943, and $45,000,000 of tax-anticipation 1 1/2s, maturing in 1942.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The United States has little cause to fear a post-war depression in the opinion of Edward J. Flynn, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, here today to see his alma mater, Fordham University, in its Sugar Bowl tilt with Missouri.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Holiday gifts to the Red Cross $50,000,000 war fund brought up to a total of $11,755,581 the contributions received thus far, S. Sloan Colt, chairman of the campaign, announced today.

Record-breaking supplies of sulphur at no advance in price were the reply of the American sulphur industry to the Axis challenge, Langbourne M. Williams Jr., president of the Freeport Sulphur Company, says in a year-end statement.

There were wide variations in yields on the Treasury's weekly issues of discount bills during 1941, because of changes during the year in tax features, and because of differences in sizes of individual issues and also because of the demand, at times, from buyers other than commercial banks.
Followers of many of the world's religions prayed yesterday for peace and universal understanding at a special all-faith prayer service in the Union Methodist Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill visited the tomb of George Washington at Mount Vernon today after praying together for the success of Allied arms in the quaint church at Alexandria, Va., where Washington worshiped. The leaders of the two great English-speaking powers sat together in the white pew in Christ Church, which Washington, who was a founder of the church in 1773, had occupied.

The Japanese are rapidly extending their air positions in the neighborhood of Singapore. They are established in North Borneo and are attempting the capture by parachute troops of Medan airport in Dutch Sumatra.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- The effects of America's re-armament activity in 1941 were reflected by sharply increased loans made by Chicago banks, it was disclosed today in annual statements made by the banks.

Pennsylvania Company The Pennsylvania Company for Insurance on Lives and Granting Annuities reported as of Dec. 21, 1941, total deposits of $310,224,183 and total assets of $341,087,239, compared, respectively, with $280, 349,268 and $308,418,216 on Nov. 30, 1940.

PANAMA CITY, Panama, Dec. 27 -- The Central American and South American countries near the Panama Canal face prospects in 1942 little different from those in 1941 but with more favorable outlooks in some countries despite the spread of war to the Americas.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- The Brooklyn Americans, outplayed by a wide margin for fifty minutes, staged a furious closing drive before bowing by 5 -- 4 to the Boston Bruins tonight before a holiday crowd of 10,732 at the Boston Garden. The triumph enabled the Bruins to tighten their grip on the National Hockey League's top rung.

More than forty firemen were overcome by smoke yesterday as a fire of undetermined origin swept through the Brazilian freighter Pocone, berthed at Pier 18 at State and Joralemon Streets, Brooklyn, and destroyed the bulk of its cargo of 40,000 bags of castor beans, 30,000 bags of coffee and a considerable number of bales of cotton.

The relationship of an individual corporate enterprise to the national economy, subjected to annual appraisal at this time of year, is overshadowed as 1942 opens by the all-important fact that the United States of America is at war, said Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president of the Celanese Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The first six months of 1942 will be the crucial period for small business enterprises in this country, Floyd B. Odlum, head of the OPM's contract distribution division, asserted in a statement outlining their difficulties.

A winged bearer of life, purely imaginary and commonly known as The Stork, was the only aerial visitor to fly over New York as the year 1942 dawned. However, the visitor, whose appearance had been fully anticipated, was not recorded on the listening devices at Mitchel Field.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Casa del Pastor was the setting today for the annual reception given by Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard to celebrate Mr. Shepard's birthday and to mark New Year's Day. Mr. Shepard is 85 years old.

Production in most branches of the electrical manufacturing industry will be pushed to the absolute limit in 1942 to fill requirements of the armed services and the greatly intensified effort in all other fields of manufacturing, transportation and business, according to W.J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique today said:

DETROIT, Jan. 1 -- Alvan Macauley, official spokesman for the automotive industry, endorsed tonight the government's order for cessation of passenger car and light truck production but urged that the industry receive more defense contracts to cushion dislocations and speed the armament program.

Although the men's wear industry chalked up fairly substantial gains in 1941, ranging from 15 per cent for department stores to 30 per cent for chains, a good part of this increase was due to price advances and unit sales did not come up to expectations.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1 -- New evidence of the willingness of the American people to make financial sacrifices for the war effort is revealed in a survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Enactment of basic labor laws to give the War Labor Board soon to be appointed by the President "positive legislative backing and support" was urged yesterday by Walter D. Fuller, retiring president of the National Association of Manufacturers, in a year-end message addressed to the association's members.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A complete ban on the retail sale of new passenger automobiles and of light and heavy trucks was imposed here tonight by the Office of Production Management. The order "freezes" all stocks in the hands of dealers until Jan. 15, by which time a rationing system similar to that being applied to new tires, is scheduled to be established.

The war crisis has given the organized prohibitionist "new hope and zeal in the promotion of his particular brand of intolerance," according to Howard R. Walton, vice president of Hiram Walker Sons, Inc. Joining with other distillers' executives in statements prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES, Mr. Walton pledged the industry's support of the wax effort and denied that it makes heavy denieds on the supply of critical defense materials.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 30 (Delayed) -- (Reuter) -- It would appear that British troops around Ipoh are fighting a withdrawing action designed to hold up the Japanese advance and inflict as many casualties as possible.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- Fordham's football team burst into its dressing room after the Rams' 2-0 Sugar Bowl victory over Missouri and uncorked grins and yells that cracked open mud a half inch thick on some faces.
BERLIN, Jan. 1 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today follows:
American forest products industries will face in 1942 the heaviest production responsibility in their history, according to I.N. Tate, president of the American Forest Products Industries, Inc.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 -- An assertion that the United States had not always been fair in its evaluation of the political and cultural accomplishments of Ibero-America was made here today at the second session of the Conference of Spiritual Inter-Americanism at Barry College for Women.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A building and repair program to enable the nation's railroads to keep pace with rising transportation demands of the victory program won approval of the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board at its weekly session today.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 1 -- Although cut off by the war from markets that in normal years absorbed over 50 per cent of her exports, Argentina had a comparatively prosperous year in 1941.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- The Office for Emergency Management assured the country tonight that the government was exploring "all possible" means of relieving the No. 1 materials problem of the war -- the pressing rubber shortage which already has resulted in rationing of automobile tires and tubes for civilian use.
Mayor La Guardia swore in Henry W. Ralph as the first citywide Register for New York City yesterday and made thirty additional appointments and reappointments.

Radical changes in the marketing and advertising plans of the country's leading national advertisers have developed in the last months as a result of the entry of the United States into the war. More than ever, all merchandising effort will have to be attuned to the availability of goods, advertising budgets will have to be geared for higher media costs, and media must operate under a wartime censorship and restrictions on supplies.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 1 -- The Groton Iron Works, a World War shipyard, will be opened as an extension of the Electric Boat Company's plant for the construction of submarines.

" The First Crocus," produced by T. Edward Hambleton, will be the only Broadway opening tonight, due to the last hour postponement by George Hale of "The Lady Comes Across.' Although both managers had insisted they would open their shows this evening, the reported illness of Jessie Matthews forced Hale to announce a Jan. 9 premiere.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Union vowed today to make the Germans pay "a hundredfold" for the "outrages and violence" committed against the non-combatant population of occupied Russian towns and villages in violation of international law.

The justification belatedly put forward by the State Department for its unpopular protest in connection with St. Pierre and Miquelon, as stated by Arthur Krock in your issue of Dec. 31, seems to be an afterthought, but not a happy one.

Over muddy jungle roads, manganese ore has been pouring in on mule-back and ox-cart to help swell the shipments of "strategic material No. 1" from Cuba to the United States during the past year. The 1941 total of 245,000 tons represents an increase of 85 per cent over 1940 and compares with an increase of about 70 per cent in Brazilian shipments, 15 per cent in Indian and 10 per cent in South African deliveries.

SANTIAGO DE CHILE, Jan. 1 -- Chile's gradual adjustment of her economy to war conditions abroad during 1941 enabled her to reach the year-end with renewed confidence, even if developments in the Pacific caused unconcealed anxiety in all circles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Frederic A. Delano, chairman of the National Resources Planning Board, has appointed a special "Committee on Wartime Requirements for Specialized Personnel." The committee will function as part of the National Roster of Scientific and Specialized Personnel, of which Dr. Leonard Carmichael, president of Tufts College, is director.

Wholesale druggists, whose 1941 sales rose 16 per cent above the previous year, are prepared to aid civilian defense by holding supplies of first-aid equipment, drugs, chemicals, botanicals and pharmaceuticals at strategic points for pharmacists who may operate emergency aid stations, according to W.J. Murray Jr., president of McKesson Robbins, Inc.

Brookhattan defeated Hatikvoh by 4-1 in the National Challenge Cup soccer game at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday before a crowd of 3,000. The victors gained a 3-0 first-half lead on goals by E. Skiba, Bodgansky and Jennette.
A six-point wartime program to be carried on under a coordinating committee for wartime service was made public yesterday by the executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches.

Despite the wartime emergency, packaged foods will not be replaced by bulk foods except in a few instances, according to Clarence Francis, president, General Foods Corporation, who added that "about four-fifths of all the foods America has been sending abroad in recent months has been processed."

TOKYO, Jan. 1 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Premier General Hideki Tojo said in a broadcast today that "It is only a question of time until Manila and Singapore meet the same fate as Hong Kong," the captured British Crown Colony.

Accusing most Americans of "geographic illiteracy," Dr. Howard E. Wilson of the Graduate School of Education of Harvard University yesterday emphasized that Hitler's successes have been made possible by a thorough understanding of the geography and economics of the nations he proposes to victimize.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Jan. 1 -- Mr. and Mrs. Norman K. Toerge of the Hitching Post gave a tea dance today at the Piping Rock Club to introduce to society Mrs. Toerge's daughter, Miss Nancy E. Redmond. The entire lower floor of the club, including the Mackay Room in which the long buffet table was placed, was used for dancing.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Jan. 1 -- Some 3,000 gayly-clad enthusiasts from seventeen States spent the New Year's Day running down Cranmore Mountain, though snow conditions were not what skiers would like for a steady diet.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Detroit's Red Wings came out of a slump tonight to hand the Black Hawks their fifth straight National League hockey defeat, 3 to 0.

Business on the New York Stock Exchange continued its downward course last year. There were no signs of life until well along in November and the volume for the year was the smallest in twenty-three years. Seat prices fell to the lowest since the Spanish-American War.

OTTAWA, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Production of automobiles and light trucks in Canada is being drastically curtailed with a view to virtual discontinuance of manufacture at March 31, R.C. Berkinshaw, chairman of the Wartime Industries Control Board, said tonight.

Although the United States is taking virtually the entire output of copper in the Western Hemisphere, the situation at the year-end probably was tighter than in the World War I, when this country had more than 60 per cent of the world's production.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 -- Wartime restrictions on Weather Bureau reports were temporarily lifted to some extent today by the military authorities when the New Year brought falling temperatures to California.

Dr. and Mrs. Edward Arthur Bullard of 55 East Seventy-second Street gave an afternoon reception yesterday at their home to introduce their daughter, Miss Marion Bullard. Receiving with her mother, the debutante wore a pink satin gown studded with brilliants and carried a muff of blue orchids.

The cotton and allied garment industry has proved its capacity to meet the apparel needs of the armed forces without necessarily depriving civilians of adequate supplies of the best-made work clothes, shirts and similar garments, according to A.F. Allison, secretary of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 1 -- Canada has gone through her second year of war with her financial and economic structure intact and unshaken. It could indeed be argued that the country is now on a more solid foundation than it was at the beginning of the war.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 1 -- The effectiveness of attacks by British bombers operating from Malta on Axis trucks, troops and supplies throughout Tripolitania has led the Germans to turn all their available air power on that British island base in an attempt to keep its raiders grounded.

After weeks of preliminary organization, during which many large unsolicited contributions were received, the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York will formally begin its city-wide drive Monday for a quota of $7,330,000 toward the national goal of $50,000,000, it was announced yesterday by the general chairman, Leon Fraser.

There are now about 50,000 university students in China, a gain of almost 20,000 since that country went to war, and the number will continue to increase despite the war, according to Zing Yang Kuo, Chinese educator and lecturer, who arrived from Europe yesterday on the Dixie Clipper.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- A raiding force of Commandos returned to Britain today after a successful operation on the German-occupied Lofoten Islands off Northern Norway. The operation, apparently timed to coincide with the one last Saturday at Vaagsoe, farther south, was completed with the return of all ships and men unharmed. They brought with them German prisoners and Quislings and about 100 Norwegian men and women who wanted to come to this country.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 1 -- The presence of United States Senator William H. Smathers at Mayor Frank Hague's annual New Year's Day reception in City Hall here today was interpreted by observers as an apparent move by the Mayor to reassert the leadership of the Democratic party in New Jersey which he recently "relinquished" in favor of Governor Charles Edison.

A significant job has been done in 1941 in keeping retail prices from spiraling and in adjusting operations as needed, E.C. Sams, president of the J.C. Penney Company, declared in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

CHUNGKING, China, Friday, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- The fate of Changsha hung in the balance today as Japanese aggressors and Chinese defenders grappled in sanguinary battle on the plain between the Laotao and Liuyang Rivers, the latter at one point only three miles from the North Hunan communications and supply center.
SINGAPORE, Dec. 31 (Delayed) -- The development of Allied-Japanese hostilities in this part of the world is proving anew the vital importance of air power.

George Santayana has just sent word to his publisher, Scribner, that he is safe and well and still living in Rome. A Spanish citizen, Mr. Santayana's Italian residence causes him no embarrassment. The author, now 79 years old, has been working on his autobiography, "Persons and Places," and has completed about half of the sixty or more chapters which will make up the long book.

Changes of a revolutionary nature in the nation's economic structure took place last year. The current year will see this process, forged under the hammer of national defense, carried forward to the point where America, almost completely stripped of its normal peace-time pursuits, will unfold the most gigantic wartime effort in history.

Puccini's "La Boheme" received its first performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Grace Moore sang the role of Mimi, Frederick Jagel, making his first appearance this season, was Rodolfo, and Paul Breisach, who made his debut recently with "Aida," conducted it as his second opera assignment with the company.

HONOLULU, Dec. 31 (Delayed) -- After having awarded the Navy Cross at Pearl Harbor today to an officer and an enlisted pilot who put their big seaplane down dangerously on a rough sea last night to rescue nine Army fliers who had been adrift for four days in two tiny rubber boats, Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, new commander of the United States Pacific Fleet, praised the rescue as an example of Army-Navy cooperation.

Mayor La Guardia defended vigorously yesterday his achievements in the dual capacity of chief magistrate of the nation's largest city and of director of the Office of Civilian Defense in an address over WNYC, the city's broadcasting station.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- All German, Italian and Japanese nationals in the United States, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands are required to surrender all firearms in their possession to local police authorities before 11 P.M. Monday, under new regulations of the conduct of enemy aliens issued today by Attorney General Francis Biddle.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 1 (AP) -- As the United States enters the war year of 1942 the nation has on hand "the largest supply of food in the history of the country" and "the means of producing at an even greater rate," Secretary Claude R. Wickard declared in a New Year's statement today.

Through continued research and development of the electron microscope in 1941, science passes along to 1942 and the years to come an instrument of far-reaching possibilities for use in industry. At the close of the year sixteen of these instruments, produced by the RCA Manufacturing Company, have been delivered.

In the first sale of the property in eighteen years, the five-story apartment house at 2014 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, was sold by a client of the Herman A. Acker Corporation to David W. Frankel. Said to have been held at $75,000, the building contains suites of three and four rooms.

The year of 1941 showed that a war may raise railroad profits to normal, but it brought a permanent peacetime solution to their problems no nearer. Profits, it is felt, are not important in wartime and the railroads have announced that they are disregarding their own interests in order to become a perfect unit in the defense machine.

Industry in the United States last year reached the highest operating rate in history as a result of the nation's defense activities. Results of this unprecedented rate of activity were not transferred entirely into net profits because of increased taxes and operating expenditures.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Robert Riskin, film writer and former partner of Frank Capra, has joined Metro as a producer-writer. His first assignment will be the studio's next "Thin Man" picture, with William Powell and Myrna Loy, for which no title has yet been announced.

VICHY, France, Jan. 1--The opening of the trial at Riom of those accused of responsibility for the French defeat will be delayed possibly as much as one month by the change of the Chief Justice, it was announced tonight.

Several veteran professional football devotees who watched the National League All-Stars practice yesterday at Garden City, L.I., came away with the impression that perhaps George Halas was right when he asserted the team seems unbeatable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Anti-Trust Division of the United States Department of Justice intends to see that the abuses that have been so flagrant in other wars are not repeated in this one, Thurman Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of anti-trust prosecutions, assured the public today.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Great Britain's powerful bombing forces in the Middle East were carrying the war to the Axis tonight with sustained assaults on the German bases in Greece, where there is increasing evidence of preparations for an air and sea assault on Britain's Eastern Mediterranean Fleet.
A matter of extreme importance which seems to have escaped notice concerns the question "Who are alien enemies in time of war?"
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Harry Woodhead took over control of the Consolidated Aircraft Corporation today, and pitched into his job of increasing heavy bomber output.
DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- A ghost in a Crimson shirt skipped through the Texas Aggies today as Jimmy Nelson carried Alabama to a 29-21 victory in the sixth annual Cotton Bowl football game.

Pending a more thorough check of box-office receipts when the accountants resume work today, managers of the leading first-run film houses in Times Square and adjacent areas last night summed up the New Year's Eve and New Year's Day business as equal to any in the last three years.
Recruiting in the armed services was virtually at a standstill here yesterday, with applicants merely trickling into recruiting offices.

Entry of the United States as an actual belligerent into the world conflict finds foreign traders probably more uncertain with regard to its effects than any other business group. Hedged about by a wide variety of restrictions and general difficulties, which for them started when the war began in Europe, the traders recognize the inevitability of further limits on their activities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Hungary has agreed to allow United States diplomats to leave Europe as soon as Hungarian diplomats arrive in Lisbon from the United States, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A new phenomenon that made its appearance in the financial world in the closing weeks of 1941 was the War Insurance Corporation, under which property owners in the United States and its possessions have been insured against war damage.

Greater cooperation between management and labor as a means of avoiding controversies, increasing efficiency and speeding production was forecast for 1942 by Elmer F. Andrews, labor relations consultant and former Wage and Hour Administrator, in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Plans for the establishment of a nation-wide program for cooperation by the liquor industry with military, civil and civilian defense authorities will be discussed at a joint meeting of the board of directors and the executive committee of Allied Liquor Industries, Inc., to be held on Monday, it was announced yesterday by Thomas P. McCarthy president of the recently formed organization.

Control of prices will be a major problem of war economics in the coming year. Industrial production will be stepped up to produce as many airplanes, ships and guns as possible. Government spending will be greatly increased. National income will rise to record levels.

The shock of the war upon business was moderated by the extent to which the economic organization already had moved toward a war basis, and adjustments in the markets were orderly, according to the January monthly bank letter of the National City Bank of New York.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 1 -- Celebrating the tenth anniversary of Winter dinghy sailing, the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club held the first session of its three-day regatta this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The large stocks of foodstuffs this country already has on hand combined with our exceptional capacity to produce more give the United States two assets that no other warring nation has or can achieve so long as hostilities continue, Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of the Department of Agriculture, held in a statement prepared specially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The quality of automobile tires has been so good and the price relatively so reasonable that most drivers in recent years have given little thought to the care of the rubber on their cars. Driving along at high speeds and in all weathers, changing tires only when a flat compelled them to and taking only a casual interest in the air pressure maintained, the casual motorist has counted upon his tires to "take it."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Farreaching decisions were believed imminent tonight as Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt resumed their war planning after a conference with strategists which, it was announced, dealt with all theaters of the conflict.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 1 -- For one relatively a tyro in stenography, 18-year-old Lietta Shearer got a nightmare assignment the other day, but she found that it was a lot easier than she had anticipated.

Washington, Jan. 1 -- The first session of the Seventy-seventh Congress, which has been marking time since Dec. 22 with a fortnight of informal holiday recesses, is adjourning tomorrow to meet on Monday, when the second session will convene.
The text of the Mayor's New Year's Day address yesterday in the City Council Chamber follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Organized labor enters 1942 under a pledge to its government to use peaceful means for the settlement of all disputes with industry and to exert every effort on the production line and in the mines, mills and smelters to insure successful prosecution of the war.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Friday, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The United States and Britain are preparing something "very unpleasant for the Japanese," Lieut. Gen. Hein ter Poorten, Commander in Chief of the Netherlands Indies' forces, told his troops in a New Year's Day broadcast yesterday. Warning his men to be on guard against a Japanese invasion, he said:

Mrs. Mabel Detmold, chairman of the legislative committee of the New York State Nurses Association, yesterday expressed her complete accord with the proposal made in Albany Saturday by Miss Jane Todd, member of the Assembly, seeking delay in execution of the State Nurses Practices Act.

Virtually every phase of the petroleum industry established last year new records, according to the American Petroleum Institute in giving detailed figures covering the operation of the oil industry in 1941. Domestic crude oil production reached a peak of 1,405,218, 000 barrels, compared with 1,353, 214,000 in 1940.

Never in recorded history has any government raised by national tax levies, in a similar period, an amount of revenue approaching that which will be collected by the United States Treasury in the current fiscal year. The Federal revenues are expected to exceed $13,000,000,000, of which over one-half will come from income and excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Army will begin soon field tests of an aerial observation unit, with enlisted men used as pilots of light sport airplanes, as a part of field artillery units, Secretary Stimson said today.

Since the sale of defense savings bonds and stamps was begun on May 1, 1941, the Treasury has received more than $2,500,000,000 from these sources, a figure that will be greatly exceeded in 1942. The selling pace increased several fold after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The War Department has canceled the plan to stop accepting voluntary enlistments and draw all of its forces from the Selective Service operations.

Farmers are prepared to deliver greater quantities of foodstuffs than ever before, and as a result the armed services are now receiving more and better food than ever before in the nation's history, according to John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Soviet military dispatches hinted broadly tonight that the Red Army had Mozhaisk within its grasp and that beyond the tottering town sixty-two miles west of Moscow the Germans already were falling back on Vyazma, 125 miles west of the capital, on the Smolensk highway.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 1 -- Following is the text of the New Year address of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain of France, as heard today.

The government has placed $4, 000,000,000 of war contracts with motor car manufacturers, "a clear implication that America regards the industry as the keystone of the arsenal of democracy," in the opinion of Joseph W. Frazer, president of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Secretary of Agriculture Wickard today set 1942 sugar quotas at 8,032,074 tons -- a 20 per cent increase over the 1941 total of 6,616,871 tons. All areas supplying the United States shared in the increase.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- While the President and the Prime Minister of Great Britain have been planning grand strategy, the son of a Scots dominie in New Brunswick, who accompanied Mr. Churchill to the United States, has been engaged in another work of great importance.

Changes in brokerage firms at the year-end included the merger of Stein Brothers Boyce of Baltimore and Barclay, Moore Co. of Philadelphia, both members of the New York Stock Exchange. The first house is eighty-eight the latter forty-one years old.

Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company research engineers and scientists during 1941 completed the development of defense-needed materials and devices that, normally, would have required ten years to bring to the production stage, Dr. L.W. Chubb, director of Westinghouse Research Laboratories, reported yesterday.

Strange topics spring from unlikely places these days, and one of last week's surprises was a scientific paper on the "Effect of the Full Moon on Trout Fishing," delivered before the annual convention of the American Statistical Association.

Because of the wartime emergency, loans and credits extended to Latin-American countries must be regarded as "primarily of a political character and should not be confounded with investments designed to increase our trade," according to James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council.

Financing victory is the job that can and must be shared by every American during 1942 and for as long as the present conflict lasts, John S. Fleek of Hayden, Miller Co. of Cleveland, president of the Investment Bankers Association of America, declared yesterday in a year-end statement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Civilian pilots will be accepted by the Army Air Corps Ferrying Command to fly planes from American factories "to those allied nations which are recipients of lend-lease aid," it was announced today by the War Department.

With armed conflict now raging in the Pacific Ocean, virtually all the crude rubber supplies to the United States have been stopped. Because 97 per cent of this country's crude rubber requirements normally comes from the Far East, a situation has developed whereby the United States must look to other sources for its supply of this essential commodity during its greatest war effort.

Fifteen gunners took part in a New Year's Day shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, competing for three scratch and the usual handicap prizes. The best work was done by T.H. Lewis, who broke 97 out of 100 targets.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 1 -- At least twenty-three persons have been shot and "many others" put before summary court-martial in Vienna in connection with a reported explosion that is said to have completely wrecked the Fiat works at Wiener Neustadt, according to a report reaching here this evening. The explosion is understood to have occurred in a section of the works where shells were being manufactured.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 1 -- The British Imperial line strongly engaged the Japanese invader today around Kuantan on the Eastern Malayan Peninsula 190 miles above this base, but action on the Western Front about Perak was confined principally to skirmishes and artillery fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, beginning the new year with prayers for divine guidance, bowed their heads today in a pew where America's first Commander in Chief besought victory for thirteen colonies then fighting against Mother England. Today, they were the prayers of union in the common cause of democracy.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Otto H. Kahn, widow of the New York financier and philanthropist, left today by plane for the United States. She has made her home in Egypt in recent years.
Prices have taken a holiday along with the rest of us, and for the first time in many a long month there are no fluctuations that the prudent woman with a budget must scan conscientiously.
