MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 -- With Frankie Sinkwich, Georgia's All-America back, who is often referred to as the cracked-jaw Cracker, pacing the attack with a brilliant performance, the Bulldogs from Athens conquered Texas Christian University's Horned Frogs before a crowd of 35,505 shirt-sleeved fans in the eighth annual Orange Bowl classic today.

Whatever the oil business may prove to be in 1942 it will not be business as usual, according to Edward G. Seubert, president of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, who emphasized that the vigorous prosecution of the war will necessitate many adjustments.

The production of mercury in the United States last year reached the highest level in more than sixty years. Reflecting the demand for war purposes, the price gradually increased from $162 for a flask of seventy-six pounds in January to $215 in December.

TOKYO, Jan. 1 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Japanese forces are pressing closer and closer to Manila from north and south, and "the belief prevails that the city shortly will succumb to the attack," it was said today.

An anti-espionage and sea safety plan formulated last Fall by the American Communications Association, radio union of the C.I.O., has been enlarged to meet the war situation, according to Joseph P. Selly, president of the union, who announced yesterday that four points had been added to the original nine-point plan.

Fully 60 per cent of the plywood industry's record productive activity last year was used in national defense, comparing with an estimated 20 per cent of all American production used in defense, according to Lawrence Ottinger, president of the United States Plywood Corporation.

The United States Committee of International Student Service and the National Student Federation of America have agreed to pool their efforts by affiliation, according to an announcement yesterday by Joseph P. Lash, general secretary of the International Student Service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The following is a composite of information gathered this week from executives of various materials divisions of the Office of Production Management. It represents the latest available information on material supplies and production programs:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Langston (Okla.) Lions bottled up Morris Brown's Big Train Moody and knocked the Atlanta Wolverine eleven from the forefront of Negro football with a 13-0 victory in the Vulcan Bowl today before some 7,000 spectators.

More than ever the collective thinking of the men's wear industry is needed for use by the individual manufacturer, retailer and piece goods house, according to Sidney Garfield, president of Hirshon-Garfield, Inc., in commenting on the support accorded the Retail Men's Wear Council by the men's wear advertising field.

The New York Rovers showed Baltimore little New Year's spirit yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Registering five of their goals in the third period, the Red Shirts swamped the Orioles, 9 to 2, in the Eastern Hockey League feature of an amateur twin bill.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 1 -- Germany since 1933 has been preparing systematically for war and in so doing organized its economics to fit into the new war scheme. It was intended originally to cover half of the actual running cost by "normal" taxation and duties, and to this end soon after the war's outbreak income and corporate taxes were increased by about 50 per cent -- war tax on excess profits.

As General Douglas MacArthur's thin line of defenders, without air support, pitifully outnumbered and outgunned, commenced their last stand at the close approaches to Manila yesterday, the indomitable Russians apparently clinched their most difficult victory of the war.

Despite the war, which held export outlets to an unusually low level, the United States oil industry last year enjoyed the greatest volume of business in history. Although the high taxes sharply cut into earnings, the net profits of the industry as a whole probably exceeded those of any recent year with the exception of 1937.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- At inaugural ceremonies in Westchester County today Herbert C. Gerlach took office as the first county executive elected to a four-year term, a Board of Supervisors of record size was installed, a new administration in Yonkers prepared to appoint a mayor and a city manager, the old village of Rye became the county's sixth city and new Peekskill officials planned a purge of employes.
The air conditioning industry made tremendous strides during 1941, especially in the industrial field, J.I. Lyle, president of the Carrier Corporation reports in a statement for THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Export-Import Bank, the first organization ever created by the United States to grant "political" loans, has taken on a new importance since war came to this country.

Special prayer services were held in churches and synagogues throughout the country yesterday in response to the request of President Roosevelt that the first day of the new year be devoted to appeals for divine aid in the national emergency.

Nothing illustrates more forcibly the changes in American industry between the first and second World Wars than the record of most active stocks on the New York Stock Exchange. In 1917 the twenty most active issues accounted for 65 per cent of the year's volume.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The Government disclosed that production of new automobiles and light trucks would be stopped entirely "within a few weeks."

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- The skiers of the University of New Hampshire took up this afternoon where they left off a year ago when the twenty-first annual college men's Winter sports meet of the Lake Placid Club finally got under way, hampered by weather that refuses to cooperate with the hundreds of holiday visitors in town.

While the trend of quarterly earnings of 337 American companies engaged in all principal fields of manufacture during the last four years continued to show the usual pattern of fourth quarter peaks and mid-year dips, the cumulative earnings over twelve-month periods have not shown a single decline since 1938.

VICHY, France, Jan. 1 -- "In partial exile to which I am subjected," said Marshal Henri Philippe Petain in his New Year's message to France, "in the semi-liberty that is left to me, I strive to do all my duty. Each day I endeavor to wrest our country from the stagnation that threatens it, from the trouble that is lying in wait. Help me!"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- "The thing I feel about the Defense Plant Corporation, as well as nearly all the other branches of the Federal Loan Agency, is what a blessing it is that we had it when war came upon us," was the comment of Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, on the far-flung activities of his many-faceted organization in the year 1941.
BROWSING through Nat Fleischer's newly issued "All-Time Ring Record Book," which is the last word with reference to pugilistic history, this avid reader came across some entrancing bits.

As the banking system enters the new year its position in the nation's war effort might be summed up with the observation that the United States is facing shortages of everything but money. Defense industries never will suffer from a shortage of bank credit.

ALBANY, N.M., Jan. 1 -- In a New Year's message broadcast tonight from the State Executive Mansion Governor Herbert H. Lehman warned that the war could not be won by "wishful thinking." He called for an "all-out effort," in which factories would operate on a seven-day week, twenty-four-hour-a-day schedule, with "no strikes or stoppages."

With the statement this week by President Roosevelt that an expenditure of $50,000,000,000 is planned for the war program in the 1943 fiscal year starting on July 1, 1942, industry got the most accurate forecast of what it might expect in the new year.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Jan. 2 -- Coincident with Russian declarations that the Red Army was pursuing an enemy "at the end of his resistance," it was reported from Stockholm late yesterday that Reichsfuehrer Hitler had left Berchtesgaden for the Eastern Front to take personal charge of the German operations.

A "fair price" or anti-profiteering clause is a logical and necessary supplement to pending price-control legislation, according to Dr. Julius Hirsch, Price Control Administrator in Germany during the latter part of World War I and later State Secretary for Economics in the Weimar Republic.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The American flag flew over Westminster Abbey today alongside the British Union Jack as a brief service of intercession held to coincide with the general observance in the United States and throughout the British Empire of a day of prayer.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 -- Running the most remarkable race of the Florida season to date, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Total Eclipse stole the show at Tropical Park today when he came from far out of contention to win the Orange Bowl Handicap by a nose.

Four major problems are now facing the food industry -- the need to keep prices from spiraling out of control as in the last war, the necessity for maintaining food supplies adequate for war demands and the twofold task of educating the public to the evils of hoarding and the values of nutrition, according to Paul S. Willis, president Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America.

Gains in deposits and total assets are shown in the annual statements which New York banks have begun to issue for the final quarter of 1941, with large increases of holdings in United States Government securities.

Yarns available to the hosiery industry for manufacture of women's full-fashioned stockings will not be sufficient to permit a production approaching that of the last two years, according to Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

HONOLULU, Jan. 1 -- New Year's Day was memorial day in Honolulu. In beautiful Nuuanu Cemetery, situated in the hills overlooking the Honolulu harbor, citizens of the city, led by Mayor Lester Petrie and joined by three members of the Presidential Investigation Commission, held memorial services over the communal graves of more than 350 sailors who lost their lives at Pearl Harbor during the Japanese attack of Dec. 7.

The American steel industry produced 82,850,000 net tons of steel in 1941, eclipsing all former records by substantial margins. This output was 23.7 per cent over the 66,982,686 tons produced in 1940, the previous high mark; 31.1 per cent over the next best output of 63,205,490 tons, in 1929, and 63 per cent over the first World War peak of 50,467,880 tons, in 1917.
The order for enemy aliens to turn in firearms, radio transmitters, short-wave receiving sets and cameras to police stations resulted last night in scattered activity.

DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 1 -- Lon Stiner, a "rags-to-riches" coach who started his 1941 season by losing to Southern California and closed it by beating Duke in the Rose Bowl, thinks his Oregon State boys played "pretty good ball" today.
The first tie game of the local season in the National Hockey League competition was played at Madison Square Garden last night when the Rangers held Toronto to a 3-to-3 draw.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- With the cost of living already up 12 per cent since the beginning of the war in 1939, wholesale prices up about 25 per cent and basic raw materials up 58 per cent, effective action to prevent a serious and long-continued upswing of prices is imperative, according to Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration.

The toilet goods industry, as it faces the new year, believes it has a major role to perform in the maintenance of public morale, H.L. Brooks, president of the Toilet Goods Association, declared in a statement prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Dec. 5 -- As with other countries at war, New Zealand has been thrown on its own resources in many lines of production. This Dominion had specialized in producing farm products for export and had few manufacturing industries.

The new year's first dawn yesterday found little bands of enduring revelers dragging their tin horns, cowbells and hangovers through Times Square's otherwise deserted canyons under the droopy-lidded eyes of unhappy policemen.

A comprehensive program of social security revision intended to provide increased protection for men in the armed forces and their dependents and to reduce the impact of post-war unemployment has been drafted by sixty-eight of the nation's foremost experts on social insurance, it became known last night.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Search was pressed by air and ground parties today for a B-26 two-motored Army bomber which disappeared Tuesday evening from a flight of nine bombing planes approaching March Field in the vicinity of Cajon Pass.

The reports from Washington concerning the progress on the formation of a War Labor Board are not reassuring. We are told that it will be a board of twelve, composed of four representatives of unions, four of employers and four of the general public. One immediate question this raises is how a tie vote will be decided.

Only as to the certainty of a heavy government debt and difficult financial problems after the war was there agreement concerning the post-war outlook in statements prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by five leading economists.

Both Vichy France and Britain published budget figures on the last day of the year. In the first nine months of its current fiscal year, the British Treasury has spent almost $14,000,000,000, has had revenues of less than $5,000,000,000 and shows a deficit of $9,000,000,000.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- A year ago it was said in this review that United States policy, then slowly emerging from doubt and perplexity to a certainty of purpose and bold action, was bound to have a profound influence on Britain's position in 1941.

Merchants who are realistic about the problems of 1942 must recognize that virtually all lines of trade will be affected by the exigencies of war, according to Ward Melville, head of the Institute of Distribution and president of the Melville Shoe Corporation.

The Twelfth Regiment of the New York Guard, established on Dec. 11 to take the place of the 212th Coast Artillery Regiment of the National Guard, which had been inducted into the Army of the United States, is "almost full" now, but is still seeking men over 35 years old, it was announced here yesterday from the headquarters of the regiment in the armory at 120 West Sixty-second Street.

Restrictions upon consumer durable goods should redound to the advantage of "soft" lines, particularly apparel, in 1942, according to statements prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by officials of trade associations in the women's garment field, the largest single industry in this city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Time after time the forces under General Sir Claude Auchinleck, Commander in Chief of the British forces in the Middle East, have been trying to throw a net over the German-Italian mechanized columns in Libya.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 1 (U.P.) -- Petroleum experts here said today that Japanese occupation of British Sarawak would probably furnish the invaders with a small oil supply, but that it might take many months before Japan could utilize it, if ever. The British had reported a systematic destruction of the Sarawak fields ahead of the Japanese.

LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuter) -- Much depended on whether the Commando force could take the Germans by surprise. At least three days had to be spent at sea, although the hours of daylight would be shortened as we went farther north, until the sun no longer rose at all.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill paused in his work at midnight to toast the New Year with newspaper correspondents.

An abundant supply of top quality gladioluses and roses characterizes the flower market this weekend. Large stocks of these blooms had been laid in, in anticipation of continued holiday demands, authorities explained. Corsage flowers, such as camellias, orchids and gardenias, were also available in sufficient quantity, in demand for the social festivities attendant on the season.

HILLSIDE HEIGHTS, L.I., Jan. 1 -- Five Army airmen -- the entire crew of a Douglas medium type bomber -- were killed instantly this morning when the plane crashed into a sandpit here, caught fire and exploded.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Following is the text of the allied joint agreement as issued here today:...

In a world in which the decisions of a few men may determine the destiny of all mankind, a magnetic personality offers the most valuable type of leadership, Sir Charles Wilson, president of the Royal College of Physicians, told 1,000 physicians and surgeons at the Academy of Medicine, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, last night.

Total receipts of the Autonomous Institute for the Amortization of the Public Debt of the Republic of Chile in 1941 available for debt service amounted to $9,485,836, according to advices received here yesterday.

In an unprecedented decision, made public yesterday, the State Labor Relations Board held an American Federation of Labor union representing public school custodians guilty of violating the State abor Relations Act by refusing to bargain collectively with another A.F. of L. union representing 3,000 janitorial helpers in the city elementary and high schools.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies fighting forces issued the following communique:

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 -- The American pilot who was reported in Far Eastern dispatches Sunday as having shot down four Japanese planes in a Christmas Day battle at Rangoon was disclosed today to be 23-year-old Robert Smith of Hollywood.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr., who resigned as Markets Commissioner last Saturday in a row with Mayor La Guardia over the latter's dictation of appointments in his department, said yesterday that the Mayor was taking out his pique by ordering the dismissal of Antoinette Rounds as a department secretary and the demotion of Chief Inspector Patrick L. Sullivan.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 2 (AP) -Lem Franklin, stout-punching Ohio heavyweight, steps up as the No. 2 contender -- right behind Billy Conn -- for Joe Louis's title in the new quarterly ratings announced today by the National Boxing Association. Buddy Baer, who meets Louis Jan. 9, is the third heavyweight considered worthy of the rank of "logical contender."

War, which sends men back to eternal verities, will affect the child's make-believe world too. Robert H. McCready, publisher of Playthings, toy-makers' magazine, predicted yesterday that not only children's toys, but even Christmas trees will probably be simplified because of war priorities in 1942.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 2 -- A national program of curing alcoholics by creating a distaste for and an abhorrence of liquor was declared about 85 per cent successful in a report today dealing with original tests on 538 patients. When the treatment began a 64.3 per cent expectancy was given to these patients, based on a study of four years of total abstinence.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A British spokesman declared today that British and American fleets cannot be expected to operate effectively in the South Pacific until they can obtain adequate air support.

Few measures could bring home more quickly to large numbers of our people the seriousness of the struggle ahead than the new order of the Office of Production Management stopping all retail sales of automotive vehicles, as a preliminary to a ban on the future manufacture of these vehicles for ordinary civilian use.

G. Hilmer Lundbeck, general manager of the Swedish American Line in the United States, announced last night that the United States Government had bought the liner Kungsholm from the company and said he was leaving for Washington to arrange the final details.

SOME four years ago C. Hartley Grattan came back to New York after a long sojourn in Australia, whither he had gone on a Carnegie Fellowship grant with the firm ambition of becoming the James Bryce of the Antipodes. The business of being the Bryce of the Australian Commonwealth, however, did not promise any great monetary rewards in 1938.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The State Nurses Association went on record today as favoring a moratorium on the present Nurse Practice Act which would suspend until six months after the cessation of hostilities the act which went into effect yesterday and which requires that every nurse be registered. Thus far some 40,000 nurses have been registered.

Being somewhat imbued with the traditional chivalry of the State in which I live, I feel constrained in the name of honor to warn even a Yankee of his impending doom. If, therefore, the solemn citadel of the sports department soon finds itself on the short end of a rugged blitzkrieg, be advised of the reason thereof.
New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week consists of forty-eight items, aggregating $17,359,329, compared with $3,289,425 for this week.

The $500 bill that 13-year-old June Millard found on the floor in the Bloomingdale department store on June 27 is going to make a big change in the score of the defense stamp savings race between June and her brother Orson Jr., 12, the girl declared yesterday afternoon when she laid claim to her find at Police Headquarters at the expiration of the required six months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The first session of the Seventy-seventh Congress closed today in somber vein, yet with the determined attitude that reverses so far sustained by the United States will be surmounted. The closing in both branches was in sharp contrast to the ending of sessions in the past, which were gala occasions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The two great symbols of American development of the Philippine Islands, the city of Manila with its 600,000 population and Cavite naval base, passed today into Japanese hands as General Douglas MacArthur, commander of the United States armed forces in the Far East, tightened his lines for a final battle in the hills northwest of the city.

The Fidelity-Philadelphia Trust Company reported as of Dec. 31 total deposits of $147,831,129 and total assets of $167,990,001, compared, respectively, with $140,620,385 and $163,132,879 on Sept. 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $38,177,626, against $35,750,304; holdings of United States Government securities to $30,990,940, against $26,552,832, and loans and discounts to $38,235,965, against $38,831,714.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Representative Martin J. Kennedy, Democrat of Manhattan, renewed in the House today his appeal to President Roosevelt to remove Mayor La Guardia of New York as Director of Civilian Defense.

Last night a good time assuredly was had by all at the Studio Theatre of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman in West Sixteenth Street, not only because the first performance of Mr. Weidman's "Flickers" proved it to be a very funny piece of burlesque, but also because the program as a whole consisted of fine works spiritedly danced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Treasury revealed today that it spent $2,557,103,354 in December, the first month of the war. This was about $500,000,000 more than was spent in any month of the World War. At the same time President Roosevelt was finishing the greatest war budget in history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Manila has fallen. This may be a disappointing development for all Americans, but it is tragic heartbreak for the people of my country.

Frank C. Cole, 62 years old, of 277 Park Avenue, a member of the law firm of Dorsey, Cole Garner, was found in a critical condition last night as the result of a beating he had received in the washroom near his offices on the ninth floor of the Chrysler Building. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- The anti-Axis pact announced in Washington will become "a world charter of freedom" and it may be expanded to cover tile eight points of the original Anglo-American agreement drawn up at Prime Minister Churchill's first meeting with President Roosevelt last Summer, some commentators said today.

Fordham and Long Island University will endeavor tonight to stem the tide of adversity which has engulfed the local forces in intersectional basketball competition at Madison Square Garden, where their respective opponents in a double-header will be Rhode Island State and Creighton.
Hank Greenberg, the Detroit Tigers' $55,000-a-year outfielder, revealed yesterday that he has "re-enlisted" in the Army and that he is definitely through with baseball for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -Manila, for forty-three years a symbol of American democracy in the Far East, fell to the Japanese invader today. Thus a major American city fell to a foreign power for the first time since the British stormed and fired Washington in the War of 1812.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Tightening up the House price control measure to meet conditions of war and the danger of inflationary trends, the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency approved unanimously today a bill giving new and wider selective ceiling-fixing powers to a single administrator, presumably the incumbent, Leon Henderson.
MOSCOW, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Today's Soviet communique follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The pooling of all State-owned automobiles and trucks was ordered today by Governor Lehman. He issued a statement in which he asked citizens to make common use of their private cars and ordered all defense councils to lead in stimulating citizens to develop methods for accomplishing this purpose.

The order of the Office of Production Management freezing sales of new automobiles and trucks untiy Jan. 15 was weighed here yesterday by spokesmen for the automobile industry, who admitted that it had produced a "shock," although it had not been entirely a surprise.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Jan. 2 -- Hannes Schneider, noted ski instructor, took time from his varied activities today to discuss the progress made in the ski sport in this country. Founder of the Arlberg technique, the adopted system of the snow world, the 52-year-old transplanted Austrian looked back to three years ago when he established his school in this White Mountain region.

Contributions for the aid of New York's Neediest Cases continued to flow to the Fund yesterday from many persons who give year after year, from new friends and from children. Ninety-four contributors sent a total of $1,323, thereby increasing the amount thus far received in response to the thirtieth annual appeal to $255,306.74.

As the World War broadened to new latitudes and longitudes yesterday it became increasingly apparent that the course of the struggle -- and its duration -- would depend far more upon the action or lack of action of the democracies than upon the actions of the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Roosevelt urged employers today not to discharge workmen merely because they are aliens or even foreign-born citizens. To do this, the Executive asserted at a press conference, would be as "stupid as it is unjust," and would in the end merely play "into the hands of the enemies of American democracy."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2 -- The American Friends Service Committee announced today the outline of a plan whereby it would send conscientious objectors drafted for non-military service in this country to England to rebuild bomb-damaged homes and to construct shelters for evacuated families.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The statement of the Bank of England for Dec. 31 showed a note circulation of 751,726,000, compared with 615,855,000 the same date in the previous year. The increase was more than 135,000,000.

Nearly two-thirds of the population of the globe, more than two-thirds of its economic power and its actual or potential fighting power are committed by the Allied Joint Agreement, proclaimed yesterday in Washington, to the destruction of Adolf Hitler, his fighting forces, his friends and his satellites. There will be no sheathing of the sword, no separate armistice, no fragmentary peace, until this end has been accomplished.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 2 -General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, British commander in India and Burma and the first military leader to score a smashing success against the Axis, will head the land, sea and air forces in the Pacific, the Australian Associated Press said tonight.
A crisp command to salute rang out in the Twelfth Regiment Armory last night, and Private Sidney Antman's right hand moved uncertainly over his right eyebrow and cupped itself there.

Weekly statistics made available yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed that the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Reserve System in New York City had cut their holdings of United States Government bonds by $45,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the biggest cut in any week since early in June.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., Jan. 2 -- Gentlemen may prefer blondes, but the Army prefers brunettes -at least in chemical warfare. This was illustrated today when seventy-five women volunteers of the Nassau County chapter of the American Red Cross underwent tear-gas tests here as part of their instructions in the use of gas masks.

The change in the United States from a nation at peace to a nation at war on Dec. 7 and 8 had only a limited effect on the money market and on interest rates, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York asserts in its monthly review of credit and business conditions released yesterday.

Four union dock workers, two of them ex-convicts, were convicted yesterday in Special Sessions on a coercion charge growing out of the two-week strike last Fall of longshoremen and checkers on the British freighter Essex Lance at Jane Street and the North River.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- All twenty-six countries at war with one or more of the Axis powers have pledged themselves in a "Declaration by United Nations" not to make a separate armistice or peace and to employ full military or economic resources against the enemy each is fighting.
Berliner Co. and Herbert M. Dreyfus Co., member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, were dissolved on Dec. 31.
As a step toward collecting from the civilians of the nation 10,000,000 books for the use of the armed services, members of the Victory Book Campaign yesterday adopted the drive's official poster.

FORT DIX, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Thousands of men poured into Fort Dix today by bus and in private cars, returning from holiday furloughs unexpectedly canceled by an order from division headquarters last midnight.

The Winter's worst storm, a two-day disturbance which spread a snow blanket from Niagara Falls west through the Rockies, sent temperatures below zero and gave the Midwest its severest blizzard since 1938, was abating last night.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- Plant expansion in Massachusetts during 1941 has been of such proportions that this State is now prepared to produce defense goods in 1942 at a rate double or triple that which prevailed in the year just ended, it was declared today by the Associated Industries of Massachusetts.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Stock Exchange opened the new year with a much better tone than could have been expected, with business showing expansion in many directions. International shares were active, especially the Brazilian tractions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 2 -Drastic reprisals against loyal Norwegians were threatened today by Major Vidkun Quisling's press in connection with the British raids against the Norwegian islands of Vaagsoe and Maaloy and the latest raid against the Lofoten Islands.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Announcement that the Office of Price Administration had raised the ceiling on fats and oils to the Oct. 1 level and that the Senate committee had agreed on a 110 per cent of parity ceiling, or the Oct. 1 price, whichever is higher, dispelled much of the uncertainty which has handicapped trading in the grain markets recently, and prices advanced rapidly today, with soy beans in the lead.

The 20,614-ton passenger liner Argentina, owned by the Maritime Commission and operated under charter by Moore-McCormack Lines, was taken over yesterday by naval authorities on the eve of her scheduled departure for a foreign port.

MEMPHIS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Second Army's unique program for teaching America's soldiers what they are fighting for has attracted the interest of civilian leaders, who want to adopt it as a means of making the people at home understand and link together the military and political chain of world events.

There will be five closings on Broadway tonight, marking the season's highest number of casualties for a single week. Of the group, only one attraction, "Panama Hattie," is announced to tour, opening in Baltimore on Jan. 5. The B.G. DeSylva musical has registered a total of 498 performances.

The setback suffered by the Philippine defenders in the fall of Manila and Cavite failed yesterday to undermine the stock market, and, as if to reassert faith in the eventual victory for the Allied cause, prices climbed 1 to 3 points in the final hour, making the upturn without trouble.

The expected post-holiday recruiting rush developed here yesterday as hundreds of young men walked into Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard recruiting stations to start the new year off in a fighting service.

HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- The Urgency Court has declared the case against Marcos Sinai, former president of the Banco Popular, nolle prossed because the State's Attorney, Dr. Francisco Guiral, withdrew from the case on the grounds of lack of evidence to support the accusation of the police that Senor Sinai was involved "in an attempt against the stability of the republic."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The rationing of automobile tires was, of course, necessary and inevitable, but has not Mr. Henderson been somewhat impulsive in his classification of vehicles eligible for new rubber? For over a decade the economy of America has grown more dependent on the motor car; the sudden shock caused by unsound restrictions in rubber allotments may seriously injure rather than aid our all-out war effort.

The board of directors of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, representing approximately half of the 60,000 dairy farmers in the New York City milkshed, yesterday pledged "full support" to Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard's war production program.

Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran, making public yesterday a statistical report on traffic violations handled in the city's six traffic courts during 1941, revealed that the courts disposed of 749,859 cases, an increase of 70,833 over the previous year, and collected $1,607,902 in fines from violators, an increase of $187,366 over 1940.

Bank clearings in the principal cities of the country for the five-day week ended on Wednesday rose 20.9 per cent compared with the similar short week in 1940, but declined 11.4 per cent from the preceding week of six days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Roosevelt emphasized expanding United States armaments production at his press conference today and expressed the opinion that retooling of automobile plants for airplane, tank and weapon production would take an average of only two months a plant.

Long convinced that "a pint of milk daily for adults" is an unheeded admonition, this column decided to do some impromptu -- if not scientific -- research on its own. Accordingly, the first three persons encountered were questioned. Two of those interrogated reported that they drink a glass of milk a day.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- The spokesman of the National Military Council said today that only the Japanese drive against Changsha was a major attack of the dozen pushes intended to divert the Chinese from aiding the Allies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The historic "declaration by united nations" is a four-page type written and penned document on gold-edged white paper.

Exporters are refusing to accept orders from confirming houses or freight forwarders which hold off payment on invoices until shipment can be arranged for on steamer, it was learned yesterday. The Motor and Equipment Manufacturers Association, whose members have been experiencing difficulties in this connection, has announced that orders "will not be accepted" under such circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Passenger car production in the United States will halt "for the duration" probably on Jan. 31, after about 200,000 cars for which parts have already been manufactured are assembled. In announcing this today, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator and head of the Office of Civilian Supply, said that the action was necessary so that the entire manufacturing facilities of the automobile industry could be brought into the national armaments program.
HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- Details of war taxes imposed under the special powers granted by Congress were made public today.

More than 1,000 speakers, representing every profession, craft and racial group in Greater New York, are now available to give addresses on any phase of civilian defense, the New Fork Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, 93 Park Avenue, announced yesterday.

CAMP UPTON, L.I., Jan. 2 -- In a move designed by the War Department to speed up the recruiting of pilots for the Army Air Corps, an aviation cadet examining board was set up today. The purpose is to enlist air cadets from Camp Upton's enlisted personnel and from civilian ranks in Suffolk County for immediate transfer to air corps training centers.

In the interests of national defense, Government has asked industry to enter into various agreements with respect to prices and production which in ordinary times might have a very dubious standing before the anti-trust laws. But while this is going on in one section of Government, new moves to extend the scope of anti-trust action appear in others.
LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Admiralty announced today that the British cruiser Neptune had been sunk by a mine in the Mediterranean.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 1 (Delayed) -- Soviet sources sought today to take the sting from the Pravda editorial that called the United States a coward for declaring Manila an "open city" and not defending each street and building to the end.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 2 -- United States warships and planes already are helping the small but modern Netherland fleet to defend the Netherlands Indies, Batavia disclosed today in a communique reporting Japanese attacks on one United States warship and two planes.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 2 -- Throttling any hope the Germans and Italians might have cherished of creating an Axis version of Tobruk at Bardia, South African troops, supported by British tanks, artillery and planes, this morning smashed the last Nazi strong point in the perimeter and captured the town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Italy's poverty in raw materials has been intensified by the war, the Commerce Department reported today. Since the outbreak of the war, the report said, Italy has been almost entirely dependent on raw materials from continental Europe.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2 -Mr. and Mrs. John Moffat gave a dinner tonight at the Chambord, having as guests Prince and Princess Alexis Zalstem-Zalessky and Lady Pasco-Rutter, who arrived today from Nassau to visit them; Prince and Princess Alexis Obolensky Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Charles Grey, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Timbal and Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ladd.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The loss of Manila today left General Douglas MacArthur's unified remaining forces within a great arc north and northwest of the city with Manila Bay, the South China Sea and the fixed fortifications at the entrance of the bay to their rear.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 -- Happy in victory and glad its all over, Fordham's football players, conquerors of Missouri in yesterday's Sugar Bowl game, today broke a long training siege.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 -- With the Sugar Bowl game out of the way, members of the New Orleans Midwinter Sports Committee today devoted their attention to the East-West game, which will be played in Tulane's stadium tomorrow before a crowd estimated at 40,000 to 45,000.

Alexander Sved hang Iago for the first time here in last night's performance of Verdi's "Otello" at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Sved replaced Lawrence Tibbett, originally announced, who was unable to appear because of his recent emergency operation.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2 -- Eight hundred prominent American educators, opening a precedent-breaking three-day conclave here today to formulate a unified program for education in wartime, offered to place the vast resources of the colleges and universities of this country at the disposal of the Federal Government.
The Stock Exchange on Monday will admit to the list and to dealings Decca Records, Inc., capital stock, $1 par value.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of government securities for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year.

In response to a suggestion of Ambassador Winant, a short history of the United States is available for the first time in the secondary schools of Great Britain. This introduction to American history for British students is written by Professor Allan Nevins of Columbia, whose knowledge of the historic backgrounds of both countries is sufficient guarantee that the text possesses the balance and perspective so often lacking in the one-sided school compendium.

TOKYO, Jan. 2 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in the United States) -- Philippine defenders under General Douglas MacArthur were reported officially tonight to have withdrawn to the island fortress of Corregidor and the mountains of Bataan peninsula for a "last stand" after the fall of Manila.

ABOARD FLAGSHIP QUEEN ELIZABETH, of the British Mediterranean Fleet, at Alexandria, Egypt, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A British destroyer squadron sank three Axis submarines -- two German and one Italian -- and was joined by other large units of the imperial fleet in a smashing bombardment of Halfaya Pass and Bardia, helping pave the way for the final capture today of Bardia.

A church service "from the people of the United States to the people of England," will be held at 2 P.M. tomorrow in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. It will be broadcast over the entire network of the British Broadcasting Company, it was announced yesterday.

Gifts of $50,000 from the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and $12,500 from Bourjois, Inc., headed the list of additional unsolicited contributions made yesterday to the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, which plans to raise $7,330,000 here toward the national goal of $50,000,000.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Jan. 3 -- Announcing to the prospective victims, reported surrounded in a vast pocket on the central Mozhaisk front, that they had until 2 o'clock this afternoon to surrender "or take the consequences," medium wavelength low-power transmitters in the Moscow region have been calling on an estimated 150,000 German troops in that area to lay down their arms since 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, it was learned here late last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A contract with Savannah Shipyards, Inc., for the construction of twelve emergency cargo vessels has been canceled by the United States Maritime Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Although the "Declaration by United Nations" is merely that and not a treaty, the arrangement goes much further than putting in writing an existing informal understanding of the signatories. The "no separate peace" pledge was considered in diplomatic quarters as strengthening the Allied cause at a time of military setbacks in the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -Scoring two goals in the final period, the second-place New York Rovers came within a point of the Eastern amateur hockey leaders, the Johnstown Bluebirds, by defeating the Washington Eagles, 3 -- 2, tonight.
Recent surveys indicate that men's wages are not keeping pace with the rising cost of living and that wages for women in industry are showing an even slower rate of increase.

FORT RILEY, Kan., Jan. 2 -New classes will begin at Fort Riley Cavalry School on Monday. A third officer candidate course will have 200 students, twice as many as heretofore. Three courses for officers will have 160 enrolled. All classes are for three months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -Selective Service officials said today that only part of the unregistered men between the ages 18 and 64, inclusive, would be registered at any one time, to avoid undue disturbance of the war effort.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 2 -Horses owned by women won the first four places in the Lake Wales Purse at Tropics Park today, with Mrs. A. Torriente's Aerial Bomb proving the fleetest with a time of 1:11 flat in the six-furlong dash.

Encouraged by developments in price control in Washington, trade buying, price-fixing orders by mill interests and covering operations lifted quotations on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday as much as 49 points, or $2.45 a bale, above Wednesday's close.

DOVER, N.J., Jan. 2 -- The sale of the Scrub Oak Mine, New Jersey's largest iron mine, and of the Oxford Mine for a reported price of more than $1,000,000 to the Alan Wood Steel Company by the Warren Foundry and Pipe Corporation of Phillipsburg was announced here today.

ST. PIERRE-MIQUELON, Jan. 2 -- To give them the opportunity to start the New Year off right, Vice Admiral Emile Muselier, head of the Free French forces here, released today all the prisoners he had been holding except former Governor Baron de Bournat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Immediate strengthening of the strategic Aleutian Islands, potential Pacific ramparts for the rich territory of Alaska, and concentration in the area of "planes, more planes -- lots of planes" was urged today by Alaska's delegate to Congress, Anthony J. Dimond.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Jan. 2 -Brig. Gen. Edwin P. Parker Jr., commanding the field artillery replacement center here, announced this afternoon that his organization would provide special training for new artillery officers in addition to its regular work.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, who succeeded Thomas J. Dewey on Thursday, announced yesterday several promotions because of staff resignations. He will fill the vacancies next week.
The St. John's University basketball team had too much speed and court knowledge for the University of Maryland quintet last night as it swept to a 64-48 victory in the De Gray gymnasium in Brooklyn.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- A supplemental Russian communique issued here tonight said more than 15,000 Germans had been killed between Dec. 26 and 31. In "notable" booty taken the communique listed sixty tanks, 287 guns and more than 6,000,000 rounds of ammunition.

The mighty Chicago Bears, football champions of the world, gave a bizarre touch yesterday to their preparations for tomorrow's charity game with the National Football League All-Stars at the Polo Grounds by practicing on -- of all places -- Eighth Avenue.

Streaks of fresh gray paint spread quickly over the rusted, dirty colors on the sides of the long-idle Normandie here yesterday as several thousand workmen, stripping the luxurious 'Masterpiece of France Afloat" of her peacetime glory, speedily prepared her for war service as the United States naval auxiliary Lafayette.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Several hundred Filipinos residing in this country may now enlist in the United States Army, President Roosevelt today informed J.M. Elizalde, resident Philippine Commissioner in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Acting to check any inflationary price movement that may develop in the floor covering markets, which open Monday, Leon Henderson, Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, today put a sixty-day emergency ceiling over prices that wholesalers, jobbers, agents, brokers or importers may charge for rugs and carpets.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- A new schedule of commissions, providing an upward revision of the rates adopted on Aug. 11, was put into effect today on the San Francisco Stock Exchange. Except for a minimum charge, no change was made in the low-price shares, but the rates in the higher brackets are slightly above those existing before Aug. 11.

A new field of research which opens the most encouraging approach science has had for the conquest of typhus fever, dreaded war disease that cost millions of lives during the first World War, was announced yesterday at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

The Catholic Church in the United States has no need to alter its system of education to meet the war crisis, since its educators have always been "outstanding in their loyalty to American ideals," and needed "no such crisis as the present war to shock them into patriotism," the Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of New York, declared yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 2 -- Apparently fearing the possibility of a sweeping Russian counter-offensive, the Germans are reliably reported to be building three lines of defense, two in Poland and the third, designed to protect Germany, along the old German-Polish frontier. The first of these lines is being built along the Polish-Russian frontier. Here the Germans are hastily rebuilding the Russian fortifications which the foreign press has called the "Stalin line."

Police Commissioner Valentine told reporters yesterday that a large number of policemen, hitherto assigned to other municipal departments, have been recalled to the Police Department to strengthen the city's defense program. He said they went back to regular police duty at midnight Wednesday, but did not reveal the number involved.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Britain's jungle-tested defenders of Malaya were engaged in battle with newly landed contingents of Japanese invaders nearly 300 miles above Singapore tonight, and latest reports stated that the fighting was becoming increasingly heavy.

VICHY, France, Jan. 2 -- While newspapers in the unoccupied zone of France displayed today Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's New Year message the Paris press has not yet printed it. The message was addressed to the whole nation.

Spring lines of women's hosiery began to appear yesterday, with several manufacturers announcing styles and prices, and the remaining companies were expected to make their announcements next week All-silk numbers were virtually absent from the lines listed yesterday, and there were only a few lines which included silk in combination with other fibers.

Because the annual Universal Week of Prayer will begin tomorrow pastors will preach sermons in which they will ask their parishioners to pray through not only the first week of the new year but every day for this country's successful part in the war and for a righteous victory before 1943.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 2 -- Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, long the antireligious polemist of modern Germany and the protagonist of the "new national church," has just released for publication a thirty-point program that will form at the same time the program and tenets of the "religion of National Socialism."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Winston Churchill's magnificent address before the Canadian Parliament contained for the first time a direct reference to Joseph Stalin. Stalin's brilliant and determined leadership accounts, of course, in no small degree for the turn of the tide on the Eastern Front which will go down in history as the "miracle of Moscow."
Mrs. Charles Duncan Miller gave a dinner last night for her debutante daughter, Miss Evelyn Miller, in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center. The guest of honor wore a flame taffeta gown.

The loss of Manila was clearly foreshadowed on Dec. 26, when General Douglas MacArthur declared it an open city. None the less, with the Japanese entrance into the city and the retirement of the American-Filipino forces to a precarious defense line, this country now drinks the unaccustomed and bitter draught of defeat in battle.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- British officials and diplomatic circles here took the view today that the speech of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain last night showed chiefly the impotence as an independent government of the Vichy French regime of which he is Chief of State.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 2 -Tomorrow, the eighteenth anniversary of the end of the constitutional regime in Italy and the birth of the "new order" when Premier Mussolini, in his own words, "broke once and for all time all opposition to Italian progress," the Premier will address the National Directorate of the Fascist party at a meeting in the Palazzo Venezia.

Despite the increased area thrown open to New York State deer hunters this season, the total kill was 351 under that of last year. Considering the lack of good hunting conditions throughout the State, however, it was surprising that the decrease was not larger.

Advertising linage of eight New York newspapers sustained a fractional loss in December, chiefly because there were only four Sundays last month as against five in the corresponding 1940 period, according to compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Jan. 11 has been designated as Red Cross Sunday, Norman H. Davis, chairman of the American Red Cross, announced today following consultation with leaders of the various relief agencies.

The lack of success our local basketball representatives experienced in their holiday games against teams from other sections in Madison Square Garden should provide some excellent food for thought for the coaches of the metropolitan squads.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System made a small post-Christmas gain in the final week in December, according to figures disclosed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, but the rise was very small compared with that one year ago.

Dr. Leon Pratt Alford, widely known as an industrial engineering expert and author, died at 7 o'clock yesterday morning at the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals of a heart ailment. Dr. Alford had been ill for the last year and was taken to the hospital Wednesday morning.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Yugoslav Legation here made public today a document prepared by the Archbishop of the Serbian Orthodox Church that said more than 180,000 persons were slaughtered in the Nazi puppet state of Croatia up to the early part of August.

In an endeavor to widen the facilities for finding trained domestic help in all sections of the metropolitan area, the New York State Employment Service, an affiliate of the State Department of Labor, has recently opened ten new offices in four boroughs of New York, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Am extra day of heavy Christmas shopping this year was reflected in an increase of 39 per cent in department store sales during the week ended Dec. 27, compared with the corresponding week of 1940, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

A net income of $338,818 was reported yesterday by the Patterson-Sargent Company, manufacturer of paints, enamels and varnishes, for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last. After allowing for dividend requirements on the preferred stock the income is equal to $1.63 a share on 200,000 common shares, and compares with $191,401 or 90 cents a common share earned in the preceding fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Taxicabs are not conveyances which can qualify as public necessities and therefore have been ruled off the "eligible list" of vehicles entitled to new tires, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, revealed today.

In her new book, "The Road to Disappearance," Angle Debo, who has specialized in the history of the five civilized tribes of Indians, tells the story of one of America's minority peoples -- the Creek Indians. The University of Oklahoma Press has published her study.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 2 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, fully equipped with modern arms, have marched into Burma and placed themselves under British command to fight the Japanese, the spokesman of the National Military Council announced today.
FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., Jan. 2 -- With a cast of thirty-nine, including twenty-four girls, "Follow the Crowd," a musical variety show, was staged twice tonight.

Judge Mortimer W. Byers, in Federal Court in Brooklyn, imposed yesterday prison sentences aggregating 310 years and nine months on thirty-three defendants convicted of violation of the Espionage Act. Fourteen of the persons sentenced were found guilty by a jury on Dec. 12, on an indictment containing two counts, one of furnishing defense information of this country to Germany and the other with failing to register as agents of a foreign government.

As holiday, week-end travelers and thousands of students returning to colleges taxed transportation facilities here to the utmost yesterday, a nation-wide survey by The Associated Press revealed that at least 265 persons lost their lives over the New Year's holiday in traffic accidents, drownings, falls, shootings and by other violent means.

The members of Borough President James A. Burke's cabinet in Queens are to have a starting time but no quitting time because of the "emergency," they were informed by the new borough head at a conference in the Borough Hall yesterday.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- An accelerated program of nurse-training and expanded activities of school nurse-teachers were announced today by the Education Department to meet "an acute shortage of trained nurses" and assist defense activities in New York State.
GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Jan. 2 -- The Ministry of Government has ordered Walter Guisse, a German, to proceed to the interior town of Guaranda for interment or to leave Ecuador.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 2 -- The German Ambassador, Baron Edmund von Thermann, this morning officially informed Foreign Minister Enrique de Ruiz-Guinazu that his government had recalled him to Berlin "to report." This step came more than three and one-half months after the Chamber of Deputies had passed a vote of censure against the envoy and implicitly demanded his expulsion.

The height of quality would be if one of the world's ten best-dressed women, escorted by one of the nation's top-ten tennis players, bought tickets for one of the ten best motion pictures of the year featuring the star who has just been selected as the best screen actor of the year.
DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 2 -- Wallace Wade looked back on the two straight setbacks for his Duke football teams in Rose Bowl games, each by 4 points, and admitted today his "Rose Bowl luck is running out."

Manila, capital of the Philippines, is also the largest city of the archipelago and its principal port. Through it have passed annually millions of tons of the islands' principal exports -- rice, hemp, sugar, lumber and tobacco.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Dollar sales of all retail stores in November are estimated at $4,502,000,000, 3 per cent below October and 11 per cent above November, 1940, the Commerce Department reported today. Adjusted for the number of working days, however, November sales were 5 per cent above October and 13 per cent above November last year.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Frank Frisch said today that "baseball can take it" when war starts dealing 'em off the bottom of the deck.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 2 -- Brigadier A.H. Gatehouse, commander of the British Fourth Armored Brigade, which so ably used United States light tanks during the British offensive in Libya, has long been a strong supporter of American tanks, but now with the first phase of the campaign completed he cannot say enough in praise of them.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- The elation of the City Manager League here last November when three of its "reform" candidates were elected to the five-man City Council was dimmed today when Dr. Benjamin F. Barnes, one of the league-supported Councilmen, decided to collaborate with the two Democratic-endorsed Councilmen in retaining City Manager Raymond J. Whitney in office.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Prices of hogs advanced 15 to 25 cents a hundred weight today as the price ceiling on lard was revised upward and the Surplus Marketing Administration announced heavy purchases of lard and pork products. Best hogs rose to $11.50. The new ceiling on lard was placed at approximately $1.30 a hundred pounds above the previously prevailing top.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- War Department communique No. 41, based on communications received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- It was believed in diplomatic quarters tonight that Russia insisted on the escape clause in the "Declaration by United Nations" which pledges the signatory powers to use their resources against the Axis nations with which their governments are "at war."

No one can accuse Arnold Sundgaard of having written another living-room, divan and bookcase number. In "The First Crocus," which was acted at the Longacre last evening, he is writing about a warm-hearted and hot-tempered Norwegian family in Albion, Minn. The family is bossed by an over-bearing mother who is acted by Martha Hedman, who in turn has not appeared on Broadway for almost twenty years.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 2 -In a dazzling display of college hockey, the Crimson ice men of Harvard tonight evened the series being played at this resort as part of College Week activities by defeating Princeton, 2 -- 1. The Tigers won the first contest last night, 6 -- 2.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- As the Pacific Coast reacted calmly to Admiral Nimitz's observations in Honolulu, citing the possibility of an occasional shelling by Japanese submarines, cities and towns of California made formal requests to the Legislature today for about $50,000,000 of State aid to meet civilian defense requirements.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 -- Ginger Rogers's next picture for RKO will be "Behold the Bridegroom," George Kelly's Broadway success of the 1927-28 season, which the studio purchased some years ago, it was learned today. Judith Anderson, Thurston Hall and Mary Servoss were seen in the stage play.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday sent formal notification to Rear Admiral Adolphus Andrews, Commandant of the Third Naval District, and Major General Irving J. Phillipson, commanding the Second Army Corps Area, of its readiness to cooperate fully in the conduct of any sports activities under its jurisdiction for the entertainment of service men.
A loan exhibition of paintings by Van Gogh for the benefit of the American Red Cross will be held at the galleries of Paul Rosenberg Co., 16 East Fifty-seventh Street, beginning on Monday.

CAMP CROFT, S.C., Jan. 2 -Elaborate preparations for a gay holiday in celebration of the arrival of 1942 were upset this week at this infantry center when orders came from headquarters of the Fourth Corps Area in Atlanta converting New Year's Day into a full work day for the garrison.

Twenty-two district tire rationing boards were appointed yesterday and provided with instructions for the issuance of permits authorizing truck and car owners to buy new tires and tubes. The district boards were chosen by Harold W. McGraw, New York City Tire Rationing Administrator and his borough deputy administrators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- News of the Japanese entry into Manila naturally brought discussion here today of trade relations between the United States and the Philippines, a relation so intimate that 94 per cent of the total island exports last October came to this country while for the first nine months of 1941 80 per cent of imports into the Philippines originated here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Kearny, N.J., yard of Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company, commandeered by the Navy on Aug. 23 because the company refused to accept a "union maintenance of membership clause" recommended by the National Defense Mediation Board, probably will be returned within a week to its owner, the United States Steel Corporation, it became known in official quarters today.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Fifteen thousand Japanese soldiers were killed or wounded yesterday morning in a terrific Chinese counter-attack in the outskirts of Changsha, a special Chinese communique said today.

School children in New York City were determined to uphold tradition yesterday. Although the Board of Education broke a precedent by opening the public schools, which in the past were customarily closed on Friday when New Year's Day was observed on Thursday, many of the city's boys and girls took an extra day's freedom from books and lessons.

The battered wallet containing two $10 bills which 11-year-old Michael McCabe found Thursday on the car track at Flatbush Avenue and Bergen Street, Brooklyn, was identified and claimed at the Bergen Street police station yesterday by Thomas Fleming, 22, a clerk of 479 Dean Street, Brooklyn.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 2 -Buddy Baer, who will get his second chance at the world heavyweight title in a fifteen-round bout against champion Joe Louis next Friday night in Madison Square Garden, is in A-1 condition.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 2 -- In the one-week period ending Dec. 24, a survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion found colds reported in one-third of American homes, with an estimated total of 18,000,000 persons afflicted.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2 -- Speaking at the Conference on Spiritual Inter-Americanism at Barry College for Women today, Dr. John C. Hayes, Assistant Professor of Law at Loyola University, said in relation to his topic, "Social Legislation in South America," that there had existed there since 1900 a number of enlightened laws designed for the protection of native workers.

Steps toward coordination of campaigns to raise funds for Allied war relief are under discussion by leaders of the British War Relief Society, the Russian War Relief and the United China Relief, Edward C. Carter, chairman of Russian War Relief, disclosed yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor, at which the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, C.I.O., gave $15,000 to the American Red Cross and overseas relief agencies.

CAMP WHEELER, Ga., Jan. 2 -Many families from New York City and the metropolitan area were among visitors from all parts of the country who came to spend New Year's Eve with Camp Wheeler trainees, at the post service club and all available entertainment places in near-by Macon.

New bond financing continued in light volume in the second holiday period with $4,819,000 in new issues placed on the market this week, compared with $7,833,000 last week. In this period a year ago $30,528,250 in new bonds was offered to the public.

Retail trade here continued active last week, with promotions of fur and cloth coats getting off to a good start. The gains over a year ago were not as marked as in the preceding Christmas week, but some establishments here had estimated increases ranging around 20 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 2 -The Schwarze Korps, organ of the Nazi Elite Guard, has an article in its last issue regarding the sufferings in operations on the Eastern Front that appears to be directed more at accentuating the unrest at home than calming it.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command issued this communique today:

Recently the newspapers reported the case of a Western college football player whose parents tried to have him exempted from service in the Army because he was getting his education by an athletic scholarship. If he were drafted he would lose the opportunity to finish college, they said.

Record gains in all forms of group insurance last year, increasing the volume of protection in force in American industry to a new high mark of $18,500,000,000, were announced yesterday by Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Two of baseball's most prominent families were united today by the marriage of Eddie Collins Jr., 24, son of the former famed second baseman, and Jane Pennock, 22, daughter of Herb Pennock, once one of the game's greatest southpaw pitchers.

Thus in Washington last week the anti-aggressor bloc of twenty-six nations vowed to fight together in World War II until victory is achieved. In a historic declaration they affirmed their conviction that complete defeat of the enemy was "essential to defend life, liberty, independence and religious freedom."

ATLANTA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Former Governor E.D. Rivers and nineteen others, including a former national chief of the Ku Klux Klan, were indicted today on felony counts resulting from prolonged investigation of his four-year administration.

THE American motorist, long the envy of the entire world, is about to learn how the other half lives. The days of carefree motoring ended with 1941 and the Axis attack on us, and the motorist is keenly aware that 1942 will be the leanest period he has ever known.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- The yachts Ronaele, owned by Mrs. Eleanor Wiedener Dixon of Elkins Park, and Scout, owned by Hugh L. Adams of Haverford, were acquired by the Maritime Commission for use by the Navy in ceremonies today at the Corinthian Yacht Club in Essington.

Through the efforts of the Metropolitan Opera Guild in the last two years the radio audience that follows the Saturday afternoon performances at the Metropolitan has been augmented by several thousand music lovers organized into listening groups.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Clare S. McArdle, 45 years old, vice president and sales manager of the Missouri Portland Cement Company of St. Louis, and Mrs. Nancy La Motte Wassman, 38, a Chicago beauty parlor operator, were found dead early today in a private dining room of L'Aiglon Restaurant some hours after they had ordered a champagne and pheasant dinner.

The chief character in this story is Miss Ann Thorne, a spinster who lives in a small New England town. Her nearest neighbor is Anthony Bayne, a novelist of no great distinction and no moral character worth mentioning.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- General Manager Charles H. Strub of Santa Anita sounded a note of undisguised optimism today when he told horsemen that racing might get the go-ahead signal from Army authorities in the near future.

THE "Selected Poems" of John Peale Bishop is one of the really good books of contemporary American verse. It has unusual variety and versatility, it is virtuoso in the way that it uses almost every style and form that has been invented, and still it is perfectly self-sufficient.

The morale division of the Army has formulated a plan which, if approved by the High Command, will give American soldiers a thorough educational course in the background of the war, especially why they are fighting and what they are fighting for.

To help this country's war effort, the Municipal Art Society, which has watched over esthetic matters of public interest in the city for many years, is now turning its attention to local problems that the war may make acute.

ALESS modest man than Sterling Fisher, Columbia's director of education, could boast that he is the world's most influential schoolmaster. For Columbia's "School of the Air of the Americas," which he supervises and which is heard here on WABC, is tuned in by more than ten million school children in every part of the Western Hemisphere.

A breakdown of the nation's income during a typical pre-war year in the Thirties has revealed that 27 per cent was spent on food, 15 per cent on housing and 8 per cent on automobiles. Only 1 per cent -- $590,814,112 -- went into the nation's military establishments.

Reports from Washington indicate that in addition to the three and one-half billion dollars added by the 1941 tax act for a full year's operation, the House Ways and Means Committee is considering a further tax increase of between five and six and one-half billion.

When things looked black for the Dramatic Company of the Rockies, as they frequently did in the Summer of 1865, the whole family from Grand Patrick down to 12-year-old Hittybelle began to talk of the chicken farm they would soon buy and settle down on.

Letter writing has been one of the dormant arts for a long time. But who knows but that it may be coming back in a big way? In wartime, certainly, it's one's impulse to write good substantial letters to far-away friends and boys in the Army by way of bolstering up one's own morale as well as other people's.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Withstanding a strong Princeton rally in the second half, Syracuse University quintet defeated the Tigers tonight, 38 to 32, in the annual game between the two rivals.
SOME children help around the house; others don't; and parents have various ideas about their helping.

The new nine-story brick Archbishop Spellman Pavilion of St. Vincent's Hospital at 143-47 West Eleventh Street will be dedicated this afternoon by the man for whom it is named, the Most Rev. Francis J. Spellman, Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The problem of more than doubling the present war production rate in the quickest possible time is being approached along four lines, William S. Knudsen, director general of the Office of Production Management, and Sidney Hillman, associate director general, stated today.

Those dreadnaughts of the professional football ranks -- the Chicago Bears and the National League All-Stars -- have cleared the decks for their all-out gridiron battle at the Polo Grounds this afternoon that will enrich the treasury of the Navy Relief Society.

The Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation of the Department of Commerce has issued, for the benefit of ship and boat owners, a miscellaneous set of proposed amendments to the general rules and regulations covering ship operation.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 3 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The appointment of Hubertus J. van Mook as Lieutenant Governor-General and his decision to remain in the Indies have been pointedly commented upon by the press in view of the key position that the islands are believed to be assuming in the war.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Aggressive buying of wheat futures by mills came into the market on the Board of Trade late in the session today and advanced prices more than 1 cent a bushel to the highest level since October and to within about 2 cents of the best prices of the season.

Men's clothing manufacturers have completely suspended all plans for Fall operations as a result of the OPM order curtailing the use of wool for civilian purposes, they reported here yesterday. Cloth mills are refusing to quote on Fall fabrics which, while not officially open, have been available for large contracts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, has authorized chiefs of supply arms and services to make advance payments up to 50 per cent on contracts under $5,000,000 to speed production through decentralization of Army procurement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 -- A cold wave which struck the entire Pacific Coast kept smudge pots burning today in the citrus groves of Southern California and, more than a thousand miles to the north, caused the Weather Bureau to warn Eastern Oregon and Idaho stockmen to take added precautions for the care of their cattle and sheep.

SULFA FOR WOUNDS -- Wounds are now sprinkled with sulfanilamide to bring about rapid healing. But it is much better to apply a sulfanilamide and allantoin ointment after the third or fourth day, Drs. Roy G. Kelpser and J. Ross Veal of Gallinger Municipal Hospital, Washington, told the Society of American Bacteriologists last week.
