WEST ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Dick Van Winkle of Paterson, a student at Montclair Academy, was the outstanding winner in the eleventh annual midwinter horse show today at the Montclair Riding Club.

The announcement made at the White House yesterday that General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, assisted by high ranking officers of our own Army and Navy, will have command of all forces operating against Japan in the Southwest Pacific area is news of great importance. General Wavell has demonstrated his ability and his qualities of leadership.

The launching at Chester, Pa., last week of the new 8,000-ton cargo ship Sea Serpent marked the conclusion of a wartime building program by the United States Lines that has seen ten vessels go down the ways in yards on the Pacific and Atlantic coasts.

THE clues to the motivation of Dr. Erich Fromm's "Escape from Freedom" may be found in three quotations which he uses to indicate the mental climate in which he writes. The first is a Talmudic saying; the second, from Pico della Mirandola, and the third, from Thomas Jefferson.

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, wife of the late President, and Mrs. Clark H. Minor, as co-chairman of patronesses, are receiving the cooperation of a large group of women in plans for the First Reserve Aero Squadron dinner dance, to be given next Saturday in the Embassy Suite and Garden of the Ambassador as a benefit for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (Reuter) -- An abundance of goals with Sale, Stoke City center forward, claiming individual honors with six, featured the first full New Year's soccer program in England today. Attendance aggregated 120,000 for thirty-three matches, the Newcastle-Gateshead game drawing 20,000.

His card reads: A. Hicks, M.S. O.T.P.B.O.M. If you know what these letters mean you've been peeking. In any event, you will understand why his friends call him Alphabet Hicks. When we first meet Hicks he is driving a taxi, and his passenger is Judith Dundee, wife of R.I. Dundee, manufacturer of plastics.

THE eighteenth annual series of auditions for pianists, violinists, 'cellists and singers "who are of mature talent and ready for professional careers, but who have not already had a New York recital reviewed by critics" will begin shortly under the auspices of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation.
LONDON, Jan. 3 (Reuter) -- Field Marshal Sir John Dill, who has just relinquished the post of Chief of the Imperial General Staff, has sent a "Victory is assured" farewell message to the army.

HAVANA -- While the entrance of the United States and Cuba into the war may greatly reduce tourist travel in the Caribbean area, Cuba, located only ninety miles from American shores, expects many visitors during the next few months.

The Giants, who already have remodeled themselves to the extent of installing Mel Ott as manager and revitalizing their front line by such notable additions as Johnny Mize and Bill Werber, gave further indication yesterday, with the announcement of their 1942 Spring training plans, that they mean to make an all-out effort to lift themselves into the National League's first division next Summer.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 3 -- The dismissal of General Field Marshal Walther von Brauchitsch and the assumption by Reichsfuehrer Hitler himself of the direct command over the German Army has provoked a great deal of speculation as to the actual role of Herr Hitler in the leadership of the war and also regarding the personalities of his direct advisers.

COPS feel sorry for illegal parkers. Tomorrow the city will open what promises to be its most determined attack in recent years to solve the parking problem. Planned to force unoccupied cars off the streets and thus end day and night "open-air storage" abuses, it is primarily a war measure to keep streets unobstructed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- An assertion that powerful private groups hampered the first ten months of the national defense effort through their fears that production expansion would endanger their future control of industry was made today by Thurman Arnold, assistant attorney general, in the annual report of the Attorney General's office to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Roosevelt has told Lowell Mellett, Coordinator of Government Films, that there should be no restrictions on motion pictures except those made imperative by the "dictates of safety."

CLEVELAND -- Development of a new and revolutionary type of automatic pilot for military aircraft was announced here recently by the Jack Heintz Company as the War Department placed an initial order for $4,525,650 worth of the new equipment.

To give emigres in the city a place in civilian defense, the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women is opening a center where they may enroll for opportunities available and undergo training in lines of activity in which they may become useful.

Retail activity last week was generally good in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, with January coat, fur and white sales accounting for the bulk of consumer response, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

The Propeller Club of the United States plans to intensify its nationwide educational activities during the war to fix in the public consciousness the value of a strong merchant marine in time of peace and war.

The speedy new tanker Kentucky, the first big ship launched in an American yard in the new year, went down the ways of the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company at Chester, Pa., yesterday afternoon in a simple ceremony curtailed by the exigencies of war.

A survey conducted recently disclosed that 33 per cent of American women are bothered by dry skin. Causes of dry skin, besides contrary glands which fail to supply sufficient oil, are listed as high altitude, dry climate, excessive sun and wind burn, use of hard water.

British waves, which until America's entry into the war sought to woo American war support, are beginning to throw off the propaganda mask.

DETROIT -- Three vital meetings in the next fortnight will establish automotive conditions for 1942 and probably the war duration. While two meetings mainly concern dealers, action also will affect manufacturers and motorists.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 -- East and West battled to a 6-6 tie in today's seventeenth All-Star football game, staged in the Sugar Bowl instead of in San Francisco because of the war.

THE other day a noted radio man was speaking of the future of broadcasting and television -- when peace comes and engineers have time to incorporate in those arts the host of new ideas now being developed for war.

THREE hundred and fifty miles north of Nairobi and about two degrees above the equator on the northern frontier of Kenya Colony is an area of unspoiled wilderness. A densely forested mountain rises 6,000 feet above sea level and on it is a fresh water lake, designated on the official map of East Africa as Lake Marsabit.

THE parking problem, a hardy perennial that flourishes in congested business areas of New York City and other municipalities, faces a unique frontal attack this Winter. Sought will be the creation of a State parking agency.

In addition to accelerating its academic program to enable students to be graduated in three instead of four years, Columbia College will revise its curriculum so that military and governmental aspects of courses now being given will be stressed, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- An alcohol anti-freeze for auto radiators in which the evaporation of alcohol is reduced to a minimum, thus cutting replenishment, has been developed. This is revealed in a patent (No. 2,268,388) granted to Forest J. Funk of Wilmington, Del.

This war has produced many military surprises, foremost among which must be listed the unexpected resistance offered by Soviet Russia to the German invasion. When open hostilities broke out between the two powers, it was freely predicted that the Russian forces would be crushed with comparative ease by the Wehrmacht.

The new year will bring new and strange duties to teachers. Some of them will be called upon to protect children against death from the air. All of them constitute a vital factor in maintaining the morale of 30,000,000 young people -- nearly a fourth of the population -- who are enrolled in the nation's schools.

ON the hot sands of Libya, American-built tanks have made their power felt and have survived their first ordeal of battle. Their mass production was started in this country a little more than a year ago, yet already our output is ahead of Britain's, and the story has scarcely begun.

DENVER, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A consent decree enjoining the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association and twenty-two State and regional dealer associations from price-fixing and allocation of markets and customers was signed today by J. Foster Symes, Federal district judge.

THE social theatre is dead, long live the slicks of Broadway. With its demise, a whale of a lot of intense and mind-searing plays have been relegated to the attic, to be retrieved perhaps on a brighter day.

AN exhibition of paintings by Henri Rousseau will open in the East Wing Galleries of the Chicago Art Institute on Jan. 22 and will continue until Feb. 23. A de luxe eighty-page catalogue is being prepared for the forty-one works to be shown.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Inaugurating a Florida series of art exhibitions which is to include showings also at Palm Beach, Clearwater, Sarasota and Bradenton, will be the exhibition of works by contemporary painters opening tomorrow in Miami Beach Public Library and Art Center, where it will remain on view until Jan. 22.

TOKYO, Jan. 3 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Masaaki Iinuma, one of Japan's leading pilots, who flew the plane Divine Wind from Tokyo to London in the record time of 94 hours 18 minutes in 1937, died of wounds received during attacks on Northern Malaya, Army Aviation Headquarters announced today.

They know their way with ocean-going ships as well as tiny sailboats.
Fordham's football team, Sugar Bowl champion by virtue of its 2-0 defeat of Missouri on New Year's Day at New Orleans, will receive an enthusiastic welcome when it returns to New York tomorrow.

Nicaragua has started its first civilian defense unit at Puerto Cabezas, it was announced here yesterday by the American Women's Volunteer Services, whose organization is being used as a model by the Central American group. Shortages in school supplies which began to hit the colleges and universities two years ago with curtailments on imported articles are daily becoming more acute as America turns its own resources into weapons of war and tools of industry, Theodore M. Johnson, treasurer of the Educational Buyers Association, revealed yesterday.

THE Press of the Readers Club has brought out "Twelve Against the Gods, The Story of Adventure" ($1.50), the first chosen from Alexander Woollcott's nominations. With the United States at war, its vast network of communications facilities is playing a vitally important role in the all-out effort to defeat the Axis nations. Although the upland game season is now over, those who have not put their guns away for the year will have an opportunity to take part in the open shooting dog trials conducted by the Brookhaven Game Protective Association.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The nation's leading squash players will come here this month to participate in the annual Atlantic Coast men's squash racquets championships at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall courts.

The total volume of ship construction in the United States, embracing both the merchant and naval programs, is greater than any ever attempted before, either by this country or any other maritime nation, according to a yearend review by the National Council of American Shipbuilders, issued last week by H. Gerrish Smith, president.

Britain today is feeding and housing millions of war workers as a national undertaking. THE lowly trench mortar, long and scornfully referred to as the "gas pipe on crutches," is now one of the most important weapons of the modern army. It forms, with the machine gun, the backbone of infantry fire power.

POST-HOLIDAY snow sports are luring regulars back to familiar snowfields in Canada, together with first-timers who want to try their skill on ski slopes about which they have heard so much. Then there are those who go just for a Winter holiday, using Montreal or Quebec as centers from which to excursion and sight-see.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- The Bergen County police sprang into action afternoon after the headquarters of the department here had received a request from the headquarters of the State Guard in Passaic to be on the lookout for "five or six Japanese riding in a car" and "suspected of taking pictures on Routes 3 and 6."

DETROIT, Jan. 3 -- The virtual wiping out of Detroit's chief industry through Federal Price Administrator Leon Henderson's order banning the production of new passenger cars and trucks has been accepted here with resignation which is tinged, in some quarters, with resentment.

ON the theory that experience in photography is a more effective training method than the classroom, the Photography Workshop of the National Youth Administration offers young men and women between the ages of 17 and 25, unemployed American citizens, the unusual opportunity of receiving training that not only is without charge but also carries with it a monthly subsistence salary.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 -- An eighteen-point program for the operation of colleges and universities during the war emergency, which included plans for accelerated school courses, financial assistance to students and credit for military service, was proposed here today at a conference of leading American educators sponsored by the National Committee on Education and Defense and the United States Office of Education.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Jan. 4 -- Russian artillery began a bombardment of the town of Mozhaisk yesterday evening in preparation for an attack to drive the German Ninth Army Corps out of that important position in the inner Moscow defense area, according to information reaching here this morning.

Public offerings of railroad securities in 1941 amounted to $272,491,000 par value, representing forty-two issues, compared with $274,078,000, or twenty-seven issues, in 1940. Most of the securities sold in 1941 were equipment trust certificates. There were no railroad stock offerings in 1941.

ONCE more District Attorney Douglas Selby tangles with that wily lawyer, A.B. Carr, and once more Carr is defeated, although he is clever enough to keep his own skirts comparatively clean. The case is an involved one.

Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Slidell Neilson of 84 Spooner Road, Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced to friends here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Neilson, to Ensign Albert Frederic Gallatin, U. S. N. R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Gallatin of 7 East Sixty-seventh Street, this city.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Jan. 3 -- The prominent role skiing has played in warfare was evidenced during the first World War and in the present crisis. United States Army officials have recognized the value of skiing and have established a ski regiment at Fort Lewis in Washington.

SOME thirty years before their annexation by the United States the Hawaiian Islands, known as the Sandwich Islands, were the home of a promising but as yet undistinguished literary genius. Mark Twain's presence there had come as a surprise to himself, he said.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 3 -- After four favorites and one second choice had bounded down in front in the first five races, an upset marked the Winter Handicap, $2,500 dash at Tropical Park today. R.W. Collins's Sweet Willow, one of the best mares in 1941, was a 3-to-5 favorite in the field of seven but went down to a nose defeat behind Wexler Shagrin's Red Dock, a $25.60 for $2 chance.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3 -- Baseball is too uncertain this year for Jack Doyle to be quoting odds now, but the Cardinals and Yankees look like pennant winners to the Broadway betting commissioner.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Substantial public support for immediate adoption of daylight saving time for the year 'round until the war is over is indicated in a nation-wide survey just completed by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Home gardeners who are planning to take part in the Victory vegetable garden campaign this Summer are naturally anxious to know what the prospects are for an adequate supply of seeds for city, suburban and village vegetable patches.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Bitter cold is sweeping Southern Europe, adding to the suffering of people already distressed by lack of fuel.

HAVANA, Jan. 3 -- A decree ordering the detention and internment of 4,084 German residents of Cuba and the taking over of their property by the custodian of enemy alien property, was signed by the Minister of the Interior today, according to information from that department.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Defense stamps are displacing the orchids and gardenias customarily worn by speakers before a number of women's clubs here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The National Rifle Association today ranked Dave Carlson, New Haven, Conn., as its No. 1 small-bore marksman for 1942 and placed Harry W. Reeves, Detroit, first among the country's pistol shots.

VICHY, France, Jan. 3 -- That Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's New Year message to the French nation was, in the words of the Progres de Lyon, a document "of great political importance" was obvious even in cursory reading. This is made crystal clear today by one fact -- that the Paris press has not yet printed the text and there is reason to suppose that it never will.

Extending Friday's gains by about 2 points, the stock market ended yesterday a week in which values made their widest recovery since the middle of June, 1940. Railroad shares were again the spearhead for the advance, as traders bid eagerly for the carrier issues on the assumption that this group represents a type of security not likely to feel the shock of war economy as much as other sections of the list.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- After a five-day running battle both by sea and by air, a British convoy of over thirty ships has arrived safely in Britain -- less two sunk by the enemy -- bearing much invaluable material, it was announced today. The trip of this con voy -- and the action which, it is believed, did not take place in the usual Atlantic area -- was eventful in the extreme.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Because patrol planes saw that Japanese warships and loaded transports already were "sailing up and down the entrance of the Gulf of Siam," Netherland warships were ordered to sea as long ago as Nov. 30, while United States-Japanese negotiations still were under way, it was disclosed officially tonight.

PLEASED: Three "Winston hats" -- as the headgear of Prime Minister Churchill is known -- have become familiar. (1) A derby-type, which seems like a reduced and rounded topper. (2) A Homburg, black and rakishly brimmed. (3) A seaman's visored cap, part of the uniform of the Elder Brothers of Trinity House, a British life-saving society.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 -- Somewhere in Egypt, where the green valley of the Nile fades into the deep brown hues of the desert, stands a tank maintenance plant, which, although still far from perfect, illustrates what Anglo-American cooperation may achieve in doing an actual wartime job.

While automobile dealers and other spokesmen for the motor car industry began moving on Washington for tomorrow's conference with OPM officials on a rationing program under the order freezing the sales of new cars, the appointment of Rolf Nugent as Associate Price Executive in the Automobile and Truck Section of the Office of Price Administration was announced in New York City.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Under pressure of the new draft bill and expanding war production, employers are adding the words, "Women Wanted" to factory bulletins throughout the country. Concurrent with this, announcements from both the State and national capitals urge immediate organization of vocational trades classes throughout the State to prepare women to accept an extensive number of industrial jobs.

PLANS for the 1942 tournament schedule are being made as in previous years by the American Contract Bridge League; if the war is to affect bridge tournaments it will be largely by reducing attendance.

War finds the gas industry of the United States prepared and on the alert and, in the all-out program to speed production of war materials, it is inevitable that gas fuel will be utilized to the utmost limits of its potentialities, especially in highly industrialized areas, according to George S. Hawley, president of the American Gas Association.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3 -- Senora Aria Rosa Martinez de Guerrero of Buenos Aires and Dr. Herbert Eugene Bolton of the University of California were named today at the closing session of the Hemisphere Conference on Spiritual Inter-Americanism as the South American and North American making the richest contributions to spiritual inter-Americanism during 1941.

Just before he goes on the air for the first time in his life, Rufus Reed, reporter on The Fairmont Express, discovers a dead body in the news room of Station WDFM. The deceased is Harvey Turner, one of the announcers, and it appears to every one but Reed that he has met with an accident.

FROGMORE, S.C. -- Two thousand Gullah Negroes, descended from slaves who once worked on the flourishing indigo and rice plantations of South Carolina, live today on St. Helena Island and other sea islands where they preserve customs and speech of the eighteenth century.

DANGER and bad news are widely credited with unifying the nation since Pearl Harbor; but "The Star-Spangled Banner," that grand old national anthem, has had a mighty part in the welding. Never has it been played and sung more often in so brief a period, never has it been heard by more people at once.

TODAY this department gives its space to the closing sentences of Thoreau's "Walden." They seem singularly appropriate, in this first week of the New Year, as a kindling expression of the hope and expectancy in which life must be lived by those who would keep their faith in the forging of a better world:

Voluntary abandonment by manufacturers in the electrical appliance field of some of their less active products to conserve materials, consolidate operations on leading items and forestall a government ban loomed as a definite possibility last week, according to executives.

Where are the Big Berthas and other shell-hurling Titans of the last war? We hear nothing of them. Having committed herself to a war of rapid movement, Germany relied chiefly on quick-firing guns of 15, 30 and 50 millimeter caliber. In comparison, the 75's of the last war are slow and cumbersome.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Dec. 27 totaled 243,990,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 373,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 579,000 barrels in domestic stocks and a decrease of 206,000 in foreign stocks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- National defense activities have almost overshadowed the regular work of the Department of Justice, Attorney General Biddle informed Congress today in his annual report, which promised that no matter how arduous the days ahead might be the department would not diminish the endeavor of its growing task.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Federal District Judge Ben Moore granted today the petition of the $25,000,000 Fidelity Assurance Association of Wheeling, W. Va., for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Dartmouth spiked a last minute rally by Seton Hall to win by a point, 43 -- 42, before a capacity crowd of 6,100 in Setonia gym tonight.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 3 -- The second session of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's tenth anniversary regatta of Winter sailing in dinghies was next to a flop today.

"Total war" is a crucial test of our ordinary theories and practices of government and of the democratic and libertarian principles by which we strive to live. The fearful exigencies of war force us to re-examine many of our political premises. Among those are the premises concerning our civil liberties.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Japanese forces waging a costly and losing battle for Changsha, Hunan Province capital, were reported by the Chinese to have lost 7,000 men today for a two-day total of 22,000 invaders killed or wounded.

HONOLULU, Jan. 3 -- It was relatively busy last night on the Honolulu civilian front. Several prowl cars and foot patrolmen in one sector of the island rounded up three light violators in four hours, which was said to have been a big haul in these days of military rule.

There never was a time when all nations were so deeply concerned with the problem of nutrition as today. The discovery and study of vitamins accounts for this concern. Man simply cannot live by calories alone. Nor by vitamins alone for that matter.

TWO signs in the past week indicate that the motion picture industry is in a thoughtful, not to say puzzled, frame of mind. First, no one asserted that 1942 will be Hollywood's greatest year. Second, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences decided to give awards for the best documentary films of the twelvemonth just ended.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- With the Christmas-New Year's holidays past, the leading resorts of this region are entertaining Winter sports enthusiasts, including members of many school and college house-party groups and Winter conferences and conventions of business men and women.

Murray T. Quigg and David I. Ashe, while arriving at different conclusions, argue the closed shop issue from the same approach -- that is, Is the closed shop morally right or wrong? The former thinks it is wrong because it violates the principle of human freedom, while the latter maintains it is right because it is based on the sacredness of majority rule.

In Provincetown today the thoughts and desires of the young people turn as eagerly and inevitably to the tides as did their forefathers' in clipper ship days. Alice Dickerson, at 13, fretted because girls couldn't go to sea, and worried even more because there would never be a ship for Silas Inwood, who wasn't actually her beau but was certainly her best friend, to captain.

GRANT took Vicksburg and Sherman marched to the sea. This is the essence of most Americans' knowledge of half the Civil War. The conflict has its dark and bright hemispheres. Sharpsburg, Antietam, Spotsylvania, Cold Harbor are illumined names.
New York University's basketball team had to rally in the late minutes to defeat Fort Monmouth in the Violets' gymnasium last night, 46 to 43.

In common with all other institutions of American life the schools and colleges face the greatest crisis in their history. Upon their ability to readjust themselves to the present cruel circumstances depend the supply of trained men and the development of that morale which are so necessary to ultimate victory.
The City College basketball team had a brisk albeit pleasant workout, but nothing at all in the way of competition, in beating Geneva, 61 -- 22, in the Lavender gymnasium last night.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The pooling of resources of the Allies in the Pacific area is beginning to affect Britain's consumption of commodities. Several moves taken in the last week intensify the control of certain materials and increase the flow of domestic supplies for others.

Associate alumnae of Barnard College are sponsoring the performance of "Tosca" to be given Friday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House to augment the scholarship fund of the college. Grace Moore, Lawrence Tibbett and Charles Kullman will sing the leading roles.

NEW BERN, N.C. -- Motorists who follow the coastal route through North Carolina on the annual trek to Southern resorts will be amazed at the changes which are transforming the long-peaceful sand dunes and sleepy little towns into armed fortresses and bustling centers intent upon national defense.

Much that had been predicted for education in 1942 has already come to pass. The schools have been long engaged in the preparatory stages of this war; hundreds of thousands of boys especially trained for defense jobs have taken their places in the production lines.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that city departments would be placed on a seven-day-week basis under an order that he would issue tomorrow. The Mayor did not amplify his announcement, which was in line with earlier statements made by him.

SERGEI SAZONOVITCH SVIRIDOFF is just about as good an example as one can find of the average soldier in the Red Army. He was born thirty-four years ago in the village of Roga, in Central Russia. He is about 5 feet 6 inches tall and before he was wounded weighed around 160 pounds.

PROFESSOR QUINN in his recent communique attacks the critical "heresy * * * that an actor or actress can give a great performance in a mediocre play." The history of the drama, he continues, tells us that it cannot be done.

GROWING response to retail clearance sales was reported last week and was attributed by merchants to the spreading notions among consumers that long-threatened shortages may soon eventuate. Another period of "scare" buying may be set in motion as a result of the drastic action taken on tires and new automobiles, it was suggested in some quarters.

WARRENTON, Va. -- During January and February the Warrenton Hounds will meet generally on Mondays, Wednesdays and Saturdays, weather permitting. Time and place may be learned by telephoning Warrenton 318. The Casanova Hunt has announced meets on Tuesdays and Saturdays from Jan. 1 to March 15, with an occasional bye day on Thursdays, conditions permitting.

No war was ever so literally a world war as this, which is fought in Arctic snows, in desert wastes, and in equatorial jungles. From the cold Russian front, which stretches far beyond the Arctic Circle, the war spreads south to the Libyan sands, and the steaming, fever-filled Malayan wilderness.

Retail trade here was active during the week, with strong promotional efforts on fur and cloth coats and white merchandise tending to offset the usual post-holiday reaction. Gains over a year ago were reported by department stores, although they were not as sharp as those which marked the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Aviation writers and publishers and editors of aviation publications from all parts of the country attended a symposium held today by the Civil Air Patrol of the Office of Civilian Defense. The attendance was about sixty.

Winter has its compensations. Soup, for one. What can surpass the leisurely delight of a steaming bowl of full-bodied soup after a brisk day in the open? Not as an appetizer. Not as a prelude to a meal. Simply as a meal in itself. With coffee, perhaps, or with tea. With crackers, if they are crisp and salty. But basically soup.

In which of these are we plunged? The Abbe Lemaitre juggled a symbol designated in the relativity equations by the Greek letter lambda, a symbol which stood for a mysterious "cosmological constant" and which had been introduced to offset gravitation.

THE democratic world has been stirred by the fight Russia has put up against the invading Nazis, and Am-Russ Music Corporation has sent us a document that gives a hint of why the Russian spirit has been so magnificent.

WHAT Erno Rapee calls the greatest undertaking in his career as conductor gets under way on WJZ at 12:30 P.M. today when he and the Radio City Music Hall open a festival of nine symphonies by Gustave Mahler, the Moravian composer whose hotly debated work has seldom been heard in this country and has never, it is said, been played on the American air.

To 9-year-old Beatrice Yunker of 191 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, her soldier brother's big revolver, which she discovered yesterday morning on a bedroom chair, was a fascinating plaything. It was made more so by the presence of three shiny-cased bullets lying near by.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 3 -- The arrival in advance of the opening date, Jan. 15, of members of the delegations to the conference of Foreign Ministers of the American republics -- called to consider hemisphere decisions regarding solidarity with the United States in its war with the Axis powers -- was indicated today.

The railroads have a large task in aiding defense but they are better prepared to meet it than ever before, F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, said in a new year statement to employes. His statement read in part:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee reported to the Clerk of the House today that its receipts totaled $651,573.94 and its disbursements $663,155.88 during the 1941 calendar year. The Republican National Committee reported receipts of $170,145.92 and disbursements of $232,088.68 for the same period.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Prime Minister Churchill, smiling and chipper, let the war go hang for ten minutes this afternoon while he showed his powder-blue "siren suit" to twenty-five news photographers.

Here in far-extended islands, fabulously endowed with rubber, tin and oil, is also quinine, friend and savior of fighting men. Japan is lashing out to seize, the Allies are fighting to retain, this strategic material which troops need to carry on the struggle.

With the annual meeting of its directors scheduled for Thursday, there is every indication that the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association will carry out its Spring program with a view to aiding wartime charities.

IN a recent Sunday edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES there appeared a very erudite article by one John F. Wharton, counselor-at-law, based on the quite proper assumption that since every one taking part in theatrical enterprises is unionized, the producers should be unionized as well, so there can be a reasonable basis of collective bargaining.

CHRISTMAS, I am happy to be able to inform you, is Christmas still in the West End of London. In four working days from Monday to Friday of Christmas Week I visited three pantomimes, two fantasies, two straight plays and one revue.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 -- Us, a 5-year-old mare, carried the colors of Mrs. Samuel Orr to victory in the feature race, an allowance contest at six furlongs, at the Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Secretary Morgenthau said today that the Treasury had turned over to Vice President Wallace, as chairman of the Supply, Priorities and Allocation Board, an inventory of $200,000,000 worth of materials useful in wartime which are held in storage places in this country for foreign owners.

Concerned over the growing number of complaints that air raid wardens were soliciting funds to purchase equipment, Police Commissioner Valentine said yesterday that the situation was being investigated and, "if true, appropriate action will be taken."

The scholarship fund of the New York Vassar Club will be aided by the performance of "La Boheme," with Grace Moore, Salvatore Baccaloni and Annamary Dickey in the leading roles, on the afternoon of Jan. 30 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mrs. William L. Kallman of Briarcliff Manor is president of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Civilians were admonished today not to buy air raid protection equipment until instructed to do so by their air raid wardens. The admonition was issued here following a conference between officials of the War Department, OCD and OPM.

MERIDA, Yucatan -- In Yucatan that nostalgia for a jungle fastness, for palm fronds and exotic bird songs; for crumbling ancient cities and carven temples and treasures strangely hidden; for thatched huts and simple native peoples; that yearning for the faraway and the forgotten which haunts us all from childhood, is fulfilled at last.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The combination of Jim Bickford, former United States Olympic team member, and Bill D'Amico of Lake Placid won the opening two-man bobsled event on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run today.

Surrendering of cameras, short-wave radios and firearms by enemy aliens in compliance with the Federal order took a sharp surge upward yesterday when police stations in Manhattan and the Bronx reported a total of 1,061 cameras, 124 radios and eleven assorted firearms turned in by midnight.

Three major courses begin this week at the New York Botanical Garden. The class in "Outdoor Flower Gardening," which is the Winter term of the two-year course in practical gardening meets Thursdays, beginning this Thursday at 7:45 P.M. Given by P.J. McKenna, the course consists of twelve lectures on the preparation, planting and maintenance of flower gardens and lawns.

TARPON SPRINGS, Fla. -- The observance of Greek Epiphany, or Cross Day, will begin before dawn on Tuesday with colorful ritual in the tiny Greek Orthodox Church here. Archbishop Athenagoras, spiritual head of the Hellenic Orthodox Church of North and South America, who has conducted the Epiphany ceremony here for several years, is expected to return for the service again this year.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3 -- The patio of Casa Marcheta was the setting tonight for a buffet dinner given by Mrs. Frank Vernon Skiff for Mr. and Mrs. T. Harris Smith of Queenstown, Md., house guests of Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne.

SINGAPORE, Sunday, Jan. 4 -- British forces inflicted very heavy losses upon the Japanese on the lower Perak front, reports early today said, with particularly effective blows being dealt by the Royal Air Force.

Stanley Schleifer, 24-year-old ex-convict, of 170 Larch Avenue, Teaneck, N.J., was held without bail yesterday for a hearing Jan. 16 by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio in Felony Court on a charge of suspicion of felonious assault. Schleifer was arrested Friday night after Frank C. Cole, 62, patent lawyer, had been beaten in a washroom on the ninth floor of the Chrysler Building, Lexington Avenue at Forty-second Street.

Throughout 1941 the electrical industry placed all emphasis on production for defense, according to a year-end review of the industry by Guy Bartlett of the General Electric Company. At the close of the year, he reported, vital electrical products were being completed in ever-increasing quantities, with the blueprint and tooling-up stage being passed in case after case.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 -- Bernie Bierman, Minnesota football coach and one of the East's mentors in the East-West All-Star game, today received telegraphic orders to report Jan. 15 at the United States Marine Corps Station in Quantico, Va. Bierman is a major in the Marine Corps Reserve.

Now that trees and shrubs again are bare, and "barren branches shake against the cold," the gardener more appreciates those few species (outside of the coniferous evergreens) that still hold a green banner against Winter's brown and gray.

DORIS HUMPHREY'S new work, which she calls "Decade," may not rank among her most distinguished creations, but the conclusion to which it points is one of both philosophical and practical importance for the native American dance art.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Netherlands Indies newspapers, warm in their praise for General McArthur's stubborn defense of the Philippines, but aware it cannot be carried on indefinitely in the face of superior Japanese forces, re-emphasized today the mounting importance of the Indies in the Pacific theatre of war and the urgent need to reinforce the islands' defenses.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Attention continues to center on the war effort, the war theme having dominated even the traditional New Year's Eve dinner-dance at the Everglades Club, where decorations were war and recruiting posters.

THE Victory Book Campaign, sponsored by the American Library Association, American Red Cross and United Service Organizations, opens on Jan. 12, when readers in homes throughout the land are asked to share the books they have enjoyed with our soldiers, sailors and marines.

The year 1942 will produce no revolutionary changes in the field of education. It will accelerate some tendencies that have been operative through years; it will check or even suppress other tendencies.

In celebration of its twentieth anniversary, the Judson Health Center is planning a benefit entertainment for the night of Jan. 18 at the New York Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The evening's program will consist of a buffet dinner followed by an illustrated newsreel lecture by Arthur Menken, whose subject will be "The Battle for the Pacific."

The Rams from Rhode Island State and the Rams from Fordham stampeded all over Madison Square Garden in a spectacular, wild-and-wooly basketball game last night to the hysterical delight of a crowd of 17,076 as the New Englanders outscored the New Yorkers, 60 to 55, in an overtime battle.

A $750,000 automobile theft racket, involving several allied rings of car thieves and dishonest automobile dealers, operating in New York and other States with the most elaborate set of disguising equipment ever uncovered by police, is under investigation by the office of District Attorney William O'Dwyer of Brooklyn, it was disclosed yesterday.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- A freakish terrain, which has confounded residents of this area for months by leading them to believe that mysterious magnetic forces in the earth drew their automobiles uphill and backward although they were driving downhill and forward, was examined and explained today by two engineers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Further sharp curtailment in the production of washing machines, vacuum cleaners, refrigerators and similar consumer durable goods is entirely probable in the near future but no complete suspension of such manufacturing is contemplated, Leon Henderson, head of the Office of Civilian Supply, said today.

SEATTLE, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Declaring that two Seattle shipyards had been brought to a virtual standstill by refusal of certain union leaders to permit their men to work Saturdays for less than double pay, a statement by the Thirteenth Naval District tonight called the union attitude "200 per cent unionism, but zero per cent Americanism."

BY its very nature this book was certain to possess compelling news interest and definite historical value. Mr. Davies, who was Ambassador to the Soviet Union from 1936 to 1938 and subsequently served in the same capacity in Belgium, sets down his impressions of Russia from the time when he entered on his mission to the present.

AN EAST COAST CANADIAN PORT, Jan. 3 (Canadian Press) -- One thousand German prisoners are safe in Canadian internment camps after crossing the Atlantic under the eyes of Canadian soldiers, headed home for a few weeks leave after eighteen months in England.
The city's business women are joining forces for war service, both as volunteers and as workers with special skills they can contribute to the national productive effort against the Axis.

Affixing the last section of a gigantic poster at Times Square and Forty-third Street, publicizing the "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, opened at noon yesterday the 1942 New York drive for funds of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill announced today the creation of a "unified command" in the Southwest Pacific area with General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Britain's tough 58-year-old defender of India and Burma, as "supreme commander" of all United States, British, Netherland and Dominion forces in that area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A consent decree under which the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association and twenty-two State and regional dealer organizations are enjoined from price-fixing and allocations of markets and customers was filed today in the Federal District Court at Denver.

WHEN Japanese warplanes attacked the United States Dec. 7 there followed an immediate reaction that resulted in the grounding of 80,000 American private pilots. A survey of the effects of that grounding and a view of the future curtailment of private flying indicate that American skies will soon be largely free of all planes but airline transports.

Spring showings of furniture, rugs, curtains and draperies will feature developments in the wholesale markets this week, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. Most markets were quiet last week, although some orders were placed for Spring apparel.

Fear that the mobilization of man power and material resources for the war effort would lead to a destruction of human values and individual rights was expressed yesterday by Aubrey Williams, National Youth Administrator, at the twenty-seventh annual convention of Phi Alpha fraternity at the Park Central Hotel.

While not slighting their academic programs, colleges and universities today face the serious problem of gearing the campus and classroom to the immediate goal of helping to win the war, leading educators of this country are agreed.

NOW that the holidays are over, attention is going to be focused increasingly on resort travel. To warmer climes will speed those who dislike the chill of the North, and many who are keen to escape the talk of blackouts and sirens in big cities.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in 1941 was in the largest volume in four years, or since 1937. This increase took place despite the fact that dealings in Japanese, German and Italian dollar loans were suspended on the declaration of war early last month.

A list of 143 tire dealers and garages in this city authorized by local rationing boards to inspect tires and tubes and to certify cases where new tires are required, was made public yesterday by Harold W. McGraw, Federal Tire Rationing Administrator for New York City.

A definitely American character is now developing in the design of our home furnishings. Even in the past, when we borrowed more freely from Europe, there was always a tendency to simplify and adapt. Householders were seeking, perhaps unconsciously, something more akin to our democratic tastes and accelerated tempo of living.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt is sponsoring the annual theatre party in aid of the work of the Women's Division of the National Jewish Hospital at Denver to be held at the performance of the musical comedy, "The Lady Comes Across," on the night of Jan. 13 at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.
MOSCOW, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following:

LAST Winter between 300,000 and 400,000 visitors thronged to the national parks for Winter sports. This year, with good snow conditions, increased prosperity and some of the park roads kept open to the ski areas, an equal crowd is expected.

Brought to the United States from Sydney, Australia, by boat and by airplane, two ichidnas, or spiny anteaters, were found to be none the worse for their 10,000-mile trip when they were warily examined at the Air Express office at La Guardia Field at noon yesterday.

A rise of from 10 to 25 per cent in holiday travel to and from New York City this week-end, as compared with the like period last year, was predicted yesterday by officials of railroads and bus lines. The peak is expected today.

An important sports event for the new year is the eleventh annual women's New York State singles and doubles squash racquets championships scheduled on the courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club, starting tomorrow and continuing through Wednesday.

Eugene List, who played the Chavez piano concerto on Thursday and Friday with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Dimitri Mitropoulos, last night at Carnegie Hall before a capacity house, played a very different work with the orchestra and conductor, the Schumann A minor piano concerto.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Joe Louis's workout today was about the best the world heavyweight champion has had since he started training more than a fortnight ago for the defense of his title against Buddy Baer in Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Arrangements for conducting "open house" at various nurse-training schools and hospitals in the State were discussed today at a meeting of some thirty-five representatives of the fifteen districts of the State Nurses Association.

Balancing of the forces likely to exert major influence upon retail trade this year leads to the expectation that enough of the outpouring of all-out war funds will find their way to the department store to result in a volume of business during 1942 which may come close to that of the year just ended, according to Bernard Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Montreal extended its winning streak to two games tonight by scoring three times in the third period to defeat Detroit, 4 to 1, before a crowd of 8,000. The Canadiens rose to a sixth-place tie in the National Hockey League standings with the Brooklyn Americans.

THE Rochester International Salon, rated by American Annual of Photography as this year's No. 1 salon in the world, announces its seventh annual exhibition. The salon will be held in the Rochester Memorial Art Gallery, at Rochester, Feb. 27 through March. 29.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Notre Dame inflicted the fifth basketball defeat of a five-game road trip on Harvard tonight, 39 to 31. Earl Brown Jr., young Harvard coach, was captain of the 1938-39 Notre Dame team.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Temple romped to an easy 57-to-41 victory over Duke in the feature of a college basketball double-header before 5,000 at Convention Hall tonight. In the opener St. Joseph's came from behind to beat North Carolina, 33 -- 28.

A movement to knit Canadian and United States women's organizations more closely together is rapidly taking shape under the stimulus of a single war objective, as well as through a desire of representatives on both sides of the border to strengthen hemispheric solidarity.

TORONTO, Jan. 3 -- Toronto went into a tie with Boston for the National Hockey League lead by defeating the Brooklyn Americans, 4 -- 2, in a ragged contest at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight. However, the Bruins can break the tie by beating or tying the Americans in New York tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Nylon leather an a substitute for natural leather has been developed by the research laboratories of the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., it is revealed in a patent (No. 2,268,160) awarded to John B. Miles of Greenville, Del. The same patent reveals how, by a slight change in the manufacturing process, nylon sponge and cork substitutes may be produced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- One of the most important chapters in the history of American medicine was written at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7 when United States Navy physicians and nurses, aided by assistants who rushed to their aid from Honolulu, cared for 960 casualties -- in many cases terribly burned and wounded men -- by working constantly for sixteen hours.

Members of the Citizens' Housing Council of New York have taken over the performance of Marc Connelly's new play, "The Flowers of Virtue," with Frank Craven and Isobel Elsom in the leading roles, on the night of Jan. 29 at the Broadhurst Theatre in behalf of the organization.

Whether or not you believe in them -- and if it has never been proved conclusively that ghosts exist, neither has it been proved that they don't -- this collection of stories will appeal to those of any age who love the "folk-say" and legends of America.

ON the day the Germans crossed the Seine north of Paris the old gentleman left the village in the Jura Mountains and set out with the two English children, homebound through France. They would eat and sleep comfortably on the train, he planned, and make the fast Calais-Dover crossing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Sixteen members of the United States diplomatic and consular service were reported today to have been in or near Manila after the outbreak of war with Japan. Whether any or all of them remained in the Philippine capital when the Japanese marched in has not been announced here.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The British Middle East general headquarters communique said today:

Prominent in the plans for hundreds of thousands of "victory gardens" discussed at the recent horticultural call to arms by the Secretary of Agriculture was the emphasis placed on home fruit growing. In many a garden tree fruits -- such as apples and pears -- of standard size are ruled out for lack of space. The same varieties of fruits, grown on dwarf stocks, offer the possibility of overcoming the handicap.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Accelerated pooling and coordination of existing manufacturing facilities, reduction in the number of types of fighting planes and greater emphasis on mass output of long-range bombers have put a new face on the program for aircraft production.

EARLY in the war the British Government ordered bread enriched with B1, characterized as the morale vitamin. Now American housewives have taken on the job of seeing to it that their families also eat food that will give them sufficient stamina to take whatever the new year may hold for them. And in making out their grocery lists they will be including more and more of the foods that build stout hearts and strong nerves.
TOKYO, Jan. 3 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The first Japanese
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The chances are ten to one there will be little change in the 1942 college football rules.

The new Board of Estimate, holding its first meeting yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office in City Hall, voted an appropriation of $48,028,800 for relief in the first six months of 1942. This is exclusive of personnel costs, for which appropriations have already been made.

A gift of $35,000 from General Foods Corporation and contributions of $15,000 and $9,500 from anonymous business concerns in the city headed yesterday's donations to the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, which is conducting a city-wide appeal for $7,330,000 as its quota in the nation-wide $50,000,000 drive by the American Red Cross.

OVERNIGHT, Washington has become a war capital. It is a town where barricades suddenly appear in streets that bore heavy traffic Soldiers stand guard at doors where colored folk used to bow a smiling welcome. Fences are suddenly erected to block off sidewalks where tourist guides, a famous popcorn stand and flocks of peanut-hungry pigeons had become landmarks.

ISN'T it about time that radio gave music lovers some consideration? Any number of instances of execrable taste are represented by the one example during the broadcast of a Brahms symphony on Friday, Dec. 19, in a performance of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

With the struggle for the Philippines entering upon what may be, for the time being, its closing phase, attention naturally focuses upon Singapore. While Hong Kong, Luzon, Indo-China and North Borneo, now in Japanese hands, safeguard Japanese sea communications, a direct naval attack upon Singapore still seems unlikely.

At the Hotel Roosevelt today and tomorrow there will be benched 240 spaniels of various types, making up a total entry of 299. It will be the twenty-fifth specialty exhibition of the American Spaniel Club and will attract spaniel breeders and fanciers from all sections of the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In tightening up the Price-Control Bill which the House adopted last November, the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency reported to its parent body today that it was seeking to provide an urgently needed emergency authority to protect the nation from inflation.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 3 -- It is remarkable how little attention has been paid to the Falange Espanola in all the inquiries that are made from time to time in South America to uncover activities of actual or potential enemies of the United States.

VICHY, France, Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- The German-controlled press tonight launched an attack against the Vichy Government and claimed that a new "crisis" has arisen for which it blamed United States Ambassador William D. Leahy.

Whether or not significant of a more liberal future attitude in the interpretation of laws governing pension and profit-sharing plans, at least the United States Board of Tax Appeals has shown courage in approving such an arrangement in which only certain executives of an enterprise, all of them stockholders, are the beneficiaries.
The Patent Office finished its 1941 business by granting 835 patents, among which were the following inventions:

This is a costume piece, and the costumes are all Spanish, for the California town of Todos Santos is celebrating its annual Fiesta de las Rosas in honor of the descendants of the original Spanish settlers. Among the lookers-on is Johnny Dane, who is interested in the spectacle only because he has to report it for The Associated Press.

The banner of the Rising Sun flew last week over Manila, where the Stars and Stripes had waved since 1898. The fall of the old Philippine capital, overlooking the waters where the power of imperial Spain had been broken by Dewey's fleet, symbolized the first major defeat of United States arms in World War II.

The Neediest Cases Fund for 1941 has reached a total of $257,193.79 today, the final Sunday of the thirtieth annual appeal on behalf of the men, women and children who are in the greatest distress known in New York City. Yesterday's seventy contributions aggregating $1,887.05 are included in this total.

Donald V. Murray of 2710 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, is the winner of a full four-year scholarship to Fordham Preparatory School, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Joseph B. O'Connell, principal of the school. Murray, a graduate of Our Lady of Refuge Parochial School in the Bronx, won the award in competition with 378 other graduates of metropolitan elementary schools who participated in the recent scholarship examinations at Fordham.

Yachting's close affiliation with the Federal government's services is made strikingly apparent on the slate of officers and the national governing board of the Power Squadrons reported yesterday by the 1942 nominating committee, headed by former Chief Commander Harold H. Funk. Eight Federal officers of tile uniformed forces have been named to the board because their duties recurrently touch the field of yachting during the year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The hard-hitting "Cinderella Fleet" of submarine chasers which fought the German U-boat menace in the first World War is being augmented to strike the same enemy again, the Navy disclosed tonight.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 3 -- In the midst of serious war news and defense work, the State Federation of Women's Clubs maintains its firm belief in the importance of music in everyday life. Mrs. H. Albert Phillips, music chairman, has announced that to eight girls from New Jersey College for Women, Meta Thorne Waters part scholarships have been awarded in various branches of music.

Joe Louis, Detroit's famed Brown Bomber, will make his twentieth defense of the world heavyweight title Friday night in Madison Square Garden in the interests of the New York Auxiliary of the Navy Relief Fund.

HONOLULU, Jan. 3 -- Lessons in surgical and medical treatment learned in Honolulu during the Japanese attack of Dec. 7 will be invaluable to the United States, Dr. John J. Moorhead, professor of surgery at New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, said today.

The Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York reported as of Dec. 31 total deposits of $88,237,901 and total assets of $98,491,837, compared, respectively, with $83,052,069 and $93,766,793 on Sept. 30. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $39,780,223, against $33,437,452; holdings of United States Government securities, to $8,655,862, against 87,250,842, and loans and discounts to $34,396,960, against $37,263,256.
FORT KNOX, Ky., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Three Army officers were killed and a fourth was injured in two separate airplane crashes today at Fort Knox.

On Christmas Day there were probably more Americans at home than any other day in the year. Now most Americans, when home, turn on the radio. How, then, did our great networks salute this day? How was this vast audience entertained?

Commissioner William F. Carey was at the Sanitation Department offices early this morning to supervise personally the city's snow-removal forces as the first heavy snowfall of the Winter, which started last night, threatened to blanket the city to a depth of several inches.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Americans may as well face the music, to the tune of $150,000,000,000 as a war effort.
The Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America yesterday urged increased buying by consumers as a mean of preventing inflation and improving the national health.

Higher education must have for the coming year an intelligent and a consecrated leadership. The Selective Service and other war measures have already disturbed its program. More drastic changes are quite possible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Department of Justice has moved swiftly since the outbreak of war to meet the internal problem of 1,100,000 enemy aliens. Plans of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were so well laid that within two hours after the bureau had received the order for action, practically all of the persons it deemed dangerous were in custody.

Under the impetus of the post-holiday rush of hundreds of young men to join the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard the recruiting curve of the nation's armed forces here shot up again yesterday.

PERHAPS the best way to realize just how good a book L.A.G. Strong has made out of the life of a tenor is to imagine what this life could have been in different hands. And to that rare reader who knows nothing of Mr. McCormack's art the surest proof of the taste his biographer claims for him is that he chose so skilled a man of letters for the job of writing this book.

The Tokyo radio, in an English-language broadcast to North America, recorded last night at the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave listening station in New York, quoted "a German military expert" as being "highly optimistic about future developments in the war situation both in Europe and East Asia."

WHEN, some days ago, Sam Wood unpacked his bags in an East Side hospice, he had arrived ostensibly to spend the Christmas holidays with his daughter, K.T. Stevens, the spirited young lady in the recent "The Land Is Bright," who continues to spurn the prestige of her father's name and continues to do very well under her own pseudonym.

EVEN a program director couldn't foresee all that war in the Pacific would do to network programs on the West Coast, but Charles Vanda, who holds that post out there for the Columbia Broadcasting System, had a pretty good headstart.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Skiers are dotting the slopes of Mount Mansfield, highest peak in the Green Mountains and one of the few places in the East where good skiing is available. The past week has been a busy one at Stowe and Smugglers Notch on the eastern slope of Mansfield, with nearly all Winter resort places filled.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 3 -- The seventeenth anniversary of the disappearance of any legal opposition to the Fascist party in Italy passed today with pledges by and orders to the Fascisti to exert renewed "will and energy" under Benito Mussolini toward an Italian and Axis victory.

A PROGRAM devoted entirely to Canadian works will be presented by the League of Composers next Sunday at 3 P.M. at the New York Public Library as the first of its four young composers' concerts. Of the group to be represented only two are over 30, and one has reached the ripe age of 12.

Nation-wide concern among motorists that severe rationing -- effective tomorrow for new tires and Jan. 15 for new vehicles -- may bring wholesale tire and car thefts is recognized by law enforcement authorities, who already have taken preventive steps, it became known here yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden. Jan. 3 (U.P.) -- Scandinavian reports today said that Germany was feverishly augmenting defenses from Narvik to Brest, possibly as preparation against any British attempts to open a new Scandinavian front.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 3 -- With the largest entry in its history, the Ox Ridge Hunt Club today held its twelfth annual indoor horse show in the club's riding ring. The exhibition was favored by clear weather and the prospect of excellent competition brought out a capacity attendance.

The detective who does his stuff in this store is Quinny Hite, a former New York policeman. He is a crude individual and no intellectual giant, but he has a keen nose for red herring, and he thinks he detects the odor of that species in the circumstances surrounding the murder of Dred Braider, head of the Braider Construction Company.

HOLLYWOOD, which sometimes bewails the lack of acting talent while ignoring what is already waiting in its own purlieus, is finally bringing Elisabeth Bergner to the screen after a year's delay in her first American-made film, "Paris Calling."

Scoring eight points in a second overtime period, the Brooklyn College basketball team won its sixth consecutive game by defeating Davis and Elkins, 47 -- 41, last night before 1,500 fans at the victor's home court.

The cotton market continued its upward movement yesterday, although the sharp advances of the previous two days were moderated by profit-taking and realizing operations. Final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 8 to 12 points over Friday's close.

FROM England comes word that "M.E.F." was overprinted, late in 1941, on Great Britain's 1-penny scarlet, 2p deep orange, 2 1/2p ultramarine, 3p bluish violet and 5p yellow-brown with portrait of King George VI, for use in occupied territories formerly under Italian control in East Africa.

LARGELY brought about by the defense effort, civil aviation showed remarkable gains in 1941. During the year the nation's civilian pilot roster passed the 100,000 mark, private plane sales increased, airports and airways were vastly improved and airline traffic reached new highs.

TODAY, when those who take no interest in war are the exception, this book, offering as it does authoritative information on military matters, should be especially welcome. In the initial chapter Colonel Portway rightly tells us once more that "war is no longer fought by the man in uniform alone but by the whole industrial strength of a nation."

CARMEL, Calif. -- This is the largest incorporated city in the country without mail delivery -- in spite of the fact that its postoffice does a greater volume of business for its size than any other place in the United States.

SEVERAL hundred fliers, who are qualified pilots and flight instructors and high-ranking graduates of the CAA's most advanced cross-country course, will be trained to ferry lease-lend material to those nations fighting the Axis powers, according to plans worked out by Civil Aeronautics Administration and Air Corps ferrying experts.

EX-PACIFIST: The versatile author of the relativity theory, who is also a master of the violin and now the sage of Princeton University, once stood as a champion of militant pacifism. During the years after World War 1 and even after his expulsion from the Nazi Reich, Professor Albert Einstein often lent his prestige to anti-war movements. "Militant pacifism is re-

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Dartmouth had only one skier in the curtailed college men's Winter sports meet of the Lake Placid Sno Birds this afternoon, but he stole the show on the 30-meter hill at Intervale.

THERE have been new heroes made for America since this book was published a few weeks ago, yet there is still room for the elder ones, and the deeds of the young and gallant seem to underscore the point which Anne Malcolmson makes in her clear-sighted preface: that one way for us to foster a love and appreciation of our native heritage in the young is to help it to know our folk-heroes.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 3 -- A five-hour Japanese air attack on Corregidor Island, the United States stronghold commanding Manila Bay, was announced today by the Army, which said thirteen men were killed and thirty-five injured but that there was no material damage to installations.

There's not much difference between morale and mental health, according to Dr. D.A. Thom, from whose remarks in Mental Hygiene we gather that both terms imply a state of mind in which people do their best, get as much satisfaction out of life as they can, with a minimum of waste motion, and take whatever comes with "courage, fortitude and confidence."

THE 150th anniversary of the birth of Lowell Mason, leading American pioneer in hymnody and public school music, is being celebrated this week among churches and public schools of the country, under the leadership of the Hymn Society of America, the Music Educators National Conference, and the Commission on Worship of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

NOBODY likes to be bombed, and air raids such as this war has produced are not much fun. In fact, they are a dreadful nuisance when they are kept up day after day, week after week, month after month, as they were in London. I know, because I lived through several hundred of them -- exactly how many, I don't know, since I stopped counting after the first couple of hundred.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 3 -- Anxiety for the fate of Finland and impatience with the "wait-and-see" attitude of the Finnish Government have become more and more evident in Sweden in connection with the continuous progress of Russian Armies on the Eastern Front.

IF knowledge of a country's history can be acquired by a cursory reading of its historical fiction, the British public ought by this time to be well informed concerning that of the United States, for several American historical novels have in recent years gained a large circulation here.

Without questioning the logic of the premise -- now generally recognized as axiomatic -- that had the United States become a member of the League of Nations, then this war would have been impossible, let us consider why the premise did not prevail here -- let us brush aside the generalities which have long been favored and place the blame where it belongs, so that the conditions which inspired that blame shall not be repeated.

When a former District Attorney turns crook and is indicted, that is news, and it is up to Flash Casey to get a picture for The Express. Casey gets the picture, but circumstances over which he has no control prevent its reaching the office.

WASHINGTON, Jan 3 (AP) -- Henrik De Kauffmann, the Danish Minister, said tonight that "Danes in the free world" adhered to the Declaration by United Nations signed here Jan. 1 by twenty-six States warring against the Axis powers.

AMID the most austere solemnity that has ever marked one of their voting sessions, and with a dispatch which baffled belief, the New York Film Critics made their choices of 1941's best movie, best screen performances and direction last week, and thereby pulled down the curtain on the year now so distantly sped.

Bobby Ruffin, 133, Astoria, lightweight contender, stopped Harold (Snooks) Lacey, 128, New Haven, in the star attraction listed for ten rounds at the Ridgewood Grove's boxing show last night. A crowd of 3,000 saw Ruffin gain the victory when Lacey was unable to come out for the ninth round.

ON declaring war against Japan, Germany and Italy, the Republic of Haiti in the West Indies installed a board of censors at its capital, Port au Prince. The board is under the Secretary of the Interior, who has charge of the special war police.

IF there had been lists of best sellers in France during the months of passivity which preceded the sudden and tragic collapse, the prophecies of Nostradamus, doctor, scholar, poet and prophet of the sixteenth century, would have certainly ranked near the top.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Authoritative sources, expressing themselves as well pleased with appointment of General Sir Archibald P. Wavell as Supreme Commander of the United Nations in the Southwest Pacific, pointed out tonight that he was known as a general "who can do much with little."

TEN years ago, though it may not seem that far back, New York City was a green pasture for the mobsters. Their beer caravans rumbled to appointed drops every night with disregard for the city's 18,000 finest. Their rum fleets, loaded with rich cargo from the West Indies, Newfoundland and St. Pierre, shuttled in and out of New York Harbor.

WHEN Eddie Cantor stepped onto the stage of the Hollywood on Christmas night he was still the same bobbing comic with eyes like loose marbles and hands forever playing patty-cake with each other that Broadway remembered.

Permanent headquarters have been acquired by the Pan-American Women's Association, to enable the group to intensify its program of cultivating hemispheric understanding in the New Year. The new center, which will be opened formally on Jan. 17, is located in two rooms in the Hotel Sheraton, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

The mystery which enveloped the sudden illness of Babe Ruth early yesterday began clearing later in the day when Dr. Philip G. MacDonald, his personal physician, disclosed that the retired home run monarch was confined in a private hospital recovering from an "upset nervous condition," brought on, he believed, by a recent automobile crackup, as well as from over dieting.

Miss Maria Cerra, veteran foils-woman of the Salle d'Armes Vince, came through to victory in the first Amateur Fencers League of America competition of the new year, the annual Voorhees tournament, at the Fencers Club yesterday.

Defeat of the bill that would require members of the Communist party and the German-American Bund to register as foreign agents was urged yesterday by the Greater New York Industrial Union Council of the C.I.O. In a telegram to Congressional leaders, the council asserted that passage of the bill would "result in a witch hunt against the labor movement at a time when complete unity of all those opposed to fascism is imperative."

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Owners of pointers and setters from all parts of the South are gathering for the twenty-fifth annual Pinehurst Field Trials, which open tomorrow over the Sandhill courses of the Pinehurst Field Trial Club.

"NONE of the characters in this novel is imaginary," says the author of "The Ivory Mischief," introducing his long and fascinating story from the France of Louis XIV. But this assurance does not mark Mr. Meeker's only reversal of formula.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A new scale of maximum time charter rates for United States and foreign flag cargo and tanker vessels was announced today by the Maritime Commission. The new scale, to be effective Jan. 20, cancels scales set by the commission last Summer and materially reduces existing rates.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese planes diving out of a clouded sky onto Corregidor fortress at the entrance to Manila Bay today destroyed anti-aircraft batteries, artillery emplacements and machine- gun nests by direct hits, German dispatches reported from Tokyo today.

ST. PIERRE-MIQUELON, Jan. 4 -- As a reply to rumors circulating here that a conference between the United States, Canada and Vichy France would be held to return the islands partly to Vichy control, Vice Admiral Emile Muselier, head of the Free French forces here, said in an interview:

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 4 -- When the Chungking radio, which speaks for Free China, broadcasts the pronouncements of the Chiang Kai-shek government from a station far up the Yangtse River, Ying Ong, a Phoenix grocer, operates the official listening post in this country.

The American ted Cross is appealing for $50,000,000 to provide relie! for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services lor the armed lorces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the live boroughs, as lollows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,00.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- British Royal Air Force fliers made a daylight raid on Northwest Germany today, penetrating Nazi anti-aircraft defenses to strike at railway communications and other objectives.
BERLIN, Jan. 4 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:
