Knowing that the work of the Fund is carried on through the year by eight participating private charity organizations and that those agencies still have many cases on their lists who desperately need care, old friends of the Neediest Cases Fund in this and near-by States sent thirty-nine contributions totaling $431 yesterday.
Quick resales of loft properties in Manhattan featured realty deals reported over the week-end.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 4 -- There are signs that Finland is approaching a crisis from which she can be saved only by a rapid change in the government's attitude.

The American people today are under great emotional strain due to the duplicity of the Japanese Government in ordering an attack upon our citizens and our fleet while negotiations looking for a formula for peace were still going on. This sense of moral indignation has been heightened by the declaration of war by Germany and Italy.

Those nations that have set themselves against Christianity must win this year or they never will have another chance, warned the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Women fliers taken into the Civil Air Patrol probably will put in considerable time in ground service before receiving their wings, according to Miss Cecile Hamilton of this branch of the Office of Civilian Defense. Miss Hamilton spoke at a symposium of aviation publication publishers, editors and writers held here yesterday by the Civil Air Patrol.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 4 -- New defeats for the defenders of Singapore and Borneo were acknowledged by the British today.

Sir Thomas Beecham will make his debut as a Metropolitan Opera conductor next week, which will be the eighth of the season. He will conduct a double bill, consisting of Bach's "Phoebus and Pan" and Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Le Coq d'Or" on Thursday evening, Jan. 15.

With the higher penalties for illegal parking effective this morning, special orders were issued last night to all police captains calling for "rigid enforcement of all parking ordinances as well as accurate records to enable magistrates to determine 'habitual parkers.'"

BERLIN, Jan. 4 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command reported today that its air force was-carrying out night and day air raids against the Russian troops that counter-attacked in Crimea and won a foothold at Theodosia.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, lowest scoring team of the season, achieved the most one-sided victory in National Hockey League history tonight by whipping the Montreal Canadiens, 10 to 0, before 7,227 spectators.

One of New York's great stores is celebrating its centennial with an affirmation of faith that is particularly appropriate to these troubled times. It is just a hundred years since a young man named Adam Gimbel came to the frontier village of Vincennes, Ind., without friends, without money, without credit, but with confidence in himself and in the future.

Major Gen. John F. Curry, national commander of the Civil Air Patrol of the OCD, newly formed organization of volunteer private fliers, met yesterday at La Guardia Field with wing and group commanders of the metropolitan area and discussed plans for utilizing civilian pilots, their experience and their planes in national defense work.

Once again the Trade Book Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts, after sitting in judgment on the books published in December, singles out those titles that embodied especially good designing and sound and purposeful manufacture.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Lifting of the price ceilings on fats and oils and announcement that a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee had approved a price ceiling of 110 per cent of parity on agricultural products resulted last week in an advance in wheat prices to the highest marks since early in October, the May and July rising within striking distance of the highest level of the season.

Not fear, but a desire to help God, is drawing worshipers to their knees, the Rev. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday in a sermon on "Strength for the Day," delivered as pastor at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

With stores having carried over fairly large stocks of merchandise into the new year, retail advertising campaigns on clearance sales during this month and next will be heavy, according to advertising managers. Not only will soft goods be promoted, but in many instances stores will have surprising stocks of durable items such as small appliances to sell.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 4 -- Word that Bernie Bierman, Minnesota's famous coach, had been called to active duty with the Marine Corps served to emphasize to the nation's leading mentors today that plans for college football are on a day-to-day basis.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Bitter factional fights of long standing within the metropolitan milk producers bargaining agency, marked yesterday by withdrawal of the powerful Eastern Producers Association, resulted in more withdrawals today and the threat of others to quit the organization.

VICHY, Jan. 4 -- As no newspapers are published on Sunday in either the occupied or unoccupied zone, there have been no further outward reactions to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's New Year's message to the nation, which made it plain that "collaboration" with Germany had not produced all the results expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The care of American children in wartime was discussed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt tonight in her weekly broadcast over the NBC-Blue network. Answering questions put to her by Mrs. Ernest K. Lindley, her guest on the program. Mrs. Roosevelt advised that children should continue to live lives as normal and as regular as possible.

Orders regulating conduct of "enemy aliens" apply to nationals of Germany, Austria, Italy and Japan, but not to citizens of occupied countries, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa announced yesterday.

Fire partly destroyed yesterday an old parish house and threatened to spread to the historic St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, near Fort Hamilton, in Brooklyn. The structure is known as the "Church of the Generals," as famous American military leaders, including Generals Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson, had worshiped there.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 4 -- A thousand prominent American educators, representing virtually every type of college and university in this country, adopted unanimously today a fifteen-point declaration of policy to govern higher education in the war period, at the closing session of a three-day emergency conference called by the National Committee on Education and Defense and the United States Office of Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The peoples of every nation under the Axis heel were offered today by the United States an opportunity to adhere to the principles of the victory declaration by United Nations, signed here Jan. 1 by twenty-six States as a pledge to fight Hitlerism to the finish.

A banking syndicate headed by John Nuveen Co. of Chicago will offer today to the public $8,300,000 of 2 1/2, 3 and 3 1/2 per cent revenue bonds of the Western Nebraska Division of the Consumers Public Power District of Nebraska.

The first session of the Seventy-seventh Congress ended on Friday. A new session begins today at a time when the whole world is engaged in a great struggle to preserve free democratic government. In the year ahead the Congress of the United States has an opportunity, as well as a duty, to prove in action that the parliamentary system of representative government is worth fighting for.
LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique said:

Mr. and Mrs. William G. Scarlett of Baltimore will give a dinner on Friday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Virginia Penfield, daughter of Mrs. Eugene W. Ong, and William G. Scarlett Jr., whose marriage will take place on Saturday in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

The first snowstorm of the Winter, part of a coastal disturbance that swept over the New England States and northern New Jersey, took New Yorkers by surprise yesterday and left the city streets under a three-inch blanket of snow, sleet and slush before it ended late in the forenoon.

CHUNGKING, China, Monday, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- The Japanese offensive against Changsha "collapsed" yesterday afternoon and Chinese troops began battering units of three enemy divisions, which were cut off in their retreat, the official Central News Agency reported today.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (Reuter) -- This, normally, is the time when fashion houses show their Winter collections. War has wrought many changes in the fashion world. Paris is momentarily eclipsed, but London is carrying on.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Army and Navy announced jointly today that they plan to offer the automobile industry another $5,000,000,000 in defense contracts. If accepted the automobile industry will have orders for war materials totaling $9,000,000,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- Governors of most of the forty-eight States face their 1942 job of mobilizing military and civilian resources already armed with emergency powers which in 1917 required months of legislative sessions.

College women who desire technical positions in America's war industries will be accepted in a basic training program at the Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president. The new twelve-week course, given as part of the defense training program of the United States Office of Education, will begin on Feb. 2 and will equip women for such positions as draftsmen, inspectors, supervisors, engine testing and computation.

FREDERICK L. SCHUMAN, that acute and belligerent historian-critic-oracle who is Woodrow Wilson Professor of Government at Williams College, has written a full-length report on the roots and first fruits of the Second World War. He calls it "Design for Power: The Struggle for the World."*

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Corregidor Island, guardian of Manila's great harbor, was again raided from the air by the enemy last night. This was announced in a communique that also charged "discrimination against the white race" by the Japanese in Manila.

Led by Arthur Tauber of N.Y.U., intercollegiate epee champion, who came through the concluding round with an unbeaten record, six fencers gained berths yesterday at the Salle Santelli in the metropolitan district's qualifying round for the All-Eastern intermediate foil championship.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Donations of gold teeth, diamonds, pennies and large bank drafts are flowing into the Treasury to help win the war.

Cotton prices rose sharply in post-holiday trading last week and recorded substantial net gains for the period as a whole. At the close of market on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances for the week of 83 to 87 points.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 4 (Reuter) -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell's appointment to the Supreme Command did not come as a surprise here owing to rumors on the subject these last few days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A decision to concentrate allied forces in the Far East for the defense of Singapore and the Netherlands Indies, and to fight a delaying action in the Philippines, was inherent in the announcement here yesterday that General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Britain's foremost military leader in this war, would take command of the forces of the United Nations in the Southwest Pacific.

There are two good reasons why the appeal of Alaska's Delegate to Congress for more planes to strengthen the defenses of that Territory deserves consideration. The first is that the 586,400 square mile outpost which guards our northwestern flank is a tempting prize both economically and strategically, and may well prove Japan's next objective if she succeeds in her desperate attempt to reduce British and Dutch defenses of the rich Netherlands Indies.

The only opening scheduled at the moment for this week will take place on Saturday morning at the Squire Theatre, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. The film is the religious drama, "The Eternal Gift," a feature-length pictorial account of the celebration of the Roman Catholic Solemn High Mass.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday a report opposing the Master Plan of Land Use proposed by the City Planning Commission on Nov. 20, 1940, as a guide for future zoning. The report, a copy of which was sent to the planning board, urged the commission to modify its proposals and to submit an amended plan for consideration at a public hearing.

For the duration of the war, no man in uniform need go hungry in the midtown area. From noon to midnight every day free coffee, sandwiches and doughnuts will be standard fare for all service men at the mobile kitchen operated by the American Women's Voluntary Services at Sixth Avenue and Forty-second Street, alongside Bryant Park.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 4 -- With a snow-banked shore, the tenth anniversary regatta of Winter dinghy sailing ended today at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club with Jack Sutphen in his Class B craft Rum-Dum, Fred Gade in his D boat Janie and Ed Miller with his Penguin Draftee taking the first prizes.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- "True to Life," a screen story by Ben and Sol Barzman and Bess Tafel, has been purchased by Paramount as a probable vehicle for Bob Hope and Bing Crosby. They will be seen in the photoplay as writers of a radio family serial who take lodgings in a private home to get background material for their program.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose slightly from 101.1 to 101.2. The outstanding price change of the week was the 1.8 per cent rise in the chemical group, which resulted from rises in fertilizer and creosote prices.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 4 -- The number of Axis prisoners captured at Bardia is now estimated at 7,000, including 1,000 Germans, Middle East Headquarters announced today. Materiel is still being picked up on the battlefield.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 4 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Commander in Chief of the Allied Forces in the Southwest Pacific area, spoke confidently today about his new job, declaring that although the ground won by the Japanese could not be immediately regained, the tide would eventually turn against them.

Four weeks of unrelieved Anglo-American reverses in the Pacific have obscured our view of the tremendous panorama unfolding on the snowclad steppes of Russia. The war of the world was highlighted last week by the Japanese capture of Manila and Cavite, on the island of Luzon in the Philippines; continued but slower Japanese advances in Malaya; additional German retreats in Russia, and a recrudescence of German submarine and air activity in the Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

The Parodi Cigar Company of New York, Inc., with general offices and main plant at Scranton, Pa., bought the building at the northwest corner of Provost and Fifteenth Streets, Jersey City, N.J., at the exit of the Holland Tunnel.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- The necessity of adjusting the moves and policies of the State government to the needs of the nation engaged in a total war is scheduled to dominate the 165th session of the New York State Legislature, which will be opened at noon on Wednesday by Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The week of Feb. 8 was reported today to be officially favored for the first of a series of registration dates at which an estimated 25,000,000 additional men are to be enrolled for possible military or other service in the war effort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- An aggregate of 665,000 young men, war veterans, Indians and territorials have received training useful in national defense in Civilian Conservation Corps camps since President Roosevelt declared a limited emergency in May, 1940, James J. McEntee declared today in a report to Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4 -- Hundreds of complaints, directed chiefly at the inaudibility of San Francisco's new sirens, poured into newspaper offices and police stations today as the Bay area studied the defects of its seventh blackout of the war.

Artur Schnabel launched his series of five programs devoted to piano works by Schubert at the concert given by the New Friends of Music late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. In the course of the cycle Mr. Schnabel will perform the majority of the principal compositions in Schubert's legacy for the keyboard, a feat for which he has prepared himself by constant study of these masterpieces throughout his artistic career.

They defeated the Bruins, holders of the Stanley Cup and the hockey championship of the world, in the National League contest at Madison Square Garden, to the amazement of a crowd of 13,272 and doubtless, the Bruins.

PITTSTON, Pa., Jan. 4 (AP) -- A Lehigh Valley passenger train, pounding through a driving snowstorm, struck a stalled automobile near here early today and hurtled from the track, killing one passenger and injuring thirteen others.

Speaking to the people in Britain by radio, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday afternoon that they would have to help the people of the United States, after the war was won, in building a world-wide "supra-government" to restore ruined economies and police large parts of the earth that will be in chaos.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Jan. 5 -- The second day's shelling of German positions on the Mozhaisk salient, sixty miles west of Moscow, ended last night with no major change in the opposing lines, it was reported this morning by a military spokesman on the Moscow radio.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 4 -- Machine-guns of the Nazis had the last word in a Paris demonstration of students in the Latin Quarter yesterday afternoon, according to a report reaching diplomatic quarters here tonight. At least thirty-two persons were reported to have been killed and scores of others wounded.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Prices of corn failed last week to keep pace with the upturn in wheat, due in part to the liberal quantity of government-owned cash grain offered for sale at a price equal to that of corn of comparable quality in the spot market, but closing sales on the Board of Trade here yesterday showed gains of 1 to 1 3/8 cents a bushel.

Lehman Brothers will announce today the establishment of a corporate bond trading department under the direction of Richard K. Buechler. For six years Mr. Buechler had been a partner in charge of the bond department at Newman Brothers Worms. Prior to that he was manager of the bond department at H. Hentz Co.

A full schedule of six games was played yesterday in the tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club. All were completed without a single draw. The winners were Herbert Seidman, Milton Hanauer, Jack W. Collins, Carl Pilnick, Joseph Hidalgo Jr. and Joseph Richman.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 (U.P.) -- The National Industrial Traffic League voted today to support a "general increase in rates, fares and charges" by railroads to help finance increases of wages granted last month to railroad workers, but it refused to favor the 10 per cent advance requested by the carriers.

William H. Matthews's letter. "To Those Who Seek to Help," is very fine. We are woefully lacking in our offense program and we cannot win this war until we can build up sufficient armament to carry the war to the enemy.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Although victories in the Pacific have come to Japan as eaasily as they did to Germany in the first two years of the war, the financial markets here ended 1941 with a display of dogged cheerfulness over a satisfactory record for the year.
Three United States steamships painted war gray, with their ports and skylights blacked out, arrived yesterday from the West Indies and Central America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A wage increase of 10 cents an hour plus four-tenths of a cent per mile traveled, retroactive to Nov. 16, was awarded today by the National Defense Mediation Board to about 50,000 "over the road" truck drivers in twelve Midwestern States.

NEW DELHI, India. Jan. 4 (AP) -- A group of fifteen distinguished Indian leaders appealed today directly to Prime Minister Winston Churchill for "some bold stroke of far-sighted statesmanship without delay" to avert a political crisis in India and insure her full cooperation in Britain's war effort.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 4 -- "Here have been Hitler's men," is the phrase used in Pravda to describe the invader's vandalism. "Klin and Kalinin have been laid in ruins, the grey northern beauty of Pskov and Novgorod have been defiled, where Istra stood we found the snow-covered plain with heaps of smoldering rubble."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- In a virtual advance acceptance of the gigantic Army-Navy program, the automobile industry tonight pledged wholehearted cooperation "in letter and spirit" with whatever demands the government makes.

VICHY, France, Jan. 4 (AP) -- While a new "terroristic" outbreak in Paris resulted in the imposition of a 5 P.M. curfew by the German occupation authorities, a "serious incident" in the occupied port of Brest led to the suspension today of the entire City Council.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The second session of the Seventy-seventh Congress, one likely to be known as the most momentous war session in the nation's history, will begin tomorrow with three major war measures at the top of its agenda, but with only one scheduled for either floor or committee consideration in the first fortnight.

A reception was given yesterday by the Women's National Emergency Committee to Miss Eloise Davison, assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense, at the National Broadcasting Company studios. Among the guests were officials of many women's organizations throughout the country.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 -- Despite the holiday last week, both incoming steel orders and steel production were materially unchanged in volume.

Although a price ceiling on exports may be necessary, particularly on essential commodities for Latin America, consideration should be given to the additional expenses involved in conducting foreign trade, the National Foreign Trade Council asserted in a special bulletin issued for publication today.

TOKYO, Jan. 4 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Japanese air force bombed steadily at American forces withdrawing from the Manila area, damaged 140 trucks along the western coast of Bataan peninsula and blasted at communications and military objectives in the area.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American warplanes shattered a force of Japanese fighter planes attempting to raid a British Royal Air Force station in the Moulmein area, on the Gulf of Martaban, 100 miles east of here, this morning, destroying seven of them.

JACKSON, N.H., Jan. 4 -- Snow finally fell today on this popular Eastern Slope resort, which teemed with activity as several thousand skiers went "schussing" and "tail-wagging" down the mountainsides. The trails and slopes at Jackson, North Conway, Kearsarge, Bartlett, Intervale and Pinkham Notch formed a network of ski tracks.

VICHY, Jan. 4 -- The 1942 budget, promulgated on Jan. 1, shows estimated receipts amounting to 80,000,000,000 francs, an increase of 11,800,000,000 over 1941. Expenditures under the ordinary budget get come to 105,500,000,000 francs, an increase of 8,500,000,000, and for the supplementary budget to 33,000,000,000 francs, a decrease of 4,300,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP)--Senator Carter Glass, 84 years young today and every inch a scrapper, is looking forward to the time when the United States will "shoot Japan off the map."

To the welfare of the sick in peace or war, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday dedicated a new nine-story building constructed as the major part of a $1,300,000 modernization program at St. Vincent's Hospital.

Two third-period goals by the Boston Olympics spelled defeat and spoiled what might have been a highly successful afternoon for the New York Rovers in the Eastern Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Dr. Juan Negrin, last Loyalist Prime Minister of Spain, now a refugee in London, has made himself a human guinea pig in extremely painful and dangerous experiments designed to make escape from submarines less hazardous.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- By a fraction of a point, Middlebury College defeated an old rival, the University of New Hampshire, to win the annual College Week ski competition, a final tabulation showed today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 4 -- Fordham's football team, victor in the Sugar Bowl game with Missouri on New Year's Day at New Orleans, stopped here for six hours today before resuming the journey to New York. Part of the entourage went direct to New York, but the others attended mass and went sightseeing in the historic city.

The Guaranty Trust Company, largest of the Wall Street banks to report thus far, shows its statement of condition as of Dec. 31 total deposits of $2,259,895,401, including checks outstanding, compared with $2,401,580,046 on Sept. 30.

The Chicago Bears overcame the obstacles of snow, rain, mud and the National Football League All-Stars at the Polo Grounds yesterday in the fourth annual Pro Bowl game and with a performance as dazzling as the weather was miserable scored a spectacular victory over the selected squad, 35 to 24.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Japanese bombers today extended their forays to within 800 miles of Australia, twice bombing the Australian Air Force Airdrome at Rabaul on the island of New Britain in the Bismarck Archipelago, an Australian Air Force communique said.

John Feeney, Irish tenor, who made his debut in Town Hall last season, gave his second local recital in the same surroundings last night. Except for the opening group, which included the aria "Where'er you walk" from Handel's "Semele" and the "Panis Angelicus" from Franck's "Messe Solennelle," the program was composed almost entirely of the Irish airs and ballads in which the singer specializes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Ugo Carusi, executive assistant to Attorney General Francis Biddle, said tonight that the government would not permit the persecution of enemy aliens, but that it would deal swiftly and effectively with "disloyalty and hostility on the part of any person, alien or citizen.''

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 4 -- Mr. and Mrs. Theodore W. Stemmlet entertained with the first in a series of buffet dinners tonight at their residence for Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Pell, house guests of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Henderson.

Last-minute improvement in holiday trade left retail inventories low in many departments, leading wholesalers to expect active buying at the markets this month. This was particularly true in the low-priced dress field, where good-sized reorders were received, especially in printed jerseys.

Champion Eldgyth Apollo established a new record yesterday as the two-day twenty-fifth specialty show of the American Spaniel Club started in the Hotel Roosevelt. This beautiful liver and white English springer spaniel won in his breed for the second year in succession, becoming the only dog to gain this honor twice.

Opposition to a proposal of the New York City Board of Health to confine its milk inspection service to sources actually supplying the city was expressed yesterday in a statement issued in behalf of the Farmers Union of the New York Milkshed.
GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- The long-suffering fistic faithful are going to get their money's worth when Joe Louis tangles with Buddy Baer in Madison Square Garden Friday night.

It was learned today that he had been acting as the chief adviser of the American and Allied governments on the most difficult problem confronting the mission and the Roosevelt Administration -- the transformation of the American industrial economy into the greatest military arsenal in the world's history.

ON THE PERAK FRONT, WESTERN MALAYA, Jan. 4 -- The Japanese who made a landing near Telok Anson in Southern Perak on the west coast of Malaya came down the coast under the cover of night in a nondescript collection of steam launches and junks, it is learned here. The shipping evidently was collected in Penang and other ports farther north in Japanese hands.

Striving to make his forthcoming revival of "Hedda Gabler" one to be remembered, Luther Greene has recruited quite an imposing cast for the Ibsen play due Thursday night, Jan. 29, at a West Forty-eighth Street house which may not be designated yet.

Godfrey D.N. Haggard, British Consul General, and the Rev. WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--Considerable progress has been made over the week-end in unifying and coordinating the military, naval, supply and shipping establishments of the United States and Great Britain, it was learned today.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- G.L. Sears was the only double winner at the traps of the Westchester Country Club today. He took the handicap cup at singles by breaking 50 straight targets. At skeet he tied with M. Zilinski for the scratch cup at 48, then won the trophy on a toss.

WASHINGTON, Jan 4 -- Appointment of Dr. John R. Steelman of the Department of Labor, Captain Edward Macaulay of the United States Maritime Commission and Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, as members of the new Maritime War Emergency Board was announced today by Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, Maritime Commission chairman.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Massachusetts C.I.O. pledged itself today to settle all industrial disputes during the war by negotiation or arbitration, without strikes, and appointed a committee to work out an industrial peace policy in cooperation with the State Federation of Labor.

The several days' business in the foreign exchanges in the new year failed to bring any important variation in rates or turnover. WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association, in newspaper advertisements to be published tomorrow morning in Washington and Detroit, reviewed its contribution to armament production thus far and declared that attacks on the industry's war work "are designed to create a division so that certain groups may obtain control of the productive machinery of the United States."

Mayor La Guardia issued a proclamation yesterday serving as a spearhead for the American Red Cross drive here for $7,330,000, the city's quota in the nation-wide campaign for $50,000,000 as a special war fund.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday that he would recommend legislation for re-establishment of military training in the high schools in the event that the Army favored the step. He recalled that military training was instituted in the high schools during the last war, "when the danger was less than it is now."

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Announcement that the Office of Price Administration had lifted the price ceiling on fats and oils to the level prevailing on Oct. 1 resulted last week in an upturn of around 75 cents a hundred weight in lard, but the advance was not as sharp as many operators had expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- A resolution calling for complete severance of diplomatic relations between the Latin-American republics and the Axis powers will be one of the key measures introduced at the forthcoming consultative meeting of foreign Ministers at Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, according to advance indications.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- An organization to acquaint State employes with a plan for payroll-deduction purchase of defense bonds is about ready to function, State Controller O'Leary said today. It is expected that the deductions will be made from the mid-January payrolls. The State's annual payroll totals about $95,000,000.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 6 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Russians announced today that the Germans had been routed from almost the whole of the Kerch peninsula, Crimean gateway to the Caucasus, by Red armies that blasted the Nazis from town after town in a forty-five mile advance within two days.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 5 -- The International Red Cross Committee in Geneva has been requested by cable from the American Red Cross to send food packages at once to 100 Americans held prisoner in German-occupied France, it was announced today by Norman H. Davis, Red Cross Chairman.

The directors of General Motors Corporation yesterday approved formation of a war emergency committee, of which Donaldson Brown, vice chairman of the board and vice president of the corporation, will be chairman.

Claude Corbitt, young shortstop who was favorably regarded as a prospect for a regular berth with the Dodgers next season, yesterday notified the club that he had enlisted in the Navy. He joined up at Raleigh, N. C., was announced.

Captain Erling Vorberg, a stocky Norwegian master of a motor tanker that was sunk by torpedoes Oct. 17, revealed yesterday in an interview that his countrymen have been using a rubber suit that keeps seamen afloat, dry and warm when they are forced to abandon a ship without a chance to use lifeboats.

Members of the Federal attorneys' staffs in Manhattan and Brooklyn were struggling yesterday to administer the regulations governing travel of enemy aliens with as little interference as possible with the plans of the individuals concerned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A provision of the New York Decedent Estate Law permitting a widow or widower the right to elect to share in an estate regardless of the terms of a will was held constitutional by the Supreme Court today by a unanimous opinion written by Justice Jackson.

An exhibition containing 179 paintings by seventy-two American artists opened yesterday on the eighth floor at Macy's. The work, which is offered for sale, will continue to be shown for three weeks. It was chosen by Samuel M. Kootz, whose book, "Modern American Painters," was published some years ago.

VICHY, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- A razor-wielding terrorist raided the headquarters of Marcel Deat's political party in Paris today, badly hacking the only man he found there and putting a new strain in the general tension that followed the killing a few hours earlier of Yves Paringaux of the Ministry of the Interior.

NEVIL SHUTE'S new novel, "Pied Piper,"* is good, the best of his novels I have seen, although I haven't seen them all. In some respects it is sentimental, and in fact it would probably assay at least 50 per cent sugar in any actual test. But it is effective even so, and builds up to a fine and unexpected climax.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A gift of $200,000 received today from Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller and their six children brought to a grand total of $15,229,827 the contributions to date to the war relief fund of the American Red Cross.

Could there have been a better education and discipline for the stage than the humble Philadelphia theatre where Otis Skinner began his apprenticeship ? Application, patience, memory were required when the bill was "changed every evening" and matinees were likely to be given every day but Sunday.

Secretive back-room transactions in which envelopes containing graft money totaling $7,343 allegedly were given to former Municipal Court Justice C. Ernest Smith, long a political power in Staten Island and twice president of the Richmond County Bar Association, were described yesterday in testimony at disbarment proceedings against Smith.

Fred C. Moffatt was renominated as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange for a one-year term at a final meeting yesterday of the nominating committee, under the chairmanship of Frank J. McCormack.

A sustained interest in the work of the Neediest Cases Fund in rehabilitating men and women who are struggling against heavy odds to re-establish themselves as self-supporting members of a democratic nation was indicated by the flow of gifts from sixty-eight contributors yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Veteran Chinese troops are believed to be on their way to Malaya to help block the Japanese drive toward Singapore, British sources said today.

Robert Stevenson, a young pianist and composer from Melrose, N.M., who is now an instructor in music at the University of Texas, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program included fugues by Bach and Mendelssohn, the Chopin B minor Sonata, Scriabine's Ninth sonata and a divertimento and sonatine of his own.

A syndicate of Minnesota banking firms headed by Wells-Dickey Company of Minneapolis was the successful bidder yesterday for an issue of $2,700,000 of State of Minnesota rural credit deficiency fund certificates, receiving the award on its tender of 100.07 for the obligations bearing interest at the rate of 1.60 per cent.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- Chairman Walter Okeson said tonight the National Collegiate Athletic Association football rules committee would announce not more than a half-dozen rule changes out of sixty proposed revisions when its meeting is concluded late tomorrow.

Applauding demands by speakers that Earl Browder, imprisoned Communist leader, be freed, 20,000 Communists jammed Madison Square Garden last night for a Lenin memorial meeting at which a pledge to support the fight of the United States against the Axis "gangsters" was unanimously adopted.

For the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, an exhibition of paintings by Vincent van Gogh, one of the most important figures in modern art, was opened yesterday afternoon at the Paul Rosenberg Gallery, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 4 (Delayed) -- The press department of the Greek Legation at Kuibyshev has released a comprehensive document alleging Bulgarian spoliation and terrorism in occupied Macedonia and Thrace. According to it, the Greek population's situation in the occupied territory may be summed up as follows:
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Jan. 6 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique early today:

All this hullabaloo about Mayor La Guardia and civilian defense is missing such a vital point that it is utterly unconvincing. A volunteer, popular movement like civilian defense manifestly must have popular leaders. It is quite different from OPM and all the government offices in Washington, where the relationship is usually one of contract or definite order.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 5 -- The German Foreign Minister, Joachim von Ribbontrop, has arrived in Budapest on the invitation of the Hungarian Regent and the Hungarian Premier, it was announced this evening. Officially the visit is classified as one of courtesy in return for the recent trip to Berlin by Premier Ladislaus de Bardossy.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- Bad news was brewing for the fops and fashion plates among the males of the nation tonight as the delegates to the International Association of Clothing Designers assembled in Philadelphia for their annual convention.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today:

KINHWA, Chekiang Province, China, Jan. 4 (Delayed) -- Japanese held Shanghai today is a city of desperate hunger, anti-British and anti-American propaganda and sharp rivalry between the Japanese Army and Navy over division of the vast wealth of enemy property.

The stage, screen, radio and arts division of Fight for Freedom, Inc., will present as a means of raising funds for war work organizations, "Fun to Be Free," a revue, at a Broadway theatre for two weeks, beginning Jan. 27. Performances will be given nightly, except on Mondays, and twice on Saturdays and Sunday.
The New York Rangers will skate out on the ice in Madison Square Garden tonight in quest of one of the most amazing records in National Hockey League history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- War stops prosecutions by enemies in the Federal courts of the United States, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled today, in barring the Italian Government from opposing seizure of the tanker Brennero and its $431,000 oil cargo at Hoboken, N. J., last March.
A number of sales involving Brooklyn properties were reported yesterday by two large financial institutions.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M. today, follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The recommendation of a Bureau of Immigration inspector that Harry Bridges, West Coast C.I.O. leader, be deported to his native Australia for membership in or affiliation with subversive organizations was unanimously rejected today by the Bureau's Board of Immigration Appeals on the ground that evidence taken in a three-months hearing did not support the charges.

The fiftieth annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Artists opened with a reception at 9 o'clock last evening in the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Guests of honor were Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Watson.
Prince and Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff will leave on Friday for Palm Beach to visit Princess Kaplanoff's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. James Abercrombie de Peyster.

WASHINGTON, Jan 5 -- series of twelve new instruction pamphlets was released today by the Office of Civilian Defense. Included are handbooks for the individual members of the volunteer services, manuals for staff members, and training guides for enrolled volunteer workers.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Today, for the first time, a foreign court of law functioned on English soil. Two Netherland merchant seamen were arraigned before the newly instituted Netherland Maritime Court in the Middlesex Guild Hall.

HONOLULU, Jan. 5 -- An appeal was made today to civilians to present any information which would assist the Presidential investigation commission in deciding "whether any dereliction of duty or errors of judgment on the part of the United States Army or Navy personnel contributed to such successes as were achieved by the enemy" in the surprise attack of Dec. 7.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Herman Shumlin, who staged and produced Lillian Hellman's "Watch on the Rhine" on Broadway, will come to Hollywood to direct the film version for Warner Brothers, the studio announced today. Long negotiations for screen rights to the play were concluded by Warners last week, and a term contract with Shumlin, under which "Watch on the Rhine" will be his first venture, subsequently was signed.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- The $50,000 added Widener Challenge Cup Handicap at Hialeah Park on March 7 became the standout classic of the Winter racing season today with cancellation of the $100,000 added Santa Anita Handicap, scheduled for the same day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Domestic consumption of cotton reached a new daily high in November, the Department of Agriculture said in a statement today. It added that if the average were maintained annual consumption might surpass 11,000,000 bales this season.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 5 -- War conditions in the Pacific, which caused the transfer of the annual New Year's Day Rose Bowl football game to the Atlantic Seaboard, resulted today in the cancellation of Santa Anita Park's 1942 horse racing season.

In order to make sure that the colors it issues are not only fashionable but also obtainable at this time, the Textile Color Card Association has appointed an advisory committee composed of representatives of leading dyestuff producers, Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's proclamation fixing Feb. 16 as the date for registration of male citizens between 20 and 44:

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The stock markets were influenced today by the continued advance of the Russian armies and the satisfaction with the Anglo-American war policy and displayed a cheerful tone. Gilt-edged securities were firm.

As one of those who, until Dec. 7, urged that the United States keep out of the war, but who have since then supported the war and have offered their services to the government in the war's prosecution, I wish to object emphatically to the contents of the page advertisement published recently in THE TIMES urging that "to win this war we need union now."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Here is the text of the radio talk given tonight by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, director of selective Service:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Treasury, "in view of the situation created by the temporary enemy occupation of important parts of the Philippine Islands," issued a circular today calling attention to the fact that Philippine assets have been automatically frozen under the Dec. 26, 1941, amendment to the freezing orders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Dec. 20 was 7,517,930 shares, compared with 10,701,960 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

Mrs. Dudley Pound, American-born wife of a British officer with the forces in the Near East, called yesterday at the headquarters of the British War Relief Society, 730 Fifth Avenue, to offer her services as a voluntary worker in the Allied war cause. She was the last woman, so far as is known, to visit Guam and Wake Islands before their capture by the Japanese.

WESTERN MALAYAN FRONT, Jan. 5 -- A battle for Kuala Lumpur, capital of the Federated Malay States and second city of Malaya, was developing today. Japanese forces have landed in the vicinity of Kuala Selangor, port city thirty miles airline northwest of Kuala Lumpur and 240 miles north of Singapore.

In a move believed designed to anticipate action by organized prohibitionists resulting from the wartime situation, establishment of squadrons of trained "inspectors" who will assist local authorities in eliminating socially undesirable conditions in the retail sale of liquor, particularly in military areas, is contemplated in a plan announced yesterday by the newly formed Allied Liquor Industries, Inc., following a meeting of the group's directors and executive committee at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today that next week the Treasury would refund into regular Treasury issues $1,076,063,200 of securities of government agencies such as the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, Federal Farm Mortgage Corporation and of the Treasury itself.
ROME, Jan. 5 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's Italian High Command communique follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- The Evening Public Ledger, founded on Sept. 14, 1914, by the late Cyrus H.K. Curtis, was ordered tonight by the Federal District Court to suspend publication because no satisfactory plan of financial reorganization had been presented by its trustees.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 5 (Reuter) -- The dramatic story of an aerial fight over the outskirts of Rangoon yesterday afternoon when six American fighter planes took on twenty-seven Japanese fighters was related by two American airmen today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The first of an undisclosed number of airship patrol squadrons, which will constitute an important element in the Navy's coastal defense forces, has been commissioned, the Navy announced today.

The number of prisoners captured at Bardia, more than the lost British garrison at Hong Kong, indicates that the Axis Powers meant to hold the Libyan port. Yet Bardia could never have become a stronghold like Tobruk. With the British Navy offshore, the Axis would have lacked, the vital sea link that saved Tobruk.

VICHY, France, Jan. 5 -- The mangled body of Yves Paringaux, chief of staff of Vichy's Ministry of the Interior, intimate collaborator of the Minister Pierre Pucheu and director of the Ministry's task of repressing anti-German activities, was found early today on the railroad tracks near the small mainline station of West Flamboin, near Melun, about thirty miles southeast of Paris.

Following a day of adverse comment on his plan to decree a seven-day week for 156,489 city employes, Mayor La Guardia left City Hall at 6 o'clock last night without having issued his threatened order and without comment on his failure to do so.

Complete confidence in the soundness of New York basketball despite the succession of reverses suffered by the local teams at the hands of holiday visitors was voiced by the home coaches at yesterday's luncheon meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association at the Hotel Lincoln.

Marian Anderson's art grows deeper and richer with the years, even though the voice has not quite the magnificent lustre of half a dozen seasons ago. The American contralto, who had an audience that jam-packed the last inch of standing room at Carnegie Hall last night, sings with more restraint now, and with even greater variety of color effects.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 5 -- Supplemental regulations affecting the conduct of German, Italian and Japanese nationals throughout the United States, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands were announced by Attorney General Biddle today.

Mr. and Mrs. Average American can look forward to living in a smaller house, having one egg instead of two for breakfast, wearing patched clothes and playing parlor games instead of going to the movies, for the duration.

George L. Harrison of the class of '10 of Yale University and president of the New York Life Insurance Company was elected yesterday a life trustee of Columbia University at a meeting of the trustees. Frederick Coykendall, Columbia, '95, a member of the board twenty-five years, was chosen chairman for the ninth consecutive time.
Vitamin-poor diets are not so extraordinary as they should be in this land of plenty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Swift conversion of the automotive industry to turn out $5,000,000,000 to $6,000,000,000 worth of war material during 1942 was asked by the government today as the automobile makers were told that the 204,848 authorized quota of passenger car production in January probably would end civilian output.

In quieter and better days to come, when people are writing history instead of making it, the scholars will give particular attention to the six-week period between Nov. 22, 1941, and the present moment of writing. The serious historians may call it the battle for Moscow, or the turning of the tide.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- A scramble for the $12,000-a-year job of Westchester County Commissioner of Public Works ended today when James C. Harding of Mount Kisco, consulting engineer to six communities, was appointed to the post by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach.

Recruiting in the armed services here surged upward yesterday as men of all fighting ages poured into Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard offices in crowds not much smaller than those of the day following the attack on Hawaii.
Private builders during the past year have taken an important part in providing needed housing according to the annual statistical summary just released by American Builder.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Japanese planes flew over scattered points in the Netherlands Indies today but dropped no bombs. A communique said one plane was believed downed by anti-aircraft fire.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Members of the American Women's Volunteer Services were in a dither tonight borrowing three uniforms back and forth.

Blackout materials, the first ever to make their appearance in any of the New York Curtain and Drapery Shows, were a prominent feature of the twenty-first exhibit, which officially opened yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker. In addition to sateen and pyroxylin coated cloths, black-lined draperies were shown and hardware companies came through with transverse tracks, which permit the complete overlapping of draperies for blackouts.

Formation of the firm of Harry Parker Company to deal in oven-the-counter securities, with offices at 74 Trinity Place, was announced yesterday. Mr. Parker, who is an active member of the Security Traders Association of New York, was formerly manager of the trading department of the New York office of Colonial Bond and Share Corporation, Baltimore.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 5 -- The Russian campaign has profoundly modified the external aspect of the German soldier, writes the special correspondent of the Corriere della Sera of Milan, Italy, in a significant article dated "On the Russian Front" today.

The record total for 1939-40-41 of 26,093 new infantile paralysis cases in the United States appears to have "alarming significance because it may indicate that the disease is getting a foothold in America," Dr. John C. Curran said yesterday. He is Greater New York Director of Organization of the Committee for Celebration of the President's Birthday for the National Foundation of Infantile Paralysis.

There was little change in the rate of steel operations scheduled if or this week, indicating that operations are proceeding on an even keel. In comparison with the situation a year ago, operations are about 1 1/4 per cent higher. On a tonnage basis, however, there will be 57,900 tons more steel made this week than in the first week of 1941, a gain of 3 3/4 per cent.

If we are to win the war without needless loss of time and treasure and American lives the new session of Congress that began yesterday must show itself more alert and efficient than the session which ended a few days ago. But if Congress is now to act with the centralized efficiency and responsibility necessary to command public confidence in this crisis, it must reform its internal organization.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Jan. 6 -- One of the largest-scale pincer movements of the Russian war -- which already has surpassed itself several times for the use of the superlative -- appeared to be under way this morning on the central front.

Active purchasing of women's Spring apparel got under way here yesterday with the arrival of many ready-to-wear buyers on their initial purchasing trip for the coming season. They reported as an encouraging, and perhaps significant development, the improvement during the last ten days in retail sales of seasonal apparel, particularly coats, together with interest in advance Spring styles.
BERLIN, Jan. 5 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's High Command communique said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Elevation of the United States diplomatic missions in Paraguay, Ecuador and Bolivia from the rank of legation to that of embassy was announced today by the State Department. As a result of this action, all heads of United States delegations in South America will have ambassadorial rank.
The team that will open Columbia's basketball season tonight is one of the Lions' least experienced in many years, but Coach Paul Mooney is not downcast. As a matter of fact, he seems proud.

HONOLULU, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A 1,500-ton United States destroyer with four young ensigns as her officers put to sea under withering fire during the Japanese attack Dec. 7 on Pearl Harbor, helped shoot down at least four of the invading planes and depth-bombed two enemy submarines.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 6 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in the United States) -- The American-Filipino Army, taking advantage of the big guns of Corregidor fortress, is putting up its "last resistance" against the Japanese on the east coast of the Bataan peninsula, military dispatches from the Philippines war front said today.

Gone is the day when an astronomer glued his eye to a telescope and scanned the skies at random, hoping for a new star to swim into his ken. Astronomers are now as systematic and specialized as business men. The camera has taken the place of the eye. But what kind of camera?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Roosevelt will have a "siren suit" like the one "demonstrated" last week at the White House by Prime Minister Churchill if Mrs. Roosevelt, who is planning it, is allowed by the Office of Production Management the wool and the zippers required for making it.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The Free French National Committee issued a statement today .saying it had "made a preliminary study of conditions under which France could eventually adhere" to the Washington declaration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- In the first Senate speech of the new session, Senator McCarran of Nevada charged today that "an organized propaganda drive" was in progress to "prejudice" any legislation looking to the establishment of a separate and independent air force.

Charley (Lulu) Costantino, unbeaten East Sider, ran his string of victories to forty-nine last night when he easily outpointed Nat Litfin of the Bronx in the star bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace. Costantino scaled 131 3/4 pounds, Litfin 136. About 2,500 saw the show.

Agreements for the coordination of volunteer services have been reached between the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Offices, a branch of the Office of Civilian Defense, and a large number of social and civic organizations, including the American Women's Voluntary Services, the Y.M.C.A., the League of Women's Voters, the United Hospital Fund and the American Women's Association, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress on the state of the Union, starting at 12:30 Eastern standard time tomorrow, will be broadcast to the world.

The first unit in the apartment-house development known as Terrace Gardens at Avenue I and East Seventeenth Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn is now entirely rented, reports Frank J. Carroll, manager of Friedberg Co., agents for the buildings.

A tract of ten acres of land in Cedar Grove, near Montclair, N.J., has been purchased by J.M. Felson, New York architect, and will be improved with an initial fifty defense homes selling for about $6,000 to $6,750. The Jenkins Realty Company has been appointed sales agent.

The foxhunters turned out, in force on Sunday, and a number evidently ran the dogs yesterday morning, for we had a half-dozen calls from Connecticut and the Catskills reporting the best runs of the season.

Progress toward gaining "full equality in the life of the nation" for the American Negro was reported yesterday afternoon at the annual meeting at 69 Fifth Avenue of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which has a membership composed of 45,000 Negroes.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 5 -- Miss Elizabeth Pearson, the defending champion, and Miss Hope Knowles, both from Philadelphia, had little trouble today reaching the final round of the twelfth annual New York State squash racquets championship, being contested on the courts of the Rockaway Hunting Club.

"Dim-outs" of street lights in three trial areas -- on Fifth and Eighth Avenues in Manhattan and on Union Turnpike in Queens -- were announced yesterday by Patrick Quilty, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue warned taxpayers yesterday to read carefully all instructions on tax forms before making out their Federal returns. Because of the more complicated tax structure this year, taxpayers were advised to make their returns early.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Dec. 31 aggregated $12,442,000,000.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 17 per cent for the week ended Jan. 3, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week, including the extra selling day before Christmas, the bank had reported a gain of 31 per cent over the preceding year.
When automobile tire rationing went into effect throughout the nation yesterday the local boards in New York City received only twenty-six applications and approved of but three.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Tire and tube rationing, set up in twenty-five days and called by some defense officials "the biggest organizing job since the draft," began functioning today in a majority of the nation's counties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Congressmen were eagerly awaiting President Roosevelt's annual message tomorrow in belief that he might disclose some details of the grand strategy worked out for defeat of the Axis.

The publishers of Stefan Lorant's "Lincoln: His Life in Photographs" (Duell, Sloan Pearce) issue a report on the early copies of the first edition of the book. President Roosevelt received the first of the limited edition and the Lincoln Memorial University at Harrogate Tenn., the second.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Although operations in the grain markets were somewhat restricted today, wheat, corn and rye sold at new high prices since last October in the early trading, with oats at a new high since September as the result of an accumulation of buying orders.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 -- (AP) -- Staging a stretch rush that proved the undoing of several faster beginners, J.W. Rodgers's 4-year-old filly Lady Waterloo easily won the St. Augustine purse, a six-furlong dash, at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Seventy-seventh Congress convened in its second session today, organized, and prepared to meet in joint session tomorrow at 12:30 to hear President Roosevelt's "State of the Union" message in which he is expected to give an account of the war to date and to state the major aims of the Allied powers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- An order of the Interstate Commerce Commission that changes the methods of making rates for transportation of grain through principal Midwestern milling centers was sustained by the Supreme Court today in an opinion by Justice Frankfurter. All the tribunal, except Justice Roberts, concurred.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Prices of hogs advanced today to new high prices for the last few months as Eastern shippers provided local killers with keen competition for available offerings. Best hogs brought $11.75 a hundred pounds, or 15 cents above the previous high. The close was on gains of 15 to 25 cents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- War expenditures were increased more than $113,000,000 a week immediately after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and are still rising rapidly, said officials of the Office of Production Management today.

The American Safety Razor Company will soon introduce a new double-edge blade to fit standard double-edge razors, under the name Star, Milton Dammann, president of the company, announced yesterday. The company has been selling only single-edge blades since 1880 and this new blade marks a departure in the company's policy.

A black cocker spaniel, Heartsease Heritage by name, yesterday was awarded the title of best in show to cap the twenty-fifth specialty exhibition of the American Spaniel Club at the Hotel Roosevelt. A great gathering of spaniel enthusiasts cheered the victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The National Labor Relations Board was within its authority in refusing to order an election to determine bargaining agents for workers in the P. Lorillard Company plant after the board had already chosen a bargaining agent, the Supreme Court held today in a memorandum opinion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed Monday, Feb. 16, as the date for registration for military service of all men in the United States, Hawaii, Alaska and Puerto Rico between the ages of 20 and 44, inclusive.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops struggling to escape from a death trap north of Changsha, where they already have suffered casualties estimated at more than 50,000, were caught today in a rainstorm, which bogged them down in mud and deprived them of air support, front dispatches reported.

Last Sunday's football game between the Bears and the National League All-Stars netted $26,654.84 for the Navy Relief Society. A check for that sum was delivered yesterday to Rear Admiral Adolphus J. Andrews by Tim and Wellington Mara of the Giants, who promoted the contest after war conditions had made necessary its transfer from Los Angeles.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 -- Ann Sheridan and George Brent were married here tonight in a surprise ceremony. Plans for the wedding were kept secret until after Judge Richard P. Robbins of the County Court had performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's sister, Mrs. Sam H. Harris, widow of the producer.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Bombay Clipper," a Universal mystery melodrama, which is scheduled to arrive at the Rialto on Saturday. William Gargan, Irene Hervey, Maria Montez, Lloyd Corrigan, Mary Gordon and Charles Lang head the picture's cast. . . .
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Widescale augmentation of facilities for building ships and supplying ordnance, and for personnel to man the growing sea power was asked of the Congress by the Navy today.

The Bell System experienced last year the largest telephone gain in its history. The American Telephone and Telegraph announced yesterday the system had a net increase of 1,361,000 telephones in service. The largest previous annual gain was 950, 000 instruments in 1940.

Ruth Diehl, New York soprano who appeared on the National Music League's first "artists of the future" program in 1940, last night gave her first solo recital at Town Hall. Her interesting program included an aria from Gluck's "Iphigenia en Tauride," and one from Bach's "Wedding" Cantata, lieder by Schubert folksongs of the British Isles, and four songs by Grieg.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull told his press conference today that reports of "especially harsh" treatment of American civilians by Japanese invaders of Manila were such a monstrous thing that he wanted more details before discussing the matter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The sentences of three men convicted of income tax evasion in connection with the publication of racing sheets by Moe Annenberg, Philadelphia newspaper publisher, were unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court today in an opinion by Justice Black,
Minority members of the City Council designated Mrs. Genevieve B. Earle yesterday as minority leader for the next two years. She held that post in 1940 and 1941.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 5 -- General Golubeff, whom the Council of the Supreme Soviet has honored as one of the most distinguished defenders of Moscow, writing in the government newspaper Izvestia today, says:

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor resulted in "severe types" of casualties, but military and civilian doctors in Honolulu were able to treat the injured quickly and public and military morale was unimpaired.

A general price increase of 5 per cent was announced by manufacturers of wool floor coverings yesterday at the opening of the annual market week here. However, buyers were less concerned about prices than about the expected curtailment of production due to the curb on wool use and the tighter deliveries that will result.

The Chase National Bank and the National City Bank, the world's largest and second largest commercial banks, respectively, reported yesterday their condition statements, as of Dec. 31. Both showed declines in deposits and in total resources for the final quarter of the year, as did the third largest bank, the Guaranty Trust Company, which had previously reported.

PINKHAM NOTCH, N.H., Jan. 5 -- This White Mountain National Forest skiing paradise, known throughout the world for both its alpine and wooded terrain, was covered today with a fluffy white blanket that extended from twenty-two inches in depth in the valley to thirty at the Hermit Lake shelter.
The Japanese were trying yesterday to extend their incompleted conquest of the Philippine Archipelago, and they were suffering losses.

To the tune of airplanes whirring overhead, fourteen members of the Brooklyn division of the American Women's Voluntary Services tackled yesterday the first day of a regular schedule at Floyd Bennett Field.
After advancing early yesterday to new high prices for the current movement, the cotton market eased under profit-taking and hedging operations.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The intention of Governor Lehman and the legislative leaders to avoid any possible wholesale assault on social legislation, under the guise of an emergency created by national defense, has already been manifested.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Roosevelt proclaimed Feb. 16 as the date for registration for military service of men 20 to 44, inclusive, conferred with legislative leaders from Capitol Hill and with Secretary Knox and Attorney General Biddle. He worked on the message to Congress he will deliver tomorrow.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midday communique broadcast today said:

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Mme. Nikolayeva, a member of the Russian trade union delegation visiting Britain, told workers today at a factory in the Midlands where tanks are being made for Russia that "our attacks are the beginning of the end" and that no force in the world could break the unified forces of Britain, the United States and Russia."

The city-wide drive for $7,330,000 sought by the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York was opened officially yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, who read a proclamation on the steps of City Hall urging every one to support the campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Senate investigation into alleged propaganda in motion pictures has been suspended and the special subcommittee conducting it dissolved "in the interest of national unity."

LONDON, Jan. 5 (U.P.) -- Japanese spearheads, in advances down the west coast of Malaya, have reached the mouths of the Bernam and Perak Rivers, seventy miles northwest of Kuala Lumpur, vital communications center, and British Imperials are hurriedly piling up defenses in preparation for a siege of Singapore, military commentators said today.

Wreathed in smiles and happy to get home to their snow-capped campus, Fordham's football warriors returned last night from their successful visit to New Orleans, where they defeated Missouri in the Sugar Bowl classic.

ST. PIERRE-MIQUELON, Jan. 5 -- Free French investigators who have been toiling through the great mass of government archives here discovered today a bundle of confidential telegrams sent by the former administrator, Baron G. de Bournat, to the Minister of Colonies in Vichy, telling a connected inside story of events here under the Petain regime in the troubled period of the latter half of 1940.

The motors section snapped a lagging stock market out of an uncertain course yesterday on the Stock Exchange as Washington prepared to make the automotive industry the arsenal of the war. Ready to award armament contracts of $5,000,000,000 more to the motor car makers, which would practically double the current backlog of defense orders for the industry, Federal coordinators went ahead with the task of gearing other industries of the nation to the all-out effort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 31: Decreases of $56,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans; $76,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills, $56,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds, and $344,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, an increase of $72,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

Former District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, Thomas Curran, New York County Republican leader, and Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel were among the speakers yesterday in the County Court House in Foley Square at a ceremony marking the formal induction of Supreme Court Justice William C. Hecht Jr., former secretary to Justice Wasservogel.

Because New York City's industries are not equipped to handle large defense orders, and many of the consumer goods industries here are encountering increasing difficulties in obtaining materials needed for continued operation, the city is facing "a very serious situation,'' according to reports received yesterday at a meeting of the Federal Advisory Council for this region.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 5 -- German artillery and dive-bombers completely destroyed the Serbian resort of Banja Bachka during an attack three days ago against the suspected headquarters of General Draja Mikhailovitch, Commander in Chief of the Royalist Serbian Armies, according to dispatches received in foreign military intelligence circles here today.

The city's evening traffic flowed more freely last night, particularly in the rush hours, after 600 policemen carrying 100,000 summonses had grimly worked side streets and avenues all day to enforce wartime parking restrictions.
A national organization of independent ship workers' unions between Bath, Me., and Newport News, Va., was created and officers elected at a meeting yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A railroad economics expert declared today that the proposed 10 per cent increase in freight and passenger rates was "absolutely essential" if the railroads were to continue to do their part in winning the war.
Sales of a number of business properties, including loft buildings, taxpayers and a factory, in Manhattan and the Bronx, were reported yesterday.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Jan. 5 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- A $10,000,000 expansion program will be launched by the Standard Oil Company at its Lago plant on the island of Aruba in the Netherland West Indies, it was announced today.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 5 -- Joseph Harvey Ladew, member of a family prominent in society and yachting circles and in the early industrial life of the North Shore, burned to death this morning on his eighty-six-foot schooner Columbia, moored in Glen Cove Creek off Hempstead Harbor, on which he made his home the year around.

An annual increase of $1,000,000 in payments to hospitals on behalf of subscribers to the three-cents-a-day hospitalization insurance plan was announced here yesterday by Dr. S.S. Goldwater, president of the Associated Hospital Service of New York and former Commissioner of Hospitals.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- While lowering skies and cold rain in the Agedabia area of Libya helped to keep both sides quiet there, British planes and artillery began yesterday to give the Halfaya area the same sort of pounding that preceded the successful attack on Bardia.

Vultee Aircraft, Inc., in a preliminary statement covering the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 and published yesterday, estimated the net profit before audit and year-end adjustments at approximately $2,900,000 after provision for estimated Federal income and excess profits taxes.

Victor Borella and John P. Hanson have been elected to the board of directors of Rockefeller Center, Inc., the corporation announced yesterday. Mr. Hanson is controller of Rockefeller Center, Inc., and Mr. Borella is director of personnel and industrial relations for the company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- By a concerted attack which, in dictator countries with a controlled press, would be thought to be following a planned "party line," industry -- especially the automotive industry -- the OPM and Mr. Knudsen are being assigned chief blame for the business-as-usual boom of 1940 and 1941 and the consequent deficiency in war production.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- Ending a two-year investigation of Yonkers municipal affairs, a Westchester County grand jury filed in Supreme Court today a presentment charging that several Yonkers officials had been guilty of slipshod bookkeeping, lax handling of finances, tax favoritism and evasion of competitive bidding laws.

HONOLULU, Jan. 5 -- A Tokyo claim today that a United States warship and military objectives ashore at Hilo, Hawaii, had been hit in a surprise attack by Japanese warships on Dee. 31 was greeted with derision in both military and civil circles here.

Probably for the first time yesterday a group of women found themselves laughing at the mention of mustard gas, identified as "hot stuff" that has the odor of garlic, and at ethyldichlorarsine, which became known as "enemy's delight" in a lecture by Fireman Edward F. Kehoe.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Governor Charles Edison accepted today an invitation extended by Republican majority leaders to deliver his annual message in person at the opening session of the 1942 Legislature next Tuesday. The Governor appeared before the Senate and Assembly a year ago to give his inaugural address.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Heavy United States Army bombers that appeared surprisingly from an unnamed base today scored three direct hits on a Japanese battleship, sank a Japanese destroyer and damaged other vessels operating off Davao, the principal port of Mindanao, at the southern end of the Philippine Islands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The resignation of Nathan Straus as administrator of the United States Housing Authority has been received by President Roosevelt. It has not been accepted by the President and there is no official confirmation of its submission, no announcement having been made at the White House or by Mr. Straus, who refuses to discuss the subject.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The question of who should apply wartime curbs to farm prices split the Senate today as it prepared to open debate tomorrow on the broad price control measure.

Large industrial users of sugar said yesterday that they have been restricting deliveries of their products to distributors to the levels of 1940. This is in line with the OPM order of Dec. 13, 1941, which restricts deliveries of sugar to the industrial users themselves to the rate prevailing in the previous year, based on the individual sugar buyers' record of inventory purchases during that period.

Reflecting the increased buying of retail merchandise last month, the volume of sales reported yesterday by several chain store companies for December and twelve months rose substantially over the corresponding periods of 1940.

The news trickling out of Vichy is like a thin stream of lava breaking through the walls of a volcano in eruption. The first thought it suggests is that so far Hitler has really won nothing in this war. Wherever he stands in Europe, from Norway to Greece, he has to keep on fighting day after day to reconquer the conquered.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 6 -- According to reliable information, 300 persons are dying of spotted typhus daily in the Warsaw ghetto, which is one of the worst centers of the epidemic now raging throughout Poland, especially in camps for Russian prisoners of war.

Ice fishing, according to letters received recently, is enjoying something of a revival this season, and many anglers who find it impossible to make their annual trips to southern waters due to the war are turning to this sport as a substitute and finding it good.

GREENPORT, L.I., Jan. 6 -When thirty-five employes of the Greenport Basin and Construction Company, which is building ships for the government, appeared at a National Labor Relations Board hearing in Village Hall here today, Howard Myers, trial examiner, feeling that they should be at work on naval craft needed by the government, virtually ordered them to leave.
Mayor La Guardia is expected to address the new City Council on the state of the city when it holds the first meeting of its two-year term in City Hall at noon today.
