WASHINCTON, Jan. 6 -- Reversing a pre-war Federal labor policy, the Navy turned back today to the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company its Kearny, N.J., shipyard without requiring acceptance of a National Defense Mediation Board decision under which the company would have given the C.I.O. Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers a "maintenance of membership clause."

HONOLULU, Jan. 6 -- "More than twenty" Japanese planes were shot down by anti-aircraft fire from Pacific Fleet ships in Pearl Harbor during the attack on Dec. 7, the fleet press office announced today in the first disclosure of Japanese casualties at the Navy's hands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, appointed Walter Gellhorn, Associate Professor at Columbia University Law School, today as regional attorney at New York. He also will be an assistant general counsel of the OPA.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Another women's swimming record fell tonight before Miss Maria Lenk, 20-year-old Brazilian, when she clipped 16.4 seconds off the American short course mark in the 440-yard breast-stroke.

The taxpayer's obligation to file a return covering income received in 1941 is based upon gross income, the Bureau of Internal Revenue pointed out yesterday, reminding individuals that the 1941 Revenue Act lowered the exemption of single persons from $800 to $750 and that of married persons and heads of families from $2,000 to $1,500.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 (AP) -- More than 1,000 accidents within the jurisdiction of New York's new safety-responsibility law have been reported in the first week of the act's operation, Carroll E. Mealey, State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, said today.

The four-story, twenty-family apartment house at 55 Hague Street, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company, trustee, to the Merwal Corporation, Rose Willing, president. Sale was for a consideration of $26,000, the seller taking back a purchase money mortgage for $19,500.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art presented "Theophilus," a thirteenth-century miracle play by Rutebeuf of Paris, yesterday afternoon at The Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park. This setting for the production was in keeping with the old drama which interested an invited audience.

Active cotton futures contracts lost as much as 20 points, or $1 a bale, in the early trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, then rallied, principally on New Orleans buying, to close at net gains of 4 to 11 points.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- Six Mennonite youths were convicted in Federal District Court today on a charge of failing to report to work camps for conscientious objectors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- Orson Welles's third film production, "Journey Into Fear," went before the cameras this morning at RKO with Dolores Del Rio playing the feminine lead opposite Joseph Cotten and Norman Foster, a former actor, directing.

Cotton is destined to play an increasing role in women's fashions during wartime, taking the place of other materials allocated for war purposes, Miss Virginia Jewel, fashion director of the Cotton-Textile Institute, told a group of merchandise managers, store buyers and students last night at a meeting at the Hotel McAlpin sponsored by the Laboratory Institute of Merchandising.

In one of New York's most important changes of a racing official in years, Francis Dunne was named State Racing Commission steward yesterday to succeed Marshall Cassidy. The formal announcement from the commission cleared up rumors current since the close of the season here that there would be a shakeup.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The people of Great Britain welcomed today President Roosevelt's message to Congress for the confidence it reflected and the promises it contained, for its breathtaking scope and its sweep. Even here the President's plans were a surprise, exceeding as they did the expectations of most persons.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Dispatches from Shanghai, quoting Japanese military information from the Philippines, said today that the "final annihilation" of American troops in the Bataan peninsula was at hand.
Construction work is the first field of realty activity in Manhattan to feel the full effect of the nation's war effort.

The firm of E.P. Dutton made known yesterday its plans for the next five months, listing some three dozen general or semi-specialized books and a number of juveniles. One of the leading titles is John E. Washington's "They Knew Lincoln," a portrait gathered from out-of-the-way persons who had memories of Lincoln.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt seemed to be predicting the reaction of the joint session of Congress today to his momentous speech on the state of Union when he spoke of "the mood of quiet, grim resolution which here prevails." And so it was.

The State Department's announcement that our legations to Paraguay, Ecuador and Bolivia are to be raised to ambassadorial rank is a graceful gesture, especially since it comes shortly before the meeting of Pan-American foreign Ministers at Rio de Janeiro.

The First National Bank and Trust Company of Minneapolis reported, as of Dec. 31, total deposits of $179,816,269 and total assets of $196,859,881, compared, respectively, with $172,743,800 and $189,499,893 on Sept. 24.

It is not easy to assume the role of a prophet in war time. Situations change too rapidly for that. Present indications, however, are that there will be no curtailment of any of its sports by the Amateur Athletic Union or any of its forty-one district associations.

KEARNY, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Rear Admiral Harold G. Bowen left the Federal shipyard here at 5 P.M. today "for good," after a hectic afternoon spent in tasks involving the transfer of managerial operations at the plant. With him went the few Naval aides and executives who had been working with him since the Navy seized the yard last August.
HAVANA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Cuba looks for a real boom in 1942, based chiefly on United States purchase of her entire crop of sugar, the biggest cash product of the island.
Three of the world's greatest players of racquet games will take part in an exhibition for the benefit of the Red Cross on Saturday at the Racquet and Tennis Club on Park Avenue.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- The Japanese reported today that the British defense line in Malaya was collapsing from Kuantan, on the east coast, to the southern end of Perak State, in the west.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 6 -Under the headline "War Difficulties Have Shattered German Nerves," the Svenska Dagbladet publishes a colorful report from its Berlin correspondent on the gradual loss of feeling of solidarity among the civilians and the growing irritability often amounting to downright rudeness.

Things being as they are in the world just now, the Theatre Guild has been obliging enough to put on a light and completely entertaining play. "Papa Is All" is what they are calling it in Pennsylvania Dutch idiom, and it was acted at headquarters last evening.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Japanese bombers attacked Singapore just before dusk today, but ran afoul a strong force of British fighters and were dispersed before they could do any serious damage.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market last week totaled 1,120, compared with 247 in the previous week and 1,199 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 941 as against 198 for last Tuesday.

Lehman Corporation closed the half-year ended Dec. 31 with net asset value of $26.74 a share on the 1,988,277 shares of stock in the hands of the public, Robert Lehman, president, reported yesterday. This compared with $28.77 at the end of June.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Sharp restrictions in the use of ethyl and of methyl alcohol were imposed today by the Office of Production Management. Methyl alcohol, used widely in the manufacture of antifreeze was banned entirely for that purpose, the only exception being for the production of anti-freeze for use in vehicles of the armed forces and for defense purposes.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The stock markets were cheerful again today in most sections, with renewed investment buying reported in the gilt-edge issues. The industrials showed further improvement. British Celanese and United Molasses were strong features. Woolworth's strengthened on the expectations that the final dividend will be maintained.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Acquisition of the former David Luke estate here for development into a new home for the Tarrytown Hospital was announced today by Frederick P. King, president of the property, but Mr. King said the mile south of the present hospital buildings, embraces a large mansion on twenty-one acres between the Hudson River and Broadway.
The one thing that Frank Paganini, 39-year-old ex-convict, did not lack when he attempted two Bronx hold-ups yesterday was imagination.

A new means of easing the way for frequent travelers to comply with the enemy alien travel regulations was introduced yesterday by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa in the Southern District of New York, which includes Manhattan and the Bronx but not the other boroughs.

While commodity prices will advance this year inflation can definitely be avoided, Dr. Marcus Nadler, consulting economist to the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and Professor of Finance at New York University, declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The trucking industry served notice at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing today of its intention to ask for higher rates comparable to any increase authorized for railroads and water carriers.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 6 -Mr. and Mrs. LeRay Berdeau gave a dinner at their villa tonight. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont, Commodore and Mrs. Louis Beaumont, Mrs. Elisha Dyer Hubbard, Mrs. Charles O. Parsons, Miss Jane Thomas, Arthur Bradley Campbell, Charles Monroe and George Henry Payne.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Members of the National Retail Furniture Association devoted a series of clinic discussions today to the problem of doing business during a wartime economy and elected Louis S. Bing, Cleveland, president for the coming year.

With the coldest weeks of the Russian Winter now about to start, Adolf Hitler's armies were still retreating along the Central Russian front yesterday and still hard-pressed in north and south after almost six weeks of defensive fighting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Automobile management and labor were reported deadlocked tonight on the extent of labor's participation in directing the task of converting auto factories to turn out more than $5,000,000,000 worth of war materials this year.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 6 -- Isolated cases of spotted typhus, which are reported to have broken out in Spain, Finland, Yugoslavia, Rumania, the Netherlands and Belgium, are being closely watched by health authorities in the various occupied countries for any signs of developing into an epidemic.

Pointing out that the Boy Scouts of the city constitute an important element in the civilian defense program, J. Stewart Baker, president of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York, Inc., announced yesterday that the 1942 campaign for $325,000 for the Scout organization would be started Jan. 20.

Increasing numbers of automobile owners came forward yesterday on the second day of Federal tire rationing to make application for new casings. Harold W. McGraw, Federal Tire Rationing Administrator, whose offices are at 330 West Forty-second Street, announced that the Local Tire Rationing Boards of the five boroughs had received seventy-two certified applications as against twenty-seven on Monday.

If the reaction of the securities conscious public, as expressed through the stock market yesterday, to President Roosevelt's staggering war program was anything more than the acceptance of the obvious and natural pattern for the United States, it was certainly effectively hidden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -Senator W. Lee O'Daniel, Democrat, Texas, urged "voluntary" prohibition today against alcoholic beverages for the duration of the war and a mandatory ban on their sale in the vicinity of Army and Navy posts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Blue food stamps added about $8,800,000 worth of farm products to the diets of about 3,300,000 persons eligible to receive public assistance during November, the Department of Agriculture stated today in its monthly report on the Food Stamp program.

Katherine Eyman, a pianist, living in East Orange, N.J., gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The romantic works on her program were Schubert's Valses Nobles, Beethoven's Sonata in D major, Op. 10, No. 3, Schumann's Fantasiestuecke and four short Chopin pieces.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Yankees breezed past the Dodgers, four games to one, in the 1941 world series, but the National League champions had just as much all-star talent, in the collective opinion of the Baseball Writers Association of America.

An out-and-out bid for the attention of men was made yesterday when Walter Florell launched his new Spring and early Summer millinery collection. His hats were definitely created to "please the boys," said the milliner in announcing the show.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Russian Embassy in Washington today received the following cabled message from Colonel 1Viikhail Tolchenoff in Kuibyshev:

CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 -- Construction of United States merchant ships not only will help to bring about the defeat of the Axis powers, but will aid in the reestablishment of peace and commerce and enable the United States to maintain its place among the seafaring nations of the world, Captain Howard L. Vickery, U.S.N., a member of the United States Maritime Commission, declared today.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, Outside Agedabia, Libya, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- A German panzer unit and Italian infantry, believed to have been bolstered by reinforcements, were still holding out today in this little town on the Bengazi-Tripoli road.

It was reported on good authority yesterday in financial circles that the coupon rates on the forthcoming $27,500,000 financing by Schenley Distillers Corporation will be 3 1/4 per cent for the $10,000,000 of ten-year debentures and 4 per cent for the $17,500,000 of fifteenyear debentures.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Jan. 7 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Red Army has retaken 57Z villages and killed 10,000 Germans in five days, and the big counter-offensive still is rolling westward, the Russians announced today.

According to the press releases by the Treasury Department in connection with the defense savings payroll allotment plan, "The employer holds these funds in a separate bank account and delivers a bond to the employe each time his allotments accumulate to a sufficient amount."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Scattered commission house and mill buying lifted wheat prices around 1 cent a bushel at one time today on the Board of Trade, but when new buying failed to appear on the upturn professional traders turned to the selling side and caused a reaction.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Suspension of New York labor laws to speed war production is "purely and exclusively" an emergency measure, Governor Lehman assured State Federation of Labor representatives today at a labor-defense rally.

A minority stockholders suit to restrain directors of the New York City Interborough Railway Company, a street railway subsidiary of the Third Avenue Railway Company, from holding a stockholders' meeting and taking other steps to carry out a "declaration of abandonment" of street car lines for bus operation was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Dr. John R. Steelman, Federal Conciliation Director, tonight requested "uninterrupted production" at the Ryan Aeronautical Company plant in San Diego, Calif., pending a special conciliation hearing here Monday on a union wage dispute.

Women should pay less attention to the "glamorous" side of civilian defense and devote more of their time to the "homey" side, which might affect more directly the lives of men in the armed forces, Mrs. Irwin Bussing, vice chairman of the Volunteer Information Center for Civilian Defense of Brooklyn, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the Central Branch of the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A., 30 Third Avenue.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Pursuing a general hands-off policy in regard to new statutes, the National Collegiate Football Rules Committee moved to take a few kinks out of the rules and adjourned its annual meeting tonight.

" Louisiana Purchase," which enters its second week at the Paramount today, has grossed more than $93,000 and has been attended by close to 200,000 persons during its first week, the theatre reported yesterday. The Paramount musical drew $13,000 more than "Love Thy Neighbor," last year's New Year attraction, which held the previous record for the theatre.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey announced yesterday that it would spend $15,000,000 in 1942 for new equipment, extensions and replacements for its subsidiary operating companies. In addition to this sum, $5,244,400 was appropriated for electric power construction in July of last year, in advance of the 1942 budget and supplementing the 1941 budget of $28,000,000.

Two contributions yesterday to the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York totaled $310,000, it was announced by Leon Fraser, chairman of the city-wide drive to raise $7,330,000 toward the national goal of $50,000,000. Mr. Fraser also reported that at least 500,000 civilian evacuees in the Philippines will look to the Red Cross for relief and assistance.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Great Britain imported from Canada during the first eleven months of 1941 goods valued at $609,800,000, according to J.A. MacKinnon, Canadian Minister of Trade and Commerce. The figures for the comparable periods were $477,150,000 in 1940 and $298,800,000 in 1939.

Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway have arrived from Pooks Hill, Bethesda, Md., accompaniel by Colonel Nikolai Ostgaard and the Countess Ragni Ostgaard, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 6 -- Rear Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, retired, who is on a trip for Secretary Knox, inspected the Electric Boat Company's shipbuilding plant today and said that his report would make the Navy Secretary's face "turn red -- with pride."
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to the reassembled Seventy-seventh Congress on the state of the Union, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Soviet Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff formally charged today, Radio Moscow announced, that German authorities had perpetrated massacres, villainy and bestial outrages in the Soviet territories they had occupied.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A three-goal scoring burst during the last six minutes of the first period enabled the Boston Bruins to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3-2, and regain the undisputed National Hockey League lead tonight before 10,800 at the Boston Garden.

Explaining that he wanted his story to serve as a warning to other cab drivers in the city, Max Friedman, 33 years old, a cab driver of 40 Bristol Street, Brooklyn, told reporters at Brooklyn Police Headquarters yesterday that he had been shot at twice by a soldier on waterfront guard duty after he had driven past Pier 16, near Montague Street, without hearing an order to halt.

The first all-metropolitan college basketball double-header of the campaign will be presented tonight at Madison Square Garden, with St. John's opposing City College and Manhattan clashing with N.Y.U. C.C.N.Y., winner of the local honors last season, and N.Y.U. are favored to emerge on top, although brisk competition is expected in both encounters.

OTTAWA, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress was listened to throughout Canada with eager interest, for its immense promise redeemed the disappointment that has attended performance during this first month since the United States entered the war.

Recruiting in the armed forces here dipped yesterday, although enlistments still surpassed longtime peace records. In some cases the number of applicants was half as lareg as on the previous day, but in others the "backlog" of applicants who had been waiting for harried recruiting officials to swear them into service increased actual enlistment figures over the day before.

Close to 100,000,000 lines of advertising were carried in 1941 by the eight leading New York newspapers, according to a compilation yesterday, based on Media Records figures. The actual total was 99,582,508 lines, a gain of 1.2 per cent over the 98,416,919 lines carried in 1940.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Comment of members of Congress on President Roosevelt's war message today was unanimously favorable and generally enthusiastic, although there was an undercurrent of skepticism on the ability of the country to turn out the tremendous amounts of fighting equipment according to the time schedule set up by the President.

At a meeting of the board of directors of the investment banking concern of Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., yesterday, Joseph P. Ripley was advanced to the office of chairman and Pierpont V. Davis was promoted to president of the company.

The Parisian group of French Nazis has suddenly become intensely vocal about its disappointment over the failure of Marshal Petain to achieve a perfect partnership with Hitler. This shrill group in Paris is warning that unless Vichy collaborates fully with the Nazis in their efforts to clamp their "New Order" upon Europe, Hitler's patience again will be exhausted and he will occupy French Africa.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- The executive committee of the City Manager League of Yonkers made public today a resolution it has adopted criticizing severely Mayor Benjamin F. Barnes for "reversing his word for good government by embracing machine politics."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The attack by American heavy bombers yesterday on Japanese warships off Davao, southern tip of the Philippines, when three direct bomb hits were scored on a battleship and at least one destroyer was sunk, probably caused even greater damage than was first reported, the War Department announced tonight.
TOKYO, Jan. 6 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Army Section of Imperial Headquarters said in a communique today:

Signalizing the strongly indicated revival of consumer interest in home sewing during the present emergency, the first piece goods session to be held in six or seven years by the National Retail Dry Goods Association will feature the annual convention of that organization next week at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was announced yesterday by T.L. Blanke, manager of the merchandising division.

In explanation of the severe restrictions that have been put on rubber, tin and other strategic materials from the Far East, the National Industrial Conference Board yesterday issued statistics to show that current stocks amount to little more than a normal year's supply.

Columbia College will break a ten-year precedent in its initial step to speed wartime training of students by admitting a freshman class at the beginning of the Spring term on Feb. 2, it was announced yesterday by Dean Herbert E. Hawkes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- How the crew and five passengers of a Norwegian freighter, torpedoed by an unseen submarine, were tossed about in lifeboats throughout a dark night before being rescued by an American warship was related here tonight when an undisclosed number of evacuees arrived at a San Francisco pier.
KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 6 -- Thirty or forty cropped-head boys and pig-tailed girls gazed from their kindergarten desks at a teacher who sifted sand through her fingers as she said:

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- On the eve of the opening of the Legislature, the question of State revenues and possible income tax modification came sharply to the fore. While Governor Lehman, in his annual message to a joint session, is expected to concentrate on the State's place in national defense, bills changing the State income tax and lessening the amount due have been prepared and are scheduled for immediate introduction.

Yesterday, second day of the wartime drive against overtime and other illegal parking, found New York streets and avenues strangely free of cluttering motor cars. Six hundred policemen working in freezing temperatures relentlessly tagged offending vehicles, but the cars were comparatively few and far between.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Jan. 6-- Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia came from behind with a hard smashing game to win the New York State squash racquets championship today at the Rockaway Hunting Club. She defeated the defending champion, Miss Elizabeth Pearson, also from Philadelphia, 13 -- 15, 15 -- 13, 6 -- 15, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 10.

Patrick Pryor, 57-year-old maitre d'hotel at the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Forty-third Street, and familiarly known to guests as Pat, will celebrate thirty-five years of service at the hotel on Saturday by welcoming the one-millionth guest.

Coordination of volunteer services between the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Offices, a branch of the Office of Civilian Defense, and the American Women's Voluntary Services was characterized yesterday by Mrs. Isabella Greenway King, chairman of the board of directors of A.W.V.S., as "a first step toward the real cooperation that will allow fulfillment of universal service."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., was issued today as follows:

SINGAPORE, Jan. 6 -- The Tokyo radio's wild exaggeration of the bombing of Singapore has irritated and amused the residents of this city. The latest claims of Tokyo are that all important government buildings are heavily damaged and that one is split in two.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 6 -- Plans for extending the program of the National League of Women Voters in relation to the new problems facing the government were discussed today at a meeting of the National League's board of directors, as a prelude to the two-day emergency meeting of the general council which opens tomorrow.

President Roosevelt delivered to Congress yesterday his annual message "on the state of the Union," but the Union of which he spoke has now become an alliance of twenty-six sovereign nations pledged to a common purpose. In the whole course of the President's message there was not a word of advice or of warning, an expression of faith or of hope, which does not apply with equal force to every member of this grand alliance.

John Milton Claypool, nonagenarian commander-in-chief of the United Confederate Veterans and an eager volunteer for civilian defense work, arrived in New York yesterday with "still a lot of pep left to do anything I can for Uncle Sam."

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and Police Commissioner Valentine disclosed yesterday that prosecutors presenting evidence in the courts and the 18,000 members of the uniformed and detective forces of the city had been ordered to deal "unrelentingly" with criminals who attempted to take advantage of wartime conditions and blackouts.

A taffy pull -- that simple pleasure that smacks of the Mauve Decade -- is a pleasant thing to revive in the friendly warmth of the kitchen after a chilly skating party. And it's the sort of not-too-strenuous labor that bears rich, rewarding results.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (From Russian zroadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau's midday communique today said:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 6 -- The government announced major mobilization for war today with the statement that all the remaining unmarried men in the 18 to 46 age groups and all childless married men would be drafted for army service.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 6 -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell will direct the Allied war against Japan from a headquarters on the island of Java, in the Netherlands Indies archipelago, which forms the strategic gateway of the Allied life-line between the Pacific and Indian Oceans, it was announced officially tonight.

The task of the physical educator today is to "toughen up a soft generation," Dr. Jay B. Nash, chairman of the New York University department of physical education and health, declared yesterday in announcing that the university would emphasize war emergency needs in its annual "Winter Summer school" for physical educators.

Detailed plans for the safeguarding of the vital lines of transport that bring food, fuel and other supplies to the 12,000,000 people of the metropolitan area have been worked out by the Metropolitan Defense Transport Committee, it was announced yesterday by its chairman, Billings Wilson, in an address before the Society of Professional Engineers, 2 Park Avenue.

The Russian Winter has not descended on German troops in the Crimea. This milder land does not feel the grip of the ferocious cold that closes over the northern steppes. German mechanized equipment is not affected by its lighter freezes. From a military standpoint the whole peninsula is a natural stronghold.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 -- Some of the major concrete forms of Mexican-United States defensive cooperation that are now in effect were described to your correspondent yesterday by General J. Salvador Sanchez, member of the General Staff, who has just become the right-hand military man to President Manuel Avila Comacho.

Shortly after being knocked out by Jerry Moore, 135 3/4, Harlem, in 1:41 of the fourth of a six-rounder at the Bronx Coliseum last night, Lou La Salle, 131 3/4, West Side, collapsed while viewing another bout.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A fight centering around Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Mayor La Guardia of New York threatened today to delay Congressional action on civilian defense appropriations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -The Treasury has bought an additional $20,000,000 of gold from Russia to furnish dollar assets to the Soviet Union "to purchase goods and services in the United States in addition to materials being obtained" under the lease-lend program.

The coldest temperature of the Winter -- 10 degrees at 8:30 A.M. -- was recorded in the New York area yesterday. The suddenly falling temperature, arriving a day later than the predictions of the local Weather Bureau, played freak tricks on the city's subway mechanism during the morning rush hours, delaying thousands of commuters on their way to work.

James Madison High's basketball team had the Section 2, Brooklyn P.S.A.L., lead all to itself until it opposed Abraham Lincoln High yesterday, when the Honest Abes staged a strong second-half rally to upset Madison, 36 to 31, on the Lincoln floor.

CHUNGKING, China, Wednesday, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Chinese announced officially today that 7,000 more casualties had been inflicted upon remnants of Japanese forces on the Changsha front, but that some of the invaders had broken out of a Chinese trap northeast of the Hunan Province capital and were fleeing.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 6 -- "The answer to an eventual German demand for further transport of troops through Sweden can be but one: 'No,'" says the Swedish Socialist newspaper Oestgoten in an article examining the subject that chiefly occupies the Swedish press -- namely, a possibility of increased Russian pressure on Finland.

Former King Carol of Rumania, who is now living in Mexico City, has accepted the leadership of the Free Rumania Committee for the Triumph of Democracy and has authorized the publication of a statement to that effect. A telegram sent by Carol from Mexico City yesterday morning to Leon Fischer, president of the Free Rumania Committee, with headquarters at 419 Lafayette Street, New York, disclosed the intention of the former king.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 6 -- Japanese forces were less than an hour's flight from Singapore tonight after the seizure of Kuantan airdrome, in Eastern Malaya 190 miles from here, and this vital Allied naval base braced itself for heavier air attacks.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 6 -- It was intimated in official Berlin circles today that the Wilhelmstrasse was "considering the desirability" of sending a stiff note to the Vichy government, demanding more energetic measures on its part in the suppression of the recrudescence of terrorist activity in France's occupied zone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The spur of national anger and alarm that followed the Japanese attacks in the Pacific is credited in government circles here with the generally accelerated armament production of December, especially in warplanes.

It is with some measure of apprehension that public-spirited citizens and waterfront devotees are awaiting details of the project to enlarge and beautify Battery Park with the ground excavated from the Brooklyn tunnel now under construction. The scant news on the subject would indicate, if anything, that the whole project is dwarfed by the lack of vision or timidity.
LONDON, England, Jan. 6 -- The British people have resigned themselves to a much longer war than they had expected a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- We now have a full view of the work accomplished by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill within the last fortnight. It is unprecedented in scope and importance.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 (From Japanese Broadcasts Recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Domei news agency dispatches today reported heavy Japanese land and air attacks on American and Philippine forces in Southwestern Luzon, including bombing raids on Subic, Olongapo naval base, Balaga and the Mariveles area.

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, and Buddy Baer, challenger, will end hard training today for their fifteen-round title bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden for the Navy Relief Society. Both are in fine shape.

The frame office building together with coal pockets at 198 Morgan Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the Baker estate to the Coal and Fuel Associates, Inc., through Gordon S. Braislin, Inc., brokers. The property comprises about 60,000 square feet of land and includes barge loading facilities.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and two friends declined to attend last night's performance of "In Time to Come" at the Mansfield Theatre, 256 West Forty-seventh Street, because they refused to cross a picket line of musicians. The play has President Wilson for its leading character and aims to be a factual account of Wilson's attempt to insure world-wide peace through the League of Nations.

The Neediest Cases Fund received forty-one gifts yesterday amounting to $1,303.34. These contributions to the thirtieth annual appeal in behalf of the most distressed persons in New York City known to eight leading private charities increased the Fund to $259,635.13.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt spoke to the Congress on the state of the nation; he canceled his press conference and held instead the annual seminar with reporters on the budget which goes to Congress tomorrow; his visitors included Mayor La Guardia and James M. Landis.

Headed by the United States Steel Corporation, several large corporations made known yesterday that they had joined the long list of concerns that are establishing voluntary payroll deduction plans for the sale of defense savings bonds.

LONDON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Imminent Scandinavian developments were predicted tonight in reliable London quarters on the basis of increased diplomatic activity in Scandinavia by both the democracies and the Axis powers.

EVEN the most parochial New Yorker knows at least three things about Cleveland, Ohio. The first is that one of the main avenues is called Euclid. The second is that the city faces Lake Erie (or is it Lake Ontario?) The third is tha it is the home of a daily paper called The Plain Dealer.

A suggestion that all Americans born in January dedicate their birthdays to the 1942 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign by contributing to the fund being raised in the drive was made yesterday by Dr. Walter Damrosch, conductor and composer, who will be 80 years old Jan. 30, President Roosevelt's sixtieth birthday.

Two young men, both carrying unloaded pistols, were captured by two policemen after a short chase early yesterday morning several minutes after a $121 robbery in the Hotel Chelsea. No shots were fired during the pursuit.

The support of executives of business, finance and large employe groups was pledged yesterday to the campaign of St. Vincent's Hospital building fund at a luncheon for members of the men's committee of the campaign at the Hotel Biltmore.
Held even until the final six minutes of the game, the Fordham varsity basketball team staged a belated spurt and defeated Columbia by 54-43 before 2,000 persons in the Maroon gymnasium last night.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 6 -- Malta's Royal Air Force garrison has suddenly turned the tables on the Axis fliers who have been attempting to bomb it out of existence.

Kit Edward Carson, grandson of the famous Kit Carson, looks a young man of 25 or 30 in the picture which shows him volunteering for the Marines at Denver. The first impulse is to ask how could he possibly be the grandson of a hero from our remote epic past?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt and the country were assured today by armament procurement agencies of the government that the production objectives set by the President would be met this year.
A group of Chinese residents was listed among other aliens here yesterday who have offered their services in the defense program, in whatever capacity they may be needed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A bill which would direct the War Department to put back the name of the late William L. Mitchell on its rolls as a brigadier general, the rank he held as commander of the air forces of the American Expeditionary Force of the first World War, was approved unanimously by the Senate Committee on Military Affairs today.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 6 -- Despite the war, New Hampshire will experience one of its most successful skiing seasons, Don Tuttle of the State Planning and Development Commission revealed today at the State House.

This is a boom week for contemporary music. Every orchestral concert at Carnegie Hall, beginning with the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy last night and including the Philharmonic-Symphony and the Boston, has at least one score by a living composer on its program.

Continued heavy shipments of United States currency to Cuba in large denomination bills, presumably for the account of hoarders, was revealed yesterday in the regular monthly report on shipments of currency abroad issued by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- The American Friends Service Committee, terming conditions of malnutrition and starvation throughout Europe as "increasingly acute," said tonight that, beginning tomorrow, it would start daily supplemnetary feeding for 84,000 school children in thirteen cities of unoccupied France.

A revolutionary new method for making X-ray pictures of the interior of the brain, thus helping to locate accurately hidden brain tumors or foreign bodies, was described last night at a joint meeting of the New York Neurological Society and the section of Neurology and Psychiatry of the New York Academy of Medicine, held at the Academy Building, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A proposal for rotating the chairmanship of the new War Labor Board among four $10,000-a-year public members, was understood today to be under consideration by those drafting the machinery under which the board will function.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Roosevelt called today for the expenditure of $56,000,000,000, or more than half the national income, during the fiscal year beginning July 1 to produce sufficient armaments to overwhelm the Axis. He announced that American expeditionary forces would be sent to many parts of the world, including the British Isles.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Failure of the cold weather to bring any halt to fairly liberal marketing of hogs was accepted by buyers today as a reason for price markdowns. Hogs lost about 10 cents a hundredweight and best offerings declined to $11.65, against $11.70 yesterday. Eastern shippers and small operators bought weights under 240 pounds.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 6 -- Mrs. Ella K. Bryson's Marksman, winner only once in ten outings last year, inaugurated his 3-year-old campaign with one of the easiest triumphs of the Tropical Park meeting in the Tallahassee Purse today.

While the Manhattan trading reported yesterday involved several business properties, it was of a more varied nature than has been the case in recent weeks. Besides a loft building and a taxpayer, a number of residential parcels in scattered sections of the city went into new hands.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 (From German broadcast) -- Gigantic war tasks have kept Adolf Hitler steadily at his headquarters in Eastern Europe, except for occasional one-day trips since the Russian campaign started on June 22, says Dr. Otto Dietrich, the Nazi press chief, in urging upon Germany "complete trust in victory."

SO the Navy Relief Society received $27,777 in the wake of the thumping the Great Big Bears gave the professional All-Stars, and the sum would have been larger if the confounded weather man had been more charitable. It was a smashing good game, considering the ground conditions. And finally a way was found of stopping those Great Big Bears from running over all football opposition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (U.P.) -- Harry Marselli of the tax division was named "official air raid siren" of the Justice Department today by the protection committee which, unable to obtain a mechanical siren, found it "necessary to enlist the aid of a full-throated, suitable substitute, or ersatz barker."
VICHY, France, Jan. 6 -- The Paris press is more and more angry with Vichy, this time to the length of about 2,000 words written by Jean Luchaire, editor of the Nouveaux Temps.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 6 -- Luis Fernando Guachalla, Bolivian Minister to Washington, will be the first Bolivian Ambassador to the United States, it was announced here today in circles close to the Foreign Office.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new commercial quarters was Anton Smith Co., Inc., one of the oldest industrial diamond concerns in the country, which leased an entire floor of 6,000 square feet in 333-39 West Fifty-second Street.
In Topics of The Times of Dec. 30 my ideas on Blitzkrieg and propaganda have been commented on with partial objection. It seems to me that the problem is worth while of further discussion.

Heads of units of the American Legion Auxiliary in New York City and Westchester will meet tomorrow at the New York Times Hall, 238 West Forty-fourth Street, for clarification of information on volunteer participation in civilian defense.

Rather than tarry for the customary Saturday night closing, "The First Crocus" ended its Broadway career at the Longacre last evening. In all the Arnold Sundgaard play, which brought back Martha Hedman to the stage after a retirement of almost twenty years, chalked up a run of five performances only.

The island fortress that splits the entrance to Manila Harbor is about the size of Wake. Though it rises to heights of more than 600 feet, it does not look like a fortress, for none of its defenses can be seen either from the sea or sky. Its whole area is covered by a thick growth of trees planted carefully by Army engineers to form a camouflage.

Jim Lansing, star right end of the Fordham Sugar Bowl football team, was chosen captain of next season's eleven, it was announced yesterday. Lansing was picked by a vote of twenty-one lettermen. His election came as no surprise since he has been one of the best-liked players on the squad.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Lieutenant Walter S. Osipoff of the United States Marines, who tried a parachute leap on May 15 only to dangle helplessly in the air for thirty-five minutes until he was rescued by a daring aerial manoeuvre, jumped again today -- successfully.

With confusion still surrounding Mayor La Guardia's threat of a seven-day work week for 156,489 city employes yesterday, Police Commissioner Valentine disclosed that he had prepared a new work schedule for the 18,000 members of his department in the event that added duty was to be assigned to them.

The administration building at La Guardia Field, the airline passengers who "enplane" there, its visitors and employes, and the many services necessary to flight operations received added protection yesterday when the first of a squad of women volunteers arrived at 8 A.M. and assumed duty as "monitor-guards."

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The shoe industry was warned today by Harold M. Florsheim, Chicago shoe manufacturer and former chief of the shoes and leather products section, Division of Purchases, OPM, that production of civilian shoes must be curtailed below 1941 levels in order to make room for the growing needs of the Army, Navy and lease-lend program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- It was believed here today that when the resignation of E. C. Eicher to accept a Federal judgeship in the District of Columbia takes effect in a few days, Ganson Purcell, 36year-old commissioner, would become chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The wholesale dry goods business showed considerable improvement last year, according to the annual reports of two St. Louis companies that announced their earnings results.

The Engineers Public Service Company and its subsidiaries in the twelve months to Nov. 30 had a consolidated net income of $4,871,959 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, according to the report made public yesterday.

Alfred B. Stanford has been re-nominated for commodore of the Cruising Club of America and LeRoy Frantz has been renamed for the same office at the Larchmont Yacht Club, according to announcements made yesterday by the two organizations.

Total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $2,096,369,706 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on Dec. 31 was $24.46, compared with $25.87 at the end of November.
An agreement was concluded yesterday with a scrap metal dealer to buy the 1941 license plates that motorists are contributing to war industry.

Alfie Pike scored a goal for the Rangers in the second period of their game with the Detroit Red Wings last night, and the Blue Shirts were quite satisfied with this performance. The tally, in itself, did not bring victory, but it enabled New York to equal its own National Hockey League record of seventy-seven games in a row without being shut out
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 6 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

A group composed of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; Blair Co., Inc., and Hemphill, Noyes Co. submitted the successful bid yesterday for $1,021,000 of refunding and home relief bonds of Albany County, N.Y., receiving the award on a tender of 100.16 for 1.90s.

Upon the collaboration of all of us with Russia depends the continuation of "everything wrested from brute force" -- the Swiss democracy, the safeguards of the Magna Charta in Britain, the Bill of Rights and Declaration of Independence in the United States and unionism, Miss Helen Keller declared in a letter written to the Appeal of the Women's Anti-Nazi Conference in Moscow and published yesterday in the current issue of Soviet Russia Today.

HONOLULU, Jan. 7 -- The authorization by Colonel P.M. Smoot, Hawaiian Adjutant General, of the formation of an "inactive reserve infantry company" of the Hawaiian Territorial Guard followed days of agitation by white residents for means to defend themselves and the islands.

With the skyscrapers of lower Manhattan and their 1,000,000 working occupants particularly subject to enemy air attacks, plans were announced yesterday for setting up emergency facilities in Beekman Hospital and for raising $500,000 to cover the cost.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- War Department communique No. 49, based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M., E.S.T., today, follows:

Lotte Lehmann, German soprano who is now waiting to become an American citizen, last night celebrated the tenth anniversary of her first appearance in this city with a recital at Town Hall, the auditorium where she made her eventful debut ten years ago to the day.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The western coast of Norway, which is becoming a proving ground for British offensive tactics, was the scene last night of a raid that was carried out by warships and aircraft. The British attacked in a fjord between Bergen and Trondheim, where they sank three vessels and shelled a factory without loss or damage to themselves.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 7 (AP) -- A proposal for a British and American Red Cross benefit boxing show featuring a bout between Freddie Mills, member of the Royal Air Force, and Billy Conn or another leading American heavyweight was made today.
WELLINGTON, N.Z., Thursday, Jan. 8 -- The creation of three new generals is announced by the Defense Ministry, strengthening the Army Higher Command here.

A new publishing house founded by two men with a wide experience in Continental and particularly German-language publishing has just opened in New York as the L.B. Fischer Publishing Corporation, 381 Fourth Avenue. Its president is Gottfried Bermann-Fischer, son-in-law of the founder of the old Berlin publishing house of S. Fischer Verlag, which brought out for the first time the works of Thomas Mann and others.

HAMMONTON, N.J., Jan. 7 -- Two persons were killed and six others were injured seriously when an automobile crashed into the rear of a heavy truck of the Atlantic City Electric Company on the White Horse Pike here this afternoon.
Various banking groups headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. were the successful bidders yesterday for $7,672,000 of Series A bonds offered for sale by nine local housing authorities.

Twenty-five hundred persons have been invited to visit the new $1,000,000 Roosevelt Hospital building at 428 West Fifty-ninth Street today from 3 to 6 P.M., when the structure will be officially open for inspection by the public.
A SECOND winner in the recent Latin-American Prize Novel contest is brought out in an English version this morning: "Nayar,"* by Miguel Angel Menendez of Mexico, translated by Angel Flores.

Speaking yesterday at a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club of America in the Hotel Belmont-Plaza, Crown Prince Olav of Norway told of the continued determination of the Norwegian people to resist the Nazi invaders of their country and pledged their cooperation with all countries fighting the Axis powers.

Laurence A. Steinhardt represented the United States in Moscow during the three eventful years which witnessed a double somersault in Soviet foreign policy. He observed the efforts of the British and the French to reach an agreement with Russia in the Summer of 1939.

The General American Investors Company, Inc., reported yesterday that its net assets on Dec. 31 were equivalent to $235 for each share of preferred stock and $7.06 for each share of common. The latter figure compared with $9.17 at the end of 1940 and with $9.13 on Sept. 30, 1941.

Colonel John J. Moorhead, medical director of the city's unified transit system, who was in Honolulu when the Japanese launched their surprise attack on Pearl Harbor, will return here today and confer with Mayor La Guardia in City Hall.

Bold thinking and bold action are needed from American business in this time of national emergency, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared yesterday in the first public address he has made since assuming his present position.

Expanded activities of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, originally established to serve only the men in the armed forces of this country, but now taking care of the leisure-time requests of service men in all the Allied forces, were described yesterday by Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, co-chairman of the committee.

The Misses Pauline T. Kingsland and Pauline B. Herrick, both of Woodmere, L.I., gave a dinner last night in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for Miss Marjorie Sloane Handy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cortlandt Waite Handy of 1120 Fifth Avenue, and Dudley Foulke Cates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Cates of New York and Winnetka, Ill., whose engagement was announced recently.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by The United Press in London and New York) -- The German news agency D.N.B. reported today that Soviet forces that landed at Eupatoria in the Russians' Crimean drive had been wiped out except for a "feeble remainder," who will have difficulty in receiving supplies under German bombardment of Russian ships.

Adolf Busch, whose Chamber Music Players, became widely known in Europe six years ago, is assembling here a similar group, which will give a series of three subscription concerts at Town Hall the evenings of March 16 and 27 and April 15.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 7 -- Donna Leona, the pint-sized mare with the big heart, withstood a long, bitter drive to score by a half a length in the Fort Lauderdale purse at Tropical Park today. Flying the Miami-owned silks of Mrs. T. Christopher, the 7-year-old daughter of Don Leon was a 3-to-1 second choice in the field of nine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- French and Spanish resistance to German pressure has been strengthened by American entry into the World War, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was told today by Breckenridge Long, Assistant Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Registration of about 1,100,000 enemy aliens through a system of requiring them to carry identification cards is being seriously considered by the government, Attorney General Biddle told his press conference today.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Ticket holders were richly rewarded at the Fair Grounds today when I Might, a long shot, won the first race at $50.80 for $2.

The first of a series of special Wednesday night dancing parties for the soldiers assigned to the Fort Hamilton reservation, Brooklyn, was held in the post gymnasium last night under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Association.

Premier Molotoff's estimate of 95,567 civilians killed by German troops in Russian cities is not likely to be accurate to the last digit. A refugee escaping from occupied Kiev could not have taken a census of 52,000 slain before he fled. The dead of recaptured Rostov can be more easily counted, but they numbered only 308.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- Sparked by Arnold Beinstein, diminutive senior forward, Pennsylvania opened its forty-first basketball season with a 45-24 victory over Swarthmore in the Palestra tonight before 2,000 spectators. This was the first meeting between these old rivals since 1937. Penn led at the half, 19 -- 7.

The most spectacular record in the history of local school basketball came to an end yesterday when Benjamin Franklin High, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, bowed to Seward Park High, 37 to 34, in a Manhattan Division game on the latter's court.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 7 -- Marshall Bartholomew, director of the Yale Glee Club for a quarter century and Associate Professor of Singing at Yale University, will devote a month to conducting a demonstration at Fort Bragg, N.C., in the development of recreational singing activities in the United States armed forces.

A survey of twelve major defense plants in the metropolitan area reveals that women will be needed now more than ever to take jobs in war industries, Dr. Harry W. Reddick, director of the Defense Training Institute, 375 Pearl Street, Brooklyn, announced yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Philip Rhinelander have come to the Carlyle from Oyster Bay.
Mayor La Guardia personally greeted the first colonel to appear at the information booth set up yesterday in the lobby of the Hotel Commodore to serve officers of the Army and Navy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Department of Agriculture urged Congress today to take immediate action to foster production in this country of the guayule rubber plant as a precaution against a long war.
At a luncheon held yesterday noon in the Rainbow Grill, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the board of Coty, announced an annual American fashion critics award to be given by his concern.

The city's cold snap went into its second day yesterday with the temperature dropping to 11.4 degrees at 2:30 A.M., or only 1.4 degrees higher than the low of 10 degrees registered at 8:30 A.M. on Tuesday.

Continuing the "dim-outs" begun Monday, the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity last night extinguished every second light on Broadway from Fifty-ninth Street south to the Battery, as well as the double-light standards in the island strip between the traffic lanes from Columbus Circle north.
Following is a transcript of Mayor La Guardia's address to the City Council yesterday:

John Shubert of the famous theatrical clan will make his initial Broadway effort as a producer tonight with "Johnny on a Spot" at the Plymouth. His first production is a political satire dealing with the troubles of a young campaign manager who becomes entangled in the intricacies of a political machine in an unamed Southern State.

The trading on the West Side of Manhattan yesterday was led by a transaction in which the four-story studio and store property at 1845-7 Broadway was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to the 1845 Broadway Corporation, Irving Maidman, president.

CHUNGKING, China, Thursday, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have inflicted 5,000 more casualties on the Japanese around Changsha, bringing to 65,000 the number of enemy killed or wounded in a week of fighting, a communique announced today.

VICHY, France, Jan. 7 -- Dr. Paul a noted autopsy surgeon, delivered today his report on his examination of the body of Yves Paringaux, chief assistant to the Minister of the Interior, whose body was found Monday beside the railroad tracks near Melun. It was stated here tonight that no announcement could be expected until after completion of the police investigation.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Official Finnish spokesmen denied today widespread rumors that Finland was ready to withdraw from the war against Russia.

All the interesting possibilities for a very pretty kettle of soup indeed are encased in the small but substantial glass jars that stand for the first time this week on city grocery shelves. A two-and-a-half ounce container of concentrated ingredients, layer on layer, reveals -- reading from top to toe -- slender egg noodles, scarlet slivers of dehydrated tomatoes and powdered beef and chicken extracts.

A large apartment house development in Westchester County which was repossessed by the Federal Housing Administration is being disposed of by the latter in a deal representing an investment of about $2,000,000. A contract has been signed for the purchase of Larchmont Acres, a 384-family project in Larchmont, the buyer being a client of William A. White Sons, brokers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The war will cost the country an extra $13,500,000,000 above the $67,000,000,000 already appropriated if the current inflation trend continues at the present rate, Senator Brown told the Senate in opening the discussion today on the Price Control Bill.

Back in 1911 when Dartmouth held its first Winter carnival the program consisted principally of intramural skiing and snow-shoeing events. Then in 1915, competition with teams from McGill began, thus adding to the carnival the color and excitement of the first intercollegiate skiing rivalry in North America.

A different kind of shopping crowd filled the aisles of McCreery's department store, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, early yesterday morning. A thousand store employes became prospective weekly investors in their country's future as they opened a campaign for all-out purchase of defense stamps and bonds.
Merrill Hartman has joined the office of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane in Dallas, Texas. He will be in charge of the unlisted securities department.

Governor Lehman's first wartime message to the Legislature yesterday dealt of necessity with some national problems and contained some earnest and moving passages that will have significance far beyond the State boundaries. He took it for granted that the Legislature would be willing, as he is, to "lay aside partisanship for this session."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Small business men today received an insight into workings of the new plan which the Office of Production Management, under instructions from the Supply Priorities and Allocations Board, has substituted for the so-called "Odlum plan" for making a blanket allotment of sufficient critical materials to tide small business over the first stages of priorities restrictions.

In order to promote a more accurate understanding of the rather complicated "wild bird plumage law," recently passed under the sponsorship of the Audubon Society, and to discuss the possibility of amending the statute for the benefit of fly tyers, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne will hold a conference of interested parties next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- American taxpayers were told by President Roosevelt in his budget message today that they must pay $2,000,000,000 more in social security contributions and $7,000,000,000 in other new taxes in the fiscal year of 1943. The President did not specify how this tax increase was to be met, but his message implied that much of it would come from increased corporation taxes and from new and heavier excise taxes.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, who began his fourth and final week as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, has brought a fresh point of view to his temporary stewardship. Though he can be as much the virtuoso conductor as the next man, he has devoted himself steadfastly to absorbing music-making.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- An active demand for cash corn and oats furnished the background for fairly aggressive buying of both grains on the Board of Trade today with corn moving up fractionally to a new high level since early in October and all deliveries of oats sold at new seasonal high prices.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 7 (AP) -- With the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company returned to private management less than twenty-four hours, contract negotiations between the company and a C.I.O. union ended tonight and the union announced the new War Labor Board would be asked to settle the question of a maintenance of membership clause asked by the union.

Existing shortages of certain medical drugs have been aggravated by hoarding, with perhaps the government's own publicity agencies partly responsible, Hugh P. Beirne, president of the National Association of Retail Druggists, declared last night at the mid-Winter meeting of the New York State Pharmaceutical Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 7 -- Japanese bombers damaged grounded planes of the Royal Australian Air Force in the second of two raids this morning on Rabaul, New Britain. There were no casualties.

What the well-dressed American woman will wear for war work was shown yesterday at the Traphagen School of Fashion, 1680 Broadway, in cooperation with the Cotton-Textile Institute and Free-For-All, Inc. Miss Virginia Jewel, fashion director of the institute, conducted the show.
Many of the lessees of commercial space figuring in the transactions reported yesterday signed for full-floor units in midtown structures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Laurence A. Steinhardt, who has served as Ambassador to Moscow since 1939, was nominated today by President Roosevelt for the post of Ambassador to Turkey, a neutral country which is regarded as of great strategic importance by both the United Nations and the Axis.

After the campaign in October of the Bureau for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency against malicious false fire alarms there was an average monthly decrease of 111 of these alarms in New York City in November and December, compared with the same months in 1940, Justice Stephen S. Jackson, bureau director, announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Jan. 7 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 -- After two scoreless periods, Johnny LeBoutillier netted two goals for Yale early in the final chapter tonight on passes from Captain Ted Harrison and George Pillsbury as the Eli sextet beat the Queens Victorias of New York, 5 to 0.
The apartment leasing reported yesterday was well distributed, with both East and West Sides participating in the activity.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt's announcement that an expeditionary force would be sent to Britain cheered the stock markets today. Gilt-edge issues were firmer. Industrials also showed gains with Woolworths again improved, Dunlop and the tobaccos higher and Lancashire Cotton and most textiles up a few pence.

The weight of the biggest budget ever formulated by any nation in the world's history was passed off yesterday by the stock market with the same poker face that greeted President Roosevelt's call for the gigantic war effort on Tuesday.

Henrik de Kauffmann, the Danish Minister who refused to recognize the German occupation of his homeland, was honored last night by 600 persons at a dinner in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria at which $4,716 was donated to the American Red Cross.

The Yale Club scored a 3-to-2 victory over the Harvard Club in the Class A Metropolitan Interclub squash tennis series last night at the victors' courts. F. Barry Ryan Jr. accounted for the No. 1 victory when he downed Willard K. Rice, 18 -- 17, 10 -- 15, 15 -- 5, to give the Yale players the crucial point in a hard-fought match.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 7 -- Former King Carol of Rumania said here today that he intended soon to proclaim himself Regent for his former kingdom and, in that capacity, take leadership in establishing a Rumanian government in exile, which would "take its place beside the United Nations in fighting for liberty and justice."

BOSTON, Jan. 7 -- With John Paine and Mark Beebe scoring two goals each, the Harvard hockey team defeated Williams, 7 -- 1, on the Skating Club of Boston rink tonight for its fourth victory in six games.

The Columbia University Club maintained its two-game edge over the second-place Princeton Club in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C race as each team scored a 5-0 victory last night. Columbia invaded the Union Club courts to triumph, while Princeton repulsed the visiting Amherst combination.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 7 -- The Colin Kellys maintained a permanent "rendezvous with death."

An American cargo-passenger liner, effectively anonymous under a coating of gray paint that was applied at sea by seamen and passenger volunteers, docked yesterday in New York Harbor at the end of a voyage that began nearly three months prior to American entry into the war a month ago.

That most marvelous and illuminating letter from Meyer D. Rothschild on the editorial page of your issue of Jan. 4 should be read by everybody and particularly by our honored Secretary of the Treasury. May I make two suggestions.

Dr. George Baehr, chief medical officer of the Office of Civilian Defense, accompanied by Dr. James Mackintosh, chief medical officer of a Scottish division of the British Department of Health, departed last night from La Guardia Field on a nation-wide tour to study civilian defense medical requirements.

In reading about the Japanese maltreatment of Americans and other foreigners, we have again erred in judging the Japanese by our own civilized standards of sportsmanship and fair play. We have forgotten the Rape of Nanking, but fortunately the Japanese officers have not.

Prosper Merimee's gypsy, adopted by Bizet, has yielded to time. Her offstage name was Emma Calve. Survivors of the ancient generation fell in love with her in the second consulship of Abbey and Grau at the Metropolitan, close on fifty years ago. In that prime of virtue "Carmen" was suspect.

Mrs. Roosevelt wrote day before yesterday: "A very busy day and three of us ate lunch together at my desk. I barely managed to reach home in time to get this column off." Young men and women who cherish the ambition to become newspaper columnists, in preference to any other road to fame and fortune, may be attracted, in some degree, by one pleasant aspect of the columnist's business.

Buddy Baer is destined for another knockout at the hands of Joe Louis when the two meet in their world heavyweight title bout at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, according to a brief statement made by the Brown Bomber as he wound up his training exercises at Greenwood Lake, N.Y., yesterday.

The country will be showing wisdom and a commendable charity if it turns a deaf ear to those who are now clamoring for retaliation against Japanese in Hawaii and California for the mistreatment of white people by the occupying Japanese forces in Manila. It was evident from the start that Hitler's repressive and inexcusable measures against white people in Germany who were Jews would eventually find their counterpart elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- An urgent appeal was made to the State Department today by a delegation of the United American Spanish Aid Committee, a national refugee and service organization with headquarters in New York, to intercede with General Francisco Franco to prevent the deportation to Germany and Italy of more than 150 members of the International Brigade of the former Spanish Republican Army who have been interned in Spain since the civil war.

The heavy iron bar gate on the "singing room" in Seventh District Prison, 317 West Fifty-third Street, stands ajar, for the dormitory, which only a year ago housed material witnesses for the State, has been converted into a chapel. The work was undertaken by plasterers, electricians, carpenters and painters among the inmates who are serving short terms for petit larceny, disorderly conduct and bigamy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Increased railroad earnings as a result of motor-traffic restrictions and other developments of war, in combination with some recent court reversals of Interstate Commerce Commission plans to reorganize certain railroads, may herald a return of prosperity to the carriers and the re-establishment of their post-war securities as good family investments.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The American League, as does all baseball, stands ready to do its part in the crisis which faces our nation.

THE speaker was stout Jack Adams, the manager of the Detroit Red Wings of the ice arenas, and he was talking about hockey players. Favorably, too. He's a genial gent and he was spreading his compliments around.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Reorganization of the British system of defending airdromes probably will be announced soon in Parliament.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Three American fighter pilots tackled a Japanese air fleet of 108 bombers and fighters in the big Christmas morning raid on Rangoon, Burma, it was learned today. Later other American and British pilots joined in the battle.

Net income of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company in 1941 was $2,239,089, according to the annual pamphlet report mailed yesterday to stockholders. The report, made jointly by Dunham B. Sherer, chairman, and Ralph Peters Jr., president, lists net earnings from operation at $2,004,097, after providing for expenses and taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt submitted to Congress today the biggest budget estimate of all time -- $58,927,902,000, excluding debt retirement -- of which the war effort will take $52,786,186,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission's report of transactions by so-called "insiders" in November reflected the approaching year-end in the number of gifts of stock. The report, made public today, covers disposals and acquisitions of securities by officers, directors and principal owners of corporations.

In case any one asks Horton Foote, "How's your last act?" he can reply, "Stunning." Mr. Foote is the young man who disturbed the calm of last Spring with an interesting play entitled "Texas Town." Since then he has been in Texas long enough to gather the material for a sort of successor, "Out of My House," which the American Actors Company put on last evening at the Studio, 108 West Sixteenth Street.

In the far-away days when the followers of Mr. Browder and the admirers of Mr. Hitler saw eye to eye, these factions and their more or less innocent camp followers sometimes mingled in parades carrying banners bearing the device "The Yanks are not coming."

The downtown insurance district, the scene in recent months of several important realty transactions, was the center yesterday of another large deal in which the Royal Insurance Company sold the seventeen-story office building at 84 William Street, northeast corner of Maiden Lane.

Revoking for the occasion a ban of many years standing against performances by union musicians under non-member conductors, James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, gave permission last night for a series of concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society under the direction of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Governor Lehman, delivering his tenth annual message to the opening session of the Legislature today, pledged economy and tax reduction as part of the State government's program of wartime acts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The House passed bills today authorizing the Navy Department to spend $845,000,000 for shipbuilding, ship repair and ordnance and increase the enlisted strength of the Navy and Marine Corps from 360,000 to 604,000.

The British, after a hard-fought drive of 310 miles across the face of Libya, were still stationary near Agedabia yesterday. At sea -- in the Mediterranean and Atlantic -- a renewed German offensive was meeting a new Allied defense.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Authorities of the Netherlands Indies, elated over President Roosevelt's implied promise of unstinted aid in the defense of the archipelago, voiced hearty confidence today that the Netherlands Indies could hold off a full-dress Japanese offensive until American reinforcements arrived.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Formal announcement of the creation of a unified air field defense command is understood to have been reached at recent meetings of the War Cabinet in response to growing alarm over repeated loss of vital air bases in Norway, France, Greece, Crete and Malaya.

LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 8 (Reuter) -- Gestapo [secret police] machine-gun posts have been erected at key points throughout Berlin and other German cities as protection against a possible attempt by the German Army to overthrow the Nazi regime.

The National Catholic Community Service clubhouse for soldiers, sailors and marines at 17 East Fifty-first Street, opposite St. Patrick's Cathedral, began yesterday several new services for the entertainment of visiting service men on furlough.

MOSCOW, Jan. 7 (Tass Agency to U.P.) -- Russia, in one of the most terrible indictments in the history of modern warfare, has charged the German armies and the German Government with crimes ranging from the stealing of children's toys through rape to mass murder and mass destruction.
LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- A joint communique of the British Admiralty and Royal Air Force follows:

Agreement on a detailed interpretation of Attorney General Francis Biddle's order governing the travel of enemy aliens was sought yesterday by United States Attorneys Matthias F. Correa, who has jurisdiction over Manhattan and the Bronx, and Harold M. Kennedy, whose district includes Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond.

The Broadway film roster remains unchanged today as three midtown theatres hold over current attractions. At the Strand, "The Man Who Came to Dinner" will begin its second week. The Astor's tenant, "The Shanghai Gesture," enters its third week today, while the picture at Loew's Criterion, "Sundown," will open its third and final week.

A survey of major property additions and improvements by subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation in 1941, including plant and equipment financed by and to be operated for the government, shows considerable work was under way at the year-end.

Using a 13-point scoring splurge as a springboard that bounced it into overtime, City College defeated St. John's, 48 to 46, in a dramatic basketball game before 13,503 in Madison Square Garden last night. The Redmen lost their drive and the Beavers picked it up in the latter stages of the regulation struggle to turn a runaway for the Brooklynites into a stirring battle.

Forty-seven gifts totaling $421.54 were received yesterday for the Neediest Cases, increasing the Fund to $260,056.67. The day's largest contribution was $100 from a friend who asked that only her initials, A.F.K., be used.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Jan. 8 -- The entire western Kaluga front was severely shaken and at some points the German lines had collapsed, enabling Soviet troops in the last forty-eight hours to make advances that even at their accelerated pace had been calculated to take days or even weeks, the Moscow military spokesman declared this morning.

A descendant of Isaac Hull, whose exploits as captain of the U.S.S. Constitution mark the pages of every naval history, enlisted here yesterday in the sea service as recruiting in each of the four armed forces continued at a slower pace.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday his intention of retaining for the present his dual positions of United States Director of the Office of Civilian Defense and Mayor. He made his announcement in a seventy-minute message to the new City Council, in which he described the impact of military and civilian defense preparations on the city departments.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The Senate swung into immediate action today by moving to order of final passage a bill introduced by Senator Mahoney of Buffalo which suspends for the duration of the war the Nurses Practice Act so as to assure to hospitals and institutions in the State an adequate nursing staff.

R.J. Schaefer, President, United States Brewers' Association, is reported in your issue of Jan. 2 as saying there has been a "notable increase" in 1941 in the public acceptance of beer as an "essential food." If that is so, many are being notably misled.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 7 -- The formation of a Yugoslav-Greek customs union with mixed commissions for foreign policy and military collaboration became known here today in foreign diplomatic circles.

HILLSIDE HEIGHTS, L.I., Jan. 7 -- In appreciation of the heroic sacrifice of the five Army airmen who were killed last Thursday in averting possible damage to private homes, the residents of this community have sent flowers to the homes of the fliers, it was learned today.

Maria Markan, Icelandic soprano, made her first operatic appearance at the Metropolitan as the Countess in last night's performance of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro." The artist had been heard previously this season at two of the company's Sunday evening concerts, but had not before been allotted a stage role at the house.
