WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill authorizing President Roosevelt to advance or retard the clocks of the country up to two hours in any area.

Younger members of society have held several meetings recently to further the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of "The Daughter of the Regiment," with Lily Pons and Salvatore Baccaloni in the leading roles, on the night of Jan. 24 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Grenfell Association of America.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Germany has passed the peak of her armament output, according to the Ministry of Economic Warfare, which places the high point in the Reich's munitions industry at some time last Spring. This finding is most inclusive, inasmuch as it covers all European territory under the domination of Hitler and every kind of manufacture for war.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 7 -- In a speech today at a luncheon he gave for his colleagues from Chile, Peru and Paraguay who will head their countries' delegations to the Rio de Janeiro conference, Foreign Minister Enrique de Ruiz-Guinazu made it plain that Argentina would oppose any interpretation of continental solidarity that entailed going to war against the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission told Congress today the railroads must have materials necessary for the prompt construction of new equipment and repair of existing rolling stock to enable them to provide adequate and efficient war service.

Children in our society have been needlessly over - protected from every unpleasant aspect of life, Dr. Margaret Meade, assistant curator of anthropology of the Museum of Natural History, told 1,000 teachers of kindergarten and kindergarten extension classes during the annual Luella A. Palmer Memorial Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday afternoon.
The Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries showed a net profit of $4,052,370 on operations during the six months ended on Nov. 30, according to the report announced yesterday.

The recovery of a man whose heart had stopped beating for twenty minutes during a surgical operation will be reported in the Jan. 10 issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, official organ of the American medical profession.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 7 -- "The last war gave the women of England the vote, and this war is showing them how to use it." Mrs. Patricia Strauss, wife of a Labor member of the British Parliament, declared today in a talk on "Britain as a Democracy in War" at a luncheon conference at the New Jersey League of Women Voters in the Kresge store restaurant here.

The National Academy of Design formally opened its new building at 1083 Fifth Avenue with a reception last night. Guests were enabled both to inspect the academy's permanent headquarters and to view the initial exhibition, composed of works from the collection that the National Academy has been assembling since this organization was founded, more than a century ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- An official report by one of the governments of the United Nations telling of dissension, hunger and disease among German troops on the Russian front and of a plot by German army officers to overthrow Adolf Hitler and his ac complices was handed today to the War Department, which did not authenticate or comment on the document.

Out of the chaos of the Securities and Exchange Commission -- chaos which probably will continue at least until the Senate confirms the nomination of Edward L. Eicher, chairman of the SEC, to a Federal judgeship -- a few names are appearing.

The cotton market moved quietly yesterday with orders on either side generally limited as traders awaited developments on the price- control bill now before the Senate. On the New York Cotton Exchange final prices of active futures were 1 point higher to 2 points lower than Tuesday's close.

Protests against continuation of present milk prices in New York and proposals that would result in a further price increase of 2 or 2 1/2 cents a quart were made yesterday by representatives of the city administration and many consumer organizations at the opening session of a public hearing on proposed amendments to the Federal- State order governing the marketing of milk in the metropolitan area.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The Republican-controlled Legislature gave a concrete example of unity on the national war effort today when it adopted unanimously within a few minutes after it opened its annual session a Democratic-sponsored resolution pledging "patriotic and determined loyalty" to the President and the Government of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A bill providing death and injury benefits for air raid wardens and other volunteer civilian defense personnel was introduced in the House today by Representative Martin J. Kennedy of New York.

Credit problems arising from the declaration of war by Latin-American countries against the Axis powers and the consequent blocking of transactions with the nationals of those powers without regard to the United States "blacklist" were principal topics of discussion at the regular round-table conference of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau, at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

BARDOLI, India, Jan. 7 -- Civil disobedience in India -- in the sense in which it was launched -- is not likely to be revived by the Nationalist Congress until the war is ended, Mohandas K. Gandhi said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A charge that George Hill, a secretary of Representative Fish of New York, worked closely with George Sylvester Viereck and in less than a year distributed more than 500,000 pieces of "propaganda speeches," under Congressional frank, was made by William P. Maloney, government prosecutor, as the trial of Mr. Hill began today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt called for war expenditures of more than a billion dollars a week to translate the nation's blueprint for victory into actual armed men, planes, tanks and ships, in the budget which he submitted to Congress today.

New York City's 40,000 school employes are being classified according to their special skills, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday. Questionnaires sent to the teaching staff seek qualifications that might be useful in an emergency.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 7 -- The Middle East Command of the Royal Air Force announced today that it had been established that British air raiders destroyed forty-four Axis aircraft, including thirty troop-transport planes, in Sunday's raids on the airdrome at Castelvetrano, Sicily.

An offer to give a "command performance" of the play, "In Time to Come," was made to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt last night by the producer of the historical drama that the First Lady refused to attend on Tuesday night because of the presence of a musicians' union picket line.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 (From German Broadcasts Recorded by the United Press in New York) -- Jorge Vargas, former secretary to President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines, has been appointed Mayor of Manila, according to reports received today from Tokyo.
The triumph over the Bruins last Sunday night has filled Red Dutton's Americans with ambition.

Leaders in 100 fields of business, industry and the professions will meet today to plan organization of one of the largest groups of volunteer workers ever formed in the city for the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York. The meeting will be held at 4 P.M. in the offices of the General Foods Corporation, 250 Park Avenue, with Colby M. Chester, chairman of the campaign's commerce and industry division, presiding.

Fear of shortages and higher prices as a result of the entry of the United States into the war has combined with the cold wave to bring about a sharp rise in the sale of men's clothing this week, retail executives reported yesterday. Additional factors are the lure of cut prices and the fact that the mild weather here in the last three months of 1941 enabled men to hold off purchases until the clearances.

The existence of neighborhood defense councils, unauthorized by any official agency, was brought to the attention of civilian volunteer defense heads last night and resulted in an on-the-spot determination by Mrs. Winthrop Aldrich, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, and Clarence King, executive director, to explore the advantages of such setups.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Marine Corps units stationed on "outlying islands of the Hawaiian area" won particular commendation from Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox today, who sent them a special message by wireless.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (U.P.) -- Nazi-controlled Netherland newspapers reaching here today reported that twenty Netherlanders had been sentenced at Maastricht to prison terms, ranging from five to fifteen years, on charges of distributing anti-German leaflets.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- With tire rationing in effect all over the country, legislators moved today to protect State car owners by introducing two bills making it a felony to steal tires or automobile accessories.

Twenty British airmen, whose flying boat was shot down by German fighters in the Mediterranean, landed unarmed in Axis-held territory in Libya, argued with the Italian patrol whether they or the Italians were prisoners, and finally reached the British lines fully armed and with 250 Italian prisoners, The United Press reported yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 7 -- The National League for Women Voters will shift its program from amassing knowledge about government "to reporting and interpreting what government is doing and how it is doing it," it was decided today as the general council of the league began a two-day emergency meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Making the first of a series of monthly short-wave radio addresses tonight to the Japanese people, Senator Elbert D. Thomas warned them in the Japanese language of the retribution that will follow the attack on Pearl Harbor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 7 -- A discovery that San Francisco, a month after the war began, has not ordered a single item of emergency fire-fighting equipment despite the city's exposed position, sharpened local newspaper criticism today of Mayor Angelo J. Rossi's handling of the civilian defense problem.
Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic Seaboard last week increased by 78,000 barrels to 20,118,000, it was announced yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

Eastern intercollegiate athletic directors and officials opened a three-day convention yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel under the general supervision of Asa Bushnell, executive director of the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics.

Chatham Manufacturing Company, the largest maker of all-wool blankets, yesterday canceled its scheduled opening of a Fall line, scheduled for Jan. 15, and at the same time notified salesmen that it would offer only a limited line of part-wool numbers at that time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- News of the bombing and machine-gunning of undefended towns in the Philippines, in addition to the devastation wrought on Manila, reached the War Department tonight in dispatches from General Douglas MacArthur, commanding general of the United States armed forces in the Far East.
Thirteen-year-old June Millard received $250 yesterday as the reward of honesty, a sum that might have been doubled had it not been for the publicity that surrounds this virtue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Virginia's senior Senator, Carter Glass, tonight presented the Washington Touchdown Club's annual trophy to William (Bill) Dudley, University of Virginia All-America halfback, with the admonition to "keep it and cherish it as long as you may live."
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature today:

SINGAPORE, Jan. 7 -- Japanese sea-borne forces were believed tonight to be preparing for landing attempts at Port Swettenham, in the vital Kuala Lumpur sector 200 miles northwest, and at Mersing, only seventy-five miles northeast of Singapore.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- A Federal grand jury returned indictments today against forty-four corporations, a trade association and eighty-nine officers and directors of the concerns on a charge of engaging in a nation-wide conspiracy to control the production and prices of waxed paper products.

Leather production in November ran somewhat ahead of consumption again, according to data issued yesterday by the Tanners Council. Production, in hide equivalents, was 2,423,000, compared with 2,659,000 in October and 1,945,000 in November, 1940. Consumption was 2,200,000 in November, 1941; 2,524,000 in October, and 1,761,000 in November, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Every bank in the United States has been requested by Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, to cooperate with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in making loans to small businesses to help them carry out war contracts.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 7 (From Chinese broadcast recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- A Chinese War Department bulletin said today that fifty Japanese officers and men were captured and an undetermined number killed and wounded by Chinese forces who overtook them as they tried to escape from Changsha by swimming the Laotao River.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 American former consular officers in Tokyo, Yokohama, Kobe and Osaka are in good health and have no complaint to make over living conditions, according to a report received by the State Department today from the Swiss Legation in Tokyo under date of Dec. 31.

A syndicate composed of Welsh, Davis Co. of Chicago, B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc., and Sullivan, Nelson Goss, Inc., received the award of an issue of $1,919,000 of refunding bonds of Bay County, Fla., at a net interest cost of 3.307 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Three members of the Interstate Commerce Commission held separate sessions today to hear testimony in opposition to the application of railroads and barge lines for a general increase of 10 per cent in rates. Shippers of mine and forest products appeared before Clyde D. Aitchison, acting chairman; shippers of agricultural and animal products before Commissioner Charles D. Mahaffie, and miscellaneous groups before Commissioner Walter N.W. Splawn.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 (From German Broadcasts Recorded in London and New York by The United Press) -- Official German spokesmen, commenting on President Roosevelt's speech concerning plans for United States production, described the figures as "fantastic."
Baron Munchausen had nothing on Albert Mason, 10 years old, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Mason, of 49 Mackay Place, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, announced today that an estimated 2,200,000 employers reported taxable wages paid during the second quarter of 1941 to an estimated 33,400,000 employes, and that the taxable wage payments for this April-June period totaled $10,352,000,000.

The third day of New York's stern movement against parking offenders disclosed four definite improvements yesterday. Fewer cases turned up in the traffic courts, streets were more navigable in all parts of town, garage men reported "a terrific amount of cars gone into dead storage," and truckers reported loading and unloading facilitated.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The veteran Harry Bassier of San Jose, Calif., firing two rounds of 68 and 69, turned in a 137 at the Griffith Park course today to lead qualifiers for the $10,000 Los Angeles open golf championship.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 7 -- Dr. and Mrs. Hobart Endicott Warren entertained with cocktails today at their home for Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ladd.

Wilen W. Easterday, whose activities have made him known to the police of many States under a number of aliases as a swindler, was arrested yesterday and charged with being a fugitive from Paterson, N.J. In that city Easterday has been named in twenty-five indictments charging embezzlement, issuing worthless checks and false pretenses.

John Bernard Flannagan, whose strongly individualistic sculptures are in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art and in other museums on both sides of the world, sent his wife, Margaret, to spend the recent Christmas and New Year holidays with relatives in Boston.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Russians were threatening the entire surviving German Army of the Crimea tonight and were smashing forward in every other vital area along a vast battle line extending to the far northern Finnish front.

Pointing out that President Roosevelt's production schedule for 1943 would call for the completion of a plane every four minutes and a tank every seven minutes during that year, the National Association of Manufacturers surveyed yesterday some of the requirements of the program in terms of labor supply, floor space, and machinery.

Led by Miss Nadine Conner of the Metropolitan Opera in singing "The Star-Spangled Banner," several hundred women who as a group have made extensive contributions to national defense will open a meeting at 2:30 P.M. today in The New York Times Hall at 238 West Forty-fourth Street, to learn how they may serve best in supplementary capacities as volunteers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that an application had been filed under the Holding Company Act for approval of a plan of reorganization of the Southern Union Gas Company, a holding company system which has six subsidiaries -- the Arkansas Western Gas Company, the New Mexico Gas Company, the New Mexico Eastern Gas Company, the Quanah Water Company, the Texas Southwestern Gas Company and the Southern Union Production Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt's budget message to Congress was as follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- "Shadow of Their Wings," a photoplay by Harrison Orkow, Byron Morgan and Richard Macaulay has been scheduled for Spring production at Warner Brothers, with Ann Sheridan, Ronald Reagan, Dennis Morgan and George Tobias heading the cast.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador, climbed on a green brocade divan in the marble drawing room of the British Embassy tonight and proposed a toast:

SEATTLE, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Pacific Coast merchant-vessel traffic has returned to normal for the time being "after a rather ineffective" enemy submarine campaign, the Thirteenth Naval District commandants said today.

The members of the Tammany Society last evening adopted a resolution authorizing its board of sachems to sell or lease Tammany Hall. This action is believed to foreshadow the removal of the headquarters of the Tammany political organization from Tammany Hall, which might mean eventual abandonment of the name of Tammany, although no change of name is contemplated by the present leaders.

The condition which this letter describes is occasioning grave concern in the office of the Musicians Emergency Fund. These school concerts have had great educational value and have been one of the most effective made-work projects of our organization.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 -- Ex-Mayor Richard W. Reading, found guilty of violating the public trust by accepting thousands of dollars to protect gambling rackets, was sentenced by Judge Earl C. Pugsley today to four to eight years in prison.
A further increase in permits for the purchase of new tires and tubes was announced yesterday by Harold W. McGraw, Federal Tire Rationing Administrator for New York City.
A further increase in permits for the purchase of new tires and tubes was announced yesterday by Harold W. McGraw, Federal Tire Rationing Administrator for New York City.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 7 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

The American Pacific Clipper that turned up safely at La Guardia Field after having circled the globe from New Zealand may have blazed a trail that will be much traveled. For what this commercial plane did in one direction, hundreds of fighting planes should be able to do in the opposite direction, in order to meet the threat of Japanese air power in the South Seas.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Roosevelt sent his record budget request to Congress and nominated Laurence A. Steinhardt to be Ambassador to Turkey. He had no engagements during the day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Members of the National Retail Furniture Association were warned today by Louis Bing Jr., newly elected president, and Nathan S. Sachs, past president of the association and head of the Sachs Quality Furniture Company of New York, that they must begin now to meet retailing problems created by the war economy.

Several new exhibitions have been added to the schedule of the Museum of Modern Art for the next four months. A large exhibition of work by American painters and sculptors living outside the metropolitan area will open on Jan. 21.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -Thousands of young Americans who learned to fly in the civilian pilot training program were called upon today to join either the Army or Navy Air Forces.

The cold spell continued unabated in the city and the surrounding areas yesterday, with the thermometer dipping to 4.8 degrees above zero at 6 A.M., half a degree above the record low for the date, reached in 1896.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Representatives of independent petroleum producers and independent iron ore groups testified today against a proposed 10 per cent rate increase in railroad and water carrier rates at a hearing of the Interstate Commerce Commission here.

A "place of honor" for Jewish Palestine among the United Nations was asked yesterday by Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the Jewish National Fund of America, because it is "the only avowed ally in the Middle East of the United States and Britain."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee; Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and possibly other committee members will meet Secretary Morgenthau and other Treasury officials tomorrow for a preliminary discussion of a bill to increase taxes by $7,000,000,000, as recommended by President Roosevelt in his budget message yesterday.
Park commissioners in the metropolitan district found themselves unable to hoist the usual skating flag yesterday, because the red ball on a white field happens also to be the Japanese Jack.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Compromises by peace makers at the end of the war are likely to result in a third world conflict, Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, militant leader of women's organizations, said at her home at 120 Paine Avenue today on the eve of her eighty-third birthday.

The most serious aspect of the Far Eastern fighting yesterday continued to be the strong Japanese advance down the Malayan peninsula toward Singapore, keystone of the Allied bastion of defense in the Orient.

A warning that churches would have no time for "extras or sideshows" in the days ahead was voiced yesterday by Dr. James Thayer Addison, vice president of the National Council of the Episcopal Church, in a statement circulated throughout that church.

A statement defining and clarifying the regulations covering travel by enemy aliens living in New York City was issued jointly yesterday by United States Attorneys Mathias F. Correa and Harold M. Kennedy. In this city Mr. Correa's Southern Federal District includes Manhattan and the Bronx, while Mr. Kennedy's Eastern District takes in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

After two weeks of decline the earning assets of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $66,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

No advance pledge to submit the "maintenance of union membership" controversy at the Kearny, N.J., yard of the Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company to the new War Labor Board for decision has been given by company officials, it was learned last night in steel circles.

BERLIN, Jan 8 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Three British bombers from Burma gave Japanese-occupied Bangkok its first air raid of the war before dawn this morning, the German Trans-ocean news agency reported from Bangkok.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Income payments to individuals in the United States in November were almost one-fourth greater than a year previously, the Commerce Department announced today. They aggregated $7,871,000,000, as compared with $6,362,000,000 in November, 1940.

Scoring four goals in the final period, the Brooklyn Americans managed to nose out the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The visitors, leading early in the contest by a score of 2 to 0, wilted as the battle wore on and saw the hard-skating Duttonmen erase their edge with their closing rally and register a 5-to-4 triumph.

Gold holdings as stated in the subjoined table represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title to actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- In the face of urgent protests from the Secretary of War and other Administration spokesmen, the House of Representatives voted today, 187 -- 168, to transfer the functions of Civilian Defense and $100,000,000 of authorized funds for carrying it out from the control of Mayor La Guardia, the national director, to the War Department.

The Boy Scout battalions mobilized for vital emergency service with the Red Cross, air raid wardens and civilian defense authorities need funds to carry on, Phillips Turnbull, general chairman of the New York Scouts' 1942 drive for $325,000, declared yesterday in an appeal to New Yorkers to help their own Scouts by sending contributions to 120 West Forty-second Street.

One can't help wanting to sympathize and agree with Mayor La Guardia when he is in as good and amiable form as he was on Wednesday when he delivered his annual address to the City Council. He made two important points. One is that the job of administering the City of New York in wartime will be hard and dour.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 8 -- "The people of Finland are not afraid of realities, but we cannot much longer continue to bear the burden of a costly war, our second in less than three years," writes the coalition newspaper Uusi Suomi today, adding its voice to the tide of Finnish public opinion that is increasingly outspoken in asking, "Now that we have attained our strategic goal, why continue the increasingly unpopular and costly war?"

Check transactions in the five-day week ended on Wednesday were 4.4 per cent smaller than in the comparable week of last year, which did not include the New Year's holiday, but on a daily average basis clearings were up 14.7 per cent over a year ago.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command today issued this communique:

Where to enlist and how to get training for any of the hundreds of volunteer civilian defense jobs were the two major questions answered yesterday for 500 leaders of units of the American Legion Auxiliary, Department of New York, at a special defense meeting held in The New York Times Hall, 283 West Forty-fourth Street.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 8 -- The defense of Singapore -- a month-long succession of brief stands along natural lines of resistance, each followed by withdrawal in face of the foe's overwhelming numbers -- centered tonight on Kuala Lumpur, capital of the Federated Malay States.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks snapped a sixgame losing streak tonight by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 1, in a National Hockey League engagement.
One battle has been won in this war -- that of comfort and health versus woman's desire to be fashionable at the cost of freezing.

The British rediscovered early in their participation in the war that even amid great and necessary changes much of the process of living went on as usual. They were even criticized for it, as if bombs could stop flowers from blooming or small children from smiling.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr., former Markets Commissioner, who recently resigned his municipal post following a dispute with Mayor La Guardia, is now "considering" an offer to become executive director of the newly formed Metropolitan Package Stores Association, he said last night.

A report received from Rupert E. West of the North Carolina Conservation Department indicates that Currituck Sound is now the feeding ground for more waterfowl than have been seen in that area for more than twenty years.

To carry out its plan of decentralizing Washington bureaus which are not directly engaged in war work the Administration decided at first to move the Patent Office intact to New York. A staff of 1,460, of whom 650 are technically trained men and women, reconciled itself to this uprooting of work place and home, largely because it could work as effectively in New York as in Washington.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 8 -- That the Russians are developing offensive operations across the ice of the Gulf of Finland against Finnish positions either on the Finnish islands or against the mainland was indicated by today's Helsinki communique, which spoke of Finnish aviation machine-gunning Russian troops on the ice of the gulf.

Three symphonies from three centuries made up the program presented by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, last night in Carnegie Hall. In addition to Haydn's work in the form in B flat (No. 9 in the Salomon series) and the Brahms Fourth, the list contained the "Kormtchaia" symphony by Arthur Vincent Lourie, which received its first New York performance.

Outright divestment of the Blue and Red networks of the National Broadcasting Company and the creation of direct competition between the two in the radio field has been decided upon by the management of the Radio Corporation of America, parent concern of NBC, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- German influence is still evident in some areas of American industry, a House investigating committee was told today by Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Anti-Trust Division.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, billiards boy wonder forty years ago and today a greater figure than ever in the game, tomorrow night will start the defense of his world three-cushion crown against nine other experts in a tournament to run through Jan. 23.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- H.G. Wells's novel, "The History of Mr. Polly," was purchased today by RKO as a vehicle for Charles Laughton and has been scheduled for April production. First published in 1909, the Wells novel recounts the adventures of a middleclass Englishman who, by committing arson, solves the financial problems of a whole town.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation, the United States Navy, Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan began investigations yesterday into the possibilities of sabotage in early morning fires which destroyed municipal pier 83 and two buildings at Forty-third Street and the North River, and burned out part of the upper three floors of the six-story loft building at 30 West Thirteenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 8 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded in New York) -- Half of the Japanese Foreign Office was burned down today in a 2 1/2-hour fire that Domei, Japanese news agency, said was caused by an overheated stove.
BERLIN, Jan. 8 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Representatives of small business are expected to meet here early next month to devise programs which the little business man, Congress and State Legislatures can follow to ease the plight of smaller business under a wartime economy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Charles A. Lindbergh arrived here today, presumably in connection with his offer to serve in the Army Air Corps.

In using the familiar decoy of false reports to obtain information regarding the movements of the Pacific fleet, the Japanese at least admit that the vessels they claim to have attacked off the Australian coast were not sunk at Pearl Harbor, as they originally boasted.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Friday, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Japanese planes last night bombed the Netherland naval air base at Amboina Island, in the Molucca group between New Guinea and Celebes, for the third time in three days, according to press dispatches today. Damage was described as small.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The names of Senators Nye, Reynolds and Clark of Idaho, and Representative Stratton of Illinois were brought into the perjury trial of George Hill, second secretary to Representative Fish of New York, when eighteen mailbags containing franked Congressional speeches were opened in court today.

Colonel Will Le Roy Pyles, in 20 E 35th St; Lieut. Col. Arthur G. Stevens, Henry Engelhardt, president of Henry Engelhardt Co, Inc, William E. Abernethy, Charles Ritter, in 161 W 16th St; Irwin J. Pollack, in 400 E 50th St; William Wemple, through Tishman Realty and Construction Co, Inc, in 410 E 57th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc, broker.

An amendment has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Connecticut Light and Power Company advancing the dividend rates on the proposed offering of 200,000 shares of $2 cumulative preferred stock of no par value to $2.20 and on the proposed 136,088 shares of $2.25 cumulative preferred stock of no par value to $2.40.

Purchase of two apartment houses on the East Side by an investor was reported yesterday when the five-story buildings with stores at 344-6 East Forty-sixth Street were sold by the Mutual Life Insurance Company in an all-cash transaction.
In the interests of war-time charity, Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, tonight will make his twentieth defense of the title he won in 1937 from James J. Braddock.

VICHY, France, Jan. 8 -- On the Russian front the war is being fought over again -- but this time in reverse. Familiar place-names are reappearing in communiques; so are familiar phrases, such as "stubborn resistance," "withdrawal to a new position" and "pincers manoeuvre."

News from Europe these days sometimes raises more questions than it answers. For example, a few days ago THE TIMES published a dispatch telephoned from Berne quoting an Italian newspaper's disparaging comment on the appearance of German soldiers returning from the Russian front.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- It is possible only to speculate on the future of golf and on the way our game may be affected by the war. There has been speculation on the possibility of labor shortages and the chance that many courses might have to eliminate sand traps.

Dr. Fuad Isa Shatara, Brooklyn physician and president of the Arab National League, was listed by the police yesterday afternoon as a suicide after his body had been found in his offices, where he also lived, at 153 Clinton Street, Brooklyn. He was 48 years old.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 (AP) -- It may be much like bestowing a fatal kiss, but professional playmates of West Virginia Sammy Snead have named him as the one most likely to win the $10,000 Los Angeles open, which starts tomorrow.

Registration for voluntary national defense of 35,000 members of the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America, the national religious women's Zionist movement, took place yesterday throughout the nation.

Posters advising patrons of the city's unified subway lines how to act during air raids or blackouts and informing them of operating procedure under such conditions, were placed yesterday in all subway and elevated cars and stations and in all street cars and buses owned and operated by the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- A less than seasonal increase in department store sales was reported for December and the adjusted index of the Federal Reserve Board, based on the 1923-25 average dropped to 110, compared with 116 for November, 105 for October and 101 for December, 1940.

The four-story modern-style apartment house at 84-6 Highland Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., containing fifteen suites of two and three rooms, has been sold by the Broadway-Thirty-seven Street Corporation for cash above a first mortgage of $45,000 to Berclaire, Inc., for investment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Fordham's basketball team outclassed Georgetown University's five in the second half tonight to score an impressive 53-31 victory before 2,500 fans.

A quota of 2,000,000 books was set for New York City yesterday by officials of the Victory Book Campaign, a drive that will open Monday to raise nationally 10,000,000 books for the reading needs of the rapidly expanding armed services of the nation and its merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Special Bishops Committee on the Pope's Peace Points issued a statement today declaring that the wholehearted acceptance by all the nations of the world of the "Law of Nations," once the moral yardstick of the Christian West, "is the prime necessity for a righteous peace."

A budget request of $146,583,425 for the New York City school system for 1942-43 $320,089 less than the mount available to the schools this year, was presented yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the Board of Education's finance committee.

The United States steel industry produced last year 82,927,557 tons of steel ingots, or nearly 25 per cent more than the previous record output of 66,981,662 tons in 1940, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The output last year exceeded by about 65 per cent the peak output in the World War 1, which was established in 1917, when 50,467,880 tons were produced.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Highway officials in Westchester County approved today a proposal by New York City to close for the duration of the war the road that crosses Kensico Dam in the Town of Mount Pleasant, but objections were raised to a suggestion that the road across Croton Dam in the Town of Cortlandt also be closed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 8 -Drafting of single women between the ages of 21 and 35 to train them for wartime jobs is favored by an overwhelming majority of American voters polled in a nation-wide survey by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

Gerard Swope, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, yesterday presented to Commissioner Edwin A. Salmon, chairman of the City Planning Commission, an outline of a post-war rehabilitation program for seven large districts in New York.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Reports from Stockholm that Heinrich Himmler, German Gestapo chief, might have been allowed to establish an Elite Guard air force jibed today with widely circulated rumors here that Herr Himmler had established machine-gun nests in principal German cities to guard against possible revolution.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes, as petroleum coordinator, assured the country today that there was "no immediate prospect" of gasoline rationing as a war measure.

The House of Commons, like the House of Representatives, preserves its ancient habit of free speech. And since it takes all kinds of opinion to make a popular assembly, it is not surprising to find several members of the Commons arising yesterday, on the first day of general debate following the Washington conferences of Mr. Roosevelt and Mr. Churchill, to criticize the results of these successful consultations.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 8 -"Iceland's Role Today," was discussed this afternoon by Vilhjalmur Stefansson, veteran Arctic explorer, at the season's first meeting of the Palm Beach Round Table at the Everglades Club.

Senator Luigi Albertini, whose death in Rome was announced a few days ago, will long be remembered as one of the most powerful figures in Italian public life during the first quarter of this century and as one of the most courageous fighters for constitutional government once his country was overrun by fascism.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The stock markets continued today in a cheerful mood.

BATAVIA, Friday, Jan. 9 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Within a few hours after an appeal had been broadcast for native volunteer air raid wardens to work in Batavia's kampongs, or native quarters, more than 300 Indonesian men and women had volunteered.

Detailed reports from Honolulu indicate that the part played by Japanese Fifth Columnists in bringing about the Pearl Harbor disaster was considerable. Since much more than one-third of the population of the islands is racially Japanese, it is natural that this should have been so.

The 1,173 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $58,236,901,332 par value as of Dec. 31, had a total market value of $55,033,616,312, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Nov. 30, there were 1,281 issues, aggregating $57,821,383,127 par value, which had a total market value of $54,812,793,945.

Four properties in Manhattan of the late Julius Forstmann, woolen manufacturer, have been sold by his heirs in a cash transaction, it was announced yesterday. They include the twenty-five-room town house at 20-22 East Seventy-first Street and have total assessed valuation of $627,000.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 8 -- Under the cover afforded by a sandstorm that was sweeping along the coast of the Gulf of Sidra, Axis forces around Agedabia began to withdraw southwestward yesterday, apparently hoping to shorten their line of communication with Tripoli.

Mayor La Guardia received a new official residence yesterday when the Board of Estimate unanimously designated the historic Gracie Mansion, on the highest point of Carl Schurz Park, Eighty-eighth Street and the East River, as the official home of the Mayor and his successors.

The trustees of the Roosevelt Hospital, one of the leading medical institutions in the world, played host yesterday to 1,500 specially invited guests, including Mayor La Guardia, at the official opening of the new $1,000,000 building at 428 West Fifty-ninth Street, which occupies the central part of the block between Fifty-eighth and Fifty-ninth Streets at Ninth Avenue.

Paintings from the collection of Esther Slater Kerrigan, including work by old and modern masters, brought $44,050 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the first of several auction sessions.

GLADSTONE, N.J., Jan. 8 -- An emergency hospital designed to take care of overflow patients from hospitals and other institutions in the North New Jersey defense area in the event of a disaster is nearing completion today on the 5,000 acre estate, Hamilton Farms, of Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting, here.
John Homenny bought a new suit last Fall -- a double-breasted blue suit with a pin stripe. So far it has cost him an additional $15 just to wear it on three occasions, one of which was Christmas Day.
ROME, Jan. 8 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique today said:

TOKYO, Jan. 8 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- The Japanese Navy now dominates the Pacific Ocean and would welcome a battle with Anglo-American sea forces because it would "end the struggle at once," Captain Hideo Hiraide, chief of the navy press section of the Imperial headquarters, said tonight.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 8 -- Flying more than 300 miles over jungle and mountain bases in Burma, five aircraft of American volunteers operating with the British air force attacked airdromes near Bangkok today in the second raid in twenty-four hours on the Thai capital and airdromes near by.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8 -- With California's great truck farming and fruit raising valleys destined for an important place in the American program of increased productivity, the State Council of Defense took steps today looking to "a protective custodianship" for Japanese nationals who form a cog in the production machine.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- A dispatch from the Western Malayan Front by a United Press correspondent today revealed that the Imperials were making no attempt to hold a continuous line, but that they were setting up artillery emplacements at all strategic sites and were making major use of small commando units, mostly composed of Australians and Indians, including 18-year-old youths, who infiltrated Japanese-held areas to "sabotage, hamper, destroy and kill."

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- In an attempt to rid New York City of its "parked car" problems and relieve traffic congestion there Senator Halpern and Assemblyman Latham, both of Queens, introduced in the Legislature today a bill establishing a New York City Parking Authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Generally rising prices in the week ended on Jan. 3 carried the wholesale price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics to the highest level reached since October, 1929, it was announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average, advanced to 94.3 last week, compared with 93.8 on Dec. 27, 94.0 on Dec. 20, 92.2 on Dec. 6 and 80.2 on Jan. 4, 1941.

Enforcement measures in connection with the fair trade practice prohibiting group showings have been taken because of the efforts of some buying offices to revive such showings, the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 9 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Japan Times Advertiser, government organ, said today that, once a Japanese landing was made on the American Continent, "it will be a simple matter for a well-trained and courageous army to sweep everything before it."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- In findings issued by the Securities and Exchange Commission today in connection with its recent order approving the proposed fiscal reorganization of the Alabama Power Company the commission stated that it took no exception to the selection of Wendell Willkie's law firm as counsel to represent prospective purchasers of Alabama's proposed $80,000,000 bond issue although Mr. Willkie was formerly counsel and then president of Alabama's parent, the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

Reflecting the increased interest in coffee brought about by the signing of the Inter-American Coffee Quota Agreement, trading in coffee futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange in 1941 reached the highest volume since 1937, W.W. Pinney, president of the Exchange, said yesterday in his annual report to members.

With imports of rabbit fur, straw hat bodies and braids curtailed further through extension of war to the Pacific, the men's hat industry is making every effort to develop fur substitutes and to increase straw and braid sources of supply in the Western hemisphere, it was reported yesterday at the semi-annual Hat Industry and Allied Trades meeting in the auditorium of the Chanin Building.

Now that the fuss and flurry of the holidays have subsided, the Consumers Division of the New York Department of Markets has looked over the city's meat stalls and compared quotations with the pre-Christmas prices. Lamb and pork are a little lower than they were on the week-end of Dec. 20, but beef and veal are showing uppish tendencies.

The last major bond financing by New York City for the duration of the war will take place soon when an issue of $50,000,000 in long-term bonds will be offered to the public, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday. This flotation will finance outstanding contract liabilities and authorizations which have already been charged against the city's debt limit, he said.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Sir Archibald Sinclair, British Air Secretary, said in a speech today that risks were and must be taken by Britain and the United States in the Far East to make available the greatest concentration of strength against the Nazis as aid to the Russians and to beat the Axis in North Africa.

Two of Wall Street's largest banks, the Bankers Trust Company and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, held their annual meetings of stockholders yesterday. S. Sloan Colt, president of Bankers Trust, reported operating earnings for 1941 of $7,967,486, equivalent to $3.19 a share on the 2,500,000 shares outstanding, compared with $8,399,166, or $3.36 a share in 1940.

The sum of $170,777 in cash and securities was recovered for victims of stock swindlers in New York City during 1941 by the State Bureau of Securities, Attorney General John J. Bennett reported yesterday. There were 179 investors who received these restitutions, a larger number of such beneficiaries than ever before.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Jan. 9 -- The siege of Sevastopol has been lifted and the Germans' main forces southeast of that port are withdrawing to new positions southwest of Simferopol for what may develop into the battle for Southern Crimea, according to Moscow's military spokesman in his broadcast this morning.
Stewards of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association, at their annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore last night, unanimously decided to hold the Poughkeepsie regatta if at all possible this June.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt had no engagements today.

The possibility that the entire production of nylon may be diverted to use in parachutes was seriously discussed in the hosiery trade yesterday, where the action of the du Pont company in reducing its allotments of nylon yarn to hosiery makers by 20 per cent brought some confusion to initial operations for Spring.

Just how far golf activities are going to be curbed by the war will be determined today and tomorrow when the United States Golf Association, governing body of the game, holds its annual meeting here.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 8 -- The Royal Australian Air Force bombed Greenwich Island yesterday, damaging installations and destroying a Japanese seaplane, it was announced here today. [Greenwich Island is just north of the equator in the region of the Bismarck Islands.]

New York streets showed more clear space at the curbs yesterday them on any of the three previous days of the city's wartime crusade against illegal parking. The extreme cold probably had something to do with it.

Although Hank Leiber, whom Manager Mel Ott obtained from the Cubs in one of his first deals as the new skipper of the Giants, is scheduled to play the outfield for New York next Summer, there is still no assurance that the husky Arizonian will appear in the uniform of the Polo Grounders in 1942.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Officials of the Office of Price Administration and several representative newspaper publishers met here today to survey the possible effects on the American newspaper industry of newsprint price increases announced by some Canadian producers.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- New York's Court of Appeals ordered the Southern Railway today to continue payments on trust certificates issued forty years ago to stockholders of the now defunct Mobile Ohio Railroad. Affirming without opinion a lower court ruling that the certificates were a "binding and unqualified obligation," the State's highest tribunal overruled the Southern Railway's application to discontinue payments as of Oct. 1, 1940.

ROME, Jan. 8 (From Italian Broadcast Recorded by The Associated Press) -- Italy's mezzi d'assalto, virtually man-carrying torpedoes, were credited today with a surprise attack the night of Dec. 17-18 on British warships in Alexandria Harbor, Egypt, in which the High Command said a battleship was seriously damaged.

Hurdling all sorts of obstacles, some not generally encountered in show business, George Hale will have the satisfaction of finally opening his musical comedy, "The Lady Comes Across," at the Forty-fourth Street tonight.

Chiefly reflecting heavy Treasury disbursements, which reduced Treasury deposits with the Federal Reserve banks by $204,000,000, excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $300,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $3,390,000,000, highest in four weeks.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The British-American Tobacco Company, Ltd., reported today for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 a net profit of 4,087,564 ($16,432,007) after charges and provision for taxation, compared with 4,865,441 ($19,559,073) in the preceding fiscal year.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The House of Commons, critical and uneasy over Allied setbacks by the Japanese, was told today by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden that the most formidable Axis partner, Germany, was suffering reverses "far more remarkable" than those the Russians inflicted on Napoleon's army in 1812.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Seven Japanese warships, including a cruiser, were destroyed by the Marines who defended Wake Island from Dec. 8 until its capture on Dec. 22, the Navy Department said in a first-hand report issued tonight, together with a special citation of the garrison by President Roosevelt.

It isn't true, after all, as J.P. Marquand announced in print a few weeks back, that his character, the sloe-eyed sleuth Mr. Moto, is to be "interned for the duration." Mr. Marquand declared yesterday that when he said that he had forgotten that his most recent Mr. Moto story, the first, incidentally, in some while, was to be published in book form.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Production of heavy or medium motor trucks may be stepped up 15 per cent next month beyond the output of February, 1941, under quotas authorized today by Donald M. Nelson, Director of Priorities of the Office of Production Management.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Roosevelt intervened today in the Senate fight over the Price Control Bill by sending a letter in which he called for retention of the Administration provisions for a single price administrator who would have full authority over farm price ceilings as well as all others.

Stocks retreated irregularly yesterday as investors attempted first to analyze the unprecedented figures contained in Wednesday's national budget and then turned to the task of reappraising their investments in the light of the coming individual corporate tax load.

VICHY, France, Jan. 8 -- In the latest of a long series of attacks on German officers in Paris and French functionaries collaborating with them, Louis Lecureuil, a French policeman on guard outside a garage in the Boulevard Magenta that had been requisitioned by the Germans, was fatally shot last night.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Chinese successes over the Japanese on four scattered fronts, including Changsha, were claimed in a war communique today as Chungking underwent a brief air raid alert, its first this year.

Declaring that the war has necessitated many additional duties for social workers, Mrs. Jean T. Bainum, volunteer placement secretary of the Community Service Society, reported yesterday that volunteers working with the society's Queens Family Service were taking part in a variety of semiprofessional projects.

The appointment of Marshall Cassidy as assistant secretary and assistant treasurer of the Jockey Club was confirmed yesterday at the organization's annual meeting. The first word of this came two days ago when the State Racing Commission stated that Cassidy had resigned as steward and that Francis Dunne had been named to fill Cassidy's post.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Red Cross workers were urged today by Mrs. Dwight F. Davis, Director of Volunteer Services, to cease and desist from all but essential use of automobiles, the purchase of other than strictly necessary woolen clothing and the waste of even a scrap of wool or bit of yarn, "extra scraps of which can be made into sweaters."

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 8 (U.P.) -- Fred Erwin Peal, 45, former Communist labor organizer, who fled to Russia to escape serving a seventeen to twenty year sentence for murder conspiracy, and later returned to give himself up, was paroled today by Governor J.M. Broughton after serving three years and eleven months.

Trains of the New York Central Railroad, including some of the "crack" specials, still show a high percentage of tardiness after eleven months of efforts to improve service, according to testimony given yesterday at a hearing before the Public Service Commision at 80 Centre Street.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Navy Department today issued the following communique, No. 25, hazed upon reports received up to noon E.S.T.:
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 8 (Reuter) -- Today's Chinese communique said:

Many parties will be held in connection with the First Reserve Aero Squadron dinner dance to be given tomorrow night in the Embassy Suite and Garden of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. Proceeds will be used to increase facilities for the welfare of men in all branches of the service.

Skiing enthusiasm was running high last night in the metropolitan area as the prospect of the first big week-end skiing this Winter appeared very favorable. Reports from all parts of the North Country indicated that skiers might find sport wherever they choose to go.

The season still is young, but it is difficult to see any of the other teams in town beating City College for the metropolitan championship the Beavers captured a year ago. By turning back St. John's in the Garden last Wednesday night City hurdled its biggest obstacle and the path looks reasonably clear from here in.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Office of Production Management submitted to the country's steel makers today a plan to speed and expand the production of steel plates, one of the most vital elements in the government's vast shipbuilding program, and urged them to operate twenty-four hours a day and seven days a week.

A suggestion that retail stores aid the national war program through extensive advertising to promote "sane, not panicky, buying," won yesterday for Mrs. Clarence C. Cox of Greenville, S.C., 36-year-old mother of two children, the title of "Mrs. Typical Customer" for 1942 in a nationwide contest of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Reporting on operations for the fiscal year ended last Oct. 11, Robert W. Wolcott, president of the Lukens Steel Company, announced yesterday that the year was one of the most successful in the 131-year history of the company.

The city's effort to obtain 1,200 acres in the Idlewild section of Queens as the site of a new municipal airport struck a temporary snag yesterday when the "Hermit of Thurston Island" balked at an official offer for his parcel of property.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- The Court of Appeals affirmed today an Appellate Division decision dismissing the complaint of the Long Island Lighting Company against the Public Service Commission on the ground that the complaint failed to state a cause of action.

KUALA LUMPUR, British Malaya, Jan. 7 -- This attractive little capital of the Federated Malay States is now unmistakeably in the war zone with the Battle for Malaya being fought in swamps, forests, rubber estates and along rivers, canals, highways and footpaths about sixty miles away.

Savings of 34,000,000 pounds of rubber a year, more than can be produced by 9,000,000 rubber trees, are being made available to the rubber reclaiming plants of the country by the B.F. Goodrich Company, according to an announcement yesterday by John L. Collyer, president.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who refused to attend a performance of the play, "In Time to Come," on Tuesday because of the presence of a Musicians Union picket line, explained yesterday that she was out of sympathy with the purpose of the picketing but that she made it a practice not to cross picket lines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Major Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, Superintendent of West Point, has been assigned to command a combat division.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Federal Works Agency started a program today to build 42,000 demountable houses for defense workers at a cost of $153,000,000.

Reclining in languorous contentment amid luxurious satins and silks, the elite of catdom from six Atlantic seaboard States displayed yesterday their fine points before an admiring throng of several hundred visitors to the opening of the fortieth annual championship cat show of the Atlantic Cat Club at the Hotel Taft.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 8 -- "Even if the alleged peace feelers or peace negotiations between Russia and Finland were correct, I may assure you that Sweden has no part in them and will not have anything to do with them in the future," an official spokesman of the Swedish Foreign Office declared to this correspondent today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Grain traders were disposed to act with considerable caution on the dull side of the markets today. Wheat had a range of around 1 cent a bushel, and while there was a moderate recovery after a break around mid-day, the close was 1/2 to 3/4 cent lower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- To conserve sugar and increase production of war-vital industrial alcohol, the OPM gave orders today that about 60 per cent of the distilling industry's capacity should be diverted to manufacture of 190 proof ethyl alcohol from corn or other grain.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Deputy Prime Minister Clement Attlee and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden presented a review of the war before the House of Commons today. The feature of the debate was not so much what either government speaker had to say but the fact that many of the speakers -- none of them with much influence in the House -- criticized the government unmercifully, particularly as regards preparations in Malaya.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Federal Trade Commission issued 357 formal complaints charging unlawful practices in the last fiscal year, according to that agency's annual report submitted to Congress today. Of the complaints issued eleven involved cases of alleged combination to fix and maintain prices, six of alleged combination and conspiracy in restraint of trade, 219 dealt with alleged misleading representation in advertisements, labels and otherwise, and fifty-seven alleged price discrimination under the Robinson-Patman Act.

Trading in cotton futures was quiet yesterday as traders continued to await the outcome of discussion in the Senate on the price-control bill. Prices of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange drifed downward from the opening under moderate liquidation operations and closed with net losses of 7 to 12 points.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- For the first time in eighteen weeks the Bank of England's note circulation registered a decrease, the bank's condition statement disclosed today. The decrease was 1,897,000.

The famed Millrose 600, one of the classic races of the indoor track season, has a new name. John W. Magan, chairman of the board of governors of the Millrose A.A., announced yesterday that the race henceforth will be known as the Mel Sheppard 600 when it is renewed at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 1.
PINEHURST, N. C., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Dogs trained and handled by George Crangle of Waynesboro, Ga., made a clean sweep in the Free-for-All Stake of the Pinehurst field trials today.

Only organization is needed to obtain the generous support of all the city's business and industrial workers, from the head men down to the manual laborers, it was insisted yesterday by speakers at a meeting of group leaders of the Greater New York Red Cross War Fund in the offices of the General Foods Corporation, 250 Park Avenue, under the chairmanship of Colby M. Chester.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 8 -- The Anglo-Russian-Iranian treaty that gives Russia and Britain control of military transport across this country and permission to station troops here during the present war will be signed in the very near future, Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi told this correspondent in an interview.

Charges of "Red control" which have agitated Actors' Equity Association for years are scheduled to be settled today. At a meeting this afternoon at the Hotel Astor, the membership will decide whether to accept or reject the proposed constitutional amendment barring Communists, Nazis or Fascists or their sympathizers from holding office or being employed by Equity.

In January, 1842, Joseph W. Gray, a Vermonter who had taught school in Cleveland, joined his brother in buying a Democratic evening paper called The Advertiser. He must have been a genius, for he gave to his new purchase the lonely and striking name, Cleveland Plain Dealer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Basic in the Reuther Plan in December, 1940, was not the proposal that motor manufacturing facilities be converted and pooled for armament production with an immediate goal of 500 warplanes a day. Many engineers outside the ranks of labor had been working for this general objective before then, though they differed as to the rate of conversion and the early ratio of warplane production.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 8 -- Government control of all banking transactions with non-American countries as a war measure to curb the activities of foreign agents was decided upon when the Cabinet met this morning with Acting President Ramon S. Castillo.

The St. Francis College five of Brooklyn made it eight victories in a row last night by downing Geneva, 67 to 52, on the home court. Captain Tony Braginetz led the victors' attack with 16 points, while Charlie De Venzio was high for the visitors with 14.

Mrs. Marie Brady, 75 years old, a widow, who, according to her neighbors, led the life of a recluse for the last two years, was burned to death yesterday when an oil stove overturned in her three-room apartment at 525 West 131st Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 8 -- This country's railroads are fully prepared to give adequate service if industry goes on a seven-day-week production basis, but because of priority limitations on materials, they are having difficulty in adding to rolling stock, it was announced here today at the eighteenth annual meeting in the Robert Treat Hotel of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board.

Dr. John J. Moorhead, medical director of the city's unified transit system, returned from Hawaii yesterday to report to Mayor La Guardia his experience as an eye-witness of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7 and to give some information on civilian defense measures adopted in Honolulu after the raid.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Ten men perished in the Atlantic today when the Army mine sweeper Arnold foundered about 20 miles off the Isles of Shoals while being towed to port.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- New York City's delicate financial condition was brought into the new legislative session today when bills were introduced to continue for another year the present city emergency taxing powers, which have been in effect, with modifications, since 1934. The principal tax levied under the taxing power is the city sales tax.

Morgan Stanley Co., since 1935 engaged almost exclusively in the business of underwriting and whloesaling of new issues of securities, will become today active members of the New York Stock Exchange. Action taken yesterday afternoon by the board of governors of the Stock Exchange in approving the transfer of a seat from Clarence R. Hayes to John M. Young, the latter a partner in Morgan Stanley Co, consummated the transition.

Our country has been attacked and is now at war. We are all expected to make sacrifices and to accept a lower standard of living in order to purchase the arms to equip those drafted to defend our way of life.

The Alabama Power Company will issue today a public invitation for proposals for the purchase of $80,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1972, with the stipulation that the coupon rate shall be specified by the bidders in multiples of one-eighth of 1 per cent, but not exceeding 3 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Enlistments in the Army in December, spurred along by the Japanese attack of Dec. 7, will probably exceed 60,000, a record 50 per cent larger than the greatest enlistment month in the last war, John J. McCloy, Assistant Secretary of War, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Joseph W. Alsop Jr., sixth cousin of President Roosevelt and second cousin of Mrs. Roosevelt, is a prisoner of the Japanese at Hong Kong, the State Department believes.

Further opposition by consumer representatives to the proposal to raise fluid milk payments to farmers was voiced yesterday at the second of three sessions here of the public hearing on proposed amendments to the Federal-State milk marketing order governing the metropolitan area.

The Prudential Insurance Company of America has sold to a client of Van Wert Swanson, Inc., the Colonial house with nine rooms and four baths at 60 High Ridge Road, in the Old Colony Ridge section of Hartsdale, Westchester.

In the belief that their primary task is to conserve rubber, local tire rationing boards are refusing permits for the purchase of new tires and tubes in most cases in which there is any doubt of the applicant's eligibility, a review of recent rulings indicated yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Vast columns of newly trained troops from Russia's almost limitless reserves tonight were reported moving up to the central front, where the Soviet offensive was rolling on toward a great collision with German forces attempting to dig in on the Vyazma-Bryansk line 130 miles westward beyond Moscow and half way back to Smolensk.

Thirty-two gifts totaling $702.50 were received yesterday for the Neediest Cases, increasing the Fund to $260,759.17. The largest gift of the day was $386.26 from the Annie C. Kane Fund, while a contribution of $100 was received from Waldes Koh-I-Noor, Inc.

Harried recruiting officials of the Coast Guard office at 1 State Street announced yesterday that a quota system had been established because of heavy post-holiday enlistments, following an already record-breaking rush of recruits that began when Japan attacked Hawaii.

An association of Free Germans, consisting of leading representatives of the political parties of the Weimar coalition that governed the German Republic, has been organized here and has declared its intention to adhere to the Allied joint agreement signed by the twenty-six United Nations on Jan. 1 in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -Senator Byrd of Virginia, chairman of the joint economy committee, declared today that actual reductions in nondefense expenditures in President Roosevelt's new budget would total only $437,000,000 under those for the current fiscal year.

CHANGSHA, China, Jan. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Eighty thousand Chinese soldiers defeated 120,000 Japanese battling for this important city on the Canton-Hankow Railway because they "completely outwitted" them, General Hsueh Yueh, commander of the victorious defenders, told American and British correspondents and military attaches today.

The recently completed twelve-store taxpayer at 98-88 to 98-108 Queens Boulevard, Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by Emm-Ess Properties, Inc., Murray Maran, president, to an investing client of L.J. Phillips Co. The building, which is said to be fully rented, has a frontage of 200 feet on Queens Boulevard and is 100 feet deep.

Squads of cautious workmen under the supervision of Navy officers are making rapid progress in removing a treasure in art work and luxurious furnishings from the former French liner Normandie, according to an announcement made yesterday by the material office of the Third Naval District.
ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Fred W. Hammond was a central figure in a bitter political fight which rent the Republican party in the State and which resulted in eventual party reorganization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The United States-Filipino forces, drawn into a tight defensive position on the west coast of the Island of Luzon, manned their lines today in expectation of an attempted crushing attack by the Japanese.

David Warfield, veteran actor whose last appearance on Broadway was as Shylock in "The Merchant of Venice," under the management of the late David Belasco, was honored yesterday by his associates in the New York Academy and the Lambs Club.

There were 473,940,000 gallons of whiskey, rum, brandy and alcohol produced in the United States in the last fiscal year and also 55,143,000 barrels of malted liquors, according to the Internal Revenue Bureau. Whiskey alone accounted for 121,726,000 gallons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Responding to a suit in a Missouri State court, the Federal Government admitted today that Negroes had been discriminated against in the hiring of employes on a St. Louis low-cost housing project and joined some Negro petitioners in asking a decree to enforce the non-discrimination covenant in contracts for the project.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Headed by Summer Welles, Under-Secretary of State, the United States delegation today left Washington en route to the Inter-American Conference in Rio de Janeiro Brazil. It is hoped here that the conference, convening next Thursday, will lead to closer Latin-American cooperation in the war effort.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 8 (AP) -The hope of the world is in the ballot boxes of America, Clarence Budington Kelland, author and new publicity director of the Republican National Committee, said today at the annual convention of the American National Livestock Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Style changes likely to affect men's and boys' clothing as a result of the wool-conservation program will include elimination of the double-breasted overcoat and of the vest now supplied with double-breasted suits, according to members of the men's and boys' clothing industry who met with executives of the Office of Production Management here today.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The British Command issued this communique today:

Because taking orders is part of a child's daily program, directors of the Children's Aid Society agreed yesterday that youthful cooperation had accounted for the success of simultaneous air raid drills in the society's six centers.

Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister and active anti-fascist leader, announced yesterday that he had sent telegrams to President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull pledging the support of 800,000 Italians living in the United States in the fight against fascism.

On the eve of the Rio de Janeiro conference Foreign Minister Enrique de Ruiz-Guinazu of Argentina took occasion to declare that his country would continue to be "neutral." "This America of ours," he said, "must be preserved for peace, work and the hopes of men."
Active trading in Bronx realty reported yesterday was marked by deals involving two large commercial properties and a number of residential buildings of various types.

"Remember the Day" will start its third and final week today at the Roxy. . . "Girl From Leningrad," the Soviet picture at the Stanley, today will begin its fourth week. . . The first program in the Fifth Avenue Playhouse's series of "Surrealist and Fantastic Films," which includes "The Blood of a Poet," "Lot in Sodom," "Object Lesson" Charlie Chaplin's "Carmen," will enter its fourth and final week today. . .

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 8 -- The successful return to competition of the former Wheatley Stable stakes horse Snow Ridge, in the Miami Springs Purse, and one of those telephone-number daily double pay-offs highlighted the racing at Tropical Park today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Federal Housing Administration will make immediate adjustments in FHA construction-cost estimates in local areas, in relation to actual building costs, where increases in costs are stabilized and adjustments justified, it was announced today as one of several changes in regulations and procedures to increase private building especially for rental to house war workers.

THE Joe Louis-Buddy Baer bout, now coming up, is one for the book. And in the book it will be written in letters of gold. Win, lose or draw, Joe Louis now moves into a class by himself in heavyweight history. The world's heavyweight champion is putting his title on the line and taking not a cent for the work or the risk involved.

Surrogate James A. Foley granted yesterday the application of Fred S. Waterman for the removal of Elisha Huson Waterman as guardian of the person and property of his daughter, Audrey Allan Waterman Hooten, and appointed the petitioner, who is her great uncle, to succeed him as general guardian of her property jointly with the guardian clerk of the court.

Arthur H. Barker of the Yale Club, the only seeded player to get into action, had little trouble beating J.A. Lynch of the Downtown A.C. in straight games, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 12, as part of the first round was completed in the eighth annual New York State squash racquets tournament at the Downtown A.C. yesterday.
City department heads established new echedules for their clerical employes yesterday in line with Mayor La Guardia's order that city employes must work a full day on Saturday instead of a half day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- On Dec. 31, 1941, three weeks after the formal entry of the United States into the war, every resident of the United States theoretically had $83.38 in his pocket, as compared with $40.23 in 1917 when the United States entered the first World War. These figures emerge from the circulation statement of United States money issued today by the Treasury.
A twelve-pound dark Cornish cock was selected as "best bird in the show" from among 5,000 poultry entries here yesterday at the forty-second annual New York Poultry Show.

DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Acting on the request of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), the Office of Production Management has agreed to raise the quotas assigned to automobile plants for manufacture of replacement parts, Richard T. Frankensteen and Richard E. Reisinger, members of the U.A.W.-C.I.O. committee on defense employment, said today.

Twenty 5 1/2 year-olds of exceptional intelligence have been chosen by the Hunter College Elementary School to enter the kindergarten next month, Dr. Florence N. Brumbaugh, principal of the school, announced yesterday. The new group of "gifted children" will be the second selected for the 7-year experimental program conducted by the Board of Higher Education in the education of children of superior intelligence.

The Western Union Telegraph Company in the eleven months to Nov. 30 had a net income of $6,079,274 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, it was announced yesterday by A.N. Williams, president. This was equal to $5.81 each on 1,045,277 shares of capital stock.
New Year's resolutions for the woman who wants to volunteer her services to help defend the country are urged by the Volunteer Participation Division of the New York State Council of Defense.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 9 -- The major social event tonight was the opening dinner at the Beach Club.

States and municipalities will continue their vigorous opposition to the renewal of the Treasury Department's attempts to tax future issues of State and municipal securities, Austin J. Tobin, secretary of the Conference on State Defense, declared in a statement issued yesterday.
Seafarers using New York Harbor and waters in the vicinity were warned yesterday of radical changes in harbor entrance lights normally used by incoming vessels.

TRENTON, Jan. 9 -- The Court of Errors and Appeals upheld today the authority of Hudson County's Municipal Criminal Courts to try alleged violators of the Disorderly Persons Act. The decision was regarded as binding also on the courts in Bergen and Passaic Counties, where the setup is similar to that in Hudson.
