LONDON, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Spearheads of Russia's midwinter offensive are now 130 miles west of Moscow, one-third of the way back to the old Latvian border, and are battering down the German siege lines around Leningrad, raising hopes that the old Czarist capital may soon be relieved, Eastern-front dispatches said tonight.

The first formal resolution of a college sports governing body calling for continuation of football in the East through a full season of 1942 featured the second day's meetings at the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics in the Biltmore yesterday.

Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, is to be commended for his recommendation that military training be again established in the high schools of the city. It was demonstrated during the World War that the training of high school students in the Reserve Officer Training Corps units is entirely feasible.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 8 (delayed) -- Russia's 200th day of war against Germany coincided with the Christmas Day of the Russian Orthodox Church. In Kuibyshev's large church members of Russia's older generation gathered last night for a solemn candlelit Christmas Eve service with all its formalistic pomp.

The crack City College basketball forces will clash with St. Joseph's of Philadelphia at Madison Square Garden tonight in the opening game of a double-header which will send Long Island University against Georgetown in the finale.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9 -- The New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals today sustained the legality of the 1937 Fair Trade Act allowing manufacturers and wholesalers to place minimum resale prices on their products through contracts with their customers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- War Department communique No. 52, based on reports up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

The former residence of the late Spotswood D. Bowers, a five-story building with marble front and deep extension at 4 East Seventy-seventh Street, will be altered into small apartments as the result of its sale yesterday by the Union Dime Savings Bank to a client of Willkie, Owens, Otis Bailey, attorneys. The property has a frontage of twenty-five feet, 120 feet east of Fifth Avenue, and is assessed at $85,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Reporting the highest paid-up membership in its history, 4,827,724 on Dec. 31, the American Federation of Labor joined the Congress of Industrial Organizations today in contending that President Roosevelt's huge armament production goals can be met if there is full cooperation between management and labor, with both groups "given real representation in all war-production policy-making and activities."

WASHINGTON is a white-collar town, with all that the phrase implies. For the past six years I have been going there regularly; I have never learned to like it. There are some wonderful people there, men and women who are doing their selfless and largely anonymous best to keep the country going, or to prod some dream alive. But the atmosphere smells of paper work, of desk work, of inter-office memos.

IT may be recalled that, one day last Autumn, the distinguished Albert Benjamin (Happy) Chandler, Junior Senator from Kentucky, rose up in debate on the Senate floor and, in urging a change from a defensive to an offensive position in the matter under consideration, said that he was a former football coach and never saw a team that could score when the other team had the ball.

The first step in the divorce of the Blue network from the National Broadcasting Company system was taken yesterday with the formation of the Blue Network Company, Inc., as a separate and wholly owned subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America. Incorporation papers for the new company, which is to be cut loose from the RCA-NBC organization, were filed in Dover, Del.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Free French leaders will withdraw their forces from the French islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon soon and announce their adherence to the twenty-six power pact, informed diplomats said today.

More than three months ago the Nazi invaders laid siege to Leningrad. Not long afterward they encircled the great Russian naval base of Sevastopol in the Crimea. This was at about the time that Hitler was assuring his people that the Soviets were beaten and so badly crushed that they never could rise again.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Jan. 3 were 244,440,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 450,000 barrels in the week, comprising increases of 284,000 and 166,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks respectively.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Administration took steps to expedite the passage of British and United States officials between this country and the United Kingdom today by authorizing Pan American Airways to stop at Foynes, in Southern Ireland.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A registration statement covering $32,500,000 of first-mortgage bonds, due 1972, and 34,000 shares of cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value was filed today by the Pennsylvania Electric Company, Johnstown, Pa., with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The securities will be sold through competitive bidding.

About 3,500 attaches, prisoners and visitors to the new Criminal Courts Building, which faces Centre, Leonard and Baxter Streets, unexpectedly participated yesterday forenoon in the first air raid alarm and blackout test in the seventeen-story structure.

A fur coat from the wardrobe of the great Prince Bismarck is among the warm clothing now being collected for the use of German soldiers in Russia. If the spirit of the Iron Chancellor and founder of the German Empire three-quarters of a century ago is anywhere in touch with present events, the incident of his warm overcoat must cause him double sorrow.

Recruiting offices of the armed services were plunged into mild turbulence here yesterday as Army and Navy officials, succeeding as usual in quietly enlisting many a "little fellow," came to three rather well-known individuals who wanted very much to serve.

Statements like "Camilli hit a very good .285" or "Nicholson batted only .254, but he's a clutch hitter" have been forthcoming with increasing regularity. The inadequacy of the present system may be seen in the numerous shifts made in the scoring rules.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- In a minister's small study, his ear tight against a telephone receiver, Private Charles R. Bogar was married last night to Margaret Pickering about 1,500 miles away in Hutchinson, Kan.

The Department of Justice, which has become an autograph collector of great power and range lately, began yesterday to collect at least eighty-eight signatures from Ezio Pinza, basso of the Metropolitan Opera Company. As an Italian, Mr. Pinza must comply with the department's ruling that all enemy aliens file statements of their plans for traveling at least a week in advance.

New York City's participation in the national campaign to collect 10,000,000 books for the use of the armed services and the merchant marine got off to a head start yesterday when contributions of books started to flow into receiving centers.

The rare spectacle of a puppy winning specialty show laurels was unfolded at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night as the fawn-coated, black-muzzled Jai-Bee of Dah-Lyn, owned by John B. Royce of Brookline, Mass., gained the top award in the Pekingese Club of America's annual exhibition for American-bred specimens.

Ralph Budd, who for a year served as defense transportation commissioner in the transport department of the advisory committee to the Council of National Defense, has left Washington and resumed his duties as president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, it became known in railroad circles yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The White House announced the appointment of James M. Landis as executive of the Office of Civilian Defense. President Roosevelt had no engagements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Employment in the war effort of the productive services of every available man and woman was urged today by high officials of the government, representatives of labor and of industry, and of agricultural, educational and civic organizations, at the opening session of the Federal Advisory Council for Employment Security.

The dairy industry of the United States "has received the most formidable challenge in its history," according to Theodore G. Montague, president of the Borden Company. That challenge, which he says is "compliance with stupendous needs arising from the war, has, at the same time, presented the dairy industry with the most tremendous opportunity of its history."
MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communique said today:

Alvaro M. Garcia was re-elected president of the Cigar Manufacturers Association of America yesterday at the association's fifth annual meeting in the Hotel Waldorf- Astoria. Walter Popper was named treasurer and Samuel Blumberg was reappointed general counsel.

Although they spent most of yesterday in conference, getting ready for the annual meeting to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria this morning, starting at 11 o'clock, officials of the United States Golf Association refused even to hint at what action they are going to take concerning this year's championships.

HONOLULU, Jan. 8 (Delayed) -- With greatly increased strength, including troops and aircraft, the Army in Hawaii is ready for a Japanese attack at any time and will hold these islands as the bastion on which control of this part of the Pacific rests, Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, the new commander of the Hawaiian Department and military governor of Hawaii, declared today at his Fort Shafter headquarters.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. "Bombay Clipper," a Universal melodrama with William Gargan, Irene Hervey, Charles Lang and Maria Montez, will be the new attraction at the Rialto.... "The Eternal Gift," a feature-length religious documentary depicting the celebration of the Roman Catholic solemn mass, will be the new offering at the Squire Theatre, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

Blue-garbed Japanese airmen sporting brown shirts with red swastikas, manned some of the planes that swooped down on Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, according to an eyewitness who has just returned to New York. The eyewitness Mrs. Roy Shanabarger, the wife of a Navy man, who was evacuated to the United States mainland around Christmas time.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 9 (AP) -- British General Headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Office of Production Management today could extend no assurances of early action on requests from manufacturers of foundation garments for an allotment of rubber necessary for production of elastic garments.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9 -- In a document in possession of the Mexican Government, one of the principal secret agents of the Spanish Government relates in detail and with gusto how he worked in the United States and Latin America in close collaboration with Germans to prepare armed resistance to the United States throughout Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The British Royal Air Force, acting for the United States Government, has dropped 2,000,000 leaflets over occupied France telling the French people of the great scope of the American war effort and counseling them to be hopeful of a victory by the United Nations. An announcement to this effect came from the White House today.

A plan for increasing milk production in the war effort through government guarantee of cost of production to farmers so they can expand their herds and achieve maximum use of their farms was proposed yesterday by Archie Wright, leader of the Farmers Union of the New York milkshed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The compromise whereby Dean James M. Landis was appointed executive of the OCD came as a $100,000,000 authorization measure for civilian defense headed for a joint Congressional conference committee after the House had voted to strip Mayor La Guardia of much of his authority by giving the War Department control over expenditure of the funds.

The first four days of the drive for the sale of defense savings stamps and bonds in Manhattan and Brooklyn retail stores yielded $468,701, it was announced yesterday at staff headquarters, 1270 Sixth Avenue. The drive was started Jan. 2, when stores instituted special facilities to increase public investments in the war effort.

TOKYO, Jan. 9 (from Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- A 10,000-ton United States cruiser, its mast visible over water, and two submarines, one of them broken in two, were found sunk at Cavite, evacuated United States naval base on the southeast shore of Manila Bay, it was said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The first regulations by Byron Price, new Director of Censorship for the war emergency, were issued today. They were of a mild nature, merely informing the public how to avoid pitfalls in writing letters to enemy or other foreign countries.

Wendell Willkie's oratorical prowess impressed Joe Louis much more than anything else at Madison Square Garden last night. When he visited the champion after the fight to congratulate him, the Brown Bomber, with more enthusiasm than he customarily shows, declared, "that was a fine speech, Mr. Willkie. Yes, sir, that was the first speech I ever heard that I liked."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Gallery favorite Horton Smith, displaying his old-time magic on the greens, knocked four blows off par to take the lead at the end of the first round of the annual $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament today.

The connection of Dr. David Hart and Dr. Frederic L. Weber, suspended chemistry professors, with the Kemkit Scientific Corporation, a concern that sold chemistry kits to students, was deliberately "kept out of sight," it was testified yesterday by the former president and general manager of the company before a Board of Higher Education trial committee at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

Response to clearance sales this week was excellent and average retail volume for the week through Wednesday, which included New Year's Day this year but not last, was estimated at 6 to 11 per cent above a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

A defense of chain broadcasting was made by Dr. Adolfo Cosentino, director of radio communications of the Argentine Republic, last night at a dinner given in his honor at the Waldorf-Astoria by the National Broadcasting Company. Fifty radio executives attended.
The St. Lawrence Flour Mills Company, Ltd., declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 35 cents a share on the common stock. This is an increase of 10 cents over the previous quarterly rate.

TOKYO, Jan. 9 (From Japanese Broadcast Recorded in New York) -- An enemy submarine torpedoed the 2,250-ton Japanese freighter Unkai Maru No. 1 yesterday morning off Izu Peninsula, the tip of which is seventy-five miles southwest of Yokohama, the navy section of Imperial Headquarters announced today.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The British Far East Command communique said today:

Six honor students who will be graduated next Friday from the Midshipmen's School aboard the Prairie State, at 136th Street and the Hudson River, received swords at a party given yesterday afternoon by the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

A large Long Island City industrial property, built just after the last war and occupied for some years by the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, has just passed into new hands in an all-cash deal involving a consideration in the neighborhood of $250,000.

Donald Frame of the Harvard Club, top-seeded player in the New York State singles squash racquets championship, captured his opening-round match at the Downtown A.C. yesterday by defeating Frank Bowden, Seventh Regiment, in straight games, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 5, 15 -- 12.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Saturday, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Sinking of a Netherland freighter by a Japanese submarine in the Java Sea, northeast of Batavia, was announced by the Navy Department today as these vital islands braced themselves for a major Japanse invasion thrust that authoritative quarters believed to be imminent.

Bonds called and prepaid before their maturity dates in 1941 exceeded in voulme redemptions in any year since 1936. The total of retirements last year was $2,553,505,000, compared with $2,081,622,000 in 1940, and with $3,392,217,000 in 1936.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The interruption of Malayan exports of rubber and tin by Japanese hostilities not only threatens to put the American citizen back on iron tires and sole leather, but seriously affects the British balance of payments with the United States, thus increasing the burden on Lease-Lend.

Thomas Wilfred opened the second half of his Lumia season last night at the Art Institute of Light in Grand Central Palace. As usual, no performances were given during the holidays. From now until some time in May recitals on the color organ will be offered every Friday evening.

Brewery trucks that deliver beer have been ruled ineligible for new tires and tubes, as have the cars used by district attorneys and their assistants, Harold W. McGraw, Federal Tire Rationing Administrator for New York City, disclosed yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 9 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Concentrated British artillery fire against Axis pockets in the Solum area was acknowledged by the High Command today, but it said that German and Italian fliers effectively bombed and machine-gunned encampments and troops in the Agedabia sector of Libya.

Tea for two -- or tea for twenty -- is a bright and pleasant prospect as the metropolis settles down to those damp gray days that make New Yorkers swear theirs is the chilliest city in the world. Draw the table nearer to the fire, polish the copper kettle till it shines with a warm, inviting glow, and invite your friends in to tea.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The loss of the 8,000-ton ship Ruth Alexander, owned by the American President Lines, as a result of bombing by a Japanese airplane in East Indies waters was reported by the Navy in a communique issued tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Two Ger man planes, tackled by fighters of the American Volunteer Eagle Squadron, dived or crashed into the English Channel today, the Air Ministry news service reported tonight.

H.M. McAdoo, president of the United States Leather Company, reported to stockholders in the annual statement for the fiscal year ended last Oct. 31, consolidated net profit of $1,064,920 after depreciation, interest, $300,000 reserve for income taxes, $1,261,103 provision for inventories, contingencies and other charges.

Mrs. Preston Davie, national vice president of the American Women's Voluntary Services, announced yesterday that Mrs. George Lewis Callery has accepted the chairmanship of a committee in charge of active organization of the unit in Delaware, last of the three States of the Second Corps Area region to be organized.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- General conditions on the Stock Exchange were much quieter today and in some directions prices became irregular, but the undertone remained good. Under the leadership of Woolworth there was some improvement in the stores shares The textiles received fresh stimulus from the Lancashire Cotton report. Building shares advanced.

Twenty-two years ago this afternoon the representatives of fourteen nations deposited their ratifications of the Treaty of Versailles at the French Foreign Office in Paris. In so doing they brought the League of Nations into official existence. Five great Powers and nine small nations had shared in the work of the commission which had drawn up the League Covenant.

Although trading in cotton futures continued quiet yesterday, prices of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with net gains of 9 to 13 points, except for January, which finished nominally at 17.66 cents, up 27 points from Thursday's close.

Mr. Roosevelt in his budget message announced that expenditures for other than direct war purposes had been reduced by slightly more than $1,000,000,000. Senator Byrd points out that the actual reduction in items listed as nondefense total only $437,000,000. Both statements are correct.

The executive board of the United Lutheran Church in America, at its quarterly meeting yesterday in its headquarters, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street, granted wartime emergency powers to the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the church, to expedite anything the church might do in aiding the war effort.

Puccini's "Tosca" received a special performance for the benefit of Barnard College yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Grace Moore again assumed the name part at this second presentation of the work this season, and Charles Kullman as before was the Cavaradossi.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue called attention yesterday to the simplified form 1040A available in cases of individual gross incomes not exceeding $3,000 and derived wholly from salary, wages, or other compensation for personal services, dividends, interest, rent, annuities, or royalties.

Today's events: "The Magic Flute," 2 P.M., and "Rigoletto," 8:30 P.M., Metropolitan Opera House; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; Eugene Gash, piano, Town Hall, 8:30 P.M.; Raya Garbousova, 'cello, Washington Irving High School, evening; Philharmonic-Symphony Chamber Orchestra, young people's concert, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 3 P.M.

More than a month has passed since we were attacked by Japan. During that time their naval, military and air operations have indicated a major economic objective for which they are now apparently striving. That is to create a rubber shortage in the United States and Great Britain by attacking Malaya, the Dutch East Indies and the Philippines, which were producing about 95 per cent of our rubber supply.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- A nation-wide campaign for $1,000,000 for immediate war work will be started Monday by the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

The most famous cat in America, Glenn Echo September Sunshine of Dunesk, won new honors yesterday at the closing session of the fortieth annual championship cat show of the Atlantic Cat Club at the Hotel Taft. The show, held in conjunction with the twenty-third Silver Society Specialty Show, was for the benefit of the Bide-A-Wee Home for Friendless Animals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- James M. Landis, dean of Harvard Law School, was appointed "executive" of the Office of Civilian Defense by President Roosevelt today. The action came on the heels of the House vote yesterday to transfer to the War Department civilian defense functions and funds from the OCD, of which Mayor La Guardia is national director.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- In the course of today's war taxation conference the Treasury's suggestions for new revenue, calculated to increase the nation's tax bill to about $27,000,000,000 in the next fiscal year, apparently revolved largely around proposed increases in present taxes.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Britain's food position has improved to such an extent that the stocks of staple commodities are actually better than before the war started, Major Gwilym Lloyd George, Parliamentary Secretary to the Food Ministry, said today at the opening of a new restaurant in Middlesbrough.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 -- A tall Cornell five came from behind to defeat Harvard, 31 -- 27, on the Crimson court tonight in the opening game of the Eastern Intercollegiate League.
For the fourth year I take this opportunity to write in praise of Sid Luckman, as fine a football player as ever put on a pair of cleats.
CHUNGKING, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A Chinese headquarters communique today said:

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The average value of daily retail sales in Great Britain for November was 1.2 per cent lower than in November, 1940, according to monthly figures issued here today by the Bank of England and the Retail Distributors Association.

Fighting with a fury he hasn't shown since the night in 1938 when he knocked out Max Scheming in one round, Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, last night stopped Buddy Baer, 250-pound Californian, in the first session of their scheduled fifteen-round bout in Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the New York Auxiliary of the Navy Relief Society.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- William Knudsen, Director General of the Office of Production Management, and Sidney Hillman, Associate Director General, followed the recent lead of President Roosevelt and Attorney General Biddle today by urging employers not to discriminate against aliens.

Many States reported an unusually large number of hunting accidents during the past year, despite the expanded efforts of conservation authorities to instruct hunters in the proper handling of firearms.
ROME, Jan. 9 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command communique said today:
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Seeded players today advanced to the semifinals of the eighteenth annual Dixie tennis tournament at the Davis Islands Club.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 9 -- During a three-alarm fire here this after noon in a three-story building at 331 Broad Street, a man unaware that his wife and daughter had been rescued by a passer-by, rushed into the structure and suffered a fractured leg on a falling stairway during his vain search.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 9 -- Fines totaling $2,200 and sentences ranging from four to eight months in the Essex County Penitentiary were imposed here today by Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan on four defendants, who had been found guilty by a jury Nov. 29 of conspiring to defraud the Pennsylvania Fire Insurance Company. All the defendants served notices of appeal, automatically staying execution of the sentences.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The Polish Army in Russia will be increased from two to six divisions as a result of the agreement reached between General Wladyslaw Sirkorsi, Polish Premier, and Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union, General Sikorski said today in reporting at a press conference on his visit to Russia and the Near East.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- By a vote of 48 to 37, the Senate rejected today an appeal of President Roosevelt by adopting the Bankhead amendment to the Price Control Bill giving to Secretary Wickard a veto power over all farm crop ceilings imposed by the Price Administrator.

Workers in New York hotels organized in the American Federation of Labor will raise $500,000 out of their own pay checks to purchase defense bonds and support the American Red Cross War Fund drive and will take a full part in all civilian defense activities, their leaders decided last night.
I was shocked to read in Joseph M. Sheehan's basketball story in THE TIMES of Jan. 3 that Creighton University's -- and I quote -- "Jay-hawks" were in town for a game at Madison Square Garden.

The appearance of several fair sized tax exempt loans lifted the total of new bond financing this week to $11,332,000, compared with $4,819,000 in new issues marketed last week. The volume of new issues, however, continued relatively light, particularly in view of the outlook for the new issue market in the next month or so.

The three-story apartment house with accommodations for twenty-four families, known as 128 East Fortieth Street, Irvington, N.J., has been sold by Coleman House, Inc., to Fred Henderer for investment. Feist Feist were the brokers and the New Jersey Realty Company, correspondent for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, arranged a new first mortgage.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Japanese dive bombers have devastated Kuala Lumpur, reports from the front said today.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Called hurriedly for consultations with British Ministers, John M. Andrews, Prime Minister 0f Northern Ireland, arrived here today on a mission whose nature was not divulged.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 -- An eye infection which, it was testified, had incapacitated about 2,000 shipyard workmen in the bay area for an average period of two or three weeks caused concern today to Federal officials interested in pushing defense production to a maximum level.

The threat to Singapore was greatly intensified yesterday as the Japanese commenced a large-scale offensive that apparently broke through the British lines along the Slim River, 235 miles by airline from Singapore.
Isn't it about time for some one to say something about the pathetic basketball officiating which has been seen in Madison Square Garden of late?

Drastic reorganization of the New York City high school courses of study, placing the schools on a wartime basis and permitting students to complete their work in three and one-half years instead of four, was announced yesterday by Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent assigned to the secondary division.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin denied yesterday an application by Sol Simons, as a stockholder of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., for an order restraining the directors of the company from carrying through an amendment to the certificate of incorporation increasing the authorized stock issue.

The need for the "France of Tomorrow" in the reconstruction of Europe after a democratic victory was emphasized yesterday at a luncheon given by the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies in the Hotel Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Agriculture Department reported today in its January citrus fruit report that the orange crop for the 1941-42 marketing season is placed at 84,726,000 boxes, compared with 84,482,000 a month ago, 84,082,000 for the 1940-41 marketing season and 60,283,000 in the ten-year average.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Selective Service System, in its wartime operations, must assume in effect the dual responsibility of apportioning able-bodied men between military and naval service, on the one hand, and essential industry, on the other, it was stated today by Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director.

Two men, slackers or thugs hired by a slacker, entered the office of a local draft board in the East New York section of Brooklyn at 6:30 o'clock last night, beat a young woman clerk into unconsciousness when she barred their way and ransacked the files, apparently in an effort to remove data on a prospective draftee.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 9 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) --The Finnish High Command issued this communique today:

Management and labor in the metropolitan clothing industry launched a joint effort to raise $150,000 for the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York at a luncheon yesterday in the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue. Pledges for $80,000, or more than half of the industry's goal, were obtained before the meeting adjourned.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- The proposed expenditure this year of $14,500,000 in Westchester County for parkway extensions, road improvements and railroad crossing eliminations will doubtless be postponed for the duration of the war, the County Park Commission announced today.

At 83, Carrie Chapman Catt is still talking about the one thing sure in an uncertain world -- the future. A mellow veteran of many wars, political, social and military, she is young because she has spent a rich and eventful life in looking forward. She has never regarded either victory or defeat as the end of the story, but only as the starting point for the next fight.

Twenty-eight patriotic organizations will be represented by delegations at a special service tomorrow at 4:30 P.M. in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street. It is the first time such a gathering has been held in a church of that denomination.

The British Broadcasting Corporation yesterday quoted official statistics of the German medical authorities as proof that "spotted typhus has spread to Germany." The text of the British broadcast, as recorded at the Columbia Broadcasting System's short-wave listening station said:

Last year some scenery worth quite a lot of money was abandoned from a musical show that decided not to come in, thank you. In any tolerant consideration of "The Lady Comes Across," which was put on at the Forty-fourth last evening, it is necessary to keep this highly materialistic fact in mind.

The Perkin Medal for 1942, awarded annually for outstanding work in applied chemistry, was presented last night to Dr. Martin H. Ittner, director of research for the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, Jersey City, N.J., for his numerous contributions in the field of soap, glycerine and similar products.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 9 -- By a vote of 3 to 1, the Newark City Commission found City Clerk Harry S. Reichenstein guilty this afternoon of misconduct during the municipal election last May and ordered him dismissed. Mr. Reichenstein announced he would appeal to the State Supreme Court.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has completed arrangements with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to act as an issuing agent for defense savings bonds purchased by its employes, it was disclosed yesterday. The A.T. T. thus becomes the first issuing agent in the Second Pederal Reserve District other than a bank. In general, corporations which assist in defense bond sales collect the money and transmit it to the Reserve Bank.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- A preliminary conference today between Congressional fiscal leaders and Treasury officials to discuss how to raise $9,000,000,000 in new taxes and social security levies indicated that the former are inclined to lean most heavily on what would be in effect a general sales tax, while the Treasury still puts the accent on heavier corporation taxes.

Compromise on two men to fill one job is often the President's favorite method of solving an administrative problem, and this is the method he has used in the case of the Office of Civilian Defense. Mayor La Guardia remains as "Director." Dean Landis of Harvard Law School becomes "Executive."

Mary Crary, diseuse, and Byrd Elliot, violinist, gave a joint recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Miss Crary's most extensive contribution was an imaginative and well-written story, "The Goddess of Joy," of which she is the author. She also was heard in three poems set to music, in which she was assisted by Miss Elliot, with Brooks Smith, the accompanist of the evening, at the piano.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 9 -- Imperial air forces are inflicting new losses on Axis sea and land supply convoys as British columns in Libya pursue the retreating Germans and Italians from Agedabia toward El Agheila, where they are expected to make a stand. The Axis forces are fighting vigorous rearguard actions to cover the withdrawal, which is on an extensive scale.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, in Western Malaya, Jan. 9 -- Strong Japanese tank and motorized forces broke through British defense positions in upper Selangor State today, ran a gamut of devastating artillery fire and advanced on Kuala Lumpur, gateway to Singapore.

Borough President Joseph A. Palma of Staten Island, testifying yesterday in Brooklyn at disbarment proceedings against his friend and former campaign manager, C. Ernest Smith, former Municipal Court justice, denied any knowledge of an alleged conspiracy for three contracting firms to pay off his 1933 campaign deficit and thereby receive open market orders on paving contracts.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Drastic curtailment of expenditures under the $60,000,000 highway bond issue approved by the voters last Fall was indicated today as a result of the war emergency. The intention of Governor Lehman, as announced in his message to the Legislature Wednesday, to drop unnecessary public work and the difficulty of obtaining materials under the priority system combine to force the curtailment.

NEWARK, N.J. Jan. 9 (AP) -- George F. Harris, dean of the Newark University Law School, recommended today legislation relieving municipalities of liability for personal injury or property damage due to the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A belief that General Douglas Mac Arthur had withdrawn his forces possibly fifteen miles to a new Philippine defense line since last Sunday's bloody repulse of the Japanese was expressed tonight by military officials.

Restudied and revitalized in some particulars, 'Lohengrin" had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Productions of this Wagner opera had fallen into a near-moribund state in seasons past; now an effort has been made to bring it to life.

More than thirty college, high and prep school mentors attended the first annual meeting of the National Soccer Coaches Association, which opened its two-day session at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. J.D. Brook, head of the organization and coach at Springfield College, presided.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Scientists are breeding a new kind of bug which they expect to exterminate the boll weevil and pink boll worm, destroyers of millions of dollars' worth of growing cotton.
Scoring its eighth victory of the season, the St. John's University basketball team turned back the Hampden-Sydney quintet of Virginia, 68 to 51, in the De Gray gymnasium in Brooklyn last night.

Plunged three weeks ago into a new situation economically and politically, the Middle West has necessarily revised its outlook for the immediate future. Politics has been abolished for the present. This most pacific section has accepted the war with a devotion and prompt response to the nation's needs.

Two actions, demanding a total of $11,183,786, were filed yesterday in Federal court by the trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation. The first, for $10,881,743, named as defendants the Public National Bank and Trust Company, depository, and Henry D. Fitch, Sanford J. Magee, Benjamin B. Robinson and Daniel Starch, escrow agents under a debt rearrangement plan for the Associated Gas and Electric Company in 1933.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Congressional activity today attracted the attention of business men concerned with the armaments program. Of prime interest was the action of the House Ways and Means Committee in approving legislation repealing a requirement in existing law that defense contractors obtain certificates from the War or Navy Departments before they can pay off plant expansion through excess profits tax deductions.

An intensive program of education and training for New York City's teachers and parents, designed to protect children during air raids, was presented yesterday by James Marshall, president Board of Education. A similar program had been undertaken last month by principals and their assistants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull indicated today that a settlement would be reached on the question of the occupation of the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon, at the mouth of the St. Lawrence River, by the Free French forces of General Charles de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Labor will receive a full place on the committees of the Defense Communications Board which are to plan the work of the country's communications systems under war conditions, James Lawrence Fly, DCB chairman, said today.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 9 -- One of the most important developments in the recent fighting on the eastern front is the conclusion of air experts that the Russians, at least temporarily, have achieved air superiority over the Germans.

The ornate ram's head perched on the end of the marble staircase inside the old Tiffany Building, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday faced a scene very different from that of the dignified, quiet shop of past years.

No country in the world today finds itself in a more bitter dilemma than Finland. As the victim of a ruthless and unprovoked attack by the Soviets, Finland thought it saw its opportunity for regaining its lost territory by joining forces with Hitler when he invaded Russia.

Mr. and Mrs. William G. Scarlett of Baltimore gave a large dinner in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday for Miss Virginia Bacon Penfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Walter Ong, and their son, William G. Scarlett Jr. of Baltimore, who are to be married today in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A National Safety Council expert predicted today that the possible combination of rattletrap automobiles, thin tires, bicycles, horse-drawn buggies and blackouts would increase the nation's traffic accident rate.

Four productions terminate their Broadway careers tonight. The latest addition to the list is "Johnny on a Spot," which will vacate the Plymouth after four performances. Others departing tonight are "Candle in the Wind," "Theatre" and "Letters to Lucerne."

The heavy silence enveloping Germany these days is only partly due to the absence of direct reports. Since the last lines of communication have been cut off, we realize that considerable light on conditions at the front and behind the front did filter out between the lines of the official versions of the news.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Charges that government officials had been negligent in failing to provide facilities for producing synthetic rubber against the day when rubber imports from the Far East were cut off were made by Senators today in the course of a conference called to consider the plight of automobile retailers hit by the government order against sales of new cars.

Although farmers had one of the most profitable years on record in 1941, the reverse was true for the grain trade. Effects of the war in Europe, which restricted exports of wheat and other grains, were more than offset by high government loans on wheat and corn and a guaranteed price of around 9 cents a pound for hogs in Chicago.
BATAVIA, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Three Japanese bombers attacked unsuccessfully the important Netherland Borneo oil center at Tarakan yesterday morning, military authorities announced today.

The first for this season of the After Dinner Dances, a subscription series for young married couples and debutantes of former years, took place last night in the Crystal Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Thomas G. Terbell is chairman of the committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Corn is rapidly becoming the center of attention for speculators. Cash interests were on both sides of the market today, with liberal hedging sales early and again at the close, while at other times there was buying against sales made to the East.

All matches in the first round of the tenth annual invitation squash racquets doubles tournament of the Greenwich and Apawamis Clubs were strenuously fought last night, most of them going four or five games.

The Graff Ballet, formerly of Chicago and now with headquarters at Newfane, Vt., made its formal New York debut last night at the Concert Theatre after several seasons of touring. Grace and Kurt Graff are its featured dancers and choreographers, there is a supporting company of eight and the music is well played on two pianos by Ann Marley and Joseph Hawes.
The United States entry into the second World War started a marriage boom across the country in the historical wartime pattern.

As a milk producer I was greatly interested in THE TIMES'S account of the recent hearing in New York to determine price advances to the farmer and hence to the consumer under the Federal-State marketing order.

The first pulp allocation order, in which the Office of Production Management will attempt to ease the burden on manufacturers of nitrating pulp, will be issued shortly, reports yesterday indicated. It was originally scheduled for the early part of this week but the OPM decided to hold it back until replies to inventory questionnaires from pulp and paper users were received.

When Mayor La Guardia announced that the five-day week was "out for the duration" in city departments and that all municipal employes would be required to work six days, he apparently meant all except 500 per diem workers in the Park Department.

Rare paintings from the collection of Esther Slater Kerrigan of this city were sold at auction last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $73,305, making the total for the first three sessions of the sale $134,767. At the second session in the afternoon $17,412 was realized.
LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Admiralty issued the following:

BOSTON, Jan. 9 -- Sales executives attending the annual New England sales management conference here today were told that, despite the oversold condition of many industries and despite the likelihood of still deeper cuts in the production of civilian goods, they should strive at all costs to maintain their sales forces and not to dissipate the work of years by the indiscriminate firing of trained men.

Alsab, winner of fifteen of twenty-three starts and prize money totaling $110,600 during his career as a 2-year-old, tops the list of 123 racers rated by John B. Campbell, handicapper and racing-secretary of New York tracks, for the third running of the Experimental Handicap, which will be run during Jamaica's Spring meeting.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A complete reshuffling of dates for the first eight weeks of the 1942 Grand Circuit harness-racing season was made necessary today when stewards of the organization received word there would be no night racing at Roosevelt Raceway on Long Island.

As a result of a shortage of merchant seamen to man vessels in vital defense trades, the National Maritime Union and the Greater New York Industrial Council of the C.I.O. have issued an appeal to former seamen asking them to return to the sea.
American horse shows will be carried on during the war as far as the fighting program permits.

CHANGSHA, China, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Two "tombs of the unknown invaders" were ordered dug today to hold the bodies and ashes of some 21,000 Japanese slaughtered by Chinese forces who sent them reeling back from Changsha in one of the worst Japanese defeats of the present conflict.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 9 -- It was officially announced today that the government had "decided to ascertain the man power available for carrying out essential war work" and was taking steps for the registration of men and women qualified to perform certain special services. The statement added:

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 9 -- Members of the Pratt family have received assessment reductions totaling $400,000 on properties on the 1,800-acre estate acquired by the late Charles Pratt, co-founder of the Standard Oil Company of New York and founder of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, according to Mayor H. Bogart Seaman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The War Department waited today in momentary expectation that General Douglas MacArthur, Commander in Chief of the United States armed forces in the Far East, would report the beginning of a new and perhaps crucial attack by the Japanese forces on the Island of Luzon, site of the sole remaining American stronghold in the Philippine Islands.

The Ingersoll-Waterbury Company, makers of Ingersoll watches, has expanded its 1942 advertising campaign, which will break in the last week of January. Two magazines distributed with Sunday newspapers, one national weekly, three farm papers and a large group of weekly newspapers will be used.

Wages went up faster than living costs in the first eleven months of 1941, according to a report made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Average weekly wages rose 20 per cent from November, 1940, to November, 1941.

VICHY, France, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- The 4,713-ton Mediterranean passenger liner Lamoriciere was caught in a violent storm and sank off the Balearic Islands in the Mediterranean today with probable heavy loss of life.

Municipal Financing State and municipal officials and many municipal bond men are taking seriously for the first time the threat of Federal taxation of the income from future issues of those political units. As a result many of those borrowers are expected to anticipate their financial requirements as far ahead as possible by speeding up the sale of new issues under the present tax exempt status.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- All amateur radio operators were ordered today to stop sending immediately. The regulation was issued by the Federal Communications Commission at the request of the Defense Communications Board.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The story of a German alien who said he failed to register because the bund threatened to harm his family in Germany was disclosed today in the Federal District Court.

What police believe to have been a lovers' quarrel ended at 3:20 A.M. today with the deaths of Amelia Velgogo, 28 years old, of 632 Willis Avenue, the Bronx, and Anchel Moreau, 32, of 501 West 146th Street. Moreau, police said, shot the girl to death and then took his own life by leaping from a roof.

The slogan "Remember Pearl Harbor" has already become the title of a book. Modern Age received yesterday from Honolulu a manuscript written by Blake Clark, Professor of English at the University of Hawaii, whose "Paradise Unlimited" was published last Fall, and Will Williams, a reporter on a Hawaiian newspaper. The book is an eye-witness account of the Japanese attack on the islands.

Another spotty performance was turned in yesterday by the stock market, with the rising rails widening the gap between them and the industrial issues. The demand for the carriers heartened some other sections of the list, but the improvement was modest and not general.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Gordon Spielman of New York City testified in District Court today that George D. Hill, secretary to Representative Fish of New York, used the frank of Senator Lundeen of Minnesota to mail speeches which the government alleges were written by George Sylvester Viereck, German propagandist. The witness was a clerk for Senator Lundeen from July, 1939, to December, 1940.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- L. Clare Cargile, president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, told the committee that, while automobile manufacturers were receiving big defense orders, the 44,000 dealers were being swept "virtually without notice or consideration into bankruptcy."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Year-around daylight saving, probably on a country-wide scale and for the duration of the war, to conserve power and fuel for defense production, seemed assured today by a 67-20 vote of the House of Representatives.

Mayor La Guardia, on his arrival [ from Washington, at La Guardia[ Field, in an Eastern Airlines plane I last night, told reporters that the] new OCD set-up would not allow him more time for his duties in New York City.

Smarting from Congressional accusations during the past few years that it is dominated by Communists, Actors Equity Association finally tried to clear itself yesterday by voting on a proposed constitutional amendment. It would prevent Communists, Nazis and Fascists and also their sympathizers from holding office or being employed by the union, an A.F. of L. affiliate.

State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by thirty-one municipalities aggregates $9,513,608, compared with $19,995,329 for this week. The average of new offerings for the first two weeks of the year stands at $11,642,377.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9 -- A joint allied war council with full control over the fighting forces of each country, including those of the United States, meets with the full approval of public opinion both in the United States and in Britain. That is the indication from surveys of public opinion just completed in the United States by the American Institute of Public Opinion and in Britain by the British Institute of Public Opinion.

Although anticipated for some time in trade circles, the OPM order requiring all distilleries that have facilities to manufacture 190 proof alcohol from corn or grain to use them in the production of that type of alcohol beginning Jan. 15 found those affected somewhat confused yesterday as to its actual effect, pending official clarification.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Louis Levine, Federal Employment Service analyst, estimated today that 17,500,000 workers, or more than 10,000,000 above the number now employed in war industries, would be required by the end of this year to produce the war materials under the President's program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- Robert Cummings will be starred in 'Boy Meets Baby," a photoplay by Leonard Spiegelgass which Henry Koster will produce and direct, Universal announced today. The scenario is based on a Hungarian play by Regis Ginoux and Jacques Thery and production will start when Cummings completes his current assignment in "Saboteur.''

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Easing of the subzero wave brought a rebound in today's buyer attendance to last year's levels and brought hope that next week's furniture market attendance would make a much better showing at both big exhibit buildings.
The public is beginning to stock up heavily on merchandise, chiefly of wool or containing rubber, that it believes is likely to become scarce in coming months, merchants here reported yesterday.
The Netherlanders are good payers as well as fine fighters. They pay 100 per cent for all armament they take from this country.

Net earnings of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for 1941 amounted to $3,392,000, after reserves, including a special reserve on bank premises, compared with $9,555,000 the previous year, Allan Sproul, president, reported yesterday in the twenty-seventh annual statement to the stockholder member banks.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Chinese Central Daily News said today that more than 500 American and British nationals had been taken into custody by the Japanese in Hankow, Wuchang and Hanyang at the Yangtze bend in Hupeh Province.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe of New York, the game's perennial wizard of the ivories, opened defense of his world three-cushion billiard championship tonight with a 50-to-29 victory over Earl Lookabaugh, veteran Chicago expert.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The 5,220-ton cruiser Galatea, which had a normal complement of 450 officers and men, has been torpedoed and sunk, according to an Admiralty communique which, as usual, did not disclose any details regarding the date or the location of this latest British naval loss, except that she was sunk by a U-boat.

The first big snowstorm that strikes the metropolitan area will send hundreds of skiers and potential enthusiasts scurrying to the hills and trails that are to be found in the city's public parks as well as the many near-by golf courses that make their facilities available for the sport.

The first week of rigid enforcement of parking regulations as a wartime measure closed yesterday. Offense lessened considerably and public officials agreed the drive has worked out astonishingly well.

The most portentous event for the coffee industry in 1941, and the most far-reaching for inter-American relations, was the implementing on April 15, last, of the Inter-American Coffee Agreement, accompanied by vigorously stimulated coffee consumption in the United States, according to Eurico Penteado, chairman of the Pan-American Coffee Bureau.

TOKYO, Jan. 9 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press) -- Kuala Lumpur, gateway to Singapore, is in Japanese hands, with British resistance broken and 200 prisoners and much booty taken, according to reports here.

Among the first to arrive at Madison Square Garden last night for the Joe Louis-Buddy Baer return meeting was a group of some two dozen British seamen. With more than two hours to wait for the championship bout to start, the visitors sat nervously, counting the minutes.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Jan. 9 -- The William MacFarland Memorial High School here was destroyed by fire today after 700 pupils and twenty-seven faculty members had marched to safety, all reaching the street one minute after the alarm had been sounded.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Railway Express Agency, Inc., which is controlled by the Class I railroads, applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for an emergency surcharge of 10 cents on each shipment. The request came near the end of a week's hearing on the application of the railroads and water carriers for a general 10 per cent increase in freight and passenger rates.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 9 -- Chinese troops pressed into Canton's suburbs today in an effort to oust the Japanese from South China's largest city with the same relentless tactics used to rout them at Changsha, 350 miles to the north, the High Command announced here.
Fordham's swimming team defeated Colgate, 46 -- 29, yesterday in the Rose Hill pool. It was the second victory of the season for the Rams, who took six of the nine events.

Stocking up by the public on merchandise likely to be scarce in the coming months boosted retail trade here this week. Consumer demand for merchandise of wool or containing rubber was especially brisk, with men's wear and children's wear topping the list.

A private dinner in the Big Room of the Rovers Club ends with the disappearance of the host. One moment Rupert Storm is sitting at the head of the table; then the lights go out, and when they are turned on again he is not there.

IT is a safe guess that nothing Fannie Hurst chooses to write, now or at any date in the foreseeable future, will fail of a large and interested feminine audience. She knows what American women, in the expert and doubtless justified opinion of women's magazine editors, want to read about.

Since THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine on Dec. 14 published excerpts from former Ambassador Joseph E. Davies's book "Mission to Moscow," and since Ralph Thompson reviews the book most favorably in your issue of Dec. 29, I venture, in the interest of truth and for the sake of the record, to offer a few observations which are none the less pertinent for being unfashionable now.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 10 -- Although the Germans may occupy Tunisia, it is highly unlikely that they will ever again threaten Egypt through the Western Desert, expert strategists here insist. They acknowledge, however, the obvious advantages of a Tunisian base.
ONE HUNDHED years ago today William James was born in the old Astor House in New York City, where a few days later Ralph Waldo Emerson came to give his blessing to the philosopher-to-be.

In a recent column we mentioned the value of snake guards for Florida quail shooting, and we received a letter from an indignant hunter who had just returned from a "solid week of shooting" in Florida and had not seen a single snake.

DOROTHY E. STEVENSON has, in the novels published since she won notice with her "Buncle" books, carved out for herself a special niche among those modem fictionists who have taken English humor as their province.

WASHINGTON -- Most cities scintillate with little facets of facts which spice the tourist's "bill of fare" while sight-seeing. Washington and Annapolis are certainly no exceptions. But there is presented here some fantastic yet true information which might transform the two cities into treasure troves for believe-it-or-not fans.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 10 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today:

Was Samuel John Gazeley murdered by the Nazi Luftwaffe or by a private individual? His body is found beside a bomb crater after an air raid on an English village, and the natural supposition is that the bomb killed him.

My generation is one which has been spoiled with ease of living and the gratification of material desires. The new but not unexpected developments may be a blessing in disguise for many of us. I have found many of my friends to have thoughts and ideals which I never expected.

Like "The Umbrella That Got Wet," by the same authors, this is a story of real children and everyday happenings told so simply that beginners can read it for themselves. It deals with matters within the young child's interest and experience -- a day in school, trips to the zoo and birthday parties.

In one of the major upsets of the basketball season highly favored City College was badly beaten by lightly regarded St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, 44 to 33, last night before a gathering of 15,826 in Madison Square Garden.

TOMORROW marks the launching of the Victory Book Campaign, which has for its objective the collection of ten million books for the use of the men in the armed forces of the United States. The campaign is sponsored by the American Library Association, the American Red Cross and the United Service Organizations for National Defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Senator Wagner, co-author of the national Labor Relations and Social Security Acts, said today that any move to crack down on the working man would be fatal to the war effort.

The amounts of the war budget submitted last week to Congress by the President are so big as to be incomprehensible. But one can be certain that government expenditures of this size will have a profound and lasting effect upon our economic life. The budgeted expenditures of $59,000,000,000, plus about $3,000,000,000 to be spent by government corporations, such as RFC, bring the total outlay for the year beginning next July 1 to $62,000,000,000.

EVERYBODY remembers the cold horror induced by the reports circulating shortly before Munich that Nazi Germany had 10,000 or even 18,000 warplanes. Many aeronautical experts in this country doubted the figures -- it was just too much for minds accustomed to thinking in terms of planes by the hundreds.

CHINATOWN has its own motion-picture theatre. Every night from 11 o'clock until 1 in the morning the Chatham Theatre on the Bowery becomes the exclusive show window for first-run Chinese films. The Chatham is a dingy grind house under the rattling Third Avenue "El," which during normal hours plays worn and dated Hollywood pictures.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 10 -- The thirty-five-room mansion and fifteen-acre shorefront estate of the late Walter P. Chrysler, automobile manufacturer, on Kings Point on Manhasset Bay, is being acquired by the United States Government in negotiations expected to be completed next week, it became known today.

THREE days after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor the United States Government clamped down a ban on the sale of new automobile tires, and followed this step, as quickly as experts could work out the details, with the first civilian rationing scheme of the war -- a drastic program designed to reduce civilian consumption of rubber by nearly 80 per cent by limiting its use to bare essentials.

The hum and bustle of activity at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York is augmented these days by the sound of hammering and pounding on the third floor game room. This large room, center of entertainment for the seamen, is being enlarged and completely transformed as the women's groups maintaining the center gear their efforts to a wartime pitch.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Three Department of Agriculture research workers have developed a process which utilizes corncobs and other farm wastes, like cornstalks, bagasse, sawdust and straw to remove iron and manganese from water.

The industrial program which President Roosevelt outlined as our goal for the next two years is so stupendous that its real significance is not easily grasped. Any one can understand that 125,000 planes, 75,000 tanks and 10,000,000 tons of merchant shipping by 1943 means a prodigious effort; but what it means in terms of labor supply, floor space and machinery only experts in such matters can tell.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 -- General Motors Corporation now is committed to turn out war supplies with a contract value of $3,758,000,000, and is prepared, if the government desires, to turn out 10 per cent of the huge manufacturing program outlined to Congress by President Roosevelt. C.E. Wilson, president of General Motors, made these figures public in an Interview today.

The Port of New York Authority has reelected four of its officers at its annual meeting. Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the organization, was named for another term, thereby becoming the oldest member in point of service.
Statistics gathered here last week indicate that since the declaration of war by the United States martial matters have not absorbed public attention to the exclusion of the peaceful arts.

Another year of sterling athletic accomplishment has just been completed by the New York Athletic Club, according to the seventy-third annual report that President Henry W. Ryan released for publication today. The report will be presented to the members at the annual meeting and election in the city clubhouse on Tuesday.

OCALA, Fla. -- The recent completion of State Road 26 across the Everglades makes this "Orange Blossom Trail" one of Florida's most direct routes to Miami. Cutting down the center of the peninsula, the "trail" passes through Lake City, Orlando and Clewiston, in its 458-mile course from the Georgia State line to Miami.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco and Otto Reiselt of Philadelphia today joined Champion Willie Hoppe and Joe Chamaco as first-round victors in the world three-cushion title billiard tourney.

The next stage of America's war with Japan is likely to be fought from the base of Australia. This is the consequence of the strong strategical position of Japan in the China Sea and her initial success in the opening weeks of the war. For the defense or recovery of the Philippines, the Netherlands Indies, Singapore and Malaya, American supplies must move down into Australian waters and thence upward toward Singapore.

AN almost life-size picture of Nadine Conner, the new lyric soprano at the Metropolitan Opera, is tacked up on the inside of the closet door in the office of assistant general manager Earle Lewis, next to the ticket office.

A RECENT broadcast from Rome on Italian contributions to the development of the United States said that President Lincoln asked General Giuseppe Garibaldi to take command of the Union forces during the Summer of 1861.

UNLESS That Man on the Coast is all off again, Eddie Dewling almost at once should be giving Broadway an evening's entertainment called "Life, Laughter and Tears." This is a group of three one-act plays, "Life" and "Tears" being by William Saroyan, "Laughter" being by Sean O'Casey.

Yachting will have a changed coloration for 1942. Instead of gleaming white on Long Island Sound and other pleasure boat waterways, there will be a predominant warring gray. A preview of the season ahead makes exciting speculation.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Jan. 10 -- In one of the most extensive intercollegiate and government-college cooperative programs undertaken at Mount Holyoke College, the political science department will "bring government to the students" next semester, when the class in current problems in government will be conducted by specialists.

Captain Robert Huntington, principal of the merchant marine school of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York for more than twenty-five years, has retired and will have the title of principal emeritus, it was announced last week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 10 -- Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha set forth today three principles on which he said the program of the conference of American Foreign Ministers, opening here Thursday, must rest and on which, he said, Brazil stood pat.

THE belt of a thousand stitches found on a Japanese pilot shot down during the Dec. 7 attack on Pearl Harbor was a sennin-bari, and a similar belt is worn by most Japanese soldiers. It is in the nature of a charm which it is believed will protect the wearer from bullets or other danger.

Local tire rationing boards throughout New York City issued certificates for only about 10 per cent of their quota in the first week of tire rationing, it was announced yesterday by Harold W. McGraw, Federal Tire Rationing Administrator for New York City.

JENSEN, Fla. -- Erosive processes of the sea have given Florida a few stretches of rock-bound coast, where the wash of waves has uncovered outjuttings of coquina rock. The sight of waves breaking in foamy whiteness against a rocky shore and tossing salt spray high into the air is so unusual amid Florida's wide, shelving beaches that the rocky stretches are becoming the objectives of curious tourists in increasing numbers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The Mutual Broadcasting System filed suit today in the United States District Court in Chicago for $10,275,000 in damages against the Radio Corporation of America and its subsidiary, the National Broadcasting Company.

The annual meeting of the New York Foreign Freight Forwarders and Brokers Association to be held on Tuesday night at the Hotel Roosevelt will be one of the most important in many years because of the increasing importance of the movement of foreign commerce in the war, officials of the organization said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- As the Japanese sweep down the Malay Peninsula toward four objectives -- Singapore, the world's greatest production areas of rubber and tin, Australia and the gateway to the Indian Ocean -- wonder increases that a region always so vital to the British Empire, and now of paramount importance to the United Nations also, should be thus rapidly endangered.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Two outstanding lecture courses, part of each Winter's cultural pattern and planned this season to cover phases of world conflict and conditions, are getting under way. They are the Palm Beach Round Table, whose meetings will be at the Everglades Club or homes of subscribers, and the Palm Beach Forum, always at the high school auditorium.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A new amateur fairways event was entered in the 1942 sports calendar today -- the All-American amateur golf championship to be sponsored next September by the Tam o' Shanter Club in conjunction with its $15,000 open tournament.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- The Penn Athletic Club, a twelve-story modern building facing on Ritten-house Square, will become the new home of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

IN its survey and forecast of travel for January, 1942, the American Express Company announces that the travel and recreation year 1941 set some new highs in this third largest industry in the United States, and that many States consider it near the top of the list as a source of income.

Members of the Smith College Club of New York have taken over the performance of "Carmen" on the night of Feb. 4 at the Metropolitan Opera House to augment the organization's scholarship fund. Mrs. Howard J. Rogers is president of the Smith College Club of New York, which opened recently its new headquarters at the Weylin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- This week Germany's "official spokesmen" rushed forward to brand as "fantastic," "bombastic" and "skycraper figures" President Roosevelt's announcement that the United States would produce 60,000 planes this year, 125,000 the next; 45,000 tanks this year, and 75,000 in 1943; 20,000 anti-aircraft guns this year, and 35,000 the next, with 8,000,000 deadweight tons of shipping for 1942 and 10,000,000 for 1943.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A major move toward increasing the Army to the wartime size necessary to execute President Roosevelt's program of hitting the enemy at any world point where he can be reached will be taken Feb. 16, when about 9,000,000 men between the ages of 20 and 44 inclusive will register for possible military service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A call for women's organizations to marshal forces and superintend a program which will improve living conditions for women workers snared in the maelstrom of migrating peoples surging into defense industries, was made today by the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

During the Spanish-American War it was the custom for our Army -- officers excepted -- to look tough in their blue shirts and campaign hats and the "Hot Time in the Old Town Tonight" atmosphere. That was all right; we hadn't had a war for a long time.

Admiral J.K. Wetherbee, U.S.N., retired, is the real hero of this story, for it is he who discovers who caused the disaster which resulted in the death of twenty-two men on the U. S. Submarine Starfish and subsequently murdered three men in the attempt to prevent the cause of the disaster from becoming known.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 10 -- The effect of the war and New Jersey's key part in production for military needs was reflected in a record volume of telephone service in 1941, the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company announced today in a preliminary report of the year's operations.

TEANECK, N.J., Jan. 10 -- The war emergency is bringing many changes to the campus of Bergen College. Both faculty and students are busy studying problems of defense for their buildings and grounds as well as methods of service to the defense units in the county.

Mozart's "The Magic Flute" received its third performance of the season yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House. Bruno Walter again conducted and the cast was the same as at the first performance on Dec. 11.

"Plants for the Home" will be the subject of the free lecture to be given at the New York Botanical Garden Saturday at 3 P.M. by George Gillies. Mr. Gillies is in charge of the gardens at the Marshall Field estate.

Air Marshal William A. Bishop of Canada urged the Allied nations to follow the example of the Axis powers by behaving like "victors, not victims," and by showing a "healthy hate" for our enemies instead of clinging to the "stupid fallacy and sheer nonsense that we are fighting the present leaders of the countries with which we are at war."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- It is indicative of the change of mind in some official circles that reports this week of dissension in Germany have made very little impression in Washington and London, where many had been lulled in the past by reports of such tenor.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Several Winter get-togethers and college house parties are on the programs for January week-ends at Pocono Manor, Buck Hill Falls, Lutherland and Skytop Club. Members of the Prudential Life Insurance Company's Newark, N.J., athletic association are to gather for the first of their series of outings at Pocono Manor on Saturday, where the thousand-foot tow and skating by day or night on Lake Minausin are expected to be popular attractions.

In a large South American city, a young North American went to the home of his friend, Senorita Alvarez, for luncheon. The young man enjoyed a pleasant meal, found that his Spanish was quite acceptable to the girl's family, and noted that the hour to return to work approached with alarming rapidity.

BANDOENG, Java, Jan. 9 -- The most menaced spot in the Netherlands Indies is Tarakan, a tiny, palm-fringed island, fabulously wealthly in oil, off the northeast coast of Netherland Borneo. It is 1,200 miles from Bandoeng.
JOSEPH SZIGETI has received a letter from Harold Fielding, an English violinist who has turned to concert managing. Mr. Fielding writes:

BECAUSE of the success of the Town Hall Music Forum, started last year in the Town Hall Club's private quarters by Kenneth Klein, director of concerts at Town Hall, the series will be continued next season in the main auditorium on four Wednesday nights.

MEXICO CITY -- Motor tourists would not think of leaving Mexico without buying a few pieces of artistic pottery, glassware, fiber-plant products or woven work for which Mexico is famous, but few people find their way to the small back-country villages where all those works of art come from.

A system of free enterprise is essential to our morale, our future, our democracy. Any proposal for a 100 per cent tax over a fixed rate of return on invested capital is contrary to this fundamental principle.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 10 -- The Winter's first real prolonged cold wave and heavy snow -- combined with wartime adjustments and post-holiday lethargy -- gave Ninth District retail merchants a bad week. Trade fell off an estimated 13 per cent from the previous week but remained 9 to 11 per cent better than the corresponding 1941 week.

FOR all his worries, President Roosevelt is still able to relax. The war has interfered with almost everything else at the White House, but it hasn't stopped the President's evening session with Falla, the shaggy little Scottish terrier that has been at his feet since the beginning of the crisis.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- Important changes affecting the biology and public health programs of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology were announced by President Karl T. Compton today with the appointment of Dr. Francis O. Schmitt as head of the newly created Department of Biology and Biological Engineering and Dr. Clair E. Turner as administrator of courses in public health formerly given in the Department of Biology and Public Health.

Four months of air raids over London -- the worst four months -- left no serious trace in the health of the city's children. This is the finding of the London County Council's medical department for the year 1940, as summed up in our dispatches last week.

ALEXANDRIA, Va. -- Following a Summer and Fall of strong construction and widening activity, only one minor detour remains along the entire stretch of United States 1 highway in the 1,395 miles from New York City to Miami.

IN the chronicle of the radio the first religious service was broadcast by Westinghouse Station KDKA from Calvary Episcopal Church, Pittsburgh, on Sunday evening, Jan. 2, 1921. The rector, the Rev. Edwin J. Van-Etten, D.D., conducted the service, preached the sermon, and the choir sang Gounod's "Credo" and led the congregation in Christmas carols.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Lack of snow to pack the Mount Van Hoevenberg bobrun to the mile mark today forced postponement of the Commissioner Osborne Trophy race. The event was rescheduled for Jan. 25, when it will be incorporated with the Samuel Packer Trophy contest.

WAR slogans have played an important part in American history. Stirring phrases seem to produce an emotional disturbance in man and to instill in him the determination and courage to overcome obstacles.

HERE is a book about Mexico which was not written from a table in Sanborn's. It is the cheerful result of six months' travel and study in the southern republic. Mr. Gessler personally visited all the principal tourist spots, as well as some that tourists rarely see.

Vital readjustments demanded by the total war economy in merchandising, sales promotion and store operation will be surveyed by department store and specialty shop executives from all over the country at the opening tomorrow of the thirty-first annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A TIRE reconditioning plant, now center of every motorist's acute interest, is not a place of sulphurous fumes, infernal activity and devilish din. In reality it is quiet and dirty, as is any shop handling tires that have traveled 10,000 to 100,000 miles of road in all weather.

Several candidates are under consideration as eligible for the post of Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, soon to be vacated by Bishop Ernest M. Stires, who gave notice of his resignation a year ago, because of his age.

It takes a snowfall to remind us how populated is our world. The gray countryside of Winter seems so deserted that we smug humans fancy it is our land, with only a few bold and well-upholstered squirrels and juncoes still in business.
