The American air route to the Far East, smashed by the Japanese attack in the Pacific on Dec. 7, has been reformed on a 16,800-mile airway spanning two-thirds of the world east of the United States, Pan American Airways disclosed yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia has designated Police Inspector George W. Heitzman to coordinate the defense activities of the city's loyal organizations of German background, it became known yesterday, when initial phases of a program of war aid by 1,300 groups were unfolded.

Although industrial output this year may average 10 to 15 per cent ahead of 1941, aggregate corporate earnings will probably be lower as a result of increased taxes, according to Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, Stock Exchange members.

AMERICAN bridge players have been challenged to an international match against a Brazilian team. The challenge was contained in a letter delivered by Dr. Fernando E. Lee, representing the Bridge Club Paulistano of Sao Paulo, Brazil, to officials of the American Contract Bridge League here.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 10 -- Stewards of the Grand Circuit re-elected officers today, voted to use the saliva test and photograph finish system at all meetings and fixed definite dates for about half of the 1942 harness-racing season.

The concert given yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, was one of the memorable events of the current music season. It became so through the superb performance granted Tchaikovsky's piano concerto in B flat minor with Alexander Borovsky as soloist, and the impressive interpretation of Bohuslav Martinu's masterly Concerto Grosso, which received its local premiere.

For twenty years the taxability of stock dividends, for Federal income-tax purposes, has been crystallizing. And the end is not yet in evidence unless reports currently coming out of Washington that all stock dividends will be made taxable by statute should materialize and prove effective.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Ways and Means Committee, searching for $7,000,000,000 in new general revenue, appeared to be giving increasing though reluctant attention today to a general sales tax.

CARACAS. OIL has made Venezuela wealthy, but it has caused Venezuelans to neglect other natural resources of their country, including many minerals. The vast plains stretching southward and eastward from the Andes are untilled, so that many necessaries of life must be imported.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 -- A pick up in new orders booked by wholesale dry goods houses and shoe manufacturers, compared with this time a year ago, was reported here. Gradual advances are being marked on wholesale shoe prices, the latest of which was a 5 to 10 cent increase on two leading women's lines at one large company, which follows 5 to 10 cent increases on these lines at the beginning of the season.

ATLANTA, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Georgia may play an important part in helping to overcome the prospective shortage of manganese needed in the manufacture of heavy armament for the war effort, according to Garland Peyton, director of mining and geology, in reporting the development of a process for extracting manganese from low-grade ore, which is found abundantly in the State.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- No. 10 Downing Street announced today that Alfred Duff Cooper has been recalled from Singapore and the reason assigned was that the appointment of General Sir Archibald P. Wavel as supreme commander in the Southwest Pacific made further continuance of Mr. Duff Cooper's job unnecessary.
The Salmagundi Club, oldest art club in America, was host yesterday to several hundred patrons of the arts at a preview of the sixty-fifth annual exhibition in the clubhouse at 47 Fifth Avenue.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Five Niagara Frontier swimming records were shattered tonight as the South American swimming champions on tour of the United States scored a clean-sweep victory over a picked All-Buffalo team.
Plans for protecting its 40,000 books and manuscripts in the advent of an air raid have been formulated by Yeshiva College, Hirschel Revel, librarian, disclosed yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Jan. 11 -- The German authorities in Norway have applied martial law at the ports of Oslo, Stavanger, Bergen, Trondheim, Aandalsnes and Tromsoe in reprisal for the outbreak of a widespread insurrection, according to an un- confirmed report from Stockholm received here this morning.

After advancing as much as 22 points, or $1.10 a bale, in early trading yesterday, the cotton market eased under week-end liquidation and final prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were only 2 to 9 points above the previous close.

"THERE'S one thing about this war," an old London playgoer said to me recently; "it hasn't had the same frightful effect on the theatre as the last one. Do you remember the terrible stuff we saw in 1916?"

UP on the Russian front men are fighting not only one another but cold and sleet and wind and snow. They grow chilled and numb and sluggish. Cold has always been the enemy of the soldier; probably his greatest enemy. Men seem able to stand heat for long periods of time, although they deteriorate under it; but they have never been able to withstand cold long without shelter.

CARL CARMER, the author of "Stars Fell on Alabama," "Listen for a Lonesome Drum," "The Hudson" and, most recently, a first novel, "Genesee Fever," said that when he goes in search of unwritten history, of folklore, "my wife either stays at home and paints or goes visiting.

SINGAPORE, Sunday, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The "scorched earth" policy, effective in China and Russia, was now being carried out effectively by British forces retreating slowly before the Japanese invader, reports from the Malayan front said early today.

The New York Boy Scouts of America will launch on Jan. 20, their 1942 campaign for $325,000, the sum needed to see their vital emergency program through for this year, according to an announcement yesterday. Contributions sought under the slogan, "Defend Tomorrow Today -- Give to the Boy Scouts of Greater New York," may be sent to 120 West Forty-second Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Joe Louis, heavyweight champion of the world, will enter the United States Army next week after being given his final physical examination Monday. The fact was accepted in both Chicago and New York today by Selective Service officials.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 -- Hurry Up Harry Cooper and Ben Hogan took over leadership of the $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament late today as yesterday's pace setter, Horton Smith, surrendered to a tough par on the Hillcrest Country Club course.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Jan. 10 -- An increase of 31 per cent in jobs offered to the graduates of Wellesley College last year, and which is expected to rise this year -- has been announced by Miss Ruth Houghton, director of the College Placement Office.
The Patent Office granted 879 patents this week, among which were the following inventions:

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- High- ranking combinations from the Philadelphia area figured in most of the major developments today as the tenth Greenwich-Apawamis invitation squash racquets doubles tourney reached the semi-final round.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -- The proud old Charleston evergreen, that has seen so many wars, is taking another and new one in its stride. The old Negresses, selling their magnolia branches and their Winter Narcissuses on the steps of the postoffice, look complacently at the figures in khaki and bluejackets that mingle with townsfolk.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- Construction has started on an eighteen-inch, fresh-water pipe line from Florida City, Fla., on the mainland to Key West for use of the naval operating base and the city of Key West primarily. Distribution also will be available to the communities of Tavenier and Marathon and other settlements along the keys.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- The German official radio said today that Rumanian soldiers who had returned from the Russian war zone had failed to surrender their arms and that unless they did so by Jan. 20 they would be sentenced to death, "even if the reason for neglecting the surrender was not a political one."

That the American Negro is not giving "all-out" support to the war was the opinion of the majority of seventy delegates representing eighteen national Negro organizations at a conference yesterday at the Harlem Y.M.C.A. that considered the problems that face "Negro citizens in a world at war."

IT is a very extensive survey of American art that the week just traversed has yielded. The report begins back in the days of Gilbert Stuart, Samuel F.B. Morse, Thomas Sully, Rembrandt Peale, John Neagle, Samuel Lovett Waldo, Thorvaldsen, etc., and ends with some of the more "advanced" painters who are active -- often quite friskily so -- today.

The fortieth annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club will take place Feb. 4 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. An attendance of 3,000 persons is expected at the event, proceeds from which will be used to enlarge the facilities of the club in assisting various local service organizations in their all-out war efforts.

A group of South American swimmers who have been touring the United States for several weeks will conclude their visit in a Pan-American exhibition meet under the auspices of the Women's Swimming Association of New York at its pool in West Twenty- fourth Street Thursday at 8 P.M.

WITH all sorts of alarming rumors going the rounds concerning the availability of camera supplies now that a war is upon us, it is comforting to know that the truth is far less black than hearsay would have it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Thorough research studies of problems which currently are confronting small business and those with which the smaller enterprises are likely to be plagued in the post-war era are being undertaken by the special unit set up in the Department of Commerce, government officials said today.

BUD ABBOTT and Lou Costello have exchanged the Spartan simplicity of their home studio, Universal, for the opulence of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to appear in a remake of "Rio Rita," and are very much impressed by their new surroundings.

Skiing and Winter sports enthusiasts among members of society from New York, Long Island, New Jersey, Connecticut and neighboring Eastern States are converging this season as in past Winters -- despite war conditions -- on all the popular resorts where snow and ice are of sufficiently good condition to provide fun and exercise.

BUENOS AIRES. ARGENTINA, the most powerful of all South American States, plays an important part in Pan-American deliberations. In past conferences she has not always seen eye to eye with the United States. In Argentina there are some interests which distrust democracy, but there are also powerful groups which strongly favor friendship with the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Labor Department reports reflected a moderately upward trend in retail food prices during the last half of December. According to a survey based on reports of prices for eighteen foods in nineteen cities, the department reported rises in meats, flour, sugar, navy beans and coffee.

IN a book of etiquette, one of the convenient stage props in "Ruddigore," Gilbert makes the discovery that "you mustn't hint, in print." But ever since Gutenberg's invention there has been no lack of adherents to the idea that there is nothing wrong with the printing of an untruth, provided it be stated boldly.
THERE it stands. A perfect score for Joe Louis. Twenty consecutive victories as the defendant of the world's heavyweight championship.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Action of the Senate in voting yesterday to vest price control of raw agricultural products in the Department of Agriculture rather than in the Office of Price Administration had a bullish effect today on the grain markets.

THE prospects for 1942 and the years thereafter for all of us are bound up with the war effort. The future of the recording field is vague and uncertain, like other civilian pursuits. The main job now is to win the war, and if recording enterprises have to cut down their activities, they are no worse off and certainly no less anxious to help than other thriving concerns.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Six months ahead of schedule, the 6,000-ton light cruiser San Diego, one of the fastest ever built for the United States Navy, was commissioned today at the Boston Navy Yard and placed in command of Captain Benjamin F. Perry, a former Naval Academy athlete.

IT is heartening to find so much comedy in the field of the American dance. Within the past fortnight Martha Graham has brought in her "Punch and The Judy" and Charles Weidma has produced his "Flickers"; and though it would be futile to claim any profundity for either of them, they are both works of distinction in their own dimensions.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- The fast passing Harvard basketball team played Dartmouth off its feet to win an Eastern Intercollegiate League game tonight, 49 -- 36.

LAKE PLACID. -- "Want to try it from the top?" Rocketing downhill for a mile around glassy-ice mountain curves is something you've never done before. Safe, your mind tells you. Some 100,000 people have done it and there's never been a serious accident.

Soon the full flood of seed catalogues will be pouring into our homes. Garden-loving men and women everywhere, owners of small back yards and those with extended acres, will be studying them with mixed emotions -- emotions mixed because even the most obscure and placid gardener realizes that he has a part to play in this total war.

FIRST of the major programs to fall victim to the "war clause" in radio contracts will be the Helen Hayes Theatre of the Air, which will be withdrawn after the performance of Sunday, Feb. 1. The sponsor's decision was not unexpected, for the show was canceled once before -- as of Dec. 28 -- and then granted a reprieve.

To free 1,000 regular policemen for essential patrol duty, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday they would be replaced by an equal number of women volunteers who would handle all clerical details of the air raid warden services, including the fingerprinting of applicants.

Not meanin' to be sassy, An' not meanin' to be smart -THESE handy lines from "Calendar, an Anthology of 1941 Poetry," will serve as opening for a question: Does the compiler of the above-mentioned anthology really believe that much of what he has assembled is poetry, or that much of it is worth recording at all?
LONDON, Jan. 10 (Canadian Press) -- After three weeks of qualifying competition in the Football League's War Cup series, Liverpool is the only unbeaten and untied team.

"AWFUL": Speaker Rayburn of Texas was 60 years old last Tuesday. Among the birthday messages he received was one in longhand from President Roosevelt, who Will be 60 on Jan. 29. It read: "Dear Sam: Ever so many happy returns of the day -- it must be awful to be so old -- I don't get there for twenty-three days. F.D.R."

WASMINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The million and a half members of the Boy Scouts will be used in special civilian defense activities, and when on duty will become a part of the Civilian Defense organization, according to a joint statement issued today by Mayor La Guardia, director of the Office of Civilian Defense, and James E. West, chief Scout executive.

An educational program against prejudice, designed to reach 25,000,000 Protestant adults and children in the nation, will get under way after a two-day conference ending today at the offices of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

TWENTY-SIX years after the Treaty of Portsmouth brought the Russo-Japanese War to an end Japanese scientists announced that Japan had won the war because her soldiers ate raw fish. Lack of a properly balanced diet for the Czar's troops caused their defeat, the Japanese are convinced, so Japan increased the size of the daffy fish ration for the army and navy.

VAULTING across the archipelagoes of the Western Pacific and smashing at objectives over vast longitudes of space, the wings of the plane have cast a long shadow across the world's greatest ocean in the nation's first five weeks of war.

Fred Y. Presley, president of the National Investors Corporation, an investment trust, has resigned from that post in order to free himself for other endeavors. He has been associated with the companies in the National group since 1927.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 10 (AP) -- "Seventy-three (telegraph code for "best regards") until we meet again" was the message broadcast by WIAW, key station of the American Amateur Radio Relay League, at midnight last night to about 2,000 "hams" who have been ruled off the air by the Federal Communications Commission.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan 10 (AP) -- This "graveyard of favorites" looked like anything but that in this afternoon's opening of the eleventh annual Eastern States speed skating championships.

Even in the midst of war America will go on growing flowers, just as England has done -- that was very evident from the temper of the discussions at the recent Victory Garden conference held at the call of Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard at Washington.

AMID the current and tragic upheaval of the world more than one listener has had a slightly bitter word for the role played by the radio -- viz., that it has increased the tension and frayed the nerves of the average citizen, often unnecessarily.

ON the occasion of the fifteenth anniversary of the Treaty of Versailles, whereby Poland obtained access to the sea, special medals were struck to celebrate the event. The obverse shows an angel with a sword, presumably the Angel Michael, standing guard at the edge of the sea with the rays of the rising sun at his feet and a lighthouse to the right.

An ancient Mongolian dagger is the lethal weapon in this story of a murder game which becomes grim reality. The scene is Frantock, the home of Sir Hubert Handesley, and the occasion is a week-end party -- one of those parties for which Handesley is famous.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 10 -- The Defense Handicap, patriotic more than name only -- the entire $3,000 purse was paid in defense bonds -- resulted in an eight-length triumph for Phil Bieber's Maechance at Tropical Park today. Rushing to the front in the run for position, the 5-year-old son of Chance Shot widened his lead the farther he traveled and completed the mile and a furlong of sloppy going in 1:51 4/5.
"You're in the Army now!"

LONDON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- Radio Moscow, quoting Turkish sources, reported today that Adolf Hitler had ordered the Gestapo, the secret police, to "increase" its watch on Reich Marshal Hermann Goering, Nazi No. 2 and Hitler's official heir.

MILDRED NATWICK, who plays the brisk and balmy medium in Noel Coward's "Blithe Spirit," said that this play "is so rich and shiny a hit -- makes you think of Tiffany's and the Plaza back room" -- that it causes every one associated with it to be extremely optimistic.

The youth consultation service of the Church Mission of Help will hold its thirty-first annual meeting at the headquarters of the Colonial Dames of America, 421 East Sixty-first Street, on the afternoon of Jan. 19, when election of officers and board members will be held and reports made by the treasurer, James Madison Blackwell, and the executive secretary, Mrs. Dorothy Ellsworth.
A promotion list containing the names of approximately 200 veterans of the United States Coast Guard who have risen from the ranks was announced in Washington last week.

"WE are at war with Japan. The announcement will strike the public with amazement when the late gracious visit of the Japanese Ambassadors is considered. * * * The treacherous Orientals have illustrated the uncertainty of national friendships by plunging us into a war with them -- a war of their own seeking, without cause or provocation.

The Argentine Government has been asked to aid a campaign to develop the republic's deposits of a large number of metals and minerals required in manufacturing, according to the Argentine Information Bureau.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- The sudden enforcement of a war economy in the consumer goods industries is bringing about broad revisions in retailing operations and in the program of the National Retail Furniture Association, it was apparent here today as the first week of the 1942 Winter furniture and home furnishings markets drew to a close.

Regardless of the absence of the customary National Motor Boat Show at this time of year, many of the yachting and speed-boating bodies have scheduled their traditional meetings in New York this month and this will mean an influx of hundreds of members and delegates.

WHEN the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor Margaret Mackprang Mackay, author of "Valiant Dust," was in Honolulu and about to take a ship to join her husband in Burma. In a letter to her publishers, the John Day Company, she writes:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Tribute to Woodrow Wilson and his League of Nations ideal was paid tonight by more than 200 men and women at a dinner held to celebrate the twenty-second anniversary of the founding of the League, to pledge renewed allegiance to it, and to assert confidence in the ultimate triumph of the principles of the world order which it was designed to create.

THE progress of military events in the Pacific has brought Australia into the forefront of our thinking. That continent may be the assembly and take-off point for the next great American Expeditionary Force.

Hope that conferences with the Musicians Union by the producer would end the picketing of the play "In Time to Come" was expressed yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who refused on Tuesday to cross the musicians' picket line at the Mansfield Theatre.

On every hand these days there is talk about growing vegetables to help win the war. The home gardener as well as the commercial grower is being urged to produce "vegetables for vitamins for victory." But good intentions and enthusiasm alone are far from being sufficient to accomplish this purpose.

AT a time when the United States is massively assembling its energies for total war, and all the parts of that mountainous effort must of necessity be closely interrelated, it might be well to look northward briefly to Canada, where one weapon, as yet still wavering in the hands of nearly a dozen agencies in Washington, has been brought into full use on the home front.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The organization of an Atlantic City Symphony Orchestra has been completed and the first concert is scheduled for Jan. 28 in the ballroom at the Municipal Auditorium. The program calls for four monthly concerts from January to April.

LOMPOC, Calif. -- Echoing strangely in the low hills, church bells at Mission La Purisima Conception recently called people to worship, resuming services which ended abruptly 135 years ago. The 154th anniversary dedication of this mission was celebrated.

TO save gasoline, tires and vehicles themselves, Connecticut has a reduced maximum speed limit of 40 miles an hour. It became effective yesterday. The former top speed was fifty on main routes. The State's action probably is the forerunner of a nationwide trend that will serve both safety and economy when both are needed in time of war and always.

ON the site of the ancient Maya metropolis of Tihoo, or Tho, in Yucatan, Francisco Montejo, the younger, son of the Spanish hidalgo who was Hernando Cortes's agent in many important affairs during the conquest of Mexico, established four centuries ago the storied city of Merida, today's capital of Yucatan.

Eugene Gash, 21-year-old Negro pianist from Denver, returned to Town Hall last night and redeemed himself. The young performer was scheduled to give three recitals there last season, but, after making a favorable impression at his debut, he became so nervous at his second recital that the third one was canceled.

WHAT sort of people should a dramatist write about ? The answer is obvious. He should write about the people he knows and those who interest him. For the material of a work of art reflects the artist. What he accomplishes is not a photograph of his material, but a portrait of his ideas.

THAT William James wrote psychologies like novels and his brother Henry wrote novels like psychologies has been repeated so often that it has become trite and shop-worn, but this cannot detract from the essential truth of the statement, for Henry James was one of the most subtle analysts of the human mind and motives.

LAKELAND, Fla. -- Florida's Winter season has been given a red, white and blue color scheme by visitors engaging in their own patriotic activities between recreational outings or joining permanent residents in the defense enterprises.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A 2 per cent bond issue maturing in 1951 but redeemable in 1949 was offered tonight by the Treasury in exchange for four issues maturing at intervals between Jan. 15 and March 15 for a total of $1,075,000,000.

THE distribution of mail from home, one of the most exciting incidents in the life of a service man, is the subject of the winning photograph in the Service Men's Photography Contest sponsored by the Hobby Guild of America.

"The Sorcerer's Apprentice" is well printed and pleasingly designed. It is unfortunate, however, that the author and illustrator, who are retelling a very old legend, have succumbed to the Disney influence instead of trying to capture the atmosphere of an earlier day.

MONTREAL, Jan. 10 -- The Brooklyn Americans banged home two first-period goals and threw up a stonewall defense after that to defeat the Canadiens by 2 -- 0 in a National Hockey League game tonight before a crowd of more than 6,000.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Cornell tonight overcame Yale, 51 to 43, in opening the Eastern intercollegiate League basketball season here.

As of today, day nurseries are prepared to give wartime protection to the hundreds of children in their care. Their women's boards have seen to it that blackout rooms are already established for use in the event of air raids, and have stocked them with vital necessities and play materials to keep their charges both secure and happy.

NORWAY'S promised series marking the seventh centenary of the death of Sturlason Snorri, Icelandic historian, poet and statesman, reached New York last week. Inscribed on each is "Snorre Sturlason" and birth and death dates, 1178-1241.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 -- Dislocations occasioned in recent weeks by further transition from a defense basis to a shooting war economy were indicated in employment reports from several Fourth Federal Reserve District cities. Working forces of 100 representative Cleveland concerns were reduced during December for the first time in eighteen months because of suspension at plants making passenger car parts and equipment.

We are a big nation and we have come to admire bigness for itself. We have prided ourselves on having the highest skyscrapers, the biggest railroad terminals, the biggest factories. We have even fallen into the habit of thinking that better is almost a synonym for bigger.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 10 -- Finland is a striking example of the old axiom that it is much easier to get into a war than to get out of it. It is not an exaggeration to say that more than 90 per cent of the Finns, including many leading personalities, want peace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Army's transport glider program, anticipating the carrying of airborne infantrymen in large numbers with full fighting equipment, is about to move from the designing and building stages into active operation.

IN his recent remarks on Mozart and the Czechs, Jan Lowenbach speaks of the "obvious Viennese coolness" which was to blame for the "scandalous failure" of "The Abduction From the Seraglio" in 1782 and the lukewarm reception of "Titus" in Prague in 1791.

Representatives of 200,000 Italian-American trade unionists appealed to President Roosevelt yesterday to remove "the intolerable stigma of being branded as enemy aliens" from Italian and German nationals who had formally declared their intention of becoming American citizens by taking out first papers before America's entry into the war.

Coaches and officials of intercollegiate and interscholastic soccer concluded their meetings here yesterday with the election of officers. The prevalent opinion was that the war conditions would bring about an increase in soccer playing rather than a decline.

The $600,000 meeting at Hialeah Park, Miami, will get under way on Wednesday with the likelihood of keener competition because of the cancellation of California's Santa Anita session. Not that racing folk in one part of the country wish to gain at the expense of others knocked out by war, but the plain fact is there will be a greater concentration of top horses than ever before at a Winter track.

HARRISON, N.J., Jan. 10 -- Stephen Boros, 413 Warren Street, was fined $25 yesterday by Police Justice Joseph Gallagher on a charge of assaulting a fellow worker at the Atha works of the Crucible Steel Company of America in an argument over the latter's decision to increase production of shells for the Army and Navy.

For the first time in the history of American education a unified program has been adopted to place the resources of this country's colleges and universities at the command of the Federal Government for the duration of the war. Meeting last week at Baltimore, 1,000 leading educators agreed to make whatever revisions may be necessary to meet the present emergency.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Plans for a poll of Wesleyan University students to decide what courses will be given at the Summer school, which will be a part of Wesleyan's emergency war program, were announced by Dean Leroy A. Howland today.

On Jan. 3 there appeared in your columns an interesting letter from Hendrik Willem van Loon, telling the story of the V-sign, which, he explained, is somewhat analogous in "historico-politico" considerations to the more recent V . . . -- as applied to the opening measures of Beethoven's Fifth symphony.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A centrifugal separator similar to that used for removing cream from milk will keep the oil in airplane motors purified while the plane is in flight, according to a patent (No. 2,268,653) awarded to Alan E. Flowers of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

NOW that Yehudi Menuhin is 25 and has reached the status of a mature performer, he has confessed that, like many another prodigy, his age was given out as younger than he really was when he made his first appearance here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 10 -- To combat the epidemic of spotted typhus the Germans have created a special Typhus Institute in Cracow with a smaller branch in Lwow, where a new antityphus serum is being prepared.

"Wakey Goes to Bed," with its excellent pictures that have a childlike humor, lively action and exactly the right amount of detail to help in telling the story without confusing youthful readers, is a worth-while addition to the list of story picture books for the youngest boys and girls.

TORONTO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Detroit broke a pair of jinxes tonight when it defeated the Maple Leafs, 6-4, in a National Hockey League game. It was the first time in five starts that the Red Wings downed Toronto this season and the first time in four seasons that they beat the Leafs on Toronto ice.

New York University announced yesterday and recommended to the attention of universities throughout the country a new plan in its dental school which would establish preclinical science departments as strong as those in the modern medical school, where dentistry can train its own specialists or investigators.

LIKE "Broad and Alien Is the World' -- winner of the first award in the Latin-American Prize Novel Contest -- "Nayar," by Miguel Angel Menendez, which received honorable mention, is a story of very simple, very humble, very primitive people who live a life completely foreign to anything that we ourselves know.

UNLIKE the host of "how to" books which promise to make you a million dollars or a junior superman overnight, Mr. Whipple's book on "How to Understand Current Events" is a modest and sincere book. And unlike some of the other honest books in adult education, such as Adler's "How to Read a Book" or Howe's "The News and How to Understand It," it is presented with a great deal more humility.

As was generally anticipated, the United States Golf Association, at its annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, called off its championship schedule for this year and probably for the duration of the war.

In all parts of the world there is an increasing demand for the discussion and elaboration of plans regarding the peace that has to come after the present war. It is said that we must not risk a repetition of what occurred after the former World War, when the Governments met unprepared for the peace negotiations and therefore improvised a peace that could be no more than an armistice.

Featured by a wave of consumer stocking up on merchandise made of wool or containing rubber, retail trade continued active here last week. Sales of men's and children's apparel, corsets, sheets and pillow cases, blankets and some drug items were particularly brisk.

We'll have no more of the blarney in the greeting card field, according to the terms of a stipulation announced yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission in which Michael Cohen and Frances Cohen, trading as Meryle Publishing Company, 121 West Nineteenth Street, have agreed to cease certain representations with respect to fragments of stone attached to a greeting card sold by them.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Representatives of nine countries occupied by Axis armies will meet next week and pledge themselves to bring final justice to officials of Germany, Italy, Hungary and Rumania who are responsible for hostage executions, mass fines and the seizure of property in conquered lands.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., Jan. 10 -- The popular Eastern Slope region of the White Mountains embracing Conway, North Conway, Kearsarge, Intervale, Bartlett, Jackson and Pinkham Notch, is now enjoying its best period of skiing this Winter.

Civilian and military aspects of defense will be equally highlighted before a representative gathering next week-end when the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense meets in Washington. The session, which brings together women of thirty-four patriotic groups, many of them national in scope, will open with a mass meeting Saturday evening at the Mayflower Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Employment in America, at all-time high levels, must undergo profound changes in the next year as the American industrial economy, devoted to such peacetime accomplishments as turning out 5,000,000 automobiles in one year, shifts to the task of turning out $50,000,000,000 worth of war materials.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Mickey Rooney, the son of! vaudeville comedians, who became the screen's biggest box-office star and a shy, blue-eyed North Carolina girl, s Ava Gardner, %vere i married today in the town of ]allard, a tiny farming community! forty miles from here in the Santa Ynez Valley.

IT is scarcely surprising that several reviewers of Philip Guedalla's "Mr. Churchill: A Portrait" have devoted more space to setting forth their own ideas about the Prime Minister than to discussing the book itself. The temptation offered by so fascinating a personality was irresistible.

AXIS comment upon the war program announced by President Roosevelt last week contented itself with the one word: "fantastic." To Americans 60,000 planes, 45,000 tanks, 20,000 guns and 8,000,000 tons of shipping did not look like an impossible order.

Columbia University has acquired one of the world's most famous collections of library and museum items dealing with printing and the allied graphic arts. Known as the American Type Founders Library, the collection is the largest and the most complete in this country, and probably in the world.

HOLLYWOOD. THE peculiar snobberies of film production were illustrated this week by a casting problem which William K. Howard and the King (formerly Kozinsky) Brothers faced in preparing their Monogram picture, "Law of the Klondike," for production.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Heroism and devotion to duty of the officers and crew of the American destroyer Kearny, as all accepted their first introduction to battle last October and saved their ship, led today to the awarding of the Navy Cross to three and letters of commendation to eleven others, five of whom received promotions also.

The usual test of Summer merchandise lines at Southern resorts will be hampered this year both by indications of smaller numbers of visitors to such resorts and the fact that fabric houses have reduced their novelty lines, it was indicated last week.

LONDON -- How values of postage stamps have increased is disclosed in 1942 catalogues issued by several leading dealers here. As one example, a St. Helena 15-shilling stamp which was quoted at 6 10s is now priced at from 15 to 20.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- World strategy on the "food front" as well as on the actual fighting front was advocated today at a meeting of the British Association of Scientific Workers.

Elimination of every holiday but one during the Spring semester at City College in order to comply with President Roosevelt's request that students be released for war service as quickly as possible was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

ATBANY, Jan. 10 -- Despite a generally rising price index, New York State may be able to keep its governmental costs at least as low as it did last year, when an economy budget of $385,000,000, the lowest in several years, was adopted.

The ridge of granite mountains that forms the backbone of Malaya from its tip on the Straits of Malacca to the Thai border 400 miles northward divides the peninsula into two contrasting regions. On the west is a narrow swampy flatland, dented by numerous river valleys, where civilization in the form of roads, railways and mining enterprises has thrust a long hand into the wilderness.
ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Jan. 10 (AP) -- When the British light cruiser Galatea, struck three times by torpedoes, heeled over quickly and sank with a muffled blast, a heroic naval story began.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Increased receipts in all departments of the livestock trade during the week offset good shipping demand, cold weather and the stronger dressed meat market. Wholesale pork quotations were lifted about 1 cent a pound, however, and dressed beef rose 1/2 to 1 cent during the week.

KUALA LUMPUR, British Malaya, Jan. 8 (Delayed) -- For the first time in the Malaya fighting the Japanese yesterday and today pushed through a spearhead of tanks into the British positions on the main front along the railway and highway north of here, and up to late today the momentum of the tank thrust had carried forward.

Although the amount of mileage to be covered has been considerable streamlined, the Yankees, in announcing their 1942 Spring training plans, let it be known yesterday that the world champions of baseball will prepare themselves as thoroughly as ever they did in the past.

THE lively run on theatre ticket-windows, noted genererally these past few weeks, has been a heartening indication of public spirit at a far from cheerful time. To be sure, the holiday season had a lot to do with the boom, and the prevalence of cash in frank abundance made it easier for moviegoers to obey that urge.

After-Christmas sales have met with exceptional success and reports of increased volume were general, except from a few sections hit by heavy snows, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

Paintings of "Little Shavers and Some That Are Grown Up" will be on view at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, for two weeks beginning with a private invitation preview Wednesday, in a picturesquely devised exhibition arranged for the benefit of Bundles for Britain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- By a vote of 83 to 1 the Senate passed today a Price Control Bill so additionally liberalized in favor of farmers that Senator Barkley, majority leader, referred to it as "this farm relief measure."

EGGLESS cake, flourless bread and meatless stews were among the tribulations which beset American housewives during the First World War, when the woman who could keep her family going on the smallest amount of food received the largest number of pats on the back.

The war has heightened interest in the employment status of America's research and other scholarly workers. Those who administer the agencies of government and business, as well as college executives, are especially interested in the Ph.D. degree level or quality of personnel.

OTTAWA, Jan. 10 -- For reasons so far not explained the government is still delaying its decision to take advantage of the tide of popular feeling in favor of a total war effort and announce its plans for all-out mobilization of man and woman power.
HERE, in the prodigious pages of this book, is traced with fascinating, though sometimes redundant, detail the story of the industrial revolution as applied to sea power.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 10 -- Years of study of American public opinion have brought to light four facts which are of great importance as the nation prepares for the years of grim warfare ahead.

MR. BECHDOLT'S story tells of two lively small boys, Tad and Shrimp, who are spending the Summer in a New England fishing village. There is also an irrepressible small girl known as Letty the Pest, and with the arrival of Margot, who helped her father, Mysto the Magician, put on his show during the vaudeville season in the Winter, the trio becomes a quartet.

A proposed amendment to the constitution of Actors Equity Association barring Communists, Nazis and Fascists from holding office or being employed by the union was defeated at a voting by secret ballot on Friday because its proponents failed to gain the two-thirds majority necessary for adoption, it was revealed yesterday.

IN another few weeks -- the last three days preceding Lent, to be precise -- our Good Neighbors to the South will go mad -- gorgeously, dizzily, noisily, hilariously and shockingly mad. They will array themselves in costumes derived from unnumbered sources -- from 1941's most popular movie to the latest nightmare of the family cook.

APPEARING at this time, here is an important book. It is written by a man who has kept his head amid the chaos and crises of the twentieth century. It is intended for those who, with illusions dispelled, have to find their bearings and set their course toward a hazardous and speculative future.

RIO DE JANEIRO. SO far as the United States is concerned, Brazil today is the most important country in South America. Apart from its geographical position, which is but a short hop from Africa, its vast resources make it a coveted spot for hungry would-be world conquerors.

"A little war is going on along the Warsaw-Lublin railway" in Poland where guerrillas armed with rifles have interrupted all traffic and are fighting with police and gendarmes, the British radio said yesterday in a report on German difficulties in many occupied countries.

The National Life Insurance Company, Montpelier, Vt., had last year the largest increase in insurance in force since 1929, Elbert S. Brigham, president, reported in the annual statement reviewing the ninety-second year of operations.

LESS than a year ago, the name Dean Dixon was virtually unknown outside of Harlem. In a few days the 27-year-old Negro conductor will, for the third time in seven months, step to the podium in Studio 8H and put the NBC Symphony Orchestra through its musical paces -- for the benefit of a nation-wide radio audience.

Hens' teeth, said to be proverbially scarce, will be no more uncommon during the Summer yachting season of 1942 than a good obtainable used boat. The market has been tightening appreciably since hauling-out time last Fall.

In a war which involves continents it is intriguing that the fate of two tiny islands off the south coast of Newfoundland, mere specks on the map, should cause the furor which has arisen over the occupation of St. Pierre et Miquelon by the Free French forces under the command of General de Gaulle. The reason is, of course, not the value of the islands but because of the diplomatic tangle which their seizure caused.
ST. PIERRE, St. Pierre-Miquelon, Jan. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Free French will remain in occupation of the islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon, Vice Admiral Emile Muselier declared today.

One thousand friendly aliens declared yesterday afternoon that "those who came to this country seeking liberty want to serve America even unto giving their blood" at a rally sponsored by the newly formed Legion of Alien Volunteer Blood Donors for National Defense in Manhattan Center.

BY a happy coincidence, two gentlemen qualified to report on the film situation both in England and in Continental Europe were in town the other day, both having recently returned from abroad to give a first-hand picture of the situation to the directors of Twentieth Century-Fox.

THE Welsh have an uncommon ability in combining realism with fancy, and Hilda Vaughan's novel does this admirably. It is the story of a young Welshman with a harp who fell in love with his own songs and dreams.

The 13-year-old German passenger liner Orinoco, now renamed the Puebla and registered under the flag of Mexico, was in New York last week on her first visit here since the Mexican Government seized her in Tampico after a futile attempt to escape to sea in November, 1940.

A SCORE of one-man shows, in variety to suit almost any taste and introducing new names as well as bringing back old friends, crowded the roster last week. Stephen Etnier, at the Milch Galleries, is holding an exhibition which includes his most vigorous, varied and mature work thus far.

Heralding an important change in the elementary school education of 600,000 boys and girls, the New York City school system is to adopt the activity program when the Spring semester opens next month. Tried experimentally for the last six years, the progressive method of teaching received the official approval of the State Department of Education after a year-long survey.

The President of the United States last week summoned the nation to all-out war. In his annual report to Congress on the State of the Union, he drew a blueprint for the mightiest armament program in history. Thirty days after the country had entered World War II, its 132,000,000 people mobilized for the colossal and costly task of serving as a super-arsenal as well as front-line combatant in the fight against aggression.

CLIPPER'S RETURN: A giant flying boat, her gray, weather-stained hull adorned with American flags, came down to anchor in last Tuesday's dawn at New York's La Guardia Airport. She was the forty-two-and-a-half-ton Pacific Clipper, back home after an unheralded 31,500-mile trip around the world.

The contrast between the thin and the fat from Jack Spratt and his wife down to skinny Mrs. Snipkin and fat Mrs. Wobblechin, immortalized in verse by Laura E. Richards, has always been a popular theme in nursery literature and "Mr. Jones and Mr. Finnigan," with its lively and expressive drawings, will call forth a chuckle from the 6 to 7-year-olds.

Last year legislators in Washington turned their attention to one of the knottiest problems facing America's defense economy. The President had stressed the need of price control to stem the soaring cost of living and prevent inflation. Billions of dollars poured into the nation's economic body had caused the one and threatened to provoke the other as pay envelopes grew fatter and prices rose under the pressure of increased consumer purchasing power.

The establishment of special reserves for costs and losses arising out of the war is urged by the committee on accounting procedure of the American Institute of Accountants in a bulletin to be published on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

AUTOMATIC BLACKOUT -- The photoelectric call or "electric eye" now does night duty in blackouts. When street lights are turned off the "electric eye" sounds an immediate warning and likewise turns off lights in homes, stores, display signs and other places.

WASHINGTON Jan. 10 -- The Office of Production Management moved today to mobilize the nation's 1,700,000 retail stores in a continuing drive to salvage materials needed to produce weapons for America's fighting men. Pledge cards went out to merchants in all sections of the country asking them to enlist in a "Salvage for Victory" program by saving all possible waste paper, scrap metal, old rags, rubber and other materials urgently needed for the defense.

DELICATE fragrance, sturdy pungency and the spicy aroma of humor breathe here through memories of a North Carolina childhood. The dean of administration in the University of North Carolina recalls events and circumstances and characters in a boy's life not too long ago, as they center around his father, the Sheriff, and his mother, "Miss Sue."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 (Delayed) -- The course that French North Africa and French West Africa will take at the crucial moment of decision, believed here soon to arrive, will not be determined either by Britain or Free France -- that is if bloodshed and the ensuing complications are to be avoided -- but by the United States alone, it is said here.

LIMA. PERU is a land of varied climates and peoples, of lush valleys, lofty mountains and arid seacoast, of descendants of the Incas and the Conquistadores as well as immigrants from Germany, Italy and Japan. To see the country you must drive over mountains which rise abruptly from sea level to the clouds.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 10 -- "Switzerland and Sweden are lacking in the most elementary appreciation of the security of their nations and their future existence," says Reich Propaganda Minister Dr. Joseph Goebbels in his latest attack against "the remaining so-called neutrals in the European hegemony" in the issue of the magazine Reich that appeared yesterday.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 10 -- American and British fliers, seizing the initiative in a duel for air supremacy over Burma, today had boosted to eighteen the total of Japanese fighter planes destroyed in a series of attacks on enemy air bases in Western Thailand.

The temperature in the New York area continued to drop last night in the wake of a one-inch snowfall that brought temporary relief from the cold yesterday morning. Anticipating a dip to a low of 5 degrees in the city after sundown, Department of Sanitation officials had 7,500 day workers rushing their task of clearing the streets of snow and slush so that the job would be near completion before midnight.

THE touch of frostbite that makes the whole North shiver has set in motion those people who make such weather an excuse to migrate southward for a spell. Not all of them feel impelled to go so far and so fast that they end up with their marrow melting instead of freezing.

ATHOUGH the critical materials required for the building of model aircraft are infinitesimal when one considers the nation's tremendous productive capacity, the more than 2,000,000 aeromodelers throughout the country may not receive an adequate amount of supplies to continue their work because of government priority restrictions.

Now that gardeners are planning for 1942 and wondering what plants can be added to give their gardens increased interest or beauty, perennials come in for their share of attention, especially the newer ones not yet widely known. Of course, no plant is worth growing merely because it is new, but if the newcomer possesses some unusual and desirable trait any keen gardener will want to "give it the once over."

WE'VE abandoned the pillory, the whipping post and the ducking stool; the infliction of pain as legal punishment has pretty well gone by the board, but not as a means of making children mind their P's and Q's.

PROMPTED by the shortage of violin students in all parts of the country, a national contest to select a violinist between the ages of 16 and 22 for a year's scholarship at the Juilliard School of Music will be held jointly by the National Federation of Music Clubs, the National Broadcasting Company and the Juilliard School of Music.

It is very easy to imagine, in the light of all present circumstances, that for the first time at the next Foreign Ministers' conference in Rio de Janeiro, the results of a Pan-American conference on foreign policy will not be vague.

The prospective schedule of bond financing for the next month or so would seem to indicate that the war has had little effect yet upon the market for new issues of securities. Corporations, as well as municipalities, have outlined one of the most ambitious programs of financing seen in many months.

Displaying artistry that was entirely too much for the opposition, Pierre Etchebaster, world open court tennis champion since 1928, defeated Ogden Phipps and Robert Grant 3d, national amateur doubles titleholders, in a unique exhibition for the benefit of the American Red Cross yesterday at the Racquet land Tennis Club. The score was 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, 5 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

The course of collaboration in France has never run smoothly since the day Vichy's Chief of State Marshal Petain first met Hitler at Montoire, some fifteen months ago. That meeting was arranged by Pierre Laval, collaboration's sponsor. Since then the Vichy government has passed through many periods of crisis.

GLENS FALLS -- New York State's project to establish its North Country as one of the major Winter sports centers in the East has taken on impetus with the recent openings of many additional ski trails in the Adirondack Mountains and northwestern regions.

HAVE the arts a place in the war effort? The answer is obvious. But if we need higher authority, look at President Roosevelt's speech on the state of the Union last Tuesday. "We are fighting today," he said, "for security and progress and for peace, not only for ourselves but for all men, not only for one generation but for all generations."

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10 -- In official circles in this and other Latin-American capitals there has been some apprehension this week lest the United States seek to persuade all the American republics to show their unity in the world crisis by declaring war against the Axis when the Foreign Ministers of these republics meet with their technical advisers at Rio de Janeiro next Thursday.

General Sir Archibald P. Wavell, newly appointed Allied Commander in Chief in the Southwestern Pacific, started to set up his headquarters on Java in the Netherlands Indies last week to coordinate under the first really unified Allied command in this war the strategic direction of land, sea and air operations.

The birth certificate of an adopted child, especially a child born out of wedlock, poses a problem for many parents. From the current bulletin of the Child Welfare League of America one learns that in four States -- Minnesota, New York, North Dakota and 0hio -- a birth certificate can be obtained showing only the name and sex, place and date of birth. So much for Mrs. Grundy.

IN this the third of the series of novels which began with "World's End" and was continued in "Between Two Worlds" Upton Sinclair does much to reveal the purpose he has had in writing these books. Avowing himself to be a "historian," he has recently asserted that in his case the word has a meaning all its own.

MR. NABOKOV has published a number of books in Europe and this is his second novel in America. It is the reconstructed story of a novelist called "Sebastian Knight" who died in 1936 of heart disease. His official biography is supposed to have been written by his secretary.

Back in the rut which they had followed before the activity of year-end tax sales, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange went yesterday through the dullest and narrowest session since early November. Prices drifted without direction and closed irregularly lower on the day.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Many Yale University students are signing up for intensive courses in the Japanese language as a result of America's entry into the war and changes in the college curriculum which have followed.
To explain shocks that originate miles beneath the earth's crust, Dr. Don L. Leet, director of Harvard's seismograph station, advances a new theory of earthquakes.

OVERWHELMED by a flood of exhibitions, this column and its continuation on the next page must be content to serve this week as a signpost, merely pointing to shows many of which in less crowded weeks would receive the more extended treatment they deserve The attractions range from extreme academism to the wildest of surrealism and abstraction, with a high proportion of unusual offerings.

The only international ski competition to be held in North America this Winter is scheduled for Jan. 31-Feb. 1, at Mont Tremblant, highest point in the Canadian Laurentians, it was revealed yesterday. Mrs. Alice Damrosch Kiaer, chairman of the Women's Committee of the National Ski Association, stated that an Eastern women's team would meet a Canadian group in the third annual competition between the countries at that time.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The shortage of scrap steel and iron is banking the fires in at least 10 per cent of the open-hearth furnaces in Mahoning and Cuyahoga Valley steel mills. Eighteen of the 110 open hearths in the Youngstown and Cleveland districts will be idle next week -- twelve of them because of lack of scrap and six for repairs.

Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Greater New York Defense Volunteer Office, clarified yesterday the functions of her organization and said there was immediate need of 18,430 volunteers for the nonprotective and protective services of civilian defense.

ANDRE KOSTELANETZ, who conducts that Sunday afternoon program for WABC, thinks more than musical talent goes into playing music the way people want it. You must know in advance what people want to hear, he says; and he makes it his business to find out.

BERNE, Switzerland, Sunday, Jan. 11 -- Pounding in yesterday afternoon with a mass of materiel and man power, the Red Army launched its long-awaited counter-offensive on the extreme northern front in Russia in an effort to smash the Axis positions before Murmansk, according to an admission by the Berlin radio this morning.

As the pending price-control legislation approaches its final phase in Washington, exporters here are becoming increasingly conscious of their responsibility toward the Latin-American market under wartime conditions. The maintenance of cordial relations with such valuable customers and important sources of supply is generally desired, but with already scarce strategic supplies in heavy demand because of "boom" conditions in those countries, the task is doubly difficult.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Federal agencies reached agreement late today on the wording of a proposed executive order creating a War Labor Board, and creation of the board by President Roosevelt is expected early next week.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Post-Christmas sales this week were better than expected, topping those of the corresponding week of last year by 27 per cent. The gain for the four-week period was 12 per cent. These figures represent averages of the five major department stores.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -- In this far Western industrial area, which has billions of dollars' worth of war and defense contracts, production is being slowed by the refusal of many employers to hire alien labor, the labor supply committee of Northern California and Nevada charged today.

The South Shore Power Squadron will receive registrations on Tuesday for its Freeport class in elementary piloting and on Friday night for its Lawrence class, both of which will be held in the high schools of their villages. The series is beginning a week earlier this year to permit the addition of an extra lecture on the use of coastal charts.
President Roosevelt's fighting address to Congress on Tuesday was hailed by rabbis in sermons here yesterday. Other topics were the Red Cross and a Jewish army.

Home owners often overlook a delightful opportunity to enjoy fresh flowers in the home during Winter, without any cost whatsoever. By introducing cut twigs of various flowering shrubs, the city apartment dweller or home gardener can easily make these "dry sticks" bear a mass of flowers simply by placing them in a jar of water and keeping the jar in a sunny window at ordinary room temperature.

As its chief offering the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos, presented the Brahms double concerto last night in Carnegie Hall, with Mishel Piastro, the organization's concertmaster, and Joseph Schuster, its first 'cellist, as soloists.
ENGLAND'S Food Minister, Lord Woolston, believes that "a carrot a day keeps the blackout at bay." Carrots are said greatly to improve night vision. England has a goodly store of carrots.

Unless the public buys wool products in the Spring and Summer at a rate higher than normal, the restriction upon wool use ordered by the Office of Production Management will not cut into civilian supplies until the Fall season, according to F. Eugene Ackerman, secretary of the American Wool Council.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 10 -- Alarmed by rumors of possible Finnish-Russian peace negotiations, Finnish ultra-nationalists and pro-German circles are reported to have started an all-out campaign against immediate peace.

Is a patent a franchise to be exercised for the public good? Or perishable property which may be used only in ways stipulated by the owner? Jefferson, fully aware of the potentialities of invention, insisted that the "will and convenience of society" were paramount. So did the courts up to 1896.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Milwaukee schoolboys will make war industry tools in their classrooms as subcontractors under a plan endorsed by the Superintendent of Schools and a school board subcommittee.

January white sales and many clearance events developed excellent retail activity in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday an order directing all city agencies to cooperate fully with the Federal program of tire-rationing by restricting the use of city-owned passenger cars to a minimum, starting tomorrow. The Mayor also directed all department heads to make a survey of possible tire and tube economies in the case of non-passenger vehicles and to submit their recommendations to him not later than Jan. 31.

Four years ago if reporters had asked Mrs. Yvonne Stap about her son Bobby, she would have wondered which ship he had stowed away on and how far he had traveled. For up to 1938 Bobby, then 13 years old, had covered more than 30,000 miles aboard ships without paying.

"I WISH indeed that my mother, whose memory I cherish across the veil of years, could have been here to see me." Thus the British Prime Minister speaking before the Congress of the United States on Dec. 27.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- The tragic, heroic story of the fall of embattled Hong Kong after seventeen days of battering attack was told in part today by a British officer who escaped from that empire outpost.

Many thousands of city workers, to whom Saturday has for many years been a half-holiday, worked until 5 P.M. yesterday in compliance with Mayor La Guardia's recent order establishing a six-day week for the duration of the war. The Mayor himself set an example.

Brooklyn and Queens Colleges will offer a pre-engineering curriculum during the next academic year which will permit their students to enter the City College School of Technology on the same basis as students who take the preliminary course at that institution, it was disclosed yesterday.

One week from tomorrow night Miss Sonja Henie again will glide and pirouette over the Madison Square Garden ice to thrill anew her hosts of fans. That date, Jan. 19, will mark the opening here of the famous skating star's 1942 Hollywood Ice Revue, which will close on Tuesday, Jan. 27.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 10 -- Chilean political circles were agitated today as a result of the reinforcement of the ranks supporting General Carlos Ibanez as a candidate for the Presidency in the elections scheduled for Feb. 1. The eleventh-hour support of General Ibanez by two Rightist parties, Conservative and Liberal, has aroused the Leftists to action.

Three new courses related to the national defense program will be given by the evening and extension sessions of Hunter College in the Spring semester, Dr. Samuel W. Patterson, acting director, announced yesterday. The new courses are survey of safety education, accident prevention and first aid; survey of Latin American civilization, and study of engineering and industrial statistics.

TOKYO, Jan. 10 (From Japanese Broadcasts Recorded By The United Press in New York) -- Japanese war reports said today that troops "rolling down the Malaya Peninsula at a rate of fifty miles a day" had flanked Kuala Lumpur and stormed it from the south.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Ice boating started with a whiz out on Orange Lake today, where the match for the Eastern championship pennant of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association was staged. In zero temperature, the challenge of the Monmouth Ice Yacht Club of Red Bank, N.J., was taken up by the Hudson Highlands Ice Boat Club of Hudson Highlands, N.Y., which has held the pennant for two years.

The Archer M. Huntington Medal of the American Numismatic Society was presented yesterday to Albert Gallatin of 7 East Sixty-seventh Street in recognition of his book on large Syracusan coins titled "Syracusan Dekadrachms of the Euainetos Type," published in 1930.
The rush to join the nation's armed forces slowed down somewhat yesterday.

AMERICAN war news from the Pacific battlefronts is being broadcast nightly from California's coast by a trio of high-powered short-wave stations which work out of the Fairmount Hotel in San Francisco. "This is the United States of America" is the clear-cut announcement which opens the General Electric transmissions at 6 P.M.

Many thousands of city workers, to whom Saturday has for many years been a half-holiday, worked until 5 P.M. yesterday in compliance with Mayor La Guardia's recent order establishing a six-day week for the duration of the war. The Mayor himself set an example.

Brooklyn and Queens Colleges will offer a pre-engineering curriculum during the next academic year which will permit their students to enter the City College School of Technology on the same basis as students who take the preliminary course at that institution, it was disclosed yesterday.

One week from tomorrow night Miss Sonja Henie again will glide and pirouette over the Madison Square Garden ice to thrill anew her hosts of fans. That date, Jan. 19, will mark the opening here of the famous skating star's 1942 Hollywood Ice Revue, which will close on Tuesday, Jan. 27.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 10 -- Chilean political circles were agitated today as a result of the reinforcement of the ranks supporting General Carlos Ibanez as a candidate for the Presidency in the elections scheduled for Feb. 1. The eleventh-hour support of General Ibanez by two Rightist parties, Conservative and Liberal, has aroused the Leftists to action.

Three new courses related to the national defense program will be given by the evening and extension sessions of Hunter College in the Spring semester, Dr. Samuel W. Patterson, acting director, announced yesterday. The new courses are survey of safety education, accident prevention and first aid; survey of Latin American civilization, and study of engineering and industrial statistics.

TOKYO, Jan. 10 (From Japanese Broadcasts Recorded By The United Press in New York) -- Japanese war reports said today that troops "rolling down the Malaya Peninsula at a rate of fifty miles a day" had flanked Kuala Lumpur and stormed it from the south.

DETROIT -- While the automotive manufacturing industry is called on to divert its entire effort to all-out war production, obligations to its retail outlets still are far from fulfillment. Factory sales executives are working feverishly to complete them after the sudden cut-off of civilian production.

Erasmus Hall's quintet vanquished James Madison's tall team, 28 to 24, at Madison Square Garden yesterday in the feature contest of a scholastic basketball quintuple-header that produced a maximum of thrills and flashing action for a gathering of 7,500 spectators.

The following is an excerpt from the leading editorial of The Stornoway Gazette of Dec. 5, which I believe will be both surprising and interesting to your readers. Perhaps I should explain that the Western Isles or Outer Hebrides are the chain of islands lying off the west coast of Scotland and consist of Lewis and Harris, North and South Uist, Benbecula and Barra.

THE chief suspect in this murder case is Judge Horace Ireton, who has pronounced sentence upon many criminals in his time. There is considerable evidence against Judge Ireton, but it is all circumstantial.

"Saints Alive," a musical comedy combining efforts of three student writers, has been selected for presentation by the Columbia University Players as the forty-ninth annual varsity show, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin A. Hubbard, director of King's Crown activities.

EVEN in beleaguered England, wartime life is not all air raids. There are places, not very many perhaps, but some few fortunate ones, on which bombs have not as yet been dropped, among them the site of Angela Thirkell's new and very amusing novel, "Northbridge Rectory."

As the Legislature begins its working sessions this week, a smaller group will meet in a room of the Capitol at Albany to follow its progress in legislative matters of particular interest to women. This is the Women's Joint Legislative Forum, which, since 1931, has functioned as a watching post for its many affiliated groups.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A gentle rain of gifts for Winston Churchill has been falling on the White House ever since the Prime Minister's arrival here. The presents include a box of onions, a bottle of Napoleon brandy 1811, catnip for the Churchill cat, a carton of skin lotion and a field hat worn by Prince Bismarck, the German Chancellor of half a century ago.

A Piccadilly Circus comprising an afternoon and evening of dancing, games and special entertainment will take place on Jan. 25 at Fefe's Monte Carlo as a benefit for the British War Relief Society. The proceeds will augment the society's fund for sending good-will packages to women attached to the fighting forces of Great Britain.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 10 -- Weird jungle warfare, a mixture of modern and primitive tactics, advanced closer to Singapore tonight as Japanese hordes assailed the approaches to Kuala Lumpur, gateway city 200 miles to the northwest, in Selangor, after a further British withdrawal.

A warning that the next ten years may bring financial difficulties to the law schools of this country, and as a result entrance standards might be reduced, was issued yesterday by the Very Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, at the twenty-ninth annual luncheon of Theta Sigma Lambda, national honor law society, at the Manhattan Club, Madison Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.

The longest-running "show" on Broadway, the picket line at the Brass Rail Restaurant, will complete its third year next Sunday. Union statisticians estimate that the pickets have worn out 7,264 pairs of shoes and marched 1,728,000 miles without leaving the shelter of the huge, neon-lighted marquee on Seventh Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets.

For Federal income tax purposes, widows, widowers, divorces and married persons separated by mutual consent are classed as single persons, the Bureau of Internal Revenue noted yesterday. Individuals in these classes, together with single persons, must file a return if the gross income in 1941 was $750 or more, or the equivalent of $14.43 a week for the fifty-two weeks of the year.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Jan. 10 -- Running up a 10-point lead in the first three quarters and putting up an airtight defense in the late stages, North Carolina's White Phantoms opened the home basketball season tonight with a 34-25 upset of the Fordham Rams.

AS this is the only musical comedy I've ever worked on, I may be wrong in assuming that the procedure followed here is the usual one. My collaborator, Fred Thompson, has written fifty-five musicals and says that although he has written books to music, around a star, around a composer and around a fat advance, he has never written before to scenery.

The twelfth annual flower-show judging course will be held by the Federated Garden Club of New York State, Inc., on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria from Tuesday through Friday. The course, which comprises four days of lectures on horticulture, flower arrangement and judging and similar subjects, is open to any one interested.
The stewards of the Dad Vail Rowing Association yesterday joined the group of collegiate sports governing bodies that has decided to continue athletic programs during the war.

Japan's "great mistake" has been her alienation of other Asiatic races with the support of whom she might have carried out expansionist aims while posing as a champion against white imperialism, it was asserted yesterday by Henry C. Wolfe, writer, in an address before the Foreign Policy Association luncheon at the Hotel Astor.

Committee chairmen have just been appointed for the twenty-seventh annual Blue Ridge ball to be given at the Plaza on Jan. 23 as a benefit for the Blue Ridge Industrial School in Virginia. Mrs. Walter O. Klingman is executive chairman of the dance, Mrs. Virginius B. Hirst heads the dance committee and Mrs. William Kent Dupre is directing the sale of tickets and table reservations.

IF the Japanese raid United States West Coast cities and aircraft plants, they may employ the unusual combination of small floatplanes -- rarely used to date as bombers -- based on a type of warship not found in any navy except the Japanese -- the seaplane carrier.
MONTREAL, Canada, Jan. 10 -- Canadian students who quit their classrooms to join the Dominion's armed forces will be able to complete their studies at government expense after the war is over.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 10 -- A physical program designed to "toughen" every undergraduate at Lafayette College for whatever task lies ahead in the present emergency will be started during the second semester, beginning Feb. 4, it was announced today by Henry W. Clark, Profesosr of Physical Education.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10 -- That the Falange party in Spain, filled with dreams of new imperial expansion, takes a keen interest in the Far East as well as in Latin America is indicated in statements made by the Franco secret agent to Mexican officials during his examination here last September that was partly described in a dispatch yesterday.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $50,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the live boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,00.

NOTHING daunted by blackouts and air raid alarms, California is carrying vigorously on as a Winter vacation region. Southern California's Sun Festival pursues its flower-garlanded path despite raid drills and defense hustle.

With the object of serving the cause of national defense by helping to develop physical fitness, raising funds for the various war charities and opening club facilities to the officers and enlisted personnel of the training camps, the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association is planning to carry out a full program of tournament activity in 1942, as far as conditions permit.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies showed an increase of 25.9 per cent in December over the same month of 1940, according to a compilation made by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase, while larger than that for November, was under the gain of 26.7 per cent in September and the high for last year of 29.8 per cent in August.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 10 -- Princeton turned back Rutgers after an indecisive first half to score its fourth victory in six basketball starts, 46 -- 28, in the university gymnasium tonight.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters communique said today:

THREE families have furnished the United States with two Presidents apiece. In the familiar historical perspective the Harrison family's contribution is the least distinguished. And yet the first of that name in the White House -- the hero of Tippecanoe -- and Tyler, too -- has received less than his due from the historians responsible for the perspective.

With Mrs. Colin P. Kelly Jr., young widow of the flying Army captain who lost his life in sinking a Japanese battleship, as a guest of honor, Fifth Avenue will be dedicated this afternoon as the "Red Cross Street of Mercy of the Nation," following a patriotic parade headed by Red Cross leaders.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- "Scare" buying by consumers more than offset the effect of a prolonged subzero spell this week and sales by the large department stores bettered last year by an average of 20 per cent. Business in some departments was described as normal for subzero weather and in others ran far ahead of the 1941 period in both dollar volume and units.

THIRTY years ago a new radio society came quietly into being. The world, a few weeks before, had been given a severe jolt -- the S.S. Titanic rammed an iceberg and sank, with huge loss of life. But radio had carried the Titanic's distress signal to other vessels and 700 lives were saved.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Further curtailment of the production of steel ingots in this district because of the shortage of scrap iron is likely to result next month, or possibly sooner, unless the flow of scrap into the area is increased substantially, steel men said today.

Twenty-two Brooklyn schoolboy footbal stars were honored at a luncheon yesterday in the Gallatin Room of the West Building of Abraham Straus, where Walter Rothschild, president of the organization, presented inscribed gold footballs to them.

The Tidewater Oil Company tanker Byron D. Benson, inbound from Port Arthur, Texas, collided last night with the 966-ton freighter Continent four miles south of Scotland Lightship, and the freighter went down with a loss of one life.

Although only about 800 tons of rubber a year are needed for the elastic yarns with which cleverly devised little girdles are made, if rubber rationing is to deprive manufacturers of about 80 per cent of that amount, there may be sorry days ahead for silhouettes. Nor is it appearance alone which will be affected, according to the experts, but morale and sometimes health as well.
