ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 10 -- A tall guard, Eugene Huntemer, led Navy to a 44-to-34 victory over Columbia University today in the first game of the basketball season for the Naval Academy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (U.P.) -- Few items that go to make up the cost of living escaped the price rise of the last year, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Food, clothing, rent, fuel and household furnishings all have increased from 5.7 to 36.1 per cent since January, 1941.

Charles A. Levine, who won acclaim as the first transatlantic airplane passenger when he flew with Clarence Chamberlin from Roosevelt Field to Germany in June, 1927, was held in $1,000 bail yesterday by United States Commissioner Isaac Platt on charges originating in Los Angeles that he had helped to smuggle an alien into the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Intensive patrolling and artillery duels, the usual preludes to major offensive land actions, continued today on the Island of Luzon as the Japanese brought up heavy reinforcements and gave other signs of the imminence of a new Philippine drive.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 10 -- Japanese raiders striking at the oil center of Tarakan, off North Borneo, for the second straight day, hurled thirty bombs at a Netherland warship in the harbor, but scored no hits, the Netherlands Indies Command reported today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 10 -- Uruguayan Foreign Minister Alberto Guani left Montevideo for Rio de Janeiro today on the United States steamer Uruguay, along with the Chilean delegation headed by Foreign Minister Juan B. Rossetti.

The urge to straighten things out hits people like a great wave after the holidays. There's a lot of Christmas loot that has to find permanent quarters, and there's no time like the present to get things neat and tidy. People are going through their belongings to decide what they want to give away, and the things that are to be kept they are planing to care for to make them last longer.
RIVER VALE, N.J., Jan. 10 (AP) -- The New York Rovers defeated the Jersey Skeeters tonight, 4 to 3, in an Eastern Amateur Hockey League game.

Two Columbia teams got an even break at home yesterday and were glad to get it. Spurred by what had happened to the wrestling team against Pennsylvania on its very own mat, the Lion swimming squad gained the stand-off for the afternoon by turning back the Cornell natators, 39 -- 36.

It was not until 1835, in this country, that "lessons in music" became accessories to a college education. Courses in history, theory and composition received scant encouragement until the Eighteen Seventies, when no less than ten institutions of collegiate rank established chairs, departments or complete faculties of music.

Now that America is in the war, dog owners of the country are moving to do their share for its defense. Of course they are buying defense bonds and stamps. Many shows have given their proceeds to the Red Cross and other war charities and the exhibitions to come will follow this lead.

THE purpose of this letter is to say a fervent amen to Douglas MacKinnon's protest against the interruption of musical broadcasts for news flashes. Again this past Friday the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra was wantonly interrupted for news bulletins that had no slightest element of urgency about them, and the pleasure of listening to the music was thereby effectively destroyed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- About 300 privately owned aircraft will be purchased by the War and Navy Departments from private owners in the United States, the War Department announced today.

Members of twenty-eight patriotic organizations who attended a special service yesterday afternoon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, were told by the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, the pastor, that the peace-loving nations would not be able to discard the use of armed force for at least a century after the end of the present war.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Ray Ruge of Highland Falls, N.Y., piloted his Class C craft Charette II to victory through a snowstorm today to retain the championship pennant of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association. The triumph was the third for Charette in the challenge series started yesterday on Orange Lake.

In case of an air raid, the average Columbia College senior would like to tuck a copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES under one arm and Loretta Young under the other, the annual poll conducted by Columbian, senior yearbook, revealed yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 11 -- Charles Brinton of Princeton University, the national singles champion, and Donald Strachan of the Merion Cricket Club, holder of that distinction in 1935 and 1939, joined forces today to win the final of the Apawamis-Greenwich invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Greenwich Country Club.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Twenty-three persons were injured this morning when the all-Pullman New York-to-Miami train Florida Special was derailed a few miles north of here.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Senator Coudert and Assemblyman Mitchell, Manhattan Republicans, announced here today that they would introduce bills tomorrow night intended to eliminate the State's double taxation of odd-lot transfers of stock and to rearrange the stock transfer rates generally, abolishing the emergency tax.

Steadfast Christian faith and loyalty to the principles laid down by Jesus Christ are more important now than ever before, the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, Moderator of the Presbytery of New York, said yesterday in his sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, of which he is pastor emeritus.

VICHY, Jan. 11 -- Budgetary receipts of unoccupied France, estimated for a full year in advance for the first time since the armistice, have been set at 80,000,000,000 francs. This is 12,000,000,000 francs, or nearly 18 per cent more than the estimates for the previous year.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Miss Bessie R. Burchett, retired public school teacher, and thirteen other Philadelphians have been subpenaed to appear in Washington on Thursday for a hearing before the Dies Committee investigating un-American activities.

THEY are taking athletes in the Army, Navy and Marine Corps by the wholesale now. One amateur baseball team volunteered in a body. Five coaches at Clemson received their marching orders. One of them was Banks McFadden of football fame. John McLaughry, another football product and son of Tuss McLaughry, the Dartmouth coach, took his Air Corps physical examination recently.

Older men are not wanted -- men who are mentally and physically capable and fit. I speak particularly of men of great experience in business, organization and in productive accomplishment. They are not wanted even in governmental agencies, notwithstanding the enormous increase of employes in this emergency.

Miserable shooting conditions were responsible for poor scores at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. There was a tie for the high scratch cup at 89 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off, J.J. Van-Gonsic won the trophy with 24 to A.L. Cornwell's 23.

Maurice Abravanel conducted the New York City Symphony Orchestra for the second time at its concert last night in Carnegie Hall under the sponsorship of Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project. Josef and Rosina Lhevinne, duo-pianists, were the assisting artists.

New York City has been divided into seven zones, in each of which thirteen different kinds of emergency "batteries" or groups have been set up to meet the effects of a bombing raid, Mayor La Guardia disclosed yesterday in the second of his series of periodic reports on the progress of the civilian defense organization in this city.

ALEXANDRIA, La., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Negro soldiers were restricted to near-by Camps Livingston and Claiborne today by the Fifth Army Corps Headquarters following a disturbance here last night in which thirty persons -- twenty-eight Negro soldiers, one woman and one State policeman -- were injured.

Interest in the foreign exchange market last week centered in the upward spiral in the Canadian dollar, which climbed to 89 cents, a recovery of all of the loss sustained since the first week in November. The close on Saturday was 88.75 cents, a net gain of 2 cents from the preceding week.

The New York district council of the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers, A.F. of L., charged yesterday that its unemployed members were being denied jobs on defense construction projects in other cities because the local unions in control of hiring preferred to enrich their treasuries by obtaining initiation fees from inexperienced painters.

The Netherlands Indies, rich prize sought in the latest Japanese attack, are being defended by veteran officers thoroughly schooled in modern battle tactics on land, on the sea and in the air. They operate under the command of Governor General A.W.L. van Starkenborgh Stachouwer.

Newspaper circulation in Hawaii has jumped since the war outbreak and the newspapers now command much greater reader attention, according to letters from The Honolulu Star Bulletin and The Hilo Tribune Herald to O'Mara Ormsbee, Inc., their representatives here.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will open tonight a war-time appeal for $750,000 to help St. Nincent's HosPital prepare for any emergency. Pie will speak in behalf of the hospital's building fund at a dinner in the Biltmore Hotel, at which former Governer A/fred E. Smith, chairman of the fund, will preside.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Jan. 11 (AP) -- German submarines are being shifted from the Atlantic to the Mediterranean in an effort to curb the devastating attacks by the British Navy on Axis convoys bound for Libya, "but the attacks are not going to stop," Rear Admiral Henry Bernard Rawlings, commander of a British cruiser squadron in the Mediterranean, said today aboard his flagship. Three submarines were sunk in recent weeks, and probably others were destroyed.

Three thousand persons filled the Cosmopolitan Opera House, 135 West Fifty-fifth Street, last night to watch a pageant and revue staged as a tribute to Negroes serving with the armed forces and to hear Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt express the hope that after this war minorities in this country will enjoy the same liberties that all other groups have.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- The time for registration of all men between the ages of 20 and 44, the new Selective Service limits, was changed in New York State today from Feb. 16, as set by President Roosevelt, to Feb. 14, 15 and 16.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- In biting cold out on Long Island Sound sixteen dinghy sailors in half that many boats carried on today with their unseasonable wind jamming. Bob De Coppet, with his craft Zotom, was the winner, with Arthur Knapp in his Four Deuces the runner-up.

Artur Schnabel yesterday afternoon gave the second of the series of five all-Schubert piano programs that he is presenting on five successive Sundays under the auspices of the New Friends of Music at Town Hall. He played the remaining four of the eight Impromptus -- those published as Op. 142 -- and two more of the major sonatas, the one in B major, Op. 147, and the posthumous one in A major.
During the past year the United States Lawn Tennis Association has shown how intelligently directed sport can be of real value to our country.

NEWARK, Jan. 11 -- Mrs. J. Clarence Carr, whose husband is a leading realty broker here and president of the board of trustees of the Roseville Methodist Church, a woman widely known as a devoted church worker and an "angel of mercy" to the poor of Newark, was unmasked today as an ex-convict, known to the police across the country.

A group of 125 prominent American liberals, meeting yesterday in the Hotel Commodore under the auspices of the Union for Democratic Action, accused the State Department of following a policy of "appeasing undemocratic and pro-Axis governments" and called on President Roosevelt to reorganize the department's personnel to bring it "into line with the anti-Axis war effort to which the rest of the government and the country itself are dedicated."

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Raids on Japanese airdromes by the Allied forces based in Burma resulted in the destruction of at least twenty-six Japanese planes, including ten bombers, a communique announced today.

Ruth Page and Bentley Stone, who have recently closed an engagement at the Rainbow Room, brought some of their dances down from the skyscraper supper club to the stage of the Guild Theatre last night, supplemented them with other numbers sufficient to make up a joint recital program, and made their first Broadway appearance in five years.

TOKYO, Jan. 11 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded in New York) -- After announcing formally today the fall of Kuala Lumpur, capital of the Federated Malay States 200 miles northwest of Singapore, the Army section of the Imperial Headquarters asserted that Japanese troops along the west coast of Malaya were in hot pursuit of the retreating British.
A "nutrition issue" of Neighborhood Health, bimonthly publication of the Health Education Bureau of the city Health Department, will be published today as part of the department's nutrition campaign.

Teachers at City College and other city institutions who were dismissed, dropped or suspended as a result of the Rapp-Coudert committee investigation into Communist activities in the city schools, including one who was dismissed for indoctrination of students, are prominent on the faculty of the School for Democracy, 13 Astor Place, which announced its program yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Thomas of Utah, who spent many years as a missionary in the Far East, warned the people of China today to ignore Japan's assertion that she was fighting to maintain "Asia for the Asiatics."
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

Broad revisions bringing a general increase in automobile liability insurance rates in thirty-four States were announced yesterday by the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters. The over-all effect of the rate changes, which are effective immediately, is an increase of 3.5 per cent in premium for bodily injury and property damage on private passenger automobiles and an increase of 1.8 per cent for commercial automobiles.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Uncertainty regarding the outcome of price-control legislation resulted in prices of wheat on the Board of Trade holding within a range of about 1 1/2 cents a bushel last week, with outside interest at a minimum the greater part of the period.

THIS morning Herbert Hoover publishes what seems to be his first book in seven years. It is called "America's First Crusade."* Read it and you win see why our only living ex-President has never been celebrated for his tact or his sense of timing.

The United Jewish Appeal for Refugees, Overseas Needs and Palestine, which fills the needs of the Joint Distribution Committee, the United Palestine Appeal and the National Refugee Service, opened its 1942 campaign for funds yesterday.

I read the article "Unusual Birds Flock to City and Puzzle Experts." I don't think there is any puzzle about it at all. The birds from the North migrate into a warmer climate during a severe Winter. The owls, ravens and chickadees knew we were going to have a spell of very cold weather.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 11 -- "Owing to the great expenditure of fuel on the Eastern Front the liquid fuel situation of the Reich is exceptionally stringent. The fuel allowance for panzer Gruppe Afrika accordingly has been severely cut down. In particular we can no longer expect that liquid fuel lost by enemy action will be made good.

WASHINGTON, Jan. -- A Victory Garden Program, to be started in each community under the auspices of Local Defense Councils, was announced today by the Office of Civilian Defense. The program is the result of conferences between the Office of Civilian Defense, the Department of Agriculture, the Office of Education, WPA and other government agencies.

A syndicate of investors headed by Irving D. Goldwyn has purchased the twelve-story store and loft building at 684 Broadway from 684 Broadway, Inc., for cash over a first mortgage of $82,800. The property is 41 by 130 feet and is assessed at $190,000. Irving Brodsky and Abraham L. Stone, attorneys, represented the seller.

EAST WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- Torger Tokle, 160-pound skier from the Norway S.C., continued his record-breaking jumping today by twice smashing the Silver Lake Hill mark before a gathering that huddled along the 45-meter slide.

There has recently been published a series of articles condemning the Domestic Relations Court of New York. As a physician in the treatment clinic of that court -- which clinic, incidentally, is supported by private contribution and not by city funds -- I am in a position to know at first hand many of the problems met by these courts and many of the limitations under which they must operate.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 11 -- Violent Communist feeling is spreading throughout Greece, coincident with the famine and plague that have raised the death toll in Athens and Piraeus to more than 1,500 persons daily, according to authenticated reports brought to Turkey by Greek refugees.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 11 -- Turkish Thrace and Anatolia began to emerge this week-end from one of the worst blizzards in Turkey's history which took a heavy toll in lives and property throughout the land.

Even reveille sounded sweet to the cars of 200 service men crowded into the Tavern Room of the headquarters of the New York Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue, yesterday afternoon -- sweet because it came not from a bugle at dawn but was the popular song of the same name, squeezed through the "sweet" trumpet of Charlie Spivak.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- A mild Winter and freedom from air attacks have materially eased Britain's position as to supplies of coal. Government coal stocks, accumulated last Summer, have not been touched thus far, and the reserve for the remaining Winter months appears to be adequate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Declaring that a price ceiling for used tires would be imposed soon, Price Administrator Leon Henderson today struck directly at "widespread profiteering" in second-hand tires with the announcement of an emergency schedule of maximum prices for "retreadable" tire carcasses and "retreads."

Everybody who has been in Germany since the war started knows that the people are much better informed about events abroad than outsiders imagine. In Russia radio reception is controlled by the simple device of turning the broadcasts off and on from a central point in each building, but in other countries, including Germany, the individual listener can still fiddle with the dial of the instrument that connects him with the outer world.

VICHY, France, Jan. 11 -- Newspapers in both occupied and unoccupied France quoted German sources as having said tonight that a "Hitler Line" had been established on the Russian front and that German troops were falling back to it in the expectation that they would be able to spend the Winter there.

The cotton market continued its upward movement last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts at the close on Saturday showed net advances of 9 to 22 points. In the South, prices of spot cotton reached the highest level since 1929, the average price of middling fifteen-sixteenth inch cotton at ten markets being 18.47 cents a pound.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 11 -- Yugoslav Chetnik guerrillas staged a series of bold raids late last week upon German rear-guard units protecting the retreat of the German Army toward Winter quarters in Belgrade.

Large numbers of buyers were in the city last week to attend the opening of Spring lines. Much of the activity, however, was confined to shopping new lines, although some merchandise, notably furs and fur-trimmed coats, which were stimulated by reduced prices and colder weather, were in heavy demand.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 11 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The following communique was issued by the Netherlands Indies Command today:
The New York Rovers, seeking their third Eastern Hockey League triumph in three days, dropped a 4-3 decision to the Washington Eagles before 11,112 at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- President Roosevelt is redefining the functions of the information services of the government in an effort to coordinate the machinery for disseminating news and sustaining the nation's morale.

A national campaign of public education to "Put Thrift to Work for America" will be launched by the National Thrift Committee with National Thrift Week, Jan. 17 to 23, according to J. Robert Stout, chairman of the committee. Self-imposed personal and family rationing in both purchase and use of food, clothing, cleaning products, gas, coal, oil, gasoline, rubber, metal, wool, cotton and paper will be recommended.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 11 -- Reinforcements from the United States and Britain are on their way to the Far East, Australian Navy Minister Norman J.O. Makin announced today in a speech in which he foresaw security for the Dominion against "any menace."

The survey of living quarters for several million children, mothers, aged and infirm persons who might have to be evacuated from the New York metropolitan area in case of air raids has been "virtually completed" in eighteen rural counties of the State, Edward Weinfeld, State Housing Commissioner, reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- Paramount has borrowed Claire Trevor from Columbia to play the feminine lead opposite Burgess Meredith in "The Black Curtain," which will start this month with Jack Hively directing. The photoplay is based on a mystery novel by Cornell Woolrich.

"The Lady Comes Across," the musical comedy which arrived Friday night at the Forty-fourth Street after a hectic pre-Broadway career, was abruptly taken off on Saturday night after its third performance.

In its action on a so-called price-control bill the Senate has been reckless and irresponsible. Pass over for the moment that the bill it has put through says nothing whatever about the control of wages, the largest single element in prices.

Faced with statistics showing a 500 per cent increase in the number of cases of poliomyelitis, or infantile paralysis, within its limits in 1941, New York City will open today an intensive eighteen-day "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign for $550,000 to fight the disease that struck down 404 persons here last year.
Not long ago we had lunch with a group of men, all of whom were ardent bird hunters, and the discussion swung toward the "best all-purpose shotgun."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The national income this year is expected to reach $100,000,000,000, which is around $20,000,000,000 more than it ever has been before, but how to get an additional $9,000,000,000 of taxes out of it has put up to Congress one of the biggest puzzles it ever has confronted.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 11 -- An indication of the direction from which the German people may expect the next diplomatic move aimed at taking their minds off the Eastern campaign was given to Netherlanders Friday night when Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, Civil Administrator for the Netherlands, broadcast that Germany would annex the Netherlands soon.

Downtown Brooklyn, with 5,959 off-street parking spaces for transient cars in convenient parking lots and garages, is better equipped than any comparable Manhattan area to prevent hardship to auto users under the police drive to enforce parking regulations, it was disclosed yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 11 -- Two persons were killed and thirteen others were injured, several seriously, in a three-alarm blaze early today that caused $30,000 damage to a four-story apartment hotel at 17 Lincoln Park here.

In the present phase of the war, when the United States is under enormous pressure to increase its naval and air strength on many fronts simultaneously, most Americans are probably beginning to reach a point of sympathetic understanding of the problem that has been confronting Great Britain since the fall of France.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 11 -- For over two years Australia's peacetime routine has been imperceptibly disturbed.

It is not the function of the church to preach war sermons but to strengthen faith in God, to comfort the sorrowing, to dispel fears, to confirm high resolves and to rekindle hope, declared the Rev. Dr. Wesley Megaw in his sermon yesterday in Fort Washington Presbyterian Church, Wadsworth Avenue and 174th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- With the Price Control Bill passed by the Senate, Congress is scheduled this week to spend a post-holiday vacation while its committees iron out differences in the two major measures passed in the last week.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 11 -- Announcing today that the British Government had asked Alfred Duff Cooper, Resident Minister for Far Eastern Affairs, to conclude his mission at Singapore and return to London, Prime Minister John Curtin said the decision was a corollary to the Washington agreement and the appointment of General Sir Archibald P. Wavell as supreme commander in the Southwest Pacific.

The taxpayer at 914 McLean Avenue, Yonkers, in Westchester County, which is under lease to the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company as a food market, has been purchased by an investor through Frederick Fox Co. and Alvin S. Harte, brokers.

The Postal Life Insurance Company of New York, which has been having some difficulty with its real estate investments during recent years, has just received a guarantee of $1,500,000 from State funds and thereby regained solvency, it was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Various phases of defense activities continued in the forefront as the Legislature prepared to convene tomorrow night for its first real work week.

By contrast with the problems of military strategy and of industrial production, the financial problems of this war are relatively simple. We need have no doubts about the ability of the Treasury to furnish all the billions of dollars needed. The primary question is how to govern the flow of national income so as to avoid a costly price inflation.
BERLIN, Jan. 11 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique:

Your recent editorial "Dividing the Patent Office" is most commendable and should be thoroughly considered and its suggestions accepted by Congress and President Roosevelt before the final ultimatum is given to shift part of the Patent Office to Richmond.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Lord Haw Haw, German propaganda broadcaster, said today that the Russians undertook their offensive, "which in reality is no offensive at all," by request of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who, Haw Haw said, were in "urgent need of relief" for purposes of prestige.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Finnish communique today said:

VICHY, France, Jan. 11 -- French public opinion is occupied chiefly with the progress of military operations in the various theatres of war, especially Russia, which it is realized holds the greatest possibilities.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Air Ministry issued this communique today:

A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 a consolidated net income of $427,664 after all charges, taxes and reserves. The net was equal, after preferred divident requirements, to 86 cents each on the 440,003 shares of common stock outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Foreign Policy Association, evaluating the chances of the United Nations in the war, stated today that the Axis was superior in land and air power and "will remain a powerful and dangerous antagonist, particularly until such time as the United States can throw its full weight in the balance."

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Jan. 12 -- Soviet forces on the southwestern sector of the central front drove forward yesterday to register one of the most telling blows against German freedom of action since the recapture of Klin. This new success was achieved with the capture of Lyudinovo, an important junction on the Rzhev-Bryansk rail line, after mechanized units from the Kozelsk salient had broken the lines of the German Sixteenth Army.

The first program of works by contemporary Canadian composers ever given in this city was presented at the New York Public Library yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the League of of Composers. Compositions of six composers of the Dominion were granted a hearing, including representative creations by John J. Weinzweig, Godfrey Ridout and Louis Applebaum of Toronto, Hector Gratton and Andre Mathieu of Montreal, and Barbara Pentland of Winnipeg.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Wide-spread rumors that Adolf Hitler had carried out a purge among his army generals appeared strengthened by a Stockholm report today quoting a German spokesman as saying that changes in the German Army would be announced "at a suitable time."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Japan's destiny will be fulfilled only if the last bit of American influence in the Pacific is wiped out, and with that aim guiding its whole belligerent program the Japanese Government has conceived a war plan, the climax of which is to come when Japanese soldiers invade the Panama Canal Zone, Alaska and the three Pacific States -- California, Oregon and Washington.

Carl Pilnick, City College champion, gained a notable victory yesterday in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club, when he defeated Edward Lasker, famous internationalist, in forty-nine moves.

With the possibility that this country may be cut off from virtually its only source of natural crude rubber as a result of the war in the Pacific Ocean, it has become apparent that authorities in Washington must take decisive steps immediately to meet the rubber supply situation which threatens the war efforts of both the United States and the associated nations.

Hank Greenberg, famous Detroit Tiger outfielder, has been singled out by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association for special recognition at the organization's nineteenth annual dinner, to be held at the Hotel Commodore on Sunday, Feb. 1.

The idea that collapse after the war is inevitable is based on the lack of faith in leaders in industry, in government, in the church and in the Army and Navy, and is quite without foundation, declared the Rev. John Walter Houck in his sermon yesterday in the Pilgrim Congregational Church, Grand Concourse and East 175th Street, the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks outlasted the Detroit Red Wings tonight to win a National Hockey League game, 6 to 5, at the Stadium. It was the first meeting of the clubs since their New Year's Night contest.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Appointment of sixteen representatives of government departments and agencies to the Censorship Operating Board was announced today by Byron Price, Director of Censorship.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 11 (AP) -- British imperials fought for Singapore today along an irregular and fluid line varying from 160 to 200 miles north of this island stronghold.

The real atmosphere and technique of the Samba, a Brazilian dance which the general public often confuses with the rumba, was explained yesterday by Guido Zanette of New York, an authority on the social dances of Latin America, to the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., at its January meeting in the Hotel Astor.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 11 -- To the little that is known about German conduct in occupied Soviet territory -- except for atrocities reported by the Russians -- may be added some scanty details from the Ukraine. They reveal a state of affairs strikingly different from the rosy picture of a "liberated Ukraine" that German propagandists used to conjure up.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Americans in Hong Kong, using tommy guns, fought the Japanese invaders alongside the British defenders before the colony surrendered on Christmas Day, an escaped Briton said today.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 11 (North American Newspaper Alliance) -- The first Japanese bomber positively shot down by a fighter in the neighborhood of Singapore was sent hurtling to earth soon after dawn today by two New Zealand sergeant pilots in an American-built Brewster Buffalo.

Mayor La Guardia, speaking at La Guardia Field as a Mayor to a group of Mayors, yesterday told a Canadian delegation to the Mayors' conference in Washington that the war would end in the complete destruction of the Axis powers "no matter how long it takes.

Home defense in North America will become home defense in all South and Central America when Senora Maria Correa de Aya completes the translations she is doing at the request of the Office of Defense, Health and Welfare Services, a division of the Office of Emergency Management.

Braving a cold wind, uniformed Red Cross workers and color bearers representing scores of veterans' organizations paraded on Fifth Avenue yesterday to help dedicate that famous thoroughfare as the Red Cross "Street of Mercy of the Nation."

Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, will appear before Army medical authorities at Fort Jay on Governors Island this morning for a physical examination preliminary to being inducted into the Army at Camp Upton, L.I., on Wednesday.
The spiritual strength of this nation is menaced by a "lowering of the standard of family life," the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

While it is true that the stock market made a spotty retreat last week from the impact of the President's extraordinary budget demands for the next fiscal year, Wall Street generally concurred that the reshuffling of investment portfolios produced the main weakness.

W ASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Wartime precautions have changed the Immigration Service's three detention camps into virtual prisons, with protective and alarm systems regarded as foolproof, an official disclosed today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11 -- The common muskrat, which is found generally all over the continent of North America, was today announced at Yale and Louisiana State Universities as a source of natural musk so abundant that the war dearth of this valuable ingredient of fine perfumes may be overcome.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Ted Ellenwood, Fort Johnson stock clerk, and Miss Carmelita Landry, Massachusetts paper factory inspector, won the Eastern States speed skating championships today. Both scored clean sweeps in the eleventh annual meet.

The Japanese drive against Singapore, strongest of the Allied positions in the Orient, continued over the week-end, and the fortress island at the foot of the Malay Peninsula was rapidly accommodating itself to a virtual state of siege.

There are many scientists who champion freedom of thought and in the same breath urge the designing of what they conceive to be a rational social and economic structure under an all-powerful central government. Many economists disagree, believing freedom of scientific activity and central planning are irreconcilable.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 11 -- Polish Red Cross representatives reported here today that Polish citizens from a section of Poland with 1,500,000 population that had been occupied by Russia in 1939 and who had been dispersed in various parts of Siberia, have now with Russian permission crossed the Caucasus and are entering an Iranian region that is ill equipped to receive them.

For selection of college juniors and seniors as prospective deck and engineering officers in the Naval Reserve, a board headed by Lieut. Comdr. J.M. Young, U.S.N.R., will hold the first of a series of meetings today at Princeton University and will convene again next Monday at Yale.

Two hundred persons ranging in age from 3 to 60 took part in the colorful annual festival service of the guilds of Trinity Church, marching with the clergy and choir in the Epiphany procession to the manger at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, yesterday afternoon.

An abatement of the cold wave that has given the city an average temperature of 16 degrees above zero for the last three days was forecast for today by the local Weather Bureau. Yesterday was the second coldest day of the Winter, with a low mark of 6.9 degrees at 5:40 A.M.

A recent Tokyo radio fabrication that a Japanese flotilla had sunk one of our battleships off Port Darwin was an obvious effort to gain information on our naval dispositions around this great strategic base in the Antipodes. Port Darwin must not only be the anchor of Australia's defense but a bridgehead of our attack against Japanese conquests in the South Seas.

Playing the puck persistently and giving their rivals little opportunity to organize for an effective advance, the Canadiens of Montreal turned in a well-deserved 2-to-0 triumph over the Brooklyn Americans in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Representatives of underwriters and dealers in securities in every section of the country will meet here on Thursday and Friday for the annual election of officers and governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc. They also will complete plans for the association's participation with other organizations in the selling of defense bonds.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Representatives of cities and villages throughout the State called upon New York's Legislature today to permit localities to issue budget notes to finance defense and emergency measures.

Such outstanding concert artists as Jascha Heifetz, Albert Spalding, James Melton and Lawrence Tibbett have volunteered to make Army camp appearances, Mrs. Blanche Witherspoon, chairman of the concert talent pool for USO Camp Shows and widow of the former director of the Metropolitan Opera Company, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- British bombers savagely attacked the great German naval bases of Wilhelmshaven and Emden last night, bombed airdromes in the Low Countries, docks at Boulogne, France, and a strongly escorted convoy off the Netherland coast.

Last Monday, Osborne Cowles of Dartmouth told the metropolitan basketball writers that his current squad was fully up to the standard of the Indian fives that had captured the Eastern League title four years in a row.

Bizet's "Carmen," in which Sir Thomas Beecham will conduct and Lily Djanel, new French soprano, will make her New York debut in the title role, will be the feature of next week, the ninth, at the Metropolitan Opera, General Manager Edward Johnson announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 -- Shortages of scrap metal, increased by extreme cold weather in various parts of the country last week, coupled with necessary repairs to furnaces, kept steel-ingot operations at 97 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the week before.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 11 -- Japanese sea-borne and parachute troops, grasping for the wealth of the Netherlands Indies, have invaded Borneo and Celebes, hurling a challenge to the Allied war effort that the Netherlanders met by bombing Japanese warships and transports that took part in the operation and battling Japanese planes, it was announced tonight.

Conforming to Mayor La Guardia's program for a longer work-week for the city's 157,000 employes for the duration of the war, skeleton staffs were on duty yesterday in the offices of the City Collector, the Tax Department, the Department of Investigation and the office of the custodian of the Municipal Building.

An increased fare on all city-owned and operated rapid transit lines, on the basis of two rides for 15 cents and a single ride for 10 cents, was recommended in a report made public yesterday by the Committee of Fifteen, organized in 1940 by representatives of leading business, industrial and real estate groups and headed by Paul Windels, former Corporation Counsel under Mayor La Guardia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- War Department communique No. 54, based on information received up to 1 P.M., said:

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- While Great Britain momentarily has to forsake many of her pre-war activities to concentrate on war production, there are certain of her crafts that it is felt must be maintained at their high pitch of excellence in order to retain not only their reputation for quality but post-war outlets overseas.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 11 -- Displaying superiority in the short races, Robert Anderson, 20-year-old N.Y.U. student, registered a total of eighty points tonight to capture the men's metropolitan senior speed skating championship at the meet held under the auspices of the Middle Atlantic Skating Association on the Municipal rink.

Bringing forty-nine passengers, twenty-five of them from Europe, the Atlantic Clipper of Pan American Airways reached La Guardia Field at 6:15 o'clock last night, making an after-dark landing on the waters of Flushing Bay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The anticipated assault by heavily reinforced Japanese forces on United States and Philippine units on the island of Luzon in the Philippines was unleashed with "tremendous force" yesterday.

Encouraged by the unity of A.F. of L. and C.I.O. representatives in President Roosevelt's industry-labor conference, A.F. of L. leaders hope to work out a basis for the orderly settlement of jurisdictional conflicts with the C.I.O. in war industries, it became known yesterday.

VICHY, France, Jan. 11 (U.P.) -- A new wave of anti-Communist propaganda swept Western Europe today. The propaganda seeks to convince non-belligerents and lukewarm Axis allies that the Russians may overrun Europe if Adolf Hitler's armies cannot hold them off, with a consequent spread of communism in every country where fifth columns are ready to rise.

Half a generation ago the tabloids arrived. Fifty years ago, in the battles between Joseph Pulitzer of The World and young William Randolph Hearst of The New York Evening Journal, was born Yellow Journalism.

The National Broadcasting Company issued yesterday a statement in reply to a suit for $10,000,000 damages filed in Chicago on Saturday by the Mutual Broadcasting Company. The suit charged that a conspiracy existed to restrict Mutual in competing in nation-wide network broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Office of Production Management announced tonight the appointment of a seven-man subcommittee which will "assist" in developing the best methods for conversion of the automobile industry to production of war materials.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 -- Light Horse Harry Cooper, a two-time winner, captured undisputed leadership of the $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament today when he bettered par for the third consecutive round and wound up with a 210 score for fifty-four holes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Twenty-six reserve officers, including men prominent in the business and professional world, have been ordered to active duty, the Marine Corps announced today.
Henry Ford repudiated anti-Semitism in a letter made public here yesterday.

A RED ARMY BASE HOSPITAL, Behind the Front, Jan. 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Russian generals die with their boots on in this war. They are in the front lines with their troops, running all the risks. It has been announced that two generals died in action on the Moscow front, and others have been wounded there and elsewhere.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices made its sharpest weekly advance since March, 1941, rising by 1.1 per cent to a new all-time high point of 102.3. All but comparatively few of the commodities in the farm products and foodstuffs groups scored substantial gains, causing those indexes to increase by 3.9 per cent and 2.3 per cent, respectively.

It has become a national trait for Americans to dislike being alone; we are unused to being alone; we are afraid to be alone; we do not know what to with solitude, declared Professor Mary Ellen Chase of Smith College yesterday morning at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 11 -- i Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Royce Kent gave a luncheon today at Mi Encanto.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Office of Civilian Defense released instructions today to be observed by air raid wardens for the protection of persons with impaired hearing.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- A broad shipping demand for cash corn developed last week, and with country offerings light, futures on the Board of Trade here advanced to the highest prices since last October, while old crop No. 2 yellow corn sold in the spot market at 85 cents a bushel, a new high since 1937.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The government decreed a state of siege today, explaining that it was acting to suppress violence in the mining areas of Potosi, Sucre and Oruro.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 11 -- The British Ambassador, Sir Hughe Knatchbull-Hugessen, called yesterday at the Turkish Foreign Office, where he gave an extensive report to Foreign Minister Shukru Saracoglu on the Moscow conference of Allied statesmen.

At Simon Schuster the editors have assembled their Spring list of books and find that it adds up to thirty-two titles, eight more than were included in the firm's Spring, 1941, list. The early 1942 schedule will include books by Kay Boyle, Hendrick Willem Van Loon, Meyer Berger, John Cowper Powys, Henry Bellamann, Max Eastman and Richardson Wright.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 11 -- Two campaigns in a year's time have reduced Italian colonists and Arab civilians in Cyrenaica to a plight described by official observers today as wretched, and the American Red Cross, in conjunction with the British administration for occupied enemy territory, is making a survey of their needs that may lead to extensive allocations of American relief goods.

Vivid imaginations are busy these days picturing a sugarless future. Not a few householders, beset with a fine case of the jitters are trying their utmost to stave off just such an evil day. But they are finding that their attempted measures -- which naturally center about hoarding -- are now being halted at every turn.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Joe McCarthy is confident that despite war conditions his world champion New York Yankees "are going to be tough again."

BATAVIA, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- From the string of fifty emergency air bases in the Netherlands Indies -- one of the few surprises sprung on the Japanese in this war -- Dutch, American and Australian Air Forces were reported today to be fanning out northeastward to the Philippines and northwestward to Singapore to engage the Japanese in air battles and blast their supply lines.

Dr. David Hart and Dr. Frederic L. Weber, suspended chemistry professors, shared in the profits that accrued from the $30,000 to $40,000 yearly average gross business of the Kemkit Scientific Corporation, a concern that sold chemistry equipment to municipal college students, according to testimony given yesterday before a trial committee of the Board of Higher Education at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -Three employes of the House postoffice testified in district court today that George Hill, a clerk for Representative Fish of New York, ordered the removal of eight mail bags containing franked Congressional material which was under inquiry by a Federal grand jury investigating Nazi propaganda.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The renewed attack by Japanese invaders in the Philippines, launched Saturday on Luzon Island against the United States-Filipino defending forces, settled into an artillery duel today, with renewed bombing of American positions by enemy planes.

Five hundred leading American scientists are serving the government without cost; 3,000 more research men and a like number of assistants are on the payrolls of industry and in laboratories at 600-odd defense projects for which about $25,000,000 has been appropriated, representing the mobilization of science in this war, the Institute of Radio Engineers heard here yesterday at its thirtieth anniversary convention, which got under way at the Hotel Commodore.

John L. Haynes, chief of the lumber and materials branch of OPM, will discuss the "Outlook for the Construction Industry in View of Present Material Shortages" at a luncheon meeting of the New York Building Congress tomorrow at the Hotel Astor. R.H. Shreve, president of the American Institute of Architects, will be honorary chairman.

Sister Marie Ursulina, superintendent of Seton Hospital, Manhattan, for the last two years, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital at West New Brighton, S.I., after a month's illness. She was 75 years old.

George (the Weasel) Stern, the last of seventeen members of a gang of robbers to face sentence in General Sessions in a series of hold-ups of homes, business concerns and hotel guests in which they got away with $1,000,000 loot up to three years ago, was sentenced to five years in State prison yesterday by Judge James G. Wallace.

The ten-year-old consecutive-game scoring record of the New York Rangers in National Hockey League activity faces improvement tonight at Madison Square Garden, where the Blue Shirts will renew hostilities with their city rivals, the Brooklyn Americans.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 12 -- The Halfaya Pass stronghold, which is the Germans' North African "Siegfried Line," is being battered to pieces by bombardment from British air, sea and land forces, and it is believed that only surrender can save it from destruction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- On the ground that the "Georgia Contract Labor Law" violated the anti-Slavery Amendment to the Constitution and an Act of Congress forbidding peonage, the forty-year-old State statute was held unconstitutional by a unanimous Supreme Court decision today.

A quick resale was reported yesterday by Frederick Brown, the operator, of the eleven-story loft structure at 33-35 West Seventeenth Street, which he bought last week, to a client of Joseph Davis. Said to be fully rented to single-floor tenants and yielding an annual revenue of about $22,000, the structure is on a plot 50 by 97 feet.

The four-story apartment house for thirty-two families on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 169-73 Manhattan Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark to the 169 Manhattan Corporation through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, brokers.

Nearly 300 women appeared at the Police Department's Civilian Defense Headquarters at 300 Mulberry Street yesterday to volunteer their services to the Police Department so policemen could be relieved of clerical duties and put on more active duties.

The government's seizure of the Spanish ship Isla de Tenerife was rescinded yesterday and the whole matter of attempted circumvention of this country's export control laws disposed of with the payment of fines and penalties totaling $22,000 and the forfeiture of a quantity of radio parts, lubricating oil and rope by the Compania Transmediterranea, owner of the vessel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, announced today that the nation would spend $400,000,000 to increase synthetic rubber production to 400,000 tons a year and would stimulate the production of zinc, lead and copper by paying a premium for output in excess of that of last year.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 12 -- China in the first days of the New Year has undergone a new trial and has emerged from it with a new victory. This heartening development should give good cheer to everybody who reposes confidence in the vitality of the anti-aggression front.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- A group representing those in opposition to the recently enacted "plumage law," which eventually will prevent the sale or possession for sale of fishing flies tied with wild bird feathers in this State, met with Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne today to discuss the effect of this law and the possibility of its amendment.

To encourage enemy aliens in New York City to turn over to the police contraband items, including pistols and other "concealed" weapons forbidden to all persons under the Sullivan law, rather than throw them away, Assistant District Attorney Harold X. McGowan in Felony Court yesterday asked the police to refrain from summary arrests where there is no previous evidence of willful intent to violate the Sullivan law.

Major radio networks will be gravely injured unless recent regulations of the Federal Communications Commission, seeking to limit contractual relations between the chains and their affiliated stations, are voided, attorneys for the National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday told a Statutory Federal Court consisting of Judges Learned Hand, John Bright and Henry W. Goddard.

IT seems that Joe Louis is always doing the right thing. He is simply grand, and the words "simply grand" are used advisedly. He is simple, straightforward, honest and natural in speech and action. He is grand, whether that word is used in the colloquial English sense of "superlatively good, admirable, really swell" or with the more scholarly implications that come with its Latin derivation, "large, imposing, beyond ordinary dimensions."

A syndicate headed by Putnam Co., Chas. W. Scranton Co. and Estabrook Co. will offer today a new issue of 336,088 shares of cumulative preferred stock of no par value of the Connecticut Light and Power Company.

A two-way smuggling conspiracy with the object of getting platinum out of this country in violation of the laws covering export of this strategic war material was charged yesterday in two Federal indictments. The operators of the ring were described as Alexander Radbill, formerly of 580 Fifth Avenue, and Alphonse Kurkdjibachian of Rio de Janeiro.

The two major milk distributors here announced yesterday a reduction of 3 cents a quart in the price of milk sold under the Borden and Sheffield names in stores. The change has become effective already in most metropolitan stores. The price will be that at which the unadvertised brands have been selling.
BERLIN, Jan. 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique issued today follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Joe Chamaco of Mexico City achieved his second straight victory today in the world three-cushion billiard championship tournament by beating Earle Lookabaugh of Chicago, 50 to 31, in fifty innings. Chamaco had a high run of 6; Lookabaugh one of 5.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Star Hat and Cap Company, Inc., of Chicago, and its president, Charles Schneider, were fined $1,000 each in the Federal court here today on their plea of no defense to charges of conspiring to fix prices on Army field hats purchased by the War Department.

Whether women should wear uniforms for defense work and, more important, whether they look better in uniforms than in styles of their own, flared into a major crisis on the feminine war front yesterday as fashion designers eagerly awaited the results of a survey by the Office of Production Management.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull explained today that no insult to the Free French had been intended when the term "so-called Free French ships" was employed in the State Department's statement in connection with the Christmas Eve occupation of St. Pierre and Miquelon.
TOKYO, Jan. 12 (From Japanese Broadcasts Recorded by The Associated Press) -- Domei broadcast today the following round-up of Japanese claims in the war of the South Pacific and Southeastern Asia:

LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A foreign source whose information in the past has almost always proved correct reported today that the friction already noted in Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Army Command had spread to the navy in a sharp dispute between Grand Admiral Erich Raeder and the submarine commander, Vice Admiral Karl Doenitz.

The first three seeded players in the eighth annual New York State squash racquets championship won their second-round matches yesterday on the Downtown Athletic Club courts. The tournament is open to all amateurs resident in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut regardless of club affiliation.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The harmony program between the Republican-controlled Senate and Democratic Governor Charles Edison does not include wholesale confirmation of thirty-one pending appointments, Senate Republican leaders reported tonight after a conference.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 12 -- The Advisory War Council received today Prime Minister Churchill's reply to the commonwealth government's strong representations for Australia's right to participation in any authority directing strategy in the Pacific, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Reduction of the capital gains tax would remove an impediment to the free flow of money into industry, increase revenues, revive the security markets, and encourage investment in post-war ventures, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, asserted tonight.

None of your "tearful departures" for the boys who are inducted into the Army from Local Board 140 in Brooklyn. The neighbors sent another batch off yesterday in style. At 7 A.M. they provided the trainees good breakfasts, gave each a carton of cigarettes, made arrangements to send them extra money if they ever needed it, and then bundled them off in taxis to Pennsylvania Station, leaving jovial, not weeping, relatives behind.

The Finance Committe of the Board of Higher Education approved a tentative budget calling for $10,603,000 for the operation of the four city colleges, two high schools and one elementary school, in the next fiscal year, following an open hearing held at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue.

New capital financing for the Union Oil Company of California will be carried out today with the offering to the public by an underwriting group headed by Dillon, Read Co. of an issue of $15,000,000 of 3 per cent debentures, due Jan. 1, 1967. The debentures will be priced at 99 1/2 and accrued interest.

Fred M. Smith, 55 years old, who, with the aid of a woman assistant, stole $400,000 in five years from Annin Co., flag manufacturers, sending the concern into bankruptcy, was let off yesterday with a suspended sentence in General Sessions.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Soviet troops, opening a midwinter offensive on Rybachi Peninsula, 250 miles north of the Arctic Circle, have won control of the Mousta mountain range, commanding the entrance to Finland's ice-free port of Petsamo, military dispatches said today.

The retailers of the United States "are ready to make any sacrifice necessary to win this war," Frank M. Mayfield, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared last night at its thirty-first annual convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies communique said today:

Having experimented with one-set operas last season, the National Orchestral Association ventured into the field of works with several sets at Carnegie Hall last night. Leon Barzin, musical director of the association, chose Mozart's "Abduction From the Seraglio" this time for his young players and singers.
LONDON, Jan. 12 (Reuter) -- There are 18,000 military prisoners and civilian internees in Japanese hands in the Hong Kong area, according to an unofficial message received from Japan today.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Japanese bombers were decisively beaten today in their first major daylight raid on Singapore, and officials predicted that the United Nations would have air superiority in Malaya within three days, but they said that Kuala Lumpur, capital of the Federated Malay States, had fallen to the invaders.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A revised four-point program, which does not require curtailment of Spring sports and may result in adoption of schedules, was announced today by Athletic Director William McCarter of Dartmouth.

SOMEWHERE IN JAVA, Jan. 11 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Admiral Thomas C. Hart, Commander of the United States Asiatic Fleet and Supreme Naval Commander for the United Nations in the Southwest Pacific, authorized The United Press today to reveal that he had arrived in the Netherlands Indies by submarine.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The United States had the largest supply of foodstuffs on record Jan. 1, but wholesale prices were averaging better than 25 per cent higher than a year ago, government statisticians revealed today.
A score of canvases and panels by Ralph Blakelock may be seen at the Babcock, 38 East Fifty-seventh Street. This exhibition, which opened on Saturday, will remain current until the end of the month.

When a young American leaves a factory, a farm or an office to enter one of his country's armed services he takes his civilian tastes along with him. If one of those tastes is for good reading he will be a better soldier or sailor if he can indulge it during his off hours.

Two "fatal weaknesses" are inherent in the selective price control bill on which Congress is now acting -- the agricultural requirement of 110 to 120 per cent of parity and the omission of control over wages and salaries, Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, said yesterday at the annual luncheon meeting of the Association of Buying Offices, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

New Victory Courses in vegetable gardening, one of which will be held in cooperation with THE NEW YORK TIMES, were announced yesterday by Dr. William J. Robbins, director of the New York Botanical Garden, in a report of the garden's achievements since he became director in 1937.

Wendell L. Willkie declared last night that the United States would have to win the war "the hard way" and called on the American people to "lead Spartan lives" in order that the nation's war program laid down by President Roosevelt might be achieved.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 -- Fired with "on to Tokyo" enthusiasm, spokesmen for Filipino groups along the Pacific Coast laid preliminary plans here today for the formation of an expeditionary force to fight "anywhere" against Axis armies, provided the War Department gives its sanction.

The American Society of Magazine Cartoonists, 128 East Sixty-third Street, has formed a committee on war cartoons in an effort to aid in defense activities. The members of the committee will seek to direct the society's collective talents into channels in which they will prove moat useful.

Expansion of the activities of the Save the Children Federation to include aid to needy children in Great Britain was described yesterday by the organization's president and general director, John R. Voris.

Before very long "we shall have a control similar to the War Board set-up during World War I, under a chairman whose ability to organize rather than to specialize will be the prime factor influencing his appointment," Irving C. Fox, counsel of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, told the initial meeting yesterday of the annual convention of the National Aosciation of Retail Secretaries at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Add to the list of films opening this week "Ball of Fire," the Samuel Goldwyn comedy with Gary Cooper and Barbara Stanwyck, which will arrive at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday. Dana Andrews, Allen Jenkins, Oscar Homolka, S.Z. Sakall, Tully Marshall and Leonid Kinskey are among the featured players. . . .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- In an order issued here today the Priorities Division of the Office of Production Management has arranged to simplify considerably the procedure under which preference ratings may be extended to suppliers and sub-suppliers of the producer who received the rating.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The FBI reported today the arrest of a man with at least nine wives. Agents identified him as John William Melville, 40 year old, and said he had twenty-eight aliases, one for every arrest.

With all good intentions, the basketball rules committee has enormously complicated the task of floor and desk officials by permitting the entry of substitutes after a field goal. This point might profitably be restudied when the court legislators assemble next Spring.

The Office of Civilian Defense, Division of Physical Fitness, has requested the National Ski Association to cooperate in its program. The ski group has been asked to encourage more persons to take up skiing and to encourage a program that will make those already skiing more physically fit.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 12 -- Mrs. Frederick Winthrop Neilson entertained with a dinner tonight at La Resolona, her home in Boca Raton.

Children of a settlement house in the Bermondsey district of London gave their pennies and half-pennies the other day to help people who, they thought, needed them more than they did. The Bermondsey children know well what it is to need pennies and the things that pennies buy.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 12 -- Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles arrived here in a camouflaged clipper plane from the United States late today for the Inter-American conference opening Thursday and was received by a huge crowd at the airport.

A preview of some of the problems that will face the wage earner when he fills out his Federal income tax return some time before March 15 was held yesterday at the Hotel Bossert in Brooklyn, where 275 deputy collectors of the First District of New York were started on a six-day course of instruction on the new tax law.

St. Francis College of Brooklyn has an unbeaten basketball team. Excluding the victory over the alumni, the Terriers have taken the measure of their first seven opponents, averaging about 60 points a game. Eleven contests remain on the schedule, and Coach Joe Brennan, one of the all-time stars in the professional ranks -- he never played college ball -- was asked yesterday how many of those eleven he would settle for at the moment.

General buying, encouraged by the passage in the Senate of a price control bill favorable to agricultural products, lifted cotton futures sharply in active trading yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange the gains were 35 to 40 points, or $1.75 to $2 a bale.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Enlargement of the present New York milk marketing area to correct inequities in the problem of surplus milk was urged today by Homer S. Rolfe, secretary of the Eastern Milk Producers Association.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 12 -- There is every indication that the Germans will try to capture Malta, the British island stronghold in the Mediterranean. The recent intense air attacks on the island and the concentration of strong German air forces in Crete and Sicily point to this.

Steel operations in the United States for this week are scheduled at 97.8 per cent of ingot capacity, an increase of 1.4 points, or 1.5 per cent, compared with 96.4 per cent last week, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. A month ago the indicated rate was 97.9 per cent.

With criticism of the proposed increase in subway fares failing to develop yesterday in quarters removed from political partisanship, it appeared likely that rapid transit fares would be boosted to 10 cents for a single ride and two rides for 15 cents with the backing of real estate groups and little opposition except from Democrats in the Legislature.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- British Imperial forces inflicted some casualties on Japanese forces without loss to themselves in patrol encounters today along the northern frontier between Burma and Thailand, a joint army and Royal Air Force communique said tonight.

Stockholders of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., approved yesterday at their annual meeting in Jersey City creation of 30,208 shares of new cumulative convertible preferred stock of no par value to have a dividend rate of not more than $5.50 nor less than $5 annually.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command reported today that sharp fighting was continuing in the central sector of the Eastern Front before Moscow and in the Valdai region between the Soviet capital and Leningrad.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 12 -- Yale upset the Clarkson Tech sextet by 5 -- 3 tonight at the New Haven Arena in a rough contest. The Jock Thompson-Ben Toland combination accounted for three of the Eli markers, the latter scoring twice.

Arthur LeBlanc, French-Canadian violinist who made his New York debut in May, 1939, and has been heard here several times since, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. He was accompanied by Ernst Victor Wolff who became his partner in the two sonatas on the program, Mozart's in A major, and the one written at the age of 22 by the Belgian composer, Guillaume Lekeu.

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Exchange Telegraph, British news agency, reported in a Zurich dispatch today that it had learned "from an unquestionable source" that twenty-five generals had resigned from the German Army in connection with the dismissal of Marshal von Brauchitsch.
MOSCOW, Jan. 12 (From Russian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau said in a communique today:
Among the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday were several involving full floors in downtown office structures.

The Foster estate property on South Harrison Street, East Orange, N.J., has been purchased by a syndicate known as the Jersey Estate, Inc., of Newark, for immediate development as a defense rental housing project. The property, which was sold by Elizabeth Foster of Miami Beach, Fla., is 300 by 118 feet in dimensions.

ABOARD S.S. URUGUAY (en route to Rio de Janeiro), Jan. 12 (AP) -- "What will Argentina do?" was the one question tonight aboard this vessel bearing the Chilean and Uruguayan delegates to the Pan-American conference at Rio de Janeiro.
Before presenting himself at Camp Upton, L.I., tomorrow for induction into the Army, Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, will wind up his business with the United States Navy today.

Loomis J. Grossman, operator, purchased the two-story taxpayer at 500-06 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, and the two three-story store and apartment buildings at 1894-96 Bathgate Avenue comprising altogether a plot 85 by 113 feet; and the two-story garage building abutting on Third Avenue on a plot 51 by 97.8 feet.

Reflecting to a considerable extent increased purchasing of such wool items as men's, women's and children's apparel, and also of products in which rubber is a constituent item, such as corsets, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase last week of 26 per cent over the corresponding week last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Baltimore's three daily newspapers -- The Sun, The Evening Sun and The News-Post -- appeared with fewer pages and fewer editions today as the result of a walkout by a faction within the Baltimore Typographical Union following a deadlock in negotiations on a proposed change in the wage scale.

The abandonment of exclusive franchises in the men's wear field to permit broader advertising and sale of products was urged yesterday by Morton Freund, head of the advertising agency of that name, in an address before the Men's Apparel Club of New York State at Syracuse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Declaring that "the national interest demands that there shall be no interruption of any work which contributes to the effective prosecution of the war," President Roosevelt created by executive order today a twelve-member National War Labor Board and appointed as chairman William H. Davis, a New York patent lawyer and head of the National Defense Mediation Board, which was abolished at the same time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The annual meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors began at the Mayflower Hotel this afternoon with Mayors from 250 of the country's largest cities attending and fifteen Canadian and three Mexican Mayors present as guests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Commercial banks subscribed 40 per cent of the $3,800,000,000 raised by the Treasury in the last half of 1941 by the sale of marketable public issues, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
HOME, Jan. 12 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique today:

Speculation on the influence on transportation of the recent tire rationing order has brought the bicycle industry into the forefront of discussion, especially among housewives in suburban areas, many of whom took up cycling some time ago.

Word that the broadcasting license of Cecil Brown, Columbia Broadcasting System reporter in Singapore, has been revoked has reached the CBS office here. Company officials said yesterday that the correspondent's status remained uncertain.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $50,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Arrangements assuring whole-hearted cooperation between the United States and Mexico for wartime defense of North America were completed-except for technical details -- today when it was announced at the White House that a joint Mexican-United States Defense Commission had been formed and would meet soon in Washington.

Henry W. Ryan will be elected to a second term as president of the New York Athletic Club at the seventy-third annual meeting of the Winged Foot organization tonight. The entire 1941 slate of officers will be held over for another year. The others are Fred W. Piderit, vice president; Thomas Morrison, secretary; Lee S. Buckingham, treasurer, and Theodore J. Van Twisk, captain.

Carrying the books themselves, sending their chauffeurs with volumes stacked high on back seats, or calling up voluntary and library services to help move the larger contributions, New Yorkers began yesterday to fill the sorting tables of the Victory Book Campaign.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 12 -- Yale athletic officials and the Corporation, or trustees of the university, have failed to come to a definite decision on athletic policy after a long conference. It was stated tonight that no announcement could be made at the present time for reorganization of sports to meet war conditions.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Statistics show that injuries to United States parachute troops are comparatively few and that that branch of the service is just about as safe as any.

Arrangements have now been completed for the transfer of the Securities and Exchange Commission from Washington to Philadelphia and it is expected that before long the commission will be housed in its new home, the Penn-Athletic Club, facing Rittenhouse Square.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The offensives of China's farspread armies have scored new successes on four widely scattered fronts against a Japanese foe who is preoccupied with other wars in the Philippines, Malaya and the Netherlands Indies, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Mrs. Roosevelt believes that the Office of Civilian Defense should remain under civilian direction because its function is "one that cannot be fulfilled by the Army."

Ranch mink sold at prices unchanged from December to 12 per cent lower yesterday at the sale conducted by Lampson, Fraser Huth. The collection was good and a large percentage of the total was sold. Highest price was $20.50. Prices were unchanged for better sizes and colors in good quality.

Net operating earnings of the Brooklyn Trust Company for 1941, exclusive of profits on the sale of securities and recoveries on charged-off loans, amounted to $681,130, after all expenses and taxes, George V. McLaughlin, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Fire today destroyed the Clevedon, a 7,314-ton Army transport, in Alaskan waters, the War Department announced tonight.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 12 -- Former Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies characterized as "nonsense" today a report by Arthur Krock in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday that Mr. Menzies apparently was partly to blame for Singapore's present peril because he had preferred the investing of Greece to the buttressing of Malaya, after Australian acceptance of assurances from Air Chief Marshal Sir Robert Brooke-Popham that all was well at Singapore.

It is not alone in Russia and in Libya that Hitler is conducting a "strategic retreat." Retirement to "Winter quarters" is also under way in Serbia. The Autumn campaign to suppress the rebellion of the Serbian Chetniks, though carried out with unparalleled barbarity, apparently has failed.

Deliveries of copper to domestic consumers last year reached an all-time high of 1,513,292 tons, compared with 1,001,886 in 1940, according to the Copper Institute. Production of refined copper from domestic ores amounted to 1,065,667 tons, against 1,033,710.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- Warner Brothers announced today that Hal B. Wallis, head of production at the studio, has been signed to a new term contract under which he will relinquish his present duties to produce personally four to six pictures a year for the company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The grain markets were on the upgrade from the opening today on broad buying based on reports that every effort would be made to speed passage of the price-control bill which would give agricultural products even more favorable treatment than had been anticipated by the grain trade and farmers.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 12 -- Flying Netherlanders and their allies -- American and Australian pilots -- were declared officially tonight to have bombed two Japanese cruisers and two more transports and shot down four enemy planes in trying to smash Japanese footholds on Borneo and Celebes, south of the Philippines.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- King Gustaf told the opening session of Parliament today it was his firm resolve to pursue a foreign policy aimed at "preserving the peace and freedom of our country uninfringed."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, whose off-stage role in the play, "In Time to Come," drew a great deal of attention on Jan. 6 when she balked at passing through a picket line, has decided to cast herself in another bit part, that of peacemaker.
The President's budget message calls for 59 billion dollars for the next fiscal year, indicating a deficit for that year of 35 billions, and a national debt of 110 billion dollars.

Blame is being tossed back and forth in the quarrel about last year's automobiles. If the industry in 1941 produced five million cars when, as alleged, it should have been producing tanks and planes the fault was with the automobile manufacturers greedy for profits.

A $750,000 mortgage loan on the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues and Sixth and Seventh Streets, Brooklyn, owned by the Methodist Episcopal Hospital of Brooklyn, has been arranged with the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn. George C. Ponter Co. were the brokers. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
