WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- New York City, according to an announcement today by officials of the United States Housing Authority, has made an arrangement whereby much interest money will be saved in connection with financing construction of the $3,200,000 of housing projects now being erected there.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Governor Lehman, members of the Legislature and other State officials viewed tonight from the top of the thirty-one-story State Office Building which dominates the entire State Capitol area, the first practice blackout of the Capitol city and the surrounding industrial and port territory.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (U.P.) -- Important United States-Netherland conversations were reported impending today to establish closest harmony between American and Netherlands Indies naval, air and land forces in the Pacific and to arrange the appointment of a high-ranking Netherlands Indies officer to the unified Pacific command under General Sir Archibald P. Wavell.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- All classes of livestock were unloaded in unusually heavy numbers in the local market today and prices of hogs, cattle and sheep were under steady pressure. Hogs confined losses to within 10 cents a hundred pounds, but cattle were down as much as 50 cents and sheep lost about 25 cents.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. will give to Westchester County thirty-eight acres as right of way for a parkway spur if the county will give three acres to him so that he can donate them to the Philipse Castle restoration project in North Tarrytown, the County Park Commission informed the board of supervisors today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The American public, which has long been used to a press with freedom that Congress may not "abridge" (the word of the Bill of Rights), seems to be taking deep interest in the restrictions of information that the real perils of war have imposed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Here is the text of President Roosevelt's executive order establishing the National War Labor Board:

Spencer C. Young, a Queens Democrat who has served as chief of the Bureau of Municipal Investigation and Statistics in the Finance Department, accused Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick yesterday of political reprisals in cutting his salary from $7,500 to $6,500 and reducing him to the rank of senior bookkeeper.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Scorched earth and death await the Japanese invaders of the Netherlands Indies, Dr. H.J. van Mook, Lieutenant Governor of that Far Eastern outpost, said grimly as he arrived today from the Orient to visit Washington.

An inflationary movement tinged the stock market yesterday as prices developed the first recovery in a week, while commodities pushed forward to the highest levles in several years as traders watched price control legislation taking shape in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Jan. 7 aggregated $10,329,000,000.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Jan. 6 a London correspondent states that on Jan. 5 "for the first time a foreign court of law functioned on English soil." This is not exact.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The following communique, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., was issued by the War Department today:

Mrs. Elizabeth Pilsworth, widow of Thomas E. Pilsworth, Brooklyn lawyer and bank executive who died in 1936, was found dead yesterday in her eighteen-room brownstone home at 25 Polhemus Place in the Park Slope area of Brooklyn, where she lived alone.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- General Draja Mikhailovitch, known here as the "Yugoslav Robin Hood," was appointed Minister of War today by the Yugoslav Government in London in recognition of his successful effort to keep up resistance within his country.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- Drama and heartbreaks were written into the finish of the seventeenth annual $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament today as Ben Hogan and Jimmy Thomson wound up in a deadlock for the rich prize and history repeated itself with a slap in the face for Sam Snead.

The 1942 campaign for funds to fight infantile paralysis was opened yesterday by the Committee for the Celebration of the President's Birthday for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The national chairman, Keith Morgan, has his offices at 50 East Forty-second Street.

A streamlined program has been arranged for the annual national A.A.U. indoor track and field championships, which will be held at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 28. Entry blanks were mailed yesterday to the forty-one member associations and the 1941 champions.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 12 -- After five straight favorites had missed fire, De Kalb, claimed out of a recent winning race for $4,500 by William Hirschensohn, broke the spell with a four-length victory in the Indian Creek Purse at Tropical Park today.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Democratic leadership in the Legislature moved tonight to forestall the increase in the New York City subway fare proposed yesterday by the Committee of Fifteen, headed by Paul Windels, former corporation counsel in the La Guardia administration.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Jan. 9 (Delayed) -- Many Japanese tanks are being put out of action by British anti-tank guns and artillery as well as by less orthodox weapons, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Schedules of new and increased excise levies designed to raise an estimated $1,400,000,000 of the additional $9,000,000,000 war-tax load have been put at the disposal of the Congressional revenue-seeking committees by the Treasury Department.

Its bakers call the newcomer "the bread for beauty." It's not whole wheat nor is it enriched bread, but a kind that is said to boast the virtues of both without being one or the other. A special unbleached flour, off-white in color, forms the basis of the loaves and gives them their character.

The five-cent fare on New York City's rapid transit system exists only for out-of-towners. New Yorkers pay seven cents -- a nickle in the turnstile and two cents to the tax collector, or his deputy, the rent collector. In recent years the city's subsidy to maintain the fiction of a five-cent fare has come to $30,000,000 annually.

MORE Alec Hudson submarine lore in "Rendezvous,"* published this morning. This consists of three short stories from magazines, none of them quite as choice as some of the others he has done, but all of them fast, fine reading and now, of course, twice as appropriate as such stories were before the war.

Boxing gloves and skipping ropes, rather than "smokes for the Yanks," and vigorous athletic activities "rather than the gentle ministrations of hostesses," were advocated yesterday by Lieut. Comdr. J.J. "Gene" Tunney, former heavyweight boxing champion and now director of athletics for the Navy.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 12 -- The British have abandoned Kuala Lumpur, bitterly contested rubber center and capital of the Federated Malay States, and established a new line below the city some 150 miles north of Singapore, it was revealed here today.
Five WPA workers, accustomed to the colorless tasks of shoring up manholes in the city's sewer system, found themselves yesterday literally thrown into one of the roles of Jean Valjean.

The Red Cross War Fund Drive has swung into its second week with Fifth Avenue dedicated as the "Street of Mercy." This kind of mercy does not come from sentimental wishing. The American Red Cross has a nursing reserve of 24,000 and needs 50,000 more for the duration.

One answer to the question of what the American Navy is doing in this war was given yesterday by Secretary Knox in a speech prepared for delivery at the annual Conference of Mayors in Washington. The Navy is achieving notable success in keeping open the most important highway in the world -- the sea-lanes between the United States and the British Islands.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 12 -- The 66-year-old Lady Bountiful who once picked up a cripple on the street and paid for his treatment in Philadelphia and whose charity in general seemed as spontaneous as it was widespread, remained in Essex County Jail today while the police of half a dozen States studied her record as a swindler.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The small business section in the anti-trust division of the United States Department of Justice is one agency in the Federal Government whose energies are devoted entirely to seeing that rights of "the little fellow" are protected in the war effort, Attorney General Francis Biddle said today.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, former president of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has presented to that institution a heroic figure of Christ, nearly 8 feet high, sculptured in jacaranda wood by the Brazilian artist Maria. Although the museum made no announcement on the subject, it was learned that Maria is the professional name of the wife of the Brazilian Ambassador at Washington, Carlos Martins.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 12 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today:

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- New York State, which started its defense program more than a year and a half ago, was able to act "swiftly and decisively" when war was declared with the result that the industrial, labor and agricultural resources of New York are now operating on a full wartime basis, Governor Lehman declared tonight.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Germans announced today that all former active officers of the Norwegian Air Force and Navy had been ordered arrested because some 100 of their number had escaped to Britain to resume their fight against Germany.

The toughest fighter in the world became a soldier of the United States Army here yesterday as Joe Louis, the Negro boy whose battling fists have brought him $2,263,784 and the world's heavyweight championship, enlisted to fight for his country at $21 a month.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 12 -- Axis warplanes may be expected to bomb American cities "in the not-distant future," two high defense officials told the Southern Governors Conference today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Army revealed today that it has re-established within the Intelligence Corps a "Counter Intelligence Corps" to "function as special agents in the detection and investigation of espionage, sabotage, disloyalty and general subversive activity wherever found in the Army."

Oscar Serlin, who already controls a five-foot shelf of books, the dramatizations of which he intends to produce, has added one more to his collection. The latest, a short novel soon to be published by Viking Press, is the work of John Steinbeck called "The Moon Is Down."

On the vast checkerboard of the Western Pacific, dotted with innumerable islands, there is now in progress a desperate effort of the Japanese to seize as many strategic points as possible before Britain and America have time to make an effective counterstroke.

Robert K. Christenberry, vice president and general manager of the Hotel Astor, was re-elected president of the Broadway Association, Inc., at the annual meeting of the association yesterday in the Hotel Astor. Mr. Christenberry is the seventh to have served as president in the thirty-one years since a small group of civic-minded merchants and others banded together in 1911 to work for the improvement of the thoroughfare following the opening of the first Broadway subway.

Mrs. Roland L. Redmond is opening her residence at 760 Park Avenue this afternoon for a tea and package party to aid the Bargain Box, a thrift shop at Third Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street. Guests have been asked to bring with them a bundle of rummage suitable for resale at the Bargain Box, which operates to aid seven philanthropic agencies.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 12 -- Mexico pushed her sombrero a little farther into the ring of continental defense tonight as she officially announced that a United States-Mexican joint military commission had been formed to protect their coasts and to coordinate army operations, chiefly along the west coast of this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Roosevelt again stepped into the price-control controversy today as differences between Claude R. Wickard, Secretary of Agriculture, and Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, over who should set the price ceilings on farm products broke into the open.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A Chinese Army communique said today:

The textile industry is one of the few which can supply military and lease-lend requirements and yet meet civilian needs with some degree of satisfaction, but this cannot be done unless a coordinated "master plan" is worked out, according to Sidney Scheuer, head of Scheuer Co., textile brokers.

At the opening session of the national council meeting of the National Maritime Union, held yesterday at its headquarters, 346 West Seventeenth Street, Joseph Curran, the president, said that everything must be subordinated to one great task -- that of defeating Hitler and the fascist aggressors.

HAVANA, Jan. 12 -- The possibility of cooperation between Cuba and the United States in pilot and mechanic training and in building up this island's military forces for continental defense was voiced by United States Representative Andrew J. May, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, here today.

The Alliance Book Corporation announced yesterday that books of The Philosophical Library would henceforth be published under a joint imprint. The first publication list under this arrangement includes these titles: "The Conquest of Bacteria," by F. Sherwood Taylor; "The Dictionary of Philosophy," by Dagobert D. Runes, and "From Copernicus to Einstein," by Hans Reichenbach.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Baltimore Ohio Railroad said today that "new high records in operating efficiency" had been made on the B. O. in 1941.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Senate Labor and Industry Committee, headed by Senator William F. Condon, Westchester Republican, reported out today and moved to order of final passage the Condon bill, which changes the time employers have to file their unemployment insurance returns from Jan. 15 to Jan. 30 and change the start of the "benefit year" for unemployment insurance from April 1 to June 1.

By the beginning of April, mechanical refrigerators will meet the fate of the passenger car industry and production for all but military, defense housing and possibly lease-lend requirements will be halted entirely, it was reported yesterday by executives in the industry here.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The stock markets today developed a dull tone in most sections as buyers held off pending further developments in the Far East.

The annual report of the Missing Persons Bureau, issued yesterday at police headquarters, took note of "the attack on Pearl Harbor" in listing its reasons why the number of missing persons under 21 years of age increased last year.

Four thousand women began yesterday a city-wide canvass of railway stations, banks, restaurants, theatres and other busy public centers as representatives of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, which undertook last week the task of raising a $7,330,000 quota in the five boroughs.
Short-term borrowing featured sales and prospective offerings announced yesterday in the field of State and municipal financing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 7: Increases of $74,000,000 in holdings of United States Treasury bills, $228,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $234,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Office of Price Administration is giving close study to the question of granting special tire and car-purchasing privileges to ministers of the gospel, particularly in rural districts where public transportation facilities are limited, it was disclosed here today.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 -- Anticipating a lowering of the octane number of gasoline available for America's commercial trucks and buses as the military machine takes more and more high-test fuel, 400 members of the Society of Automotive Engineers opened their annual meeting today with discussion aimed at meeting the problem.
The M.A. Hanna Company of Cleveland announced yesterday that it is developing a large manganese deposit fifteen miles southeast of Las Vegas, Nev.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The American Federation of Labor executive council formally declared today its readiness to carry out "every requirement of President Roosevelt's $56,000,000,000 victory production program" and asked that representation be accorded to labor in all government policy-making decisions affecting the interests of workers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The athletic programs of American colleges, together with every other national institution, will meet their supreme challenge during 1942 on the basis of their potential contributions to the common welfare.

Charley (Lulu) Costantino, East Side featherweight, kept his string of ring victories intact last night when he handily outboxed Bill Speary of Nanticoke, Pa., in the main bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace. It was his fiftieth successive triumph.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The American Federation of Labor executive council formally declared today its readiness to carry out "every requirement of President Roosevelt's $56,000,000,000 victory production program" and asked that representation be accorded to labor in all government policy-making decisions affecting the interests of workers.

Charley (Lulu) Costantino, East Side featherweight, kept his string of ring victories intact last night when he handily outboxed Bill Speary of Nanticoke, Pa., in the main bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Palace. It was his fiftieth successive triumph.

Irma Rothstein, whose one-man show opened this week in the fifth-floor gallery of the School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, is a former Viennese sculptor but is now living in this country. She was born in Rostov, Russia, and her studies were pursued in Russia as well as, later on, in Vienna.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Mexico's Foreign Minister, Ezequiel Padilla, disclosed today that his nation, Colombia and Venezuela had formed a bloc that would seek a united Pan-American severance of relations with "the nations at war with the United States" at the Inter-American Conference opening Thursday.

Schoolboy track and field athletes slated to graduate late this month will be eligible to compete in the annual city P.S.A.L. senior high and vocational nigh championships to be held at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 7, it was announced yesterday at the monthly meeting of the High School Games Committee at the Hotel Astor.

New York City's tire rationers announced yesterday a plan to prevent "chiselers" from using one worn-out tire over and over again to obtain permits to buy new tires. The plan is aimed at such cases as the following hypothetical one:

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 13 -- The Broadway Bank and Trust Company today re-elected its board of directors and principal officers and made three changes in its staff. John Kuyper, who was secretary and trust officer, was re-elected secretary, and Raymond J. Cadmus was named trust officer. Miss Regina Moltane was named assistant trust officer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The House passed by voice vote today a bill which would permit the revocation of naturalization papers and thus remove the protection which citizenship might give to persons engaged in subversive activities, particularly in time of war.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 13 -- Mexico's role in controlling Axis activities in Latin America of the kind described earlier in these dispatches depends to a great extent upon the United States, whence arms long have been and still are being smuggled into Mexico by Nazi agents, according to an authorized source here who is fully conversant with the subversive plans of the Axis.

TOKYO, Jan. 13 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- By order of the Minister of Finance, Japanese firms have been appointed to administer the business of United States concerns that have branch offices in Japan.

Fearful that their record of seventy-seven consecutive games in which they scored at least one goal would be broken, the New York Rangers tried their hardest against the Brooklyn Americans at Madison Square Garden last night, and in less than two minutes attained their objective, a new National Hockey League mark of seventy-eight "blankless" contests in a row.

Two old basketball rivalries that have been in existence on and off for more than thirty years apiece will be renewed in Madison Square Garden tonight when St. John's faces Fordham in an intracity battle, while N.Y.U. meets Colgate in what can be termed, for want of a better name, an intrastate affair.

The Southern Phosphates Corporation, Winchester Fulton, president, has leased large space in the Canadian Pacific Building, 342 Madison Avenue, through the Herbert McLean Purdy Management Corporation.

The twelfth four-day course for flower show exhibitors and judges, sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, opened yesterday morning in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria with the registration of 200 women from sixteen States and the District of Columbia.

The American soldier's ration is superior in nutrition to that of any other fighting men in the world today, Dr. James A. Tobey, a lieutenant colonel in the sanitary corps reserve of the Army Medical Corps and nutrition director of the American Institute of Baking, told 500 medical reserve officers last night at an annual medico-military symposium in the Federal Building, 90 Church Street.

A fashion show featuring Spring dresses, coats and suits, sportswear and accessories in the "best selling price lines" was held yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers. The showing, which included about eighty ensembles, was attended by 200 store representatives, buyers and merchandisers.

CHANGSHA, China, Jan. 11 (Delayed) -- General Hsueh Yuen's third victory over the Japanese at Changsha clearly proved that, when he can meet the Japanese soldier on anything like equal terms, the Chinese soldier can whip him easily.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Governmental concern over metal supplies was evident today in the more than a half-dozen orders and announcements dealing with primary and scrap metals. Statements affecting metals came from the Office of Price Administration as well as from the Office of Production Management.
A thousand young men in groups of 250 filled Army offices at 641 Washington Street yesterday to take intelligence tests for entry into the Army's pilot-training classes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -Secretary Knox designated today Mrs. William F. Corry, wife of the Mayor of Montpelier, Vt., as sponsor of the cruiser Montpelier when that 10,000-ton warship is launched Feb. 15 at the New York Shipbuilding Yard at Camden, N.J.
Members of the National Security Women's Corps proved last night at the shooting range of the Manhattan School of Firearms, 24 Murray Street, that they could handle lipsticks and rifles equally well.

The advertising profession was urged to adopt a program designed to educate people to make scarce goods last longer and designed also to make this procedure fashionable by Elton G. Borton, chairman of the board of the Advertising Federation of America, in an address yesterday before the Boston Advertising Club.

A start toward eliminating confusion in the cotton goods market resulting from uncertainty over government requirements for this year was made yesterday, when the military procurement divisions began to issue lists as to their needs on duck.

Five of the principal operating executives of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, third largest manufacturer of dyestuffs in this country, were suspended yesterday by the United States Treasury, which jointly with the Department of Justice has been trying for several months to establish that the company actually is owned by the I. G. Farbenindustrie of Germany.

The Commercial National Bank and Trust Company of New York had net earnings in 1941 of $907,357, after all expenses, taxes and other charges, Herbert P. Howell, chairman, told stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in the bank's headquarters, 46 Wall Street.

With heavy caliber ammunition scarce in many gun shops, the small-bore ranks are due for a considerable increase in numbers, for many dealers have expressed the belief that the ammunition situation is going to get worse before it gets better.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 13 -- Recent developments, including an increasingly bitter German press campaign charging Britain with agreeing to hand over the Dardanelles to Russia, have reawakened the interest of diplomatic quarters here in the possibility of a German offensive against Turkey early in the Spring.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have ambushed and annihilated possibly 7,000 Japanese reinforcements that were being rushed to aid hard-pressed survivors of the battle of Changsha, a war communique said today.

There is one thing which we might as well make up our minds we shall never manage to achieve in the way of Pan-American unity. We can never prevent its being Summer in Rio de Janeiro, Buenos Aires and Valparaiso when it is Winter in New York, Washington and San Francisco; and the other way about.

A gay exhibition entitled "The Little Shavers and Some That Are Grown Up," consisting of paintings by Elsie Shaver, opens today at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. It is announced by Bundles for Britain and is presented by Brryman Ridges for the benefit of the Bombed Children's Hospitals in Britain.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 13 -- A father and three of his children were burned, one of the children fatally and the other two critically, in a fire today that started from an overturned oil stove and swept through a three-room flat on the first floor of 358 Henderson Street here.

A Good Neighbor short-wave broadcast to South America over Station WRUL will mark the opening of an exhibition and sale of Ancient Arts and Crafts of South America at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow on the fifth floor of Gimbel Brothers, Sixth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, in conjunction with the Gimbel centennial celebration.

Leslie Frick, New York mezzo-soprano, who made her first appearance here in Chickering Hall fifteen years ago at a joint recital with Dwight Fiske, who was then a serious young pianist, last night gave her first solo recital at Town Hall.

TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- The 166th session of the New Jersey Legislature convened shortly before 1 P.M. today, and heard Governor Charles Edison call for united action so the State might play its full part in the war.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Champion Willie Hoppe closed with a rush tonight to defeat the veteran Art Thurnblad, 50 to 36, for his second victory in the world three-cushion billiards tournament.

Seeking to check any increase in parking charges as a result of the police drive against street parking, Councilman Louis Cohen, Bronx Democrat, introduced a bill in the City Council yesterday requiring that all parking spaces and garages in the city be licensed by the Department of Licenses.

IT'S on account of the war. The baseball club owner and his third baseman were having a few words about a contract for the coming season. An opening skirmish, as it were. Call the club owner C.O. and the third baseman T.B. for the fun of it.

Leon Fraser, president of the First National Bank of New York, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that the bank's net income in 1941 was $10,057,764, or $100.58 a share, compared with $10,240,647, or $102.40 a share in the previous year.

Air raid warnings have been followed by an increase in the rental of safety-deposit boxes. Dunham B. Sherer, chairman of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Spokesmen for three utility groups voiced opposition today to a proposed cooperative rural electric system for Allegany County farmers on the ground it represented "unfair competition."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The government ban on the sale of new automobiles was extended until Feb. 2, in an order issued tonight by the Office of Production Management.

Adopting a "Book Production War Economy Agreement," British publishers, already sharply curtailed by paper rationing and restrictions on other bookmaking materials, are now making even further adjustments to the shortages, according to the British Press Service in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A victory for General Douglas MacArthur's force in Bataan after a twentyfour-hour artillery battle, in which Japanese batteries were silenced or forced back and armored columns shattered or dispersed, was reported today by the War Department.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel I. Rosenman approved yesterday a $200,000 settlement offer made by a group of defendants in an accounting suit brought by Burco, Inc., an investment trust, for recovery of assets looted after a sale of control of the company in 1938.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Following is the text of the address of Wendell Willkie at the annual dinner of the United States Conference of Mayors:

The three-story bank building formerly occupied by the Lincoln Trust Company at 70-72 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by Joseph F. Kearney to the Unisol Manufacturing Company. The parcel is assessed for $130,000.

Twice wounded seriously in the last three years and decorated five times, Jack Hasey, a lieutenant in the Free French forces and the only American to wear General Charles de Gaulle's Order of the Liberation, arrived at La Guardia Field early yesterday morning aboard an Eastern Air Line plane from Miami.

Fifty-eight ambulances operated by organizations devoted to the care of animals will roam New York City in the event of air raids, it was announced yesterday at the annual meeting of the Humane Society, 313 East Fifty-eighth Street.

Gordon S. Rentschler, chairman of the National City Bank of New York, told 125 stockholders at its 130th annual meeting yesterday, that a preliminary analysis of assets and liabilities in the Far East indicated that the losses to be sustained by the institution as a result of the war with Japan would not be large.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 13 -- The number of Yugoslav combatants killed in battle plus noncombatants including women and children massacred or purposely allowed to die from starvation or exposure, from the beginning of hostilities to the present time, was today stated by Yugoslavs circles in the Middle East to be at least 1,000,000.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 13 -- With the conference of the American Foreign Ministers two days off, press editorials here today were confined mostly to comment on the reception accorded yesterday to Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles on his arrival. It was a reception, said the Correio da Manha that came spontaneously from the peace-loving people of Brazil for the representative of a sister nation similarly imbued.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 13 -- Stroking away with deadly coolness and accuracy, wee Ben Hogan chopped down Jimmy Thomson, the sturdy redwood of California, today and captured the play-off for top prize in the $10,000 Los Angeles open golf championship in a struggle that was not decided until the last hole.

Harold W. McGraw, Federal Tire-Rationing Administrator for New York and vice president of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, was re-elected yesterday as president of the West Side Association of Commerce.

Service with the country's armed forces probably will be accepted by Columbia College as credit toward its Bachelor of Arts degree, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes told 1,200 students and faculty members yesterday at the second wartime convocation of the college in the McMillin Academic Theatre.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 13 -- Paced by Dick Murphy, who scored 13 of his 15 points in the second half, Manhattan College's basketball team registered its sixth victory tonight by vanquishing St. Peter's College, 54 to 45.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- Alvan Macauley, chairman of the Automotive Council for War Production, announced today a three-part program designed to expedite and coordinate the automobile industry's expanded war work.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- The attendance at the twenty-one-day Tropical Park meeting that ended today totaled 146,477, a daily average of 6,975. For the corresponding session of sixteen days last Winter the average was 7,898.

TRENTON, Jan. 13 -- New Jersey's 1941 Senate and Assembly took final adjournment today after completing last-minute business. The Senate's final action was to confirm seven of the thirty-one pending nominations for State offices by Governor Edison, and the Assembly adjourned after it had cleared its calendar of several pending bills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -President Roosevelt established the War Production Board to replace SPAB and named Donald M. Nelson chairman with authority to make "final" decisions on procurement and production; in a proclamation he established maritime control areas for protection of the Panama Canal; asked Congress for several deficiency appropriations; held his press conference and conferred with the following:

As an alien (English) I would like to answer two letters appearing in your issue of Jan. 9 from other aliens -- the one complaining that delay in granting citizenship prevented him from obtaining a defense job; and the other that his alien status rendered him unfit as an air raid warden.

Offer the man in the street -even the streets of Manhattan -- a choice of something old or something new to eat, and he will invariably choose the old favorite. Apple pie, that prosaic, everyday, average-American dessert, is the most popular pie in this city, according to statistics assembled by the leading piemakers of New York.
Mr. and Mrs. R. Horace Gallatin have purchased an estate in Tuxedo Park. They will leave it at the end of May to spend the Summer at Chepstow, their place in Newport.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Members of the Legislature sought in two separate moves today to clarify their status in connection with service in the armed forces of the country.

A vast system of Pan-American broadcasting, a balanced exchange of programs in which the problems and anxieties of continents are debated with a view to the establishment of spiritual unity and complete national and continental defense, was proposed here last night at the thirtieth anniversary dinner of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

In mass production condemnations to enable the city to acquire 1,190 acres for the construction of Idlewild Airport on Jamaica Bay as quickly as possible, Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood approved yesterday awards of $309,810 for 215 parcels of land, representing most of the site.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Election of four new directors at the Fidelity Union Trust Company featured the annual stockholders' meetings held by banks here today.

The lrgest group of payers of Federal income $2.xes eon-q-qts of salaried persons and wage-earners whose income is derived from personal services, according to the Bureau of Internal Revenue, which announced yesterday that employers are required, as in previous years, to file by Feb. 15 the names of all employes to whom, if single, they paid $750 or more in 1941, as well as the names of those married workers who received $1,500 or more.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Submission of 2,073 industrial building plans in the year 1941 broke all previous records in the State Department of Labor, it was announced today. The year's total cost of buildings projected under the plans was $46,824,610, some $3,632,818 greater than the previous high record of 1927.

TOKYO, Jan. 13 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Headquarters announced today that Japanese naval units had sunk the 1,299-ton Netherland minelayer Prins van Oranje near the island of Tarakan.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 13 -- Stockholders of the Trust Company of New Jersey at their annual meeting today elected Will/am Newmann, an architect, and Arthur M. Mueller, a vice president of the bank, new directors. 'They replace Henry Sieminski, who died last June 1, and Robert J. Rendall, who resigned today because of ill health.

Paramount's "Pacific Blackout," at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. The action drama features Robert Preston, Martha O'Driscoll, Philip Merivale, Eva Gabor, J. Edward Bromberg, Mary Treen, Thurston Hall and Spencer Charters. . . .

Gloom hangs like a dank, thick fog over local yacht rendezvous, club and repair yards. There is new pessimism about pleasure boating for 1942. It was expressed at a meeting that terminated early yesterday at the Hotel Lexington when yacht builders and brokers and engine and accessory suppliers heard an OPM field service speaker, Stanley G. Oppenheim, and questioned him about various new Federal statutes and interpretations.
Semi-final brackets were filled in the New York State squash racquets championship at the Downtown Athletic Club last night, with favorites coming through, but only one of them in straight games.

Retail prices continued to advance in December, but the increase was the smallest in several months, according to the Fairchild Publications Retail Price Index, issued yesterday. As of Jan. 2 the index stood at 108.3, the highest level since 1930 and a gain of 0.7 per cent over that for Dec. 1.

The forty-year-old Georgia Contract Labor Law, which the United States Supreme Court has just held unconstitutional, is said to have been invoked only one hundred times and to have been sustained by the Georgia courts of appeal only five times. A small matter, one might say.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 13 -- A shaken, gray-haired man, known among his friends as "an honorable business man and a pillar of the church," disclosed this afternoon that he planned to have annulled his five-year marriage to Mrs. Amelia M. Carr, 66-year-old woman who was unmasked here last Saturday as an ex-convict with a record of swindles in six States.

Reacting to reports from Washington that President Roosevelt opposed the price control bill passed by the Senate, prices of cotton lost ground yesterday in moderately active trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final prices of active futures showed net losses of 10 to 13 points.

The letter signed "Physician" in your issue of Jan. 10, regarding danger from dogs during air raids, is an evidence of the hysteria that presented itself in England during the early days of the war. We are grateful that common sense prevailed there. Recent reports from London state that there are now nearly 3,000,000 dogs in England -- as many as before the war.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The text of a communique issued today by the Netherlands Indies fighting forces said:

Grass-roots planning for Victory Day should be started immediately in individual industries and localities to combat the expectation of a post-war business slump, Malcolm P. McNair, Professor of Marketing at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, told the annual convention yesterday of the National Association of Retail Secretaries at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

"Mrs. Typical Customer" for 1942, personified by Mrs. Clarence C. Cox of Greenville, S.C., arrived in the city yesterday and urged consumers of the nation to cooperate with merchants in the national emergency by withholding the instinct to hoard and by showing a willingness to accept commodity substitutes.
Bobby Ruffin, Astoria lightweight, won a decision over Chalky Wright, world featherweight champion, last night in a ten-round bout at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx.

Closer relations with Latin America increased the foreign business of the Grace National Bank in 1941, Chester R. Dewey, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday. He added that transactions with Latin America enlarged in the latter months of the year, reaching their peak in December, and that there was reason to feel that the trend would be carried through 1942.

Two more contingents of young South American aviation students, who will be trained at air fields of the United States under a Civil Aeronautics Administration program, arrived yesterday on two American flag vessels.

Four West Side youngsters took part yesterday in the opening of the first of a network of defense bond and stamp booths to be installed in railroad stations from coast to coast. The booth, sponsored by the Hearn's Volunteer National Defense Corps in cooperation with the New York Defense Savings Committee, is on the street level at Grand Central Terminal.

Jimmy Hatcher, 131 3/4, Lake City, S.C., outpointed Guillermo Puentes, 134 3/4, South American lightweight, in the feature eight-round bout before 3,000 persons at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad received yesterday only one bid for $2,940,000 of ten-year equipment trust certificates, reflecting the reluctance on the part of investment firms to appraise new issues in competition in the current unsettlement and transition in the borrowing costs on this type of paper.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Demolition squads of Royal Engineers carried out broad and destructive blasting operations in the path of the Japanese invader today, effectively easing pressure on British forces continuing their withdrawal along a line 150 miles above Singapore.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Purchase of controlling interests of The Syracuse Post-Standard by Ernest L. Owen of Poughkeepsie was announced tonight by the management of the 113-year-old morning newspaper.

Plans for expanding the program of New York City's 40,000 teachers and administrators, to include longer hours and possibly Summer work, are being considered by Board of Education officials, it was learned yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13 (AP) -British headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Roosevelt said today that so many more defense workers would come to Washington in the next six months that Federal non-defense agencies would have to be moved out of the capital, even if an intensified building program were undertaken here.

The four-story garden-type apartment house known as Sanford Towers at 42-37 Union Street, Flushing, L.I., has been sold by the Prudence Realization Corporation to Sanford Towers, Inc. Sale was for cash.

Warning that the day of "business as usual" is over and that the nation will face realities which it has not known for generations, Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, told stockholders of the bank yesterday at their annual meeting that the "unity and devotion of civilians will match the strategy and heroism of the armed forces and that in this way the war will be won."

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- The Chinese press and government spokesmen chorused opposition today to any Allied strategy of "Europe first, the Pacific later," while the official Chinese Central News Agency accused Japan of atrocities against civilians in Hong Kong, where 18,000 Japanese troops were estimated to have been killed before its fall.

A drive for $200,000 to purchase medical equipment and supplies for the growing Norwegian overseas forces was announced yesterday by Mrs. J. Borden Harriman, former United States Minister to Norway and chairman of the American Friends of Norway, under whose auspices the campaign will be conducted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- An attractive little red-headed woman stepped into the masculine atmosphere of a Senate hearing today, announced that she bossed a big trucking company and that she came to plead for legislation making it easier for her to haul boats across the country for the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Further measures have been taken by the government, in cooperation with major oil companies operating in the foreign field, to maintain adequate petroleum supplies for our armed forces and those of our allies.

HAVANA, Jan. 13 -- American and British residents view with much displeasure the increase in foreigners' registration fees imposed at the beginning of the year by the Cuban overnment, and they are preparing to protest to their diplomatic representatives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Priority assistance has been given to all branches of the petroleum industry by the Office of Production Management.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- War Department communique No. 57, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 13 -- Continuation of the hearing on proposed amendments to the Federal-State milk-marketing order struck a snag here tonight, when Judge Glen J. Gifford warned Dr. Harry Young, sales manager of the New England Dairies, Inc., of Boston that any former government official was liable to a penalty if he testified within two years in any proceeding in which the government was interested.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Strong Soviet forces penetrated the German lines east of Mozhaisk Sunday, it was announced today, but, despite severe frost, the German division in the area counter-attacked and the Russians retreated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- War production is the most important problem the United States has to solve in playing its part in the effort of the democracies to smash totalitarianism, Wendell L. Willkie told the United States Conference of Mayors here tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Criticism of the official conduct of the war not only was permissible but was desirable and a necessity and must not at any time be dependent on the view of individual censors, said Major Hon. John Astor, owner of The Times, today at the meeting of the Empire Press Union.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 13 -- The Poconos of Northeastern Pennsylvania, appropriately termed "a ski playground for the masses," are enjoying their most extended period of Winter sport since the oldest native can remember.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Many banks in the Chicago area held meetings today at which directors and officers were elected, dividends voted and other business transacted.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Nine European governments in exile pledged themselves today to exact a swift post-war retribution against Germany and her satellites for their oppression of occupied countries.
Both the East and West Sides of Manhattan were well represented in the lists of apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday.

Suggested retail prices of Westinghouse household refrigerators for 1942 were issued here yesterday. In Zone 2, which covers this area, the base price is $149.95 for a seven-foot model. Three equipped seven-foot boxes are offered at $164.95, $179.95 and $204.95.

James F. McNamara, sales manager of mill products of the International Nickel Company, and Warren H. Snow, president of E.H. Rollin Sons, Inc., were elected directors of the Lukens Steel Company at the annual stockholders' meeting held yesterday at Coatesville, Pa., according to the announcement of Robert W. Wolcott, president of the company.

Gerry King's fourth birthday party, given by 6-year-old Daryl Thornton, was a party he will never forget. Just dismissed from the Hospital for Ruptured and Crippled Children where he was under treatment for infantile paralysis for two and a half years, Gerry was only interested in how much ice cream he could eat and what presents he was to receive.

Mathias F. Correa, United States Attorney, obtained convictions in 98.7 per cent of all criminal cases prosecuted during 1941, and, through the civil and criminal divisions of his office, collected for the government eight times the annual cost of conducting his office, it was disclosed yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 13 -Mr. and Mrs. LeRay Berdeau gave a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran, Mr. and Mrs. George Angue Dobyne, Mr. and Mrs. Chester Milton Williams, Mr. and Mrs. William Russell Huntley and Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Williams.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Donald M. Nelson, the nation's new war production chief, told the Mayors of 250 cities today that it would be impossible to prosecute the war successfully "and still lead normal lives at home."

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13 -President Roosevelt's implied approval of a general sales tax in his budget message has brought increased interest in sales tax proposals on Capitol Hill. Many Congressmen believe that the huge revenues necessary for war cannot be raised unless some kind of sales levy is imposed in addition to other taxes.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Allied and Japanese air forces battled today for control of the Malaya skies as Singapore fighter plane and ground defenses flung a thunderous challenge to daylight raiders and Allied bombers dumped tons of explosives on enemy bases in the north.
Five years ago the well-known British general Sir Ian Hamilton sounded at a London dinner party a prophetic note of warning:

Very soon now -- perhaps even today -- a certain Japanese living somewhere on Manhattan Island is going to receive a letter and he ought to be pretty glad to get it. It will tell him that it is all right for him to come out of his house now, after all these weeks since his countrymen perpetrated their surprise attack on Pearl Harbor.

The Administration's new set-up for the settlement of labor disputes in wartime is not reassuring. As compared with the old National Defense Mediation Board, which the new National War Labor Board supersedes, there are doubtless a few minor gains. The new board, for example, may take jurisdiction of a dispute on its own motion, without waiting until the Secretary of Labor certifies a dispute to it.
LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The text of a resolution signed today by representatives of nine occupied countries in a ceremony in St. James's Palace follows:

The stock market put it best foot forward again yesterday, and with even larger additions than were scored on Monday as inflationary tendencies continued to crop out and buying spread to the metals under the stimulation of Federal premiums.

HOUSTON, Texas, Jan. 13 -- The common capital stock of the City National Bank was increased today from $500,000 to $1,000,000, and three directors were added to the board at the annual meetings of stockholders. The new directors are J. A. Platt, a lawyer: Paul E. Benedum, an oil operator, and J. Claude Haynes, vice president and general manager of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation here.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Sears' Spring and Summer general catalogue went into the mails today, some thirty-two pages smaller than in 1941, and with prices of shoes, textiles, and a number of other consumer goods "soft" lines up rather sharply from Fall and Winter price levels.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 13 -- Soviet leaders are supremely confident regarding Turkey's integrity and Turkish determination to resist aggression from Germany, Sir Hughe M. Knatchbull-Hugessen, British Ambassador to Turkey, declared at a press conference today.
ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The State has taken steps toward using prison labor for civilian defense. It will consist of manufacturing stretchers for first aid in the institutions of the State.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- A prediction that a rationing system similar to the tire-allocation program would soon be put into effect on every replacement part needed to keep private cars and commercial vehicles on the road was made today by Herbert Hughes, engineer of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, before a forum on salvage for defense at the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 13 -- Twenty-one thoroughbreds, headed by Market Wise, the Cinderella horse, have been named for the $5,000 added Inaugural Handicap tomorrow, when the $600,000 Miami Jockey Club meeting will get under way at Hialeah Park.
The impact of war has thrown the athletic programs of Eastern colleges into confusion, but there seems certain to be more sports activity instead of less.
First Grade Detective Stephen A. Buckley, known to his colleagues as "Babe," and a terror to confidence men and pickpockets for many years, will retire on Feb. 3.
A refugee home became a War Work center yesterday when the women's division of the American Jewish Congress turned over Congress House, 50 West Sixty-eighth Street, to the city.

Bruno Walter was scheduled to conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra next week in Boston while Serge Koussevitzky, its regular leader, was conducting the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra here. But now, by two twists of fate, the German conductor will replace the Russian next week not in Boston but in New York.
All thoughts of uniformed women were banished when Saks Fifth Avenue presented its Spring style story yesterday morning.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Jan. 14 -- A vast frontal attack against the town of Mozhaisk has been under way for the last forty-eight hours, according to the Moscow military spokesman this morning. He claimed that "important gains have been registered," but full details were not given.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- An amendment to the registration statement of Schenley Distillers Corporation was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, disclosing a coupon rate of 3 1/4 per cent for the $10,000,000 10-year sinking fund debentures, and a coupon rate of 4 per cent for the $17,500,000 15-year sinking fund debentures placed in registration Dec. 30.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Exiled King Carol, who has announced he will head a Free Rumanian movement against the Axis, today related for the first time in his own words the inside story of his meeting with Reichsfuehrer Hitler before the war and events that led to his departure from Rumania in 1940 in a hail of assassins' gunfire.

In a jovial spirit of "arch irreverence," the Theatre Guild will introduce at the Shubert Theatre this evening its own conception of Richard Brinsley Sheridan's 167-year-old comedy, "The Rivals." Largely on that account the Guild is assiduously refraining from labeling the production a revival.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 -Nineteen shipyards of the Pacific Coast, with 55,000 employes, will work "round the clock" seven days a week on their contracts for the Navy, the Maritime Commission and Great Britain, as their share of America's war effort, under an agreement reached today at a conference of representatives of the Federal Government, labor and management.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Donald M. Nelson was named by the President today to head the entire armaments production program with power to make "final" decisions on procurement and production.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The stock market today showed a much stronger tone, but buyers still held off because of the Far Eastern situation. Gilt-edge issues were firmer, with the 3 1/2 per cent war loan higher at 105 1/4, and others in this section gaining 1-16 to 1/8 point.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -George Montgomery, Twentieth Century-Fox's cowboy actor, will make his third appearance as a full-fledged leading man in "Down to the Sea in Ships," the studio announced today. Until the Montgomery assignment was disclosed, Jean Gabin and Tyrone Power had been regarded as the leading contenders for the role.
TOKYO, Jan. 13 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York and San Fran-

The President's decision to create a new War Production Board, with Donald Nelson as its chairman, is a belated but nevertheless highly reassuring step toward bringing the full power of American industry into war production. There is not now and never has been any mystery about what our war production effort lacked.
BERLIN, Jan. 13 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13 -- German forces appeared today to be planning to make a stand along a line from El Agheila, on the shore of the Gulf of Sidra, south to Marade. Advanced British columns made considerable progress yesterday toward El Agheila.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The failure of the President to insist today that the House price-control bill conferees offer as firm opposition to the Bankhead as to the O'Mahoney amendment typifies his long tolerance of that divided and conflicting subordinate authority which has slowed up the war-production program from its inception.

When Wendell Willkie spoke last night in Washington of the "efficiency" of the totalitarians we may be sure that he was thinking of only one kind of efficiency -- efficiency in the art of making war. In no other art and no other science have the totalitarians shown themselves to be even halfway competent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The transfer of Downing Street to Washington during two of the most critical weeks of the war is an event of immense implications, for the present and the future. In addition to Lord Beaverbrook, Mr. Churchill brought with him a great number of the more important people one usually finds in government offices in London.

A business man who set out to be a professor, Donald M. Nelson went to Washington in 1939 as chairman of a special committee of the Business Advisory Council of the Department of Commerce, and in two years became perhaps the most powerful man in the defense program, as executive director of the Supply, Priorities and Allocations Board and director of priorities of the Office of Production Management.

Increases in the birth rate, general death rate and puerperal mortality, as well as in the incidence of measles, whooping cough, tuberculosis and pneumonia marked the vital statistics for New York City for last week, the first full week of the new year, as reported by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

Charges that existing radio networks would be wrecked by enforcement of recent Federal Communications Commission regulations were assailed yesterday by representatives of the Commission and the Mutual Broadcasting System at a hearing before a Federal Statutory Court consisting of Judges Learned Hand, John Bright and Henry W. Goddard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The White House disclosed today that a panel of umpires, which might be headed by retired Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes, would probably be selected to aid the new War Labor Board in settling difficult labor disputes.

BOSTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The accurate sharpshooting of Defenseman Flash Hollett accounted for the Boston Bruins' two goals tonight when they reached the halfway mark of their National Hockey League season with a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings before 12,100 fans at the Boston Garden.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 13 -- Tarakan, off Northeastern Borneo, has fallen to a Japanese assault of overwhelming power, but the one prize for which the invader has paid so heavily in ships and planes and men -- the island's oil -is still many a month out of his grasp, it was announced tonight.

HONOLULU, Jan. 12 -- Inmates of Oahu Prison, the Hawaiian territorial penitentiary, have taken over the chore of supplying fire wood for the infantry regiments that formerly made up the Hawaiian National Guard and for Bellows Field, the United States Army airdrome, Warden C.T. Stevenson said today.

Herman Taylor, Philadelphia promoter, brought suit in Supreme Court yesterday for an injunction to prevent the holding of the welterweight bout between Fritzie Zivic and Ray Robinson at the Garden Friday night. Justice Louis A. Valente reserved decision after hearing argument and promised that a decision would be handed down today.

OTTAWA, Jan. 13 -- The sinking of an Allied vessel by an enemy submarine, 160 miles off the Nova Scotian coast, was reported today. This war action was the closest to the American East Coast so far committed by the enemy.

Lack of the necessary report cards yesterday delayed until late this week the sale of motor vehicle use tax stamps at postoffices here, while Internal Revenue Bureau districts had neither cards nor stamps for the automobile and pleasure boat use tax effective Feb. 1.

When Italy entered the war and France surrendered, Great Britain's chances of holding Malta were regarded as slim. The little island that stands like a fortress in the central channel between the eastern and western basins of the Mediterranean is only sixty miles from the tip of Sicily and barely 200 miles from Tripoli, in Axis-controlled Libya.
The accent was decidedly on pretty clothes in Jonai's Southern and Spring collection, which delighted the luncheon guests yesterday at the Ritz Carlton.

Declaring that the "defense of the mind" and the maintenance of civilian morale were of primary importance in civilian support of the war, Noel F. Hall, British Minister to Washington in charge of economic warfare activities of the British Embassy, said yesterday that England guessed wrong on the effects of air raids, over-estimating the number likely to be killed and underestimating the very large number of petty annoyances caused by bombings.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 13 -- Dr. Enrique de Ruiz-Guinazu, Foreign Minister, completely recovered from a slight indisposition suffered yesterday, left for Rio de Janeiro by air early this morning.

Latin-American music will be offered at Macy's Latin-American Fair Saturday to Feb. 7, it was announced yesterday. Sambas, cuecas, tonados, boleros and folk music of all kinds will be featured. Terig Tucci, music director of the Network of the Americas of the Columbia Broadcasting System, will have charge of musical presentations.

Two first-degree grand larceny indictments handed up on July 21, 1936, against Meyer Brenner, a stock broker in Toronto, in an allegedly fraudulent transaction in which the Meade Steel and Metals Company, formerly at 15 Moore Street, lost $150,000, were dismissed yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan in General Sessions. The court acted on the motion of Assistant District Attorney Sol Gelb, head of the Indictment Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor has appealed to President Roosevelt, members of Congress and the various defense agencies, for modification of the tire rationing order "to meet the requirements of all vital transportation services, including delivery services essential to maintain the health and welfare, as well as the unimpaired efficiency and morale of our civilian population."

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Uncertainty as to the outcome of the Price-Control Bill, with prospects that some of the features which had such a decided effect on the market yesterday would be eliminated in the final draft of the measure, started today a selling movement in all pits which carried prices off almost as rapidly as they had advanced on the previous day, wheat declining 2 5/8 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- General Charles de Gaulle said here today that in choosing to fight by the side of the Allies Free Frenchmen had answered the call of honor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Roosevelt intimated strongly today to House conferees, meeting with him at his call, that he would veto the price control bill before he would allow "the emergency wage parity" amendment which the Senate inserted Saturday to become law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Whisky distillers of the country volunteered today to forego further production of beverage spirits in the interests of the war effort and to concentrate their facilities on producing alcohol suitable for conversion into 190-proof alcohol suitable for use in armaments production.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 13 -- The Melbourne Argus said editorially today that Australians were perplexed after having vainly awaited the arrival of British reinforcements for Malaya until it was now apparent that Singapore, always deemed impregnable, was gravely endangered.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 13 (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Today's Finnish communique follows:

John B. Freudenberger, in the New York Stock Exchange's employ for thirty-three years, was elected yesterday president of the institution's Quarter Century Club, composed of ninety-one active and forty-one retired employes of at least twenty-five years' standing.

LONDON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Ski-shod Red Army troops tonight were storming the German defense cog at Orel, 200 miles southwest of Moscow, and were reported on the verge of overrunning the RzhevBryansk Nazi Winter line, which already has been pierced.

BERLIN, Jan. 13 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The official news agency, D.N.B., said today that the British battleship reported by the German High Command on Nov. 26 to have been torpedoed by a U-boat off Solum, Egypt, was the 31,100-ton Barham.

A VERY interesting little book comparing Britain and Germany at war is just out. Called "Conversation in London,"* it is a report of actual conversations in London last October between Stephen Laird, former Berlin correspondent of Time, Inc., and Walter Graebner, London correspondent of the same magazine.

Governor Edison appeared in person yesterday to deliver his message to the New Jersey Legislature. That body had paid him the compliment of asking him to be present. But the invitation was far more than a courtesy. It was additional evidence of the new relations between the Executive and the majority party in the Legislature.

A.G. Becker Co., Inc., will offer to the public today $2,000,000 of Pittsburgh Steel Company first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, Series B, due in 1950. The bonds will be priced at 99 and accrued interest from Dec. 1, 1941. The bonds are an additional series of the company's first mortgage bonds which are listed on the New York Stock Exchange, where application for listing the new issues will be made.

Joe Louis, heavyweight boxing champion of the world, presented an $89,092 check to the Navy Relief Society here yesterday to mark one of his final acts in civil life before doffing his colorful attire this morning for the plebeian khaki of the United States Army.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- A proposed judiciary article for the State Constitution, abolishing the county courts of the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond, and the Court of General Sessions in Manhattan and merging their duties into the Supreme Court, was introduced in the Senate today by Benjamin F. Feinberg, chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

Higher corporate taxes, notably surtaxes, are in prospect to finance the war, Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, indicated in an address here yesterday before the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Some Barnard College freshmen may start their college careers in February, according to Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve, who discussed modifications of the Barnard curriculum to meet the war emergency at a special all-college assembly yesterday.

Carmen Amaya, the Spanish gypsy who has danced previously only in night clubs hereabout, last night made her New York recital debut in a program at Carnegie Hall, assisted by Antonio Triana, the guitarist Sabicas, and half a dozen other assorted dancers, guitarists and pianists, answering chiefly to the name of Amaya.

Two of the four parcels purchased last week by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, from the Julius Forstmann estate have been resold in a cash deal to a client of Raymond D. O'Connell, attorney, by John J. Reynolds, broker.

The American hosiery industry is now through with silk and is placing its reliance on the new synthetic yarns which the manufacturers of this country will make available, Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, said yesterday at the merchandising session of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 13 -- The general feeling in interAmerican conference circles tonight as the opening time approaches was that some solution would be found for the paramount issue -- Argentina's position. This was freely voiced by delegates, though no specific information was claimed on which to base it.

DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- With 30 per cent of the members of the Purchasing Agents Association of Detroit reporting that business during December had slackened from the November pace, the peak of activity in this city has been passed temporarily, according to the association's monthly business survey published today.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 13 -- In retaliation for Germany and Japan having placed Mexican official representatives virtually in concentration centers, this government officially announced tonight that German and Japanese Government representatives would be sent to White Sulphur Springs, W. Va. and Hot Springs, Va., respectively.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 13 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers blew up a train in the station at Muong Ratiburi, Thailand, at the extreme northern end of the Malay Peninsula, during a series of attacks on Japanese-held bases today, a communique reported.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Republican legislative leaders committed themselves today to enactment at this session of a law to permit the payment of income tax returns in quarterly payments. Under the plan which is favored payment of the tax in installments would not become effective until 1944, since a change in the State's fiscal year is also proposed.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., Jan. 13 -- A seven-car Long Island Railroad troop train struck an automobile at a grade crossing near here at 2:20 P. IV[. today, instantly killing Edward Fellerath, 67 years old, Deputy Assessor of the Town of Islip, L. I., and critically injuring the other person in the car, William H. Colson, 54, the town's Assessor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -George Hill, a Congressional clerk who is being tried on perjury charges growing out of a Federal grand jury investigation of Nazi propaganda, suffered a setback in District Court today which would subject him to a prison sentence if he was convicted.

The Red Cross War Fund drive of Greater New York will begin tomorrow one of the most extensive solicitations ever undertaken in the city's business fields when 10,000 volunteer canvassers, employes of industrial and commercial establishments, will appeal to 1,500,000 fellow-workers for contributions.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Apple eaters had a varied stock to choose from today as the State Horticultural Society opened its annual meeting. Apples by the thousands, representing scores of varieties, grown in New York State, were shown in conjunction with the meeting.

Although asserting that there is no impending food shortage, OPM officials, meeting here with food and beverage manufacturers yesterday, conceded that there will be a scarcity of supplies for packaging, forwarding and distributing of food and drink products.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -The Justice Department has dismissed one major oil company defendant and forty-seven minor defendants from its anti-trust suit against the industry, leaving the American Petroleum Institute, twenty-one major companies and more than 300 subsidiary and affiliate companies in the case.
TOKYO, Jan. 13 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -Domei news agency today broadcast the following:

Joseph Louis Barrow of 4320 Michigan Avenue, Chicago, found himself in this city on Monday, when it was time for him to be inducted into the Army, and accordingly arranged with his home board for a transfer to Local Board 20, 331 Madison Avenue. Mr. Barrow didn't ask for any special attention.

Officials of Essex County, Mass., split the award yesterday of a total of $1,250,000 short-term obligations. The Gloucester National Bank received $900,000 of tax anticipation notes, due on Nov. 10, 1942, at an interest rate of 0.327 per cent, while the Manufacturers Central National Bank of Lynn received the award of $350,000 of tuberculosis hospital notes, due Jan. 15, 1943, at 0.359 per cent.

The first of a series of public lectures and discussions on nutrition problems will be held this evening in the auditorium of the New York University School of Education, 35 West Fourth Street, at 8:15 o'clock. Dr. Norman Joliffe, Associate Professor of Medicine at the N.Y.U. Medical College, will speak on "The Prevalence of Malnutrition."

Arthur Wolf, 60 years old, who said he had been in the travel agency business for thirty years, was arrested yesterday in the office of the Consolidated Travel Bureau, which he owns, at 240 Central Park South, for allegedly defrauding Dr. Chen Chier, until recently Chinese Ambassador to Germany, of $607.50.

The underwriting community was impressed yesterday by the reception given by investors to the two major offerings of securities, representing, as they did, different types of issues. Combined, the dollar volume of the two loans was about $25,500,000, which was an amount sufficient to test the market after a period of unsettlement, price readjustment and inactivity.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. l3 -- Poles of military age, with their womenfolk and children, are now en route to a refugee camp somewhere in the Middle East, where the vanguard of 600 is expected this week. They are being transferred from Siberia to join General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck's British armies.

The closed-shop issue in the field of labor negotiations was discussed yesterday by a college dean and a labor organizer at a forum luncheon under the auspices of the Women's City Club in the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.

The report issued by the Committee of Fifteen, headed by Paul Windels, recommending an increase in transit fares indicates that the leading business, industrial and real estate groups in the city have been well repaid for their efforts in organizing this committee. The urgings of the committee favor the interest of these groups to the exclusion of those of the seven million other inhabitants of our city who use the transit facilities.

The report issued by the Committee of Fifteen, headed by Paul Windels, recommending an increase in transit fares indicates that the leading business, industrial and real estate groups in the city have been well repaid for their efforts in organizing this committee. The urgings of the committee favor the interest of these groups to the exclusion of those of the seven million other inhabitants of our city who use the transit facilities.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 14 -- The Berlin correspondent of the Nya Dagligt Allehanda quotes military circles as having said that the German Army in Russia had reached its Winter line and that there would be no more retreats.
Reports that the OPA was planning a ceiling on retail sugar prices in addition to the existing check on wholesale prices were described as "unauthorized" yesterday at the OPA headquarters here.

Dr. Marcus Nadler, research director of the New York University Institute of International Finance, yesterday predicted that the war would favorably affect the stock market and that during 1942 the net earnings of corporations would be higher than in 1939 and 1940 despite increased excess profits taxes.
After a tour of shopping yesterday, Mrs. Clarence C. Cox of Greenville, S.C., who is "Mrs. Typical Customer of 1942," became atypical. She said her feet did not hurt.

With everything that you say in your editorial "Political Price Fixing," wherein you expose as "shameless class legislation" the Senate's farm-relief bill passed last Saturday under the guise of a price-control bill, I must of necessity agree.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 -- German bombers were over Malta several times yesterday, continuing the steady intensive air attack that they have been carrying out for weeks against that British island fortress. But the Royal Air Force, far from being driven from the Central Mediterranean area, continued to strike back.

Net sales of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for 1941 established a new high record of $323,020,113, according to the annual report of James A. Gray, president, issued for publication today. Net sales for 1940 totaled $292,039,070.

Juan Carlos Blanco, Ambassador of Uruguay to the United States, is notifying holders of dollar bonds of the Republic of Uruguay that the republic is extending the period for exchange of these bonds for new readjustment bonds. The offer will remain open until such date as may be hereafter determined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- America can have a post-war economy more productive than any the world has ever known, with full employment producing peacetime goods at a rate of from $105,000,000,000 to $110,000,000,000 a year, the National Resources Planning Board asserted today in its second annual report to Congress.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Members of the Legislature who are 44 years old or less must register for the draft in February, but can not be called for service while they continue to hold their legislative posts, Attorney General Bennett ruled today.

Yesterday's papers told of a luncheon at the Children's Aid Society Newsboys Home in William Street to commemorate the 119th birthday of Horatio Alger, who wrote 119 books. Charles Loring Brace's Newsboys Lodging House was very near to Alger's kindly heart. It was his home and club.

Future curtailment in the appliance industry will be considerably sharper than it has been, Henry A. Dinegar of the electrical appliance and consumer durable goods branch of the Office of Production Management declared yesterday at a meeting of the range section of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The Battle of the Atlantic flared within 150 miles of New York City yesterday. The Third Naval District Headquarters at 90 Church Street announced that the tanker Norness, of Panamanian registry, had been torpedoed about sixty miles southeast of Montauk Point, not far from the approaches to New York Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Thurman W. Arnold, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's anti-trust division, was accused today before a House investigating committee of making "erroneous and unfounded" statements which were destroying "the morale of this country and of keymen in defense production."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A code under which newspapers, magazines and other periodicals are requested not to publish certain classes of information which might be of aid to the enemy was announced today by the Office of Censorship headed by Byron Price.

A five-year extension of the $240,000 first mortgage on 240 West Seventy-fifth Street has been arranged with the Greenwich Savings Bank for the Book Realty Corporation by Walter Samuels, Inc, brokers. The loan carries interest at 21/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Joseph B. Eastman, director of defense transportation, has created a division of local transport in his department to begin work immediately on solving the problems of rail, bus and private automobile transportation for workers in defense plants.

The residence in Montclair, N.J., of the late Frederick T. Gates, who was an associate of John D. Rockefeller Sr., has been purchased by Joseph A. Bower, executive vice president of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company and chairman of the Republican State Finance Committee.
