RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 14 -- Three grinning Japanese, representing themselves to be newspaper men, walked into the Brazilian Press and Publicity Department today and asked for cards that are being issued to foreign correspondents accredited to the inter-American conference, which opens tomorrow.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Governor Lehman is expected to send to the Legislature tomorrow specific recommendations for the strengthening of the civilian defense set-up within the State, apart from New York City, which is a separate defense unit under Federal orders.

Two tall buildings containing lofts and showrooms in the midtown section of Manhattan passed to new control yesterday when B. J. and L.V. Well bought for investment the twelve-story building at 258-60 Fifth Avenue and the sixteen-story structure at 2 West Twenty-ninth Street, forming an "L" around the southwest corner.

From all accounts Eddie Dowling is going ahead with his project of short plays by William Saroyan and Sean O'Casey, collectively known as "Life, Laughter and Tears." Rehearsals are scheduled to start next week under Mr. Dowling's direction in anticipation of a local debut the week of Feb. 15 or 22.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau announced today that prompt application of a "scorched earth" policy in the Philippines by High Commissioner Francis B. Sayre and Treasury Department representatives there had prevented "many millions of dollars' worth of securities, coins, currency, bullion, jewelry" and other property from falling into the hands of the Japanese.

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Three men died tonight of burns suffered in an explosion and fire at the United Aircraft Corporation's Pratt Whitney plant shortly before noon today. Six other men were injured.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Recipients of the Montgomery Ward Spring and Summer general catalogue late this week will find the usual offerings of Riverside Tires replaced by a two-page bulletin on the tire situation, examination of the first copies off the presses revealed today.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- Although competition has been the life-blood of the automobile industry since its inception, collaboration and mutual assistance between the various companies and men is needed in every phase of the war task, Alvan Macauley, chairman of the Automotive Council for War Production, told more than 300 members of the Society of Automotive Engineers at their annual dinner tonight.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- Automobile management and labor buckled down today to the task of converting the country's greatest mass production industry to the job of turning out $5,000,000,000 worth of materiel in 1942.
CAMP UPTON, L.I., Jan. 14 -- Joe Louis moved today from the best suite in the best hotel in Harlem to the barracks of Company L of the 1222d Reception Center here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Intercession by President Roosevelt to effect modifications of farm bloc amendments which, he holds, would convert the price control bill into a measure that would compel inflation, was denounced in the Senate today as "an interference with legislative processes."

"English tea cake," reads the neat little sign that points to a fragrant, crusty brown loaf with a snowy powdering of sugar on its top and fat, black raisins bursting through its sides. This golden cake, which now appears on the counter of a charming little shop in the East Fifties, is made from a carefully guarded recipe that comes from a British ducal household.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 14 -- Some attenuation in the German press campaign against Great Britain's "perfidious abandonment of her Turkish friend" through Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's alleged "cession" of the Dardanelles to Russia was noticeable in dispatches reaching here today from both Axis capitals.

John Kirkpatrick gave a recital devoted to piano works by contemporary composers of the United States last night in Town Hall. Here was a real chance for the many who constantly clamor for performances of American music to hear an entire program of it most efficiently performed.

Predicting "a tremendous expansion" in the public works program after the war, Commissioner William Hodson of the New York City Department of Welfare declared yesterday that if the United States can provide full employment for its workers in wartime it will have to continue to do so in the peace to follow.

With seventeen days to go before automobiles must display the new Federal tax stamps, conflicting orders from Washington yesterday set, then put off to the last five days of January, the period for public sale of the stamps in New York City.

William Fellowes Morgan Jr., former Markets Commissioner, who recently resigned after a dispute with Mayor La Guardia, has accepted the post of executive director of the newly formed Metropolitan Package Stores Association, retail liquor dealers' group, it was announced yesterday by the association.

General Foods Corporation was the leading sponsor and Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., the agency placing the most business on the Columbia Broadcasting System last year. Total CBS billings hit $44,584,378 for the year, a gain of $3,558,839 over 1940.

EASTON, Pa., Jan. 14 -- The Rev. Dr. Dale H. Moore, Professor of Religion at Lafayette College was elected today president of Cedar Crest College, a women's institution at Allentown. He will succeed the Rev. Dr. William F. Curtis, who died on May 5.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue noted yesterday a requirement that a return be filed for a person who has died if gross income to the date of death was $750 or more and the individual was single, or, if married, not living with husband or wife for any part of the taxable year.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 14 -- The heroic last stand of the Tarakan garrison, which fought even after having been completely surrounded by Japanese, under heavy air bombardment and in the midst of enormous heat and fire from burning oil wells, was told by authoritative quarters here today.

The plan used in the United States for the disposal of surplus agricultural products may help solve the problem of distribution for increased production during the post-war period, Sir Kenneth Lee, representative in the United States for the Industrial and Export Council of the British Board of Trade, said yesterday before the merchandising session of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
One of your contributors found fault with a statement praising the food value of beer and literally said that a bottle of beer does not contain more food value than the flour laid on a knife's edge.

Most city department heads showed a disposition to curtail their non-mandatory expenses in the 1942-43 budget when they appeared yesterday before Budget Director Kenneth Dayton. The five District Attorneys, however, asked increased appropriations for next year.
Alfred B. Stanford was re-elected commodore of the Cruising Club of America at its annual meeting at the New York Yacht Club last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Prices of hogs resumed their upturn today as receipts dropped 5,000 head below expectations. Prices were only 10 to 15 cents a hundred pounds under the high levels reached late last week. The wholesale dressed pork market, however, was unchanged to slightly lower.

An entire floor in the Masonic Building at 71 West Twenty-third Street, comprising about 14,000 square feet of space, has been leased by Jonas Shoppes, Inc., operators of a chain of ladies' wear stores, in a transaction arranged by Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc.

Artur Schnabel, in his forthcoming "Music and the Line of Most Resistance," remarks that coloratura, acrobatics and swing produce "similar sensations." That is, he explains, "the accomplishments are measured, the alleged risks tangible and the listener's excitement is physical."
Until just the day before yesterday you could have made a G-man wince by asking him one simple question. That question was:

The condition of American children in the Southern mountains was pictured yesterday as "more desperate" than that of youngsters in Britain. Most mountain children with enough clothes to attend school are so undernourished that the education does them little good, declared Dr. John R. Vorhis, president and executive director of the Save the Children Federation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- War Department communique No. 58, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (U.P.) -- The continued absence of Japanese aerial attack against Manila Bay fortifications further emphasized the belief here today that the bigger part of the Japanese air force had been shifted for Major assaults against the Netherlands Indies and Malaya.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Treasury and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today proclaimed their interest in the small business man and announced measures to come to his aid.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- By unanimous vote the Senate approved today a conference-adjusted defense housing program which would expand to $900,000,000 government authorizations for constructing dwellings and acquiring community facilities.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14 -- Among members of society at the opening this afternoon of the racing season at Hialeah Park were several from Palm Beach. Mrs. George Eustis Paine Jr. arrived to join her grandfather, Joseph E. Widener, and Mrs. Henry J. Topping Jr. was here with friends.

WESTBURY, L.I., Jan. 14 -- Dogs trained for the obedience tests that in recent years have become a feature of many large shows can readily be adapted to military and civilian war duties, according to Harland W. Meistrell, Westbury real estate agent, who is proving the theory with his own pets.

OUR greatest national defense task was undertaken long before this war began and will still be incomplete long after this war is over. It has to do with corn, wheat, forests and pasture lands. It has to do with hydroelectric plants and irrigation systems, hospital beds and insurance policies, diets, dwellings, bridges, schools, dams, roads and jobs.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Jan. 14 -- John J. McHugh, 33 years old, a patrolman of the Lansdowne (Pa.) force, who joined in the search for three soldiers who had escaped from the guardhouse at Fort Dix last Aug. 22 and fatally shot one of them, was acquitted of manslaughter in Common Pleas Court here tonight.

City Council President Newbold Morris told 3,200 government-employed union members at a victory rally at the Manhattan Center last night that they must make sacrifices to help win the war and must at the same time defend their social and economic gains at home and improve "substandard" conditions wherever they exist.

The already gloomy outlook for private building in the United States was further darkened yesterday when John L. Haynes, chief of the lumber and building materials branch of the OPM, confirmed recent rumors that his office was contemplating greater curtailment of nonessential construction because of growing material scarcities.

Cartoonists are not quite faithful to the facts when they show a Russian colossus named General Winter chasing a tin-pot Napoleon called Hitler on the road from Moscow to Smolensk. Something more than inclement weather stopped Hitler in 1941, as we have every reason to suspect, and as we shall learn more definitely in the future.

Net operating earnings of the Manufacturers Trust Company for 1941 amounted to $6,446,236, equivalent to $3.91 a share on the common stock, Harvey D. Gibson, president, reported to shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

Dr. Chen Chieh, the Chinese Ambassador to Berlin up to last July, on whose complaint Arthur Wolf, head of the Consolidated Travel Bureau at 240 Central Park South, is awaiting a General Sessions trial in the alleged theft of $607.50 on a fraudulent check, said yesterday that erroneous reports had arisen from Wolf's indictment.

BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Jan. 15 -- German positions on the Crimean Peninsula were gravely threatened during operations yesterday, when Russian parachute troops carried out a large-scale and apparently successful attack on the Perekop Isthmus, it was learned today.
Wendell L. Willkie will not accept an invitation to serve as an umpire under President Roosevelt's War Labor Board, it was learned yesterday.

Axel Wenner-Gren, the Swedish industrialist, is married to an American, the former Marguerite Liggett of Kansas City, a singer, and long has been friendly with many prominent Americans, according to The United Press.

The shortage of scrap steel still continues to influence operations in the steel industry. In the Youngstown district operations again were hard hit and four more open-hearth furnaces were forced to suspend operations because of the lack of scrap steel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- In the course of his evidence today before the House Migratory Committee on the progress of the civilian defense program, Mayor La Guardia indicated a speedy choice as to whether he would remain as director.

Eight pupils, representing four trade high schools of New York, received awards yesterday as winners in a millinery competition at the Central High School of Needle Trades. One hundred pupils participated in the competition, for which the Millinery Stabilization Commission was sponsor.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Formation of stock corporations in the State in 1941 declined from 16,040 the year before to 13,815. In making the announcement Secretary of State Walsh said the smaller number of new concerns was due to the large increase in voluntary dissolutions and a transformation of the character of industry from a peace basis to one of war.

The mild inflationary tendencies prevalent in the first two sessions of the week were chilled yesterday as the stock market gave early response to the tightening up of the war production effort and then proceeded to fall back into a listless affair.

Thirty-six children ranging in age from 2 to 5 years, pupils of the kindergarten and nursery school of Grace Episcopal Church at 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, took part yesterday morning in their first air raid drill.
TOKYO Jan. 14 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Domei today published this war summary:

The final round of the eighth annual New York State squash racquets singles championship was reached by Donald M. Frame of the Harvard Club, top seeded, and Richard S. Rothschild of the host club, ranked second, last night at the Downtown A.C. Frame, who was runner-up last year, is the favorite to triumph in the final tonight because of his brilliant tournament record.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 -- With the Pacific Coast, now in the "combat zone," demanding adequate defense against possible Japanese attack from water and air, the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today against any delay in the achievement of military objectives.

Mayor La Guardia's recent order requiring some city employes to work on Sunday was condemned by Frederick E. Libby, president of the Civil Service Forum yesterday as "a Communistic attempt to Stalinize the City of New York."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Secretary Knox stated today that the recent reorganization of the Navy's high command did not reflect on Admiral Harold R. Stark, Chief of Naval Operations.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company received yesterday award of $3,300,000 of tax-anticipation notes of Rochester, N.Y., at 0.42 per cent plus a premium of $12. The financing consisted of $2,000,000 of notes dated Jan. 15, 1942, and maturing on Sept. 15, 1942; $700,000 dated Jan. 21, 1941, and due on Sept. 21, 1942, and $600,000 dated Jan. 20, 1942, and due Sept. 30, 1942.

Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane gave a tea yesterday afternoon at their home, 48 East Ninety-second Street, for the Rev. Dr. Michael Coleman of All Hallows Church, London, under the auspices of the English-speaking Union. Dr. Coleman's church was wrecked completely in one of the air raids on the British capital.

Summer programs for school children in wartime should have increased cooperation of parents and more intensive planning by school authorities, according to educators and organization leaders who spoke yesterday at a conference of the New York section of the American Camping Association.

After more than one month of shortages of supplies of defense savings bonds of the smaller denominations, all issuing agents in the Second Federal Reserve District are now fully supplied, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced yesterday.

Accused of having stolen $39,000 from the 180th Street branch of the Harlem Savings Bank, where he had been a trusted employe for fifteen years, Edward Arville Veevers, 35 years old, of 106 Pinehurst Avenue, was arrested last night on charges of forgery and grand larceny.
Red Cross workers of all the Americas have been invited to be guests of honor at a team to be held today to honor Latin-American Day in the Red Cross drive for war funds.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 14 (U.P.) -- Travelers from Northern Norway reported today that Norwegian saboteurs had paralyzed land communications through Northeastern Norway all the way to the border of Finland by destroying two important bridges in Finnmark Province.

"Recently I heard an officer say, 'When I come home from duty I don't want to see my wife looking like a top sergeant.'" This was related by Florence Reichman yesterday afternoon in opening her Spring millinery showing. "With this in mind," she continued, "I set to work.

A retrospective memorial exhibition of paintings by the cowboy artist, Frank Tenney Johnson, who died in January, 1939, will open at the Grand Central (Terminal) Galleries on Tuesday and remain current through Jan. 31. Eighteen canvases, depicting the life of the old West, will be included.

With local angling limited to frigid codding offshore and icefishing inshore, and hunting bounded by foxhunting and hare harrying, the sportsmen seem to be spending most of their time with a pen and ink or a telephone, telling rod and gun editors what they think of the New York State feather law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- George Hill, a clerk of Representative Fish of New York, was described by the prosecution as "an important cog" in the Nazi propaganda machine and by the defense as the target of a "smear" campaign as attorneys summed up today at his trial on perjury charges.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The President does not exaggerate when he declares that the so-called price-control bill passed by the Senate is actually a measure to compel inflation. He is more than justified in threatening to veto the final bill if it comes to him with some of the more vicious Senate provisions in it.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Morris (Moe) Berg, the learned linguist who has served as a catcher and coach of the Boston Red Sox baseball club since 1935, obtained an unconditional release today to permit him to go on a governmentsponsored good-will tour of Central and South America.

Remarking that "if Colin Kelly could afford to dive into a Japanese battleship, you and I can afford to dive into our pockets," James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, opened yesterday the textile trade's $75,000 drive to fight infantile paralysis at a luncheon meeting in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Winning six of the nine first places, Dartmouth's swimming team turned back the Columbia mermen, 40 to 35, in the opening Eastern Intercollegiate League meeting for both in the Lions' pool last night. It was the second triumph in as many starts this season for the Hanover, N.H., squad.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. Samuel Goldwyn's production, "Ball of Fire," starring Gary Cooper and Barbara Stanwyck, will be the newcomer at the Radio City Music Hall. Directed by Howard Hawks, the comedy features Dana Andrews, S.Z. Sakall, Leonid Kinskey, Oscar Homolka, Henry Travers and Tully Marshall.

VINCENNES, Ind., Jan. 14 -- Citizens of Vincennes turned out today to honor the memory of Adam Gimbel, frontier merchant, and to hear an address by Donald M. Nelson, read in his absence, in which the head of the new War Production Board called for a manifestation of the American pioneer spirit to meet the critical tasks of a nation at war.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 14 -- Dartmouth's basketball team routed the University of Pennsylvania five by 75 -- 31 tonight and shattered the Eastern Intercollegiate League scoring record by 10 points. The Hanover squad tallied almost at will to subdue the Quakers for its first victory in circuit competition.

A series of courses in emergency work with children will be given as part of the civilian defense program by the Summer Play Schools Association, Mrs. Adele S. Mossler, director, announced yesterday. Registration for the courses is now in progress at the association's offices, 1841 Broadway, at Sixtieth Street.
Thomas (Fats) Waller, who has contributed mightily to American jazz as a pianist, singer, composer, personality and band leader, last night gave a solo recital at Carnegie Hall.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 14 -- Agreement among scientists of the world may establish a lasting peace, Waldemar B. Kaempffert, science editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared in a Bergen lecture at Yale today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan 14 -- Henry Fonda and Don Ameche were assigned today to the leading roles in Twentieth Century-Fox's "Lazy Galahad," a photoplay by George Seaton based on a screen story by Joseph Schrank. Walter Lang will direct, starting the third week in February.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14 -- Mrs. Frank C. Henderson entertained today at the Tombola luncheon given at the Everglades Club. Her guests were Mrs. Theodore W. Stemmler, Mrs. William A. Yager, Mrs. Chester Milton Williams, Mrs. John T.H. Mitchell, Mrs. Winthrop Williams, Mrs. Lewis Oliver Cameron, Mrs. Francis Wann Randolph, Mrs. Frederick Herreshoff, Mrs. Catherine M. Legget, Mrs. David Graham Legget 3d, Mrs. Edward Scott Beck, Mrs. Evelyn McL. Gray and Miss Anne Mitchell.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline along the Atlantic Seaboard at the close of last week were 19,863,000 barrels, a decline of 255,000, compared with the 20,118,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Light fuel oil supplies were down 1,404,000 barrels to 17,728,000 and heavy oil stocks decreased 880,000 to 11,053,000.

Eight altar paintings for Army and Navy chapels, created through a competition sponsored by the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc., will go on exhibition today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
BERLIN, Jan. 14 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- the German Higk Commazd communique said:

Reorganization of the Board of Education's medical bureau, to include a chief medical examiner at $12,000 a year and a part-time psychiatrist at $5,000 was voted by the board at its regular meeting yesterday after a sharp debate between James Marshall, president, and Ellsworth B. Buck, vice president.

A realignment of the duties of the merchandising and buying staff of John Wanamaker, New York and Philadelphia, was announced yesterday by Charles R. Shipley, president, who asserted that the new set-up will tie in with the lower-price policy instituted some five years ago.

If Sheridan had been lucky enough to cast Bobby Clark as Bobby Acres 167 years ago, "The Rivals" would not have failed on the first night. For Bobby is not only the funniest clown in the world but also a comedian of taste and invention.

Requests for allotments of ethyl alcohol and related solvents for February have generally been completed and dispatched to the Priorities Division of the OPM and the data in the requests will give the OPM for the first time an accurate and up-to-date picture of inventories.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- New repulses by the United States-Filipino troops of attempts in force by the Japanese invaders to dislodge them from their position in the mountainous Bataan Province on Luzon Island encouraged a belief here tonight that General Douglas MacArthur, Commander in Chief of the United States Armed Forces in the Far East, might be able to continue to resist indefinitely.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Netherland troops successfully engaged the Japanese invader today in a skirmish on the wild and mountainous frontier of Sarawak and Netherland Borneo, and Allied planes beat strongly at the enemy from the Celebes Sea northward to the Philippine Islands.
Manager Red Dutton will place a revamped squad of Americans on the ice at Madison Square Garden tonight in the club's fifth game of the season with the Black Hawks.

Events today: "Phoebus and Pan" and "Le Coq d'Or," Sir Thomas Beecham conducting, Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P. M.; New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Fritz Busch conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Maria Maximovitch.
CLAYMONT, Del., Jan. 14 -- Fire, punctuated by sharp explosions, wrecked a Delaware River pier and warehouse of the Texas Company near here today. The loss was estimated as at least $250,000.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The spread of starvation in Greece has led the British Cabinet to consider the feasibility of sending food there or allowing it to be sent through the blockade. The decision, which is almost certain to raise a stormy debate, is believed to await the return of Prime Minister Churchill.

In selecting Donald M. Nelson to be the boss of America's defense production President Roosevelt has picked a man who has shown consistently in his past utterances a realistic comprehension of the size of the job. Mr. Nelson's battle-cry for the better part of a year has been that we must double our defense program.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 14 -- In the presence of a record opening day crowd of 16,533, Hialeah Park opened the first war-time meeting in its history with the black racer, De Kalb, the winner of the Inaugural Handicap at the end of six furlongs run in 1:11 4-5.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Her blue eyes alight with pride over the most momentous happening of her fourteen years of married life, Mrs. Donald M. Nelson, wife of the newly appointed head of the nation's war production, declared today that "the country has been given the best man for the job."

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A definite program to overcome a "serious shortage" of elementary school teachers in the State was mapped today at a conference to mobilize the resources of the eleven State teacher-preparing institutions in behalf of national defense.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- The Blue Network Company, Inc., organized on Jan. 9 as a wholly owned subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America, will be a competitive network in every sense, Mark Woods, president, said here today.

Morris Shamis, operator of a parking lot at 1217 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx, was fined $25 yesterday for leaving a truck on the street after he had received a fee to park it. The fine was imposed by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney in Bronx Traffic Court as the drive on overtime parking continued.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The many stories from Europe intimating growing friction within Germany as a result of reverses in the war on the Russian front drew from Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox today a warning to regard these reports with suspicion.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 14 -- The hour is near when Pan-Americanism will receive its greatest test. The Americas and the world are keenly watching the negotiations beginning here tomorrow among the twenty-one republics on the defense of this hemisphere.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 14 -- The trial of sixty-two persons on a charge of using the mails to further a lottery in eight Eastern States ended abruptly today with the completion of the government's case, when Judge R.M. Bibson in Federal District Court ordered a jury to acquit sixty defendants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Admiral Thomas C. Hart has succeeded in bringing the entire United States Asiatic Fleet, with its warships intact, to comparatively secure waters from which to wage his fight against the Japanese, it was ascertained tonight.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Counsel for five subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Company proposed today that in the interests of operating economy and better service they be permitted to merge into one company to supply 130,000 consumers in Western Pennsylvania.

Germany is becoming increasingly preoccupied with the cultural life of Portugal, and is exerting pressure on the neutral nation in the name of "Kultur," according to passengers who arrived yesterday on the Portuguese liner Guine.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The stock markets were quieter today although some sections had bright features. Gilt-edge issues, which showed a tendency to advance were helped by the u102,000,000 record national revenue for the first ten days of 1942.

LONDON, Jan. 14 (U.P) -- Naval forces of the United Nations are forming a sea barrier against the Japanese, extending from Singapore more than 2,000 miles through the Netherlands Indies, reliable Netherland quarters said today.

The board of governers of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., will meet today in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria to review activities of the association in 1941. Wallace H. Fulton, executive director, will submit a report on last year's enforcement program.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 14 -- The third conference of the Foreign Ministers of the American republics held since the outbreak of the war in Europe to deal with problems in the Western Hemisphere raised by the war will assemble formally tomorrow with the proposal that the twenty-one republics break all relations with the Axis as its paramount issue.

A stamp racket that took delicate, painstaking work was revealed and explained in Federal court yesterday when a stamp dealer and another man pleaded guilty to counterfeiting charges and received prison sentences.

CHANGSHA, China, Jan. 11 (Delayed) -- The third battle for Changsha was lost by the Japanese when they failed to hold Graveyard Hill, a strong vantage point in a suburb south of Changsha, which commands the city and all communication lines from the south and east.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 14 -- Metropolitan skiers have generally looked upon the northlands, covering the upper reaches of New York State, Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire, Maine and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada, as the only places for good Winter sport.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins denied yesterday an application by Theodore C. Corwin as stockholders of the New York City Interborough Railway Company, a street railway subsidiary of the Third Avenue Railway Company, for an order restraining directors of the company from holding a stockholders' meeting to ratify a "declaration of abandonment" of the company's street car lines in favor of bus routes.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau said in a communique today:

President Roosevelt's committee on fair employment practice appealed yesterday to organizations, unions and individual workers to report to it all cases of racial or religious discrimination in defense employment in the metropolitan area.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Jan. 14 -- Since the attack on Pearl Harbor by his fellow-countrymen, Bunji Kurita, 43 years old, Japanese chauffeur and butler employed for ten years by Mrs. George H. Harman of Lloyd's Neck, had brooded.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A bill decreasing the pari-mutuel take by operators of race tracks in the State from 5 to 4 per cent, with the 1 per cent deducted to provide funds for local defense councils throughout the State, was introduced today in the Assembly by Norman F. Penny, Nassau Republican and co-sponsor of the State's Pari-Mutuel Law.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Uniform daylight saving on a country-wide scale for the duration of the war, with the clock hands moving forward one hour early next month, was agreed to by the Senate today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The huge plane, tank and shipbuilding program which President Roosevelt outlined for 1942 must be accomplished by Dec. 1, one month ahead of schedule, Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management, told the closing session of the United States Conference of Mayors today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Present and post-war problems of civilian defense were explored at a hearing today by the House Migratory Labor Committee.

Every British commando that lands on the Norse coast to strike a swift blow is accompanied by troops of the Norwegian Overseas Force. Every commando that shoves off for England with Nazi and Quisling prisoners brings along enthusiastic Norse recruits for King Haakon's army in exile.

Fred Fisher, publisher, author and composer of many hit tunes in the last forty years and a wellknown figure along Tin Pan Alley, was found hanging yesterday in his penthouse apartment, 617 West End Avenue.

Two bills sneaked through the House last Summer which would fasten upon the country a $15,000,000,000 Townsend Plan for World War veterans and their relatives have just been reported out by a Senate Finance subcommittee without recommendation.
TOKYO, Jan. 14 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- Domei news agency in a war summary today declared:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Roosevelt by proclamation ordered the registration of all enemy aliens in the United States, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Island and nominated several officers of the armed forces for promotion to higher ranks.

For more than a decade the little candy store at 3l0 Marcy Avenue, in the crowded Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, like thousands of other candy stores in the city, was a second home to the neighborhood boys and girls, an important part of their social life.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 14 -- Yale overwhelmed Columbia tonight, 40 to 23, in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game. The Elis now have broken even in the two circuit contests they have played.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- To American artists were offered today $3,000 in prizes in an open competition for paintings, posters, water-colors, drawings and prints interpreting the activities of the American Red Cross.

As 200 women on teams of the women's special gifts committee of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York held yesterday their first meeting in the Hotel Ritz-Carlton, it was announced from the organization's national headquarters in Washington that total contributions already stood at $25,574,148, or more than half the national campaign's minimum goal of $50,000,000.

Most Americans never heard of Tarakan, in Dutch Borneo, or Menado, in the Celebes, until the Pacific war swept southward. But the capture of these places by Japan gives that country new air bases along the route by which the United States could hope to send relief to the Philippines.

Adams Express Company reported yesterday net assets for each share of stock at $10.62 on Dec. 31, 1941, against $11.12 a year earlier. On Jan. 13, however, value had risen to $11.73 a share. Net assets at the end of 1941 were $15,547,499, against $16,683,023 at the end of 1940.

Young men who are "capable of developing into aggressive, individual fighters with great endurance" may now enlist directly for duty with the Army's parachute troops, it was announced here yesterday by Colonel George H. Baird, recruiting officer for New York, New Jersey and Delaware.

Indications that the signing of Leo Durocher to a 1942 contract as manager of the Dodgers may not prove the mere "matter of formality" that President Larry MacPhail has frequently intimated it would be came to light yesterday when Leo the Lip arrived in town to interrupt a vacation stay in Sarasota Fla.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate for confirmation today the names of six brigadier generals promoted to major generals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- If one-man control of production and procurement for national defense was the wise solution on Jan. 13, 1942, it was an equally wise solution at the outset of the armament effort. Experience and the testimony of those best acquainted with war-making established it long ago to the satisfaction of most Americans who expressed themselves at all.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 14 -- British troops strove today to fend off a Japanese threat to block the Strait of Malacca while the Imperial Command under cover of a tropical deluge revamped tactics and regrouped man power for the impending battle of South Malaya.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Three hundred retail automobile dealers who had been critical of Leon Henderson revised their attitude toward the Federal Price Administrator today following his appearance before a House Committee investigating the effect of the "freezing" order banning new-car sales by the country's 44,000 dealers.

Jeremiah T. Mahoney, Tammany leader of the Fifteenth Assembly District, yesterday sent letters to his fellow-district leaders enclosing for their signatures a blank demanding that Charles H. Hussey, chairman of the executive committee, call a meeting of the committee to consider the deposition of Christopher D. Sullivan as leader of Tammany and to take such other action as "may be necessary for the best interests of the Democratic organization of New York County."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Shaun G., from the Lexbrook Stable, scored an upset victory today in the sprint feature at the Fair Grounds and paid $28.60 for $2. Imperial Impy finished second and Yankee Dandy third

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- On a bicycle built for one, but carrying two, Leon Henderson took time off from his job as Federal Price Administrator today to furnish for Mr. and Mrs. America some idea of what wartime transportation may come to in this country.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- Praise for the appointment of Donald M. Nelson to direct arms production and procurement came today from C.E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation; Edsel Ford, president of the Ford Motor Company, and the officers of the U.A.W.C.I.O.

Liquidation and hedge-selling induced early easiness in the cotton market yesterday, but persistent trade buying brought about a recovery later. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed near their high marks for the day at levels unchanged to 2 points higher than on Tuesday.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Legislative action making it a felony punishable by a jail sentence up to five years for stealing an automobile tire or auto accessories during the war was started in the Senate today when the Codes Committee reported out the Bechtold bill.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 14 (AP) -- A big Axis air assault in the Mediterranean appeared to be well under way tonight as German and Italian planes battered unceasingly at Malta, bombed British communications across Libya and attacked imperial troops that were attempting to encircle the German units now drawn up on a line from El Agheila southward toward Marade at the gateway to Tripolitania.

Sixteen of the leading Chinese organizations in this city denounced Secretary of the Navy Knox yesterday for his statement on Monday that Hitler must be defeated first and that full-scale action by the United States Fleet against Japan in the Pacific could not be expected in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Congress could save at least $125,000 a year and a great deal of time to devote to more important business if it would delegate the handling of personal claims bills and authority for constructing bridges over navigable streams to executive agencies, President Roosevelt said in a message to both houses today.

St. John's climbed uphill all the way to vanquish Fordham in Madison Square Garden last night before a frenzied crowd of 10,094, coming from 14 points behind to achieve a 40-all tie in the regulation time and then pouring them through the hoop in the five-minute overtime period to win, 54 to 44.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- The Buick motor division of the General Motors Corporation began mass production of 1,200 horsepower, fifteen cylinder, air-cooled Buick-Pratt Whitney engines for the Army's long-range bombers today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 14 -- Prime Minister John Curtin conferred today with the new Administrative Planning Committee, which is working in cooperation with Britain's allies on problems of the Pacific war zone.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 14 -- J. Overton Paine, 72-year-old stock-broker and former head of the Paine Statistical Corporation of Newark and Chicago, was convicted today for the second time in three years on charges of engineering fraudulent stock sales.

Yesterday I was dining in a small but famous Latin-American restaurant in New York. Its proprietor had a program of symphonic music on the radio from one of New York's small stations. The announcements were German.

In this war emergency the government is handling the enemy alien problem and subversive action much better than it did in 1917-18. Nevertheless, there is much discussion and some trepidation concerning the propriety of certain types of restraint and the bounds of our normal guarantees.

Price ceilings on many or all commodities, rationing, taxes, Federal Government borrowing out of current savings of taxpayers and monetary controls as measures to halt inflation were discussed by Federal Government spokesmen at meetings of the nation's retailers here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -Robert E. Healy -- known as "Judge" to the nation's utility industry -- has resigned from the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was reported reliably today.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 13 (Delayed) -- I returned to Singapore yesterday through ranks of British forces that continued to carry out an orderly delaying retirement southward along the Malayan west coast rail and highway network after the evacuation of Kuala Lumpur.

Across the country civilians are replying to the terse, forceful request "We Want Books." With this call the Victory Book Campaign is seeking to collect 10,000,000 books for the use of the members of the ever-larger Army, Navy and Merchant Marine of the United States.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 14 -- A government communique said tonight that 600 Japanese were killed in fierce fighting near Canton, where Chinese forces are threatening Japanese lines to Indo-China and Malaya, and that "hundreds" of others were drowned when remnants of the expedition to Changsha sought to escape across the Milo River.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed in December totaled 887,326 bales of lint and 110,612 bales of linters, compared with 849,733 and 117,628 in November last, and 777,482 and 104,462 in December a year ago.

Foreign Minister Aranha of Brazil, speaking on the eve of today's opening session of the Rio de Janeiro conference, declared that "a rupture in harmony would mean that Pan-Americanism has gone back fifty years." Perhaps he overstated the case. The situation is, nevertheless, critical.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Further investigation into the JekyllHyde career of Mrs. Amelia M. Carr revealed today that the 66year-old swindler, who posed here as a good churchwoman, not only had been a partner in a bigamous marriage but had earlier changed her religion to wed a man whom she later left but never divorced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The United States carried its economic warfare tonight into Sweden, Turkey, Switzerland, Spain and Portugal by blacklisting 1,800 Axis and non-Axis companies, firms and individuals doing business with Germany, Japan and Italy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A world at war, as seen from this nerve center of United Nations strength, presents a picture overlaid in places with dark and somber shadows, but lightened in others by United Nations' successes.

What is believed to be the first equity financing in this market for a foreign industrial concern since the passage of the Securities Act will take place today with the flotation of capital stock of the Panama Coca-Cola Bottling Company. The financing is interpreted as first manifestation of the investment relations between investors in this country and private industry in the neighboring republic in recent years.

The John Fritz Medal, highest award in the engineering profession, was presented last night to Everette Lee DeGolyer, consulting petroleum engineer of Dallas, Texas, at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria held under the auspices of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers, of which Mr. DeGolyer is a member.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- An order banning the use of cans for the packaging of a wide variety of products, including some foodstuffs, has been prepared by the Office of Production Management and will be issued before the end of the week, according to reports here tonight.

Men's wear stocks in local stores have been thinned rapidly by the current buying rush and retailers face the prospect of having a poor February because of inability to replenish inventories, they said yesterday. This situation is now similar to that of a year ago when production failed to keep up with demand.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Joe Chamaco, colorful Mexican star, continued his brilliant play in the world three-cushion billiards tournament today, winning his third straight start with a 50-to-30 victory over Otto Reiselt, Philadelphia veteran.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the new War Production Board, indicated to the Army, Navy and Office of Production Management today that comprehensive changes were likely in the government's armaments production machine.

Small declines in steel ingot production rates in Chicago and Pittsburgh were the chief causes of a drop of one-half point in the national rate to 96 per cent of capacity, according to the Iron Age. The Pittsburgh rate dropped one point to 97 per cent, Chicago eased one-half point to 101 per cent and a severe shortage of scrap in Southern Ohio forced a drop there of 15 points to 93 per cent.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 14 -- It is reported from Berlin that military mail to and from the Eastern Front has been stopped by military authorities as from today.

Twelve hundred New York City architects have volunteered their services as a technical auxiliary force to survey every building in the city to determine the safest places for civilians in the event of an air raid, it was disclosed yesterday.

The report of the Truman committee on the progress or lack of progress of the defense program illustrates one of the most important functions that Congress can perform in wartime. It cannot conduct the war, but it can hold the Executive accountable for its conduct of the war and it can present to the people the facts necessary to form a judgment.

Foreign traders yesterday welcomed the issuance of the supplementary blacklist covering firms and individuals in Spain, Portugal, Sweden and Turkey, as a further clarification of the co-called "gray list" of doubtful transactions. Generally, however, the action was described, in effect, as a formality in view of the actual situation.

MONTREAL, Jan. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Nick Metz's goal after eleven seconds of an overtime period gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight before a crowd of 8,160.

The editors of the Book-of-the-Month Club announced yesterday that they had selected for April distribution two books, John Steinbeck's new short novel, "The Moon Is Down" (Viking), and a novel by Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings called "Cross Creek" (Scribner).

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A United States submarine operating in Far Eastern waters has sunk a 17,000-ton Japanese liner, one of Japan's newest types and one designed for conversion to an aircraft carrier, the Navy Department reported tonight. The vessel was identified only as a ship "of the Yawata class," but this announcement indicated that the prize was of great importance, both from the standpoint of damaging Japanese operations and of crippling Japanese morale.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Charles A. Lindbergh, who recently applied for an appointment by the Air Corps, from which he resigned last year as a colonel in the Reserves, will undertake research work for the War Department in a civilian capacity, Secretary Stimson said today.

Otis Skinner, dean of the American stage and reputed to be one of the wealthiest members of the profession, left all of his estate but $4,000 to his daughter, Mrs. Cornelia Otis Skinner Blodget of St. James, L.I., and named her sole executor.

Twentieth Century-Fox's mystery thriller, "I Wake Up Screaming," which is based on the novel by Steve Fisher, will be the new attraction this morning at the Roxy. Betty Grable, Victor Mature, Carole Landis and Laird Cregar head the picture's cast.

Larry MacPhail and Leo Durochef, whose combined talents last Summer brought Brooklyn its first pennant in twenty-one years, held their momentous meeting yesterday but, upon the solemn word of both parties, the even more momentous matter of Lippy Leo's 1942 contract "wasn't even discussed."

In the present crisis the problem is not whether capital or labor is going to save democracy, but whether, in terms of brass tacks, we are going to have enough airplanes to keep this country from being dominated by a foreign military machine.

Walter Kinsella, one of the greatest players of racquet games developed in this country, gave an amazing performance last night to defeat Lester Cummings of the Union Club, national professional squash racquets champion, in an exhibition for the benefit of the Red Cross at Midston House. The score was 15 -- 11, 15 -- 9, 18 -- 16.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- British planes, resuming offensive operations over Germany and German-occupied territory, made a concentrated raid during the night on Hamburg, Germany's greatest port, and rained bombs on other objectives.

TOKYO, Jan. 15 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press in New York) -- Japanese Imperial Headquarters claimed today that forty United States Curtiss combat planes were destroyed in a Japanese aerial attack yesterday on Denarpian airfield in Western Luzon, the Philippines.

The New York Stock Exchange on Jan. 29 will consider transfers of memberships from Raymond J. Bechdol to Edward S. Moore and from Alexander Carleton to Charles Tifft, the former for $24,000 and the latter for $22,000. On the same day it will consider William F. Luce as an alternate for Charles H. Wisher and John J. Anglim as an alternate for William E. Hutton.

The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., is capable of and will continue to police its members and will discipline them "according to the degree of abuse in which they indulge," Wallace H. Fulton, executive director, told the board of governors of the association yesterday at the annual meeting held in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The scarcity of news from Singapore and officially inspired warnings that bad tidings must be expected from the Western Pacific led to the belief in some quarters today that Britain now had hopes of holding only little of Malaya beyond Singapore itself.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- German soldiers are under orders to exterminate Russians and destroy all abjects of cultural or historical value, the Soviet Information Bureau said today in a communique broadcast by the Moscow radio.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board gave authority today for Pan American Airways, Inc., to establish a new route between New York and Lisbon.

In conjunction with its Latin-American Fair, R.H. Macy Co. will conduct a poster contest for New York boys and girls under 17 years of age. The contest will be held from tomorrow through Feb. 21, with a total of $115 in cash prizes.

"All-out" cooperation with the newly created National War Labor Board in its effort to promote industrial harmony in war industries was promised yesterday by Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service, Department of Labor.

"Strato Lizzie," the famous flying cat and mascot of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., has disappeared for the second time. All through the day, yesterday, the highly pitched cries of "here kitty, kitty," resounded in the executive offices and the hangars of TWA at La Guardia Airport.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Possibility of a sea-borne attack on the west coast of Malaya by British Imperials massing in Burma, to provide direct aid to Singapore's defenders, was discussed by observers today after official revelation that an offensive from Burma was now possible.

Ruth Winston, the milliner whose establishment has heretofore occupied quarters on West Fifty-seventh Street, has leased for a new shop the store and basement in 25 East Fifty-fourth Street through the Harold C. Samuels Company, broker.

Mrs. Jacob Hekma, in 277 Park lave; Dr. Hortense Powderrnaker, j in 401 E 52d St; Miss Barry lVfarka, I ]W_rs. Ida Lampel, in 21 W 5gth St; i Mannie R. Hoffman, in 955 5th i Ave; Morris Jaffe, in 25 E 86th St, !through Douglas L. Elliman Co; !Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, brbkers.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- A warning that Great Britain must "at all times be alive to the possibilities of inflation which are ever present" was sounded in the statement of Edwin Fisher, chairman of the board of directors of Barclays Bank, Ltd., and made public today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 -- Imperial air forces fought numerous combats over the Agedabia-El Agheila area yesterday in an effort to maintain Britain's initiative in Libyan skies, threatened for the first time since the offensive began by recent arrival of German planes in Tripolitania.

The fifteen-acre estate known as "Stonybrook," on Feeks Lane, Lattingtown, L.I., has been sold by Mrs. Agnes Pyne McLean to Alfred P. Parker of the Hotel Plaza, New York. On the place is a Georgian-type residence of more than fifteen rooms, a three-car garage, a swimming pool and a tennis court.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Governor Lehman submitted to the Legislature today, with bi-partisan approval, a drastic program for the strengthening of civilian defense in the State. It ranges from the possible removal from office of public officials who do not cooperate in civilian defense to a rigid speed limit on the highways to conserve gasoline, tires and cars.
The Chicago Black Hawks handed the Brooklyn Americans their third successive setback when they toppled Red Dutton's skaters in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

A hint that rationing will have to be extended to some articles of ordinary everyday use in the stocks of large and small retail stores was given last night by A.A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, in an address at the annual dinner of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Governor Lehman signed today the first bill of the 1942 legislative session, the Todd bill suspending until a year after the war the requirement that only registered and licensed nurses be permitted to practice in the State.

HONOLULU, Jan. 15 -- Hawaii would be strictly on a war basis for a long time, requiring many sacrifices of all residents, Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons, commanding general of the Hawaiian Department and Military Governor of the islands, told the annual meeting of the Honolulu Chamber of Commerce today in a frank lecture on what must be expected in this front line of America's Pacific war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- "Calling Manila," a photoplay by Sam Engel, will be Pat O'Brien's first picture at Twentieth Century- Fox under a contract signed a year ago. The story deals with two Army telephone engineers in the Philippines, and Irving Pichel will direct, starting on Feb. 6. O'Brien previously had been announced for "Highway to Hell" at Fox, but the picture was abandoned last October because of scenario difficulty.

Acting on new Federal orders, three Internal Revenue offices in the city began yesterday general sale of motor vehicle use tax stamps. Five hundred stamps representing $2.09 tax payments for Feb. 1 to July 1 were reported bought by automobile owners.

Permit me to take exception to "Inquirer's" bewilderment: The fact that he is puzzled by the term German-American may result from stupidity or ignorance. Assuming that he never heard of the contributions of our foreign elements to the United States, may one, who is proud of his cultural background, give "Inquirer" this information:

Continued buying by the trade lifted prices of cotton futures moderately yesterday in active trading. On the New York Cotton Exchange the net gains were 12 to 14 points over Wednesday's close, The January contract, however, which goes off the board at noon today, finished nominally at 18.10 cents, up 24 points, with no trades recorded.

One hundred and thirty-one members of the Police Department have applied for retirement since Dec. 15. And with the Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund not scheduled to sit until Monday afternoon it was expected yesterday that more names would be added to what is now the largest number of retirement applications ever filed in one month in the history of the department.

An all-time record production of 492,754,000 pairs was reached by the shoe industry in 1941, according to an estimate issued yesterday by the Tanners Council. This would be a gain of 21.9 per cent over the 1940 output. The highest previous total production was in 1939 when 424,126,000 pairs were produced.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Great Britain, to speed the flow of American supplies in the Middle East, moved today to implement plans for an all-American port in Iran.

Jeremiah D. Maguire, president of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, in his annual report to stockholders, states that earnings in 1941 were equivalent to 20 cents a share. Capital and surplus were unchanged during the year at $825,000 and $1,075,000 respectively, and undivided profits, on Dec. 31 were $306,766, compared with $213,384 one year before.

The Philadelphia Opera Company will make its first transcontinental tour of this country next season under the exclusive management of S. Hurok, it was announced yesterday in a statement made jointly by Mr. Hurok and the company.

The National Retail Dry Goods Association pledged its "complete cooperation to the government" in the prosecution of the war and at the same time voiced its emphatic disapproval of any move to federalize Social Security in two of five resolutions adopted last night.

Ray Robinson will take his second crack at Fritzie Zivic, former welterweight champion of the world, at Madison Square Garden tonight. The undefeated Harlem boxer, who subdued the former class ruler last October in a ten-round clash, will undertake to repeat over the twelve-round route in the return affray.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- An English aviation cadet, Derek M. Sharp of Yorkshire, rode an airplane's rudder to earth rather than jump, and said afterward that the ride was "pretty comfortable" and "anyway" he had seen it happen before in England.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The War Department issued the following communique today, based on reports received up to 10:30 A.M.:

Whatever may be the case for or against the closed shop, there is no possible case for the closed union. A union is not a social club. No union should be allowed to exclude competent workers from its membership either by arbitrarily limiting its numbers or by excessive and unreasonable entrance requirements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- George Hill, second secretary of Representative Hamilton Fish of New York, was convicted today of committing perjury before a grand jury investigating Nazi activities in the United States, and was held without bail tonight.

Women's role in the defense of England, China and the Netherlands East Indies was outlined yesterday by representatives of the three countries at a reception meeting held under the auspices of the world emergency committee of the Young Women's Christian Association in the home of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie, 2 East Ninety-first Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- Willie Hoppe, for two years three-cushion billiard champion, tonight was beaten by Arthur Rubin of Brooklyn, 50 to 39, in thirty-nine innings. It was Hoppe's first loss of the 1942 championship tourney and his second defeat in his last three years of tournament competition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Navy called on a group of leading educators today to assist in working out an athletic program designed to keep the nation's sea fighters in top trim.

KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 14 (Delayed) -- Details of bestial treatment accorded Russian prisoners in German camps in the Polish "Government-General" have been given to this correspondent by a non-Russian diplomatic source. The story is lightened only by touching examples of Polish fraternization, often at great risk.

Recommendations designed to save more than $10,000,000 in the 1942-43 budget of the Board of Education have been presented by Thomas H. Doyle as president of the Midtown Real Estate Association to Ellsworth B. Buck, chairman of the finance committee of the board.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 15 -- Two points strike competent foreign observers here with regard to events on the Russian front. One is that the fighting is described by German sources as "the great Winter defensive battle" and the other is the stress laid in both Berlin and Rome on the difficulties that face Axis troops.

The Wendel Foundation has sold through its agent, the Cross Brown Company, and Popper Brothers, co-brokers, to the Newark Realty Company, the north blockfront on Springfield Avenue between Bruce Street and Morris Avenue, Newark, N.J., now improved with a number of small structures including a gasoline service station and a bar and grill.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 15 -- In the Palacio Tiradentes, where Congress formerly met, President Getulio Vargas this afternoon opened the conference of American Foreign Ministers with an inaugural address punctuated by enthusiastic applause from delegates and from the crowded visitors' galleries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The War Department announced today that the United States and Filipino forces on Luzon Island were successfully withstanding further Japanese attacks, and that gunners at the fortress on Corregidor Island had bagged two of nine Japanese heavy bombers.

Opposition to a self-sustaining rapid transit system is stated in a letter by Bernard Rifkin in your issue of Jan. 14. The contention is made that such a step, involving an increase in fares, is at the expense of millions of subway riders for the benefit of a relatively small number of taxpayers.

The Louisville Nashville Railroad's traffic is running about 12 per cent ahead of last year's levels and close to last December's levels, James B. Hill, president, said yesterday. He added that cold weather increased the coal movement last week.

Beekman Hospital has signed a contract for the purchase of the property at 216-18 Water Street as the site for an addition designed particularly to serve possible war emergency needs in the downtown district, Howard S. Cullman, president of the institution, announced yesterday.

A landscape by Corot brought $3,300 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the art collection of the late Emil Winterof Pittsburgh, Pa., The session, devoted to pictures, yielded $30,190, making the total for the first two sessions of the auction $46,760.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 15 -- The National War Council met today, studied Pacific strategy, received reports from Chiefs of Staff on the war policy of the United Nations and took measures to block the Japanese southward drive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- While Donald M. Nelson was working upon the draft of an executive order formally establishing the new War Production Board and providing for reorganization of the armaments set-up, Senator Taft demanded in the Senate that Mr. Nelson's power should be made statutory.

Breaking many hours of silence during which the Navy had refused to confirm or deny widely circulated reports of the sinking of another tanker off the South Shore of Long Island early yesterday, a spokesman for the Navy Department announced late last night that a thorough check with naval and Coast Guard officials had failed to produce any confirmation of the sinking.

Latin-American nations are so interested in developing the export market in this country that one "very important" nation has created a post in its Ministry of Production for an American industrial designer to assist it in catering to American consumers, Raymond Loewy, industrial designer, disclosed yesterday.

A uniform air raid signal that can be sounded by the various types of equipment in the Second Civilian Defense Region, including New York City, New York State, New Jersey and Delaware, was adopted yesterday at a conference of the region's general staff and attended by James M. Landis, newly appointed Civilian Defense Executive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment to its registration statement, disclosing the intention of holders of 321,996 shares of outstanding capital stock, $5 par value, to sell them on the New York Curb Exchange or the over-the-counter market.

BERLIN, Switzerland, Jan. 15 -- Berlin sources today make much of the "French Legion of Volunteers Against Bolshevism," which, they say, is enrolling many men, especially in the unoccupied zone of France. But they add rather significantly that no figures are available.

Bank clearings of the twenty- three major cities of the nation increased 16.6 per cent in the week ended on Wednesday to $6,531,193,000 from $5,599,342,000 for the corresponding week a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
A formal preview of Macy's Latin-American Fair, which will have its public opening tomorrow morning, will be held for about 1,000 distinguished guests tonight at the store, 34th Street and Broadway.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Frederick Gunster were hosts today at a tea and preview of the second exhibit at the Four Arts, one of tempera and water-colors of outstanding homes by graduate students of the New York School of Fine and Applied Arts arranged by Van Day Truex, former head of the Paris branch.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday the details of the coming sale of $50,000,000 of New York City serial bonds and assessment bonds and at the same time set noon next Tuesday as the time at which bids will be opened in his office.

Fritz Busch directed the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for the first time at its concert given last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Busch, sixth of the guest conductors to appear with the organization this season, came to the podium fresh from his recent triumphs with the New Opera Company in this city.

New York University opened its wrestling season with an 18-14 victory over Brooklyn College yesterday on the Violet's mats. The meet was marred by an injury suffered by Phil Mirenda of Brooklyn College in a 128-pound match with Don Barry.

The needs of the Army, in the vital fields of clothing and equipage for the men, are not known either to the Army or to the OPM, and no man is now able or will be able in the near future to predict these needs, according to Lieut. Col. Vere Painter of the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot.

Merchandise shortages due to defense restrictions are not likely to really pinch retail trade until the third and last quarters of this year, Edwin I. Marks, vice president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., said yesterday at the apparel merchandising session of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Actions against Serge Rubinstein, international financier, proceeded yesterday on two fronts. In Special Term, Part One, of the New York State Supreme Court Andre Rubinstein filed a motion asking for a receivership and an injunction restraining Serge Rubinstein from removing the assets of the Chosen Corporation and its affiliated companies from this jurisdiction.

Shares on the Stock Exchange drifted yesterday in the dullest session since mid-October and closed on an irregular tone. Traders apparently could find no factors in the news to encourage any general activity and, as a result, sales on the Stock Exchange slumped to 446,770 shares against the Wednesday total of 610,100.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 15 -- The conference of American Foreign Ministers, which will determine the course of the entire Western Hemisphere toward the war and the Axis Powers, opened late today in the impressive meeting place of the Brazilian Chamber of Deputies.

In an effort to bring before its members the necessity of proper nutrition and clothing for children in wartime, the United Kindergarten Mothers of New York is holding a kindergarten festival today and tomorrow at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The war is "likely to last for at least five years," 200 bankers and corporate contributors to the Economists National Committee on Monetary Policy heard here last night at an invitation dinner at the Commodore Hotel. Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, speaking as the Republican member of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, made the prediction.

TOKYO, Jan. 15 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Japanese troops driving down the west side of the Malay Peninsula crossed the border into Johore State last night and occupied the strategic railway junction of Gemas, Imperial Army Headquarters announced today.

JULIA TRUITT YENNI'S "House for the Sparrow"* is a deft, spun-sugar novel about one of those antic families that seldom let an author or a reader down. And in telling the story of the crazy Larbells, who have a "sort of rubbery independence," Miss Yenni provides a judgment on her own fiction. "What can I say about them?" asks Paul Lawrence, a school teacher, as he hands Clara Larbell's children's stories back to her.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Department store sales continued to show a heavy increase, rising 32 per cent during the week ended Jan. 10 over the like week last year after having risen 26 per cent, according to revised figures, in the previous week's comparison, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Predictions of a serious crisis in the Churchill Government if Singapore fell were made today at two ends of the British Empire. In both Britain and Australia, demands were made for the government to explain why Malaya had not been strengthened earlier.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Russian dispatches said tonight that Marshal Semyon Timoshenko's southern armies had pierced a ring of German forts outside the big Ukraine industrial city of Khartov and had landed troops west of Taganrog on the Sea of Azov.

LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Note circulation showed a decrease of more than 6,000,000 in the Bank of England statement issued today. This was the second week a decline was shown after increasing steadily for the previous eighteen weeks.

It is not clear from Bernard Rifkin's letter to you published in your paper today whether he has read the report of the Committee of Fifteen, to the conclusions of which he objects. At any rate, he attempts to make two points: that the recommendation for an increased fare would not solve "the transit problem" or the "financial problem" of the city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The quantities of materials allocated by the United States for the use of Latin America thus far in the first quarter of this year were revealed today by Douglas MacKeachie, director of the Division of Purchases of the Office of Production Management.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Government deposits decreased $32,543,000 to $60,862,000 in the week ended yesterday, the Bank of Canada reported today in its weekly statement. Notes in circulation decreased $7,554,000 to $482,597,000.

The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, at a special meeting yesterday went on record in favor of a general sales tax to be imposed at the point of final sale, as a means to help pay for the war. It was said that such a tax, if imposed, would be about 3 per cent and would be levied on all heavy as well as consumer products.

A drive to raise $75,000 among New York's 200,000 municipal employes for the 1942 "Fight Infantile Paralysis" campaign was launched yesterday by Almerindo Portfolio, City Treasurer and chairman of the drive, at a luncheon of heads of municipal departments and employe organizations.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by the Associated Press in New York) -- Adolf Hitler tonight appointed Dr. Hans Fischboeck as Reich Commissioner of Prices with the rank of Secretary of State. He succeeds Gauleiter Joseph Wagner, who had held the position since 1936.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 14 (Delayed) -- The first major phase of the Battle of Malaya has been concluded and the second is getting under way.

Torpedoed without warning by a submarine commander who leisurely circled his victim and fired three torpedoes into her at ten-minute intervals, the Panama tanker Norness of 9,577 tons was sunk with the loss of two of her crew of forty men early yesterday morning, about sixty miles southeast of Montauk Point.
BERLIN, Jan. 15 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique issued today said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The documented charges of widespread incompetence in the government's war effort, published by the Truman committee today, bring to mind that many conspicuously able citizens are unemployed in it. As administrators, production and procurement experts and possessors of great qualities of leadership they have revealed their talents in definite ways.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- OPM announced today that the War and Navy Departments have worked out a plan for the coordination of their purchases of cotton duck, the first program of its kind.

WITH AUSTRALIAN ARMY IN MALAYA, Jan. 14 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Hardbitten Australian troops, trained in jungle warfare, now are at the front in Western Malaya, where they have joined British and Indian units for a showdown with the Japanese sweeping toward Singapore.

A further increase in earning assets was shown by the regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

TOKYO, Jan. 15 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in London and New York) -Imperial Headquarters said today that Japanese submarines had sunk four ships totaling 37,000 tons in Netherlands Indies waters and that Japanese naval units had captured three enemy merchantmen in the same waters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- With Reconstruction Finance Corporation help, Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator, has placed contracts to increase to about 71,300 barrels the daily output of high-octane aviation gasoline in the United States, and negotiations are on for further contracts to bring the daily output up to 150,000 barrels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, the Selective Service Director, said today it would be necessary to draw from the 9,000,000 men between 20 and 44, inclusive, who will register Feb. 16, to achieve this year the Army strength of 3,600,000 men announced earlier in the day by Secretary Stimson.

HONOLULU, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- About $4,000,000 of the $15,000,000 allocated to Hawaii for civilian defense would be used for hospital and other medical defense needs throughout the Territory, Guy J. Swope, director of the Interior Department's Division of Territories and Island Possessions, said here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Army will be more than doubled to reach a total of 3,600,000 men by the end of this year, with plans for further expansion in 1943, Secretary Stimson stated today.

Four hundred and forty-one midshipmen will be commissioned as ensigns at 10:30 A.M. today at graduation ceremonies aboard the Prairie State at 136th Street and the Hudson River, it was announced here yesterday at naval headquarters.

Owners of tankers operating on the East Coast have received an order from the United States Government to divert twenty-five of their vessels to the Pacific Coast. About two weeks ago an order for fifteen tankers was received. It is understood that the first request has been complied with and that these vessels are on their way to the Pacific Coast.

In reporting a total of $3,075,000 collected so far in the Red Cross War Fund drive of Greater New York, Chairman Leon Fraser also announced yesterday that contributions throughout the country toward the national goal of $50,000,000 already had reached a total of $26,661,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Ninety-nine and ninety-nine hundredths per cent of the newspapers and radio stations approve voluntary censorship of information that might be helpful to the Axis nations, Byron Price, director of censorship, said at a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Following Senate action on the price control bill providing for higher farm price ceilings, agricultural commodity markets rose sharply, carrying the general level of wholesale prices to a new twelve-year peak for the week ended Jan. 10, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
DETROIT, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The automobile industry struck back tonight at the Senate defense investigating committee which has accused it of hampering defense production.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15 -- Charitable bequests amounting to $60,000 were made to local institutions by the Countess de Perigny, the former Margaret Thaw Carnegie, who died last Jan. 9 in Keyna Colony, British East Africa. Her will was filed for probate today.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Polish Naval Headquarters in London said today that the Polish submarine Sokol had attacked five enemy vessels, sinking one medium-sized supply ship and probably sinking a large destroyer.

BATAVIA, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- With Amboina raided by the Japanese today, military experts here believed that the base there was marked, along with the Borneo oil port of Balik Papan, for the next invasion attempts.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles of the United States and Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu of Argentina consulted for twenty-five minutes today in the Argentine's hotel room.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- A two-week search for an Army bomber which disappeared near Cajon Pass in Southern California with a crew of nine ended today in the finding of the plane in wild country on the northeast slope of Keller Peak, about half way between Big Bear Lake and Lake Arrowhead.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Top-seeded Wayne Sabin, former Davis Cup star from Portland, Ore., was forced to three sets today to eliminate Billy Gillespie of Miami, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, in the quarter-finals of the University of Miami's annual tennis tournament.
