Ski conditions in the North Country, according to last night's reports, are comparable to the best the season has had to offer thus far. The running still is favorable at most high points, such as the Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Butterfly Wu, movie queen of China, was killed by shrapnel during the siege of Hong Kong, press reports said tonight.

DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- The fighting planes which America needs so urgently now cannot be turned out on the same scale as automobiles until the automotive engineer understands the aims and methods of the aircraft engineer, according to John C. Widman of the aircraft division of the Murray Corporation of America.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Jan. 16 -- Russian troops in the Valdai sector struck hard at the German lines yesterday, and after a series of heavy cavalry charges captured the important town of Selizharovo, south of Lake Seliger, according to the Russian midnight communique, which added that the Germans had suffered extremely heavy losses, particularly in men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Roosevelt conferred with Sidney Hillman, associate director general of the Office of Production Management, and Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator, with Governor Homer M. Atkins of Arkansas, and with Keith Morgan, chairman of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Sir Thomas Beecham and Johann Sebastian Bach made a joint debut last night with the Metropolitan Opera Association. Sir Thomas's appearance was a consequence of brilliant previous achievements in symphonic music in America, and in opera, as well, abroad.

TOKYO, Jan. 15 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Prisoners' Intelligence Bureau announced that 432 persons captured at the United States island of Guam, including Captain George J. McMillin, the Governor, arrived at Shikoku today and were interned at barracks in the city of Zentsuji.

Frank M. Mayfield, head of Scruggs-Vandervoort-Barney, Inc., St. Louis, was re-elected president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the annual convention of the organization at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday. This will be Mr. Mayfield's third term as president of the association, whose members comprise 5,800 department stores and specialty shops doing an annual volume of business of about $5,000,000,000.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 15 -- Australian troops apparently held in reserve throughout all the past five weeks of bitter fighting down the jungle trails of Malaya now are in action against the Japanese invaders above Johore State, the British announced tonight.

Continuing in the top form he displayed in four previous matches, Donald M. Frame of the Harvard Club, No. 1 seeded player, won the eighth annual New York State squash racquets championship last night at the Downtown A.C. The successor to Stanley Galowin, 1941 king, who did not compete this year, turned back Richard S. Rothschild of the home club, ranked second, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 6, 18 -- 15.

Four new government housing projects providing modern homes for 2,943 additional low-income families were completed in New York last year, Gerard Swope, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, reported yesterday in a letter to Mayor La Guardia, outlining the Authority's future plans and reviewing the work done in 1941.

A well-rounded presentation of one designer's thoughts on a Spring wardrobe for the sophisticated woman was presented at the Cotillion Room luncheon in the Hotel Pierre yesterday noon. The designer was Jo Copeland, the exhibitor Rose Amado, whose establishment is at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 15 -- Saguenay II and He Rolls were the long-shot winners of the two divisions of the Alhambra Purse, features today at Hialeah Park, where attendance and betting again showed sharp gains over last year's record figures.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- A tentative wartime agreement under which shipyard workers of the Pacific Coast will go on a six-day, forty-eight-hour week and receive double time in emergency cases when they are called upon to work on their day off, whether that day is Sunday or a weekday, was announced here today by spokesmen for the Federal Government, labor and management.

Speed boat racing in all its variations -- inboard hydroplanes and runabouts, outboards and even cruisers -- will be continued during 1942 as usual. This was the hope expressed yesterday at the Hotel Lexington, where a day-long series of American Power Boat Association gatherings culminated in the annual election last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- J. Penfield Seiberling, president of the Seiberling Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio, told the House Small Business Committee today that United States rubber supplies were large enough to meet military and "essential" civilian needs for two years, even though imports might be stopped.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- German submarine activity on the East Coast marked by the reported sinking today of a second tanker in two days, has been anticipated and follows the historical pattern of the World War.

An exhibition of paintings, mostly of children or juvenile subjects, entitled "The Little Shavers and Some That Are Grown Up," opened yesterday at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, for the benefit of Bundles for Britain, Inc.
ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Following is the text of the special message of Governor Lehman to the Legislature:

Hitler could not possibly have timed his latest move in the Battle of the Atlantic in a more dramatic manner. On the very eve of the Pan-American Conference at Rio, within a few hours of the time set for the opening of the most critical meeting in the whole history of the American republics, the German Navy begins a submarine attack at the very gates of New York harbor.

NORTH WOODSTOCK, N.H., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Breaking their way through five miles of snow-covered woodland, a volunteer rescue party brought to safety today five of a seven-man crew of an Army bomber which crashed into a mountainside last night, killing two of its occupants.

The bill market, which the Treasury utilizes in maintaining its desired cash balance without resorting to large-scale borrowing, will return next week to routine sales, it was disclosed yesterday. Last November, following the lifting of reserve requirements of member banks by the Federal Reserve Board, the Treasury allowed banks to pay for the Treasury bills with government funds on deposit with them, so-called "war loans."

Automobile dealers in the metropolitan are awaited details on Federal car rationing with great anxiety last night as local tire rationing boards were informed that they would also handle automobile rationing.
Recruiting showed an increase yesterday over the day before, with the total number of applicants in the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard reaching 1,242.

A speaker at the January meeting of the New York Society of Teachers Dancing, Inc., explained clearly the difference between the rumba and the samba. The New York public, as Senor Guido Zanette intimated, too often assume that they are the same. The samba, which is danced by the Brazilian peasants at the Samba Festival, held this month in Brazil, is, according to our own reporter, "lively and marked by jollity."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- House and Senate conferees began discussion today of differences in the two drafts of the House Price Control Bill in a leisurely manner, indicating that it would be next week before an agreement can be presented to the two houses for final action.

Despite a year of record-breaking activity, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, as parent concern of the Bell System, had in 1941 a net income slightly below that of the preceding year, according to the company's preliminary report for last year, made public yesterday by Walter S. Gifford, president.

Investments in new mortgage loans on real estate in Manhattan last year were greater than in any of the five preceding years, the monthly survey of the Real Estate Board of New York indicates. Last year investors placed $52,688,581 in 1,537 loans, as compared with $40,290,779 in 1,591 loans in 1940.

TRENTON, Jan. 15 -- Commercial interests joined private consumers today in protesting a scheduled increase of one cent a quart in the retail price of milk. The increase, effective Jan. 26, was ordered on Monday by State Milk Director Arthur F. Foran, who said it was necessary if the dairy industry in the State was to meet the increased production costs resulting from the war.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 15 -- The United States will win in the present war but not before reverses and bloodshed have been experienced, Mayor La Guardia of New York City told the South Carolina Municipal Association at its annual convention today.

Farmers from nine States, who gathered yesterday at the Hotel Barbizor-Plaza with field and headquarters officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to discuss their part in the war effort, heard two Department of Agriculture chiefs urge greater crop regulation than ever before and discussed means of meeting a farm labor shortage.

Awards for engineering construction in the current week amount to $83,262,000, a decline of 41 per cent from a week ago and 7 per cent under the volume for the corresponding week a year ago. Public construction is 44 per cent lower than last week, but 42 per cent higher than in the corresponding week in 1941 as a result of the 114 per cent gain in Federal work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The State Department has deleted the names of seventeen firms and individuals doing business in six Latin-American countries from previously published blacklists of concerns with whom trading is forbidden on the ground that they are benefiting the Axis.

Setting a minimum goal for New York State of $10,000,000 a month in defense bonds to be sold through the payroll savings plan alone, the New York defense savings staff reported yesterday to the Treasury Department that, on the basis of incomplete reports, more than 5,000 concerns, representing 3,000,000 employes in the State, already were participating in the plan.

A South American exhibition of Ancient Arts and Crafts was opened yesterday by Gimbel Brothers with a luncheon and short-wave good-neighbor broadcast to Latin America. The exhibition, held in conjunction with the Gimbel Centennial Celebration, consists of pre-Incan and pre-Columbian art as well as art of the early colonial period.

Chemical Fund, Inc., a mutual investment company of the management type, specializing in chemical shares, will announce today a special offering of 263,000 shares of its capital stock to be made simultaneously to stockholders of the fund and to the general public.

Advertising linage of newspapers in fifty-two cities measured by Media Records wound up 1941 with a gain of 3.5 per cent over the previous year, as against an increase of 2.0 per cent in 1940 over 1939. All classifications registered an increase, except automotive.

There is one information agency whose services the plain citizen has always found indispensable in the conduct of his life, and especially so in serious hours like the present. That agency is himself. The more the information offices in Washington contradict each other or themselves the more the citizen will depend on his own information agency.

After many rumors concerning the activities of Howard Lindsay and Russel McKinley Crouse, definite word came yesterday from the Oscar Serlin office that the talented team has been tapping the typewriter keys on behalf of a new play called "Strip for Action," which Serlin will submit in the Spring.

VICHY, France, Jan. 15 -- A declaration by a German Minister is reported to have said that Germany would not force any nation to "collaborate," but that those countries which do not choose to do so would not find places in the "new order."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- With many Assemblymen convinced that Congress will help pay for protecting defense plants on the West Coast, a group in California's lower house, in caucus today, agreed on general provisions of a new State Guard bill which would drastically alter a measure passed by the State Senate last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- After seven years of litigation, the terms of reorganization of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company were again brought before the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

In his message sent to Congress on Wednesday Mr. Roosevelt invited it to reform certain inveterate practices. In every Congress more than 2,000 bills to pay private personal claims are introduced. Some 400 pass. He estimates that the passage of every such bill costs $200, often more than the claim.

Miss Maria Lenk, the Brazilian swimming sensation who has been breaking or approaching records during the past month on her United States tour, last night shattered another mark in a Women's Swimming Association meet in the London Terrace 75-foot pool. It was by way of being a celebration, as she reached her twenty-eighth birthday yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Free French movement, has been asked to settle the issue over the occupation of St. Pierre and Miquelon by withdrawing his ships from these islands at the mouth of the St. Lawrence River while the people there vote on whether they wish Free French or Vichy leadership.

News on the food front takes on a bluer and bleaker tone today with the announcement by the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets that all kinds of meat have advanced in price in the last week.

A sallow, slim young man with a pleasant drawling voice, who was arrested yesterday during an attempt to hold up a finance company on midtown Broadway, revealed under police questioning early this morning that he used the money from a previous hold-up of the same company for a flying trip to Beverly Hills, Calif., to rob the home of Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt during a wedding reception for her daughter.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies Jan. 15 (AP) -- Japanese planes struck deep into the Netherlands Indies today to raid the Amboina naval and air base, second in importance only to Surabaya in the archipelago's defense system.

TOKYO, Jan. 15 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Imperial Headquarters today detailed a series of far-flung sir operations, with attacks on the Molucca island group of the Netherlands Indies, including the naval base at Amboina; Baba and Sorong, on the western end of New Guinea, and New Britain, in Australia's Bismarck Archipelago.

When Secretary Jones announced that steps will be taken at once to pluck rubber out of the air, petroleum, natural and other gases no one was astonished. That we shall have to make use of what is miscalled "synthetic rubber" was a foregone conclusion.

George C. Stoddard, 45 years old, an advisory member of the OPM Automotive, Agricultural, Farm and Implement Board in Washington and a secretary-director of the DeLaval Separator Company, Inc., at 165 Broadway, and some of its subsidiaries, pleaded guilty yesterday in Felony Court to the charge of having possessed an air pistol on New Year's Eve in a bar at 2 Greenwich Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Declaring that events since Pearl Harbor had materially broadened demands for American food, the Agriculture Department increased today its 1942 production goals for hogs, corn for livestock feed, oil-bearing crops, rice, eggs, dry beans and vegetable crops for canning.
Mrs. De Witt L. Alexandre gave a luncheon yesterday at La Salle du Bois for Mrs. R. Stuyvesant Pierrepont Jr. and Miss Mary Louise Lord.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Byron Nelson of Toledo, Ohio, shot a three-under-par 67 today to lead the field at the end of the first round of the $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament. The former United States open and P.G.A. champion posted 33, 34 to start the 72-hole route.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The House completed Congressional action today on a defense housing program which would expand to $900,000,000 government authorizations for constructing dwellings and acquiring community facilities. The bill was passed unanimously by the Senate yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Considerable progress has been made in the last forty-eight hours in establishing machinery to coordinate the war effort of the United States and Great Britain.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Reorganized imperial forces countered the Japanese on land and in the air in Western Malaya today, defeating a tank-paced infantry column in Negri Sembilan State and strewing fiery destruction through Port Swettenham behind the enemy lines.

VALLETTA, Malta, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Fourteen air alarms in the last twenty-four hours boosted Malta's total since the war began to 1,285 -- a total that is all the more impressive in view of the fact that it has failed to shatter the morale of either the defense forces or the civilian population.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Office of Production Management asked a Senate subcommittee today to approve legislation that would empower the Interstate Commerce Commission to override State regulations on limits on sizes and weights of trucks crossing State lines.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 15 -- Following is the text of the address by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State of the United States, at the meeting today of Foreign Ministers of the American republics:

As part of the war program of the National League of Women Voters formulated at a series of special conferences held in Indianapolis last week, the New York League announced yesterday the opening of a survey on consumer information to be conducted by local units throughout the State.

SPOKANE, Wash, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Two officers and seven enlisted men were killed in the crash of an Army bomber thirteen miles southeast of Boise, Idaho, late yesterday, Second Air Force headquarters announced tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 15 -- Dr. Carl E. Badgley of the University of Michigan Medical School took office today as president of the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons at the final session of its tenth annual convention at the hotel Chalfonte-Haddon Hall.

Convinced that elaborate coiffeurs will have no place in the war-minded woman's scheme of things, Madame Pauline introduced a predominant number of curl-crushing chapeaux yesterday afternoon in her salon at 6 East Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (U.P.) -- Plans have been perfected for a $50,000,000 reserve food stock program for Hawaii, Puerto Rico, Alaska and the Virgin Islands, to enable them to withstand any interruption of communications, it was disclosed tonight, the money, provided in part by Congress and from President Roosevelt's emergency fund, to be used to fill warehouses with essential foodstuffs required by the special needs of each area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Waste, inefficiency, self-interest and failures in the national defense program were charged today in a report by the Senate's special investigating committee. The indictment was so extensive -- criticizing persons and conditions both inside and outside of the government -- that calls came from the Senate floor for a fixing of "criminal" responsibility.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Only 10,000 of the 70,000 Japanese hurled against Changsha escaped the frontal and encircling counter-offensive of the Chinese, an Army spokesman said today, and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek called it only the beginning of greater triumphs to come for the United Nations.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 15 -- The Rio de Janeiro conference virtually monopolizes interest in the Argentine press. Many newspapers dedicate their whole front pages to it.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- The future of the Blue Network Company, Inc., as an indispensable part of the American broadcasting system is assured, James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today of affiliates of the newly organized chain at a luncheon here.

Reporting on operations in the ten months ended with October, H.N. Mallon, president of the Dresser Manufacturing Company, informed stockholders in the annual report that sales at $11,777,299 compared with $11,833,753 for the full twelve months of the preceding year.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:

Fifty farm women joined their husbands for the first time yesterday in a practical discussion of the agricultural war effort because, according to Mrs. Ralph Y. DeWolfe of Oneida, N.Y., "we've just got to realize how hard the men are working to make this country raise what must be raised for the war."

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The free governments of Greece and Yugoslavia made a far-reaching agreement in London today for mutual support after the war. It not only provides for the closest cooperation between Yugoslavia and Greece but expresses the belief that it should become the basis for a union of the Balkans.

The only bit of living flesh that has been artificially endowed with "eternal youth" will celebrate today the thirtieth anniversary of its "immortality" in its ultra-modern glass-jar "Olympus" in the Division of Virus Research of the Lederle Laboratories at Pearl River, Rockland County, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Speaking in the House today, Representative Dies asserted that Archibald MacLeish's Office of Facts and Figures employed as chief information analyst last week at an $8,000 salary "one of the chief communist intellectuals of this country," in the person of Malcolm Cowley, a New York writer.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The British today made another administrative change in commands as a result of the outbreak of war in the Far East when they transferred responsibility for Iraq and Iran -- both occupied by British forces -- to General Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck, commander in chief of the Middle Eastern forces.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 15 -- Chinese official sources at Kunming, terminus of the Burma Road, reported today that the American Volunteer Group of airmen had bagged ninety to one hundred Japanese planes since the outbreak of the Pacific war last month.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The stock markets were unsettled today by the news from the Far East, sales were small but most price movements were adverse for holders. Gilt-edge issues were firm. Industrials saw United Molasses affected by profit-taking and the Dunlops closed at 30 3/8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Under new regulations, each of the 1,100,000 German, Italian and Japanese aliens in the United States, who are 14 years old or more, will be required to obtain next month an identification card carrying a photograph, signature and index fingerprint, Attorney General Biddle stated today.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A bank becomes legally liable when it honors forged endorsements on checks against a depositor's account, the Court of Appeals ruled today. The court reversed, 3 to 2, an Appellate Division decision authorizing the National City Bank and the Bankers Trust Company, both of New York City, to recover $6,740 from the Fitzgibbons Boiler Company, also of New York.
Several residential buildings in various sections of the city which are to undergo extensive remodeling or have recently been altered figured in the sales and leases reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 16 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco and New York) -- An Imperial Headquarters communique at 12:45 P.M. today said that large formations of Japanese fighters and bombers carried out their fourth intensive daylight raids on Singapore yesterday and achieved "great war results."
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The epidemic of typhus in Poland is continuing to spread and is rapidly becoming worse in Lwow, according to information received in Polish circles in London.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Treasury said today it had turned over to SPAB a second list of $200,000,000 worth of foreign-owned materials useful in war production now idling in American warehouses.
Flower markets here are daily receiving 1,500 orchids from greenhouses in North Carolina, New Jersey and the New England States, making that flower the most plentiful on the market this week-end.

The four freedoms -- of speech, worship, the press and assembly -- guaranteed in the Bill of Rights were extolled yesterday by speakers at a meeting at the Bankers Club of America in connection with the restoration of St. Paul's Church Eastchester, Mount Vernon.
Manhattan's basketball team breezed through Wagner, 67 -- 44, last night at the Kelly-Green's gymnasium. This was the sixth decision of the season for the Jaspers.

WURTSBORO, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- For the past two weeks John Ames, who forgets just about everything but hounds and foxes during January and most of February, has been declaring that it was nothing more than our plain duty to help him run a few Sullivan County foxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A complete reorganization of the office of the Chief of the Air Corps, to speed up procurement and maintenance of war planes and the training of pilots and technicians, was announced today by the War Department.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (UP) -- The Yawata class vessel reported today by the Navy Department to have been sunk in the Far East was the largest Japanese merchant craft known to have been destroyed by United States naval units.

Gold holdings as stated in the subjoined table represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title to actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Jan. 10 totaled 244,364,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 76,000 barrels in the week, comprising an increase of 175,000 barrels in domestic stocks and a decrease of 251,000 in foreign stocks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Roosevelt formally appointed Donald M. Nelson as head of the War Production Board and William S. Knudsen as Director of Production for the War Department with the rank of lieutenant general.

A $40,000,000 damage suit whose proceeds were to have been divided equally between the Federal Government and two attorneys who instituted the action was dismissed summarily yesterday by Judge Alfred C. Coxe in Federal court.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Jan. 17 -- Simferopol, Taganrog and Kharkov are prizes for which tremendous battles have been under way for the last seventy-two hours, according to reports from competent German and Russian sources received here last evening.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16 -Mr. and Mrs. Robert Appleton gave a dinner, followed by bridge, tonight at the Nineteenth Hole, at which Mr. and !V[rs. Frederick Bronson, who are visiting N[r. and !Mrs. Charles Grey, were honor guests.

H. H. Dewar of Dewar, Robertson Pancoast, San Antonio, Texas, was elected yesterday chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., at the concluding session of a two-day meeting of the board of governors of the association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 16 -- I have just left a Germany that is mustering new strength for the Spring offensive announced by Reichsfuehrer Hitler and for whatever other military efforts he may decide on. At several stations on the four-hour journey yesterday from Berlin to the Baltic port of Sassnitz, I saw groups of new recruits being marched off to barracks.
With war declared, it seems to me that we should use all materials and resources to the very best advantage. Just because people knitted in previous wars is no sign they should do so in this one.

Arthur Renna, 36 years old, won a reprieve from Governor Lehman four hours before he was to be executed at Sing Sing prison Thursday night after his wife, Camille, 35, had given a statement to members of the Bronx District Attorney's staff that she was responsible for the murders for which her husband was convicted, District Attorney Samuel J. Foley announced yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 16 -Japanese bombers again raided Rabaul tonight, six and a half hours after an earlier raid had damaged public services and property. No casualties were reported. Rabaul is located on the northern tip of New Britain, off the Coast of New Guinea. An earlier Royal Australian Adr Force communiqu announced that the Japanese had bombed the l Rabaul area. The R. A. . F. at-I

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 16 -- A resolution calling on Western hemisphere countries to break off all relations with the Axis was offered to the conference of American Foreign Ministers today by Colombia, Mexico and Venezuela, which already have severed relations. Argentina is expected to accept it.

Sea-battered survivors of the tanker Norness, torpedoed off Montauk Point, L.I., early Wednesday morning, arrived in New York yesterday, and, although the story could not be confirmed by the captain, at least one ship's officer unequivocally declared that bullets were fired at seamen struggling in the water after torpedoes had sent the vessel to the bottom.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 16 -- As long as Axis airplanes and troops are kept away from the Americas' shores there is no reason for Chile to act although she is strengthening her forces for common defense of the continent, General Carlos Ibanez, anti-Popular Front candidate for President, said in an interview yesterday.
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 16 -- Byron Nelson galloped away from the field today in the second round of the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament.

The statements which have appeared in recent months and weeks about Mr. Joseph P. Lash, general secretary of the United States Committee of International Student Service, are a matter of deep concern to this committee. These statements involve not only Mr. Lash but, by implication, the general position of the committee.

Melvin Ott, the little boy from the bayous of Louisiana who developed into one of the mightiest Giants of all time, yesterday was named by the New York baseball writers as winner of their 1942 award for meritorious services to the game over a long period of years.

The Navy Department confirmed late yesterday afternoon that a second ship -- the tanker Coimbra, flying the flag of a United States ally -- had been observed "in a sinking condition" off Long Island, presumably the victim of a submarinelaunched torpedo, and warned that U-boat menace along the East Coast was "increasingly serious."

Export freight movement to Pacific Coast ports henceforth will be by permit, the Association of American Railroads announced yesterday. This means that the railroads will not accept this freight until proof is provided that steamer space is available.

Short-term borrowing by eighteen local housing authorities in the amount of $58,952,000 and the $50,000,000 New York City bond financing constitute almost all of the $114,160,391 of new State and municipal financing scheduled for next week by forty-nine municipalities. The total compares with $16,413,608 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $13,232,787.

The Appellate Division granted permission yesterday to carry to the Court of Appeals a suit involving enforcement by the courts of the State of the decree of the Netherlands Government-in-exile vesting in that government title to property here of Netherlands national or concerns in occupied territory.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- With the Netherlands Indies island of Java holding a virtual world monopoly of the quinine yielding cinchona plant, India is now seriously alarmed over the prospect of a quinine famine in view of the spread of war to the Pacific, according to the British Medical Journal.

John J. Goonan, confidential attendant to Kings County Judge John J. Fitzgerald and a member of the board of directors of the regular democratic organization of the Sixteenth Assembly District, which is headed by Kenneth Sutherland, chief clerk of the Brooklyn Supreme Court and long a political power in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on a perjury charge arising from a grand jury inquiry into official corruption.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- United States exports rose to an aggregate value of $1,157,000,000 during the months of October and November, bringing the total for the eleven months of 1941 to $4,492,000,000, the highest figure in eleven years, the Commerce Department reported today.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 16 -- Eager Australians and other fresh Empire troops dealt heavy blows to the Japanese in Southern Malaya today and the R.A.F. struck its hardest in the six weeks of the conflict as the British Command organized the final defense of Singapore.
Sergeant Walter Black was out of order in being so stuffy about the confusion of identity in THE TIMES between the "Jayhawks" of the University of Kansas and the "Bluejays" Creighton University.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Westchester County labor faces a severe dislocation because of priorities and rationing, with little prospect of the few war industries in the county being able to take up the slack, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach said today in announcing arrangements for the organization of a county-wide labor survey committee.

Three ex-convict union dock-workers, who were convicted on Jan. 2 in Special Sessions for coercive tactics in a strike on the Jane Street, North River, pier that blocked the British freighter Essex Lance from joining two Atlantic convoys last Fall, were sentenced yesterday to jail terms by Justices Bayes, Burlingame and Oliver, sitting as a special bench.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator George suggested today that taxpayers be allowed to defer part of their taxes until after the war by buying government bonds. He intended to ask the Treasury to consider such a step, he said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The National War Labor Board, representing industry, labor and the public, sent word to President Roosevelt at its first meeting today that it would strive to settle labor disputes "peacefully, fairly and finally" so that "maximum war production may continue without interruption until victory is achieved."

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Prices were altered little on the Stock Exchange today, but the tone was dull in most directions, with operators reducing commitments. A feature was a setback in the leading industrials and oils. Among the few rises was a further gain of a few pence in Morris.

A production man from the day he began work as an apprentice mechanic in his brother's bicycle shop in Copenhagen, Denmark, more than forty years ago, William S. Knudsen has always preferred the shop to the office and the conference room.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- From its annual general meeting in Old Hall, Lincoln's Inn, the English Bar sent the American Bar Association today a message of confidence in final victory for the United Nations in the war.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- The Tokyo radio was heard today inviting Americans to listen daily to its short-wave broadcasts with a promise to announce, "as soon as they are available," the names of some 400 American war prisoners taken to Japan from Guam and 1,000 more to arrive soon from Wake Island and elsewhere in the Pacific.

TRENTON, Jan. 16 -- A deficit of $4,850,000 in the State's general fund by the end of the present fiscal year on June 30 was estimated today by Controller Homer C. Zink as he urged, in his annual report to the Legislature, the enactment of a law restricting estimates of revenue of any department to the amount realized during the preceding year.

Japan's spectacular victories in Malaya and the South Seas are not being won without cost. It is hard to tell how much the Japanese have suffered in their land attacks. But on the sea it is another matter. An announcement from Washington yesterday that our Asiatic Fleet in a single day sank three Japanese transports and two cargo vessels brings our bag of combatant and non-combatant enemy craft to twenty-four.

TORONTO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The board of governors of the National Hockey League decided today to sponsor a Red Cross benefit game in Boston on March 17 between the Bruins and an all-star team selected from the other six teams in the circuit.

Miss May-Ing Hsi, second daughter of Te-Mou Hsi, general manager of the Central Bank of China, and Mrs. Hsi, was married to Tse-Liang Soong, brother of Dr. T.V. Soong, the Chinese Foreign Minister, and Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Chinese Generalissimo, at Riverside Church, yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- American warships reported today the sinking of five more Japanese ships -- two cargo vessels and three transports -- as the United States Asiatic Fleet, under Admiral Thomas C. Hart, naval commander for the United Nations in the Southwestern Pacific, carried aggressive warfare to the Japanese.

Where do the experts get off rating Joe Gordon with Charley Gehringer as a second baseman? Gordon has played four years and Gehringer has fielded and batted better than Gordon in three of those years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee asked States and municipalities today to consider reducing their taxes so individuals could better bear the burden of new Federal levies to help finance the war.

Every citizen who is interested in the preservation of our economy from the social and economic evils of inflation will echo the views of your editorial "Legislating Inflation." It is little short of shocking to observe the political jockeying, the vacillation and cowardice that are attending the efforts to forestall the rising tide of prices.

The sale by the Church Peace Union of the seven-story brick loft building at 101 Prince Street was announced yesterday by Netter Netter, the buyers. Assessed at $27,000, the property contains a store and six lofts and adjoins the postoffice at 101 Prince Street.
MOSCOW, Jan. 16 (From Soviet broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet Information Bureau communiqu said today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Close monitoring of short-wave broadcasts from Berlin, Rome and Tokyo and from stations in Axis-occupied countries on both sides of the world has revealed a remarkable shell-and-pea propaganda game in recent weeks, all grooved to a made-in-Berlin pattern.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A Japanese submarine attempted to ram a Coast Guard lifeboat searching for survivors of the torpedoed tanker Emidio, which sank off Northern California on Dec. 20, the Navy revealed today in releasing a story based on a report by the commander of the small craft.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 16 -- High military officials here said last night that with formation of the joint Mexican-United States military commission there had come into operation a new scheme of movable defense forces for Mexico's western coast.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt formally opened Macy's Latin-American Fair last night before an assembly of 600 distinguished men and women representing the fields of government, diplomacy, business, finance and society in the twenty-one American republics.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Domei war front dispatch claimed tonight that all Japanese forces advancing through Malaya had penetrated Johore, southernmost State of the peninsula, and "are now taking up positions to annihilate the British Army."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that eighty-seven Class I railroads had estimated operating revenues of $390,305,161 in December, compared with $315,685,275 in December, 1940.

The Maurice Evans production of "Macbeth" will close definitely at the National Theatre on Feb. 28. It will depart from the Broadway scene after 131 performances, out-distancing by far other presentations of the Shakespearean drama in this country.
BATAVIA, Jan. 16 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- Following is a summary of the conclusions drawn by authoritative sources from the Tarakan fighting:

Although they saw some fences still between themselves and their objective, farm leaders from nine Northeastern States agreed yesterday they would do their full share in attaining the newly stepped up production goals of the Department of Agriculture's 1942 "Food for Freedom" campaign.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- According to a statement by the Treasury today, the purchase of Paradise Beach by Axel Wenner-Gren would bar American tourists from patronizing that resort.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in effect today that a firm was within its rights to discharge employes who are intoxicated "even though union membership is found by the (labor) board to be the ruling motive" for the release.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The nominations of 113 lieutenant colonels to the rank of colonels in the Regular Army and of fifty-three majors, who already hold the temporary rank of lieutenant colonel, to colonels were sent to the Senate today by President Roosevelt for confirmation.

A suicide yesterday in the offices of the Empire Mutual Casualty Company, at 201 West Seventy-second Street, ended what was to have been a luncheon meeting between two former officers of the company and two present officers, when one of the former officers shot and killed himself instantly after trying unsuccessfully to kill his former associate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Roosevelt delegated to Donald M. Nelson today full power to mobilize American industry, labor and government for an all-out war production effort, and shifted William S. Knudsen to the War Department, where, as Director of Production with the rank of lieutenant general, he will expedite arms output in the field

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Senate declined today to give consideration to a bill which includes provisions to forbid the use, purchase or sale of liquor, beer, ale or wine on or in the vicinity of military, naval or aviation camps, posts or stations.

A serious need for the $50,000, 000 war fund being raised throughout the country by the American Red Cross was cited yesterday by Arthur A. Ballantine, chairman of the professional section of the drive for Greater New York's quota of $7,330,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- General Douglas MacArthur, Commander in Chief of the United States Armed Forces in the Far East, again today reported that severe fighting was in progress in Bataan Province on the Philippine island of Luzon.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Jan. 16 -- The entire ocean coastline of Marthas Vineyard, stretching about eighteen miles from Gay Head to Wasque Point, was searched carefully last night for traces of a Nazi U-boat, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Wendell L. Willkie, in his capacity as attorney for William Schneiderman, a Communist leader, declared in the Supreme Court today that the issue in the case was whether this government would be preserved by "totalitarian methods" or whether "freedom of political thought and belief" should continue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Prices of hogs rose 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight today as salable receipts here fell to 12,000 head against an official estimate of 15,000 and arrivals of 17,941 yesterday. Receipts at twelve leading markets in the last two days were 65,000 head fewer than in the same part of last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today it expected the general level of farm prices in 1942 to rise only about 5 per cent above the apparent present level. This forecast was based upon known present and prospective factors affecting supply and demand and government price-control operations, likewise both present and prospective.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, the defending champion, got back into his usual winning form tonight in the world title three-cushion billiard tournament, defeating John Fitzpatrick of Los Angeles, 50 to 47, in 37 innings.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of the letter President Roosevelt wrote to Judge Landis urging that baseball be kept going during the war:

NOW that, under war pressure, so many sensible reforms are being made in common customs and ordinary habits, this observer would like to slip something in the nature of a "surf rider" on this wave of reform that is sweeping the country. It has to do with the names of teams in the wide field of sports.

LONDON, Jan 16 -- The Duke of Connaught, great-uncle of King George, last of the four sons of Queen Victoria and Senior Field Marshal of the British Army, died today at his country home, Bagshot Park, Surrey, in his ninety-second year. He had been in failing health for some time.

Postoffice branches in the city began to sell yesterday Federal motor vehicle tax stamps three days ahead of the planned opening date next Monday. The public's lack of knowledge that the stamps were available made sales slow at the forty-eight postal offices and stations, which designated special windows for the $2.09 tax effective Feb. 1.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 16 -- A movement was under way in New Jersey today to organize a third national labor group comprising independent unions, with its aims being to resist pressure by the A.F. of L. and C.I.O. and to win recognition of independent groups on government industry-labor boards.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A code of wartime practices was given to the radio today, designed to prevent the enemy from receiving useful information through broadcasts.

To help mothers to give their children a normal, healthy childhood as free from the impact of war as possible, the United Kindergarten Mothers of New York yesterday opened a two-day festival. About 1,000 mothers in the metropolitan area attended the afternoon and evening sessions of the festival yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania to watch skits and puppet shows, and to listen to lectures and addresses on the care of children in wartime.

Five hundred persons, many from Tin Pan Alley, attended the funeral service yesterday for Fred Fisher, writer of many hit tunes in the last forty years, at the West End Funeral Chapel, 200 West Ninety-first Street. Mr. Fisher, who had been ill for several years, ended his life Wednesday by hanging in his apartment at 617 West End Avenue.

A child is just about as good as what he eats, and more often than not naughtiness may he blamed on poor nutrition. Not that it is our contention that you can cure a temper tantrum with a glass of tomato juice. But it has been found by nutritionists and schoolteachers alike that both grades and behavior improve appreciably with an improved diet.

With united service as its theme, the seventy-third convention of the Long Island Federation of Woman's Clubs held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania a symposium on the war conducted by Mrs. Frederick Olmstead, second vice president and chairman of defense.

Operating results for the year ended on Dec. 31 announced yesterday by the United Drill and Tool Corporation disclosed an estimated net profit of $1,348,94 after $3,294,117 provision for estimated Federal income and excess profits taxes and $100,000 provision for decline in inventory values.

ELLSWORTH, Wis., Jan. 16 -- The killing of Mrs. Arthur Petan, 29, and her three children, whose slashed bodies were found when their home was burned yesterday afternoon eight miles east of here, was confessed late today by a neighboring farmer, James Simecek, 22.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A War Department Distinguished Service Medal as presented today by Secretary Stimson on Colonel Louis J. Fortier of Gretna, La., "for exceptionally meritorious and distinguished services" in bringing about the suspension of the German bombardment of Belgrade, Yugoslavia, last April.

Private art collections have been moved from New York and other coast cities to cities in the Middle West. The local museums, after contemplating the same step, abandoned the idea in favor of other ways to safeguard their treasures.
Sales of small residential parcels in Nassau and Queens Counties accounted for most of the Long Is-] land realty trading covered by yesterday's reports from brokers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Clark Grlffith, president of the Washington baseball club, said today he would suggest at the major league meeting in New York that the present limit of seven night games in each park be doubled.

Underwriters, dealers and bond men of several of the larger banks have geared themselves for what probably will be the most active week in respect to new bond financing since July last year. Both the corporate and the tax-exempt fields will share the spotlight of investors' attention if the present schedule of new offerings is carried out.

Caterina Jarboro, Negro soprano, gave her first local recital last night at Town Hall. Miss Jarboro had attracted attention in this city in 1933 when she began a series of appearances in Summer opera at the Hippodrome. Following her final engagement there in 1935 she went to Europe, where she sang for four seasons at La Monnaie in Brussels and also in many other cities on the Continent.

Jurists, county officials and district attorneys mingled yesterday afternoon with 1,000 city and county employes and 1,000 other persons, in the bomb-shelter corridors of the eight-story Bronx County Building, 161st Street and the Grand Concourse, during a ten-minute air raid drill.

Hosiery manufacturers were advised yesterday to organize their operations in such a way that they can take successive 20 per cent reductions in volume if the need arises and can nevertheless stay in business. The advice was given by John Shireman, hosiery consultant and chief of the silk substitution section of the OPM, who spoke at the closing session of a two-day Hosiery Industry Conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Another damage suit, this one for $3,000,000, was brought today against George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., in connection with his disposal of the railroad empire built by the late M.J. and O.P. Van Sweringen of Cleveland.

An exhibition of water-colors by Edith Farrington Johnston, depicting wayside fruits that attract birds, will open today at the Museum Building of the New York Botanical Gardens. The pictures, with accompanying notes listing the birds and the fruit used by each for food, will remain on view for a month and will eventually appear in a new book by Margaret McKenny.

In his letter of Jan. 5, entitled "Luckman, King of Sling," Irving Goldberg certainly piled it on. It is apparent that George Halas is wasting a good deal of time, effort and money in coaching and training the Bears.

It is not only London that has moved into Washington in the crowded weeks since the United States was catapulted into active war. Europe has moved in. A trip to the American capital today is oddly like a round of many capitals. You see figures long familiar on the continental beat -- American diplomats and correspondents driven from their posts and European officials and journalists riding out the storm in this port.
A portrait by Sir Henry Raeburn brought the top price last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the large and varied collection of the late Emil Winter of Pittsburgh, Pa.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Miss Laura Ingalls, woman flier, pleaded innocent today in Federal District Court to an indictment charging her with failing to register as a paid agent of the German Reich. The court set Feb. 9 for the trial and continued the $7,500 bond, which had been posted a few days after she was arrested Dec. 17 on a complaint signed by an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Two films, which open in Broadway theatres this morning, complete the week's roster of new arrivals. Universal's "Paris Calling," with Elizabeth Bergner and Randolph Scott heading the picture's cast, will be the new offering at the Globe.
BERLIN, Jan. 16 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communiqu said today:

The long, long trail of a runaway soldier who stowed away from Honolulu two days before the attack on Pearl Harbor has been brought to an abrupt end in the F.B.I. lockup here, it was disclosed yesterday. This particular soldier was described as having actually benefited from the Japanese treachery, and to have made his way as far as possible from the war with the help of a series of bad checks.

The skiing public has heard so much discussion during the past year on the so-called new method of skiing -- parallel skiing -- that a few pertinent facts seem in order. My particular interest directs itself to the thousands of beginners who should not be led astray by half-truths.

CANBERRA, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- Moving to counteract both German propaganda assertions that Australian-American relations were a thorn in Britain's side and a Washington report in Australian newspapers today that Australia might forfeit sympathy if she insisted she had special claims on the United States, a spokesman declared that there was perfect understanding between Canberra and Washington.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 -- "Jackdaw's Strut," which Twentieth Century-Fox purchased from Warner Brothers last June, will go before the cameras at Fox next month under the title "White Collar Girl" with Betty Grable and Victor Mature heading the cast, the studio announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- All War Department recommendations for promotion of officers and the granting of commissions in the Army will be reviewed by a special subcommittee of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, to conform to action taken today by the committee.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16 -- A Transcontinental and Western air luxury liner carrying eighteen passengers and a crew of three was feared to have crashed and burned thirty miles southwest of Las Vegas, Nev., tonight.

Mrs. Julia Coffey, an elderly widow who has lived alone with fourteen dogs and eight cats in her century-old, two-story frame house at 6024 Riverdale Avenue, near 260th Street, the Bronx, was burned to death yesterday afternoon when an overheated coal stove collapsed in her living room.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- The National Association of Tobacco Distributors emerged today from a give-and-take discussion with Corwin Edwards, economic consultant to the Department of Justice, with a little clearer idea of what a trade association may do in connection with Unfair Practice Act activities, but with many points undecided as to the department's attitude.

A group headed by the Chase National Bank received yesterday the award of an issue of $1,700,000 city of Syracuse, N. Y., general refunding and Federal aid project. Series A and B, bonds on a bid of 100.119 for 1.30s. The bonds. dated Feb. 1, 1942, will mature serially on Feb. 1, 1943 to 1952.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Uncertainty in regard to price-control legislation cast a pall over speculative interest in the grain markets today on the Board of Trade, and prices held within relatively narrow limits. Announcement that the 1942 farm program of the Department of Agriculture called for increased production of many grains and good crops was construed as somewhat bullish by the wheat traders, although no increase is contemplated in that grain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Representative Frank C. Osmeru, New Jersey Republican, who enlisted as a buck private, has declined his $21-a-month in the belief that he is entitled to the $10,000 annual pay of a Congressman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Following is the text of the Executive order by which, President Roosevelt created the War Production Board:

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16 -- Meeting stiff opposition and forced to cross dangerous minefields, British mobile columns are still driving slowly along the Gulf of Sidra coast toward El Agheila, where the main force of the German Army in Africa has dug in awaiting attack.

The number of children interested last year by the program of released time for religious education classes was beyond the expectations of the Greater New York Interfaith Committee, its secretary, the Rev. Dr. Walter M. Howlett, said yesterday.

The Transport Workers Union was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins to reinstate Patrick Reilly of 636 West 136th Street to membership in the union, which under the closed shop contract means also to his job as bus driver for the Fifth Avenue Coach Company.

Thirty-five hundred school students from thirty communities in New Jersey and from three in New York State on the west side of the Hudson attended the season's first presentation of Smetana's "The Bartered Bride" at the junior performance given under the auspices of the Metropolitan Opera Guild yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- State highway officials expressed opposition today to legislation which would let the Interstate Commerce Commission set aside State limitations on sizes and weights of trucks, while a spokesman for the Office of Price Administration urged enactment of the measure as a means of reducing distribution costs.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 16 (AP) -- British Far East Headquarters said in a communiqu today:

LONDON. Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- Military experts said tonight that the Malayan situation still was critical despite the glowing reports of the inaugural successes of the Australian forces thrown into the battle above Singapore.

An acute shortage of store workers due to expansion of the country's armed forces was forecast here yesterday by Dr. J.C. Wright, assistant commissioner for vocational education, United States Office of Education. Dr. Wright warned of the shortage in an address yesterday morning at the closing session of the thirty-first annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

FLORENCE, S.C., Jan. 16 -- Axel Wenner-Gren, the Swedish industrialist blacklisted by the State Department on Wednesday, acquired during the past year Paradise Beach on Hog Island in the Bahamas, the most famous individual resort area in that British colony now under the governorship of the Duke of Windsor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A broad policy opposed to government operation of railroad, motor, air and ship transport, "unless there is clear need for such action,'' has been established by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation.

A major problem in the protection of the city's school children against air raid attack has been solved through the establishment of a signal system by which the Police Department can notify directly each school of imminent bombardment, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Edward I. Sanders, assistant to the administrator of civilian defense for the Board of Education.

Companies redeeming coupons for premiums have found a solution to their problem of obtaining enough merchandise to take care of the usual demand. They are beginning to offer defense stamps for premium coupons and the plan is expected to be widely adopted.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Delays in government acquisition of rubber and other raw materials to meet war and civilian needs were the object of attack in the Senate today.

The four-story apartment house for seventeen families at 133 Van Wagenen Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., in a cash deal was sold by the Plainfield Trust Company, trustee, to the Private Management Corporation through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, broker.

The executive order under which the President has created the War Production Board, to be headed by Donald Nelson, may prove to be the most important single step forward that the President has yet taken in securing efficient war organization.

After estimating that approximately one-third of Maine's residents, plus more than 57,000 non-residents, bought hunting and fishing licenses during 1941, Commissioner George Stobie of the Conservation Department announced that every effort would be made to maintain the State's fine balance of wildlife resources during the war.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, assistant director of the Office of Civilian Defense, praised yesterday the progress being made in preparedness. She was "very much impressed" by notices instructing civilians what to do in case of air raids and outlining the duties of air raid wardens, she told leaders of 150 civic groups, at a conference called by the Second Civilian Defense Region at the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- Charges made by the Truman Senate committee investigating defense production that the automotive industry had failed to meet its production obligations were challenged today by the Automobile Manufacturers Association and C.E. Sorenson, vice president of the Ford Motor Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The War Department issued the following communiqu today, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M.:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- William J. Pedrick of New York was nominated today by President Roosevelt as Collector of Internal Revenue for the Second District of New York.

CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 16 -- An official spokesman, commenting on a Washington dispatch to Melbourne alleging that Australia might forfeit American sympathy if she insisted on her special claims on America, said that Prime Minster John Curtin had never suggested that Australia had special claims, but simply that she looked to America in the Pacific war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Agreement by House and Senate conferees on the Price Control Bill by Tuesday was predicted tonight by Senator Brown, chairman of the Senate group, who added that he thought the Senate probably would take up the conference report on Thursday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 16 -- A slightly different light was thrown upon the Argentine attitude at the Rio de Janeiro conference of American Foreign Ministers by Acting President Ramon S. Castillo's statement that Argentina had been greatly misunderstood and that there were no unsolvable issues between her and the other American nations.

Hedging and liquidation sales in the cotton market yesterday outweighed some demand from the trade and prices dropped moderately. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts finished at net losses of 9 to 14 points, or 45 to 70 cents a bale.

Another negative session in the stock markets took place yesterday, with prices melting further and trading being again dull and listless. Losses in the main section of the list on the New York Stock Exchange were confined to fractions, although some groups gave way as much as 2 points.

Under a new set-up proposed yesterday at the annual general meeting of the North American Yacht Racing Union, held in the New York Yacht Club, that body appears destined to become supreme in this country and Canada as the rules administrator of all yachting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In an amendment to the government's order restricting sales of new tires, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, today made minor changes in the regulations so that light-truck owners eligible for new tires can purchase six and eight ply tires and "eligible" owners of passenger cars may buy tires of the same ply provided the latter can prove that the four-ply tires will not serve their needs.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister McKenzie King in a statement today paid tribute to the Duke of Connaught, former Governor General of Canada, who died in Britain today. He also cabled messages of sympathy to King George and to Lady Patricia Ramsay, daughter of the Duke of Connaught.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- President Roosevelt today informed Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis, commissioner of organized baseball, that he felt professional baseball should be continued during the war in order to provide relaxation for a hard-worked populace.

The annual Bassinet Ball given by the junior committee of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery will be held tonight in the Pent House and Viennese Roof of the St. Regis under the general chairmanship of Mrs. Edward Townsend Proceeds from the ball will aid in the maintenance of the nursery at 444 West Twenty-second Street, which was founded in 1910 by Mrs. Henry Dwight Chapin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 16 -- Taking a leaf from the notebook of France, which was caught early in the war without adequate evacuation plans, Far Western States are considering a purely precautionary long-range program for sending Coast residents to interior valleys and even across State lines if invasion ever dictates the step.

LONDON, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- Sir Archibald Clark Kerr, British Ambassador to China, has been appointed to succeed Sir Stafford Cripps as British Ambassador to Moscow, the Foreign Office announced tonight.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 -- Hialeah's surprisingly successful race meeting will have its first Saturday program of 1942 tomorrow with fifteen named for the $5,000 Hialeah Stakes, which is confined to 3-year-olds. Once more attention will be on the fact that the current wartime session is ahead of 1941, when new highs of various kinds were registered all along the line.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Jan. 3 was 9,280,400 shares, compared with 7,794,940 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the new War Production Board, resigned today his $70,000 a year post as executive vice president of Sears, Roebuck Co., the only company for which he has worked since he left college in 1912.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 16 -- As a means of overcoming the shortage of farm labor, delegates to the convention of the New Jersey Farm Bureau urged in a resolution adopted today that harvesting be done on a community basis, that State child labor laws and the restrictions on migratory labor be relaxed and that high school pupils be given credit for doing farm work in lieu of classroom work during the war.

Representatives of fifty parents, teachers, civic, welfare and labor groups of this city appeared yesterday at the open hearing of the Board of Education's $146,583,425 school budget for 1942-43, and made appeals for more funds. Only three of the long list of speakers expressed the belief that the budget should be cut.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 (Reuter) -- General Sir Alan Fleming Hartley has been the general officer and commander in chief of the Northern Command of India since 1940.

Dr. Frederick Houk Law, chairman of the English Department at Stuyvesant High School since 1904 and a leader in organizations concerned with teachers' legislation, announced last night his forthcoming retirement from the New York City school system. He is 70 years old.

If the designers and builders of the luxurious new Tombs Prison want to get the approval of one inmate, Gene McCann, they will have to make a lot of improvements, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals learned yesterday.

The Price Administrator's dexterity has been apparent to any one who has followed his encounters with business men and Congressional committees. Now we find him demonstrating a new "Victory" bicycle in the glaring light of the Mall in front of the Capitol. The photographs of this occasion are not only a delight to the eye; they have a value for morale.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Japanese air raiders pressed their assault on Netherlands Indies bases today on a 2,000-mile line.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -Today's report that the United States Asiatic Fleet had sent five more Japanese ships to the bottom indicated that Admiral Hart's relatively small force is disdaining Japan's naval preponderance in Far Eastern waters.

The Jo-An Improvement Corporation, represented by Peterson, Steiner Kohan, has purchased from a client of Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, the one-story taxpayer at 646-54 East 180th Street, the Bronx, in an all-cash deal. The structure is occupied in its entirety by an A. and P. food store and is assessed for $23,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The United States took two steps today to bolster defense of the Panama Canal and Central America.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 16 -- From Paris by way of the Frankfurter Zeitung comes news of the definitive organization in the occupied French capital of the Social Labor Front, suggested recently by Marcel Deat, editor of the "collaborationist'' Oeuvre.

From promoting short hair-cuts to bolstering national morale by supplying the consumer with high-style, sensible fashions, the fashion industry has a tremendous, serious job to do during these war years, Mrs. Edna Woo man Chase, editor of Vogue magazine, declared yesterday to more than 200 New York fashion experts.

Eugene Tarle has informed Oxford University Press from Moscow that he will cable the introduction to his forthcoming "Napoleon's Invasion of Russia, 1812." Oxford, reporting that Mr. Tarle has had .access to hitherto unused Russian archives, says the book will be the first complete story of Napoleon's invasion.

Memories of the colorful days in Democratic politics on the lower East Side of Manhattan, when Paddy Divver and "Big Tom" Foley ruled the destinies of Tammany in that neighborhood, were revived yesterday by the announcement of the sale of the property at 59 Madison Street.
WITH IMPERIAL FORCES, in West Malaya, Jan. 16 (U.P.) -- Australian forces in their first encounter in the Malayan jungles, "are giving the enemy jippo" -- hell.
"The most encouraging news we have yet received" seemed to express the reaction among New York's three major league club presidents to President Roosevelt's letter to Commissioner Landis.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16 -- Confronted by a shortage of natural gas stock and the appeal of the government to increase oil output, leaders of Pittsburgh's petroleum and natural gas industries have taken action for an appeal from the order of the Office of Production Management which has virtually halted drilling of new oil and gas wells in the Appalachian fields.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- After some seven weeks of retreat in Russia, Berlin still speaks of "defensive actions" against the Red Army. And with the Russian Winter in its coldest months, the Red Army still holds the initiative. The Germans were still retiring yesterday, leaving behind them the frozen bodies of their wounded, the blasted bodies of their dead.

The good-neighbor idea was injected into politics and the war yesterday when Miss Marion Martin, director of women's activities for the Republican National Committee, called upon women members of her party to canvas their neighborhoods in behalf of civilian defense.
Little attention is being given in this war to the people of Korea. In view of their well-known desire for freedom some attention should be paid to them.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 16 (AP) A head-on collision between a switch engine and a passenger train on the Missouri Pacific main line at Perla, Ark., forty miles southwest of Little Rock, killed five persons and injured twenty-seven late today.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Germany and Italy have lost a little more than double the number of planes lost by the Royal Air Force since the war began, according to figures given out here today by an authoritative source.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies High Command issued this communiqu today:

With enemy submarines making "furtive stabs at our coastline," battle stations and combat at sea within a week were grimly predicted for "any one" of the 441 new ensigns who were graduated here yesterday at 10:30 A.M. in the first war class to leave from the Midshipmen's School aboard the Prairie State at 136th Street and the Hudson River.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 15 (Delayed) -- Major Gen. Henry Gordon Bennett, gingerhaired 54-year-old commander of the Australian Imperial Forces in Malaya, is tough and forceful, despite his mild manner, and is rated as one of Australia's finest soldiers.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- General Sir Alan Fleming Hartley, Commander in Chief of the Northern Command in India, has been appointed to succeed General Sir Archibald Wavell as Commander in Chief in India. General Hartley, who is 59 years old, also becomes a member of the Governor General's Executive Council.

Ray Robinson, Harlem's spectacular contender for the world welterweight title, wrote the most brilliant chapter in a sparkling career when he knocked out Fritzie Zivic, Pittsburgh's former holder of the welterweight title, last night in the tenth round of what was to have been a twelve-round battle before a gathering of 15,475 at Madison Square Garden.

A great deal of planning for civilian defense has been done as though air raids were a brand-new form of warfare and as though the Battle for London had never been fought. This cannot be said of the recommendations made to the Legislature by Governor Lehman.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 16(AP) -- British Middle Eastern Headquarters issued this communiqu today:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16 -- Dr. Albert Galloway Keller, known to generations of Yale students as a teacher of anthropology and sociology, met his last class at the university today after more than forty years as a faculty member.
Returning to City Hall yesterday after a five-day absence from the city, Mayor La Guardia refused a press interview requested by City Hall reporters on the ground that he had nothing to say.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The White House said today that President Roosevelt believed American civilians employed abroad on essential war projects should "continue with their present labors rather than return home for service in the ranks of the armed forces."

Harry Richman, a stockholder in the American Tobacco Company, filed yesterday in Supreme Court an application for permission to intervene and bring before the Appellate Division for review the award of what he said were "exorbitant and excessive" counsel fees for attorneys who successfully prosecuted another stockholder's action.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 16 -British Imperial forces clashed with Japanese troops late yesterday at Myitta, fifteen miles from the Thai border in the long, narrow strip of Burma stretching down the Martaban Gulf, a joint communique of the Army and the Royal Air Force announced today. No details were available.

The appearance of the first industrial bond issues of the year lifted the total of new bond offerings in this market this week to $24,735,000, compared with $11,332,000 marketed last week. In this period last year $110,375,000 in new bonds was offered to the public.

The number of colors in the regular edition of the Spring hosiery card just issued by the Textile Color Card Association has been reduced to four in the interests of the national war effort, it was announced yesterday by the association.

In material resources the democracies are overwhelmingly superior to the dictatorships. Even the latter admit that. They say this is a war between the "have-nots" and the "haves." Hitler and his allies have staked their gamble for world control upon a firm conviction that the democracies, especially the United States, whatever their potential strength, cannot match the effectiveness of totalitarian organization.
The report of the New York Stock Exchange on holdings of reacquired shares of listed companies showed several large changes in December.

"The Outlaw," Howard Hughes's film saga of the old West based on the adventures of Billy the Kid, was banned from theatres in this State yesterday by the State Board of Regents. Meeting at the State Office Building, the Regents denied the producer's appeal from a preliminary ban by Irwin Esmond, director of the State Motion Picture Division.

State and Federal income tax returns showing that Dr. David Hart and Dr. Frederic L. Weber, suspended chemistry professors, failed to list $20,000 in earnings made from their association with the Kemkit Scientific Corporation, a concern that sold chemistry kits to municipal college students, were introduced as evidence yesterday before a trial committee of the Board of Higher Education at the Municipal Court House, 8 Reade Street.

Mayor La Guardia, whose last public appearance with firemen resulted in his being treated for frostbite, turned up in the company of firemen again last night at Madison Square Garden. But this time things got a little bit too hot for him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Reports today from the Philippines of the fury of the Japanese attack in the Bataan area and the vigor with which it was being pressed raised the strong possibility that General MacArthur would be forced toward Mariveles in southern Bataan and might be compelled to transfer his troops to Corregidor and fight a siege battle from that fortress.

NOBODY has ever written of the English with more justice and discernment than Emerson, and his "English Traits" is a book which retains its vitality and truth today. Turning back to it now, one finds there passages which might have been written with particular reference to the manner in which the English have met the tremendous impact of this war. Thus, he wrote:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The War Department issued the following communique today, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., Eastern standard time:

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- Trucks have moved a "tremendous amount" of American lease-lend material over the winding, mountainous Burma Road to China during the past two weeks, Lieut. Col. Adrian St. John of New York, head of the American military mission to Rangoon, said today.

THE life story of the "Father of Modern Chemistry" presents a double task for the biographer, and, by the same token, a double interest for the reader. It is a task in which Professor French of Colgate University has succeeded admirably, and this is a book, therefore, which is well-rounded and interesting as well as informative.

Increased activity and a greater demand for higher-priced goods was noticed in nearly all markets last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buying office.

REALIZATION of the phenomenal rate of expansion in the role of radio science in this war was apparent here last week at the thirtieth anniversary convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers. Rapid movements of information, troops and supplies over far-flung lines of action on land, sea and in the air are possible today only on the basis of effective radio communications.

Defeat caught up with the Brooklyn College basketball team last night on its own court, where the Long Island University quintet, with Dick Holub giving a brilliant exhibition, routed the previously unbeaten Kingsmen, 61 -- 36.

A stocky man wearing a nautical jacket and a yachting cap stepped out of a train in London's high arched Paddington Station yesterday. Smiling broadly, he greeted his wife, waved to a huge crowd that had gathered in the terminal's smoky interior. He was Winston Churchill, back from a three-weeks journey across the Atlantic to North America.

ADOLF BUSCH, the violinist who will give what is thought to be the first New York performance of Max Reger's violin concerto with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra on Feb. 5, was recalling his association with the composer.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Attracting attention here is the second exhibit of the season at the Four Arts. Tempera and water-colors of interiors of outstanding American homes done by graduate students of the New York School of Fine and Applied Arts are being shown.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 17 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:
