KUIBYSHEV, Russia, Jan. 17 -- The Russians here remain reticent about the general scope of the military operations known to be continuing in many important sectors of the front. There is good reason for this. The Germans clearly are anxious to know how far the Russians aim to advance.

David St. John, Columbia's crack sophomore sprinter, successfully defended the senior metropolitan A.A.U. 100-yard free-style title in the feature event of a swimming carnival in the New York Athletic Club pool last night. The Light Blue ace was closely pressed all the way by Michael Priano of the Flatbush Boys Club and won by a mere touch in the fast time of 54.3 seconds.

Temple's swimming team won five of the nine contests in a match with Fordham yesterday in the latter's pool, but the Rams triumphed, 44 -- 31. Six second and four third places, with victories in both relay events and the fifty-yard free style and breast-stroke races decided the thrilling meet.

ADMITTEDLY annoying, the job of changing tires has challenged the efforts of inventors since the first days of the automobile. A "simple" method for mastering flats in jig time is reported by the office of the Quartermaster General, War Department, as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A suit charging that seven construction, material and trucking firms had defrauded the government by excessive prices and "kickbacks" on contracts for the $100,000,000 small arms ammunition plant was filed in Federal court today by David Houlle in behalf of the government.

Baseball, which had thought its outlook considerably clarified following President Roosevelt's enthusiastic endorsement of the national pastime to Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis on Friday, found itself steeped in another mystifying muddle yesterday when it was learned that representatives of the National League, moving with utmost secrecy, held a special meeting with President Ford C. Frick in the latter's Rockefeller Plaza headquarters yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A naval air transport service, to provide rapidly a means of moving personnel and cargo in connection with naval operations, is being established by the Navy, it said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- When the United States goes out to spend the added $56,000,000,000 war appropriation asked for by President Roosevelt it will concentrate its shopping on the purchase of those things which "will kill a German or a Jap," government officials say.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 17 -Stressing that "in this technical war a knowledge of certain special disciplines is of the utmost importance, and that a shortage of highly trained men in one field or another may well become a limiting factor," the Harvard faculty of arts and sciences today issued to students a guide to war courses.

TOKYO, Jan. 17 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Domei war summary claimed tonight that Japanese tanks had driven through Australian defense lines to within fifty miles of Singapore.

LOS ANGELES -- The Great American Tourist does not scare easily. In spite of the fact that war has lapped the shores of the Pacific Coast, tourist travel to Southern California is about the same as last year at this time and most of the famous "Sun Festival" events will be held as scheduled.

The new War Labor Board can hope to promote labor peace and stability only if, following the example of the old War Labor Board of 1917, it announces promptly a set of principles on which its recommendations or awards will be based. In this declaration at least two points are essential, one concerning the closed shop and the other concerning wages.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 17 -- George Cummings and Dave McElroy of the University Club, winners of the invitation competition last year, made a short but impressive appearance as the second annual professional-amateur squash racquets tournament of the Nassau Country Club began today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Yale defeated Penn by 58 to 17 today in the opening Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League meet for both teams. The Elis took all except one first place.

Serving as aides in hospitals, working in day nurseries, putting domestic science training to practical use by doing household work in neighborhood homes, members of the Girl Reserves of the Y.W. C.A., are showing in practical ways their desire to share in the nation's all-out war effort.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 17 -- From his experience as Secretary of State and chairman in his time of one United States delegation to a Pan-American Conference, Charles Evans Hughes once remarked that any one who plumbed deeply in the Western Hemisphere would find flowing a strong current of Pan-Americanism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Re-establishment of direct trans pacific civilian communication with the Philippines failed today to clear up official uncertainty as to the situation in island areas not known to be unoccupied by the Japanese.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Discovery of a new and effective method of extinguishing magnesium fire bombs with hard coal tar was announced today by the Bureau of Mines.

With virtually all the coal miners in the country working under union shop contracts, John L. Lewis extended to New York yesterday an organized drive intended to bring farmers, perfume extractors, utility workers and dynamite workers into the "by-products" division of the United Mine Workers.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 17 -- Driving through along the rail to regain command after he had lost the lead, Bright Willie today captured the $6,700 Hialeah Stakes as attendance and mutuel play at Hialeah Park continued to soar.

For Total War A tall, 200-pound, bespectacled executive at the Chicago headquarters of Sears, Roebuck Co., received a telephone call from Washington on a late May day in 1940. The White House wanted him for a defense job -- the procurement of airplanes. Donald Marr Nelson agreed. He was soon on his way to a $1-a-year desk in the Treasury Department.
Mr. Horwill's London letter appearing in your issue of November 16 contains an interesting summary of the views of "P.S.", a writer in The Bookseller, on the general topic of book format.

Joy reigned yesterday in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mintz of 254 East 174th Street, the Bronx, because of receipt of the best news that could come to the family of a soldier, the tidings that the eldest of the five Mintz children had safely undergone the Dec. 7 attack on Hawaii and had been cited for "heroic and courageous action under fire."

ONE of the radio's most persistent claims to greatness concerns the time, energy and cash it saves its listeners in the course of its journeys hither and yon, although it is equally true that if the listener had the time, energy and cash he would frequently dispense with the radio and investigate for himself.

THE third volume of Katherine Garrison Chapin's poetry reveals an extensive range in theme and technique which the two earlier works had only indicated. The poems are identified with our national traits in history, epochal incidents in our national life, colorful depiction of landscapes here and abroad, and personal sentiments.

FROM the "Independent State of Croatia," part of former Yugoslavia, six definitives have arrived which are understood to have been released last September. "Nezavisna Drzava Hrvatska" (Independent State of Croatia) is inscribed across the base, and each stamp carries a word to identify the location of the scene pictured.

WANTED! A man to handle men. Must be tough and understanding; a genuine out-of-doors type competent to do desk work. Must know more than his superiors without telling them so or aspiring to their places. Must never be wrong yet must be ready to be made the goat.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Since America entered the war, students at Skidmore College have increased their list of civic responsibilities in many directions. All activities are cleared through the central office set up some weeks ago under the Skidmore Defense Council, which functions on the campus like the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office recommended for cities and counties.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 17 -- The Duke University basketball team added the Naval Academy to its victims today, coming from behind in the last 10 minutes to win by 41 to 31. It was the Navy's first defeat this season.
Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, declared in a statement here yesterday that "Carole Lombard had given her life in the service of America."

WASHINGTON, Jan 17 -- Secretary Perkins warned organized labor today that trade unions faced the possibility of government regulation like other American institutions unless they adopted "sound, intelligent economic, social, political and moral practices" and selected leaders and officers who were trusted by employers, the government and the people of the United States, as well as by the union rank-and-file.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 17 -- An innovation in cooperation between higher education and industry began here with the opening of a new research laboratory by the Standard Oil Company of Ohio under the supervision of Dr. Robert E. Burk, Professor of Chemistry at Western Reserve University and director of chemical research for the company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (Wide World) -- The American Youth Commission warned the country today to be on the alert lest it win the war abroad only to lose it at home.

The first important tournament for Class A squash racquets players this season will be the tenth annual women's metropolitan championship, scheduled to open on the New York Junior League courts on Tuesday.

A physical fitness program for the youth of the nation that recommended the establishment of work camps along the lines practised by the German and Russian youth organizations and a recommendation against the military training of youths under 18 years of age has been accepted by the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A United States submarine, carrying the battle back to the enemy's gates, has sunk three Japanese merchant ships off Tokyo Bay, possibly within sight of Yokohama, the Navy Department reported tonight.

Trade buying checked a decline in the cotton market yesterday and brought about a recovery of values late in the short session on the New York Cotton Exchange. Active futures contracts closed at their best marks of the day, unchanged to 3 points higher than Friday's close.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- Chuck Viguers equaled the Palestra record for a Pennsylvania player as the Red and Blue defeated Yale in its opening home Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game, 52 -- 34, before 2,000 spectators tonight.

America's participation in the world struggle has brought out the fact that we do not know the languages of the peoples in the ares in which we are having to fight. To remedy this situation in the shortest possible time a comprehensive program has been worked out by the Committee on the National School of Modern Oriental Languages and Civilizations under the sponsorship of the American Council of Learned Societies.

Two hundred and fifty women delegates from as many C.I.O. locals in New York City voted yesterday to establish a Greater New York Council of C.I.O. Auxiliaries to coordinate and expand women's wartime role.

DETROIT -- Conducted tours of defense plants are out of order at the present time, but if it could be arranged, there is one that should be made. Herr Hitler and his junior partners, Mussolini and the Japanese war leaders, ought to see the bomber plant the Ford Motor Car Company is building at Willow Run, near Ypsilanti, Mich.

CECIL BROWN, CBS broadcaster in Singapore, is writing a book for Random House which will tell of his war experiences. Mr. Brown was in Rome for a thne, reached Belgrade the day before it was bombed by the Nazis, accompanied British advance forces and their current Libyan push, and then proceeded to Singapore by way of Rangoon and the Malay jungle and was aboard the Repulse when it was sunk.

RECENTLY a captain in the Marines who bears the French name of Mouton began a recruiting campaign among the "Cajuns" of Southwestern Louisiana -- those French-speaking descendants of French Acadians whom the British expelled from Nova Scotia in 1755.
Thank you heartily for your editorial on Woodrow Wilson and the League of Nations, in your issue of Jan. 10, under the title "The League Dead: and Reborn."

Once the bedspread is chosen, the decoration of a bedroom is well on the way to completion. Old-fashioned patterns remain in favor because they carry with them a sense of well-established comfort; a new group of spreads, therefore, derives its designs largely from American Colonial and Pennsylvania Dutch sources.

The Federal training program for licensed officers and apprentice seamen is to be expanded immediately to meet the requirements for a 50 per cent increase in the country's ship construction schedule, the Maritime Commission announced last week.

AS the pressing needs of the national emergency, have caused a sudden expansion in the use of documentary and educational films, attention is being focused on the lack of fact-film specialists and craftsmen. As part of the effort to remedy the shortage, at least two local educational institutions already have laid plans for training courses in this field.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Under the leadership of Keene Richards, consulting engineer and general manager of the business administration of Vassar College and chief air raid warden of Dutchess County, a campus civilian defense council has been set up in which over 400 students have enlisted for training.

ONE hundred and forty years ago another Great Man was on the march. He, too, occupied most of the capitals of Europe, sent kings into exile and traditional boundaries into oblivion. He likewise gave Europe a new order.

Art has a place in the armed services of the country, according to findings of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc. The second region council of this organization, 36 East Thirty-sixth Street, has undertaken a program to help men in the Armay and Navy who are interested in art to find an outlet for this interest.

WAR news from the Malay Peninsula has been more than ordinarily confusing because of what seems to be a great similarity of place names. Actually the Malay system of nomenclature is simple, identifying each place with some natural feature. There are scores of places whose names start with Kuala, but the prefix simply means that each is at the mouth of a river, whether coastal or inland. So with Kota, fort.

WITH Lily Djanel, new French soprano, making her debut in the title role, the season's first performance of "Carmen" will be given at the Metropolitan Saturday afternoon. Other highlights of the ninth week of the opera season are the return to the company of Bruna Castagna and Richard Bonelli and the beginning of the annual Wagner matinee cycle with "Das Rheingold" Thursday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 17 (AP) -- H. Sherman Howes Jr. of Boston, the defending champion, advanced to the semi-finals of the Atlantic Coast squash racquets tournament today. He arrived by defeating Neil Sullivan of Philadelphia, 10 -- 15, 15 -- 4, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 9, after beating Dr. George Miley of Philadelphia in the first round, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 4, 15 -- 2.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 17 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- The Netherlands Indies press today expressed concern over the statement of Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox that he considered Germany the principal enemy, but voiced confidence that the United States would not abandon its positions in the Pacific.
A supper dance and Robert E. Lee birthday celebration will be given by the New York Southern Society, in connection with several other Southern organizations, tomorrow in the ballroom of the Pierre.

JUST as Kipling the novelist and poet was for two decades at the turn of the century the most popular idol in the world of English literature, so in the late Twenties, during the frenzied flight of modern first editions, his books led all the rest.

TABOR, Iowa, Jan. 17 -- A unique college, which will accept only those boys who finish high school in the lowest 25 per cent of their class, has been established in this Southwest Iowa town of less than 1,000 residents. This amazing entrance requirement, setting the educational world topsy-turvy, was created by Dr. Robert Enlow O'Brian, preacher, educator, politician and businessman, the new president of Tabor College.

Though fictional, Bobcat belongs in spirit in the gallery of game horses which Mr. Anderson portrayed in "Deep Through the Heart." It was Holley, the big black gentle groom, who had taught Patsy all she knew about horses and still had more to say, who explained to her that there were certain horses which some folks called ornery which were really "high-couraged."

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Working at unprecedented speed, New York's Legislature cleared the tracks today for the prompt passage of a bill permitting corporations to donate an estimated million dollars to the American Red Cross.

ROME, Jan. 17 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command declared today that the Axis garrison isolated in the Solum-Halfaya region on the Libyan-Egyptian frontier was facing growing supply difficulties, but said it still was offering fierce resistance to besieging British forces.

ZEKE MANNERS, who can probably be called New York's No. 1 radio hillbilly, is also what Zeke himself would call "sittin' purty." Zeke fetched himself into the offices of Station WNEW the other day and signed himself to a contract for another year. Smart fella, Zeke.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 17 -- "Palestine is as much an American front today as it is a British front, and an Allied defeat in Palestine, even as an Allied defeat in Singapore, would prove as costly and dangerous to America as to Great Britain," Rabbi Abba H. Silver said today at the opening of the National Conference for Palestine.

STRATFORD, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Mrs. Henry A. Wallace, wife of the Vice President, christened here today the Excalibur, first of three huge flying boats being built for the American Export Airlines, on the ninth swing of a bottle of champagne.

THE performance of "Carmen" to be led by Sir Thomas Beecham next Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House will mark the English director's fortieth anniversary as conductor of opera in general and of Bizet's masterpiece in particular.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 17 -- Robert Griffith, secretary of the Las Vegas Chamber of Commerce and one of the searching party that located the wreckage of the plane in which twenty-two were killed, tells this eyewitness story of the hazardous climb and discovery of the plane:

Spurred by the unexpected consumer buying rush on merchandise of wool or rubber, important revisions of buying policies involving increased purchases for current selling and also for Spring have been made by merchants visiting the local wholesale markets, reports on merchandising operations during the last fortnight indicated.

A huge new industry was created by government fiat last week when Jesse Jones, Federal Loan Administrator and Secretary of Commerce, announced that the nation would spend $400,000,000 to increase synthetic rubber production to 400,000 tons a year by the middle of 1943.

WHEN Paul Hindemith's music is good, it is very, very good. The best compositions of his extensive output stand high among the works produced in our generation, and these outstanding works should be brought to records as soon as possible.

A drive to enroll all of the 60,000 bank officers and employes in New York State in a voluntary payroll-savings plan for the purchase of national defense savings bonds on a periodic payment basis will get under way tomorrow, when more than 700 representatives of banks from all parts of the State will convene at the Federal Reserve Bank here for the fourteenth annual midwinter meeting of the New York State Bankers Association.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- It seems strange to discover that such widely different forms of bird life as bald eagles and prairie warblers, brown pelicans and marsh wrens, pigeon hawks and least sandpipers, yellow-crowned night herons and Florida yellowthroats may be found in close proximity along the Florida coasts.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- In his uniform of Trinity House, the British lighthouse service, and with a cigar tilted from one corner of his mouth, Prime Minister Churchill arrived safely in London today and all Britain felt the better for it. The Prime Minister, who flew 3,287 miles from Bermuda in eighteen hours, landed at Plymouth and then proceeded to London by special train.

Direct allocation of specific constructions of cotton goods, together with switches in use of equipment to meet war needs, was begun last week and is expected to spread rapidly over the entire list of cotton cloths needed in defense.

The Ninth District of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc., meets tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. at the Wanamaker Woman's Club. Dr. William Crocker, who directed war gardens in 1918, will speak on the methods of establishing community gardens; Mrs. Jack Beck (who lived in England during the last war) will tell of wartime gardening, based on her own experience; and Mrs. Andrews will outline plans for war gardening in the ninth district.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 17 -- According to United States consular officials who left Sofia on Bulgaria's declaration of war against the United States and Britain, there is no positive proof that Bulgarian troops are massing on the Turkish frontier, although rumors to this effect have been persistent in the Middle East for many weeks.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- As Soviet forces struck hard at the rear and the flanks of Germans imperiled before Moscow, Russian parachute troops were reported descending behind the Mozhaisk wedge tonight as other Russian forces surged forward in a new and smashing gain northwest of Moscow.

MEN devoid of humor rarely withstand the pressure of wartime Washington with any degree of success. In this nervous, chaotic city that saving grace is mandatory if one survives the daily shocks of official and even personal life.

THEY turn to Hollywood -- the Red Cross, and the Treasury Department, and the OEM, and all the other groups who have a plea to the American public. That is quite understandable, because, for better or for worse, Hollywood has had the ear and the eye of John Public for quite some time.

HAVANA, Jan. 17 -- American residents presented today to the United States Ambassador, George S. Messersmith, a protest against the foreigners' annual registration tax, raised sharply by the Cuban Government this month.

Heavy "stock-up" buying by consumers continued to feature retail trade this week. Some department stores here had sales increases ranging up to 40 per cent over the corresponding week of 1941, and the average was estimated as larger than the gain of 28 per cent reported for the preceding week by the Federal Reserve Bank.

POLLING public and professional opinion anent the popularity of movie stars is a favorite year-end pastime of the trade publications, and one which often produces some wonderfully confusing results. This corner has in mind three recent surveys conducted on a strictly popular or money-making basis, which make claim to having determined the brightest shining stars (male and female) of 1941.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Russian troops have continued to advance on several sectors of the Eastern Front, "overcoming enemy resistance and breaking his counter-attacks," a Soviet communique said tonight. It added that Soviet troops had occupied several populated places, including two regional centers, on the Moscow front.

At the same time that the Red Cross here announced a gift of $50,000 from the Curtiss-Wright Corporation toward the $7,330,000 appeal of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, the organization made known plans to expand its program of nurse aide instruction.

Students, faculty and alumni are now on an "all out" schedule of training for defense activities, a survey of seventeen colleges and universities in the metropolitan area made by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office disclosed yesterday. Twelve thousand men have been trained in highly technical fields for the Army, Navy, aviation and the essential war industries.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 17 -- The leading delegates to the Conference of American Foreign Ministers, including Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil and Sumner Welles of the United States, held conferences this afternoon under circumstances indicating progress in the move for a South American break with the Axis powers.

MONTREAL, Jan. 17 -- The cellar-dwelling Canadiens broke into a scoring splurge tonight to hand the Rangers a 6-2 defeat in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of more than 8,000.

The sprawling temporary office building that official Washington knows as "tempo D," has been since last April the home of one of the Federal Government's fastest growing agencies. The Office of Price Administration now employs 2,179 experts, statisticians, stenographers and clerks -- four times as many as last July.

IN his first novel, "Olives On the Apple Tree," Mr. D'Agostino told the story of an Italian emigrant. In "Hills Beyond Manhattan" he takes up once more the intricate problem of Americanization. This time his story is centered around a Frenchman who changed from an extravagant Old World individualist into a less original yet far more human and humane American.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- The desire of Cornell students to be kept up-to-date on the progress of the war and at the same time have an opportunity to ask questions and express judgments, has led to the establishment of weekly panel discussions conducted by faculty members.

In a report on building occupancy made public yesterday Mayor La Guardia made an indirect bid to the Federal Government to consider the removal of additional agencies and their staffs to New York. The survey, the Mayor said, was made in December by 250 inspectors of the Department of Housing and Buildings and is now being tabulated.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Livestock prices steadied today at levels below those of a week ago except in the case of heavier hogs and fat lambs. Receipts were large in all departments in the first two days of the week, but thereafter producers reduced shipments. For the week as a whole supplies were less than in the previous week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Provisions to allow clergymen of all denominations who use automobiles in performance of their religious duties to buy new tires are being drafted for inclusion in the tire rationing order, Leon Henderson, administrator of the Office of Price Administration, announced today.

CLINTON, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- An answer to the question of how many books the average liberal arts student draws from the college library during his four-year course is now available as the result of a two-year statistical study just completed by Dr. Lewis F. Steig, Hamilton College librarian.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The Winter program continues in full swing here, with thousands of resort guests enjoying the varied cultural, sport and other entertainment activities. With "Hale America" one of the national objectives, the resort has outlined a definite part it plans to play in safeguarding the health of the nation.

ABOUT the middle of the last century the little town of Mons in Belgium was blessed with a gay-hearted gentleman of diversified tastes, M. Renier-Hubert-Ghislain Chalon. A retired major and the vice president of the Societe d' Afrique, he was also interested in numismatics and was the author of several learned essays on this subject.

Roman Alvarez, East Side, scored a quick triumph over Joe Echevarria, Puerto Rico, in the scheduled six-round main event at the Ridgewood Grove boxing show last night. Alvarez was given a knockout victory in twenty-eight seconds of the second round when Referee Joe Vaccarella stopped the bout.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Trading in wheat futures on the Board of Trade here was slow today and there was no material pressure on the market. Prices dipped early, but short covering developed and a rally of around 1/2 cent a bushel followed, and closing quotations were unchanged to 1/8 cent higher than yesterday.

TORONTO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Chicago outfought and outsmarted Toronto for a 4-2 National Hockey League triumph tonight. The victory moved the Hawks to within 4 points of the second-place Leafs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Responding to President Roosevelt's directive for the construction of 8,000,000 deadweight tons of shipping this year and 10,000,000 in 1943, the United States Maritime Commission announced today the negotiation of contracts for 632 additional merchant vessels on top of a program already calling for 1,400 and promised that more were coming.

At a business meeting opening the all-day mid-Winter conference, Mrs. Earl R. Brown will ask members to support the physical fitness program of the County Defense Council.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 17 -- The Japanese today obtained a foothold in the coastal mangrove swamps on the south bank of the River Muar, within ninety miles of Singapore, as British planes sought to stem the mounting tide of invasion.

AMHERST, Mass., Jan. 17 -- Drawing upon nine college departments and the Massachusetts Department of Public Health for its faculty, a new major curriculum in public health has been instituted at Massachusetts State College to train young men who are needed for the administrative and technical duties of public health programs important in the national war effort.

THE angels of "Angel Street" are sun-tanned. They have no perceptible wings and their tastes run to swimming pools and tennis courts, and I couldn't vouch for their saintliness; but they're the only angels I know.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 17 -- Accustomed to being represented for twenty years as the economic stepchild of the country, the Middle Western farmer is going to suffer a shock to find himself held up to scorn as the nation's No. 1 example of avarice, who would rather see the country plunged into the chaos of inflation than to abate a jot his chance to make a war killing.

The first tangible effect of the recent OPA order establishing price ceilings on iron and steel sales was reported last week by an exporter here who has refused to place an order for a South American account unless some adequate differential to cover the extra costs of exporting could be arranged.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., Jan. 17 -- Al Parsells, playing at No. 2, scored fourteen goals as the Closter trio rode to a 21-to-15 triumph over the Cyclones in the opening game of the annual invitation indoor seven-goal polo tournament at the Pegasus Club tonight.
BERLIN, Jan. 17 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:

PAUL JOSEF GOEBBELS is the most disliked and distrusted man in the Third Reich. His slight stature and his clubfoot inspire distaste among a people who make a fetish of physical size and strength. His Eastern European Jewish appearance, manner and style of speaking inspire ridicule among fellow-members of a party dedicated to Nordicism and dislike among many others.

OF the group exhibitions which opened last week, three were in the nature of annual events -- the exhibition and auction of oils, water-colors and prints at the Salmagundi Club (a part of the proceeds to go to the aid of artists in Great Britain), the members' annual exhibition of painting and sculpture at the National Art Club and the members' exhibition at the Fifteen Gallery.

WINSTON CHURCHILL'S dynamic English is accounted one of the best assets the cause of freedom has. ("What kind of people do they think we are?" . . . "They have asked for total war. Let's make sure they get it.") He likes to tell how he acquired his feeling for words, his fondness for making them fit their place and do their work, "like pennies in a slot."

AS visiting British authors know, the American public has a phenomenal appetite for lectures. Lecturers are regularly engaged by women's clubs, service clubs, schools, churches, museums, civic organizations and groups of all kinds.
JOSEPH SCHILDKRAUT has been an American citizen since an unremembered Thursday in June, 1926, when Federal Judge John R. Hazel gave him his final papers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Henry Ford has just received a patent (No.2,269,451) for a welded, combined auto body and chassis frame made from steel tubes or pipes. The body is designed for use with automobiles made from plastics.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 17 -- Many persons interested in the labor movement believe that the war offers an opportunity to settle one of labor's greatest problems -- the bringing together of the A.F. of L. and the C.I.O. into one organization to end the dual unionism which has split American labor for six years.

In the Far Eastern theatre of war, the grander strategy of Nippon's bid for conquest was outlined last week by its progress over land and sea. Its initial moves had been, six weeks ago, to strike at Allied naval strength in a confusion of attacks throughout the West Pacific area and to gain a foothold in Thailand for an offensive down the Malay Peninsula toward Singapore.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- The Russian Government newspaper Izvestia said tonight that the German-Finnish front from Leningrad to the Arctic Coast had "collapsed," with the Finns losing one-third of their army, including 50,000 men in the Lake Onega sector alone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -Stucco, plaster, wall board and insulation -- all from oats -- are the latest development in building materials revealed in a patent (No. 2,269,509) granted to Michael J. Batelja of Portland, Ore.

MOSCOW, Jan. 17 -- At a Red Army training center near Moscow, in a park that a Baedeker of former years described as "a favorite resort of the lower classes on Sundays," thousands of Soviet troops are taking intensive courses in skiing and ski fighting.

Queens College extension division will be "greatly enlarged" during the Spring semester through the addition of many defense courses, it was announced yesterday. A course in practical navigation will be given by Dr. William Barton, Jr., curator of the Hayden Planetarium.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- If British and American concentration on the defeat of Germany gives Japan a free hand in the Far East, "there is grave doubt as to the wisdom of China continuing to fight," Dr. Sun Fo, Chairman of the Legislative Yuan, said tonight.

A new method in teaching the achievements of American democracy will be introduced at Columbia University during the coming Spring session, when a course on the resources of museums and libraries of American historical societies, the first of its kind to be given in this country, will begin on Feb. 2.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt today asked Congress for an additional $11,000,000,000 for the Navy, the budget bureau disclosed.

PRAISE of the correspondents of English and American newspapers from this reviewer is but a faint appreciation of their work and of the experiences he shared with them for many years in Europe, especially at Prague during 1938, the year of Munich.

HERE is modern history of a type that is already familiar to Professor Schuman's readers: sweeping judgments, crackling staccato sentences, striking quotations and an odd mixture of evangelism and wisecracking, all against the factual background of the enormously crowded last decade.

Hunter College High School held its semi-annual honors assembly last week in the college assembly hall, 695 Park Avenue, Dorothy Carey, president of the student general organization, received the Faculty Memorial Award, the service plaque of the Sigma Gamma Pi, honor society, and a gold H pin for outstanding service.

Germaine Leroux. French pianist, gave her third New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Her program included Bach's "Italian Concerto," Schumann's "Carnaval," Dvorak's Suite in A major, Op. 98; Debussy's "La fille aux cheveux de lin" and "Poissons d'Or" and a "Toccata" by Ravel.

THE grimy junkman, with his rickety wagon and bony nag, and his raucous cry, "Ra-ags, bottles, ol' iron," to the obbligato of jingling bells, has become a figure in the war picture. So precious -- to the war economy -- are the outworn wares he buys that the Office of Production Management has established a Bureau of Conservation and has launched a drive for a 20 per cent increase in salvage collections.

The President has spoken in terms that no one can misunderstand. He has called for an all-out effort, not tomorrow if it becomes necessary, nor the day after tomorrow if our backs are against the wall; but now, instantly. He has done so with a brilliant audacity that has fired the imagination of the American people.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico -- All roads lead to Guadalajara this year, when the "Pearl of the West" celebrates its four-hundredth year. This, Mexico's second largest city, was officially founded on Feb. 14, 1542.

WITH its supply depots and tactical bases scattered over wide areas, the modern well-equipped air force must have an efficient system to keep tab on all its stocks of airplane engines, tires, propeller assemblies, fuel pumps, landing gear struts and the thousands of other items and parts necessary to service aircraft in the field.

A group of debutantes who are members of distinguished Polish-American families in many cities throughout the Eastern States are looking forward to the Polka Ball, ninth annual benefit of the Kosciuszko Foundation, which takes place next Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Stressing the home atmosphere sorely missed by all service men whatever may be the comforts given in their camps, the New York State Chapters of the Order of the Eastern Star are offering a unique supplement to the national program of entertainment.

The amateur criminologist who figures in this story is Gerald Storm, who dislikes physical exertion and prefers to do his thinking while sprawling in an easy chair. However, since he has an efficient valet and general factotum to do his legwork for him, it is not often that he is compelled to bestir himself.

In what appeared to the police of the Bronx Homicide Squad to be a case of murder and suicide, the bodies of Edward J. Frazer, 54 years old, of 381 East 153d Street, the Bronx, and Miss Eleanor Feeley, 35, of 230 West 101st Street, were found last night in Frazer's apartment.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Following a series of improvements in allocations of foods in the last weeks of last year, the Ministry of Food this week ordered an immediate reduction of fat and sugar rations to the levels that existed before the middle of last November.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 17 -- A new experiment in expediting production of war materiel by putting a large number of small machine shops under one roof and making of them virtually a cooperative large establishment was started today by the city government and the local ordnance district office.

NEW YORK'S school children are ready for whatever the war may bring from the skies. A complete program has been set up by the Board of Education's Committee on Civilian Defense in the Schools, and not only are air raid drills being held but the full routine of protection is now functioning.

Federal supervision of the flow of capital into industry during the war period through the establishment of a committee or board similar in design and purpose to the Capital Issues Committee that was set up in the first World War has been under consideration by government officials.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 17 -- That organized guerrillas are a thorn in the side of the German armies in the field is admitted in an article by Gustav A. Doering in the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung entitled "War in the Dark." He adds that the German High Command is combating this guerrilla warfare with "unparalleled severity."

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A Chinese Army communique declared last night that all American missionaries on Hainan Island, off the south coast of China, had been slain by Japanese forces after the outbreak of war in the Pacific.

As a colorful feature of the special performance of "The Daughter of the Regiment" next Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, which will benefit the work of the Grenfell Association of America, an exhibition of Labrador handicrafts will be on display in the Grand Tier foyers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- After forty days of struggle in the Pacific, the Japanese campaigns in the Far East were approaching a crisis this week-end which will determine the course of the war and its duration. The Japanese are now approaching our "main line of resistance," the line where they must be stopped and held and thrown back unless the war is to be indefinitely prolonged and its entire course probably altered.

The report of the Mueller Brass Company for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,768,775 after a reserve of $2,650,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes and a reserve of $400,000 for contingent war-time and post-war adjustments and expenses.

President Roosevelt's appointment of Donald L. Nelson as chairman of a war production board with full power to mobilize American industry and labor in an all-out effort was commended yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie as a necessary but belated step toward winning the war.

A comprehensive post-war program for youth, with recommendations for dealing with the expected unemployment problem, is contained in the 300-page report of the American Youth Commission, to be made public tomorrow. Every phase of youth life is explored and analyzed by the prominent educators who served on the commission, established six years ago by the American Council on Education.

THE hen-pecked little bookkeeper, Mr. Limpet, looked rather like a fish. His prominent, pointed nose, his mild expression, his short-sighted eyes goggling a bit behind their pincenez, gave him an aquatic air. So perhaps it wasn't surprising that one day, standing on a Coney Island pier with his wife Bessie and some friends, he leaned over the railing too far to look at a fish, and fell into the briny.

A letter from Rear Admiral Ross T. McIntire, Surgeon General, denying that the Navy had given instructions to the American Red Cross to reject blood plasma of Negro donors was released here yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The text of Admiral McIntire's letter as released by the association follows:

CHUNGKING, Jan. 17 (from Chinese broadcasts recorded by The United Press at San Francisco) -- Small Chinese units have inflicted heavy casualties in night raids on Japanese invaders on a half dozen interior fronts, a war Cornmuniqu6 said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The revolution in our lives which was started by the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor is now most apparent in official Washington whose machinery and personnel are being rudely shaken out of their narrow, departmentalized habits into the severe pattern of a total worldwide war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A decision to introduce a bill appropriating $300,000,000 to $600,000,000 to compensate workers temporarily jobless by reason of plant conversion to war industries was reached at a White House conference today between President Roosevelt and Congressional and Social Security leaders.

One of the men in the large group around the table said he would not be surprised if the war was over in a year, but he was not too sure. He had burnt his fingers too often in this prophecy business. Another man said the war would last five years, but he too spoke with diffidence; he was not proud of his record as prognosticator.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The position of British Imperial forces in the Myitta area of South Burma, near the border of Thailand, where they have been in contact with Japanese troops, is "developing favorably," a communique said tonight.

WHEN the war began, most of the facilities of the British Broadcasting Corporation were dispersed in different parts of England so that the system could not be disrupted in one blow. The chief center of musical broadcasting was moved to Bristol.

IN every movie photographer's library there ought to be a reel or two of skiing. Few sports equal this recreation as a subject for the movie camera. It is a sport that combines the utmost of grace and beauty with the supreme thrill of speed.

Professor Dewey's attack on Ambassador Davies and his book, "Mission to Moscow," and his incidental but quite savage assault on Stalin, would not have called for comment had it come from a lesser man. But John Dewey is a potent name in America.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 17 -- Despite the war, Whirlaway, the Calumet Farm's triple crown winner, still can break the world's record for earnings.

Last Sunday you let me comment -- somewhat disparagingly, I fear, and I apologize -- on the number of Navy men still wearing what used to be known as "rookie caps" as distinguished from the tailored caps that were formerly worn as soon as an apprentice seaman could have one made. It appears this is being done now to conserve cloth, and the object is a worthy one.

BANDOENG, chief radio center of the Dutch East Indies, marks time on the air with ringing bells which pulse from the threatened islands toward the American sunset sky. On guard, code senders in the far-flung Netherlands Indies stand ready to flash word for help.

The centennial of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was celebrated yesterday morning by 2,200 children at the third of the season's young people's concerts conducted By Rudolph Ganz in Carnegie Hall.

ANDOVER, Mass., Jan. 17 -- For the first time in its 163 years of existence, Phillips Academy, Andover, will institute a Summer School, it was announced by Headmaster Claude M. Fuess here today. The Andover Summer Session, as the school will be called, is designed primarily to train boys from 16 to 19 years in subjects important in preparation for military service, and will last for eight weeks, from July 6 to Aug. 29.

I THINK Mr. Parker Tyler is making a sort of general stamping ground out of my brief mention of his poems. I associated his book "Metaphor in the Jungle" with Charles Henri Ford's "ABC's." Both books come from the same press.

FOR PETS: When the war began in England, many persons, fearful of what would happen to their pets in event of air raids, had their dogs, cats and birds destroyed. Last week the Humane Society, meeting in New York, found such action "needless" in this country. It was announced that fifty-eight ambulances, operated by agencies devoted to animal care, will patrol Gotham's streets during air raids and render aid to injured or terrified pets.

L.A. Wadsworth could easily give pointers to many a writer for adults on the construction of a mystery which is baffling as it is sound, yet this author always has something to say, too, in the matter of convincing character and of the problems of youth, making these books something more than mere time-killers.

Two of the international small boat classes in yacht racing had their annual meetings yesterday and both voted to carry on in the fullest degree this year. While small in size, the classes are two of the largest numerically. The Snipe Class International Association reported 4,600 boats registered and the Comet Class Yacht Racing Association set its figures at close to 2,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- Failure of employers to take steps to obtain deferment for employes before pre-induction physical examination closes the door to registrants with claims or appeals for occupational deferment, Brig. Gen. Brown, State director of selective service, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill reached a complete understanding during their recent conversations on the present and future military and naval operations to be taken by the United States and Great Britain against the Axis, the White House announced today.

SINCE the Theatre Guild is offering "Papa Is All" as pure entertainment, it naturally has to be defended. Pure entertainment is hard to understand. Every one says that he wants it, especially in wartime, when life is sad enough, etc., but he is confounded when it turns up on the stage.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The British Middle East General Headquarters said today:

CAIRO, Jan. 17 -- While it cannot be said that the British Navy is the uncontested master of the Mediterranean, Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham's fleet is still predominant and Mussolini's ambitions for a Mare Nostrum still remain a pipe dream -- or better yet, a nightmare.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Jan. 17 -- A three-point program of defense, to include acceleration, compulsory physical training courses and emphasis on vocational education, has been adopted by the College of William and Mary, following a study by a special emergency committee of college officials.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Cracking par and the hopes of his rivals for the third successive day, Byron Nelson carded a 69 for a three-round total of 205 today to cling to his lead in the seventy-two-hole $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament.

HOLLYWOOD, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The film capital, shocked and saddened by the plane crash death of Carole Lombard, was quick today to pay tribute to the actress it counted as one of its favorite daughters. Elsewhere, too, were heard expressions of sorrow and esteem.

The first part of the Mozart Festival held last night in Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the Mozart Festival Committee, was given over to works by the master performed by fifty-five members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Otto Klemperer, with Mischa Mischakoff, violin, and William Primrose, viola, as assisting artists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- General Douglas MacArthur apparently continued today to hold his Bataan Peninsula lines with overwhelmingly outnumbered American-Philippine forces intact against the terrific impact of a reinforced Japanese assault, supported by artillery and aircraft, on his right flank.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 17 -- Former Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies in a broadcast yesterday said that a great injustice had been done to the reputation of Air Chief Marshal Sir Robert Brooke-Popham, former commander of the Far Eastern Forces.

The re-registration of enemy aliens, as announced by Attorney General Biddle, is an excellent occasion for a classification of the different alien groups. Such classification would be of greatest value for the usefulness of the aliens in the military service, civil defense, defense work, etc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- In a surprise move, John L. Lewis, founder and former president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, proposed today a resumption of peace conferences with the rival American Federation of Labor and expressed the belief that the unity effort would succeed "under conditions existing at present."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The mother of one of the four Pennsylvania soldiers killed in the crash of the TWA airliner near Las Vegas, offered today another son, her youngest, to replace his brother in the armed service of her adopted country.

MUCH of the mystery about automobile prices is being shorn away by OPA, which recently began negotiations to fix new car costs at retail. Most revealing, however, was a Federal proposal to allow dealers a 5 per cent "mark-up," or profit, on "list" price and cost of shipping the car by freight from factory to dealer.

After the garage has been dug out and the walks cleared there are always banks of snow left. Most of this snow has to be moved out of the way. I use it to supplement the Winter protection of bulbs and perennials. Following a few tests which proved most encouraging, I began using it quite extensively.

HERE is a book of facts which should be serviceable reading whether or not we are looking forward to heavy air bombardment in the near future. For in "Bombs and Bombing," the science editor of PM offers succinct statement and explanation to dispel the vague terror which is founded on ignorance.

Chemical shares cracked yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange market and the whole list closed irregularly lower in the dullest Saturday session since Oct. 4. Only 221,710 shares changed hands, and of the 552 issues traded, 227 fell, 137 rose and 188 were unchanged.

Miss Sonja Henie's Hollywood Ice Revue will open its New York run at Madison Square Garden tomorrow evening. There will be eight performances of this elaborate figure-skating spectacle, six this week through Saturday evening and the others the following Monday and Tuesday evenings.

The registration of an estimated 600,000 men between 20 and 44 years old in New York City on Sunday and Monday, Feb. 15 and 16, will be conducted by local draft boards without extra cost to the government, according to Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service Director here.

The shipbuilding industry of the nation completed its expedited program for 1941 with a spurt of activity that sent twenty-six new vessels down the ways during the final month, establishing a new record since the Maritime Commission started its peacetime expansion program.

Bronislaw Huberman, Polish violinist, who has devoted most of his time to the founding and directing of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra in the last few years, returned to Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to give his first solo recital there since the eventful night of Feb. 28, 1936, when his Stradivarius violin was stolen from his dressing room. The instrument was never recovered.

In day and night classes throughout the city 217,592 men and women are studying air raid precaution techniques to protect themselves and their neighbors from possible bombings, the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, 93 Park Avenue, announced yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 17 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in the course of a twenty-hour visit to this colony Thursday and yesterday, found time to appear before the Legislative Assembly, it can be told today, to give point to his previous message to Bermudians -- that bases in British territory leased to the United States were, as he said, "important pillars of the bridge connecting the two great English-speaking democracies."

WHEN Professor Carlton J. H. Hayes calls his contribution to the Rise of Modern Europe series "A Generation of Materialism: 1571-1900" he doesn't necessarily mean that the continental peoples were any less religious than they had been in Metternich's time.

CHARLES COBURN is 63, a fact which alone gives him the right to appear in public with a monocle. Happily he also has the rather special sort of face a monocle requires, a certain paternal austerity, a benign aloofness -- in short, the countenance of a man well fed upon a rich tradition.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Acting President Ramon S. Castillo said tonight that Argentina was prepared to impose rigid restrictions upon Axis nationals to prevent their sabotaging the American war effort.

THE resignation of Hal B. Wallis this week as head of production at Warner Brothers to become a unit producer for the company is more significant than an ordinary change in studio leadership because, an authorized source at the studio disclosed, no immediate replacement of the executive is expected.

Industrial management has had a spotty record for the last eighteen months, as shareholders are beginning to discover at annual meetings. Many concerns have missed the defense-contract boat and will show it this year in lower profits. In a few cases there will be actual losses, for priorities are taking needed materials.

The wreck of the TWA plane near Las Vegas, Nev., is the third major crack-up on the commercial airlines since late in October, when thirty-four persons lost their lives in accidents twenty hours apart.

The murder victim is a gossip columnist, and a peculiarly vicious one at that, so if you have tears prepare to leave them unshed. The columnist's name is Humphrey Whittaker, and he is an uninvited and unwanted guest at the Florida bungalow of Joel and Geneva Brackett, actors and producers.

The world's largest body of yachtsmen and amateur navigators, United States Power Squadrons, yesterday elected a New York lawyer-yachtsman, William L. Sayers, to the post of national chief commander at the annual meeting and conference of delegates held at the Hotel Astor.

The Seventeenth Regiment of the New York Guard, with a personnel of 715 officers and enlisted men, held a review and dance last night at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, to celebrate its first anniversary.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 17 -- General Field Marshall Walther von Reichenau, German commander in the Ukraine, died of a stroke of apoplexy while on his way back to Germany, where he was traveling "for reasons of health," it was announced in Berlin today.

Right about now most people's wardrobes begin to pall on them. This is the beginning of the long stretch when you wear what you have and get busy with little things to pep them up a bit. The art of ringing as many changes as one can on clothes is a good one to cultivate these days anyhow, and now is the time to begin.

SHORT cuts in housework are a matter of avid interest to women who do either a part or all of their own work, at any time, but this Winter there is even more need for getting things done quickly and conserving energy; many women are (or will be shortly) just about twice as busy as they were during peace years.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. -- War has restricted touring abroad, but there remains one "foreign tour" which has not suffered in popularity. Undiminished throngs of tourists continue every week-end to pour into the border towns of Lower California, the Mexican province which lies directly south of San Diego.

TOKYO, Jan. 17 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- Domei, official Japanese news agency, reported today that it had interviewed Captain George J. McMillin, Governor of Guam, at a prison camp on Shikoku Island, and quoted him as expressing the wish that President Roosevelt be informed that Guam's defenders fought valiantly to the last.

John J. Goonan, confidential secretary to Judge John J. Fitzgerald of the Kings County Court until Friday, was arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions Court, Brooklyn, on an information charging second-degree perjury. He pleaded not guilty and was committed to jail in default of bail of $10,000 for trial on Jan. 26.
OTTAWA, Jan. 17 -- With the prospect of every debate turning on whether Canada's war effort is total enough, Parliament will resume its sittings this coming week.

NOWADAYS some of the most important news items of literary London concern not the doings and plans of authors but the mechanical production of books and their distribution to the reading public. A breakdown here would leave writers as helpless as Fritz Kreisler would be if he could get no strings for his violin.
"Business as usual" was the slogan of the New York State Golf Association at its annual meeting yesterday at the Chatham.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 17 -- Dartmouth trounced Cornell's basketball team tonight, 49 -- 29. The victory put the Green in a tie for first place with the losers in the Eastern Intercollegiate League. It was the Ithacan's first defeat in circuit play.

WASHINGTON -- To the many varied taxes borne by the American motorist -- and from which Federal, State and municipal governments draw billions in revenue -- there has been added another which goes into effect on Feb. 1. Collection has started.

Robert C. Lee, executive vice president of the Moore-McCormack Lines and national president of the Propeller Club of the United States, said last week that the foreign trade of this country would be "tremendous" after the war and that it would necessitate a merchant marine of unprecedented size.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- A number of orders imposing strict priority restrictions and other regulations upon industry can be expected to issue from the Office of Production Management in the coming weeks as America's wartime production goes under one-man direction.

Not only has the New York City Department of Sanitation, under Commissioner William F. Carey, eventually found a haven of recreational comfort for its tired street workers, after sectional objections that were not classed as neighborly, but its members are going in for yachting.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Activities at the Skytop Club this week-end are centering around the annual club members meeting and Winter reunion party. The Geographical Society of Philadelphia will gather there from Friday to next Sunday, when the Philadelphia Skating Club is to hold a skating exhibition and contest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Americans and Filipinos who were caught in Shanghai at the outbreak of war with Japan are "well and well treated," according to a cable received by the Red Cross today from James A. Mackay, a banker and chairman of the Red Cross Committee in China. The cable was transmitted through the International Red Cross Committee at Geneva.
AT SEA WITH PACIFIC FLEET, Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- That Tokyo report of the sinking of one of our aircraft carriers is what the Navy calls "bum dope." The writer ought to know. He is aboard her today.

War posters of the Allied nations of the first World War comprise a colorful exhibition to be held at 417 Fifth Avenue and to be formally opened with an invitation preview on the night of Jan. 26. The exhibit is under the sponsorship of the Maple Leaf Fund, headed by William H. Coverdale.

MEXICO CITY -- Though the initial effect of the war has been to cut down tourist traffic into Mexico, groups here believe the flow will pick up as people become more accustomed to living under wartime conditions. This is provided, however, that there are no further passport or visa requirements than are at present imposed on a native-born citizen leaving the United States.

SHRIMPS -- Of the half a million eggs laid by a single shrimp in her lifetime, an average of only two survive, yet that is sufficient to support an industry with a $15,000,000 annual take, according to Lealon E. Martin Jr. in "Natural History."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Torger Tokle, the 165-pound powerhouse from the Norway S.C., notched his thirty-third triumph in thirty-six meets over a span of three Winters today by carrying off the invitation ski jump at Bear Mountain Park.

"We will be practically out of the appliance business by June 1," the head of one of the country's leading electrical appliance companies declared last week, predicting that the war effort would force the curtailment of the manufacture of all new electrical items.

It is reported from Washington that the adoption of a Federal sales tax is under consideration. What form such a tax would take, if adopted, is of course uncertain. Agitation for a general sales tax and for a manufacturers' sales tax, however, is in progress.

HOARDING by the public against future shortages and higher prices has brought soaring increases in retail trade. Touched off by the rationing of tires, the ban on automobile sales and quotas on the use of wool, consumers have rushed to stock up on what they believe will be scarce in coming months.

FULL-BODIED, vehement, unqualified romanticism may not have been exactly rampant in the local exhibition world last week, but it zoomed to prominence several times in the course of this reviewer's round. The term romanticism may, like most terms used in art parlance, be pretty elastic and somewhat vague.

PRIME MINISTER CHURCHILL'S cigars have become an integral part of wartime England. They appear in all pictures of Mr. Churchill, they are prizes at charity auctions. An English girl who recently received a bonus for having turned out a record number of shell components presented the Prime Minister with a box of his favorite brand of protruding Havanas.

"MONEY IN THE BANK" is very good Wodehouse -- the happiest and battiest kind of escape literature. It doesn't belong to the most howlingly funny of the Wode house classics, stopping just this side of being side-splitting.

DETROIT -- Things automotive have been happening so fast that the industry has barely had a chance to catch its breath. Now, six weeks after Pearl Harbor, there is emerging a clear-cut program for the industry for the duration.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 17 -- One of the most perplexing problems in organizing the major field in American history and literature -- that of integrating fields of study of a highly diverse nature -- seems well on the way to solution at Williams College.

The fifteen Westchester cottage committees of the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry-on-Hudson, each of which sponsors one of the village cottages, will observe their annual guest day tomorrow, meeting at 2:30 P.M. at the Hotel Gramatan in Bronxville at the invitation of William V. Lawrence, a member of the Children's Village board, and Orlo McOsker, manager of the hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Roads across Africa leading to the Near East have been improved by Free French to such an extent that they now provide a possible route by which the Allies can be reinforced in Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (U.P.) -- The attack of the United States submarine that was reported today to have sunk three enemy ships off Tokyo Bay, was comparable to the action of Japanese submarines in Continued From Page One preying upon United States commerce close offshore along the Pacific Coast or of the Nazis' U-boats in attacking shipping off Long Island.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Welker Cochran, San Francisco, put on a brilliant display of three-cushion billiards midway in his match with Art Rubin of Brooklyn today to win, 50 to 38, in 39 innings and go into a three-way tie for first place.

A collision between two American ships off Atlantic City resulted last night in the sinking of one of them, the San Jose, 3,358-ton freight and passenger vessel of the United Fruit Line, and the damaging of the other, the recently built 7,600-ton Santa Elisa of the Grace Line.

THE NATIONAL FEDERATION OF STAMP CLUBS, according to the group's chairman, Harry L. Lindquist, expects to present to Postmaster General Walker shortly a suggestion that the Post office Department issue a semi-postal stamp with a picture of Pearl Harbor.

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- One question Americans probably are asking themselves and others most frequently these days is, "What effect did the Pearl Harbor bombing have on Navy morale?"

TOKYO, Jan. 17 -- (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in the United States and London) -- A dispatch from a Japanese base in Malaya said today the British had attempted to remove 20,000 persons from Singapore to India but Japanese planes disrupted the evacuation. The dispatch added that officials of the Singapore Government began leaving the city for Java in large transport planes Thursday.

Social service in the United States will expand tremendously during the war and in the post-war period, and as a result there will be a widespread shift in social work personnel and education, Dr. Walter W. Pettit, director of the New York School of Social Work, predicts in his annual report, made public yesterday.

A large group of maladjusted young men and women refugees have been assisted through the Young Women's Hebrew Association, it was revealed in the annual report of the organization's president, Mrs. Felix M. Warburg. In the absence of Mrs. Warburg, Mrs. Jerome J. Hanauer, vice president, read the report at an annual meeting held last week in the association's clubhouse, 31 West 110th Street.

No citizen of this country can have heard without deep emotion Mr. Churchill's address to the two houses of Congress. It symbolized as few things could have symbolized more effectively the opening of a new chapter of immense importance to the common destiny of our peoples.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- More than 100 German, Japanese and Italian business concerns in this country have been padlocked and ninety-eight others are operating under strict supervision, the Treasury said today.

Recruiting activities in the Army Building at 39 Whitehall Street and at all canvassing substations in the city will be conducted hereafter on the basis of a six-day week, with all offices closed on Sunday, Colonel John F. Daye, recruiting officer for the Southern New York district, announced yesterday.

JUST about three years ago Stuart Chase published his volume, "The Tyranny of Words." His purpose was apparently no more than to popularize the work of Alfred Korzybski, I.A. Richards, C.K. Ogden and others on "semantics," which is the "science of symbolism" and the study of the influence of language on thought.

In an effort to expedite power planning for national defense, particularly along the Eastern seaboard, the Tennessee Valley Authority has been called upon to map out an 8,000 square-mile region of strategic areas in New York State, it was learned yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 17 -- Fourteen prominent Germans, who, together with six others against whom warrants also were issued late last night, were believed to form the "general staff" of Nazi fifth column activities in Argentina, were arrested today and held incommunicado on charges of fraud.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The United States has started accumulating food for shipment to Russia under the lease-lend program.

IN 1930 Warwick Deeping's omnibus volume entitled "Stories of Love, Courage and Compassion" was published. At the front of his latest novel. "Corn in Egypt," will be found his "credo": "I believe in the large simplicities, in the human urges at the back of all of us.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Jan. 17 -- New Zealanders, jolted from their feeling of security behind the Singapore bastion by the raising in London of the blanket on news from the Malayan front after the past several days' silence, today studied the situation in which they are placed by the threat to the key naval base.

The privately endowed college faces some very puzzling problems brought on by war conditions. Every person, every institution, every business, is facing equally puzzling problems. Why should the college be exempt from worry, from readjustments, from sharp sacrifices?

THE name of another city in Germany has been added to that of Bielitz as places dispatching stamp less airmail covers abroad. As mentioned in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 28, covers from Bielitz bore a rubber stamp, "Taxe Percue," with the postmaster's signature as well as the amount presumably paid.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 17 -Formation of a committee to safeguard objects of historical, cultural or scientific value in New Jersey from possible war damage has been announced by Julian P. Boyd, librarians of Princeton University.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins' publicity department said today that the summoning of Woodrow (Porky) Dumart for duty with the Canadian Army might be the government's first step in a move which would affect half the personnel of the National League.

Enemy submarines are operating off the Eastern coast for the first time since the last war. They did a little damage then, and they will probably do more this time. The tankers sunk off Long Island and the steamer sunk off Nova Scotia are warnings of a possible attack on any shipping from American ports.

Entries for the sixty-sixth annual exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club to be held in Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12 are being received and tabulated by the Foley Organization, which has taken quarters adjoining the Westminster offices at 590 Madison Avenue.
THE girl, Jo Lang, is fleeing from the malicious gossip and persecution of a small Nevada town. The young man, Dick Stowe, is an aviation engineer who has been transferred from San Diego to New York.

The Rev. Leroy Lawson, youngest chaplain at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, has been appointed chaplain of the United States Maritime Service, with the rank of ensign. He was sworn in last week by Commander George E. McCabe, director of the service's training station on Hoffman Island, in the lower bay, and took over his duties as the first chaplain for the nation's merchant marine.

It has long been rumored that the Pilgrims were something more than the thin-lipped, iron-ribbed heroes that tradition has made of them, but in our admiration for their fortitude we have nearly forgotten that they loved life almost as much as the freedom which they sought and for which, as this story reminds us, Englishmen will always fight.

LAS VEGAS, Jan. 17 -- A searching party reached the wreckage of the missing Transcontinental and Western Air transport plane on Table Rock Mountain today and found all twenty-two persons aboard dead, including the actress Carole Lombard.

BACK in those halcyon peacetimes, when war was but a dimly looming cloud, much speculation was devoted by people of a social turn of mind to the speed with which our mass communicators -- namely, the films and radio -- would be geared to psychological expedients when the fated M-day arrived.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Governor Lehman and Mayor La Guardia are among the honorary patrons and patronesses for the all-star entertainment and fashion revue for the benefit of the Israel Orphan Asylum to be held on the night of March 21 at Madison Square Garden.

WITHOUT doubt young Ames has thousands of friends already. He richly deserves them. The unexpected and engaging qualities of that young American business man of the Eighteen Thirties are the sort that stick in one's memory.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan 17 -- Giving up their guns and war material intact, the battered and half-starved Axis garrison of Halfaya Pass surrendered unconditionally this morning, thus freeing Egyptian soil of the last vestige of Fascist control.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The term "accouplement" used by John L. Lewis in his proposal for a joining of the C.I.O. and A.F.L. means "the act of coupling or state of being coupled; union," according to Webster.

APPARENTLY Eugene O'Neill is starting on his second shelf of written but unproduced plays. First, there is that cycle of eight, or nine, or a dozen, which he plans to finish before allowing any single unit to reach Broadway. Second, there is the work known as "The Iceman Cometh," outside the cycle and a possibility for next season.

After praising the farmers for increasing wartime production, Mayor La Guardia warned them yesterday against seeking to take advantage of the emergency by raising food prices too high. He spoke to 500 farm leaders and AAA agents at the closing of the regional conference of the Northeast division of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration at the Hotel Barbizon-Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Roosevelt gave assurances today to Americans who are serving with the British, Canadian, Chinese and other Allied armies that those who desired it would be transferred to the armed forces of the United States "as soon as transfers can be arranged without unduly hampering the combined war efforts of the United Nations now combating the Axis powers."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Engineering and mechanical jobs at the Washington Navy Yard are open to women, the Navy announced tonight, because the supply of men available for such positions "is rapidly becoming exhausted."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Omnibus War Powers Bill introduced in the Senate yesterday by Senator Van Nuys, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, was endorsed today by Senator Barkley, majority leader, as a measure needed by various government agencies to round out their authority to deal with circumstances arising out of the war.

Janet Bush, mezzo-soprano from Montclair, N.J., who under the name of Bush-Hecht made her debut a year ago at Town Hall, last night gave her second recital there, Milne Charnley was her accompanist. Her program included lieder by Schubert, Erich Wolf and Marx, songs in English by British and American composers, and two arias from eighteenth-century operas composed in France, Gossec's "Air de Rosine," and Gluck's "Divinites de Styx."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Following reports of increases in retail coal prices in several areas, Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, requested retail dealers today not to increase prices above those charged in the period between Dec. 15 and Dec. 31. He said:

Never has their been a combination of factors tending to increase traffic like that which exists today in the railroad field. Gross revenues of the railroads in the United States this year should exceed all records, although what portion of this will reach the securities holder remains to be seen.

The old Army game was a bit too much for the Columbia basketball squad to match at the Morningside Heights Gymnasium last night as the cadets vanquished the Lions, 36 to 23. Two scoring streaks, one early in the fray and the other near the end, carried the cadets to victory as the Light Blue went down in its fourth straight setback of the campaign.

A review of national defense developments, more comprehensive than any previously made before any national body, will be given to the General Federation of Women's Clubs when its officials convene in Washington on Friday for a four-day board meeting.

Seldom has a book title been more aptly chosen than this one. Inspector Maigret almost literally sits out the two cases described in the two stories which make up this volume: "The Lock at Charenton" and "Maigret Returns." It is astonishing how much information Maigret is able to absorb just by sitting and looking and listening.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17 -- The proposals for suppressing Axis fifth columns in Latin America, made yesterday by the United States delegation at the Rio de Janeiro conference, drew the comment from counter-espionage experts here today that subversive Axis activities were a main war problem facing the American republics -- and were among the problems these countries were capable of solving.

IF only because they were once so potent, the legends of the saints deserve still to be remembered. For more than a thousand years, commanding the faith of lay and learned, they captivated the minds and hearts of men.

In these days, when war is devastating the world, beauty is needed as perhaps never before, particularly the natural beauty that springs from the soil. For this beauty, and the peace and quietness that come with it, soothe ragged nerves in a way that nothing else can.

Leaders of 500 women's organizations in this area will meet with officials of the Defense Savings staff of the United States Treasury Department in a program to be held on Tuesday at 2:30 P.M. at the New York Times Hall, 238 West Forty-fourth Street.

THE record industry has come back, bigger and better than ever. Since its firm establishment shortly after 1900 it has been twice on the verge of disaster. The radio in the middle Twenties and the depression in the early Thirties caused it to totter, but each time the sobbing requiems were premature. 1941, peak year of recording, about 110-000,000 records were sold, 10,000,000 more than the previous high of 1921.
