Carole Lombard gained her success in motion pictures in the face of numerous misfortunes which harried the early years of her career.

IF Alexandre Davy de la Pailleterie is not immediately recognizable as the name of one of Hollywood's best known script writers, perhaps it is because he receives most of his screen credits as Alexandre Dumas. Under his nom de movie he has been a famous and prodigiously prolific scenarist.

Fifty thousand persons visited Macy's Latin-American Fair yesterday where a great variety of articles from foodstuffs to art objects from "south of the border" is on exhibition and sale, on the first day it was open to the public, it was announced by executives of R.H. Macy Co., Inc.

Dog fanciers among members of society will gather in full force at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 11 and 12 for the sixty-sixth annual show of the Westminster Kennel Club. The advance reservation of boxes and seats, already impressively sizable at this early date, has been spurred no little by the fact that the club will donate the net proceeds of the show to the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill came safely home by flying boat today from his historic trip to the New World, and the happy cries of "Good Old Winnie" that welcomed him subdued, for the moment at least, British recrimination over Singapore's plight.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 17 -- Now that the conference at Rio de Janeiro has manifested clear trends, various European reactions are discernible and more importance is being attached to its progress.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- New York University staved off a late rally to beat the De Paul quintet, 38 to 37, tonight. The Violets led, 37 to 30, near the close of a battle in which the score had been tied seven times. Then the Blue Demons upset the Violets' defense and failed of a victory when a last-second shot rolled off the front rim of the goal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Heroic civilian cooperation with the Army Medical Corps, an adequate supply of plasma, and a new sulfonamide therapy in the treatment of wounds saved hundreds of lives during and after the Dec. 7 Japanese attack on Honolulu, the War Department learned today through a medical report made by Dr. Perrin Long of the Johns Hopkins University, and Dr. I.S. Ravdin, a Lieutenant Colonel in the Medical Reserves not on active duty.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 16 (delayed) -- Control of the straits of the Malaysian world, through which ships have carried the trade of treasure islands for centuries, is an apparent major aim of recent Japanese attacks in the Western Pacific.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- American democracy as it manifests itself in various areas of the nation's culture such as government, economics, science, art, literature, education, journalism, religion and philosophy will be discussed in a course on "The American Idea" to be added to Colgate University's curriculum starting with the first 1942 trimester Jan. 28.

Women active in behalf of the work of the Children's Health Service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the performance of Bach's "Phoebus and Pan," and Rimsky-Korsakoff's "Coq d'Or" on the night of Jan. 31 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over to raise funds for the organization.

THE American small boy is not only a phenomenon of American fiction; he is an institution. Outside the classics, the perennial favorites and the rubbish pile, he turns up afresh every publishing season in various guises and generally in superior novels and stories, for he is one of the best things our story tellers do.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The continued division of New York State into two separate defense zones, largely as a result of the dual jobholding of Mayor La Guardia, is causing increased concern and discussion among high officials of the State Government, it is indicated here.
THE war is having a definite effect on clothes. Say the designers: "Be feminine." Yet, it is not in good taste to be overdressed. So an important suit trend has appeared.

SIXTY thousand planes, 45,000 tanks, 20,000 anti-aircraft guns and 8,000,000 tons of shipping -- that is the nation's defense order for 1942, as stipulated by President Roosevelt. It is an enormous order for the steel mills, shipyards, factories and machine shops of the country.

In spite of a censorship code that filled two columns of this newspaper last Thursday, a great deal of news which must be comforting to our enemies is freely published in this country. The appointment of Donald M. Nelson as chairman of the new War Production Board illustrates this point. Mr. Nelson was given the job of perfecting what it is still handy to call our "defense'' effort.
THE Macy show is just what you quoted from the publicity release. It includes "every important movement now taking place among our own painters." It's as simple, as provocative, as that.
MOSCOW, Jan. 17 (From Soviet broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau broadcast this communique today:

IN the conquered countries of Europe today there is a growing hatred and re- sentment against Hitler and everything he and his Gestapo and army stand for. From the Baltic to the Aegean and from the Black Sea to the Atlantic a strong tide is running in the hearts of millions that will some day overflow to help destroy the Nazi infamy.

Main floors were busy and January white sales were active last week in practically all stores in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 17 (AP) -- British Imperials, Poles and Free French have won Halfaya Pass and thereby gained a direct route of supply to speed their drive toward Tripolitania for a showdown with the Axis in North Africa, it was announced today.

If the training experience of the United States parachute troops is typical, a jumper may expect to be killed once every 20,859 jumps, to break an ankle about once every 400 jumps, and to receive minor bruises or breaks about once every 100 jumps. The record is not good enough to induce men to enlist in the parachute battalions for their health.

Bronzes by Rodin and Barye and rare Brussels tapestries of seventeenth-century design were included in the art objects from the collection of the late Emil Winter of Pittsburgh which were sold at auction yesterday in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 17 -- Outwardly calm and confident even when faced with a 2-point deficit late in the second period, the Williams College hockey squad unleashed an impressive rally to shade Army's varsity, 4 to 3, in today's major sports attraction here.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- The Winter field and reading period of Bard College which will extend to Feb. 9 will see Bard students undertaking a greater variety of useful projects than ever before. Some of these are linked to purposes of national defense.

Curtailment of wool goods production and the uncertainty in the cotton goods market pending a determination of government needs combined to send men's wear prices in the wholesale markets soaring this week, reports yesterday indicated.

MADRID, Jan. 17 (AP) -- A semi-official Spanish report today bitterly accused the Free French of violating Spanish territory by seizing three Axis merchantmen in a the destroyer's stealthy raid on the little Spanish colonial island of Fernando Po, off the west coast of Africa.

"DIPLOMATS of the Americas meet at Rio de Janeiro to discuss common objectives in the world crisis." This announcement, to some who know the Brazilian capital, recalls a city whose lively Samba tunes at carnival time turn even pompous citizens into jitterbugs.

The executive committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, in session at the New York Athletic Club yesterday, set dates for the year's national championships and discussed plans for a full season of competition despite the war.

Today marks the opening of the eighth annual Silver Sailfish Derby sponsored by the West Palm Beach Fishing Club, and for the next twenty-one days hundreds of anglers will churn thousands of miles of salt water in search of big fish.
The Patent Office granted 809 patents this week, among which were the following inventions:

LONDON, Jan 17 -- England defeated Scotland, 3 -- 0, today in an international soccer classic before a crowd of 64,000 in Wembley Stadium. The English team held the upper hand from the start and delighted the great wartime crowd with the brilliancy and precision of its play.

IF there's anything in the theory that a boy's devotion is to his mother, a girl's to her father, the theory should apply equally in New York City, London and New Guinea. That it doesn't so apply was stated the other day by Dr. M.F. Nimkoff. Among the Manus of New Guinea both boys and girls prefer their fathers.

Bach's "Phoebus and Pan," conducted by Sir Thomas Beecham, will be presented at the Opera Festival at the Metropolitan Opera House on Jan. 27 for the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Lucrezia Bori, chairman of the program, and Edward Johnson, general manager of the opera.

The British Ministry of War Transport which has continued to handle all lease-lend cargoes despite protests by established American organizations will be eliminated as a forwarding agent as a result of the pending legislation to place such commerce under control of the Maritime Commission, forwarders now believe.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 17 -- The story that has been unfolded thus far in the investigation into the activities of Mrs. Amelia M. Carr, suspected master swindler, assumed a somber tone today with the discovery that a man occasionally employed as a gardener by the 66-year-old woman apparently had committed suicide by drowning in the Passaic River here.

LOTTE LEHMANN, the Metropolitan soprano, will receive a Town Hall testimonial in honor of her tenth anniversary in the New York music world, which will be presented to her by George V. Denny, president of Town Hall, at the Theatre Luncheon on Jan. 27, at the Hotel Astor.

THE appointment of Professor Moe Berg of the rich Red Sox as a good-will Ambassador to South America (without portfolio) has brought about a diplomatic crisis in this area. Or so said Al Schacht in so many words. The Clown Prince of Baseball and the retired head of the Department of Modern Languages of the Yawkey School of Scientific Swatting have been cronies for years.

The plants the indoor gardener has so carefully potted up and brought safely through the rooting stage into clean, strong growth demand further care during the remaining months of their prime, so that they will retain their healthily green condition.

SNOW and ice sports are now in full swing, and the coming weeks will see championship events in skiing, speed and figure skating, bobsledding, ice-boating and skate-sailing, tobogganing, ice harness racing and dog-sledding.

ALEC HUDSON isn't seriously trying to fool any one when a submarine commander in one of this set of dramatic stories of undersea naval operations decides (and in a relatively quiet moment at that) that submarining is "one hell of a way to make a living."

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, Jan. 19 -- A Russian communique last midnight reported the recapture of Polotnyany-Zavod, which brought the Soviet troops a bit farther toward the Kaluga end of the railroad to Vyazma. But a seventy-five-mile stretch of that road remains to be conquered. and much of it is over difficult terrain, in which the Germans are showing themselves to be apt students of Russian-type guerilla outpost fighting.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- The war is now beginning to show its ugly side in Berlin and elsewhere in the Reich.

TOKYO, Jan. 18 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- All British airdromes on the Malayan mainland came into Japanese possession with the occupation of one near Batu Pahat, seventy miles northwest of Singapore, dispatches from the front said today.

VICHY, Jan. 18 -- Subscriptions to the 300,000,000-franc loan of the Credit National were covered on the opening day, last Monday. The total was not large, but the rate of 3 1/2 per cent is important as showing that the government's policy of lowering interest rates is extending on the market.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18 -- With trading interest small as Congress fought over provisions of the price-control measure, limited trade demand and some outside buying based on glowing reports of prospective Army demand for cotton goods accounted for net gains of around $1.25 to $1.50 a bale here last week.
Four Broadway theatres will present new films this week. The schedule is as follows:

Sir Thomas Beecham will conduct the first performance of the season of Gounod's "Faust" next week at the Metropolitan Opera House. The date is Friday night, Jan. 30. The week, tenth of the season, will also be marked by an opera festival in aid of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 18 -- Matching in a sense the unified command of the United Nations in the Southwestern Pacific area, the Axis powers, Germany, Italy and Japan, signed today in Berlin a military convention setting forth the main lines of "common operations against the common enemy."
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan 18 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Holiday Perry gave a dinner tonight at their residence for their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Wood Robert Jr.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Treasury Department announced today that as a result of the offer by officials of various securities and investment organizations to aid in providing a larger number of issuing agents for Series E defense savings bonds, arrangements had been completed so that clearing corporations of recognized securities exchanges and properly qualified members of the recognized securities and investment organizations might now be designated as such issuing agents.

Praising the present Army policy that calls for students in college to stay where they are until called into service, Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, in a statement issued yesterday reiterated his belief that there is no point in speeding up the educational process at his institution by reducing the time needed for graduation.

Jolting Joe DiMaggio, incomparable center fielder of the world champion Yankees, has been named the "player of the year" by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association and will receive the award at the chapter's nineteenth annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore on Sunday, Feb. 1.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Mrs. J. Clarence Carr, 66-year-old ex-convict, who for five years before her recent arrest as a master confidence woman was known in Newark as a devout churchwoman and a generous dispenser of charity, does not want to go on trial again, according to Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld of Essex County.

War has all manner of effects on personality. Now, with the official weather forecasts reduced to a meager pittance by military restrictions, the amateur prophet returns to self-esteem, at least, whether his neighbors choose to pay any attention to him or not.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 18 -- A letter addressed to THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent at Ankara, and enclosing a photostat of a letter that the German Consulate at Istanbul had sent discreetly to every Nazi party member in Turkey, said that Nazis here were obliged to buy woolen goods and deliver them secretly to the German Consulate for shipment to Berlin and then to the Russian front.

MOSCOW, Monday, Jan. 19 -- Russians have fought their way back into the highly important city of Mozhaisk, on the front before Moscow, and are battling the Germans in the streets, the army newspaper Red Star said today.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- U Saw, Prime Minister of Burma, who left Great Britain Nov. 5 after unsuccessful negotiations in London regarding dominion status for Burma, and who visited the United States while en route home, has been "detained" by authorities somewhere on his journey back to Burma because he "has been in contact" with the Japanese since the spread of the war to the Pacific.

The K. L. Ice Corporation of Newark and Jersey City has purchased the former Christian Feigenspan ice plant at 183-219 South Eighteenth Street, northwest corner of Eleventh Avenue, East Orange, N.J. It will use the property for one of its subsidiary contractors in the manufacture of airplane parts and equipment, according to Louis Schlesinger, Inc., broker in the sale.

A 4-week-old spitz puppy was presented yesterday by the American Friends of Norway, Inc., to Paul Georgsen, 21-year-old Danish seaman and member of the crew of the torpedoed tanker Norness, to replace the mascot he lost when he abandoned the ship as she sank early Wednesday sixty miles southeast of Montauk Point, L.I.

SOMEWHERE IN NORTHERN JOHORE, Jan. 18 -- The Japanese have been stopped short, with heavy losses inflicted by Australian troops, in Negri Sembilan on the Johore frontier, roughly 125 miles north of Singapore, it was indicated today.

The Bronxville Field Club captured the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Westchester division championship yesterday when it defeated the Ardsley Country Club, 6 -- 1, at Bronxville as the tourney came to a close. In another match the Greenwich Country Club downed Sleepy Hollow, 5 -- 2, at Greenwich.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Housewives, restaurant proprietors and candy manufacturers must be hoarding sugar.
Anthony E. Santasiere defeated Milton Hanauer yesterday in the championship tourney of the Marshall Chess Club after forty moves. J. Richman lost to Severin Bruzza in the only other game decided.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A War Department communique, based on reports received up to 1 P.M., Eastern standard time, said:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 102.3 to 102.6, with many more individual price changes occurring than in any week of recent months. The most significant change was the reduction in the price of gasoline, which was responsible for the 1.5 per cent decline in the fuel and lighting group.

The twenty-third annual report of the Commonwealth Fund, issued yesterday, showed that in the year ended Sept. 30, the fund had appropriated $1,841,332 to further medical education, public health and other welfare activities.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 18 -- Germany has served demands upon Hungary and Bulgaria, it was learned today, for eight full army divisions to be dispatched into Yugoslavia to fight the Serbian Armies of General Draja Mikhailovitch and to garrison the major cities of Serbia, Croatia, Dalmatia and Macedonia, replacing the depleted German and Italian troops that are being withdrawn to Greece and Southern Italy for Germany's Spring offensive.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Prime Minister Churchill who came home yesterday from his historic visit to Washington, reaching London after an air trip across the Atlantic in which he himself piloted the big flying boat part of the way, spent most of today getting ready to make a statement to the House of Commons on the progress of the war in general and the Washington conference in particular.

Touching the highest point in history, engineering awards throughout the country last year amounted to $5,868,699,000, an increase of 47 per cent over the volume in 1940, which was a record up to that time. Defense construction accounted for $3,823,397,000, or 65 per cent, of last year's awards.

Mayor La Guardia made another "Talk to the People" yesterday in a broadcast over WNYC, the municipal station, but his twenty-five-minute summary of his recent activities in the field of local civilian defense contained no reference to his reported intention either to give up his post of Director of the OCD or resign as Mayor.

Christ has ever been the victorious leader, not of the world's mighty but of the "contemptibles," and his host has ever been a "rabble" from the popular point of view, declared the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer in his sermon yesterday at Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 -- The Amercans seized fifth place in the National Hockey League, dislodging Detroit with a 5-to-3 victory over the Red Wings before 7,847 spectators this afternoon. It was Brooklyn's first victory on the Olympia ice in two years.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- In light going out on Long Island Sound with a southerly air that hauled westerly, thirteen Class B dinghies competed today. In such a mild and unseasonable temperature, particularly after the week of severe cold, most of the skippers and crews thought more about budding flowers than they did of woolen garments.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 18 -- Workers employed by the contractors who are building an Army air base at the east end of the colony expect to raise $10,000 toward the purchase of a plane for the United States forces. In each worker's latest pay envelope was this statement:

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- Prices of lard held within relatively narrow limits last week on the Board of Trade, with less interest taken in futures than of late, despite sales of around 7,000,000 pounds to Mexico and more than 13,000,000 pounds to the government for lease-lend operations.

Mrs. Lucie Bigelow Rosen, thereminist, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. From the days when the theremin was still a novelty among musical instruments and in its earliest stage of development, Mrs. Rosen was one of its most serious and enthusiastic exponents.
LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued this joint communique tonight:

Since the occasion was for the benefit of producers, managers and play agents, Theatre Showcase naturally put its best foot forward last night at the Barbizon-Plaza Theatre as it presented "Pity the Kiddies" for a single performance. A comedy by George Baxt and William Boyman, with music by Wini Scott, the work offered ample opportunity for the display of varied talents.

The Department of Sanitation became the center of a fresh-water yachting mystery yesterday. Commissioner William F. Carey stoutly denied that he had asked the Comet Class Yacht Racing Association for plans and specifications for a fleet of sleek racing boats to be built for use on Whaley Lake at his department's Summer recreation center, Camp Sanita, in Putnam County.

DETROIT, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Against the recommendations of their international officers, members of the Detroit City Employes Union (A.F.L.) voted today to strike at 4 A.M. Friday to enforce demands for a 15 per cent wage increase.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- A letter describing conditions on Wake Island two days before the American garrison there was overwhelmed by Japanese invaders on Dec. 22 came to light tonight as a result of the announcement by radio from Tokyo listing United States prisoners of war who had reached Yokohama.

AN EASTERN CANADIAN PORT, Jan. 18 (AP) -- A Panaman freighter was torpedoed in the Western Atlantic and survivors, including two Americans, who reached here today said enemy submarines were "almost as thick as catfish" in the waters where they were attacked.

Six thousand lepers and their several hundred medical and non-medical attendants on the Philippine island of Culion, largest leper colony in the world, face starvation within three months unless the Japanese naval blockade is lifted to permit food supplies to reach the island, it was revealed yesterday.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Reuben White's Elisabeth R, winner of the North American Class A championship pennant for the North Shrewsbury Ice Boat and Yacht Club in 1935, triumphed in the first race of that class sailed today over the North Shrewsbury course before a large crowd.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Final legislative action on the Price Control Bill and the beginning of committee consideration of a new war conversion unemployment relief bill are the outstanding matters facing Congress this week.

Warning that fire loss in New York City could increase during war years, Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh reported yesterday that the department was better equipped to cope with wartime hazards than in the past.

The General Tire and Rubber Company had net sales of $37,353,021 in the year ended on Nov. 30, William O'Neil, president, announced yesterday. This was 60 per cent greater than the figure for 1940 and a new high record for the company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Budget Director Harold D. Smith expects an increase of 85,000 government employes in Washington this year, with a total increase in the capital's population of around 250,000. The city's population was 663,153 in the 1940 census and has increased sharply since then.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Following an exhaustive survey, the foreign minerals division of the Bureau of Mines in the Department of the Interior reported today that Germany "is surprisingly well supplied with minerals for essential military needs."

Attendance was heavy in the wholesale markets last week, and in the lines that were active there was a general tendency to trade up. This was particularly true in dress markets, where bookings were exceptionally good. Fur markets were almost cleaned out, and there was a general stiffening of prices.

Subway traffic on the Pelham Bay division was disrupted for forty-five minutes yesterday morning as the result of a collision of a seven-car IRT train without passengers and a twelve-car "dead" train on the center track between the Castle Hill Avenue and Zerega Avenue station, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- For the purpose of making it possible for small manufacturers to bid on large Army contracts on Tuesday, Leon Henderson, Federal Price Administrator, fixed today specific maximum prices for several grades of wool tops used to make Army OD serge, shirting flannel and underwear.

KUIBYSHEV, Jan. 17 (delayed) (AP) -- The first contingents of new Red Army reserves have completed their training period of three and a half months under the plan for universal compulsory military service started on Oct. 1 by the State Defense Committee headed by Premier Joseph Stalin, it was announced today.

The role of women as hardworking, full-time aviation mechanics at La Guardia Field received formal recognition yesterday as Pan American Airways announced that part of the maintenance work required by its huge flying boats had been delegated to a squad of repairwomen.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 18 (AP) -- British Headquarters issued this communique today:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- Acting President Ramon S. Castillo said today that conflicting conduct among the Western Hemisphere nations in connection with the war handicapped the work of the Rio de Janeiro conference.
Miss Sonja Henie's 1942 Hollywood Ice Revue will open its New York engagement at Madison Square Garden tonight. There will be eight performances.
ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 18 (AP) -- Two officers and an enlisted man were killed today when their medium bomber crashed into an isolated part of Lake Apopka.

BATAVIA, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- Everything useful to the Japanese, including shipping, was destroyed at Kuching, capital of Sarawak, Borneo, before the small garrison fell back to Netherland Borneo, a Sarawak Government European officer, who was among the last to leave, said on arriving here today.
OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 18 -- Racing home with another sub-par round, his fourth in as many days, Byron Nelson carded a 72-hole total of 274 to win the $5,000 Oakland open golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- With the public roads system used principally by automobiles in local community traffic rather than for long-distance travel, Federal highway expenditures should be limited to activities "clearly serving broad national purposes if costs are to be distributed according to benefits derived," according to a study of American highway policy made public by the Brookings Institution today.

John L. Lewis, founder and first president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and leaders of the American Federation of Labor are so confident of unity in the ranks of organized labor that already they have reached an understanding on officers to head a unified labor movement, it became known last night.

A three-goal deficit before the hostilities were half over meant little to the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night. The Blue Shirts, showing no inclination to accept defeat humbly, fired away, brought about a deadlock in the third period, and went on in the overtime to win, 5 to 4.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 18 -- Broadcasting the American shortwave radio offensive against Axis propagandists in the Far East, KGEI, the General Electric station in this city, will add Thai tomorrow to the seven languages in which it has been disseminating news and information on a seventeen-hour daily schedule since Dec. 7.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- All German, Italian and Japanese nationals were warned today by the Department of Justice that they must bring their "alien registration receipt cards" when applying at postoffices for certificates of identification.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., has arranged for a loan of $2,000,000 at 2 1/2 per cent from the New York Trust Company, and the Guaranty Trust Company and the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, the company announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Sara W. Clucas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Clucas, to Charles S. von Stade, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Skiddy von Stade, will take place on Saturday in the private chapel at Hamilton Farms, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. C. Suydam Cutting, in Gladstone, N.J.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 18 (AP) -- The bodies of Carole Lombard and eight others of the twenty-two who were killed Friday night in the crash of an airliner against a cliff thirty-five miles southwest of here were brought to Las Vegas tonight.

Nations who have "made a shipwreck of conscience" have been exposed by this world war, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday morning in a sermon in the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street, Brooklyn.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 18 -- The steel industry moved last week closer to a total war footing, with many companies shipping between 85 and 90 per cent of their production out on rated business. This tendency, it is said, will continue for some time, especially in view of the heavy demand for plates, munitions and lease-lend materials.

Dartmouth's return to ascendancy in the Eastern League and St. John's rousing overtime triumph over Fordham were the major items of a rather placid week on the near-by college basketball front. Farther afield it was an entirely different story and many a sectional court idol was found to have feet of clay.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 18 -- New signs of inflation threatening Germany are seen by foreign observers here in a Berlin report appearing in Stockholm's Tidningen to the effect that, contrary to their previous policy, German authorities are now permitting an increase in prices.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 18 -- Heavily increased shipments of food and medical supplies will be started for Greece by way of Turkey in the immediate future, according to reports circulating in foreign diplomatic circles here today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (From Soviet broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Soviet dispatches from abroad said today that German Field Marshal Walther yon Reichenau, whose death was announced in Berlin, was "removed" by Gestapo agents after his Sixth Army had suffered heavy losses in the Ukraine.

The seventh anniversary o5 the Catholic Interracial Council was observed yesterday in conjunction with the fifteenth anniversary of the Catholic Laymen's Union at an all-day conference at St Peter's Church, Church and Barclay Streets.

Wilson Woodbeck, Negro baritone who has been a red cap for American Airlines for the last seven years, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Although it was his second local recital, it was his first appearance for the general public.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- With the "Salvage for Victory" campaign getting under way in this State and throughout the nation to recover for munitions and necessary civilian production scrap paper, metals, rubber and rags, Governor Lehman's committee on the conservation of waste materials called attention today to a survey of possible waste recovery in Nassau County, which alone may yield 37,000 tons of paper yearly, out of 1,000,000 tons in the State.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 (AP) -- British Middle East Headquarters issued this communique today:
Finding God is an entirely personal experience, declared the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker in his sermon yesterday in Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street.

As a solution of traffic problems caused by automobile-cluttered streets, Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio yesterday urged the creation of a Parking Authority empowered to build and operate parking lots and garages. In an interview at West Side Week-end Court, where he sat following two weeks in Traffic Court, he also suggested reduction of the speed limit at night.

One of the most encouraging developments to newspaper publishers in recent months has been the spurt staged by national advertising linage in the final quarter of last year. A November gain of 19 per cent was followed by a 25 per cent increase last month over the like 1940 month.
The torpedoing of a third merchant ship in a week off the Atlantic Coast was announced just before last midnight by the Navy.

A gift of $75,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York to the Red Cross War Fund was announced yesterday by George Roberts, chairman of the men's special gifts committee of the fund. At the same time Colby M. Chester, chairman of the commerce and industry division, announced gifts of $25,000 from the Chemical and Trust Company, $5,500 from the Bowery Savings Bank and $5,000 from the Lone Star Cement Company.

The twelve-story building at 28 West Twenty-seventh Street, containing concerns in the ribbon, corset and brassiere lines, has been sold by the Ansonia Buildings Corporation to an investing client of Williams Co., brokers. It is on a plot 58 by 100 feet and is assessed at $210,000.

LONDON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Sinister intrigue behind the back of Adolf Hitler caused the death of Field Marshal General Walther von Reichenau, the British press reasoned today with unanimous skepticism of the official announcement that he died of apoplexy.

The city's emergency medical service has, ready and waiting in the event of an air raid, the services of 11,000 of the city's 15,922 registered physicians and surgeons, 15,000 hospital nurses, an additional 10,000 professional nurses now in private practice, and nearly 1,000 private and public ambulances, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Thomas Midgley Jr., discoverer of tetraethyl lead, which has made possible great advance in automotive and aircraft engines, is the winner of the 1942 Willard Gibbs medal, of the American Chemical Society, it was announced today.
Women had better hold on to their hats once they have selected their shiny straw bonnets for Easter.

After approaching early last week the peak prices of last September the cotton market developed an irregular trend, but it showed moderate gains for the week at the close of the short session on Saturday. On the New York Cotton Exchange prices of active futures contracts registered net increases, of 27 to 35 points.

WITH IMPERIAL FORCES IN WEST MALAYA, Jan. 11 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- General Sir Archibald P. Wavell visited the Malaya fighting front three days ago, so near to advanced positions that he had to withdraw hurriedly to avoid a possibility of being trapped by the Japanese.
WITH THE A.I.F., On the Malayan Front, Jan. 17 (Delayed) (Australian Associated Press) -- Japanese forces, as expected, are trying to harass the newly arrived Australian defenders by flank attacks.

Radio and press releases have again called attention to the boundary dispute between Ecuador and Peru in connection with the conference of the Foreign Ministers of the American republics in Rio de Janeiro. Some of the commentators went so far as to call Ecuador's plea for a settlement through the offices of the conference now in progress obstructionist and ill-timed.

Roland Gundry, 19-year-old American violinist, who was educated in France and made his debut here four years ago, was the soloist last night with the New York City Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall in the twelfth of the series of popular-priced concerts sponsored by Mayor La Guardia and the New York City WPA Music Project.

WITH THE SIXTIETH UNITED STATES COAST ARTILLERY, on the Bataan Peninsula, P.I., Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- The day starts early for the crack anti-aircraft units of the United States armed forces of the Far East.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- The rectorship at historic 120-year-old St. Stephen's Church in this city, vacant for more than two years, is to be filled by the Rev. Alfred William Price, rector of St. Philip's Episcopal Church, Dyker Heights, Brooklyn.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Along the narrow 400-mile Burma panhandle where hunters once bagged rhinoceroses and elephants the British today were withstanding renewed Japanese pressure and organizing forces for an eventual thrust against the invaders' lifeline.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- General Douglas MacArthur's American and Filipino troops have beaten off the latest Japanese drive for control of the Bataan Peninsula, commanding the entrance to Manila Bay, and have retaken several positions in the area after two days of sharp fighting, the War Department announced today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 11 -- An upsurge of more than 200,000 in imports from the United States during the first ten months of 1941 as compared with the same period in 1939 is noted in the report of an Assembly committee that has just finished an investigation of the operations of the colony's wartime Food and Supplies Control Board.

The investigation of the progress of our defense efforts and of the conduct of the war is one of the most important functions that Congress can perform. But as there is opportunity to study various parts of the Truman committee's report in detail, it is unfortunately becoming evident that in many directions the committee has done its job badly.

Educators, industrialists and other groups conferring in a spirit of sympathy on the problems of the industrial rehabilitation of the handicapped will find their well-intentioned gathering unproductive unless a definite, constructive plan is drawn up wherein the rehabilitation processes lead toward assured jobs in industry.

The important incident of the week was the appointment of a single head for the arms production program. Up to the naming of Donald Nelson last Tuesday as the responsible chief, ranking over Messrs. Knudsen and Hillman and Vice President Wallace, we had lived in a period of executive experiment, in which the authority of one department was bound to clash with that of another.
BERLIN, Jan. 18 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- In a leading article headed "Can America Do It?" The Financial News examines President Roosevelt's task in accomplishing successfully the gigantic arms program now launched. Particular attention is paid to the question of diversion of output, which, the writer observes, offers tremendous problems.

The vanity and whimsy of American women may be catered to through the array of Latin-American products at the Macy Fair, but for thousands of Latin-American women the display means new hope, a chance to earn the money they so sorely need to buy the bare necessities of life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard, appearing as Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's guest on her regular Sunday evening broadcast, declared tonight that the United States now had more food on hand than ever before at this time of year.

THERE came word from overseas last week that J.T. (Bossy) Phelps had died. Bossy was a great figure in rowing circles on the Thames. He was "By Appointment," which means under the royal hand and seal, "the King's Bargemaster." Further than that he was one of the Phelps family that had ruled the river from Putney to Mortlake for some 300 years.
LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The Economist's index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 108.5 on Dec. 30, compared with 108.4 on Dec. 9, 100.9 at the end of 1940 and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 18 -- The Australian ambush north of Gemas, in which from 800 to 1,000 Japanese soldiers were killed, was worked out days in advance, Major Gen. Henry Gordon Bennett, commander of Australian forces in Malaya, disclosed today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 18 -- "We have no right to the realization of our pretensions to control Europe until we have shown the courage to surmount, by revolutionary means if need be, the theory of the community of peoples in Christianity, which has outlived itself in the past 2,000 years," wrote M.F. Schmidt, vice gauleiter of Wuerttemberg, in a pamphlet addressed to the Hitler Youth, published recently in Germany.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 18 -- One South American country was prepared to break off relations with the Axis powers from the scene of the conference of American Foreign Ministers, now under way here, and thereby force a decision by the conference itself, should Argentina unduly delay in joining with the other American republics on this issue, according to a well-substantiated report today.

The capitulation of the German and Italian forces at Halfaya Pass on the Egyptian border is more important than it may seem. When the British by-passed this formidable position and swept on across Cyrenaica the surrender of the 5,500 troops isolated there appeared to be inevitable.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 -- Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., former Chief of Staff of the Fleet, told the National Conference for Palestine today that Palestine was a vital center for naval and air support for the Allied cause. He said that that country was in "a splendid geographical position to help carry forward the war."

The first of the season's major three-weapon fencing competitions the Honeycutt Memorial team tourney, resulted in a victory for the New York Athletic Club yesterday on the strips of the Winged Foot aggregation.

In order to furnish data for possible evacuation plans, the Board of Education and the Office of Civilian Defense are jointly preparing to take a census of all residents of New York City who are under the age of 21 years, as well as all residents who are incapacitated by advanced age, invalidism, or other handicaps, it became known yesterday.

All persons aboard the American freighters San Jose, of the United Fruit Line, and the Santa Elisa, of the Grace Line, were said last night to be accounted for by the rescue of thirty-five crew members of the San Jose, which sank after a collision of the two vessels Saturday night southeast of Atlantic City, N.J.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 18 -- "Priorities of 1942," a screen musical with a steel plant background, has been scheduled for production by Sol C. Seigel at Paramount, with Robert Preston and Ellen Drew in the leading roles. Art Arthur is writing the scenario to fit several specialty players who are under contract to Paramount, including Cass Daley, Gil Lamb, Betty Jane Rhodes and Johnny Johnston.
MOSCOW, Jan. 18 (From Soviet broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Bureau of Information communique broadcast today said:

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Local draft boards have been advised by Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State director of Selective Service, to grant sixty-day postponements to induction to senior law school students who come within the provisions of the Court of Appeals ruling that senior students shall take their examinations for admission to the bar in March.
There are in this country quite a number of foreigners who have always been great admirers of America and who appreciate in full the advantages of her magnificent hospitality.

The bronze liturgical altar that was presented to St. Patrick's Cathedral by an anonymous donor a year ago will be installed next month, the Rev. Michael J. Deacy announced at solemn mass yesterday, reading a memorandum from Archbishop Francis J. Spellman.
CHICAGO, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins defeated the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 4 to 3, to retain their lead in the National Hockey League race.

The German Transocean news service gave to the world on Jan. 6 what purported to be details of Prime Minister Churchill's departure from this continent for England. The story, which was not published here at the time, can now be compared with what actually happened.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 18 -- Although war production as yet is only a fraction of the goals set by President Roosevelt, the industrial regions of the Midwest have taken long steps toward conversion of peacetime industries into weapon factories.

It seems to me that some doubt still exists as to what shall be done with short-wave radios and cameras. Many people believe that as long as they themselves are citizens they do not have to turn in these articles at their local police station.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 18 -- Striking with unabated fury behind air attacks that have dealt Singapore its heaviest blow so far, Japanese invaders today pressed still closer to this Far Eastern bulwark of the United Nations but, apparently, they were able only to inch ahead against Britain's stiffening defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- A billion-dollar quota has been set for the purchase of Defense Bonds by the 5,000,000 members of the American Federation of Labor and all affiliated unions during the coming year, it was announced today by William Green, A.F.L. president.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- Torger Tokle continued his remarkable ski-jumping achievements today as he carried off both the Class A honors and the President Roosevelt Trophy at the annual event sponsored by his own club, the Norway S.C.

WHAT seems to be the first full-dress history of American commercial aviation comes out this morning as the first winner of the so-called Fellowship in History to be offered annually by the publishing house of Knopf: Henry Ladd Smith's 400-page annotated, illustrated survey, "Airways."*

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (AP) -- The Treasury acknowledged today receipts of $4,708,696 from pinball and slot machines for three months. It did not disclose particulars on the payment. The machines are illegal in some States.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 18 (AP) -- Japan's air force fanned out to attack air and naval bases over a span of 2,200 miles in the Netherlands Indies archipelago, it was announced today, possibly as a prelude to attempts at seizure of vantage points from which to flank the key island of Java.

Events tonight: "Don Giovanni," conducted by Bruno Walter, at Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 o'clock; Emile Baume, piano recital, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Erica Morini, violin recital, Town Hall, 8:30; Frederick Bristol, piano recital, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 9; National String Quartet, Hardesty Johnson, tenor, Beverly Peck, piano, and Vivian Rivkin, piano, joint recital, Room 213, New York Public Library, 8:30; program of recorded music, Emerson School, 12 East Ninety-sixth Street, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The possibility of women "in active war duty" was mentioned by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox in a message read this morning before the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense. The message, delivered by Lieut. Comdr. Thomas J. Keane of the Navy Office of Public Relations, read:

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 18 -- Advices from Germany seem today to indicate that the Nazis are about to renew their efforts to "normalize" relations with France. Indications to this effect come not so much from Berlin as from such centers as Brussels and Strasbourg, where the newspapers hint at forthcoming developments.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- Dr. Karl Otto Heinrich Lange, German-born instructor at Harvard University's Blue Hills meteorological observatory, has been in Federal custody since Dec. 8 as an enemy alien, members of the Harvard faculty revealed last night.

Breakfast can become more than the mere accompaniment to the morning paper if the familiar pattern is occasionally broken. Without disrupting routine too much, a monotonous menu of fruit juice, toast and coffee may be changed to a formula something like this:

When Pug Manders pivoted from the arms of a Giant tackler and went an extra fourteen yards in the Dodger-Giant football game last month, he gained the margin that made him the leading ground- gainer in the National Football League, according to the official 1941 statistics released yesterday.

With the completion of the program now under way, the United States and associated nations should be assured of an ample supply of high-grade aviation gasoline for both military and commercial purposes. Last week, defense authorities and oil company executives completed arrangements for a program that will increase the output of 100-octane gasoline to 150,000 barrels daily by the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- Damage inflicted on military and naval establishments in Hawaii during the Dec. 7 Japanese attack has been "completely repaired," Hawaiian Delegate Samuel W. King said tonight.
Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that the question of a fare increase on transit lines owned and operated by the city was strictly a local issue in which the Legislature should not interfere.

OTTAWA, Jan. 18 -- Certain kinds of pulpwood have been added to the list of products for which an export permit is required before they can be exported. These include pulpwood of spruce, balsam, hemlock, jackpine or poplar, either in the form of cordwood or logs.

The resignation of Alfred Harcourt, president and co-founder with Donald C. Brace of the publishing house of Harcourt, Brace Co., 383 Madison Avenue, was announced yesterday. Mr. Brace, who has been both vice president and treasurer of the concern, will become its head and will continue as treasurer.

Antoine de St. Exupery has delivered to Reynal Hitchock the manuscript of his first book since "Wind, Sand and Stars." It is entitled "Flight to Arras" and is the story of twenty-four hours in the life of an observation pilot during the final days of the French Republic.
THE NEW YORK TIMES reported that spotted typhus is rapidly spreading in the German-occupied Polish, Ukrainian and Russian areas.

Replying to those who question how the church can justify this war, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo asserted yesterday that resistance was part of the program of Jesus Christ. We cannot bring freedom into the world unless we are willing to pay the price; this is a conflict of ideals, not arms, he said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- With members of the United States Supreme Court and subordinate courts, the Cabinet and Diplomatic Corps and legislators of both branches of Congress in attendance, the annual "Red Mass," traditionally associated with the opening of the courts and legislative bodies of Europe, was solemnized this morning in the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception at Catholic University of America.

Five lectures dealing with the needs of a total civilian defense program and emphasizing volunteer services to the community in maintaining social services and public morale win begin tonight at the Town Hall, 125 West Forty-third Street, the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office announced yesterday.

During the last few days there has been some criticism in China, and by Chinese organizations in this country, of statements made by American and British officials describing Hitler as the No. 1 Enemy of the United Nations. The comment of Dr. Sun Fo, chairman of the Chinese Legislative Yuan, is a case in point.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 18 -- General Fedele de Georgis and General Francisco Buttafuoco, first and second in command of the Italian Fifty-fifth Savona Division, and Major Bach, senior German officer, were among the 5,500 prisoners taken yesterday at Halfaya Pass.

Howie Hollinger and Bill Tilson helped the New York Rovers no little as the locals beat the cellardwelling Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 5 to 2, in the Eastern Hockey League fracas featuring the amateur double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- The progress of the war in the Far East, especially in Malaya, loomed large in the thoughts of the stock markets last week and completely offset the cheering effect that the good news from Russia and Libya otherwise would have had.
TOKYO, Jan. 18 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The second group of United States prisoners of war 1,235 men from the garrison of Wake Island, reached Yokohama today.

The American people must do their share toward ridding the world of the "irresponsibility of hate and revenge" and replacing it with the "responsibility of good-will" if civilization is to outlast the present crisis, Myron C. Taylor, President Roosevelt's envoy to the Vatican, declared yesterday.

The annual commemoration service of Columbia University, "to have in special remembrance all those who during their lifetime were members of the university fellowship," was held yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel on the campus. Thirty-six members of the university died in 1941.

Joining forces once more to the surprise of no one but themselves, this morning's joyous tidings are that Katharine Hepburn, Philip Barry, the Theatre Guild and Robert B. Sinclair will be concerned with Mr. Barry's newest work, a comedy entitled "Without Love."

The Malay barrier -- the scattered archipelago that provides an almost continuous "land bridge" from Southeastern Asia to Australia -- became last week a new battleground in the struggle for the world.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 18 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces pursuing decimated Japanese units were seventy miles north of Changsha today, hammering at the outer defense lines of Yochow, important Japanese Yangtze River base.

Britain has only one Churchill. When his critics cry that if Singapore falls he falls, they are uttering a pretty hollow threat, particularly at the moment of his return to London from Washington with the most extraordinary contract ever worked out between two nations.

The 1,000 employes at the Edo Aircraft Corporation, 13-10 111th Street, College Point, Queens, worked a full shift without pay yesterday as a "Win the War" contribution to the government. The seaplane parts made will be donated to the Navy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18 -- The broadest demand for cash corn witnessed in a long time has developed recently and despite fair arrivals from the country it is estimated that the Commodity Credit Corporation has been able to dispose of 25,000,000 bushels in the last two weeks.
GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 18 -- George Cummings and Dave McElroy repeated their victory of a year ago in the Nassau Country Club's second annual pro-amateur squash racquets tournament today.

Five thousand boarded-up tenement houses in the five boroughs constitute a threat to the city as a whole in the event of attack by incendiary bombs and should be demolished or made habitable by repairs, according to a report made yesterday by the Committee on Housing of the Community Service Society.

The unexplained death of the socially prominent Dr. Allyn King Foster Jr. in the violent ward of Bellevue Hospital's psychiatric division resulted yesterday in a triple investigation by the District Attorney's office, the Medical Examiner's office and police.

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET, Jan. 18 -- It is not the war, it is the monotony that gets a Navy man down, especially a Navy flier. Sitting for hours on a parachute pack in a cockpit so small you can hardly stretch your legs, scanning a limitless sea for an enemy ship and an even more vast sky for enemy planes is not exciting.

Mme. Alexander Loudon, wife of the Netherland Minister to the United States, will speak this afternoon at a birthday celebration of the Woman's Board of Foreign Missions of the Reformed Church in America. The board was organized sixty-seven years ago.

In an argument concerning justice, Socrates once put his opponents to flight by asking whether they would prefer living in a house built by a just man or a good carpenter, and today many New York sportsmen are finding a somewhat similar parallel in setting forth their argument in favor of a nonpolitical conservation set-up.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Governor Lehman has completed work on a State budget for the fiscal year which starts on July 1, and, according to usually reliable quarters, the estimates will be less than the $385,000,000 State budget submitted last year.

Lydia Summers, contralto, was heard in her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Miss Summers, who is a member of the New Opera Company, sang Pauline in Tchaikovsky's "Pique Dame" during that organization's recent season here.

It is hard to discern why Erica Morini, who played at the Town Hall last night, does not pack them in. Is it because the general, public still looks with suspicion and reservations on a woman fiddler? What reasons there are could not have anything to do with the quality of Miss Morini's playing.
Two plain gold wedding rings -- the kind familiar a half century ago -- became a widow's mite for the British war effort yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Allout war against preventable disease was declared at the White House today where forty men and women met from all parts of the country at the invitation of Mrs. Roosevelt formally to open the 1942 Women's Week of the Fight Infantile Paralysis campaign.

Increases totaling $320,000 more than their current budgets were requested yesterday for the fiscal year 1942-43 by the office of the Borough President of Manhattan, the Court of General Sessions and the County Courts of Kings, the Bronx and Queens at hearings before Budget Director Kenneth L. Dayton in the latter's office in the Municipal Building.

As a result of their latest victories, New Rochelle and Garden City are tied for first place in the men's Class A race, according to the report yesterday of the Metropolitan Badminton Association. New Rochelle had a hard time beating Central, 3 to 2, while Garden City defeated Rutgers, 5 to 0. The pace-setters are to meet on Sunday.

To avoid conflict with a previous contract involving Bob Pastor, Promoter Mike Jacobs of the Twentieth Century S.C. yesterday advanced the date of the Inwood heavyweight's proposed ten-round bout against Gus Lesnevich, world light-heavyweight champion, to Jan. 30 at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The War Department released the following orders today, dated Jan. 17:

NOW the only reason that young Johnny Ames didn't marry the boss's daughter shortly after arriving in New York City is that the boss didn't have a daughter. Walter D. Edmonds tells all about it in "Young Ames,"* his latest historical novel, which is good history and almost perfect Horatio Alger.

Asserting that the present prices of farm products "are very satisfactory and profitable to the producer," Thomas D. Campbell of Hardin, Mont., issued a statement here yesterday deploring the "selfish and arrogant" attitude of leaders of the farm bloc in Congress in resisting President Roosevelt's program of food price control.
BERLIN, Jan. 19 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today said:
WITH THE U.S.A.F.F.E., on Bataan Peninsula, Jan. 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- With shot and shell but also with song the fighting Yanks of Bataan peninsula sound their defiance to the attacking Japanese.

January is only well begun, but the wiseacres already are beginning to wonder what the railroads will do with the increased revenues they will earn this year. When they turn to this problem the managements will have to consider taxes and determine whether increased earnings have offset the large wage increases which took effect toward the close of 1941 and how much of earnings should be devoted to the reduction of debt.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 19 -Screen rights to "Friendly Enemies,'' Broadway comedy of 1918 by Samuel Shipman and Aaron Hoffman, have been acquired by Edward Small, United Artists producer, from Al Woods, who originally staged the play, Small announced today. Allan Dwan will direct the film version, starting early in March. The scenario will be kept in the 1918 period and will remain a comedy, according to Small.

In view of the heavy condition of lamp inventories held by most stores, buyers were generally conservative in their commitments yesterday at the opening of the New York Lamp Show in the Hotel New Yorker. However, a number of buyers representing large stores known to have heavy stocks placed large orders, presumably for warehousing. Prices in general were unchanged from recent levels, though considerably above a year ago.

Bearing seventy survivors from the United Fruit steamship San Jose, which sank off Atlantic City Saturday night, and the Grace Line freighter Santa Elisa, with which the San Jose collided, two merchant ships put into Norfolk, Va., yesterday.

The Lotos Club, which tried to advance "women's rights" in a day when the women themselves were not sure they wanted them, will revive its old idea by opening a restaurant and lounge for women at its clubhouse, 110 West Fiftyseventh Street, on Jan. 31, Eugene Sweeney, executive secretary, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 14:

In preparation for government allocation of practically all important materials and for the general switch-over to war production, industrial purchasing agents throughout the country are reducing their forward purchasing to a minimum, reports locally and from other sections indicated yesterday.
Mr. and Mrs. Wright Barclay will give a reception Sunday afternoon at their home, 77 Park Avenue.

Scoring the sharpest advance of the year to date, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 39 per cent last week over the corresponding week of 1941, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan 19 -- Cornell-Dubilier Electric Company of South Plainfield, N.J., which on Dec. 29, 1941, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering an alternative offering of either $1,500,000 of convertible debentures or 30,000 shares of 5 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock, $50 par, today amended its registration statement in entirety.

The American Red Cross is appealing for $50,000,000 to provide relief for American war victims and to carry on rapidly expanding Red Cross services for the armed forces. The Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York is seeking $7,330,000 of the national goal in a united local chapter appeal in the five boroughs, as follows: Manhattan and the Bronx, $6,250,000; Brooklyn, $700,000; Queens, North Shore, $50,000; Central Queens, $250,000; Staten Island, $80,000.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The stock markets developed a firmer tendency today after opening quiet. Gilt-edge investment buying lifted old consols to 82 7/8 aind loans to 96 1/2. A few changes occurred in the industrials.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 19 -- The dramatic story of how Australian units in the Muar sector on the west coast of Johore stemmed Japanese infiltration and destroyed ten Japanese tanks was told here by official photographers with the Australians.

BATAAN, Philippine Islands, Jan. 16 (Delayed) -- Very few civilians left Manila for Bataan Province. It was reliably reported today that a mining engineer named Bonlanigan took eight Americans across Manila Bay by starboat. Perhaps a score of others reached this peninsula but the number is not known.

At the annual meeting of the Seiberling Rubber Company held yesterday in Akron, Ohio, J.P. Seiberling, president, predicted that profits in 1942 will be smaller than in 1941 despite the fact that the company is engaged in war production and vastly increased government business is in prospect.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 19 -- Borneo head hunters, masked with fright-instilling war paint and with their ancient spears sharpened, are ready to go on the war path against "the Germans and Hitler Japanese."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- All air transport in the United States, both passenger and express, was placed today under government priority regulation in an order issued by Brig. Gen. Donald R. Connolly, military director of civil aviation.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 19 -Well-informed Argentine circles believe today that the negotiations at Rio de Janeiro aiming to achieve a united American front on the question of rupture of relations with the Axis have entered into a new and more promising phase now that Argentina has proposed a formula for reaching a compromise between the majority favorable to immediate rupture and the minority favorable to the status quo.

Eight top-notch vaudevillians are being assembled under the auspices of the USO-Camp Shows to entertain the troops in Iceland, it was learned yesterday. The group, which will be directed by Edward Duryea Dowling, will be gone for about two months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today that it had asked Justice T. Alan Goldsborough of the District of Columbia court to step aside as judge in the trial of George Sylvester Viereck on the ground that he had a personal bias against the government and that the justice had refused.

The lawyers had finished their opening addresses yesterday in the General Sessions trial of twelve men, including four labor leaders and several of the old Lepke-Gurrah gang, on a forty-five-count indictment in an alleged $2,500,000 milk extortion racket, when Judge James Garrett Wallace surprised the defendants and their counsel by cancelling their bail.

There has been small cause for rejoicing in Germany since Hitler announced on Oct. 3 that Russia "is already broken and will never rise again." Whether the reverses the German Army has since suffered at the hands of the Red Army really have created a rift between the Nazi party and the Army High Command it is impossible to determine with any degree of certainty.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 19 -- ''We have the courage to speak the truth. The formation of the new government is a decisive step on the road toward the incorporation pure and simple of our country into the Greater German Reich."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 19 -- A decline in business activity, some contraction of inventories and a reduction in forward buying were reported today in the monthly business survey, covering December, of the Purchasing Agents Association of Northern California.

With the waters that lie between ourselves and our good neighbors to the south daily becoming less appealing to those with an urge to get away from it all, it's particularly cheering to find that we may enjoy their exotic foods without so much as leafing through a travel folder.

In the belief that war time interest in museums is greater than ever, as shown by experience in London, the board of trustees of the American Museum of Natural History announced at its annual meeting last night a program for widening the services of the museum.

Emile Baume, French pianist, who has given four Town Hall recitals since his debut here five years ago, last night gave his first recital at Carnegie Hall. He set himself an exacting task, for, with the exception of the opening BachBusoni Chaconne, his entire program was devoted to the twentyseven etudes of Chopin.

An entire floor at 103 Fifth Avenue has been leased to William Heller, men's clothing, through M. L. Hess, Inc., and Williams Co., Inc., one of the commercial leases reported by brokers yesterday disclosed.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Witnesses testified today at the opening of the general court martial of Colonel H.C. Kress Muhlenberg, former commandant of Hickam Field, Honolulu that in a public speech he made here while in uniform he said that blame for the Pearl Harbor disaster could be laid to the American public's sanctioning of a policy of sending aircraft to Axis foes abroad.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- The National Automobile Dealers Association asked tonight for Federal legislation to enable the nation's 44,000 automobile dealers to stay in business.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Prices of hogs advanced 15 to 25 cents a 100 pounds today under aggressive buying as producers curtailed shipments to major centers. Best hogs brought $11.75, only 10 cents under the highest quotation since the entry of the United States into the war. Dressed pork remained unchanged.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Britis Genera! Headquarters cormuiqu6 8aid today:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- The cost of civilian defense in Westchester County is increasing so sharply that real estate should be relieved of the burden of paying for it, County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach said today in his annual message to the board of supervisors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee recommended to the Senate today the confirmation of Herbert W. Christenberry as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of Louisiana. It said that charges that he possessed "neither the moral qualifications nor the character" requisite to the office were "based on conclusions and inferences rather than on fact."

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 19 -The Government of Burma of which U Saw was Premier hampered transportation on the Burma Road, according to Harold C. Davis of West Hartford, one of three American transportation experts sent over last Summer to straighten out the tangled traffic on China's life line.

The action of an air raid warden who served as an elevator operator for about ten minutes yesterday threatened to involve civilian defense authorities in a brief strike at the Hotel Empire, a twelve-story structure with accommodations for 850 guests at Broadway and Sixty-third Street.

Rosa Bok, who was injured Thursday night when the wagon overturned in which she rode on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House in the last act of "Le Coq D'Or," is not sufficiently recovered to sing her role in the company's performance of the opera tonight in Philadelphia. Josephine Antoine, the understudy, will take her place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- In a six-to-two division today the Supreme Court sustained a Fifth Circuit Court ruling preventing the reopening of a National Labor Relations Board order against the Southport Petroleum Company.

St. Vincent's Hospital, Eleventh Street and Seventh Avenue, revealed yesterday that plans have been completed to insure comparative safety for patients during air raids and for the speedy functioning of the hospital's four disaster units.

Eight top-notch vaudevillians are being assembled under the auspices of the USO-Camp Shows to entertain the troops in Iceland, it was learned yesterday. The group, which will be directed by Edward Duryea Dowling, will be gone for about two months.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Any one who is hoarding soap, sugar, silk stockings or auto tires is just fooling himself -- or herself -- in the opinion of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Banks and trust companies in New York State reported at the close of business on Sept. 24 last total deposits at another high record of $13,168,000,000, an increase of more than $1,000,000,000 over the call figure on Oct. 2, 1940, William R. White, State Superintendent of Banks, disclosed in his annual report yesterday to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

Argentina's recent conversion of 4,000,000,000 pesos of national internal bonds and national mortgage bonds will augment treasury funds about 159,000,000 pesos annually through savings in interest and increased income-tax revenue, according to a statement yesterday by the Argentine Information Bureau quoting Carlos A. Acevedo, Minister of Finance.

Despite the fact that the Pepsi-Cola Company does not expect a sales gain this year over 1941, because of sugar rationing, the company has sharply increased its advertising budget. A quality and purity theme will replace the high-pressure selling copy of last year and the campaign will be built around the use of Sterilamps, which purify the air during the filling and capping operation of each bottle in the company's plant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- With Administration reinforcements and the switching of a few votes, the House reversed itself today and by a margin of only five votes permitted funds and functions of the Office of Civilian Defense to remain under control of Mayor La Guardia and James M. Landis, newly appointed executive director, instead of transferring them to the War Department.

Winston Churchill flew from the United States to England in eighteen hours. That is one argument which may bob up in the House of Commons if ever a direct assault upon the Churchill government comes to pass.

The annual report of Helena Rubinstein, Inc., announced yesterday for the year ended on Sept. 30, disclosed a net income of $823,259 after all charges. The earnings are equal, after dividend requirements on the class A stock, to $4.59 a share on 157,658 common shares and compare with $434,575 or $2.28 a common share earned in the nine months ended with September, 1940.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Patrick Jay Hurley, Secretary of War in the Hoover Cabinet, was nominated today by President Roosevelt for a temporary appointment as a brigadier general in the Army. Mr. Hurley held a reserve rank of colonel of infantry.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 19 -- A petition was cabled to Washington today urging President Roosevelt to remove Rexford Guy Tugwell as Governor "as the only means of establishing coordination and harmony in plans for civilian defense" for San Juan.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 20 (From Broadcasts Recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- Japanese troops in the Philippines have occupied "an important enemy position" south of Olongapo navy base and are attempting to cut off the American-Filipino Army's avenue of retreat on Bataan peninsula, it was reported today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe, defending champion from New York, kept pace with leaders of the world three-cushion billiard tournament tonight by defeating Otto Reiselt of Cleveland, 50 to 34, in thirty-seven innings.

Add to the list of films opening this week "Son of Fury," which will arrive at the Roxy on Friday. Based on the Edison Marshall novel "Benjamin Blake," the Twentieth Century-Fox production features Tyrone Power, Gene Tierney, George Sanders, Frances Farmer and Roddy McDowall. . . . "Public Enemies" and "Riders of the Badlands" compose the week's new double-feature program, beginning today, at the New York Theatre.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 19 -Juan Antonio Rios, the Popular Front's candidate for President of Chile, said today that he was not in favor of breaking off relations with the Axis. He explained in an interview that he feared this would bring an attack by Japan that would be "catastrophic" for Chile, besides holding up exports of copper, nitrates and other vital war materials to the United States.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 19 -- How the shriek and crash of shells, fired from the darkness into the hull of the United States tanker Malay, started the first announced surface attack of the present war on American coastwise shipping became known here tonight from the stories of survivors.

The volume of American publishing fell off slightly in 1941 as compared to 1940, with 9,337 new books against 9,515. New editions were somewhat fewer, too, 1,775 against 1,813. Publishers Weekly, which annually charts the statistical course of publishing, discovered that last year there were 263 American publishers who brought out five or more titles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today for a record $28,500,767,495 of supplemental war appropriations and contract authorizations, made up of $15,961,945,021 for the Navy, $12,525,872,474 for the Army and $12,950,000 for other defense activities. The expenditures are to be made this year and next.

The Netherlands Indies can be held as a vital wall of defense against the Axis powers if sufficient reinforcements in airplanes and submarines are rushed to the South Pacific without delay, Dr. Hubertus J. Van Mook, Lieutenant Governor of the islands, who arrived here from Batavia two weeks ago, declared in an interview yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jam 19 (U.P.) -Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told American Legion national defense committees today that the American people have not yet received sufficiently clear directions on civilian defense procedure.

OTTAWA, Jan. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Imported consumer goods are not exempt from the retail price ceiling, Canada's Wartime Prices and Trade Board said today in a bulletin to retailers. Provision has been made for payment by the Commodity Prices Stabilization Board of subsidies on certain kinds of manufactured goods where the price to the importer has increased.

Furniture was bought cautiously, yet somewhat more actively than was anticipated, at the opening of the Spring market here yesterday in the New York Furniture Exchange. Prices in general were unchanged from November levels. Registrations at the close of the day totaled 1,820, the largest number in the history of the exchange, and compared with 1,586 on the first day of the market a year ago.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, Jan. 20 -- The latest news from the Russian front is that the Russian advance oh the Mozhaisk sector Continued on Page Ten / has resumed after several days during which Soviet gains were of but secondary importance. The Russians' midnight communiqu announced the recapture of the town of Vereya, fourteen miles southeast of ]Iozhaisk and one of the most strongly defended points on the Germans' outer lines of defenses before Mozhaisk.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has leased a private house of steel and concrete construction in the country as a refuge for some of its most valuable works of art in case of air raids in New York.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was Harold A. Ley, president of the Life Extension Institute, who leased an apartment at 400 Park Avenue through Win. A. White Sons, brokers.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va. (Tuesday), Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- An enemy submarine that attacked the American tanker Malay with shellfire early yesterday killed at least one and possibly five crew members, it was revealed early today when the crippled vessel arrived in a Southern port.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The Russian army of the north was smashing tonight at the forward anchor of the German siege lines before Leningrad in attacks of rising power synchronized with the offensive against the apparently crumbling German positions of Mozhaisk and Orel on the Moscow front.
