The suspicions of Mrs. Elsa M. Foster concerning the death of her husband, Dr. Allyn King Foster Jr., in Bellevue Hospital on Saturday were proved well-founded yesterday when Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet declared the doctor's death was caused by injuries received at the hospital.

The Metropolitan Museum win open with a private view this afternon, and to the public tomorrow, its Rembrandt exhibition, which is to remain current until March 26. The guest of honor at the preview reception today will be His Excellency Alexander Loudon, the Royal Netherlands Minister.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Jan. 19 (AP) -- Officials of North American Aviation. Inc., said today that 40 per cent of its workers at its bomber assembly plant probably will be women under a plan to step up production. Employment of women in the plant stock rooms began today and training of women for skilled work in the factory will be started immediately. Wives of men now in military service will be given preference.

Dr. Floyd W. Reeves, director of the American Youth Commission of the American Council on Education, declared yesterday that present planning for post-war-reconstruction for youth was indispensable to successful prosecution of the war and a necessary part of the will to victory.

Gus S. Eyssell, for the last eight years assistant to the late W.G. Van Schmus, was appointed to succeed Mr. Van Schmus as president of the Radio City Music Hall Corporation and managing director of both the Music Hall and the Center Theatre at a meeting yesterday of the directors board of the Music Hall Corporation. At the same time three new board members were elected and other executive appointments announced.

The long-awaited step whereby the vast securities industry of the country, including stock exchange firms, underwriters, investment dealers and traders in securities, will take an active part in the sale of Series E defense savings bonds was announced yesterday by the Treasury Department.

NEWARK, Jan. 19 -- Mrs. J. Clarence Carr, 66-year-old ex-convict whose career as a confidence woman goes back to 1901, pleaded non vult today to a charge of obtaining money under false pretenses. Common Pleas Judge Daniel J. Brennan said he would pass sentence on Jan. 28 Mrs. Carr, who by her plea threw herself on the mercy of the court, faces a three-year maximum prison term.
WASHINGTON, N.Z., Jan. 19 -Apparent satisfaction with the Pacific war line-up was revealed by Prime Minister Peter Fraser to the press today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill authorizing the President to seize and control telephone, telegraph and cable facilities if military needs so require.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A compromise proposal giving President Roosevelt the final word on fixing prices for farm products was reported to be under consideration tonight by a Senate-House conference committee attempting to iron out differences over the Administration's price-control bill.
TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 19 (AP) -- A twin-motored Army bombing plane crashed and burned at the Tacoma city limits today and the entire crew of three was killed.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 19 Tribute from the White House, Congress, motion-picture studios and moviegoers poured in today for Carole Lombard, killed with twenty-one others in the crash of a TWA airliner near here Friday night.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Back in 1922, when Bear Mountain Park entered the Winter sports picture, the late Major W. A. Welch, then general manager of the Palisades Interstate Park, foresaw the popularity of skiing and tried to purchase as many pair of skis as could be had.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP) -Thurman Arnold, head of the Justice Department's anti-trust division, told the House Small Business Committee today that the defense program had disclosed "a great tendency of established business" to keep competition out of the defense field.

The railroad issues ran roughshod over another apathetic stock market yesterday as threats of further rationing, disturbing rumors of the new tax load and nervousness over the widening submarine warfare off the Atlantic coast, retarded trading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Interstate Commerce Commission interpretations of the "grandfather clause" under which operating permits are issued to trucking companies were sustained today in opinions announced by Justice Murphy for a unanimous Supreme Court.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 19 -- Tavoy, South Burma coastal port about 235 miles southeast of Rangoon, has been occupied by Japanese troops who attacked along the road from Thailand to the northeast, a military communique announced tonight.

CAIRO, Jan. 19 -- When Major Bach, who in private life is a German Evangelical minister, joined two Italian generals in surrendering Halfaya Pass to the besieging British Imperial forces on Saturday it was not a case of a chaplain's filling a gap left by the absence of senior fighting officers.

Still restrained by the uncertainties concerning the conference report on the price-control bill, the cotton market moved irregularly for the most part yesterday in a thin and quiet session on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final prices of active futures were 2 to 5 points above the previous close.

An audience of 750 children, many so small their heads barely showed above the backs of the seats, heard a program devoted to "Fairyland in Music" yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. It was played by forty members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Rudolph Ganz acting as narrator and conductor.

After paying off $1,000,000 of bank debt and retiring 2,460 shares of its preferred stock, the net assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation, before bank loans and funded debt, were valued at $23,807,657 on Dec. 31, last. On that date, bank loans, due Sept. 30, 1943, bearing interest at 2 per cent annually, were $6,900,000 and funded debt amounted to $2,460,000.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 19 -- The persistence of Japanese raids on Medan, key Netherlands Indies port on the island of Sumatra, indicate that the Japanese are maintaining their policy of trying to break down air opposition before launching a land invasion.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- Speeches urging preservation of Boscobel, the historic Georgian mansion at Crugers Park, were made today at the Board of Supervisors meeting by A.V.S. Olcott, president of the Hudson River Conservation Society and of the Hudson River Day Line; Colonel Thatcher T.P. Luquer, president of the Westchester County Historical Society, and Harvey Stevenson, president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 19 -- Fifty-three Japanese, including the ex-Minister to Mexico, his staff and their families, soon will leave Mexico by train for Hot Springs, W. Va., for internment pending transfer to Axis territory.

Speakers at a conference on "War and Recreation" at New York University yesterday gave a picture of an almost too-successful program of time-off activities for men in the armed forces. Officers representing the Navy, Army and Marines, pleaded for more restful recreational pursuits, stressing the importance to the men of "Just sitting."

Envisioning a national income of $125,000,000,000, out of which $25,000,000,000 to $30,000,000,000 could be collected by the government in taxes, Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the board of the Federal Reserve System, declared yesterday that successful financing of the war could be accomplished only by real sacrifice and a generally lower standard of living for all classes.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 (AP) -- New York State's colleges and universities, while rapidly assuming wartime footing, will make no concessions in their educational standards, leaders of the institutions decided today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 19 -- A resolution for the severance by all the American republics of relations with the Axis powers will be approved by the inter-American conference of Foreign Ministers here by the end of the week, regardless of whether Argentina and Chile join with the rest of the Western Hemisphere on this issue, it became evident today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Presidential approval of the assignment of a definite task to the American Legion in the civilian defense set-up was reported this afternoon by Lynn U. Stambaugh, National Commander of the Legion, after a conference at the White House.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Roosevelt late today approved a budget estimate of $300,000,000 for weekly unemployment payments to workers displaced in private industry while the plants are being adapted to war production.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Heavy Japanese air raids on two major cities in Southwest China -- Nanning and Kweilin -which had been avoided for months, gave evidence today that Chinese pressure in the Canton area and possibly in Northern French Indo-China was increasing.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Civilian specialists will have the deciding word in armaments procurement when the new War Production Board begins functioning under the chairmanship of Donald M. Nelson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Brig. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey urged Secretaries Stimson and Knox in a letter made public today to wind up all recruiting of volunteers for the Army, Navy and Marine Corps and rely entirely on the selective service for their additional man power.
The Hollywood Ice Revue, with figure skating's leading personality, Miss Sonja Henie, opened last night at Madison Square Garden before an enthusiastic gathering of 16,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in leading centers for the week ended Jan. 14 aggregated $10,302,000,000.

To illustrate the methods of computing normal and surtax charges on personal income the Bureau of Internal Revenue made public yesterday a sample computation based on a net income of $8,500 in the case of a taxpayer who is single and without dependents and makes no other claims to exemption. The illustration follows:

Syracuse University's smartly drilled basketball team accounted for another upset by turning back the Fordham quintet on the Maroon floor last night, 50-43. In front at the half by a 21-14 margin, the Orange squad never lagged, although the losers pulled even early in the second period and with two minutes remaining trailed by only four points.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 19 -- Dr. and Mrs. Matthew T. Mellon gave a luncheon today at the Bath and Tennis Club. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. John Holiday Perry, Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Hasler, Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Kent Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Henry Gibson and her sister, Mrs. Samuel W. Abbott; Mrs. James B. Drew, Mrs. Henry Ellsworth Bemis, Miss Barbara Drew and Miss Louise Marsh.

The immediate and urgent relief needs of Americans both in military service and in civilian life are entirely responsible for the nationwide campaign being conducted now to raise a Red Cross war fund of $50,000,000, S. Sloan Colt, national chairman of the drive, declared yesterday.

Dr. David Hart, Assistant Professor of Chemistry at Brooklyn College, on trial yesterday before a committee of the Board of Higher Education on charges of misconduct, denied he had attempted to conceal his connection with the Kemkit Scientific Corporation.

In a dramatic appeal to the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund, Mayor La Guardia won a month's postponement yesterday on 114 of the 144 mass applications for retirement filed with the trustees since Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Drastic "civil and criminal remedies" to halt what he said investigations indicated were "widespread and serious" violations of priorities and allocations orders were recommended today by Attorney General Francis Biddle. He made the recommendation in analyzing for the Senate Judiciary committee the "second war powers" bill requested by the Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- General Douglas MacArthur, according to War Department reports today, had a breathing spell in the last twenty-four hours after recent action in which he not only repulsed another major attack by the Japanese but forced them back from advanced points where they had threatened to break his lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A request to the Attorney General that he overrule the reversal of the Harry Bridges deportation order and an expression of outright opposition to the Federal Union movement as a threat to American sovereignty were among the dozen resolutions adopted by the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense at its closing session here this morning.
Volunteers for the armed forces applied in strong force here yesterday in spite of the rain as 1,600 men of fighting age sought combat service in the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard.

Major Gen. George A. Wingate, former surrogate, who retired from the Kings County bench last December because of the constitutional age limit, was the recipient yesterday of the gold medal of the Downtown Brooklyn Association at its thirteenth annual luncheon meeting at the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 19 -- Dr. Fred W. Rankin of this city, president-elect of the American Medical Association, has been appointed chief consulting surgeon of the Army and will assume the post March 1 with the rank of colonel.

In his review of Herbert Hoover's latest book, Ralph Thompson says: "The most significant message that he can give to the American people on Jan. 12, 1942, is that they were imposed upon and swindled by the Treaty of Versailles. So they were, without question, to a degree.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A bill providing for the compulsory retirement of Federal civil service workers at 70, and extending the benefits of the retirement system to many employes not now covered, including members of Congress and legislative employes, was passed today by the Senate, 42 to 24.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 19 -- Under pressure from the German occupant in Yugoslavia, the government of Premier Field Marshal Milan Neditch has just instructed Minister of the Interior Milan Achimovitch to "suppress" the Chetnik movement throughout old Serbia, it was learned here today.

Turning in as a token contribution a book he describes as "the most important sermon on patriotism ever written," Edward Everett Hale's "The Man Without a Country," Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to New York City to meet its quota of 2,000,000 volumes in the Victory Book Campaign.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Br/ti.sh, Headquarters ,sz'ed tkia comniqu today :

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A majority of six Supreme Court justices overruling a minority of two today reversed the conviction of Daniel D. Glasser, former assistant United States attorney at Chicago, on charges of conspiracy to solicit and accept money in "fixing" cases involving violations of the Federal liquor laws.

A recent dispatch in THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding a plan to develop the great resources of the Amazon Valley with United States funds in order to increase our trade with Latin America seems to be a sound and practical idea. Such a program would help to cushion the depression that may well follow the present war if steps are not taken to avoid it.

ON THE MALAYAN FRONT, Jan. 19 (AP) -- Asserting that the Japanese never can be defeated by playing a waiting game, Australian General Henry Gordon Bennet called upon his men today to wrest the initiative from the invaders by beating them to the punch wherever they try to strike.

What shall a soldier sing? Mr. Robert Wilder raises this question in The New York Sun, and doubtless many others are worried about it. The best one can answer is that worrying doesn't do any good. Peter B. Kyne made one astute comment on the situation in his preface to Lieutenant Dolph's book of soldier songs, "Sound Off," published in 1928.

The conservation departments of other States would do well to follow the example set by the Ohio Division of Conservation and Resources which, instead of curtailing its fish production activity, is planning to double it.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- The leadership of the Assembly kept the ways cleared for income tax reduction at the current session when it spiked tonight, for the time being, a bill which would have postponed income tax collections without reducing the levy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- A War Department communique, based on reports up to 9:30 A.M. Eastern standard time today, said:

Buyers' arrivals in the wholesale markets here continued numerous yesterday. Wholesalers were particularly well represented. The indications were, however, that the total would fall below the figures of last week, confirming the belief that the peak of arrivals was reached then.

For many years the goal of organized farmers and of Administration farm policy has been "parity" prices. Now "parity" has at length been achieved. In the past year the general price level of all commodities other than farm products has gone up only 14 per cent, but farm prices have gone up 39 per cent.

A resolution urging the creation of a city-wide adolescents court "properly staffed with probationary officers and psychiatric workers" was unanimously adopted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Protestant Big Sister Council held at the Spencer Memorial Presbyterian Church, Clinton and Remsen Streets, Brooklyn.

The First National Bank of Boston and the First Boston Corporation purchased yesterday an issue of $2,000,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts one-year notes at 0.29 per cent, plus a premium of $36. The obligations will become payable on Jan. 25, 1943.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The House of Representatives repealed by a voice vote today the requirement in the excess-profits tax amortization law that contractors holding war orders and seeking to defray costs of plant expansion through tax deductions must obtain a certificate that the contracts themselves do hot reimburse them.

A schismatic pronouncement by Neil Cohalan that his Manhattan squad would take a fling at the "firehouse" basketball so spectacularly and successfully demonstrated here by such visitors as Rice, Washington and Rhode Island supplied added evidence that the local court mentors are begining to reconsider their traditional tactical conservatism.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Jan. 19 -- Striking without warning in the pre-dawn darkness shrouding the North Carolina coast, an enemy submarine today shelled and torpedoed the 8,207-ton American tanker Malay, killing one crew member and sending four others to probable death.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 19 -- Basil James, who packed his tack and came to Hialeah Park when racing at Santa Anita was canceled, continued to fare well when he drove the Cedar Farm's gray filly Miss Goshen to victory in the Brickell Purse of six and a half furlongs today.

A funeral service for William Morehouse Patterson will be held at 8 o'clock tonight in GraceMethodist Church, Seventh Avenue and St. John's Place, Brooklyn, by the pastor, the Rev. W. E. Thompson, after a service there under the auspices of Commonwealth Masonic Lodge, No. 409, of which Mr. Patterson was Past Master.

The Alabama Power Company, unit in the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation system, yesterday sold $80,000,000 of first mortgage bonds under the compulsory competitive bidding rule of the Securities and Exchange Commission, but, to the disappointment of officials of the utility, received only one bid for the issue.

The battle for the Malay barrier, "main line of resistance" of the United Nations in the Far East, was intensified yesterday. And as the threat to Singapore increased in confused jungle-fighting American and Netherland planes traded blows with the enemy in widespread raids over the world's richest archipelago, the Netherlands Indies.

HONOLULU, Jan. 19 -- There is humor as well as tragedy in war. Some of the best stories of the Dec. 7 attack on Pearl Harbor are just now getting general circulation. One of the best is about the old soldier and the husky sergeant who would not let him go back into burning barracks after his false teeth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Agreement on prices to be paid by canners for tomatoes and peas for the coming season's pack, as well as the price schedules which will govern the canners' sales to wholesale distributers is expected to be announced at the annual Chicago food conventions next week.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced yesterday the election to the board of directors of Lammot du Pont Copeland and Crawford Greenewalt to succeed Charles Copeland and F.B. Davis Jr., who resigned.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19 -- Milady will be more feminine than ever before, if the Spring fashions exhibited for retail store buyers here today indicate the trend, and the war will be responsible.

Likening the tactics used by John L. Lewis in his one-man move for unity between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations to the Japanese assault on Pearl Harbor, Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, said yesterday that the question of "so-called peace" in the labor movement would have to be relegated to a position of secondary importance until the C.I.O. completed its current contract negotiations with four "Little Steel" companies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull, in a statement tonight, praised the speech made by President Vargas of Brazil before the Brazilian editors Saturday in which he declared Brazil had decided on what course she would pursue regarding the war and was no longer neutral.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Five United States Army bombers that attacked a Japanese air base at Menado, in Northeast Celebes in the Netherlands Indies, shot down nine Japanese interceptor planes, the War Department reported tonight. The United States planes lost two of their number, which were reported as "missing," and a third was damaged, with injuries to four members of its crew. The attack was carried out on Saturday.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Japanese planes yesterday bombed Sabang, off the northern tip of Sumatra, and damaged a lightship in another raid on the East Borneo oil port of Balik Papan, it was announced today; but observers said that Japanese penetration generally in the Southwestern Pacific had been slowed by new air forces unleashed by the United Nations.
Several sales of choice New England properties were reported yesterday by Massachusetts and Connecticut brokers.

Philip Murray's cool reception of the proposal by the usually intransigent John L. Lewis for a merger of the C.I.O. and A.F. of L. is not difficult to understand. Mr. Lewis in effect made his proposal over Mr. Murray's head; and Mr. Lewis is proposing to do now what he failed to do when he was himself president of the C.I.O.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress for an additional appropriation and contract authority of $28,500,767,495 for the Army and Navy; nominated William S. Knudsen to be a lieutenant general, Patrick J. Hurley to be a brigadier general, Brig. Gen. Julian F. Barnes to be a major general, and former Representative William A. Ekwall to be a judge of the Customs Court at New York.

DETROIT, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -- Charles Leonard Gehringer, 38, one of baseball's greatest second basemen of all time, did something today he once said he never would do. He signed a one-year contract as non-playing coach with the Tigers. His salary was not disclosed.
CORAL GABLES, Jan. 19 (U.P.) -Favorites advanced easily today in the tenth annual Miami Biltmore amateur golf tournament.

HALFAYA PASS, Egyptian-Libyan Frontier, Jan. 19 -- The capture of this German-Italian stronghold has released a little band of British war prisoners who passed almost two months in caves suffering constantly from hunger, thirst, filth and boredom.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The post-war emergence of Russia as a decisive factor in world affairs, and especially in Central European affairs, was predicted today by Dr. Hubert Ripka, a Minister of the Czecho-Slovak Government in Exile, in an address to the Czecho-Slovak State Council.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 19 -- Soon after Governor Charles Edison recommended to the Legislature today that expenditures from the State's general fund and the highway account be restricted to $76,157,993, or about $27,000,000 less than the total of sums sought by the various departments, the joint appropriations committee organized and arranged to begin hearings next week on the spending bills.
Because you have such a splendid paper I have been shocked and surprised at Ralph Thompson's review of "America's First Crusade," by Herbert Hoover.

The proposed visit of the National League's champion Dodgers to Havana for Spring training became doubtful yesterday when the Giants, through Treasurer Leo Bondy and Secretary Eddie Brannick, placed themselves on record against participation in the trip.
MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (From Soviet broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet Bureau of Information communique broadcast today said.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 19 -"Until they may return to their homes" the Italian Government will pay pensions to all settlers who have been forced to leave Ethiopia and Libya because of the war. A dispatch from Rome points out that the obligation assumed represents a financial burden, since the number of such refugees is great and "no date can be set for their return."
MOSCOW, Jan. 19 (From Soviet broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Soviet Bureau of Information communique broadcast today said.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 19 -"Until they may return to their homes" the Italian Government will pay pensions to all settlers who have been forced to leave Ethiopia and Libya because of the war. A dispatch from Rome points out that the obligation assumed represents a financial burden, since the number of such refugees is great and "no date can be set for their return."

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 19 -- New Jersey will receive fewer tires during February than in January for allotment to passenger car and truck owners, State Rationing Administrator Robert W Johnson announced today.

An additional group of thirty-three dwellings in the Bedford Homes development between Fifteenth and Sixteenth Avenues and Eighty-second and Eighty- third Streets in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn is nearing completion. The houses are of the one and two family types.

Echoes of Mahatma Gandhi's non-cooperation movement in India have from time to time agitated the people of Burma, especially that group of Nationalists among them who are impatiently demanding dominion status and home rule. The religious differences which in British opinion bar immediate independence for India do not exist in Burma, whose people are mostly Buddhists.

Then Empire Trust Company had net operating earnings of $336,128, or $4.80 a share, in 1941, Henry C. Brunie, chairman, reported yesterday. Profits from the sales of securities and other assets and recoveries from assets previously charged off amounted to $99,693 and were credited to reserves.

The Librarian of Yale University announced yesterday the presentation to the Yale Collection of American Literature of the manuscript notebooks of the late Sara Teasdale. The manuscripts contain all the poet's work from 1911, when as a young girl in St. Louis she bought her first small red notebook, until her death.

A slight increase in the number of deaths in the city last week to 1,641, against 1,631 in the preceding week, was reported yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner. For the corresponding week in 1941, however, there were only 1,571 deaths.

The $80,000,000 issue of Alabama Power Company 3 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds, which was awarded on Monday to an underwriting syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and Bonbright Co., Inc., will be offered to the public today.

There are times when we are convinced that the jinx that often accompanies us on hunting and fishing trips is a champion in its field, but the letter we received yesterday from an unhappy sportsman convinces us that our jinx is almost a friend in comparison.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 -- After spotting the Bruins a pair of goals, the New York Rangers pulled into a first-place National Hockey League tie with Boston by skating to a 4-2 victory before a capacity crowd of 14,900 tonight at the Garden. It was the Stanley Cup champions' first regular home game setback since last Feb. 25, when the Rangers shut them out, 2 -- 0.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Chilean railway and nitrate issues moved up today, otherwise the stock markets were subdued. The oil shares encountered a particularly poor market on the Japanese drive on Burma. The rubbers were easier where any changes occurred.

A nation-wide banking syndicate of 131 members headed by the National City Bank and the Chase National Bank received yesterday the award of $50,000,000 of New York City serial and assessment bonds on a bid representing a net interest cost of 2.43987 per cent to the city.

In a Berne dispatch printed in this newspaper there were edifying extracts from a pamphlet written for the benefit of Hitler Youth by one Schmidt, assistant Gauleiter of Wuerttemberg. With so many other Hitlerian philosophers he says that Christianity won't do.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Existing orders and regulations reported in preparation will eliminate the manufacture of new electrical heating appliances of all kinds for homes after April 1, in the opinion of government officials as well as members of the industry here today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Roosevelt signed the Daylight-Saving Bill today and it becomes effective at 2 o'clock in the morning of Feb. 9 for all interstate commerce and Federal Government activities.

When it is recalled how steep a rise in rates was necessary in the Revenue Act of 1941 to produce $3,500,000,000 of additional revenue, it must be obvious that a very difficult task confronts the framers of this year's tax bill if they are to accomplish the President's objective of raising $7,000,000,000 of new taxes, in addition to $2,000,000,000 of new Social Security revenues.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Hog prices closed about 10 cents a hundred pounds lower in a slow market today.

The legality of the traditional underwriting agreement, for many years the heart of the mechanism by which investment bankers facilitate the offering and distribution of new issues of both corporate and municipal securities, has been challenged by members of the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The British communique said today:

HAMILTON, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- Dr. George Barton Cutten will retire as president of Colgate University Aug. 31 when he completes twenty years of service, he announced today. He reaches the Colgate retirement age of 68 in April and indicated that he could not consider proposals being made in some quarters that he be "drafted" to continue as president of the university for the duration of the war.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 20 -- The flying figures of Thorleif Hang, Birger and Sigmund Ruud, Reidar Andersen and Casper Oimoen left indelible shadows on the snow slides with their mighty ski jumps in the past, but Torger Tokle, Norwegian star who is awaiting his call from the Army, has eclipsed the records of those immortals with phenomenal and daring exploits that have won wide acclaim.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 20 (AP) -- "We'll be going back to sea in a couple of weeks," said "Shanghai" tonight at Newark Airport as he stepped off a plane from Norfolk, Va.
Employes of the Peoples-Pittsburgh Trust Company of Pittsburgh are to share in its profits in 1942, it was announced yesterday by L.H. Gethoefer, chairman, and Gwilym A. Price, president.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Champion Willie Hoppe registered his fifth victory in the world three-cushion billiards tournament tonight by trimming Ralph Greenleaf of Monmouth, Ill., 50 to 31, in forty-nine innings.

Lou Schwartz, 166, Brownsville, received the decision over Augie Arellano, 158, Houston, Texas, in the feature eight-round bout before 3,000 persons at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. It was a hard and interesting battle, but Schwartz's margin was a clear one.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 20 -- Japanese forces in Western Malaya advanced today to within sixty-five miles of Singapore, their blows falling hard along a thirty-mile sector stretching from the Muar River down to the vicinity of Batu Pahat. On the eastern front enemy patrols penetrated to the area of Endau, about seventy-five miles above Singapore.

The master agreement between the Realty Advisory Board and Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, A.F. of L., governing the wages and working conditions of 26,000 workers in 2,600 Manhattan buildings, does not bar new labor elections where another union claims to represent a majority of the employes, the State Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- The National Congress of Parents and Teachers sent from its headquarters today a petition to the Office of Civilian Defense in Washington calling for a system of registration and identification of all children in the United States.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Thai troops, presumably under direction of the Japanese, who have occupied their country, were reported tonight by Reuters, British news agency, to have attacked Southern Burma sixty miles northeast of the important port of Moulmein.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The government mints by working around the clock, made more money in 1941 than ever before.

Continued maintenance of high standards of community and family life as the best defense against the enemy was emphasized yesterday at the first annual meeting of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, 670 Lexington Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- An appropriation of $300,000,000 to aid workers who are thrown out of employment through conversion of plants to war production was asked of Congress today by President Roosevelt, who proposed that such benefits be conditioned upon the worker's willingness to take special training to equip himself for war work.

In the President's request to Congress for the unparalleled total of $28,500,000,000 for supplemental war appropriations and authorizations, more than half, or approximately $16,000,000,000, is for the Navy alone. This brings once more into the foreground the question of what kind of Navy we now need.

WATERBURY, Conn., Jan. 20 -- Joseph E. Talbot of Naugatuck, Republican, was elected today Representative from the Fifth Congressional District of Connecticut over John S. Monagan of Waterbury, Democrat. The district has been Democratic for ten years.
Several lofts and other business properties figured in the Manhattan realty trading reported yesterday.

Formation of a salvage committee to expedite the collection through normal trade channels of scrap metal, rubber, paper, rags and other material needed for war production, was announced yesterday by George A. Sloan, chairman of Mayor La Guardia's business advisory committee.
Ten thousand American artists have organized to help win the war against an ex-Austrian ex-painter and his Axis partners.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 20 -- The typical American believes that it will take another two years at least to whip the Axis enemies. That is the indication from a nation-wide poll by the American Institute of Public Opinion.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- Organization of the Nells, the first officially sanctioned woman's auxiliary to the Navy, was revealed today by a group which will be known formally as the Navy League Service. It is backed by the Navy League of the United States and will parallel the work being done by the famous Wrens of England.

Costume designers from varied fields and from a number of cities made up a standing-room-only audience last night as the Museum of Costume Art in Rockefeller Center, initiating a laboratory course in designing. Three top-ranking fashion creators of the country lent their time and their talents to show by different techniques how they evolve exciting and wearable styles for American women from the growing and extensive source material at the museum.

Service campaigns in the automotive field, scheduled for this year, will take up some of the advertising slack resulting from the ban on car and tire sales. Latest to be started are campaigns by Standard Oil of Indiana, Chevrolet and Goodyear.

Visiting buyers registered in the market last week totaled 1,528, which compared with 2,023 in the previous week and 1,340 in the like period a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES' listings. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 772, as against 1,088 for last Tuesday, when the highest record for a single day was reached.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Special war traffic schools for police will be conducted in 120 cities of the United States, beginning Feb. 9. Experts from the FBI will give courses of six days each.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Absorption in war and defense legislation continued today to be the tone of the Legislature, with the result that members have become restive while waiting for the defense bills which Governor Lehman outlined last week and to which the legislative leaders have agreed in principle.

Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, was elected yesterday president of the Philadelphia Company of Pittsburgh. Frank R. Phillips, who has served as president of the company for many years, was elected chairman of the board and the executive committee. Mr.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Doris Duke Cromwell, tobacco heiress, testified here today in her tax dispute with the Township of Hillsborough that she would rather live in Hawaii than in the United States and that she intended to make her permanent home there as soon as conditions permitted.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 20 -- Acting President Ramon S. Castillo indicated in an interview tonight that Argentina had said her last word as far as the proposed joint rupture of relations with the Axis countries was concerned and that she intended to make no further concessions at the conference of American Foreign Ministers in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

Keeping track of the various college basketball teams scattered the country over is a well-nigh impossible task. It almost would take a staff of full-time statisticians to check the thousands of scores that accumulate in the course of a week.
The consolidated net profit of the Rustless Iron and Steel Corporation for 1941 amounted to $2,332,298 after Federal income and excess profits taxes, according to a preliminary statement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Roosevelt said after a conference with legislative leaders today that the pending Rivers and Harbors Bill was being studied with a view to eliminating all projects which did not bear directly upon the war effort.

Officials of eighteen local housing authorities sold yesterday a total of $58,952,000 of temporary-loan notes, maturing variously from June 30, 1942, to Feb. 9, 1943. A group headed by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company purchased $38,545,000; the Girard Trust Company bought $9,889,000, while the remainder went to five other banks or investment dealers.

No reward is deserved for the simplest of duties -- to keep faith to the ideals of freedom in spite of menaces alternated with offers of bribes. My compatriots -- especially in the Americas -- have granted me an undeserved reward when, by hundreds of thousands, they have chosen me, in recent occasions, as the interpreter of their ideals without asking me questions.
BERLIN, Jan. 20 (from German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- President Roberto M. Ortiz of Argentina, in retirement because of illness since June, 1940, told the newspaper Nueva Era today that the Pan-American Conference at Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, would show the world the "decisive solidarity" of American nations.

The Boy Scouts of Greater New York began an appeal yesterday for $325,000 to enable them to intensify their efforts in the civilian defense program, and to carry on their other activities during 1942, at a "reveille breakfast" in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Wall Street's defense bond drive moved ahead yesterday with two new developments. The New York Curb Exchange Clearing Corporation applied to the Federal Reserve Bank for qualification as a defense bond issuer and the firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane announced a concerted effort to sell bonds by its ninety-three branches.
Lewis E. Waring was re-elected president and chairman of the executive committee at the annual meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress for $300,000,000 for these unemployed during the conversion of industry to war production; signed the bill which will make nation-wide daylight savings time effective at 2 A.M., Feb. 9.
LEONIA, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Miss Kate Gausmann, artist and member of a colonial family, died early today in a fire that destroyed her home at 223 Leonia Avenue here. She was 82 years old.

Close on the plea of Ralph Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad and former Commissioner of Transport for Defense that the railroad receive sufficient supplies of steel to meet the needs of wartime traffic came advices from Washington that the manufacturers are adhering to a schedule which calls for the delivery of 36,000 freight cars by May 1.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Satisfaction with the government's fiscal policies was expressed today by Reginald McKenna, chairman of the Midland Bank, Ltd., in his annual statement. Handling of the nation's budget deficits, he said, has been "a great achievement in combined financial and monetary management" and "far superior to anything we have known hitherto."

The cotton market found steady support yesterday in persistent price-fixing orders, but scale-up hedging operations and other selling kept prices from making anything but moderate advances. As a result, prices of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved within a narrow range throughout the session and closed with net gains of 10 to 11 points.

Wartime conditions in no wise diminish the important role of the fashion industries and their products must now, more than ever, create interest and inspire courage and morale, Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University and president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, declared yesterday at the fashion merchandising clinic of the Millinery Merchandising Executives Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A branch office of the decentralization service of the Public Buildings Administration will be opened here this morning at 33 East Forty-seventh Street, James D. Landauer, assistant general manager of the service, announced yesterday at a meeting of realty men at the offices of the Real Estate Board of New York.
Mr. and Mrs. James A. Moffett returned yesterday to the Waldorf-Astoria from Prospect Hill Plantation, their place at Yonges Island, S.C.

Metro's mystery-comedy, "Mr. and Mrs. North," which arrives at Loew's Criterion, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Gracie Allen and William Post Jr. co-star in the title roles, and the supporting cast includes Paul Kelly, Rose Hobart, Tom Conway, Millard Mitchell and Felix Bressart.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission opposed today a proposal by the Investment Bankers Association for enlargement of the commission and longer tenure of office for its members.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 -- An increase in the draft age for home defence and the possibility of a national referendum to release the government and Members of Parliament from their two-year-old election pledge not to send drafted men overseas are foreshadowed as likely to be the principal proposals to be placed before the new session of Parliament opening here on Thursday.
ROME, Jan. 20 (From Italian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command issued this communique:

Plans for establishment of a New York State youth correction authority received impetus yesterday when Austin H. MacCormick, former New York City Commissioner of Correction, took over chairmanship of a State-wide committee of prominent citizens who are sponsoring the plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The major differences between the House and Senate conferees over the price-control bill remained unsettled after two sessions today, but they said every effort would be made to reach a compromise tomorrow.

By a vote of seventeen to seven, the City Council re-established yesterday its special committee investigating the Municipal Civil Service Commission and Paul J. Kern, its president. Councilman William M. McCarthy, Brooklyn Democrat, who served as acting chairman of the old committee that went out of existence Dec. 31 after Alfred E. Smith Jr. was called into military service, was named chairman of the new committee.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals made a ruling yesterday that is pretty sure to bring a reward of $100,000 a year to a tribe of American Indians for the patience they exercised over a period of nine years. The residents and business people of Salamanca, N.Y., are expected to put up the money on lands rented from the Indians of the Seneca Nation.
Enemy submarine operations off our coasts so far have had more of a nuisance value than of major military importance.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Colonel M. C. Kress Muhlenberg, retiring Fifth Corps Area air officer, told a general court-martial today he had no thought of criticizing the government policies or the United States Navy in an address made here Dec. 17.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Reports that offers are being made to Argentina of duty-free admission for her canned beef and for flaxseed, with the possibility that she may also be able to ship frozen beef here under a wartime suspension of normal tariff and trade restrictions, persisted here tonight among foreign traders despite denials from the Department of State.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Army communique No. 67, based on reports received up to 9:30 A.M., said:

A BRITISH PORT, Jan. 20 -- Thousands of Canadian airmen, one of the largest contingents to reach Britain since the start of the war, debarked here today from a convoy that also brought further reinforcements for Canadian troops in Britain.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Kenesaw M. Landis, Commissioner of Baseball, tonight called a meeting of major league club owners at New York on Feb. 3 to consider expansion of night baseball. The call followed a suggestion last Friday by President Roosevelt that more night games be played.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Most of today was given over at the Inter-American Conference to committee meetings and consideration of new proposals. Among the resolutions offered were these:

Sales of twenty-seven chain-store companies, including two mail-order houses, amounted to $570,738,889 in December, an increase of 21.2 per cent over the $470,866,932 volume reported for December, 1940, according to a compilation by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane.

The five-story apartment house on a plot 91 by 143 feet at 91-97 Fairview Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by Benjamin Goldberg to the 93 Fairview Avenue Corporation. The property is assessed for $215,100. It is subject to a $129,500 mortgage held by the Fidelity Union Trust Company.

The eighty-third birthday of Lucius Nathan Littauer may be taken as the occasion publicly to recognize the successful manner in which his benefaction has contributed to fellowship and understanding among religious groups. From his gift there has been organized, mainly through the efforts of President Finkelstein of the Jewish Theological Seminary, the Institute for Religious Studies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today decided that despite changes effected in the relations between the Hartford Gas Company and the United Gas Improvement Company since its original order finding that Hartford is a subsidiary of U.G.I., Hartford was still under U.G.I.'s influence and that consequently the order could not be modified.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 20 -- Paramount announced the purchase today of "Storm," a new novel by George R. Stewart, for $30,000. The story follows the course of a storm from its discovery by a meteorologist as a speck in the Pacific through the ultimate devastation it causes in the Western United States.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 20 -- Consultations on the proposal for a joint severance of diplomatic relations with the Axis nations brought together the chiefs of the Brazilian and United States delegations and the Argentine Foreign Minister at the Inter-American Conference here today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A Japanese cruiser has been destroyed by Army bombers operating in the Southwestern Pacific region, the War Department announced today.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Air and Home Security Ministries issued this communique today:

For the first time this season there will be two Broadway openings tonight. They are "Jason" at the Hudson and the double program at the St. James of the Jooss Ballet's "Green Table" and the Boston Comic Opera Company's revival of "Pinafore."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A measure appropriating $12,525,872,474 for expansion of the Army Air Corps toward President Roosevelt's goal of 185,000 planes in the next two years was approved today by the House Appropriations Committee's subcommittee on deficiencies after only one day of hearings.
Restricted home consumption of certain foods by next Fall and rationing by 1943 "at the latest," were forecast yesterday by Dean Carl E. Ladd of the New York State College of Agriculture at Ithaca.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 20 -- After suffering heavy casualties in the first clashes with Australians at Gemas and the Muar River, the Japanese are refusing to risk a major frontal attack and have resumed their tactics of filtering through the lines and positions of British and Imperial forces.

The Production Requirements Plan, which is expected eventually to be the basis on which all vital materials are allocated by the government, has not found many adherents among purchasing agents, they reported yesterday at a forum of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at the Builders Exchange Club.

Business men should plan now for a post-war slump, according to Murray Shields, economist of the Irving Trust Company, but there is a good chance that the dip will be brief. Mr. Shields addressed the opening session of the three-day convention of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

PALM BEACH, Ma., Jan. 20 -Mr. and Mrs. Guernsey Curran entertained with a dinner at the Beach Club tonight, guests including Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West, Mr. and Mrs. LeRay Berdeau and Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill.

A record of social service extending over a period of more than forty years parallels and measures the transition from the simple days and comparatively simple problems of America at the very turn of the century to the social complexities and new social horizons of today.

Expanding into one of his more explosive moods, Larry MacPhail, generalissimo of Brooklyn baseball, let out a loud snort yesterday that shook all Flatbush and even rattled the windows in the Giants' offices on West Forty-second Street.

Export prices should be specifically exempted from price control, except as such regulation is exercised by the Office of Export Control, Board of Economic Warfare, and not by the OPA, the Export Managers Club urged yesterday at its regular luncheon meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ON the day before Rogers Hornsby was signed up for the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., Charley Gehringer signed up as a coach with the Detroit Tigers. That makes Gehringer a future candidate for the honor just bestowed upon the Rajah. A man's name doesn't appear on the ballot until his playing days are over.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20 -- While the United States is worried about a fifth column in Mexico and the rest of Latin America, Mexican officials and industrialists are deeply disturbed by Mexico's complete economic dependence upon the United States and the difficulty of getting machinery and raw materials from the United States for Mexican industries, it was pointed out in authoritative circles today.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Jan. 20 (AP) -- William Dudley Pelley, leader of the Silver Shirts of America, was sentenced today by Superior Court Judge F. Don Phillips to serve two to three years in prison for violation of the North Carolina Security Laws.

Lou Salica of Brooklyn, world bantamweight champion, received a championship belt from The Ring, a boxing publication, at the New York Coliseum, the Bronx, last night and then hammered his way to a decision over Aaron Seltzer of the Bronx in the ten-round feature bout.

There is as much difference between knowing something and realizing it as there is between looking at an object and seeing it. When Adolf Hitler first visited Godesberg on the Rhine, Dreesen, the innkeeper and a former officer, thought he had not met the Nazi leader before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- "Excessive and unconscionable" profits on ships, planes and facilities vital to the naval program, and war-boom gains in the financial strength of labor unions were reported to the House of Representatives today by its Naval Affairs Committee after ten months of investigation.

Business men who have taken the trouble to find out what priority orders have been issued and to learn the procedure have little or no trouble in obtaining priority ratings for such materials as they are entitled to receive, it was asserted yesterday at a clinic session of manufacturers of basic chemicals, drugs, disinfectants, dyes and cosmetics, sponsored by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York at its office in the Woolworth Building.

Services to the foreign-born, to refugees and needy inmates of hospitals and other institutions were rendered last year by the New York section of the National Council of Jewish Women, according to reports presented yesterday at the forty-eighth annual meeting of the organization.

The 700 member agencies of the Welfare Council offered their services to Mayor La Guardia and the New York City Defense Council at the first meeting yesterday of the War Time Coordinating Committee, recently set up by the Welfare Council. Frederick I. Daniels, executive director of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, is chairman of the committee.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- A bill for compulsory military training for high school boys over 14 is to be presented in the Legislature with the approval of the New York City school authorities. Detailed plans for voluntary instruction had already been worked out by the city authorities.

The mile run will be the choice of Leslie MacMitchell, N.Y.U. captain, in the metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships at the Coliseum on Saturday. This was announced yesterday by his coach, Emil Von Elling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- In command of the United States Navy torpedo boat that torpedoed a 5,000-ton Japanese ship in Subic Bay was 30-year-old Lieutenant John D. Bulkeley of New York and Texas. The Navy said today he had been commended for carrying out his mission successfully.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20 -- Congress was memorialized today by the San Francisco Board of Supervisors to take immediate steps "to insure complete and invincible protection" to the Pacific Coast, which was described in a resolution as "the most militarily strategic area in our country."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Theatre managers representing nationwide interests met yesterday with Major Gen. L.D. Gasser of the Office of Civilian Defense to discuss means by which a maximum of protection can be accorded to theatre patrons in the event of blackouts or air raids, the OCD made known today.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 20 -- General Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel, Chief of Germany's armed forces, arrived in Budapest, Hungary, at noon on a visit of several days. According to dispatches received here, he was greteed at the railroad station by the Minister of National Defense, the Chief of the General Staff, the German Minister and the German, Italian and Japanese military attaches.

One by one the names of the diamond's immortals are finding their way into baseball's Hall of Fame, and the latest to make his entry is Rogers Hornsby, brilliant batsman and stormy petrel of the major leagues for close to a quarter of a century.

The row of four six-family apartment houses at 35-17, 35-37 land 35-41 Crescent Street, Astoria, L.I., has been sold by a client of James C. McCormick, Inc., broker, to the Lango Realty Corporation, Joseph Crisa, president. Sale was subject to mortgages totaling $63,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Automobile dealers were told today that Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, does not at present contemplate rationing used cars or commandeering private cars. His assurance was given at the annual convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association in a speech read for him by Cyrus McCormick, chief of the automobile and truck section of the Office of Price Administration.
The armed services received 1,000 applicants here yesterday as the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard recruiting offices kept moderately busy during the day.

Confidence that unity in the labor movement would result from the peace moves initiated by John L. Lewis, founder and first president of the C.I.O., was expressed last night by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A.F. of L., in an address before 4,000 members of the Dressmakers Union, Local 22, at Manhattan Center.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The R.A.F. Middle East Command issued this communique tonight:

The Cuban-American Sugar Company will be able to increase its output in the current year by about 50 per cent through a fortunate policy of maintaining a surplus supply of cane for some years, David M. Keiser, president, declared at the annual meeting of stockholders held yesterday in Jersey City.

WITH THE AUSTRALIANS, in Northern Johore, Jan. 19 (Delayed) -- Despite the successes that fresh Australian troops have had on the Western Malaya front, the situation confronting the British remains serious. The Japanese still have predominance in numbers and a wide margin of front-line aerial superiority.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, opened with a private view last evening for members and guests a large group exhibition containing work by eighteen American artists living in nine States. The show is installed in galleries on the second floor and will open to the public today.

Actors Equity Association has appointed Bert Lytell, president of Equity, to represent it in all of the existing entertainment organizations designed to supply amusement to the men in the armed forces. This was decided yesterday at a meeting of the union's governing board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Representatives of the Federation of Independent Unions, claiming to speak for approximately 200,000 workers, failed today in an effort to win postponement of National Labor Relations Board hearings on charges that the Curtiss-Wright Corporation had dominated Propeller Craft, Inc., an independent union, at its Clifton (N.J.) plant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Roosevelt said today that the appearance of German submarines off the east coast came as no surprise to him. He indicated that the activities of the American Fleet in protecting shipments of war supplies to many parts of the world were responsible for whatever success the undersea raiders had achieved.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 20 (AP) -- It will take a lot of wool to clothe this nation's soldiers and civilians and the armies of her allies, but America's sheepmen are ready to produce it, according to a statement issued on the eve of the seventy-seventh annual convention of the National Wool Growers Association, which begins tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Department of Justice withdrew today its affidavit that Justice T. Alan Goldsborough of the District of Columbia Court was too biased against the government to preside at the trial of George Sylvester Viereck and a few moments later Justice Goldsborough removed himself from the trial.

Paced by John Mugavin, who made 17 points, the St. Ann's Academy basketball team broke a first-place tie with La Salle Academy and gained undisputed possession of the Manhattan-Richmond C.H.S.A.A. lead by topping the latter, 40 to 37, on the former's court yesterday.
The slogan "If you can't go -- give!" was selected yesterday for the Red Cross War Fund drive in this city, to raise a quota of $7,330,000 toward the national goal of $50,000,000.
The five-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 100 feet at 3346-8 Hull Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Albert J. Schuss to a client of Morel J. Fuchs, attorney, through Hyman Leff, broker.

The six-story apartment house at 405 West 118th Street, in the Columbia University area, has been sold by the Leeflor Corporation to the Ohmer Realty Corporation, which plans to bring the structure into compliance with the Pack law. Now operated as a residence club, the building contains 135 rooms and occupies a plot 60 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Army needs about 12,000 women at once, a Congressional committee was told today, for use in the airplane interceptor service and other Army branches.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Roosevelt conferred today with Dr. Hubertus J. van Mook, Lieutenant Governor of the Netherlands Indies, and the opinion was expressed in high official circles afterward that, if Singapore and the Netherlands Indies could hold out for thirty days, the United Nations would have air superiority over the Japanese in the Southwestern Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Plans have been made by the State Department for evacuating Americans from danger areas, particularly in the Far East and Middle East, and for the supplying of financial assistance to other United States citizens who are stranded in enemy countries.

Twenty-five years, lacking four months, elapsed between the landing of the first American contingent in Britain in the First World War and yesterday's landing of the first American troops on the same soil. Twenty-three years and two months have passed since the United States Senate, rejecting the League of Nations, retreated from the European front.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 20 -- Since operations in Europe continue to dominate the war, competent foreign observers here keep their eyes turned on the Russian Front. Their chief concern is to obtain definite replies to two questions:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Beaming as he left the White House today after a conference with President Roosevelt, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, told reporters that his reorganization program, "streamlined to get action," had been approved by the President.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Even bankers were not immune to the scheme of Mrs. Amelia M. Carr, 66-year-old ex-convict and confidence woman, it became known today when Robert L. Ross, president of the Franklin Savings Institution, here, told Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld that she had defrauded him of $7,984.
Holders of high priority ratings no longer are a favored group under tire rationing regulations, it was disclosed yesterday by Harold W. McGraw, Federal Rationing Administrator for New York City.

A deficit of $361,010 in the taxable estate of Jesse L. Livermore, stock market speculator, who shot himself on Nov. 28, 1940, was disclosed in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday. The appraisal showed assets of $107,047, against debts of $463,517 and funeral and administration expenses of $4,540.

May I extend congratulations to the museums of America, which, under the able leadership of the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Francis Henry Taylor, set forth resolutions that will have repercussions wherever culture is cherished. Mr. Taylor and his colleagues deserve a great deal of co operation and thanks for the initiative they have taken.

A leading apartment rental yesterday was reported by Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., brokers, who leased to Oliver D. Keep, president of Cue, Inc., publishers of the magazine of that name, a penthouse of seven rooms and four baths in 320 East Seventy-second Street.

Hollywood designers say it will be a feminine season in dress. "There's no reason that the girls should look plain just because they work in a factory." Quite right. One of the best known women of all time was a girl named Carmen who worked in a cigarette factory, and by all accounts was far from plain.

TOKYO, Jan. 20 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Dispatches from Manila reported today that the left flank of the Japanese attacking forces had pierced the defense line between Abuke and Matuv Mountain on the Bataan peninsula of Luzon Island.

Jose Iturbi's sister, Amparo, whose appearances in this country have almost all been as a duopianist with her brother, last night gave her first New York solo recital at Town Hall, and, to underline the fact that she plans to pursue her career independently, instead of using the name Iturbi, as she has in the past, she used her married name and appeared as Amparo Navarro.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 20 -- Louis J. Schiller, for many years an engineering expert in the sugar industry, died in Englewood Hospital this morning after a long illness. His age was 82.
WE know now how vulnerable the Philippines were, and are. It never was a deep secret.

Approving a 1942-43 budget of $146,620,725, the Board of Education attached yesterday a request to the Board of Estimate for an additional $980,362 to pay salary increases to 8,800 school employes who earn less than $2,400 annually, to "meet the rising cost of living."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- William Fox, bankrupt motion picture producer, told from a witness stand today for the third time his story of turning over $15,000 to Morgan S. Kaufman of Scranton, an attorney, to be given to J. Warren Davis, retired judge of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Jean Ferrante, 11-to-10 favorite owned by Frank P. Letellier of New Orleans, won the six-furlong Tulane Purse at the Fair Grounds today for his second victory in the only two starts of his career.

Japanese strategy for the conquest of the whole South Seas archipelago, the richest insular possession in the world, is making rapid strides. The first phase of the plan is clearly to erect a wall of air and naval outposts from Formosa directly southward to Australia.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (U.P.) -- Coincident with the fall of Mozhaisk, the Russians today also announced the capture of Ostashkov, 105 miles west of Kalinin, former northern anchor point of the Moscow battle line. Ostashkov, on Lake Seliger, is 180 miles north of Smolensk and Russian operations there represented a vast sweep westward from the Moscow-Leningrad railway.

Miss Emily Turk's plea for sensible tolerance in a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES tends to remind of the words of Addison: "The ill-natured man gives utterance to reflections which a good-natured man stifles." However, many have absorbed some little ill nature of late toward those who have capped down upon us so astounding a magnitude of peril.
CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Chinese High Command tonight issued this communique:

The Boxing Writers Association of New York, and patrons, executives and associates of the ring sport tonight will pay tribute to Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, and Lieut. Comdr. James Joseph (Gene) Tunney, retired former titleholder.

Enemy submarine activity continued yesterday off the East Coast from Cape Hatteras, N.C., to Newfoundland, but the Navy was taking "strong counter-measures." This was announced in a Navy Department communique issued at Washington. No details of the "strong counter-measures" were made public, and so there was no information on whether those measures had meant the sinking of any German submarines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- The railroad industry has notified the Office of Production Management that it will meet the production schedule of 36,000 freight cars by May 1 outlined for the industry by the government earlier this month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Industrial activity declined less than seasonally in December and the first half of January, retail trade continued in large volume and prices of many commodities, principally farm products and chemicals, rose further, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 20 -- Williams College announced today that a regular semester program would be offered during the Summer and that members of the three classes remaining after commencement would be required to attend the Summer semester, beginning June 29 and ending late in September.

The North American Company, second largest utility holding company in the United States, took steps yesterday to divest itself of control over the Union Electric Company of Missouri, a $270,000,000 subsidiary serving St. Louis and surrounding territory.

Lucius N. Littauer, retired manufacturer and philanthropist, received the Phi Epsilon Pi National Service Award yesterday for having made "the richest contribution to the essential Jewish life of America" in 1941. Yesterday was Mr. Littauer's eighty-third birthday.

There is a silver lining to the dark domestic cloud of conserving sugar, according to Miss Lillian Anderson, assistant director of the Nutrition Bureau of the Community Service Society. For it seems that refined sugar, though it's packed with energy, has no other food value -- no protein, no minerals and nary a vitamin.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- Failure of the House and Senate conferees to reach an agreement in regard to price-control legislation, especially the controversial ceiling on agricultural products, resulted in only a moderate trade in wheat and other grains on the Board of Trade today.

After conferring with officials of Bellevue Hospital and with the widow of Dr. Allyn King Foster Jr., who died in Bellevue on Saturday of injuries received at the hospital, Assistant District Attorney Jacob Grumet announced yesterday that the case "is far from solved."

Jackson Heights maintained its winning pace in Metropolitan League Class B squash racquets last night with a hard-earned 3-2 victory over the Princeton Club on the latter's courts. It was Jackson Heights' eleventh successive victory in the circuit and it can clinch the title next week by winning three games from the Union League Club even if Bronxville, second in the standing, sweeps its five games with the Seventh Regiment.

There was considerable resentment among city policemen yesterday because the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund at its meeting on Monday had postponed taking action on 114 applications for retirement.

Efrem Zimbalist, who gave a program for violin at Carnegie Hall last night, remains, above all else, a serious, straightforward musician who evidently despises ostentation. Either because of temperament or intent, he adheres to a restrained approach.

The Women's League for Palestine announced purchase of $76,425 of defense bonds at its tenth annual donor luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, at which $1,000 was presented to the American Red Cross. The $20-a-plate luncheon, attended by 1,000 members of the organization and their friends, marked the half-way point in the league's drive for $150,000 for purchase of defense bonds.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, Jan. 21 -- Mozhaisk, the last German stronghold in the immediate vicinity of Moscow, fell to Russian forces yesterday afternoon after eighteen days of stubborn resistance in the face of what was probably the most intensive pressure yet exerted by the Soviet against any point on the Eastern Front.
LONDON, Jan. 20 -- In his first public statement since his return from Washington, Prime Minister Winston Churchill said in the House of Commons today:
Many of the business leases reported yesterday involved space in downtown and midtown buildings. Several firms were listed as expanding their quarters to take care of increased business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The State Department announced tonight that Germany, Japan, Italy and Rumania had accepted in principle and in some particulars, proposals by the United States Government regarding the exchange of diplomatic and consular officers but added that some "essential" particulars remain to be settled.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 20 -- A resolution introduced today by the United States at the Inter-American Conference here called for monetary stabilization and proposed setting up an international fund to that end.

Money for the vast war production program must be made available to the government by "those unable to wear the uniform," Lewis Douglas, chairman of the Defense Savings Staff of the Treasury Department in the metropolitan area, told representatives of 500 women's organizations yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The report of Justice Roberts and his associates on the battle of Pearl Harbor presumably is well along in the process of preparation, and among the findings most eagerly awaited is that which will deal with the lack of alertness by the Army and the Navy.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20 -- The most tumultuous demonstration given to a jockey so far at the Hialeah Park meeting greeted Don Meade today after he had scored with the Blenheim Farms' Belle Poise in the Little River Purse. Only five started over the slow track, with Belle Poise, the third betting choice, winning by two lengths at $8.30 for $2.

In another session dominated by the railroad issues, the stock market turned slightly firmer yesterday although the pattern was similar to that followed on Monday. Most stocks took the path of least resistance, but once again the activity, except for the carriers, was too light to avail of any definite conclusions.

ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- Assemblyman Patrick H. Sullivan of Manhattan made public today a resolution he will introduce Monday night in the Legislature, protesting admission to the State bar of John F. Cassidy, whom Mr. Sullivan identifies as the director, in Brooklyn, of the Christian Front. Cassidy was one of the sixteen tried and acquitted in the Christian Front trial in Brooklyn last year.

The program of work camps for youths between 8 and 18 years old, which was part of a plan adopted by the American Association for Health, Physical Education and Recreation, and the bill for compulsory military training for high school boys, which will be introduced in the State Legislature today, both were sharply criticized at last night's session of the "War and Recreation Conference" at New York University.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 21 (AP) -- British Continued From Page One ish artillery firing point-blank over open sights appeared tonight to have brought the Japanese offensive to a halt in Northwestern Johore State, and Singapore's anti-aircraft batteries and fighter planes shot down at least thirteen enemy raiders in the best day's work yet for the defenders of this base.

SHEFFIELD, Mass., Jan. 21 -- Seaver B. Buck, founder and for 35 years headmaster of the Berkshire School, will retire at the end of the school year. He will be succeeded by Albert Keep, assistant headmaster, a graduate of the school in 1924 and a member of the faculty for the past 14 years.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 21 -- The Royal Australian Air Force announced today new Japanese air attacks in the Bismarck Archipelago and along the northern coast of the island of New Guinea, and Prime Minister John Curtin said that the menace of war was now "nearer, clearer and deadlier" to Australia than ever before.

Denials by Paul Klopstock of New York, a broker, of statements reportedly made concerning him by Serge Rubinstein, international financier, to Sir Harry Peat and incorporated by Sir Harry in his report on the Chosen Corporation to the British Board of Trade, featured the hearing yesterday into the affairs of that company.

Some unusual sidelights developed yesterday in connection with the highly successful flotation of $80,000,000 of Alabama Power Company 3 1/2 per cent bonds by a large underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Bonbright Co.

As in the case of the Truman report, the justice and value of the 400-page Vinson committee report can be determined only after there has been opportunity to study it in detail. But the digests of and selections from the report so far made public are far from reassuring regarding either the spirit or the competence with which the committee has gone about its task.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Fire in the skyscraper Netherland Plaza Hotel, Cincinnati's largest, routed guests and employes from the thirty-nine-story structure in the center of the downtown district today and caused damage estimated at $200,000.
THE rationing of auto tires has been a double-barreled shock to Al Schacht, the Clown Prince of Baseball.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that instead of adopting a rule regulating payments by subsidiaries of public utility holding companies of debt due to their parents, it would deal for the present with such problems by order on notice issued by the commission.

The board of directors of the Irving Trust Company announced yesterday the election of Harry E. Ward as chairman of the board. Mr. Ward, who has been president of the bank for twenty-three years, will be succeeded in that post by William N. Enstrom, who has been first vice president.

BERLIN, Jan. 21 (From German broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York) -- Adolf Hitler has appointed Jakob Werlin, a high officer in the Hitler Elite Guard, to be Inspector General of Motor Transport with control over nonmilitary motor vehicles and certain categories of automobiles and motor trucks in the military service, the official news agency, D.N.B. announced today.
Prominent members of the entertainment world made appeal yesterday from the steps of the New York Public Library for contributions to the Victory Book Campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The officials named by Donald M. Nelson to carry out the "streamlined" productions program which he outlined today have all had experience under the national defense program, and the tasks for which they have been named are similar in most instances to those they performed under preceding agencies.

The American Export Lines, Inc., reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30, net profit, including excess profits subject to possible recapture, of $10,018,362 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 21 -- A slip of paper reading: "Six German prisoners received with thanks," and signed "Sergeant P.," represents a receipt which a young British airman serving in Libya sent his mother as a souvenir, it was learned today.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Amendments of the automobile financial responsibility law to exclude from its coverage vehicles owned and operated by the Federal Government and the reporting of accidents where the resultant damage is less than $25 was sought in a bill introduced today in the Legislature.
