Although price controls may be necessary when some items of merchandise become so scarce that competition ceases to keep prices down, there is no such thing as a "good" price control plan, a subcommittee of the Retailers' Advisory Committee has reported to Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, following an analysis of food price control methods, the group announced yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Russian troops have begun a powerful drive on the northern front, apparently intended to knock Finland out of the war, smash the German stronghold of Novgorod and enable the Red Army to swing into the rear of Germans besieging Leningrad, Eastern Front dispatches said tonight.

The battle against the recently enacted "plumage law" seems to be gaining new recruits every day, but it must be admitted that there is a certain amount of confusion in the minds of some opponents of the law as to its effect on amateur fly-tyers.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of parents and teachers of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21 -- Bill Wood, Yale forward, not only turned the hat trick tonight as the Elis defeated the St. Nicholas H.C., 6 -- 4, in an overtime contest, but he went one better and rifled four shots past Goalie Pete Grace. His final two, the only goals tallied in the overtime, broke the 4-4 tie and gave Yale its two-goal margin.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The atmosphere was heavy in the Court of Appeals today. It resembled somewhat a day in midsummer, when black clouds hang low, and a violent electrical disturbance seems imminent.

Retail credit collections during December showed an increase of 1.35 per cent over the same month last year, according to the twenty-local-store index, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. Sixteen stores had increases for the month.

Mayor La Guardia ordered yesterday the cooperative rationing of "critical" supplies, materials and equipment carried in stock by the Department of Purchase and used by various city agencies. Departments having their own purchasing agencies, such as the Board of Transportation, the Board of Water Supply, the Board of Education and the Board of Higher Education, were asked to set up similar programs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The World War pension bills which recently went through the House under the guidance of Representative Rankin, chairman of the Committee on World War Veterans' Legislation, appear to have struck a snag in the Senate Finance Committee.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad bought in 1941 $1,432,900 par value of securities of subsidiaries for $763,476, which will make a saving of $74,681 in interest annually, William White, president, said yesterday. The company also repaid a $2,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan and a $900,000 bank loan.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A general court-martial acquitted Colonel H.C. Kress Muhlenberg today of charges that he wrongfully criticized the United States policy of sending American warplanes to foreign powers.

President Roosevelt summoned Philip Murray, C.I.O. president, to the White House yesterday and in a secret, one-hour conference promised to back the C.I.O. leader in his controversy with John L. Lewis over the latter's one-man drive for resumption of peace negotiations with the American Federation of Labor, it was reported authoritatively last night.

Despite a continued, heavy registration for training in civilian defense courses and placement at various civilian defense projects, Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, emphasized yesterday that thousands of persons were still needed to fill important civilian defense jobs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 -- Charles Boyer signed an exclusive three-year contract with Universal today as a producer-actor under which he will receive a percentage of profits as well as a flat salary. The deal is a decided departure for Boyer because he has never produced films before.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Delegates to the convention of the National Automobile Dealers Association were starting for their homes tonight with little hope for any speedy solution of the problems created by the government's orders banning automobile production after Jan. 31 and the regulations affecting tires.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- A seaman of the tanker Allan Jackson thought it was worth gambling his life to recover $80 from his locker. He lost.

A basic working agreement covering wage scales, hours and working conditions for ten motion picture studio craft unions affiliated with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes was negotiated yesterday by union officials and representatives of the eight leading film-producing organizations.

Sinking fund and other payments on account of principal of all outstanding Danish dollar bonds have been suspended until further notice, it was announced yesterday by Henrik Kauffmann, the Danish Minister.

PEARL BUCK'S "Dragon Seed"* is the latest of her Chinese novels. Except for a lapse toward the end, it is a good one, for here again she writes of the plain people of China, and no one else, American or English, does so with more apparent fidelity, and actual skill.

The vast majority of informed citizens will agree that the air raid protection service in this city is necessary. It is, in fact, wishful thinking to believe that the enemy will refrain from raids when such action would create a clamor for anti-aircraft protection for New York, thus diverting valuable equipment from strategic centers and, furthermore, would provide the best kind of propaganda for the war-weary German people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- America's aluminum production will be doubled and the magnesium output will be increased fivefold by expansion programs already under way to meet the heavy bomber schedule, the Office for Emergency Management disclosed today in a survey of natural resources.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 21 -- United States Ambassador Norman Armour, after calling on Acting Foreign Minister Guillermo Rothe, had a long interview today with Acting President Ramon S. Castillo. The visit, it is understood, was connected with the Argentine attitude at the Rio de Janeiro Conference of American Foreign Ministers toward the proposal for a joint rupture of relations with the Axis.

A resolution introduced in the House of Representatives recently by Mr. Somers of New York requests President Roosevelt to direct the State Department to petition Great Britain "to take such action as may be necessary to permit the organization of all-Jewish military units in Palestine."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Glenn L. Martin, aircraft manufacturer, asserted today it was "untrue" that his company made an $8,000,000 profit on a huge Navy contract and expressed amazement that the House Naval Affairs Committee "should reveal facts which the government regards as Naval secrets."

Many records have been set in the years 1937-42 but few of their holders can measure up to a pretty, hazel-eyed young woman much in the public eyes and ears these days. No patriotic rally, from prizefights to fashion shows, is complete without her presence.

The submarine attacks on shipping off the Atlantic Coast mark a new phase in Germany's war at sea. That tankers have been the chief victims of the U-boats is due probably to the fact that they form a large part of our coastwise shipping, and to the fact that they are especially tempting prizes because of the shortage of sea-borne carriers for oil and gasoline.

Nine seamen from the torpedoed Latvian freighter Ciltvaira, who thought so little of the perils of shipwreck that they went back, after being once rescued, to attempt to salvage their ship, were brought to New York yesterday by the Brazilian vessel Bury, which had picked them up for the second time.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 21 -- Mrs. Catherine Connor McInnerney of Riversville Road, young wife of Thomas H. McInnerney, 74-year-old chairman of the National Dairy Products Corporation of New York and former president of the concern for eighteen years, has filed papers in the Town Clerk's office in a divorce action and in an attachment on $1,000,000 worth of her husband's Greenwich property.

What Samson Raphaelson thinks of drama critics and Saroyan gradually comes to the surface in "Jason," which was acted at the Hudson last evening. For Jason, the sybarite and elegante, is drama critic of the New York Something-or-Other, and the skyrocketing genius who haunts Jason's house is Mr. Raphaelson's notion of Saroyan.
HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 21, (From Finnish broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Finnish war communique said:

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Mud-stained and tattered, but proudly carrying new rifles and dragging machine-guns and heavier pieces, veterans of China's four-and-a-half-year war have trudged 1,000 miles to take up positions defending Burma in the lofty gorges of the eastern frontier.

Despite the fact that the bulk of the small electrical appliance industry is headed for extinction, as a result of orders curtailing the use of nickel-chrome wire, only a few manufacturers have reduced their previous allotments to distributors, reports yesterday indicated.
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 21 -- Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Soviet Commissar of Foreign Affairs, will soon go to London, according to reports received here from various sources.

The position taken by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, that all moves for peace with the American Federation of Labor would have to be initiated through him, with the approval of the C.I.O. executive council, was supported yesterday by R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers and a vice president of the C.I.O.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 21 -- An oil tanker slipped quietly up to Fort Sumter here some time yesterday and transferred to a Coast Guard craft twenty-one survivors and two victims from the torpedoed Latvian freighter Ciltvaira.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Secretary Hull repudiated today as not expressing "the views of this government" a statement by Chairman Connally of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, comparing Argentina's foreign policy with that of a gambler "attempting to play both the red and the black at the same time."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A hemispheric war production plan, designed to integrate the effort of New World nations opposing the Axis, was disclosed here today.

Aiding Americans in their quest for the well-nourished life is the mission of a large company of age and prestige, which now brings to the fore a new version of the old, familiar "chocolate malted." This revised edition of a faithful friend is a fine-as-dust powder that behaves becomingly in the company of water or milk, either hot or cold.

Additional hearings yesterday in the office of Budget Director Kenneth Dayton revealed that city departments and agencies were continuing to ask for larger allowances in the tax budget for 1942-1943 than were provided in the budget for 1941-42.

Preparations for blackouts, the evacuation of children from the city and the building of bomb shelters are not as essential to national defense in this area as the production of materials of war, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, declared yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this communique today:

To discourage theft of new $2.09 Federal automobile tax stamps, the Third Internal Revenue District office, 110 East Forty-fifth Street, advised motorists yesterday to brush shellac or varnish over the stamps after gluing them to the windshield.

The annual report of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, announced yesterday, disclosed a net profit for the year ended on Dec. 31, 1941, of $17,850,460 after Federal income and excess profits taxes and other deductions.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 21 -- The text of the Pan-American declaration for rupture of relations with the Axis agreed upon by the twenty-one American republics tonight is as follows:
Carlos Concha, special envoy of Peru to Washington, and Senora Concha are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Governor Lehman called upon the farmers of the State tonight to make the "maximum contribution" to the nation's defense and war efforts by increasing production of basic commodities and products despite a corresponding decrease in farm labor and machinery.

With Larry Adler and Paul Draper already touring the concert halls with a harmonica-tap dance double bill, it remained for the Messrs. Shubert to bring together two other items that might reasonably be expected to remain asunder.

A group of thirty banking and investment firms headed by Lehman Brothers, Phelps, Fenn Co., R.W. Pressprich Co. and Goldman, Sachs Co., as joint managers, will offer today to the public $17,350,000 of New York City Housing Authority refunding bonds.

According to William Rose Benet, president of the League to Support Poetry, it is growing steadily through formation of new groups that encourage and give publicity to the league's work. Since poetry is the least remunerative of all writing fields and since publishers are chary of poetry by new writers (leaving the amateur poet the prey of "vanity publishers"), the league's program is to publish each year on a royalty basis four volumes of poems.

The Institutional Securities Corporation, owned by the savings banks in New York State, is to finance, build and manage defense housing, it was announced yesterday. This decision followed a favorable vote by the corporation's stockholders.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 21 -- The charge by the House Naval Affairs Committee that the Weston Electrical Instrument Corporation of this city made a profit of 247 per cent on a naval order of $1,033 was condemned here today by Edward F. Weston, president of the company, as having "grossly misleading and unfair" implications.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- The Most Rev. and Right Hon. Cosmo Gordon Lang, Archbishop of Canterbury, made known his intention to retire March 31 at a meeting of the full Synod here today. He said that at seventy-seven years it was time for him to step down in favor of a younger man who could not only tackle current problems but also would be fitted to face postwar difficulties.

Orders and reorders thus far placed for women's Spring ready-to-wear clothing average somewhat better than a year ago, with many manufacturers credited with volume gains of 15 per cent or more over the corresponding period last year, reports here indicated yesterday. Buying activity continued brisk this week, although the peak of buyers' arrivals was reached a week ago.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Premier, General Hideki Tojo, told Parliament today that Japan, acting in close cooperation with Germany and Italy, planned "increasingly vigorous operations" in the Pacific and would go on fighting until the United States and Britain were "brought to their knees."

Salomon Brothers Hutzler, Dick Merle-Smith and Stroud Co., Inc., were the successful bidders yesterday for $1,800,000 of Northern Pacific Railway one-to-ten year equipment trust certificates, receiving the award on their offer of 99.069 for the certificates bearing interest at the rate of 2 1/8 per cent, an interest cost basis of 2.31 per cent.

Elizabeth Schmidt, who recently acquired a loft property on West Twenty-fifth Street, has now acquired through 270 Seaman Avenue, Inc., the twelve-story lofts at 25-7 West Thirty-sixth Street, paying cash above a ten-year first mortgage.
In a setting that was appropriate, Private Joseph Louis Barrow and Lieut. Comdr. James Joseph Tunney last night were honored for their contributions to their country and to boxing.

Deprived of the last vestige of leadership when the railway shares joined the downswing, the market plunged yesterday to new levels for the year as the list became more attuned to the war developments at home and abroad. Volume picked up during the noon period and stocks then were at the worst points of the day, with values reduced as much as $3 a share.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21 -- Mrs. Robert Appleton entertained at today's Tombola luncheon at the - Everglades Club for her granddaughter, Miss Anne Milholland, and Miss Cynthia Myrick, both of whom are visiting her. Others in the party were Miss Harriett Wells and her guests, the Misses Elizabeth V.M. Taylor and Lowrie Flagg, Princesses Camilla and Francesca Rospigliosi and the Misses Nancy Bell, Joy Plummer and Betty Munson.

Add to the list of films opening over the week-end "Three Cockeyed Sailors," which will arrive at the Little Carnegie Playhouse on Sunday. The English comedy, which deals with three British seamen who board a German cruiser by mistake, was produced by Michael Balcon and directed by Walter Forde and is released here through United Artists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill authorizing expenditures of $750,000,000 to expand facilities for construction of 1,799 minor naval vessels.

Of all newspaper classifications, department store advertising in 1941 came closest to the 1929 figures, according to an analysis yesterday of Media Records figures for fifty-two cities. Department store figures were only 4 per cent under the 1929 level, which was the highest on record, while newspaper lineage as a whole was only 70 per cent of that year's figure.

Your correspondent Pauline K. Skinner writes concerning hand-knitted garments for the fighting forces and for civilians: "All this knitting and crocheting is a waste of wool. I believe that it should be done by machines and a uniform product turned out."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Creation of a volunteer women's Army Auxiliary Corps for noncombatant service with the Army of the United States, under the provisions of the bill introduced by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, was supported at a hearing today before the House Military Affairs Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- War Department communique No. 68, based on reports received here up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Grain markets were on the upgrade today, due more to lack of pressure than to aggressive buying, and closing sales on The Board of Trade here were around the top. Wheat finished at gains of 3/4 to 1 cent a bushel, corn was up 1 1/8 to 1 3/8 cents, oats 1/4 to 3/8 cent and rye 1 1/4 to 1 3/8 cents.

The estate of the late Mrs. Edwin S. Townsend, at Center Island, Oyster Bay, Nassau County, has been purchased by Joseph S. Stein, an executive of Lucien LeLong, Inc., perfume manufacturer. There are six acres of land in the property, which has a shore frontage of 500 feet.

OTTAWA, Jan. 21 -- Canadian mechanical equipment originally destined for the use of the Canadian troops in Hong Kong reached Manila last Dec. 12 and "remained under direction of the United States naval authorities there," Colonel James L. Ralston, Minister of Defense, revealed today in the House of Commons.

The Pan-American Society held its thirtieth annual meeting yesterday at the University Club, 1 West Forty-fourth Street, closing its most active year. Frederick E. Hasler, chairman of the Continental Bank and Trust Company, was re-elected president for a third term.

Yesterday morning, in a little room gay as a Paris bandbox, Bloomingdale's opened a new custom-made hat department. Its guiding spirit is Mme. Lil Picard, who until recently has had a millinery establishment of her own. She moved with all of her fine straws and her staff into her new surroundings on the third floor of Bloomingdale's in time to create her new line.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 21 -- Blinding sandstorms along the coast of the Gulf of Sidra yesterday further delayed British movements around El Agheila and prolonged the respite that a combination of bad weather and difficult terrain has gained for the Nazi armies.

Mrs. Margaret Boyle, 48 years old, a widow and the daughter of the late Charles C. McChord, at one time chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, went on trial yesterday before Judge J. Sullivan and a General Sessions jury on an indictment charging she used the names of prominent persons in Washington last year to defraud a New York jeweler.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Willie Hoppe of New York ran up a 27-to-0 lead tonight in his world three-cushion billiard tournament match, apparently setting a record with the feat. The champion easily defeated Jake Schaefer of Cleveland, 50 to 23, in forty-one innings.

John S. Fleek, president of the Investment Bankers Association, has urged in testimony before the House Interstate Commerce Committee that the membership of the Securities and Exchange Commission be enlarged from five to nine, that the term of office be lengthened from five to ten years and that the salary of members be increased from $10,000 to $15,000 annually.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A British communique today said:

Reporting on operations for the fifty-two weeks ended on Nov. 1, J. Cheever Cowden, chairman of the board of the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., said in the annual report mailed to stockholders today that the consolidated net income amounted to $4,396,499 after all charges except income and excess profits taxes. This compares with $2,861,472 on the same basis for the preceding fiscal year.

Yesterday morning the issue at Rio de Janeiro seemed to be whether or not the Government of Argentina, and with it that of Chile, could be coaxed out of an attitude of neutrality. Today Argentina and Chile have swung into line at the very moment when every one's thoughts have switched to the breath-taking war production plan which the United States yesterday pulled out of its sleeve.

Stage and screen stars gave an impromptu revue in the middle of Times Square yesterday while comely Conover and Powers models mingled in the crowd and coaxed thousands of dimes from bystanders to aid in the fight against infantile paralysis.

Dr. Hu Shih, China's Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday that President Roosevelt's statement of the importance of all war fronts had done much to allay the "natural anxiety and worry" occasioned among Chinese every where by Secretary of the Navy Knox's recent declaration that Hitler must be defeated first and that full-scale action by the United States Fleet against Japan could not be expected in the near future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The "second war powers" bill, requested by the Administration to give the President authority to seize plants, tools and equipment for war purposes and putting teeth into the priorities and allocations law, was approved unanimously today by the Senate Judiciary Committee and sent to the floor, probably for debate next Monday.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, Jan. 21 -- Seven Navy men told a thrilling story here today of drifting helplessly for eight days far seaward from the Canal in a disabled patrol plane, which threatened to sink any minute and required constant bailing by two men to keep it afloat.

The Ballistic Bureau of the Police Department announced late yesterday, following an all-day investigation, that a bullet from the pistol of a hold-up man and not one from that of a Negro patrolman was responsible for the death of Claude Phelps, a 65-year-old painter of 132 East 122d Street, who was shot yesterday at 2 A.M. outside a bar and grill at 1748 Park Avenue.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company announced yesterday that it will accept bids on its $25,000,000 financing program on Feb. 2. The financing involves the issuance and sale of $10,000,000 of 3 per cent new first mortgage bonds, due in 1962, and 150,000 shares of new cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

SCRANTON, Pa., Jan. 21 -- Manhattan College's basketball team started in whirlwind fashion tonight against the University of Scranton, piled up a 13-to-4 lead in the first few minutes, but then slowed up and permitted the home team to forge to the front and stay there to win by 63 -- 51.

Despite the fact that its top player, J.J. Lordi, national champion, met with a reverse, the New York Athletic Club continued along its unbeaten path in the race for Class A honors in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association, last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Frank Lloyd Wright has lost a commission from the government to design 100 defense homes for Pittsfield, Mass.

The last remaining fleet of the intercoastal steamship services is to be liquidated and the vessels dispersed by the Maritime Commission to routes that it considers more urgent, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Sinkings of two cargo vessels in waters off the Atlantic Coast by German submarines, both of which occurred on Monday, were announced tonight by the Navy Department.

Plans for a large cafeteria at Parkchester, the housing development of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in the Bronx, were revealed yesterday with the announcement that the Waldorf System, Inc., of Boston had leased 14,000 square feet in a unit at Metropolitan and Wood Avenues, adjoining Macy's branch.

TOKYO, Jan. 21 (From Japanese broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Domei news agency reported today that Japanese advance detachments in Malaya were within six miles of the Johore Strait, between Singapore and the mainland, and said that large Japanese forces were moving up for a direct assault on the British stronghold.

The Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships to be held at the Bronx Coliseum on Saturday have drawn an entry of 213 individuals and twenty-nine relay teams, it was announced yesterday by Chairman Pinky Sober. In point of quantity this is one of the largest entries ever received and in point of quality it is one of the best the meet ever has had.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 21 (AP) -British Headquarters issued this communique today:

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 21 -- The addition of 2,000,000 men in 1942 to our present Army of 1,750,000 men will require a minimum of 200,000,000 pounds of scoured wool, or approximately 450,000,000 grease-weight pounds of wool for uniform equipment, Brig. Gen. C.L. Corbin, chief of the supply division, Quartermaster General's Department, declared today before the members of the National Wool Growers Association in convention at the Hotel Utah.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- There is urgent need for further curtailment of consumer spending in Britain, Colin F. Campbell, chairman of the board of directors of the National Provincial Bank, one of the group known as the "Big Five" in banking circles, said in his report for the 109th annual meeting, made public today.

Milwaukee County, Wis., will enter the market on Feb. 9 with $11,000,000 of new securities, it was announced yesterday. The financing will consist of $7,200,000 of relief bonds, and $3,800,000 of corporate purpose notes. Other details in connection with the offering were not made public but will be announced at a later date.

Supreme Court Justice Harry E. Lewis in Brooklyn signed yesterday an order requiring Special Prosecutor John Harlan Amen, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick and City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio to show cause on Tuesday why an injunction should not be issued restraining the city from paying Mr. Amen and his staff for salaries and expenses in connection with investigations other them those specifically mentioned in Governor Lehman's order authorizing Mr. Amen's inquiry into official corruption.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Ernest C. Kanzler, automobile finance company president and former production director of the Ford Motor Company, was put in charge today of the job of converting the automotive industry to the task of turning out war materials in great quantity in the shortest possible time.

Mrs. George A. Fitch is to be congratulated. Her "Message to China" in THE TIMES last Sunday is filled with compassion for the China she loves, yet she manages also to be generous in her interpretation of Secretary Knox's "Hitler First" speech.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The House completed Congressional action today on legislation increasing retirement benefit contributions by Federal employes and blanketing members of Congress into the program.

The First Avenue Association will renew its effort for early demolition of the remaining section of the Second Avenue elevated structure between Chatham Square and Fifty-ninth Street, Clyde R. Place, president of the organization, announced in his report presented at the annual meeting of the association yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

A large program of government aid to the nation's colleges and universities through student loans and other forms of financial aid was urged yesterday by Dr. George Barton Cutten, who will retire as president of Colgate University in the Summer, upon his arrival here to attend a dinner tonight in his honor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- War fattened the national income to the new record total of $92,200,000,000 in 1941, or an average of $693 a person, government economists estimated today. This was $16,200,000,000 more than 1940 and $8,800,000,000 above the 1929 total.

The conviction is strong that we shall see the letters WPB in print much less frequently than OPM or any other alphabet combination at Washington. WPB is War Production Board, succeeding OPM, which is Office of Production Management. Actually WPB is Donald M. Nelson, and that is the name which will be featured in connection with public laurels and public bricks.

With eight teams again taking part, the fifth annual national invitation college basketball tournament will be staged on the Madison Square Garden floor starting Tuesday night, March 17, it was announced yesterday by Jack Coffey, chairman of the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Basketball Committee, sponsor of the competition.
As United States forces stood at bay in the Western Pacific yesterday, the nation was winning its greatest victories -- perhaps decisive victories -- on the Home Front.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- There was a firmer tendency in most markets today with renewed demand for shares of the tin companies outside Malaya. Gilt edge issues were firm. The electricals were the firmest of the industrial section, the others showing little change and several of the leaders losing a few pence.

After he had been arrested yesterday on a charge of embezzling $40,000 over a five-year period from a liquor distributing concern, Karl Kucker, 36 years old, a German, confessed last night, according to the District Attorney's office, that he had used the money to establish an importing and exporting business with which he dealt directly with four South American countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 --Employment of the services of the American Legion posts throughout the country in the civilian defense program was urged upon President Roosevelt today by Senator Butler of Nebraska.
BERNE, Switzerland, Thursday, Jan. 22 -- "There is no more Moscow front."
MOSCOW, Thursday, Jan. 22 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following today:

Back to the Broadway stage tonight come all the Negro neighbors from Catfish Row singing the lusty George Gershwin melodies at the Majestic in Cheryl Crawford's revival of "Porgy and Bess." Much of the recitative that displeased the critics when the opera first opened seven years ago has been eliminated.

The Brooklyn Museum will open with a private view this afternoon (to the public tomorrow) two one-man shows, which have been installed in the special exhibition galleries on the ground floor. The preview today will be preceded by a luncheon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Donald M. Nelson, war production chief abolished the Office of Production Management today and in its place set up an organization which he believes will put industry into high gear for the manufacture of armaments, munitions and supplies.
The woman power of the nation can be harnessed into a force essential to victory, Fannie Hurst, author, declared yesterday.

Building and engineering contracts awarded last year in the thirty-seven Eastern States amounted to $6,007,474,000, compared with $4,003,957,00 in 1940. This is the first time the total has topped the six billion dollar mark since 1928.

Miss Ann C. Reinicke, daughter of Captain Frederick G. Reinicke, U.S.N., and Mrs. Reinicke, gave a tea yesterday afternoon at her home, 340 Park Avenue, for a group of young women serving with her on the junior committee for the fortieth annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly Republican Club to be held on Feb. 4 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Two Americans long since given up as lost after the sinking of the Egyptian ship Zam Zam by a German raider in the South Atlantic last April 17 were reported tonight to he war prisoners in Germany.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES on the Malayan Front, Jan. 21 -- British artillery roared into action at 2 P.M. today as infantrymen moved forward to attack a strongly reinforced Japanese Army threatening the western flank of the British defenses in Northern Johore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Chairman Nelson of the War Production Board has asked the Truman committee of the Senate, he said today, for an opportunity to speak in defense of the group that is serving without pay in the mobilization of American industry for war.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in the House of Commons today, withdrew his motion to authorize an electrical recording of his next parliamentary speech on the war, for broadcasting. His decision met with general approval in the House.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- The United Light and Power Company, a utility system serving twelve central States, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to approve a plan under which the company would redeem on May 1 all its outstanding debentures totaling $15,093,800, without paying a redemption premium estimated at $1,358,460.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- In the presence of a small group of close friends and relatives, a funeral service was held late today for Carole Lombard of the films and her mother, Mrs. Elizabeth K. Peters, victims of an airline crash in Nevada last Friday in which twenty other persons were killed.
NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Mrs. Alice Snow Trapnell said today it was nice to hear that her husband was an Army hero but that it was even nicer to learn where he was.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Tire dealers, distributors and wholesalers who are overstocked with new tires or tubes are permitted to sell them back to their suppliers at prices which "permit them to recover their investment," Leon Henderson, Price Administrator, ruled today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Despite a plea that interference now with newspaper ownership of radio stations would hinder a unified war effort, the Federal Communications Commission unanimously refused today to drop its investigation of this matter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Office of Facts and Figures, which has been operating in secret for three months, will henceforth function publicly as the policy-making body for all government defense information, Archibald MacLeish, director of the agency, stated today.

Stocks of finished and unfinished gasoline stocks, including aviation gasoline, along the Atlantic coast were 20,361,000 barrels at the close of last week, an increase of 498,000 over the 19,863,000 a week earlier, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The Netherlands Indies armed forces issued this communique today:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- William Fox, bankrupt motion-picture producer, testified in a hearing before three special masters of the Federal District Court today that he would settle a $4,900,000 income-tax claim by the government some time this week by payment of $295,000.

The police, in cooperation with the District Attorneys of the five boroughs, declared war on pin ball machine operators after a decision yesterday by Magistrate Ambrose J. Haddock in Bronx Magistrates Court sitting as a justice of the Court of Special Sessions, which held that the 11,080 pin ball machines in the city were gambling devices to defraud the public.

Twenty-three of Manhattan's largest commercial banks have raised $516,000 for the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Lewis E. Pierson, chairman of the drive's finance section.

The New York State ski jumping championship, scheduled for the Telemark S.C.'s hill at Rosendale, N.Y., Sunday, will not be held unless more snow falls in that vicinity, it was made known yesterday. A strong field, headed by Arthur Devlin, Hans Strand, Carl Holmstrom, Bjorn Lie, Kyrre Tokle, Charley Blum and Leif Hansen, is expected to compete.

An unofficial open championship to take the place of the national open tournament that was scheduled for the Interlachen Club, Minneapolis, this year and canceled along with the amateur and women's championships because of the war, was announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- The synthetic rubber industry is prepared to give an excellent accounting of itself as to quantity and quality of its product during the wartime emergency, said E.R. Bridgwater, manager of the rubber chemicals division of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in an address tonight before the annual meeting of the Franklin Institute.

In view of the present rubber shortage, the Haitian Government, in cooperation with the United States Department of Agriculture, has set out vast rubber plantations in Haiti which will eventually employ 50,000 workers and produce 30,000 tons of rubber annually, according to Frank C. Magloire, chief of the Division of Agriculture of Haiti.

BERLIN, Jan. 21 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Russian forces broke through German lines on the upper Donets River yesterday, but were repulsed by counter-attacks, the High Command said today. The fighting was described as bitter.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Local Chinese offensives scattered across four Provinces from the Kwangtung coast to northwest of Hankow were announced today in a communique that told of intensified frontal assaults and raids deep into Japanese lines.

Leon Henderson expects the Price Control Bill to come out of conference containing the so-called farm protection provisions and he believes these provisions are inflationary and likely to cost the American public millions of dollars.

DETROIT, Jan. 21 -- The Common Council rejected today the ultimatum of Detroit city employes for blanket wage increases as the only alternative for averting a city-wide strike which has been called for Friday morning by the Municipal Employes Union (A.F.L).

A rare Kipling item, a copy of the first edition of "The Smith Administration," brought $2,700 last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., at the auction of the Kipling collection of the late Ellis Ames Ballard of Philadelphia.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- The synthetic rubber industry is prepared to give an excellent accounting of itself as to quantity and quality of its product during the wartime emergency, said E.R. Bridgwater, manager of the rubber chemicals division of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in an address tonight before the annual meeting of the Franklin Institute.

In view of the present rubber shortage, the Haitian Government, in cooperation with the United States Department of Agriculture, has set out vast rubber plantations in Haiti which will eventually employ 50,000 workers and produce 30,000 tons of rubber annually, according to Frank C. Magloire, chief of the Division of Agriculture of Haiti.

BERLIN, Jan. 21 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Russian forces broke through German lines on the upper Donets River yesterday, but were repulsed by counter-attacks, the High Command said today. The fighting was described as bitter.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Local Chinese offensives scattered across four Provinces from the Kwangtung coast to northwest of Hankow were announced today in a communique that told of intensified frontal assaults and raids deep into Japanese lines.

Leon Henderson expects the Price Control Bill to come out of conference containing the so-called farm protection provisions and he believes these provisions are inflationary and likely to cost the American public millions of dollars.

Perhaps it would be hard to convince those who saw the pair in action on the National Football League All-Star team earlier this month, but the statistics prove Cecil Isbell of the Green Bay Packers to be a better forward passer than Slingin' Sammy Baugh of the Washington Redskins.

In a final effort to satisfy men's appetites for fashionable clothing before the war reduces the available number of styles and fabric patterns, stores will introduce a wide range of new business, sports and leisure clothes in the coming Spring and Summer months, it was indicated yesterday at the fashion clinic and forum of the Retail Men's Wear Council of New York in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Conferees on the Price Control Bill again failed to reach agreement today despite predictions that differences would be resolved, but there were indications that these differences were narrowing.

An increase of at least 25 per cent over normal peace-time enrollment of student nurses is needed to meet the minimum requirements in this profession three years hence, according to a report submitted yesterday to the Nursing Council on National Defense at the Hotel Roosevelt.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 21 -- Unanimous agreement by the twenty-one American republics on a resolution for severance of relations with the Axis powers was reached late today at a three-hour consultation in the office of Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil, who is chairman of the Inter-American Conference.

The directors of Bonwit Teller, Inc., authorized yesterday the regular quarterly dividend of 68 3/4s cents a share on the 5 1/2 per cent preferred stock and 25 cents a share to holders of the common stock, both payable on Feb. 1 to stock of record of Jan. 24.

Jose Iturbi seemed to be in an objective frame of mind in his piano recital last night, which was the fifth event of the Town Hall Endowment Series. His playing as well as his attitude toward the job was businesslike. He scarcely gave the appreciative audience a chance to applaud one composition before he was off on the next.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 21 -- Burma's air and ground defenders effected a strong coordinated defense tonight in heavy fighting, against mixed Japanese and Thai invaders who had struck almost a third of the way across Lower Burma toward the Gulf of Martaban.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 -- Officials of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange suspended trading on the butter and egg market today for several minutes as government activities left buyers bewildered. Back of the confusion was the Department of Agriculture's announcement made on Monday that it "didn't want eggs at any price for export purposes" and the disclosure today that it had bought some.

The Princeton Club remained in the running for the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C title by defeating the University Club, 5 to 0, on the latter's courts last night. However, Princeton failed to gain on the leaders as the Columbia U.C. was credited with a 5-to-0 triumph when Rockaway defaulted.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 21 -- The Vatican today took a decided stand regarding the situation of the Catholic Church in Germany and the discussion of Christian doctrines in Italy. Dispatches received here from Rome indicate that in the first instance the stand is tantamount to contradiction of Adolf Hitler and in the second of Benito Mussolini.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- While two members of the House Labor Committee hailed today new efforts for unity between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, an A.F. of L. spokesman, Philip Pearl, Federation publicity head, asked: "What new form of skullduggery is John L. Lewis up to now?"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The railroads of the country received authority today to increase passenger fares by 10 per cent to help meet increased operating costs and to continue "adequate and efficient" transportation for the duration.

Preparedness for post-war conditions, through the advance planning of a vast public works program to be held in readiness for the day of victory, was a major topic of discussion yesterday at the opening sessions of the eighty-ninth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, one of the four national engineering societies, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

Credit for dependents as well as personal exemption of income tax payers must be prorated where their status is changed, as by marriage, during the taxable year, the Bureau of Internal Revenue pointed out yesterday. An exception is made, however, in cases where the optional simplified form of return is used by taxpayers eligible to submit such a form.

Mrs. T. Ferdinand Wilcox, president of the New Canaan (Conn.) Garden Club, gave a luncheon yesterday in the Roosevelt Portrait Room at the American Museum of Natural History, before the Winter meeting of the club.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- Reports that Soviet Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff Molotoff might come to London to confer with British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden on military matters and post-war problems were heard in diplomatic quarters tonight.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 21 -Mrs. Henrietta Stout, considered one of the foremost authorities on dahlias in the country died today at her home Charlecott, after a two-year illness at the age of 66. She was born in New York, a daughter of the late Francis and Lucy Langdon Schroeder, and had lived in Short Hills nearly forty years.

There was not much left of Mozhaisk when the Russians entered, although more than of some cities the Germans have lost. A key position was taken but the town was ruined, and with it the system of strong entrenchments built by the Germans during three months of occupation.
Two figures prominent in the entertainment field were listed yesterday among the lessees of residential quarters.

Under heavy trade and mill buying, cotton futures yesterday reached the highest level in more than twelve years. On the New York Cotton Exchange quotations advanced as much as 14 points before profit-taking reduced the gains.

Preparedness for post-war conditions, through the advance planning of a vast public works program to be held in readiness for the day of victory, was a major topic of discussion yesterday at the opening sessions of the eighty-ninth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers, one of the four national engineering societies, at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 21 (U.P.) -- The Brazilian Government has taken over the 23,861-ton Italian luxury liner Conte Grande and the German steamship Windhuk, it was announced today.
BERLIN, Jan. 21 (From German broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

CLEVELAND, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The shortage of scrap iron in December increased the consumption of upper lakes iron ore to a record 7,061,981 gross tons, the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association reported today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Willie Hoppe barely defeated Joe Chamaco tonight in the world three-cushion billiard championship tournament. The score was 50 to 46, in forty-two innings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (U.P.) -- Philippine President Manuel Quezon has sent a message to Resident Commissioner Joaquin M. Elizalde here, expressing confidence in the loyalty of Jorge Vargas, who is acting as Mayor of Manila under the Japanese occupation forces, Mr. Elizalde disclosed today.

The 4,497-ton American freighter Brazos, long in the coastal and West Indian trade, was sunk on Jan. 13 in a collision with another vessel 150 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, it was announced here yesterday at the headquarters of the Third Naval District at 90 Church Street.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- The Municipal Employees Union (A.F.L.), whose threatened strike set for 4 A.M. tomorrow might have paralyzed municipal transportation and affected 21,000 other city of Detroit workers, voted at a mass meeting tonight to delay the strike.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The buying splurge of the last several weeks continued last week and the Federal Reserve Board's report on department-store sales for the week ended Jan. 17 showed a gain of 45 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago.
BERLIN, Jan. 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command communique today follows:

Warning that Australia may be "just on the verge of an invasion," Richard G. Casey, Australian Minister to the United States, in a radio address at the dedication of Freedom House last night, appealed to America not to "let us down."

IN a football way nothing much came out of the meeting of the Football Rules Committee on the edge of the Arizona desert just outside Phoenix except the agreement that, if only as a symbol, a brave football player should always start by facing the foe. Thus Ossie Solem's turned-around or reversed center -- lining-up with his back to the enemy forces -- was treated with a polite heave-ho off the collegiate gridiron.

For the duration of the war the Metropolitan Museum is sending many of its treasures to a hidden refuge in the country. But nothing could be more precious than the collection of Rembrandt paintings, etchings and drawings which the museum has assembled for public view.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- While belief grew that Japanese marines had landed on New Britain Island, newspapers cried out today for United Nations air reinforcements and defense officials, planning to blackout all cities on the mainland, began accepting enlistments from resident aliens -- Germans, Austrians, Danes, Italians and Czechs.
Sugar was being rationed, unofficially in some restaurants yesterday because of market conditions and the desire to assist the government in conserving existing supplies.

It is a happy fact that this city, like countless other American communities, can interrupt its daily work and take its mind off a great war to help the campaign against infantile paralysis. The "March of Dimes" is rightly heard above the tramp of marching feet. The crusade for a healthier nation, which must go on year after year, is in perfect harmony with the military crusade for human rights.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, chairman of the St. Vincent's Hospital Building Fund, reported yesterday that in the first week of the institution's war-time campaign for $750,000 gifts totaled $145,279.

Joseph T. Sharkey, Brooklyn, Democrat and vice president of the City Council, made public yesterday a letter from Park Commissioner Robert Moses thanking the Democratic majority leader for sponsoring the local bill that would authorize Mr. Moses to delegate his duties as City Planning Commissioner to a subordinate.

Steven George Saxon, 22 years old, of 112 Huron Street, Brooklyn, who pleaded guilty a week ago to an indictment charging him with failure to report for induction into the Army, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn, to serve two years in jail.

VICHY, France, Jan. 23 -- Food demonstrations have been reported in the last few days, according to the Cri du Peuple, published in Paris, at Montpellier, Nimes and Sere, all in the south of France. "Their causes," says the newspaper, "arose, as always, from the poor organization and the insufficiency of the supply system in these towns."

Although some 50 per cent of the nation's production is earmarked for the war effort, American manufacturers should allocate a larger proportion of their output than usual for export to the Latin American market, according to a survey released yesterday by the foreign credit interchange bureau of the National Association of Credit Men.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The British Middle East Command communique today follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The United States has made considerable progress in preparing itself mentally and materially for a modern world-wide war, but must "mobilize every available man, woman, dollar and thing" to reach the ultimate objective of total victory, Archibald MacLeish, director of the Office of Facts and Figures, told President Roosevelt today in a report to the nation.

A plan to canvass nearly 150,000 municipal employes for contributions to the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York was agreed upon yesterday by representatives of 100 branches of the city government who met at the Arkwright Club, 40 Worth Street.

In addition to the program already made known, the fourth act of Bizet's "Carmen" will be presented at the opera festival to be held by the Metropolitan Opera Association, Tuesday night, for the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York, it was announced yesterday by Lucrezia Bori, chairman of the program committee.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 23 -- Communications with Rabaul, on New Britain Island in the Australian-mandated Bismarck Archipelago, ceased at 4 P. M. yesterday, a half-hour after eleven ships had been sighted thirty to forty miles off Watom Island, which is fifteen miles northwest of Rabaul.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- A sensational report that it had been proposed that all tariffs and other trade barriers between Western Hemisphere countries be eliminated as a result of the Pan-American Conference came in for a little attention from the grain trade today, although it was responsible for a small dip in prices early.

The eight-point "Hemisphere Production Plan" to integrate the effort of American nations opposing the Axis, which is, being considered at the Rio de Janeiro Conference, contains a number of features long favored by foreign traders here, it was said yesterday in trade circles.

Reorganization would be impracticable at present, according to Gordon Grand, president of the American Superpower Corporation. Accordingly, the board has decided to continue its policy of buying its own first preferred stock.

In so far as rubber is concerned, the "scorched earth" policy of the British in Malaya for which a clamor has been raised in England and the United States, is impossible of application, Sir John Hay, authority on rubber growing, declared in an interview yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Bank of England's weekly statement today disclosed a decrease in note circulation of more than 3,000,000. This is the third consecutive weekly decline, which totals more than 11,000,000 for that period. Public deposits showed a good increase and the Bank's reserve improved about 3,000,000.

A program designed to obtain employment in war industries, for its members who may be thrown out of work because of dislocations arising from the war, was launched yesterday by Typographical Union No. 6 (Big Six).

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, on the Malayan Front, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The British counter-offensive seventy miles above Singapore has stopped the Japanese invaders in the positions they reached two days ago, a tour of advanced headquarters in Northwestern Johore disclosed late today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that 7,995,377 short tons of refined sugar, a record quantity, had been delivered to the American market by manufacturers and importers during 1941. This figure did not include deliveries by mainland cane mills, information on which was not available.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- The Chicago Black Hawks scored a 4-2 victory over the Brooklyn Americans tonight before 7,341 customers in the Chicago Stadium. The defeat dropped the Americans into sixth place in the National Hockey League standings, Brooklyn trading places with the Detroit Red Wings, who beat Boston tonight.
The possibility of international sandlot baseball was indicated yesterday by John T. McGovern, president of the New York City Baseball Federation, at the annual meeting of its board of directors.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A high government official reported today that since the Pearl Harbor attack the Army had been able to start a stream of reinforcements to the Southwest Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The National War Labor Board settled its first strike today by appealing to the patriotism of the workers and their union leaders and urging a return to work "in the interest of victory over our enemies."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- Trim Benny Hogan, the 137-pound golfer with a heavyweight punch in his clubs, made the game look easy today as he took the first-round lead in the 72-hole San Francisco open tournament with a seven-under-par 65.

Harvey Ladew Williams of Greenwich, Conn., manufacturing executive, disclosed last night that his 14-year-old daughter, Eleanor Ladew Williams, had been missing from home since last Sunday. An intensive search, including a nine-State alarm sent out by the New York City Police Department, has failed to produce any clues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The War Production Board authorized automobile parts manufacturers today to triple their 1941 production rate of spare parts for passenger cars and light trucks during the period from now until June 30.

A special advisory committee of metallurgists, who will assist small or large metal producing or metal working manufacturers engaged on war production, has been formed and will function without compensation and without charge, it was announced yesterday by W. O. Crabtree, district manager of the contract distribution branch, Production Division of the War Production Board.

Twelve college presidents were among the 300 persons who attended a dinner last night to honor Dr. George B. Cutten, the 68-year-old president of Colgate University, who will retire this Summer after twenty years of service as college president.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that labor unions could sue for libel, in actions brought in their behalf by their officers. The general law had been that unincorporated associations could not bring suits of this kind, but that the suits had to be instituted by individual members.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 22 -- Brazil plans to break off relations with the Axis forthwith as a demonstration of her determination and an example to the Inter-American Conference, to which she is host. The Brazilian Government expects Germany to retaliate by declaring war, but President Getulio Vargas, Foreign Minister Oswaldo Aranha and other officials refuse to be disturbed by this prospect.

IS the present effort by Mayor La Guardia to stimulate the saving of waste paper by civilians a genuine effort to collect war material or merely an effort to stimulate a war psychology? I ask because the City of New York is destroying more waste paper every day than the efforts of individuals can save in weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A bin requiring annual registration with the Federal government of labor, business and trade organizations, together with financial statements and other data as to their activities, was introduced in the House today by Representative Vinson, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Japanese, with more than 200,000 troops on Luzon and reinforcements still arriving, today directed hammer blows at General Douglas MacArthur's army in an apparent attempt to crush it by sheer numbers.

Two new varieties of flowers, said to be the first ever produced by the action of X-rays on seeds, will be exhibited on Monday to horticulturists and garden editors in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by David Burpee, seedsman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP)-- New Jersey borrowers of the Home Owners' Loan Corporation have repaid $36,725,000, or 19.2 per cent, of their total principal indebtedness of $190,194,381. An additional of $29,261,601 has been realized on the sale of 6,935 of the 13,531 New Jersey properties taken over by the HOLC.

From a motley group of amiable squatters found in a Second Avenue restaurant, H. S. Kraft detected the nucleus of an idea which developed into the comedy, "Cafe Crown," opening tonight at the Cort. Into this dining establishment come members of the Yiddish theatre to eat a bit and talk a lot. Around the story of these actors, artists and their colleagues, the plot is centered.

G.S. Eyssell, managing director of the Radio City Music Hall and of the Center Theatre, as well as president of the Radio City Music Hall Corporation, has been elected a director of Rockefeller Center, Inc.

The official National Football League statistics on pass-catching that were released yesterday confirmed what every one has known all along -- that Don Hutson of the Green Bay Packers is the greatest receiver in the sport. The Alabaman betters two records every time he catches a pass.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- A declaration pledging a democratic regime for the restored Polish republic -- equality of citizens, rights for national minorities and social justice -- forms the basis of a reconstruction of the Polish Cabinet in London following Premier Wladyslaw Sikorski's return from Russia.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 22 (U.P.) -- Bombers of the Chinese Air Force struck inside French Indo-China for the first time today, dropping twenty tons of bombs on a Japanese air base and other military installations, and inflicted heavy damage, according to the Central News Agency.

According to several letters received from ardent blue-water anglers who went to Florida for balmy weather and big fish, they would have been almost as warm and would have taken almost as many fish had they remained at home, for the past ten days have been driving the Miami publicity men to distraction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The motion-picture industry has not yet proved that discriminations in licensing of films can be remedied without the divorcement of theatre owners and distributors, a special unit of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice reported today.
A plan to mobilize every medical man in New York County for civilian defense, drafted by Dr. Condict Cutler Jr., chief of Emergency Medical Service for the county, was made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers and representatives of the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges gave the House Interstate Commerce Committee today their conflicting views on proposals to change proxy regulations of the 1934 Securities Exchange Act.

There is a noticeable tendency to "wait and see" before jumping to the conclusion that our problem of industrial organization for war has been solved finally by the appointment of Mr. Nelson and the creation of the new War Production Board. This is a healthy state of affairs.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 22 -- Two men were crushed to death and two others narrowly escaped serious injury this morning in an avalanche of chemical residue at the Natural Products Refining Company at 902 Garfield Avenue, here.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Friday, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The Netherlanders yesterday set afire the rich oil fields and refineries of Balik Papan and sardonically informed the Japanese they "might just as well forget about their plans" for invading the East Borneo section "except for establishing a base" there.

It seems that an unwarranted hysteria is seizing educational institutions throughout this country. The patriotic zeal on the part of our colleges and schools may contribute greatly to winning the war. The accelerated college program will be a boon to those who, under the ordinary program, would have their college education cut in two.

Mrs. Mildred Fleming, matronly owner of a fashionable Washington boarding house, continued her testimony yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Mrs. Margaret Boyle, another resident of Washington, accused of defrauding a New York jewelry broker of $41,000 in gems between March and July of last year.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 22 -- An interstate call for the continuation of racing was sounded today at the convention of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners, following which practically all in attendance went to Hialeah to see the Woolford Farm's Signator capture the featured Jacksonville Purse.

OTTAWA, Jan. 22 -- All the circumstances regarding the Hong Kong expedition will be investigated by a special committee of the Canadian House of Commons, it was agreed today when the Conservative Opposition leader, R.B. Hanson, took up again the debate begun yesterday following the statement oy defense Minister J.L. Ralston that the Canadian Expeditionary Force had contained more than 130 untrained men and that it had arrived in Hong Kong without its mechanical equipment.

A three-point law enforcement program for the city during the war was outlined by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Grand Jury Association of New York County at the Hotel Commodore.

Directors of the General Steel Castings Corporation authorized yesterday a dividend of $1.50 a share against arrears on the preferred stock. The previous payment was $1.50 in November, last year, the first payment since 1931.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The hockey game between the Bruins and All Stars, scheduled for March 17 at the Boston Garden, will not be played because the Red Cross has refused to accept it as a benefit, the Bruins' management today advised Frank Calder, National League president.

Pinball machines throughout the city clacked and jangled merrily yesterday, but only on the backs of policemen ordered to confiscate them. The raids, started on Wednesday, had resulted up to 11:30 o'clock last night in a total haul of 2,325 machines, one-fifth the number believed to be in the city. Summonses issued stood at 1,427.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Early and favorable action by Congress on the bill, introduced by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers, providing for creation of a Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, was predicted by officials today, on the basis of the hearings ended yesterday before the House Military Affairs Committee.

Cuba Day will be celebrated at Macy's Latin-American Fair today, with Cayetana Queseda, acting consul general of Cuba, as the guest of honor. Graziella Parraga will be master of ceremonies in a program featuring Pepita Lopez and Herbert Curbelo's orchestra to be broadcast by short wave to South America from Fiesta Square at 4:30 P.M.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 22 -- Strong British counter-assaults on all the main land and air fronts in Malaya eased the Japanese aerial siege of Singapore today, shattered an invasion spearhead on the east coast and slowed or stopped the enemy drive in Northwest Johore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Treasury feels "sympathetic" toward citizens who may find themselves caught between the upper millstone of higher income taxes and the lower one of wartime industrial dislocation, but has done nothing yet to meet their situation, Secretary Morgenthau said at his press conference today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- As might have been expected, the first publication that has come from the Office of Facts and Figures is good craftsmanship, because OFF's personnel includes many good craftsmen. As also might have been expected, the "report to the nation" is in good taste, typographically and textually, because the calibre of gentility is high at OFF.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Senator Walsh, chairman of the Naval Affairs Committee, told the Senate today that reports on war profits by two inquiry committees constituted "a source of humiliation" to the Congress. Previous attempts to curb profits, he asserted, had prompted "bombardments" of protest, not only from "big business interests" and airplane manufacturers, but from the Office of Production Management.

Plans for canvassing the 675,000 structures in New York City to reclaim all scrap materials valuable for war production were announced yesterday by Clarence H. Low, chairman of the New York City Salvage Committee.

A twelve-year-old labor racket murder case in which the Lepke-Gurrah gang was accused was revived last night with the arrest here of two men and the filing of a General Sessions bench warrant in a State prison against the third alleged slayer, whose identity District Attorney Frank S. Hogan refused to reveal.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 (From German broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York) -- War developments of recent months have "lent a new and grandiose profile to the military struggle, and before its dimensions the cares occupying us two years ago are shrinking to nothingness," Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels said tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan, 22 -- Columbia announced today that Rita Hayworth will be starred in "Cover Girls of 1942," a screen musical to be produced after the actress finishes her forthcoming assignment in a Fred Astaire film. The studio has obtained agreements from twelve national magazines by which each publication will nominate its most successful front-cover model for the season, and the models will be signed for roles in the picture.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture assured farmers today that it would support price of eggs at 85 per cent of parity during the heavy production season next Spring. The support will be given, it said, through greatly increased government purchases for the lease-lend program and for domestic relief distribution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Herbert Wechsler, a former assistant Attorney General of New York, has offered to resign as executive secretary of the Board of Legal Examiners because of mention of his membership on the National Board of the International Juridical Association, which Representative Starnes described as "a Communist party auxiliary."

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- The necessity of conserving automobile tires and the overcrowded condition of some of the more popular trains are taking their toll of the attendance at Chicago trade shows this year and as a result the Chicago Association of Commerce today forecast a buyer registration of around 18,000 for the three Spring market weeks commencing next Monday. This would compare with a registration last year of 20,300 buyers.

A telegram, suggesting to Mayor La Guardia that he name a committee of all interested parties, including the Transport Workers Union, to study all phases of the proposal for higher transit fares and report recommendations, was authorized last night at a mass meeting of the union, representing transit workers, at the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue.

" All Through the Night," a Warner melodrama starring Humphrey Bogart, Conrad Veidt and Kaaren Verne, will be the new attraction at the Strand this morning. Directed by Vincent Sherman, the picture's supporting cast includes Judith Anderson, Peter Lorre, Jane Darwell and Frank McHugh.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 22 -- Replacing of the "Communist peril" by the "yellow peril," dear to the heart of the late Kaiser Wilhelm, and conclusion of an all-around peace between the white nations to enable them to start a joint crusade against Japan -- such are the lines of a new "peace feeler" that, emanating from what are described as certain German circles, circulated today in Stockholm.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22 -- Engineers at the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company's laboratory today released an electrical force equal in destructive power to that of many lightning bolts and demonstrated how it could be controlled and made harmless with improved safety devices to protect power systems against short circuits caused by bombings and sabotage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate, for the protection of American civilians against air raid and other war hazards, the $100,000,000 which it authorized earlier this week for use by the Office of Civilian Defense.

Gale F. Johnston, third vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, urged members of the Life Underwriters Association of New York yesterday to lend every effort to increase the sale of defense bonds for the benefit "of the boys on the firing line" and to preserve the typical American method of voluntary subscription.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 22 -- British Imperial forces have repulsed elephant-riding Japanese and Thai invaders with heavy losses at Kawkareik, forty-five miles east of the port of Moulmein, and they have sent troops to Ye, 100 miles south of Moulmein, to guard the right flank of the defenders of Burma's southeastern frontier, it was announced today.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in New York and San Francisco) -- Dispatches from Malaya said today that Japanese troops were fiercely attacking the British defense forces all along the front below the Muar River and were advancing south toward Singapore in a number of sectors.

American Friends of Norway, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the preview performance of the new American version of Ibsen's "Hedda Gabler" to be given on Wednesday at the Longacre Theatre. The new translation is by Ethel Borden and Mary Cass Canfield.

All types of complexion suffer from quick changes of weather such as the past few weeks have produced. To go from a steam-heated house into a wintry blast plays havoc with the best of faces. Even oily skins can become flaky and less flexible, while to textures especially thin and delicate these extremes can be almost disastrous.

The American Association of University Presses will hold its annual meeting today at the Vanderbilt Hotel. E.W. Palmer, chief industrial consultant to the pulp and paper section of the OPM, will speak on priorities as they affect printing and publishing.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 22 -- Adrian Hegeman, a real estate dealer and construction engineer, was elected president of the County Savings and Loan Association to succeed James E. Stiles at the annual meeting here yesterday. Mr. Stiles, who is publisher of The Nassau Daily Review-Star and newly elected president of the New York State Publishers Association, resigned because of press of other affairs.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 22 (AP) -- Higher earnings of industrial workers generally are being used not for savings but to pay past-due obligations and other debts, Charles H. Watts of Newark, N.J., president of the Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation, said today at a meeting of the New York Association of Personal Finance Companies.

Because the action covered a continuous front 1,500 miles long, two months ago the Russian battle line was regarded as the index of the unparalleled scale of this war. But the Battle of the Pacific, besides immensely extending the area of the conflict, has introduced a new measure of distance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- New issues of securities offered for cash in the first nine months of 1941 amounted to $7,884,000,000, which was more than in any year since 1936, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- As Parliament prepared today for the forthcoming airing of the war effort, Prime Minister Winston Churchill put the Conservatives "on the spot" by threatening to ask for a vote of confidence if the debate became too stormy.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 22 -- The task of explaining the home front to the soldiers in the firing line and the soldiers' front to the people who are shouldering the production effort at home is one in which the Propaganda Ministry in Berlin is exerting all its energy.

Another all-out railroad session was witnessed yesterday on the Stock Exchange, but in spite of the increase of 10 per cent in passenger fares allowed by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the carrier issues failed to enjoy major advances.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22 (From Soviet broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- German armies floundering back along Napoleon's road of retreat from Moscow were harried tonight by Russian ski troops that skimmed the snowdrifts on fast, propeller-driven sleds and struck fiercely at their flanks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Through its priorities section the Division of Industry Operations of the War Production Board today served notice that it will conduct a plant-by-plant survey of some ninety primary fabricators of copper at once.

Metropolitan skiing enthusiasts will have to travel to distant points for their sport this week-end, according to reports from Winter playgrounds last night. The popular Laurentians of Eastern Canada, extending from Shawbridge to Mont Tremblant and Lac Beauport, outside Quebec city, are the only sections in Eastern North America where ski conditions are uniformly fine.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- There must be a recognition of the necessity for some post-war international agreement and control based on the fact that "we'll all be neighbors, independent if you will, but interdependent and incapable of taking individual action without some repercussion on the fortunes of others," Lord Wardington, chairman of Lloyd's Bank, Ltd., declares in his annual report for 1941.

Does any one remember when it was generally believed in this country that Chinese troops carried fans and umbrellas, stopped fighting whenever it rained, and slew their enemies, if at all, by scaring them to death with gongs and firecrackers? The Chinese, in fact, were never so foolish as that.

The 10 per cent increase in passenger fares now granted to the railroads was made necessary mainly by the very substantial increase in railway wages granted recently by the President's emergency fact-finding board. While it is estimated by the railroads that the present fare increase will bring in only $45,000,000 additional revenue a year, the recent railway wage increases added about $350,000,000 a year to the roads' operating costs.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 22 -- Until recently the Bulgarians confidently expected a German victory; now they are beginning to realize that they have backed the wrong horse again, according to two former high American officials of the United States Legation at Sofia, who have arrived here en route to the Middle East after closing the legation.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The first rest home for civil defense workers was opened yesterday by Admiral Edward Evans at Cooper-Sale Hall, Epping, Essex. The home was made possible through gifts of the British War Relief Society of America, which contributed 900 toward its upkeep for a year in addition to providing bedding and equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Japanese troops, which control a longer arc of territory around General Douglas MacArthur's forces than has been reported heretofore, today renewed along his entire line a heavy attack that was still in progress when the Army issued the sole communique of the day, based on information received here up to 9:30 A. M.

Some slackening in the consumer rush for men's clothing since the start of the year has taken place in other sections of the country, manufacturers reported yesterday. One explanation was that stocks have been thinned out considerably, particularly in worsted clothing.
