" Where's the fire?" will replace "number please," in the vernacular of 800 telephone operators who will begin refresher courses next week at the Greater New York branch of the American Women's Voluntary Services, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street.

ROCKLEIGH, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The semi-final bracket in the New York Athletic Club's annual low-goal polo tournament was filled tonight as the New York A.C. trio downed the Penguins, 15 -- 13, and the Pegasus Club conquered the Magpies, 15 -- 7, in games played at the Pegasus arena.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- Westchester County officials expressed resentment today that the Federal Government had not begun construction of a defense airport on the Rye Lake site in Purchase, as the county had agreed to buy the site a month ago today after prodding by Army men and other government representatives, who said speed was imperative.
Britain has just given the world a sign! Only a few lines of press dispatch tell the story, but it is enough to quicken the hearts of the victims of German "schrecklichkeit."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that where physical verification of inventories by independent public accountants would curtail production of war materials, it might be omitted so long as the company concerned and its accountants took reasonable practical alternative measures to assure the substantial fairness of inventory amounts stated.

New York is so "full of loose talk" that the safety of seamen and cargoes vital to the war is being endangered by little bits of careless gossip, according to Allan Harvie, a chief steward in the British merchant marine, who has been here about a week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A Sixth Armored Division will be added to the Army's battle force of tank troops Feb. 15, Secretary Stimson said today at a press conference in which he described plans for expediting the work of expanding the Army this year to a force of 3,600,000 men.

OTTAWA, Jan. 22 -- The holding of a national referendum on the conscription of Canadian troops for overseas service -- to release the government of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King from its commitments against such a measure -- was announced in the program speech from the Trone, read today in the Senate by the Governor General, the Earl of Athlone, at the opening of the new session of Parliament.

Hope that Republicans in and out of Congress would give complete support to the National Administration in attaining victory but at the same time would criticize and seek to rectify anything they thought wrong about its conduct was expressed last night by Thomas E. Dewey at the seventeenth annual dinner of the New York Young Republican Club at the National Republican Club.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $205,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $1,210,000,000, highest since last October, or just before the higher reserve requirements of the Federal Reserve Board went into effect.

William H. Rankin, advertising counselor, made public yesterday a letter to Thomas O. Woolf, advertising director of the American Legion magazine, urging support by the entire advertising industry for a plan under which the government would compensate employes of advertising agencies who are forced out of work by the conversion of industry to war production.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York reports that savings bank customers are using savings instead of current income to buy defense bonds and stamps. Although the savings banks sold a record amount of defense obligations in December, their deposits went down by a somewhat larger amount.

The Polka Ball, ninth annual benefit dance and entertainment of the Kosciuszko Foundation, will be given tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the honorary patronage of the Polish Ambassador, Jan Ciechanowski, and Mme. Ciechanowska and the Polish Consul General here, Sylwin Strakacz, and Mme. Strakacz, all of whom will be official guests of honor at the ball.

Seven new tenants, including Major Alexander P. de Seversky, the airplane designer, have taken! quarters in the recently completed apartment house at 40 Central Park South, according to Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., agents. Others were Edward lrI. York Jr., Friedrick V. Seckel, Joseph Seidel* men, Alfred E. Shebel, Frank E. Bliss, and through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., rs. ladeleine M. Ryland.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 22 -- The prospective breaking of relations with the Axis powers by the remaining eight American republics might lead to the internment in the United States of all Axis diplomatic and consular officials from Latin America, it was said here today.

Attempts to raise revenues at this time by taxing educational properties would be shortsighted, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham Universiyt, said at a luncheon of the Bond Club in the Bankers Club yesterday.

The Whitney Museum's most important exhibition of the Winter season, "A History of American Water Color Painting," will be opened to the public on Tuesday. This survey, the first to be attempted on so extensive a scale, will begin with the early nineteenth century.

Unanimous support of Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, in his controversy with John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers and former C.I.O. president, over the latter's recent proposal for a unified labor movement, was voted yesterday by the executive board of the United Automobile Workers at a meeting at the Hotel Roosevelt after Mr. Murray had appeared before the board and stated the issue.

A penny up or a penny down are the only changes in retail meat prices to be reported by the Consumers Division of the Department of Markets this week-end -- but in most cases, fortunately, it is a penny down. The only exception to prove this rule of one-cent fluctuations is the price of loins of pork, which have lost 2 cents since last Friday and may now be had for a quarter a pound.

One of the most improved players in the metropolitan area this year is Dick Holub of Long Island University. It hardly would be proper to say that he has been overlooked because it is extremely difficult to miss any one standing 6 feet 5 inches tall.

After more than six years George Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess" is back on the stage. It was put on at the Majestic last evening. Since the memorable opening in 1935 Gershwin has died, leaving music that has been steadily in use and accumulating prestige; and DuBose Heyward, who wrote the libretto, died a year and a half ago.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22 (From Soviet broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A dispatch from the central front told today of twenty-eight Red Army soldiers, crying "Moscow is behind us -- there is no retreat," battling against fifty German tanks before losing their lives.

BERNE, Switzerland, Friday, Jan. 23 -- Seventeen miles west of Mozhaisk on the Vyazma road, Soviet forces in yesterday's operations encountered -- and crushed -- the first determined resistance they had met since the fall of Mozhaisk, according to Moscow's military spokesman this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Plans for promoting the employment of women in war industries and related fields of activity and for the development of a post-war program in which the abilities and experience of women may be effectively used were reported today by Miss Mary Anderson, chief of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

In some of the popular restaurants the freedom of the sugar bowl has vanished. When a patron orders coffee they ask him if he wants sugar and bring him two pieces if he says yes. No doubt they will give him a third piece if he feels he must have it.
The Save the Children Federation, Inc., announced yesterday that because of the war it would answer requests for aid to child war victims anywhere.

The controversy resulting from Mayor La Guardia's opposition to granting mass applications for retirement from the police force was taken to Supreme Court yesterday in two test suits to compel the board of trustees of the Police Pension Fund to grant pensions to patrolmen who have served twenty years or more but have not served the twenty-five-year period set by the Mayor as a condition for retirement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Following a conference with Leon Keyserling, Director of the United States Housing Administration, here today the entire Newark, N.J., Housing Authority resigned. In a statement issued after the conference, the Authority said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A plan to divert to the WPA rolls persons whose loss of jobs is directly attributed to the defense program and who do not come under the training program proposed by President Roosevelt, or whose unemployment compensation would not be adequate to support them, was announced today by Howard O. Hunter, WPA Commissioner.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Jan. 22 -- United 'States Ambassador Norman Armour had a long conversation this afternoon with Acting Foreign Minister Guillermo Rothe and Under-Secretary Roberto Gache. Both Argentine officials then motored to the Summer residence of Acting President Ramon S. Castillo and remained in conference with him for about half an hour.

The Japanese have interned in Wuhu, China, Bishop Ralph A. Ward, head of the Methodist Church in Shanghai, and a group of other American Methodist missionaries in China, according to a cablegram received yesterday from Dr. Chester B. Rappe, missionary and superintendent of the Chungking district of the Methodist Church, by the Methodist Board of Missions and Church Extension, 150 Fifth Avenue.

Bank clearings of the twenty-three principal cities of the nation in the week ended on Wednesday rose almost 10 per cent above the volume for the preceding week and 22.7 per cent above the comparable 1941 week, Dunn Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

An explanation for the method used by the now defunct OPM in setting up its wool allocation program was offered yesterday by Fessenden S. Blanchard, textile consultant to that group and who now has the same post in the production division of the War Production Board.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- News of the satisfactory agreement reached by the South American republics gave a more cheerful all-round tone today to the stock markets. Notwithstanding the bright features in other sections, gilt-edge issues closed with fractional losses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Despite war difficulties, the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs will continue to bring some groups of Latin American students to this country for specialized training.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- The special session of the Legislature, which Governor Olson summoned last month to act on a requested appropriation of $17,500,000 for a State Guard, ended a long deadlock tonight and adjourned after voting slightly under $8,000,000 for the purpose.

The Giants were informed yesterday that the local draft board in Sunnyside, Queens, had ruled that the 1-A classification of Babe Young, first baseman, would have to remain final. No date has been set for Young's induction into military service, but it is believed to be not far distant.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The war, which is changing many things, is to take some of the tin from the penny, as well as nickel from the nickel.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 21 (Delayed) -- The Japanese have opened up a new east coast sector in their offensive against Singapore by the occupation of Endau in the extreme northeast corner of Johore. The British outposts have withdrawn from Endau in the face of superior enemy forces.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Little Kiss, J.C. Ellis's fast mare, showed a clean pair of heels to a good band of sprinters today in the Galvez Purse, six-furlong dash that topped the Fair Grounds program.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The Bruins muffed a chance to recapture undisputed lead of the National Hockey League tonight when they bowed to the Red Wings, 4 to 3; but of even greater consequence was Boston's loss of its ace playmaker, Bill Cowley, with a possible fractured jaw.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 22 -- The German Ambassador to Turkey, Franz von Papen, left Ankara tonight for Istanbul, where, according to diplomatic sources and Axis press circles, the envoy will board a German plane for Vienna and Berlin.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Three wide changes in the educational system and organization of the University of Chicago were announced tonight by President Robert M. Hutchins. One of them, the awarding of the bachelor's degree after two instead of four years, was regarded by educators as most as startling as the "Chicago plan" put into operation by the university twelve years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The military convention signed in Berlin Jan. 18 by Germany, Japan and Italy naturally flows from the formal treaty of alliance put in force on the day Adolf Hitler declared war on the United States Dec. 11.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The British Headquarters communique today follows:
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22 -- A survey of American public reaction to the tire rationing program reveals one striking fact.

Two sharply contrasted Viennese works, the compact, spontaneous Fifth symphony of Schubert and the gigantic, complex Second symphony of Mahler, formed the program given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Bruno Walter, last night in Carnegie Hall.
Two large Bronx apartment properties were disposed of by the trustees of a mortgage certificate issue in transactions reported yesterday.

As Japanese bombing raids intensified the assault upon the Malay barrier yesterday and the enemy's new attack upon New Britain and New Guinea constituted a direct threat to our supply lines to Australia, the victories on the Home Front eased some of the shocks of the early defeats in the Far East.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Sir Archibald Sinclair warned the Commons today that "the efficiency of our fighter defense should not hide from our minds the reality that although the German bomber force in the West has been greatly reduced during the last few months, there are at this moment, and have been for weeks past, large numbers of German bombers within striking distance of this country."
BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 22 -- Germany's attitude toward the Catholic Church continues to preoccupy Vatican circles, according to information reaching here from Rome.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- In a move to protect sources of water supply, airports, docks, factories and other important places against possible sabotage, a bill was introduced in the Legislature today under Republican sponsorship which would permit the State Defense Council, on authorization of the Attorney General, to post these properties.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 22 -- From Berlin comes a commentary on the controversy that has been waged in France since Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's New Year message, in which he spoke of his "semi-freedom" and the "abject tasks" undertaken by "deserters" in France and elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Roosevelt was reported tonight to have submitted to leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations a plan for labor peace, without organizational unity, which would continue for the duration of the war.

" Das Rheingold," prologue to the "Ring," introduced the matinee Wagner cycle yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House. The writer is not of those who rate this opera as less than the other Works of the trilogy. It has special colors and a special imaginative appeal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An estimated $15,000,000 worth of war materials destined for Far Eastern areas now occupied by Japan, some of which was actually on its way across the Pacific, has been saved for the war effort of the United States through prompt action by the Foreign Fund Control, the Treasury announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An increase of three-tenths of a cent a gallon on all grades of gasoline sold in fifteen Eastern and Southern States was approved today by the Office of Price Administration.

Gold holdings as stated in the subjoined table represent the item "gold certificates on hand and due from United States Treasury." Title to actual gold in possession of the Federal Reserve was transferred to the United States Government by the law of Jan. 30, 1934.

The Treasury issued yesterday a call for depositary banks to turn over to it on Monday 50 per cent of the deposits resulting from the sale of tax-anticipation notes up to Jan. 10. It is estimated that the banks will turn over $45,980,000. Treasury disbursements are proceeding at a rapid clip these days, and special deposit accounts do not remain long untouched.

The two eight-family flats on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 296-298 Barrow Street, Jersey City, have been sold by the /VIaca Corporation of Hoboken, Max B. Cane, president. The purchaser, Siegfried Schwartz of Otisville, N. Y., paid $4,500 above a first mortgage of.$17,500 held by the Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey.

Lewis W. Douglas, president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, announced yesterday the establishment of a voluntary payroll deduction plan for employes and field representatives of the company for the purchase of defense savings bonds.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 22 -- Reports of an interview granted to a Baltimore Sun reporter two weeks ago by John Van Antwerp MacMurray, former United States Ambassador to Turkey, on alleged Soviet ambitions toward the Dardanelles have been ballooned into a major sensation by Russian newspapers and in the German press and have received prominent display in Turkish newspapers.

LISBON, Portugal, Jan. 22 (AP) -- Portuguese troops have sailed from Mozambique, Portuguese East Africa, for the Indies island of Timor, after Portuguese conversations with Britain, "to take charge of the defense of the part of the island that belongs to Portugal," an official announcement said tonight.
Three language professors at City College, who have reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 are retiring today.

The marriage of Gloria M. Vanderbilt, daughter of the late Reginald C. Vanderbilt, on Dec. 28 to Pasquale (Pat) di Cicco, Hollywood actors' agent, is listed under her maiden name in the January issue of Dilatory Domiciles of the New York Social Register for 1942.

Nugent Fallon, president of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that a number of factors had combined "to produce a decidedly favorable 1941 business volume" for the bank.

The United States Pipe and Foundry Company reported yesterday in a preliminary statement for the year ended on Dec. 31, net profit of $2,614,586 after all charges including depreciation, amortization and $2,795,000 provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- A Domei war round-up today asserted that the Japanese had developed a new drive down the center of Johore State toward Bekok on the main north-south rail line eighty miles north of Singapore and midway between the east and west coasts.

I want to express my deep gratitude for the editorial about the late Solomon Lowenstein. It was my good fortune to be intimately associated with him for over a third of a century in all types of social and philanthropic activities -- sectarian and non-sectarian, in this country and abroad.

With the exception of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, the railroads that serve New York plan to raise their commutation rates 10 per cent by March 1 or sooner. This will be in conformity with a decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission permitting a 10 per cent increase in all passenger fares.

YUMA, Ariz., Jan. 22 (AP) -- The words "in here," scrawled on the top of a sealed packing box, led Sheriff T. H. Newman today to the body of Gavin Grey, 40-year-old recluse whose detective stories thrilled many pulp magazine readers.

Problems created by the war and its effect on the civilian economy drew statements yesterday from representatives of three media -- the magazine, radio and outdoor fields. Two were explanatory, while the third was a denial.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- On the eve of Governor Lehman's "budget school" tomorrow, when the State budget and tax program will be disclosed for the information of newspaper men, it became known today that the Governor would recommend to the Legislature a percentage reduction in the income tax, to be computed as an "emergency deduction" after the normal tax is figured.
Sales of small residential properties in scattered sections of Queens and in Nassau County featured the .Long Island activity yesterday.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 22 (UP) -- Thousands of Japanese troops drowned before the eyes of Commander H.C.J. van Well Groeneveld as he peered through the periscope of his Netherlands submarine, watching his torpedoes drive home into an enemy convoy off Borneo, he reported today.

' Hats off to Sally Victor" was the consensus of fashion experts who gathered to see that designer's showing of "wartime" Spring hats yesterday afternoon. The approval was so generally expressed because Sally had designed a variety of millinery finery that women will want to "smack" right onto their heads.

The rhythmic jingle of coins early yesterday attracted Patrolman Anthony Capolongo to a vacant lot on Fourth Street near First Avenue, where he saw a man spreading $48 in pennies, nickels, dimes and quarters on a white cardboard.

Persistent and widespread buying from mill sources lifted the cotton market sharply yesterday and into the highest ground since October, 1929. On the New York Cotton Exchange, final prices of active futures were near their best levels of the day, showing net gains of 35 to 37 points, or $1.75 to $1.85 a bale, over Wednesday's close.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Behind the resolution introduced Tuesday at the Rio de Janeiro conference of American foreign ministers in favor of calling a currency stabilization conference lies a United States Treasury plan for a hemisphere export currency, the use of which might be extended to the rest of the world, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission gained a new commissioner today in Robert H. O'Brien, former director of its Public Utilities Division, and is to retain an old one in the person of Robert E. Healy, who, at President Roosevelt's request, has withdrawn his resignation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A new system for setting sizes for retail women's wear has been worked out by experts of the Department of Agriculture. If the results of this scientific study of women's weights and measurements are put to use quickly by the clothing industry of the United States women's buying of wartime clothing should be simpler and more economical, it was stated.

A year ago Chairman Pinky Sober turned crystal gazer before the Metropolitan A.A.U. track and field championships and predicted nine records. Seven were broken and two tied. This season he again has made a guess that nine marks will be touched for the renewal of the annual title show at the Bronx Coliseum tomorrow.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 22 -- Jacques Stern, former Secretary of State for the French Colonies, and Mrs. Stern entertained with a dinner tonight at the Beach Club for Prince and Princess Alexis Zalstem-Zalessky, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Waterbury, Mrs. Margaret Emerson, Mrs. Edgar A. Bryan, Miss Mary Munn, Charles Munn, Baron Lejeune and Milton W. Holden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An agreement on the Price Control Bill representing a substantial victory for the Administration was reached by Senate and House conferees today after more than a week of discussion.

Through a spokesman in Washington the American Federation of Labor took issue yesterday with Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, on his contention that peace negotiations between the A.F. of L. and C.I.O. at this time would prove abortive in that they merely would serve to accentuate existing differences and create new controversies.

Austin J. Tobin, secretary of the Conference on State Defense, denounced yesterday the attempt of the Federal Government to levy a tax upon the income from State and municipal bonds as threatening the existence of the States as independent units of government.

Ninety-five per cent of the citizens of Argentina are opposed to the government of Acting President Ramo S. Castillo because that administration has not practiced democracy, Eduardo Araujo, member of the Argentina Chamber of Commerce, charged last night at a dinner by the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League at the Commodore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The House passed its first regular appropriation bill of the session today, providing $2,096,048,875 for forty-three independent agencies and including the Executive Office.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Jan. 22 (AP) The board of trustees of Purdue University voted today to relieve A.H. (Mal) Elward of his duties as athletic director but retained him as head football coach until Dec. 31, 1942.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- Isaac Brown, New York insurance broker, was sentenced here today by County Judge Frank H. Coyne to serve ten to twenty years in Sing Sing Prison for his attempt to murder Miss Mathilde le Boyer, now 18 years old, in a Mount Vernon school yard on the night of Dec. 19, 1940.

Glore, Forgan Co. and associates were the successful bidders yesterday for an issue of $589,000 of Schenectady, N.Y., public works and refunding bonds, receiving the award on their bid of 100.277 for 1 1/4s. The bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1942, and maturing on Feb. 1, 1943 to 1955, were reoffered at prices to yield 0.40 to 1.20 per cent, according to maturity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate the nomination of Robert H. O'Brien to be a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission and to the House a request for an appropriation of $100,000,000 for civilian defense equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The Army has swung 600,000 men into the Western defenses of the United States, including the Pacific Coast, Hawaii and Alaska, together with large numbers of combat airplanes and anti-aircraft weapons, it was learned authoritatively here today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 22 -- The Brazilian Government began early this morning to clamp down on the activities of fascist groups without awaiting the result of resolutions still under discussion at the Inter-American Conference for the curtailment of Axis activities in the Americas.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 22 -- Striking out in an apparent effort to disrupt British plans and to hold advancing British forces at bay until help arrives, General Erwin Rommel, the German commander in Libya, sent three columns of tanks, mobile artillery and truck-borne troops eastward from the El Agheila area yesterday, forcing British light units that had been harassing the German rear guard to fall back.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- An official disclosure that sugar-rationing cards will be issued in about three weeks to combat the nation's first serious food shortage since the war began was made here tonight.
SINGAPORE, Jan. 23 (AP) -- British headquarters issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Automobile manufacturers were authorized to manufacture 34 per cent more medium and heavy trucks in March than they did in the corresponding month a year ago, under terms of an order through which the War Production Board hopes to create a stockpile of trucks for essential civilian uses.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Trade circles here today watched cotton quotations soar to 20 and 19 cent levels on the New York and New Orleans Cotton Exchanges and estimated that at these prices the 1941 crop of 10,976,000 bales was worth approximately $1,100, 000,000, exclusive of seed, itself worth millions.

Ship sinkings and rumors of ship sinkings, it was apparent yesterday in the hiring halls of the National Maritime Union at 346 West Sevententh Street, do not keep American seamen off our merchant vessels. Instead, current shipping activity has brought thousands of men off the South and West Street beaches and from remote farms and inland cities to which they had returned when shipping fell off the past few years.

The Erie Railroad declared yesterday the first dividend it will have paid since 1931 by approving the disbursement of the full $5 dividend on its new preferred stock in quarterly installments on March 1, June 1, Sept. 1 and Dec. 1. A payment of $45 on each $1,000 of new income bonds on April 1 also was approved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on Jan. 17 were 246,267, 000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented an increase of 1,903,000 barrels in the week, comprising rises of 1,610,000 and 293,000 barrels in domestic and foreign stocks, respectively.
Fear that prices of furs might advance still further led to a wild scramble for merchandise this week, according to the market bulletin issued yesterday by United Fur Brokers.

Astrid Varnay was the new Elisabeth in last night's performance of Wagner's "Tannhaeuser" at the Metropolitan. This was the fourth role assumed by the 23-year-old artist in as many appearances, and each of the parts has been a leading one.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Royal Air Force bombers carried out a concentrated attack on Muenster, Germany, last night, the Air Ministry announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A government order prohibiting the use of new rubber in the manufacture of girdles, brassieres and other foundation garments raised the question today as to whether they could be manufactured hereafter.

A carryover of the heavy buying by trade and mill interests raised prices on the cotton market yesterday as much as 46 points, or $2.30 a bale, in the early trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. The sharp advance, however, attracted heavy realizing and prices of active futures eased slightly to finish with net gains of 26 to 32 points, or $1.30 to $1.60 a bale, over Thursday's close.

A group of American women airplane pilots under the leadership of Jacqueline Cochran, winner of many air races and holder of the women's transcontinental speed record, will leave for England "in the near future" to ferry warplanes from English factories to airfields in the British Isles, it was announced here yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 23 -- While agents of United States rubber companies are scouring Mexico to buy up every ounce of raw rubber available, experts here said today that Mexico's production could easily be raised to nine or ten thousand tons a year by reviving what was once a booming industry.

Miss Elsie G. Robinson gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq Rouge for Mrs. James G. Harbord, Mrs. Robert Rubin, Mrs. William F. Irwin and Mrs. Edward J. Waring. Other guests were Mrs. Egbert H. Lillie. Mrs. Andrew Shiland, Mrs. Dean Clark, Mrs. Roynon Cholmeley-Jones, Mrs. A. Heyward McAlpin, Mrs. Alexander Walker, Mrs. Alexander Russell, Mrs. Harris Brownlee and Mrs. Robert Forgan.

Sending a little girl out to do a big girl's job is a pitfall into which the national Girl Scout organization is determined not to fall in adapting the Scout program to the war, Mrs. Alan H. Means, national president, said yesterday.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Four boys in a 1932 roadster were killed on North Avenue here at 3:30 A.M. today when their automobile sidewiped twice a friend's sedan being driven in the same direction, mounted a curb, caromed off a tree and was wrecked against another tree.

The nation-wide efforts to collect waste paper are steadily increasing the available supply, particularly in the small and medium-size cities, dealers reported yesterday, but in metropolitan centers such as New York improvement is less noticeable.

WILLY LEY is a wonder. Just yesterday he was writing a handbook for bemused civilians called "Bombs and Bombing." Now he turns up with "The Days of Creation,"* which he modestly describes as a "biography of our planet." The "biography" is mainly devoted to telling us how little we know about our origins, our present circumstances and our destiny.

Traditional festive customs of the Old World, particularly those centering around the heritage of Polish culture, were revivified last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, where the Kosciuszko Foundation presented a gala Polk Ball as its ninth annual benefit dance in this city.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Long shots scored in one of the season's biggest pay-offs at the Fair Grounds today when Balaxy won the first race at odds of $189.20 for $2 and, combined with Pop's Rival in the second race, ran the daily double up to $559.40.

Harold W. McGraw, Federal Rationing Administrator for New York City, announced yesterday that the city's February quota for new tires had been fixed at 5,939 and the tube quota at 8,541. The quota on casings is more than one-third under January, but the tube quota is larger.

The American Federation of Musicians has refused to permit Carlos Chavez to conduct a nonunion organization like the Boston Symphony Orchestra, and his appearances slated for Feb. 27 and 28 as guest conductor of that orchestra in Boston have been canceled.

Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, duo-pianists, gave a recital last night in Town Hall which attracted, as usual, a large and appreciative gathering. There were no arrangements of transcriptions on the program, which was devoted entirely to original works for two pianos.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -Japanese pressure on a battle line spanning Malaya sixty to seventy-five miles above this island fortress has wiped out earlier British gains, a war communique said today, but the defense of Singapore still blazed with unabated ferocity and determination.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Red Armies raging forward on the north-central front are within 110 miles of the Latvian border in an enveloping drive that threatens the entire German position east of White Russia, the Soviet High Command announced officially tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The New York Stock Exchange urged Congress today to turn down a Securities and Exchange Commission request for authority to enforce rules of exchanges relating to the disciplining, suspension or expulsion of members.

The long arm of A. Hitler (which, directly or indirectly, is cropping up in so many unexpected places these days) has reached into the quiet, well-kept confines of the Flushing Cemetery, and has rapped with demanding knuckles on the granite posts of enclosures around the ancient plots, it became known yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 23 -- Japanese forces have landed in the Solomon Islands and invasion operations in other Australian outlying territory are impending or in progress, it was announced officially today as the government appealed to President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill for immediate and effective assistance.
After having read Donald Freeberg's letter in THE TIMES of Jan. 17, about City College sportsmanship, I wish to put in my proverbial two cents' worth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Roosevelt, in a press conference lasting barely three minutes, declined this morning to answer all direct questions, and vouch-safed only one piece of information -- that he expected a report soon from the Pearl Harbor special investigating board.

AN EAST CANADIAN PORT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Survivors of a British freighter torpedoed in the Western Atlantic were landed here tonight and reported that forty-two had been saved out of a crew of forty-five. They were adrift seven hours.

The declaration of war Dec. 8 caused no sudden flurry in the grocery stores of the nation. The average cost of the family market basket on Dec. 16 was, in fact, exactly the same as it was a month earlier.

A big sporting goods firm is canvassing its customers. It wants to buy things from them. There is a shortage in firearms and field glasses. Articles no longer in use with their present owners can be reconditioned and sold again.
Gordon Graves Co. have retired from membership in the New York Stock Exchange. J.E. Swan Co. will dissolve on Jan. 31 and Soucy Co. will dissolve on Feb. 9.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 (From broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- Addressing Parliament this afternoon, Premier General Hideki Tojo reiterated Japanese willingness to accept any Chungking overtures for peaceful reconciliation if that regime changed its attitude.

OTTAWA, Jan. 23 -- Protest against the government's proposal to hold a plebiscite to clear up the situation with regard to conscription for overseas service has run so high that today some persons think the government's position has been gravely compromised.

It is barely possible that wars are more interesting to read about after they are over than they are to live through. The Trojan War may have been a gruesome wrangle, but it was a point of departure for the Homeric epics. Our own Between the States War was a nightmare, but what a grand time the novelists and dramatists have had with it!

A crew of men started working yesterday to prepare the fifty-meter Bear Mountain ski jumping hill for tomorrow's New York State title event. The surrounding mountainsides were stripped of snow and the hill should be available for trial leaps today for competitors who want to test the in-run, take-off and landing slope.

Officials and leading members of the Greater New York Hospital Association agreed yesterday on a plan to raise a substantial contribution within their own organization for the Red Cross War Fund of Greater New York. They met at 233 Broadway, headquarters of the commerce and industry division of the war fund drive.

GRAND RAPIDS, Jan. 23 -- Despite the decline in demand for furniture toward the end of last year, 1941 as a whole was by far the best year in the history of the industry, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, reported today.

In an article published in your paper a few months ago, the sixty million American-born citizens without proof of birth were mentioned. My father was one of the sixty million and I can well sympathize with this group of men and women who have stayed in the background, quietly, patiently, building a nation only to find that officially the nation knows them not.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Announcement that the House and Senate conferees had reached an agreement in regard to price control legislation on agricultural products brought in a rush of buying in all grains and soy beans in the early trading today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- In a statement edged with grim irony, a Navy spokesman disclosed tonight that an unspecified number of enemy submarines had been liquidated off the Atlantic coast but that details on these "excursionists'' were being kept secret to deal a blow to Nazi morale.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 23 -- While political parleys took place behind closed doors at the Conference of American Foreign Ministers in Itamaraty Palace today subcommittees dealing with economic matters approved all but two resolutions which are tied to the settlement of political issues.

As the costume jewelry industry proposes for a tussle with priorities, it looked yesterday as if a shortage of flour would be the only thing that could seriously disturb renew lines being considered as war-time merchandise.

Speaking of the territory that lies in the path of Japan's armies in the Far East, the Australian Minister to the the United States made this statement in an address in this city on Thursday evening: "Don't let us say we'll get it all back in 1943. It will be ten times as hard to get it back as it is to defend it now."

It is cheering to learn that Dr. Hubertus van Mook, Lieutenant Governor of the Netherlands Indies, now on a mission to this country, has received assurances from President Roosevelt that help for the beleaguered colonies is on the way. The Dutch, wise administrators and sturdy fighters, deserve our help and need it desperately.

Se+/-orita Teresa Rosa Durland, one of Cuba's few women diplomats, was guest of honor yesterday with Dr. Cayetano de Quesada, Cuban Consul General in New York, at the observance of Cuban Day at Macy's Latin-American Fair.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- Miserliness and short vision by Westchester County officials has delayed work on national defense projects in the county, the Westchester Federation of Women charged today in a 2,000-word county government report adopted at its twenty-first mid-Winter conference.

WASHINGTON, Jan 23 (U.P.) -- The Navy's policy of suppressing information about the sinking or capturing of enemy submarines was conceived and used effectively by Great Britain to shake the morale of the German people during the first World War, authorities said tonight.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 23 (AP) -- A Navy plane plunged into the Atlantic Ocean early today near Oregon Inlet, N.C., carrying its entire crew of eight men to death, the Fifth Naval District announced tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 23 -- From all parts of Continental Europe comes news of further restrictions of civilian populations. In Germany passenger traffic on railroads has been curtailed again. The use of white table linen in hotels and restaurants has been prohibited.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- After clearing the Germans out of the last point in fertile and economically productive Tula Province, the Russians have published a survey of the effect of the war there, which shows that whatever other changes the war has made it has not affected the Soviet passion for statistics.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- challenge to the critics of Whitehall was thrown out in Manchester today by Sir Archibald Sinclair, Secretary for Air, who demanded: "Who is it who says that the inferiority of our forces in the Far East is due to the complacency or incompetence of the government ?"

Military service, which already has called approximately three dozen major leaguers and 300 minor leaguers into uniform, seems sure to determine the pennant races this year and may decide the All-Star game, too, according to The Associated Press.

In churches tomorrow, in synagogues this morning and over the radio at various times, the fight against infantile paralysis will be the subject of sermons. Tomorrow will be the fourth annual "Infantile Paralysis Sunday." In some houses of worship direct appeals will be made and congregations will be informed of greeting cards and coin containers in which contributions may be placed.
The Harvard Club won the Class C championship of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association last night when it closed the season by defeating the City A.C., 4 to 1, on the latter's courts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Names of enemy aliens arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the disposition of their cases will not be revealed, Attorney General Biddle said today. The attitude of the Department of Justice is understood to be that the revelations might subject families of the aliens to injustice such as petty persecutions by their neighbors.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 23 (From Japanese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco, New York and London) -- The British defense system in Johore faces immediate collapse under pressure of Japanese Army units rapidly advancing toward Singapore from three sides, news dispatches from the front asserted today.
LONDON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique today said:

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 23 (U.P.) -- The Japanese airport outside Hanoi, the capital of French Indo-China, reportedly was left in ruins by a force of fifty-seven American and Chinese planes which bombed and machine-gunned the field and surrounding barracks yesterday noon.

Joseph E. Swan, pioneer American broker in the Far East and South America, on Feb. 1 is to join the firm of E.F. Hutton Co. George R. Kantzler, his partner, a member of the New York Stock Exchange board of governors, also is joining the Hutton firm, and the firm of J.E. Swan Co. will be dissolved.

The General Sessions court room in which Mrs. Margaret Boyle, a middle-aged Washington widow, is being tried on charges of defrauding a midtown jewelry broker, sparkled yesterday when three local pawnbrokers produced on the witness stand $103,000 worth of diamonds, sapphires, rubies and emeralds which the complainant, Jack Blauweiss, later identified as part of his loss.

A summary of the regulations issued by the Brazilian Government establishing an import licensing system for imports from the United States was published yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York. Contrary to earlier reports, the association stated, licenses are required only for United States goods subject to export control by the United States and not to all shipments.
Many dinners were given before the second and last subscription Coffee Dance of the season held last night at the Cosmopolitan Club. Miss Constance Curtis was chairman of the patroness committee.
Newbold Morris's tactless remarks anent civilian defense efforts must surely result in the resignation of many air raid wardens and a heightening of inefficiency in the local defense effort.

Students who are between the ages of 17 and 19, inclusive, now attending school or college, may enlist in the Naval Reserve for inactive duty until the close of the current semester, when they will be sworn into active service as apprentice seamen, it was announced here yesterday at the Navy Recruiting Bureau, 90 Church Street.

Argentina has joined the twenty other American republics to approve a compromise resolution of her own devising which "recommends" but does not require them to break relations with the Axis Powers. It cannot be said that Argentina's insistence on thus weakening hemisphere solidarity was due to her offense at the remarks of Senator Tom Connally of Texas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Joint Congressional-Executive Department Committee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures, which recommended last month the abolition of the Farm Security Administration, has been asked to investigate a program of that agency which contemplates making loans for the payment of current and accumulated poll taxes by prospective voters in Southern States.

Having replenished the supply of new bonds this week to the extent of more than $150,000,000, investment bankers expect a breathing spell next week in which to prepare for what promises to be a resumption of large-scale financing early next month.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 23 -- The football coaching career of Major Biff Jones, guided largely by the War Department for twenty-one years, was ended today by an Army order that brings him back to the United States Military Academy.

SINGAPORE, Jan. 23 -- Japanese troops threatened tonight to turn the British left flank at Batu Pahat, sixty miles northwest of Singapore, but elsewhere across the peninsula the outnumbered defenders were reported holding on doggedly against increasingly heavy blows.

New State and municipal bonds scheduled for sale next week by thirty-two municipalities and local housing authorities aggregate $30,309,780, compared with $116,960,391 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $39,64,688.

As consolation for the impending departure of Babe Young to the nation's armed forces, the Giants yesterday received word that Johnny Mize, long-range clouting first sacker obtained last month from the Cardinals, had completely recovered from the shoulder injury which put him out of action last September and that he would start training at Hot Springs on Feb. 1.

Mrs. Helen Peck, a widow living at 530 First Street, Brooklyn, received word from England yesterday that the body of her only son, Sergeant George James Peck, American flier with the Royal Air Force, had been recovered after he had been missing in a flight over the English Channel.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Seventeen, including Sweet Willow and The Chief, have been named for the seven-furlong Palm Beach Handicap, feature tomorrow at Hialeah Park, where the meetings winning stride was continued today.

The diamond jubilee of the birthday of President Roosevelt will be mentioned tomorrow in sermons and pastors will ask parishioners who have not already done so to aid the campaign against infantile paralysis. Tomorrow will mark the close of the annual world-wide Octave of Prayer in the Roman Catholic Church for Christian unity, and the topic of sermons by priests will be "The Missionary Conquest of the World for Christ."

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- One of the peacetime luxury trades that can be traced directly to World War I is that of hand-knitted "deluxe" clothes, providing one more instance to prove that wars inspire fashion. It is too early to see in which way this war will affect styles, but hand-knitting is one of the crafts in which the war will have made all women adepts.
BERLIN, Jan. 23 (From German broadcast recorder by The Associated Press) -- The German High Command issued this communique today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Opposition to President Roosevelt's request for $300,000,000 for benefits to workers dislocated by transition of plants from a peacetime to a wartime basis developed in the House today, chiefly for two reasons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Hopes of the Administration's Congressional leaders of sending the Price Control Bill to the President today were dashed when the House got into such a bitter partisan dispute over an appropriation bill that majority leaders said they dared not submit the price measure.

Prior to the attack on Pearl Harbor the House of Representatives passed a deplorable "price-control" bill. After the attack on Pearl Harbor the Senate passed a price-control bill that was in most respects a great deal worse. It was hardly to be expected, therefore, that a satisfactory compromise could emerge from conference even if the worst features peculiar to each bill had been dropped.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Representative Martin Dies said today that he did not think Joseph P. Lash should he inducted into military service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- James M. Landis, executive of the Office of Civilian Defense, told a press conference today that State and local defense councils, if they were composed "entirely of the blue stocking class," would not know what the needs of the communities were.

Leaving on his bureau a notice from his local draft board to report for pre-induction examination, John A. Stevenson Jr. of Springdale, Pa., plunged to his death yesterday from a room in the Hotel New Yorker.

In 1939 Sylvia Brockway Boardman, an American girl, married to an Englishman, visited this country with her husband and two children. With war her husband returned to their home in St. John's Woods, London. Soon the household's cook, an English cook, apparently embodying all the traditional and legendary qualities of solid English cooks, began to write "comforting" letters to her mistress in America.

Since the time of the bank holiday, when commercial banks found themselves in such popular disfavor, there has been a great improvement in the amount of information about earnings given by the major banks to their shareholders. Many of the large downtown banks now present full and informative reports, as the accounts of the annual meetings currently taking place show.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- Several organizations representing consumer interests protested before the State Milk Control Board today against the 1-cent-a-quart increase in the price of milk ordered for next Monday throughout New Jersey.

The council of seventeen of the Bombshell Group will hold a meeting tomorrow afternoon and on the afternoons of Feb. 1 and 8 for the purpose of accepting members to be included in the Bombshell exhibition to be held at the Riverside Museum from March 1 to 22.
The crews of two lost freighters, one American and one Latvian, told here yesterday in separate interviews of futile efforts to save their vessels as they went down off the Atlantic Coast.

It was with interest that I read the letter from Edwin Hilbert concerning soccer as a sport which should be considered in our program for bettering relations with our Central and South American neighbors.

DUBLIN, Jan. 23 -- Belief grows stronger in Dublin that Eire is getting closer to the war, though Prime Minister Eamon de Valera continues adamantly to assert that his government intends to maintain neutrality even if it means that his people will suffer slow but virtually complete economic strangulation.

Two men were drowned early this morning and a third miraculously escaped when an automobile in which they were riding plunged off a stringpiece at the foot of West Thirtieth Street into the North River.
Perhaps it was the impact of the pending start of daylight saving time upon Bill, the venerable wall clock above the magistrate's bench in Jefferson Market Court, that finally caused it to stop.

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 23 -- Heavy bombers and dive-bombing fighters of the Netherlands Indies Air Force caught a squadron of Japanese warships and a train of invasion transports in the Strait of Macassar, east of Borneo, today and left them crippled with twelve direct hits on eight ships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- New Japanese assaults have been launched with great force against the United States-Filipino forces holding Bataan Peninsula, on the Island of Luzon, in an apparent effort to reduce the defenders regardless of the cost in Japanese lives, the War Department announced today.

A 30,000-mile journey that began under cloak of darkness in Oslo on Feb. 1, 1941, when Gestapo agents were closing in on him, yesterday brought a 20-year-old Norwegian electrical-engineering student into the offices of the Inter-Allied Information Centre, 610 Fifth Avenue.

The first delivery of gasoline by the Plantation Pipe Line Company was completed yesterday, according to C. R. Younts, president. He said that 420,000 gallons of gasoline had been delivered to the Standard Oil Company of Kentucky at Meridian, Miss.

The annual "raucous caw-cus," known better as the crow-calling contest, will once more be numbered among the features of the annual Sportsmen's Show, scheduled to be held at Grand Central Palace from Feb. 21 to March 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Adverse playing conditions, probably the worst ever experienced for a major tournament in this area, caused postponement today of the second round of the seventy-two-hole $5,000 San Francisco open golf competition.

The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad is preparing to raise its commutation tariffs by 10 per cent in conformity with a decision issued Wednesday by the Interstate Commerce Commission, William White, president of the company, said yesterday.

Three new films will open in midtown theatres over the weekend. RKO's "Joan of Paris," starring the French actress, Michele Morgan, and Paul Henreid, will have its world premiere at the Rivoli today. Featured also in the melodrama, which was directed by Robert Stevenson, are Thomas Mitchell, Laird Cregar and May Robson.

The 1942 track season will get off to a belated but attractive start tonight when the Annual Metropolitan A. A. U. indoor track and field championships are staged at the Coliseum in the Bronx. The finest entry in years figures to make this affair an interesting beginning, particularly since the banked track at the Coliseum is fast.

ST LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 23 -- Associate Justice Frank Murphy of the United States Supreme Court declared tonight in a speech broadcast nationally from a dinner of the Lawyers Association of Missouri that "before the world and ourselves we must make good our word" in pledging independence for the Philippines.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 23 -- Germany urgently needs more troops for the Eastern Front -- that much was readily conceded in informed Berlin quarters before the writer left the Reich's capital last week. Not only were new recruits being called up at that time from all over the country but pressure was being applied on Hungary and every other "possible'' State to contribute more men.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Lord and Lady Halifax, who have been at Hobe Sound, were luncheon guests today of former Ambassador Joseph P. Kennedy and Mrs. Kennedy at their residence, leaving immediately afterward for Washington.
The police drive against pinball machines continued yesterday throughout the city, despite efforts to have the courts restrain authorities from seizing, destroying or interfering with the devices.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- A possibility of conflict over the maximum speed limit to be permitted on all roads in the State appeared today, as Chairman Rapp of the Assembly Motor Vehicle Committee introduced speed-control legislation at variance with that suggested by Governor Lehman.

Eugene L. Lubovitch chairman of the board of the Mercantile Metals Corporation, has leased furnished residential quarters in the apartment house at 300 Park Avenue through Wm. A. White Sons, broker, and Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., agent.

In a sluggish market which approximated in pattern the previous sessions of the week, the stock market made yesterday some minor gains. Only in the final hour was there any disposition on the part of buyers to become active but the quietness of the earlier hours kept the trading volume down to about that of Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A bill carrying $12,525,872,474, the greatest single military expenditure in history, for 33,000 planes, airplane plant expansion and ammunition and bombs was passed by the House today, 389 to 0.

BERNE, Switzerland, Saturday, Jan. 24 -- German resistance in the Valdai sector has been crushed and the Axis troops have been driven back sixty-five miles in one of the greatest defeats inflicted by either side since the Battle of Minsk, according to a series of special communiques issued by the Russian High Command late last night and early this morning.

WEST POINT, Jan. 23 -- Public relations directors from seventy-five Eastern colleges and universities, attending a regional conference of the American College Publicity Association, were urged today to combat the complacency of the American public in regard to the war effort.
Might I ask Mr. Freeberg, who rose to the defense of City College's sportsmanship in these columns last week, whether he has ever attended a basketball game at the City College gymnasium?

Now that "Care Crown" has turned up on the stage at the Cort, where it was acted last evening, the Care Royal on Second Avenue will probably begin to do a large tourist business. For H.S. Kraft, who was co-author of "Cue for Passion" last season, has written a hospitable comedy about the culture club of the Yiddish Theatre and the geniuses and kibitzers who lounge there and play cards in the back room.

The Alabama Power Company, a unit in the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation system, announced yesterday that it has called for redemption between March 1 and June 1 its entire mortgage debt of $95,572,000 bonds.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Smaller receipts of hogs and heavy government buying of pork products lifted prices of hogs 10 to 20 cents a hundredweight today and the best offerings brought $11.75. Losses of the last two days were erased. Hogs have brought the highest average price this week for any January in fifteen years.

Pierre Matisse opened this week in his gallery at 41 East Fifty-seventh Street a group show composed of "figure pieces," which, with two exceptions, are by European moderns. Paintings by the contemporary Mexican artists, Tamayo and Siqueiros, round out a display that is scheduled to remain current until Feb. 14.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 23 -- All twenty-one American republics formally voted at a plenary session of the defense committee of the Conference of American Foreign Ministers this evening for a recommendation for a rupture of diplomatic relations with the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Mayor La Guardia told the General Federation of Women's Clubs today, in what he called "perhaps my last appearance as director of the Office of Civilian Defense," that ultimate victory was coming to the United Nations, but warned that "we've never been in a more difficult situation than today."

The old Fairmount Athletic Club property on the northeast corner of 137th Street and Rider Avenue, in the Bronx, which for years was the scene of many of the city's most notable boxing contests, has just been sold by the Iniflor Realty Corporation to Webster Auto Parts, Inc.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan. 23 (Netherlands Indies News Agency) -- A thrilling, episode of the war at sea was told to the Netherlands Indies News Agency today by Quartermaster C. De Wolf, a Netherland submarine officer, who swam thirty-five miles in shark-infested waters to land after his vessel had been blown up by a mine.

In the placing of anti-aircraft guns in parks the convenience of the civilian population and preservation of park property should be considered, the Park Association of New York City, Inc., suggested yesterday in letters to Mayor La Guardia and Generals Irving J. Phillipson and Sanderford Jarman of the local Army Corps Area.

While retail activity here kept up at a good pace this week, the buying was not as hectic as in the previous week and the gain over last year was reduced. Estimates by retail executives yesterday were that volume rose about 25 per cent as against a gain of 41 per cent in the preceding week.

Quick-freezing and packaging of poultry lead to the establishment of recognized brands and make available to the poultry industry all the advantages of national advertising and merchandising which have built up other branches of the food industry, Donald Barr, marketing manager of Frosted Foods Sales Corporation, declared yesterday in an address before the annual Fact-Finding Congress of the Institute of Poultry Industries at Kansas City.

Members of the New York State Bar Association adopted resolutions yesterday recommending tax reforms to ease the burden of taxpayers under wartime conditions. The association proposed among other things that New York State personal income taxes be made payable in quarterly installments and be computed after allowing deductions for Federal income tax payments.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Earl Carpenter, detective chief, said that jewels, furs and clothing, insured for $39,592.50, were stolen early today from the Miami Bach home of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Richard of New York.

The recapture of lost ground by the Axis forces in Libya may mean much or little. Battle in the desert is like battle in the sea, flowing back and forth across a shifting waste, the troops as lightly anchored to their movable bases as a ship tethered to the ocean floor.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 23 -- Possessor of a proud record under fire in the first World War, General Manager Warren C. Giles of the Reds has advised his players he would rather close up shop than have "even one player of military age" shirk duty with the armed forces.

I have just finished reading your article "Lewis to Organize State Farmers Into Unit of United Mine Workers," in the issue of Jan. 18, and I'm wondering whether John L. Lewis is being sold a bill of goods by subordinates or whether the farmers are going to be talked into selling their birthright for the proverbial mess of pottage.

The Stock Clearing Corporation, wholly owned subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange, has qualified as an issuing agent for United States defense savings bonds, Series E, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Roosevelt was believed tonight to have succeeded in establishing the basis for a truce between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as John L. Lewis, continuing his campaign for organizational units of the two groups, challenged the authority of the C.I.O. president, Philip Murray, or his executive board to unseat him as chairman of a standing C.I.O. committee authorized to negotiate for peace.

Civilian defense training by television will be started here Monday evening, with more than 100 viewing posts to be set up ultimately for civilian volunteers, Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday. The Police Department already has staged a test "preview'' of television defense instruction and, regarding it as satisfactory, it has decided to expand the experiment.
MOSCOW, Jan. 23 (From Russian broadcast recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following today:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- War Department communique No. 71, based on report received here up to 9:30 A.M., follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Less than four hours after it received the request from its Appropriations Committee, the House voted unanimously today to pour another $12,525,872,474 into this nation's drive to seize aerial mastery over the foes of the United Nations wherever they may be found.

RANGOON, Burma, Saturday, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- British Imperials were making a new stand east of Moulmein, apparently about thirty miles from that city, after falling back from their mountain outposts near the Thai frontier, army headquarters announced today.

Because of the war, Day Tuttle has given up his plans of producing "Out of the Night," the dramatization by Dorothy Calhoun of Jan Valtin's book. Mr. Tuttle, however, is not remaining idle. He has joined forces with Harold Bromley for the presentation of William Roos's baseball comedy, "The Life of Reilly." Casting is announced to start in two weeks and Broadway may see the production around mid-March, according to Mr. Bromley.

With the announcement that local draft boards are reviewing the cases of all registrants over the age of 28 to determine if they should be reclassified, it became known yesterday that the case of Joseph P. Lash, protege of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and adviser to the Youth Division, Office of Civilian Defense, is to be reviewed again and will come before his local board in the next week or ten days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Great Britain has stopped trying to push her exports, even to British Empire countries, and as a corollary is relying increasingly on American lease-lend for her imports, the Commerce Department reports in connection with its series of studies of trade policies of foreign countries during 1941.

The investment market experienced this week the most active period in more than a year in respect to the volume of new bond financing. A total of $152,835,000 in new issues was offered for public subscription. This is the largest volume to appear in any one week since the period ended on Dec. 6, 1940, when $248,113,000 in new bonds were marketed.

The formation of a Women's Council of the Navy League to aid this civilian organization in promoting the interests of the Navy and helping its personnel through community activities was announced yesterday at an informal meeting held under the auspices of the New York committee.
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A British headquarters communique said today:

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A musician and two married sisters, one of them the mother of four children, were found dead today on Johnnycake Road, near Catonsville, slain by an assailant who wielded a gun and a knife.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan, 23 (AP) -- A Netherlands Indies High Command communmique today said:
CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A British headquarters communique said today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- An additional $60,000 was voted by the Senate today to its special committee investigating the national defense program. Although $100,000 had been requested, Senator Truman of Missouri, chairman of the committee, expressed the view that it could continue its work throughout this year with the sum allowed.

The Aetna-Standard Engineering Company of Youngstown, Ohio, reported yesterday in a statement for the six months ended on Dec. 31 net earnings of $304,667 after provision for taxes, depreciation and reserves. The sum compares with $367,196 earned in the fiscal year ended on June 30, 1941.

The four-story apartment house at 61-3 Corbin Avenue, Jersey City, containing fifty-nine rooms, divided into twenty-six suites, has been sold by the Public Realty Company to Fannie Schneiderman in a deal arranged by Ben Schlossberg, Inc., broker.

Contributing to the war by using part of their scholarship money to buy defense stamps and bonds was the first thought of two youngsters who received $150 each yesterday as the "most deserving and outstanding students" in the city's school system.

Baseball fans with a sense of fitness should join in a campaign to have the Yankee Stadium renamed "Ruppert Stadium" as a permanent monument to the man whose efforts made the Yankees synonomous with baseball excellence.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 (AP) -- A musician and two married sisters, one of them the mother of four children, were found dead today on Johnnycake Road, near Catonsville, slain by an assailant who wielded a gun and a knife.
BATAVIA, Netherlands Indies, Jan, 23 (AP) -- A Netherlands Indies High Command communmique today said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Food canners have been promised ample supplies of cans for the packing of corn, tomatoes, beans and peas but have been warned that tinplate would be made available for other perishable fruits and vegetables on a restricted basis, it was revealed after a three-day conference between government officials and canners this week.

The nine-story loft building at 102-4 West Thirty-eighth Street and the abutting four-story store and loft building at 1011 Sixth Avenue have been sold by the Bank for Savings to David Realties, Inc., through Edgar P. Goodwin and Robert F. Thorley, brokers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Already working at top speed on orders for military equipment, which are expected to total $1,200,000,000 this year, the radio industry may be asked to aid Pan-American solidarity by making 750,000 low-cost receiving sets for Latin-American listeners.

Benjamin Franklin High, defending city P.S.A.L. ruler, broke a first-place tie with idle Commerce and gained undivided possession of the lead in the Manhattan P.S.A.L. basketball race by beating Stuyvesant, 44 to 27, on the former's floor yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 23 -- Ruth Warrick and Edmund O'Brien will play the romantic leads in RKO's "Angel Face," with Joan Carroll, child star, who was last seen in "Obliging Young Lady," the studio announced today. Mary McCarthy is writing the scenario from a magazine story, a small-town domestic comedy, by Jean C. Beckett, which RKO bought last October for a reported $10,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Under the compromise price control bill the government could prohibit any further price rises in four major farm products, while other agricultural products could rise well above current levels before a ceiling could be imposed.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- The State Banking Department today authorized Empire Branch 36 National Letter Carriers Credit Union to change the location of its place of business from the Capitol Hotel, 840 Eighth Avenue, to 276 West Forty-third Street, New York.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 23 -- What many observers had believed to be a reconnaissance in force on the part of the German army in Libya turned out yesterday to be a full-fledged counter-attack, apparently aimed at pushing British forces out of the region of El Agheila and Agedabia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A warning that the War Production Board would use its requisitioning powers if necessary to acquire the junked cars stored in the yards of dealers was issued tonight by Lessing J. Rosenwald, chief of the board's Bureau of Industrial Conservation.

The Grace liner Santa Paula docked yesterday afternoon at Pier 37, Pioneer Street, Brooklyn, with sixty-eight passengers after a hazardous voyage through the South Atlantic from the West African coast. The stories of the passengers were approved for publication by the Navy Department.

The twenty-third annual appeal of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York will be held the week of April 12 by designation of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, according to an announcement yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, executive director of the organization.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The news of expanded activity by the Japanese caused the markets to turn dull today. Jobbers lowered their prices in nearly all sections, but there was little selling, with the result that small rallies developed here and there later.

The illegal radio transmitter "Gustav Siegfried I," which broadcasts in German and at least gives the impression of being run by malcontent German Army circles, asserted yesterday that the spotted typhus epidemic in Germany had advanced as far as Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Total round-lot volume on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on Jan. 10 was 3,919,330 shares, compared with 9,280,400 in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

LONDON, Saturday, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- The Polish and Czechoslovak governments-in-exile announced today that they had signed an agreement looking to cooperation, common policy and joint action to be implemented after the war.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23 -- John Van Antwerp MacMurray, former Ambassador to Turkey, charged Nazi propagandists today with attempts to create dissension among the nations united against the Axis powers by "unscrupulous perversion" of an interview he gave to The Sun shortly after his return from his post at Ankara.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- In a coop that once housed 200 chickens on the estate of Adolph Zukor, the movie producer, the North Clarkstown Defense Committee has established its headquarters that houses its emergency equipment and an array of defense posters that may appear shortly all over the country.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Prices of livestock here were steady today at the week's irregular decline which affected most classes except hogs. There was hardly enough activity at the yards to test prices. New York University probably will give up football as a varsity intercollegiate sport next Fall, sources close to the university divulged last night. NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- The twisted wreckage of a 1932 roadster, in which four young men met death in a crash following a tavern party early yesterday, was placed today on the grounds of New Rochelle Senior High School near the scene of the tragedy as a warning to students and to the public in general.

THE Red Cross performs an invaluable service as postal agent between belligerent countries by forwarding mail to prisoners of war. International headquarters is Geneva, Switzerland. ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 24 -- Ken Bartholomew of Minneapolis got away to a perfect start in defense of his senior men's North American speed skating championship at Lake Como today by sweeping his first three races. BOSTON, Jan. 24 -- Although the owners of industrial properties in New England have been doing "a lot of wishful thinking, envisioning the legendary pot of gold at the end of the rainbow of industrial expansion," the fact remains that current demand throughout this section is limited almost entirely to storage facilities, according to Ray M.
