To meet the new challenges confronting social work because of the exigencies of war and emergency planning, the fundamental concepts are being elaborated in the evening program of the Fordham University School of Social Service.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24 -- The result of the Rio de Janeiro conference of American Foreign Ministers, with nearly all American governments that have not declared war adopting the course that Mexico took within twenty-four hours of the Japanese aggression, is regarded here as conferring upon Mexico some of the leadership among Latin-American nations that Argentina has long coveted.

The celebration tomorrow of the fifteenth anniversary of the organization of the Board of Higher Education marks a milestone in the expansion of public education which has gone "practically unnoticed'' by the people of New York, it was asserted yesterday by Dr. Guy E. Snavely, executive director of the American Association of Colleges.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 24 -- The American republics today began preparations for breaking off diplomatic relations with the Axis as the conference of American Foreign Ministers completed plans for a plenary session Monday when signatures will be affixed to the agreements for an organized front.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Some members of the House Ways and Means Committee and representatives of the War Production Board, the Federal Security Agency and State Unemployment Compensation Directors explored today the question of aiding workers dislocated by the war effort, but reached no conclusion except as to the conviction that the $300,000,000 asked by President Roosevelt for the purpose was "only a starter."

THE first Buick-built aircraft engines, 1,200-h. p. Pratt Whitneys, roared in test stands last week as the Genera Motors Buick division at Flint, Mich., accelerated production for the Army Air Corps. This launching of mass production marked completion in record time of a program which involved the conversion of two large automobile factories and building of new facilities.
THE tenth annual championship tournament of the Long Island Bridge League will begin this afternoon and last through next Sunday. It will be held at the Plaza Hotel in Brooklyn.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- Civilian defense in the Detroit metropolitan area is fairly well organized on paper, but so far it has gone very little beyond that stage. For several weeks the city has been in the throes of an organizational campaign, but if an emergency were to develop suddenly at this time Detroit would have to rely almost entirely on its police, fire and other municipal services.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 24 -- An "army" is being formed here for the defense of the community in extraordinary emergencies, such as a land or air invasion.

FROM London comes a report that Great Britain's postal officials and the Universal Postal Union may decide to recognize the validity of stamps which have been in use on Lundy, a Bristol Channel island on the northern coast of England's Devonshire.

The largest mobile field weapon possessed by the United States Army, a 240-mm. howitzer, said also to be the largest in the world, arrived at the Knightsbridge Armory in the Bronx at 11:45 A.M. yesterday, escorted by police and a convoy of soldiers armed with Garand rifles.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- Two Britons described as Field Security police had a busy time recently when they spent several hours wandering around a London suburb dressed in authentic German uniforms -- one in a soldier's and one in that of an airman.

JOURNEY'S END: Last Autumn a smiling little man from Burma traveled to London, where he talked with high officials about dominion status for his country. He was U Maung Saw -- the "U" stands for "Mr." -- and he was Burma's Premier.

A patriotic and war effort motif will be applied to the stage setting for the fortieth annual ball of the Fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, which will take place on Feb. 4 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Funds obtained from the event will provide additional facilities in the club, 122 East Eighty-third Street, for local war service organizations.

THIS tale by C.S. Forester was published in England in 1926, and now appears in book form on this side for the first time. Dramatic and motion picture versions, however, have been shown on both sides of the Atlantic, with Charles Laughton and Elsa Lanchester in the leading roles.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The longstanding differences between Russia and Japan will never be dissolved except by force, said Sir Stafford Cripps today. Holding his first interview since returning from Moscow where he was British Ambassador since before the war, Sir Stafford repeated that he was "convinced" Japan and Russia must come to blows to settle their feud.

A public administration program for the benefit of Juniors and seniors interested in governmental work has been instituted by the department of political science at Hunter College, it was announced yesterday by Assistant Professor Ruth G. Weintraub.

"THE Complete Poems of Emily Jane Bronte," edited by C.W. Hatfield, is a volume that deserves more attention than can be given it in a review of this length, for it is an outstanding example of painstaking research and editing.

NORMAN, Okla., Jan. 24 -- Far-reaching plans for the University of Oklahoma to become the State's center in virtually every phase of wartime activity has been launched, according to a report by Herbert H. Scott, director of the university war council.

ALTHOUGH there has been a marked advance in the costs of hotel operation, the Greater Miami Hotel Association announces that hotel rates will remain as they have been for the past three years. There will be no boost in prices at the seventy-five hotels which are members of the association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The mobilization of women factory work in 1943 and the creation of labor shock troops of skilled mechanics to move around the country easing industrial bottlenecks were predicted today by Secretary Perkins in a speech before the National Defense Forum of the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

Providence College, one of the few unbeaten court teams around, added to its fine record last night by routing Manhattan, 59 -- 39, in a contest in which good and bad basketball was in evidence. The score is a reasonable indication of which team contributed the good basketball.

VICHY, Dec. 7 -- Official French tennis ratings just published for 1942 put Bernard Destremau at the head of the men's list and divide the women's leadership between Madame S. Lafargue-Iribarne and Mlle. A. Weivers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- America's wartime production was being stepped up this week under the driving force of a new all-powerful production chief who is confident he can bring the nation's economy to "the highest levels it has ever achieved."

An invitation to be bridesmaid at the wedding of her class-mate, Lavinia Dumont, brings Peter Piper to the Cajun country near New Orleans. Her real name is Katherine, but she is called Peter because her last name happens to be Piper.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Concerned over a possible yarn shortage, the Associated Knitters for the United States Army and Navy is experimenting with a design for a cloth and wool garment which will be offered for official approval to replace regulation service sweaters.

Convinced that there are still many obstacles to an outright reunion in the ranks of organized labor, President Roosevelt stepped in last week with a plan intended to provide assurance that even if the two major labor groups did not get together they would not fight at the expense of the war effort.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas -- "Muy sympatico," they say in the Mexican language, and these words describe the people and their attitude here when they reach back into their carefully guarded clothes boxes and draw out their gorgeous costumes for Charro Days, one of America's most unusual fiestas. "Muy sympatico" means something akin to hospitality, courtesy and friendliness.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 24 -- Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld of Essex County disclosed here today that seven additional complaints of obtaining, money by false pretenses would be made Monday against Mrs. Amelia M. Carr, 66-year-old ex-convict and confidence woman, who is awaiting sentence on her recent plea of no defense to a charge of having defrauded a fellow-church member of $4,700.

WEST POINT, Jan. 24 -- Cited for "outstanding" service" in the field of college publicity, Louis C. Boochever, Director of Public Information at Cornell University for fifteen years, received at the closing session of its two-day regional conference today the first annual award of merit, established by the American College Publicity Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The United States Asiatic Fleet is taking the offensive. Striking in the night at a Japanese convoy in the Strait of Macassar, a fleet of destroyers sank or badly damaged three large enemy ships and damaged others, the Navy Department reported late today.

In line with the war news of the day is the newly opened exhibition of East Indian textiles at Holland House, 10 Rockefeller Plaza. These strange, beautiful fabrics bring home to us how rich is the native culture in Java, Sumatra, Bali and our own Philippines as well as Burma and Indo-China.

SOME of the most skillful practitioners of the art of detective fiction seem curiously reluctant to stake their reputations on their achievements in this field. Conan Doyle, for instance, wished to be remembered for "The White Company" rather than for the Sherlock Holmes stories.

Unless the pending price control law is so administered that they are given some relief with regard to export ceilings, foreign traders generally asserted last week that they were of the opinion that export trade to Latin America might be brought to a virtual standstill.

Rejecting John L. Lewis's call for organizational unity with the American Federation of Labor, the national executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations voted unanimously yesterday to accept the plan put forward by President Roosevelt for labor peace without a formal merger.

May I add to the discussion of Mozart and the National Socialist Reichsmusikkammer. In the October, 1940, number of the Zeitschrift fuer Musik, which Robert Schumann founded in 1834 (I am sure he would barely recognize it now), one Hermann Stephani made the following contribution to the Kreux und Quer departmeut.

Because spring-flowering bulbs were not too plentiful last Fall, most gardeners went a little slow in potting them up for Spring bloom. Therefore there is bound to be a notable absence of many favorites which normally flourish in sunny windows during late Winter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- President Roosevelt is nominating five officers for advancement to the temporary grade of brigadier general.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- Cornell's basketball team got the jump on Yale tonight, opened up a 16-1 lead in less than nine minutes and coasted to a 51-34 victory that gave the Big Red undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate League.

In computing a Federal income tax, the Bureau of Internal Revenue pointed out yesterday, the taxpayer must ascertain his gross income, his net income and his surtax net income. The two last-named steps need not be taken if the taxpayer is entitled to and does use the simplified optional method of filing a return for gross incomes of $3,000 or less.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (U.P.) -- Japan apparently had gone all-out today against the American and Filipino defenders of Bataan, hammering General MacArthur's positions with ceaseless fire from warships along the coast, masses of aircraft and hordes of fresh ground troops.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- A new method of "analytically" roasting coffee which insures that the coffee has the optimum flavor and aroma has been developed. Herbert S. Polin of New York City and Joseph F. Aims of Teaneck, N.J., have received a patent (No. 2,270, 768) for their process.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- West Texas State Teachers College made its eastern basketball debut tonight by breaking all Buffalo college scoring records in a 105-41 triumph over Buffalo State Teachers College before 5,676 spectators.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- Good maps of Russia are at a premium here today among foreign observers, especially road maps, for the situation on the Eastern Front as it is now developing cannot be understood without consideration of lines of retreat.

I WOULD like Mr. Atkinson to write a Sunday essay (preferably a book) on "A Morality for the Drama Critic." This he would do brilliantly. After he has done so I would then like to defy Mr. Atkinson to defend his recent review of Clifford Odets's "Clash by Night" in the light of whatever theory of dramatic criticism he happens to embrace in his essay. Whatever one.

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- As school opens this week the student citizens of the Rye School embark on the second part of a new brand of government, the Conduct Corporation. Last September, when the need for training in democracy was felt, the first half of the plan was introduced through the chartering of the upper grade home rooms as corporations, concerned in the business of good conduct.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Treasury Department opened a campaign today to get millions of citizens to sign pledges to set aside a certain amount of money weekly or monthly for the purchase of defense bonds.

With a view toward solving the various problems that war has brought to children and youth in this country, leading educators have joined forces in forming an emergency committee that will act as a clearing house in coordinating the efforts in these fields.

Whichever way the manufacturers turn they are confronted by priorities and shortages of material. The resulting search for substitutes means a radical departure in designing and manufacturing about nine-tenths of the articles in daily use.
GREATEST of all sports arenas, Madison Square Garden almost nightly puts on a show that the crowds never see -- a modern miracle of quick-change.

Broadening its curriculum in the interest of defense, Brooklyn College has announced that it will add for the Spring term several new courses on chemical warfare to the defense courses already being offered. The college is also expanding its Western Hemisphere studies.

Lily Pons, the star of the evening, and Newbold Morris, "understudying" for Mayor La Guardia, conducted a defense bond drive from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House last night at the close of the second act of Donizetti's "La Fille du Regiment," which was presented there for the fourth time this season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- "Saws" for cutting wood, glass, stone, concrete and synthetic plastics, which are manufactured from chinalike ceramics, are revealed in a patent (No. 2,270, 607) granted here to Eugen Ryschkewitsch of Frankfort on the Main, Germany.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, Jan. 24 -- Scores of fully equipped infantrymen and marines, rushed from their bases in fast moving trucks this morning, repulsed simulated enemy invasions in the second daylight mock attack staged here within two weeks.

TRAVEL LINES: Thos. Cook Son is continuing its weekly conducted trips to Mexico.. . . Canada's ski trains are carrying well-filled coaches to high hills north of Montreal. Lac Beauport and other sections report new trails. Last Winter the Canadian Pacific transported more than 125,000 skiers to the Laurentians over holidays and week-ends.

THE chasing of wild geese, in the lively expression of Charles Allen Smart, novelist and farmer, is a term for the pursuit of the art of living. And if living is not to be organized as an art, he makes us feel as we look at the world about us, it must become an insanity.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust, which holds $3,000,000 of the first and refunding bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, announced yesterday that the trustees of the trust will vote against the proposed reorganization plan of the carrier on the ground that a more equitable plan should be worked out.

One of New York's longest-established charity events, the annual Kettledrum in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged, will be held on the afternoon of Feb. 11 in the ballroom of the Hotel Delmonico. The event has been given on St. Valentine's Day or closely thereto, with few exceptions, since 1873 and over the course of seven decades has enlisted the support and active interest of many women of society.

As a contribution to the local Victory Garden Program the New York Botanical Garden and THE NEW YORK TIMES are cooperating to provide a free course in vegetable growing at The New York Times Hall (formerly the Little Theatre), west of Broadway on Forty-fourth Street.

BABYLON, L. I., Jan. 24 -- Suffolk County, where prosperity is largely measured by the activity of real estate, shows definite signs of emerging from a period of stagnation. While the trend of the market is only slightly up on the averi age there are indications that there will be a surge, provided that priority ratings do not affect the building business too greatly.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 24 -- The machinery of German production has been developing large squeaks lately. If it is too rash to say that raw materials are lacking, it may be observed that the many accessories that are needed to keep a factory running at top efficiency are beginning to get scarce or to give out.

An attendance of nearly 4,000 persons, including many high-ranking officers of the various branches of service, is expected at the 116th annual military reception and ball of the Old Guard of the City of New York, which will take place next Friday night at the Hotel Commodore.

The curtailment of new buildings because of the priorities ruling should create a demand for apartments and afford an opportunity of decreasing present vacancies, according to Herman A. Acker, president of the Bronx realty firm bearing his name.

In the war against the Axis there are roles even for America's comic strip characters, as will be demonstrated at an exhibition of posters made especially for United China Relief, to be opened to the public on Tuesday at the Fifth Avenue Branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Led by Norman Siegal, who gained two first places and led the victorious 300-yard medley relay team, Rutgers University ran away with top honors in the second annual New Jersey State senior A.A.U. swimming championship tonight in the Seton Hall College pool.

For men familiar with the waters bordering the Third Naval District, comprising the States of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, fifty-three ratings, including that of chief petty officer, are available in Class M-2 of the United States Naval Reserve, Lieut. Comdr. L.J. Carro, 90 Church Street, announced yesterday.

THE death of an important film star has always been a public loss accompanied by assorted manifestations of grief. But the death of Carole Lombard evoked a somewhat graver response in the motion picture colony than had previous tragedies of the same sort.

THERE are twenty-eight of them, present, past and "unofficial," to be read about in this book. And to those who wish to make "arm-chair" explorations of Brazil the reading may be well recommended. For Brazil's provincial capitals are not secondary towns, as is ordinarily the case in this country, but "by custom are the industrial and commercial, cultural and artistic, religious and social, educational, scientific, military capitals also."

An informal talk with illustrations will be given by David Burpee on Monday at 3 P.M. at the Waldorf-Astoria, before leading horticulturists, horticulture writers and garden editors. Of particular interest will be the two new calendulas -- Glowing Gold and Orange Fluffy -- called the X-ray Twins.

WHEN strongly stimulated, whether by genuine emotion or by more synthetic products, the average American is Likely to announce that he or his countrymen can lick their weight in wildcats. An ideal example in these times of that rootin', tootin', shootin' mood is the United States Marine Corps.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Jan. 24 -- An extensive campaign to promote physical fitness, supplementing many voluntary student projects, such as special training courses and the collection of books for all branches of the armed forces, has been started at Smith College.

MONTREAL, Jan. 24 (AP) -- Montreal's last place Canadiens came from behind to gain a 2-2 overtime tie with the world champion Boston Bruins in a National League hockey game before a crowd of 10,467 at the Forum tonight. The Canadiens remained in the cellar, but picked up one point on the sixth-place Brooklyn Americans, who bowed.

The bench and bar of New York State were rallied yesterday to the defense of civil liberties and other constitutional rights so that democracy may not be permanently lost at home while we are fighting for it abroad, and so that American institutions may survive in the post-war world.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 24 -- While demand for plant space since the beginning of the war has absorbed a considerable portion of the available property in New Jersey, the State still has between 9,000,000 and 10,000,000 square feet of manufacturing space available, according to A.W. Coffin, managing director of the New Jersey Council.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- For the first time since 1938, Pennsylvania defeated the Navy in basketball tonight, 37 -- 32, when Chuck Viguers sparked a second-half rally before 4,000 spectators.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Jan. 24 -- A comprehensive volunteer program, offering training in all fields of the civilian defense services in which there is an immediate need has been set up at Bryn Mawr College and made available for all the community -- students, faculty, staff and neighbors.

As concrete evidence of the determined acceleration in the program of building fighting ships, the United States Navy announced here yesterday that it would purchase the dilapidated old Submarine Boat Corporation yards at Port Newark, N.J., and would spend $12,000,000 in converting it at top speed into a "new, modern steel shipyard."

Business was generally good last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Mid-Winter furniture sales opened with steady action noted.

Back in 1936 when skiing started to "catch on" there were many skeptics who said that it was just a "fad" and would not survive another year. What has occurred in the interim is history. Today, the ancient Scandinavian sport is definitely established during the snow months.

LONDON, Jan. 24 -- The German retreat from Mozhaisk, sixty miles west of Moscow, was a great triumph, the Nazis finally explained today, but the radio announcements of Commander in Chief Adolf Hitler's latest "victory" were made without the customary trumpet fanfares and rolling drums.

CHUNGKING, China, Jan. 24 (From Chinese broadcasts recorded by The United Press in San Francisco) -- A Chinese Army communique today announced that Chinesee units had cut off Japanese communications lines north of Hankow, chief Japanese base in central China.

BERNE, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- A Swiss correspondent telegraphs to his newspaper from Vichy, "At present France is submerged by unfounded reports." This statement is all the more interesting in view of the fact that on Jan. 20 one year ago an attempt was made to ease the censorship regulations, at least so far as the foreign press was concerned.

DRAMATIC critics still are experiencing the invariable post-Christmas period of inaction, except for changes in the bill of Donald Wolfit's Shakespearean season at the Strand. But if professional playgoers have no shows to see, things are far otherwise with the paying public.

ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 24 -- Germany's strong new demands for fresh manpower from Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania, coupled with severe Axis reverses in Yugoslavia and the plague and famine in Greece, threw into bold relief last week the picture of the seething Balkans, torn between pledged loyalties and age-old hatreds and turning inevitably against the cause of their disasters -- Germany.

HARDLY a man is now alive who remembers the famous day and year when Richard Brinsley Sheridan produced "The Rivals." If you want to be literal about it, not a man is now alive who remembers Jan. 17, 1775, but once a poet has turned a phrase, no one has the right to alter it.

PRACTICALLY every time you look up, a radio program is having a birthday. This month, for instance, Amos 'n' Andy are celebrating their sixteenth anniversary as a broadcasting team. Just once during that period have they taken a vacation -- in 1933, when Mr. Correll went abroad and Mr. Gosden went fishing.

College basketball will interrupt its examination lull long enough this week to provide one of the biggest attractions of the season at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night when West Texas State's heralded "tallest team on earth" faces Long Island University's stellar quintet.
The 15,000-ton tanker Jack Carnes, the last in a series of four being built at the Federal Shipbuilding yards for the Sinclair Refining Company, was launched at Kearny on Monday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 24 -- One hundred and thirty graduate appointments to Syracuse University for the academic year 1942-43 are open to qualified graduates of universities and accredited colleges in the United States and Canada, Dean William L. Bray announced today.

At the home of Mrs. Junius Spencer Morgan, 30 East Thirty-sixth Street, tomorrow afternoon, a tea will be given to initiate a weekly series of such functions to develop plans for a forthcoming auction sale to benefit the armed forces in the Second Corps Area under the sponsorship of the Citizens Committee for the Army and Navy, Inc.

Arthur W. Seale, who was elected president of the United States Customs Inspectors Association at the organization's annual meeting a week ago, is one of the few men in the inspector division here who have two law degrees. He is a member of the New York State Bar.

LET me assume that you are a playwright -- known or unknown -- and that a play of yours has just been bought by a producer. This, to the uninitiated, should be the moment when your troubles cease, the hurdles of getting the play read and accepted being now behind you and there remaining only a clear, straight path that leads right up to the opening, with nothing but the critics left to worry about.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 24 -- Australia is greatly heartened by overseas messages indicating that the Pacific apparently is ceasing to be a sideshow in the eyes of the people and press of the United Kingdom.
Mrs. Austen Fox Riggs of Stockbridge, Mass., is at Mayfair House.

The Conference on State Defense, of which Henry Epstein, Solicitor General of New York State, is chairman, issued yesterday an attack on the proposal of the Secretary of the Treasury, Henry Morgenthau Jr., to levy a Federal tax upon the income from State and municipal bonds which have been issued under the covenant that they were tax exempt.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 24 -- In a nation-wide broadcast entitled "Our American Allies," former Premier Robert G. Menzies yesterday endeavored to explain Americans to Australians and in doing so he selected President Roosevelt, Secretary of State Cordell Hull and John G. Winant, Ambassador to London, as the types of Americans he wished his own countrymen to understand and appreciate.

What would Winter be without a sniffle? Well, it's anybody's guess; for where is the spokesman who can speak with authority? Presumably it would be a season of boisterous good health, good temper and uninterrupted good work. But that's only presumption. As a matter of fact, it's a guess.

Announcement was made yesterday by Alexander P. Gest Jr., race chairman of the Larchmont Yacht Club, that the decision had been made to go as far as possible with the regular racing schedule next Summer. As Larchmont has been foremost among the Long Island Sound racing clubs for many years, the announcement was deemed significant, and it was expected to be followed by similar decisions by other clubs.

THE most commonplace subjects make good salon materials if photographed at the right moment and with an eye to beauty, declared J. Ghislain Lootens in an address on "Making Salon Prints" before the second convention of the New York City High Schools Photographic Council at the Brooklyn Museum yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The only woman member of the Cabinet, Secretary Perkins, and about 1,000 clubwomen had a good laugh today at the expense of the male economic adviser to the Secretary of Agriculture.

To the attractive series of Picture Tales from different countries Dan Storm has added a volume of Mexican folk stories, which he heard told during his association with Spanish-speaking people in Mexico and in the southwestern part of the United States, and which he has now set down in English.

High school pupils, chosen by the School Art League for skill in draftsmanship and design during the past school year, received certificates in place of bronze medals yesterday when these awards were presented to 106 boys and girls in the auditorium of the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

A CONCERT devoted entirely to works by Bach, Beethoven or Debussy is hardly news today. But a program of music by Lassus, incredible as it may seem, is an unusual event. In fact, we have not been able to find records of such a concert ever having been undertaken.

All German, Japanese and Italian nationals were again warned yesterday by the Department of Justice that when they apply at postoffices for certificates of identification they must bring the alien registration receipt cards issued to them when they registered as non-citizens.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 24 -- Several columns of German tanks and truck-borne infantry, pushing northeastward from Agedabia yesterday, encountered the British main force, and a tank battle on a scale that is as yet unknown was thus begun.

WITH the lights already dimmed on Fifth Avenue and most homes prepared for a blackout, Vitamin A takes on dramatic importance According to Dr. Selig Hecht of Columbia (nationally known for his research on this particular member of the vitamin group), a person's consumption of Vitamin A may increase as much as a hundred times his ability to see in the dark.

From one of our readers we have received the following communication: "THE TIMES for Jan. 13 says foodstuff stocks are at record highs yet wholesale prices are up 25 per cent. A bewildered reader pleads for enlightenment."

Herbert E. Gaston, assistant secretary of the Treasury, told 300 persons yesterday at the New York Conference on War and the Consumer that "inequities in the present tax structure will need to be remedied." Mr. Gaston said that "too much of our population now is living below an adequate subsistence level" and that "we are not going to gain efficiency by starving our workers."

OMAHA, Jan. 24 -- If the Red Cross is to do its job, the people who eat in the kitchen must take some of the bows along with social leaders, William M. Jeffers, president of the Union Pacific Railroad, writes in a letter to Norman H. Davis, national chairman of the Red Cross.

In the blue equatorial waters of the Southwestern Pacific, off the great island of New Guinea, appeared last week gray men-of-war and transports. The ships anchored beside palm-fringed beaches, where natives for centuries have berthed dugout canoes and fished with net and spear.

RELEASE of the first units in the long-promised series of embossed stamped envelopes is expected to begin some time in February, it was learned last week at an authoritative source. The envelopes had been tentatively scheduled for the latter part of 1941 but were deferred for reasons not officially announced.

The Maritime Commission announced last week that contracts had been approved for the construction of twenty-eight more liberty ships in addition to the large number of new orders announced on Jan. 17.

Opposition to passage of any bill to permit deduction of the Federal income tax in making State income tax returns was announced yesterday by the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union in its first report this year on activities of the Legislature.

FANNIE HURST repeated that she was very hard to stop. "Please make no mistake. I am really very clearly aware that I am not a darling of the critics. I have a vast popular audience -- it warms me, it's a furnace (the girl at the glove counter who asks: 'Are you THE Fannie Hurst?' the fact that I am required reading in college courses ) -- a marvelous big audience."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- In order to "keep 'em flying," the Civil Aeronautics Administration issued today new rules under which civilian pilots who have proved their citizenship and loyalty may continue many of their pre-war flying activities.
BLACK STEAM -- Luminous steam from cooling towers and gas-manufacturing plants presents a problem when a city is blacked out. The British have solved that problem by adding carbon to the steam.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP) -- A constitutional amendment to permit ratification of treaties by a simple majority vote of Congress, or of the Senate alone, was proposed today by Senator Pepper of Florida.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Industrial realtors in this area seemed agreed today that Philadelphia stood on the threshold of a period of unparalleled activity, but were at odds on the amount of floor space available to meet it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Representatives of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F.L., and other interested unions offered to the Labor Division of the War Production Board today four proposals to insure the daily delivery of milk and other dairy products.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Jan. 24 -- The Inter-American Conference of Foreign Ministers, now drawing toward a close here, will undoubtedly be looked upon in retrospect as a landmark in the history of the present World War and in the development of Pan-Americanism; but the extent to which it has achieved success must naturally await the test of events.

Members of the Woman's Board of the Church Charity Foundation of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island have taken over the performance of Sheridan's "The Rivals," with Mary Boland, Walter Hampden, Bobby Clark and Helen Ford in the leading roles, on the night of Feb. 2 at the Shubert Theatre to raise funds for furthering the charitable projects of the organization.

THE stagnation of our musical life, which has been commented upon by a number of thoughtful observers, including Spengler in his "Decline of the West," may be explained partially by a lack of understanding of the social and cultural currents which affect the destiny of arts and letters even in the smallest details.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24 -- Based on the findings of a three-year study of library resources, needs and opportunities in the area, plans for coordination of the services of more than 150 libraries within a twenty-five-mile radius of Philadelphia are presented in a report prepared by the Bibliographical Planning Committee of Philadelphia.

The renewed buying surge on the part of the public was reflected in the wholesale markets last week as buyers continued to place substantial commitments on goods for immediate use, for Spring and for Fall, according to a report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

DONALD M. NELSON, America's new arms production chief, has set his sights for "too much and too soon" to wipe out the memory of "too little and too late." He is gauging his course by the question. "A year from now, what will we wish we had done today?"

AT half a dozen places in this curious triangle story the reader feels that Miss Hanna is about to push out into really deep water. One wishes that she had, except that by steering her course among the shallows she has probably won a more popular success.

DETROIT, Jan. 24 -- Approximately 750 manufacturers of automobiles, parts, tools and dies responded today with a rising pledge of cooperation to the appeal of Ernest C. Kanzler, head of the Automotive Branch of the War Production Board, to "do things faster in a new way to get out production, even though it may cost more" to turn out the airplanes, tanks, guns and bombs in the vast quantities needed to defeat the Axis.

WITH one of the most dramatic, most amazing events in all the world's history to elaborate upon and to embroider, Rafael Sabatini has, it would appear, thoroughly enjoyed writing this novel. The towering figure of Columbus himself is the book's central character, its background the splendid pageantry of the court of Ferdinand and Isabel, the mysteries and marvels of that "Ocean-Sea" of which Columbus was proclaimed admiral, and of the New World which lay beyond.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the world strategy which the Allied nations now aim to construct, what is the function of that new and potent weapon, air power, particularly in our American effort? It is vital to inquire as to the kind and quality, not alone the quantity, and the uses and organizations that are suitable to the full potentialities of aircraft.

LONDON, Jan 24 (AP) -- Australia's urgent demands for aid deeply stirred Britain tonight and imperiled what most parliamentary circles regarded as Prime Minister Churchill's plan to protect criticized Cabinet members with the mantle of his prestige.

THE standard work on the literature of American history, Milton Waldman's "Americana," published in 1925 and still invaluable, contains acknowledgments to a number of scholars. In the midst of them appears a sentence which has aroused speculation among readers: "The heartiest of all my debts is due to one who will not permit his name to be mentioned, and to him my gratitude must remain anonymous, though none the less heartfelt for that."

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 -- If enemy planes were suddenly to strike at Chicago tomorrow, this Middle Western metropolis would be found to be quite well, if not totally, prepared. Under Mayor Edward J. Kelly, metropolitan coordinator of civilian defense in this area, Chicago has accelerated its defense program until it has now taken an encouraging solidity of shape and complexion.

LISTENING to our Prime Minister over the air from Washington the other day, we couldn't help wondering what it felt like to be Alexander Korda, and remember that you once had this spellbinder under contract.

Even girls who would sooner read a book than sew of an evening are likely to find themselves taking up sewing again, now that it's so important to get the longest possible wear out of clothes. People who are smart enough to sew entire dresses for themselves are much better off, as they can whip up exactly what their wardrobes need and save money in the bargain.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- Russian troops driving a great wedge into the German Winter line between the central and Leningrad fronts were reported tonight to be crushing all resistance in hammering advances against the key towns of Rzhev, Velikiye Luki and Staraya Russa.

FORT RALEIGH, Roanoke Island, N.C., Jan. 24 -- Thirty months ago Colonel Robert Olds drew a diagram in the gravelly sand in front of the John White cottage within the enclosure of the restored bastion of democracy's beginning here and from a finger a drop of blood trickled, seeping through emergency bandages.

In response to the many changes in college entrance requirements brought about by the entrance of the United States in the war, the College Entrance Examination Board has replaced its customary three-hour June examinations with a series of one-hour objective achievement tests to be given in April, and repeated in June and September, it was disclosed yesterday at the board's headquarters, 431 West 117th Street.

This biography of a great musician and an extraordinary man is written with sympathy and sincere admiration. It is based on a thorough study of the circumstances of Wagner's life, and it is written with careful reference to the times in which he lived.

A harvest of profits for imports of sorely needed goods has sent buyers into foreign fields in a feverish search for goods. In spite of impediments of tariff, black lists, price control, lack of shipping facilities and direct prohibition on purchase of foreign goods by government agencies, private enterprise for months has been sensing the shortage of goods and already has organized the movement of a huge volume of foreign-made goods.

MISS STERN'S "The Life of Margaret Fuller" is the fourth biography of this astonishing woman to appear during the past twenty years (the others were Katherine Anthony's "Margaret Fuller, a Psychological Biography"; Margaret Bell's "Margaret Fuller," and Mason Wade's "Margaret Fuller: Whetstone of Genius").

Looking to enlistment of 2,000,000 American youths from 16 to 18 years old as volunteer pre-flight students later to join the United States fighting air services, Air Training Cadets of America announced yesterday its organization and the formation of its first training unit.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 -- Coming on with a rush in the stretch, Get Off, a son of American Flag and On Her Toes, captured the $6,740 Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah Park today as more than a few noted the victorious connotation of the winner's breeding.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Price Administrator Leon Henderson said today that his office would extend to the Latin-American republics the same price protection it provided for domestic buyers. He said that every effort would be made to see that price ceilings would not interfere with the normal flow of exports.

BOSTON, Jan. 24 -- Taking the position that more, rather than less, technical competence and maturity will be required of its graduates during the war and reconstruction periods, Simmons College has definitely rejected the "speedup" program announced by many colleges and universities as a war emergency measure.

ROME, Jan. 24 (From Italian broadcasts recorded by The Associated Press) -- The Italian High Command announced today that a German-Italian offensive in Cyrenaica had forced strong British forces to retreat east of Agedabia. The offensive is continuing, the Italian communique said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The disastrous Japanese attack on the United States' main Pacific naval base at Pearl Harbor Dec. 7 was due mainly to the failure of Admiral Husband E. Kimmel and Lieut. Gen. Walter C. Short to take adequate joint action for the defense of the Hawaiian Islands despite repeated warnings from the War and Navy Departments, Associate Justice Owen J. Roberts, chairman of President Roosevelt's special investigating commission, reported today.

Elliott Bates, Bronxville broker, J Westchester County, announces that in both rentals and sales 1941 was; a more active year in Bonxville than 1940. Houses for rent, he points out, have become somewhat scarce, and in both apartments and houses the tendency has been for rents to increase.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Social activities at Pocono Manor are centering around Winter sports. Twenty-five miles, of ski runs, an ice toboggan chute, the new 1,000-foot ski tow and skating facilities on Lake Minausin are enjoyed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In my opinion, one of the most despicable concomitants of any war is the wave of economic sabotage it engenders among the ignorant, the panicky and the plain greedy buying public.
